column2: There is to be a hearing at Albany to-day on a bill providing for the government of third-class cities. It is introduced by Mr. SANGER, but is substantially the measure reported last year by the commission created the year before to devise a uniform system of government for cities of that class. It is in its main features, if not in all details, an excellent bill.

The Cambridge (Mass.) hockey team played a match with the St. Nicholas team of this city last night, at the St. Nicholas Rink, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. The visitors appeared in neat costumes of dark red sweaters, trimmed with white, and caps to match. They are a strong lot of men, and did some good playing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Speaker Reed made an order a few days ago absolutely prohibiting "smoking in the corridors, elevators, and passageways" of the House; and directing policemen and other employes to see that the rule was observed.

CANTON, Feb. 9. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Saxton of New York called on Major McKinley this afternoon. He said: "I have come to Canton in the interest of a friend, and do not care to state the precise purpose of my errand. I will say this much, however, that it has nothing to do with the selection of a New York member of the Cabinet in any shape or form.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 9. -- Bondholders of the Columbus and Cincinnati Midland Railroad have filed a bill in the Circuit Court of the United States against the receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to enforce the payment of $150,000 worth of bonds. There are $2,000,000 worth of bonds upon the road, and the suit is a test case to define the status of and obtain settlement for the bonds.

The Third Avenue Railroad Company, in behalf of itself and the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Company, now part of the system, made application yesterday to the Board of Aldermen for a remarkable series of new lines, extensions, and connections.

There is nothing thrilling about the expression of opinion upon arbitration which has been extracted from Prince BISMARCK. He is careful to explain that he knows nothing about the pending treaty between us and Great Britain, and that his remarks are purely theoretical or academic. But if he had not made this reservation, and if, moreover, he were still Chancellor, they would commit him to nothing.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- A bill for a receiver for the Suburban Construction Company was filed in the Circuit Court to-day by Charles S. Leeds, who is a stockholder of the corporation, owning 242 shares. The Suburban Construction Company was organized for the purpose of building the Suburban Electric Railroad, through Cicero, Riverside, La Grange, Western Springs, Grosdale, and other towns.
John Q.A. Herring, Director of the Adams Express Company and General Manager of its Baltimore division, died suddenly at the Holland House, Thirtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, at 6 o'clock last night.

Sir MICHAEL HICKS-BEACH'S rather Pogramatic defiance in the House of Commons last week has created less excitement in France than might have been expected. Of course, it was only the tone taken by the Chancellor of the Exchequer that was novel. It has been well enough known, certainly since the expedition to Dongola was undertaken, that England not only had no intention of abandoning Egypt, but was preparing to extend and consolidate her occupation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee devoted this morning's session to a consideration of the duty on steel billets. In the law of 1890 the duty on steel billets costing 1 cent a pound or less was four-tenths of 1 cent. In the present law the duty on billets of this grade is three-tenths of 1 cent.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- It is reported that the English shipbuilding firm of Armstrongs are about to sell to Spain, with the permission of the Chilean Government, two ironclad warships now under construction in Armstrongs' yards upon the order of Chile, and which are nearly completed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 9. -- In response to a resolution addressed to Senators Voorhees and Turpie, by members of the Third Christian Church of this city, in which the church indorsed the pending arbitration treaty, letters were received today from each of the Senators, giving their indorsement to the measure, and saying that they would support it.
To-night will end the Bradley Martin ball agony, and everybody will have a chance to breathe and rest. But it will be a grand and dazzling affair. No doubt is expressed about that.

The immediate cause of the troubles in Crete is evidently enough the forth-putting policy which the Government of Greece has suddenly developed. The misconduct of the Mussulmans is made the pretext of the activity of the authorities at Athens in putting into commission all their available warships and dispatching them to the Cretan coast.

An outgrowth of the preparations for the Bradley Martin ball that was not down on the programme was a rudely constructed bomb that was sent by some crank, and was received at the Twentieth Street house Monday.
HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- Caspar Betancourt, a naturalized American citizen, who was acquitted a few days ago of the charge of aiding and abetting the rebels, was finally released from custody to-day.

The Tammany Aldermen yesterday elected, or declare they elected, John T. Oakley a member of the Committee on Finance to succeed W.M.K. Olcott. The Finance Committee elected Mr. Oakley its Chairman, thereby making him a member of the Sinking Fund Commission. The Republican members of the board declare that the election was not legal, in that sixteen votes were not cast for Mr. Oakley.

Some old family records belonging to W.F. Chrystie, who owns an old mansion at 32 East Ninth Street, and who makes his home at his country place, Hastings-on-the-Hudson, were sold a few days ago by his butler to a ragman, and then to a book-dealer, and since then Mr. Chrystie has been endeavoring vainly to get them back without paying an exorbitant price for them.

William Berri, the new President of the Bridge Trustees made an official inspection of the bridge yesterday, with special reference to the report made by the board of engineer experts. He aproved of the plans as a whole, but had some suggestions to make as to the loading and unloading of passengers.

Argument on the application for a mandamus to compel the Department of Public Works to remove sidewalk obstructions on Vesey Street was postponed yesterday by Justice Truax until to-morrow. E.M. Wight for the applicant, L.J. Callanan, announced himself as ready, but Assistant Corporation Counsel Foley said Mr. Sterling, who has the matter in hand, was sick, and asked an adjournment.

HAMBURG, Feb. 9. -- Ever since the decision of majority of the men who took part in the great strike here of dock laborers and others employed in the shipping trade to return to work, there has much discontent among the men, and those who watched the situation closely could see that trouble was brewing.

Mayor Strong, in the concluding message of his series sent this year to the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, pointed out the enormous growth of interests in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, and showed that property there now has an assessed valuation, exclusive of park lands, of $69,546,809, whereas in 1890 the assessed valuation was $44,448,914.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Ferdinand W. Peck, President of the newly organized National Business Men's League, accompanied by Franklin H. Head, returned from the East to-day, where they were in conference with legislators and Representatives at Washington. On their way back from the capital they stopped at President-elect McKinley's home last evening, and when they meet the Executive Committee of the association they say they will have valuable information to impart.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- News has been received here of the loss, near the Island of Ushant, off the coast of Brittany, France, of the British cargo steamer Cyanus, bound from Bilbao for Glasgow. The advices giving the story of the wreck say that only one of the ship's company was saved.

Mrs. Bradley Martin's costume was a surprise to many of her guests, when, upon going to the dais in the small ballroom to greet her, they saw their hostess as Mary Queen of Scots, in a gown copied from an old painting.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- The remains of Charles W. Brooke, the noted criminal lawyer, were brought to this city from New York to-day and interred at Woodland Cemetery. The remains were accompanied from New York by the dead lawyer's two sons, Charles and Alexander, and quite a number of distinguished lawyers of that city.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- Gov. Bushnell talked freely this evening about the Senatorial vacancy and the proposed appointee. He settled one thing, and that is that no extra session of the Legislature would be called to select a successor to Senator Sherman.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- Much interest centred in the visit to-day of P.C. Knox or Pittsburg, who has been discussed as a Cabinet possibility. Major McKinley sent his carriage to the station to meet him, and welcomed him heartily. Mr. Knox took luncheon with the President-elect, and left for Pittsburg in the afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10. -- Foggy and rainy weather to-day kept down the attendance to the 2,000 regulars. The track was slushy. Three favorite won. McCaren's Pat Dunne secured the One-Thousand-Dollar Le Compte Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. - Ex-Senator Frank Hiscock has made an apparently ineffectual fight on Inter-State Commerce Commissioner Martin A. Knapp to prevent the confirmation of his nomination, and has accomplished little more, in the estimation of Commissioner Knapp's friends, than to show that the anti-McKinley faction of the New York Republican Party is willing to open the fight upon the new Administration before it has taken the reins of Government.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10. -- The death of the Rev. Willis Warren, in Lee County, removes one of the most remarkable negroes in the South. He was a man of strong character.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The following bulletin, prepared by the Division of Statistics, was issued by the Department of Agriculture this afternoon:

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10. -- A peculiarly interesting case, involving the question whether a School Board can punish a parent through excluding the children, comes up on appeal to the Supreme Court. It is that of Mrs. J.L. Purse of Carterville against the Board of Education of that place.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee to-day heard Frank Platt of New York in support of the bill for the incorporation of the New York Law School, with power to confer degrees. Mr. Platt complained that the Regents of the university enforced harsh rules against this school and discriminated against this school in favor of some of its rivals.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10. -- Harvard has submitted a final proposition for Yale to consider for a reunion of the two universities in all branches of athletics.

The much-heralded fancy dress ball given by Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Martin took place at the Hotel Waldorf last night. Twelve hundred invitations had been issued for the event, but little more than half the number of those invited were in attendance. Of those that came, also, quite a number left early.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Charles T. Yerkes, looking both well and contented, talked over the immense deal in West Chicago bonds which he had succeeded in negotiating, to-day:

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 10. -- President Gates of the Illinois Steel Company submitted his statement at the annual meeting to-day. The unsatisfactory business of last year is attributed to the Venezuelan message and the Chicago Convention. The latter, it is said, caused a large amount of capital to be locked up.

Capt. Stephen O'Brien of the Detective Bureau submitted to the Police Commissioners yesterday, through Chief Conlin, the report of his bureau for 1896. It praises the work of the last year, and, to show the improvement, a comparison is made with the year 1894. That year was the last under the old regime. In almost every instance the figures given show an improvement in the amount of property recovered, arrests of all kinds, and convictions.

Charles Schneider, a house owner at 235 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, and Catherine Fagan of 232 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, and the owner of nine lots adjoining, asked Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, to-day, to grant an injunction pendente lite to restrain the Metropolitan Traction Company from operating its line in One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 10. -- The brick building 11 and 13 Cornhill and 44 Brattle Street, most of which was occupied by William R. Schaeffer Sons, gunsmiths, was wrecked by fire and explosions of powder to-night.

If the attack upon the civil service system of this State makes a stanch supporter of it out of such a stalwart Tammany Democrat as Senator CANTOR, on the ground that he will not countenance efforts to evade the Constitution, it will not be without its good effects. There is no manner of doubt about the meaning or the purpose of the Constitution, and Democrats are or profess to be sticklers for its strict observance.

I have been a reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES this Winter, and am very much pleased with the improvements in the paper. I approve particularly of the efforts to exclude sensational and unclean reports of the crimes and vices with which so many leapers are filled. These things, in my opinion, are not news at all; they are merely filthy food for diseased imaginations or malicious scandal provided to gratify an ignorant curiosity.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Gov. Black to-day received the annual report of the State Civil Service Commission.

Please find remittance of my subscription herewith. I have been a subscriber for the daily TIMES almost continuously for several years. It was to me a very acceptable paper before its recent improvements; it is now still more so.

At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday a letter was read from Elsie L. Hess of 2 Willett Street complaining of as a nuisance the "relief station" recently established by a newspaper at the corner of Grand and Willett Streets. The matter was submitted to Chief Conlin for investigation. The letter was as follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The report of the Printing Committee, exonerating the Public Printer from charges of delinquency, provoked an angry discussion in the Assembly to-day between Mr. Robbins, who made the charges, and Mr. Glen, Chairman of the committee.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 10. -- Cobb's Island, a famous Summer resort and life saving station six miles off the Virginia coast in the Atlantic Ocean, seems to be doomed to annihilation by the action of the sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Morgan, (Dem., Ala.,) in charge of the Nicaragua Canal bill, withdrew it, but announced that he would present it again at the extra session and press it to a vote.
County Clerk Purroy organized the new "Tammany Home Rule General Committee" in Lyric Hall, near Forty-second Street, on Sixth Avenue, last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, at their meeting this morning, considered that part of the iron and steel schedule relating to nails.

To-morrow, Feb. 12, being the anniversary of the birthday of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, is a legal holiday in the States of Illinois, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, and Washington. This fact will produce a considerable amount of inconvenience and confusion to citizens of these Commonwealths and also to citizens of other Commonwealths who have dealings with them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- According to the official report of Naval Constructor Linnard of his examination of the cruiser Brooklyn after her bottom was exposed in the League Island dry dock, that vessel's injuries are more serious than at first reported, and it will probably, take three weeks to remedy the damage, at an expense which may reach as high as $50,000.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 10. -- Mayor Smith and a Committee of Reception and Entertainment visited Admiral Bunce on the flagship New York at noon to-day and extended the privileges of the city to the fleet

At the meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday the committee appointed to consider the matter of sidewalk obstructions and the bills now before the Legislature to legalize them presented this report:

The Greater New York Commission will probably take its final vet, on the charter at its meeting in the Mayor's office to-morrow and may not meet again until after the draft is presented to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The story that the President and Mrs. Cleveland are engaged in making a general distribution of their four years' accumulation of articles, valuable and otherwise, has gone broadcast through the land, and the White House clerical force is in despair over the increase in the mail.

Chicago puts up with no half-way work. Visitors from the East and Chicago men in New York sometimes bring to us appalling stories of her municipal Government and the evils with which it is honeycombed. But when Chicago sets her broad shoulders to the wheel of reform it moves, moves at once, rapidly, and with effect.
Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for Abraham Stern, to Samuel Levin, at about $18,500, the five-story brick tenement 186 Broome Street, 51 by 25.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The Governor to-day sent to the Senate a number of recess appointments for confirmation. Among them were those of Robert B. Miller as Port Warden of the Port of New York; Harvey W. Putnam of Buffalo as Commissioner of Charities, and Peter M. Wise of Ogdensburg as Commissioner in Lunacy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Republicans are promising to add to the troubles of Major McKinley in other ways than by pestering him for office. Some intimations have been given in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the opposition to Gen. Alger as Secretary of War. That cloud still hovers over the incoming Administration, and now another one appears.

PEEKSKILL, Feb. 10. -- Factional differences in the congregation of the old Dutch Reformed Church, at Montrose, in this county, have resulted in the withdrawal of a number of members from active work in the church. The fight is waged over the pastor, the Rev. Henry Smith. Charges preferred against him were dismissed by the Consistory some time ago.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 10. -- It is rumored here to-night that the Pabst Brewing Company of this city has completed negotiations for the purchase of the Madison Square Garden.

A club of street urchins whose club life is under the direction of a philanthropic woman up town has taken to going to church since its members have joined the great army of the organized. Outside the club the boys are known as a "gang," and the "toughest gang" in New York, so the police say.

MARTINEZ CAMPOS has a peculiar standing, both in Spain and Cuba, as a badly beaten General who, in spite of his defeats, has retained the confidence of his Government and the respect of his antagonists. He is entitled to both, and it would be hard to name a man who would be more acceptable to both Spain and Cuba as a mediator, if mediation were still possible.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Senator Cantor to-day, in speaking about proposed, changes in the late civil service laws, said:

DENVER, Col., Feb. 10. -- Congregational Church circles are greatly worked up over the alleged questionable methods the Congregational Church Building Society of New York employs in transacting its business. Three church societies have a grievance, and they have the sympathy of all others in the city.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The annual assembly of the National League of American Wheelmen opened to-day. The entire day was devoted to the consideration of the question of good roads. When the assembly opened in Jermain Hall every State in the Union was represented by delegates, with the exception of Florida and Louisiana.

Last night was souvenir night at the cycle show, and the fun was fast and furious. A crowd, as notable for its humor as for its size, struggled without cessation for the buttons, stick-pins, badges, paper knives, and other articles given by the various manufacturers.

Conditions in Charleston Harbor have changed very much since the war days of 1861-3, when some of the best ships in the Federal navy endeavored ineffectually to maintain a blockade at that point. There are some veterans of the navy still in the service who have a vivid recollection of the hazardous patrol duty in which they were then engaged.

At the lectures given in Carnegie Hall yesterday by the Rev. F.B. Meyer the clergy and religious workers were present in such large numbers as to leave standing room only. The Rev. A.C. Dixon conducted the proceedings, and there was the usual song service by the choir and Mount Hermon Quartet, under the leadership of J.H. Burke.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Capt. William Haubennestel, the commanding officer of the Nineteenth Separate Company, to-day received an order from the Adjutant General's office at Albany, detailing him to command a battalion composed of separate companies along the river. The order is as follows:

An audience of 2,500 people at the Metropolitan Opera House last night saw Armand Castelmary die on the stage, and applauded to the echo, thinking it a splendid bit of acting. That was at 9:05 o'clock, and the curtain was descending for the close of the second scene in the first act of Flotow's opera, "Martha."

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10. -- "Chattanooga and Augusta will be connected with a direct line of railroads." These were the words used by Mr. E.A. Richards, lessee of the Northeastern, in speaking of a gigantic scheme which he has on foot this morning. The new line will connect the two cities, and will place them seventy-four miles nearer each other by rail than they are at present.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- No incidents of an unusual character attended the counting of the electoral votes to-day by the two houses of Congress in joint session.

The decision not to report the "anti-scalping" bill is explained partly by the fact that there would be no chance of its getting to a vote. But we are bound to say that, on the testimony given before the Senate committee, it is well that the whole subject should be more carefully considered before final action is taken.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- In the House to-day Mr. Hainer (Rep., Neb.,) presented the Fortifications Appropriation bill, and Mr. Loud (Rep., Cal.,) the Post office Appropriation bill.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- The Tribune of this morning says:

The correspondent who admits his error in stating that the Raines law was the first in this State to authorize the selling of liquor on Sunday by hotel keepers to their guests seems to us to fall into several others in making his explanation, printed in another column.

In THE TIMES of the 6th inst., Mr. Thomas A. Fulton, who subscribes himself as Secretary Excise Reform Association, asserts that my facts are all wrong, and my deductions, therefore, worthless. This easy method of disposing of my suggestions is founded upon one error in one of my statements; which error is of but slight, if any, importance to my argument.

The attendance at the big bicycle show in the Grand Central Palace grows larger each day, and it is expected that the total for the week will make a record for exhibitions of the kind. The attendance for the first four days footed up 63,851.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 11. -- A large number of golfers from most of the prominent clubs in this section of the country have made Lakewood their headquarters to-day, and to-morrow they will appear on the links of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club to compete in the big tournament for the silver trophy given by Mrs. George Gould.

An early local political sensation was produced yesterday when a semi-official announcement was made that Richard Croker was going to be Tammany's candidate for Mayor this year. On Wednesday Jefferson M. Levy, James J. Coogan, and a few others called upon Mr. Croker at his office, and told him that he ought to run for Mayor.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Assemblyman Finn's bills, one of which relates to the granting of permits for booths and stands about Washington Market and the other to the use of the stoop line of sidewalks on streets adjacent to the other markets in New York City, were before the Assembly to-day on the order of their final passage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The National Wool Growers' Association and the National Association of Wool Manufacturers have split on the wool schedule in the new tariff bill.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- The Tribune this morning publishes the following:

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 11. -- The call issued to-day by Col. A.S. Buford, President of the Virginia Board of Agriculture, for a conference at Washington, on March 5, to decide upon the question of summoning a National convention of farmers, has been under consideration for some time past.
ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Cities Committee gave a hearing to-day on Senator McNulty's bill providing for municipal ownership of gas and electric-light plants in cities of the first class.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Mr. Vest (Dem., Mo.,) reported back from the Committee on Commerce the House bill authorizing the construction of a bridge across the Columbia River, in the State of Washington, stated, as an instance of legislative carelessness, that that same bill had already passed both Houses, had been signed by the President, and was now law.

At a meeting of prominent Baptists in this city last night, at the residence of John D. Rockefeller, Mr. Rockefeller promised to contribute $250,000 toward paying off the total indebtedness of $486,000 resting upon the Baptist Foreign and Home Missionary Societies. Great enthusiasm prevailed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The President this afternoon sent to the Senate the correspondence relative to the killing of Segundo N. Lopez, son of M.F. Lopez, an American citizen, by the Spanish troops in Cuba. It was claimed that this son was registered at the United States Consulate at Cienfuegos as an American citizen, but his name does not appear on the register.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day discussed the bill to reorganize the Consular Service which Mr. Adams (Rep., Penn.,) has prepared as a substitute for several bills on the same subject referred to the committee.

Dr. Levi H. Cobb, Corresponding Secretary for the Congregational Church Building Society, said yesterday that the Trustees of the society had had under consideration the complaints which have been coming from Denver, Col., regarding the methods of the society in loaning money to Denver churches.

The Bradley Martin fancy dress ball continued well into yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Martin did not leave the Waldorf Hotel until just before 6 o'clock, when the first suggestions of daylight were being seen, and even then a number of guests had not started for their homes.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Mr. Nixon's free school-book bill provoked considerable discussion in the Assembly to-day. It was amended to provide that the taxpayers of a district be duly notified whenever there was to be a vote on the question of the purchase of text-books at a school district meeting. Then it was advanced to third reading. The following bills were passed:

A discussion pertaining to the production and distribution of gas was heard yesterday at the City Hall by the Gas Committee of the Board of Aldermen. It was the first of several public hearings to be held before the Legislature acts on the committee's bill for legal investigating powers, the purpose being to enlarge the committee's knowledge of the subject before the work of probing the local gas companies begins.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations this afternoon gave a hearing on the Telephone bill, designed to constitute the State Engineer and Surveyor, Attorney General, and Controller a commission to investigate the operations of the telephone companies throughout the State with a view to obtaining cheaper service.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11. -- Weather very warm, showery; track a sea of mud to-day.

The annual report of the New York State Civil Service Commission to Gov. BLACK is a document which that gentleman will doubtless study with care. He will not, we fear, find in it any serious support for his theory that there is too much starch in the civil service of the State.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11. -- "Has a husband a lawful right to whip his wife?" Judge W.E. Settle of the Circuit Court of Warren County, this State, has just decided the question in the negative in a learned opinion delivered from the bench.

A small but very choice collection of paintings by masters, both ancient and modern, has been brought together by the Art Committee of the Union League Club, and will be opened to members and their guests this morning at 10 o'clock.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 11. -- In the Summer of 1895 a series of daring burglaries and highway robberies were committed in this State on and along the roads leading from River Point through West Greenwich to Rice City, and thence into Connecticut. These outrages became so numerous and the operators were so bold that the farmers and country "cops" organized to hunt the robbers down.

The most exciting game thus far of Maurice Daly's amateur tournament was played last night between Mial and Bernard. Mial succeeded at one time in overcoming Barnard's long lead, but the latter recovered himself in time to win by 9 points. The Score:
CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 11. -- Major McKinley shook hands with four score or more officeseekers to-day and found time to dictate a number of letters and to talk to an old friend or two.

The Society of Alumni of Bellevue Hospital held its fifth reunion and dinner in the main ballroom of the Waldorf last evening. Over 175 members and guests of the society were present. The walls of the ballroom were still adorned with the floral decorations of the previous night.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- The various rumors in this morning's New York papers to the effect that Yale would row Cornell have again stirred up the undergraduate body to a considerable extent.

A brilliant pageant marked the opening of the Arion ball and carnival at Madison Square Garden last night. At 10:30 a fanfare of trumpets gave the signal, and the entertainment began with a grand ballet, entitled "Arion in Olympus." Twelve German athletes started the procession, and were followed by eight warriors in armor, carrying spears and standards.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -The existence'of the Window Glass Trust is seriously threatened, and, unless conditions change for the better within the next month, it is thought that the two organizations that have dictated prices--the Western Window Glass Company and the Pittsburg Window Glass Company--will have to materially change their policy, or they will no longer be able to make prices as formerly.

The ball night before last, or, rather, yesterday morning, at the Waldorf was naturally a great occasion for the freak journals. Inasmuch as the ball did not really begin before midnight, and as the freak journals went to press within an hour or two thereafter, the large and elaborate pictures of "the scene" with which they favored their readers were open to much suspicion.
ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- A great number of additional petitions asking that the liquor tax for druggists under the Raines law be reduced were received in the Senate this morning.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Peekskill will be the Mecca of the Christian Endeavorers of Westchester County to-day. Five hundred delegates are expected here to take part in the deliberations of the fourth annual convention. It will be held in the First Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The correspondence between the State Department and Consul General Lee at Havana on the arrest in Cuba of Gaspar A. Betancourt, an American citizen, was to-day transmitted to the Senate by the President. A telegram to the department from Gen. Lee, on Dec. 28, announced the arrest of Betancourt, and was followed by instructions to the Consul General to take proper steps for his release.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Senator Sherman, who is in charge of the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain, now under secret discussion in the Senate, is beginning to show some uneasiness. Just before the adjournment this afternoon he notified the Senate that it was time an agreement was reached when the final vote should be taken.
There was some sharp manoeuvring yesterday between the Baptist Mission Society and the Rev. Dr.. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Baptist Tabernacle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- A misplaced semicolon in the bill providing for the refunding of the bonded indebtedness of the several Territories was the innocent cause of a wholly unexpected debate on the monetary question in the House to-day, lasting two or three hours.
WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 11. -- A decidedly stirring scene was witnessed on Moody Street, Waltham, this morning, when the Fire Department was responding to an alarm for a fire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- There is good Republican authority for the assertion that Judge McKenna of California, who has been selected for Secretary of the Interior in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet, will be shifted from that position to the office of Attorney General, and that a new man, but not New York Republican, will be chosen for the Interior.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Knowing the destitution existing in Cuba, Miss Clara Barton, on her return from the field of Armenia, offered the services of the Red Cross for relief in Cuba. Some flaw coming up in international law, Miss Barton promptly offered the individual services of herself and her officers in relieving the destitution in Cuba, provided an amount sufficient to relieve the field be furnished.

An Englishwoman, expert in palmistry, who is highly, esteemed in London, says that Americans are among her best customers. She does not consider Americans more superstitious than other persons on this account; she credits it to their vanity. They like to talk about themselves, she Says, and palmistry gives them a good opportunity to hear much upon the all-important subject.

David Morris is a butcher at 42 Seigel Street. Williamsburg. The neighborhood constitutes a Jewish quarter. It is a populous district, and the people are a poor, hard-working class, mostly garment workers.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- Boston's charity ball will be a gilt-edged affair in every respect, and judging from the preparations now under way for the party, Mechanics' Hall will present a very gay appearance next Tuesday evening. At all the clubs and wherever society folks assemble, the charity ball is the chief topic of conversation.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- I.B. Potter of New York was elected President of the League of American Wheelmen at to-day's meeting of the National Assembly, receiving 155 votes to 115 for Sterling Elliott of Boston. The election was made unanimous upon Mr. Elliott's motion, ending happily a warm contest. The annual reports reflected the largest growth and the most successful racing year in the history of the league.

Capt. Philo Norton McGiffin, the young American naval officer, hero of the battle of the Yalu in the Chinese-Japanese war, who was an inmate of the Post-Graduate Hospital, at Twentieth Street and Second Avenue, shot himself, early yesterday morning, in his room in the hospital. He died instantly. Besides the revolver which he used, another was found on the floor.
Stock market dull and soft. Call money, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

The Union League Club at its regular monthly meeting last night received the report of the committee of fifty, of which William D. Guthrie was Chairman, appointed to urge upon the Legislature the election of Joseph H. Choate. This report, in part, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Committee on Appropriations to-day completed the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill and directed Mr. Cannon to report it to the House. The bill carries $50,664,743, over $8,000,000 below the estimates and $17,500,000 in excess of the appropriation for the current year. The estimates include $17,529,053 for river and harbor contracts, and the committee allow $18,615,996 for such purposes.

Mr. GEORGE BLISS has addressed an "open letter" to Gen. B.F. TRACY which is an effective answer to the claim of that gentleman and of Judge DILLON and other defenders of the Greater New York charter draft, that the proposed Municipal Assembly would be "composed of better men than have constituted our Aldermen and Council in the past," on account of the "increased powers and emoluments" of its members.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 11. -- The Southern Pacific Company is not yet out of the toils so far as the danger to its charter is concerned.

President R.W. De Forest and General Secretary Devine of the Charity Organization Society have issued a protest in the name of the society against the distribution of free food now being carried on by a daily newspaper in this city. The protest is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- At the meeting of the House Committee on Pacific Railroads to-day, it was developed that expected support for the propositions reported to have been made by Mr. Hubbard of Missouri relating to the settlement of the Government's debt had not been secured and they could not, therefore, be longer considered within the category of possibilities.

ATHENS, Feb. 11. -- The Government has formulated a notification to the powers, setting forth that Greece cannot remain a mere spectator of the events which are taking place in Crete, and that the ties of race and religion compel her to intervene in behalf of the oppressed and outraged Christians in that island.

The Mormon Church has set out to convert persons in the East. It will begin an evangelistic movement in this city Sunday. It has sent its best speaker, Brigham H. Roberts, and one of its best tenor singers, George D. Pyper, to follow the lines of Moody and Sankey. Sunday evening at Hardman Hall Mr. Roberts will preach on "The Relationship of Mormonism to Christianity,'' and Mr. Pyper will sing some characteristic Mormon hymns.

UTICA, Feb. 11. -- The annual address before the Press Club of Colgate University was delivered in the chapel in William Colgate Memorial Hall, Hamilton, to-night, by W.W. Canfield, city editor of The Utica Observer. The subject of the address was, "Islands of News in Seas of Ink."

The collapse of the steel rail pool, the attitude of the Rockefeller-Carnegie interests toward those of the Illinois Steel Company, and impending trouble for the iron ore pool, or Iron Ore Association, were associated on the Street yesterday with comments and predictions in regard to railroad conditions and prospects in general.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Harvard men are happy this afternoon at the outcome of the negotiations for a resumption of athletic relations between Harvard and Yale.

MARIANNA, Fla., Feb. 11. -- A party of "drummers," under the leadership of F.M. Parsons of Boston, G.G. Pommell of New York, and S.F. Gale of Chicago, had a rather hard experience in one of the Chipola Caves last week.
L.J. Philips Co. have sold to J. Hooker Hammersley, the four-story and basement brownstone dwelling on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, 23.2 by 125.

Under the title, "Let Us Have Peace," The American Federationist, the organ of the American Federation of Labor, publishes a strong article by the editor, Mr. GOMPERS, in support of the general arbitration treaty with Great Britain. The Federationist says:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11. -- A movement is on foot among the Kentucky distillers of Bourbon whisky to organize a trust, in opposition to the American Spirits Company, makers of high wines, popularly known as the Whisky Trust, though instead of whisky, spirits are made.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Gov. Black's scheme for completing the new Capitol Building by contract during his present term is embodied in a bill introduced to-day by Senator Ellsworth. The bill provides that the Governor shall appoint and may remove at his pleasure an officer to be known as the Capitol Commissioner, who shall receive an annual salary of $7,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The National Wool Growers' Association takes exception to the statement of its differences with the manufacturers about the wool schedule, as voiced by Secretary North of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. President William Lawrence of the Wool Growers' Association voices this dissent as follows:

The main interest in the Cycle Show centred last night in the room occupied by the Quill Club Wheelmen of America. This young organization held a reception for its friends, and the occasion was one of great festivity. A large room on the fifth floor was prettily decorated with palms and flowers, a Hungarian band supplying the music.

There is an excellent suggestion offered by Philip Burne-Jones in The London Times relative to the plates of engravings. English print sellers and American ones are in the habit of having a certain limited number of prints struck from a plate, and then they destroy the engraver's work. This, of course, secures a certain number of copies, but there can be after the plate is broken up no more copies possible.

In Mr. Andrew Lang's "At the Sign of the Ship" (Longman's Magazine) he brings into notice a very ugly criticism, printed in Blackwood's Magazine in September, 1844, on Coventry Patmore. Here is a part of this withering review: "The weakest inanity ever perpetrated in rhyme by the vilest poetaster of any former generation becomes masculine verse when contrasted with the naseous pulings of Mr. Patmore's muse.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 12. -- A scheme to effect a joint star comic opera combination to include Miss Lillian Russell, Miss Delia Fox, and Jefferson De Angelis was consummated in this city yesterday, when Miss Fox affixed her signature to the contracts.

It is of course without any intention of belittling so excellent-a citizen as Mr. PIERPONT MORGAN that we take occasion to deprecate the election of another steam yachtsman to the Presidency of the New York Yacht Club. But the truth is that yachting and steam yachting have very little to do with each other.

In Mr. Edward L. Pierce's "Recollections as a Source of History," (Addresses and Papers, Roberts Brothers,) he has written a valuable paper on memory, and memory must be more or less "the basis of historical narrative." The ability to tell exactly what we have seen must depend on two things -- power of observation and, after that, skill in the telling of it.

There is no sense in the criticism of the police for keeping the streets clear in the neighborhood of the hotel at which the Martin ball was given. It was their duty to do it, and they did it in the way required by the circumstances.

-- London Truth says that just before Christmas a London bookseller received an order from a lady for some Christmas stories as presents for her servants, leaving the selection to the bookseller. He sent up certain books published by the Religious Tract Society. The lady returned them on the ground that they were unsuitable for servants, because they had gilt edges.

A large audience assembled yesterday in the lecture room of the Hebrew Technical Institute, 36 Stuyvesant Street, to celebrate the formal opening of its new building. This has been completed and in use since Jan. 4, but the dedicatory ceremonies were postponed to Lincoln's Birthday.
Great Britain drew first blood in the International Chess Tournament, which began yesterday morning between ten representative players of America against the same number of English experts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Secretary of the Interior Francis to-day addressed the following communication to the Commissioner of the Genral Land Office:

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The canal men, who have representatives here looking after proposed legislation affecting their interests, have proposed that the so-called elevator trust be investigated by Senator Lexow and his committee. This investigation, they believe, would have a bearing on the fate of the Parshall bill, which they oppose, because they say it tends to give the control of the canals into the hands of a single concern.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The New York Custom House bill came in for a vigorous overhauling by Mr. White of Illinois at to-day's meeting of the House Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, and the charge of a "deal" in the appointment of two of the Commissioners was made.

The only known facts in regard to Mr. RICHARD CROKER and the Tammany nomination for Mayor are these: The matter has been discussed by Mr. SHEEHAN with the Tammany sub-leaders, and a "Committee of Taxpayers" has called on Mr. SHEEHAN and proposed the nomination.

The bluntest and bravest of soldiers was Sir Charles Ash Windham, Lieutenant General in the Queen's service, who distinguished himself in the Crimea and during the India mutiny. Gen. Windham, as may be noticed in his recently published correspondence ("The Crimean Diary and Letters of Lieut: Gen. Sir Charles Ash Windham, with an introduction by Sir William Howard Russell." London: Kegan Paul,) did not mince his words.

According to the preface, the object of this new life of Sir Richard Burton, written by his niece, Georgiana M. Stisted, is, "first, to tell the truth concerning one who can no longer defend himself; secondly, to supply a want often complained of -- the story of the great traveler's life in a popular form."

The purpose of an amendment to the law prohibiting the public appearance of children under sixteen seems to be to give more latitude than is given by the existing. law to youthful public performers. In fact, the present law is all right. It throws the burden of proving that there is nothing objectionable about the proposed employment of children upon those who wish so to employ them, and this is as it should be.

The spectacle now presented by Greece is probably without any precedent since the balance of power came to be recognized as a factor in European politics. The chastisement of Turkey, which every great power was afraid to undertake singly or in any combination less than the whole, seems to have been actually attempted single-handed by one of the smallest powers in Europe.

It might be supposed as the East Gallery is the smallest in the old Academy of Design, that the Hanging Committees of the various exhibitions would favor the placing there of a selection of the best pictures in the displays. The room is especially well adapted to the hanging of cabinet-size oils and small water colors.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Speaker O'Grady to-day appointed Messrs. Nixon, Whritner, Sanger, Tupper, and McKeown as the members of the Joint Conference Committee on Assemblyman Whritner's Cuban resolutions. The Senate members of the committee are Senators Ellsworth, Lexow, and Grady.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- In the course of his remarks at the farewell banquet given him at the Commercial Club last night, Lyman J. Gage, who will be the next Secretary of the Treasury, expressed his views fully on the present disturbed economic conditions in the United States. Among other things, he said:

A bill was introduced early in the session of the Legislature to create a "Board of Gas, Electric Light, and Water Commissioners." The complaints about the exactions of gas companies were the excuse for it, and the desire to make some new offices and furnish the incumbents with salaries and "expenses" was the probable reason for it.

Horribly energetic -- in a frenzy -- is that German painter Franz Stuck. He would away with all that is tender and gentle. Here is "blood and iron" in art, for no matter what Stuck handles, with his fierceness he carries you off your feet. As to your own personal locomotion, you might rather like to be wafted, as is a leaf by a gentle stream, than to be slung into space by a cyclone.

" Le Cid," a grand opera in four acts and ten tableaus, the book by Messrs. Adolphe D'Ennery, Leon Gallet, and Edouard Blau, and the music by M. Jules Massenet, was performed for the first time in New York last evening in the Metropolitan Opera House. This city cannot claim the honor of the first performance in the United States, because the work has already been heard in New Orleans.

Harper Brothers are now busy with the printing of Nansen's book, "Farthest North," in which are described by the explorer his adventures during the recent expedition of the Fram. In England the first edition will comprise 35,000 copies. As there are also to appear editions in America, Norway, Germany, France, Italy, Holland, Sweden, and Bohemia, it is estimated that the total number of copies first issued will reach 100,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Allied with the Minnesota Iron Company, the Illinois Steel Company stands squarely defiant of the Carnegie-Rockefeller combination. The smashing of the steel-rail pool, with its reduction in prices, has precipitated this duel of corporations. By this alliance a monopoly in steel rails, it is said, is rendered impossible.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Prof. Wheeler this morning gave the following statement concerning the position of Cornell with reference to a triangular race between Cornell, Harvard, and Yale:

I think we are in danger sometimes of considering the Decalogue obsolete. Perhaps to those in this danger a different arrangement of the words and amplification of thought in the light of the New Testament might not come amiss:

The art exhibition held under the auspices of the Sketch Club of Utica was opened last week. There are on view 200 pictures, and among these works by Moran, Inness, Blenner, Rhoda Holmes Nichols, J.G. Brown, Parton, Walter Shirlaw, G.H. Smillie, Ridgway Knight, Elizabeth R. Coffin, N.W. Dodge, Remington, Contoit, Wyant, Rehn, and others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will to-morrow morning endeavor to frame an amendment that will meet the objections that have been advanced in debate against the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain, that has been under discussion in secret session for the past week.

Between the Lower Congo and the delta of the Niger is a vast spread of country, which would seemingly be about the last of places in the world where a woman would voluntarily so for pleasure or study. Female curiosity has apparently no limits. Two subjects, so Miss Kinssley indicates, led her to these extended travels.

HAVANA, Feb. 12. -- Advices have been received here that a party of rebels made an attack upon the Spanish steamer Fausto at Media Luna, a port near Manzanillo, when Commander Pon, on board the Spanish gunboat Cuba Espanola, came up and opened fire upon the rebels, driving them away and compelling them to leave their dead behind them.

There seems to be a general agreement that one great difficulty, if not the chief one, in getting a satisfactory class of men elected to public office lies in the manner of making nominations. Where party issues are involved, or where there is a party division in presenting candidates, whether party issues are involved or not, one set of "regular candidates" is generally sure of being elected.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- The storm greatly detracted from the attendance at the fourth annual convention of the Westchester County Christian Endeavor Union, which was held here to-day. Many of the delegates from the different towns in the county were unable to come or were afraid to venture out in the snow.

The snowstorm of yesterday, which was in some respects the most annoying of the season, began at 3:30 A.M. It marred the anniversary celebration of Lincoln's birthday, especially for those who had planned outdoor recreation. The temperature was comparatively high, and the wind, although due north at times, was moderate, moving at the rate of thirty-six miles an hour at the maximum.

In the Michigan House of Representatives, Feb. 2, resolutions offered by Mr. Gillam were adopted in relation to the bill which has been introduced into the House of Representatives, in Washington, for the purpose of abolishing ticket brokers, and entitled, "A bill to amend the act entitled 'An act to regulate commerce.'"

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 12. -- The battleship Indiana and the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius arrived off Charleston Bar last night. Contrary to all expectations, the cruiser made no effort at all to come into the harbor or run the blockade. She came to anchor near the other ships of the squadron, and is still lying there.

" It is poor pay for what I did to rush the nomination of Mr. PAYN as Superintendent of Insurance through the committee," whined J. IRVING BURNS of Westchester when he was induced to move for a withdrawal of his Commissioner of Jurors bill from the Governor by a strong intimation that otherwise it would be vetoed.

ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- The report of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1896, as filed with the State Railroad Commission, shows: Gross earnings from operation, $2,482,990; operating expenses, $1,347,390; net earnings from operation, $1,135,000; other income, $42,500; gross income from all sources, $1,178,199; fixed charges, $806,838; net income from all sources, $371,261; cash on hand, $62,717; profit and loss, (surplus,) $-4,282,346.

Superintendent Martin of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge announced yesterday that on next Monday trains will be running under a sixty second headway. The change will be made to-morrow, when traffic is light. During Sunday a new cable will replace the one now in use, and a second one for the additional tracks will also be laid.
ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Owing to the activities of yesterday and the banquet last night the League of American Wheelmen Assembly had a small attendance this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The fight for the Nicaragua Canal project was not definitely closed for the session two days ago, when Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) withdrew the bill from present consideration. A new phase of it was opened to-day by the introduction of a joint resolution declaring the Clayton-Bulwer treaty of April 19, 1850, abrogated.

The fortieth annual session of the Newark Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church will be held in Centenary Church, Newark, N.J., beginning April 7. Bishop Edward G. Andrews of New York City will preside. The territory of the conference includes the northern part of New Jersey, Staten Island, a few towns in Northeastern Pennsylvania, and several places in New York just across the New Jersey State line.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 12. -- In spite of abominable weather, the open tournament of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club came off to-day, according to announcement. The players competed for a handsome silver prize, offered by Mrs. George Gould. Neither Mr. nor Mrs. George Gould was present, but Mrs. Edwin Gould, through the windows of the clubhouse, watched the golfers weathering the gale and snow.

Mrs. Nansen, represented as a particularly lively and strong woman, has been driven wild by the interviewer. She is said to have adopted at the end a manner something akin to imbecility. So when she was required to give the enterprising press representative some details of Nansen's explorations her mien was one of blank wonder. "Nansen? Did you say Nansen? I know nothing about Nansen."

Taking into consideration the times, the prices paid at the sale of the Crosby pictures are regarded as good. The sale took place on Wednesday evening at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, 366 Fifth Avenue, and the pictures in oil and water color -- sixty-six in number -- belonging to the estate of Mrs. F.E. Crosby, brought in total $54,405.
ALBANY, Feb. 12. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast to-day issued a general order announcing the Governor's approval of the recommendations of the Board on Uniforms and Equipments.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 12. -- Major McKinley's callers to-day numbered more than 150, and many of them had to wait several hours before they saw him. A flag, indicating that Lincoln's Birthday was not forgotten, floated from a third-story window.

There are two Morlands which provoke discussion in England. The pictures represent two handsome young women. One is washing lace in a basin, the other is ironing. Are they or are they not laundry maids, or young women of "quality"? There seems to be strong and positive evidence that the washer and the ironer were the Misses Gunning.

Some one -- was it Taine? -- has said of the young Englishman that he greets the morning with the remark, "It is a fine day; let us go and kill something." The number of sporting books that hail from the English press would certainly support this statement, and it must be said for the hunter of "big game," at least, that he is prepared to undergo, physical hardships in the satisfaction of his zest.

HAVANA, Feb. 5. -- For three days I have been taking bearing, as it were, or rather reviewing the situation before I start upon my tour of the island. My wheel is in good condition and runs lightly, and even if it is not taken from me I do not know that it will withstand the rough trails over which I will be compelled to go.

GLASGOW, Feb. 3. -- Queen Victoria's reign of sixty years is to be celebrated in so many ways in this country that a considerable boom in some branches of business may be expected. Gold, silver, and bronze medals are to be struck to celebrate the event, and in the hardware and soft goods, varieties of manufactures are to be fashionable in commemoration of the event.

Prof. GEORGE GUNTON has a variety of reasons to account for BRYAN'S vote in New York last year, but they do not agree very well one with another. He is sure that the Mugwumps from 1884 to 1896 did the most mischief. They set the workingmen against the Republican Party by teaching them that the policy of protection injured them.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 13. -- It must go down in the history of golf at Lakewood that the first tournament of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club was planned under an unfavorable star. After once being postponed from New Year's Day because of the snow, it seemed quite unnecessary that the ground should be white again, with falling sleet and a high wind on Friday, Lincoln's Birthday, which was the time set.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 13. -- Sidney Root, the closest personal friend of Jefferson Davis after the war, died in this city this morning. He had reached the age of seventy-three, and had been very feeble for some time. For months he had been confined to his home, and for the past week he had been compelled to remain in bed.
The first bulletin of the New York Public Library has made its appearance, and we now know what has been accomplished in the past, and what is to be done in the future.

" A coal mine is nothing but a hole in the ground," William H. Vanderbilt ejaculated when Franklin B. Gowen in urging him to come to the financial aid of the Reading Railroad cited the extensive mining possessions of that company as a valuable asset.
ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the following bills:

The proposal of our charter makers to cut down the salaries of City Magistrates from $8,000 to $6,000 a year is not a wise one. The Magistrates are and ought to be required to forego private law practice and devote their time wholly to the public service. If this leaves too much time on their hands, it shows that there are too many Magistrates, and not that their salaries are too high.

In line with the criticisms made by the "new journalism" and some of the uninvited persons, on the arrangements for the Bradley Martin ball, was an attack on Deputy Chief Cortright and the police, who kept Thirty-third Street, from Fifth Avenue to Broadway, cleared of curious crowds while the guests were arriving.

The Meshveret, an organ of the Young Turkey party, printed in Paris, publishes a story purporting to come from a former Sergeant in the Turkish Army, who says that he was a witness of the assassination of Midhat Pasha.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The House to-day in committee of the whole considered the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill.

A large class of women listened to Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders in the second of her course of lectures upon "Health Food" in the department of domestic science of the Brooklyn Institute last week. The subject was "Exercise and Massage."

BERLIN, Feb. 13. -- The policy of Germany in regard to Crete, according to direct authority from the Foreign Office, is in strict adherence to the course agreed upon by the concert of the powers recently established in respect of Turkey, and it is further announced, upon the same authority, that Germany particularly stands by the side of Austria and will support Austria's lead in the present crisis.

Miss Leila Lockwood of the Mount Vernon School for Girls, speaking recently of the proper dress for school children, said: "I am much gratified at the interest parents are taking in this subject. I find now that there are few corsets, few high-heeled shoes, and a large proportion of sensible gowns worn by the girls.

AITKIN, Minn., Feb. 13. -- During the present very severe Winter in Northern Minnesota the wolves, which abound in the swamps and scantily settled timber lands, have become very bold under the pressure of hunger. These wolves generally feed on deer and rabbits, but when wolves and deer are abundant the latter very soon tire of their voracious neighbors, and effect a temporary change of base.

One of the distressing results of the hard times during the past year has been the neglect and abandonment of young children by their parents. There are six or eight cases on record where the police have come across children deserted in the streets, and have been unable to find parents or relatives, either by systematic search or by advertisement.

Sleighing on Fifth Avenue below Fifty-ninth Street will be possible to-day and tomorrow unless some unexpected orders are given to the contractors by the Department of Public Works. Yesterday no snow had been removed from this thoroughfare, and no indication of intention to remove it today was given.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- The Massachusetts Reform Club dined at Young's last evening. Congressman Charles N. Fowler of New Jersey, who took a prominent part in the recent business men's convention in Indianapolis, was the special guest of the evening and spoke on "Specific Remedies for the Evils of Our Present Currency System."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- The American Lloyds, a New York insurance corporation, instituted a proceeding in mandamus, and filed a motion for an alternative writ in the Supreme Court to-day, to compel Insurance Commissioner W.S. Matthews to issue a license permitting the company to do business in Ohio.

The joint Legislative Committee appointed to investigate trusts resumed its sittings yesterday. Chairman Lexow had adjourned it last Monday to meet at 9 A.M. yesterday, but the members did not get together until a few minutes before 10. Patrick H. McCarren, Democratic Senator from Brooklyn, appeared on the committee in the place of Senator Gallagher, who resigned some days ago on account of sickness in his family.
The following is from the philosophic pen of The Boston Herald's financial editor:

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The resuscitation of the French proverbe at the Comedie Francaise is the theatrical event of the hour. M. Pailleron's new piece, "Meux vant Douceur -- et Violence!" has been talked about in literary salons for many weeks past. In fact, it has been too much talked about. We were told that it represented the famous Academician's delaissement during the labor of producing a more serious work.

The Committee of Citizens selected by Mayor Strong to take charge of the ceremonies incident to the transfer of the Grant Memorial in Riverside Park to the city on April 27 met in the Governor's Room of the City Hall yesterday.
SEPTEMBER 11. Latitude 81 degrees 40 minutes north, longitude 2 degrees east.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- All the public squares on Pennsylvania Avenue are being covered with stands, preparatory to the inauguration, and the city is making ready to accommodate the large crowds which are expected to arrive here before inaugural week.

In the course of lectures that he is giving at the American Museum of Natural History, under the auspices of the State Department of Public Education, Prof. Albert S. Bickmore has already described and illustrated the most interesting scenes on the Continents of North America and Africa, and he has now transferred his studies to Asia.

There have been two balls during the past week the reception of which by the various organs of public opinion has been very different. Curiously enough, it was the private ball, with which the public really had no business, that has attracted by far the greatest share of public attention.

-- Prof. OTIS T. MASON, Curator of the Ethnological Museum of Washington, has made a study of primitive methods of transportation, and in a lecture on the subject delivered at Philadelphia last week he said that the practice of bearing burdens on the back, supported by a band across the forehead, was typical of the North American aborigines, and that the practice may be traced from Alaska down to Central America.

A valentine dinner was given last night by the Woman's Press Club, at the Windsor Hotel. There were 250 persons present, and each received a valentine. The menu cards were decorated with hearts, cupids' arrows, and various emblems of St. Vaentine. Each guest wore a red pasteboard heart, and the informal speeches were devoted to love and valentines.

The Rev. Dr. Emil G. Hirsch, the Chicago rabbi who came to this city to deliver the Lincoln Day oration before the Verein Freundschaft, was visited by a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, with whom he talked on various topics.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- Mr. Rhodes is credited with having a trump card to play in the game of disclosures before the Select Committee on the Transvaal raid. He is said to be in possession of letters that passed long prior to the Jameson expedition between President Kruger and Emperor William and between Dr. Leyds and the German Foreign Minister.
I,EXIXGTON, Ky., Feb.-.13. -- John Iarrs this morning killed his four-year-old son, John, shot his fourteen-year-old daughter, I-Ielen, tried to kill his sister, Ida, and killed himself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The meeting of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations this morning made it apparent that no agreement could be reached on the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain that would bring the contending factions, -- either in the committee or in the Senate, together.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington society was well represented to-day before the Senate Committee on the Library at a hearing given to the representatives of rival societies of Colonial Dames upon bills introduced by Senators Hale of Maine and Lodge of Massachusetts, respectively, to incorporate the Society of Colonial Dames of America, and the National Society of Colonial Dames of America.

Prof. E.A. MacDowell has succeeded in making the new department of music under his charge in Columbia University popular with the students. Now he will branch out and endeavor to attract public attention to the department.
The heavy snow of Friday, followed by a frost during the night, put the roads in prime condition for sleighing yesterday, and New Yorkers were not slow to take advantage of the condition.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- The Republican County Central Committee this afternoon chose George Beard, a McKinley-Keifer man, for Chairman. The selection simply dazes the Bushnell-Foraker people, who did not have an inkling that Beard would enter in the race.

Joseph A. Iasigi, the Turkish Consul General at Boston, Mass., was arrested last evening by Central Office detectives at the Albemarle Hotel. He was taken to Police Headquarters and locked up on a charge of embezzlement.
" I like the classical drama best. You know Irving says that when one can do the classical drama well one can do anything."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- According to the reports from the Inauguration Committee headquarters there will be in line, in the parade on inauguration day about fifty civic organizations and eight military organizations. The expected military turnout was to include the Pennsylvania National Guard, several regiments of the National Guard of New York, the West Point and Annapolis cadets, and several separate companies.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- Joseph A. Iasigi, who was arrested in New York to-night on a Boston warrant, is not only Turkish Consul here, but is one of the wealthiest and most aristocratic members of the Back Bay set and a member of the Somerset Club.

The optimistical theorists of the Charter Commission recall Dr. JOHNSON'S comment upon the widower who remarried, though his wedded life had been unhappy: "Sir, it is the triumph of hope over experience." In the constitution of their Municipal Assembly it has been recognized by everybody that they are hopelessly abstract and theoretical.

HOBOKEN, with its quaint old Dutch name, is known throughout the country as the spot where, on its Elysian Fields, the great financier, statesman, and co-organizer of the Republic, Alexander Hamilton, was shot in a duel by the brilliant and dissolute Aaron Burr.

The past week was an extraordinarily dull one for the brokers -- duller, in fact, than has been indicated by the reports of sales at private contract during any week since last September. None of the small number of transactions was, moreover, of the slightest significance so far as its relation to the market of the immediate future is concerned.

THE most wretched as well as the most brilliant period of Edgar Allan Poe's life was spent in Fordham -- in the humble little cottage which has lately been the subject of so much curiosity, controversy, and legislative enactment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- It was very evident Thursday night that the sparse attendance at the White House reception to Congress and the Judiciary just a fortnight earlier was to be attributed to the bad weather, the opera, and some other inconvenience and diversions rather than to lack of interest in an expiring Administration.

We print elsewhere a characteristic communication from Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS about the Public Library. The view which the writer takes of that institution is, we venture to say, peculiar to himself. The charge he makes against the Trustees of the Lenox and of the Astor Library is a grave one.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Members of the Legislature are protesting under their breath because of the "orders" they receive from the representatives of the Republican organization with reference to pending legislation. These orders, they complain, refer to subjects which have nothing to do with political questions, but are matters of business, pure and simple, among them being the bills relating to telephone companies, to railroad companies, and to other corporations.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- There was a large assemblage in the Princess Room of the Hotel Cecil at 3 o'clock this afternoon, owing to the fact that the British chess players were in the lead. Lawrence's defeat was much deplored, as he was considered one of the strongest players.

Gen. Jo Shelby died at his farm, near Adrian, Mo., yesterday morning, aged sixty-six years. He was born in Lexington, Ky. He obtained what was considered in those days a fair education, and entered mercantile life. At the age of nineteen years he settled in Waverly, Mo., and engaged in the manufacture of bale rope.

Members of the Manhattan Club admitted unofficially yesterday that John D. Crimmins had transmitted his resignation as Treasurer to Frederic R. Coudert, the President of the club. It has been known for some time that he wished to be relieved of the duties and responsibilities of the office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Senate to-day, without question and without a moment's consideration, adopted a joint resolution introduced by Mr. Perkins (Rep., Cal.,) to have a naval vessel placed at the disposal of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce to transport wheat and corn contributed by California, Oregon, and other States for the relief of the famine-stricken people of India.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The Assembly yesterday adopted a resolution asking Gov. Black to transmit to it the report of a special commission which investigated and recommended to Gov. Morton a new arm for the State National Guard. This report, which has never seen daylight, and was thought to have been buried out of sight, was once the centre of scandalous charges brought before Gov. Morton.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- The management of the Yale athletic organizations this noon admitted that the final effort was in progress to settle the Yale-Harvard controversy.

An event of great interest in the history of ecclesiastical music in this country will be the celebration on Tuesday of this week of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the introduction of the Gregorian or plain chant into the ritual of the Church of the Paulist Fathers, on Feb. 11, Quinquagesima Sunday, 1872.

The Hon. CHARLES H. GROSVENOR is a Representative in Congress from the Eleventh District of Ohio. He has served four terms in the House, and has been elected for a fifth. He is a Connecticut Yankee by birth, an Ohio lawyer and politician by education and practice. He was a gallant soldier in the war for the Union, and fought his way up from the rank of Major to that of Colonel, with Brigadier brevet.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 13. -- The most disastrous blizzard of the Winter is raging over Minnesota, both Dakotas, and Western Wisconsin. Snow fell steadily thirteen hours, and to-night a forty-mile wind is blowing. The drifts are from three to ten feet deep, and travel by wagon road is entirely suspended.

Mary Mary McNerney, a crippled widow, seventy-six years old, was burned to death about 3 P.M. yesterday on the fourth floor of the tenement at 31 First Street. She was alone in the rooms, where she lived with her two grown daughters, when the fire occurred.

The annual meeting of the Larchmont Yacht Club is to be held at Delmonico's Wednesday evening. Clarence A. Postley, owner of the schooner Colonia, has been nominated for Commodore; E.S. Hatch of the yawl Huron, for Vice Commodore, and Major Charles F. Ulrich of the cabin naphtha yacht Blitz, for Rear Commodore.

The Sir George Newnes Cup, neatly packed in a mahogany chest, will be placed, next Wednesday, in the hold of a trans-Atlantic steamer bound for England. This is the consequence of the defeat which the American chess players suffered at the hands of their British opponents yesterday, in the international chess tournament, losing in addition to the trophy, the championship wrested from Great Britain a year ago.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- The last delegate to the League of American Wheelmen Assembly left for home this afternoon. It was Mr. Monahan of Southern California. Everything is harmonious once more in the ranks of the League of American Wheelmen, apparently, as far as the East is concerned.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The Metropolitan Street Railway Company of New York City to-day filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of its intention to make proposed extensions of its line on the Bowery, from Delancey to Broome to Cherry Street, to connect with an extension of the Broadway and Seventh Avenue Railroad Company.

IT was interesting to note the consensus of opinion in the critical press in regard to the B minor symphony of Borodine, the Russian composer, produced at the latest concert of the Symphony Society. There was a general agreement that it lacked nothing in the way of vigor and color, and that it was thoroughly Russian.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- John Jenkins, the prize fighter, who was indicted by the recent Grand Jury for taking a principal part in a "mill" at Enon, one year ago, has been sentenced to one year in the penitentiary.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- The Chronicle publishes the following: "All the carefully-thought-out arrangements of the men who made the theatre trust may feel the force of a head-end collision with an actors' cambination some day not far off. And if things continue to gravitate aslant in the theatrical world, this is what stage people expect to see happen.

THE lives of the painters that Vasari wrote, what a storehouse of information and personal gossip does not the simple mention of them recall to the mind, and what days and nights of the most delightful reading in all the range of biographical writings, ancient or modern?

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- Major McKinley's sole callers when he stepped out of his breakfast room this morning were Dr. and Mrs. Seward Webb of New York. Dr. Webb talked for more than an hour with the President-elect, and left at noon on a special train for Cleveland.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13. -- Princeton has been overrun to-day and yesterday with visitors from New York, Philadelphia, and surrounding towns, the occasion being the great social event of the Winter season -- the Junior Promenade. The guests began arriving yesterday morning, and ever since the campus and clubs have swarmed with girls and their mammas and chaperons.

ANNAPOLIS, Feb. 13. -- Deep is the interest in and earnest the work of preparation for the Spring races at the Naval Academy. Before Christmas the squad from which the crew was to be evolved was in the embryo, training in the gymnasium, and never before has the crew made such progress for the great events of May and June which will give the racing on the Severn the coming season a National interest.

It may be regarded as a symptom of the times that a costly private ball given at a prominent hotel in this city should have excited a general discussion of the question of the propriety of rich people squandering large sums of money in extravagant luxury and ostentatious display.

The Rev. Dr. E.G. Hirsch of Chicago occupied Dr. Kohler's pulpit in Temple Beth-El, Seventy-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning. He chose for his text the lesson of the day, Exodus 28, and the general subject of his sermon was "Religion -- A Consoler." In the course of his sermon he said:

HAVANA, Feb. 13. -- Gen. Weyler continues to advance into the Santa Clara Province. He is escorted by Gens. Prats, Gasco, and Ruiz, and Cols. Albergoti, Maroto, and Rubin, with four and a half brigades of troops.

The cycle show in Grand Central Palace came to an end last evening after having had the largest patronage ever accorded to an industrial exhibition in this city. Not including yesterday's figures, which were enormous, the daily records show an aggregate attendance of 104,469, divided as follows: Saturday evening, (opening,) 11,000; Monday, 14,000; Tuesday, 18,450; Wednesday, 20,401; Thursday, 19,265; Friday, 19,353.
LEXINGTON, Va., Feb. 13. -- The Hon. John Randolph Tucker died at 8:05 o'clock to-night. He was conscious up to a few hours of his death, and died very quietly.
