WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- New York members of the House are not a little annoyed because Representative White of Illinois has undertaken to direct the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds in their action upon the New York Custom House bill. A report of his attack upon the measure was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- There is still time in which the Senate may pass a Bankruptcy bill if good use can be made of time now being wasted. As it is generally admitted by Senators that the arbitration treaty with not be approved at this session, the friends of a bankrupt law are hopeful that a few hours a day may be given to consideration of the subject.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 13. -- In spite of a heavy covering of snow and freezing weather, the golf tournament of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club went merrily on. Two good contests were decided to-day, and each brought out a surprisingly large number of entries, considering the difficulty of playing a good game on snow-clad links and over greens thickly incrusted with a mixture of packed snow and ice.

JULIA MARLOWE is an actress of rare personal charm, of extraordinary artistic perception, of excellent natural gifts and good training fancy no one will deny these statements. This actress has suffered, probably, less than any other of her distinction from unjust and hostile criticism.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 13. -- They say down at Admiral Bunce's fleet to-day that it was neither a fair nor an official test, but the fact still remains that the Vesuvius ran the blockade into the harbor last night with an ease that startled the squadron. The run was made early in the evening, the cruiser crossing the deadline and whistling a notice of her success at 7:32 o'clock.

The sub-committee of the bridge Trustees appointed to consider the report of the experts who decided that the elevated and surface cars could safely use the bridge for the transportation of passengers met yesterday at the bridge office, in Brooklyn. President Berri, Mayor Wurster, Controller Palmer, Chief Engineer Martin, Presidents Rossiter, Solomon, Sullivan, and Partridge of the surface roads and President Uhlmann of the Union Elevated were present.
" I probably received the last letter that Lincoln ever wrote. I didn't keep it, but I would give a thousand dollars for it now."

The Italian missionary work started at the Mariners Temple, in Oliver Street, about three years ago, has met with such continued success that in all probability a new church will be established within the coming six months. This will be organized as the First Italian Baptist Church of New York City, and it will be an event of more than usual interest as the result of home missionary work.
Water and a tub mean much to a healthy person; they mean more to a cleanly household, and they mean still more to a municipality in which an intelligent regard for sanitary conditions prevails.

A fire which tested the discipline of the Roosevelt Hospital staff occurred last evening, and, though it caused damage to one of the buildings estimated at $20,000 by the firemen, no life was lost, and, save two firemen cut by falling glass, no one was injured.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 13. -- Clay Clement, the character actor starring in "The New Dominion," was taken severely ill with an attack of pneumonia while playing here last night. A doctor who called braced him up so that he managed to get through his performance, but not without great suffering. After the show his condition became worse, and he is now laid up here.

GRAMMAR SCHOOL NO. 86, for the past eight years in the handsome and commodious building at the southeast corner of Ninety-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, is nearly fifty years old. It was originally known as No. 37, and its first location was in a small frame building at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, then a sparsely settled neighborhood in the heart of the Yorkville district.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- It is many years since Europe confronted a situation at once so menacing and so obscure as that which opened out before her this week. It is seen that very little will be needed to produce a convulsion of the first magnitude, yet we are entirely without information as to the position which any one of the powers is prepared to assume toward any phase of what seems to be impending.

The annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, which is to be held Wednesday evening, Feb. 17, at Delmonico's, will be one of the most important events in the golf world this season. Several important matters will have to be decided and, judging from a partial list of the delegates already chosen, the representation of able golf men will be one of the most imposing ever brought together.
Four cities are trying to solve a mystery that has grown out of the sudden disappearance of Charles A. Jackson of Jackson, Mich., who is said to have been kidnapped.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- The inaugural wardrobe of Mrs. William McKinley, preparations for which have been the subject of two visits to this city on the part of the coming first lady of the land, is completed. Nearly all of the materials are imported.

The annual dual games between Columbia and Princeton will be held this year at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge. Columbia bases her hopes on her crack cycle team and newly acquired athletes. Capt. Fearing is very sanguine as to the results of the intercollegiate cycling championship. Every one of last year's victorious riders is back again this year, with the exception of H.K. Bird.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 14. -- British makers of iron and steel products are alarmed by the invasion of their home markets by American manufacturers. It is stated that tin plate bars have been exported to the Welsh tinned plate mills for several months, and that some of the tinned plates imported recently were made out of American steel.

A wave of infidelity swept over "Val" Stark's Bowery mission meeting yesterday afternoon. Mr. Stark has adopted the plan of answering questions, and his meetings at 382 Bowery are attended by people of all, shades of belief and unbelief, who generally hold lively discussions. The meeting yesterday was of an unusually boisterous character, some young men of atheistic tendencies having come in to combat the young missionary's teachings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Some members of the Inauguration Committee are beginning to talk quietly about an alleged plot to belittle the ceremonies. They admit that they have no evidence on the subject, but say that recent events have caused the belief to become general in the committee that certain hostile influences are at work to prevent Major McKinley's inauguration becoming an unusual event.

BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- Society takes the arrest of Joseph A. Iasigi as a blow. It had been known in the clubs to which he was attached that he was in some kind of trouble, but it was set down as a civil matter, and just what it was nobody cared to find out until the telephone rang out late Saturday night its astonishing announcement of Iasigi's arrest.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 14. -- Superintendent J.M. Barr of the Great Northern Road has tendered his resignation. The circular announcing the retirement of Mr. Barr and the appointment of Russell Harding as his successor is expected soon. Mr. Barr has been General Superintendent of the Great Northern since last July.

Upper Third Avenue was crowded with pedestrians yesterday afternoon shortly after 1 o'clock, when an accident, which caused considerable excitement, occurred at the corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Third Avenue.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The reform of the Military Procedure Code is once again engaging political and official attention. It was expected that the Reichstag would see some perfected bill before it during the present session, but it transpires that the divergence of views between the Federal States, which were announced as being on the joint of agreement, has become accentuated and broadened.

A committee from the Social Reform Club, consisting of Ernest H. Crosby, James B. Reynolds, and Moses Oppenheimer, called yesterday on the Central Labor Union, and asked its co-operation in urging the authorities of the City Government to provide work at once for the unemployed. The Rev. Dr. Rainsford had also been appointed on thin committee, but he was unable to attend.

Every Winter the question of evening dress for men has arisen in New York social circles, and has caused much discussion. The old, embarrassing mistake in speaking to a waiter for a gentleman and to a gentleman for a waiter has been a nightmare to many of the prominent beaus, and some of them have been agitating constantly the adoption of some distinctive style of dress.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 14. -- A great mining enterprise has just been started at the foot of Pike's Peak, on the eastern slope, near Colorado Springs. The work is under the supervision of L.S. Nye of 10 Wall Street, New York, and it is known as the Pike's Peak Tunnel, Mining and Transportation Company, with a capitalization of $50,000,000 -- 500,000 shares of a par value of $100 each.

The rigid Government inspection as applied to export cattle is operating to the advantage of Northern farmers and dealers. The cattle industry has been stimulated during the last two years by an improvement in prices, the better facilities for marketing and the discriminating care of buyers in selecting well-bred, as well as properly fattened, stock.
BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The Kaiser has appointed the most prominent professors of the Royal Academy to design the costumes for the fancy dress ball fixed for Feb. 24 at the Royal Castle.

-- A Philadelphia paper announces that Prof. HERMANN V. HILPRECHT, the archaeologist and Assyriologist, expects to sail for Europe again in April, and complete the work undertaken by him two years ago at the request of the Sultan of Turkey, of cataloguing and arranging the archaeological sections of the Royal Museum at Constatinople.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- State Controller Roberts has prepared and published, at his own expense, a souvenir book to be issued in connection with the celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the creation of the office of Controller in this State. The anniversary comes on Wednesday, and will be celebrated quietly with a dinner given by Mr. Roberts to the ex-Controllers, of whom there are eight living.
Mayor Strong was the guest of honor at the annual convention of District Grand Lodge No. 1, Indepedent Order Free Sons of Israel, held at the Lexington Opera House yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- The police have seized the books and accounts of the Concordia Life Insurance Company, and as a result of the subsequent examination of the records it was found that the company had only 4,000 paying clients, while at the same time its list of members contained 75,000 names. The losers through the fraudulent practices of the company are mostly in the ranks of the working people.

The municipal charge for water according to consumption, estimated by the front foot and the number of stories to a building, with an additional charge for each extra faucet, closet, and bath, or by meter, is an exhibition of legislative folly that experience shows is harmful. The theory that charges should be imposed according to use is made to apply to water consumers also.

In the Church of the Messiah, yesterday morning, the Rev. Minot J. Savage preached the fifth of his sermons on "Religion for To-day." The special subject was, "God as Inside the Universe, Not Outside." Dr. Savage said, in part:

Marco Fursco and Michael Mascalli of 83 Mulberry Street married sisters. About four months ago Fursco's wife eloped with her sister's husband. Fursco has since devoted himself to hunting up the fugitives. He and his brother Sabatti found Mascalli and Mrs. Fursco living together at Grand and Seventh Streets, Hoboken.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- William Sanford Lawton, of the firm of Foote and Lawton, with offices in the Home Life Building, New York City, committed suicide last night at 7 o'clock. Lawton sought a quiet spot in Lincoln Park, and shot himself in the right temple. He was found soon after in an unconscious condition and conveyed to the Alexian Brothers' Hospital, where he died at 10 o'clock.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Legislation is progressing slowly. Few important local measures affecting the various municipalities have thus far been introduced. Measures intended to carry out the principal policies of the Republican majority touching Greater New York, the excise, civil service, the Adirondack Park, and trusts are yet to come.

In the Senate last week the Secretary of Agriculture was attacked and denounced by several Silver Democrats and Republican bimetallists, who asserted that by him "the money of the people had been diverted from its legitimate purpose," meaning, we presume, that he had made an unauthorized and improper expenditure of the department's funds.
The Rev. A.J. Diaz, pastor of a Baptist Church in Havana, told of his experiences in Cuba, in the Church of the Strangers, Mercer Street, near Eighth Street, last night.
Great interest attaches in shipping circles to the report made by Col. George L. Gillespie, United States Engineer Corps, in charge of harbor improvement, to the War Department.
The following sales are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

Bishop Potter yesterday, in the Church of the Incarnation, made his second appeal on behalf of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. His first appeal was made some weeks ago in Grace Church, the results of which have been subscriptions of over $60,000.

PANAMA, Feb. 14. -- The Ecuador Land Company recently received from its lessees, the Pailon Company, Limited, trustworthy information to the effect that the Ecuador Government had declared parts of the settlement upon the Pailon estate held since 1861 to be waste lands, and had proceeded to hand them over to the traders from elsewhere, under the authority of the Governor of Esmaraldas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- When the Senate adjourned yesterday after another afternoon of useless discussion on the general arbitration treaty, the impression held by many Senators was that Mr. Sherman had become convinced that there was little, if any, chance of getting any action during this session of the Senate.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- After being closed four months for repairs, Christ Church was opened to-day for divine service. There was early communion at 8 o'clock and the regular service at 10:30 o'clock. In the evening, under the auspices of the St. Andrew's Brotherhood, addresses were made by the rector, the Rev. J. Seldon Spencer, who has been in charge of the parish forty-three years; Silas McBee, G.A. Warburton, and others.
Mrs. Annie Besant will arrive in this city early in March. She expects to remain in this country for six months, and will visit all the larger cities and deliver lectures.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 14. -- John G. Roach, a prominent distiller, left for Chicago last night to meet by special appointment a number of New York capitalists who may invest their money in Kentucky whisky for the purpose of keeping up the market and sustaining the prices.

Smoke coming through the cracks of the floor waked Tony Troiano at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and he found the four-story brick tenement house at 2,492 Second Avenue, on the first floor of which he lives with his family, to be on fire. He at once roused the tenants and called a policeman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- An Ohio Republican of undoubted veracity and intimate acquaintance with the President-elect has suggested to the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES that the dispatch published this morning from Washington stating that the belief is a settled one here that Mr. Depew is to go to England as Ambassador, overlooks the fact that there is another candidate for that high position in the State of New York.

At this season, when the socially inclined individual of no matter what class of society, may surfeit his soul with balls, receptions, and entertainments, efforts to secure a good attendance at the affairs has resulted in a fierce rivalry. Every "feature" calculated to interest the attention has been employed.

-- The bad weather has brought profit to the riding schools, and the tanbark rings of the various academies are well filled each day by enthusiastic equestrians. Extra music rides have been added to the regular programme, and new riding classes formed, and the various proprietors are jubilant over the fact that this season will be the most successful in a number of years.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 14. -- Last week's sales in the print cloth market will break the record. So far they amount to something over 1,100,000 pieces, including, of course, the 750,000 pieces which M.C.D. Borden purchased last Monday. The mills generally are refusing offers at 2 11-16 cents, and asking 2 3/4 cents for spot goods.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14. -- The State Board of Health has submitted its report for the year 1896 to Gov. Black. The board recommends that the terms of office of its members should be so arranged that the term of one member should expire each year, thus insuring a continuous board. The physician members should have at least ten years' actual experience and practice in sanitary matters.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- An open market for window glass and the collapse of the trust controlling it is predicted. A conference between the National Executive Committee of the trust and the Eastern importers and jobbers has been called for next Wednesday at the Hotel Imperial, in New York, and the fate of the combination hinges on the result.

The Greater New York Commission is dealing with the charter too much as though it was the affair of its members or of certain political powers to which they pay deference and not the business of the people who are to live under the government they are framing and pay for its support.
A dance was held in the main ballroom of Sherry's last Saturday evening by the members of Mrs. Anson Hard's dancing class, among which are many of the debutantes of the season.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Unless some legislators who have been conferring with Gov. Black and others on the proposed changes in the civil service law are mistaken those who favor the "Abe" Gruber variety of reform are likely to be disappointed. The radical measure which was first contemplated, in the opinion of the leaders will not be prepared at the suggestion of the organization leaders.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Feb. 10. -- As there are several murder trials impending in this State in which the State depends on circumstantial evidence for conviction, that class of evidence is under animated discussion in this State by both laymen and members of the bar.

" The Relationship of Mormonism to Christianity," as Elder Brigham H. Roberts expounded it in Hardman Hall last night, is that of a reincarnated spirit to a dead body. Next Sunday he will tell what is the Mormon conception of the Gospel thus revealed afresh.

Joseph A. Iasigi, the Turkish Consul General at Boston, Mass., who was arrested at the Albemarle Hotel Saturday, on a telegraphic dispatch from the Boston police that a warrant had been issued in that city for his arrest on a complaint charging embezzlement, spent Saturday night and yesterday and last night as a prisoner at Police Headquarters.

The list of arbitrations between the United States and other powers which Mr. SHERMAN laid before the Senate the other day has been printed. It is not complete, and there is no indication as to how nearly so it is. It embraces thirty-eight cases within almost exactly a century. Of these, nearly one-half, or fifteen, are with Great Britain, and they are the only ones of serious importance.
BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- The agreement between the athletic authorities of Harvard and Yale, which settles all points of dispute for five years, is as follows:

Work will be begun to-day on Blackwell's Island on the new charities buildings which are to be erected there at an expense of $400,000. The work on the island is but the beginning of improvements to be made under the direction of the Commissioners of Charities, on which the city will spend $1,000,000.

The funeral services of Armand Castelmary, the opera singer, who died suddenly Wednesday night on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, were held yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul. The body was taken on the 3:15 o'clock train to Kensico Cemetery and was put in the receiving vault, where it will be held until preparations can be made for its removal to France.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 14. -- The cotton mills of the South will not close down. This is an interesting and important piece of news from a commercial standpoint, when taken in connection with the statement that all the mills of the East have been ordered shut down, for an indefinite period, two days in every week.

The New York Public Library has issued the first bulletin for 1897. They will be issued monthly, and will record the progress of the great, library organized under the Astor, Lenox, and Tilden combination. It is also purposed to publish each month in these bulletins some famous, manuscript from the treasures of the library.

Policeman ROBERT C. CONNOR of the West Thirtieth Street Precinct and the Sergeant on duty at the station Sunday morning, if the reports made at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday be correct, should be sharply looked after by the Commissioners and charges should be ordered against them.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Some of the legislators are in trouble over the elaborate report of the Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission published a few weeks ago. Demands for copies are coming in by hundreds, and the supply is so limited that the legislators are compelled to refuse them. This makes trouble for the office holder among his constituents.

A new industry has sprung up in Kansas within the past few weeks, that of hunting jack rabbits for their pelts, which find ready sale at numerous points in the State, where they are collected and shipped to hat manufactories in the East. The discovery that the jack has a commercial value will undoubtedly prove his undoing.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 14. -- Admiral Bunce's squadron suspended their warlike work to-day and observed Sunday in regulation fashion. Episcopal service was held on the flagship New York, Catholic services on the Maine, and general services, including other denominations, were celebrated on the Columbia.

Edward Smith, a bachelor, fifty years old, was found dead in his home, at 172 Butler Street, Brooklyn, at noon yesterday by his friend, Robert Spierman, who lives a few doors away. Smith had been known for years as a man of miserly habits, and when the police searched his house they found bank books calling for nearly $13,000 and $235 in cash concealed in the lining of a sofa.

TORONTO, Ontario, Feb. 14. -- The trial of William Hammond upon the charge of murdering his girl wife, Katie Tough Hammond, last March, is set for to-morrow at Gravenhurst, and the prosecution is said to have the strongest combination of circumstantial evidence that has been put before a jury in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- "I read with interest," said Internal Revenue Collector William Ryan to a reporter of The Washington Post, "the story told by The St. Louis Globe-Democrat correspondent, reproduced in The Post of Friday, explaining why President Cleveland did not attend the funeral of ex-Vice President Hendricks.

We are having our periodic discussion of trusts and of the evil resulting, therefrom. But nowhere was Tweed's famous query more pertinent -- "What are you going to do about it?" Really, now, what are you going to do about it? My friend says, "Not anything through this Legislature." But can you through any Legislature make headway against the trusts as such? I think not. The evil lies further back.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 14. -- The death of an old man named Barber, in Hancock County, has proven quite a windfall to the State, since all the property that he left, amounting to $150,000, will be covered into the State treasury.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 14. -- Charles J. Bronston, State Senator for this county, eloped to St. Louis yesterday with Miss Belle Wisdom. In St. Louis they obtained a license to marry.
ATHENS, Feb. 14. -- Advices have been received here giving details of the detention at Candia of a Turkish vessel by a Greek warship.

Carnegie Hall was crowded in every part yesterday afternoon when Evangelist Moody began to preach. What has become quote a noticeable feature of the meetings is the fine attendance in the boxes. Yesterday the number of seats in boxes did not suffice to accommodate all who came. The singing service which J.H. Burke conducted was taken up spiritedly by the congregation.
The Senate can pass the House Bankruptcy bill this session if it chooses, and it ought to do so.

The emphatic but well-weighed and deliberate speech of Mr. WILLIAM E. DODGE at the Chamber of Commerce meeting in this city on the 4th inst. is exciting much interest and much hopeful feeling in the South. Mr. DODGE was a delegate to the sound-money convention at Indianapolis, and he afterward spent some time in Washington in connection with the Arbitration Committee.

Bishop Doane thinks women are too emotional to be trusted with the ballot, Mrs. Crannell, in confirmation of this view, cites the fact that at a political reception where there were ten thousand people and a great crush, "several women fainted," and that a number of young women in California hed tears when the woman suffrage amendment was defeated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14. -- The large poolroom which has been causing the wealthy citizens of Elmhurst so much trouble in the past month was burned to the ground at 5 A.M. to-day. According to two watchmen who were in the place just before the fire, it was the work of three incendiaries, who appeared and compelled them to leave while they carried out the plan of destruction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Supreme Court reassembled to-day to hear argument upon the appeal of the United States from the judgment of Judge Locke of the United States court in Florida in the case of the Three Friends, the steamer seized last November for engaging in Cuban filibustering movements.
The Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art met yesterday in the offices in the museum building.

The excitable SOVEREIGN, who holds the title of General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, has written a letter which appears in a "labor organ" in Denver about the revolutionary plot of two secret revolutionary societies, the "Iron Brotherhood" and the "Industrial Army."

" The times are not as hard for the poor as some people represent them" said the Rev. William I. Nichols, General Secretary of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities. "Of course, there is great need; there always is at this season, and it ought to be properly met. It is not met by indiscriminate charity.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 15. -- Major McKinley was unable to receive any of the numerous politicians who were on hand early this morning. He is suffering with a mild attack of influenza, and was confined to his bed until this evening, when the family physician permitted him to sit up for a time.

The new double-track system was successfully operated on the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday, with fourteen in place of twelve trains and a reduction in headway from ninety to seventy-five seconds. Both sides of the outer-track platforms at the terminals were used, and the excessive crowding which has made travel by the bridge so unpleasant was considerably abated.

The trial of William J. Koerner for killing Miss Rose Redgate, his betrothed, at Fourteenth Street and Seventh Avenue, Sept. 23, 1896, was begun yesterday before Judge Newburger in General Sessions. The murder is admitted. The difficulty of the prosecution is to establish a motive. The defense is insanity induced by phenacetine, cocaine, and other drugs.

The Meadowmere Kennels announce that they will give eight silver cups as special prizes at the coming dog show in the Madison Square Garden -- six for the best poodles sired by Emperor and Champion Milo from 1891 through 1896, the best dog of each year winning, and two cups for the best poodles purchased from the kennels.
ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Governor sent to the Senate to-night the following nominations:
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Isaac Van Bomel, 124 West Ninety-first Street, a five-story limestone and brick double apartment house, 33.4 by 90 by 100, to Mr. Thomas.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- On Friday or Saturday of last week Rose Coghlan, the actress, who last week played in this city in "The Sporting Duchess," lost a valuable diamond and ruby horseshoe. The robbery was discovered by her on Saturday night as she was packing up her belongings to leave the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Bankruptcy bill was taken up as the unfinished business in the Senate to-day. The Senate substitute for the bill was read in full. The reading having been concluded, a substitute for the first sixteen sections was offered by Mr. Nelson (Rep., Minn.) It was not read. The bill was then laid aside.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The new Belgian Minister, Count de Lichtewelde, was presented to the President this morning.

The vote by which the Senate yesterday overrode the Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee and gave the freedom of the arena to the turbulent MORGAN was not quite a fair test of the sentiment of that body for and against arbitration, since Senator TURPIE and one or two others who favor peaceful methods voted in favor of taking up the purely obstructive business of smashing the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- E.P. Speer of Georgia, a Chief of Division in the Treasury Department, this afternoon, while in his office, became involved in a quarrel with William Callan, a collector, during which Speer stabbed Callan. Callan was taken to the Emergency Hospital, where his wounds were dressed.

CANEA, Feb. 15. -- The commanders of the British and other foreign warships stationed here have informed Prince George, commanding the Greek torpedo flotilla, that they have received orders to prevent the occupation of the Island of Crete by Greece, and, if necessary, to use force to carry out these instructions.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 15. -- Late Saturday night officers arrested as a "suspect" man who gave his name as Harry Davis. To-day it was learned that Davis is none other than Harry Crawford, wanted in Ohio for murder. He was taken into custody as he was leaving the home of his brother, Edward S. Crawford, on South Tenth Street, near Colfax Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A new point has arisen in the case of the Bermuda, now detained at Philadelphia, different from any attaching to other suspected filibustering vessels, with the possible exception of the Danish steamer Horsa.

The ice carnival of St. Valentine, a fancy-costume affair, very prettily presented, entertained a large gathering of Brooklyn fashionable society in the Clermont Skating Rink last evening. The carnival was held for the benefit of the Brooklyn Nursery and Infants' Hospital. A beautiful arrangement of electric lights of various colors and fine music added their charms.

It was a very large and fashionable audience which witnessed the production of the comic operetta "Cleopatra" by the Columbia University boys at the Carnegie Lyceum last night. Financially, as otherwise, the play was a success. Cleopatra has had her romance recited in many ways, but certainly never was such a unique turn given the tale as in the version Charles Chapin Sargent, Jr., has written.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The Times will publish to-morrow a dispatch from Canea giving details of the landing from the foreign warships of the force which occupied Canea. The debarkation of the men took place in the afternoon under the direction of the Italian Admiral, who is the senior commander.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 15. -- President M.H. Smith of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad has written a long newspaper article in defense of the Anti-Scalpers' bill, in which he denounces the scalpers in the strongest terms. In one paragraph he says:
WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Feb. 15. -- Government Engineer C.B. Scars to-day opened bids for dredging the harbors of Superior and Duluth under the continuing contract system.

The celebration of tho Iussian Festival of the Presentation of Christ in he Temple, at the Russian Orthodox hurch, in this city, Sunday, was marked by- a r'her unique ceremony, tile baptism of a young Jewish convert into the Church.

We print this morning another letter from the correspondent who attributed the difficulty in getting satisfactory men into elective offices to our nominating system. In this he sets forth in outline his ideas as to the remedy for this difficulty, and simultaneously with this letter we have received a printed leaflet signed by J.N. LARNED dealing with the same matter in more detail.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Governor sent to the Assembly to-night the report of the commission appointed two years ago to select an arm for the National Guard. This report, which recommended the Savage gun, was disapproved by Gov. Morton, after scandalous charges had been made in connection with the selection of the weapon.
At a meeting of members of this club held to-day the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Methodist clergymen who attended the meeting of the Metropolitan District Association yesterday, at 150 Fifth Avenue, became involved in a discussion of the infallibility of the Scriptures. The meeting was executive, and those who were present are unwilling to give details, but it is known that some sharp things were said on either side of the proposition.

A New York merchant who has had commercial and other interests in the Island of Cuba for many years, and who has frequently visited many of the prominent towns in the central and western provinces, has given this statement to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

One of the most important questions which will come before the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association to-morrow night at Delmonico's will be the limit of handicap allowance for eligibility to the amateur championship tournament.

President Silas C. Croft of the Commissioners of Public Charities, when asked yesterday about the conference the Commissioners will have to-day with the committees of the Social Reform Club and the Central Labor Union in regard to giving employment to men out of work, said:
NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 15. -- Warm, rainy weather, and a heavy track were features in the racing to-day. Three favorites won.

Gen. COLLIS is entitled to credit for giving fair notice to the residents of Fifth Avenue that that thoroughfare will be out of order "until next Winter." It is considerate of him to let them know so that they may make their arrangements to leave town earlier than they are in the habit of doing in the Spring and to return later than they are in the habit of doing in the Autumn.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The many rumors concerning what actually occurred in Athens as a result of the two conferences of the diplomatic representatives of the powers yesterday, and the subsequent representation of the conclusions arrived at by the conference to Premier Delyannis, M. Bouree, the French Minister, being the spokesman of the diplomats, have been set at rest by a semi-official statement which was given out here to-day.

Julia Marlowe secured a triumph, memorable and complete, in a new role at Wallack's Theatre last evening. In all her previous engagements in this city she has suffered somewhat from the influence of inevitable comparisons. Remembrance is the keenest enjoyment of the old and critical playgoer, and frequently the young actor's bane and confusion.

There has been more discussion over the subject of quick consumption, pneumonia, and sudden deaths within the last six months than ever before. Doctors, and all thinking people have been interested in it, and the fact that more than two-thirds of all deaths arise from throat and lung troubles has intensified it.

ATHENS, Feb. 15. -- Advices received hers from the Island of Crete anounce that the "Corps of Occupation," consisting of infantry, artillery, and engineers, and numbering 1,500 men, which embarked at Piraeus yesterday, have landed at Platanias, fourteen kilometres west of Canea.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The matter of the disorders in Crete and the independent action taken by Greece in sending a torpedo flotilla and transport ships with troops to that island, came up in the House of Lords to-day, when Lord Salisbury declared that reforms for the Island of Crete had been arranged and were already being put into effect when Greece intervened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of the exports of merchandise from the United States during the month of January, 1897, and during the seven months ended Jan. 31, 1897, as compared with similar reports during the corresponding periods of the preceding year were as follows: January, 1897, $94,984,067; January, 1896, $86,970,028.

The glory of Navarino will be effaced at Canea if the Western powers put a restraining hand on Greece. For generations Turkey has put them off with promises of reforms and fooled them and defied them. They are partners in her deceptions. The blood she has shed stains their garments.

A car wheel enveloped in a cloud of steam was the device drawn by a friend of George Stephenson early in the present century to typify "the railways of the future." That was at a time when the professional engineers of Great Britain were scoffing at Stephenson for daring to appear before a committee of Parliament and urge the superiority of locomotive engines over stationary engines.

You say this morning, "a correspondent whose letter we printed two days ago attributed all our trouble to the existing 'methods of nomination,' and urged that we 'bend our efforts to change the methods by which we nominate our candidates for office, and keep our heritage of popular self-government,' but he did not intimate what methods he would substitute for those in use."

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- There was a taste of old-time sentiment on Change this morning, wheat, having a jump of more than 1 1/2c from the Saturday closing the first minute. The feeling was not all one way. The shorts were scared to cover, but, at the same time, holders welcomed the temporary strength to market their lines, already heavy on their hands.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- The will of Albert M. Billings, who died Feb. 7, was admitted to probate to-day. The estate in Illinois is valued at $2,300,000, which is a smaller amount than Mr. Billings popularly was supposed to be worth.
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Prof. Charles Tomlinson, F. R. S.; F. C. S.; the well-known writer and lecturer upon scientific subjests, died at Highgate to-day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Inventor Gathmann has succeeded in obtaining from the Navy Department permission to make a test of his dynamite shell exactly on the lines which he originally indicated.

HAVANA, Feb. 15. -- Gen. Aldave, with two columns of Spanish troops, has entered the town of Siguannea, in the Province of Santa Clara, defeating the insurgent forces, which were intrenched there, and pursuing them to the Niguendo Hills.

-- A German professor has been studying that article of masculine apparel which the irreverent call a "stovepipe," and has found in it proof of man's superiority to woman. Time was, he says, when men, like women now, ornamented their hats with ribbons and feathers more or less beautiful, and wore garments of the brightest colors they could find.

The Turkish Consul at Boston was arrested in this city, through a telegraphic request to the police by the police of Boston, where it seems he is "wanted" on a charge of embezzlement. Warrants for his arrest were issued by a magistrate of Boston and have been forwarded by mail.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 15. -- Representative Jackson of Columbia County this afternoon called up a bill he introduced in the House several days ago, reducing the salary of members of the Legislature from $6 to $5 a day.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Gov. Black has been so overrun with public business and with visitors that he has fixed upon regular hours when he will be accessible to visitors in the Executive Chamber. The hours will be from 10:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. and from 3 to 4 P.M.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 15. -- J.R. Sovereign, General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, has written a sensational letter to The Industrial Advocate, with Private Dalzell's exhortation for war with a foreign nation as his text.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The British steamer Mobile Capt. Layland, from New York Feb. 1, for London, passed the Lizard this morning and signaled that she had lost sixty head of cattle and nine horses on the voyage.

William Pope St. John, the former President of the Mercantile National Bank, who gained National prominence through his advocacy and support of the free-silver cause, died Sunday night at his home, 121 East Thirty-fourth Street. He had been sick for some time -- really since the close of the campaign in November -- and his death was not wholly unexpected by his relatives and near friends who knew the nature of his disease.

The little article on the "Forgetfulness of Authors" in this week's number of the Sunday Magazine Supplement of THE TIMES is of interest to me. Only last night I read the "Strange Ride of Morrowbie Jukes." A number of queer things in it set me to thinking just what a man would do in such circumstances.

The joint legislative committee, appointed to investigate trusts, resumed its examination into the affairs of the Sugar Trust yesterday. The investigation was conducted on somewhat new lines, and more interesting results were obtained than in any or all of the previous sesions of the committee.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- A special to The Inter Ocean from Fond du Lac, Wis., says:

Samuel Fishblatt, arrested on Monday night by Agent Agnew of the Gerry Society for the abduction of Bessie Turtle, fourteen years old, was arraigned before Magistrate Mott in the Harlem Court yesterday morning, and held in $2,500 bail for examination on Thursday.

CHICAGO, Fe}). 16. -- 0he of the greatest auction sales of trotting and pacing horses ever held in the West ws begun this morning in the Dexter Park Horse Pax, ilion, at the Union Stock Yards. The sale is being held under the direction of SDlan Newgass, and is well attended. Sandy Boy, with a trial record of 2:073, brought the top price of $3,100.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The Parliamentary committee recently appointed by the House of Commons to inquire into the causes and circumstances of the troubles in the Transvaal began its sittings to-day. The committee room was crowded with privileged persons, among whom was the Prince of Wales, who showed great interest in the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- In the House to-day, Mr. Coffin (Rep., Md.,) moved to pass over the President's veto the bill to pension at $30 a month the widow of Peter H. Allabach, a veteran of the Mexican war, who, in the latter years of his life, was Chief of the Capitol police.

CANTON, Feb. 16. -- Ex-Senator Warner Miller left for Cleveland to-day without having seen Mr. McKinley. In conversation with friends, he said the Empire State would probably be without a representative in the President's official family. To the press representatives he declined to discuss the Cabinet situation.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- There was a hearing before the Assembly Committee on Cities to-day on Assemblyman Austin's measure regulating the height and fire-proof requisites of buildings in New York City. J.W. Gerard, Jr., representing the Lorillard and other estates of New York; Richard Deeves, and Capt. Leo, builders of New York, appeared in favor of the measure.

Propositions are pending in the Legislatures of Illinois and Wisconsin for investigation of the "evils" of department stores, presumably with a view to statutes to remedy these "evils." They are the natural outcome of a belief much too common that all the inequality, inconvenience, and annoyance in life can be cured by law.

The legislative trust committee completed yesterday its investigation of the American Sugar Refining Company, and began its examination into the methods of the United States Rubber Company of New Jersey. As the Board of Aldermen wanted the use of the hall at 2 o'clock P.M., the committee sat only half a day.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16. -- The will of Dr. F.B. Thurmond, leaving his estate of $100,000 to his cousin, Mrs. Underwood, thus consigning his wife to destitution, was presented in court to-day.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 16. -- Mrs. Polly Cloud Graves to-day celebrated her one hundredth birthday at the residence of her son, Col. James M. Graves, on South Broadway.

UNION, Mo., Feb. 16. -- Arthur Duestrow, a wealthy citizen of St. Louis, was executed to-day for the murder of his wife and little son in that city Feb. 13, 1894. At the time of the murders he was a medical student.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 16. -- Judge Jenkins has entered an order in the United States court which completes the legal sale of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company's properties, and the transfer to the Northern Pacific Railway Company. The order confirms the acts of Master Cary in executing the deeds to the property and disposing of the proceeds of sale.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A dispatch from Athens to The Evening News says that Greek troops have landed at the Bay of Kolymbari.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Methodist ministers here incline to agree with Dr. Buckley of New York in his opinion of the fallibility of the English Bible. One of the editors of The Northwestern Christian Advocate said today:

Mr. McKINLEY'S ultra-protectionist admirers cannot avoid the dilemma in which they are placed by the foreign silks and laces of Mrs. McKINLEY'S wardrobe and the American goods worn by her husband by questioning the authenticity of THE TIMES'S report concerning them. There is no doubt at all that the fact was as stated in our columns.
MONTREAL, Feb. 16. -- For the first time in the history of the Grand Trunk Railway the traffic returns of that road this year show a surplus.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The Assembly Excise Committee will hear arguments on the Pure Beer bill Thursday afternoon, instead of to-morrow, as at first announced.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- "To Russell A. Alger, Prospective Secretary of War in the McKinley Cabinet," J.E. Defebaugh of The Timberman addresses an open letter in the current issue of his paper. The letter deprecates the fact that rumors have arisen connecting Gen. Alger's name with a movement to reduce the tariff on lumber so as to give to the Canadian lumbermen the entry to United States markets, and says:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16. -- Warrants were issued by the Federal court this afternoon for the arrest of J.M. McKnight, President of the defunct German National Bank, and Alderman F.A. Britt, charging them with collusion in negotiating a note for $2,000 on the bank, and with conspiracy.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Secretary of State Palmer, who has been to Canton to visit President-elect McKinley to urge the appointment of Gen. Stewart L. Woodford of Brooklyn to a place in the Cabinet, was back at his desk in the Capitol to-day.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Feb. 16. -- Members the of the Modern Woodmen of America, in this city made a theatrical attempt at 1 o'clock this morning to gain possession of the equipment of the head lodge in the village of Fulton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Under date of Jan. 30, Louise de la Ramee, the novelist, better known under her nom de plume of "Ouida," addressed the following letter to Secretary Olney relative to the Immigration bill, the conference report on which measure will come before the Senate to-morrow for final action:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 16. -- The city was to-day thrown wide open to about 500 business men of every section of Arkansas, who have convened here in State convention for the purpose of discussing strictly business problems, conditions which now confront the people of the entire country in general, and those of Arkansas in particular.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Anti-Scalping bill was reported to the Senate this morning with several material amendments, none of which, however, has been antagonized by the railroad companies.

That there is not absolute harmony of views among the Greater New York Commissioners as to certain provisions of the charter that will be sent to Albany tomorrow will probably be made apparent at to-day's meeting of the commission in the Mayor's office.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 16. -- E. Payton Wright, an attorney of Pittsburg, will play a prominent part in a wedding in London, for which place he left to-night. He will give away his sister, Miss Kathryn Wright, to Sir Edmund Lechmere, Baronet and Deputy Lieutenant of Worcestershire.

The joint committee of the Social Reform Club and of the Central Labor Union, on behalf of the unemployed, called yesterday on two city officials to urge them to begin work at once, or as early as possible, on all city improvements in their departments for which money has been appropriated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The resolution to permit the United States cadets at the West Point and Annapolis Academies to participate in the ceremonies attending the inauguration of President McKinley was called up in the House Military Committee this morning by the Chairman, Mr. Hull, of Iowa.
The Parochial Missions Society of the Episcopal Church for the United States held its annual meeting at the Hotel Manhattan, at noon yesterday. Bishop Potter presided.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The Senate to-day, after a sharp debate of an hour, confirmed Frank M. Baker of Oswego, Col. George W. Dunn of Binghamton, and Col. Ashley W. Cole of Brooklyn as Railroad Commissioners. They were nominated by Gov. Black about two weeks ago.

Alberto Tedesco, who had been one of the proprietor of a barber's shop at 3 Mulberry Street, was found dead in the shop early yesterday morning, and the police are holding Alexander Berticcio, twenty-three years old, a former partner, and Olacio Picolo, twenty years old, an assistant, for his murder.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16. -- Mrs. Ella B. Kendrick is at the head of a body of women here who have organized themselves into a committee to erect a twenty-five-thousand-dollar statue of Harriet Beecher Stowe. They ordered a model three months ago from Sculptor Clark Noble of New York.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 16. -- The blockading fleet spent this morning in practice with the heavy guns beyond the bar. The ships were strung out in line of blockade, and considerable work was done with the heavy batteries.

The sanctuary choir of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary last evening with a concert in Columbus Hall, 126 West Sixtieth Street. Under the leadership of the choirmaster, Edmund G. Hurley, the choristers rendered a long programme, consisting of two parts -- church music, including several of the Gregorian chants, which were first restored to all the church offices in America by this choir, and secular music.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 16. -- A special train from Chicago over the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and the Burlington and Missouri Railroads reached this city at 3:52 A.M. to-day, having traveled 1,026 miles in eighteen hours and fifty-two minutes. This journey goes into history as the greatest railroad feat ever accomplished.

Your editorial on "Greece and Crete" in to-day's issue must strike a responsive chord in the hearts of your readers. It states the situation clearly, and its warm praise of Prince George is a tribute of justice to the liberty-loving people of Greece. May the small spark kindle a flame that will compel the European powers to bring the unspeakable Turk to terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Congress of Mothers, a gathering suggested by Mrs. T.W. Birney of this city, will meet tomorrow, and the indications to-night are that it will be as successful in point of attendance as its most sanguine promoter expected. The centre of activity for the Mothers' Congress is at the Arlington.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16. -- Elias B. Servoss, Jr., lost his life this morning in the Servoss Summer residence in Whitneyville, in a shocking accident. Elias B. Servoss, father of the unfortunate man, tells the story of the accident, as follows:

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- The question of changes in class-day exercises at Harvard was settled this evening. The scheme finally adopted provides for the lowering of the flowers around the tree, and also the wearing of ordinary clothes instead of football clothes.

-- A curiousillustration of the way in which facts can be twisted out of shape by sentiment is furnished by a paragraph in The Springfield Republican. Plainly stated, the facts are that not long ago one of the officials whose duty it is to distribute the municipal charity of the town of Chicopee gave to a certain poor woman an order on a local store for a specified amount of specified provisions.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16. -- The racing today took peace in fine weather, but the track was heavy. The attendance was about 3,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The Assembly this morning passed, without a dissenting vote, Mr. Finn's bill, which grants the use of the stoop line in streets about the public markets of New York City for the display and sale of merchandise.

It would not surprise those who take an interest in art matters, if the adornment of the new Court House, at Twenty-fifth Street and East Madison Square, for the Appellate Branch of the Supreme Court, should provoke almost as big a row among sculptors as did the Heine Monument question in this city, the Hahnemann competition at Washington, and the Sherman statue for the Nation.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- As a result of the recent State civil service examination for record clerks in the courts of New York city and County, at salaries ranging from $1,200 to $1,800, thirty-four passed and fourteen failed. The following were the successful ones, in the order of their standing:

Mrs. Charles Russell Lowell, Chairman of the Committee on Vagrancy of the Conference of Charities, read a paper yesterday at the third conference, in the United Charities Building, on the influence of cheap lodging houses upon city pauperism. She said they are an unmitigated evil, and cheap living is a curse for those who are content to live without work.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Last week's eastbound business out of Chicago and Englewood aggregated 90,782 tons, as compared with 80,645 for the preceding week and 71,070 for the corresponding week of last year. The increase is attributed to the influence of cut rates, of which there have been many rumors.

Mrs. Annie F. Raymond of 617 West One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, at noon yesterday, was robbed of her pocketbook, containing a check for $50 and $5 in money, at Hamilton Place and One Hundred and Forty-second Street.

We publish this morning a statement concerning the gift of Mr. EMANUEL LEHMAN to the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum Society, which is a striking example of doing good in a practical and permanently useful fashion. The capital of the gift is $100,000. From the revenue of this fund money is to be loaned in amounts not exceeding $250 a year to graduates of the asylum to assist them in learning trades or professions.

The American Newspaper Publishers' Association had a special meeting at the Hoffman House yesterday, preliminary to the annual meeting which begins to-day. The representatives of the big proprietary concerns of the country were present for a conference with the publishers, but the disposition of questions of mutual interest was deferred, a joint committee being appointed to discuss them.

Magistrate Cornell, in the Centre Street Court, yesterday decided that the Consul of a foreign power is not exempt from arrest on a criminal charge and committed Joseph A. Iasigi, Consul General for Turkey at Boston, to the City Prison for thirty days, to await requisition papers from Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.-The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of Francis B. Sands of the District of Columbia to be a Commissioner of the District of Columbia.

When Mr. T.C. PLATT solemnly and publicly took note of the names of the Republican legislators who had presumed to vote for somebody else for Senator, it was to be expected that something would come of the proceeding. It is reported from Albany that something has already come of it.

The tenth annual banquet of the Life Underwriters' Association of New York was held at the Windsor Hotel last night. Speaker Reed, it had been expected, would be present; he was, however, detained in Washington. James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, was one of the guests, and responded to a toast.

Ill luck beset the British steamship Beechdene throughout a long voyage from Hamburg and Newcastle, which ended in this port yesterday. A three days' tussle with field ice gave her the blunted nose she poked into the harbor, and a fore peak which was filled with water weighted down the heard and gave her a dejected appearance.
ATHENS, Feb. 16. -- The first definite news of a Greek victory in Crete was received this evening, and the wildest enthusiasm followed the receipt of the intelligence.

Slawson Hobbs have sold for the Clark estate, to Wagner Wallace, two lots on the south side of West Eighty-fifth Street, 300 feet west of Central Park. The purchasers propose to erect three American basement private dwellings on the lots.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 16. -- A conference of whisky men, representing perhaps $100,000,000 of invested capital, was held to-day.

Although the art season was late in beginning this year, the dullness of its early weeks has been more than compensated for of late by the unusual number of exhibitions in the clubs and the dealers' galleries. The fashion of holding "one-man" exhibitions or displays of a carefully selected number of characteristic and representative canvases by one artist, has become very prevalent.

We learn from Mr. WHARTON BARKER'S paper, The American, that "a protective tariff frees consumers from the grasp of foreign monopolists, while a monopoly tariff puts consumers at the mercy of domestic monopoly."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Major William Warner of Missouri, according to advices received here, has accepted the position of Assistant Secretary of the Interior with the assurance, it is understood, that if Judge McKenna leaves the Cabinet and goes upon the Supreme Bench, he will be promoted to be Secretary of the Interior.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- The cloak factory of A. Ellinger Co., at No. 282 Madison Street, was closed under two chattel mortgages to-day, afterward broken open by United States Marshal Arnold and deputies, the custodian turned out, and the establishment closed again, with Federal guardians, on a writ of attachment.

In celebration of his seventieth birthday Monday, Mr. Emanuel Lehman offered to the Board of Trustees of the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum Society, of which he is President, $100,000 for the endowment of an industrial and provident fund for the benefit of graduates of the asylum.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Daily News will publish to-morrow a dispatch from its correspondent at Canea, Crete, saying that, accompanied by an escort of 600 insurgents, the writer visited the Greek camp at Platanias, a short distance west of Canea, where he found the Greek force occupying a lofty and virtually inaccessible fortress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Senate today confirmed the nomination of William Dempsey to be Postmaster at Malone, N.Y.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The Greater New York charter is expected to reach this city to-morrow, although the basis of this expectation is the newspaper reports from New York City, rather than any communication from the Greater New York Commission.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 17. -- Vice President Garret A. Hobart, in speaking of his business interests in relation to his election to the Vice Presidency, to-day said:

" If those books contain the same doctrines as the Koran," wrote Caliph OMAR in reply to Col. AMRU'S request for instructions as to the great Alexandrian Library, "they are merely repetitions and not worth their shedroom. On the other hand, if they contain matter not in the Koran, they are manifestly heterodox and sinful: Burn 'em up."

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The Assembly to-day passed Mr. Hanna's bill fixing the pay of Inspectors of Election, Ballot and Poll Clerks at not less than $2 nor more than $6 per day, and Mr. Abell's, transferring all unexpended balances in Kings County to a general fund account.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Mr. W.E. Benjamin, the New York stamp dealer, who purchased some of the manuscripts of Turner, who, it is charged, purloined them from the Congresisonal Library, arrived here this morning and was at the Capitol endeavoring to have Congress reimburse him for the money he paid Turner for the manuscripts.
LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Stock Exchange market opened higher to-day under the influence of the improvement in the state of affairs in the East and the subsequent fluctuations were unimportant.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 17. -- The second day's session of the Business Men's Convention was marked by much earnest discussion by leading business men from the different sections of the State.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 17. -- The meeting of the stockholders of the Southern Mutual Building and Loan Association which has been called for next week will be nothing more than lawyers' meeting.

Our readers will recall the valuable interview with President FOWLER of the New York, Ontario and Western Railroad on the plan of independent audit, published in THE TIMES of Feb. 7. In commenting on this interview The Financial Chronicle calls attention to an act of the Legislature approved April 17, 1896, the object of which is to establish the profession of "Certified Public Accountant."

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- A big trade war has opened between the New York Biscuit Company and the American Biscuit Company. Late yesterday the New York Biscuit Company decided upon a sweeping reduction, averaging 35 per cent. in the price of all the goods sold by it. It will take effect from one end of the country to the other.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- There is promise of rebellion against the Republican plan of putting the Tariff bill through the extra session of Congress under a rule of the House forbidding amendments. The indications are that the resistance will be strong if the Ways and Means Committee shall report a sugar schedule calculated to benefit the Sugar Trust at the expense of the beet sugar interests.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 17. -- The Homier homestead, West Templeton, is a fairly substantial cottage on the Gatineau bank of the Ottawa, opposite Kettle Island, four miles below this city. On a bed in the kitchen to-day lay the farmer, Joseph Homier, not dead, but certain not to live more than a few hours.

CANEA, Feb. 17. -- Vice Admiral Canevaro, commanding the Italian warships in Cretan waters, has been chosen to command the combined naval forces of the powers in these waters, as the senior Admiral of the united fleet.

The condition of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, who has been ill at his home, 133 West Thirty-fifth Street, since Monday, was pronounced yesterday, by his physician, Dr. Clarence E. Beebe, to be such that no danger is to be feared. Dr. Beebe was, however, very reticent all day yesterday, and declined to describe Dr. Parkhurst's condition or his illness.

The so-called "Trust" investigation has served the purpose of bringing out considerable information, not altogether new, about great combinations of capital and their relation to the law, but in the process the officers and counsel of the corporations have shown a disposition to turn upon the committee and show that what most needs investigating is not capital, but legislation.

We remark with pleasure that the correspondent who contributed an account of the searching of a Cuban young lady to one of our esteemed freak contemporaries has been forced to "card it out" in the other. The correspondent, who is the eminent Mr. RICHARD HARDING DAVIS, writes to The World entirely disavowing the picture which was contributed to The Journal as an illustration of his account by the not less eminent Mr. FREDERIC REMINGTON.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The crowd of 1,800 received by Mrs. Cleveland grew considerably before the hour arrived for the afternoon session, and the large banquet hall of the Arlington was found to be much too small for the meeting. Arrangements were quickly made for holding the second session in the First Baptist Church, corner of Sixteenth and O Streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- When Senator Sewell of New Jersey read The Record this morning and found that the nominations of Postmasters at Swedesborough, Bridgeton, Bayonne, Atlantic City, Paterson, Ocean City, Cramer Hill, and Rockaway, New Jersey, had been confirmed yesterday, he was indignant.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 17. -- Town Clerk and Treasurer George S. Dyer is a defaulter. Town Auditor James D. Thurber has found a shortage of $10,240, and the Selectmen have made it public.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The State Controller's office in the State Hall to-day was appropriately decorated with flags and bunting in honor of the one hundredth anniversary of the creation of the office in this State.

Greece has done what not one of the powers would have ventured to do in undertaking to discipline the Turk. Without doubt the action of the Greek Government has been forced upon it by public opinion, but public opinion was nearly as unanimous a few months ago in England upon the propriety of restraining and punishing the Great Assassin as it can now be in Greece.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 17. -- Senator Ford to-day asked the Railroad Committee to report favorably his bill extending for five years, from April 20 next, the time within which the New York Connecting Railroad Company shall be given for the construction of its road.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Five hundred tanners and curriers employed by W.N. Eisendrath Co., at the foot of North Sangamon Street, went on a strike yesterday morning against a cut of from 10 to 20 per cent. in wages, and this morning 1,500 more were out of employment because the other leading tanneries in the city have closed their doors against their workmen until a settlement is made in the Eisendrath establishment.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 17. -- A mob attempted to take Edward Flanagan, now on trial for murder, from the Sheriff in Decatur this evening. The design was frustrated by the prompt action of Sheriff Austin, and Flanagan was safely landed in the Fulton County Jail.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The trial of the suit for divorce brought by Virginia Shepherd Cropper, an American, against her husband, Edward Denman Cropper, a native of this country, was concluded to-day in the Divorce Division of the High Court of Justice, the court granting plaintiff a decree.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- At an adjourned meeting of the New England Emigrant Aid Company to-day, it was voted to transfer all property belonging to the company to the University of Kansas, in the City of Lawrence. In the establishment of this institution the members took an active interest.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 17. -- Major McKinley is considerably better this evening. Upon the advice of his physician he took a short drive this afternoon. Mrs. McKinley, who has also been suffering with the grip, accompanied him. Major McKinley will recover his usual fine health by the first of next week, if he continues to improve and to abstain from work.

Our news columns yesterday resounded with the bitter cry of sculptors who object to the plan that has been adopted of securing sculpture for the new Court House of the Appellate Division, seeing nothing in it for them. But in fact the plan is all right, and the objectors, except from the point of view of their personal interests, are all wrong.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- After a four hours' debate in the Senate to-day, the conference report on the bill to amend the immigration laws was agreed to by a vote of 34 to 31. As the report had already been agreed to in the House, the bill, as modified in conference, now goes to the President.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Everybody in the paint business is talking about the suit of the Heath Milligan Manufacturing Company against the National Linseed Oil Company for $25,000. In the business it is known that the suit is to recover damages for alleged short deliveries. Painters and paint-makers all over the country are concerned.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17. -- A monument is at last to be erected over the remains of Francis Scott Key, author of the famous anthem "The Star-Spangled Banner." The Committee on Design has accepted the product of Sculptor Alexander Doyle of New York, with the understanding that the monument is to be completed in time for unveiling June 14, 1898.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- About a dozen delegates from New York, Buffalo, Albany, Utica, Syracuse, Rochester, and Little Falls met here to-day and formed the New York State Association of Builders. The delegates represented contracting Builders Exchanges, , and the State Association is formed for trade purposes.
ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- In the Senate to-day the following bills were passed:

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17. -- Since the collapse of the steel pool, orders have been placed in this city with the Carnegie agents and the Illinois Steel Company for 30,000 tons of rails. The drop in price to $17 found many roads anxious to buy, both for extensions and renewals, and orders have piled up largely in excess of early production.

The Trust Investigating Committee met yesterday morning in the Aldermanic Council Chamber at 10 o'clock, Senator Lexow in the chair. The proceedings excited considerable interest, and there was a good attendance of the general public. Mr. Lexow announced that the affairs of the National Wall Paper Company would be taken up this morning.

J. Wheatfield has sold for Adler Herrman and Ernst Brothers to Cohn, Goldman Co. at $8,500 each, five three-story and basement brownstone dwellings, 111 to 119 East One Hundred and Third Street, each 15 by 55 by 100.

A radical difference of opinion has developed between Controller Fitch and the Board of Education. The Controller has held up the payment of the salaries of eighty-nine employes of the educational department, who, he asserts, are not holding their positions in conformity to the civil service law.

The draft of the Greater New York charter was adopted yesterday by the commission unanimously, all the members being present except Mr. GREEN, who has been, unfortunately, ill during all the proceedings, and Attorney General HANCOCK and State Engineer and Surveyor ADAMS, who are members ex officio and have taken little part in framing the charter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Executive officers of the Western Freight Association roads held an important meeting here to-day. The issues at stake affect the vitality and permanency of the organization for the maintenance of rates in a vast territory.
John Pritchard, who is in business in this city, and lives at Ridgefield, N.J., yesterday made three attempts to kill himself at Hoboken Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Secretary Herbert left Washington for Charleston this afternoon in a private car over the Atlantic Coast Line, accompanied by his daughters, Miss Herbert and Mrs. Benjamin Micou; Mrs. Richardson Clover, Mrs. W.H.H. Southerland, Mrs. George P. Harrison, ex-Senator M.C. Butler, Col. T. Stobo Farrow, and Lewis Harvie Finney.

Michael Milesci, three and one-half years old, was knocked down by a cable car at Broadway and Grand Street yesterday morning, and died in his father's arms a few minutes after being removed from beneath the car. Several women in the crowd which gathered fainted at the sight. The gripman running the car, Powell C. Morgan, of 983 Columbus Avenue, was placed under arrest.

-- Chicago's respectable newspapers are rejoicing over the fact that the United States Supreme Court has affirmed the conviction of JOSEPH DUNLOP on the charge of conducting an indecent and demoralizing journal, and has decided that the editor of The Dispatch had a perfectly fair trial, and must pass the next two years of his life in doing hard labor in Joliet Prison.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- The bill which proposes to exchange with the Federal Government the Remington rifles now used by the State National Guard, for Springfield rifles, had a hearing before the Military Committee of the Assembly to-day. It brought into plain view another attempt to arm the State troops with the Savage gun, which was recommended by a commission to Gov. Morton, who rejected the commission's report.

The Commercial Travelers' Protective Association has issued a protest against the passage of the "Anti-Scalpers'" bill by Congress. The protest is signed by President John A. Lee of the association and will be sent to members of Congress.

The trial of William Jay Koerner for killing Miss Rose A. Redgate at Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street Sept. 22 was continued yesterday in Part IV. of he General Sessions before Judge Newburger and a jury. The testimony for the defense was to prove Koerner irresponsible.

Messrs. Andrews and Parker varied the monotony of the Board of Police Commissioners' meeting yesterday by a discussion which ended in an exhibition of temper. The Bertillon system for identifying criminals and the new photograph gallery caused the trouble. Mr. Andrews has had charge of the new system, and there has been a hitch in putting it in operation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- Mrs. Henry M. Shepard of this city stands sponsor to a unique scheme, to be sprung at the forthcoming Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, to be opened Friday at Washington. Mrs. Shepard will submit a plan for a magnificent structure, to be erected at the National capital, under the auspices of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 17. -- The much-mooted question, whether or not patrons of Louisville street cars shall be their own conductors, will at last be tested in the courts.
The closing out of the San Mateo Stock Farm at the second day's sale of trotters in Madison Square Garden, yesterday, resulted in spirited bidding for horses of good pedigrees.

At a meeting of the Fire Commissioners yesterday there was discussion as to the advisability of declaring off the contracts with certain coal dealers who were recently concerned in an alleged cheating of the city through false weighing. Commissioner La Grange thought that this would not be advisable, as the city was saving money by the contract and that such advantageous terms could not be gotten on new contracts.

The Holland Dames of the New Netherlands sat down to a distinctly Dutch luncheon at the Holland House yesterday in a room decorated with the Dutch colors and a table the centrepiece of which was formed chiefly of tulips -- the flowers of Holland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- After a debate in the House to-day on the policy of granting large pensions to the widows of officers, the conference report on a bill granting a pension to the widow of Col. J. Scott Payne was rejected, 28 to 96, and a new conference was asked. The Senate bill fixed the rate at $50 per month, the House at $30, and the conferrees agreed on $50.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- A hearing was held before the Assembly Judiciary Committee to-day on Assemblyman Austin's bill, incorporating the New York Law School. Bishop William Croswell Doane, Prof. Clarence D. Ashley, Dean of the Faculty of the University Law School of New York; Prof. A.V.V. Raymond of Union College, and Mr. Frank Platt of New York, participated in an argument in which not a few serious charges were made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Inquiries are being made to-night to ascertain whether the President will approve or veto the Immigration bill. As passed, the bill is considered so feeble by the advocates of strict exclusion as to be worth little more than the existing law, while those who consider any additional law of exclusion unnecessary denounce the bill in heated language.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Aside from the regular sessions of the National Congress of Mothers to-day, there were several meetings held this morning before the regular session, at which different members of the congress presided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- J.W. Gates, President of the Illinois Steel Company, hears on every hand the story set afloat by the Carnegie lobby that his proposition to manufacture armor plate has been stamped by the House Committee on Naval Affairs as "an empty bluff."

The celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Stevens Institute of Technology began last night with a banquet at the Hotel Waldorf. Covers were laid for 300, and nearly every seat at the long tables was occupied.

BUTTE, Mon., Feb. 18. -- B.C.W. Evans, recently indicted in Chicago for participation in alleged fraudulent mining deals, figures largely in a sensational affidavit filed in the United States court to-day, in the case of Caroline V. Kelly, administratrix of the estate of John D. Allport, against Ella L. Fegen-Bush for one-third interest in the Minnie Healy Mine, worth about $25,000.
BOSTON, Feb. 18. -- President Potter of the League of American Wheelmen, has been here several days with a view to bringing about harmony among the wheelmen, but the worst has not yet come.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations was to have given a joint hearing this afternoon with the Assembly Gas Committee on the Cantor-Laimbeer bill reducing the price of gas in New York City to $1.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Assemblyman George W. Wilson addressed the Assembly Commerce and Navigation Committee to-day on his bill providing for the municipal ownership of a ferry between Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Rutgers and Corlears Streets, New York City.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 18. -- Secretary Herbert arrived here at 6 o'clock this morning. He received friends at the Charleston Hotel until 11 o'clock, and then boarded the revenue cutter Colfax, which took him to the warship Maine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The McKinley rate of duty on coal was restored at this morning's session of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee. Under the present law the duty is 40 cents a ton for bituminous and shale. The former rate of duty was 75 cents for a ton of twenty-five bushels, with eighty pounds to the bushel.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The brewers of the State and others interested in that industry had a hearing before the Public Health Committees of both houses in the Senate chamber this afternoon, on the various measures pending in the Legislature providing for pure beer.

MADRID, Feb. 18. -- A dispatch to the Imparcial from Havana says that the opinion is generally prevalent in Cuba that the proposed reforms in the island will have absolutely no influence upon the Cuban war.
