WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Controller Eckels as before the House Banking and Currency Committee to-day, when the General Banking bill introduced by Mr. Fowler (Rep., N.J.,) was taken up.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- Delegates from nineteen influential commercial associations in Eastern and Western States attended the annual meeting of the National Transportation Association, which was held today in the Board of Trade Building. These delegates represented 20,000 shippers, merchants, Board of Trade men, and others.

The debate in the Senate over the conference report upon the Immigration bill turned very largely upon the clause which prohibits the introduction into this country of "occasional labor." The main object of the bill is to apply an educational test to immigrants who are likely to become citizens of the United States. Doubtless the adoption of this proposition will not keep out all of the dangerous elements of our immigration.

CANEA, Feb. 18. -- Many refugees are arriving here from all parts of the island. Most of them are Moslems, who have fled from their homes, fearing the vengeance of the Cretan Christians or their allies, the Greek soldiery. They all have stories to tell of the dangers from which they have escaped, and declare that the life of no Moslem is safe without the limits of the cities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The indications are that the total of the Sundry Civil bill when reported to the Senate will be increased by a large number of amendments providing for the carrying on of certain public works not provided for by the House. The Senate Committee on Commerce this morning ordered favorable reports to be made to the Committee on Appropriations for the following purposes:

The legislative investigators of trusts continued their work yesterday in the Aldermanic Council Chamber, Senator Lexow presiding. There was a further overhauling of the affairs of the United States Rubber Company, and Charles R. Flint occupied the witness stand until the afternoon recess.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 18. -- Representative Moore gave notice to-day in the House of Representatives of a bill to repeal the special charter of the Michigan Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- When Mrs. Birney, President of the congress, called the meeting to order this afternoon, notwithstanding that the morning session had adjourned only an hour before, there was no visible decrease in the number of attendants.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 18. -- A resolution was introduced yesterday in the House providing that a committee of five Representatives be appointed to attend the Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight in Nevada, with a view to reporting the advisability of legalizing prizefighting in Missouri. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Militia.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 18. -- A message was received to-day from Shortstop "Tommy" Corcoran, for whom the Reds traded "Germany" Smith with Brooklyn. The message read: "Have not signed with Cincinnati, and have no intention of doing so. Will not start, with Reds for South." John T. Burch telegraphs that he is losing no sleep over the refusal.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 18. -- The most select, as well as the most picturesque, social function here for a long time was the cotillion given to-night by Major Lewis Ginter. This took place at the Jefferson Hotel, and was given in honor of Mrs. Oldfield Brown of New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Assemblyman Robbins of Allegany County, who was Chairman of the Judiciary Committee last year and led the opposition to the Greater New York consolidation bill, has been consulting with the Kings County legislators who were opposed to the greater city last year, to learn if there is a sentiment which warrants any fight against the charter this year.

The Brooklyn Baptist Social Union held its annual election of officers and banquet at the Clarendon Hotel in Brooklyn last evening. After the dinner addressed were made by several of the ministers present.

ATHENS, Feb. 18. -- Despite the action of the Powers in restraining the Greek troops in Crete from aggressive operations against the Turks, and the probability that that island will eventually be handed over to Greece without the necessity of her fighting for its possession, the war feeling here is increasing hourly.

By its action yesterday the Senate threw over the arbitration treaty to the next Administration. It then passes into the hands of Mr. SHERMAN, whose care of it in the Senate has been weak, if not half-hearted. Unless the voice of the people address those responsible for the fate of this great measure in tones that must be heard and heeded, we are likely to suffer the disgrace and injury of its practical failure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The evening session was held in Central Hall, and an enormous audience was present. The report of the Press Committee was prefaced by a statement from its Chairman, Miss Isabella Tyson of Baltimore, regarding the impure press and its baneful influence.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 18. -- An exceedingly handsome and costly diamond badge has been made by a firm of jewelers of this city, to be presented by Postmaster General Wilson to President-elect McKinley on the evening of March 3, on behalf of the Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity, of which Mr. McKinley is an active member.

HAVANA, Feb. 18. -- Advices received here from Madrid report an interview with the Marquis de Apezteguia, the leader of the Cuban Conservatives, on the subject of the relations between Spain and the United States. Referring to the question of a commercial treaty, the Marquis said that the matter should be most carefully considered, in order that the interests of Spaniards in Cuba should not suffer.
PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 18. -- Senator Kyle was to-day re-elected, securing the solid Republican vote and a few Populist votes.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The bill which authorizes the New York Parcel Dispatch Company to lay pneumatic tubes beneath the streets of New York and under the East River, was passed by the Assembly to-day under circumstances which have caused so much adverse comment as to the methods of doing business that the leaders have concluded they cannot indorse what took place, and will move to reconsider the action to-morrow.
ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Senator Martin today introduced the following resolution:
Will you permit me another word about corporations with limited liability?

The Greater New York Commission finally completed its work yesterday, so far as the submission of the charter to the Legislature is concerned. The commission was in session in Mayor Strong's private office all day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Speaker Reed had no stronger or more active supporter as a candidate for the Presidential nomination than Representative Aldrich of Illinois, and there were at St. Louis no more zealous Reed men than the little group of Aldrich's friends from Chicago. One of these was James R. Mann, who was nominated for Congress from the First Illinois District, to succeed Aldrich.

There is not much danger, we suppose, that the Illinois Legislature will pass the absurd bill to prohibit contracts payable in gold. But that the bill should get a favorable report even from a majority of a bare quorum of the Judiciary Committee of the House is not a pleasant incident. The bill is exactly on a plane with the Weylerism in finance to which we referred yesterday.

A summary of the report of the special committee appointed to watch the operation of the Raines law has been published. Much of its information has already become common knowledge, such as the decrease in the number of places selling liquor and the increase in the revenue derived from the traffic, both the result of a tax three or four times as high as the old license fees.

The officials of the Health Department consider, that in securing the demolition of five rear tenements without a legal fight they have made a long step toward abolishing that nuisance entirely. While Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court are getting testimony of the value of the Mott Street Barracks for a test case in the Appellate Division, the owners of the other five places that had been condemned have accepted the department's offers.
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Quite a scene was created in the House of Commons to-day by Mr. John Burns, Socialist member for the Battersea Division of Battersea and Clapham.

Abram S. Hewitt referred to the work of the Lexow committee Wednesday night at a meeting in the United Charities Building called by the Conference of Charities to consider the condition of the tenement district. There were present representatives of the Society for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor, the Charity Organization Society, the United Hebrew Charities, the St. Vincent de Paul Society, the City Mission, and the University Settlement.

In the assemblage that filled the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning, at the funeral of William Pope St. John, there was a large proportion of representative New York business men. The public services, which began at 10 o'clock, followed a private and simple service at the family residence, 121 East Thirty-fourth Street.

" Few people," says an old New York housekeeper discussing the domestic servant question, "remember an effort that was made by a body of men about twenty-six years ago to settle the domestic problem. They organized what was called 'The Employment and Indemnity Company,' with offices at 4 Union Square. They started in with handsome offices -- men believe in a good appearance on the outside when they go into business.
The most interesting news yesterday affecting real estate was the following two building projects of more than average importance.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- In the Assembly to-day Mr. Forrester, speaking to a question of personal privilege, denied that in his remarks before the Cities Committee Tuesday in reference to the bill to prohibit the employment of married women as school-teachers, he intended any reflection upon the teachers of Brooklyn, or upon any member of the Board of Education.

The twelfth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York will open to the public in the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to-morrow. Yesterday a press and artists' view of the exhibition was given, and the members of the league enjoyed their annual dinner in the galleries last evening.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The Chronicle tomorrow will publish a communication from its Special Commissioner Henry Norman, who is now in Athens, and who will be remembered as the representative of that paper at Washington during the Venezuelan dispute.

It is only within the last few years that something like a standard of education for the bar has been established in this country. Formerly a systematic education of any kind was hardly required for admission to practice, and when our law schools were first established students were admitted to them without examination or any test of previous preparation, and degrees were granted after eighteen months' or two years' residence without examinations.

The February meeting of the Physical Education Society was held in the vestry room of the Church of the Incarnation last evening. Papers on "Athletics in Preparatory Schools" were read by Dr. John S. White, Dr. L.V. Ray, Dr. Thelberg of Vassar, Dr. Foster of Bryn Mawr, Miss Richardson of Vassar, and Dr. Lucy Hall Brown, Dr. John B. Knapp and Dr. Henry Ling Taylor took part in the discussion which followed.

David Strong, twenty-three years old, of Jonestown, Penn., was arrested last night on a charge of selling forged tickets of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Ticket brokers believe the attempt to get rid of the tickets is a plan to bring their business into disrepute and influence legislation against them.

There was a very lively meeting of property owners in Manhattan Avenue, between One Hundred and Sixteenth and One Hundred and Twenty-third Streets, last evening at 44 Manhattan Avenue. The Third Avenue Railroad Company is desirous of securing the right to lay tracks in the avenue, and the Manhattan Avenue Protective Association has been organized to protest against the intrusion.

Another magnificent donation has made possible a new source of good for the inhabitants of the upper east side. Miss Serena Rhinelander has made a tentative gift of a new mission house and ten city lots, adjoining, aggregating in value almost $300,000. St. James's Protestant Episcopal Mission, East Eighty-third Street, near First Avenue, is to reap the immediate harvest of this bounty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- When the Senate adjourned at 8 o'clock to-night, after a secret session of seven and a half hours, it was apparent to the most sanguine friends of the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain that no vote could be secured at this session of the Senate.

There are now on exhibition at the American Art Galleries an unusually important and interesting collection of 301 pictures, the property of the Holland Art Gallery, for the most part examples of the modern Dutch and Italian schools, with a few Dutch pictures of the Seventeenth Century, and which are to be sold at auction in Chickering Hall on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings next.

MONTREAL, Feb. 19. -- If the new United States tariff contains a clause reimposing the old McKinley duty of $2 a thousand on lumber, Canada will at once retaliate by clapping an export duty on saw logs.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- A't midnight the "Lake' Shore elevator, on the river front, Is in flames, and will be destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee to-day reported favorably on the bill of Mr. Adams of Pennsylvania to reorganize the Consular Service by a commission to be composed of two Senators, two Representatives, and an officer of the Department of State. The reorganization covers all offices in the service.

The legislative investigating committee met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in the Aldermanic Council Chamber, and resumed the hearing of the testimony in regard to the Rubber and Wall Paper comsolidations. The members of the committee were all present, and Senator Lexow presided.
CANEA, Feb. 19. -- The Austrian Vice Consul at Heraklion confirms the report of the massacre of 2,000 Moslems by the Cretan Christians at Sitia, on the eastern extremity of the island.

Mayor Strong and President Low of Columbia College yesterday sent a communication to George M. Pinney, Jr., Secretary of the Greater New York Commission, in which they criticise some of the moat important provisions of the new charter, which was taken to Albany yesterday by the sub-committee appointed at Thursday's meeting of the commission.

ATHENS, Feb. 19. -- The Greek steamer Pan Hellenic, conveying munitions of war to the insurgents in Crete, has been stopped and turned back by a British cruiser. A British ironclad has also prevented the steamer Junon from debarking provisions intended for the use of the Greek troops in Crete.
The thirty-first annual banquet of the Harvard Club of this city was held last evening at the Waldorf. The attendance was the largest of any recorded at these yearly events.

Mme. Calve's indisposition last night and her consequent inability to appear in the part of Carmen, for which she was billed at the Metropolitan Opera House, was due in some measure to the worry and annoyance which she has undergone in the past few days on account of the notoriety some sensational newspapers thrust upon her in detailing thrilling accounts of an alleged crank's threats to shoot her and his persistent efforts to raciest her.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- Two important bits of political news were developed here to-day. One is that James A. Gary of Baltimore has been selected for a position in Major McKinley's Cabinet and has accepted.

ITHACA, Feb. 19. -- The afterhum anent the acceptance of Yale's halting offer to row is somewhat discordant. A considerable portion of the undergraduates thought Cornell ought not to have admitted Yale without imposing conditions. There is a general feeling of satisfaction, however, that Cornell is to "have it out" with Yale at last, at whatever cost.

As a maker of fiction Anthony Hope has many qualities, but he is first of all diverting. His readers escape from their work-a-day world on the vigorous wings of his imagination, to find that he has contrived for them a kingdom in which they may feel the charm of a joyous gayety that is not levity, an ease and freshness rare in other kingdoms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Previous to the regular session of the Congress of Mothers this morning conferences were held at the Arlington Hotel and at the regular meeting place of the congress -- the First Baptist Church.

Who were the great makers of furniture in the near past? They certainly were the Italians. Marie de Medicis introduced Florentine artisans to France. There are no Tudor or early Stuart pieces which are really distinguishable for excellence. If any are found to-day it is its big, heavy clumsiness which has helped it to resist time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- "I have been willing to do more than the square thing by McKinley and Hanna, but I don't intend to walk off the roof for anybody."

Three men went into the butcher shop of Demeaminer Ruffo, 261 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon and asked for a leg of mutton. Ruffo went into the ice-chest to get it for them, when one of the men sprang forward and locked him in. Together with his companions, the man rifled the cash drawer, containing $25, and the three fellows then made their escape.

The supporters of Senator FORD'S "Pneumatic Tube" bill protest that there is nothing wrong in that measure, notwithstanding the disreputable trick by which it was snapped through the Assembly on Thursday without consideration and without a chance for opposition.

The Century Company has organized a novel competition for prizes aggregating $1,000. Answers are required for 150 questions relating to topics concerning which all persons need information. They are not technical subjects, nor especially learned ones, but may be called every-day subjects. The answers to them all are to be found in that unrivaled storehouse of useful knowledge -- The Century Dictionary and Cyclopedia.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The Greater New York charter reached Albany late this afternoon. It was brought here by Secretary George M. Pinney and ex-Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy, members of the commission. They arrived on the 4:15 train from New York, and had previously telegraphed the clerks of the Senate and Assembly, asking them to be on hand to receive the charter.
Frederick Zittel has sold for George C. Edgar's Sons Co. the four-story private dwelling, 20 West Eighty-eighth Street, 20 by 60 by 100.

Several days ago the cable brought the information from Paris that the French Government had decorated an American painter named Donnat. In and about the studios it is conjectured that the writer of the paragraph may have written Dannat, and many are the wishes expressed that such was the case.

Maggie Geraty, nine years old, of 211 East Forty-first Street, had her left foot cut off by a cake of ice falling from an ice truck belonging to the National Ice Company. She sued the company for damages, claiming that the cake of ice slipped over the tailboard of the truck upon her foot, on the sudden starting of the truck in Forty-third Street.

Our esteemed freak contemporary The World continues to maintain the lead it gained over our other esteemed freak contemporary The Journal by exposing The Journal's "fake beat" touching the search and seizure of a young female Cuban upon an American steamer. Yesterday The World printed a special dispatch to itself from the Greek Minister of Foreign Affairs.

The annual dinner of the Alumni Association of Lafayette College was given at the Hotel Savoy last night. The principal guests were John J. McCook, who has been mentioned for a place in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet, and Gov. Griggs of New Jersey. The red dining room of the hotel was decorated with the college colors -- maroon and white. About 100 of the alumni were present.

Sir Mountstuart E. Grant Duff is a man who has seen a great deal of the world, in Parliament and out of it, and who during his life has associated with many distinguished statesmen, authors, and other notable persons. The announcement of Sir M.E. Grant Duff's "Notes from a Diary, 1851-72" (London: John Murray,) has awakened a great deal of curiosity in England.

One would scarcely regard a tapestry in the light of an astronomical chart, but how shall we account, then, for a comet, strongly accentuated by means of thread and needle, shown on the Bayeux tapestry, which tapestry, representing the conquest of England by the Normans, was supposedly the work of Matilda, William the Conqueror's Queen?

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 19. -- Ten thousand people witnessed the presentation of the sliver service to the battleship Texas, on the plaza in front of the Beach Hotel this evening. Capt. Glass, accompanied by his officers, arrived at the wharves shortly after 1:30 o'clock this afternoon.
For the second time the Civil Service Reform Association has triumphed in its fight against the city officials of Brooklyn in their interpretation of the civil service provision of the Constitution.

In Cosmopolis may be read some of the letters written by George Sand in 1831 to her husband, M. Dudevant. This correspondence is taken from a volume M. do Lovenjoul has just prepared, explanatory of the production of that terrible book, "Elle et Lui." These letters show the amicable relationships existing between wife and husband.

When Archbishop Martinelli, the Apostolic Delegate from the Holy See at Rome, was making a tour of this country two years previous to his appointment as Pope Leo's representative in the United States, he formed the acquaintance of the Rev. Father P.F. O'Hare, the well-known temperance preacher, of Brooklyn, who has done much to further in this country the interests of the Augustine band of missionaries, of which Archbishop Martinelli is a member.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Preceding the afternoon session of the Congress a conference was held in the church, over which Mrs. T.W. Birney presided. There were several short talks given, at the conclusion of which Mrs. Birney read a long article on "Suggestions for Mothers' Clubs."

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The South African Committee to inquire into the troubles in the Transvaal, and particularly into the raid made by Dr. Jameson and his followers into the Boer territory, resumed its sittings in Westminster Hall to-day.

PIERRE, S.D., Feb. 19. -- In an interview last night Senator Kyle denied the report that he had made any deal with the Republicans. He declared that he is a Populist still, has not changed his principles, and that the Republicans came to him solidly because they thought Senator Pettigrew was against him, and they wished to humiliate Pettigrew.

So far as the American people are permitted to know the secret proceedings of the Senate, these are not likely to enhance the reputation of that body. Yesterday, when the Senate had gone into "executive" session -- there is a bitter irony in that term applied to recent sessions -- on the arbitration treaty, Senators DANIEL and TELLER consumed some hours in talk.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Division, has approved Justice KEOGH'S decision in the Brooklyn civil service cases without qualification or reserve. This is, on the whole, the most important judicial decision yet rendered as to the civil service provisions of the Constitution, as Justice KEOGH'S was the most important at the time it was rendered.

Obviously, discussion of the dramatic or theatrical quality of a new work by Ibsen is uncalled for. The theatre out of Scandinavia has rejected him. It is useless to say that his works are successfully performed in Germany, for in the sense of that phrase, "successfully performed," here and in England, it is not true.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 19. -- Judge Badger, in Common Pleas Court, decided to-day that Patrick McGraw, plaintiff in a suit for $10,000 personal damages against John R. Hughes, must submit to an examination by the X rays, as demanded by the defense, to ascertain the nature of the alleged injuries to the plaintiff's bones.

The managers of St. Luke's Home for Indigent Christian Females are relying on the generosity of church friends to aid them in paying off a comparatively small mortgage on the site of their proposed new building, on the southeast corner of the Boulevard and One Hundred and Fourteenth Street.

The draft of the charter for Greater New York goes now from the commission to the Legislature, and the appeal of the people for a hearing is to that body. There is no injustice in saying that the course of the commission in dealing with this vastly important subject has been far from satisfactory, and does no credit to its members as citizens of high standing in the communities affected.

Harper's Weekly publishes a careful and interesting letter from Mr. ARTHUR HOUGHTON in Madrid on "The Political Condition of Spain." It is a friendly and even sympathetic view of the Spanish Nation, but, though Mr. HOUGHTON tries to be hopeful, the facts that he gives are not cheerful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The House spent most of the day in wrangling. A spirited debate began the day's proceedings -- based on a conference report which showed that the House conferrees surrendered to the conferrees of the Senate on a bill granting $75 a month to the widow of Brig. Gen. and Brevet Major Gen. Carr, instead of $50 as provided by the House bill.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The legislators from the cities and towns which are to be included in the Greater New York when the consolidation takes effect have introduced many bills affecting their particular localities which they desire to have passed in advance of the new charter.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- There was no quorum in the Senate today, and after Senator Humphrey's bill to tax the stock of trust companies the same as that of banks had been advanced to third reading, an adjournment was taken till Monday night. Not a bill was introduced.

In considering the matter of charges to be made for the use of the bridge by the Brooklyn railroads, the Trustees are a unit in the opinion that there shall be no change in the two-and-a-half-cent fares. The bridge has never been self-supporting. In the twelve years ending with 1896 the expenditures exceeded the receipts by $581,766, and the deficit had to be made up by a tax levy against the two cities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The open session of the Senate to-day lasted for only half an hour. Two conference reports on pension bills were agreed to -- one giving $50 a month to the widow of Gen. Stoneman and the other $75 a month to Gen. Julius H. Stahl.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- Chief Justice Mercer Beasley of the Supreme Court of New Jersey, died of bronchial pneumonia shortly after 7 o'clock this morning. All the members of his family, save his son, ex-Judge Chauncey H. Beasley, were at his bedside when he expired. The latter is confined to his home with pneumonia.

I read with surprise, under the heading "New York City," in your issue of the 18th inst., that a delegation of Vesey Street merchants, headed by the President of the Board of Aldermen, called upon Mayor Strong yesterday to urge him to approve the Finn bills. Now, what is the purport of these Finn bills?
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- C.H. Kilpatrick, '99, one of Princeton's athletes and the world's champion half-mile runner, has decided to enter the ranks of the professionals.

Mr. David Bispham, the popular baritone of the Metropolitan Opera House company, has earned for himself in his single season in his native land a reputation of no mean sort. His song recitals recently given in the Carnegie Lyceum attracted such large audiences that he was induced to give an extra concert yesterday afternoon in the Mendelssohn Glee Club Hall.

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- A fire in the Everett School, at the corner of Northampton and Tremont Streets, this forenoon, caused a stampede among the pupils, and in the rush to leave the building ten or twelve children were crushed and bruised, but it is thought none is fatally injured.

-- A Berlin correspondent tells as true a story about a joke that resulted somewhat seriously for the man who invented it. This person was incredulous about the discriminating appreciation of wines which a distinguished friend of his claimed to posses, and to test the matter invited him to dine at a hotel whose landlord had previously been instructed to set before the connoisseur a bottle of excellent Moselle.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday vacated the injunction which was to restrain the Hartford Insurance Company from becoming the virtual successor of the Broadway Insurance Company.
GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Feb. 19. -- Reports from Colima say that the inhabitants of the city and State are very apprehensive over a prospective eruption of the volcano's old crater.

M. Charles Gavard may be said to have had greatness thrust upon him, but, no matter what were the positions he assumed in the French Diplomatic Corps, he showed conspicuous ability. Attached to the French Embassy in England from 1871 to 1877, first as Secretary, then as Charge d'Affaires, matters of great importance requiring good judgment, with delicate handling, were confided to his care.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- It is generally understood here among those who are closest to President-elect McKinley that the statements published as to the two last-selected members of the Cabinet -- Gary of Maryland and McCook of New York -- are accurate, and that the completed Cabinet of the new President, as it will be submitted to the Senate on the 5th of March next, will be as follows:

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- It is announced that Messrs. Kidder, Peabody Co., R.L. Day Co., and Estabrook Co. have bought of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company a large block of bonds, the proceeds of which will clear up the floating debt of the whole system.

Mr. Leslie Stephen, in The National Review, writes in praise of M. Emile Legouis, "La Jeunesse de Wordsworth," a volume published last year in Paris, and to be published by the Messrs. Dent Co. the coming Spring. Where M. Legouis's book is of interest is where he follows the poet who was to be, while in France, at the crisis of the Revolution.

The announcement that a British man-of-war has prevented a Greek steamer from landing provisions and ammunition on the Cretan coast comes in a form which does not afford any apparent reason for discrediting it. Yet it is in opposition to the story which has been published for some days without denial, and which seems to have had a semi-official sanction.

SALEM, Oregon, Feb. 20. -- The forty days set for the session of the Legislature expired yesterday, and both houses adjourned to Monday. They can keep up the session as long as they please at their own expense, however. Senator Mitchell has issued this circular letter to his friends.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Although we are very near the close of the first act in the drama of "Is It Armageddon?" and it can be seen that the drop curtain is going to fall on a dramatic situation of thrilling suspense, the powers who are acting the chief roles are still playing them in a spirit of high comedy.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The Stock Exchange market opened dull under the influence of the general Continental stagnation caused by the situation in the East. The selling offers were chiefly on German account. Shortly after the opening consols for money were 1/4 lower than yesterday's closing, and consols for the account showed a decline of 3-16.
Among the high-bred canines who will not appear at the Dog Show this year are Mrs. Eugene Clarke's silky-haired little Japanese dogs, with pedigrees several yards long and Li Hung Chang.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The National Zeitung, in an article referring to the circular note sent to the Powers by Lord Salisbury favoring the granting of autonomy to Crete under the administration of a Prince of Greece, asserts that Great Britain stands alone in the matter. Italy, the paper says, adheres to the other powers and will act in accord with them.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Feb. 20. -- At 7 o'clock this morning Mrs. Chapin, the wife of Postmaster Walter C. Chapin, was found dead on the floor of the Chapin dining room. A few feet away was the body of Charles Mead, a man about twenty-five years of age, the son of the Rev. H.B. Mead, formerly a Congregational preacher here, but now of Scotland, a small town in Eastern Connecticut.

If Mr. JAMES A. GARY of Baltimore goes into the Post Office Department he will bring to its duties good business ability and warm personal sympathy with the President. How far he will be able to handle the problems of the department successfully, it is not easy to say.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 20. -- This morning Capt. Glass and the officers of the battleship Texas entertained Gov. Culberson and staff and the members of the Legislature. The former went out in the Government tug Anna, the latter on the revenue cutter Galveston.

THE year in which Washington was born (1732) found the world of Europe and America in a state of profound peace. That eighteenth century some years before had witnessed stirring and momentous conflicts on the Continent of Europe, and America, along the northern borders of New England. had seen reflections of that strife; but the peace established by the treaty of Utrecht remained as yet unbroken.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- The second day's session of the State Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association opened at the First Reformed Church this morning in the presence of about 400 delegates. The organization was completed this morning, and President F.M. Olyphant of New York called the convention to order and appointed the following committees:

There are now on exhibitions at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries and the galleries of Boussod, Valadon Con. respectively, exhibitions of pictures by two clever American painters -- W. de L. Dodge and J. Alden Weir. Mr. Dodge's fifty-three paintings and studies and fifty-two, original drawings for the decorations of the Congressional Library at Washington are to be sold at auction in the galleries where they are exhibited on Tuesday evening next, Feb. 23.
It is easy to make candy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20. -- Active work in the development of the Princeton baseball team began this week. On Monday the freshmen candidates for the team were ordered to report in the cage. Thirty-two responded to the call, and were set to work under the coaching of the old 'Varsity men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- When the House adjourned this afternoon it had finished the discussion, in Committee of the Whole, of the General Deficiency Appropriation bill, with the exception of one paragraph, providing for a payment to the Southern Pacific Company. Three hours' debate will take place on that item Monday.

Officers of the American Sugar Refining Company were not disposed yesterday to talk about the scheme of the Marsden Company of New Jersey to manufacture sugar out of cornstalks by an electrical process. The incorporation of the new company, with a capitalization of $50,000,000, is, however, regarded by the sugar men as an interesting event.

Gen. Horace Porter has taken charge of the inaugural headquarters at 1,419 F Street, in Washington, and with the aid of his chief of staff, A. Noel Blakemen, will perfect next week all but the final arrangements for the great parade.

No man pays any taxes to the State in New Zealand until he is worth more than $2,500, neither does he pay anything for education. He is not, however, exempt from taxation for local purposes, such as highway improvements, and, if he holds city property, he must contribute toward the maintenance of the Municipal Government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Seven explosions of natural gas at 7 o'clock this morning in the engine room of The Chicago Chronicle, at 184 and 186 Washington Street, badly shattered the basement and business office and injured ten persons, five of them seriously.

The New York Tribune a few days ago published a communication, coming apparently from Monmouth County, N.J., relative to the Allaire Iron Works. Accompanying the article was a picture, representing what was said to be the ruins of the first iron works in New Jersey. The assertion was not directly made that the Allaire Works were the first where iron was manufactured in New Jersey, but that was the inference.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 20. -- The subject of consolidating the City of Orange and the townships of East, West, and South Orange into one city of some 60,000 inhabitants is now again being discussed here with vigor, because of the introduction into the Legislature this week by Assemblyman Peter B. Fairchild of this city of a bill which makes such plan possible.

"All, so far, has been tentative -- indeed, we are yet in the experimental stage, so far as choice of a motor in place of steam is concerned," said William J. Fransioli, General Manager of the Manhattan Railway Company, yesterday.
A German society in this city has made a bold and apparently successful attempt at solving the much-discussed and interesting domestic servant question.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Municipal Inaugural Committee, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, last Wednesday evening, Mayor Strong announced that he had appointed Cornelius N. Bliss Chairman and James C. Reed Secretary of the Executive Committee, and Gen. Horace Porter Chairman and Walter C. Gilson Secretary of the Committee on Plan and Scope.

Why should the Metropolitan Traction Company expect that the City of New York will furnish it with additional facilities for doing its business so that it may avoid killing or maiming citizens? The company is not a benevolent or charitable institution. It is organized for the purpose of making money, and it is reported to be making a great deal.

The politicians in the League of American Wheelmen continue to talk almost as much over the prospective successor to George Gideon as Chairman of the Racing Board as they did over the contest for the Presidency. Among those who know President Potter best, it is intimated that the coming Chairman will not be a New Yorker.

The first acknowledgment of the golden vase sent by the members of the Woman's Union Republican League to Mrs. McKinley, wife of the President-elect, on Jan. 5, was received by Mrs. Virginia Chandler Titcomb last week.

The near approach of the date set for the dedication of the Grant monument in Riverside Park has reawakened public interest in this project to commemorate the life and character of America's greatest soldier. Hundreds of people are now visiting the park daily. The mild weather of the past week has been taken advantage of by a great many who desired to view the mausoleum and the conditions surrounding it.

The proposition to have the dangerous curve at Fourteenth Street on the Metropolitan Traction Company's line abolished is greatly interesting the business men in that neighborhood. Yesterday John Daniell, the dry goods merchant, called upon Mayor Strong and submitted a plan which, he said, would relieve the dangerous conditions created by the curve.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20. -- Capitalists of this city are engaged in an enterprise which it is expected will have a marked effect upon transportation between the North and the South. The scheme contemplates a general enlargement of the Dismal Swamp Canal, and the restoration of that ancient waterway to something like its former importance as a means of bringing freight from the Carolina rivers to Norfolk or into Chesapeake Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Secretary of War Lamont and Mrs. Lamont are assuming that Gen. Alger will be confirmed as Secretary of War, and are prepared to make his official entry as agreeable as possible. The Star of to-night says:

There is a valuable manuscript in this city the exact ownership of which is for the present a matter of doubt. It is now in the Lenox Library, but whether it will remain there or go to the Congressional Library, at Washington, is a matter which Mr. John S. Billings, Director of the New York Public Library, has to decide.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20. -- The undergraduates of Princeton University are very much stirred up over the painting of the old water tower west of the village.

DURING the coming week New Yorkers will pay court to the aristocratic beauties of the canine world. Fine animals of almost every known breed will be on exhibition at the Madison Square Garden. The occasion will be the twenty-first annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club.

Joseph Stewart, forty-two years old, employed in the Insane Asylum on Ward's Island, is the latest victim of the cable car. Stewart was crossing Third Avenue at Fifty-second Street at 8 o'clock last night, when a south-bound cable car struck him and knocked him down. He received a fracture of the skull and internal injuries. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 20. -- Following Gov. Bushnell's visit here last evening The Daily Gazette, his newspaper organ, printes the following triple-leaded editorial article this evening, which is taken to mean that Hanna is the man who will be appointed Senator to succeed Sherman.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 20. -- The H.J. George Grocery Company has shipped a carload of eggs to Martin, Seusiar Co. of San Francisco. The car contained 450 cases, thirty dozen to the case, making a total of 13,500 dozen.

Very likely Mr. CECIL RHODES could not have done better for himself than by making the frank and cynical avowal which he has made of his purposes and methods in South Africa. Yet he appears in his own recital as a perfectly unscrupulous filibuster, aiming to anglicize South Africa without the least regard to the rights of the previous occupants.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- Upon the confession of George Roehl in police court to-day of a conspiracy to manufacture evidence in the damage suit of James Van Tassell of Haverstraw against Peer Adriance Son of this city, District Attorney Wood determined to prosecute Van Tassell and caused his arrest upon a sworn complaint charging subornation of perjury.

Charles L. Tiffany, President of Tiffany Co., approves of the plan suggested by President McMillan of the Park Board for removing the sharp curve at Fourteenth Street by cutting off a small part of Union Square Park. Mr. Tiffany said yesterday that a great many accidents are caused by that part of the curve immediately in front of his store.

The work of the Greater New York Commission having been completed, so far as the construction of the charter is concerned, it is interesting to note the changes that the charter makers have proposed for the government of the great territory that is to be included in the greater city.
As a very intimate friend of the late Gen. Alfred Pleasonton, I feel it to be my duty to the dead to add the following to the interesting sketch of his life, published in THE TIMES of to-day:

People whose residence up town constrains them to use the service of the Manhattan Elevated Road during the rush hours of the morning and early evening are complaining loudly of the inadequate service and of the slight regard for their convenience and comfort evinced by the management.

GLASGOW, Feb. 6. -- Lord Dunraven's anxiety for press notices must have been gratified by constant references to his ketch Cariad, which has been fitting out at Southampton for several weeks for a voyage to what is vaguely called the South. The fitting out has at length been completed by Summers Payne, and the Ketch lies in the Itchen ready to said.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 20. -- Exceptionally fine weather has marked the latter part of this week in direct contrast to the snow and cold that met the golfers in last week's tournament. To-night the hotels are all crowded for Washington's Birthday-in-fact, the Laurel House and the Laurel-in-the-Pines have found it difficult to accommodate the arrivals of the past three days.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Wells Champney gave reception at Mr. Champney's studio, 96 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon to a large number of artists, literary and society people in honor of M. and Mme. Theobald Chartran. The walls of the studio were covered with Mr. Champney's work, and one room was set apart for his series of pastel paintings of well-known society debutantes who have been portrayed as types of American girls.

People in the northwestern portion of the city are urging the passage by the Legislature of Assemblyman Mathewson's bill, providing that the temporary bridge at Macomb's Dam and One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street be permitted to remain where it is for five years longer. In this matter they are acting in harmony with the officials of the Union Railway Company.
-Besides her tea on Thursday, Mrs. J. G. McCullough of 88 Park Avenue gave dinners on Wednesday and Friday of last week to parties of twenty each. Her last reception will be held, on next Thursday.
LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The Globe recently published an article from a correspondent at Canea which may throw some light on the Cretan situation for American readers. The writer said:

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The Educational bill, in which Mr. Balfour has risked his place and reputation, approaches its really critical period, as it is now entering the committee stage. Its passage through a first and second reading was assured -- the Liberal opposition complained in vain that the bill was being rushed through with only a few days elapsing between the next of the measure being put in circulation and the second reading.

Assemblyman Van Keuren's bill providing for State Steamboat Inspectors, their salaries and expenses, enacting into State law most of the United States regulations governing steam inland water craft and their navigation, and some additional features is not likely to become law if the steamboat and tugboat owners of New York are consulted.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 19. -- Tuesday will be the one hundred and nineteenth anniversary of the battle of Spanktown. The Rahway of to-day is what was known in the last century as Spanktown, the name having been given because an early settler publicly took his spouse across his knee and chastised her.

The discussion which certain School Inspectors had at a recent meeting about overtaxed teachers in this city, in the course of which one Inspector alleged that the teachers were "dying by the dozen" of overwork, has aroused sharp criticism in the Board of Education Building. The assertion was also made that more teachers were wanted by the Board of Education.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 20. -- The special function to-day with Admiral Bunce's fleet was the reception tendered by officers to citizens on board the dispatch boat Dolphin. The Dolphin lies just off the battery, and was gayly decorated for the occasion; the Admiral was on board, and his broad pennant floated from the mainmast.

F.G. Logan -- The pacific character of the news, and higher London markets brought general buying into the market of a fair character, Northern Pacific, Atchison, and Louisville and Nashville. Better weather is expected to make a better showing for the Grangers, on increased grain business, and they are looked upon favorably.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- The forty fish and game protectors in the employ of the State Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission have just concluded a session of several days' duration. The meeting was called to discuss the best means for forest preservation and the protection of fish and game in the several counties of the State.

The play of this week will be the new Sardou drama, freshly turned out from the great playmaker's Paris workshops. "Spiritisme" was produced in Paris, at the Theatre de la Renaissance, about a fortnight ago. We are to have it here, so to speak, fresh from the griddle.

Dr. Edward C. Spitzka of 712 Lexington Avenue, who is recognized as an expert in mental diseases, watched with keen interest the progress of the Duestrow murder case in the Missouri courts. At an early stage in the proceedings he became convinced of Duestrow's moral responsibility for the killing of his Wife and child.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- The attention of politicians absorbed just at present by the Eastern question. There was a great day at the Chamber yesterday, when M. Deloncle made his periodical declaration of war with England, but as most of the Deputies are bondholders in Egyptian stock, he met with a frozen reception.

Hands off the public parks! Cut through the block on the west side of Broadway, from Fourteenth to Thirteenth Street. That will make a curve as easy as the one proposed by Mr. McMillan. Make the railroad company pay for it.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 10. -- To-night I returned to the City of Havana after an absence of three days, during which I made my way to and from the camp of the insurgent, chief Gen. Adolfo Castillo. I made the trip in the company of a Cuban guide.
President W. W. Sherman of the National Bank of Commerce, in discussing the financial outlook, said yesterday to a representative of The NEW YORK TIMES:

CANEA, Feb. 20. -- The insurgents who are occupying the hills back of Canea sent warning yesterday of their intention to attack the town from Akrotiri. To this notice Admiral Canevaro, commanding the combined fleets, sent a reply giving the insurgent leaders to understand that the foreign warships would intervene at the first sign of an attack on the part of the insurgents.

The reported sales at private contract last week, exclusive of many that were announced by brokers simultaneously with or subsequently to the filing of the deeds, indicated some recovery, from the slump experienced in the previous six days, not enough, however, to bring the business up to the average value that held good during the first five weeks of the year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Feb. 20. -- The efforts of the old whalemen were rewarded to-day. Thursday's fruitless chase of a bull whale, that sported with them from dawn to dusk, had almost worn them out. Yesterday they had equally bad luck with a cow whale and her big calf, but at nightfall the latter were still off shore, as if loath to leave such good feeding grounds.

Although the New York Yacht Club has decided that it will not take the initiative in the formation of a National Yacht Racing League, there is every likelihood of such a league being formed. It will be formed, though, through the efforts of the Yacht Racing Union of Long Island Sound, an organization composed of all the clubs having stations or clubhouses on the Sound, except the New York and Larchmont Clubs.

OF all the social events which have made New York society famous, both for lavishness of expenditure as well as for taste, none has attracted such widespread attention as the Bradley Martin ball, but lately passed into history.

There will be no race for five college crews at Poughkeepsie this Summer, but, instead, two contests for three crews; the first in which Harvard, Yale, and Cornell will compete, on either June 24 or June 25; the second, for Columbia, Cornell, and the University of Pennsylvania, on July 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Mrs. Cleveland received about 200 ladies by appointment at nbon to-day, including the Facility and pupils of Park Seminary, at Forest Glen, Md. These ladies wished to pay their respects to the first lady of the land before her retirement to private life, and have been heretofore unable to do so.

The legislative trust investigating committee did not accomplish anything yesterday. The witnesses subpoenaed did not appear, and had they obeyed the subpoenas, it is doubtful whether anything would have been done. Senator Lexow was not there, and it is known that he desires to conduct the examinations. The absence of the witnesses caused a good deal of talk in the Aldermanic council chamber.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 20. -- President Andrew Freedman and Manager William Joyce of the New York Baseball Club were here to-day, and selected the grounds for the Spring practice of the club. The club has always practiced in the South.

We have been glad to note the response which has come to our suggestion that the making of LINCOLN'S birthday a public holiday in the State of New York was an improvident and unwise piece of legislation. That we have too many public holidays, and that we have some of them at the wrong times, is just now brought powerfully to the attention of the business world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures to-day ordered favorably reported, with an amendment, the Senate bill providing for the representation of the United States by Commissioners at any international conference to be called hereafter.
The annual inspections, under the direction of Inspector General Hoffmann, in the First and Second Brigades will begin about April 1.

I observe in a New York journal of a recent date an impassioned appeal for contributions from all sects including the Jews, to build the Episcopal Cathedral; even the little children art urged to come forward with their hoarded pennies. In justification of this sweeping inclusion it is said that the cathedral is to be National, and on the broadest grounds of Christian unity.

Wall Street is not much merrier than a graveyard. Barely more than 100,000 shares of stock a day represented .transactions on the New York Stock Exchange last week. Something more than a score of stocks: fluctuated as much as a whole point. Commission houses apparently had nothing to do but lament.

Charles Blair Maodonald and H.J. Whigham, the Chicago golf representatives, who came to this city to attend the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, have been at the Holland House, and when seen yesterday were naturally much pleased that the big tournament had been awarded to their city. Mr. Whigham is the champion amateur golfer of America, and the previous year Mr. Macdonald held the honor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Joint Traffic pool lines and the Western Freight Association lines are greatly exercised over the formation of new combinations, whereby a number of roads and fast freight lines expect to secure the bulk of the business between Missouri River points and the Eastern seaboard.

The close of the season of grand opera in French, German, and Italian at the Metropolitan Opera House is a topic that might be discussed from many points of view. It began on Monday, Nov. 16, with a performance of that highly familiar product of French art, "Faust," in which Mme. Melba and the two De Reszkes were the conspicuous figures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The Cretan uprising against Turkey was recognized and encouraged by the Senate of the United States to-day in the unanimous adoption of a resolution offered by Mr. Cameron, (Rep., Penn.,) as follows:

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The Emperor has been much blamed for taking precipitate action against Greece, but there is good reason for stating that his Majesty's sudden invitation to blockade the Piraeus was largely due to the receipt of concurrent dispatches from Constantinople and Athens representing the imminence of the danger of a Turkish invasion of Greece, which the Greek forces are utterly unprepared to resist.

WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 20. -- A remarkable example of the wholesale swindling carried on in Kansas in the early days is recalled by a bill introduced in the Kansas House of Representatives to provide for the payment by the State of $100,000 of Comanche County bonds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

He was a brand-new street-car conductor. He was new from the crown of his head to the soles of his boots. He was new in the city and new to the street-car business. His clean, gray cap, with the shining black peak, had yet to see its first storm. The new gray ulster also awaited the christening of a northwest blizzard.

Last Friday in this judicial department the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court announced twenty-three decisions, of which thirteen reversed the judgment of the court below, six affirmed it, and four modified it in one respect or another. Here is a large proportion of reversals, and it seems at first glace like a reflection upon the Supreme Court Judges who hold trials and grant orders from which appeals may be taken.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- When spending a Winter of study in the French art schools, a comfortable abiding place forms a larger factor for successful work than one is at first inclined to suppose. The true bohemian spirit inspires many students, and it is not until a long course of hastily consumed meals or insufficient fare has reduced one to a "good-for-nothing" physical state, that one descends to practicalities.

The unwillingness of the powers to allow Greece free hand in Crete, at least without an extravagant amount of protest, is undoubtedly due to their fear of complications in Macedonia. The situation there is really serious, due to the rivalry of interests among the various populations.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 20--The volume during the past week was small, but it was largely due to increasing firmness of the actual holders of securities. The Westinghouse grdip led the advance, with Union Switch and Signal the special feature. The annual meeting, of the latter company will: be held on the 9th prox., and this. week President Westinghouse mailed stockholders the financial report.

-- Curious reasoning is displayed by The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle when it says: "The size of the audiences that were permitted to gather in St. John's Church a few weeks ago was recklessly hazardous. A fire in the church or its immediate vicinity during one of those meetings would have resulted in terrible loss of life and bodily injury to many.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The President has commuted to four years' imprisonment with all deductions for good conduct, the sentence to five years' imprisonment, imposed on John E. Bielby in New York for embezzlement and making false entries in books and in reports to the Controller of the Currency.

While the various Senators have been piling amendments on the Sundry Civil bill that came up from the House, most of them increasing the already outrageous extravagance of that measure, Senator CHANDLER has a little scheme of his own aimed at the patronage of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- President-elect McKinley's Cabinet appears to be made up fully two weeks before the time for his inauguration. The announcements from Canton putting Mr. James A. Gary in the Post Office Department and Col. John J. McCook in the office of Attorney General were accepted at once as likely, and both of the nominations had been "mentioned" with more or less favor some time ago.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Feb. 20. -- Reports from all parts of the State indicate that the production of many Rhode Island textile mills will be increased next week. Several mills that have been closed for some time will start Monday morning, and others will add to their machinery now in operation.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 20. -- Just beneath the equestrian statue of Washington, and with the bronze figures of Mason, the author of the bill of rights, and other Revolutionary heroes looking down upon him, a Philadelphia electrician to-day made a desperate attempt at suicide.

Angelo Gannacore, thirty years old, of 136 Mott Street, cruelly beat his mother last evening, and a crowd of Italians drove him to the street. He kept the crowd back until a policeman came to his rescue. He went up to his rooms again and was attacked by his countrymen.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- United States Senator E.O. Wolcott of Colorado, who has been visiting Berlin in the interests of bimetallism, has left a very favorable impression here with all of the officials, financiers, and others with whom he came into contact. Despite the negative aspect which the semiofficial press gives to the results of Mr. Wolcott's mission, it is said he obtained a full discussion of the question of summoning an international monetary conference.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 21. -- A court verdict which materially affects 20,000 persons in the United States, largely residents in the Northern States, was the final decree rendered last night in the consolidated causes against the East Tennessee Land Company by United States Appellate Judge Severans of Michigan, presiding for Judge Clarke, disqualified.

The objections filed "for record" by Mayor Strong and Seth Low to the completed work of the Commissioners on a charter for the Greater New York, of which they are members, have incited the majority of the commission to file an answer.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The developments of the Austrian elections almost divide interest in Germany with the Eastern crisis. The submerging of the German Liberals, the growth of the New Czech and anti-Semite elements, and the obvious strength of the Clerical Party, are all factors which are felt as destined to have influence upon German affairs, internal and external.

The Board of Trustees of the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum Society, at its monthly meeting yesterday morning, formally accepted the gift of $100,000 from its President, Emanuel Lehman, who, on his seventieth birthday, last Monday, announced his intention of endowing the society with that sum, for an industrial and provident fund for the benefit of graduates of the asylum.

NEWARK, Feb. 20. -- George A. Dowden of this city, President of the Champion Burglar Alarm Company, who had Mason Renshaw Jones, the son of a former President of the Chemical Bank of New York, arrested in Newport, R.I., for debt, told to-day why he took that course.

Miss Serena Rhinelander is to give a building in East Eighty-eighth Street to St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church. It is next the plot occupied by the Rhinelander Industrial School, and will be called St. Christopher House. The building is nearly completed, and will be ready for use by Easter Sunday.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Feb. 21. -- There were no important developments to-day in the investigation of the deaths of Mrs. William H. Chapin, the wife of the Postmaster here, and Charles F. Mead, both of whom were found dead yesterday morning at the Chapin home with bullet wounds in their heads.

The fuss and excitement during the past two or three weeks occasioned by Dr. Lyman Abbott's utterances regarding the book of Jonah seem in the highest degree puerile. The sensational press has teemed with articles on the subject, clergymen of all denominations have been interviewed, and resolutions denouncing the preacher have been plentiful.

The Chicago Stock Exchange is having more trouble. New trading rules have been adopted, and much dissension has arisen among the members of the Exchange over "substitution" and other matters of which the New York broker wots not. According to the decision of the Governing Committee made last week the Chicago Stock Exchange is to go back to its old system of trading, and on March 1 forced substitution in account trading will be resumed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 21. -- When a dispatch from Columbus was shown Mr. Hanna to-night announcing that Gov. Bushnell would appoint him United States Senator to fill Senator Sherman's unexpired term, the National Chairman refused absolutely to discuss the matter.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- The second annual report of State Historian Hugh Hastings will be sent to the Legislature to-morrow evening. The report will be voluminous, and will contain facts intended to refute many accepted versions of the conduct of New York in the Revolution and during the civil war.

At St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, yesterday morning, the Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Rylance delivered a sermon on "The Good and the Evil of Newspapers." His text was taken from Acts, xvii., 21, "For all the Athenians and strangers which were there spent their time in nothing else, but either to tell, or to hear some new thing."

Just as a South Ferry train of the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad was slowing down to stop at the Cortlandt Street station yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock, an elderly, well-dressed man fell or jumped in front of the engine, and was injured so badly that he died two hours later, in the Hudson Street Hospital.

CANEA, Feb. 21. -- The Admirals commanding the foreign fleets here yesterday visited Col. Vassos, the commander of the Greek army of occupation, at his camp at Agnia. What transpired there has not been made public, but upon the return of the Admirals they invited the commander of the Greek warship Navarchos Miaoulis to visit them.

The member of the Indiana Legislature who objected to the distribution at public expense in the school libraries of a book containing what he alleged to be an attack on the Catholic Church carried the House with him, for his resolution condemning a specified book was adopted by a large vote.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- Prof. W.L. Tomlins, speaking of his visit to Kankakee, accompanied by thirty members of the Apollo Club, who sang before the inmates of the asylum for the insane, said to-day:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 21. -- Division No. 1 of the Missouri Supreme Court yesterday rendered a decision the effect of which is to open to women nearly all the elective county and State offices in Missouri.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 21. -- E.I. Field, representative of the North American Exploration Company of New York, is having extensive development work done on the Prospect Creek properties near Telluride. A contract has just been let for driving 900 feet of tunnel on the Stella vein, which, in this distance, will cut six cross leads at a depth of 2,000 feet.

The funeral services of Mrs. Annie Louise Bischoff, wife of Justice Henry Bischoff, Jr., were held yesterday at 1:30 P.M., at the residence, 19 West Ninety-sixth Street. They were conducted by the Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 21. -- When James A. Gary, the Southern representative in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet, returned from Canton to-day, he found over 1,000 congratulatory telegrams and letters piled on his desk. He said he could not state what portfolio he would have, but intimated that he expected to be the Postmaster General. Speaking of his relations with Mr. McKinley in the past, Mr. Gary said:

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- The Thomas Orchestra performed Richard Strauss's extraordinary tone-poem, "Thus Spake Zarathustra," for the first time in America last evening. It proved to be one of the most complex and technically difficult compositions ever offered to an orchestra. Its emotional demonstrations are as complex as the life they endeavor to portray, but, although it is reminiscent of ancient story, it is as variable and inconsistent as the times of to-day.

Mr. HANNA is not by nature or propensity of the Senatorial type. HAMILTON had very different types in view when, with cheerful optimism, he wrote of the Senate that "there is reason to expect that this branch will generally be composed with peculiar care and judgment." Mr. HANNA is too deep in business to be broad-minded and impartial.

The announcement of a wedding in the Russian Orthodox Church of St. Nicholas, at 321 Second Avenue, yesterday attracted a larger assembly than usual. The ceremony was as impressive as though the couple had come from the high classes, except that the clergyman gave them some advice, which he would have omitted in a high-class wedding.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- The Universal Peace Union and its co-operating organizations will hold public meetings Washington's Birthday in many parts of Europe and America to urge the establishment of arbitration between all civilized peoples and the ratification of the arbitration treaty between the United States and Great Britain.
What a lying pretense it is to set up the need of more revenue in justification of tariff revision when we are paying out $140,000,000 a year in pensions a generation after the close of the war!

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 21. -- Rain has fallen in torrents all over Eastern Kentucky for the past forty-eight hours, and a universal flood is raging over that section. The mountainous character of the country makes the sudden rising of the streams unusually dangerous, and from reports already received it is believed there has been loss of life as well as of much property.

" The financial affairs of the Exempt Firemen's Association have been investigated twice within the last five years," said Joseph C. Divine, to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, "and if anybody thinks another inquiry is needed, we are ready."
Mayor Strong has appointed the following sub-committees for the Grant Monument municipal inaugural, under the General Committee previously announced:

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The rate of discount during the past week for three months' bills was 2 per cent., and for thirty-day bills 1 3/4 per cent. The quantity of Australian sovereigns coming to this country and African bar gold meets the foreign demand. Silver was steady. The stock market was stagnant, but uneasy over the Cretan situation.

ROME, Feb. 21. -- The popular agitation in Italy in favor of the union of Greece and Crete is increasing daily, and it makes the position of the Government difficult. Thirty members of the Chamber of Deputies have telegraphed congratulations to Athens upon the decided stand taken by Greece.

While the subject of cheaper gas for New York City is before the present Legislature the writer would like to call attention to the public demand for cheaper gas in other portions of the city comprising the Greater New York; and, at the same time, to the great need for a thorough search into the reports made by some of these outside gas companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Having forty-five votes in sight, or expecting to have them by good management, the Republicans of the Senate are devoting some thought to several problems that must be confronted after March 3.

Your correspondent -- A.F. -- devotes much space to showing my "lack of information" on this subject, kindly hoping that I do not "intentionally misrepresent." To prove his point he gives no better authority than long quotations from The Saturday Review. Their flippancy and irreverence I do not undertake to refute, but surely that journal was never before reckoned an infallible guide in architectural matters.

We all thought that the defeat of Bryan made an end of the doctrines he championed, and so we hugged ourselves with delight and went to work with renewed confidence and courage after the election. Even the jingoism of the Senate over Cuba only gave a temporary check to this good feeling.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The Daily News's correspondent at Canea telegraphs a detailed account of the fighting at and the abandonment of Fort Voukoulis, which the Christians subsequently blew up with dynamite. The Moslems lost fifty killed in the fighting.

George Gwyer, twenty-three years old, of 117 Clinton Street, Hoboken, was placed under arrest yesterday on a charge of arson. His wife, who is twenty-one years old, was locked up as a witness. The house is a three-story frame building and is occupied by five families. The Gwyers, with their infant child, live in three rooms on the first floor.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 21. -- R.G. Peters, the Manistee lumberman, is out of debt, and has a million dollars to the good. Mr. Peters failed six years ago, and the debts of himself and the R.G. Peters Salt and Lumber Company aggregated nearly $2,500,000. It was the biggest failure Western Michigan had known, and the banks here and in Chicago, and Milwaukee, were involved deeply.

The Rev. Dr. RYLANCE spoke yesterday with much good sense in regard to newspapers. If what he said was not strikingly original, that is due to the fact that the subject is a simple one which sensible men generally understand, and the only way to be novel about it is to talk sheer nonsense -- which some ministers, unfortunately, do.

Dwight L. Moody preached twice yesterday in Carnegie Hall, and next Sunday will end the series of addresses which he has been giving over three months past in this city. He will enter upon his last week of revival services in Boston to-day, and during March will conduct evangelistic work in Cincinnati.
If GEORGE WASHINGTON could come and look at the country that is still proud to call him father, what would he think of it?

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 21. -- The twentieth annual report of Railroad Commissioner J.C. Hill of Virginia is just issued. It shows that the reports from all companies indicate gross earnings of $50,000,617.25 for the fiscal year ending June 30 last. The Commissioner says that the roads in the State are in good physical condition, and will compare favorably with the general average of the country.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Feb. 21. -- Fire this morning destroyed Thomas Beare's dry goods store, the clothing store of Ephraim Brothers, the shoe store of Rand Brothers, and the hardware store of Higham Brothers, in the Syndicate Block.

Several important Canadian concerns have given notice that if the exclusion of Canadians from employment in this country be enforced by law, they will instantly discharge all Americans in their employ. This is perfectly natural, and our people can have no reason to complain, but it would be an economic mistake, nevertheless.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 21. -- Gen. Benjamin Harrison is the father of a little girl, who arrived at the Delaware Street mansion at 5 o'clock this morning. Mrs. Harrison and the daughter are progressing finely.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 21. -- John Jacobs, Charles Lefler, and Richard Flannagan were returning yesterday afternoon from digging clams in Woodbridge Creek when, to shorten the distance, they struck across lots. When about 500 yards to the north of W.W. Berry's factory Flannagan came on some loose earth, and, as it gave beneath his weight, the man heard something squeak.

There was a big attendance at the annual indoor athletic games of the Long Island Inter-Scholastic League, held Saturday at the Cycle Club, on Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. The track was poor, and no records were broken, and no particularly fast time was made. Prizes were awarded to the first, second, and third men in each event, Berkeley School receiving a silver cup for the greatest number of points scored.

I have just read with much interest in a recent issue of your paper the article on "Southern California." California is a long way off to be reached by invalids, and it occurs to me that I might suggest to persons with weak lungs a place somewhat nearer, but still worth trying -- Fort Davis, Texas.

DENVER, COL., Feb. 21. -- Snowslides have wrought much damage and at least two lives were lost in the last twenty-four hours. Mail Carrier E.J. Bell, who was supposed to be dead, has saved himself, and about the only damage apparent, excepting his very weak condition, is a few frozen toes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 21. -- Advices from Tahiti to-day give a full account of the latest conflict between the French authorities and the natives of the Society Islands.

Recent efforts of Mormon missionaries in the East, and particularly in New York and vicinity, have aroused various religious bodies to an unsual sense of watchfulness and aggressiveness. There is a growing sentiment among church people that active measures should be taken to combat the Mormon ideas that are now being disseminated in Eastern communities.

Leslie's Weekly of Feb. 25, an advance copy of which has been received by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will contain an article by John A. Sleicher, on the Kansas City, Pittsburg and Port Arthur Railroad, a new line now nearly completed. The road is 787 miles long, and runs almost directly south from Kansas City to the Gulf.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- A dispatch from Athens to the Central News says that the fleets of the powers to-day bombarded the insurgent positions in the vicinity of Canea. The dispatch adds that the Greek dispatch boat Peineios has exchanged shots with a Turkish frigate, but in this case also details are lacking and both reports are accepted under reserve.

NOGALES, Arizona, Feb. 21. -- At El Plomo, west of here, there is serious Indian trouble. For three weeks, since the Government had a misunderstanding over a lot of cattle with a band of Papago Indians, there has been trouble with the leaders, with prospects for bloodshed. At the same time Gov. Raymon Carral sent a new Commissario of Police to this station.

SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 21. -- In the Civil Court, Judge Laughlin has issued an order in the case of Newton Finney of New York vs. The New Mexico Mining Company, enjoining all officers and agents from interfering with or disposing of any of the property of said company, which consists of the Ortiz Mine Grant in South Santa Fe County, and continuing in force the appointment of S.B. Elkins as receiver of the corporation.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 21. -- Deputy Sheriffs, acting for Helen Windsor Wilson, a New York modiste, tried to attach the costumes in which Mrs. Leslie Carter appears in the "Heart of Maryland" here to-night. The claim, which was for $1,635, was settled by Manager Gilbert. One item of the bill read: "White cotton dress, $1."

The Central Labor Union is still fighting every effort that is made to reintroduce labor in prisons. Delegate Harris yesterday asked that body to condemn a bill introduced in the Assembly to provide for the manufacture of certain school books in prisons.

The Laimbeer bill providing for the establishment of a Farm Colony by the City of New York for the detention, reformation, and instruction of persons convicted of vagrancy, habitual drunkenness, and repeated disorderly conduct, will be considered by the Committee on Cities on Tuesday, at Albany.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 21. -- A furious religious war broke out in the Legislature yesterday when Representative Wallrath, a Democrat from Logansport, introduced a resolution condemning the circulation of the "Story of Liberty" in the Indiana Reading Circle.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- The Legislature soon will settle down to work in earnest. All of the important questions upon which legislation is to be enacted this session will be covered by the introduction of bills within the next two weeks. After the inauguration at Washington the legislators will have to take hold of things with a rush.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 21. -- Gov. Bushnell issued the following statement this evening:...
