A lady who recently happened to visit a neighbor, found her in a terrible state of misery. Her head was tightly bound with a handkerchief, and there were dark circles around her eyes.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- In the House of Commons to-day, Sir. Labouchere (Radical) moved to adjourn with a view of discussing the situation in Crete, and the motion was seconded by Mr. John Dillon, the leader of the Irish National Party.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 22. -- The National Reform Press Association began its annual meeting to-day, with 250 delegates present.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Capt. Julius A. Palmer, at present acting secretary to the ex-Queen of Hawaii, furnished the following statement in contradiction of sundry rumors which have been circulated since her arrival in Washington:
The report of the Greater New York Commission to the Legislature was signed by all of the Commissioners except Andrew H. Green, who was ill and unable to attend the meetings. It is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The annual Senatorial observance of Washington's Birthday by having his Farewell Address read by one of the leading elocutionists of the Senate took place to-day in the presence of a large audience, Mr. Daniel (Dem., Va.,) being the reader chosen for the occasion. The reading occupied an hour.

The report of the Greater New York Commission, accompanying the draft of a charter submitted to the Legislature, was so framed as to command the support of all the members and receive a unanimous signature, and it therefore deals lightly or not at all with the few controverted points.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22. -- Heavy rains in the valleys of the Missouri River and its tributaries have flooded those streams, and the Mississippi is receiving the extra volume of water to swell its own rise. The river here showed a rise of four feet in twenty-four hours and is still rising. River men are preparing for an overflow of lowlands.

It is not without significance that the death of STEINITZ should have been due to mental disorder and that he should have died in a private asylum. He had just come unsuccessfully out of a match which had involved the most intense mental application for days and weeks in succession.

BRASS, Niger Coast Protectorate, Feb. 22. -- The expedition which was formed to punish Drunami, King of Benin, for the murder of the members of a peaceable British expedition which was attempting to reach Benin City, has been entirely successful. The expedition has captured Benin City and the King is a fugitive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Secretary Olney spent an hour in his office this morning assorting his private papers, which were being boxed for transportation to Boston. Senator Sherman, his successor expectant, interrupted him for a few minutes to inquire whether anything unusually aggrevating had occurred in regard to our relations with Spain, and learned: "Nothing, absolutely."

Crete, the "Jewel of the Levant," is an island measuring in length 156 miles, and in breadth from 7 to 30 miles, its total area being 3,326 square miles, or about twice the size of Hampshire. It is for the most part mountainous, the loftiest peak being Mount Ida of classic fame, now called Upiloriti, which rises to a height of 8,000 feet.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 20, 1896. -- An article was recently published in many of the leading newspapers of the United States to the effect that an English company had secured a concession from the Nicaraguan Government to construct and operate a railroad from Lake Nicaragua to the Atlantic coast.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The Athens correspondent of The Chronicle telegraphs that Greece will instantly declare war if the Turkish troops give provocation. He adds that it would be impossible to exaggerate the intensity of national feeling. Greece cannot and will not draw back. If she did there would be neither a crown nor a government in twenty-four hours.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The report of the examination department of the State Board of Regents for 1896 shows that 913,500 question papers were printed for use in the examinations, and that 5,000 bulletins, containing 363 different papers, or 1,815,000 question papers, were also required, making a total of 2,728,500.

Recorder McDonough of Hoboken yesterday committed to jail a man who has caused annoyance for many years to families of prominence in this city, Newport, and other places. The prisoner was arraigned under the name of August Johnson, but he has been known also as A. Jansen and as Count Swedenbourg.

The bombardment on Sunday of the Greek forces at Canea to prevent them from beating the Turks was a disgrace to Europe. It was an outrage upon civilization perpetrated in the name of civilization. The "concert of the powers" which has shown itself impotent to protect the Armenian victims of the Turk has shown itself efficient to prevent the Cretan victims of the Turk from protecting themselves by throwing off his yoke.
WHEELING, West Va., Feb. 22. -- Western West Virginia is very largely under water to-night, with the rain still descending and the waters rising at nearly all points.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- In the Reichstag to-day the Government was interrogated as to the attitude of Germany in the matter of the situation in Crete. Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, Minister of Foreign Affairs, replied that the first task of Germany in Crete would be to secure the restoration of peace in the island and remove the danger of war which has been created by Greece's rupture of international law.

It seems that the Great Eastern was just forty years in advance of her time. She was launched in 1857, and, if she had not been by chance extremely well adapted to the business of laying submarine telegraph cables, she would have been entirely useless. She was only the imperfectly realized dream of a naval engineer, not a practicable sea-going ship.

-- It is noted as both remarkable and alarming that Bombay, where the ravages of the plague have been vastly greater than in any other part of India, is the cleanest city in the country, has an excellent system of sewers and general sanitation, and in ordinary times boasts of a death rate so low as to compare fairly well with that of more than one European capital.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- A large audience of students and distinguished visitors gathered in the armory at Cornell University this morning for the ceremonies in celebration of Washington's Birthday. Over 1,000 invitations had been sent to distinguished members of the bar and other eminent men, and such an audience was assembled as has graced but a few occasions in the history of the university.
The following sales are down for to-day at 111 Broadway, unless otherwise specified:

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Washington's Birthday proved no deterrent to the working of the Assembly machinery, which started up again to-night after the usual Saturday and Sunday recess. Mr. Ives offered the following:

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Feb. 22. -- John Grissom, one of the members of the gang who raided the town of Stroud three weeks ago, was killed in a battle with a posse of Deputy Sheriffs, eighteen miles northeast of Chandler, yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Superintendent Aldridge of the State Department of Public Works to-night sent to the Legislature a communication bearing on the rate of wages to be paid for unskilled labor on the public works of the State, and urging that a minimum price of not less than 15 cents per hour be fixed by the Legislature for such work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- C.W. Stone (Rep., Penn.,) submitted to the House today the report of the Committee on Coin-age, Weights, and Measures, recommending the passage of the bill providing for the appointment of Commissioners to represent the United States at any monetary conference which may be called hereafter.

The principal reason given for the retention of the four-headed Police Department in the original report of the Committee on Draft to the Greater New York Commission was that the duties with which the board was charged in connection with elections made it necessary under a Constitutional requirement that it be "composed of equal representation of the two dominant political parties."

The opening of the twenty-first annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club has started discussion among fanciers of dogs that will only be settled to-day, when the dogs that have caused the dispute are judged in the ring. This duty will fall to the lot of George Raper or L.P.C. Astley, the two English judges who have come here to help award the prizes.

A crowd of chess players thronged Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, yesterday to witness two chess tournaments, in connection with the nineteenth annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association. One was a masters' tournament, players of the first rank only taking part, while the other was open to all members of the association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Congress of the Daughters of the Revolution was opened here this morning, and, despite inclement weather, with every promise of success. With but few exceptions the accredited State delegates from all points of the country were present at the Columbia Theatre at 10 o'clock, when the meeting was called to order by the President General, Mrs. Letitia Green Stevenson, wife of the Vice President of the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- It is proposed to introduce in the Legislature this week a bill to pay salaries to over a hundred employes in Brooklyn city departments who, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has decided, were appointed in violation of the civil service provisions of the State Constitution.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The Washington Association of this city held its annual celebration in honor of Washington to-day. The celebration consisted of dinner, served to the 360 present, at 1:30 o'clock P.M., after which exercises fitting to the day were held, one of the principal features of which was the reading of an article by William Nelson of Paterson, entitled "Alexander Hamilton in New Jersey."

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Two brilliant balls at the Laurel-in-the-Pines and the Lakewood Hotel to-night closed the most crowded holiday ever known in the history of Lakewood. Elaborate decorations and distinguished guests and parties of young people made the balls the most notable this season.
The funeral of Walter S. Neilson, who died Friday at 12 West Forty-seventh Street, was held at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- A force of carpenters was put at work this morning in front of the Senate end of the Capitol Building on the platform upon which Major McKinley will be inaugurated. Since the time of Jackson until now the Presidents have been inaugurated upon a Platform constructed in the centre of the front, directly in advance of the doors leading from the rotunda.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The report of the Greater New York Commission, its proposed bills, and the charter were presented in both branches of the Legislature tonight. Owing to the fact that the commission sent up but two copies of these documents, and these bound together in a single volume, the charter could not be introduced as a bill to-night.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, the Government was sharply questioned by the Socialist leaders MM. Jaures and Millerand and others in regard to the situation in Crete, and in the course of the ensuing discussion of various motions the Government's general policy in the East was severely criticised.

CANEA, Feb. 22. -- The British, Italian, and Russian Consuls, who recently went to Selino to inquire into the situation there, returned to-day, bringing with them 170 Mussulmans who feared to remain in the town.

An independent citizens' movement is now being organized, having in view the separation of city issues from State and National politics and the nomination of an independent ticket at the coming municipal election.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Senator Voorhees introduced a resolution yesterday which was adopted unanimously, urging New Jersey's Representatives in Congress to oppose the passage of the bill to prohibit the ticket brokerage business. The resolution follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The Greater New York Commission will be invited to appear before the two Cities Committees Thursday and begin a series of explanations of the charter. This was determined this morning at a consultation between Senator Stranahan and Assemblyman Austin, the Chairmen.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Mrs. Cleveland and her children arrived in Princeton this afternoon, and are now snugly settled in their new home, on Bayard Avenue. The party reached the little village station of the Pennsylvania Railroad a few minutes before 4 o'clock. It contained ten members. Mrs. Cleveland, her mother, her three children, Ruth, Marion, and Esther, two nurses, and three servants.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- Many callers came to Canton to-day to see the President-elect, but only a few with whom he had appointments saw him. The doctor still insists that Major McKinley must not see visitors. Those who come without having been sent for will waste time and money.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The steamers Miller and Hasbrouck of the Poughkeepsie Line will begin their regular trips to and from New York Thursday, and an early resumption of navigation is expected. The warm weather of the past few days has caused the residents of the towns on the Hudson between Albany and Poughkeepsie to get ready for the annual inundation which follows the breaking up of the ice.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- The Paris correspondent of The Chronicle telegraphs that the Austrian War Office is making every necessary preparation for the mobilization of the forces. The work proceeds day and night. Emperor Francis Joseph spends hours every day with his military advisers.

Seventy-one oils and forty-eight water colors, painted by members of the Salmagundi Club, now fill the dainty little gallery of the clubhouse at 14 West Twelfth Street, The exhibition, which opened on Saturday last and, which will close on Saturday evening next, has already been visited by several hundred persons and is attracting deserved attention in art circles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The House late this afternoon ran unexpectedly into an interesting and possibly significant discussion of the civil service law. It came about by the consideration of a bill to amend the Revised Statutes, so as to give the Governors of Territories the power to remove as well as to appoint certain Territorial officers.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Superintendent Kilburn of the State Banking Department today submitted his annual report to the Legislature regarding the foreign mortgage, loan, or investment companies which are licensed to transact business in this State.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- In the Assembly today Assemblyman Nixon's bill amending the consolidated school law so as to provide for the furnishing of free text books in union free school districts and providing the manner of voting for or against the furnishing of such books was passed after some debate.

Ex-President Jorge Montt of Chile, who is known in his country as the "fighting Admiral," reached this city yesterday on the steamship Altai of the Atlas Line, and will make the Fifth Avenue Hotel his headquarters for the next two months.
CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee, who came here to-day to see Major McKinley, was in a talkative mood this evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Notwithstanding the objections advanced by the commandant of the Military Academy, Col. Ernst, to the cadets at West Point participating in the inauguaral parade, the House Committee on Military Affairs to-day, by a practically unanimous vote, ordered a favorable report on the joint resolution providing for their attendance.

It is now more than two years since the manager of CARNEGIE'S steel works at Homestead, Penn., in explaining the marked improvements and extensions made there remarked, in substance, that they were intended to prepare for the advent of free trade, of which the CARNEGIES entertained no doubt.

The concession by Nicaragua to Henry A. Barling and Frank H. Davis, formerly of New York, to build a railroad from Lake Nicaragua to the Caribbean Sea, exclusively announced in THE TIMES yesterday, was discussed with considerable interest in this city yesterday by persons who have some acquaintance with Nicaraguan affairs.

The Social Reform Club expressed its disapproval last evening of the proposal to give a portion of Union Square Park for the Metropolitan Traction Company to lay its tracks in, at least without Adequate compensation.

ALBANY, Feb, 23. -- The canalboatmen have prepared a bill which was introduced to-day by Senator Koehler, to offset the proposition of the Consolidated Lake and Canal Transportation Company, that it be allowed to use unlimited capital to operate boats on the canals of this State. This is the company which Erastus Wiman is interested in.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A material increase in the rate of duty on tropical fruits such as are raised in this country was made this morning by the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The Westchester County Grand Jury, which has been investigating the official acts of town Assessors, made its presentment to-day to the Supreme Court, Justice J. Keogh presiding. The Justice had ordered the investigation, complaining that the Assessors were in the habit of making the real estate of the county bear nearly all the burden of taxation, while personal property was let off very lightly, and he wanted this corrected.

That is an excellent bill for the protection of privacy which Senator ELLSWORTH yesterday introduced into the Legislature. It provides that no portrait shall be published without the written consent of the person it purports to represent. We believe this is virtually, the law in France, and some such law is urgently needed in this country to protect people who shun publicity from having publicity forced upon them.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 23. -- Heavy rains have swollen the streams enormously in this vicinity. Two railway trestles near this city were washed away last night. All telegraph and telephone wires east of Knoxville are down, and trains are standing still. Clinch River, at Clinton, registers 40 feet, and residents, are leaving their houses.
I welcome THE TIMES'S suggestion that the anniversary of Washington's Birthday be devoted to efforts in behalf of the arbitration treaty pending in the Senate.

The Morris Wheelmen gave an entertainment and reception last evening at Schnorer Club Hall, One Hundred and Sixty-third Street and Eagle Avenue. An address of welcome was made to the several hundred guests present by Dr. W.K. Doty, President of the club. Among the performers were H.L. Price, vocal soloist; Miss Edyth M. Hallett, who recited; Prof. William Kimmelmann, pianist, and Mrs. Edith M. DuMond, vocal soloist. Dancing began at 10:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- In the Senate to-day the consideration of the Indian Appropriation bill was resumed, the question being on a point of order made yesterday by Mr. Vilas (Dem., Wis.,) against the committee amendment for the opening of the Uncompahgre Indian reservation, as general legislation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The following address was issued this afternoon by the silver Republicans of the Senate and House:

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Senator Ellsworth today introduced a bill prohibiting the publication of cartoons or portraits in newspapers and other publications. It was referred to the Committee on Codes. The bill provides as follows:

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 23. -- The action last night of the Council Committee in accepting an invitation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of Virginia to visit New York on March 7 and inspect its long-distance telephone service has aroused opposition.

Justice Beekman of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to grant an injunction to Mrs. Nellie R. Kurtz of 700 West End Avenue, restraining E. Clifford Potter from leasing the house next door -- No. 702 -- to the Riverside Wheelmen for a clubhouse. The property which Mr. Potter has leased to the wheelmen is on the east side of the avenue, and at the corner of Ninety-ninth Street. It is a comparatively new building.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- "The new scheme of employing the prisoners in the State institutions bids fair to prove an unqualified success," said Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, this morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The Assembly Committee on Public Health gave a hearing to-day on Senator Higbie's bill permitting the sale of poisons by merchants. The bill was opposed by William Muir of Brooklyn, President of the Kings County Pharmaceutical Society; Dr. Barcley of Brooklyn, and E.S. Dawson, Jr., of Syracuse. Another hearing will be had March 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Cuban affairs occupied the attention of the Senate for a considerable time to-day. Mr. Mills (Dem., Texas,) offered a resolution, which was agreed to, requesting the President to transmit to the Senate a statement of the facts concerning the arrest, imprisonment, and death of Dr. Ricardo Ruiz, in the jail at Guanabacoa, Cuba, with copies of the correspondence on the subject.
Buerman Co. have sold for the estate of Frederick Lowe, to Harris Cohen Co., 290 Broome Street, northeast corner of Eldridge Street, 20.3 by 102.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23. -- The Yale Navy has received a communication from the New London Board of Trade, asking if Yale will consent to row the Yale-Harvard-Cornell race on the Thames, provided the consent of Harvard and Cornell can be obtained. Yale has answered that Yale will be glad to row there.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- The Ohio River is rising at the rate of seven inches an hour. At 9 o'clock to-night it had reached Water Street, and registered fifty-four feet. The railroads using the Central Union Station will probably have to seek other quarters from which to run their passenger trains before the day is over.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Most of to-day's session of the House was taken up in consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill. Mr. Barrett (Rep., Mass.,) criticised the bill for its failure to make appropriation for what he deemed to be one of the most important parts of the service, the construction of dry docks, and he moved an amendment authorizing one to be built at the Boston Navy Yard, to cost not exceeding $1,000,000.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 23. -- Speaker Tappan to-day called L.L. Coffman of Boone to the chair, in the State House of Representatives, and took the floor in behalf of the concurrent resolution to accept the State's compromise with the National Government on the bill now pending before Congress.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23. -- Charles Connors, alias Herbert Masters, claiming to be a son of an Enlish nobleman, is under arrest here. He is twenty-seven years old. It is believed he is wanted at several cities.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 23. -- Streams in Kentucky are clear out of their banks and doing unmeasurable damage. Several people have been drowned in various parts of the State, Much Stock has been lost, fencing swept away, and other property almost ruined. The streams all through the mountains are higher than for years, and the greatest damage is feared.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Assemblyman Palmer of Schoharie this morning introduced a resolution, asking for information as to the sales of salt spring lands on the State reservation in Onandaga County. It was adopted. It calls on the Board of Land Commissioners to furnish a list of the lands sold, with the location, price, and purchaser. Also to send maps showing the sites which have been transferred.

Argument on L.J. Callanan's application for a mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Public Works to remove the obstructions in Vesey Street was again postponed in the Supreme Court yesterday because of the illness of Assistant Corporation Counsel Sterling. Justice Beekman set the hearing for to- day and solid there must be no further delay.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23. -- The jury in the ease of the Government against John D. Hart of this city on the charge of aiding in a Cuban filibustering expedition on the steamer Laurada in August last this morning in the United States District Court rendered a verdict of guilty. Judge Butler suspended sentence.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- The examination of Cecil Rhodes by the Parliamentary committee appointed to inquire into the Transvaal raid was resumed in Westminster Hall today. The Prince of Wales was again present during the proceedings, and Dr. Jameson, the leader of the Transvaal raiders, made his appearance at the inquiry for the first time.
You ask me to state my reasons for thinking that the consolidation of New York with the surrounding country is not desirable from the New York point of view. I can only suggest these very briefly:

George McAneny, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, wrote to Controller Fitch Tuesday, calling his attention to the appointment of certain stenographers and other clerical employes in the District Attorney's office without competitive examination. Mr. McAneny asked the Controller not to sign any Day warrants for any persons so appointed.

On Tuesday Mr. WILLIAM M. GROSVENOR of Ohio, a Republican, an ardent professed supporter of Mr. MCKINLEY, made a violent and unseemly attack on the merit system in the House of Representatives. He was supported by several Republican members and Delegates.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 24. -By a formal resolution adopted two years ago by the Faculty of Vassar College, it was agreed that Washington's Birthday should not be given to the students as a holiday. This action did not meet with favor among the students, but as the anniversary last year fell upon the last day of th week, and so seemed like a holiday, in many respects, no formal protest was made.

The dogs in the Madison Square Garden received homage yesterday from hundreds of visitors. Black Prince Brampton, the best mastiff; Alton II., Le Prince and La Princess, the best St. Bernards; Simon de Sudbury, the English bloodhound; J. Pierpont Morgan's collies, George Gould's pointers, George Work's French bulldogs, the Boston terriers, and all the cracks in the other breeds were sought out and their points commented on.

Mrs. Josephine Richarden, a young French woman of 143 West Thirtieth Street, was so badly burned at her home yesterday that it is believed she will not recover. She was taken to the New York Hospital.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Representative Abell of Kings to-day protested against Speaker O'Grady's assumption of absolute power in the Assembly. A resolution by Mr. Garby was before the Assembly urging the New York members of Congress to support Congressman H.M. Baker's amendment to an appropriation bill permitting the reinstatement to the Federal service of dismissed employes without civil service examination.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 24. -- Gov. Bradley will not go to the inauguration of President McKinley. He said to-night that business complications of an official nature would make it necessary for him to remain at Frankfort, although he was anxious to attend the inauguration.
BOSTON, Feb. 24. -- Four Harvard students were in the Municipal Court this morning as the result of a fracas with The Boston police this morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Adjt. Gem Tillinghast to-day issued, the following special order, giving the itinerary as arranged for the Commander in Chief, Gov. Black, who will go to the inauguration of President-elect McKinley next week:

The Trust Investigating Committee sat yesterday morning in the Aldermanic Council Chamber and took the testimony of several witnesses connected with the Tobacco Trust. President Duke was again on the stand.

An exhibition drill was given at the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club last night, by two platoons of Brooklyn's crack cavalry organziation, Troop C. Nearly 1,000 spectators were present. Pretty girls were in the majority.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 24. -- In the House this morning the Railroad and Canals Committee reported favorably the Equal Taxation bill presented in accordance with the recommendation of the commission appointed by Gov. Griggs to investigate the matter. The committee at the same time reported adversely the Klink bills providing for equal taxation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The decoration of the Treasury Department Building for the inaugural festivities began to-day, and the rest of this week and the first three days of next week will be devoted to putting the city into appropriate garb for the quadrennial occasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Cuban affairs and personalities kept the Senate in an uproar throughout the session to-day. Early in the day Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) offered the following resolution, and asked for its immediate consideration:

-- Two Maine game wardens have just returned to Augusta after a 300-mile tramp on snowshoes through the forests in the northern and northeastern parts of the State. They made the journey for the purpose of investigating the Winter slaughter of game, and were successful in securing evidence that may result in the arrest, conviction, and punishment of a lot of men who have been illegally killing large numbers of moose, caribou, and common deer.

The object of Senator ELLSWORTH'S bill to prevent the publication of what purport to be portraits of people without their consent is, as we have already said, entirely admirable. But a consideration of the actual text of the bill makes it doubtful whether it would not go much beyond the public requirements or the author's intention.
ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Assemblyman Roehr to-day introduced a bill intended to regulate lobbying for and against measures introduced in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The appearance of William Jennings Bryan, the Democratic candidate for President last Fall, upon the floor of the House was the most noticeable event of to-day's session. He had the entre of the floor as an ex-member, and came into the hall at 4:30 o'clock, about an hour after his arrival in the city.

Yesterday the Police Board furnished a new "object lesson" illustrating the utter viciousness of having an official board capable of dead-lock. Any public official should be entitled to take the position upon any question which he considers right, but no one or two officials should be able so to split the trend of an administrative department that it is incapable of action.
ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Senator Stranahan said, after the Senate session to-day, that by some "fluke" the Greater New York bills had not been announced by the Senate Clerk before the adjournment.

The periodical report that Madison Square Garden is to be abandoned, converted to other uses, or modified because it does not pay is again revived, in a more specific form than usual. A special meeting of the corporation which runs it has been called to take decisive action in the premises.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 24. -- W.A. Gamo, a business man well known in Chicago and the East, has secured a divorce from his wife, Grace Gamo, of New York, with the custody of their two children.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Canea giving a vivid description of the burning of the Governor's palace there to-day. Vice Admiral Canevaro of the Italian squadron, who is in command of the united naval forces in Cretan waters, resided in the palace, which was guarded by a strong force of Italian sailors.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The Assembly Cities Committee gave special hearings to-day on all bills which have been introduced up to date affecting the erection of buildings in New York City. There were four measures -one by Mr. H.T. Andrews, one by Mr. Husted, one by Mr. Finn, one by Senator Page, and two by Mr. Austin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- A question that has arisen is whether there is sufficient justification, outside of Gen. Lee's impatience and ambition, for an armed demonstration in Cuban waters that may lead to a war with Spain. Gen. Lee is understood to be dissatisfied because the Administration has not acted with sufficient vigor in seconding some demands which he has suggested should be made in behalf of persons reported to be American citizens.

The "great" prizefight advertised to take place in Nevada next month arouses in certain classes a brutal and vicious sentiment to which some of the newspapers are pandering with all the skill and ingenuity at their command. The policy is disgusting to decent people and demoralizing to those who come under its influence.

Delegates from nearly all the States that have sound-money associations met at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday and completed the organization of a National Sound Money League on a non-partisan basis. The announced objects of the league are the continuance of the efforts made during the last campaign for National honor and sound money, and the education of the people to a realization of the necessity for maintaining the gold standard.

District Attorney Olcott announced yesterday that he had decided to ask the Supreme Court to authorize a special Grand Jury to sit in March and clear away the thousands of bail cases which have come down to Mr. Olcott from his predecessors.

The American Paper Manufacturers, who dined at the Waldorf last evening, took no small part in their own after-dinner exercises. They listened attentively to the speakers, and applauded sentiments that pleased them, and every pause for effect was cure to be filled in with a question or comment from the floor.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Petitions enough to fill a big basket have been circulated among members of the Legislature in behalf of men who want appointments from President McKinley in the foreign diplomatic and consular service.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 24. -- The Ohio River continues to rise at Louisville and has passed the danger line. The water rose three inches an hour all last night and two and one-half inches an hour to-day. At 6 o'clock this evening the marks showed twenty-seven feet on the falls, which is three feet above the danger line.

William Jay Koerner, the newspaper artist, who shot and killed Rose A. Redgate of Brooklyn on Fourteenth Street last September, was found guilty yesterday of murder in the first degree. The jury in Part IV. of General Sessions brought in the verdict before Judge Newburger at 5:45 last night, after being out about an hour and a half.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- That part of the annual report of State Superintendent of Banking Frederick D. Kilburn relating to savings banks, trust companies, and safe deposit companies and miscellaneous corporations under the supervision of the State Banking Department will be sent to the Legislature to-morrow.
In the course of an article on "Trusts and the Government" Harper's Weekly has the following explicit statement:
Slawson Hobbs have sold for John J. Egan and Daniel Rallecy the five-story double apartment house 424 West Twentieth Street. This is the last of a row of three completed last Summer.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The Senate Codes Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on Senator Mullin's bill, prohibiting the appearance in any theatre or public resort of any person in tights or in a practically nude state in the presence of the opposite sex.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 24. -- An incoming passenger train on the Georgia Division of the Southern Railroad, bound from Atlanta, struck a wagon at a crossing four miles east of this city at noon to-day.
I have just been reading the details of the examination of Mr. James B. Duke before the Lexow committee. From this it appears:

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- A discussion that was short but lively while it lasted took place to-day between L.J. Callanan of New York and Assemblyman Dempsey over the Finn bill, which proposes to grant the use of the stoop line in streets about the New York City markets.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- In the Senate to-day, by a strict party vote of 25 to 13, Mr. Martin's resolution instructing the Lexow committee to investigate the department stores was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

The veil of secrecy which was drawn so closely over the names of the figurantes in the tableaus to be given to-night at Madison Square Garden Concert Hall for the benefit of the St. Mary's Hospital for Children was lifted yesterday afternoon, at the dress rehearsal. Invitations to the rehearsal were sent out by Mrs. Richard Irvin, and about 150 persons were scattered throughout the concert hall and galleries.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Assistant Prosecutor Shaw broke down in court here to-day at the conclusion of a criminal trial and wept hysterically, and declared he could not obtain justice for the poor. Philip Geyer of Heledon had been acquitted on a charge of unlawfully living with Mrs. Augusta Schoenahl.
Maclay and Davies have sold for the Pelhamdale Land Company to Arthur L. Cushman, six lots on east side of Manida Street, between Spofford and Lafayette Avenues, Twenty-third Ward.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 25. -- An excited crowd of men met here to-day, as the stockholders of the Southern Mutual Building and Loan Association, and discussed the wrecking of this institution by its officers. The association was thrown into a receivership some time ago, and this meeting was called by President W.C. Hale.
Mr. Hinrichs Says the Two Old Parties Are Willing to Make Concessions and that a Mayor Should Be Elected for His Personality.
ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- In the Assembly today Senator Ellsworth's bill exempting State bonds from taxation was made a special order for March 2.
The New York City Commission on the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition, appointed by Mayor Strong, met yesterday at the Cotton Exchange.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 25. -- Since the State Assembly has been in session there have been daily charges that bribery and fraud have been used in passing or defeating certain corporation measures. The first open and direct charge was made by W.B. Masterson, the famous frontier Sheriff of Dodge City, which was published in a morning paper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- An obstacle to the prompt ratification of the Anglo-Venezuelan arbitration treaty has been encountered in a provision of the Venezuelan Constitution necessitating the use of the Spanish language in documents for consideration of the Congress. When the convention was concluded, Feb. 2, both the copies signed by the plenipotentiaries were in the English language, this being deemed advisable, as the proceedings of the tribunal would be conducted in that tongue.

A progressive euchre party was given last night, under the auspices of the Prospect Heights Euchre Club, at the Pierrepont Assembly Rooms, Pierrepont and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, to aid the Rev. John C. York, rector of St. Patrick's Church, at Huntington, L.I., who is trying to lift an eleven-thousand-dollar church debt.

President Cleveland's eight years of service as Chief Executive of the Nation will be commemorated at a banquet to be given in this city, probably the last week in April, by the Reform Club. This decision is the outgrowth of quiet talk that has been in progress for several weeks past among prominent men of the city.
ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Assembly Committee on Commerce and Navigation will to-morrow report favorably the following bills:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Senate to-day spent nearly all its time in considering Cuban matters. The discussion was started by Senator Allen, who spoke in support of his resolution, offered yesterday, instructing the President to send warships to Cuba for the protection of American citizens.

The fourth concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra was given in the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The audience was the largest which the orchestra has enjoyed this Winter, and there was room for doubt as to whether this was caused by the attractive powers of the soloist, Mme. Teresa Carreno, or the extreme lightness of the programme.

The President of the West End Association seems to have been driven to the end of his resources by Col. WARING'S exposition of the need of a dump near the foot of West Ninety-sixth Street. He has nothing more to the purpose to say than to lament that Col. WARING desires to establish a dump "within sight" of GRANT'S tomb.
" What do I think of the Citizens' Union?" said Abraham Gruber, repeating the query of a TIMES reporter. "Well, I think unutterable things.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25. -- Judge Nathan Goff of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals handed down an order to-day, which is likely to prove of far-reaching importance to telephone and other corporations having franchises from municipalities.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 25. -- The lower branch of the Arkansas Legislature this afternoon passed the Railroad Commission bill, which has been a bone of contention before every legislative body that has assembled in this State for the last ten years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- A prominent Republican, who was familiar with some of the inside operations of the late campaign, to-day gave an explanation of the Lexow investigation of trusts that sustains some of the New York reports.

HARMONY GROVE, Ga., Feb. 25. -- Grady Reynolds, a merchant of Belton, Ga., was arrested here to-day by the Marshal of Belton for the murder of his business partner, M.C. Hunt, a prominent citizen of Belton.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- There was a large attendance of peers and visitors at the opening of the sitting of the House of Lords this evening. Several peeresses were present, and a number of Bishops other than those entitled to sit in the House of Lords, together with some members of the House of Commons, looked on from the galleries.
WINSTED, Conn., Feb. 25. -- Col. Salmon Algernon Granger committed suicide this morning, shooting himself in the right temple at his home in this town.
BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 25. -- The Spring meeting of the National League and American Association of Baseball Clubs opened here this morning. Little business of importance was transacted to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25. -- C. Stuart Patterson, Chairman of the Indianapolis Monetary Convention, was directed to appoint an Executive Committee of fifteen to continue the work of the convention, and in particular to bring before Congress and the country the subject of the appointment of a Currency Commission.
Among the "questions which the Cleveland Administration will leave unsettled" our neighbor The Sun includes "a revenue sufficient for the needs of the Government economically administered."

As one who has given much attention to municipal government, I have never been able to comprehend the genius of the Greater New York project; and even now I cannot believe that, when it comes to the consideration of any definite plan of organization, the people of this city will sanction it.
A conference of wool men was held yesterday at the Wool Exchange Building, on Beach Street, for the organization of a Wool Exchange on the lines of the Stock and Produce Exchanges.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 25. -- The Reorganization Committee of the Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis Railroad Company to-day acquired a controlling interest in the New Albany Belt and Terminal Company. The committee purchased a majority of the $300,000 of bonds at 57 1/2 cents. The Belt has been operated by the Kentucky and Indiana Bridge Company, with which it connects the lines entering Louisville by way of New Albany.

The legislative power of the State of New York appears to have returned from Florida, and there is a revival of interest in matters of importance which have been in abeyance. Doubtless we shall soon know what the course of proceeding will be with reference to the Greater New York charter and whether or not the legislative mind inclines toward putting it through in the shape reported by the commission.

Gen. LEE seems to have got involved in an unfortunate situation. He went to Cuba with the approval, sympathy, and respect of the country, which recognized in him a gallant and manly soldier, who had shown an admirable spirit in his public career since the close of the civil war, and, in the field that he had occupied, more than usual ability.

The second of the three nights' auction sale of Dutch and Italian pictures, in oil and water color, that comprise the Holland Art Galleries collection, was conducted at Chickering Hall last night, Thomas E. Kirby, for the American Art Association, disposing of the paintings.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- The Athens correspondent of The Standard telegraphs that it is reported that Col. Smolentz, Minister of War, has renewed his offer to resign. There are signs that the remainder of the Cabinet are inclined to take a similar step, but any indication of retreat from the King's policy would involve the greatest danger to the throne.

The hearing yesterday in the matter of the investigation of trusts by the joint legislative committee was announced as the last of these meetings, and, notwithstanding that the committee will ask for an extension of time until March 9 to present its report to the Legislature, it is extremely improbable that it will take any additional testimony.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Greater New York charter and accompanying bills were formally read by the Clerk in the Senate this morning and were referred to the Cities Committee Senator Raines desired to have the separate bill amending the general election law go to the Judiciary Committee, as that committee was now considering proposed amendments to that statute.

The Committees on Finance, Sites, By-Laws, and Legislature of the Board of Education, acting jointly, have sent to the Board of Aldermen a communication concerning the bill which they have prepared for presentation to the Legislature providing for an additional schoolhouse bond issue of $7,500,000.

The dog show came to an end yesterday. It has been the most successful exhibition in the history of the Westminster Kennel Club from a fancier's standpoint and from the way Treasurer F.O. De Luze will look at it. The attendance has been large each day, and the total for the four days is a record breaker.

The Reform Club held a meeting last night to discuss the proposed arbitration treaty between this country and Great Britain. Although only a limited number of notices were sent to the members, the assembly hall of the club was pretty well filled, and the discussion proved to be lively and patriotic.

Here is a queer quandary. Some greedy legislators, to wit, Senator WILCOX and Assemblyman KAVANAUGH, have been introducing bills to enable Senators and Assemblymen to ride free on railroads. The bill includes with legislators the Governor and Lieutenant Governor and Judges of the Court of Appeals and the Supreme Court, and proposes that the Secretary of State shall issue to these functionaries a certificate that they are "traveling on official business."

The members of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of this county assembled in St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church, 108 West Forty-first Street, yesterday afternoon and for two hours were drilled in parliamentary tactics by Mrs. Helen L. Bullock, who holds the office of State Superintendent of Parliamentary Usage, and Miss Orpha M. Conklin of Brooklyn.

The report that the gas companies are trying to bring about some compromise as to legislation on the basis of the price of gas is very likely to be true. They could very well afford to do so. The price they get is, of course, of some importance to them; they would much prefer to reduce it gradually, if at all.

CANEA, Feb. 25. -- On Monday last the dispatches of The United Associated Presses told of the bad faith of the Moslems at Hierapetra, who, after their co-religionists in the vicinty of that place had been given a safe conduct to the town on condition that the Christians in the town be allowed to depart unmolested, broke the condition and held as hostages 150 Christians.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- The State Board of Charities in its thirtieth annual report to the Legislature shows that the number of beneficiaries in the various State institutions subject to the supervision of the board are 66,848. The board, in the course of its report, says:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 25. -- United States Judge Sage to-day appointed President Nicholas Monsarrat of the Columbus, Sandusky Hocking Railroad receiver for the Columbus, Hocking Valley Toledo Railway Company, on petition of the Central Trust Company of New York. The petition alleged that there will be due in the next thirty days $290,000 as interest on the company's bonds, for which there is no money in the company's possession to pay.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 25. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad has declared war on the Union Pacific Denver and Gulf Railroad, with the purpose of diverting freight business from the Gulf ports and compelling shippers to use the all-rail route to the Atlantic seaboard. To-day a schedule goes into effect reducing the tariff on all classes of freight sufficient to meet the Gulf differential. For first-class freight this means a reduction of 43 cents per 100 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Gen. Porter, Marshal of the inauguration parade, estimates that here will be 20,000 men in line, exclusive of the league clubs, whose numerical strength is still unsettled. D.D. Woodmans of Cincinnati, President of the National League of Republican Clubs, expects a large representation of his organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- By a vote of 144 to 46 the House, after two hours' debate, passed the bill of Mr. Johnson (Rep., Ind.,) authorizing National banks to take out circulation to the par value of the bonds deposited to secure it, an increase of 10 per cent. over the limit now allowed.

We have never seen any reason to change our opinion that Police Commissioners ROOSEVELT and ANDREWS were animated by an honest desire to improve the character and discipline of the police force of the city and conduct the affairs of the department with a view solely to its highest efficiency and usefulness.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations gave a hearing this afternoon on Senator Cantor's New York City Dollar-Gas bill. Senator Cantor offered several amendments, the most important of which was one designating the Mayor, Controller, and Corporation Counsel as Gas Commissioners.

HAVANA, Feb. 16. -- I witnessed this morning the execution of Jose Gonzales, a youth of twenty, and Rafelius Gomez, aged forty-five, in Canabas. The moon was just sinking behind the great tower of Morro Castle, when the boat containing my companions and myself sailed across the bay from Havana to the grim inclosure where the two men were executed.

Of course the King of Greece could do nothing else than what he is reported to have done; that is to signify that he would obey the injunction of the powers to withdraw his troops from Crete. He was forced to go to the rescue of the Cretans by a public opinion which would have shaken his throne if he had not complied with its demands.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 26. -- The unique poems and letters of the late Emily Dickinson attracted the attention of all literary circles two or three years ago. Out of the editing of these poems and letters has arisen a peculiar lawsuit, in which the editor, Mrs. Mabel Loomis Todd, well known as author and lecturer, and wife of the Amherst College Professor of Astronomy, is the defendant.
BOSTON, Feb. 26. -- At a special meeting of the Massachusetts Reform Club this evening these resolutions were adopted:
BOSTON, Feb. 26. -- In the case of Elizabeth A. Curry versus Laselle Seminary, the lull bench of the Supreme Court to-day overruled the plaintiff's exceptions.

The fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the Calvary Baptist Church, of which the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur is pastor, will be celebrated in the church to-morrow with three special services, in the morning, afternoon, and evening. A preliminary service was held in the chapel last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- The National Association of Merchants and Travelers, to the number of several hundred, met here today for nearly a week's session. The meeting place is the Masonic Temple, and most of the sessions will be secret.
As an old resident of New York and a frequent visitor, I am much interested in a solution of the problem of the deadly Fourteenth Street curve.

Mrs. Annie Maria Brennan, thirty years old, was accidentally shot and killed by Mrs. John Delaney of 74 Greenpoint Avenue, Long Island City, in the latter's home, yesterday. Mrs. Brennan was helping Mrs. Delaney with her washing, and when they had finished Mrs. Delaney had an old trunk forced open. Mrs. Brennan took out a dilapidated hat, and, putting it on, danced about the room.

The Tiffany Studios at 332 Fourth Avenue were thrown open to visitors on Wednesday and Thursday last, between the hours of 10 A.M. and 4:30 P.M., and were thronged with those who have from time to time coveted such an opportunity. Admission was by cards.

Sonn Brothers have purchased from the Atlas Improvement Company the northwest corner of One Hundred and Seventh Street and the Boulevard, 27 by 100, and will shortly improve the property by the erection of apartment houses. They have also purchased the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-third Street, 100 by 45, and will erect on the plot a ore-proof apartment house.
C.L. Tiffany has written the following letter to the committee through which a testimonial was presented to him on his recent birthday:
The main feature of the banquet was the patriotic feeling, which was shown in the language of the speakers. Patriotic songs were sung, and the decorations of the hall were in keeping with the event.

-- Harvard and other educational institutions in Massachusetts are somewhat troubled by a decision just rendered by the Supreme Court, upholding the Assessors of Williamstown in levying taxes on property owned by Williams College and occupied as residences by its professors and instructors. Harvard, too, owns much real estate which is used in a similar way, and it has hitherto been exempt from taxation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- When the resolution demanding that Spain release Julio Sanguilly was laid before the Senate to-day Mr. Frye (Rep., Me.,) said a telegram had been received showing that Sanguilly and his attorney both had acknowledged that the judgment was just: that the punishment was just; that they had withdrawn the appeal; that the Queen Regent had signed the pardon, and that Sanguilly was free.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Several Senators of the United States have learned since yesterday that Julio Sanguilly is not a name to conjure by, Messrs. Morgan, Frye, Mills, and Sherman, who were almost persuaded twenty-four hours ago that Spain must surrender Sanguilly or fight, to-day were mad enough to fight because Sanguilly had surrendered to the Spanish.

A large and fashionable gathering witnessed the tableaus given last night at Madison Square Garden Concert Hall for the benefit of St. Mary's Free Hospital for Children. All the boxes were taken, and the orchestra and gallery were comfortably filled. At 9:30 the first tableau, "Marie Stuart's First View of Rizzio," was shown, and was greeted with a shower of applause.

Staggering about a crazy course at the behest of baffling gales, contributing stick and stay and plank and canvas and human life itself to the rapacious seas, the Norwegian bark Persia has worked out her old life, a victim to the storms that have made memorable to navigators the early days of 1897. Veritably eaten piecemeal by the elements, she was abandoned Feb. 19, with spars dismantled and seams agape, burrowing her own proper grave.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Burglars entered the residence of John D. Rockefeller, on the Bedford Road, a short distance from the Pocantico Hills Station of the Putnam Railroad, this morning, and were discovered at work by the butler, who opened fire upon them. The men escaped, taking nothing from the house except $250 belonging to the butler.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Assemblyman William Cary Sanger of Oneida County has received a letter from Alfred R. Conkling on the subject of campaign contributions by corporations. It was written from Paris, and was inspired, Mr. Conkling said, by the remarks made by Col. Sanger when the resolution for an investigation of trusts was under consideration in the Assembly.

The semi-annual meeting of the New York State Art Teachers' Association began yesterday afternoon in the Art Association Gallery, Brooklyn. The meeting will be concluded to-day with a forenoon session.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Following is the full text of the Alaskan boundary treaty recently signed by Secretary Olney and British Ambassador Pauncefote:

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union in many counties of the State is asking legislators to support the anti-treating measure now pending in the Senate. Petitions on this subject were introduced to-day by Senators Krum, Brush, Burns, Stranahan, Raines, Ellsworth, and others. These petitions, coming from many parts of the State, are alike in their phraseology, and the Senators believe indicate an organized movement.

CANEA, Feb. 26. -- Most of the foreign warships that were lying in the harbor here have left and gone to Suda Bay, where there is a better anchorage. It is likely, however, that their presence here will again be required, as the situation has become more critical than ever before, and it would not be surprising if a conflict should occur.

The Aldermen's Committee on Ferries yesterday considered the application for the establishment of a ferry to operate between the foot of Market Street, this city, and the Wallabout Market, in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day approved several amendments to the civil service regulations governing the city department appointments in New York City. The violation of the provisions of the civil service law and the regulations by any person in the civil service of the city shall be hereafter considered a sufficient cause for dismissal.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 26. -- The National League and Association of Baseball Clubs was in session again to-day. The changes in rules recommended by the Committee on Rules were adopted.

The resisting power of the skin of the rhinoceros against powder and ball has been much exaggerated. The hide on the living animal offers no greater, if as much, resistance as does that of the buffalo; a heavy charge of powder and a hardened projectile are required, not to penetrate the outer cuticle, but to go through the mass of animal matter lying between skin and vital organs.

At the Vever sale of pictures in Paris the purchases made by M. Hamman on account of a well-known house in New York amounted to $54,000. M. Vever is making a new collection. He is the owner of Daubigny for which he has declined a price considerably higher than was paid for "Les Bords de l'Oise," 78,000f. Years ago M. Vever appreciated the merits of Corot.

Conditions in the extreme West and Southwest, according to representatives in the recent Newspaper Publishers' Association who came from those sections, are steadily improving, and the people are confident that prosperous times are near at hand. All who were asked for their views agreed in the belief that the period of depression is almost at an end.

On Thursday Chairman Lexow announced the close of the testimony in the "Trust" investigation, and it was no more evident than at the beginning what the committee expected to accomplish by its inquiry. What it has accomplished is to bring out afresh and in some points more clearly than heretofore the facts regarding certain great combinations of capital.
Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst made public yesterday a letter which he had written to Police Commissioner Andrew D. Parker on Thursday:

When collections of pictures become immense, as are those of the Louvre, how are they to be arranged? That is a problem which hardly troubles us here to-day, and we might leave its solution to the future. But occasionally it will crop up. Shall we work up a collection, historically, chronologically, or according to subjects? The first two methods would be the scientific ones, but unless the canvases were innumerable our gaps would be many.

The debates in the Senate on the Sanguilly case, empty as they seem, ought not to be without uses. A main moral to be drawn from them is the danger that lies in the recklessness with which our naturalization law is administered. This has often been deplored by reason of the perils which it entails upon our domestic politics.

The ostensible reason why an anonymous Frenchman -- one of whose ancestors was a close friend of Lafayette " -- undertook the perils of the sea, and bore the innumerable ennuis of a sojourn in the United States, was apparently to please his sister. Mademoiselle, or Madame, as the case may be, but who prided herself on her good looks, was dying to know whether she "resembled the beautiful Madame R. of New York."

It is now ten years since a boy of twenty-one broke upon a public long used to "deep, premeditated lines" with "sudden and extemporal speech." "Plain Tales from the Hills" was the title of the volume in which the uneven thoughts of youth found crisp expression, and it hailed from India.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 28. -- John Smock, colored, had an interesting forenoon to-day with the Red Bank police. Smock had trouble with a policeman a month ago and ran away. He staid away as long as he could, but his love for home was too strong for him to stay away forever, and finally he decided to come back and take his thirty days in jail.

The following communication has been received by Tomas Estrada Palma of the Cuban Junta in this city from Gen. Juan Rius Rivera, who succeeded Gen. Maceo in command, in Pinar del Rio, on the latter's death. This brings the first news, from Cuban sources, of the campaign in that district since Gen. Maceo's death.

Whether Olive Schreiner's short African story will have any present political importance we do not know. Written somewhat in the style of a parable, "Trooper Peter Halket of Mashonaland" is direct in its charges of cruelty against the Chartered Company, and signals Cecil Rhodes.

Harper's Magazine for March contains an article on Mr. Henry G. Marquand by Mr. E. A. Alexander, who tells how this gentleman has in no small measure helped in advancing art in New York. Mr. Marquand was among the first who conceived the idea of an art museum on a grand scale, worthy of New York, and in 1871 became a Trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGHTON, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Loyal S. Nye was in Chicago yesterday, and is expected home to-night. Nothing is known here about unauthorized drafts. Mr. Nye and his family have lived here about fifteen years, and stand high in the community. About eight years ago he purchased a house on one of the principal streets for $8,500, and placed a mortgage on it for about $6,000.

I read with interest the dispatch from Washington in THE NEW YORK TIMES in regard to the valuable manuscripts stolen from the Congressional Library. I think the press should call attention to the evident want of care that the authorities bestow on such invaluable historic documents. Such theft should be made impossible.

In view of current events in Eastern Europe, a glance may be taken at the present strength and condition of the Greek Army, which has recently been noticed at some length in the German military papers. It will not be out of place to recall the fact that last December the King sent a special message to his Prime Minister dwelling on the necessity of reorganizing the army.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The South African Committee of the House of Commons appointed to inquire into the Jameson raid into the Transvaal resumed its sittings today. A number of peers and members of the House of Commons were present, but for the first time since the inquiry began the Prince of Wales was absent.

Col. Pollok does not place much confidence in what he calls "theoretically good men," (that is, for action,) and makes a difference between ornamental and practical soldiers. He cites such acquaintance as he had with officers who served with him during the second Burmese war, and how useless when in the field were "the pets of the ladies in the drawing and ball rooms."

Richard Watson Gilder had warm words of praise for President Cleveland last night. He spoke at the annual dinner of the Dickinson College Alumni Association, at the Windsor Hotel, on the subject, "Our New Patriotism."

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Late last night the opera managers and Mr. Milward Adams of the Auditorium decided that if dates could be secured in other towns the season here would be cut short at the end of the coming week.

VEEDERSBURG, Ind., Feb. 26. -- During the recent campaign Joseph Taylor, a farmer, attended a meeting, and, stepping up to a lunch stand owned by Mallott McAllister, picked up a sandwich. He did not pay for it, and the proprietors laughingly threatened to have him arrested.

Sergts. Ruddy, Donovan, and Weiser of the Brooklyn detective force, noticing on Thursday night a suspiciously acting stranger, followed him to a saloon on the corner of Ralph Avenue and Broadway, Brooklyn. The man not reappearing, the officers entered, and made the arrest, and boarded a street car with their prisoner, bound for the Police Headquarters.

The Controller of the Currency spoke last evening to the "National Merchants and Travelers' Association" in Chicago. It was an excellent audience for a man of Mr. ECKELS'S clear views and sound practical sense. GAMBETTA was wont to say that the monarchical reaction in France never could have been successfully resisted and overthrown had it not been for the active, incessant, intelligent work of the "commis voyageurs" -- the exact equivalent of our commercial travelers.

After Culloden, the escape of Prince Charles Edward, and the Flora McDonald episode, which Walter Scott has immortalized, what became of the Prince? "Bonnie Prince Charlie," with Lord George Murray, escaped to the Continent. It is Mr. Andrew Lang, in "Pickle the Spy," who explains a portion of Prince Charles Edward's wanderings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The President has approved the following acts:

Two hundred and fifty participants in the pre-election sound-money parade in this city, and a dozen or more guests who were prominent in the last Presidential campaign, assembled at Delmonico's last night to commemorate that event according to a programme planned by the Business Men's Republican and Sound Money Association.

At the annual dinner of the Society of Authors of London, a few weeks ago, Sir John Lubbock presided. Among the guests were Mrs. Craigie, Mrs. Lynn Linton, H. Rider Haggard, Mrs. Steel, Lady Colin Campbell, Holman Hunt, Moncure D. Conway, Sir Walter Besant, Sir Martin Conway, Henry Norman, Dr. Richard Garnett, Anthony Hope Hawkins, Dr. Conan Doyle, Grant Allen, Florence Marryat, Mr. Le Gallienne, and Joseph Pennell.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The annual ball of the Ilderan Outing Club was given last evening under the following patronesses: Mrs. George B. Young, Mrs. James T. Barnes, Mrs. George F. Brown, Mrs. E.A. Campen, Mrs. W.E. Cladek, Mrs. F.W. Dunham, Mrs. Leslie Lupton, Mrs. M. Walter Pratt, Mrs. Charles B. Squires, and Mrs. A.E. Woodruff; Fred W. Dunham Chairman.

The library of a New York gentleman was sold last Tuesday and Wednesday at auction by Bangs Co., 91 and 93 Fifth Avenue. The collection comprised Americana, Shakespeareana, works on art and drama, and in other departments of literature. Some of the books which brought out active competition were these:

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff to-day promised to clear the Senate floor of the lobbyists, the book agents, the "write-up" men, and the hundred and one other hangers-on in the Senate. He announced from his desk that on and after March 8 he would enforce the rule which was adopted last year to keep the Senate floor clear for the use of Senators:

Admirable is a recent lecture that Max Muller delivered before the Manchester College. The topic was "How to Work." With that for a subject the learned lecturer permitted himself to indulge in all kinds of excursions, yet these all served to illustrate his text. Caller upon to give "advice," and the occupation of Max Muller's life being the picking out, sorting, classification, and polishing of words, he explains how that word "advice" came about.

We have already reported the views of two practical statesmen upon the Citizens' Union. As might be expected, they are highly unfavorable. Mr. ABRAHAM GRUBER "thinks unutterable things" about the union, and so does ex-Senator PLUNKITT. Mr. GRUBER, indeed, is not so practical a statesman as he would like to be. He has not got an office by his politics, or even a contract, that we know of.

To get a really good curry nowadays, even in India, is difficult. The native cooks, than whom there are no better in the world in learning to prepare what are called 'Europe' dishes, have, to a great extent, lost the art of preparing their own national ones, but in those days most Madras cooks would give you a different curry at each meal, and continue to vary them daily for a month.

It is reported among the politicians most familiar with the inner workings of the mind of Senator-elect PLATT that the Lexow investigation of "Trusts" is a means of giving notice to certain corporations that their contributions to the advancement of Republican principles have not been satisfactory. This is a report as to which no conclusive evidence is accessible, but it contains an explanation that explains.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Assembly to-day adopted a resolution for adjournment until one week from next Monday night. A concurrent resolution extending until March 9 the time for the Lexow committee to report was adopted also. The following bills were passed:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- William J. Bryan left this morning for New York with Alexander Troup. Both were very indignant at the refusal by Lawyer Brown to withdraw the attachment against the box office receipts of Mr. Bryan's lecture here last night.

In Our days culture has been proposed as a substitute for religion, and poetry offered as a better guide for our lives than the loving word of God. "More and more," says Matthew Arnold, "mankind will discover that we have to turn to poetry to interpret life for us, to console us, to sustain us.

Some of Mr. Henry's Parisians are quite old in fame; M. Daudet, for example, who must be a godsend to newspaper writers; M. Henner, and the consummate Sarah; while others have not yet reached their fourth decade, and are bright planets in the constellation of the "Jeunes," M. Hervien is among the latter, and lends himself readily to picturesque delineation.

" The President," says a contemporary writer, "was literally pursued by a motley concourse of people, riding, running helter-skelter, striving who should first gala admittance into the Executive Mansion, where it was understood that refreshments were to be distributed." An abundance of refreshments had been provided, including many barrels of orange punch.

The late Archbishop of York was a very notable man in many respects, and his life by his lifelong friend is, to say the least, interesting reading. Of all men -- and especially of all Irishmen -- Dr. Magee seemed the last mall that could be thought of for the office of an English Bishopric, his eloquence being his only qualification, and all Irishmen are eloquent.
The will of Samuel Pepys, it is believed, has never been published. It is a document of good length, and G.A. Aitken gives a summary of it in The Athenaeum:

" Art and How to Disseminate a Proper Appreciation of It in Our Communities" was the subject of the talk by William A. Coffin, the landscape artist, before the members of the Public Education Association at their clubrooms, 64 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon.
A dispatch received here last night from Canton, Ohio, says:

William J. Bryan spoke at Carnegie Hall last night on "Money." It was one of a series of lectures he is giving in different cities of the country, but his audience plainly expected a political speech, and it was not disappointed.

About a month ago in these columns was given an account of the severe criticism which has been aroused in England by the publication of W. Carew Hazlitt's "Four Generations of a Literary Family." What mainly led to criticism was the plainness of speech shown in regard to living persons; but there was also a superiority of tone which aroused dislike.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- A resolution for the adjournment of the Assembly over next week came up immediately after the Senate met to-day. Senator Grady authorized the resolution and favored the adjournment of the Senate, which could transact little business if the other house were not in session. He offered an amendment for the adjournment of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- United States Treasurer Morgan sent a modest-looking package to President Cleveland about noon to-day. It was an official envelope, containing a Treasury warrant in his favor for $4,166.67, being Mr. Cleveland's last month's salary as President of the United States. It was taken to the White House by George L. Larson, a messenger in the Treasurer's office, and delivered to Mr. Crook, the disbursing officer at the White House.

The senior class of divinity students of Yale University yesterday saw part of the slums of New York, inspected some of the principal charitable institutions, and made calls on city officials. The class, which numbers thirty-five, came here under Prof. W.F. Blackman, the Professor of Social Science, for the purpose of securing practical ideas on sociological subjects.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- L.H. Goldsmith, aged forty-five, a resident of 14 Neptune Park, New Rochelle, was struck and instantly killed by a train near the New Rochelle station last night. He was a fruit dealer at 25 East Twentieth Street, New York, and it was his habit to walk the track to the station every morning for the early New York train.

The review which follows of the pictures hung in the south gallery and corridor of the Academy of Design, in the thirtieth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society, will conclude the series which have appeared in this supplement during the past four or five weeks. The exhibition itself will close this evening.
A mass meeting of citizens will be held in the Real Estate Exchange, 59 Liberty Street, at 4 o'clock next Monday afternoon, for formulating and expressing a protest against the Finn Stoop-Line bill.

Abraham Spitzer of 105 Goerck Street was held in $1,000 bail for trial at the Centre Street Police Court on the charge of violating the Raines law. The detectives who arrested him said he was a walking Raines law hotel. His custom, it was alleged, was to visit a sweatshop, carrying with him several flasks of whisky, some crackers and cheese, and a few bottles of soda water.

American shares closed slightly higher in the London marker. The principal changes were: Advanced -- St. Paul, 1/4, to 77 3/4; Reading, 1/8, to 12 1/2; Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 50 1/2, and Atchison, 1/8, to 14 3/8; Declined -- New York Central, 1/8, to 95 1/4; Canadian Pacific sold at 56, Erie at 14 5/8, do first preferred at 34 1/2, and Illinois Central at 94 3/4.

A wholesome disposition seems to be developing at Albany, especially in the two Committees on Cities, in favor of giving full hearings on the Greater New York charter. There is no reason why these should be greatly prolonged, if confined to the merits of the charter and not permitted to stray to the irrelevant question of the merits of consolidation.

If sensible Senators are willing to allow he "courtesy of the Senate" to be abused by the blatherskites so as to make the whole body ridiculous, they have only themselves to blame. All the talk yesterday about SANGUILLY'S case was perfectly pointless and inane. The case was ended, and had been ended before the Senate took it up, by the pardon of SANGUILLY.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Quay (Rep., Penn.,) asked unanimous consent to take up and consider a substitute for the Labor Commission bill.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- According to Eli Gage, son of Lyman J. Gage, who has just returned from Alaska, United States troops are needed immediately to preserve order on the Yukon gold fields. Young Gage is connected with the North American Transportation and Trading Company, and as an officer of that organization will ask the new Administration to send troops to Alaska without delay.

There is trouble between the Pike's Peak Tunnel Mining Railway Company and its Treasurer and Director, Loyal S. Nye. Mr. Nye retains his corporate titles, but ironclad orders have been issued which prevent him from dealing with the funds or business of the company. The trouble came of the drawing by Mr. Nye of seven drafts which the company claims were unauthorized.

ANDERSON, Ind., Feb. 26. -- A man claiming to be Dr. Simmons of Matthews, Ind., has caused a sensation among druggists and in liquor and religious circles. Unknown to Andersonians he has been making the rounds of all drug stores in Anderson in company with "pals," and, claiming to be a doctor, has procured drinks, it is claimed, at every drug store but one.

Mr. Nye retains his corporate titles, but ironclad orders have been issued which prevent him from dealing with the funds or business of the company. The trouble came of the drawing by Mr. Nye of seven drafts which the company claims were unauthorized.

ANDERSON, Ind., Feb. 26. -- A man claiming to be Dr. Simmons of Matthews, Ind., has caused a sensation among druggists and in liquor and religious circles. Unknown to Andersonians he has been making the rounds of all drug stores in Anderson in company with "pals," and, claiming to be a doctor, has procured drinks, it is claimed, at every drug store but one.

-- Mrs. Hanna Rose, who lately died at Highland Falls, N.Y., in her one hundred and sixth year, never saw a railroad train until last year. She was then so frightened that it was several days before she recovered. It is said that she was never ill until the time of her death.

-- There is in Natal -- or at least so the natives say -- a kind of snake which, if its domestication were possible, might make less important the question of municipal gas works. For this serpent, according to the stories told about it, is provided with an illuminating apparatus beside which that of other light-bearing creatures, including men with lanterns, is hardly worth consideration.

There is one class of people, never heard from outside, but which takes the most absorbing interest in things pertaining to the stage. The chief performers in the various plays themselves are hardly less anxious and excited on those momentous occasions known as "first nights." This class includes, in the feminine half of the stage world, the maids of the stars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Gen. Russell A. Alger, President McKinley's prospective Secretary of War, who has taken up his quarters at the Arlington, preparatory to moving into the residence occupied by his predecessor, Secretary Lamont, as soon as he shall evacuate it, in an interview published this morning, says:
