ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 27. -- For the first time in fifty years an Indian is under sentence of death in Georgia. He will be hanged in Glynn County next month. Marcellus Lowry, the condemned man, is a Crotan Indian from the celebrated band in North Carolina, many of whom have drifted with the turpentine and timber men into Southern Georgia, where they are called "Melungeons."

Appearances at the Cuban Junta of late seem to indicate that those who enjoy the confidence of the leaders here or are participants in the councils, are in receipt of news of a felicitous character. The impression prevails that it has to do with the grand strike which in a vague way has been hinted at for a month past.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 27. -- One of the most serious boiler explosions and fires in the recent history of the city occurred this morning shortly after 8 o'clock. The boiler house, harness shop, and cloth room of the Acushnet Mills were wrecked. Two men and possibly more were killed outright, a dozen or more operatives were injured, and the whole city was thrown into a state of intense excitement.

I have been for some few years past a subscriber to your valuable journal, and yesterday read with great interest the letter of Mr. Abraham Mills. Being an Englishman who has resided for eighteen years in this country, I have, of course, formed some opinion on the present political condition. It seems to me that the root of the whole trouble lies in high protection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The unclaimed $8,000,000 of the Alabama award, gravely discussed in the British House of Commons last night by Mr. Curson, Parliamentary Secretary for the Foreign Office, and Mr. Thomas Gibson Rowles, Member of Parliament, have no more tangible existence than the unclaimed millions stated to be lying in the Bank of England and Bank of Holland, awaiting American heirs to English and Dutch estates.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 2. -- Grady Reynolds, one of the murderers of M.C. Hunt, to-day confessed the crime.

It was a curious contrast that was presented on Friday evening when Mr. BRYAN was speaking to a small audience at Carnegie Hall and the Sound Money Association was celebrating its victory in the election at Delmonico's. In one respect the two occasions were alike. Both were relatively expensive to the participants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- George Schneider, President of the suspended National Bank of Illinois, which went into the hands of a receiver last December, to-day turned over to the receiver $200,000 to secure any indebtedness of the bank caused through lack of judgment on his part as an official of the institution.

The business accomplished at private sale during the past week showed a decided gain over that of the previous one both in the number of transactions closed and the aggregate investment involved. When it is remembered that the celebration of Washington's Birthday, on Monday, reduced the working hours of the week, the showing made must be considered satisfactory in every sense.

Biblical quotations, bicycles, saddles, short skirts, experiences of married life, Delsarte movements, and horrible men were the subjects discussed simultaneously and in a potpourri of argument at a meeting of the Health Culture Club, at 53 Orange Street, Brooklyn, the residence of Dr. O.F. McCune, last Tuesday.

The controversy over the Finn Street Obstructions bill and the occupancy of stoop lines and sidewalks for business purposes attracted more interest than ever yesterday. Merchants, real estate men, lawyers, landlords, and market men discussed the question with much animation.

Members of joint committee appointed by the Social Reform Club and the Central Labor Union called upon Mayor Strong yesterday morning and urged that the public improvements for which money has been appropriated be pushed as rapidly as possible in order that work may be given to the large numbers of unemployed in this city.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The news agency dispatch from St. Petersburg published in the London and Continental newspapers yesterday purporting to describe Russia's attitude on the Cretan question, and asserting that the Russian Government had ordered Greece to recall her troops from Crete within three days, is now known to be authentic, though its publication has been belated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce this afternoon ordered a favorable report on Senator Proctor's amendment to the Deficiency bill, dividing the State of Vermont, after Oct. 1 next, into two customs collection districts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 27. -- The largest seizure of opium ever made at the Port of San Francisco was accomplished this afternoon by four special agents of the Treasury. The opium is valued at $400,000, and was seized because of a violation of the custody rules, which provide that no Chinese shall import the drug.

An interesting concert was given at the New York College of Music yesterday afternoon, chiefly for the purpose of producing a fantasia for piano and orchestra written by Clarence Barker, who died last Spring. Mr. Barker was a grandson of Commodore Vanderbilt, and although a young man of independent fortune, he undertook the study of music seriously, went abroad, and was a pupil of Raff.

The changes of the seasons and the recurrence of seedtime and of harvest must from the earliest times have been associated with certain changes in the position of the sun. In the Summer at midday the sun rises high in the heavens; in the Winter the sun is always low. The sun, therefore, had an annual movement up and down in the heavens, combined with the diurnal movement of rising and setting.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- Like the season of 1896, the season of 1897 in Boston waters promises sport in the classes of under thirty feet water line. No boats of a greater length than twenty-nine feet water line are being built with racing in view, but in that length and below many new ones will be found, enough in fact to assure racing of the liveliest kind.

The season of Spring brides is at hand, and to many the beginning of housekeeping duties for the first time. It is not so difficult to furnish a house, particularly the upper part of it, but the lower region presents many problems even to the young housekeeper with a modicum of experience in the culinary department.

C.E. Pellew of Columbia University gave the last of his series of lectures on "Alcohol and Alcoholic Beverages" in the Museum of Natural History last night. He discussed the "General and Special Properties of Alcohol" before a large audience, which followed him closely. He first talked about the theory that alcohol is a food, and admitted that it is such when taken in quantities below a certain limit, beyond which it becomes a poison.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- In the Senate to-day, while the Post Office Appropriation bill was under discussion, Mr. Dubois (Rep., Idaho,) said:

The Court of Appeals of this State has made a decision in a breach of promise case which seems to extend considerably the legal limitations of flirtation. Formerly, the opinion of the Court says, the rule was that an engagement could be inferred from circumstances. Under this rule mere "keeping company," if continued long enough and assiduously enough, might imply a betrothal and afford a basis for a suit for breach of promise.

IT is seldom that an occasion is given to the possessors of rare and valuable laces to display them in all their beauty. When seen at the opera or dinner, or even at a later social function, there is never opportunity to use more than a single flounce or a trimming upon the corsage of a gown.

A SAMPLE of the dialogue and "business" in the new Sardou play, "Spiritisme," will serve better to indicate its quality than any attempt at mere description. Therefore I will try to reproduce, from my memory, a noteworthy scene in the first act, premising only that my memory is apt to be a bit treacherous.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27. -- It is certain that the election of Feb. 20 in the constituency of St. Boniface, in Manitoba, to which such, great interest attached as showing the sentiment among the French Canadians of Manitoba over the school settlement, will be protested on the ground that undue clerical influence was exerted to secure the vote of the electorate in favor of the Conservative candidate.

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court has issued an order staying all proceedings in the Murray Hall Bank receivership matter, and requiring the Attorney General of this State to show cause next Tuesday why the recent appointment, by Judge Dickey at Newburg, of Edward H. Hobbs and Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., as receivers, should not be set aside.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Washington Post this morning says:

WHEN Frank Thomson left the Pennsylvania Railroad shops in Altoona, at the age of twenty years, after four years of rigid discipline and thorough mechanical training, he was qualified not only to build a locomotive, but also to operate it as an expert engineer.

When Col. H.G. Otis, editor of The Los Angeles (Cal.) Times, was here a few days ago as a delegate to the Newspaper Publishers' Association, he gave to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter the history of Judge McKenna's appointment as Attorney General in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet. The story fully explains why Col. John J. McCook of this city was not offered a portfolio that he felt that he could accept.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- An interesting report on the operations of the co-operative savings and loan associations for the year 1896 was made public to-day by Supt. Frederick D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department. There are 368 savings and loan associations and 23 building lot associations operating in this State. Of the latter, 21 are in Monroe County.

Cyrus Clark, President of the West End Association, sent a letter to Mayor Strong yesterday, relative to the controversy over the establishment of a garbage dump at the foot of West Ninety-sixth Street. Mr. Clark expresses his willingness to pass over in silence the Mayor's alleged characterization of the West End Association members as "stiff necked, self-willed, and obstinate," and quotes a fellow-member and taxpayer as follows:

THE unpublished works of Gibbon, which John Murray has just issued in London and the Scribners have imported for American readers, constitute what may properly be called the most important literary event of the Winter, and perhaps the whole year will not yield a rival.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured yesterday morning at the American Museum of Natural History, on "Northern Palestine and Damascus." It was next to the last lecture of the present series the Professor is giving under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction. The last lecture will be on "Switzerland."
CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Members of the Chicago Athletic Association won all but one event this evening in their several contests with the Knickerbocker and New York Athletic Club teams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- At the British Embassy at noon to-day the Spanish draft of the Anglo-Venezuelan treaty was signed by Sir Julian Pauncefote and Senor Andrade, and that document is finally ready for submission to the Venezuelan Congress, conforming to the Constitutional provision of being in the language of that country.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 27. -- The baseball chiefs did not get down to work until after 1 o'clock this afternoon, nearly three hours behind schedule time.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 27. -- The Circuit Court Grand Jury returned indictments at noon to-day against J.M. McKnight, President of the German National Bank Sterling B. Edmunds, politician, and Aldermen R.E. King, C.J. Jenne, John E. Leatherman, R.C. Breur, N.J. Frick, and F.A. Britt, members of the "combine" known as the "Big Seven." The other member, Alderman J.W. Reeder, escaped by turning State's evidence.

Mr. CECIL RHODES, by his conscious and unconscious disclosures on the witness stand, has given the British public a clearer notion than it could have had beforehand of the state of things in South Africa. He has insisted that the condition of the Uitlanders in the Transvaal, of whom a majority are British subjects, is intolerable.
A man who was apparently a Swede or Norwegian threw, himself before a loaded truck in front of 193 canal Street about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

She was a careful mother. The family of children had been well brought up, but they were rather fastidious in some things, and hard times had made it difficult to please everybody. However, the good soul always insisted upon the plate of porridge and milk every morning for breakfast as a good commencement for the day.

The University of Pennsylvania hockey team played the Columbia men Friday night at the St. Nicholas Rink. There was a good-sized crowd present, and college cries and cheers went up from all sides of the rink, especially when some player got a hard fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Vice President Stevenson, whose term of office expires next Thursday, was this evening presented with a magnificent silver service at his apartments in the Normandie. The parchment testimonial accompanying the service, and signed by every Senator, was as follows:

PANAMA, Feb. 19. -- The new Panama Canal Company has expended a good deal of money, time, and labor in collecting accurate information in regard to the physical condition and difficulties to be overcome in carrying out its scheme.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 2. -- Yale's recent union with Harvard in all branches of athletics will make no difference in the relations between Yale and Princeton. It was stated at Yale to-day on high authority that official assurance to this effect had been sent to Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- In the Senate to-day a long sworn statement was read by the Clerk from officers of the Knights of Labor in regard to the dismissal of some employes by the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company of Washington, and in support of a concurrent resolution introduced by Mr. Hill (Dem., N.Y.,) for the withdrawal from the President of an act authorizing an extension of the company's road.

One of the best results to be looked for from such movements as that of the Citizens' Union, which proposes to organize for the non-partisan control of municipal affairs, is the cultivation of the civic spirit and the awakening of a vital interest in the concerns of the City of New York.

LOVERS of flowers and persons interested in horticulture would be well recompensed by a visit to Miss Helen Gould's conservatories at her country seat, at Irvington-on-Hudson. The fame of the greenhouses and graperies, the flower beds and propagating plots, which during the past thirty-five years have been undergoing constant improvements, and are provided with all the appliances known to modern gardening, has spread far beyond the limits of this country.

PARIS, Feb. 17. -- As I write these lines the streets are resounding with cries of war declared between Greece and Turkey, of a great international crisis imminent, of murder, bloodshed, and destruction. Fortunately we are sufficiently blase, here in Paris, to take all these thrilling announcements with the necessary pinch of salt -- Attic salt, if you like.
Prof. Stewartson Brown of the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia recently lectured in that institution on "The Color of Flowers -- the Relation of Insects to Plants," in which he said:

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 27. -- As a preliminary to the appointment of a permanent Papal Ablegate to Canada, it is announced that the Pope has named a commission of Cardinals to thoroughly investigate the charges against the Canadian clergy in connection with their participation in the recent general election campaign and subsequent bye-election, contests.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 27. -- A matter of National interest will occupy the attention of the Louisiana Republican State Committee as soon as its leading members return from Washington next week. This will be the preparation of a bill to reduce the Congressional representation of this State to about half its present number, because half of the voters of the State have been disfranchised by the election law passed last Spring.
Three lively bouts were fought at the Broadway Athletic Club last night, the gate receipts being for the benefit of the poor.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27. -- A peculiar accident happened to the Yale crew this afternoon during the regular practice. The boat was being manned up the Quinnipeac, and in attempting to make way past rocks near the new bridge, ran aground on a hidden reef.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The police of this city are investigating the death of an unknown man whose body was found close to the tracks of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, about 300 feet over the Passaic city line. The body is that of a man of medium height and of middle age.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 27. -- From information received in this city it is evident that a bloody war of extermination is brewing between Mexicans of El Plomo mining camp, in Sonora, Mexico, and the Papago Indians.

Empire State cyclists regret very much that the Higbie Good Roads bill, which has been so elaborately advertised, will not pass the present Legislature. While favoring the bill, the Governor has had to interpose an objection on the ground of economy. The Governor's solicitude on this point is understood to mean that the bill will be held over until next session, a promise of some sort having been made about "next year."

M. Decroix, the delightful President of the Society for the Prevention of the Abuse of Tobacco, must have jumped for joy at reading in the papers that the young Czarine is so opposed to the use of cigarettes that she is trying to take some action in her own immediate circle against the habit of smoking, which has become quite prevalent among women in the best society in Russia.

The annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association, which was held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon, was in decided contrast to the meeting of last year, when the strife was so intense.

The Covell Trophy and the team of five match engaged the Seventh Regiment riflemen last night. The Covell Trophy match is open to teams of six from each company, three of whom shall not be armory sharpshooters. Five shots were standing and five prone. Company B, which has a fashion of winning the Covell Trophy, did so last night.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 27. -- The first fatality incident to the high water occurred at 4:15 o'clock this afternoon. Three of the floors of the five-story stone-front warehouse on Front Street, near Vine, owned by Hinkle, Wilson Kreis, wholesale grocers, caved in at that hour. The building is surrounded by several feet of water.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- In the House to-day the rules were suspended, and a bill was passed to amend the act permitting the use of the right of way over public lands for tram roads, canals, and reservoirs, granting the same right to private persons and corporations furnishing water for domestic purposes only.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Gen. Russell A. Alger called at the White House this afternoon and paid his respects to the President. He was accompanied by Mr. Don M. Dickinson, who also presented him to Secretaries Olney and Herbert.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- The contest for office at the charter election of this village, which will take place next Tuesday, particulars of which were detailed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday last, is becoming more bitter every day as the time approaches.

GLASGOW, Feb. 13. -- The Duke of Abbruzzi, an Italian nobleman, has commissioned G.L. Watson to design a first-class racing yacht, which is to be built by Messrs, D. W. Henderson of the Anchor Line, at Glasgow. The confirmation of the previous rumor gives the load water line at eighty feet, the shortest limit for a first-class yacht.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 27. -- The first bank failure in St. Louis for ten years occurred to-day, when the Mullanphy Savings Bank closed its doors. In the panic of 1893 the bank had some trouble pulling through, and it seems it has never fully recovered from the effects.

BANGOR, Me., Feb. 27. -- A petition asking that logs cut on the American side, manufactured in the Canadian Provinces and reshipped to the American market, shall be exempted from the proposed duty on lumber in the new tariff bill, has received many signatures in Northern and Eastern Maine, this week.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Gov. Black's suggestion in his first message that too many "expensive and unnecessary" laws are passed each session of the Legislature fell from the ears of the legislators like water from a duck's back. No session in the history of the State has kept the pace of the present one in the number of bills introduced.
" The History of the Alleghanies" was the theme of a recent lecture by Prof. W.B. Scott of Princeton University before the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. Prof. Scott said, in substance:

Mulberry Street in the vicinity of Police Headquarters was full of rumors yesterday of the probability of Chief Conlin retiring from the force and of a general tangle which would result if he tried to retire.

William Jennings Bryan was busy yesterday. In the early morning he took a drive over the city, and then went to the office of the Bennett Tea and Coffee Company with his friend, Philo S. Bennett of Connecticut, and attended to his correspondence. After this he returned to the Bartholdi Hotel, held a reception for an hour, lunched for two hours, and then prepared for his speech at night.
The Rev. Walter Hughson, curate of Calvary Episcopal Church, has accepted a call to the vicarate of Trinity Episcopal Church in Detroit, Mich.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- "It is our intention," said Impresario Maurice Grau to-day, "to have a supplementary season of opera in New York after our Western engagements. The exact time is not yet fixed. Nor have all the details been arranged, but that there will be a supplemental season is practically assured."

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- A notice has been served upon Attorney General Hancock, through his New York office, that on March 2 a motion will be made in the Supreme Court in Kings County for the appointment of a new receiver for the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company of Brooklyn. The application for a new receiver will be made on behalf of Andrew J. Nutting, who has an unsatisfied judgment of $14,000 against the road.
THE twelfth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York, now being held at the American Fine Arts Society Building in this city, is composed of more than 1,100 contributions.

District Attorney Olcott and Coroner Tuttle are working together in the preparation of a bill which will provide for the establishment of a department of toxicology and chemistry in connection with the District Attorney's office. Mr. Olcott hopes to have the draft of the bill completed in a few days and to have it adopted by the present Legislature.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 2. -- This afternoon's gymnasium meet, under the direction of the Williams Athletic Association, was very successful. C.N. Prouty, 1900, of Spencer, Mass., cleared 5 feet 9 1-6 inches in the running high jump. Williams's record to date was 5 feet 7 inches, and the new intercollegiate record is 5 feet 9 inches.

There is going to be a national Yacht Racing League in spite of the action of the New York Yacht Club in refusing to take the initiative in the formation of one. It will be simply the coming together of the Yacht Racing Union of Long Island Sound, the Massachusetts Association, and the Great Lakes Association, and each of these organizations extending their influence to other clubs in their vicinity.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Loyal S. Nye, Treasurer and Director of the Pike's Peak Tunnel Mining Railway Company, arrived from Colorado this evening. Mr. Nye read a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES containing the charges made against him by George H. Proctor. This was the first intimation Mr. Nye had of any serious trouble between him and the President of the company. After reading the story, Mr. Nye said:

The dramatization of Thomas Hardy's "Tess of the d'Urbervilles," which Minnie Maddern Fiske will produce Tuesday night at the Fifth Avenue Theatre was made by Lorimer Stoddard. The story is circulating that Mr. Hardy wrote a play on the subject of "Tess" himself, which was not found actable, and that he willingly withdrew it in favor of Mr. Stoddard's version of the novel.

SAID a lady sitting in her box at the last performance of "Faust" to a gentleman somewhat disposed to a foolish seriousness about matters artistic: "Do you think that New York is a musical city?" And the gentleman, gazing out over the sea of faces with an infinite weariness in his amused smile, said, with an intonation of contempt:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Washington's Birthday was the most crowded holiday ever known at this resort. There simply was not accommodation for the people who came, and rooms anywhere, at any price, were in demand Saturday night. The balls to celebrate the event were brilliant affairs Monday night, ushering in a season of gayety before Lent.

A young woman, who gave the name of Jennie Kelly of 7 Carmine Street, appeared yesterday morning in Jefferson Market Police Court as complainant against a young rough, John Donlevy of 324 West Twenty-fourth Street, whom she charged with having brutally beaten her because she had thwarted him in his designs upon a young girl.
President Seth Low of Columbia University talked before the City Club last night on the new charter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The desire to dispose of the appropriation bills and leave none to fail because they had been unacted upon at the adjournment of Congress, caused the Senate to sit to-night.

GREENPORT, L.I., Feb. 27. -- George Plaskett, the nine-year-old son of George Plaskett, a shipbuilder of this place, was badly bitten on the hand and leg last night by a dog owned by G.M. Baker. Dr. Ireland was summoned, and he cauterized the wound.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- The Globe says: "One of the largest corners on wool ever attempted in the United States at present exists in the City of Boston in anticipation of the restoration of a tariff on wool in the near future by the McKinley Administration. The steamer Columbian, which arrived in port yesterday, brought 8,000 bales of wool, making a total of 126,160 bales which has arrived in port during the present month.

About 100 members of the Fifth Street School Association were present at the fifteenth annual dinner, given at the Arena restaurant last night. The association includes many prominent lawyers and business men, who as boys attended the Grammar School in East Fifth Street.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 27. -- Paul L. Le Fevre made a heroic and successful effort to save the life of his father this morning, but lost his own. Eugene Le Fevre Son were house raisers, movers, and carpenters. When the accident occurred they were engaged in moving an old building sheathed with iron, but their progress was obstructed by wires.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The proposals for the settlement of the Cretan troubles are widely commented upon by the newspapers throughout the country. The Conservative organs, as a rule, find in them a full solution of the difficulty, but there is a divergence of opinion on the part of the Liberal organs.

A brilliant assembly met at the large banquet hall of the Hotel Savoy last night to take part in the banquet given by the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni Association, composed of honors graduates of the foremost universities of this country. For the first time in the history of the association ladies were present, and a few invited non-members filled the small gallery overlooking the hall.

Mr. CHARLES STEWART SMITH is quoted as saying of the "Trust" investigation that he fears it has "done more harm than good." He thinks there is in the public mind "a hostility to corporations, and certain politicians regard it as good politics to exploit this sentiment in order to catch votes."

That excellent charity, the Children's Aid Society of this city, in addition to its diversified labors on behalf of children who have inherited ignorance and poverty as their portion in life, is now engaged in perfecting plans for the special benefit of truants. How to overcome their dislike for tasks assigned them in school and the fascinations of the streets has long been a puzzling question.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Daughters of the American Revolution began their last day's work with but a slim attendance. The selection of State Regents was announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The President has granted a pardon to John R. Patterson, convicted in Texas of making fradulent use of the mails and sentenced Jan. 18, 1896, to eighteen months at hard labor in the Fort Leavenworth Prison. Patterson's sentence would have expired in April, and the pardon is granted to give him a chance to redeem himself.

BAYONNE,, N.J., Feb. 28. -- A fire at 5 o'clock this morning in the works of the Bergen Point Sulphur Works, at Constable Hook, was handled by the employes of the adjacent manufactories, mainly by those of the Standard Oil Company. The melting room and warehouse were entirely destroyed, but the main works were saved.

The semi-centennial anniversary of Calvary Baptist Church was celebrated yesterday with three special services, morning, afternoon, and evening. The church was crowded at each service, and special musical numbers were sung by the choir.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 28. -- The proposed high duty on Canadian lumber in the new United States tariff is causing a great deal of solicitude here. The lumber industry is by long odds the most extensive and flourishing of Canada's resources, and a larger number of persons will be affected by hostile legislation toward it than would be in any other direction.

A six-story tenement house at 204 East Sixty-fifth Street was the scene of a fire shortly after noon yesterday which, but for the prompt action of the firemen, would have ended with a loss of life. The work of the firemen in general was excellent, but that of the members of Hook and Ladder Company No. 16 was especially good.

Few men have studied the problem of municipal government more thoroughly or discussed it more intelligently than Mr. ALBERT SHAW, whose opinions regarding the Greater New York charter we present elsewhere this morning. He has dealt with it especially in the light of actual experience in European cities, whose forms and methods of administration he has studied and written about so extensively.

It is by no means certain that the effort to hasten the work of public improvement in this city for the purpose of giving employment to workmen is altogether wise. Where this work has been decided upon or is required in the interest of the public it should never be unnecessarily delayed, nor should it be hastened at the risk of sacrificing any safeguard of economy or of a proper execution of the work.

DULLUTH, Minn., Feb. 28. -- In June, 1895, a verdict for $940,000 was rendered against John D. Rockefeller of New York in the United States Circuit Court here in favor of Alfred Merritt. Mr. Merritt was one of the numerous Merritt brothers of this city who had explored and brought to public attention the valuable Mesaba Iron Range.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The open session of the United States Senate this afternoon drew crowds to the north wing of the Capitol an hour before 3 o'clock, the time to which the Senate, at 2:30 o'clock in the morning, had taken a recess.

District Attorney OLCOTT is said to be intending to ask for authority to establish a bureau of experts in his office to furnish evidence for the prosecution in cases where chemical analyses are necessary, especially cases of poisoning, as a means of lessening the cost of expert testimony.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 28. -- The suggestions contained in the report of the Investigating Committee that the strike of the Leadville miners be submitted to arbitration will not be heeded by the mine managers. Several of them are emphatic in their declaration that they will pay no attention to the suggestions.

In your issue of the 22d inst. there appeared a letter under the heading "Jonah in the Oxford Bible," signed by "A.E.G.," written in defense of Dr. Lyman Abbott, and censuring those who differ with the latter, which contains a serious misstatement, and one so well calculated to mislead that I request space in your columns to correct it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The inaugural crowds have not begun to arrive yet, owing, it is explained, to the limited time allowed by the railroad companies on excursion tickets, and except for the suggestiveness of a holiday appearance given the town by the decorations on public buildings, business houses, hotels, and residences, and the reviewing stands, there is little to indicate that the Nation's great quadrennial event is at hand.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Whatever may be thought and said outside of Germany as to the Kaiser's line of action on the Greece-Cretan imbroglio, the dominant, if not the unanimous opinion in Germany is that it has been consistent with his whole Eastern policy and inspired by a desire to maintain the European peace.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- It is customary to regard music as having harmonizing influences. The people of this city, however, have been treated to a free entertainment during the last few weeks in which the direct effects of music have been a veritable groundswell of discord.

Mme. Nordica's plans are still unsettled. She spent yesterday in her apartments at the Waldorf with her sister, Mrs. Baldwin of Boston, and denied herself to all callers. She still contemplates leaving for France Wednesday, however, and taking a long rest before the Covent Garden season begins.

The almost unanimous vote of the House for the Monetary Conference bill will probably be taken to have more significance, especially in Europe, than it really has. There is, as a matter of cold fact, absolutely nothing essentially new in the bill. It authorizes the President to do nothing of any importance that he could not have done under the law already in force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The confidential correspondence of Secretary Olney with Senator Sherman, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, and Minister de Lome, which preceded the Pardon of Julio Sanguily, is made public. The first letter, apprising Senator Sherman of the negotiations in progress was as follows:

The women teachers in the public school of Greater New York are taking steps to secure an advance in and regulation of salaries under the charter for the greater city, and a joint committee of the Woman Teachers' Association will be charged with bringing the matter before the State Legislature.

The so-called "anti-scalpers" bill was passed by the House of Representatives on Saturday by a very much heavier vote than had been expected. The question has been very carefully investigated, not only by the House and Senate committees, but by the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

Women say "thank you" more frequently now than formerly when a man in a crowded street car gives them a seat, but sometimes they don't. One didn't the other day when she boarded a Broadway car at Fourteenth Street. She was handsomely dressed and had the manner of one of assured position in the social world.

The bill now pending in the Legislature providing a uniform charter for second-class cities appears to be an excellent measure, for which reason we fear there is little prospect of its enactment without change. The vicious bi-partisan business injected into the draft prepared by the commission of 1895, and submitted to the Legislature last year, has been eliminated.
CANEA, Feb. 28. -- A new danger threatens this island. Every day the situation is becoming more desperate. The state of war prevents any attention being paid to the crops.
The citizens who have organized lo defeat the Finn Stoop Line bill say they will not stop with a formal protest. The measure, if it becomes a law, will be attacked in the courts.

CANEA, Feb. 28. -- The presence of foreign warships off this port has not had the effect of preventing fighting between the insurgents and Turks, save in the town itself, where a comparatively small force of sailors and marines was recently landed for the purpose of preserving order. A skirmish occurred to-day at Malaxa, a short distance from Canea, in which the Turks were worsted, although they outnumbered the Christians.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 28. -- Over 1,500 boomers are gathered along Columbia River, near Hunter and Fruitland, Spokane County, equipped for a grand rush into the southern half of the Colville Indian reservation, which Congress is expected to order thrown open in March. They are supplied with fleet horses.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 28. -- Major McKinley's last Sunday at Canton before setting out for Washington to be inaugurated President of the United States was marked by no unusual happenings. He went to the Methodist Church, of which he has been a member since he was seventeen years old. The church has a seating capacity exceeding 1,000, and it was crowded.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 28. -- The village of Red Hook is stirred up by a bitter quarrel between the Rev. J.R. Lambert and D. C. Lehman, Principal of the Union Free School.

The prospect of securing a fair proportion of the trade of South and Central America is interesting New York business men. The wholesale business with that part of world is practically monopolized by the leading European countries, though it naturally belongs to the United States.

Sandy Hook, the first land that greets the eye of the voyager to New York from the old countries, is again an island by reason of the formation of a new inlet. When Sir Henry Hudson discovered it and anchored his good ship Half Moon in the lee of its sheltering cedars, on Sept. 4, 1609, he described it as a cape, connected with the Highlands of Navesink by a narrow isthmus, or bar.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, discussed in his sermon yesterday. "Christ and the Old Testament."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The report of the Venezuelan Commission, which was presented to the President yesterday, opens with a reference to its organization by the election of David J. Brewer as President and Severe Mallet Prevost as Secretary, and mentions that at the outset the commission was confronted with the fact that its work was both novel and difficult. Respecting this, it says:

Within the next fortnight the rich and curious library of the American Bible Society will have been transferred from its old home in the Bible House to the shelves of the Lenox Library, where, unless something now unforseen happens, it will take its permanent place as no mean portion of one of the most notable Biblical libraries in the world.

Wherever men with Wall Street interests were met yesterday there was keen interest displayed in the disclosure by THE NEW YORK TIMES of the conditions shown by the annual report of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company -- hitherto suppressed -- making it plain how the Jersey Central has been able to show fully earned dividends while other anthracite roads have been obliged to present different exhibits.

A double runaway on the south drive of Brooklyn Bridge, about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, created considerable excitement, smashed two coaches, hurt slightly two drivers, and caused a policeman of the bridge force injuries of a serious nature.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The rate of discount during the past week for three months' bills was 2 per cent., and for thirty-day bills 2 3/4 per cent. Gold continues to arrive from Australia and South Africa. A portion of the consignments from the latter place has been bought for Japan. Silver was weak, and there was only a small inquiry.

Charges of blackmail were made yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court against Detective John J. Gerrity of the Charles Street Station by Thomas Jones, a prisoner charged with conducting a gaming house at 60 Downing Street.

The Central Labor Union talked a good deal about union whisky yesterday, and hereafter when any delegate is invited to take a drink he will not do so unless the new label, a cross, has been stamped on the bottle, guaranteeing that the whisky is union made.

We gave yesterday morning a brief statement of some of the facts as to the distribution of the money received from Great Britain under the award of the Geneva tribunal in satisfaction of what were known as the Alabama claims. It is not a chapter of our history of which we have reason to be proud.

Lawyer H.K. Sheldon, Jr., of 220 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn and his wife, had a narrow and almost miraculous escape from serious injury yesterday by the running away of a team of horses, attached to a coupe in which they were driving to this city.

-- The conductor of a train running between Washington and Philadelphia is quoted as telling a story which illustrates the pitiful possibilities of human ignorance that still exist, despite the schools that are scattered so thickly over all parts of the country, and the migratory habits of a majority of its inhabitants.

I have often wished it were possible to persuade our countrywomen to abandon the practice of wearing birds and feathers in their hats, but felt powerless to do anything in that direction. Now, however, the Rev. O.P. Gifford has come to the rescue and has said all one could desire on that subject. If, after reading his appeal, women continue the fashion, the responsibility rests with them of encouraging a cruel and wicked traffic.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 28. -- But little over a month from now an election will be held in Tennessee to decide whether there shall be a Constitutional Convention. The date set by the Legislature at its extra session last August was April 5, and the interest taken by the people has been growing of late.

Evangelist Moody's meetings came to an end in this city yesterday, with the afternoon and evening services in Carnegie Hall. Long before the doors were thrown open, crowds gathered, and at the afternoon meeting the house was filled to overflowing. Even the boxes were crowded.

For a long time it has been known that the wheels within wheels which controlled the operations at Police Headquarters were not working properly; that they were out of gear and threatening to stop altogether and block all but the most ordinary routine business of the department. A little light has been let in on the confusion by a statement made by a man intimate for many years with the police and police methods.

In your notice of my communication relating to the consolidation of libraries, you start out by saying my charge is a "grave one." That is what I intended it to be. You assert inferentially that because the name of Lenox is to be bracketed with Public Library, Astor and Tilden, that as a distinctive signification standing for something apart and individual, it has not lost its identity.

It is a safe prediction that no material change will be made in the "Raines law" at this session of the Legislature so far as it affects the question of Sunday liquor selling. The club loophole was apparently not foreseen, but the "hotel" loophole was purposely provided, and, though it may have proved larger and more elastic than was intended, there will be no serious attempt to close it up.

The German question in England bears a decided resemblance to the Chinese question in California. The British clerk and the British manufacturer find that they are ruined by cheap German labor, and they don't seem to like it. Lord Rosebery's recent speech has almost raised the German question to the dignity of a great national problem, and the difficulty of solving it satisfactorily to the British mind will increase year by year.
MARSHALL, Mo., Feb. 28. -- A through freight on the Alton Road was wrecked near here last night.

By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreelogur0 sale, William A. Duer, referee, 815 Delancey Etreet, south side, 50 feet west of Goerck Street, -5 by 75, four-story brick tenement, with stores. Due on judgment. $15,904.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 1. -- The whole country was ablaze from Canton to Pittsburg, and there were hundreds of people at every station to see the train bearing the President-elect go by.

The fiftieth annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, for 1896, issued to-day over the signature of President Frank Thomson, shows for the three grand divisions east of Pittsburg and Erie gross earnings of $62,096,502.66. and expenses $43,549,326.91, or, net earnings $18,637,175.75. This is swelled to a gross income of $24,056,056.59 by interest and rentals.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The President was busy at his desk this morning long before many of the leading Government officials had their breakfasts. Before noon he had spent four hours studying the huge amount of legislation which has been pouring in upon him for several days.
ATHENS, March 1. -- After a recess that called forth the protest of the opposition the Boule, the single Parliamentary Chamber of Greece, met to-day.
" He was a splendid racer once, but is all broken down now," 'was the remark of a gentleman who saw a well-known horse hobble by. The horse has been overtaxed and "broke down."

The Aylesmere, a seven-story fashionable apartment house on the southeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, caught fire about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and the twenty families in the building were forced to flee for their lives. No one was injured, but two women were overcome by smoke and carried out by policemen.

CANEA, March 1. -- Reports have been received to-day of skirmishes in many parts of the island. A number of houses have been burned, in some cases the fires having been started by Christians, and in others by Moslems.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 1. -- The Vesuvius overhauled the Dauntless to-day as the filibustering tug was about to leave the harbor. The Dauntless was ordered back to her dock, and the order was backed by a show of force. The Dauntless obeyed, but her Captain made quite a show of resistance.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The House took a recess this evening with the bill to discourage prizefighting still under discussion. The bill would prohibit the extensive publication by newspapers and periodicals of the details of the doings of prizefighters and accounts of prizefights.
Just arrived from the old country, and joyous at being reunited with a sister who had preceded her to the New World, an immigrant girl died on Ellis Island last evening in the sister's embrace.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Senate to-day, in the space of about one hour and a half, passed the District of Columbia Appropriation bill, carrying items to the amount of $7,444,677, being an excess of $1,655,000 over the bill as it passed the House. Half of the amount is to be paid out of the Treasury of the United States and half out of the revenues of the District of Columbia.
CANTON, Ohio, March 1. -- President-elect McKinley and party left Canton for Washington at 7 o'clock this evening. Fireworks, cheers, and a little speechmaking marked their departure.

PATERSON, N.J., March 1. -- A stranger who chanced to trudge through the snow in this city to-day and who knew that here lives the Vice President-elect of the United States, who will go to Washington to-morrow to take the oath of office, might be pardoned for thinking the people strangely unconcerned about the matter. Yet he would be greatly mistaken.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, March 1. -The committee appointed by the Legislature to investigate the charges of bribery against Senator Heitfeldt, Representative Perkins, and C.C. Fuller, sits behind closed doors, and although it has examined quite a number of witnesses, it is difficult to ascertain what has been discovered.

The Executive Committee of the North Side Board of Trade held a meeting last evening at 278 Alexander Avenue. James L. Wells presided. It was reported that a letter had been received from Senator Charles L. Guy, in which he stated that it was his intention to present an amendment to the Third Avenue Bridge bill whereby the appropriation will be increased from $1,800,000 to $2,000,000.

William Henry Holloway, ragged and homesick, turned up at his home late Sunday night, to learn that the Coroners' office had him recorded as dead, that a body supposed to be his had been buried in Evergreen Cemetery, and that his wife had collected the insurance on his life.

Mr. A. Muller-Ury has placed on exhibition at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, some fifteen examples of his brush, for the most part portraits of well-known people, including Chauncey M. Depew, Theodore Havemeyer, Judge Daly, Mrs. Jefferson Davis, Mrs. J. Lee Tailer, Miss Emily Hoffman, Dr. Clement Cleveland, and Mme. Calve and M. Plancon of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

When the sessions of Columbia University are opened on the first Monday of October next the students will assemble in the new halls on Morningside Heights. This decision was first officially announced at the meeting of the Trustees yesterday. They made an appropriation for the expenses of the removal and laid out their plans to accomplish the task.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 1. -- The sparring exhibition advertised for to-night at the Winnikee Rink under the management of the Poughkeepsie Athletic Club, against which there has been a great outcry by the clergy, and press, was interrupted by Chief Platto and six officers shortly after John Fox and Robert Gormully, two boxers, entered the ring, about 9:30 o'clock this evening.
BERNE, March 1. -- The left wing of the great monastery of St. Bernard has been demolished by an avalanche.

The unique spectacle of husband and wife running rival street stands close together and engaged in bi//ter business competition may be sen any day at tho corner of Market and Henry Streets. Jacob Isaacson and his wife have parted, company, and, though the divorce suit that was entered has been withdrawn, there does not seem to be a prospect of any reconciliation.

A season that has been remarkable for the brilliancy and variety of its gatherings was brought to a close last night, when the Society of Patriarchs assembled its members to the number of over four hundred at the Waldorf for the second and final ball of the Winter. It ended the twenty-third year of the organization.
Stock market narrow and irregular. Money market featureless.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- President-elect McKinley will be here to-morrow, and he will be received with great warmth and made welcome by hosts of people who are not office seekers. Before he has been here many hours he will find that there are Republicans waiting to give him advice about completing his Cabinet. He will find some of Mr. Platt's friends more anxious to have New York represented than is Mr. Platt himself.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 1. -- A small-sized riot occurred on the streets of this city early this morning, in which one man was killed and several more or less seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The correspondence of the Department of State with Consul General Lee at Havana, in the case of Charles Scott, an American citizen, which was laid before the Senate to-night, confirms the published story that Gen. Lee threatened to resign unless the department supported his demand that Scott be released from solitary confinement.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during February of $4,592,137.10. The interest-bearing debt increased $200, the non-interest-bearing debt increased $2,066,772, and cash in the Treasury decreased $2,525,165.10.

CARSON, Nev., March 1. -- It is reported on good authority that Assemblyman Timothy Dempsey, who was one of the most ardent supporters of the boxing bill, will introduce a bill in the State Legislature within the next few days asking for an appropriation of $3,000 for the purpose of having made a gorgeous belt of silver, with diamond setting, to be presented to the winner of the Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight.

A large number of persons from this State, and especially from this city and its vicinity, will be in Washington on Thursday to witness the inauguration of President McKinley. Many have already gone, and others will go to-day and to-morrow.

Sorosis held its annual election yesterday. It was not only the annual election, but the meeting which comes once in three years -- every Sorosis President is re-elected twice -- when the President has served the full term allowed by the constitution and the contest for the vacant office is usually a warm one.

It was not till the end of the second act that any one not committed to approval of everything done at the Casino could tell why "La Falote" had been produced. Then the prima donna and the female chorus ran on the stage clad in the familiar toggery of the serpentine dance, the electrician under the glass slide in the stage turned on his lights, and we all discovered where we were.

M. L. Hess have sold for Messrs. Collins Collins, to E. Coffin, 116, 118, and 120 West Thirty-fourth Street, known as the Old Fourth Presbyterian Church, size 80 by 100, at $275,000. It is intended to improve the plot by the erection of a nine-story fireproof office building.

" One Plus One Equals Three; or, The Sins of the Fathers," is the cumbersome title of a smart but crude play acted for the first time yesterday afternoon in the Garrick Theatre before an invited audience. Edwin Milton Royle wrote it, and the house bill announced that it was produced under the stage direction of Mrs. Royle, (Selena Fetter.)

ALBANY, March 1. -Senator Cantor to-night fulfilled his promise, made last week, to insist that the Republicans maintain a quorum if they insisted on keeping the Senate in session during the week of inauguration. As a consequence, there was turmoil from the start this evening, and very little business was transacted.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Manager Grau of the Grand Opera Company yesterday received a telegram from the manager of Ella Russell, the American Prima donna, who is now on her way to this country, to the effect that she would join the Grau combination in Chicago in the last week of the present engagement.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2. -- In the House to-day the Equal Taxation bill, providing that all real estate owned by railroads shall be taxed at local rates, came up on a second reading and was advanced to a third reading without debate or amendment.

At this auspicious moment, when one-half of the American people are making ready their aprons in which to catch the shower of larks so soon to fall when the advance agent of prosperity takes the reins, it may be ungracious to remember the message of Gen. Bonaparte to the Army of Italy: "Nothing is done while aught remains to do."

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The old controversy between the Senate and House over the matter of the control of ceremonies in connection with the inauguration of the President came to the surface in the House this morning.

HAVANA, March 2. -- A desperate engagement is reported to have taken place sixty miles south of Jaruco, Thursday, between some of Gen. Rodriguez's forces and a large Spanish column commanded by Major Martot.

ALBANY, March 2. -- The Republicans had a quorum in the Senate to-day, and Senator Center's efforts to renew the filibustering tactics of yesterday were largely unavailing. Mr. Cantor protested against all entries in the Journal where Senators were credited as "present but not voting." His motion to strike out was defeated -- 26 to 9.
The Amherst Association of New York held its annual reunion and dinner at the Hotel Savoy last night. The banquet hall was comfortably filled, and presented a brilliant scene.

The report of the Venezuela Commission is not only the record of a piece of public work which has been most faithfully performed. It has the curious fate of having been rendered quite useless for its original purpose by the progress of events, and yet of serving even a more important purpose and of having a value beyond that which was expected of it.

What does the South need as to currency? That is a question that has been eagerly asked by many of the advocates of sound money who are convinced that beneath the very general agitation in that region for unsound money there is some substantial basis of necessity, some real grievance demanding a remedy and capable of one.

Samuel F. Jayne Co. have sold for Harry Chaffee, builder, the recently completed eight-story limestone front store and loft building 29 to 33 East Nineteenth Street, 60 by 92, at $450,000, to J.C. Kendall, who will give in trade at $125,000 the two five-story buildings 43 and 45 East Nineteenth Street, plot 50 by 92. The latter will be improved at an early date by the erection of a business structure.

TOPEKA, Ken., March 2. -- The State Senate to-day was thrown into a tremor of excitement by P.J. Titus of Harper County, who arose in his place during a fiery debate on the bill to reduce charges at the Kansas City Stock Yards, and declared that he had been offered a bribe of $1,000 to vote against the measure.

The Rev. Dr. George Scovil Mallory, editor of The Churchman, died unexpectedly at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Hotel St. Andrew, in this city. Although he had been sick with pneumonia for about two weeks, his improved condition within the past two or three days led to a confident belief in his recovery.

The Rev. Dr. W.H.P. Faunce of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church made some remarks on new and old journalism last night in a speech at the twenty-fifth anniversary of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, at Carnegie Hall, which drew forth from the audience the warmest applause of the evening, excepting only, perhaps, the cordial reception given to Anthony Comstock.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The fastest run ever made from Jersey City to Washington was concluded at 3:23 P.M. this afternoon, when Vice President-elect Hobart's special train stopped in the Baltimore and Ohio station here.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 2. -- Andrew Carnegie, who was attacked with pleurisy Saturday at his residence here, passed a comfortable day, and to-night is resting easily.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Senate to-day concurred in the House amendments to the Monetary Conference bill, but not until several silver Senators had expressed their views. Mr. Dubois of Idaho declared his conviction that the only way to reach an international agreement was for this Nation to stand out, as in 1776, and declare its intention to regulate its own affairs.

The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill invites a veto as wickedness invites chastisement. It is a robber bill, swollen to proportions of extravagance, by the old dodge of log-rolling. It has been pointed out that every member of the committee gets about $400,000 for his constituents by its provisions.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 2. -- At a meeting of the Cabinet to-day, an order was passed allowing the law to take its course in the case of Sullivan, the New Brunswick murderer, and Bad Young Man, alias Charcoal, the Indian, who killed Sergt. Wilde of the mounted police, in the Northwest. Sullivan will be hanged March 12 and Charcoal March 16.

CANEA, March 2. -- The Turkish gendarmes in this city refused yesterday to perform further duty unless they were at once paid fifteen months' arrears of wages. The money, of course, was not paid, for the reason that the officials did not have it. To-day the men openly mutinied, threatening to burn the town and massacre the inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Paymaster John Corwine, United States Navy, stationed at Newport, R.I., has absconded, taking his checkbook with him. This statement is made on the authority of the Navy Department. Yesterday afternoon Paymaster Corwine cashed a check for $5,000 and then left Newport.
It was a striking statement that we published yesterday morning from the gentleman who in a day or two will be Secretary of the Treasury.
Col. Waring yesterday made the following statement to the West End Association concerning the controversy over the establishment of a steel pocket dump at the foot of West Ninety-seventh Street:

Garret A. Hobart, Vice President-elect, his wife, son, and some of the friends who accompanied him to Washington, were standing in a group on the rear platform of the special car Atlas in the station of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at Communipaw at 11:15 yesterday morning, when the signal was given to start, and the train began to glide slowly out of the station.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 2. -- The municipal election was held here to-day and proved to be one of the closest in results on the vote for Mayor ever held. Arthur C. Hastings (Rep.) was elected Mayor by a majority of 9 votes over O.W. Cutler, (Dem.) A Republican Overseer of the Poor, a Democratic Police Justice, two Democratic Justices of the Peace, one Republican Alderman, and three Democratic Aldermen were also elected.

Since the two New York exponents of the new, the freak, and the "fake" journalism, The World and The Journal, went hurriedly together out of the back door of the Newark Free Public Library, Feb. 4, at the order of the Trustees, nothing has affected them that will so please persons of cleanly minds as the action of the Library Committee of the Union League Club, Monday evening.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Vice President-elect Hobart and Mrs. Hobart remained at the Arlington Hotel all evening, except for about a half hour, when they called upon the President-elect and Mrs. McKinley at the Ebbitt.

WICHITA, Kansas, March 2. -- Oklahoma is in a fever of excitement to-day over the report that both gold and silver in paying quantities have been discovered in the Wichita Mountains in the Indian Territory, and companies of prospectors are forming secretly in Kingfisher, El Reno, and a number of Oklahoma towns, with the intention of opening up mines immediately.

The condition of James P. Kernochan, the banker and clubman, who fell in Forty-first Street, at Fifth Avenue, while walking down town on Monday forenoon, did not change for the better or worse yesterday. His injuries are serious, however, owing to his age, and the chances of recovery not good.

The expenditure of over $500,000 for new asphalt pavement was authorized Monday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment upon the report submitted by Commissioner Collis of the Department of Public Works. Controller Fitch caused the report to be so amended that a section of West Eleventh Street should be paved with asphalt.

LONDON, March 2. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. G.N. Curzon, Under Foreign Secretary, read telegrams received from the British Consul at Canea saying that the Mussulmans in the Island of Crete had declared that they would not consent to a union of Crete with Greece and placed high hopes in the action of the great powers to prevent it.

Messrs. Smith Stewart, 45 William Street, have sold for Mrs. O.H.P. Belmont her city house and furniture, at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-second Street, for $300,000, to Richard M. Montgomery Co., who represent W. Bayard Cutting.

A syndicate for refunding the bonded debt of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad Company has been formed, with Speyer Co. at its head. Interested with this firm are Lazard Freres, Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co., F.S. Smithers Co., the Central Trust Company of New York, J. Kennedy Tod Co., E.H. Harriman, Teixeira de Mattes Brothers of Amsterdam, Speyer Brothers of London, and Laz. Speyer Ellissen of Frankfort-on-the-Main.

LONDON, March 2. -- The farewell banquet given by the Right Hon. George Faudel Phillips, Lord Mayor of London, in honor of Ambassador Bayard, took place to-night in the Egyptian Hall, in the Mansion House, the official residence of the Lord Mayor. The scene in the hall was a most brilliant one, all the guests who were entitled to do so wearing the uniform of their respective ranks.
ALBANY, March 2. -- The Court of Appeals has decided that the law of 1895 legislating the New York City Police Justices out of office is Constitutional.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Secretary Olney to-day responded to the Senate's resolution for the correspondence in the Ruiz case by sending an abstract of the matter, declining to send the full correspondence on the ground that it "would not seem to be in the public interest." The abstract furnished by the State Department shows the following facts:

Minnie Maddern Fiske acted Tess Durbeyfield in a play made by Lorimer Stoddard out of materials found in Thomas Hardy's sad story, "Tess of the d'Urbervilles," at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night. Hardy's novel is not essentially dramatic, though it contains certain episodes that were sure to suggest a play, some time or other, to a person of theatrical experience.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The President and the President-elect met socially to-night in the White House, which one has occupied for the past four years and which the other expects to occupy for the four years next to come.

MONTREAL, March 2. -- Developments in the fight between the Laurier Government and the Roman Catholic hierachy in Quebec are transpiring rapidly. Last night, suddenly, Archbishop Begin, coadjuter to his Eminence Cardinal Taschereau of Quebec, left for New York, whence he sailed for Rome to-day.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The President sent the following message vetoing the Immigration bill to the House late this afternoon:
PHILADELPHIA, March 2. -- It is understood that two, and possibly three, expeditions left the United States to-day with men and munitions of war for Cuba.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt entertained the Colonial Dames of the State of New York at her residence, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon. She left her husband in Washington and made a flying trip to this city to meet her guests. A paper on "Table Furnishings in Colonial Times" was the feature of the afternoon, and was read by Miss Harriet Mumford Campbell.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Number Eight in the Cabinet has not yet been found. The politicians and the President-elect are all at sea to-night about it, and the difficulty of reaching a conclusion has appeared to be so great, twelve hours after the arrival of Major McKinley, that the President-elect has declared the matter will not be settled within twenty-four hours.
ALBANY, March 2. -- The gist of the decisions in the two racing law cases handed down to-day, both written by Judge Martin and concurred in by the full court, are as follows:

Judge McMahon, in Part I, of General Sessions, yesterday listened to arguments on demurrer to the indictment of the Metropolitan Traction Company for alleged maintenance of a nuisance at Broadway and Fourteenth Street. De Lancey Nicoll and Elihu Root appeared for the company and District Attorney Olcott for the people, and there were some sharp exchanges of language between counsel.

The fruitless and disturbing second session of the Fifty-fourth Congress, which comes to an unlamented end to-night, supplies good arguments in plenty to support the proposition that Congressmen should take their seats on the 4th of March following their election, instead of waiting a year and a month, as is now done.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 3. -- The elections in Monroe County yesterday show some marked changes. In Pittsford the Democrats made a clean sweep, although the town is nominally Republican. The excise question was the principal issue.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The President has approved the bill providing for an international monetary conference; also these:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 3. -- A dispatch from Frankfort says Gov. Bradley has appointed Major A.T. Wood of Mount Sterling, United States Senator from Kentucky, to succeed J.C.S. Blackburn, and that the appointment will be announced to-morrow afternoon or early Friday morning.

Mayor Strong has asked Corporation Counsel Scott for a written opinion on the constitutionality of the Finn bill. This opinion will most likely be ready before the bill is disposed of by the Legislature, for the bill, if it passes at all, will come from the State Solons substantially as it now stands. If it be altered in detail, the principle will not be affected.

LONDON, March 3. -- All of this morning's papers publish editorials upon the banquet given at the Mansion House last evening in honor of the Hon. Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador, and eulogize Mr. Bayard and contain expressions of regret at his coming retirement. Most of the papers also comment upon the approaching change of administration at Washington.
Hell Gate Republican Club and Quigg Legion Vied with the Seventy-first Regiment for Public Applause -- Thirty-seven Train-Loads Sent Out.

The revenue cutter Manhattan returned to her pier at the Barge Office yesterday evening at 5 o'clock, after having had nothing more than a rough experience on the Atlantic for the pains her crew were put to in the effort to overhaul the Laurada, suspected of filibustering.

The article of incorporation of the City Realty and Investment Company was filed with the Clerk of Hudson County (N.J.) yesterday. The incorporators are Henry O. Havemeyer of Greenwich, Conn.; Theodore A. Havemeyer of Mahwah, N.J.; Charles F. Havemeyer of New York, and Lowell M. Palmer and Henry M. Palmer of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Indian Appropriation bill caused a warm debate in the House to-day. A disagreeing report of the conference committee was presented.

Nelson Wheatcroft, Director of the Empire Theatre Dramatic School, died yesterday afternoon at 2:25 o'clock at his home, 153 West Forty-sixth Street. His death was caused by pneumonia, following a cold caught early last week while acting in "Spiritisme" at the Knickerbocker Theatre.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- A partial report of the conferrees on the Naval Appropriation bill started a debate in the Senate to-day. Mr. Hale, (Rep., Me.,) in reporting the progress of the conference, said that all the general items in dispute had been arranged and that the controverted matters which were still open were as to the increase of the navy by torpedo boats, and as to the price of steel armor for ships.
The deficit is still maintained, a million dollars a week, and more. -- The Tribune.

The first day of the annual Spring sale of high-bred trotting horses at Madison Square Garden yesterday drew a large crowd of horsemen. William B. Fasig Co., under whose management the sale is being conducted, not only offered a promising lot of youngsters, but a number whose work on the track has already gained for them a position in the turf world.

Lawyers Steinhardt and Goldman of 11 Pine Street say they have discovered that Ferdinand May, who was arrested here Feb. 19, on an order of arrest issued by Justice Pryor, charged with having swindled the Allgemeine Elssaessische Gesellschaft Bank out of $222,000, has really defrauded the bank of nearly $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- It lacked about three minutes to the noon hour when President Cleveland left the White House to pay his visit of ceremony to his successor. The big State carriage of the President, closed to suit the condition of the weather, waited under the portico for Mr. Cleveland's appearance, while about a hundred people, held in check by the policemen on duty at the mansion, hovered near to see the retiring Executive.

The girls' basket ball team of the Horace Mann Gymnasium met the class of '98 of the Montclair High School yesterday in the gymnasium in their first match game. All the friends of the home team were present to applaud their favorites, and the excitement was as intense as the applause was vehement.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The treatment accorded to sailors was discussed in the Senate to-day, when a conference report was presented on the bill to amend the laws relating to navigation. When it was read, an inquiry was made by Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) as to whether the bill now contained any of the "flogging clauses."

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- It was just 11 o'clock when the President-elect drove up to the White House in the rain to make the customary formal call on the President. Quite a crowd had collected near the portico in anticipation of his arrival, and hats were removed with a slight cheer when he alighted, followed by Secretary J. Addison Porter and Chairman Bell of the Inauguration Committee.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- The wheat trade made a stagger at starting a bull market here to-day. After the first hour the action indicated that the bulls were sorry for what they did yesterday and this morning, and liquidation became the order in the pit.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- In the House to-day Mr. Cannon (Rep., Ill.,) moved to non-concur in the Senate amendments to the General Deficiency bill.

Eight women out of fifty who attended the regular meeting of the Rainy Day Club yesterday wore rainy-day suits. The club met at the residence of Mrs. J.A. Brown, 228 West One Hundred and Fourth Street. Of the eight present, only two appeared to be equipped with the bona fide article and not wearing an abbreviated member of an ordinary every-day wardrobe.

Some pains seem to be taken by the power that controls legislation in this State to have it understood that when the Greater New York charter is reported by the committees which are now going through the form of considering it there will be no delay in passing it without amendment.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3. -- The institution by the Attorney General of suits to debar the Home of New York and the St. Paul Fire and Marine Companies from doing business in this State has revived the report that the Lloyds and the "old-line" companies have entered upon a war of extermination.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Washington is not exactly packed with visitors, but the population is vastly increased, and there is no doubt whatever that the inauguration of Major McKinley as President will be witnessed by a great throng of people.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, who for more than three weeks has conducted a somewhat unique and successful fight against the Baptist Mission Society for the possession of the parsonage of the Baptist Tabernacle, 162 Second Avenue, was forcibly put out of that building yesterday afternoon.

Commissioner Taft's resolution, aiming to expedite the acquisition of sites and the commencement of work on new school buildings, was the most important business before the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday. The resolution was adopted. It gives the city possession of property while the condemnation proceedings are under way, and means the saving of much valuable time.

CRANFORD, N.J., March 3. -- Mrs. H.C. West of Cranford and Elizabeth Avenues, wife of a New York rice broker, was shot and badly injured this morning by a burglar, who entered the residence of her husband and was detected while at work.

LONDON, March 3. -- The Post to-morrow will publish a dispatch from Constantinople to a news agency here, saying that the collective note from the powers presented to the Porte yesterday, mentions the gradual withdrawal of the Turkish troops from the Island of Crete, and suggests a military convention between the powers and the Porte for the settlement of details.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 3. -- The Three-Cent Car Fare bill precipitated trouble in the House to-day. Last night the bill failed for want of a Constitutional majority, and to-day its friends pressed a second vote.

The sentiment against the so-called new journalism, which appears to have been accumulating among the better classes in this vicinity, has been brought generally into evidence by recent public action against the leading representatives of the innovation.

BALTIMORE, March 3. -- Stuyvesant Fish, President of the Illinois Central Railroad and Vice President of the National Park Bank of New York, has given The Manufacturers' Record an interview upon the need of better banking laws. In the course of the interview Mr. Fish says:

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The session of Congress to-day was marked by confusion. Each house was sitting in continuation of Tuesday's session. Members were lounging in committee rooms, only appearing in their respective chambers when matters in which they were specially interested were under consideration.

ALBANY, March 3. -- The Court of Appeals has decided that the State Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission may bring proceedings in the form of certiorari to review the actions of State Controllers in canceling the sales of lands for unpaid State taxes.

BALTIMORE, March 3. -- The one hundred and thirteenth session of the Baltimore Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was opened this morning with the sacrament of the Lord's Supper in historic Eutaw Street Church. The Conference will be in session for a week or ten days, and will be presided over by Bishop Willard F. Mallalieu of Buffalo, N.Y.

The gentleman who, in our columns, described the fight against the sidewalk obstructions as the "fight of the old and the new" sees things as they are. In some respects New York is more provincial than scores of towns of one-tenth its size and population. The peculiar phase of backward civilization shown by the toleration of the particular abuse referred to belongs rather to an Algerian market town than to a great modern business city.

-- Gov. HASTINGS of Pennsylvania has had the courage to withhold his approval from a joint legislative resolution requiring that all architects, contractors, and laborers employed in building the new Capitol shall be citizens of the State, and that none of the materials used shall be imported from beyond the State's boundaries.

Before the revision of the Constitution of this State in 1894 it contained a prohibition of the sale of the salt springs belonging to the State, and while it authorized the sale of contiguous lands "necessary and convenient for the use of the salt springs," and the purchase of others "alike convenient," it forbade any diminution of the quantity of these lands by such sale and purchase.
ALBANY, March 3. -- The Senate began its work to-day by confirming these nominations:

The dependent poor of this city lost an old and serviceable friend in the death of William Blake, which occurred early yesterday morning at his brother's residence, 237 East Twelfth Street. As Superintendent of Out-Door Poor in the Department of Charities, Mr. Blake was constantly brought into contact with the destitute and the disabled, and there were many hundreds of the city's helpless charges to whom he was the only friend and the only adviser.

It is quite in keeping with Mr. CLEVELAND'S thorough and painstaking way of doing his work that his review of the Immigration bill brings out a number of points that were not even suggested in the considerable debates of the two houses.

The editor of The Emporia Gazette, who has made himself conspicuous in Kansas by his free and picturesque expression of sane and sober views, contributes to the current Forum an entertaining paper upon that Commonwealth. It is expressed, we must own, in Kansan rhetoric, but it considers the Kansan epidemic from the point of view of a dispassionate critic.
