Sergt. John Kelleher, one of the senior service men in the Police Department, yesterday sent his petition for retirement to the Police Board. He has seen thirty-six years of work on the force.

To the plain man the difference between a "collective note" from all the powers and an "identical note" from each of the powers is not obvious. To him, therefore, it appears indifferent whether the powers all say the same thing in chorus or each power says it for itself. But that is because the plain man is not a diplomatist.

LONDON, March 3. -- A terrific southwesterly gale is prevailing along the coasts and in the interior of England. A number of vessels have been wrecked off Yarmouth, and isolated cases of drowning are reported.
ALBANY, March 3. -- The Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, Episcopal Bishop of Albany, to-night gave the following statement for publication:

Twenty years ago, when "Boss" Tweed and his methods were the subject of investigation by a special committee of the Board of Aldermen, one of the questions asked Mr. Tweed was: "How about the public press?" He replied, "They were generally against us in private and with us in public.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 3. -- A bold attempt was made at Green Cove Springs, ten miles south of here, this week, to "bunco" William Kennedy, a wealthy resident of Troy, N.Y., and a partner of Senator Murphy, out of a large amount of money.

The Rev. Dr. FAUNCE hit the nail on the head in his Carnegie Hall address on Tuesday night, when he said that the new journalism is as old as sin itself. It is simply human nature flaunting its ignoble propensities without shame in the eyes of the world.

Augustus J. Fleischmann and Miss Lillie Rosenberger were married at Victoria Hall yesterday, and immediately after they were united, a silver wedding ceremony was performed for the parents of the bridegroom, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Fleischmann. Both services were read by the Rev. Stephen S. Wise.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The night sessions of the Senate and House were watched by large numbers of people in the galleries. An angry passage between Senators Hoar and Quay set the Senate galleries in a flutter.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 3. -- Edith Behr was to-day for the second time sentenced to prison for assaulting the Bloy brothers. She is to serve three months in the county jail. Her father has also been sentenced for this offense, but is out on appeal. After her previous sentence she served five days, and an appeal served to release her temporarily.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The flagship Philadelphia with Admiral Beardslee aboard, has been ordered to leave San Diego at once for San Jose de Guatemala, where the Admiral, with his staff and the chief officers of the ship, will attend the opening of the Guatemalan International Exposition March 15.

BOSTON, March 3. -- A novel cycle race will be run off at Charles River Park track May 19. It will be called the "Blue Ribbon Meet," and will be under the auspices of the Bostonian Cycle Club, composed exclusively of ladies.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3. -- The power house at Thirteenth and Mount Vernon Streets, from which the Union Traction Company operated a half dozen of its lines of trolley cars, was destroyed by fire this evening.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- John Corwine, the absconding Paymaster of the United States Navy, who was stationed at Newport, R.I., was arrested in Chicago this afternoon. He arrived here this morning from New York.

Police Commissioner GRANT is reported as having said, just before starting for Washington to attend the inauguration, that he thought the only solution of the difficulty in the Police Board was to legislate the board out of existence and provide for the appointment of new Commissioners who would "work in unison from now until the inauguration of the Mayor of Greater New York."

The officers of the Cloakmakers' Union, like those of the Shirtmakers' Union, have not been able to keep their people well in hand and to restrain them from striking prematurely. The Executive Board of the cloakmakers had decided that no strikes should take place before Friday, but the men complained that it was too long to wait.

Four lodges of the Independent Order Benai Berith entertained their friends at the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, last evening, in honor of the birthday anniversaries of Washington and Lincoln. There were several addresses, and an excellent programme of music. The lodges interested were "Washington Lodge No. 19, Rehoboth Lodge No. 38, Henry Jones Lodge No. 79, and America Lodge No. 410.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Cornelius N. Bliss will be a member of President McKinley's Cabinet. Under the pressure of political and business friends of New York City and of Chairman Hanna, Mr. Bliss reconsidered his determination not to accept a portfolio, and about noon to-day placed himself at Major McKinley's disposal. Unless some readjustment of posts is made at the last moment, Mr. Bliss will be Secretary of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The New Yorkers who are here put in a busy day of it. Gov. Black went up to the Capitol to see some of his old associates, and there was quite a little demonstration in his honor in the House.

Alexander McKinny, Acting Collector of Internal Revenue of the First District in Brooklyn, and William N. Rome, the Senior Deputy Collector, are at sword points. This situation reached a climax yesterday, when Mr. Rome, who has been Deputy for nineteen years, made an attempt to seize the Collectorship, and was sat down upon by Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle and the incoming Secretary, Mr. Gage of Illinois.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 4. -- The final qualifications for the Kentucky Derby made a decided change to-day in the Winter book.
CANEA, March 4. -- The situation at Selino and in the vicinity of that town is uncertain, the reports from there being vague.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Four of the annual appropriation bills failed to become laws owing to the refusal of the President to approve them. The Sundry Civil, the Indian, and the Agricultural bill reached the Whithe House so late that Mr. Cleveland was unable to give them that close scrutiny upon which he insists. He therefore refused to sign any of them.
LONDON, March 4. -- The Standard, commenting upon President McKinley's inaugural address, will say to-morrow:

BOSTON, March 4. -- An explosion at 11:45 o'clock this morning of gas which leaked from the two great six-inch mains which cross the subway at the corner of Tremont and Boylston Streets killed six persons and injured about fifty others, two of whom probably are hurt fatally.

It was not an unhappy inspiration, whosever inspiration it was, that led to the publication in yesterday's World, a few hours in advance of the delivery of the inaugural message of the President, of a message to the people of the United States from the defeated candidate for the Presidency.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 4. -- Gov. Bradley of this State to-night antagonized Hon. Mark A. Hanna. He sent a telegram defying Hanna, the Senate Steering Committee, and the new Administration in their demand upon him to call the Legislature in extra session, and not to appoint a Senator to succeed Senator Blackburn, whose term expires to-day.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- President McKinley will to-morrow issue his proclamation for an extra session. It will be called to meet March 15, which falls on Monday.

The Rev. Charles Frederick Hoffman, D D., LL. D., D.C.L., rector of All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, died yesterday morning at Jekyl Island, off Brunswick Ga.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- William McKinley is President. Under a cloudless sky, in the presence of 40,000 of his applauding fellow-citizens, a citizen of Ohio, a State that has furnished four Presidents, to-day took the oath of office and succeeded Grover Cleveland of New York.
Golding Whitehouse have sold for Mrs. Penfield, at about $32,000, the four-story-and-basement brownstone-front dwelling 109 West Seventieth Street, on lot 20 by 100.5.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The quadrennial "march down the avenue" to-day was one of the most notable of recent years. At 10 o'clock Senator Sherman and Senator Mitchell of Wisconsin, the committee from the Senate of the United States appointed to escort the President-elect from the hotel to the White House, were ushered into Major McKinley's reception room, at the Ebbitt House.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Soon after the conclusion of the inauguration parade this evening, the Quigg Legion, headed by the St. Joseph Mission Band, marched to the Arlington and serenaded Senator Thomas C. Platt. The legion was in command of Jastrow Alexander, who, with Deputy Commissioner of Jurors Dunn and Louis Dunkle, arranged the serenade.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- New York furnished one officer of Cleveland's Administration who has justified his appointment. Commissioner of Navigation Eugene T. Chamberlain has not only demonstrated that the place offered opportunity to give an active and thorough man some reputation, but he has secured great advantages to commerce while saving money to the people. He sketched his work a few days ago in a letter to a friend, as follows:
At the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday the regular order of business was interrupted in recognition of President Cleveland's _Administration and his public services.

-- Texans seem to be almost as ready to shriek with anger over anything that can be tortured into a reflection on their State's perfection as are the residents of Chicago when the "greatness" of their beloved city is questioned. For instance, The Galveston Tribune fills many lines with fierce invective against "the malicious newspaper correspondents and ignorant landlubbers," who said that the battleship Texas grounded while lying in Galveston Harbor the other day.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 4. -- Fire broke out in the Barnes bicycle factory, on East Water Street, this city, at 7:40 o'clock this morning, and within less than ten minutes one section of the building, which was a five-story brick structure, was a mass of flames. Soon after the first alarm of fire was sent in Chief Eckel turned in another alarm, calling out additional apparatus.

ATHENS, March 4. -- The warlike preparations here continue without abatement. The reserves of 1891, 1890, 1889, and 1888 have been summoned to join the colors, and they are responding with alacrity. All seem imbued with the desire for open hostilities against the Turks, and the greatest enthusiasm is reported everywhere.

The country will observe with hearty satisfaction that President McKINLEY puts at the very beginning of his message, confirming the clear and positive meaning of his words by the emphasis of their position, the declaration that the value of our money "must not be further threatened -- it should all be put upon an enduring basis, not subject to easy attack, nor its stability to doubt or dispute."

Twelve property owners in the vicinity of West End Avenue and West Ninety-ninth Street met at the residence of W.K. Kurtz, 700 West End Avenue, last night, and formed an organization the avowed object of which is to prevent the Riverside Wheelmen from taking possession of the large four-story stone edifice at 702 West End Avenue, which they have leased for a period of five years.

The trial of a suit brought by Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan, widow of Dr. Alexander Buchanan, who died Sept. 3 last, against Mrs. Kate M. Foster for $50,000 for the alienation of her husband's affection, was begun yesterday before Justice Bookstaver and a jury in the Supreme Court. Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy appeared for Mrs. Buchanan and Col. E.C. James for Mrs. Foster.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Garret A. Hobart of New Jersey became Vice President of the United States about 12:30 o'clock this afternoon. He took the oath of office in the Senate Chamber. It was administered to him by Mr. Stevenson, then Vice President. Having subscribed to the oath, Mr. Hobart became Vice President and Mr. Stevenson retired to private life.

ALBANY, March 4. -- When the reports of committees were submitted to the Senate this morning among them was the bill of Senator Ellsworth, aimed against prohibiting the publishing of any portrait or alleged portrait of any person without first obtaining the written consent of the person represented.

The stockholders of the Berkeley Athletic Association Corporation, Limited, decided at a meeting yesterday, held at 19 West Forty-fourth Street, to dissolve the corporation and to take steps for the appointment of a receiver to wind up the affairs of the corporation.

HILLSDALE, N.J., March 4. -- Joseph Sisco, a negro, was shot in the head to-day by Michael McDermott, a white man. The shooting was done with a fowlingpiece, and, while Sisco's forehead was badly lacerated, none of the shot penetrated the brain. It is thought the wounded man will recover.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Following is the text of President McKinley's inaugural address:

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- When President McKinley left the reviewing stand at about 6 o'clock, a carriage was waiting at the White House entrance. As the President was passing Bishop John P. Newman of Nebraska alighted and hurrying to him told him that Mrs. Gen. Grant was in the carriage.

MONTREAL, March 4. -- The annual report of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company to Dec. 31, 1896, has been issued, together with the usual statements and schedules. The report shows: Gross earnings, $20,681,596; expenses, $12,574,015; net earnings, $8,107,581, which, with $511,165 other income, makes $5,618,746, to which is applied $6,708,084 fixed charges, leaving $1,910,552.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Thousands witnessed the display of fireworks on the White Lot, near the Washington Monument, to-night. The weather was perfect for the exhibition, and it was one of the biggest displays of the kind ever witnessed here.

Hypnotism was the subject discussed at the meeting, last night, of the Psychological Section of the Medico-Legal Society. The section met at the house of Miss Marie Hamill, 317 West Eighty-seventh Street, and about fifty ladies and gentlemen were present.
HAVANA, March 4. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon on the transport Legazpi from Caibarien, Province of Santa Clara. He was accompanied by the members of his staff.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The sun looked all day like a great disk of burnished gold. It was weather truly emblematical of the victory which resulted in the ceremonies of to-day. In more senses than one it was a golden inaugural. All Washington was in its finest vestment. From sunrise to sunset the sky was cloudless, and the fine weather was a subject of an excusable amount of talk and congratulation.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- In the general glad rejoicing over the advent of "Protection and Prosperity," there were 200 sad hearts this morning, and they belonged to members of the Cook County Marching Club.

At the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Stevens Institute recently celebrated, President Morton drew attention to the fact that while the original endowment and subsequent gifts had supplied all that was necessary for present requirements, the natural and necessary growth of the institution would make more ample accommodations and a larger revenue essential for an adequate future development of the work which had been so successfully carried on heretofore.

Expressions of approval of the main points in President McKinley's inaugural address were general among New York business men yesterday. His unqualified declarations in favor of preserving the Nation's credit, in advocating an immediate ratification of the arbirtation treaty between this country and Great Britain, and in support of civil service reform elicited warm commendation from citizenS, irrespective of party.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The inauguration ball in the Pension Building to-night was perhaps the most notable event of its kind ever known in Washington. An immense crowd was in attendance.

LIVERPOOL, March 4. -- The Belgian steamer Belgenland, Capt, Doxred from Philadelphia, Feb. 21, has arrived here. She reports that on Feb. 28 last. in laatude 49 degrees north, longitude 9 degrees west, she spoke the British teamer Lake Wannipeg, Capt. Taylor. from St. John, N.B. Feb. 14, for Liverapool, with her machinery disabled and water in her engine

CAMDEN, N.J., March 4. -- Burglars to-night, after robbing the house of J.P. Carwell at 28 Arch Street, this place, set fire to the place. The thieves entered the house by way of an empty house adjoining. They ransacked the residence of Mr. Carwell and secured $50 in money.

Emma Kitchel Mouton, widow of Alexander Mouton, former Governor of Louisiana and United States Senator, died on her plantation, Il Copal, on Bayou Teche, Lafayette Parish, La., last Monday, after a short illness. Ailments incidental to advanced years were the cause of death.

A general meeting of the section on public health of the New York Academy of Medicine was held last night, at 17 West Forty-third Street, to discuss the Greater New York charter in its relation to the Board of Health. Dr. E.G. Janeway presided. Dr. Stephen Smith read the paper of the evening on "The Health Department of Greater New York."

NEWARK, N.J., March 4. -- The Rev. E.J. Oldknow Millington, pastor of the Fairmount Baptist Church, is missing. He left Newark Monday morning, and, beyond two telegrams received from him that afternoon nothing has been heard from him by his family or friends.

Edward H. Johnson, a man of much consequence in electrical matters, is President of the Interior Conduit and Insulation Company, and holds $300,000 of the par value of its stock. He is also President of the Standardizing Company. The former company owes the latter one $87,500, and the President being desirous that his company should liquidate this indebtedness, proposed certain changes in the stock values which proved distasteful to the minority stockholders.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 4. -- The afternoon session of the Senate to-day was taken up in hearing the exhaustive veto message of Gov. Jones on the debt settlement question.
BISMARCK, N.D., March 4. -- The Railroad bill, which has been almost the sole topic of legislative talk for the past three weeks, was passed by both Houses yesterday by a unanimous vote in each.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Mrs. McKinley's ball costume was of white satin, brocaded in a rich design. The material was so elegant that it needed little trimming, and this was entirely of lace. The many gored skirt had paneled effects in point lace, alternating with plain gores of the satin.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 5. -- There is a story behind the fight of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad to retain absolute control of the Georgia Railroad. The determination of this fight will carry with it the control of the Atlanta and West Point, and at the same time will either work for or against a through line which the Louisville and Nashville wishes to establish over its own tracks to Charleston Harbor.

Golding Whitehouse have sold for Henry Stanton to Mrs. J. Stacy Bradford, at $45,000, the four-story and basement brownstone-front dwelling, 10 West Forty-ninth Street, 16.6 by 55 by 100.5. George W. Chandler is the buyer of the residence, 109 West Seventieth Street, reported sold by the same firm yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- J.A. Loening, a well-known elocutionist, has a novel idea based on his conception of "Hamlet." He believes that Hamlet was not crazed or simply filled with a desire for revenge, as many have thought, but that, in fact, he was a messenger of the Divine Being, commissioned to bring the retribution of heaven upon the guilty for their wickedness.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President McKinley arose at 7:30 o'clock this morning, after a good night's rest, in no wise the worse for the fatigue incident to the inaugural ceremonies. Mrs. McKinley also has not been harmed by the excitement of the week.

Star Pointer was bought at the Madison Square Garden-last night for $15,600. James H. Murphy, the wealthy Chicago broker, bought him, after two other men had bid him up, step by step, from $10,000 to $15,000. Then Mr. Murphy made his bid, and soon had the horse.

'fine Board of Street Opening at its meet' .'i yesterday urged the presentation of a to he Legislature granting to the 5rd discretionary power in the appoinaent of commissions for the opening and acquiring of title, in the city's name, to roposed streots.

Here is a picture of the Roman book canvasser. The snow-white Mauritanian steeds, with the heaving flanks, the pointed ears, the crimson nostrils, are reined up. From the chariot descended the master, who, giving his flowing toga an extra graceful fold, entered a house on the Via Aurelia. Presently a Scythian slave followed his lord, bearing in his sturdy arms a precious fassiculus, fully illustrated, up to date, and superbly bound in Persian cloth.

President McKinley's inaugural address has received the cordial praise of nearly every prominent man in this city, irrespective of party, who has expressed an opinion as to its propositions and its policy. The peaceful, dignified, and practical temper of the address have been especially commended, and all regard its warm advocacy of the arbitration treaty as manly and just.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 5. -- A special to The Globe-Democrat from Guadalajara, Mexico, says that almost a warlike spirit is being aroused among the people of Mexico by the coming of Messrs. Bruce, Stone, and Pierce of Boston to enter into negotiations with the Mexican Government for the return of the flags captured by the Mexican troops during the war of 1847.

John Wesley Harper, who has been chosen President of the new corporation of Harper Brothers, is the senior member of the house. Within the last year two members of the firm passed away -- Philip J.A. Harper ad Joseph Wesley Harper.

Steps have just been taken to organize Christian men who, as proprietors, receive an income from the occupation or operation of their property by others into a Brotherhood of St. Paul, the principles of which are to unostentatiously practice Christian Socialism, especially toward employes and each other.

The publication of Nansen's account of his northern pilgrimage, to which he has given the title "Furthest North," is now the most eagerly awaited event among book sellers and book readers, Harper Brothers have been busily engaged with it for several weeks past and expect to have the first edition ready by March 19.

We are all of us more or less curious to know how far the noted names of fiction are founded upon fact or how far they are pure creations of the fancy. We were shocked to learn that Mr. Micawber was based upon Dickens's father, and that Dora and Flora were two distinct portraits of Dickens's wife.

A series of Friday noon services for the Lenten season began in old St. Paul's Church yesterday, with the first of three short addresses by the Rev. Dr. Henry Lubeck, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Zion and St. Timothy. The Rev. William Montague Geer, vicar of St. Paul's, was associated with Dr. Lubeck in conducting this service.

Mr. Robert Hoe has written for the March Bookman a notice of the Baron Jerome Pichon, who in his day was the leader of the French bibliophiles. This scholarly man died in 1896, aged eighty-three. For half a century he was President of the Society of French Bibliophiles. In 1860 he had brought together a grand collection of books and manuscripts, which he disposed of in 1869.

Permit me to express my regard for and the gratification I feel upon reading your paper. In point of excellence THE TIMES is America's greatest paper, and is fast being recognized in this country as such; in Europe it has been so thought for several months. * * * Continue your prosecution and ridicule of those damnable freak sheets.
CHICAGO, March 5. -- Prof. Herman E. von Holst will return to Chicago and take up his classes in Chicago University for the Spring term.
CANEA, March 5. -- The British battleship Rodney, with three foreign warships, has started for Selino, with orders to assist the Turks who are besieged by Christians near that town.

Oscar Krause, a druggist at 343 Seventh Avenue, who had been arrested on complaint of the County Medical Society, charged with having prescribed as a physician, was discharged by Magistrate Cornell in Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

BALTIMORE, March 5. -- " Dave" Foutz, the well-known baseball player, and of recent years manager of the Brooklyn League team, died at his mother's home in Waverly, a suburb of this city, to-day of asthma.

To-day we paint the episode of the battle, an incident in it, not the general tumult, and Wouvermans never did aught else. The old Vernets show their 5,000 or 10,000 men in line, and all not ruled perspectives. How could it be otherwise? A field of battle of to-day may cover square miles, with hundreds of thousands of men in action, scattered everywhere.

A man who passed away without being regretted or even missed by his own children was John Fitzharris, the recluse, who died from injuries received at the fire at 214 West Twenty-seventh Street last week. It was some reparation to his children for his cruelty to them in their younger days that they found among his effects fifteen bank books, in which are recorded deposits amounting to $30,000.

The explosion in Boston by which six persons were killed and nearly fifty seriously injured has naturally created much popular excitement. As naturally, it has been supposed to show a danger in the subway, in the course of the construction of which the accident happened to take place.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 5. -- Mr. B.W. Hunt, a banker of Eatonton, Ga., passed through Atlanta en route to his Putnam County home after a trip to Paris for treatment for a bite received from a cat which he thought was rabid. Mr. Hunt's trip was a rapid one, and was, as he believed, a race between life and death.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Secretary Olney and Secretary Lament were not present yesterday in the Senate Chamber when the Vice President was sworn in, and the fact that President Cleveland was accompanied by only six members of his Cabinet was accounted for by some of the newspapers without giving the actual reasons for the absence of Mr. Olney and Mr. Lamont.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Cleveland refused his assent to three of the great appropriation bills because of objection to matters contained in them. The Sundry Civil bill, carying a total appropriation of $53,030,000, contained river and harbor improvement items to the amount of nearly $18,000,000.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- The mysterious death at the Palmer House nearly three months ago of Rudolph A. Bigelow, who traveled for years for a New York house, is recalled by a sensational affidavit filed to-day in the Probate Court, by Elizabeth Bigelow, a wealthy woman, who obtained a divorce from him last May.

"I do not believe," said one who knew Dr. Deems, "he ever willfully wasted an hour in his life. This marvelous energy, illumined by the higher order of intellectuality, and directed by a spirit wholly consecrated to the services of God, inspired his life of vast usefulness and made Dr. Deems the great and good man he was."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 5. -- Shortly after the curtain rose on the first act of Margaret Mather's production of "Cymbeline" to-night, a Deputy Sheriff served attachment papers on Manager Tillotson. The attachment suit was brought by Claude Hagan of New York, a stage carpenter who had the contract of building the scenery for "Cymbeline:"

THE strongest associations with the career of Mr. Green in the minds of his contemporaries are with the Central Park, with his work in the financial department of the city after the wreck wrought by the Tweed Ring, and of late with the great scheme of the consolidated cities that we commonly think of as "Greater New York."

" Bob" Armstrong and "Joe" Butler of Philadelphia met each other for a fifteen-round bout at the Broadway Athletic Club last night. The fact that there had been a grudge between them since a vicious six-round go they fought in the City of Brotherly Love drew a large gathering of sporting men in anticipation of lively fight.

THE dream of an endowed theatre in London seems to be nearer realization than it ever was before. The recent performances there of Echegaray's "Mariana" were under the direction of the company or group of enthusiasts who were responsible for the production of "Little Eyolf."

The strike in the building trades in this city is not as yet very important, but it is very sympathetic. The ultimate purpose of it appears to be the not unusual purpose of enabling the walking delegate to live without manual labor. The plumbers decline to contribute to this end by joining the Board of Walking Delegates.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 6. -- A special from down the coast states that Walter Ralston, connected with the Smithsonian Institution at Washington, has caught the python that has terrorized the natives around Black Key, a ten-miles-around sand spit, covered with mangroves, fifty miles below Rockledge.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Turkish Consul General Iasigi, in this city, has been indicted on more than fifty counts. All the counts charge him with embezzlement, and the sum total of the embezzlements alleged is more, than $100,000.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 6. -- William H. King, a millionaire of this city, died to-day at the Butler Insane Asylum, in Providence, where he had been confined since May 1, 1894.

SANTA CATALINA, Cal., March 6. -- How many years ago goats were placed on the Island of Santa Catalina no one knows but the legend has it that the early Spanish settlers, thinking that there was danger of starvation if wrecked here, left several of these animals on the island for the benefit of unfortunate mariners.

A movement of importance to the South will be begun in Waco, Texas, to-morrow. A convention of cotton growers will be held on the call of the American Protective Association of Cotton Growers, to be followed on Wednesday in Memphis and a third in Augusta on the 15th. The purpose is to consider how far the cotton acreage can be limited and more land and labor given to food products. The Atlanta Journal says:

In the twenty-third annual report of the Board of City Magistrates ending with Oct. 31, 1896, and just published, a comparative table of classified cases dealt with by the former Police Justices and present Magistrates since 1886 is presented.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President McKinley's first official proclamation was issued this afternoon, with the attestation of the new Secretary of State, John Sherman. It reads as follows:

HILLSDALE, N.J., March 6. -- Mrs. Clara M. Jaccard, granddaughter of Laura Keene and daughter of Artist Albert L. Rawson of Woodcliff, died at her home in this place last night of pneumonia. She had been sick since a week ago yesterday, when she gave birth to a son. Mrs. Jaccard was but twenty years of age, and had three children.

The report that Walter Damrosch had broken down in Pittsburg from overwork was refuted at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday afternoon. He had a temporary indisposition, which interfered with his work in the "Tannhauser" performance on Friday night, but was so far recovered that yesterday he telegraphed to his brother, Frank Damrosch, that he was all right.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 6. -- The heavy training of the Cornell crew candidates is now on. The crew room is crowded to its utmost capacity, and every afternoon, between 4 and 6, presents an interesting scene.
Neville Bagge will prepare plans for a five-story apartment house, to be built on the north side of Ninety-second Street, 80 feet east of West End Avenue, for William Drought.

THERE is an adage that the first essential to a peaceful existence is a comfortable home. If this be true, then the life of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer must, indeed, be the very ideal of tranquillity; for a more luxurious abode than that occupied by these well-known leaders of New York's upper society circles would be difficult of conception.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Unexpected success has been enjoyed by the Inaugural Committee with the concerts given in the inaugural ballroom by Herbert's Twenty-second Regiment Band. At last night's concert there was a prodigious jam of people, who went to see the ballroom and hear the music, 12,000 persons getting in, and several thousands being turned away because there was not room for them.

My attention has just been called to a cablegram published in your esteemed paper on Jan. 22, in which it is stated that in the course of a lecture before the Royal Society of Geography, in Madrid, I declared that "Japan and the United States had agreed to conclude an alliance."
" Prosperity is getting closer," said Mr. Russell Sage yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- This city is in bad shape financially, and in the opinion of experts like Controller Wetherell the cause may be traced directly to the annexation of outlying territory. In commenting upon this condition Controller Wetherell says:

When Mr. THOMAS WATSON of Georgia was informed that Mr. HAROLD M. SEWALL, son of the Bryanite candidate for Vice President, was stumping the State of Maine for McKINLEY, he observed in his lively way that he should consider himself a weak candidate if he couldn't carry his own son.

CANEA, March 6. -- Col. Vassos has intimated to the Admirals of the foreign fleets that he will secure the liberation of all the Mussulmans captured by the insurgents on condition that the prisoners abandon their arms and take no further part in the fighting.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President McKinley was at his desk at 9 o'clock this morning and hard at work. The correspondence is accumulating rapidly and is being handled by Mr. James Boyle, who was Major McKinley's private secretary at Canton, and Col. Cooper, the President's stenographer.

DENVER, Col., March 6. -- The report of Receiver Frank Trumbull of the Gulf Railway for the year ending Dec. 31, 1896, has been made public. The report is the third of the kind which has been issued by Mr. Trumbull since he was placed in charge of the property.

Detective Sergeant McNaught of Capt. O'Brien's staff and George S. Dougherty, Assistant Superintendent of Pinkerton's National Detective Agency, lodged in the Tombs yesterday a man of good family, and formerly of good position, who has made himself widely known as Alonzo J. Whiteman, alias Delafield, alias Whiting. The crime for which he was arrested was committed last month, under the name of J.H. Williams.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Benjamin R. Sargent, the conductor of the West End Street Railway car which was caught in Thursday's explosion, died at 1:40 o'clock this afternoon at the Emergency Hospital. The physicians at this hospital this afternoon reported Paul Hackett, who has two broken legs, as getting along nicely.

Coroner Dobbs held a preliminary examination yesterday afternoon into the circumstances attending the death of James P. Kernochan, who was knocked down and injured fatally last Monday in Fifth Avenue by an open wagon driven by Miss Florence T. Baker.

The Teachers College was founded eight years ago for the purpose of creating a more intelligent and active interest in public education, of establishing an institution for the scientific study of the educational problems of the time, and for training supervisors and teachers of all grades of schools.

RIVERTON, N.J., March 6. -- L.C. Davenport of the Carteret Gun Club, New York defeated A.D. Williams, a non-resident member of the Riverton Club, on the grounds of the latter to-day in a 100-bird match for $250. The conditions were thirty yards rise and fifty yards boundary. F.C. Arnold of the Riverton Club was referee.

Chicago bankers just now are having numerous discussions among themselves on the question of reducing the interest rate on country balances from 2 to 1 1/2 per cent. As yet no agreement has been reached, and there seems to be much opposition to the plan. Conferences continue, however, and there are hopes that eventually some good will come of the matter.

The big armory of the Seventy-first Regiment, at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, echoed with this slogan yesterday afternoon when Bernard won the beautiful silver cup offered to the school scoring the greatest number of points at the first scholastic indoor games of this season. The Harlem boys were hard pushed by Pingry School of Elizabeth, N.J., and were beaten three points by Berkeley School.

Louis N. Parker's new play, "The Mayflower," which is understood to be a romantic drama in three acts, with a strong comic interest, will be produced at the Lyceum Theatre to-morrow night. Only the main theme, the emigration of the Pilgrim others, is historical. The incidents of the play are purely imaginary.

Within two weeks, it is promised, there will be established in this city a public electric cab service. The service will be started with twelve vehicles of the coupe, surrey, and hansom patterns, operated with electric storage batteries. The vehicles are all handsomely constructed and finished, and are equipped with pneumatic tires.

Boston is bullish again on Atchison securities. It is admitted that some of the foreign holders of stocks have been selling out, but, according to the New England interests in the property, there are more stockholders in the company now than ever hitherto, showing recent acquisitions by the general public on an extensive scale.

" Suicide, of course," was the brief opinion of the police officers of the Twenty-first Precinct Station yesterday, when the fact was made known of the finding of the body of Mrs. Ann McCarthy floating in the East River, at the Thirty-fourth Street Ferry slip. The fact of the discovery was reported by Policeman Kerns shortly before 1 o'clock, and the body was viewed by Coroner Tuthill, after which it was carried to the Morgue.

A week of comparative quietness has followed several which were more lively than usual in the club world of New York. Pool tournaments, some private dinners, and one or two art receptions have been the only events or incidents worthy of record since Sunday last. The centre of club activity in the country was transferred early in the week from New York to New Orleans and Washington.

It looks very much as if history were repeating itself in the relations between Greece and Russia. The first effective measures for Greek freedom from the Sultan were taken early in the century by an association called the Hetairia, comprising a number of influential and patriotic Greeks in Asia Minor and Greece, who were also in communication with Europe.

ELMIRA, N.Y. March 6. -- A wagon containing Lawrence L. Lavancher, wife, and a fifteen-year-old son of Fasset's, Penn., was struck at Fentons Crossing, near this city, shortly before noon to-day by a Northern Central train. Lavancher was instantly killed and the wife and son fatally injured.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Stilson Hutchins bought The Washington Times Dec. 12. Today he filed a bill in equity against Charles G. Conn, from whom he purchased it, and against Jackson H. Ralston and Frederick L. Siddons. Trustees, to rescind the contract for the purchase.
BOSTON, March 6. -- Transit in Boston has come to be a problem fraught with most staggering perplexities.

Ex-Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy was not a guest of the Reform Club last night at the dinner given at the clubhouse. The Committee on Municipal Administration had arranged the dinner, and chosen as the subject for discussion "The Greater New York Charter." Among the gentlemen invited to be the guests of the club were the members of the Charter Commission.

The Rev. E.L. Fox, pastor of the Eleventh Street Methodist Episcopal Church, near Avenue B, is working very energetically and successfully among the boys and men of the east side, and his aides are doing equally good work for the mothers and babies in that district.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Secretary Long of the navy reached the department about 11:30 o'clock. He received the bureau officers, the chiefs of divisions, the clerks, and several hundred visitors who were about the corridors. Ex-Secretary Herbert stood with his successor. The officers and clerks were first introduced to Secretary Long, after which they passed to the ex-Secretary and bade him farewell.

One of the most interesting meetings of the Colonial Dames of the State of New York this season was held at the house of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Tuesday. Mrs. Vanderbilt came to New York from Washington to entertain the society, of which she has been a member for about a year.

Prof. Prince of the New York University reports that friends of his have just presented to the Semitic Department a valuable collection of ancient Babylonian tablets which were found at Tello, in Southern Babylonia, in 1895, and recently sent to this country for sale. There are in all 204 Pieces, the most important of which is a very uncommon black baked clay cylinder, inscribed in old Babylonian characters.

ALBANY, March 6. -- State Superintendent of Banking F.D. Kilburn to-day announced that the recently embarrassed German-American Bank of Tonawanda will open Monday morning for business. Depositors owning $225,000 of the deposits, out of a total of $401,000, have agreed to wait at least a year for one-half their money and two years for the other half.

The Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Teachers College, Mr. SPENCER TRASK, and the Treasurer, Miss GRACE H. DODGE, make an appeal to the public in our columns this morning which we have no doubt will find a prompt response. In our judgment, it should find one both prompt and generous.

When Congress meets in extraordinary session to study how customs revenue can be increased by preventing imports, the Ways and Means Committee of the House will be met by a committee of the New England Shoe and Leather Association. This committee and the association it represents are not beggars.

POMONA, Cal., March 6. -- What would the tobogganists of the East say of a toboggan slide fifty long miles! Think of sliding down a chute that extends from arctic to semi-tropic regions -- through snow-clad and icebound canons, around rocky fastnesses, over foaming cascades and rushing rivers, and then through vineyards and orange groves, and landing amid gardens of roses and lilies.

THE days of the large quartos are not altogether past, although their numbers long since had begun to grow less. The practical spirit of the age has called more and more for books that may be easily handled and easily read.

The announcement made yesterday that the Gerlach Hotel, in West Twenty-seventh Street, was to be transformed into a "Home Club" must have struck as very singular New Yorkers whose recollections go back more than a decade. Some twelve or fifteen years ago the "home club," or "associated dwelling," seemed to a considerable number of people a desirable form of investment.

CINCINATI, Ohio, March 6. -- Scores of homes ruined, immense loss to property, and great suffering is the record for one day as a result of the second flood within a month in this city. All the creeks and larger streams in this vicinity have overflowed their banks, and the mad rush of waters carried houses, bridges, trees, and everything that offered an obstruction before them.

There are indications that the mass meeting in Cooper Union next Thursday night in favor of the arbitration treaty will test the capacity of that hall. The call for this demonstration bears the signatures of more than 200 preeminent citizens. That the meeting will be in no sense a class, sectarian, or partisan one is shown by the representative character of the speakers and the signers of the call.

The Lotus Club held its final Saturday night entertainment of the season at its rooms, on Fifth Avenue, last night, and presented a programme of excellent variety and artistic merit. Floral decorations were profusely arranged in tasteful designs.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- Little has been seen of the Clevelands since their arrival. With the exception of a daily drive for the benefit of the children, Mrs. Cleveland has remained at home, busying herself with the final arrangements of the new home. Before her arrival several of the family servants had been here some days, putting in order the furnishings which were sent on last week.
The successful run of "Secret Service" at the Garrick Theatre was brought to a close last night. The house was crowded.

Last week was the best of the year for real estate from a broker's point of view. The aggregate investment reported, including trades, was over $3,200,000, and it is safe to say that were the full details of the business accomplished at private contract made public that sum would be increased at least one-third.

LONDON, March 6. -- A dispatch from Madrid to the Central News says that President McKinley's inaugural address has not caused much of an impression in Spain. The ministerial newspapers in their comments mistrust the reserve of the new President, and public opinion is very suspicious in view of McKinley's antecedents and the attitude which Secretary Sherman recently manifested in the United States Senate.

LONDON, March 6. -- At last the ordeal for which a terrified Europe has been preparing for a quarter of a century seems really at hand. On all sides, in every capital, it is taken for granted today that Armageddon is upon us. Even now, however, events may not keep pace with the excited expectations of the man in the street.
Three distinct funeral rites are observed by the natives of India -- the Hindus, the Parsees, and the Mohammedans.

The examination of CECIL RHODES, now concluded, has established his full responsibility for all the acts which have endangered the peace of South Africa, and which the Boers have been justified in resenting. But it seems that their resentment has carried them to unwarrantable lengths.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 6. -- An insane man named James Stevens, in charge of two attendants, created a sensational scene at Fishkill Landing Station of the Hudson River Railroad this afternoon. Stevens asked permission to go into a closet, which was granted, and when he came out he was told to button up his vest.

Senator Thomas C. Platt and Mrs. Platt returned from Washington yesterday afternoon. They were driven to the Fifth Avenue Hotel. When asked for his views on politics in general, last night, the Senator said, in substance:

BERLIN, March 6. -- The authorities of the Foreign Office here continue to express confidence in the ultimate submission of Greece to the demands of the powers for the withdrawal of the Greek fleet and troops from Crete, though the King and Government of Greece, for reasons of domestic policy, may go to the most extreme verge of war with Turkey before complying with the requirements of the powers' demands.

We observe with interest that our esteemed freak contemporaries are contending with each other for the contributions of Mr. BRYAN. The World published his survey of the state of the Nation at the same time with that of his successful competitor. This was undoubtedly "good newspaper," and we have already made some comments upon Mr. BRYAN'S views.

It was at the performance of "Secret Service." The thrilling moment had come when Mr. Gillette as Capt. Thorn was coming down the stairs, having been tried and about to be shot. But the audience knew there was even then a chance of escape, for it had seen the old darky bite the bullet from every cartridge in the soldiers' guns, stacked in the lower room.

The Rev. Dr. Rudolph Grossman was installed as rabbi of the Temple Rodolph Sholom, at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street, yesterday forenoon, in the presence of a congregation that completely filled the spacious edifice. Rabbi Kaufman Kohler of the Temple Beth-El, with whom Dr. Grossman has been associated as assistant, delivered the charge to the new rabbi.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 6. -- The Mississippi River this morning was rising at the rate of four inches an hour, and at noon the gauge marked twenty-two feet, or within six feet of the danger line.

BUDA-PESTH, Feb. 21. -- Not even the recent thrilling developments in the East have been able to divert public opinion in Hungary from the subject of paramount interest to every Magyar heart -- the renewal of the Austro-Hungarian compromise. This is easy to understand for any one who is versed in the interior politics of this dual empire.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 18, 1897. -- Referring to the coming exhibition, which will be opened on the 15th of March, and from which all Guatemala expects the most favorable results, it must be remembered that this republic has had great difficulties to contend with, and, considering its limited means of communication, inexperience, and other disadvantages, it has displayed an amount of energy unequaled, perhaps, by, any other country.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Consul Coughly, at Messina, reports to the State Department that a man shot himself at Reggio, Feb. 3, whose death is wrapped in so much mystery that no end of curiosity has been caused. He was apparently an American, as indicated by the following unsigned note left by him:

Gen. Julio Sanguily, the American who, after two years in a Cuban prison, was recently pardoned and released through the efforts of Consul General Lee, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon. He was accompanied by his wife, his son, Julie Sanguily, Jr.; his nephew, Enrique Diaz, and Col. Manuel Le Chuga.

The stock market wants to go up. Many indications of this are apparent. Influences of consequence are back of such tendencies. Obstacles in the way are conspicuous, but may not be substantial enough to last.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 6. -- One of the most unique gifts ever received by Princeton University is from Laurence Hutton, the writer, of New York, and was announced to-day. This present is a collection of over sixty death masks of distinguished men. It is said to be the only collection of its kind in existence.

BERLIN, March 6. -- A collision between the Government and the Reichstag over the Government's demands for a large naval credit for the purpose of increasing the naval strength of the empire is inevitable. Dr. Lieber, the leader of the Centre, or, Clerical, Party in the Chamber, declares that the Centrists will uncompromisingly resist the demands, and both of the Freisinnige factions and some of the National Liberals will also oppose them.

-- A Washington paper prints a story, much more sensational than definite, about a very high-flying poker club in which it declares some statesmen well known all over the country have been ruining themselves at the National Game. According to this tale the club is composed of about twenty Representatives, two or three Senators, and a few semi-professional gamblers of political proclivities.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 6. -- Nearly all trains entering this city are late to-day because of the floods over the State. The Big Four, Cincinnati Division, is one of the worst sufferers, though the through Vandalia trains are also badly delayed The Big Four train on the Peoria, Division, which left here at 7:25 Friday night, got no further than Morefield, Ind., seven miles west.

LONDON, March 6. -- Mr. Arthur J. Balfour, the Government leader in the House of Commons, has taken advantage of the weakness of the Irish leaders to chouse them out of all effective discussions of the Irish financial grievances. The one great Irish question of the session is virtually shelved, so far as it can be made use of against the Government's new Financial Relations Commission.

Mr. MARTIN, member of Assembly from Barton County, Mo., living at a considerable distance from any of the navigable waters of this Republic, may be pardoned for the ignorance he displays in the resolutions prepared and introduced by him condemning ex-President CLEVELAND for the "confiscation" of the lighthouse tender Maple and for the indulgence of his unholy passion for duck shooting "at the public expense."

The work of revising the new drill regulations for the army has been completed. The book contains many important changes. All movements are explained much more elaborately than formerly. The old double-column formation is restored, and movements in single rank are authorized, but double rank formations are the rule.

Clarence A. Henriques, Bridge Trustee for this city, has put himself on record as strongly opposing the scheme indorsed by the committee of experts to run surface and elevated railroad cars across the Brooklyn Bridge. Mr. Henriques said last night that after long and careful consideration he had decided to make public his opposition to the scheme.

There was a large attendance at the regular monthly meeting of the New York League of Unitarian Women at the Lenox Avenue Unitarian Church on Friday. Delegates were present from Plainfield, Staten Island, Montclair, Yonkers, and Brooklyn. Mrs. E.C. Low of Brooklyn presided.

TALLAHASSE, Fla., March 6. -- John A. Henderson, General Consul and Vice President of the Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad, to-day received the ad interim appointment of United States Senator to succeed Mr. Call, whose time expired March 4. This was a great surprise to many politicians throughout the State, and some curiosity is felt over its result.

LONDON, March 6. -- The correspondent of The Chronicle in Athens telegraphed at midnight last night that there is reason to believe that the situation is improving, adding that more than one power has intimated in an unofficial way that if Greece is willing to meet the powers half way, it is still possible for her to escape from a difficult situation in an amicable way.

Arrangements for the erection of a new City Prison to take the place of the Tombs are fast nearing completion. Plans and specifications have already been drawn, and are merely waiting to be approved before the contracts for the building are given out; and the historic structure so closely associated with New York criminal annals will soon sink into oblivion.
The afternoon and evening programme of lectures to be given during the week by the various departments of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences will include the following speakers and subjects:

Nearly 1,5000 persons assembled at Cooper Union Hall last night to hear Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring's lecture on "Sanitary Relations of Cleanliness," delivered under the auspices of the Board of Education. Dr. Leipziger presided at the meeting, and the speaker of the evening was heartily applauded.
In the opinion of city politicians who are watching the progress of the Stoop-Line bill Assemblyman Finn's political future depends on the final success of this measure.

The first annual report of the Commissioners of Fisheries, Game, and Forests was made to the Legislature more than a year ago. It covered a period of more than five months -- from April 25, 1895, the date of the organization of the commission, to Sept. 30, 1895. The second annual report, to Sept. 30, 1896, has just been presented at Albany.

In a recent lecture before the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences Prof. Amos P. Brown told of interesting experiments in the way of making gems from their natural constituents, and the whole matter of the transmutation of minerals. From the lecture these excerpts are taken:

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 6. -- The foreign Ambassadors here presented a collective note to the Porte on Thursday requiring the withdrawal of the Turkish troops from the interior of the Island of Crete to the coast towns. The Sultan was also notified that it had been decided by the powers to abolish the international gendarmerie in Crete.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 6. -- There was a time in the history of South Carolina when it was an easy matter to say who would be the next Governor or Senator. A close corporation attended to these matters with a mutual understanding that the members should take turns at office holding, and there was no trouble whatsoever about it.

" Clothing and the Care of the Skin" was the subject of Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders's lecture before the Brooklyn Institute last week. The greater part of the afternoon was devoted to the treatment of the skin.

Mr. Curie J. Blenner will open a loan exhibition of his portraits and other paintings in the small ballroom of the Waldorf tomorrow afternoon. The exhibition will remain open until Saturday evening next. There will be tea and music at the opening of the exhibition to-morrow afternoon.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 6. -- At Lakewood Lent has come to be regarded almost as a season in itself. The indications for a fine Lenten season, which were apparent some time ago, have been more than realized this week. This is especially pleasing to hotel managers, since a late Easter will carry the prosperity well into the Spring.

An explosion in a cab Saturday night which broke the glass of the cab windows and tore into shreds some of the clothing of Jacob Schnitzer, the only occupant, is shrouded in mystery, though the police worked on it all day yesterday. The Bureau of Explosives, to which the problem will be submitted to-day, may not throw much light upon it.
CHICAGO, March 7. -- Prof. J.E. Bergsten arrived in Chicago from Amelia, Holt County, Neb., to-day, bringing his means of locomotion with him.

The east side had a brilliant wedding yesterday evening at the Chaari Zedek Synagogue, 38 Henry Street. The bride was Miss Sadie Cohen, the favorite daughter of Harris Cohen, the head of the east side merchants of that name.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 7. -- A fleet of United States men-of-war have suddenly made their appearance in Carrabelle Harbor, fifty miles from this city. The Marblehead, the Montgomery, and the Texas are there, and rumor has it that others have been ordered there.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 7. -- Mrs. Juliet Riley of Muncie, Ind., has in her possession a letter written by Cotton Mather, one of the first Colonial Governors of Massachusetts, in which he vigorously excoriates the Quakers and proposes a plan by which their leader, William Penn, may be captured.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The powers are in no wise agreed among themselves as to the precise terms upon which an autonomous administration of the affairs of the Island of Crete shall be established, nor are they in concert of opinion as to how far Turkey shall be allowed to provoke war in the Balkan Peninsula by massing troops on her frontiers.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Rylance preached yesterday morning in St. Mark's Church, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, on "Foolish and Perverse Handlings of the Bible." He read from the One Hundred and Nineteenth Psalm the words: "Thy Word is tried to the uttermost," and said that the Bible to-day is being sorely tried by friends as well as enemies.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 7. -- The alleged decision of Land Commissioner Lamoreaux in favor of the McKee scrip claimants, involving property here worth $50,000,000, created great surprise, and many doubts are raised as to the genuineness of the document, although Charles Bary, one of the attorneys for the scrip holders, insists that what he gave the press is a true copy of the original.

" Religion of To-day" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's lecture before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning. Prof. Adler has just returned from Chicago, where he has been for the past month, and in honor of his return a special musical programme was arranged for the morning exercises. The opening hymn, "Save Me, My God," furnished the lecturer with the text for his discourse.

The summary of Senator Brush's bill in regard to military instruction in the public schools, which has been telegraphed from Albany, while correctly stating the general details of the bill, conveys an erroneous, impression. That is, that the bill requires that all the pupils over eleven years of age must be enrolled by the Principals as members of the American Guard.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Representative A.M. Dockery of Missouri, in a "leave to print" speech which is to be published in Tuesday's Congressional Record, attacks the Fifty-fourth Congress for its expenditures in strong terms. He says, in part:

The American Line steamship St. Louis arrived yesterday from Southampton after the longest voyage she has yet made. Her time was 8 days 5 hours 3 minutes, the average hourly speed being 15.82 knots. Her record, made in August last, was 6 days 2 hours and 24 minutes, with an average speed of 20.87 knots.

Four young colored men of Coney Island were cast away upon the unhospitable rocks of Plum Island during the storm of last Wednesday and nearly succumbed to cold and exposure before being rescued. One of the men, Edward Pierson, is in a precarious condition, and the others, "Buck" Jones, "San" French, and Frank Peters, will long remember their experience.

LONDON, March 7. -- A large Radical meeting was held in Hyde Park to-day, to give voice to the feeling in favor of Greece which generally obtains among the masses of England. Among the speakers were Joseph Havelock Wilson, member of Parliament for Middlesborough, and Edward J. Morton, member of Parliament for Devonport.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 7. -- It is declared in official circles here that an examination of the treaty just signed at Washington by Secretary of State Olney and the British Ambassador, Sir Julian Pauncefote, for the delimitation of the boundary between the Canadian Northwest Territories and Alaska makes an important surrender to the United States of what is here held to be indisputably Canadian territory.

Commissioner GRANT said the other day that the Legislature ought to take action to put an end to the strife in the Police Board. Action should be taken, that is certain, but not by the Legislature. There is a shorter and a safer way.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 7. -- Maggie Kennedy, a former queen of the circus ring, transformed her bed into a funeral pyre this morning, and was literally cooked to death. She saturated her bed with kerosene oil, lay down upon it, and then touched a match to the oil, making no attempt to escape from the flames she had started.

Being a connoisseur and collector of old lace, I must take exception to several statements made in the article on lace published in THE TIMES Supplement of Feb. 28. Your writer speaks of "Honiton" lace being worn by a gentleman who impersonated Francis I., and as being singularly appropriate, as it was a lace much affected by men of that period."

Though the disappointment at the failure of Yale and Harvard to join with Cornell, Pennsylvania, and Columbia in a five-sided race has been keenly felt by all followers of the white and blue, they have taken the matter philosophically and have settled down to do their best against Cornell and Pennsylvania.

The Central Labor Union had an animated discussion yesterday over the bill of Senator Ellsworth of Lockport to prohibit the publication in any newspaper, book, or pamphlet, of any portrait or caricature of any person without his or her written consent.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 7. -- The country along every watercourse in Central and Southern Indiana presents a scene of unprecedented devastation. The waters began to recede yesterday, and along the miles and miles of railroad tracks on the dozen different lines that have been washed out it soon appeared that the reported damage was little more than a forecast of the real destruction to railroad property.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Yesterday's caucus of Republican Senators and some admissions made by leading Republicans make it apparent that there is not a strong conviction in the Republican mind that the party will be able to obtain just the legislation it wants from the extra session of the Fifty-fifth Congress, and that it will be necessary to wait for two years before anything decisive can be done.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 7. -- Paymaster John Corwine, United States Navy, who left the naval station last Monday and was arrested in Chicago Wednesday, was brought here this afternoon and waived the reading of a warrant charging him with obtaining $5,000 from the First National Bank under false pretenses.

ALBANY, March 7. -- This promises to be a busy week on the Legislature. The Annual Appropriation bill, which passed the Assembly some time ago, will be passed by the Senate this week, and a Conference Committee will then be appointed by each house to consider the changes made by the Senate in the appropriations for the different State departments.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 7. -- Prospects for a mammonth cotton acreage this year have become alarming. State Commissioner of Agriculture Culver has issued to the farmers a note of warning. He says present indications point to a twelve-million-bale crop, and that means 4 cent cotton.

In the preliminary scheme for the celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the foundation of Trinity Parish, which will take place two months hence, it is re marked that, besides the public rejoicings, "the occasion would seem to require for completeness some fine act of beneficence by corporation, or people, or both, in celebration of God's so great goodness and loving kindness during two centuries."

If, in the break-up of the European concert, Germany and Russia should be found acting together, and France, released from the fetters with which her pride and longing for revenge have bound her to Russia, should seek her natural alliance with Great Britain, it would be an enormous gain for France and for civilization.

A strike is threatened for to-day of the men who are working upon the new buildings of Columbia University, at Morningside Heights. For over two weeks the plumbers and the steamfittters have been at outs, and nightly sessions of their unions and efforts on the part of walking delegates have failed to patch up the differences.

ALBANY, March 7. -- There has just come from the press one of the handsomest State reports New York State has ever issued -- that of State Botanist Charles F. Peck. A large part of this report treats of boleti, with colored plates, showing the edible and poisonous fungi.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Senator Hale of Maine expresses a high opinion of the reform measures recently promulgated by the Spanish Government for Cuba, and does not see how the reasonable and patriotic men among the insurgents can fail to accept the reforms as affording a liberal measure of local self-government.

A committee for the Mott Haven Local Improvement Association and a number of property owners and residents of the north side have petitioned the Legislature through their counsel, Adam Frank, to defeat Senate Bill No. 31, which provides for the use of the temporary Macomb's Dam Bridge by the "Huckleberry Railroad" for a term of five years.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Virginia and New York exchanged some graceful courtesies last Thursday, and one instance of the good will existing between the Old Dominion and the Empire State is worth printing as a part of the history of the inaugural parade.

" Nothing has ever been made plainer at a general election than that the controlling principle in the raising of revenues from duties on imports is zealous care for American interests and American labor. The people have declared that such legislation will be had as will give ample protection and encouragement to the industries and the development of our country." -- President MCKINLY'S Inaugural Address.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 7. -- The diplomats here have received the answer of the Porte to the collective note presented on Tuesday last setting forth the desires of the powers regarding the granting of autonomy to Crete under the suzerainty of Turkey. The Porte assents to the terms of the powers, and says it hopes that there will be a definite understanding between itself and the powers respecting the details of the autonomy to be granted.

The President's call for an "extra" session -- that is a queer slip for Mr. SHERMAN to let him make; the conventional term has always been "extraordinary" -- fixes the date at next Monday. It is plainly his intention to confine Congress to such measures as he may recommend, and in theory he has that power.
A decision was arrived at in Senator Platt's parlors yesterday to legislate out of office the present Board of Police Commissioners of the City of New York.

A great diversity of opinion prevails among wholesale fruit dealers and handlers in this city, concerning the increase in duty rates on tropical fruits, varieties of which are growing in this country, as agreed upon recently at Washington by the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House.

The Volunteers of America will celebrate their first anniversary to-night with a monster demonstration at Association Hall, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Commander Booth has at last consented to break the long silence in regard to the Salvation Army, and in reviewing the progress of the new movement, he will prove that the events of the past twelve months have fully justified his action, which culminated in his separation from the Army.

Mr. CARL SCHURZ has in the current number of Harper's Weekly a strong article on "The Quadrennial Disgrace." He describes with the sober emphasis of one who has both seen and experienced it the onset of office seekers on a new Administration. He makes this simple, practical, though radical, proposition of policy for Mr. McKINLEY:

The Greek Church, at 340 West Fifty-third Street, was the centre of interest yesterday to all the Hellenes in this city. It was known that the call to arms addressed to Greeks here would be read at the service. It had been posted Saturday, however, in the restaurants and other resorts frequented by the Greeks.

The petition for a mandamus to compel Commissioner of Public Works Collis to remove sidewalk obstructions on Vesey Street, which is to come up before Judge Lawrence in the Supreme Court to-day, was filed by L.J. Callanan in January. Argument has been deferred from time to time for one reason and another, but the expectation of all the parties to the case is that the attorneys will be heard to-day.

HYERES, March 7. -- A large crowd witnessed the yacht race here to-day for the Town Prize of 1,550 francs. The sun was shining brightly. At the start the wind was fluky, but later settled into a fine westerly breeze. The course was the same as that sailed over yesterday -- three times around an eight-mile triangle.

TACOMA, Wash., March 7. -- Business interests of this State are greatly alarmed over what was apparently a mistake of President Cleveland, when, on Feb. 22, he, under authority vested by Congress, issued an Executive order, setting aside three great forestry reservations in this State.

The St. Nicholas Magazine and several newspapers, in referring to the recent inauguration, announce Major McKinley as the twenty-fifth President of the United States. This is an error which I will thank you to afford me space to correct. The Presidential term upon which we have just entered is the twenty-eighth, and will include the Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Congresses.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- President McKinley's first Sunday in the White House was a quiet one. No callers were received, and the President had an opportunity of resting from the fatigues of the week. He arose later than usual, much refreshed from a hard day's work on Saturday, Breakfast was served at 9 o'clock.

BERLIN, March 7. -- In the course of his speech before the Budget Committee of the Reichstag on Friday in advocacy of the Government's demand for a large credit to be devoted to increasing the strength of the navy, Admiral Hollmann, the head of the Imperial Admiralty, mentioned an "oberste kriegsleitung," or chief conductor of war measures, as approving the credit asked for.

The most interesting and trustworthy reports on the Greek-Cretan situation come from HENRY NORMAN of The London Chronicle, who is in Athens, doing for his paper as solid work as he did for it in Washington at the time of the Venezuela difficulty. One important point in his dispatches is confirmed by the Berlin dispatches of The London Times.
The following warning appeared in a religious paper Saturday:
GREENFIELD, Mass., March 7. -- The powder house of Sheldon Newcomb, on the outskir s of the village, was set on fire by boys this afternoon.

MONTREAL, March 8. -- The cabled report from Rome of the appointment of Mgr. Raffaele Merry Del Val as Papal Ablegate to Canada is confirmed by private cablegrams received in this city and Ottawa to-day. It is understood that Mgr. Del Val will sail for Canada within a few days.

BALTIMORE, March 8. -- The Baltimore annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church put itself on record on the arbitration question to-day. The subject was first mentioned in the missionary sermon and afterward resolutions were introduced and passed unanimously.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Mr. Murphy's bill, providing that the Common Council of New York shall have the power to grant permits for the erection of news and flower booths, met with some opposition in the Assembly to-night from Democratic Leader Finn, who feared this authority might be exercised to the detriment of the owners of similar booths.

Lieut. W.H. Stayton, commander of the Fourth Division of the Naval Militia, has resigned, owing to a difference with Commander J.W. Miller, and his resignation was yesterday made the excuse for some sensational stories about the Naval Militia which, it was asserted, threatened the existence of that organization.

There was a dramatic scene at the meeting of the New York Presbytery, in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, yesterday afternoon, when Pastor Herman Warszawiak of the American Mission to the Hebrews sprang to his feet and in an impassioned manner demanded to be heard in defense of his character.

It is a pretty shallow pretense for grown men to keep up that the Constitution of this State requires the Police Board of this city to be bi-partisan, when the Police Department of Brooklyn is single-headed, and when the Court of Appeals has practically held that the Legislature ha no Constitutional right to circumscribe the power of appointment with any political requirement.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- During the executive session of the Senate this afternoon Senator Davis moved to refer the general treaty of arbitration between the United States and Great Britain, which is now on the table, back to the Committee on Foreign Relations, together with the pending amendments.

The sentence of Capt. HART, the owner of the steamer Laurada, to two years' imprisonment and a fine of $500 is severe. In sentencing him, Judge BUTLER took occasion to make an explanation of the gravity of his crime which ought to be extensively read and pondered. It is the duty of our Government to use due diligence to prevent the departure of filibustering expeditions from our shores against a friendly nation.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- In disposing of the case of the yacht Conquerer, the property of F.W. Vanderbilt of New York, the Supreme Court of the United States to-day announced, through Mr. Justice Brown, its opinion that yachts are not subject to duty under the tariff law.

Kind words were spoken and subscriptions given in encouragement of the Volunteers of America at last night's anniversary meeting in Association Hall, Twenty-third Street. It is a year since Commander Ballington Booth severed his connection with the Salvation Army and started this new organization. In his first annual report, presented last night, he claimed that they were making substantial progress, and that 18,000 persons had professed conversion at their meetings during the year.

Richard Mansfield disposed of his lease of the Garrick Theatre yesterday to his Managers, Hoyt McKee. It is not known what arrangements will be made between Messrs. Hoyt McKee and Mr. Frohman, but it is said that Mr. Frohman will remain in control of the house until the end of the present season.

Mr. Walter Damrosch's season of grand opera in German began at the Metropolitan Opera, House in a most auspicious manner. There was a large audience, which welcomed old favorites with joy and greeted new-comers with enthusiasm, and which filled the house at all times with its feeling of happiness.

" The Mayflower," a new three-act play, written by Louis N. Parker, one of the authors of "Gudgeons" and "Rosemary," was produced at the Lyceum Theatre last night. The performance was received with every manifestation of favor. The author was called out twice after his "great" climax, at the end of his second act, and both his play and the acting were noisily applauded.

The struggle that is going on to restore the sidewalks of New York to their legitimate use for the people of the city affords an illustration of the manner in which an old abuse becomes sanctified by long familiarity and makes claims to vested right when in fact it is only a vested wrong.

ALBANY, March 8. -- A bill has been prepared at Buffalo, and will be introduced by Senator Lamy and Assemblyman Braun, to provide for press censorship in this State. The text of the bill is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, March 8. -- John D. Hart of this city, who was convicted in the United States District Court on Feb. 23 on the charge of aiding in a Cuban filibustering expedition on the steamer Laurada in August last, was to-day informed by Judge Butler that a new trial was refused, and Hart was sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary, $500 fine, and the costs of prosecution.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Secretary Long started in at the Navy Department today with an appointment which meets general approval from those who believe in civil service reform.

The arbitration treaty loses a friend in the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee by the promotion of Senator SHERMAN and an enemy by the retirement of Senator CAMERON. Senator DAVIS of Minnesota advances to the Chairmanship held by Mr. SHERMAN, but there remain two Republican vacancies to be filled.

ALBANY, March 8. -- The application of the Metropolitan Traction Company for permission to change its motive power on certain of its lines to the underground trolley system will be considered by the State Railroad Commission at a meeting to be held on Wednesday morning at 11 o'clock, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, in New York City.

'' Jim the Penman '' is the week's play at the Grand Opera House. Edward Emery appears in E.M. Holland's old role of the detective, George Edgar plays the part of James Ralston. May Sargent acts the role of Agnes, and J. C. Dixon and Marie Edith Rice are also in the cast.

It is a well known fact that a large percentage of whiskies upon the market and in use to-day are simply cheap adulterations. They may be called "straight goods," "blends," or any other name that an unscrupulous manufacturer or dealer chooses, but the fact remains that they are simply concoctions and adulterations which are injurious to any one who uses them.
PARIS, March 8. -- Marie Van Zandt, the American opera singer, has been nominated by the Government as an officer of the French Academy.

GRIFFIN, Ga., March 8. -- An important lawsuit was ended in the City Court of Griffin that will prove of interest in professional and railroad circles.
