The question was as to what are the rights of passengers holding round-trip tickets of the iron-clad kind, when the validating agent declines to accept the statement and evidence of the holder of the ticket that he is the original purchaser, and demands that it be validated.

Johan Gustaf Rinnblad committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the head while two Deputy United States Marshals and Mr. Woxen, the Swedish Consul, were pounding on the door of his room at the Astor House and demanding that he surrender. They held a warrant issued for his arrest at the cabled request of the Swedish Government.

It is interesting to remark that "labor leaders" are quoted as opposing the appointment of Col. HAY to be Ambassador to England, upon the ground that he wrote "The Breadwinners." It is quite conceivable that a "labor leader" should not enjoy that not yet forgotten work, but it is at least an open question whether his failure to enjoy it could be the fault of the author or of the labor leader.

Edward Lauterbach, President of the Republican County Committee, who was selected Sunday by the party leaders in their conference with Senator Platt to draft a bill to "legislate out of office" the present Police Commissioners of this city, began work on the proposed measure yesterday.
LONDON, March 8. -- The Chronicle tomorrow will publish a dispatch from Athens giving the full text of the reply of Greece to the powers. After a brief preamble, the reply continues:

" Are all the doctors criminals?" was the subject of a paper read by Lawyer Stephen C. Baldwin before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at a meeting held last night in the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street.
CHICAGO, March 8. -- After the successful matinee Saturday, when "Faust" packed the Auditorium, the opera managers and the principal singers held a caucus.
ALBANY, March 8. -- In the Senate to-night the following bills were introduced:

ALBANY, March 8. -- The Senate to-night passed the bill which requires all railroads to carry members of the Legislature, Court of Appeals Judges, Supreme Court Justices, and State officers free upon the presentation of a certificate issued by the Secretary of State. There was no discussion upon the bill, except that Senator Ellsworth explained that it was intended to facilitate the performance of State business.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Japan is the next nation which will furnish the battleground for a contest between the advocates of a gold and silver standard. The report has been recently printed that the Japanese Government had adopted the gold standard, but this proves to be incorrect.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The term of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Maxwell will expire to-morrow. He was appointed March 9, 1893, to succeed E.G. Rathbone of Ohio.

Tammany has a new plan. It is going to issue manifestoes at its General Committee meetings, every month, against the management of the different city departments. Each meeting is to be devoted to one or more departments. This is part of John C. Sheehan's campaign.

The police were unable to give any solution yesterday to the mystery surrounding the explosion in a cab occupied by Jacob Schnitzer Saturday night. Acting Inspector Brooks, who had the matter in charge, said he was working on the theory that the explosion was not accidental, but could make no explanation of the ease. Mr. Willis, the owner of the cab, who has been making an investigation, could throw no further light on it.

Is there any difference in principle between portraying a person, public or private, in pictures and in words? Should a close personal description be permitted and not a portrait? May an imperfect and misleading description be given with impunity, while a defective pictorial presentment involves a penalty?

A consignment of rare and interesting books, from Bernard Quaritch of London, were put up at auction yesterday by Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue. Yesterday's offerings were the small-sized volumes. Among them were:
BALTIMORE, March 8. -- A sermon preached here yesterday by Bishop Mallalieu of Buffalo, the presiding officer of the Baltimore Methodist Episcopal Conference, has caused great stir.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- A report from the White House says that the President to-day expressed the hope that Congress would at once take steps to adopt a resolution to prevent importers from taking advantage of the existing rates of duties to import goods, and so defeat the efforts of the House and Senate to obtain greater revenue by a new tariff bill.

ALBANY, March 8. -- The report of the Lexow Trust Investigating Committee will be presented to the Senate to-morrow. It is a document of the usual length of those written by Senator Lexow, containing about 10,000 words.

LOUISVILLE, March 8. -- The Kentucky Senatorial fight is fairly on in Louisville. The hotels are filling up with politicians, and a general move will be made on Frankfort Friday, the day before the special session is called to meet. Dr. Hunter has opened headquarters at the Victoria Hotel. He has had a great many callers since his return from Washington last night.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Congressional Record to-morrow will contain a statement made by the Chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations, Mr. Joseph G. Cannon of Illinois, relative to the appropriations made by the Fifty-fourth Congress. Mr. Cannon's statement is, in part, as follows:

The sidewalk obstruction question came before Judge Lawrence in the Supreme Court yesterday on two motions, but no decision was obtained. The first on the calendar was L.J. Callanan's petition for a mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Public Works to remove the obstructions on Vesey Street. The other was the intervention motion of interested property owners and merchants, who asked to be made parties to the action.

There is difficulty in sending home the Greek reserves. King George has ordered to Athens for active war service all the reserves in America under forty-seven years of age, and they are bound to report in two months, under penalty of two years' imprisonment and a fine; but there is no money to pay their fares.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Two things of interest are noticed by persons who have begun to look about to observe the effects of a change of Administration. One is that the Cuban question has apparently ceased to provoke any warlike sentiments at the Capitol, and the other is that the arbitration treaty seems to be in the way of approval.

Further testimony was given yesterday for the prosecution in the suit on trial before Justice Bookstaver in the Supreme Court, in which Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan is seeking to recover $50,000 damages from Mrs. Kate M. Foster for the alienation of the affections of her husband, Dr. Alexander Buchanan, now dead.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 8. -- Mrs. Henry Ward Beecher died at 10:42 o'clock this morning at the home of her son-in-law, the Rev. Samuel Scoville, at 38 South Street, this city, where she had hovered between life and death for many weeks. It was just ten years ago to-day, and almost exactly at the same hour, that her husband passed away.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The whereabouts of the Rev. E.J.O. Millington, the Baptist clergyman who disappeared a week ago, is still unknown, but it is believed by many of his parishioners that he has eloped with a Mrs. Dickerson.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Executive Committee of the National Republican Committee held a short session this evening. A full membership was not present, and another meeting will be held in a few days.

Ever since HOGARTH English art has abounded, 'and ever since SHAKESPEARE English literature has abounded, with the unhappy fate of strolling players. This trite theme has for some years been worn still more threadbare by the American humorist, to whom "one-night stands," "barn-storming," and walking home on the ties often furnish sustenance when other resources fail.

There is now notobstacle to the general arbitration treaty with Great Britain that public opinion, fully expressed, cannot overcome. The President has declared for it with a sincerity and force that leave no room for doubt that all his influence will be used for the treaty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 9. -- The ownership of $17,000,000 worth of land in California depends upon the legal construction of the word "brought." The act of Congress approved March 3, 1891, provides that no suit shall be "brought" by the United States to vacate or annul any patent to public lands issued before the date mentioned, except within five years from the passage of the act.

The police believe they have caught the brutal robber who has been spreading terror lately in Morrisania, Detectives Pepperted and Perkins of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station yesterday arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court a man whose description tallies with that given by the robber's victims.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 9. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Missouri Pacific Railway held here to-day four-fifths of the 450,000 shares were represented. The following Directors were re-elected: George J. Gould, Russell Sage, Edwin Gould, Louis Fitzgerald, John P. Mann, John G. Moore, Howard Gould, Samuel Sloan, Thomas T. Eckert, D.D. Parmley, S.H.H. Clark, C.G. Warner, and D.K. Ferguson.

The defense of Mrs. Kate M. Foster in the suit brought against her by Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan, before Justice Bookstaver in the Supreme Court, to recover $50,000 damages for the alienation of the affections of her husband, Dr. Alexander Buchanan, will be opened this morning.

Theatrical managers have been in a quandary for some time as to what means they could employ to compel chorus girls to live up to their contracts. The unusual demand that exists at the present time for full choruses and ballets for the many musical comedies that are being made ready for production has caused what managers call a "corner" in much stage performers.

Corporation Counsel Scott stated yesterday that he had been unable so far to give attention to the Finn bill. He had just returned to the city, and only learned through THE NEW YORK TIMES that the Mayor was looking to him for an opinion on the constitutionality of the bill. He said it would be several days before he would have time to give the subject the study that it demanded.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Alfred Hamilton O'Neill, claiming to be a son of James O'Neill, the actor, filed a suit against him to-day. He claims that his mother married O'Neill in 1871. She applied for a divorce, but O'Neill procured a decree to be entered that no marriage ever existed and had her bill dismissed.
CHICAGO, March 9. -- John Cram, a well-known clubman of New York, and a son-in-law of C.H. Deere, the plow manufacturer of Moline, Ill., recently had his personal baggage attached by Constable Kline.

At a regular meeting of the Association of the Bar, held last evening in the association's new quarters, in West Forty-fourth Street, James E. Carter, in the Chair, Wheeler H. Peckham read the report of the committee appointed under a resolution adopted Feb. 9, to examine the proposed Charter of the Greater New York.

Mrs. Rita Lesclade de Ruiz, the widow of Ricardo de Ruiz, who is alleged to have been murdered while confined in the jail of Guanabacoa, Cuba, on the charge of being in sympathy with the insurgents, arrived here at 9 o'clock yesterday morning on the steamship Seneca of the Ward Line, after a stormy passage of four and half days.

At the last meeting of the Conference of Charities of the City of New York, composed of active members of many of the leading philanthropic agencies of the city, there was a comparison of experiences as to the amount of destitution in this city during the present Winter, as compared with former years.

The Bar Association of this city has added its voice to the general protest against forcing through the Greater New York charter in its present defective form. Its action is the result of an examination of the commission's final draft, as careful and thorough as time would permit, by a committee of nine well-known members of the bar.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- For a little more than two hours this afternoon the Democrats of the Senate endeavored to reach some conclusion upon the question of the organization of that body. Like the Republican conference of Saturday, it was fruitless in results. Two factions in the Senate are arrayed against each other.

Every truly tender heart must bleed for the young man from Ohio whose sad ease was related in yesterday's TIMES. This was the man who "came on" for the Chiefship of the Washington police and was greeted by the President with an unfeeling inquiry when he was going back. There is no doubt that a large part of the unemployed population of Ohio has been expecting to browse upon public office for the next quadrennium.

The committee of the Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room, Limited, to which was referred the question of limiting the height of buildings, submitted its report yesterday to the Directors, and it was unanimously adopted. Copies of the report will be sent to the Governor and Legislature.

William H.W. Howell was held in $2,500 bonds in the Butler Street Police Court by Justice Tighe yesterday morning to await the action of the Grand Jury, and two bicycle manufacturing firms believe they have run to earth a very able swindler and have opened the way to breaking up an organized gang of swindlers.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 9. -- Several days ago St. John Boyle, representing the Louisville Trust Company, filed a petition asking that the foreclosure of the Louisville, New Albany and Chicago Railway be set aside, fraud and collusion being alleged, and that the sale appointed for to-morrow by the special master be postponed.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 9. -- After wandering about for nearly a week among the Catskill Mountains a fugitive from justice, Charles Green, the murderer of aged Isaac White of Keefer's Corners, Albany County, gave himself up to the Sheriff at Roxbury, Delaware County, on Monday, saying that he could stand being a fugitive no longer, and would go insane if he was not sent to jail to repeat for his crime.
The Board of Special Inquiry had passed upon his case, and the immigration officials decided that Giuseppe Mintello, a penniless immigrant, must be sent back to Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- A statement was issued by the officials of the Lehigh Valley Railroad this afternoon announcing that the Trustees of the Packer estate have arranged with Drexel Co. to fund for a period of years the entire indebtedness of the estate. In connection with this, the statement says, Drexel Co. are the voting power on all Lehigh Valley stock controlled by the estate.

Four persons lost their lives as the result of a tenement-house fire in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon about 12:35 o'clock, at the corner of Canton Street and Auburn Place. The building is a five-story brick one and is owned by L. Arensberg, the tobacconist and match importer.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The outlines of the sugar schedule were agreed upon to-day by the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee. Only two points were definitely decided, but they will form the skeleton of the entire schedule.

FIVE FORKS, Ga., March 9. -- The Brooks family of this place has had a season of joy turned into one of sorrow. Several weeks ago Bud Brooks, a son of the family, who had been absent from the home for years, returned. To welcome him the fatted calf was killed, and the neighbors were invited in. He bestowed upon his sisters valuable presents worth hundreds of dollars and to his mother he gave $350.

ALBANY, March 9. -- When the Levow trust investigating committee's report was submitted in the Senate to-day it was made a special order for Tuesday next, together with the bills which are to be introduced to carry out the recommendations of the committee.

Mrs. Elizabeth Hannon, a widow, aged forty, who had a junk shop, and lived in it, at 233 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, failed to appear at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. Mrs. Sheppard, owner of the premises, became uneasy, and knocked at the door. No answer being made, Mrs. Sheppard sent for Mrs. Mary Kelley, a sister of Mrs. Hannon, and the two women tried to get into the place, but failed.

Simeon W. Dutton, a member of the McLaughlin-Valentine-Dutton gang, was convicted yesterday, before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, of having obtained a signature to a deed of property under false representation.

John T. Williams is reported to have bought for improvement the old Cyclorama property, 131 by 150, on the southeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Nineteenth Street. Mr. Williams could not be seen yesterday, and the employes of his office were non-committal regarding the alleged purchase.

Neither the howling of Tammany, which attributes to the present Police Department the iniquities of that which preceded it, nor the scheming of PLATT to attach the police system of the metropolitan area to his State machine should be permitted to obscure the actual issue which has been raised in the Mulberry Street Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Presidential turnouts have been received -- a brougham and landau, bearing the monogram "McK" on a black ground. The carriages are fitted with rubber tires and have interior upholstery of dark morocco leather.

Greece has undoubtedly achieved "a diplomatic triumph." She has achieved it in the only way in which such a triumph is worth winning or durable -- by a clear showing that she has right on her side. In a sense it is mere madness for her to defy "the concert of Europe," and yet her failure to respond to the demand for the evacuation of Crete is in effect a defiance.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 9. -- The Germania Safety Vault and Trust Company assigned to-day as the result of the company's close connection with the suspended German National Bank, both concerns having practically the same officers until the closing of the bank and the placing of the Trust Company in the hands of a receiver.

THE TIMES receives a large number of letters commending it for refusing to publish vicious and sensational matter. We reprint below an extract from one of these letters because of the evidence it contains that the recent movement of protest against contaminating newspapers is taking a direction not hitherto generally foreseen:

ALBANY, March 9. -- The St. Lawrence and Adirondack Railway Company to-day filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of an increase of capital stock from $1,090,000 to $1,300,000. The whole amount of the company's debts, including liability to its stockholders and to the holders of the bonds, is $2,146,011.

The second and concluding day's sale of rare books from Quaritch of London by Bangs Co., 91 and 93 Fifth Avenue, yesterday had to do with large-sized volumes. Among the books disposed of, and the prices they brought, were:
ALBANY, March 9. -- Gov. Black has signed the following bills:

ALBANY, March 9. -- The Assembly Committee on Ways and Means has completed the second of the general appropriation bill, and it was sent to the printer this morning. It is known as the Supply bill, and it carries the annual appropriations for special purposes not involved in the general bill for the maintenance of the department.

ALBANY, March 9. -- The opponents of the Greater New York charter had another opportunity to be heard before the joint Cities Committees of the two houses to-night. There was quite a large delegation of them, including representatives of the various women's organizations of New York, political organizations, and attorneys of private clients.

The reduction in the Manhattan dividend was by no means a surprise to Wall Street. The stock has been sold down on rumors of such reduction for the past two weeks. And it was generally supposed that there was a very large short interest in Manhattan in anticipation of the action of the Directors. The professional element was said to be heavily short of the stock.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Assemblyman Bates to-day introduced bill providing that after Jan. 1, 1898, a tax shall be annually levied upon the gross profits and income received the previous calendar year by every citizen of the State, whether received from property rents, interests, dividends, salaries, or any source whatever. Such tax is to be one-half per cent. per annum on an income over $1,000 and less than $5,000; 1 per cent.

The report of the majority of the Lexow Trust Committee is unexpectedly moderate and lucid. There is almost no eloquence in it, and the vibration of the wheels of the car of Juggernaut is imperceptible. The obscure and difficult features of the situation are set forth with surprising candor, and the possibility that radical legislation may produce complex, unforeseen, and disastrous effects is clearly recognized.

CANEA, March 9. -- M. Baraklis, the Greek Vice Consul, the staff of the Consulate, and a number of Greek newspaper reporters embarked upon a vessel this afternoon to return to Greece, Admiral Canevaro insisting that his order that they leave the island must be obeyed.

ATHENS, March 9. -- The reply of the Greek Government to the ultimatum of the powers having been delivered to the foreign representatives here, preparations for hostilities between Greece and Turkey, which are apparently inevitable, are being hurried forward with all possible speed.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson to-day issued Order No. 1, concerning the exportation of beef. It directs that after March 15, 1897, all beef offered for transportation to European ports shall be accompanied by a certificate issued by an Inspector of the Agricultural Department, showing that the cattle from which it was produced were free from disease and the meat sound and wholesome.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Testimony was brought out before the Senate Finance Committee to-day, at a hearing on Mr. Higgins's bill for the construction of an electric lighting plant in the Capitol, which may lead to an investigation of the business of lighting the big building.
TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- In the Senate to-day the Newark Armory Appropriation bill was referred the Committee on Appropriations.

As we have already said, Mr. McKinley has at last officially announced, what Mr. Hanna was enabled to announce unofficially some time ago, that there will be an extra session of Congress. The Weekly has already expressed its opinion on this subject, and we return to it only to repeat that we believe that Mr. McKinley is beginning his administration with a mistake.

It looks as though BOSS PLATT and his minions were in earnest about putting through the infamous scheme of establishing a metropolitan Police Board for the Greater New York territory. This dastardly blow at local home rule was conceived in hypocrisy and is masked by a variety of false pretenses intended to weaken opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Gen. Russell Hastings of Bermuda, West Indies, who commanded the Twenty-third Ohio Regiment, in which President McKinley was an Officer, was knocked down by a wagon while crossing Fifteenth Street, opposite the Treasury Department, this afternoon. His right leg was fractured near the knee joint.

It seems that the Legislative Power of this State has held a secret or confidential session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and consented to the amendment of the Raines liquor tax law in deference to the rural sentiment which is so concerned for the moral and social well-being of the benighted and incapable people of first-class cities.

Frederick Zittel has sold for David E. Oppenheimer and Joseph Hamerschlag a plot of lots on the north side of Eighty-sixth Street, 60 feet west of Central Park West, 140 by 100.8, to John C. Umberfield. Six handsome dwellings will be erected on the plot.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 10. -- The Louisville and Nashville limited train southbound from Chicago was wrecked this morning at 12:30 o'clock at a point one mile south of Hazelton, Ind., and thirty-seven miles north of Evansville, on the Evansville and Terre Haute Road. Five men were killed and two seriously injured, as follows: ...

The indications are that when the Finn Stoop-line bill arrives at the Mayor's office from Albany it will receive a warm reception. Business men and taxpayers all over the city have signified their intention of entering a protest against it. Incidentally some of them will take occasion to express hostility toward all forms of street obstruction and all efforts to give it the sanction of law and municipal authority.
ALBANY, March 10. -- The Senate and Assembly Codes Committees gave a further joint hearing this afternoon on he Anti-Scalpers bill.

In his recent very instructive interview in The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore Mr. STUYVESANT FISH presents certain facts from the report of the Controller of the Currency showing the relative capital and surplus of the National and State banks in 1891 and 1896. We collate them in tabular form and commend them to those who are victims of the delusion that the National banks constitute a grasping and growing monopoly:

LONDON, March 10. -- The Daily News to-morrow will publish a dispatch from Canea saying that the Mussulmans who had been besieged at Kandamos and who have arrived at Canea, were conveyed there on board the Italian transport Trinacria, and that another vessel is expected to arrive shortly with more refugees. The force which relieved the beleaguered inhabitants of Kandamos also assisted 112 soldiers who were besieged in the Spaniako blockhouse.

The ultimate limit proposed by the committee of the Real Estate Exchange upon the height of buildings is certainly liberal enough. That body proposes to fix it at 200 feet, exempting churches and public buildings even from this regulation. On the other hand, or perhaps on the same hand, the committee proposes that the permissible height of structures not fire-proof should even be increased.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The extra session of the Senate ended this afternoon, when the Senate adjourned without day. The most important matter considered at to-day's session was the question of admitting A.T. Wood as a Senator from Kentucky.
More than 250 names of men well-known in the social, political, commercial, and religious life of the city are signed to the following call:

ALBANY, March 10. -- Assemblyman Roehr of Kings County to-day introduced a bill to issue bonds to the amount of $2,213,330.86, for the purpose of refunding the direct tax raised in 1861 "for the defense of the Union," to those who paid it.

The charity ball for the Montefiore Home for Incurables, given at Carnegie Hall last night by the Young Ladies' and Gentlemen's League, was a success. It was patronized by about 3,000 people, and nearly $10,000 was realized.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., March 10. -- A shortage running far up into the thousands has been discovered in the books of the Merchants' National Bank here, one of the oldest, most careful, and conservative banks in the State.
TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- The results of the township elections throughout the State are mixed. Neither side can claim a general victory.

Wheeler H. Peckham said: "I do not believe in patching up bills. The matter should be left alone until we get a complete charter. The idea seems to prevail, despite the protestations of the Charter Commissioners, that they were giving us a large 'measure of home rule,' that we should have to go to Albany for relief, just as we have had to do.

Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" was brought forward last night at the Metropolitan Opera House by Mr. Walter Damrosch. The performance was the first of a series of successive presentations of Wagner's music dramas in their chronological order, which will be continued at the ensuing evening performances until it reaches its conclusion with "Die Gutterdammerung."

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The office seekers down town and the Senators at the Capitol who are trusting that the applicants from their States will find favor at the White House, have suddenly become nervous and anxious. The conviction that no more places will be filled at once had much to do with the final adjournment of the special session of the Senate, making it one of the shortest sessions on record.

Large bequests were given to charities by wills filed in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. The principal of these was the will of Simon Goldenberg, late of 29 West Seventy-second Street, who died on Feb. 19, leaving an estate valued at $200,000 in real and $100,000 in personal property.

The completion of the short line of the New Jersey Junction Railroad Company, which was practically accomplished yesterday, marks the termination of a bitterly contested legal fight extending over a period of eight years. This little railroad, built in the interest of the West Shore system, has cost nearly $3,000,000.
The Republican financial plank does not prove strong enough to suit the business men of Boston. They insist on the gold standard, the retirement of legal-tender notes, and an elastic bank currency.
ALBANY, March 10. -- In the Assembly to-day the following bills were advanced to third reading:

Justice Bookstaver charged the jury in the suit of Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan against Mrs. Kate M. Foster yesterday afternoon and directed a sealed verdict to be rendered this morning. The suit is to recover $50,000 damages for the alienation of the affections of Dr. Alexander Buchanan, husband of the plaintiff.
ALBANY, March 10. -- Senator Ahearn today introduced the following resolution, which was laid on the table:

Among the many distinguished lawyers who have given the Greater New York charter critical examination is John E. Parsons, the President of the City Club. He finds numerous important objections to the charter, and nothing in its favor. In fact, he is strongly opposed to the Greater New York scheme itself.

A race with death in a special train was made from Washington to Boston during Tuesday night and yesterday morning by Robert Treat Paine, the Boston millionaire. Mr. Paine had received word that his wife, who was ill with pneumonia, was likely to die He started on a special at 8:27 P.M. and reached Jersey City at 1:12, beating the time of the Congressional limited, the crack Pennsylvania Railroad train, by twenty minutes.

Several members of the Fourth Division of the Naval Militia presented themselves before Commander J.W. Miller on the New Hampshire on Tuesday evening. These were the men who, acting under orders given by Lieut. W.H. Stayton, the commanding officer of the division, had worn the new hats that so incensed Commander Miller.

William C. Whitney, representing the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, made an earnest appeal to the State Railroad Commissioners, in the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday, for a prompt decision in the application to change the motive power of the Sixth, Eighth, and Ninth Avenue street railroad lines, and the Belt Line from horse power to underground trolley.

The Rev. Anthony B. Schwenniger of the Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary is seriously ill with heart disease in Baltimore, at the convent of the School Sisters of Notre Dame. Small hopes are expressed of his recovery, though reporters who called at the parish house in this city last night were told that he was some better yesterday, and had passed a quiet day.

BOSTON, Mass., March 10. -- At the meeting of the Massachusetts Division of the League of American Wheelmen to-night there came very near being a row in reference to the reported treachery on the part of delegates from this division in voting for Potter for President when they were supposed to be solid for Elliott.
City Magistrate H.C. Kudlich made public last night the letter he sent to the Police Commissioners. It was as follows:

The committee of wool men appointed at the meeting of the wool trade Feb. 25 to consider the desirability of organizing as an association in co-operation with the Wool Exchange reported yesterday at a meeting held in the Wool Exchange that such an organization should be formed and recommended the appointment of a committee on organization.

BOSTON, March 10. -- The committee on liquor laws reported against the petition for an amendment of the 400-foot law, so as to exempt J.R. Whipple's new hotel, La Touraine, corner of Tremont and Boylston Streets, from its operation. The vote was 8 to 3.

It is much to be desired that the meeting to be held at Cooper Union this evening to urge the ratification of the arbitration treaty may prove to be as impressive in point of numbers as it will be representative of public opinion.

Certain associations of women school teachers in this city have sent a petition to the Legislature demanding that under the Greater New York charter "when men and women teachers are performing similar duties in similar grades they shall receive equal compensation," and this was backed up by some eloquent remarks at the committee hearing on Tuesday night.

It is reported that after his first Cabinet meeting President MCKINLEY, Judge MCKENNA, and Gov. LONG, who were close friends in the House years ago, quietly lighted their cigars and sat for nearly an hour talking over old times.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Navy Department received a dispatch this morning, dated at Hatteras Cove, N.C., from the commander of the monitor Puritan, stating that his vessel's engines were disabled, and asking that a ship be sent to tow her to port.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Private Secretary Porter issued his first official order to-day. It provides for the transaction of business with the President, and fixes the Cabinet days and the hours and times for public receptions. The order omits the rule in force during Mr. Cleveland's Administration, providing that the President should be free from all callers on Mondays.

For some six years a case has been wending its slow way through the courts of this State, which, reaching the Court of Appeals, has brought out a decision of great importance as to what we have ventured to call the Labor Trust.

Information about the dealings of William H.W. Howell, who was held in the Butler Street Police Court, Brooklyn, Tuesday, literally poured in yesterday upon the Dayton Wheel and the Hunter Arms people, who caused his arrest. It is believed that before the end of the case is reached a gang of swindlers will be exposed.

The sudden decision of Senator Platt and the managers of the Republican machine at this end of the State to reverse their previous judgment and allow some of the Raines law amendments to be introduced in the Legislature astonished many of the local Republican politicians.

A brief prepared by the City Club's Committee on the Greater New York Charter, at the request of the Committees on Affairs of Cities of both houses of the State Legislature, expressed at the joint hearing in Albany last Tuesday night, was yesterday sent to the Chairmen of the Senate and the Assembly committees.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11. -- Great indignation has manifested itself among the Yale students on account of the action of certain members of the junior class, who sent a ale flag to Corbett, the prizefighter, and a message expressing the hope that he would whip Fitzsimmons in the coming prizefight.
The Alumnae Natural Science Committee invites all teachers interested in nature study in the schools to be present at the "At Home" in the Normal College Library to-day from 3 to 5 P.M.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 11. -- Gov. W.O. Bradley has called the Legislature of Kentucky to meet in extraordinary session at Frankfort Saturday. The Governor enumerates forty-two subjects for the consideration of the lawmakers, some of them trivial, others of vital importance to the welfare of the State.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 11. -- The actress Miss Anna Held has bought of N.H. Rowland, Lexington, the saddle horse Kentucky for $2,000. This is one of the finest horses in the State, and was shipped this afternoon to New York.
ALBANY, March 11. -- Abraham Gruber has been here to-day doing some work on behalf of New York City Republicans against the proposed Raines amendments to the liquor tax law.

In a letter addressed to the Executive Committee of the New York Civil Service Reform Association, Everett P. Wheeler explains his reasons for retiring from the Chairmanship of that committee. The letter was read at a meeting held last Wednesday night, and its reading was followed by many expressions of regret over Mr. Wheeler's withdrawal from active service.

Advertisers begin to inquire whether newspapers which have lost or are in process of losing their respectable readers -- their readers who have the means to purchase goods -are any longer valuable mediums for their announcements. They begin to see clearly that the newspapers that have and hold the attention of intelligent and respectable men and women possess the highest value for the advertiser. -- NEW YORK TIMES.

LONDON, March 11. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times telegraphs that he has obtained from the highest authority the outlines of the scheme which Greece is willing to accept pending a final solution of the Cretan question.

ALBANY, March 11. -- In the Senate this morning the resolution offered yesterday by Senator Ahearn providing for the appointment of a special joint committee to investigate the question of labor in prisons coming in competition with outside labor was called up, and Senator Ellsworth moved that the resolutions be referred to the Prison Commission, which, he said, was created for the purpose of making just such investigations.

LONDON, March 11. -- A dispatch from Rome to The Daily News says that Admiral Canevaro, the Italian who is in command of the combined fleets in Cretan waters, insists upon the necessity of landing troops to quell the rebellion in the interior of the island. The Italian Government, after conferring with the Governments of the other powers, has therefore decided to send a force of troops to Crete.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 11. -- The finest church ever erected for the negro race is to be built here. It will be called the Lincoln Memorial African Methodist Episcopal Church, in honor of the emancipator.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The report of the special committee to investigate the workings of the Raines law is signed by Senators Raines, Ford, Nussbaum, and Higgins. Senator Foley, the Democratic member of the committee, will present a minority report.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 11. -- Charles Spear, Assistant Secretary of the National Democratic Committee (Gold) and promoter of a non-partisan currency campaign in the South, to be directed by the committee and the New York Chamber of Commerce, arrived in Birmingham to-day.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 11. -- Cavanaugh's bill making the salary of Chicago Aldermen $3,000 a year came up on the order of second reading and provoked a long and at times caustic debate.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11. -- A letter received from Santiago de Cuba dated March 4, refers to an incident which shows the utter lack of consideration Spanish authorities have for representatives of foreign powers. American authorities are not the only ones treated with insult.

ALBANY, March 11. -- A bill was introduced by Senator Wray (Rep., Brooklyn,) to-day to permit the Mayor of New York City to remove members of the New York City Police Board. The bill amends Section 1 of the power of removal law of 1895, to read as follows:

" Der Mann im Mond" was substituted for "Grafin Fritzi," which was to have received its first presentation at the Irving Place Theatre last night. Fraulein Braga, who was billed for a principal part in Oscar Blumenthal's new comedy, has not sufficiently recovered from her recent illness to go through a first night, so "Der Mann im Mond" with Fraulein Elly Bender as Wera, was put on at the last moment.

BALTIMORE, March 11. -- The Chamber of Commerce to-day appointed a committee composed of Robert Ramsay, R.D. Fisher, and Louis Muller to represent that body and the interests of Baltimore grain dealers at the hearing in New York next Monday before the Inter-State Commerce Commission.
MONTREAL, Quebec, March 11. -- There are several queer laws in the Province of Quebec. In November, 1894, the following extraordinary note was signed in this city:
TRENTON, N.J., March 11. -- The introduction of a race-track bill put a bit of life into to-day's session of the House. Mr. Armbruster of Hudson fathered the bill.

The bill to distribute the direct tax of 1861 to those who paid it or to their heirs, which has been presented to the Legislature, has an equitable purpose, though there are some difficulties in the way of its equitable execution.

The lacrosse team of the Crescent Athletic Club, which has held the championship of the United States since 1893, will sail to-morrow on the Cunard Liner Aurania for a six weeks' tour through England and Ireland. While abroad the team will play thirteen games against representative clubs, five in Manchester, four in London, and four in Belfast. A trip to France is contemplated.

Did Senator HOAR represent the Administration when he proposed in the Senate the amendments to the rules that would stop filibustering and enable the Senate to come to a vote when the majority wished so to do?

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Mrs. Caroline Bragg, who was shot yesterday morning, is in a precarious condition at St. Luke's Hospital. To-day she became conscious and sent for her attorney, and told him to change the will which she had made some time ago giving all of her property to Josephine, the adopted daughter.

The Greater New York charter has been attacked at three points by pretty much everybody who has had anything to say about it, and apparently its only defense at those points is the will of its putative creator. The points of attack are the cumbersome but impotent Municipal Assembly of two chambers, the four-headed bi-partisan Police Board, and the limitation of the Mayor's power of removal to the first six months of his term.

The fancy dress carnival at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue, last night, was a great success. The big building was well filled, and all enjoyed the fun furnished by the Carnival Committee. The rink was very tastefully decorated, streamers of laurel and bunting extending over the roof to the side walls.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Morris K. Jesup, President of the American Museum of Natural History in Central Park, has preparations well advanced for an exploring expedition which he proposes to send out in search of information in the line of anthropology and ethnology. The expedition will be the greatest, it is said, in point of time spent and territory traversed ever backed by private individuals in this line of research.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The Fayerweather will contest will be continued on Monday before the Court of Appeals. This court on Tuesday last refused to amend its remittitur directing that the remaining $3,000,000 of the estate be distributed among the twenty colleges, as originally intended by the tenth article of the will.

Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan has won her suit against Mrs. Kate M. Foster and recovered the full amount of damages asked for the alienation of the affections of her husband, Dr. Alexander Buchanan, deceased, who was a prominent physician on the west side. The case was given to a jury by Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, Wednesday afternoon, with instructions to bring in a sealed verdict yesterday morning.
Mr. Herbert S. Carpenter of the Stock Exchange house of Thomas L. Manson Co., in discussing the financial outlook yesterday, said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CANEA, March 11. -- It cannot be denied that the actions of Sir Alfred Biliotti, the British Consul here, during the present disturbances, have created a deep feeling of animosity against him among the Christians everywhere in the island, and it is believed that whatever may be the outcome of the struggle, his usefulness as British representative has come to an end.
One of the leading carpet houses of the country, Messrs. W. J. SLOANE, send out to their customers the following circular:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 11. -- The members of the Senate and Assembly Cities Committees and President Benjamin F. Tracy, Secretary George M. Pinney, Jr., William C. De Witt, and Silas B. Dutcher of the Greater New York Commission, met in executive session to-night to finally complete the Greater New York charter.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- One hundred and eighteen Democrats are expected to attend the minority caucus to be held in the Hall of Representatives on Saturday afternoon. The votes of sixty members will select the candidate of the Democrats for Speaker, to be voted for on Monday, the 13th.

A most determined attempt was made last night to convert the mass meeting at Cooper Union, called in favor of the ratification of the arbitration treaty, into one of protest against that treaty. This attempt was made after the meeting had been in progress for over an hour, and was apparently carefully planned in advance. It came as a surprise to only a part of the audience, but to them it was a surprise indeed.

The Directors of the Brooklyn Baseball Club met in Brooklyn yesterday and decided to abandon the grounds at Eastern Park. They also decided to reduce the price of admission to 25 cents, retaining a few 50-cent admissions in order to comply with the requirements of the National League Association.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 11. -- Edward Odell has a mill at Smithfield, near Amenia. As the water supply is not large, he makes the most of it by starting his mill about 3 o'clock in the morning. Yesterday morning he had just entered his mill with a lanterr in his hand when a man in a white mask stepped in front of him and told him to throw up his hands.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The McKinley schedule on wools and woolens was substantially adopted to-day by the Republican majority of the Ways and Means Committee.

The proper remedy for the dead-lock in the Police Board and the demoralization produced by it is that proposed in the bill introduced yesterday by Senator WRAY of Brooklyn. It simply removes the limitation imposed upon the Mayor's power of removal by the act of 1895 and allows it to be exercised "at pleasure."

MIAMI, Fla., March 11. -- John J. Finn of New York, now hunting near Fort Pierce with a party, had a terrible experience with a panther the other day while fishing. Being interested in the sport, they threw the fish on the banks as they went along and got separated. Mr. Finn, on going through a picket, came face to face with a huge panther feasting on some of the fish that had been left.

ATHENS, March 11. -- The situation here is improving. The city is quieting, and apart from occasional outbursts of enthusiasm on the part of the populace there is very little of an exciting nature to engage public attention.

We have had ample evidence that the feeling of disgust and indignation at the one active intervention upon which the powers have ventured in the Levant is scarcely less strong in France than in England. The French Government was fortunate in putting off until Saturday the debate in the Chamber which seemed imminent on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The State Department to-day received a copy of President Crespo's message to the Venezuelan Congress, Feb. 20, sent by the American Minister at Caracas, in which he discusses the Venezuelan arbitration treaty at considerable length. He says, in part:

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President McKinley and his Cabinet officers must have formed the opinion by this time that the chief purpose for which they have been chosen is to make appointments to office; and if the growing impatience of the office seekers indicates anything, it is that the offices must be filled at once or the country will go to ruin.

It is permissible for private neutrals to express sympathy with combatants, and every sympathetic American must feel for the Consul of Greece at this port. Some hundreds of his excited countrymen desire to return home in order to kill Turks or representatives of the Christian powers, and insist that the Consul shall send them home for that purpose.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President McKinley has proclaimed he new patent convention with Japan and it is now operative.

Alderman Frederick A. Ware, Chairman of the Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen, is one of the men who for several years have been making a persistent fight against street and sidewalk obstructions. The young attorney went into the Board of Aldermen largely on this issue. His activity has made enemies, but his course is sustained by a strong majority of his constituents.

Retired Police Captain Patrick H. Pickett was one of thirteen candidates who appeared at the rooms of the Civil Service Commissioners yesterday to be examined as to their fitness for the position of Warden of Ludlow Street Jail.
The body of James Stevens of 287 Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City, was found yesterday morning at the foot of Eighty-eighth Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

On the southerly side of the high hill overlooking the older section of Greenwood Cemetery the body of Mrs. Henry Ward Beecher was laid beside that of her husband yesterday afternoon. Fully a thousand persons surrounded the grave while the simple burial service and prayer were said by the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, pastor of Plymouth Church.

Prof. Charles Howard Hinton, who holds the chair of mathematics at Princeton University, explained last night to members of the Princeton Club of this city the baseball gun which he has invented. About 300 Princeton men were present and manifested great interest in the operation of the machine.
ALBANY, March 11. -- That the establishment of a greater City of New York shall be appropriately commemorated is the desire of Senator McNulty of Brooklyn.
With only a record for slow going and not an incident to enliven the monotony of a log 218 days long, the German ship Henry Bischoff arrived yesterday from Hiogo, Japan.

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, March 11. -- A dispatch from Tamatave says that Ranavalona III., Queen of Madagascar, who has been only the nominal ruler of the island since it was made a French colony last June, has been exiled to the Island of Reunion, and started for that place on March 1.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The Assembly to-day passed the bill exempting State bonds from taxation. This action followed a spirited debate, opened by Mr. Armstrong, who declared that the motive which induced the drawing of the bill was the desire to make a present of these bonds to a number of favored people, who were awaiting legislation which would permit them to purchase at a ridiculously low figure.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the Metropolitan Improvement Company six lots on the southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street and Central Park West, 125 by 125, to George C. Edgar's Sons Co., who give in part payment three five-story American basement dwellings on the south side of Eighty-eighth Street, 125 feet west of Central Park West.
The cruiser New York, now in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, is, to the ordinary observer, none the worse for her experience with fire last Tuesday.

LONDON, March 12. -- The examination of Sir Graham Bower, formerly Imperial Secretary at the Cape Colony, was resumed today by the South African Committee. He testified that he had never told Cecil Rhodes to communicate his intention of assisting in the rising in the Transvaal to the High Commissioner.

ST. PAUL, March 12. -- Last night's storm was the greatest of the Winter -- the greatest for several Winters, in fact. The fall of snow was six inches and a heavy wind drifted this and the snow already on the ground to ten to fifteen feet. Street railway traffic was pretty completely resumed to-day, but steam railways are still in a state of demoralization.

BALTIMORE, March 12. -- Edgar H. Gans, ex-Assistant State's Attorney, in a speech last night made some remarks about Senator Gorman which have excited great interest among the politicians of Baltimore.

TACOMA, Washington, March 12. -- The Sitkas are the most warlike Indian tribe in Alaska. They frequently cause the authorities much trouble. News was received today that two weeks ago they attempted to hold as slaves fifteen Hoonah Indians who had gone to the Sitka camp in canoes on a visit.
Mayor Strong has announced that there will be a public hearing on the Finn Stoopline bill at his office at 3 o'clock next Tuesday afternoon.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold to Lyman G. Bloomingdale (Bloomingdale Brothers) the four four-story brownstone-front dwellings, 140 to 146 East Sixtieth Street, with the valuable plot, 80 by 100.5, on the southeast corner of Sixtieth Street and Lexington Avenue. The sellers are L.S. Davidson, Samuel Stein, and Mandelbaum Lewine.

Will you kindly give to the readers of your journal a few lines concerning the Americanism and lineage of Justice Wauhope Lynn, who last night at Cooper Union Hall descanted so patriotically upon "Our Country," "Flunker Hill," "The Continental Fathers," and the "spirit that stood behind the guns at Lexington."

When the baseball season opens there is a strong probability that the pick of the Cleveland team will be found in the ranks of the Brooklyn players. An offer was made a few days ago by President Byrne of the Brooklyn team to F. De Haas Robinson, President of the Cleveland Club, to transfer the latter team to Brooklyn.

ALBANY, March 12. -- In the Senate this morning Senator Cantor inquired what had become of his bill to reduce the price of gas in New York City to $1. He introduced it at the beginning of the session. Chairman Brown of the Cities Committee said a report on the matter probably would be made next week.
A "short cut" to the solution of our Whole police trouble would be the prompt passage of the Wray bill, giving the Mayor the power of removal which he ought to have at all times.

If the subject were not so serious, there would be something diverting in the squirming and twisting of those statesmen who try to solve the problem of employing convicts in productive industry without competition with "free labor," as if there were necessarily something evil in labor competition, while competition in trade was necessarily a benefit.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12. -- A peculiar but abortive attempt at train robbery occurred last night near Samaria, sixteen miles north of here, on the Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Road. Two men got on the train at Jackson, taking seats some distance from each other, and pulled their slouch hats over their eyes.

The details of the expedition proposed by Morris K. Jesup, President of the American Museum of Natural History, for the exploration of the coasts of the North Pacific Ocean and the study of the races living there, which was reported in a dispatch from Albany to THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, were given out yesterday by Dr. Franz Boas, Assistant Curator of the Anthropological Department of the museum.

The death of Louis de Madrazo, an elder brother of the portrait painter, is announced M. Louis de Madrazo, born in 1825, followed the bent of the family, and was an artist. His two best-known pictures were "Pelayo at Carvandonga." and "The Funeral of St. Cecelia."

The third annual exposition of the Sportsmen's Association will open to-day at the Madison Square Garden. It will last all next week. The amphitheatre is occupied by the exhibits of manufacturers of sporting goods, of periodicals devoted to sports, specimens of taxidermic art, and other interesting features.

OMAHA, Neb., March 12. -- In General Ordens, No. 5, Commander in Chief Clarkson of the Grand Army of the Republic includes an extract from a letter written to him by the Chairman of the committee appointed at St. Paul last year to examine the histories in use in the public schools.

While the trial of Magnus Holm was in progress yesterday before Recorder Goff, in the Court of General Sessions, an exciting half hour was caused by the lawyers for the defense serving a stay of proceedings on Assistant District Attorney Hardwicke.

Senator Ellsworth has in prospect from at least one quarter opposition to his anti-cartoon bill. There are persons who are just now reading every word printed about the prospect and progress of the measure, add, while they are in no position to make a minority report, or even a protest, they comprise a group toward which the average public man might think several times before incurred their antipathy.

It was reported in Brooklyn yesterday that efforts are being made by certain Republican politicians to cause the removal of C.C. Martin, Superintendent of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge. The object of the movement, it is said, is to replace Mr. Martin by some one who will be more pliable.

If Mr. McKINLEY should select Mr. H. CLAY EVANS of Tennessee for Commissioner of Pensions he would get a man of sound reputation, energy, ability, and excellent executive capacity, who would attend to the administrative business of the office with fidelity and efficiency. He would also add to his Administration a popular and vigorous representative of his party in the South.

Spain seems to have enough upon her hands in the Western Hemisphere, and yet the rebellion in the Philippines, according to the latest accounts, would be quite enough to tax her resources if there were no rebellion in Cuba at all. It is now declared, and by the correspondent of a Spanish journal, that reinforcements of 15,000 men are needed to make the Philippines safe.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 12. -- The annual meeting of the University Track Athletic Cup Association was held at the Massasoit House this afternoon.

Senator Thomas C. Platt reached here from Washington late yesterday afternoon. Senator John Raines arrived in the city from Albany early in the evening. Mr. Platt and Mr. Raines will have a talk over the tax law amendments to-day. Mr. Raines said last night that, in his opinion, the amendments would pass.
There can be no doubt that the Cooper Union meeting on Thursday evening spoke the sentiment of the great body of the people of New York regarding arbitration.

ALBANY, March 12. -- Edward Lauterbach came to this city this morning bringing a copy of the police bill he has drawn. He submitted it to Gov. Black, and endeavored to show that it ought to have the support of the Chief Executive.

The Eastern papers picture him as a mighty warrior, leading hosts to battle, performing prodigies of valor, and inciting his followers to renewed deeds of daring heroism, He was not a warrior at all, but a shaman -- a priest or medicine man. His mission was to mare "medicine" for the other Sioux before the beginning of a fight.

Leaving the cases containing special letters of great men for those in which are preserved miscellaneous manuscripts, the visitor is simply dazed by the extent and value of the collection. The department contains more than 9,000 volumes of manuscripts written in Oriental languages, and each one is either a rare work in itself or a representative of a particular type.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The daily dispatches from this city have mentioned the fact that the President is no longer a prisoner, afraid to venture into the streets to take a walk, although some accounts by careless observers have given the impression that the old rush of office-seekers is here at the old business.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 12. -- A special to The Times from Washington, D.C., says:

When you read Japanese verse, after it has passed through, two media, German and English, the probability is that you get only a faint conception of the original. Florenz, who Germanized the Japanese in this volume, says that "the great majority of Japanese poems are of such a kind that very little remains if they are divested of their superficially Japanese expressions, especially as most of them have the brevity of aphorisms."

It was the aim of George Edward Sears to make a collection of books which should illustrate the main stages in the history of bookmaking. He succeeded, in getting together a fairly representative collection, and incidentally of possessing himself of many volumes that are known by reputation to collectors and rated in catalogues at high values. This library is now displayed at George R. Richmond Co.'s, 12 East Fifteenth Street.

Messrs. Thomas Y. Crowell Co. publish this month Prof. William Trent's "Southern Statesmen of the Old Regime." The volume is historical and biographical, and treats of the political conditions which surrounded Washington, Jefferson, Randolph, Calhoun, Stephens, Toombs, and Davis.

A number of overdue transatlantic vessels arrived yesterday. The Atlantic Transport Line steamship Massachusetts, which was among them, was due on Tuesday. She suffered no damage, but the entries on her log book indicated that there has been no abatement in the severity of the weather on the ocean.

NEWARK, N.J., March 12. -- The Rev. E.J. Oldknow Millington, pastor of the Fairmount Baptist Church, who disappeared from New York on Monday, March 1, and who returned to his home a few days ago, has confessed to the Deacons of the church that the rumors that he and Mrs. Dorothy Dickerson, a member of his church, had been together during his absence were true.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- A new phase in the scheme of the Cook County Subway and Terminal Railway Company developed today. The plan proposed, it is said, includes as a part of the underground loop connecting the railroad depots a scheme to tunnel beneath the three branches of the river, and thus tap by rail underground the elevators, warehouses, and docks along the river front.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- The break of 2 cents in wheat and the reported selling out by the bull leaders left the pit in an uncertain state of feeling. To add to the perplexing situation there was no positive news to shape prices. In the morning wheat was hesitating around the Thursday price. Sales for May were 72 1/2c to 72 5/8c and 72 3/4c, and 72 1/8c.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The appointment of a Fourth Assistant Postmaster General to succeed Robert A. Maxwell is expected within a few days, as Maxwell's resignation was filed with President Cleveland March 4. Mr. Maxwell has been the first incumbent of the office whose policy has rid the position of the opprobrious epithet "headsman."

There is a painting of" The Holy Family" now on exhibition at the Seton Apartment House, 411 West Fifty-seventh Street, attributed to Peter Paul Rubens, and which, whatever may be its origin, is certainly an interesting work.

In a tone of almost triumphant conviction Dr. PARKHURST renews his declaration of three years ago, that he would rather fight five Crokers than one Platt. "What do they think now," he asks, "with CROKER a political incident and PLATT both Governor and Legislature of the State of New York?"

One of the points of discussion in regard to the provisions of the Greater New York consolidation has been that portion of the measure which relates to the permanence of the boundaries of the new city.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- A new feature in connection with the attempted murder of Mrs. Catherine E. Bragg presented itself to-day in the reported disappearance of $10,000 worth of diamonds, supposed to have been concealed in the flat at 211 Thirty-first Street, where the mysterious shooting occurred. The police to-night found the missing diamonds in pawnshops, where Mrs. Bragg herself had placed them.

Of the proposed amendments to the liquor tax law the only ones that will excite special interest are those which relate to the question of Sunday selling. The exemption of hotels from the prohibition is continued with such a definition of the term "hotel" and of "guest" as would be intended to limit the privilege of Sunday selling to bona fide hotels and real guests.

Enthusiasm ran high at the meeting of sympathizers with Crete held under the auspices of Consul General Botassi and Seth Low, in Chickering Hall, last night. Every period in the speeches evoked a clatter of hands and feet. The greatest uproar followed the peroration of Michael Anagnos, a visitor from Boston.
Apropos of prevailing conditions in the anthracite coal trade and current developments in that quarter, Mr. Alfred de Cordova said yesterday:
FRANKFORT, Ky., March 12. -- Dr. W. Godfrey Hunter has not been nominated for United States Senator by the Republican legislative caucus.

We do not suppose that it is with any hope that it will pass that Mr. HENRY D. HOTCHKISS has prepared and sent to Albany a bill to prohibit political contributions by corporations. Mr. HOTCHKISS, though a Sachem of Tammany, is an anti-silver man and kicked over the Chicago platform last year without ceremony.
It was rumored yesterday that a petition requesting the City Fathers to change the name of the Bowery was to be presented to that honorable body in a few days.

Although a critic of the proposed charter and heartily in accord with those who would secure sufficient delay in its enactment to afford more ample opportunity for careful revision and amendment, I am opposed to any treatment of the matter which disregards or attempts indirectly to defeat the popular mandate for consolidation.

E.C. Newton, twenty-four years old, the son of a wealthy Englishman, took paris green about 10 o'clock Thursday night at the Hotel Warwick, Fortieth Street and Broadway, and died at 3 o'clock A.M. yesterday. Some time ago Newton married Miss Foote, an actress, who is to appear in "Gay Manhattan" at Koster Bial's next week, and because of his marriage his father cast him off.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12. -- Miss Virginia Fair, daughter of the late ex-United States Senator Fair, to-day filed a complaint in intervention in the suit pending against Mrs. Nettle R. Craven and others for the possession of certain property in this city, valued at over $1,000,000, alleged to have been deeded to Mrs. Craven by the late Senator.

A majority of the Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States and Canada will go abroad in either May or June to attend the fourth Lambeth conference, the first of which was held in 1868. The conference, which is a meeting for consultation by all Bishops of the Anglican communion, is to be held in London, and will occupy the whole of the month of July.

The bill before the Legislature to require the City Works Department to do the paving of the city will certainly prove a costly experiment if the city is still to be required to pay $2 a day for eight hours' work. The current wages paid by contractors are reported by Deputy Commissioner WILDS to be $1.50 per day for ten hours.

A bust of Dr. Arnold, the famous Head Master of Rugby School and the father of Matthew Arnold, made by the sculptor, Alfred Gilbert, was unveiled last month in the new school at Rugby by the Archbishop of Canterbury. The bust is of marble and of heroic size. It was originally intended for Westminster Abbey, but was found to be too large for the arcading, and a smaller one was substituted.

All that illustration can lavish on Harper's Weekly has been given with the freest hand to the inauguration number. The artists are de Thuistrup, with "The Chief Justice Administering the Oath to the President,'' Mr. Brooks's strong picture of Mark A. Hanna, Senator from Ohio; Mr. L.W. Hitchcock's drawing of "President McKinley and His Cabinet," Mr. G.W. Peters's "President, McKinley reviewing the inaugural procession from the stand in front of the White House."

The fire-proof building of to-day has been the reviving factor for the mosaicist. When architects began planning our monumental and indestructible structures that make New York City's sky line serried, the decorative artist was called in to display his art with materials that would effectually resist the corrosion of natural and artificial decay -- ones that would hold their pristine beauty longest.

A new Cardinal will soon be created in the Roman Catholic Church in America. It is to be the Most Rev. Louis N. Begin, the present Coadjutor Bishop of Quebec, who was consecrated Archbishop of Cyrene in 1891, with the right of succession to Cardinal Taschereau of Canada, who now lies at the point of death.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 12. -- Ward Lutes, a wealthy stock raiser of Lexington, Ky., shot himself here last night while in a dream. About 3 o'clock this morning occupants in rooms adjoining that of Lutes heard a pistol shot, and going into his room found him lying on the floor bleeding. A pistol was at his feet with one chamber empty.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12. -- Sportsmen here are much excited to-night over the capture by J.B. Cauldwell of New York of the first tarpon of the season. Mr. Cauldwell was fishing in Biscayne Bay when the fish was struck. He was a giant and leaped, flashing in the sunlight. The big fish shook its head angrily, trying to dislodge the hook, but in vain.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 12. -- A renewal of the outbreaks in Asia Minor is imminent, and Sir Philip Currie, the British Ambassador, has called the Porte's attention to the state of affairs existing there, with a view of averting the atrocities which are threatened.

-- One of the most perplexing difficulties which are encountered in equipping lighthouses and lightships with effective sound signals for use in times of fog, is due to the fact that, under certain circumstances, not yet very well understood, sound waves are deflected from the straight course in passing through the air, with the result that zones or regions of silence are produced at distances comparatively close to the sound-producing apparatus.

The will of the Very Rev. Charles Frederick Hoffman, who died on March 4 last on Jekyll Island, Georgia, was filed in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. The estate is known to be very large, but in the petition the value is given as unknown.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12. -- Hot weather, the thermometer registering 87 degrees, gave the race course a Summer appearance to-day. The large crowd present spent a pleasant day, although only two favorites won.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12. -- In the suit brought to annul the charter of the American Tobacco Company and break up what is known as the Tobacco Trust, Vice Chancellor Reed this morning filed an opinion dismissing the bill and ending the present litigation against the company.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Gratifying reports have been received at the Navy Department of the speed in ordinary service conditions of two of the finest flagships of the navy -- the New York of the home station and the San Francisco of the European squadron.

BREWSTER, N.Y., March 12. -- Dr. E.P. Strunk, a prominent physician of this town, was instantly killed this morning by the 11:15 o'clock eastbound passenger train on the New England Railroad at the crossing just east of this village.

"Tannhauser" was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House by Mr. Walter Damrosch's company. It was the second of the performances in the cycle of Wagner's works in chronological order. The audience was not what it ought to have been in the circumstances; for it is not often that "Tannhauser" is given, and in some respects it ranks with the greatest of Wagner's dramas.

Formal charges against Police Commissioners Andrew D. Parker and Frederick D. Grant were presented to Mayor Strong yesterday, by a committee of the City Club, and a demand was made for their removal. The committee was composed of Wheeler H. Peckham, Chairman; John E. Parsons, W. Harris Roome, Arthur Von Briesen, and R.W.G. Welling.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- In the artistic world the great subject has been, and still is, the Goncourt sale, at which the prices obtained were very much higher than any one expected. The total was just short of a million francs, and the Japanese collection still remains to be sold, and is by no means the least valuable.

An executor's sale of ninety-seven canvases will take place at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries on Tuesday evening next, March 16. The pictures are now on exhibition in the galleries, and will afford a pleasant hour's study. The collection is made up for the most part of examples of good American artists, with a few canvases by well-known foreign brushes.
NEW HAVEN, March 12. -- Plans were completed to-night for the annual Yale indoor games at the Second Regiment Armory in connection with the athletes of the Connecticut National Guard to-morrow night.

ALBANY, March 12. -- Assemblyman Mathewson's bill allowing the Macomb's Dam temporary bridge in New York City to remain for five years, for use by railroad companies, has been amended by Senator Guy as follows:

In The Academy there is an interesting account of a visit paid Paul Verlaine, and at the time when his fortunes were at their lowest ebb. He was living in the Rue St. Victor, in Paris, "au quatrieme." The street was a narrow one, and inhabited by the poorest class.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12. -- The old Chicago House, at the southeast corner of Washington and Exchange Streets, was nearly destroyed by fire at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon. So rapid was the spread of the flames, fanned as they were by a gale raging with a velocity of over seventy miles an hour, that three inmates lost their lives and two were injured.
ALBANY, March 12. -- In the Assembly today the following bills were advanced to a third reading:

The vast expense at which The Journal has engaged the exclusive services of CORBETT and FITZSIMMONS to report for it their coming contest is beginning to be justified. Hitherto their communications have been confined mainly to boasts about the perfection of their respective "condition" and direful threats of what they would do to each other on the fateful day.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 12. -- Representative McLaughlin to-day introduced a bill to provide for the establishment of a Court of Conciliation.

Two disgusted detectives, a sealskin sack, and a group of men made a picture before Police Justice Wentworth in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday. The detectives, Daly and Charton of the Central Office, saw a well-dressed man walking down Broadway Thursday afternoon with the sack over his arm and followed him.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee were working over the pottery and woolen schedules of the tariff bill to-day and endeavoring to arrange the reciprocity clauses so as to open French and German markets to American meat products and live stock.
Mrs.Harriot and Miss Florencen Harriot, 454 West Twenty third Street, on March 19 will give their last Friday evening at home, with music, before going South.

The New York baseball team will go tomorrow morning to Lakewood to train for the baseball season. President Freedman's office, in Cortlandt Street, was well filled yesterday with the players who are to represent this city in the struggle for the championship.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 13. -- The fruit growers of the Hudson River Valley, who have been in session here for several days, favor very strongly the introduction in the public schools of New York State of nature studies through the natural sciences, with their application made to country living.

Apparently it is high time that the Papal Ablegate for Canada were at work in his new field. There seems to be a good deal of objection to him upon the ground that he does not know Canada. This seems an important disqualification, seeing that his usefulness will principally consist of the fidelity and accuracy of his reports to the Vatican upon the condition of things in Canada.
NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -- The Rev. E.J. Oldknow Millington, who yesterday made a full confession of his elopement with Mrs. Dorothy Dickerson, made another statement to-day, as follows:

The opponents of the sidewalk and stoop-line bills are rapidly organizing, and will be prepared on Tuesday to go before the Mayor with a strong protest. The point of attack will be the Finn bill, which business men consider the most pernicious of all the measures of this kind.

Men of importance in Wall Street are confident that the turning point in financial affairs has been reached, and that the country is on its way to material improvement and prosperity. That there has been of late some betterment in general business conditions is everywhere recognized, and there is a general feeling that this improvement will continue steadily.

There were three shooting matches at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night, by the prone, veteran, and sharpshooter classes. In the veteran match Capt. Melville and Lieut. Clark were tied, the final score, being decided in favor of the latter, by the location of the shots only. The matches and winners were:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 13. -- Well-filled hotels have marked another week of the Lenten season. The weather is like April, with varying sunshine and shower, and only an occasional gust of wind to tell that March is not yet past. Outdoor pleasures, informal social affairs, Lenten lectures, and exceptionally fine music at the hotels have made up the incidents of the week.
MILTON, Del., March 13. -- The murdered woman, whose body was found in Broadkill Creek Thursday, is supposed to be Mrs. Mary Lewis of 309 West Thirty-ninth Street, New York.

One element in the situation in the Levant, and one which, while powerful, is not ordinarily recognized, is the ecclesiastical. We are accustomed to think of the Greek Church as a unit, in the same sense that the Roman Catholic Church is. This is a mistake. There are a number of branches or divisions of the Church, each recognizing, yet each jealous of, the others and bound to preserve its own identity.

The moderate weather of the last few days has cheered the hearts of the local cyclists. While the roads may be in a very ridable condition and the sun may shine brightly, the cyclist at this period should exercise more than ordinary care. For days to come there will be a chill in the air that will mean mischief to many if due caution is not observed.

MONTREAL, March 13. -- The statement made by Premier Laurier to a delegation which waited upon him requesting a subsidy for a new canal project, that the present Liberal Government, which has been in power only six months, has already demands upon it for more than $50,000,000 in subsidies, draws attention to the evil from which this country has suffered during the past sixty years.

William E. Rogers lectured yesterday morning before the League for Political Education, at the Berkeley Lyceum, on "The New Charter." The assembly hall was filled with members of the league. Mr. Rogers is a member of the Bar Association. He devoted himself generally to the effect of consolidation on what is now known as New York.

HAVANA, March 13, via Key West, Fla., March 13. -- Very little news has reached Havana of what has happened in the Philippines. Local papers have received long telegrams, but their publication has been prohibited by the censor.

Some little stir was made among dry-goods men yesterday by the report that a movement had been started among the New England manufacturerers to sell their product at retail. It was said that certain mills, especially in Rhode Island, were already selling their goods at the factory to retail dealers, instead of limiting their sales, as is customary, to jobbers.
