The yachts Corsair, Atalanta, Colonia, and Iroquois, the flagships of the four big yacht clubs in this section of the country, are American from stem to stern, and yachtsmen are proud of the fact.

The statement is made in a dispatch appearing in the news columns of your issue of yesterday that a Mr. Charles Spear, Assistant Secretary of the National Democratic Committee, is now visiting the South as the promoter of a non-partisan currency campaign, "to be directed by the committee and the New York Chamber of Commerce."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Secretary Bliss to-day vacated and annulled the orders and proceedings in the Chicago Lake Front cases, and directed a new trial before the Commissioner of the General Land Office within thirty days.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 13. -- The committee which is charged with the management of Cornell's boating interests purposes to equip the crews this year with every convenience possible.

GLASGOW, March 3. -- The Prince of Wales has arrived at the Riviera, and with old Britannia winning, as usual, the French populace arc recognizing him as the "boss" of their regattas. The crowds on shore shout over Britannia's victories because she is owned by the Prince of Wales, quite forgetting that the crowd is a crowd of citizens of a republic and that Princes are an abomination.

On the ground that it is no violation of Federal law to take packages from the top of mail boxes in the street, Commissioner Shields yesterday refused to hold Michael Vitali of 178 Mulberry Street and Yoley Edwards of 118 Mulberry Street, who were sent to him from Centre Street Police Court on the charge of having taken a package from the top of a mail box opposite 220 Bowery.

The third annual exposition of the Sportsmen's Association was opened in the Madison Square Garden last night, and all the evening the big amphitheatre was well filled with those who take a lively interest in all kinds of sports. The show was opened in the evening, and until it closed the attendants at the different booths were kept busy.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 13. -- An interesting divorce suit was filed in the Superior Court this afternoon, accompanied by the arrest of the defendant for bigamy. The plaintiff is Benjamin B. Randall of Goldsmith Edmundson, Whitehall Street.

The 1,800 people who attended the eighth annual indoor games of Barnard School, at the Eighth Regiment Armory, Ninety-fifth Street and Park Avenue, yesterday at 2 P. M., witnessed clean, fast sport. Four interscholastic indoor records were broken. The record for the sixty-yard dash, junior, was held by W. Wilson of Bernard School, with a record of 0:07 1-5, made in 1896, until it was lowered yesterday by G. Whitmore of Dwight.

William Loewenthal, a plumber, living at 639 Sixth Street, was astonished yesterday morning at the receipt of a dispatch from his father, D. Loewenthal, of New Haven, Conn., asking him to go to the Fourth Precinct Police Station, take charge of "Benny," and send the latter home on the 3 o'clock boat. He left the matter to his wife, and she visited the Oak Street Station, where she found her brother-in-law in custody.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 13. -- Dr. W. Godfrey Hunter proved his statements today and was nominated for United States Senator on the first ballot by the Republican legislative caucus. He received 38 votes, all he had ever claimed. There were 15 votes cast for Holt, 5 each for Lewis and Boyle, and 2 for John W. Yerkes. The nomination was at once made unanimous.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13. -- At the regular meeting of the Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, in New York, to-day, the quarterly 2 per cent. dividend was declared.

There is in the Astor Library a worn pamphlet, in a ragged brown paper cover, of great interest. It is one of the few copies extant of a publication of fifty years ago which attracted such wide attention and had such a large circulation that it ran through ten editions in a very short time.

It is the opinion of those experts in antiques who have seen the silver and enamel shrine given by J. Pierpont Morgan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art that the piece was made by Benvenuto Cellini. Whether or no it is the work of the great Florentine goldsmith, at all events it is deemed a finer piece of old enamel than is owned by any other American museum.

Mrs. Mary Johnson, who was a widow over sixty years old, was buried yesterday in Calvary Cemetery. The funeral services were held in All Saints' Church, Father John J. Powers, Mrs. Johnson's friend, spiritual adviser, and one of the executors of her will, officiating.
William E. Werner of Rochester, Supreme Court Justice for the Seventh District, has been assigned by the Governor to this city for a month, and is presiding at the trial term of the Supreme Court.

These are busy days among college athletes. Calls have been issued at all the larger institutions for team candidates and coaches, and trainers are at their wits' ends to discover those who will replace the stars who have been graduated. During the indoor season more than one promising novice has been unearthed.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- The subject of the desecration of the uniform of the National Guard and the regular army formed a fruitful and interesting discussion at the session of the military men at the Wellington Hotel to-day. The officers present mostly favored legislation protecting the garb of the soldier.
BOSTON, March 13. -- Following are excerpts from a column interview, printed here to-day, with Dr. Herbert Stevens, recently a Colonel in the Cuban army:

CHURCHILLVILLE, N.Y., March 13. -- Miss Anna L. Perry, now studying at the American School of Classics at Athens, has recently written to friends here letters which have a peculiar interest at this time, referring as they do to the situation at the centre of the trouble in the Cretan matter.

The boxing bouts at the Broadway Athletic Club last night opened with a "slugging" match between two colored men and closed with a farcial go between "Solly" Smith of Los Angeles and Oscar Gardner of Kansas City.
CHICAGO, March 13. -- The Times-Herald this morning publishes the following:
President Seth Low of Columbia University sent the following letter to Mayor Strong yesterday in reference to the present condition of affairs in the Police Department:

ITHACA, March 13. -- Even before the backdown and apology of certain Yale students concerning their gift of a flag to Corbett, rumors were afloat here that a certain coterie of Cornell men had made a similar present to "Bob" Fitzsimmons. These rumors now turn out to be true.
Consul General Mason, writing from Frankfort, sends the following report concerning the importation into Germany of American apples:

The two hundredth anniversary, which occurs in May, of the completion of the first Trinity Church on this island, is to be made the occasion of an elaborate celebration. Such an event surely deserves all the commemoration that it can receive. Trinity is almost the only institution in New York that goes back to the seventeenth century, being inferior in antiquity only to the Collegiate Church.
NEW ORLEANS, March 13. -- Cloudy, warm weather and 6,000 people marked today's sport. A race for gentlemen riders was an extra attraction. The track was fast. Only two favorites won.
What was called "the plantation dinner" of the Thirteen Club was served last evening in the palm garden of the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street.

Commander Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army has submitted to Gen. Booth a plan for the latter's visit to this country. The General has decided to come over in October, and his visit will last six weeks. During that time he will hold meetings in all the prominent cities in the United States.

The New York Athletic Club's entertainment last night consisted of a series of events comprising hand tennis for the club championship in doubles, the second swimming competition for the indoor club championship, and a contest between the Fencers' Club and chosen members of the New York Athletic Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 9. -- William C. Squier, the naturalist, of Rahway, N.J., has presented Princeton University with a large assortment of New Jersey zinc and iron minerals, many of which it is impossible to duplicate for the reason that the sources from which they were taken are now exhausted.
TRENTON, March 13. -- So general has become the search among the people of New Jersey for information bearing on their ancestry that it has become a fad.

BOSTON, March 13. -- When F.O. North sold his twenty-one-foot knockabout Bo Peep early in the Winter he said, "Now to beat the Cock Robin." The Bo Peep had been an excellent second to the Cock Robin in the season's racing. The Bo Peep was of Lawley build and design, and it was understood that Mr. North would give the City Point builder another trial with the new boat.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 13. -- A stranger passing through Delaware County some years ago asked what the county was most noted for. A long, lank farmer who stood near and heard the rather sneering question eyed the questioner sharply for a moment, and then responded:

ITHACA, March 13. -- Manager Fuller of the Cornell Baseball Assocation gave out this schedule of games for the season of 1897. The list is longer than usual, and the number of out-of-town games is greater than last year. Only three big games are to be played on the home grounds, Princeton, Pennsylvania, and Michigan.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 13. -- The Mississippi River here now registers a higher stage of water than ever before known.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Feb. 16. -- The Royal Commission on the condition of the sugar industry in British Guiana and the West India Islands has concluded its sittings in this colony and some important evidence has been obtained.

It seems strange that the negroes of our country have not retained one scrap, word, or sentence of the language spoken by their early ancestors in Africa perhaps not many generations ago. The American people, to whom the negroes were first sold as slaves, have so thoroughly civilized the colored people that every trace of their native language has been lost.

Justice John M. Davy of Rochester is holding court in New York for the third time, by appointment of the Governor. He has been on the Supreme Court bench for eight years and has made an enviable record, not only for his satisfactory decisions, but for the rare courtesy he displays toward the attorneys who appear before him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 13. -- President McKinley's proposed raise in the duty on Canadian lumber has a very visible effect on the Canadian lumber trade. At the present time Canadian dealers are unable to supply the demand for lumber from American buyers. Larger and better sales are being made this season than ever before.

DENVER, Col., March 11. -- In every section of the mountain ranges of Colorado much heavier snows have fallen during the present Winter than in any year since 1886. The severe storm of the last of February piled up the snow along the slopes of the Sangre de Christo range for 250 miles to a depth of from 11 to 15 feet on the level.
BERLIN, March 13. -- The Budget Committee of the Reichstag has rejected the Government's demand for an extra credit for the purpose of building two additional cruisers.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- A large number of additional applications for places were received at the Treasury Department to-day. The names of the applicants, and the positions they ask for, are as follows:

Green posters liberally distributed around the Eastern District of Brooklyn during the past few days have announced that the Rev. Wm. T. McElveen, pastor of the New England Congregational Church, South Ninth Street, near Driggs Avenue, that city, purposes to celebrate St. Patrick's Day by a lecture and services in his church.

It is not necessary to go to the plains of Texas or the Bad Lands of the Dakotas e to see the handling of cattle in its liveliest and most picturesque aspect. A scene of bustle and excitement pertaining to the transportation of live stock may be observed at the foot of West Houston Street three or four days in the week all the year round.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 13. -- With the weeding-out of superfluous material and the appearance of the old 'Varsity men at the daily baseball practice in the cage, a considerable improvement is shown in the general playing of the 'Varsity squad. The entire list of candidates now numbers twenty-seven players, and from these the nine will be selected.

"A healthy condition of all the functions of the body depends largely upon the care given in early life," said Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders in beginning her lecture upon the care of the "Eyes, Teeth, and Hair" before the members of the Brooklyn Institute last week.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- "Silver Dick" Bland was treated with small consideration in the Democratic House caucus to-day, but he was not handled so rudely as was Mr. McMillin of Tennessee. McMillin was a very energetic candidate for the honor of being named for Speaker, and thus securing the nominal leadership of the minority.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- Among responsible statesmen, the announcement made yesterday by Lord Salisbury in connection with Crete gives perfect satisfaction. The danger of interfering with the integrity of the Turkish Empire is patent to them all. Unfortunately, wise heads are not in the majority in France.

Mr. JESUP, we think, should be reckoned a wiser and greater patron of science than Dr. NANSEN. The secret of the pole has been almost revealed by NANSEN. The next heroic explorer or some fortunate one of the next half dozen, drifting in the ice packs or scrambling over them, will open wide the frozen book, and we shall know all about the polar region.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 13. -- Allan B. Endicott, who holds two offices, that of City Solicitor of Atlantic City and County Collector of Atlantic County, says the law has placed him in a peculiar position. As City Solicitor he advised City Controller Heston to pay one-half the expenses incurred at the Spring election, and said the other half should be paid by the county.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Traders had their attention called to fresh influences this morning. The wheat trade gave less attention to Greece, more to wheat -- especially to wheat fields. The crop is again the leading topic, and crop talk made the market strong. The weather was a bull feature. The provision trade had fresh force. The "crop" here was also the force under prices.

The real estate market of the past six days failed to show satisfactory evidence of a continuation of the activity that distinguished it during the previous week. The brokers closed negotiations at private sale that involved in the aggregate a considerably smaller investment than was then reported.

ATHENS, March 13. -- A dispatch from Larissa, in Thessaly, says that a railway bridge over the River Varduari, near Salonica, Turkey, was blown up with dynamite while a train with 3,000 Turkish troops on board was crossing on it.

Issues of the London newspapers arriving by the latest steamers give completely the text of the speeches made at the farewell banquet tendered to Ambassador Bayard by the Lord Mayor of London at the Mansion House. In response to the address of the Lord Mayor to the guest of the evening, and the toast, Mr. Bayard, who met with a most enthusiastic reception from the brilliant assemblage, said:

Walter Camp, Yale's celebrated coach and football authority, gave his views on the present athletic situation yesterday at a meeting of the Schoolmasters' Association of New York and vicinity, held in Hamilton Hall, Columbia University.

There are two pretty front rooms in a big apartment house on Montague Street, in Brooklyn, into which, if a stranger should find himself suddenly dropped, he would be likely to believe he had been transported to the arctic regions. There are furs on the walls, furs on the floors, furs on the couches and cushioned seats, and the face of a social-looking Eskimo greets the visitor with a comical smile.

In obtaining an order requiring the Police Board to show cause why it should not be enjoined from further proceeding for the removal of Capt. DEVERY the counsel for that officer has raised the question of the constitutionality of the law under which the members of the board hold office.

A young woman, pretty and well dressed, staggered across the City Hall Park shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and sank, apparently exhausted, just as she reached the railing around the Marshal's office under the windows of Mayor Strong's quarters in the City Hall. Policeman Sheehan of the Park police ran to her assistance and she tried to prevent him raising her from the ground.

In a lecture on "Domestic Economy" delivered yesterday afternoon before the cooking school of the Young Women's Christian Association, East Fifteenth Street, Miss Parloa said that, while there is no article of daily food that is so necessary to health as good bread, there is none which is generally so incorrectly made.
The high wind which prevailed yesterday caused considerable inconvenience to craft in the harbor. It came out of the northwest at a fifty-two-mile clip and tossed up lively white caps in the bay.

All the companies of the Seventh Regiment have voted in favor of making a trip to Boston, the Board of Officers has decided that the trip shall be made, and a committee of arrangements has been appointed, comprising Col. D. Appleton, Capt. W.G. Schuyler, Quartermaster; Lieut. J.W. Meyers, Commissary of Subsistence; Capts. W.C. Fisk, Robert McLean, and F.G. Landon.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Speaker Reed was unanimously nominated for Speaker of the House of Representatives at to-night's Republican caucus. The attendance of members was unusually large, 192 of the 203 Republicans being present. The new members were conspicuously numerous.
LONDON, March 13. -- The sonorous press chorus, which takes its key from the Premiers and Chancellors of Europe, is vehemently shouting "Peace, peace!" but all the same there is no peace.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President McKinley has been obliged to divide his time since his inauguration between meeting visitors and applicants for office and the preparation of the message which he will on Monday or Tuesday send to the extraordinary session of the Fifty-fifth Congress.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 13. -- The ticket office of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was entered by burglars about 1 o'clock this morning, and the safe was blown open with gunpowder. The office was badly wrecked by the force of the explosion.

ALBANY, March 13. -- State Factory Inspector O'Leary is much gratified by the results of new mining rules, which he and Mine Inspector King formulated last Fall, and which have been posted in all the mines of the State since Sept. 1 last.
Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe delivered a lecture last night at the American Museum of Natural History on "Edible and Poisonous Mushrooms." A large number of illustrations accompanied the lecture.
Monmouth Park race track, in many respects the finest racecourse ever constructed, is to be sold at auction at the Real Estate Exchange rooms in this city on April 22 next by Adrian H. Muller Sons.

The new President of Sorosis, Mrs. Mary Lyon Dame Hall, who will be installed in office at the annual breakfast of the club, to-morrow, is a comparatively recent member of Sorosis, having joined the organization in 1890. This makes her unanimous election as chief officer of the oldest woman's club in the country the more complimentary.

In a lecture delivered by Dr. H. Augustus Wilson before and for the benefit of the Jefferson Maternity Hospital, in Philadelphia, the subject of the prevention of deformities in childhood was treated at length. From his remarks these excerpts are given as of special interest to parents:

MONTREAL, March 13. -- The looked-for rush to the gold fields of British Columbia has already set in, and each morning the outgoing Canadian Pacific express carries a large number of passengers. It is thought that by the time the snow is fairly cleared from the slopes of Rossland several thousand miners, prospectors, and fortune seekers of all sorts will have been added to the population of the Canadian gold districts.
Open and fair management of corporations is a requisite whose need is becoming daily more and more recognized in every investment quarter.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 13. -- Judge Prentice of the Superior Court to-day filed his decision in the case of Timothy H. Porter, the Stamford millionaire, who sued Thomas G. Ritch and Schuyler Merritt for $250,000 damages. The decision is in favor of the defendants throughout.

The most entertaining of the Lenten diversions of society this season was the "Spielgartenfest," with whist with living cards, at the Waldorf last night. It concluded a day of celebration of the fourth anniversary of the opening of the Waldorf, and the matinee and evening event were given for the benefit of the Society of Decorative Art of 14 West Thirty-fourth Street.

The New York Society of Ceramic Arts held its regular monthly meeting at the Waldorf Monday. A paper on "Enamels for Glass, Soft Glaze, and Unglazed Ware" was read by Miss Anna Siedenberg and illustrated by her work. It was followed by an exhibit of the following art works by members:

The Republican tangle over the Raines law amendments and the Greater New York Police bill, and the fact that Senator Platt came over from Washington to give these and other legislative matters his personal attention, brought almost all of the Republican leaders from Albany yesterday. They swarmed about Mr. Platt's office early in the day, and later they sought to talk with him at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

LONDON, March 13. -- Chief Justice Kotze's determination to shut up the High Court at Pretoria for some months, rather than to submit to the Volksraad's decision placing the law under the heel of Parliament and the Executive, has greatly intensified the discontent among the non-Boer section of the white population.

Rarely has Wall Street had such a week as that just closed. With the stock market exceptionally dull, it was exceptionally strong. For a long time past it has been recognized as natural for stocks to go down whenever dullnees ruled. The firmness of last week is, therefore, taken to be not exceptional only, but significant.
"Meg Merrilies, or the Witch of Ellangowan," will be presented at Daly's Theatre at every performance this week, except those of Tuesday and Friday nights, when "The Geisha" will be given.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore gave yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History his lecture on "Switzerland," which is the last of the series he has been giving under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction.

BOSTON March 13. -- Prof. F.S. Putnam, the celebrated Cambridge archaeologist, has formulated the plans for the exploration in Northwestern North America and Eastern Asia, to ascertain if the peoples constituting what we now know as the American Indian and the Eskimo originated on the Asiatic Continent.

RICHARD WAGNER has come to town. Mr. Damrosch's season of grand opera in German has begun. Grand opera in German in these days means simply performances of Wagner in the original text and the Bayreuth spirit, with occasional intermezzi in the shape of Beethoven's "Fidelio."

Francis Scott Key, the author of "The Star-Spangled Banner," is to have a monument erected to his memory by the citizens of Baltimore, Md., the city in which he died. The monument will be in the form of a bronze statue of heroic size, with a suitable pedestal -- the work of Alexander Doyle, a sculptor of this city.

Assemblyman Lawrence E. Brown introduced at Albany on Friday a bill which provides that the Recorder, City Judge, and the Judges of the Court of General Sessions of this city shall be paid the same salary as is now paid to the Surrogates. The Judges now receive $12,000, and the Surrogates $15,000. Recorder Goff receives $2,000 extra for services as a member of several city boards.

SING SING, N.Y., March 13. -- A daring escape, the first in Sing Sing Prison in over a year, occurred in broad daylight to-day. As near as can be ascertained, James Blane, alias James Irwin and James Irving, got away from the prison about 9:30 o'clock, but it was not until nearly noon that he was discovered to be missing.

Police Commissioner Roosevelt visited Ellis Island yesterday and observed the work of receiving examining, and landing immigrants. He was invited to a seat beside Chairman Ellis of the Board of Special Inquiry, and was permitted to examine some of the immigrants himself.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., March 13. -- It is found that the fire in the Middle Creek Shaft, near Tremont, which was supposed on the 5th inst to have been extinguished, is still burning. On the 3d inst. an explosion of gas occurred in a pump slope, in which accident Thomas Barry and Fred Kreiss lost their lives.

LONDON, March 13. -- Queen Victoria, who arrived at Nice yesterday, will reside during her sojourn at Cimiez at the Excelsior Hotel Regina. An entire wing of the building has been set apart for the use of herself and her attendants. There are about sixty rooms in this wing, which has been completely isolated from the rest of the hotel by a wall running from top to bottom.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Ex-Chairman Dingley of the House Ways and Means Committee to-day said the new tariff bill was nearly completed, and probably would be introduced in the House next Monday or Tuesday. He said, however, that the rates were subject to change, and alterations probably would be made in many cases.

A suit against Benjamin Gates and Levi Shaw, Trustees of the Shaker society of New Lebanon. Columbia County, has been brought by Greene Johnson, of THE TIMES Building on behalf of the Graves Elevator Company of Rochester in the Supreme Court, Columbia County. The object is to hold the society responsible for some of Robert Valentine's extensive dealings in real estate in this city.

Booker T. Washington, Principal of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, delivered an address at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church last night. There was a large audience, Mr. Washington having a reputation here as an entertaining speaker and a capable instructor and manager.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The new Tariff bill will be introduced in the House to-morrow as soon as the organization is perfected, and will be referred to the Ways and Means Committee, by whom it was prepared. It is still incomplete. The committee spent the better part of to-day revising the schedules, and this work will be continued until to-morrow noon. Many details require careful consideration, and are liable to change at the last moment.

-- The Lewiston Journal, a paper which has a reputation for knowing a joke even when it is not accompanied with a glossary and a map, says that a mechanical genius whose "studio-shop" stands not far from that paper's office has invented a rotary engine beside which the one GRANT BRAMBEL didn't sell for $6,700,000 is no more impressive than a coffee grinder.

Strained relations exist to a degree approximating bitterness in Republican machine politics, aggravated by the outcome of the conference held in the parlors of Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, when the amendments to the liquor tax law advocated by Senator Raines were virtually indorsed.

A number of women interested in the education of children met in the Art Building of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences the other day to listen to a practical talk on anger and its manifestations from Mrs. Franklin W. Hooper. Many of them are engaged in teaching, and were able to contribute amusing bits of their experience in meeting the obstinacy or bad temper of their scholars.

At Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, Dr. Lyman Abbott reviewed his former sermons, under "Summary of Results." He made a general answer to the criticisms that he has undermined religious faith and impaired the usefulness of the Bible. He read a list of some of the universities and theological seminaries that are teaching the results of the higher criticism, in order to prove that his sermons contained no new or unusual doctrines.

ALBANY, March 14. -- With one exception every important question upon which legislation is expected this session by the Republican Party leaders is about ready for legislative consideration. The exception lies in the fact that as yet no bill has been prepared to carry out Gov. Black's determination, as expressed in his annual message, to take the "starch" out of the civil service.

ALBANY, March 14. -Superintendent Louis F. Payn has made public the report of the State Insurance Department for the year ended Dec. 31 last, on the business of fire and marine insurance companies transacting business in this State. This report was written by former State Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- To-morrow at noon both houses of the Fifty-fifth Congress will convene in extraordinary session. It is not likely that the Senate will remain in continuous session during the week, unless the President is much more expeditious than he has been in making nominations.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 14. -- Hattie H. Canfield of this city, widow of Edward Canfield, a nephew of John Canfield, the millionaire lumberman of Manistee, Mich., has brought two suits against John Canfield to recover $2,000,000 worth of property.

DENVER, Col., March 14. -- The Middle- of-the-Road Populists had an exciting convention here yesterday. There was a great deal of violent language and some personal encounters. Women were in the thick of the fighting, and two of them severely punished a man who said something they did not like.

Mary Caurisi, twelve years old, of Albany Avenue, King's Bridge, and her eight-year-old brother. Michaelo, were locked up in the King's Bridge Police Station Saturday night, charged with having stolen two oranges from John Tague of 345 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Prof. J. Leverett Moore of Vassar College, in a lecture before an audience of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences last week, showed that many of the social problems of the present age worried the Romans in the first century.

CHICAGO, March 14. -- A church with a seating capacity of 3,000 persons, heated by three furnaces, and lighted with electric lamps, was built between daylight and midnight yesterday at Winchester and Wilson Avenues, in Ravenswood, and was dedicated at 10:45 o'clock this morning by the Rev. M.B. Williams of Atlanta, Ga., assisted by nearly all of the clergymen in Ravenswood.

Various reports have been circulated recently as to the future of Transfiguration Chapel, at the Boulevard and Sixty-ninth Street, and Protestant Episcopal church circles in the diocese are wondering what will be the future of this interesting adjunct to the up-town work of "The Little Church Around the Corner."
CHICAGO, March 14. -- Nearly 2,000 unemployed workmen met to-day at Zepf's Hall and indulged in the most threatening demonstration since the labor disturbance of 1894.

When the House meets to-day Mr. DINGLEY will report "An act to Procure Revenue for the Government and to Protect the Industries of the United States." The question of how much revenue is needed depends upon two facts -- the receipts and the expenditures. The expenditures for the coming fiscal year were fixed by the appropriations of the Congress just expired.
The following sales are announced for to-day at 111 Broadway:

LONDON, March 14. -- Another Radical manifestation to express sympathy with Greece in her efforts in behalf of the Cretan Christians was held this afternoon in Trafalgar Square At last Sunday's meeting in Hyde Park there were 20,000 persons present, and to-day it was estimated that the assemblage was fully as large, if not larger.

LONDON, March 14. -- The Morning Post will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople saying that advices have been received there from Adana showing that the people of that town are in a terrible condition. The Armenians are in fear of their lives, and dare not leave the quarter allotted to them for occupancy.

It has been a long time since Wall Street has had the chance to begin a week with prospects so fair as now appear. A long list of depressing factors have disappeared, and such bad features as remain in the situation do not threaten to become dominant.

ALBANY, March 14. -- The cost of "maintaining" the State Capitol and other public buildings here for the two fiscal years last passed, as shown by warrants drawn in the Controller's office, was $648,425.50. Of this, $295,221.13 was spent in 1895, and $353,204.37 in 1896. These were increases over the preceding year of about $60,000 in the first instance and $121,000 in the second.

The very means which the powers have taken to show that their concert is unbroken show that it cannot be maintained. The Greek proposition that the powers must either allow Greece to protect the Cretan Christians or assume that task themselves is so manifestly reasonable that it is not opposed by any nation of Western Europe.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 14. -- The Mississippi River here is higher than ever before since the establishment of the weather office, in 1872, and probably since the sinking of the lowlands of Missouri, Arkansas, and Tennessee by earthquakes. The rise to-day was slightly above half a foot.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14. -- The New York World has been excluded from the Yale University reading room.

CANEA, March 14. -- As has before been stated, the fact that the powers have decided to establish an autonomous Government in Crete is not generally known to the insurgent leaders. This it is said, is due to Admiral Reineck, lately in command of the Greek fleet, who refused to act as an interpreter between the foreign Admirals and the insurgents for the conveyance of information furnished by the former.

The first fruits of Mr. DINGLEY'S new tariff have come to market, and, naturally, in the form of a curtailment of American trade and a damage to American interests. Its enactment threatens to cut off $10,000,000 of our export trade in a single product.

" The Temple of Humanity," as Lazarus Morgenthau calls his residence, 178 East Seventy-second Street, which is also the headquarters of the Orphan Dowry Fund, that he founded some time ago, was the scene last night of the second wedding held under the auspices of that fund.

ROANOKE, Va., March 14. -- Some of Roanoke's ex-Confederates took occasion to-day to mildly remind Bishop Mallalieu of Boston that his utterances condemning the Confederacy will not be tolerated in the South without protest.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 14. -- The new altar and reredos erected in the Church of the Ascension were dedicated this afternoon by Bishop Talbot of Wyoming, assisted by the Rev. F.M.S. Taylor, rector of the church, and several visiting clergymen. The altar was given to the church by E.B. Wesley, a well-known New York business man, in memory of his wife, Elizabeth Wesley.

A resolution to place the Brooklyn Bridge employes under civil service rules will be introduced by Trustee Henriques at the next meeting of the Board of Trustees. The proposed resolution is as follows:

A small bit of card, with the word "No" marked in plain black letters, has recently been placed conspicuously on the desk of a well-known and successful merchant, whose office is less than a mile from the Equitable Building. It is a sad epitome of the prevalent hard times, and the frequent untrustworthiness of human nature.

BERLIN, March 14. -- The Kaiser Wilhelm centenary celebration, which will begin on March 22, is the absorbing matter of internal interest just now. The preparations for the celebration have called into existence an amazing Collection of industrial and literary products. There are centenary trinkets, bracelets, watches, cigar cases, postcards, medals, stamps, songs, and everything that fertile brains can think of as being likely to strike the public taste.

The first of four recitals entitled "Evenings with the Poets" will be given at Association Hall, Bond and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, on April 2, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
The Rev. Minot J. Savage of the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, delivered a sermon yesterday on "Man Not Fallen, but Rising."

AUBURN, N.Y., March 14. -- The jury in the case of the accused wife-murderer, Frank N. Sheldon, has been out seventy-two hours, and gives no intimation of having arrived any nearer to an agreement than when it went out Thursday evening.

HAVANA, March 14. -- Gen. Jimenez Castellanos, learning that the members of the revolutionary Government were at San Geronimo, started on the 4th inst. from Puerto Principe with a strong column, with the intention of making an attempt to capture them.

BALTIMORE, March 14. -- Richard Matthias, thirty-five years old, is locked up at the Central Station on a charge of bigamy. It is alleged that on April 7, 1890, Matthias married, in Philadelphia, a Miss Sealer. In September, 1893, he disappeared. A few weeks later it became known to Mrs. Matthias that her husband had married Miss Julia Birchner of Flushing, L.I.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 14. -- The new Board of Village Trustees, which was chosen at the late charter election, has decided to investigate the financial affairs of the village with a view to discover whether some of the old officers conducted the business of their offices in a straightforward way.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., March 14. -- In the vicinity of Prairietown, a German settlement twelve miles north of here, a peculiar disease has been raging during the last five weeks, baffling the skill of the medical profession.

ALBANY, March 14. -- Senator Jacob A. Cantor, the Democratic leader in the State Legislature, has some decided opinions about trusts and the work of the Lexow Trust Investigating Committee. In discussing the question to-night, the Senator said:

CHICAGO, March 14. -- MM. Jean and Edouard De Reszke gave a dinner last night in the Auditorium Annex. Fourteen guests, including the stars of the opera company and several friends from New York City, were present. The dinner was served in the ladies' cafe of the annex, on the first floor.

PHOENIXVILLE, Penn., March 14. -- Barney McKernan, a survivor of the Light Brigade which was made famous by the charge at Balaklava during the Crimean war, died at the home of his daughter, in this place, last night, aged seventy-two years.

LONDON, March 14. -- The rate of discount during the past week for three months' bills was 1 1/2 per cent., and for thirty-day bills 1 1/4 per cent. Gold continues to arrive from Australia and Cape Colony. Japan has purchased most of the bars. Silver was weak owing to the passage by the Japanese House of Representatives of the bill establishing a gold standard.

Gardiner's Island, which lies well out to sea, a considerable distance east of Shelter Island, has a great interest for those lovers of salt air and historical tradition who spend their Summers on or near the extreme eastern end of Long Island. This is a quaint and fertile spot, about which the general public knows but little.

Mayor STRONG is responsible for the continuance of the Police Board scandal. In preventing the trial and punishment of gross offenses against the discipline of the force Commissioners GRANT and PARKER have committed acts of malfeasance justifying their removal. In such an emergency the law expects the Mayor to intervene, and provides a way. It becomes his duty to act.

BERLIN, March 7. -- The war that ever wages between the Chancellor that is out and the Chancellor that is in registers its effects in the art world of Germany. Last Summer the art exhibition at Berlin, and even more so the exhibition of the year before, testified by the presence of numerous statues of Bismarck the great popularity of the heroic grumbler of Friedrichsruh; this Winter there is a counter demonstration.

In St. Michael's Church, Ninety-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday, the Rev. Dr. John P. Peters preached from the text, "Man shall not live by bread alone." In the course of his address Dr. Peters referred to the Cretan question, saying among other things:

PANAMA, March 4. -- According to official returns something like 105,000 immigrants arrived at Buenos Ayres, Argentina, during the year 1896, principally from Italy. This is the best record since the year 1890, and yet there is still a cry from Estancieros and farmers at seasons for hands, a pretty sure indication that the country is prospering as far as production is concerned.
The two dominating forces which now seem to be in control, the one of the Democratic Party, the other of the Republican Party, are

No tidings of George W. Mandel, the young Brooklyn business man who so mysteriously disappeared a week ago Saturday, have been received yet. Mandel's father is dead. His mother and sister, who live at 155 Vernon Avenue, Brooklyn, are nearly prostrated over his disappearance, and are doing everything in their power to locate him.

KEITHSBURG, Ill., March 14. -- William Drury, the millionaire land owner, aged eighty-seven, died to-night at his magnificent home Verdurett, north of this city. He was the largest individual land owner in the United States, having hundreds of thousands of acres in Colorado, Nebraska, Kansas, and Texas, besides 6,000 acres of the richest farming land in this county.
Alderman Ware's Opinion that It Is an Outrage for the Legislature to Authorize Such Obstructions -The Streets Disfigured and the City Injured.

The Central Labor Union yesterday received a letter from District Assembly 253, Building Constructors, Knights of Labor, complaining that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company refused to give transfers at many of its points in violation of its charter.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- President McKinley again attended services this morning at the Metropolitan Methodist Church, where President Grant was a communicant during his residence in the White House, and half a block distant from the First Presbyterian Church, in which President Cleveland had a pew.

HAVANA, March 14. -- The spectacle of poor, weak women and sickly babes under arrest was presented here Friday, it being a party of Cuban women brought in from Santiago, Bejucal, and other points nearby, in accordance with Weyler's last orders.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Ex-Senator Hill is on his way back to New York. He has been ill, and only recovered in time to finish his packing and get away to-day.
BALTIMORE, March 15. -- There seems to be little doubt that the missing steamer Laurada of fiilibustering fame has succeeded in landing another expedition on the Cuban coast.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Before the Congress met to-day the Representatives and Senators found time to go to the White House and see the President. Most of them said that they went to "pay respects," but the belief is that, with the exception of such silver Democrats as Culberson of Texas and such others as ex-Senator Dubois and Representative Hartman, they went to get places for constituents.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Weather Bureau reports from the central valleys indicate continued rise in the Lower Mississippi River during the next ten days or two weeks, and from the water now in sight and rainfall likely to occur within the next few days, it is probable the impending flood will prove very destructive in Arkansas and Northern Louisiana.

CANEA, March 15. -- The village of Kissamo, to the westward of this city, is now in ruins from the bombardment of the insurgents, and the fires which followed the bombardment. The fort guarding the village is, however, intact, the insurgents not yet having succeeded in reducing it, though they have been firing upon it for nearly four days.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Secretary Long issued orders to-day for the official acceptance trial of the gunboats Wilmington and Helena in Long Island Sound over the twenty-seven-knot measured course of New London next Monday and Tuesday. The Secretary has designated the following board to conduct the trials:

As "the proof of the pudding is in the raisins" it would be well for the high tariff editorial writers of The Tribune to read the news that the paper contains before they try to delude their readers with their cure-all for commercial depression. I cut the following from a Fall River dispatch printed in that paper's news columns yesterday:

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Vice President Hobart has selected as his secretary Mr. Frederick Evans, Jr., of Newark, N.J. Mr. Evans entered upon his duties to-day, succeeding Mr. Lewis G. Stevenson, a son of ex-Vice President Stevenson.

A score or more of property owners and merchants in Eighth Avenue conferred with William C. Whitney and John D. Crimmins, representing the Metropolitan Traction Company, in Mr. Crimmins's office yesterday afternoon, in relation to the proposed change of motive power on the Eighth Avenue Railroad.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Mr. Dingley, Chairman of the last Ways and Means Committee, the Republican members of which prepared the Tariff bill presented to the House to-day, makes public this statement:
TRENTON, N.J., March 15. -- Both branches of the Legislature met at 8:30 o'clock to-night.

Twenty-two athletic young men representing the New York Baseball Club left the city yesterday forenoon for Lakewood, N.J., where they hope to get into condition for the opening of the championship season. This will fall on April 22. The players have, therefore, over four weeks in which to limber up after their Winter's rest.

An exciting race with fire took place in the North River yesterday, when the tugboat Reindeer was discovered to be in flames. The crew of five men were saved by the bravery of Capt. Almer Downer, who, with the flames breaking through the flooring, stuck to the wheel until the boat was run ashore.

The proposed erection of a new place of worship at Seventy-sixth Street and Central Park West, by the Fourth Universalist Church, better known as the Church of the Divine Paternity, of Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, has caused quite a stir among the members of the Church of the Eternal Hope, Eighty-first Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, Some of them declare it is an encroachment upon their field.

Mr. Walter Damrosch gave the opera-going public an admirable performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The auditorium was packed as it has not been this Winter except at representations of "Faust," and the air was filled with gladsome sounds of jubilation.

Mr. DINGLEY is talking nonsense when he says that a higher tariff is needed to protect American industries from "excessive foreign competition." The imports under the present tariff have been smaller than under the McKinley tariff, and if he is at all fit for his place at the head of the Ways and Means Committee he knows it.

We should be glad to believe that the topsy-turvy reasoning and quack statecraft of President McKINLEY'S message proceed from an honestly deluded mind. That theory of his utterances may not be flattering, but it is the pink of courtesy compared to the alternative hypothesis that he has sent this message to Congress and to the country conscious of its perversions of fact and well knowing that its recommendations are hostile to the general welfare.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 15. -- The weather to-day was fine and the track was fast. Five favorites won.

The Congregational Club of New York and vicinity met at the St. Denis Hotel last night, and, after partaking of a dinner, the members listened to a discussion of the question, "Are Trusts and Great Combinations of Capital a Menace to the Public Welfare?" The speakers were Prof. J.W. Jenks, who holds the chair of political economy at Cornell University, and Francis B. Thurber of this city.

The record of large customs receipts was broken yesterday. The little pushcart that carries imposts from the Custom House to the Sub-Treasury was freighted with $2,667,979.51 in cash, or its equivalent, but with little more than $50 in gold coin. The cart left an hour after its usual time, 4 o'clock, and Cashier W.E. Northrup looked relieved when he was handed a receipt for the large sum.

The Sportsmen's Exposition proved a great attraction at Madison Square Garden all day yesterday. Sportsmen in large numbers studied carefully the guns, rods, camping outfits, boats, launches, and various other accessories that bring joy to all sportsmen.

ALBANY, March 15. -- There were more deer killed in the Adirondacks during the last open season than there were in the previous one, if the first report made to the Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission is an index.
Pincus Lowenfeld and William Prager have bought of J. and J. Reubell 301 and 303 East Third Street, two three-story brick dwellings, on plot 40 by 96.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- All else except the climax of to-day's spectacle at the Capitol was usual and commonplace. The climax was reached when Mr. Dingley, standing in his place in the House, introduced the bill "to provide revenue for the Government and to encourage the industries of the United States."

No more explicit provision was put into the Constitution of this State when it was revised and ratified in 1894, and none of which the meaning is more unmistakable, than that prohibiting public officers from accepting free transportation from corporations.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The Cologne Gazette confirms the report that Admiral Hollmann, the head of the Imperial Admiralty, has resigned in consequence of the action of the Budget Committee of the Reichstag in rejecting his demand for increased credits and because of disagreement with his colleagues in the Ministry in connection with his recent speech before the Budget Committee.
Archbishop Corrigan presided at the meeting held last night at the Lenox Lyceum under the Archdiocesan Union of Temperance Societies to discuss the subject of "The Social Betterment of the Masses."
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 15. -- The first loss of life resulting from the high water was recorded to-day, an entire negro family and one white child being drowned near Marion, Ark.

The monitor Puritan, in a partially disabled condition, on account of broken down engines, arrived off Sandy Hook yesterday morning, towed by the cruiser Columbia. It took her twelve days to return from Charleston, where she participated in the naval manoeuvres. The Columbia dropped her tow off Sandy Hook, and from there the Brooklyn Navy Yard tugs Nasheeta and Nina took her to the Navy Yard, where she arrived at about 2:30 o'clock.

The women who complain that their sex has not its due share of influence in public affairs ought to be reassured by the present aspect of National politics. It is credibly reported that the appointments are "held up" because the wives of the persons proposed to be appointed have assumed some sort of social superiority to the wives of some of the Senators who are to pass upon the appointments.

Mayor Strong will begin the hearings in the street and sidewalk obstruction cases thirty minutes ahead of schedule time today. He announces that the Leonard bill will be taken up at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, with the hope that the discussion can be concluded before the Finn measure is called.
PARIS, March 15. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Government was questioned as to the Greco-Cretan situation and the action which had been taken by France in regard thereto.

The regular weekly meeting of the Methodist ministers was held this morning at 150 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. F.M. North, Corresponding Secretary of the City Church Extension Society, offered the following resolutions, which were adopted:
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President McKinley's message to the extraordinary session of Congress was submitted this afternoon, as follows:

There was a golden atmosphere of Spring, love, and jonquils in Sorosis yesterday. It was the great day of the year in Sorosis's calendar, her annual breakfast, with the installation of her newly elected officers.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The new naval Administration will soon take under consideration plans already matured by naval experts for laying up some of the United States warships in reserve, according to the practice of every European navy.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 15. -- Gov. Bushnell this afternoon appointed Ray S. Kayler of Alliance State Commissioner of Railroads and Telegraphs, vice William Kirkby, whose term had expired.
ALBANY, March 15. -- When the Senate convened to-night a communication was received from the Governor nominating as Trustees of the New York State Soldiers and Sailors' Home at Bath:
The boxing bout last night between "Mike" Sears and "Dave" Wall, at the Cosmopolitan Athletic Club, was brought to a stop unexpectedly.

BOSTON, March 15. -- This morning the Boston Rubber Shoe Company, one of the largest corporations in the manufacture of rubber shoes, sent out a circular to the trade, in which a reduction of from 12 to 16 per cent. was made from the price list of last year. This action was taken in some quarters as an indication of a fight against the United States Rubber Company.
LONDON, March 15. -Prof. James J. Sylrester died in this city to-day.

HAVANA, March 15. -- La Lucha, echoing the rumors that have been in circulation for some time, announces the dissolution of the Autonomist party, and says that the Marquis de Montoro, Senores Cueto, Zayas, and Saladrigas, the leaders of that party, will join the Reformists. The programme of the Reformists will be radically extended.
CHICAGO, March 15. -- The Tribune this morning publishes the following:

-- From a brief announcement in The Gainesville (Ga.) Sun we learn that "by the end of the present month a site for Editoria, the National Home for Editors and Publishers, will have been determined upon." Evidently some scheme is on foot that deserves wider discussion and closer examination than it has yet had in this part of the country.

WEST POINT, March 15. -- The report that Miss Blanche Berard, Postmistress here for the past fifty years, had resigned, was heard with regret by all who are acquainted with the venerable woman. The resignation was sent to Washington last week, but has not yet been accepted.

James Hayes, once a prominent figure in city affairs, died on Sunday at his home, 87 Fourth Avenue. He was a power in politics when it was considered tile proper thing for a politician to belong to the Volunteer Fire Department and run with the machine, and when the ourteenth V'ard was the hot-bed of Tammany politics.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 15. -- William Clement, (colored,) who was put in the county jail at Rustburg last week for assaulting Mr. George Rosser was taken from his cell at an early hour this morning and shot several times.
Richard Healy of Worcester came to New York week before last to discharge about $10,000 worth of debts, which had been outlawed.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 15. -- Frank Sheldon was this morning convicted of murder in the first degree for the killing of his wife, and was sentenced to be executed the week of April 25. The jury was out 84 1/2 hours. The trial lasted seven weeks. The verdict seemed to greatly surprise Sheldon, his counsel, relatives, and friends.
BOSTON, March 15. -- Judge Colt in the United States Circuit Court to-day ordered the public sale of the Atlas Tack Corporation, known as the Tack Trust, now in the hands of a receiver.

ALBANY, March 15. -- As soon as it had met to-night the Assembly took up Senator Wilcox's bill requiring railroad companies to transport State officers free of charge, which had been made a special order for to-night on second and third readings. The bill was advanced to a third reading without delay, and was about to be placed on its final passage when Mr. Robbins announced that he proposed to debate the measure.

More business was done on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday than on any day for some time past. The general list showed advancing tendencies. Many conspicuous stocks went up materially. Wall Street still pins its faith to the theory that Vanderbilt interests have combined to bring about conditions which are quickly bound to result in big gains in market values.

PADUCAH, Ky., March 15. -- Milton G. Cope, former President of the First National Bank, has disappeared, and it is charged that he is a forger to the extent of $13,000. The facts have been reported to United States District Attorney Smith, who will place them before the Federal Grand Jury.

The dispatches indicate that the line of cleavage between the Governments that are controlled by public opinion and the Governments that defy it is more and more clearly drawn. With one noteworthy and anomalous exception, it is a geographical line between Eastern and Western Europe, between mediaeval and modern Europe.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 15. -- Superintendent of Police Bull has lodged with the District Attorney a charge against Superintendent of Streets Thomas F. Maloney, of attempted bribery, and has demanded an investigation by the Grand Jury. Superintendent Bull accuses Superintendent Maloney of declaring in the presence of witnesses that he (Bull) had accepted money to protect the Goelet Club, a gambling enterprise at 17 West Eagle Street, and had afterward caused it to be raided.

The sarcophagus in which the body of Gen. U.S. Grant will permanently rest arrived here yesterday from Montello, Wis. It came through, and was brought across the river from Jersey City, on the same flat on which it was loaded at the quarry, and is now in the Pennsylvania Railroad yard, Thirty-seventh Street and North River.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The extraordinary session of the Fifty-fifth Congress was opened in the Senate by reading the President's proclamation convening it. Sixty-eight Senators answered to the roll call, and the galleries were filled to overflowing.

The Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution met last evening at the Hotel Normandie and had a warm discussion over the adoption of a report, a resolution, and a bill to be presented to the Legislature prohibiting the use of the National flag for advertising or political purposes.

ST. LOUIS, March 15 -- A fire which started in the fourth floor of the building occupied by the Ely Walker Dry Goods Company, southwest corner of Eighth Street and Washington Avenue, at 8 o'clock to-night, destroyed the entire building.

The proposed Tariff bill prepared by the Ways and Means Committee of the House, is entitled "A bill to provide revenue for the Government, and to encourage the industries of the United States." Its provisions are as follows:

Representatives of several of the important bonded warehouses told a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that the rush to pay duties and withdraw goods in bond is evidently over, and the report from the Custom House appears to confirm their opinions.
KINGSTON, March 16. -- It is said that Luman Reed Mulford, a prominent young married man of this city, now confined in the Poughkeepsie Insane Asylum, is a forge.

LONDON, March 16. -- The Daily Mail, under the caption "The Transvaal; A Grave Situation," will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Cape Town saying that the British troops there have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness for an emergency.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 16. -- The big Haden land suit has been thrown out of court on the ground that the marriage agreement underlying it was made on Sunday, and was therefore illegal.
TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 16. -- At the session of the House this afternoon a resolution urging Senators Quay and Penrose to vote for the ratification of the arbitration treaty was returned from the Committee on Federal Relations with a negative recommendation.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The new Tariff bill was considered to-day by the Ways and Means Committee. The morning session lasted three hours. The time was occupied principally in discussing the several schedules and explaining the reasons for the various increases. These explanations were made by the members who were most conversant with the work.
Charles Griffith Moses has sold for Samuel L. Laderer three lots, 75 by 100, on the east side of Vermilye Avenue, 25 feet north of Hawthorne Street.
ATHENS, March 16. -- Crown Prince Constantine, with the First Regiment of infantry, is momentarily expected to leave Athens to assume command of all the Greek forces in Thessaly.

It was ten years before last night since Mozart's opera, "The Magic Flute" had been heard in this city. It was last performed by the ill-fated American Opera Company, when the only memorable feature was Pauline l'Allemand's Queen of the Night. It was brought forward once again last evening in aid of a deserving charity, the Workingman's School.

PARIS, March 16. -- M. Hanotaux, Minister of Foreign Affairs, made in the Senate to-day a declaration of the policy of France in the matter of the Greco-Cretan situation similar to that which he made in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday, when he announced that France would adhere to the concert policy, and at the conclusion of his statement asked for a vote of confidence in the Government.

There was much studying of the new Tariff bill by manufacturers and importers, merchants and brokers, lawyers and bankers, and business men generally in this city yesterday. In almost every branch of commerce and of professional industry ordinary matters were put aside for the time being, while the measure introduced in the House of Representatives by Mr. Dingley last Monday was scanned with an eager interest.

It appears that the vote on the Wilcox bill for the free transportation of public officers did not carry that bold defiance of the Constitution through the Assembly on Monday night, though it "came within one of it." The vote was 27 short of the full membership of the Assembly, and the motion to reconsider was left on the table, where it could be taken up again.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Senator Wieman's bill permitting barbering in Greater New York and Saratoga Springs up to 1 o'clock Sundays met with considerable opposition when it came up on second reading in the Assembly to-day. Mr. Dudley favored an amendment permitting Niagara Falls to enjoy the same privileges.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 16. -- The indignation of the student body at Cornell over the alleged sending of a flag to Fitzsimmons has been growing day by day. This morning Prof. Hufficut of the College of Law devoted a part of his 10 o'clock lecture hour to the juniors of the school to a ringing speech on the disgracefulness of the proceeding.

The latest plan of the Rapid Transit Commissioners was considered yesterday by the Board of Aldermen in committee of the whole. Alderman School presided, and A.B. Boardman of counsel to the commission made a few introductory remarks, in which he said that Commissioners John Claflin and Woodbury Langdon and Secretary Delafield were present to answer questions.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The usual crowd of office seekers gathered at the White House to-day, and many of them had an audience with the President.
CHICAGO, March 16. -- Earnings of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road for the second week in March were $514,334; for the corresponding week of 1896, $630,544; decrease, $116,210.
The Finn bill virtually received its deathblow yesterday. Mayor Strong announced his disapproval of the measure, at the close of a long discussion.

One of the notable society weddings of the Lenten season was that of Miss Elizabeth Mary Coster, daughter of Mrs. Charles R. Coster of 27 West Eleventh Street, to Alfred Egmont Schermerhorn, son of Mrs. Alfred Schermerhorn of 441 Park Avenue, and a Yale graduate of the class of '95, which was celebrated in Grace Church yesterday at noon, in the presence of nearly 1,500 friends and relatives of the bride and bridegroom.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Senator Lexow today introduced two bills to regulate trusts. They were prepared by Charles Z. Lincoln, the Governor's legal adviser, and are intended to carry out the recommendations of Mr. Lexow's report.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 16. -- Three men were fatally burned at the Emma blast furnace early this morning by a series of explosions of molten metal. They were covered with the seething, hissing metal, and are at St. Alexis Hospital.

MADRID, March 16. -- The Archbishop of Manila, the capital of the Philippine Islands, has cabled to the authorities here that 20,000 additional troops, to reinforce the Spanish soldiery there, are imperatively necessary, and that there should be no delay in forwarding them.

A match game of basket ball, between a team from Yale and the team of the Central Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, took place last night at the armory building, Flatbush Avenue and Hanson Place, Brooklyn. Yale won by a score of 11 to 4. In the first half the score stood 8 to 3 in Yale's favor.

Mr. DINGLEY'S Tariff bill has a defective and dishonest title. It is described as "A bill to provide revenue for the Government and to encourage the industries of the United States." If the authors of the bill had been willing to reveal their secret purposes and its actual effects, it would have been entitled:

President MCKINLEY has made very good use of the two diplomatic places which have more to do with the estimation of this country abroad than any other two in the gift of the President. The London Embassy is the most important. Bad French may be forgiven to our Ambassador in Paris, but bad English is not permissible from the American representative in London.

ALBANY, March 16. -- When the bill of Senator Brackett increasing the number of Railroad Commissioners from three to five and reducing the salary from $8,000 to $5,000, and the salary of the Secretary of the commission from $6,000 to $4,800, came up in the Senate to-day, in general orders, Senator Grant offered an amendment to restore the salaries to their present amounts.

Patriotism and Irishmen may be considered synonymous words to-day, for everywhere the sons of Erin may be found there will be seen some sort of observance in honor of the memory of Ireland's patron saint.

Although the maintenance and enlargement of the Adirondack forest preserve is a matter which concerns most of all the citizens of the State of New York, yet its importance is understood and interest in it is felt far beyond the limits of your State. People who believed in Gov. Black's zeal in regard to this matter must be surprised at his sudden weakening before the assaults of the lumbermen and papermakers.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16. -- Warm weather, a fast track, and 3,500 people marked to-day's races here. The sport was lively, favorites and outsiders dividing the card. In the fourth race, however, it looked to most people as if a claim of foul made by the jockey of Marquise on Robert Bonner should have been allowed, as the jockey of the latter in the last sixteenth repeatedly hit Marquise on the head with his whip.

The Board of Managers of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, representing the Church throughout the United States, met yesterday afternoon in the chapel in the Methodist Building, at Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street, for the transaction of general business. One matter which has been before the Church in one way and another for some years past was definitely disposed of.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 16. -- The Grand Jury this afternoon found indictments for arson against Pearl Clifton, Maud Gallagher, and Charles R. Newhof, Pearl Clifton's stepfather, who are charged with setting fire to the residence 250 Normal Avenue on Feb. 27.

ALBANY, March 16. -- The Assembly Committee on Codes gave a hearing to-day on Assemblyman Green's bill making less restrictive the present statute prohibiting the employment of children in various occupations.

BOSTON, March 16. -- Great dissatisfaction with the Dingley Tariff bill is expressed in the wool and sugar trades. Henry H. Reed of the Revere Sugar Refinery said to-day: "It is a pretty high tax to put upon that which is so essentially a food necessity as is sugar; upon that which affects not only the rich man, but all the poor alike.

The late Artemus Ward sagely remarked that the trouble with NAPOLEON BONAPARTE was that he "tried to do too much -- and did it." It is a question whether Senator PLATT, "boss" of the Republican "machine," has not been trying to do too much and whether he is not in danger of doing it, with consequences disastrous to his party.

HARRODSBURG, Ky., March 16. -- Tollgate raiders from Washington and Anderson Counties swooped down on Mercer County toll gates Sunday night and destroyed seven of them on the Mackville, Cornishville, and Oakdale turnpikes.

No doubt the vote in the French Chamber on Monday settles for some time to come France's position in Europe. She will, for the present at least, maintain the concert. Our London correspondent sent us in the cable letter printed last Sunday the cynical explanation current in Paris in advance of the event.

The dispatch from Berlin to a London paper, setting forth that the Kaiser has exhibited symptoms of actual derangement, should not be too lightly dismissed as incredible. There has indeed been something in the recent behavior of the Kaiser to prepare us for such an announcement.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 16. -- Amy Busby, the actress, arrived in this city today and is now at the home of her father, Thomas M. Busby. Miss Busby dictated the following statement contradicting the announcement of her coming marriage to William Gillette, and also as to her reasons for leaving the " Secret Service " company, now playing in Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- There is every indication of a much freer interchange of views and of confidences between the State Department and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate since the advent of the new Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:
ATLANTA, Ga., March 16. -- "Get guns, negroes," is the advice which Henry M. Turner, Bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, gives to his people.

Alderman Hall presented to the Board of Aldermen yesterday a petition for the consent of the city to the sale of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum property which occupies the entire block just north of the cathedral on Fifth Avenue. It was originally acquired from the city to be used for hospital purposes only, and the consent of the city is necessary before it can be sold.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- In the Senate to-day the President's message, on motion of Mr. Morrill, (Rep., Vt.,) was referred to the Finance Committee.

Frank Linden, "the man in gray," who is accused of committing several robberies in Morrisania, yesterday confessed that he stole an overcoat from the hallway of 129 East Thirty-fifth Street March 1 at 7:30 P.M. Walter Taylor had been arrested for this crime, and Agnes Kelly, a servant, who said she had been choked by the robber, had identified him as the thief.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission resumed yesterday morning, in the Board Room of the Produce Exchange, its hearing of the complaint of the Produce Exchange against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company and other railroads forming the Joint Traffic Association. The complaint is that the defendant railroads maintain arbitrary and unjust differential rates on freight from Western shipping points, to the great and increasing detriment of the trade of this port.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 16. -- The cut in discounts announced by the Boston Rubber Shoe Company is accepted here as a notification to the Banigan Rubber Company that it will be war to the knife between the Rubber Trust and the Boston Shoe Company on the one side and the Banigan Company on the other.

LONDON, March 16. -- Answering a question by the Earl of Kimberley, late Minister of Foreign Affairs, in the House of Lords to-day, Lord Salisbury said that instructions had been sent to the Admirals commanding the foreign warships in Cretan waters to put the blockade of the ports of the Island of Crete into operation at once.
Gen. James M. Warner, a wealthy and prominent business man of Albany, died last night from a stroke of apoplexy while witnessing a performance of "The Geisha," in Daly's Theatre.
The fly-casting tournament is one of the main attractions at the Sportsmen's Show, and during the contests each afternoon and evening the space in the vicinity of the artificial pool is crowded.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 11. -- The elected representatives of the people of this island are united in their determination to leave no stone unturned to secure closer and more satisfactory trade relations with the United States. Some years ago an effort was made to negotiate a reciprocity treaty, but the British Government quashed it in the bud. Now the attempt is going to be repeated.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., March 17. -- The epidemic which is sweeping through this place, taking for its victims, as yet, only employes of the rubber mills, claimed three fresh victims to-day. Five have died this week, and three more cases of sickness reported to-day makes the total of those now sick fifty-two. Those who died to-day were Jeremiah Layhen, Rancel Cole, and Michael Riordan.

The steamer Island, Capt. Thompson, of the Thingvalla Line, reached her pier in Hoboken yesterday after a very stormy passage from Copenhagen. Once the vessel ran short of coal, and high seas had severely injured her and crippled some of her seamen.
What a message President McKINLEY could write with the letter of the Union veteran which we published yesterday morning as a text!

Louis McCoy, a negro, is one of the most desperate prisoners in the Kings County Penitentiary. On Saturday he attempted suicide by jumping from the third tier to the flats, twenty-four feet below. Yesterday morning at 6:40 o'clock he poured kerosene oil over his neck and chest and set it on fire.
CHICAGO, March 17. -- It was decided today that the Metropolitan Opera Company will give four performances in New York before leaving for London. The repertory is as follows:

The Brooklyn members of the Bridge Trustees met yesterday afternoon in Mayor Wurster's office, in Brooklyn, to receive the proposition of the elevated and surface roads in regard to crossing the bridge. The members present were Mayor Wurster, Controller Palmer, Trustee Keeney, and President William Berri.

The championship schedule of games which will decide the cricket championship of Greater New York this year was drawn up on Monday night at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, held at the Murray Hill Lyceum. The clubs represented were as follows: Staten Island, R.T. Rokeby; New Jersey, F.F. Kelly; Manhattan, (Brooklyn,) Jerome Flannery, and New York, E.A. Smith.

The tournaments in progress at the Sportsmen's Exposition are proving very attractive, especially that for fly casters. While the contestants are at work every inch of space around the pool is occupied and every good cast is liberally applauded. Bass casting was the programme yesterday and in the evening R.C. Leonard again distinguished himself by breaking a record.

ALBANY, March 17. -- In the Assembly Chamber this morning wherever the eye turned, bows, ribbons, and shamrocks were visible, pinned to the members' coats. The Sergeant at Arms and the clerks of the House were all decorated in honor of Ireland's patron saint, ad legislators who, by birth and ancestry, would never have been suspected of being partial to St. Patrick were profusely covered with the emerald badge.

The Lenten Sewing Class, organized by leading society women in aid of the Lying-In Hospital, held its first meetings yesterday morning. About 200 society women are already enrolled as members of the club, whose object is to provide garments for the mothers and children at the hospital.

CARSON, Nev., March 17. -- In a saloon brawl to-night, "Dick" Bradford, a Montana miner, who backed Fitzsimmons in today's fight, was shot by a stranger named Smith, who took Corbett's side. Smith is in jail. Bradford will die.

Gov. BLACK assumes to have some political sense of his own and some concern for the future of his party in this State. He is credited with the belief that forcing through the bill for a State Police Commission for the Greater New York territory would be disastrous for the Republican Party and that belief does credit to his political judgment.
Meetings of the Directors of the Missouri Pacific Railway and the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railway Companies were held yesterday at the Western Union Building.

Among the professional traders on the Stock Exchange none is more conspicuous than Mr. L. Schepp. He swings big lines when he is interested, and just now he seems to be very much interested. Mr. Schepp is a bull -- a conservative bull, he says -- and this is the way he talks:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 17. -- A stunning rebuke to two papers which are the leading exponents of the "new journalism" was administered by the Current Events Club, one of the leading social and literary organizations of this city, at their meeting on Monday night. The action is along the lines of the crusade which has been undertaken in other cities against the disgusting sensationalism exemplified by the New York World and the New York Journal.

The two bills which have been submitted to the Legislature in pursuance of the recommendations of the joint committee which lately investigated "Trusts" are said to have been drawn by the Governor's legal adviser, Mr. LINCOLN, with a view to giving effect to those recommendations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- Frederick Frank, aged thirty-seven years, at 6 o'clock this morning, shot and killed his son William, aged nine years, shot and dangerously wounded his daughter Amelia, five years old, and then turned the pistol on himself, inflicting a fatal wound.

Those who wore the shamrock and marched in honor of St. Patrick had an ideal day for their parade. Bright sunshine encouraged the gayest of crowds to come out yesterday, and the wind was tempered exactly to suit them. The flag of Erin fluttered along with the Stars and Stripes from thousands of buildings all over the city.

ALBANY, March 17. -- The Senate Codes Committee gave a final bearing this afternoon on Senator Ellsworth's Anti-Cartoon bill. Thomas S. Fagen of Troy opposed the bill on the ground that the present law was sufficient to protect people from being held up to ridicule.

The League of American Wheelmen Consulate of New York City elected officers last night at Sherman Square Hall, Seventieth Street and the Boulevard. James B. Townsend, Senior Consul; Jefferson Seligman, Junior Consul, and F.M. Frobisher, Secretary, were re-elected. John E. Roosevelt was elected Treasurer.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House last night by Mr. Walter Damrosch in a manner that must have given great satisfaction to the fervent adherents of the "Meister." The large auditorium was filled as it used to be in the old days of German opera, when "Tristan und Isolde" was the crowning glory of the times.
