KINGSTON, N.Y., March 17. -- A tale of a mother's intrepid bravery and devotion has just come down from the hills. Up in the Catskill Mountains, where the woodsmen are just beginning to break out from their Winter's embargo of ice and snow, comes the story of a mother who, single-handed, fought two hungry bears to a finish, that her babe might live.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- A court of inquiry consisting of Capts. Watson and McCormick and Chief Engineer J.A.B. Smith has been ordered to meet at the New York Navy Yard Friday at 1 o'clock to investigate the recent cruise of the Puritan and the causes which led to that vessel's disablement off Cape Hatteras. It is expected that the result may be the ordering of a court-martial.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Tariff bill will be reported to the House on Friday.

Increased interest was shown yesterday in the application of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for permission to change the motive power of the lines in Sixth, Eighth, and Ninth Avenues, and the Belt Line, from horses to the underground trolley. A large number of property owners filled the Chamber of Commerce rooms when the State Board of Railroad Commissioners resumed its hearing in this case. Eighth Avenue, below Fifty-ninth Street, was largely represented.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations spent two hours this morning in the consideration of the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain, and then ordered a favorable report to be made to the Senate to-morrow, with amendments in line with those indicated in previous dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 17. -- Owing to the many changes in pastorates, much interest is taken in the coming New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which will be held in the Highland Avenue Church, at Sing Sing, beginning on Wednesday, April 7. Bishop Merrill will preside.

John P. Truesdell of Morristown, N.J., was the witness first called yesterday morning to testify before the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the matter of the complaint of the New York Produce Exchange against the railroads composing the Joint Traffic Association for maintaining rates that are a serious detriment to the export trade of this port.
LONDON, March 17. -- The British bark Lord Dufferin, Capt. Roberts, which sailed Oct. 7, from Montevideo for New York, has been posted at Lloyds as missing.

RUTLAND, Vt., March 17. -- An interesting divorce case is to be heard at the March term of court now in session in this city. It is a petition filed for a bill of separation of Mrs. Emiline Knapp, daughter of Mr. Joseph Knapp of Peekskill, N.Y., aged 35 years, from her husband Carlos A. Hitchcock of Washington, D.C., a wealthy man, formerly of Pittsford, Vt., whose age is 75 years.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The cases of the three appointed Senators from Florida, Kentucky, and Oregon are now before the Committee on Privileges and Elections.

CARSON, Nev., March 17. -- After two years of doubt and vexatious postponements the heavyweight championship of the world for pugilism was decided beyond cavil today when Robert Fitzsimmons sent James J. Corbett helpless to his knees with a left-hand blow under the heart after one minute and forty-five seconds in the fourteenth round.

LONDON, March 17. -- The Byron Society of London learns that the agent of the Sultan at Athens offered to withdraw the Turkish garrisons in Crete and assign the island to Greece, provided the suzerainty of Turkey be recognized by the payment of an annual tribute. Greece and the Moslems in Crete, it is said, were entirely willing to agree to these conditions, but the powers suddenly put a stop to the negotiations.
The people of the State of New York are under deep obligations to your valued paper for the good work done by it in the interests of the forests of the State.

There was no meeting of the Police Board yesterday, owing to the absence of commissioners Grant and Parker. President Roosevelt and Commissioner Andrews got together at the regular hour and directed Chief Clerk Kipp to bring before them the annual report of the Police Department for last year.
ALBANY, March 17. -- Assemblyman Finn read in THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day that Mayor Strong had refused to sign his Stoop-line bill, and said:
The following letter from Mr. Frederic B. Cochran of the New York Stock Exchange has been received by THE TIMES:

ALBANY, March 17. -- Among the bills returned from the Assembly to the Senate this morning was the bill exempting State bonds from taxation. It had been amended so as to include only the canal improvement bonds.

There seems to be a serious dislocation in the Platt machinery of legislation at the Albany end. Of course, Senators and members of the Assembly do not count for much, and BLACK'S man PAYN and PLATT'S man LAUTERBACH might come to terms "on the outside," for bargain and dicker is with them the basis of legislation, but the Governor himself is getting troublesome.
TRENTON, N.J., March 17. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Former Congressman Henry G. Burleigh of Washington County made a visit to the Legislature to-day. He came to attend the hearing on the Adirondack Forest bill, which is one of Gov. Black's pet measures. Mr. Burleigh is opposed to it as it now stands.
CARSON CITY, Nev., March 17. -- The story of the fight is told in the report by rounds as follows:
Gen G.M. Dodge, Grand Marshal of the Grant Monument celebration, to occur on April 27, is busy at his headquarters, 1 Broadway. He is encouraging the attendance of cadets.

It is hardly necessary to consult a dictionary for a strict definition of prevarication, and if one were asked for an example, no better could be found than that part of McKinley's message in which he speaks of the gold reserve.
William A. Read of Vermilye Co. has bought of Henry A.V. Post, at between $90,000 and $100,000, the four-story and basement brownstone-front dwelling 4 East Sixty-second Street, on lot 27 by 100.5.

The greatest of all its many banquets was the one hundred and thirteenth anniversary dinner of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, which took place at the Waldorf last night. The main banquet hall was used, and more than 500 persons sat at the tables.

ALBANY, March 17. -- The most prominent Republicans in the Legislature believe that the Lauterbach Police bill will not be introduced, and they regard the metropolitan police project as good as dead. They say Gov. Black is responsible for it, and that it is so, takes a load off their minds.

The first woman to be graduated from a Presbyterian Theological Seminary was awarded a rating yesterday by the Faculty of the Union Theological Seminary at Seventieth Street and Park Avenue, in the class of '97. She is Miss Emilie Grace Briggs, a daughter of that famous Presbyterian minister, Charles A. Briggs, who was suspended by the General Assembly for certain alleged heretical and unorthodox teachings, but who is still a Professor in the seminary.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The American Consul General at Tangier, Mr. Burke, reports an incident which, unimportant as it may appear at first sight, may grow to a serious complication if the Sultan of Morocco is stubborn. Mr. Burke writes:

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Greater New York charter was reported favorably in each House of the Legislature this morning. There were numerous amendments to the charter adopted in committee, but the most important action taken by the Cities Committee was in refusing to accept amendments that would materially affect the operations of the charter.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Job E. Hedges, private secretary to Mayor Strong, reached this city this evening to lay charges against Commissioner Parker before Gov. Black. He brought with him a copy of all the testimony taken last Summer at the investigation, which will be placed in the Governor's hands to-morrow morning.

Police Commissioner Andrew D. Parker was yesterday removed from his office by Mayor Strong. The Mayor gave out his order of removal at 6 o'clock last night, together with a copy of the letter which he sent to Gov. Black announcing the removal and giving his reasons for it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 17. -- The Louisville team for 1897 is made up as follows: Pitchers -- Hill, Herman, Fraser, Cunningham, McFarlan, and McGee; catchers -- Wilson and Butler; first base -- Werden; second base -- Rogers; third base -- Clingman; short stop -- Dolan; left field -- Dexter; centre field -- Pickering; right field -- Holmes; utility man -- Johnson.

The opponents of sidewalk obstruction and stoop-line legislation felt a lively appreciation yesterday of the victory which they had won. The discussion before the Mayor developed that the substantial business interests of the city are solidly arrayed against the growing evil of street and sidewalk obstruction.

LONDON, March 17. -- The Times to-morrow will publish a dispatch from Athens, under to-day's date, saying that a strict blockade of Cretan ports began to-day. The blockading of the Greek ports, the dispatch says, will, judging from present appearances, not begin for some time.

Mrs. Edwin A. Abbey, wife of the artist, was a Vassar girl, a fellow-student of Mrs. J. Wells Champney of New York. She was a pet pupil in astronomy of Prof. Maria Mitchell of Vassar, and the depth of researches into the science has been shown in the translation from the French she has made of an astronomical work to which Maria Mitchell wrote the introduction.
TACOMA, Washington, March 18. -- Northwestern mining circles are much interested over the ending to a "boom" over the Stanley Mine near Chewelah.

Powell Clayton was born in Bethel, Penn., in 1833, and was educated for the profession of civil engineer. In 1855 he went to Leavenworth, Kan., and two years later was appointed city civil engineer. He retained this position until the commencement of the civil war, when he raised a company and entered the First Kansas Volunteer Infantry Regiment as Captain.

The executors of the will of William H. Gunther, the furrier, have sold, at about $165,000, the four-story and basement brownstone-front dwelling, 9 West Fifty-seventh Street, on lot 30.6 by 100.5. Mr. Gunther bought the house in 1875 for $100,000.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., March 18. -- What is perhaps the most important decision ever handed down by a local United States Land Office was the one which was given out yesterday by Register Bruener and Receiver. McDonald in what is known as the inland cases, covering lands in Big Stone and Traverse Counties.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Immediately after the Senate went into executive session this afternoon Senator Davis, for the Committee on Foreign Relations, submitted a report on the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain, with certain amendments made by the committee. He offered a resolution that the treaty, as amended, be ratified, and this started the discussion.
ALBANY, March 18. -- Greater New York matters occupied the attention of the Assembly for a good share of its session today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 18. -- Two war vessels launched simultaneously was the unusual spectacle witnessed by many thousands of people at the yards of the Union Iron Works this morning. The vessels are the gunboats Wheeling and Marietta, and among the interested spectators of their baptism were delegations from the West Virginia and Ohio cities in honor of which they are named.

The unpopularity of the new tariff measure introduced in the House of Representatives by Mr. Dingley becomes more clearly apparent the more the business men study it and subject it to a practical analysis from a purely business standpoint. Below are given some additional expressions of opinion from New York merchants and importers:

ALBANY, March 18. -- Superintendent F.D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department has returned from New York, where he went yesterday to assist in the transfer, by Spencer Trask and Miles M. O'Brien, of the assets of the broken Murray Hill Bank to the receivers appointed by the Court at the request of the State Banking Department, Messrs. Hobbs and Odell.

BALTIMORE, March 18. -- In an interview with Attorney General R.C. White of Delaware, who has been in charge of the collection of evidence against James M. Gordy, accused of the murder of his wife at Georgetown, Del., Mr. White compares Gordy to H.H. Holmes, and says that his (Gordy's) crimes have been even more atrocious than those fastened upon Holmes.
CARSON CITY, Nevada, March 18. -- Robert Fitzsimmons to-day received the financial reward for his prowess.

The action of the Committee of Ways and Means upon the importation of books and works of art is the act of a band of savages. There is really no other way of characterizing it with justice. The committee seems to have had no more statesmanlike notion than that of "talcing everything in sight."
ALBANY, March 18. -- The following is the bill reducing the price of gas in New York City which the Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations unanimously agreed this morning to report favorably:

ALBANY, March 18. -- The report of the Lexow trust investigating committee and the bills presented as a result of that investigation were the special order in the Senate this morning, and there was a full attendance of Senators in consequence.

Assemblyman BARRY, as a minority of the committee which was lately investigating "Trusts," quite eclipses the majority in the volume and weight of his recommendations. He does not hesitate to say that he has found "corporate monopolies in the necessaries of life," which "exist and operate principally by means of the enormous amount of capital actually employed or capitalization permitted."

Sir WILLIAM HARCOURT'S savage attack "out of doors" on Wednesday upon the programme of the British Government was followed yesterday by an arraignment of it "within those walls." But neither the speech of the Liberal leader to the National Liberal Federation nor his speech in the House of Commons is likely to be very effective.
President Duncan D. Parmly of the Phenix National Bank, in discussing the financial outlook, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 18. -- The perilous condition of the low lands south of that junction of the Mississippi and the Ohio River is strongly emphasized by the hourly receipt of messages here telling of the encroacchments of the flood. All that section of Missouri, Arkansas, and Louisiana drained by the St. Francis, the White, Arkansas, and Red Rivers is either under water or soon will be.

The pamphlet which Mr. GLADSTONE has written upon the Eastern question gives us fresh cause to wonder at the vigor which he has carried into his eighty-eighth year. But it is sure also to have a very marked effect in concentrating and organizing English opinion against the European concert.

Robert C. Lehmann, the English rowing expert, returned to America on the Teutonic yesterday to coach the Harvard 'Varsity crew for its race with Yale at Poughkeepsie on June 25. He left New York on the midnight train for Boston.

Our esteemed neighbor The Sun shows some surprise at our declaration that if the Dingley bill and the President's message had been published three days before the election the cause of sound money would have been put in grave peril. Quoting our statement, The Sun makes this comment:

Dramatic scenes were witnessed last night at a fire which broke out at 137 Steuben Street, Brooklyn. Two lives were endangered and several sensational rescues were made. The building was a four-story tenement, and the flames spread to a similar building adjoining, owned by Mrs. Mary McClosky.

Seventy-eight lives lost; four saved to tell the story of suffering and death and the fate of the steamship Ville de St. Nazaire off the dreaded Hatteras. It is a story of torture, of death by drowning, of death from hunger, from thirst, and from exhaustion.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 18. -- A daring attempt at crime was frustrated this morning at 3 o'clock, when detectives killed Walter Hughes as he was in the act of entering the house of Frank Dunn, a wealthy resident of this city.

BOSTON, March 18. -- President Clark this month will complete ten years' service with the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company. At the last meeting of the board he presented a statement of the expenditures on capital account made under his administration.

GEORGETOWN, Del., March 18. -- Coroner's jury to-day found that Mrs. Mary Lewis, or Gordy, had been murdered by her husband, James M. Gordy. A report has reached here that a mob is gathering with the intention of lynching Gordy before daylight.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 18. -- Charles Green of St. Louis, who is a trustee for the stockholders of the Kentucky Association, who hold $30,000 worth of stock, arrived here to-day, and this afternoon inserted an advertisement in a local paper offering the grounds, grand stand, and all the property of the association for sale, because the association has failed to pay the last Installment of interest, which was due several months ago.

OMAHA, Neb., March 18. -- A few weeks ago Rudolph Neuman of Chicago committed suicide in this city because a mechanical device on which he had spent much money and time had been stolen from him just when he was about to derive the profit for which he had so long striven.

When the Inter-State Commerce Commission met, yesterday morning, in the Produce Exchange building, to continue the hearing in the complaint of the Exchange against the Joint Traffic Association and railroads allied with its members, Commissioner Knapp announced that F.B. Thurber wished to present a statement. Mr. Thurber took the stand and read as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Gen. B.F. Tracy, who is Police Commissioner Parker's counsel, is here with Judge Dillon to present a case to the United States Supreme Court. He heard the report last night before retiring that Mayor Strong had removed Commissioner Parker, but he was too busy to-day to read over the accounts of the removal in the papers.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 18. -- A number of thoroughbred breeders, among them Col. W.S. Barnes, Catesby Woodford, L.B. Broadhead, J.N. Camden, Major Thomas, and Col. Milton Young, met here to-day and made arrangements to sell their yearlings at auction in New York in June. Each of these breeders will have a large consignment of the best in the State.

CAPE TOWN, March 18. -- It is stated here on what is regarded as good authority that as a result of the visit of President Kruger of the Transvaal to President Steyn of the Orange Free State a federal union of the two republics has been decided upon. Such a union is regarded here with much concern, as it would seriously complicate the situation.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- Word was received in Chicago to-day that "Archie" Fisher, a prominent old-time operator on the Board of Trade, was near the point of death in Dublin, the affliction being a cancer, from which he has been suffering for a long time.

The Board of Education, at its next, or at an early, meeting, will consider the courses of study outlined for high schools, as proposed by the Committee on High Schools. A descriptive enumeration of the courses is as follows:
ALBANY, March 18. -- The charges on which Mayor Strong removed Police Commissioner Parker and the evidence in the trial of last Summer lie on Gov. Black's desk, awaiting his action.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Assemblyman Barry, the Democratic representative of the Assembly on the Lexow Trust Investigating Committee, to-day submitted a minority report as a result of the investigation. The report says: "It has been established, as a result of the committee's investigations:

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 18. -- Senator Miller to-day introduced a bill increasing the tax on the earnings of insurance companies doing business in this State from 2 to 4 per cent. on their gross earnings. The bill applies to all classes of insurance companies.
The defeat of the Sidewalk Obstruction bill proves to be more complete than was supposed when Mayor Strong declined to approve the Finn measure.

When Robert Fitzsimmons, the champion pugilist, arrives in this city, he will be entertained by his admirers with a dinner at the Hotel Bartholdi, where he made his headquarters when in New York some time ago.

The day pupils of the Baron de Hirsch Fund classes celebrated the Jewish feast of Purim yesterday with an entertainment in the auditorium of the Education Alliance Building. A.S. Solomons, the manager of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, took great delight in showing the friends of the school the progress of these children of Roumanian and Russian Jewish families in their studies preparatory to the public schools.
TRENTON, N.J., March 18. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day.

Edward Lauterbach, in a speech accepting the permanent Chairmanship of the Republican County Committee last night, declared in favor of putting only Republicans on the Municipal ticket next Fall, favored partisanship in city affairs, and outlined the main issue against Tammany as being its recent position in favor of Bryan and repudiation.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Things looked comparatively quiet around the White House to-day. The crowd was small, and the President had a fairly easy time. He had a conference with Secretary Alger during the morning while the applicants for office waited in the corridor.

LONDON, March 18. -- Under the title "The Eastern Crisis," a sixteen-page pamphlet by Mr. Gladstone will be issued to-morrow. The pamphlet is in the form of a letter from Mr. Gladstone addressed to the Duke of Westminster, in which the ex-Premier says:

Mrs. Fannie Bean Carrere appeared before Justice Fitzsimons and a jury in the City Court yesterday as plaintiff in a suit against Robert G. Dun to recover $350 for services alleged to have been rendered by her husband, Col. William Carrere. When the case was called she asked and obtained permission to conduct her own ease.

There has been a general belief for some days that the Lauterbach bill for taking the control of the Police Department away from the City of New York by creating a State Police Commission for "Greater New York" has received a check amounting to defeat from Gov. BLACK.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- Sixty-four Chicago young people in costumes of Louis XVI. period will dance a minuet at the Auditorium the evening of April 27, at the benefit performance to be given for the Chicago Orchestra. The other features will be a concert and a ball. The entertainment will be the largest and most fashionable of the Spring.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- A lage number of bills, most of them survivors of the last and prior Congresses, were introduced and referred.

CANEA, March 18. -- The Admirals commanding the fleets of the powers here have cabled to the representatives of their respective Governments in Constantinople notifying them that the blockade of the island would be inaugurated on Sunday. Warships will make a cruise around the island delivering to the inhabitants of the chief ports proclamations declaring that the powers intend to establish autonomy in the island, and that the blockade will begin on the day specified.

At the meeting of the Academy of Medicine last night the report of the committee appointed to investigate the subject of the Health Department in the charter of the Greater New York was presented. It is signed by Drs. Edward G. Janeway, President of the Academy; Stephen Smith, Joseph D. Bryant, George G. Wheelock, and Prince A. Mooner, Secretary.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The Tariff bill will be reported to the House to-morrow by the Ways and Means Committee. If Chairman Dingley and his Republican associates can influence action, the final vote on the measure will be taken in the House on the 31st inst. The bill will be called up for consideration in the House Monday.

It is not to Ceylon that we would go to find ruins to rival the greatest that the world possesses, and yet from a recent traveler's book it may be learned that Ceylon contains the remains of cities not inferior in boldness of conception and richness of design to any in the world. They lie in the northern half of the island, almost buried among vegetation, and in some cases still difficult of access.
ALBANY, March 19. -- Gov. Black has signed the following bills:

President Francis L. Eames of the Stock Exchange and one of its Governing Committee gave notice yesterday to the Western Union Telegraph Company that the Exchange would not renew the "ticker" contract, which expires June 30 next.

The Long Island Interscholastic League held its championship skating races at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night. The winners were: 220 yard, junior -- Emery, Adelphi Academy. Time -- 0:31 3-5. 220 yard, senior -- Hawkins, High School; time -- 0:35 1-5; semi-finals, 220 yard dash -- Beasley, Adelphi, first; time -- 0:34 1-3; one-half mile -- Hawkins. High School; time -- 2:12 1-5; one mile -- Alaire, High School; time -- 4:22.

The growing feeling that some more drastic measures should be taken for the protection of privacy is likely to be made the pretext for schemes that are not at all in the public interest. A member of the Illinois Legislature from Chicago has introduced an act "prohibiting the printing, posting, and distribution of any libelous matter."

We all know Dr. Johnson's ideas about the lexicographer. The great man declared himself in doubt as to his own status; whether he was "worthy of literary praise," or held "the lowest place"; but with a clearer intelligence to-day we accord the highest place to the dictionary maker.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The following applications for office under the Treasury Department were made public this morning:

There was a large audience at the public rehearsal of the Symphony Society yesterday afternoon, and it enjoyed a performance that was full of interest. The programme consisted of Dvorak's symphony in E minor, "From the New World "; the air from Weber's "Oberon," "Ocean, Thou Mighty Monster"; an adagio by Bach, Liszt's song "Die Lorelei," and Ber!ioz's "Carnaval Romain" overture.

President Alfred E. Marling of the Real Estate Exchange, who presided over the Greater New York mass meeting at the Real Estate Exchange last Monday, announced yesterday that he had appointed John F. Doyle Chairman of the committee to visit Albany in regard to the Greater New York bill and urge the Legislature to use deliberation concerning the charter.

The public libraries, as already stated in "The Review of Books and Art," note a renewed interest on the part of readers in American history. This is by no means contined to the class known students. A feature of this inquiry into the past surprised the librarians' assistants, and at the same time contributed largely toward increasing their daily tasks.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 19. -- A further half-inch rise in the Mississippi means the devastation of property and probably a loss of life unequaled in the flood history of this section. The rise is threatened because rain is still falling.
CHICAGO, March 19. -- A Chronicle special from Lima, Ohio, says:
Columbia defeated Harvard in the debate held last night at the Carnegie Lyceum, between representatives of the Columbia University Debating Union and the Harvard Forum. The subject was:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 19. -- The continued rains of the past week in North Alabama have wrought heavy damage, and to-day the most terrific rainstorm for a decade added to the havoc. In this city rain fell in sheets for thirty minutes, flooding cellars, overflowing sewers, and washing away small bridges.

It is said that ever since the marble tablet and brass star were placed in the Baltimore and Potomac Railway station at Washington to mark the spot or which GARFIELD fell when assassinated, the company has received frequent complaints from people who disliked to be reminded of the great crime every time they had occasion to take a train or to enter the waiting room.

A man who has been defeated for re-election is not in a fit frame of mind to legislate for his people. There is a sting in defeat that tends to engender the feeling of resentment which often finds expression in the vote of such members against wholesome legislation. The same feeling often produces such a want of interest in proceedings as to cause the member to be absent nearly all the second session.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 19. -- Before a little company of six persons, at the Brick Presbyterian Church, yesterday afternoon shortly after 5 o'clock, was celebrated a wedding which, had it been announced, would have packed the large auditorium to the doors. It was the marriage of Miss Amy Busby, the well-known actress of this city, to Eugene H. Lewis, a prominent lawyer of New York City.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 19. -- M. W. Johnson, an illiterate farmer living in a cabin at Paint Lick, Garrard County, died three months ago, it was alleged, because of a fall from his horse.

It is the elder men who remember the Cafe Greco, so frequented by the artists at Rome in the fifties. There was then a waiter there, by name Rafaello, who had the true art instinct. He knew every model in Rome, and Rafaello made commissions when he recommended a Magdalen or a Moses. Rafaello had an album, and young artists filled many of its pages with their sketches and water colors.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 19. -- The representatives of the New York Baseball Club were put through their usual course of Spring training to-day under the watchful eye of Capt. Joyce, but under cover. Rain fell steadily all through the day and prohibited outdoor work, but should the rain cease during the night the sandy nature of the soil where the diamond is located will enable it to dry sufficiently for exercise tomorrow.

What is the demand of the Produce Exchange before the Inter-State Commerce Commission? Briefly stated and in substance, it is that the railway companies shall not maintain such lower rates to competing ports as will deprive New York of the trade which, with fair rates, it would easily get.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Senate this afternoon in executive session spent three hours in the discussion of the general treaty of arbitration with Great Britain, and, without taking any action, adjourned over until Monday.

Investigation of the fire which destroyed the upper story of Grammar School No. 61, at One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, during the noon recess on Wednesday, has resulted in the arrest of three boys who, the detectives claim, started the fire for the purpose of forcing a vacation by burning the building.

The contests in progress at the Sportsmen's Exposition were continued yesterday, and many good scores were made. The rifle and revolver ranges were crowded all day long, and every inch of space around the artificial pool was occupied while the fly-casters were at work.

Late one Autumn a whaler on her return voyage brought up in front of a populous village on an island in the northern part of the Bering Sea. A lively trade ensued with the natives, who were anxious to make their bargains quickly and go in pursuit of the walrus which were now passing, and which every year provided the Winter's food supply.

Miss Mary H. Kingsley, in a letter to the Athenaeum, declares that her visit to Africa was paid only to acquire ethnological knowledge. As to climate and its terrible effects, the lady says the danger was less to her, as she was always on the move, than it was to the wives of missionaries, who were forced to remain in one and the same locality.

The Common Council of Chicago has just accomplished a unique piece of legislation. It has voted $900 a year for an "escort" to one of its members who happens to be blind. Of course, there is no more reason why a blind legislator should be provided with an escort at the public expense than any other blind man.

HAVANA, March 19. -- Consul General Lee expects that Jose L. Cepero, a naturalized American, who was arrested on Feb. 24, 1896, on a steamer bound from Cienfuegos to Batabano, will be released soon. Cepero is confined in the prison at Santa Clara.

LONDON, March 19. -- The Dublin correspondent of The Daily Graphic telegraphs a story, which is taken in all seriousness by the police of that city, who are greatly exercised over the prospect of a raid by Irish-Americans. The Dublinites are going to celebrate the centenary of the Irish revolution which began in 1798, and which cost the lives of 150,000 Irishmen and 20,000 Englishmen before it was suppressed in the year following.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Owing to the fight between the Ogden Gas Company and the Chicago Gaslight and Coke Company many householders on the North Side are enjoying free gas. In many buildings only one feed pipe enters the premises. The Ogden Company, having secured the promised patronage of many of the flat dwellers in some of these buildings, cut off the Chicago Company and connected its own main.

The Duc d'Aumale having presented to the Institute of France his collection of the books, engravings, drawings, and art objects in the Chateau de Chantilly, is now having a catalogue prepared by various experts. A history of the chateau will be written by the Duc d'Aumale.

ATHENS, March 19. -- It is rumored here to-day that Russia is urging Turkey to attack Greece, offering financial assistance to the Porte if this is done. Russia believes that the first battle would result in a disastrous defeat of the Greek troops, and Russia then could call off the Turks, and propose terms that Greece would be bound to accept.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The tariff battle was opened in the House to-day when Mr. Dingley reported the Ways and Means Committee. As he concluded his announcement of the report there was loud applause.

" Some Points to be Emphasized in Our Public School Work" was the subject of a lecture before the Public Education Association, 64 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon, in which the lecturer, Newton Dougherty, Superintendent of Schools at Peoria, Ill., suggested that in view of the rapid development of public education the question of what kind of development it was should not be overlooked.

FLUSHING, L.I., March 19. -- At the feast of St. Joseph celebration to-day, in the St. Joseph's Academy, white veils were received by the following girls, who are thus admitted as novices to the community: Miss Ellen Willis of Long Island City, Miss Hanorah O'Malley of the County of Limerick, Ireland; Miss Lydia Margins of Fall River.

Dr. Maire, the surgeon of the lost steamship Ville de St. Nazaire, and fourth engineer Sauts, were taken from the French Line steamship La Normandie yesterday to the Hotel Martin. Both men were able to walk from the carriage to the hotel. They are said to be recovering rapidly from their experiences.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Siberian Railway Committee, according to a State Department report from Consul General Karel at St. Petersburg, has selected the Bay of Gold Horn for the Pacific Ocean terminus of the line instead of Vladivostock, which, however, is near by and will continue as a secondary terminal.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- President McKinley, after a full investigation of the charges made against Judge Lamereaux, Commissioner of the General Land Office, to-day decided that they were without foundation, and that he had acted within the scope of his authority in his decision on the Chicago lake front case.

A telegraphic message was received at the Navy Yard yesterday from Secretary Long, ordering the removal from the Dock Board of Naval Constructor John F. Hanscomb and Civil Engineer C.C. Walcott, and substituting Naval Constructor John B. Hoover and Civil Engineer Robert E. Peary.

The mass meeting of Knights of Labor last evening at Cooper Institute, to protest against allowing the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to change the present motive power to electricity on certain of its lines unless it gave transfers at all intersecting and diverging points of its roads and reduced the fare to 3 cents during commission hours, was slimly attended.
ALBANY, March 19. -- In the Assembly this morning Mr. Nixon moved that the Greater New York charter be advanced to third reading.

Senator Thomas C. Platt arrived from Washington last evening to consult with his lieutenants about the legislative programme, which is mixed up just now. It was reported from Albany that Mr. Platt would go to that city to-day to call upon Gov. Black.
ALBANY, March 19. -- The Senate worked with a bare quorum this morning. The following were among the bills passed:

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 19. -- Senator A.T. Wood, who was appointed by Gov. Bradley to succeed J.C.S. Blackburn, has returned from Washington, where he went to claim his seat. He has been to Frankfort, viewing the situation. TO THE TIMES'S correspondent he said, regarding the fight Dr. Hunter is making to secure his election:
NEW ORLEANS, La., March 19. -- Rain spoiled a fast track here to-day, making it slow and also affecting results. Not a favorite won. Attendance, 3,000.

The warfare between the Metropolitan Traction Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company was resumed yesterday before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen, at a public hearing on the applications of the Traction Company and some of its associated roads for extensions.
The executors of the estate of William Henry Gunther say that the reported sale of 9 West Fifty-seventh Street was untrue.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Mr. John Addison Porter, the secretary to the President, made a rule to-day, designed to save Mr. McKinley from physical and mental exhaustion. It provides that no speeches shall be made in the presentation of claims of office seekers. Before the day was over it had been violated twice, and each time by a delegation from Delaware.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Mr. Dingley of Maine, Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means, to-day reported the tariff bill to the House. The report accompanying the measure, which was written by Mr. Dingley, is as follows:

" Why are there more women than men in the churches"? is a topic that has been discussed by the Pastors' Association of the Reformed Church. The Rev. Dr. James Demarest of Flushing, Long Island, read a paper on the subject, which had been called to his attention by the fact that women dominated in the Sunday schools, in mission work, and in all church organizations.

CANEA, March 19. -- An Italian officer has started for the camp of the Greek troops with instructions to notify Col. Vassos, their commander, that the blockade of the island will begin at 8 o'clock Sunday morning, in accordance with the proclamation issued by the foreign Admirals.

Talking about the meaning of words, what is "mistal"? I find it used in "God's Failures," the new volume of Yorkshire sketches by J.S. Fletcher, author of "The Wonderful Wapentake." It seems to bear some sort of relation, from the context, to the fold and the stable. The word is not in our dictionaries, not even in the Century.

Casper Knauer, who was formerly a picture frame maker in Centre Street, and who owns considerable real estate in this city, is trying, through the courts, to obtain his own release from a private insane asylum, to which he was committed in 1892.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Obstacles are beginning to loom up ahead of the Tariff bill before it has been taken up in the House, and may develop serious proportions before the President shall have the chance to restore the McKinley duties of 1890.

The very first bill introduced in the Senate at the present session of the Legislature was that limiting the price of illuminating gas in this city to $1 per 1,000 cubic feet. All of Senator CANTOR'S efforts to get this bill out of the hand of the committee to which it was referred have thus far been futile.

Dr. E.H. Wilson, Chief Bacteriologist of the Brooklyn Board of Health, submitted a report yesterday giving the result of experiments with bacilli of the bubonic plague. The experiments were made with a view to the possible introduction of the plague into this country from the infected ports of India.

The Ladies' Auxiliary Committee of the Orthopedic Ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital, Twentieth Street and Second Avenue, held a sale of fancy goods at the Waldorf yesterday for the benefit of the crippled children of the hospital.

The Greater New York charter was advanced to a third reading in the Assembly yesterday with a slight show of opposition and will come up for final passage in that body on Tuesday. Assurance was given that opportunity would then be given, not only for debate, but for amendment. No doubt opportunity may be given for offering amendments, but there will be no chance of adopting any of the least importance. That is understood.

ALBANY, March 19. -- At the meeting of the Regents just concluded, the most important business was the final adoption of the revised ordinances, which have been under consideration for the past three months. That referring to the LL.B. degree is as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- After the House had disposed of the rule for considering the Tariff bill this afternoon, Mr. Henderson (Rep., Iowa,) reported a resolution providing for the passage of the appropriation bills which failed at the last session of Congress, in this order -- the Sundry Civil, General Deficiency, Agricultural, and Indian.
Next week's issue of the Review of Books and Art will be twice the size of the regular issue -- that is, sixteen pages will be published, instead of eight.

Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. Judge Lacombe concurring, yesterday affirmed the opinion of Judge Wheeler, dismissing the complaint in the action brought by the United States for an injunction against the Joint Traffic Association. The Government sought a perpetual injunction to restrain the various railroads forming the association from continuing in the combination, and Judge Wheeler denied it.

The court of inquiry appointed to investigate the alleged inefficiency of the engines, boilers, and auxiliary machinery of the monitor Puritan continued its labors yesterday. Morning and afternoon sessions were held behind closed doors.

Opposition to the Dingley Tariff bill is developing in every line of business. The more closely the measure is studied the stronger becomes the conviction in the minds of merchants and importers that it is in no sense a revenue maker, but simply an old-fashioned high protective measure. Most of the criticisms that are passed upon it by business men resolve themselves into three words -- crude, inconsistent, and prohibitive.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 20. -- Two important cottage rentals at Jamestown were reported to-day. The distinguished jurist, Judge Henry D. Harlan of Baltimore, has taken the Anthony cottage, on Green Lane, and will arrive early in July, with his family, for the season.

TAILORS are a unit in declaring that the preparations made for the current season's fashions have been on a more extensive scale than has been the case during any previous corresponding period in the history of the trade. The elaborate productions would certainly seem to justify this assertion.

James W. Pryor, Secretary of the City Club, lectured yesterday morning before the League for Political Education at the Berkeley Lyceum. His subject was "The Bicameral Provisions of the New Charter," but he devoted most of his time to a general discussion of that instrument.

A young girl who is two different persons in one body has just been exhibited by Dr. Albert Wilson to the members of the Clinical Society of London, and this most interesting case of dual states of consciousness is exciting much attention in the medical world.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Gov. Black gave a good portion of this forenoon to the consideration of applications for appointment to the Court of Claims. As a result, former Lieut. Gov. Saxton probably will be appointed in a few days.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 20. -- A few days ago passengers on a West Shore Railway train, which was passing Storm King Mountain, had their attention called to a score or more of birds flying in great rings high up in the air, and several others which were almost lapping their wings in the frigid water of the river.

The increasing interest in child study marks the evolution of the people. The Puritans thought it a mark of total depravity in a child not to be able to sit quietly on a Sunday through a long, dull sermon, and spend the remainder of the day of rest in reading an equally dull religious book.

American shares were lower, in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- Erie first preferred, 1, to 34; New York Central, 5/8, to 102; Illinois Central, 1/4, to 98 1/4, and Reading, 1/8, to 12. Canadian Pacific sold at 50 3/4, Erie at 14 3/8, St. Paul at 79 3/4, Louisville and Nashville at 50 3/8, and Atchison at 14 3/8.

Pursuant to a resolution passed by the Presbytery of New York at its last meeting, the session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church held a special meeting last Wednesday night to consider the fitness of Herman Warszawiak, the missionary who conducts the mission for Jews on Grand Street, to be taken under the care of the Presbytery.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- President McKinley and his Cabinet have already developed a very well-marked inclination to look about and see something as well as to listen to what people say. This may not strike the reader of these lines as remarkable, but it is. For Presidents and Cabinets are not commonly of an investigating turn.

MONDAY, MARCH 22. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, George C. Austin, referee, 1,438 Lexington Avenue, west side, 50.9 1/2 feet south of Ninetyfourth Street, 16.7 by 75, four-story and basement brownstone-font dwelling. Due on judgment, $2,076.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 20. -- The New York baseball players found, on awakening this morning, another unpleasant day before them, and every appearance of rain. The rain held off, however, but black clouds hung over the village all day, and made it very difficult to watch the ball. The usual gymnasium exercise was taken, and then the whole team ran around Lake Carasallfo, a distance of about five miles.

Senator Thomas C. Platt did not go to Albany yesterday to see Gov. Black, as many of the politicians said that he would. Instead he called Gov. Black up on the telephone in the afternoon, and the two talked for about half an hour. Afterward Mr. Platt's friends declared that the interview was of a very satisfactory character.

Among the important men of the dry goods trade -- the wholesalers, the jobbers, the commission men, those who have largest interests -- there has developed decided confidence that good times are close ahead.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Additional applications for places in the Treasury and other Federal departments have been filed as follows:

Even the worm will turn. The question of women's hats at theatres has entered upon an acute phase. During the performance of "Madame Putiphar," at the Athenee Comique, a gentleman seated in the orchestra stalls coolly retained his headgear, and, when protests and cries were raised around him, he took no notice of them.

PITTSBURG, March 20. -- Our market has displayed a broadening tendency during the past week, particularly in the investment department. Some of the local bond issues are higher now than for more than a year. Traction shares remain quiet, owing mainly to political influences? The declaration of the Westinghouse dividends did not have any important effect upon this group of stocks, although all of them are in better shape than for years past.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 20. -- Fine weather, rather too warm in the sun, drew out 5,000 people to the race course to-day. The sport was of a lively character, with seven races run, of which favorites won three, P. Dunne, the Crescent City Derby colt, won a mile handicap in 1:43 3/4 cleverly, with 110 pounds.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 20. -- The Great Northwest continues a victim to rising waters, and the damage financially is very large. The railroads are the principal sufferers from washed-out tracks and bridges. Reports received to-night from points in Minnesota, Wisconsin, and South Dakota indicate a further rise in the rivers, due to melted snow, which has been unusually heavy in depth this Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- A blow near the heart, similar to the one with which Fitzsimmons defeated Corbett, caused the death at 12:30 o'clock this morning of Edward Gibbons, who late last night met Samuel S. Perry in a boxing bout at the Tenth Ward Democratic Club.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The President is considering the advisability of curtailing the freedom given officeseekers and others who think they can best advance their interests by personal visits.

There has been such a rapid increase in the number of sidewalk stands and street vendors in the upper part of the city this Spring that citizens have become aroused to the necessity of clearing them out.

We are at some loss to see what it is in the policy or prospects of THE TIMES that affects the mind of our neighbor The World so uncomfortably. We venture to assuage its irritation by a candid assurance that so far from being engaged in a "conspiracy" to undermine its prosperity or check its marvelous career, we do not regard it as in any sense a rival.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 20. -- The flood situation to-day is improved. The rain has ceased. Rescuing parties are still coming in with people taken from dangerous positions. The river gauge is stationary, and no breaks in the levees have occurred today.
One-third of the 28,000 patents granted in England in 1896 were for improvements in bicycles or motor-cars and carriages.

In the opinion of the Rev. Dr. DEMAREST of Long Island women are taking a part in church work so much greater than that of men that it is seriously influencing the course of the ministers and the tendencies of the churches. This he regards as unfortunate, not because of what women contribute, but because of what men fail to contribute.

An unknown man was killed yesterday at about 1:30 P.M. by a north-bound train on the Second Avenue elevated railway at the Twenty-third Street station. George B. Reeve, the engineer of the train, was placed under arrest and taken to the East Twenty-second Street Station.
ALBANY, March 20. -- The Governor's bill for the acquisition of the Adirondack forest has been reported from the Senate Committee on Finance, with amendments, and recommitted to the same committee.

BOSTON, March 20. -- Taken in connection with the dates claimed by the Corinthian Yacht Club for its midsummer series at Marblehead, the schedule of dates for open races under the auspices of the Yacht Racing Association of Massachusetts, as arranged at the association's annual meeting last Thursday evening, the racing season in and around Boston is very closely outlined, and yachtsmen can lay their plans intelligently for the season's sport.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The streamer Finsbury, at this port to-day from Rotterdam, reports a severe experience. She left the latter port Feb. 20 in ballast. On the first day out from port the steering gear gave way, and the vessel had to put into Plymouth for repairs. Leaving Plymouth four days later, she encountered heavy westerly gales and fearful seas for twenty-four days.

CUMBERLAND, Md., March 20. -- Baltimore and Ohio Train No. 2, from Cincinnati and St. Louis, was derailed near Oakland at 8 o'clock this morning. The engine, baggage car, and forward coach landed in a ditch, and the first sleeper rolled into a stream of water. One man was killed and five persons are reported seriously injured. The following passengers were injured:

"The Protective Value of Action, Volitional or Otherwise, in Protective Mimicry" was the title of a paper read in the Museum of Natural History last Tuesday evening to members of the New York Entomological Society.

The well-known collection of pictures formed by Mrs. Sarah M. Kimball of Cleveland, Ohio, and which she intended at one time to present to the projected museum in Cleveland, is to be sold by auction at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms on Thursday and Friday evenings next. The pictures will be on exhibition at the auction rooms to-morrow, Tuesday, and Wednesday.

NEWPORT, Ky., March 20. -- At 12 o'clock last night Scott Jackson and Alonzo Walling, who were condemned to the gallows for the murder of Pearl Bryan, ate a substantial lunch. Jackson, who had been slightly sick before, said he felt much better. They lighted cigars after lunch and sat in their windows calmly smoking and chatting.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20. -- The Cercle Francais, or French Club of Harvard, has in rehearsal and will produce twice in Cambridge and once in Boston Moliere's "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme" -- in Brattle Hall, Cambridge, March 29 and April 3, and in Copley Hall, Boston, March 31. It has been the practice of Harvard students since 1891 to give annually a play from the French.

LONDON, March 20. -- To-morrow morning at 8 o'clock the combined European fleet begins its active defense of the Turk against the Christians in the very same Cretan waters where four centuries ago the fleet of the Venetian Republic did battle in defense of Christian Europe against the Turk.

The Rev. Dr. Ignatz Grossman died yesterday at the residence of his son, 1,347 Lexington Avenue, in the seventy-fourth year of his age. Dr. Grossman was a native of Hungary, and was ordained as rabbi forty years ago. He officiated seventeen years in his native country, and twenty-three years in this country, eleven years being spent in Brooklyn, and twelve years in Chicago.

There was a large number of entries in the three interesting shooting matches at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon and evening. In the revolver match, at 4:30, 5 shots, 10 yards, open to officers and non-commissioned staff officers, Lieut. G.N. Carnochan of the staff won, with a score of 24, and Sergt. R.M. Kalloch, non-commissioned staff, was second with 24.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Two gentlemen once stood in a parlor of the White House waiting to meet the President.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- When the House met to-day, Mr. Grosvenor, (Rep., Ohio,) Chairman of the Republican caucus, offered a resolution providing for the appointment of John F. Clancy as a special employe of the House, to be subject to the Speaker.

In a lecture before the Brooklyn Arts Institute recently, on "Projects for Crossing the East River," First Assistant Engineer O.F. Nichols of the new East River bridge gave an account of the many schemes that have been proposed for facilitating passenger and general railroad transportation over the East River, presenting at the same time a comparative table of travel between New York and its sister cities across both rivers.

After a week almost devoid of new theatrical incidents, there will be an unusual number of new productions this week. The idea of presenting a topical burlesque or review in the Spring, recently introduced here by the Casino managers, will be imitated this year by other theatre managers and the directors of the two large music halls.

SELECTIONS offered for covert coats embrace every desirable shade. The single-breasted fly-front top coat can be properly ordered of either vicunas, undressed worsteds, Venetians, buckskins, kerseys, coverts,

Next Friday afternoon the Liverpool Grand National Steeplechase is to be run over the famous Aintree course. It is the "blue ribbon" of English cross-country racing, and has always been regarded as one of the greatest tests of equine speed and staying powers. The run is over the stiffest sort of a course, measuring 4 miles and 856 yards, and plentifully studded with brooks, hurdles, dry walls, and double fences of a most trying character.

The managers of the Boys' Club of Bethany Memorial Chapel of the Madison Avenue Reformed Church, at First Avenue and Sixtieth Street, have decided to add a system of manual training to their other work, and a special room is now being fitted up for the purpose.

PARIS, March 5. -- All the week has been colored by the carnival -- a wonderful multicolor, from the palette of an impressionist, made up of specks of blue and yellow and red, with here and there a splash of gold. These countless specks, which were the millions of confetti, hung in the air like fantastic snowflakes and carpeted the ground.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The duty on granite in the new Tariff bill is 40 per cent. ad valorem. To increase this duty to 100 per cent., if possible, is the purpose of the visit to Washington of James Thompson, the President of the Granite Manufacturers' Association of Quincy, Mass. Mr. Thompson is accompanied by Mr. John Shaw of Boston, a member of the Home Market Club.
BERLIN, March 20. -- The Reichstag to-day by a vote of 245 to 91 adopted, the decision of the Budget Commission to grant an extra credit for the construction of one new steel-clad warship.

Pool tournaments at the Metropolitan and Calumet Clubs, picture exhibitions at the Colonial and Manhattan Clubs, the opening of the new house of the Engineers' Club, and the annual meeting of the Manhattan Club have been the chief incidents of interest in the club world during the last week.

Ten young women played "The Merchant of Venice" at Pelham Manor yesterday afternoon. The performance was given upon the stage of the Manor Club, and all the women of Pelham Manor's best society were present. The actors were students at Mrs. Hazen's boarding school. The cast was as follows:

Mimicry in color in animals, the use of color as a protection for animals, birds, insects, and fishes, and collateral matters formed the subject for a novel and interesting talk by Dr. Benjamin Sharp before the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. From that talk the following excerpts are taken:

GLASGOW, March 10. -- To celebrate the sixtieth year of Queen Victoria's reign is the present anxiety of our yacht clubs, many of these desiring special yacht races should be sailed for special prizes. The Prince of Wales has officially explained that the Queen desires that the celebrations of the event should be in accordance with the tastes and fancies of her loyal subjects, and are not to be interfered with by any official dictation.

There is no doubt something discreditable in the interest that civilized men take in a fight like that which lately occurred at Carson City. It springs from brutal instincts inherited from the days when men fought for the possession or the protection of whatever they held to be their own.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- "I think," said Jean De Reszke to-day, "that we will sing in the German cities next season. There have been frequent opportunities and invitations, but we are always busy elsewhere. Now there is a chance, and we rather expect to improve it.

A dinner was given last night at Delmonico's in celebration of the passage of what playwrights call the anti-piracy amendment to the copyright law. The hosts were the American Dramatists' Club, and several theatrical managers and the guests were there who had assisted in securing the passage of the law.

We hear it said that opposition to Mr. DINGLEY'S Tariff bill is prejudicial to the business interests of the country. Uncertainty hurts business, the enactment of the bill will put a stop to uncertainty, and business will then have a chance -- that is the argument.

MEDFORD, Mass., March 20. -- This city was visited by a fire calamity this evening, as the result of which Mrs. Margaret McDonald, the wife of John A. McDonald, of 30 Henry Street, was burned to death in her own home. She leaves a husband and three small children.

The New York State Convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, to be held in St. Luke's Church, Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, will open on Saturday morning, May 22, at 8 o'clock, with a celebration of the holy communion. At 11 the Right Rev. Dr. Littlejohn, Bishop of Long Island, will give the welcome and the charge.

BOSTON, Mass., March 20. -- The open scratch games of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, at the Technology Gymnasium, to-night, brought out a large number of athletes, and, while no records were broken, the contests were spirited and interesting. The results follow:

ATLANTA, Ga., March 20. -- The Rev. Sam P. Jones, together with several other ministers of Atlanta, has complained somewhat bitterly of late against the newspapers instructing the clergy how to preach and what to preach about. What Mr. Jones considers is news and what he considers is not news is certainly interesting, whether it be instructive or not.

In speaking of the prospects of the Citizens' Union at a Good Government Club gathering the other night Mr. JAMES C. CARTER declared that there was nothing to be gained by dickering with any political party and that the only hope was in non-partisan effort. He thought that with an enrollment of 50,000 a non-partisan administration for Greater New York might be elected next Fall.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20. -- Yale defeated the University of Pennsylvania here this evening at basket ball by the score of 32 to 10. Yale's players took the lead at the start, and maintained their advantage until the close of the contest. The team play of the visitors was inferior, although several fine individual plays were made.

A ray of hope that there may be other survivors of the wreck of the French steamship Ville de St. Nazaire came in from the Ocean yesterday, with the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm H., which arrived from Mediterranean ports.

In his annual report to the Board of Trustees, which will be issued shortly, Dr. Thomas Hunter, who has been President of the Normal College for over a quarter of a century, will have the following to say about high schools:

New fancies in stationery are forever springing up, and this season everything in the way of note and letter paper is spick span new. The shape, size, color, everything, is changed. The young woman who has any desire to be swagger may throw away every scrap of paper she has if it is a month old, for it will surely be out of fashion.

The Sportsman's Exposition ended last night. The Madison Square Garden was crowded all day long, and the members of the association are very pleased with the result of the week's show. The fly-casting, revolver, and rifle contests which have been in progress during the week were finished during the day, and those in charge of the contests were very glad when they had finished.

Wall Street is not yet enjoying activity. Through the earlier part of the week just closed much strength developed, though dullness continued. At the end of the week a reaction came -- not a serious setback, but enough to damp enthusiasm somewhat.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Statements recently made by ex-Minister Thurston of Hawaii regarding the dangers which he alleges Hawaii has cause to dread on account of the influx of Japanese have aroused some indignation among members of the Japanese Legation in this city.

The blockade of the Piraeus is intended, of course, primarily as an act of intimidation to prevent further proceedings by Greece for the rescue of Crete. Probably even to the palaces of Berlin and St. Petersburg there has now penetrated the consciousness "that Europe, though silent, is yet indignant," and that it would not be politically safe in Germany, however it may be in Russia, to outrage too much the opinion of Europe.
CHICAGO, March 20. -- The members of the Metropolitan Opera Company will leave for St. Louis to-morrow morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 20. -- William Earle, Princeton's baseball coach, arrived Wednesday and took charge of the candidates for the 'Varsity nine. His work last season was regarded as a prime factor in developing the team that brought back the championship to Old Nassau, and his presence with the players again this season is expected to effect great things.

ALBANY, March 20. -- After many years of planning the Albany Historical Society has at last decided to have an art gallery of its own, and has purchased suitable property, which is a building opposite the Capitol, on State Street, with a frontage of 33 feet and a depth of 140 feet. There is ample room on the rear of the lot for the erection of a fire-proof gallery, which the society intends building.

John King, one of the most widely known of American railroad men, died at Beaulieu, near Nice, Wednesday, March 17. A cable dispatch announcing this fact was received from Mrs. King yesterday by David Bosman, for many years private secretary to Mr. King. Mr. King was President and co-receiver of the Erie Railroad during its latest reorganization period, and as railway financier and executive head he ranked among the best.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 20. -- A serious charge was made against a member of the Ulster County bar this morning at the regular Special Term of the Supreme Court at the Court House. The lawyer is Carroll Whitaker of Saugerties, and the charge was made by William A. Sweetser of the firm of Sweetser Sulzer of 45 Broadway, New York City.

RUTLAND, March 20. -- A large shipment of guns from the Watervliet Arsenal, on the line of the Albany and Rutland Railroad, to the testing grounds at Sandy Hook will be made next week. The contract for the transportation of the huge guns has been awarded to the Maxwell Wrecking and Dredging Company of New York.

It is not likely that the victory of Columbia over Harvard in a debate was received by the undergraduate body of the winning university with anything like as much enthusiasm as if the contest had been a boat race. But it is really a much better credential for the university in the eyes, if not of the undergraduates, of their parents and guardians.

THE hunting suit herewith portrayed is a distinctive novelty in brown Bliss tweed. The coat is a full and comfortable four-button sack, straight front, with two outside breast and hip pockets of ample dimensions, patched on with overhanging flaps.

Oscar S. Straus, formerly Minister to Turkey, arrived in New York late yesterday afternoon on the steamer Kaiser Wilhelm II. He was accompanied by his wife, wish whom he has been making an extended European tour.

ST. LOUIS, March 20. -- The warning sent out by the Government Signal Service yesterday that the Mississippi River and all its tributaries would continue to rise has been fulfilled to the letter. The communication with the flooded section has become difficult, but dispatches received from widely separated points show that all have suffered alike.

About thirty women identified with the Public Education Association met in the association rooms, at 64 Madison Avenue, one afternoon recently, to listen to Dr. Woods Hutchinson, a well-known educator of Buffalo, on "The Instinct and Interest of the Child in Education."
A landmark of Eastern Connecticut was removed when on Wednesday last the old Seminary of Music Vale was destroyed by fire.

ST. LOUIS, March 20. -- Republican and Democratic City Conventions were held here to-day. The former was placid and perfunctory, Henry Ziegenhein being nominated unanimously, on the first ballot, for Mayor. He is the choice of Chauncey I. Filley, the recognized "boss" of Republican Municipal politics, and the remainder of the ticket is of the same character.

The Rainy Day Club of New York has been received by the world at large with a degree of interest and consideration which has been a surprise to even the most enthusiastic of its founders. Letters are received from all parts of the country, and innumerable questions are asked concerning the work of the club and dress of its members.

A Pittsburg iron and steel trade authority says: "Thus far no rails have left Pittsburg consigned to Liverpool." The British newspapers are busy denying that any such shipments will be made. It can be stated, however, upon the authority of one of the most important American manufacturers that orders for a large amount have been actually closed and will in natural course go across the ocean.
