LONDON, March 20. -- The racing season which starts next week promises to be the biggest for many years. The new patrons of the turf are many and wealthy. Besides blue-blooded debutants like the Duke of Marlborough, there are a group of South African gold and diamond kings and some new-made millionaires in the bicycle company boom.

LONDON, March 20. -- The fight for conciliation of the Irish parties on financial reforms proceeds in merry faction fashion. When Mr. Healy at the first conference of last week insisted upon asserting the existence of a Healyite party as a separate entity, and declared its independence by the appointment of a separate Secretary, the remotest hope of a coalition of Unionists and Nationalists disappeared.

SALE OF LANDS FOR PAYMENT OF TAXES. -- Interesting questions involving the validity of a tax lease issued by the Controller of the City of New York have just been passed upon by the Court of Appeals in the much-litigated suit brought by Josephine Clason to recover from Elizabeth S. Baldwin the premises at 42 Sheriff Street.

On Thursday next, Mi-Careme, the Lenten season will have run half its course. The last half of Lent is, as a rule, more devoid of social entertaining and entertainments than the first half, for it brings the two most solemn weeks, Passion and Holy Week, of the church year, so that there will remain only about two weeks after Mi-Careme in which entertainments of even a mild nature can be given or enjoyed.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 20. -- The Grand Jury, which has been investigating charges against Broome County officials and others in connection with the building of the new county jail and plans for a new Court House, to-day handed up eighteen indictments against fourteen different persons.

Mortimer C. Addoms, attorney for George T. King, the defendant in the suit brought by Charles Waite to have a judgment for $4,281.95 held by King against him set aside, said yesterday that as his motion to dismiss the complaint was granted by Justice Russell, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, there was no opportunity to present the facts in the case o behalf of Mr. King.
The decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the suit for an injunction against the Joint Traffic Association is interesting mainly as defining the actual condition of the law.

Four students of Stevens Institute, Hoboken, were arraigned before Recorder McDonough yesterday. They were Leo Greenbaum, Henry F. Appleton, Charles McCracken, and Edward H. Cooper. The complainant was Louis M. De Azevido. The row was between a party of sophomores and another party of freshmen.

The present season just opening will witness a great campaign of improvements in the public parks all along the line of the city's superb open-air reservations. To begin with, New York has never before had such an efficient and productive handling of the generous funds set apart for enlarging and beautifying its breathing spots for the metropolis.

A four-oared racing gig of the Union Boat Club, Harlem, was capsized in the Hudson River off Ninth Street, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon. The crew, under Coxswain Harry Ward, had raced against time through Spuyten Duyvil Canal for the Valencia Club's boathouse, Hoboken, on a wager made several weeks ago with the racing crew of the Hoboken club.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21. -- At Staatsburg on Friday a number of schoolboys came near burning to death two of their companions. The lads had their minds filled with Indian exploits from reading trashy novels and newspapers. To imitate some of the deeds described in the literature upon which they had been feasting, they tied Willie Terpening and Allen Burger to a tree, piled leaves and brush around them, and started a fire.

LONDON, March 21. -- The Norwegian steamer Garonne, from Bordeaux for Aberdeen, has arrived in Dover Roads, with her after-hold full of water, having sustained serious damage in a port-side collision with the Belgian steamer Noordland, from Antwerp for New York, at 4 o'clock this morning, when off Dungeness. The Noordland sustained no damage, and proceeded for her destination.

CUMBERLAND, Md., March 21. -- The most extraordinary efforts were made to-day to find the body of Gen. J.S. Fullerton of St. Louis, who was killed in the railroad accident near Oakland yesterday, but met with no success.

SAN LUCIE, Fla., March 21. -- Senator Quay caught a fine tarpon Friday after a hard tussle. After securing the tarpon the party landed a mile south of the Senator's house and started up through the woods.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- A locomotive attached to the Chicago and Boston special on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad blew up this morning, instantly killing the engineer and fireman, and completely demolishing the engine.

A large number of Bishops of the American Church will accept the invitation of the Archbishop of Canterbury to attend the sessions of the fourth Lambeth Conference of Bishops of the Anglican Communion, to be held at Lambeth Palace, London. It will probably be the largest of the kind ever held, as more than 200 Bishops have signified their intention to be present.

The bill providing for a new Hall of Records in this city has been signed by the Governor, and is therefore a law. It has the exact title and the exact purpose of an act passed in 1888, and in its main provisions it is almost identical with that act. The differences are of interest, and it is to be hoped that there will be a contrast in the results.

Your article under the above caption must have been written by some individual unacquainted with the facts, when he reflects on the liberality of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. I have been a patron of this line for twenty-five years, and when obliged to carry packages, have never been interfered with in any way.
The following sales are announced for to-day at 111 Broadway:

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The representatives in Washington of the six powers signatory to the Berlin treaty -- Great Britain, France, Italy, Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Russia -- have in concert notified this Government of the blockade of Crete, the respective notes of Sir Julian Pauncefote, M. Patenotre, Baron de Fava, Baron von Thiellman, M. Hengelmulle von Hengervar, and M. de Kotzebue having been delivered to Secretary Sherman to-day.

ALBANY, March 21. -- The Hamilton Whist Team of Philadelphia last night defeated the Albany Club in a game of the series for the American Whist Club's trophy. The score was 35 to 17. This victory gives the Hamiltons a lead of 15 games in the series. The Albany Club had won eight consecutive games.

The elections now taking place in Austria are significant and of great value as indicating the trend of popular thought and the extent to which certain influences are controlling the development of political ideas.

A new engineers' union, called the Greater New York Central Association of Steam Engineers, was organized yesterday afternoon at 62 East Fourth Street, and those who were present claimed to represent 20,000 engineers in the Metropolitan District.

HALIFAX, March 21. -- The Furness Line steamer Halifax City, which arrived to-day from London, was twenty-three days out. She experienced a terrific hurricane for three days, beginning March 2, during which the sea was running at a mountainous height. At times during the heaviest squalls St. Elmo lights danced on trucks and stays like balls of fire.

The Church of the Messiah, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, was packed to the doors yesterday morning, with extra seats placed in the aisles. The Rev. Minot J. Savage spoke on the theme, "Revelation, Natural and Progressive."

BERLIN, March 21. -- To-day's ceremonies in connection with the celebration of the centenary of Emperor William I., which properly begins to-morrow, consisted of religious services in the Kaiser Wilhelm I. Memorial Church, at which the Emperor was present.
VIENNA, March 21. -- The elections for members of the Reichsrath, which began on March 9, under the new law, which provides for almost universal suffrage, are now almost finished.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The House To-day will enter upon a four days' general tariff debate, which will close at 11 o'clock P.M. Thursday.

As we understand the matter, the attempt of the Governors of the Stock Exchange to cut off the "ticker" service of the bucket shops is not based on moral consideration. These gentlemen feel, of course, that comforting sense of superiority which enables the conductors of a square game to look down with contempt upon the squalid operator of a skin game.

LINCOLN, Neb. March 21. -- When State Treasurer Joseph Bartley retired from office and was arrested for being a half million short, much speculation was indulged in as to the location of the warrant for $200,000, the appropriation for which was made by the Legislature to reimburse the State school fund for money stolen in the Capital National Bank collapse.

Coroner's Physician Donlin made a report yesterday on a case which he has had under investigation, and in which he found that a woman's heart had burst open. "I have heard of people dying from a broken heart," he said, "but this is the only case on record to my knowledge where a heart has actually burst open."

Over 100 companies incorporated in the State of Pennsylvania have been called upon to show why they should not pay larger taxes into the State Treasury. Decisions in some important cases are soon expected.

The Christian Workingmen's Institute began yesterday afternoon its series of free Sunday afternoon discussions in Amity Hall, 310 West Fifty-fourth Street. These meetings, according to a circular, are held "in pursuance of a belief that the principles of the Christian religion afford a perfect solution of the social problems of our times."

The new Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. DAVIS of Minnesota, plainly intends to insist on the amendment to the arbitration treaty which requires the consent of the Senate in every case before it can be submitted to arbitration. This is a contention, not for the benefit of the country, but in the interest of the "dignity" of the Senate.

The ten purses offered by the Driving Club of New York for its grand circuit meeting, Sept. 6 to 11, which closed last Monday, have all been filled to the satisfaction of the Executive Committee, the members of which anticipate one of the best meetings ever held at Fleetwood.
ALBANY, March 21. -- Six weeks remain of the present legislative session if final adjournment is to take place April 29, the date suggested by several of the party leaders.

The large bronze gates for Gen. Grant's tomb that are being made by the firm of Borkel Debevoise, at Houston and Mulberry Streets, will be finished by the end of this month, and will be put in position about the middle of April.

LONDON, March 21. -- The rate of discount during the past week for both three months' and thirty-day bills was 1 1/4 percent. Gold continued to flow in from Cape Colony, and Australia silver was firmer Saturday on a small demand. The continued stagnation at the Stock Exchange is almost unprecedented. Consols showed a decline of 1/4 on the week.

A.H. Sexton of Alfred Field Co., manufacturers, exporters, and importers of cutlery and guns, and American agents of Joseph Rodgers Sons and Joseph Elliot Sons, commented on the cutlery schedule in the Tariff bill as follows: "The scheme is to prohibit entirely importations of quite 80 per cent. of all the knives heretofore imported.

Mr. DINGLEY'S Tariff bill is unsparingly condemned by the very interests it professes to protect. We must protect the American manufacturers, says the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. By their votes the people have declared for adequate protection, says President McKINLEY.

So far as the shipping of the United States is concerned, the blockade of Crete is of no consequence, for we have none in Cretan waters. But the President may well consider carefully the question of protesting against the principle of the blockade. There is no avowed state of war in Crete.

Historians and statesmen have speculated much upon the long duration of the Imperial Republic of Rome. That a so-called republic should have survived over a thousand years with its institutions unimpaired by war, conquest, and revolution is indeed one of the marvels of human history.
In Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last night, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott continued his series of sermons on "The Bible as Literature."

The third and last day of the celebration of the silver jubilee of the Rev. Patrick F. O'Hare, rector of St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church, in Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, took place yesterday, and Archbishop Martinelli, the Papal Delegate, presided at the ceremonies in the church.

At last Mr. DINGLEY has put in figures his estimates of the amount of revenue to be got under his bill. The figures are elaborate, minute, definite, and worthless. Their value is vitiated by the series of "ifs" that precede them, like heralds bearing white flags in front of a supposed attacking column.

The Rev. William G. Frost, President of Berea College, Berea, Ky., delivered an address at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church last night. He is making a trip through the North for the purpose of awakening interest in Southern educational matters. He was formerly a professor in Oberlin College, Ohio, and has also had the advantage of foreign travel and study.

John D. Crimmins is an appreciative collector of old manuscripts, letters, and relics of early American history. His private office is a cozy little museum of historic interest. Each picture on the wall has its own particular story to tell, and the inviting miniature library contains many rare volumes treating of the affairs of Manhattan Island as well as of the Nation.

Oscar S. Straus returned Saturday from three months of travel in Europe. He came home on the Kaiser Wilhelm II., having taken ship at Gibraltar after completing his short tour abroad by a visit to Spain.

The tangle of Republican affairs growing out of strained relations between local factions and those of the back counties disputing over proposed legislation is no nearer a solution to-day than before Senator Platt arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Saturday.

PERRY, O.T., March 21. -- Jamison McClure, son of ex-Gov. Tecumseh McClure of the Choctaw Indian Nation, a full-blooded Indian, committed suicide yesterday by throwing himself in front of a train. He was mangled to death.
CANEA, March 21. -- According to the proclamation issued by the foreign Admirals, the blockade of Crete began at 8 o'clock this morning.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 21. -- A terrific race riot prevailed last night at Brookside, a mining camp near Birmingham, a place noted for such things.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21. -- Charles Ennis was shot to-day and probably fatally wounded by James Giles, a saloonkeeper. Giles had been dragged from his place by Ennis and several others, and was being kicked brutally when his wife rushed out with a revolver and gave it to her husband. whereupon she also was attacked, knocked down, and kicked. The shooting followed.

MIDDLEBORO, Mass., March 21. -- The Rev. Dr. William Bayard Hale, the young Episcopal rector and protege of the late Philips Brooks, whose magazine criticisms of "Church Entertainments" and whose "Analysis of a New England Town" brought him fame, is out with a new book entitled "The New Obedience; a Plea for Social Submission to Christ," which is by far the most sensational work he has yet put out.
ALBANY, March 22. -- Chairman Nixon of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee to-night introduced the annual Supply bill.

The entertainment offered at the Broadway Theatre last evening, comprising serious drama with music, (melodrama in the true sense of the word,) was conceived in a reverent spirit and executed with a gravity of purpose and a degree of artistic skill worthy of respectful attention and cordial approval.
The Council of the University Settlement Society has bought a plot of ground on the southeast corner of Rivington and Eldridge Streets, 67 by 80 feet, for the new Settlement House.

As a result of a quarrel growing out of a cartmen's boycott in Long Island City, Thomas Cavanagh, a well-known contractor, shot and seriously wounded Martin Smith, fifty-two years old, of 107 Seventh Street, Long Island City, a sympathizer of the union men, on the ferryboat Rockaway, yesterday afternoon.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 22. -- Prof. Winthrop More Daniels, head of the Department of Political Economy, published to-day in The Daily Princetonian, the following letter:
The four-story brick tenement, with store, on the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, 25 by 100, has been sold by the O'Rourke estate for about $40,000.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 22. -- Mrs. Charles W. Russell of New York, who has been spending the Winter at the Lakewood Hotel, was badly shocked and bruised at noon to-day by a peculiar accident. She started from the hotel shortly before noon in one of the hotel carriages to take a drive.

Some workmen who undertook to paint a new house at 17 West Side Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday trespassed on the adjoining lot, owned and occupied by Henry Frank. Mrs. Frank turned a garden hose on them and drove them from her property.
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Do President MCKINLEY and Mr. DINGLEY think this is a good time to increase the cost of living in this country? Do they assume that after four years of business stagnation and loss the people's pockets are bulging with money which they will cheerfully pay out to meet their increased expenses under a Dingley tariff?

ALBANY, March 22. -- The largest calendar and the largest attendance of visitors and members at any session were all in evidence in the Assembly this evening. The prospect of the hardest legislative week of the year was everywhere talked of. All of the Greater New York measures are scheduled to pass, and all the committees have a heavy list of hearings.

The most striking fact about the centennial celebration of the first German Kaiser is that it is in so small a measure popular and spontaneous, in so large a measure official and artificial. Sure enough, the old Kaiser had a wonderful career, little as his personal qualities may have had to do with its success.
BOSTON, Mass., March 22. -- Cards have been received in this city announcing the marriage of Louise Baldwin and Alberto Randegger, which took place in London March 11.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 22. -- The local committee, which has charge of the arrangements for the college boat races, held a meeting to-night to formulate an offer to offset the inducements made by New London to the college to go there.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- By a majority opinion, delivered by Justice Peckham, the Supreme Court of the United States today announced its decision that the agreement of the Trans-Missouri Freight Association to maintain rates within its territory was a violation of the anti-trust law of 1890, prohibiting contracts or combinations in restraint of trade, and must be abandoned.
ARLINGTON, Ga., March 22. -- A terrible tornado passed through the south side of the town at 8:30 o'clock this morning and totally wrecked the Academy and partially demolished several other houses.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The Senate, in executive session to-day, made good progress with the general treaty of arbitration. All of the important committee amendments were agreed to without division. Senator Morgan offered an amendment eliminating the Nicaraguan Canal from the terms of the treaty, but this was voted down viva voce, the Senate believing this had been cared for by the committee amendments.

ALBANY, March 22. -- The Greater New York charter will be up for final passage in the Assembly to-morrow. The Republicans have a programme by which they say they will take a final vote on it before the day's session ends. They do not propose to amend it in the slightest particular.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- In an editorial The Times-Herald, Republican, asks for the withdrawal of Judge Sears, Republican candidate for Mayor; Harlan, independent Republican, and Hesing, independent Democrat, on the score that none can be elected, and that the presence of all three in the field means the election of Carter Harrison, Jr., the Democratic nominee.

" You are to decide," said Recorder Goff to a jury in Part IV, of General Sessions yesterday, "if the kick was a legitimate kick, if it was lawfully delivered, and if the defendant was justified in kicking. You must, however, bear in mind that to tell a man to go to the devil is not legal cause for an assault.''
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The following applications for posts under the Treasury Department were made public this morning:

ALBANY, March 22. -- The Republican leaders from the interior of the State have argued that the Greater New York was the first step toward the creation of a separate State, and Assemblyman Trainor will justify their fears by introducing two bills looking toward the union in a new State of the counties of New York, Kings, Richmond, Queens, Suffolk, Westchester, and Putnam.
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The tariff debate in the House began to-day. The bill was considered in Committee of the Whole, Mr. Sherman (Rep., N.Y.,) in the chair.

For sheer weight of notable names representative of the brains and character of the American people the memorial sent to the Senate by the National Arbitration Committee stands unique among prayers to Congress and Legislatures. It is, as the memorial says, "a large and intelligent jury" that asks for the ratification of the arbitration treaty.

LOUISVILLE, March 22. -- This is the day the players of the Louisville Baseball Club were to report for duty. Nearly all are now here. On Wednesday morning all will go to West Baden Springs for ten days' practice. The remainder of the practice work Will be on the home grounds. Outfielder Clarke is not expected, he having refused to sign for less than $2,400.

The Military Committee of the Grant Monument ceremonies met yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Grand Marshal, Gen. Grenville M. Dodge, at 1 Broadway. There were present A. Noel Blakeman, Col. H.C. Corbin, Gen. Daniel Butterfield, Col. A.G. Mills, Gen. Nicholas W. Day, Col. Charles N. Swift, Gen. Burnett, and Gen. Wager Swayne.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- The largest lobby which ever assailed a Legislature departed to-night for Springfield. It comprised 600 small merchants of Chicago, who left on a special train of twenty cars, to help put through tfhe Anti-Department-Store bill, now under consideration. They are thoroughly organized with branches in all the trades, covering thirty-nine towns.
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The Senate Finance Committee is affected just now by the criticism of the tariff bill to a degree not appreciated in the House.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 22. -- W.E.D. Stokes of New York has leased the charming place of James Gordon Bennett, on Belleview Avenue, directly opposite the Casino.

A miniature society in wax entertained in the large ballroom of the Waldorf yesterday afternoon, and the participants in the waxen event rivaled the gatherings of New York's social circles in beauty and stylishness of costume. It was the opening of the second Model Doll Show, in aid of the Scarlet Fever and Diphtheria Hospital, and the waxen beauties were inspected by nearly 2,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The views of the minority of the Committee on Ways and Means upon the tariff bill were presented to the House this evening in a report written by Representative Bailey, (Dem., Texas,) the leader of the Democracy. The report reads as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., March 22. -- Both branches of the Legislature met to-night. In the House, Mr. Wildes offered a concurrent resolution directing the Attorney General to begin legal proceedings against Henry C. Kelsey for the recovery of certain State moneys which it is alleged the Secretary of State, whose term is about to expire, has given no account of.

What will unquestionably prove to be the American Cycling Derby took form yesterday when a committee of wheelmen, representing the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York, went before the Park Commissioners and practically obtained permission to conduct a twenty-five-mile race on Riverside Drive on May 29.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22. -- The passengers on the Olivette to-night tell a story of the horrible murder committed in Pinar Del Rio Province last week, near Artemisa, of the family of Capt. Luis Perez, a Cuban leader, by the Spanish guerrillas. His wife, three sisters, and five children were killed in cold blood.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- There was no indication, in the opening speeches on the tariff bill to-day that the Republicans had been moved at all by the criticisms made upon the provisions of the measure reported by Mr. Dingley. The strictures of Republican as well as Democratic papers pass for nothing. No attention whatever is paid to the objections of importers.
ALBANY, March 22. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill is opposed to the charter as it now stands, and takes a position substantially in sympathy with the amendments which Senator Cantor will offer.

Wool dealers are not agreed as to the advantages of a protective tariff, but they are unanimous in admitting that the New England mill owners have been buying large supplies for future delivery, in anticipation of a tariff and higher prices on foreign products. The mills were generally low in stocks last Fall, but as the belief of manufacturers in the election of McKinley increased, extensive buying for future delivery began.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22. -- The intercollegiate golf tournament will be held May 13 and 14. It will be open to all American and Canadian college teams. The Ardsley Casino offers a cup to the winner, J.H. Choate of Harvard will have charge of the entries, which will close May 1.

The important point in the Supreme Court decision in the case of the Trans-Missouri Freight Association against the railroads that entered into a traffic agreement for controlling transportation and maintaining rates in their territory lies in its holding that the Sherman Anti-Trust act of 1890 applies to railroad cor porations and their traffic agreements.
NEW ORLEANS, March 22. -- Warm, cloudy weather and a heavy track marked the sport to-day. Favorites won four of the events. Attendance, 2,500.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Gov. Black to-day signed Senator Ellsworth's bill providing for the completion of the State Capitol Building by contract under the supervision of State Superintendent of Public Works George W. Aldridge. The present Capitol Commission, comprising Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, State Engineer Adams, State Superintendent of Public Works Aldridge, Ira M. Hedges of Haverstraw, and Archimedes Russell of Syracuse, is abolished.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen held two sessions yesterday to consider the various applications that have been made recently by both the Metropolitan Traction Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company for extensions and new lines.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- State after State, Territory after Territory, made its way to-day to the President in search of places. Since the last delegation came away the same story has been heard in many hotels, that the President is indisposed to create vacancies merely to gratify the desire of his party friends to hold office.
There seems to be a dislocation of the gearing of the Platt machine, but it will not do to be too sure that it is not going to grind out the results expected of it.

The Committee on Organization of the Citizens' Union met last evening in the committee room of Cooper Union and effected a permanent organization by choosing Robert Fulton Cutting Chairman, Charles Stewart Smith First Vice Chairman, J. Kennedy Ted Treasurer, and John C. Clark Secretary.
BERLIN, March 22. -- The celebration of the centenary of Emperor William I., who was born March 22, 1797, began to-day, and was observed throughout Germany as a national holiday.
ALBANY, March 22. -- Although a calendar of twenty-three pages confronted the Senate at the opening of the session to-night, nothing was shown in the transaction of business.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 22. -- Judge Jenkins issued an order in the United States Court this morning directing Special Master Cary of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company to cancel the $2,000,000 par value consolidated mortgage bonds which were pledged with the Northwestern Equipment Company as security.

CYNTHIANA, Ind., March 22. -- A cyclone at 3:05 o'clock this morning did great damage here. The opera house was demolished. On the opposite side of the street a frame dwelling was torn to pieces. The occupants, Mr. and Mrs. Garrett Nisby and Mrs. Tomlin, escaped by rushing from the house just as it fell.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 22. -- An unexpected number of the crack wing-shots arrived at Elkwood Park td-day, in order to be on hand for the big shoot of three days which commences to-morrow. Up to the arrival of this morning's mail, 140 entries were received for the Grand American Handicap, and many more are looked for.

Since the death on March 2 of the Rev. Dr. George S. Mallory, who was editor of The Churchman, an effort has been made to induce some of his creditors to settle for 40 cents on the dollar their claims against the Hotel St. Andrew.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Gen. Daniel Butterfield of New York City appeared before the Governor to-day on behalf of the committee having charge of the military display at the Grant Monument dedication, and asked that the entire National Guard of the State be present at the dedication. The Governor said he approved of the plan, and would favor an appropriation of $50,000 to carry it into effect.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 23. -- The Greater New York charter was passed to-day by the Assembly without amendment. The final vote was 118 in favor of and 28 against it. Four members were absent.

" This Supreme Court decision necessarily invalidates the joint traffic railroad agreement," said United States District Attorney Wallace Macfarlane yesterday, in commenting on the opinion handed down by Justice Peckham of the United States Supreme Court, adverse to the Trans-Missouri Freight Association.

There is no denying that "for purposes of foreign conquest and subjugation," as WEBSTER put it, a despotism "has its advantages. The recent diplomatic successes of Russia form a case very much in point. When a Government has not to reckon with any public opinion in its own people and does not find it uncomfortable to defy the opinion of the rest of mankind it has superior facilities for the transaction of business.
F. Vivanti has bought of Isaac Mayer and Victor Kallman the five-story brick flat, with store, 25.11 by 80, on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundredth Street.

The hockey teams of the New York Athletic and the St. Nicholas Skating Clubs contested for supremacy on the ice at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The match had aroused considerable interest, because it decided the amateur championship of the United States. At the call of time there were fully 1,500 people present.
ALBANY, March 23. -- Gov. Black has signed the following bills:
ALBANY, March 23. -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day.
The Society of Christian Endeavor of the First New York District voted at a meeting Monday night, at the Mariners' Church, to send the following message to Gov. Black:

The Committee of Organization of the Citizens' Union is proceeding in a businesslike way to prepare for the work of the campaign for non-partisan government in this city, whether this city is to be what it is to-day or what it is to become if the Greater New York charter goes into effect.

Peter C. Kellogg's twenty-fifth annual sale of trotting stock will begin in the Madison Square Garden to-day. The horses were shown yesterday afternoon and evening. Among the judges of horses present were Gen. B.F. Tracy, W.R. Janvier, Dr. J.H. MacCormac, C.H. Kerner, F.W. Corey, F.M. Ware, J.H. Shults, R.W. McCully, C.A. Bates, J. Driscoll, and the Meyer brothers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- The question as to whether a railroad corporation which has taken possession of a property for the purpose of building its road has the right to, after it has built that road over and above the property seized and paid for, sublet that property for other than railroad purposes is about to be tested in the courts.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., March 23. -- The Thousand Islands House at Alexander Bay, one of the largest hotels on the St. Lawrence River, was sold by Referee Thomas F. Kearns at public auction on a mortgage foreclosure sale at the law office of Mullin, Griffin Walker, in Watertown, Saturday morning, and was bid in by Orrin G. Staples of Washington, D.C., for $24,300.

NEW ORLEANS, March 23. -- Clear, cool, and bright weather drew out 3,000 people to the race course to-day. The track was lumpy and slow, but the talent landed three favorites and three second choices, beating the books well. About the only bookmaker here who has made much money this Winter is Ham May of St. Louis, who is well over $30,000 ahead of the meeting.

LONDON, March 28. -- The Linconshire handicap, the first important turf event of the season, attracted a large crowd to the Lincoln Spring meeting to-day. The race was of special interest to Americans, as Mr. Pierre Lorillard's four-year-old bay colt Diakka, entered by Mr. Lorillard's racing partner, Lord William Beresford, was thought to have a good chance of winning, and the horse was well backed by American bettors.

PARIS, Texas, March 23. -- At 10 o'clock this morning the Farmers and Merchants' Bank, one of the oldest and thought to be the strongest financial institution in North Texas, with a paid-up capital of $200,000 and a surplus of $60,000, made an assignment to Judge D.H. Scott.

Schedules of Crook Perham, wholesale coal dealers at 1 Broadway, show total liabilities $428,346, of which $91,388 are direct and $336,958 contingent; nominal assets, $357,060; actual assets, $232,164. The contingent liabilities consist of indorsements on discounted notes of coal dealers in this city, Hartford, New Haven, Providence, and Baltimore.

Samuel Alexander Frazer, for a time the third mate of the clipper ship T.F. Oekes, the long overdue vessel which arrived in port Sunday, lay in his cot at the Marine Hospital on Staten Island yesterday afternoon. Around him were his eleven companions from the vessel, and all of them, Dr. Stoner said, were doing remarkably well.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Senate Insurance Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on the Hobbie bill to allow insurance companies to invest their funds in the stock of other insurance companies not doing the same class of business.

The scramble for sidewalk privileges is more keen and genera] this Spring than it has ever been, despite the fact that Mayor Strong, Commissioner Waring, and various other officials are doing the best they can to discourage the practice of misusing the sidewalks.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 23. -- The Raines amendments to the liquor tax law will be considered by the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment Thursday.

ST. LOUIS, March 23. -- Dispatches from many points in the flooded section show but slightly varied conditions from those of yesterday. Slight rises are reported at New Madrid, Mo.; Columbus and Paducah, Ky.; Cairo and Metropolis, Ill.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 23. -- Mrs. Grover Cleveland was formally introduced to Princeton's society ladies this afternoon at a tea given in her honor by Mrs. Patton, wife of Dr. Francis Lindley Patton, President of Princeton University.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Senate Cities Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on Senator Wieman's bill providing for the depression of the steam railroad tracks on Atlantic Avenue, in Brooklyn, and on Senator McNulty's bill providing for the removal of the tracks altogether. There has been considerable agitation for several years on this question.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- William Leland, a real estate dealer, and son of ex-General Auditor Leland of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Road, tried to commit suicide this morning by hanging himself in a police station.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed, with costs, the judgment of the lower court in the case of The Sun Printing and Publishing Association and others, appellants, against the Mayor and other authorities of New York City, Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, and others, respondent.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- If James Blane, alias Bland, the burglar who escaped from Sing Sing Prison last week, is caught it will be due to a woman whom he jilted in New York City after his escape. This woman, whose name is Mary Enright, notified the Chicago police by letter that Blane was hiding at the Albemarle Hotel, a cheap lodging house at No. 387 Clark Street.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23. -- Lewis F. Post, an associate editor of The Cleveland Recorder, was to-day sentenced to ten days' imprisonment in the County Jail, and fined $200 and costs by Judge Lamson of the Court of Common Pleas of this county, for contempt of court. The action is important, as it threatens the liberty of the press in the State of Ohio.

Doubtless the process by which the Greater New York charter was passed in the Assembly yesterday will be known as "jamming it through," although the vote was 118 to 28 and was not a "strict party vote." No very violent "jamming" was necessary where a vote of nearly five to one was waiting to be cast.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- Three men arrested here yesterday on suspicion that they were green-goods men and confidence men, prove to be members of the notorious Valentine gang of swindlers that was broken up in New York last Fall.
MACON, Ga., March 23. -- A.J. Riddie of Columbus, Ga., who died yesterday in that city, was buried here to-day. He was born in Baltimore sixty-eight years ago, but spent many years in Georgia.

The residents of Greater New York who read the report of yesterday's proceedings in the Legislature with regard to the charter of the same will be apt to experience some impatience. While the residents of this district do not yet comprise a majority of the population of the State, they pay considerably more than half its expenses.

Mrs. Richard Irwin, as President of the New York Association of Sewing Schools, opened last evening the exhibition of work which the association is holding in the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street. Mayor Strong had agreed to give the opening address, but sent word at the last minute that his ill health would keep him at home, and Charles Bulkley Hubbell, President of the Board of Education, took his place.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 23. -- It is believed that between twenty-five and thirty tramps are buried in the Big Four freight wreck at the Ohio Southern Viaduct, twenty-seven miles east of this city. The wreck which occurred this morning is probably the worst in the history of the road.

A peculiar suit, in which the laws and customs of the Jewish Church will be made the basis of an action for damages, will soon come up in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. The cause leading to the suit originated in the office of District Attorney Backus.

An elevated railroad engine on the Second Avenue line jumped the up-town track at Twenty-third Street yesterday morning just before 8 o'clock, and but for the fact that it was coupled to a train behind which did not leave the track, would have toppled over into the street. The accident occurred just after the train had pulled out from the Twenty-third Street station.

The body of an unknown man was found yesterday at noon in the area in the rear of 119 Walker Street, where it had evidently lain many hours. No one is missing from the adjoining tenement, and the police are puzzled to account for its presence. The area is about 50 feet long by 3 wide, running parallel with Walker Street.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23. -- The following statement, issued to-day by the Ore Producers, effectually winds up the affairs of the Ore Pool:
The second section of the library of the late Prof. E.A. Carre of St. Louis was sold yesterday afternoon, by Bangs Co., auctioneers, at 91 Fifth Avenue.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 23. -- Parliament will assemble on Thursday of this week. The budget will be introduced early in the session, and a tariff bill also. The latter will likely come as a surprise to Canada, and to not an inconsiderable portion of the exporters of the United States.

Columbia will certainly have a crew on the water at Poughkeepsie this Summer. The Columbia University Union, which has charge of the boating interests, also announces that all its indebtedness has been paid. These two announcements were made yesterday by Dr. W.K. Otis, the new Treasurer of the union.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- President McKinley this morning granted a respite to four men who were to have been hanged at noon to-day at Santa Fe, New Mexico. A telegram directing a stay of execution for ten days, to enable the President to examine the case, was sent to the United States Marshal there. This was the first opportunity of exercising clemency presented to the President since he entered the White House.

Mrs. Centlivre's ancient comedy, called "The Wonder -- A Woman Keeps a Secret," put forward at Daly's Theatre last night without any fuss, but with a very satisfactory result, proved to be vastly more alive and humorous than any person who had seen it only in Lawrence Barrett's revival a few years ago could have expected.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- In the House to-day the debate on the tariff bill was continued. The opening speech was by Mr. Gibson, (Rep., Tenn.,) who spoke in favor of the bill.
TRENTON, N.J., March 23. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Senate indulged to-day in an almost one-sided denunciation of the civil service law and its administration. The matter came up in the shape of a resolution offered by Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) directing the Committee on Civil Service to inquire into the dismissal of some half-dozen employes (microscopists) of the Bureau of Animal Industry in South Omaha, Neb.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 23. -- The Ward Line steamer Niagara, Capt. Crocker, was towed to Charleston Bar this morning. She had lost her rudder, and her passengers had spent an anxious week at sea.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The skies were dull and overcast this morning, though there were occasional intervals of sunshine. The streets were filled at an early hour with people anxious to witness the great historic procession, which was the principal outdoor feature of the day's programme of the celebration of the centenary of Emperor William I.

There is some good Democratic doctrine in Mr. BAILEY'S report of the minority of the Ways and Means Committee against the Dingley bill. "No man," says the report, "would defend a system of taxation under which the Government first collected the money and afterward distributed it among its favorites."

Secretary of War Alger has sent a communication to Gen. Grenville M. Dodge, Grand Marshal and Chairman of the Military Committee of the Grant Monument Inaugural Celebration, stating that he has issued orders for the following representation of the United States Regular Army to participate in the celebration on April 27:

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Within a week it is expected by high railroad officials that not one of the organizations having jurisdiction over passenger and freight rates will be in existence in this country, as a result of the plain decision of the United States Supreme Court, and all associations which have for their purpose the maintenance of agreed rates and the division of traffic are illegal.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23. -- James J. Corbett and Robert Fitzsimmons will never meet in the prize ring for another championship battle. This question was practically decided this morning when the two pugilists met in the barroom of the Baldwin Hotel and talked over their plans quietly and dispassionately. There were no threatening gestures and no loud talk.

ALBANY, March 22. -- There was a long calendar in the Senate this morning and the first upon it were the Anti-Trust bills, reported by the Lexow Investigating Committee, which were the special order for the day, together with the report of the committee.

CHARLESTOWN, Ind., March 23. -- The famous Tunnel Mill, three miles from here, and about twelve miles from Louisville, is to be sold at public auction Friday. This old flour mill is one of the historic landmarks of Indiana. It was built in 1798, when Southern Indiana was a wilderness, the hunting ground of hostile Indians.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 23. -- Two hundred or more crack pigeon shots from every part of the country came to Elkwood Park to-day and participated in two interesting matches. Two other events were on the programme, but they could not be decided on account of the time occupied in shooting the Nitro-Powder Handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Secretary John D. Long of the Navy Department has made an emphatic answer to Congressional delegations from New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and California, who have been requesting him for the last two weeks to "let down the bars" at the Brooklyn, League Island, Norfolk, and Mare Island Navy Yards, so as to admit party workers, irrespective of merit qualifications.

The Executive Committee of the Driving Club has decided upon a Spring meeting at Fleetwood Park, to be held June 8 to 11, and have decided upon offering five-hundred-dollar purses for the following classes, viz.: 2:15, 2:19, 2:24, 2:30, and 3:00 trotting, and 2:12, 2:20, and-3:00 pacing, with entrance fee of 5 per cent. and an additional of 5 per cent. from winners.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Capt. Otto L. Hein, First Cavalry, has been selected as Commandant of Cadets at West Point, with the temporary rank of Lieutenant Colonel, to relieve Capt. S.M. Mills, Fifth Artillery.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24. -- Chairman Edward Lauterbach of the New York County Committee, Fred S. Gibbs, and Lemuel E. Quigg were here to-day and conferred with Gov. Black on the proposed Metropolitan Police bill and the Raines excise amendments.

By far the most puzzling plank in the St. Louis platform was that which dealt with reciprocity. "Protection and reciprocity," it read, "are twin measures of Republican policy and go hand in hand." Every thinking reader of that plank must have wondered what the author of it thought that he meant.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- Until the term of President Potter of the League of American Wheelmen expires, or he shows a disposition to consult the wishes of the officials of the Illinois division, the newly-elected chief of the cycling world will be ignored by this division.

ALBANY, March 24. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast to-night appeared before a joint session of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly and Finance Committee of the Senate and asked for an appropriation to transport the National Guard to New York to participate in the celebration attending the dedication of Grant's tomb.

Preparations for the Grant Monument inaugural celebration are progressing, and the parades on land and water on April 27 will be imposing. The two parades will move simultaneously. A long line of merchant vessels will take part in the marine parade, which will proceed as did the ships in the centennial parade.

ELKWOOD PARK, N.J., March 24. -- One hundred and thirty-four contestants to-day began to shoot for the Fifth Grand American Handicap. There were 146 entries, but twelve forfeited the $25 entrance fee. This is the largest number that have ever shot for a sweepstakes of this kind. The Interstate Association guarantees the stakes to be worth $1,000, of which $500 goes to the first high gun, $300 to the second, and $200 to the third.

That the East is not indisputably as advanced as the great Middle West in all departments of education is the opinion of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, as expressed with some emphasis last night in the last of four conferences at Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, under the auspices of the League of Parents and Teachers.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- For the dispatch of business in the Senate, it is to be hoped the Republicans will be able to fill up the skeleton committees of the body and go on with the matters referred to them as speedily as possible.

The third concert of the American Symphony Orchestra took place at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon. The entertainment was made interesting by the production of two works which may be regarded as novelties, though one of them was written more than 100 years ago and the other has already been played in this city.

LONDON, March 24. -- The St. James Gazette, in a leading editorial article upon the action of the United States Senate in adopting the amendments to the arbitration treaty reported by the Foreign Relations Committee, says:

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Large audiences in the galleries and an unusually large attendance on the floor of the House of Representatives heard the third day's general debate upon the Tariff bill. The principal speeches of the day were those of Johnson, (N.D.,) Grosvenor, (Ohio,) and Evans, (Ky.,) Republican members of the Committee on Ways and Means, in favor of the bill, and McMillin, (Tenn.,) the oldest Democratic member, against.

William R. Grace, his wife, Lillius G. Grace, and his son, Joseph P. Grace, have jointly set aside $200,000 for the founding of a manual training school for young women and girls. A bill providing for the incorporation of the institution was introduced in the Legislature Tuesday by Assemblyman L.E. Brown. The school, when established, will be known as the Grace Institute of New York City.

A cold breath from the ocean enshrouded the Long Island and Jersey coasts and the bays and inlets hereabouts with an impenetrable fog early yesterday morning, and during the preceding night. While it continued, three vessels found the sands. The alert lifesavers did a deal of hard work during the night and early morning, but they were able to be of little assistance, as little assistance was required.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Visitors to the room of Senator Platt to-night found him in very good humor and willing to listen to all requests. The explanation of this happy condition was the report, which Mr. Platt did not deny, that New York State is to have another important appointment.

-- If a resident of Boston who determines upon suicide is considerate enough of the city's feelings to go somewhere else before he performs the desperate act, it does seem too bad that one of the Boston papers, in giving news of the tragedy, should use language calculated to give a wholly wrong impression in regard to the man's motives.

Cotton corduroy of the cheaper sort is used very largely for the manufacture of trousers and knee breeches for men of small means and for their boys. It costs net about 15 cents a yard, 27 inches wide. The present duty equals 47 1/2 per cent.; the McKinley duty was 90 per cent.; the Dingley duty is equivalent to fully 130 per cent.
ALBANY, March 24. -- The following bills were to-day introduced in the Senate:

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Embarrassment to incumbents is as serious over the delay in patronage distribution as it is to office seekers in a number of instances, the most notable cases being in the diplomatic and consular service, where several officials are seriously incommoded by the failure to get their resignations accepted.

Senator RAINES still expects, or professes to expect, to have the jamming through process applied to his amendments of the liquor tax law. The bill for making these amendments is streaked and spotted with changes to many sections, but those which most interest people relate to liquor selling in clubs and in hotels on Sunday.
Peter Jansehin, a Russian wheelman, was among the immigrants examined by the Board of Special Inquiry at Ellis Island yesterday. He had no money.
A cable message from London yesterday informed the relatives of Howard Potter that he had died suddenly. The cablegram was very short, and the cause of his death was not given.

Wall Street talked unceasingly of the Trans-Missouri decision yesterday, but those who discussed the question with settled views as to its merits or the results were few. If there was a prevailing opinion, it was that the only remedy for the Joint Traffic and kindred associations lies in Congressional action. The only authorized statement was the following by Woerishoffer Co.:

ALBANY, March 24. -- The Finance Committee of the Senate and the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly gave a joint hearing to-night on the bill proposed by Gov. Black and prepared at his suggestion, which appropriates $1,000,000 for the acquisition of land in the Adirondack forest preserve.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- All railroad traffic Associations in this city refrained from transacting any business to-day which had to do with the regulation of rates or division of business. Practically all the associations are in a state of suspended animation, "looking over the ground and waiting to find out where they stand," as Chairman Caldwell of the Western Passenger Association, expressed it.

The railway companies directly affected by the anti-trust decision of the Supreme Court are reported to be taking steps promptly to withdraw from the organization condemned. Those connected with the Joint Traffic Association have taken no such steps and wisely refrain from any decisive action until their own case shall have been distinctly decided by the court of last resort.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Senate spent only half an hour in open session to-day, the remainder of the time being given to the consideration of the arbitration treaty behind closed doors. The Agricultural Appropriation bill -- one of the four money bills that failed at the last session -- was reported back in the shape in which it passed the House last week, and was placed on the calendar.

A large number of women met at the Buckingham Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning in behalf of the George Junior Republic, at Freeville, N.Y. The association working in conjunction with W.R. George, the founder of the republic, is at present $1,500 in debt, and requires at least $5,000 to carry on the work for the next year.

The golden jubilee of the priesthood of the Very Rev. Augustine F. Hewit, the Superior General of the Paulists of this city will be celebrated next Sunday at the Paulist Church, Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue. The fiftieth anniversary of Father Hewit's ordination occurs on the Feast of the Annunciation, which is to-day, (the 25th,) but the event will be commemorated by one continuous service on Sunday.

Definite progress was made yesterday toward the establishment of a great zoological garden in Bronx Park, under the auspices of the New York Zoological Society, when the Sinking Fund Commission allotted to the society, under certain well-defined conditions, 261 acres of land in the southern end of Bronx Park, adjoining the botanical garden.

Permit me to call your attention to another evidence of the carelessness which characterizes the framing of the Dingley bill. Or is this too charitable a judgment, and had I better call it another proof of the monumental greed that has inspired many of its provisions?
A spectacular production called "Nature," by William De Verna, will be seen at the Academy of Music next season. It will be presented early in August.

A mistaken impression and one that Episcopalians feel might easily prove most hurtful has gone abroad respecting action taken Tuesday by the Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. As reported in some quarters the Trustees at their meeting in the See House, 29 Lafayette Place, decided to build on the grounds of the Cathedral a magnificent See House, or palace, for Bishop Henry C. Potter, at a cost of $400,000.

Will you kindly draw the public's attention to the mass meeting in Cooper Union Thursday evening, March 25, under the auspices of the Central Labor Unions of New York and Brooklyn and the Social Reform Club? Unfortunately most of our citizens are very ignorant of the actual wrongs and barbarities endured by sailors under the American flag.

If the opposition, to the so-called Ellsworth Forest Preserve bill -- which was really drawn by Gov. BLACK'S special legal counselor to meet his views on the subject -- came only from the lumber and wood-pulp men, who object to the manner of taking property, it would not be evidence of anything really objectionable in the measure from the point of view of public interest.

ALBANY, March 24. -- The conference committee appointed by the Legislature to consider the annual Supply bill has completed its work. Among the changes made by the conference committee are the following:

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24. -- Theodore A. Havemeyer, the sugar king, and E.A. Watson were in luck to-day, bringing in two fine tarpon, the former's weighing 100 pounds. Watson's was larger, weighing 176 pounds and measuring 6 feet 10 inches.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- The gross earnings of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road for the third week of March were $508,538, against $625,811 for the corresponding week last year, a decrease of $117,273.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24. -- The sixty-first session of the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference met this morning at 9 o'clock in the Central Methodist Church. Bishop Henry W. Warren opened the session with devotional exercises. The following officers, were elected: Secretary -- J.L. Roe, Bridgeton; Assistant Secretaries -- J.H. Payson, G.C. Stanger, Henry Belting, M.E. Snyder, J.L. Howard, and J.F. Shaw; Statistical-Secretary -- J.H. Boswell, Trenton; Treasurer -- H.G. Williams, Bridgeborough.

The Greater New York charter was advanced to a third reading in the Senate yesterday and will doubtless be "jammed through" to-day. Five bills and three concurrent resolutions proposing Constitutional amendments, all supplemental to the charter, were submitted by the commission and have been agreed to by the Cities Committees of the two houses.

At yesterday's meeting of the Police Board a report on the Inspector McLaughlin matter was presented by Col. Grant, Chairman of the Committee on Rules and Discipline. The report recited the facts connected with the trial of McLaughlin for bribery, his conviction, and the subsequent reversal by the Court of Appeals.

The task of removing sidewalk obstructions from Ann and Nassau Streets was undertaken in earnest yesterday. After consultation with Commissioner Collis, Superintendent of Incumbrances Henkel issued orders to the owners of 200 stands and show cases on Ann Street to remove the same from the stoop-line within forty-eight hours.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Mrs. Pauline Smith at $20,500 the three-story and basement brick dwelling 271 West Seventy-first Street, on lot 16 by 92.2.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Mr. Dingley has very earnestly argued in justification of the rates of the new Tariff bill, but his committee has been so far affected by the criticism upon the proposition to tax scientific books and apparatus that he has restored them to the free list.
FRANKFORT, Ky., March 24. -- The first legislative joint ballot for United States Senator was taken at 12:20 to-day. It resulted in no election.

HAVANA, March 24. -- Gen. Llnares reports that his command of 1,600 men, comprising infantry, cavalry, and artillery, left Songo, in the Province of Santiago de Cuba, and at La Sel ranch encountered several parties of rebels under the leadership of Cebreco, with whom they had a sharp engagement.
TRENTON, N.J., March 24. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day.

The surrender to the custody of the American Ambassador in London of the original log of the Mayflower is a graceful act. It rather gains in grace from the performance of it precisely at the time when the United States Senate is evincing so remarkable an exhibition of boorishness toward England.

The Barber Asphalt Company may close down its works in Long Island City because of the trouble it is having with the men who formerly did the carting of the asphalt to this city, and who are now opposing Contractor Kavanagh and his men.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Some depression has been discovered among the resurrected officeholders who are applicants for appointment at the announcement that has come from the White House that former occupation of an office would not be regarded as a superior argument for reappointment as a rule, although some of the ex-officeholders are inclined to believe that it applies to every one but the man who is serenely confident that his papers render him invincible.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- More withdrawals from railroad traffic associations came to the headquarters in this city to-day, or were made known at the general offices of the companies. The Chicago and Northwestern's lawyers advised a severance of official ties with other roads, and the notice to this effect was received at the offices of the Western Freight Association.
Madison Square Garden can be saved by $50,000 a year of additional income. Failing that, it must be sold under foreclosure. How shall the needed income be provided?

Now that all doubt of the validity of the provision of the rapid transit law for a construction of the proposed roads at the expense of the city has been removed, and the consent of the local authorities has been granted by an almost unanimous vote of the Board of Aldermen, there should be no delay in obtaining the consent of property owners along the route.

The announcement made in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that former Mayor William R. Grace, his wife, and his son Joseph P. Grace, had set aside $200,000 for the founding of a manual training school for women in this city, has revived interest in the proposed Sevilla Home, which would long ago have been founded by the bequest of Jose Sevilla had not an irregularity in the will made it impossible.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday adopted two important resolutions, which were offered by President Alexander E. Orr, Besides President Orr, there were present Commissioners Langdon, Rives, Claflin, and Chief Engineer Parsons and A.B. Boardman, counsel for the board.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 25. -- Further and probably more accurate details of the recent massacre of Armenians at Takat, in the Sivas district of Anatolia, have been received at the Armenian Patriarchate here.
ALBANY, March 25. -- The following is the Anti-Cartoon bill, reported in the Senate to-day by the Committee on Codes, as amended:

A mass meeting was held in the large hall of the Cooper Union last evening under the auspices of the Central Labor Unions of New York and Brooklyn, and the Social Reform Club, to tell the story of the wrongs of the sailor in the merchant marine of the United States, and to endeavor to create a public sentiment that will demand and secure the righting of those wrongs.

Charles A. Gibson, the private detective who was indicted for perjury for the testimony he gave in the suit for divorce of George Shrady against his wife, tried before Justice Pryor March 8, was convicted yesterday in Part I., General Sessions, after a trial that has lasted a week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 25. -- Representatives of the lake and rail lines had an all-day conference to-day at the office of Commissioner McCain for the consideration of through rates from the Atlantic seaboard and interior points to the Mississippi River. The business was transacted in secret session, but it is understood that harmony prevailed to an unusual extent, and the basis will be practically the same as it was last season.

ALBANY, March 25. -- A certificate granted on an order of Justice Smyth of New York, permitting the Seventh Regiment Veteran Club to change its name to "The Military Club of New York," was filed with the Secretary of State to-day. The change takes effect April 27.

The awards at the Model Doll Show were unexpectedly made yesterday afternoon. The committee comprised Mrs. William C. Whitney, Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, Mrs. Richard Irvin, Mrs. Arthur Turnure, and Miss Virginia Fair.

Superintendent of Incumbrances Henkel yesterday was made to realize that he had undertaken a huge task in the effort to clear the streets and sidewalks of pushcarts, merchandise stands, and showcases.

Few Greater New Yorkers but will be uplifted in their spirits by the return of GIBBS, QUIGG, and LAUTERBACH from Albany with three large fleas in their respective ears. These three metropolitan statesmen seemed to discern in the precipitate and jamming temper of the Legislature a chance for their own mastery of the situation.

Mrs. H.A. Davidson of Albany delivered a lecture on the evolution of George Eliot's novel, "Romola," at the Teachers College, Morningside Heights, yesterday afternoon, in which she showed how the author, without making Savonarola the central figure, had brought out and emphasized the influence of his life and its final tragedy.

RAHWAY, N.J., March 25. -- A midnight attempt to rob a house in Sewaren, three miles from this place; was made last night. Mrs. Moschelle, whose husband is away from home most of the time, resides in the suburbs of the town, and has for a companion another lady, a school-girl friend. It has been rumored that a large sum of money is kept in the house.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. Pasco (Dem., Fla.,) presented, in an amended form, the credentials of John A. Henderson as Senator from the State of Florida, under appointment by the Governor until the next meeting of the State Legislature in April next.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 25. -- The Dominion Parliament was opened at 3 o'clock this afternoon by His Excellency the Governor General. In the course of a "speech from the throne" the Governor General said:

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 25. -- Byron McClelland to-night denies the report that he is training and backing Will Wallace's Panmure, a candidate for the Kentucky Derby. He says Panmure will not in his opinion start in Kentucky's historic race.

Mrs. John A. Lowry, Vice President, presided at the monthly meeting of the Auxiliary Society of the University Settlement yesterday morning, in the United Charities Building. Mrs. Edward S. Mead, Mrs. Edward R. Hewitt, Mrs. Nicholas Fish, Mrs. Edward Macy, Mrs. J.W. Pinchot, Miss Edith Kendall, and Miss Florence B. Dike were among the ladies present.

A solitary flat car placed at the intersecting lines of the Brooklyn Heights and Nassau electric roads, at Ninth and Flatbush Avenues, facing Prospect Park Plaza, caused a blockade yesterday morning lasting for five hours, and made thousands of passengers walk blocks to other lines in order to reach their places of business.

LONDON, March 25. -- A match game of lacrosse was played to-day between the Crescent Club team of Brooklyn, N.Y., and the team of the West London Club, the champion lacrosse team in the South of England.
ALBANY, March 25. -- Two bills introduced by the majority of the Lexow trust-investigating committee were special orders on the Assembly calendar this morning. The House took them up at once.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 25. -- The Court of Appeals at Frankfort to-day affirmed the decision of the lower court, giving the actress, Pauline Markham, $6,000 damages for a broken leg. She fell into a cellar while going from the station to her hotel in this city four years ago. The suit was against the city and the contractors who were doing the excavating for the cellar.

BOSTON, March 25. -- Ex-President Sterling Elliott of the League of American Wheelmen returned to-day from an extended trip through the West. In an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES representative on the secession sentiment relative to Sunday cycle racing he said:

The Senate's chief amendment to the arbitration treaty is indefensible. No matter what form it takes, whether it is left vague enough to cause misunderstanding between the Executive and the Senate, or whether it be made perfectly definite and self-operating, it is a foolish amendment. What it is meant to do is to require the assent of the Senate, by a two-thirds vote, before any differences with Great Britain can be submitted to arbitration.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 25. -"Tom" A. Marshall of the Keithsburg, Ill., was the winner of the Grand American Handicap, which was decided at Elkwood Park this morning. Marshall made a clean score of 25 birds. His share of the prize money is $500. This is insignificant, however, compared to the honor of winning the greatest shooting match in the history of the sport.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 25. -- Kate Lyon, sixty years old and unmarried, was committed to the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane March 13. She lived in abject poverty on the outskirts of the city, and often suffered from hunger and cold.
Discussing the financial outlook, yesterday, President Langdon of the Central National Bank said:

NEW ORLEANS, March 25. -- A large crowd witnessed to-day's racing over a fast track. The weather was fine. Only one post favorite was successful, the books winning on the day. The damage suit of Jockey Scherrer against Dave Gideon came up to-day in the Circuit Court here and was settled by Gideon paying the jockey $900 and assuming the costs of the suit.

The atmosphere at the dinner given by the Authors' Club to Richard Henry Stoddard at the Savoy last evening was charged with sympathy. Every one present was intimate with the guest of honor, at least in his poetry. Almost every one present was a personal friend of his, and many had received from him both encouragement and advancement in their profession.

CANEA, March 25. -- The fighting in the vicinity of Malaxa continued throughout the day. It was especially desperate at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the village of Tsicalaria, where the insurgents set fire to a number of Turkish houses.

Mr. McKINLEY has made an excellent choice for the German Embassy, and Senator PLATT shows sound sense in not opposing it, if indeed he does not support it. The fact that a gentleman from New York has already been appointed to the French Embassy can have weight against this choice only with those who take a very narrow view of the public service.
Sonn Brothers have sold to Charles H. Kivlen a plot on the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-third Street, 44.6 by 100.2, on which the purchaser will erect a ten-story fire-proof hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Five Philadelphia clergymen called on President McKinley this morning, and asked him to give his views on the plan advocated by David Lubin of California to relieve the burdens of the farmers by granting an export bounty on the staples of life.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The tariff debate in the House to-day was opened by Mr. Talbert, (Dem., S. C.) Mr. Talbert put the House in good humor by prefacing his speech with a story. He said this tiresome debate reminded him of a preacher of whom he had once read, who discoursed to his people on the major and minor prophets.

The capture of a Turkish fort in Crete is remarkable on several accounts. It is mainly remarkable as a defiance of the concert. For the capture was effected in spite of the fire of the Turkish warships, and therefore under the guns of whatever foreign men-of-war may be left in the harbor of Canea.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 25. -- Former Senator Charles Stadler of New York, with a number of other brewery owners, called on Senator Raines to-day for a consultation on the proposed amendments to the excise law. They gained the impression that the amendments will be passed if the machine can do it.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Concerning the recent action of Japan in adopting the gold standard, Senator Wolcott, who has but recently returned from abroad, after interviews relating to the proposed international monetary conference on behalf of this Government, this afternoon said:
The fiftieth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of the Very Rev. Augustine F. Hewit, Superior General of the Paulist Fathers, occurred yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The following applications for positions under the Treasury Department were made public this morning:
ALBANY, March 25. -- The ten-million-dollar boulevard scheme for the annexed district in New York City will be reported favorably in the Assembly to-morrow by the Cities Committee.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25. -- Both branches of the Legislature were in session to-day. The Senate passed the bill authorizing the Superintendent of Public Instruction to purchase 2,500 copies of the book entitled, "Birds of New Jersey," to be placed in the public schools, at a cost of $2,000.
ALBANY, March 26. -- The following bills were progressed to third reading in the Assembly:

Many German Geographical names now scattered along the Hudson, Mohawk, and Schoharie Valleys came from immigrants whom the wars of Louis XIV. had forced out of the valley of the Rhine. Seeking an asylum in America, these men struggled here against hardships and injustice such as fell to the lot of few American pioneers in the early days of the settlement of the Atlantic seaboard States.

WOODBURY, N.J., March 26. -- Three workmen were blown to atoms and several others were injured shortly after noon to-day by an explosion at the Repauno Nitro-Glycerine Works, on the Delaware River front, below Lincoln Park. The dead are:

BERLIN, March 15. -- The desire to perpetuate the glories of the house of Hohenzollern and to honor Prince Bismarck has been the cause of a very notable encouragement of sculpture in North Germany since Wilhelm II. began to reign. Painting has not been so powerfully supported, although in truth it has not much to complain of.

If the gentlemen in Washington could only be induced to look in a dictionary, say The Century, they then might appreciate the difference between an object which is an antiquity and another which is a curiosity. An antiquity is "that which is ancient or belongs to old or ancient times; something left by or peculiar to the ancients, as Greek or Roman antiquities."

It is very hard for the average office-peddling politician in Congress to understand how men of opposite views on the tariff can agree about the civil service and work together to improve it. Some of these gentlemen were given a chill the other day when they learned that the Cabinet officers had dined with Col. RICE, one of the Federal Civil Service Commissioners.

In compliance with instructions from the Attorney General, arrangements have been made by United States District Attorney Wallace Macfarlane to send the case of the Federal Government against the Joint Traffic Association direct to the United States Supreme Court, on appeal from the decision rendered a few days ago by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, here. A certified copy of the case will be sent to the Department of Justice in Washington to-day.

Exactly why clergymen of Philadelphia should seek to secure the payment of export bounties on agricultural products we do not pretend to understand. If the protective system has not given the farmers of Pennsylvania that home market which in supposed to be the one benefit that farmers can get from the scheme, it must be a pretty bad failure.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- A conference of legal representatives of Chicago railroads was held to-day in the office of George R. Peck, general counsel of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road. B.F. Ayer, general counsel for the Illinois Central Company, presided, and there was a full attendance of lawyers from the important lines west, south, and north of Chicago.

BOSTON, March 26. -- Yale won in the debate with Harvard in Sanders Theatre, Cambridge, this evening, it being the first time Yale has won against Cambridge since the joint debates were instituted. Gov. Roger Wolcott presided.
ALBANY, March 26. -- Gov. Black has signed the following bills:

The New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which will meet in Sing Sing the second week in April, will be asked to consider the proposition to make one conference of the present City of New York. The question will be brought up on this resolution, passed by the Methodist Social Union of this city at its monthly meeting Thursday night, as follows:

Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Health Officer of the Port, sent to President Wilson of the Health Board yesterday a report as to the experiment's recently made with the view of finding an antitoxins for the bubonic plague. He visited Egypt and India some months ago, and made some study of the plague while in those countries.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 26. -- Lawrence Wallace of Fanwood denied, during his examination before Justice Ira Hall of this city to-day, the charge of setting fire to the roadhouse of John Benner, in Netherwood.

The plans of the various committees in charge of the preparations for the Grant Monument celebration are rapidly maturing. President McKinley yesterday assured Gen. Horace Porter, Chairman of the Committee on Plan and Scope, that he would be present and deliver an address on the day of the celebration.

The Distributing Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association met in the Mayor's office yesterday and apportioned $50,000 among the hospitals benefited. Mayor Strong presided, and Alexander E. Orr, former Mayor Edward Cooper, Dock Commissioner Edwin Einstein, and Postmaster Dayton were present.

Early American newspapers possess a distinct individuality, and one need not be an antiquary or a deep student of history to appreciate the crude little sheets which furnished our pre-Revolutionary ancestors with foreign and home news. It was not daily news, by any means, for the colonists never knew the luxury of a daily paper, and it was not until well after the Revolution, in 1786, that the first daily newspaper in America was established.

Cleverness is the essential and manifest characteristic, as usual, of the annual exhibition of the Society of American Artists -- the nineteenth -- which will open to the public Monday morning in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, in West Fifty-seventh Street. Yesterday the artists and critics were admitted to the galleries, and to-day will be held the annual reception and private view.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Bills which authorize New York City to raise $12,500,000 for school buildings and sites were reported favorably from the Assembly Cities Committee to-day. They are two in number, both being introduced by Mr. Austin and both indorsed by the Board of Education of New York.

Certain of the steamship companies have been trying for some time to obtain from the Dock Board leases of the new piers to be constructed in the North River near Gansevoort Market, but have offered terms lower than the Dock Commissioners have been willing to accept. The amounts discussed for compensation have not been made public by either the companies or the Commissioners.

In a separate publication, Science records the Goode Memorial meeting of last month, which commemorated the life and services of the late Director of the United States National Museum at Washington, George Brown Goode.
