SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., March 26. -- The death of Lyman Epps occurred at his home at North Elba, Wednesday, March 24.

PARIS, March 26. -- Lord Salisbury, who is here on his way to Cimiez, where he will act as Minister in Attendance upon Queen Victoria, had a conference with M. Hanotaux, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to-day.

-- Advocates of Spanish rule in Cuba, both those who take that side as official representatives of Spain and those whose motives are more mysterious, are still talking about the now somewhat musty promises of reform that were offered several weeks ago to the insurgents, and they continue to express mingled wonder and indignation that the Cubans did not, when these reforms were suggested, at once lay down their arms.

Arthur C. Smith, a seaman on the schooner Goodwin Stoddard, arriving in this port last Wednesday from Fernandian, Fla., tells a story of cruelty and starvation which he says was inflicted upon the crew of the clipper ship T.F. Oakes by Capt. Reed on a voyage in 1893.
Your opportune exposure of the dangerous features of Senate Bill No. 718 has borne good fruit.

The public rehearsals of the Oratorio Society at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon was an entertainment of which the officers of the organization must have been proud. They certainly had good reason to approve of themselves, for so good a performance of Mendelssohn's "Elijah" has not been given in this city in years.

There never was such a prodigal as is Maurus Jokal. He flings around a wealth of romance, and is lavish of personages and incidents. In "The Green Book," a story of Russia in 1824, having to do with conspiracies, you deal with poets, Generals, courtiers, spies, censors, Emperors, Grand Dukes, actresses, assassins, gypsies, monks, Tartars, Circassians, Cossacks, and all conceivable persons.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Parliamentary South African Committee to-day resumed its inquiry into the Transvaal raid. Quite a number of the friends and admirers of Dr. Jameson, the leader of the famous raid, were present.

Mr. Simon Sterne, whose eminence in corporation law is recognized, was seen yesterday by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES in reference to the Supreme Court decision in the matter of the Trans-Missouri Freight Association. He said:

It is generally conceded in the trade that the duties on oranges and lemons in the Dingley bill are practically prohibitory for the cheaper grades of fruit. These duties are not protective, for there is no American fruit that can replace the imported, all of our oranges being of the higher grade and the lemons not being either sufficient in quantity or cheap enough to reach the poorer buyers.

Nansen's book, published a week ago, may still be called the book of the Spring season. For this reason and, moreover, because it has a lesson for him who is interested in arctic matters, it invites further comment from THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Executive Committee, which was created at the Monetary Convention held at Indianapolis in January to secure the appointment of a commission to revise the currency system called on Speaker Reed to-day. Among the number was H.H. Hanna of Indianapolis, who was the Chairman of the Indianapolis Convention: ex-Gov. Stanard of St. Louis, George F. Peabody of New York, and John P. Irish of San Francisco.
The trial of Louis Nolte, charged with perjury, ended in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The House to-day, under the five-minute rule, began consideration of the tariff bill for the purpose of amendment. The Clerk no sooner had begun to read the bill than a lively political contest was started, which lasted three hours.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Before the National Geographic Society to-night, John W. Foster, ex-Secretary of State, who, while holding that office four years ago negotiated a treaty of annexation with the representatives of the Hawaiian Islands, delivered a lecture on that country, in which he discussed the question of annexation to the United States.

One last effort to prevent the Legislature from passing the Raines law amendments is to be maple by the local Republican machine. It looked to some of the politicians last night as though this final effort might make a further breach between the local and State machines, if some of the hotheaded ones among the local leaders are allowed to have their way.

While Mayors STRONG and WURSTER may be expected to accept, in behalf of this city and Brooklyn, the charter which they took part in framing and which they joined in recom mending to the favorable consideration of the Legislature, there should be full, fair, and open-minded hearing given to those who oppose it.

For its vigor and direct speaking. The Globe, a quarterly review of literature, science, religion, art, and politics, takes a decided stand. If arbitration fails, and there is a recurrence to war, Mr. Thorne thinks that "nations cannot help the natural results of their actions any more than individual men."

BERLIN, March 26. -- In the course of the progress of the estimates toward their third reading in the Reichstag to-day, an amendment proposed by the Radicals, providing for the payment of members of the House, was adopted by a vote of 179 to 49.

The new Hall of Records, which has been authorized by the Legislature, will probably be built on the eastern half of the block bounded by Broadway on the west, Centre Street on the east, Chambers Street on the south, and Reade Street on the north. This was tacitly agreed upon by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Mrs. Clausine Seaman, William C. and Matilda R. Dosher, the four-story and basement dwelling, 150 West Seventy-fourth Street, 22 by 57 by 102.2, to Henry W. Eaton.

One of our contemporaries has taken the trouble to elicit the views of the Mayors of all the cities from London to San Francisco upon the enactment of the charter of Greater New York. They are all congratulatory and commonplace with one signal exception. The exception is furnished by the Mayor of Chicago, whose dispatch is worth reproducing:

Around the tables in the smaller dining room of the Windsor Hotel, last evening, about seventy members of the Alumni Association of Phillips Exeter Academy, of Exeter, N.H., and a few of their friends, met and enjoyed their fifteenth annual dinner.

LIVERPOOL, March 26. -- The Grand National Steeplechase, the principal event of that character on the English turf, was run at the Liverpool Spring meeting to-day in the presence of the usual large crowd of spectators, and was won by Mr. H.M. Dyas's Manifesto, aged, carrying 157 pounds.

Strong demonstrations of opposition to the Greater New York charter are likely to be made before Mayor Strong and Gov. Black as the result of the active efforts of Alfred E. Marling, President of the Real Estate Exchange; James W. Pryor, Secretary of the City Club, and John F. Doyle, Chairman of the Committee of Fifty, members of the Bar Association, and numerous other citizens, who on important occasions interest themselves in public affairs.

The entertainment at the Broadway Theatre yesterday afternoon, in aid of the Actors' Fund of America, proved to be one of the most attractive benefit performances of the season. It was under the personal direction of Daniel Frohman and his Lyceum Theatre staff, assisted by Mr. McCormick, the manager of the theatre.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- In the open session of the Senate to-day, which lasted only an hour, the Civil Service Commission was subjected to another attack by Mr. Gallinger, (Rep., N.H.)

To-day's Issue of the Review of Books and Art, published by THE NEW YORK TIMES, appears with its size enlarged from eight to sixteen pages. Since this feature of THE NEW YORK TIMES was introduced, six months ago, it has met with wide favor from readers everywhere.

It was in 1847, M. Halperine-Kaminski says, that Turgueneff became acquainted with George Sand. It is not likely that in 1847 Turgueneff had made a distinguished mark in literature, but George Sand's reputation was at that time firmly established. It was "The Sketches from the Diary of a Sportsman" that particularly excited her attention. It was to the Russian novelist that, in 1872, she dedicated her story, "Pierre Bonnin."

CANEA, March 26. -- The Christian sympathizers here caustically comment upon the action of the powers in taking possession of the town of Malaxa on the ground that the foreign Admirals hold that its occupation by either Christians or Turks is dangerous to the Europeans in this city.

Why sewing should be taught to children in schools and how instruction should be given were the subjects discussed yesterday afternoon at a conference in the interest of industrial education. The meeting was held in the Charities Building, corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, at the invitation of the New York Association of Sewing Schools.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The National Association of Democratic Clubs, of which Chauncey F. Black of Pennsylvania is Chairman, and Lawrence Gardner of Washington is Secretary, has issued a general call to each Democratic society in the United States, asking them to join the National Association of Democratic Clubs in the celebration of the one hundred and fifty-fourth birthday of Thomas Jefferson, on the 13th of April.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 27. -- Lispenard Stewart, President of the State Prison Commission, paid his first visit to Auburn Prison to-day. After an inspection of the institution he submitted to an interview, in which he expressed his satisfaction of the condition of affairs as he found them, and he also made several suggestions.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 27. -- The traditional lion and lamb of March have each taken a turn this week, and the weather has varied accordingly from the warmth and sunshine of late Spring to blustering winds, snow flurries, and showers.

THE two plays of last week were "The Wonder" and "L'Arlesienne," for "Miss Manhattan" is scarcely a play, though it is an entertainment which, with a few wise changes, may be made longlived and profitable.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 27. -- Joel B. Wolfe of New York to-day rented the so-called Rutherford place, on Harrison Avenue, for next season. It is one of the best-known villas in Newport to society from the fact that its owner, Henry White, entertained there last season Lord Russell of Killowen and Chief Justice of England, and his family, as well as a distinguished house company of Americans.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 27. -- The new gunboat Wilmington, constructed by the Newport News Shipbuilding Company and designed especially for river service, had her official speed trial run to-day over a twenty-seven-knot course in Long Island Sound. The course marked out was from Horton's Point to Oldfield Light, and over this course the gunboat sped along with ease and at a rate that was admired by all who witnessed the trial.

Won't you kindly tell your readers by what authority a Catholic Church has been built in the grounds of our Bellevue Hospital? Why is a place of worship dedicated to any particular religious belief, and who may or did give the right to do this?

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- The filibustering steamer Laurada arrived at the Delaware Breakwater this evening, after having, it is said, landed the most important expedition yet sent from this country to Cuba.

A movement is on foot among a number of insurance brokers of this city to have the Legislature pass a bill materially affecting the business of fire insurance. Some time ago these brokers appointed a committee, consisting of P.C. Ralli of P.C. Ralli Co., M.I. Tannenbaum, W.W. Owens, E.J. Sullivan, and Mr. Riger, to investigate conditions of the insurance brokerage business in this city, and to take much action as should be deemed advisable.

The men who light the lamps of the cars on the Sixth Avenue Elevated Road did their work last night with a certain air of pride. They were pleased with the Pintsch light in the 300 cars equipped with the apparatus, and they swung themselves upon the ear platforms with an air of nonchalance and handled their tapers with an affectation of independence that was refreshing.

New York managers are very shy about giving openings to new-comers, as they are about producing plays by unknown authors.

LENOX, Mass., March 27. -- The country places are rapidly being put in condition for their occupants, and a number of the cottagers have been up recently to look over their places and order repairs and improvements. The season will open early, as many are coming up in May, which is a very charming month in Lenox.

It is not unlikely that there may be new developments in the relations between the Western Union Telegraph and the Bell Telephone Companies. The recently expired contract between the two corporations is still far from renewal. Both sides are willing to make some concessions, but agreement seems still far distant.

The Managing Committee of the American School of Classical Studies in Rome will offer for the year 1897-8 three fellowships, as follows: A fellowship of $600, established by the Managing Committee. A fellowship of $600, given by the Archaeological Institute of America. A fellowship of $500 for the study of Christian archaeology, contributed by friends of the school.

The Executive Council of the Social Reform Club last night resolved to co-opera with the Atlantic Coast Seaman's Union in an endeavor to bring a criminal process against Capt. Reed and wife of the American clipper ship T.F. Cakes.

The steam yacht Marietta was sucessfully launched from John N. Robins's yard yesterday afternoon. The sole piece was cut through at 8:30 o'clock. For a few minutes the boat stood on the ways and wedges, and hydraulic jacks were used to move her. Then she slid slowly down the ways and into the water.

LONDON, March 27. -- Regarded from most points of view Armageddon seems to have move up perceptibly nearer to us during the week. The correspondents at the front talk to-day as if they already felt its hot breath on their cheeks. Yet, oddly enough, those who are in control of the national destinies are taking things more easily now than they did a month ago.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 27. -- The roll call at to-day's joint session showed only fifty-six members present, the anti-Hunter Republicans and free silver and gold Democrats refusing to answer to their names. The President ruled that there was no quorum present, but said he would liberally construe that statute requiring a daily ballot for Senator, and ordered the roll call.

The text of the opinion of Justice PECKHAM in the "anti-trust law" railroad case does not remove the unpleasant impression received from the portion first given out embodying the conclusion of the majority of the court. On the contrary, that impression is deepened. It now appears, unfortunately, that the court fully recognized two features in the case in a way which the decision as at first reported did not disclose.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The most careful examination of the Philadelphia papers will not enable the reader of them to learn anything about the objections heard here from Pennsylvanians to the appointment of Charlemagne Tower as Minister to Austria or any other leading diplomatic position.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 27. -- The Wilmington was designed especially for river service. She is 250 feet 8 3/4 inches long on the water line, and 251 feet 10 inches over all, with a maximum beam of 40 feet, and a depth from the flat keel to the top of beams of upper deck of 25 feet and 2 inches. At a draught of 9 feet, her displacement is 1,391 tons.
DETROIT, Mich., March 27. -- Secretary Houston of the Michigan Railway Association has announced the following:

ITHACA, N.Y., March 27. -- Although Cornell's Easter vacation recess has just begun, there is to be no home-going for the athletes. Oarsmen, baseball players, and runners alike have been ordered to stay in Ithaca, and, what is more, to stay in training.

-- A New York traveler is interested to know why, on the Philadelphia ferryboats, there are separate cabins for men and women. In both cabins smoking is strictly forbidden, and there seems to be no reason for the distinction, as in New York, where the men's cabin is so unpleasantly suggestive of smoke and smokers at all times that it is shunned even by men when they are not smoking.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 27. -- The following appointments are announced from the State civil service eligible list:

While April is rather a quiet month, astronomically speaking, it contains a great gift for all churchgoers in the full moon that occurs on the 16th. It is the first full moon following the vernal equinox, and it determines, according to ecclesiastical usage, that Easter shall fall on the following Sunday, the 18th, in this case.

LONDON, March 27. -- Collating opinion from various centres interested in the Dingley tariff, the representative here of The United Associated Presses finds in no quarter anything approaching the dismay which fell upon British traders when the tariff of 1890 was announced. The new tariff has been scanned of course with the greatest interest, but almost with confidence.

The hitch between the New York City end of the Republican machine and the "up the State" end over the proposed amendments of the Raines liquor tax law is due mainly, if not wholly, to the difference in sentiment prevailing in urban and rural communities on two subjects which cannot properly be regulated by law -- intemperance and Sunday observance.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Judge William Lindsay, Senator from Kentucky, and recognized as one of the ablest lawyers in the Senate, reintroduced the Torrey Bankruptcy bill on the last day of the session of the Senate of the Fifty-fourth Congress.

BOSTON, March 27. -- William T. Adams ("Oliver Optic") died shortly after 9 o'clock this morning at his home in Dorchester. His health had been gradually failing for a year or more, an two weeks ago he became critically ill.

GLASGOW, March 13. -- The Prince of Wales must feel well pleased. His Britannia is winning as she pleases, and has not been outclassed by Ailsa just yet. The new mainsail of Britannia is doing the cutter fine service, and when her steel boom is shipped, on her return from the Mediterranean, she will no doubt do better.

A big hat, a prettily indignant but timid young woman, a tall, athletic young man, and two gentlemen who having paid for their seats thought that they had at the same time paid for the privilege of seeing the performance created a disturbance -- almost a riot -- at the Herald Square Theatre Friday night.

The plan of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York to hold a big road race on Riverside Drive has caused much comment during the past week. The wheelmen are delighted with the prospect, although it is not positive that the Park Board will grant the privilege. The board will probably decide to-morrow.
The following is the text of the notes addressed by the representatives of Great Britain, Austria-Hungary, France, Germany, Italy, and Russia to the Turkish and Greek Governments in regard to Crete:

The Grammar School Assistants' Association gave a reception at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Normal College. President Hunter of the Normal College presided, and the Glee Club, directed by Miss Augusta Will, sang several old English ballads. Miss Louise Growoll rendered several piano selections.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 27. -- It has been suspected that an organized band of murderers and robbers has been operating near Montgomery, several persons having mysteriously disappeared, and numerous robberies having been perpetrated lately. Last week Wiley Lewis, colored, while intoxicated, boasted that he knew something of the disappearances, and said proof of his statement could be found in the abandoned Straughan mine.

The Board of Aldermen last week granted permits for the erection of eighty-one soda water, news, and bootblack stands. Last week the number was fifty-nine, and the week before it was eighty. These permits embrace all the business districts of the city, as well as many of the most populous residence streets. The resolutions granting these permits were all returned by Mayor Strong without his approval.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27. -- The eyes of the insurance world are just at present centred on Madison, the capital of the State of Wisconsin. There, within a week, action will be taken on the most radical insurance legislation ever proposed in the West regarding a bill which is of vital importance to every insurance company or organization -- life, accident, or fire, old line or mutual -- doing business in the State.

ERNEST RENAN many years ago described the United States as a country which had provided itself with an extensive popular instruction without any serious higher instruction. If this was ever a true account of our educational condition, it has long since ceased to be so. No European scholar with a reputation to lose would now venture to assert that the United States had no serious higher instruction.

The incidents attending the sale or attempted sale by Richard V. Harnett Co., at the Liberty Street Real Estate Exchange, on Friday of 5,000 shares of Bay State Gas Company of Delaware stock and $100,000 of its income bonds furnish another chapter to an old story.
The Health Culture Club of Brooklyn met Wednesday afternoon in the Hotel St. George and listened to an address from Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders on "Cycling for Health."

GREENVILLE, Miss., March 27. -- This is a time of feverish anxiety, and it may be said the crisis is now on. The Mayor has issued a proclamation warning all merchants to close their places of business today, and calling every able-bodied man to the levee.

DENVER, March 25. -- The people of Colorado are beginning to think that the long-promised "wave of prosperity" has reached the State. The banks are loaning money more freely; capitalists are ceasing to talk of hard times, and instead are searching for investments. The real estate business has very materially improved during the past thirty days, and the mining outlook has not been as promising in a dozen years as it is now.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Mr. Walker, (Rep., Mass.,) by request, to-day introduced in the House a bill directing the Secretary of the Treasury to call in and cancel the paper monew "now injuring the prosperity of the country."

The Reform Club discussed the subject of "Taxation of Personal Property" at its monthly dinner last night. The discussion was arranged by the Committee on Local Taxation. It was expected that Josiah Quincy, Mayor of Boston, would be present and take part in the debate, but he sent word that he found it impossible to come.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 27. -- Two thousand five hundred dunkard colonists will reach Chicago next Tuesday from Eastern States on their way to join the dunkard colonies already established in North Dakota.

In a recent lecture before the Franklin Institute of Philadelphia, Prof. W.P. Mason of the Rensselaer Institute, at Troy, N.Y., spoke of sanitary problems in connection with municipal water supplies from which the following extracts are taken:

Fire was discovered in a basement closet of Bliss, Fayban Co.'s big dry goods store, 32 to 36 Thomas Street, yesterday morning at 7 o'clock. Workmen sweeping out the store saw smoke issuing from the basement. The fire was located in a closet, where the employes kept their clothing, and the sweeping force fought the flames till the engines arrived.

FELICITATIONS to the Bostonians are in order. Henry Clay Barnabee smiles a long and satisfied smile, and William H. MacDonald wears an expression of deep and abiding content. For "The Serenade" is applauded of the people, and the populace goes up to the gray temple in Upper Broadway with gladsome faces.

BERLIN, March 13. -- Since Eleanora Duse was here the topic most discussed anent the stage has been "Die Versunkene Glocke," by Gerhardt Hauptmann. It met with unsparing criticism on the part of the public, and not a little ridicule, although the audiences themselves did not take the trouble to protest.

JAMES M.E. O'GRADY, Speaker of the New York Assembly, found the steps up to the desk easier of ascent than has any other man in recent years. The Speakership came to him by a few turns of the wheels in the Republican machine, which has been adjusted with the unerring nicety of a time lock.

PUBLIC SCHOOL NO. 15 of Brooklyn bears an enviable reputation. For years it has been highly thought of, and commended alike by the Board of Education and the parents of children fortunate enough to secure desks in it. It has the third largest registry in the city -- No. 74 being first, No. 26 next, and third place being tied by it and No. 35.

The building of the two caissons which are intended for the new East River Bridge is watched daily by crowds of persons who are interested in civil engineering and submarine architecture. The caissons are being constructed in the old shipyard at the foot of North Second Street, corner of Kent Avenue, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, which was formerly occupied by the Yellow Pine Company.

Denis Ryan, the St. Paul hotel proprietor, is a frequent visitor in New York, and has many acquaintances in business circles here. He has become somewhat famous as the owner of one of the finest hotels in the Northwest and as the friend of "Jim" Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway.

DETROIT, March 27. -- George Dench of Allegheny, Penn., got first money ($250) in the six-day (thirty-six hours) bicycle race which ended at the Auditorium here tonight, covering 737 miles and 19 laps. Out of the nine riders who started only four staid to the finish.

ALBANY, March 27. -- When the State Prison Commission some time ago assigned to the State Superintendent of Prisons the industries that were to be carried on in the State penal institutions, printing was included among them. The Prison Superintendent thereupon prepared requisition blanks for printing supplies and sent them not only to the State departments and institutions, but also to the political divisions of the State, or to County, City, and Town Clerks.

DENVER, Col., March 27. -- The Denver and Rio Grande express from the Pacific coast pulled in nearly two hours late last night, the delay being due to an adventure of August Belmont, who arrived in the luxurious private car Oriental. The car contained Mr. and Mrs. Belmont and Mr. and Mrs. H.V.R. Kennedy of New York.

THE Union League Club of New York is the child of the United States Sanitary Commission. This commission dates from June, 1861, and was in the most active period of its life when the Union League Club was born. The men who conceived, organized, and controlled the commission were also the originators of the Union League Club.

ALBANY, March 27. -- To-morrow the Albany Club will open a poster exhibit, the proceeds of which will go into the building fund of the Albany Hospital. The Art Committee consists of Joel W. Burdick, J. White Sprong, Henry Whiting Garfield, Gardner C. Leonard, Donald McDonald, and Arthur D. Mills. This committee has been busy the past week in hanging the works of art, beginning with those of the French school.

INVENTIVE genius and advanced thought were not directed toward firearms with any degree of success until about the middle of this century, and so at the time of the war in the Crimea the English and their allies battled with their foes with arms that were practically the same as those that had been used in the time of Queen Elizabeth.

Major Gen. Thomas H. Ruger, commanding the Department of the East of the United States Army, with headquarters on Governor's Island, retires from the active list of the army on Friday next, when he reaches the age limit of sixty-four years. Gen. Ruger was made a Major General Feb. 8, 1895, and succeeded in his present command Major Gen. Miles when Gen. Miles became commanding officer of the army.

The politicians and citizens of Brooklyn who usually take an active interest in public affairs appear, on the surface at least, to be doing little or nothing, in view of the probability of consolidation, to deter mine the role they are to play in deciding what party or union of parties is to acquire control of the Greater New York, and who is to have the distinction of being its first Mayor.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- President McKinley has drawn to him this week a throng of office-seekers, possibly larger and more importunate than those who had preceded them. As day after day has passed, and only a few nominations have gone to the Senate, the anxiety and desperation of some of these men has become greater, and they redouble their efforts to obtain favorable recognition and immediate action.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 27. -- On the morning of April 15 the season for shad fishing will open, and hundreds of shad fishers will push their dingy old boats and dories from the shores of the Hudson to those places where the fishermen know the shad love to go in spawning time.

Casts and photographs hung upon the hitherto bare walls of the assembly room in the Wooster Street School. The Art Committee of the Public Education Society contributed them, and yesterday afternoon Mrs. Edward S. Mead, Chairman of the committee, supervised the disposal of the gifts.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Presidential dinner of the Gridiron Club at the Arlington to-night was attended by the President of the United States and a majority of his Cabinet, two or three Ambassadors and Ambassadors-to-be, Justices of the Supreme Court, Senators, Representatives, and other distinguished guests, covers being laid for 130, including the forty hosts, the Washington correspondents, who form the regular membership of the club.

The Republican leaders in this city and Brooklyn are now in hopes that they will be able to secure some important modifications in the Raines law amendments, particularly in the club amendment. Within a day or two they have heard from Albany that Gov. Black is anxious that the amendments be passed in such a way as to avoid giving offense to the Republicans at this end of the State.

"Domestic Service" was the subject of animated discussion at a recent women's meeting in Brooklyn, held under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute. The first paper presented was that of Mrs. Benjamin Estes, who is very much opposed to the sharp line drawn between the social standing of servants and employers.

The first big race of the yachting season will be that of the Atlantic Yacht Club. This will be a special regatta for classes composed of racing yachts, and will be sailed on Saturday, June 12. Chairman Newberry D. Lawton of the Regatta Committee has already begun to look for entries for this day's racing, and has been very successful. J. Rogers Maxwell and C.A. Postley have promised to race the schooners Emerald and Colonia.

Collector Kilbreth said yesterday that his order to Surveyor John C. McGuire that boarding officers shall accept verifications of manifests from Captains on the bridge of their craft was an admonition to such officers to be less huffy and punctilious. Complaints have been many in regard to the boarding officers acting far from cleverly in the "little brief authority" with which they were clothed.

On Christmas Day, 1864, Curtis's brigade had by hard fighting worked its way close up under the Confederate works at Fort Fisher. The Union trenches ran close to the ditch in front of the parapet, and the sharpshooters of both armies were on the alert for a chance to send a bullet whistling at any head exposed by the enemy.
BOSTON, March 27. -- Something akin to terror exists in this city as a result of the great number of fatalities that have taken place here in the past year from the effects of poisonous gas.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 27. -- The American Exchange Bank went into voluntary liquidation at the close of business to-day. Those who are interested in the bank say the closing up of the business is due to the hard times and to the fact that none of the small banks in this city can now realize profits.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 27. -- Eight hundred and thirty-seven entries have been received to the eighth renewal of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association's twenty-five-thousand-dollar Futurity, which closed this week. The best-bred mares in the land are nominated, and they are with foal to the leading stallions.

When American shipping was successfully disputing with the merchant marine of the world for the carrying trade, two generations ago, a section of New York City conspicuously shared in the incident prosperity. This neighborhood was on the east side, and embraced the general lines of the old Eleventh Ward, though its local designation to this day is "Dry Dock."
A well-attended auction sale of rare and standard books was held at the rooms of Bangs Co., 91 Fifth avenue, Friday afternoon.

Table linens, to be quite correct, must at all times be spotless and perfectly white. In order to attain this result, each of the various processes of laundering must be carefully performed. Soiled table linens, as they accumulate during the week, must be placed in a basket kept specially for this purpose.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- The first open flat out rate since the anti-association decision of the Supreme Court of the United States was made to-day by the Missouri Pacific Railroad. It made a rate of 33 1/2 cents on eggs on car lots from all Kansas points to St. Louis, subject to the Missouri River minimums.

The boys of the Worcester High School distinguished themselves at the inter-scholastic athletic meeting, under the auspices of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, at Madison Square Garden, last night. They scored the largest number of points in the games and secured the much-coveted trophy offered for the most successful team.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27. -- The baseball season of the Princeton team will open next Wednesday, when, in accordance with the time-honored custom, the Tigers will meet the nine of Rutgers College. The game is to be played on the home grounds, and will assume the usual social character, with special engraved invitations for members of the Faculty and friends of the university.

J. WELLS CHAMPNEY, the artist, is about to give the world something that it has never before had -- types of the American girl. There has never seemed to be a typical America girl. We hear of types of girls of other nationalities, but the American girl is to a certain extent a cosmopolite.

LONDON, March 27. -- A farewell dinner was given to-night at the Cafe Monico to Sir Alfred Milner, the newly appointed Governor of Cape Colony. Among the guests were Colonial Secretary Chamberlain, Mr. Balfour, Lord Rosebery, Sir William Harcourt, the Marquis of Lansdowne, Viscount Peel, and Mr. John Morley.
Gen. Stewart L. Woodford addressed a meeting of the League of Political Education yesterday morning, at 23 West Forty-fourth Street, on "The New Charter."

Mgr. Merry Del Val, who is expected to arrive here to-day on the Umbira, on his way to Canada, was appointed, it is understood, through the influence of a Canadian Cabinet Minister, with the personal influence of Cardinal Vaughan behind him. A promise was given by the Minister in question, it is said, that the Delegate could settle the ugly Catholic education agitation in Manitoba by coming to Canada.

CHICAGO, March 27. -- Jerome C. Patterson, the athlete who dived from a pier at Manhattan Beach last Fall, and sustained a puzzling complication of injuries, including a broken neck, died last night at his home, 580 Sixtieth Street. Roentgen's X rays and electricity in a variety of styles were all used by the physicians in an effort to save his life, but in vain.

Business improved with the brokers last week, and their reports indicate a slight increase, both in the number of transactions closed and total amount invested, as compared with their work of the previous week. The improvement, however, is by no means startling or such as it should be at this season of the year.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March. 27. -- Knights Templars throughout the country will be interested in a ceremonial to be conducted at the asylum of Zion Command -- ery, No. 2, of this city, to occur on Wednesday next. The ceremony of Malta, rarely presented at all, is to be rendered in a most elaborate and impressive manner.

Those were very hasty and ill-advised remarks which Mayor STRONG made at the last meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment regarding the service of TWEED to the city in planning and starting great public improvements. It was an echo of a foolish tribute sometimes paid by ill-informed people to TWEED because while he was in power the West Side Boulevard was laid out and some other public improvements were projected.

A peculiar rivalry in the construction of two large office buildings on Lower Broadway, which has been of great interest to builders for some time, will end early next month. During the Winter there has been an intense though quiet desire on the part of the workmen on the Central National Bank Building, at Broadway and Pearl Street, and those on the New York Life Building, at Broadway and Leonard Street, to excel each other.

The observance of mid-Lent, or Mi-Careme, is growing more popular in New York society every year. It is only recently that any special attention was given to the day, but the idea of relaxation from or laying aside of Lenten obligation, which is now associated with it, seems to be growing popular.

The Trustees of the Carteret Gun Club and J.W. Hubbell, representing the Stewart estate, have signed a lease for a piece of property at Garden City, L.I. Work is to be begun at once fitting it up for the club's use. A nine-foot fence is to be erected around the entire lot, and inside this the shooting grounds are to be arranged.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The Post to-morrow will say:

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Sardou's "Spiritisme" ended its American tour at the Lafayette Square Opera House last night, and the company has returned to New York. The production played to Door business here.

At a meeting of the trustees of the Baron de Hirsch Fund yesterday afternoon the fact was brought out that a new enterprise in philanthropy and one of great importance to the public is soon to be undertaken in New York. It is a stupendous project -- nothing less than to relieve the congested district of the east side by building homes and establishing industries in the suburbs.

LONDON, March 28. -- The demand for money has been somewhat brisker during the last few days, as the end of the quarter has approached. But discount, after a slight hardening, relapsed. The act that twelve-month Treasury bills have been allotted under 1 1/2 will indicate the rates. These are not expected to rule at high figures in the future, and probably the bank will fall below the minimum for some time past.

Those New Yorkers who had looked forward to yesterday expecting a repetition of the ideal weather conditions that marked the previous Sunday were somewhat disappointed. The cheerful warmth and refreshing breezes of a week ago were lacking, and the crowds attracted out of doors were less in evidence.

Lieut. RICHARD MITCHELL, United States Navy, has in the April number of Harper's Magazine a most interesting article on "Our Trade with South America, with Special Reference to Brazil and the River Plate Republics." If is the fruit of long and varied observation in the region discussed, and is marked throughout by shrewd sense as well as keen interest in the commercial prosperity of the United States.

-- One of the little wars which England knows how to carry on better than any other European nation has just been brought to a successful termination on the frontier of Assam. A tribe known as the Apatanangs had raided a tea estate in North Lakhimpur, murdering two native servants and carrying away three others.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee were in session several hours to-day and again to-night considering amendments to the pending Tariff bill, some of which have been urged by those whose interests are affected by the schedules as originally agreed on, and others which have been suggested by the debate on the bill.

One of the most interesting things about "Das Rheingold," which will be produced by the Damrosch Opera Company at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening, will be the scenic effects. It is said by theatrical people that this opera is one of the most difficult to stage, and that it would be given more often if the mechanical effects were not so costly.

In honor of the Very Rev. Augustine F. Hewit, Superior General of the Community of St. Paul, who completed last Thursday fifty years of service as a Catholic priest, Archbishop Corrigan was present at the Paulist Church, Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue, yesterday morning, and a solemn pontifical mass was celebrated.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Three more days will end the struggle over the Dingley Tariff bill in the House. The bill will be open for amendment until 1 o'clock Wednesday, and then the debate will close with a two-hour display of oratory by Mr. Dingley (Rep., Me.,) and Mr. Bailey, (Dem., Texas.)

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 28. -- Lee Pon, Grand Recorder of the Chinese Free Masons in America, was buried here to-day. His funeral provided entertainment for 5,000 persons and scared more horses than the police have any record of.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Prof. Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, to-day issued the following special bulletin:
Hinrich Juntke, a German, about fifty years of age, yesterday morning jumped into the bay from the ferryboat New York shortly after she had left the Battery for Thirty-ninth Street, South Brooklyn.

The interesting and instructive artitle entitled "Some Causes of Unrest," by "Democracy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the 22d inst., should be read by every American, and especially would it be well for our legislators to profit by the words of warning.

A lad just out of knickerbockers addressed a meeting at the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at 5 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, and talked so intelligently of tariffs, currency ratios, and legislative problems that his hearers were subdued with astonishment.

The Palisades will have to go, we suppose. Here and there a languid and impotent protest is heard. A few who love nature undefaced and admire those noble cliffs throw up their hands, exclaiming, "It's too bad!" They lament, but they are helpless. And the hard-fisted contractor puts in more dynamite and throws down another hundred tons of rock.

There is a good deal of talk indulged in about the anti-trust decision of the Supreme Court which is wild and foolish. In the first place it must be remembered that the court does not legislate. It simply interprets, according to the views of a majority of its members, the laws which Congress and the President enact.

In his address in Washington last evening on Pope LEO XIII., Archbishop IRELAND of St. Paul declared that the "encyclicals of the Pope, especially that on labor and that on the Republic of France, prove him to be indeed the Pontiff of the age." It is not generally understood in this country how much courage and initiative were required in the venerable Pope to take the stand he has taken in France.
Prof. Felix Adler's discourse before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning was on "The Need of a Substitute for Religious Teaching in the Public Schools."

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 28. -- The Elms, the magnificent residence of Col. A.C. Tyler, on Pequot Avenue, with all its elaborate furnishings, valuable paintings, bric-a-brac, musical instruments, silver, , was destroyed by fire early this morning, causing a loss of over $300,000. Insurance, $75,000.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28. -- The twelfth and last week of the legislative session of 1897 will begin to-morrow night. According to a resolution adopted by the House, which will undoubtedly be concurred in by the Senate, the session will end on Wednesday at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman took for his subject at the Temple Emanu-El yesterday "Religion Against Religion; or, Inconsistencies in Faith and Practice."

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Under date of March 20, Sanitary Inspector Burgess of the Marine Hospital Service at Havana reports that smallpox continues in active epidemicity, the number of deaths from it in the past week being a little more than in the previous one. A number of deaths from yellow fever have occurred in the military hospitals among Spanish soldiers, and one civilian died of it in the city, near the Cathedral.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- The British tank steamer Delaware, from London, which has met with a series of misfortunes during the last few weeks, and which was picked up helpless 600 miles east of Halifax and towed into that port by the Atlantic Transport Liner Missouri, out of coal, has been held at Delaware Breakwater, smallpox having spread among the crew.

The character of the opposition excited on the Republican side in the House by the barbarous provisions of the Dingley bill concerning books and scientific apparatus imported for colleges and libraries is indicated by the speech made on the 23d inst. by Mr. N.D. SPERRY of Connecticut, who represents the New Haven district in Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Many applications have been received for appointment as Chairman of the Chickamauga Park Commission in place of Gen. Fullerton, deceased. The commission being in the classified service, this vacancy can be filled only by transfer from similar duties within the War Department, or through a competitive examination under the Civil Service Commission.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The State of Manhattan, including within its boundaries the territory now included in the Greater City of New York, is not at this writing as much of an impossibility or of as little probability as was supposed when Assemblyman Trainor early last week introduced the consenting bills in the New York Legislature.

The facts which are to serve as the basis of "tariff taxation," adopting the phrase so rightly used by President McKinley in his inaugural address, have now been placed before the public in exact terms. The official statements have been published. They are given by Mr. Dingley, Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means; by Mr. North, Secretary of the Wool and Woolen Association, and by the President.
The Ellsworth Anti-Cartoon bill was again the subject of discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union.

Mr. CHAUNCEY F. BLACK, whose friends had a right to expect better things of him, is not only a Bryan man himself, but he has succeeded in turning the National Convention of Democratic Clubs into a Bryanite and Populist organization. He is arranging to desecrate the birthday of THOMAS JEFFERSON by a banquet and meeting of officers and members of these clubs at which cheating will be extolled and dishonor affirmed as a party principle.

LONDON, March 28. -- The Graphic to-morrow will give prominence to a statement, which it claims to have received from an unquestionable source, to the effect that the Greek situation is extremely grave. It says that with the departure of Crown Prince Constantine from Athens to take command of the troops in Thessaly the die seems to have been cast.

Carnegie Hall was filled yesterday afternoon at the revival service to hear the Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon preach on "Eternal Life." Before beginning his sermon, Mr. Dixon announced that Mr. Moody would be unable to begin the contemplated April series of meetings in Carnegie Hall, because he was detained by his meetings in the West.

Unless forbidden to do so by a Justice of the Supreme Court, County Judge Stephen D. Stephens of Richmond County, District Attorney George M. Pinney, Jr., and Sheriff John L. Dalley will meet at the Court House in Richmond this morning to select a bipartisan Police Board of two Commissioners, to succeed the present Police Board, which consists of Nicholas Muller and Robert N. Hazard, both Democrats.

Several representative labor leaders yesterday expressed their views upon Justice White's dissenting opinion in the United States Supreme Court in the Trans-Missouri Freight Association case under the anti-trust law. Their comments were particularly in reference to Justice White's remark that "the interpretation of the statute makes it embrace every peaceable organization or combination of the laborer to benefit his condition."

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul preached to-night at St. Patrick's Church on Pope Leo XIII. This was an age, he said, of wondrous social and political transformations, of great intellectual activity, of great discoveries and inventions. He asked what was to be the position of Catholics toward the age.

Barnum Bailey's Circus took formal possession of Madison Square Garden early yesterday morning. Before nightfall the arena overhead was a wilderness of ropes, nets, rings, and curious-looking devices, whereon strange feats are to be performed. Downstairs, where the animals are kept, the air was charged with hoarse mutterings and the chattering of monkeys.

One more bridge car has broken its axle, making the fourth accident of the kind within two weeks. It is now said that the motors are too heavy, and will have to be removed from sixteen cars or stronger axles must be built.

Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City will, it is said, be an independent candidate for Mayor of Greater New York. He is quoted as having said that as soon as the Greater New York charter becomes a law he will proceed toward securing the requisite signatures to the petition necessary to qualify him as a candidate.

A. Macchi, Foreign Commissioner General for the Nashville ,(Tenn.) centennial and international exposition, arrived on the New York Saturday from Europe, where he encountered many difficulties but succeeded in doing important work.

Since so much discussion has been afloat regarding the most acceptable, distinctive, euphonious, and suggestive name for the greatest city on the American Continents, to be formed by the union of Brooklyn, New York, Staten Island, and some outlying districts of Westchester and Queens Counties.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The final disposal of the Greater New York charter by both branches of the Legislature last week, and the passage by the Assembly of some of the Anti-Trust bills, has cleared the way for pending minor measures, and many such measures are likely to go through the Legislature from now on.

The flower ride for charity at Durland's Riding Academy, at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, this evening, promises to result in a substantial sum for the benefit of the Church Settlement Club, an organization of thirty-three young women having charge of the charitable work of the Church Settlement House, at 329 East Eighty-fourth Street, among the poor and the needy of the upper east side.

The horror of Mr. ABE GRUBER at the Mayor's mention of TWEED as a benefactor of the city in that he planned and authorized certain public improvements, and the ready reckoning by which Mr. LAUTERBACH proves that a Republican Mayor of Greater New York will be elected next Fall, show how hard it is for machine politicians to catch the real drift of things.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28. -- John Penrose, Jr., twenty years old, of 172 North Eleventh Street, was arrested at 2:45 o'clock this morning, after he had jumped from a second-story window in the residence of Alfred W. Jennings, at 176 North Eleventh Street, which he had entered for the apparent purpose of burglary.

GREENOCK, March 28. -- The report that the steamer Yanariva, a British tramp vessel, from Newport News for Glasgow, had picked up some of the survivors of the foundered steamer Ville de St. Nazaire of the West Indian Line of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique turns out to have been correct.
ALBANY, March 28. -- Gov. Black's Adirondack bill will be considered by the Senate Finance Committee at a public hearing in the Senate Chamber Tuesday night.

Mr. REED told the Committee of the Sound Money League last week, in substance, that nothing would be done about the currency at the present session. Mr. GAGE, the Secretary of the Treasury, seems to think that nothing can be done. The attitude of the Secretary is not that of the Speaker.
AUSTIN, Texas, March 28. -- This afternoon at 2 o'clock this city and surrounding country was visited by a terrific cyclone that did great damage to property.

LONDON, March 29. -- A dispatch to The Times from Athens says that when it became known on Saturday afternoon that the Crown Prince Constantin would leave the city in the evening for the Greek camp at Larisse to take command of the Greek armies in the field a large crowd gathered on Constitution Square, adjoining the palace.

President Hubbell of the Board of Education and Commissioner Waring paid a visit to Grammar School No. 69, on West Fifty-fourth Street, yesterday, and a junior street-cleaning brigade was organized among the boys of the school. Both officials, it is said, went merely to see the children and hear them sing, but the Principal, A.S. Whiteside, introduced them to speak to the pupils, and the result was as stated.

Women were heard screaming in the saloon kept by Kreft Jansen, at 125 Washington Street, Hoboken, yesterday afternoon. A moment later an old woman ran out of the saloon, carrying a little boy in her arms. Inside of the saloon a second woman was struggling in the grasp of two men.

Mayor Strong delivered thirty-three diplomas at the closing exercises of the East Side Evening High School, at 25 Norfolk Street, last evening. The news of his coming, together with an attractive programme, drew a big crowd.
The exhibition of sewing at the American Art Galleries, O East Twenty-third Street will close at 10 o'clock to-night. It has had a large attendance daily.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The Finn bill, which proposed to legalize the use of portions of the public streets of New York City for the display of merchandise, is sleeping on the Clerk's desk in the Assembly Chamber.

The great strides made by THE NEW YORK TIMES within the last few months form a notable chapter in American journalism. During a period of business depression THE NEW YORK TIMES has made steady progress, having within six months nearly doubled its circulation. This growth, while indeed gratifying, serves only to stimulate the management to greater efforts.

LONDON, March 29. -- The Lord Mayor of Dublin, in full robes of office, attended the bar of the House of Commons to-day in order to present a petition praying the Commons to take into consideration the financial relations between Great Britain and Ireland, and to redress the state of affairs whereby Ireland is overtaxed.

Hartley House, the home of the new industrial settlement of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, was opened to the public yesterday afternoon. There was a reception at the house 413 West Forty-sixth Street, several hundred persons being present, among them well-known philanthropists of this city, who inspected with interest the newly acquired buildings.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 29. -- Gov. Black to-day received a letter from the Clearing House of New York City, calling his attention to the fact that the law making Grant's birthday, April 27, a legal holiday, in order to be operative, must be supplemented by a proclamation of the executive declaring the day to be a legal holiday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 29. -- The flood situation in the vicinity of Greenville, Miss., is alarming. The reported break at Wayside, nine miles south of that city, is confirmed, and the latest reports are that the water is pouring through a crevasse 500 yards in width.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The proposition which has been discussed by the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, that all goods imported after a certain date before the enactment of the bill shall be made to pay the duties carried by the bill, is likely to crystallize into definite form.

ALBANY, March 29. -- It is the opinion of those who have the amendments to the Raines liquor-tax law in charge that they will be passed without substantial changes. Members of both houses have considered the question to-night, and say they see no practical way of distinguishing in the law between genuine and "fake" clubs, and they are disposed to levy a tax on all.
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis called at the Mayor's office yesterday morning with their report upon the investigation into the affairs of the Park Board prior to Feb. 18, 1895, when the first reform board was appointed by Mayor Strong.

-- Acting under orders from the authorities of the town of Bradford, England, a chemist has just made an analysis of a Testament which has been used in the Ripon court for sixty years and which is said to have been kissed by 40,000 people. The analysis was made with a view to ascertaining what danger there is in the practice of "kissing the book." No germs of typhoid fever, tuberculosis, or diphtheria were found.

While Charles E. Tripler, a chemist and inventor, of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, was exhibiting a secret fluid compound to some friends who had gathered in the Hotel Endicott, Eighty-first Street and Columbus Avenue, last Saturday night, there was an explosion, which injured several of the spectators. The facts concerning the accident became public yesterday.

PARIS, March 29. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day, and the liveliest interest was manifested in the proceedings, as some sensational Panama scandal incidents or revelations were expected. MM. Jullien, Clovis Hugues, Salis, Goirand, and Rouvier, whose names have been mentioned during the course of the Panama exposures, loudly protested against the statements made and demanded the suspension of Parliamentary immunity in order to permit them to confront their calumniators.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 29. -- In the messages from the Assembly, which were read in the Senate to-night, were the anti-trust bills, and when the clerk finished reading their titles Senator Lexow asked that they be substituted for the identical bills under his charge, which were on the third reading calendar.
CHICAGO, March 29. -- The Chicago Record to-morrow will intimate in its story of the death of its Cuban correspondent, C.E. Crosby, that he was assassinated. In the course of its article it will say:

LONDON, March 29. -- At the St. James's Theatre to-night Mr. Arthur Pinero's new play, "The Princess and the Butterfly; or, The Fantastics," had a brilliant premier before a distinguished audience, which included the Princess Christian, the Countess of Shrewsbury, the Viscountess Galloway, Lady Jeune, Lady Bantry, Lady Tenterdon, Marcus Stone, the painter; Anthony Hope, James M. Barrie, and other people of note in the world of art and letters.

It took some little time for either Mr. Clay Clement or his play, "The New Dominion," to favorably impress anybody worth impressing in last night's large audience at the American Theatre. The ushers and the "paper" applauded vigorously from the very beginning. But as the evening wore on the applause became more general and more sincere.

The robbery of jewels and diamonds the value of about $5,000 from a wealthy guest of the Hotel Buckingham, at Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, was reported to Capt. O'Brien of the Detective Bureau yesterday morning. It is supposed to have occurred some time last Wednesday night.
Brokers Schrag Richtberg have sold for the Kingsland estate the four-story brick dwelling, 37 East Twentieth Street, on lot 25 by 92.

Archibald Campbell, all English jockey, twenty-seven years old, of 968 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday afternoon in a rowboat off Robbin's Reef. It is believed that he committed suicide.

Mgr. Merry del Val, the Papal Delegate to Canada, left here last evening for Quebec, in the private car of Vice President T.G. Shaughnessy of the Canadian Pacific Railway. He was accompanied by Mr. Shaughnessy, his private secretary, Father Tampien, and Mgr. C.O. Gagnon, Arch-Vicar of Quebec, and Father Arsenault, the two ecclesiasts sent here from Quebec by Cardinal Taschereau to greet Mgr. del Val.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29. -- The Senate to-night, by a vote of 11 to 6, passed the bill introduced by Senator Perry, providing for a separate Board of Managers for each of the State Hospitals for the Insane at Trenton and Morris Plains.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Among the memorials presented to the Senate to-day was one from the Monroe Doctrine Club of Philadelphia concerning the Anglo-American arbitration treaty. It referred to the document as a craftily constructed political treaty which would operate to the great advantage of England.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 29. -- The weather to-day as pleasant and Capt. Joyce permitted the New York Giants to resume their practice on the diamond. The Giants have only about a week more to stay here, and it is hoped that no more time will be lost by reason of bad weather until the team leaves Lakewood.
Long Island's open season for trout fishing began yesterday with ideal weather for this season of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- The "Shamus O'Brien" opera company, which was to open here to-night at the Chestnut Street Theatre, was compelled to close its season because of a strike on the part of the chorus. The principals had accepted an offer of a part of their back salary, and Local Manager J.F. Zimmerman guaranteed the salaries of the chorus for the present week.

Several savings banks in New Hampshire have suspended during the last two years, chiefly because too large a proportion of their funds were invested in Western farm mortgages. The Keene Savings Bank has just resumed, but it will for the present decline all Western business, making loans on Eastern securities only.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29. -- A company of Harvard students, organized as the Cercle Francaise, gave a fine performance to-night of "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme.

LONDON, March 30. -- The Times publishes to-day a dispatch from its special correspondent at Larissa, the headquarters of the Greek Army in Thessaly, which says that 10,000 Greeks have been stationed at the east end of the frontier, with their base at Rapsani, on the hillsides north of the Vale of Tempe.

HAVANA, March 29. -- Gen. Hernandez Velasco left San Cristobal under secret orders at noon last Saturday with the Castillo Reina Battalions and two field pieces. He pitched his camp amid the Brujito Hills. The insurgents attacked the regulars from the very outset of the advance. Yesterday the Spanish column marched upon Perico Pozo, where Gen. Ruis Rivera awaited them in a strongly intrenched position.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- This was by far the most exciting day the House has witnessed since the tariff debate began. The proceedings throughout were of a lively order, and several times bordered on the sensational.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 29. -- H.R. Jacobs, the theatrical manager, is in this city, and, together with A.A. Graft of Syracuse, he has formed the H.R. Jacobs Amusement Company, with Mr. Jacobs as President and manager and Mr. Graff as Secretary and Treasurer. The company will build some new theatres in cities between New York and Chicago, and will also put some companies on the road.

James Robinson and S.A. Fraser, two of the twelve members of the crew of the clipper T.F. Oakes, who were taken to the Marine Hospital on Staten Island, suffering from scurvy, appeared before Assistant United States District Attorney Hinman yesterday afternoon.

The Mississippi River has been making its annual demonstration of the consequences of the costly attempt to control its waters by the levee system. This system undertakes to confine the lawless stream within a certain restricted channel by artificial banks.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama to-day presented a minority report on the bill recently reported favorably to the Senate for the adjustment of the Pacific railroad debts through the agency of a commission.

FALMOUTH, March 29 -- The North German Lloyd steamer Konigin Luise arrived here to-night. Her rudder quadrant and steering gear are broken. The mishap occurred when the vessel was 600 miles west of the Scilly Islands. She sailed from Bremen March 22, for New York.
FRANKFORT, Ky., March 29. -- The fifth joint Senatorial ballot, taken to-day, resulted: Hunter, 58; Blackburn, 41; Davie, 12; Boyle, 7; Stone, 1. Necessary to choice.

ALBANY, March 29. -- There was a controversy in the Assembly over the bill to permit the City of Syracuse to own and control the subways. Mr. Bondy moved to discharge the Cities Committee from further consideration of the bill, which was carried, 85 to 18.

The discussion as to the cause of the Grippe is, of course, interesting, but gives little satisfaction to its unfortunate victims. Whether caused by microbe or vagaries of the weather, its ravages continue, and the country still bends under the scourge.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- It is predicted by Pennsylvanians that the President will give to Senator Quay the appointment of John G.A. Leishman for Minister to Switzerland. Mr. Leishman was until recently the President of the Carnegie Company at Homestead. He resigned in order to be ready to accept an appointment to Switzerland, where he is desirous to live with his family.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 29. -- A.H. Carman was the first resident of Patchogue to land a trout in this vicinity. His prize weighed two pounds. Albert Conklin, Emerson G. Terrill, Robert Bishop, Edward Lockitt, Ryland Palmer, G.G. Roe, Samuel Boddy, and John Raynor were all busy casting near Patchogue.

The Park Board did not answer the wheelmen's application yesterday for permission to use Riverside Drive on May 29 for the purposes of a road race similar to the Irvington-Millburn race. President McMillan was away in Virginia with his son, who is not in good health, and the decision of the board had to be postponed. It is not likely now that the board will meet before next Monday.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 30. -- The body of Ashel Bell, known as the "Miser of the Hudson," was found floating in the Hudson yesterday.
Mayor Strong has vetoed another stoop-line bill. He decided yesterday to send back the Senate bill recently passed giving more explicit authority to the Board of Aldermen over the sidewalks.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Senator Foraker of Ohio, to-day introduced a pooling bill. It is a repetition of the Patterson bill introduced in the last Congress. It is intended to meet the objections to pooling which were raised by the Supreme Court of the United States in its decision recently rendered in the Trans-Missouri Freight Association.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Senator Allen, a Populist of Nebraska, made a long speech in the Senate to-day on the unconstitutionality of tariff taxes beyond those requisite for revenue. Although it was the first tariff speech the Senate has heard this session, it did not attract marked attention. Mr. Allen severely criticised the trusts and combinations which, he declared, reaped the main advantage of tariff taxes.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 30. -- If the reports just received here from the Turkish headquarters at Elassona are correct, fighting has already occurred on the Turkish side of the frontier of Macedonia. It is said that a Greek insurgent chieftain, Alexis Taki, a brother of the famous chieftain of that name, crossed the frontier into Macedonia on Sunday last, accompanied by about twenty-five of his followers.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 30. -- The tug Monarch has been captured by the revenue cutter Winona and was brought here this morning in charge of one of her officers. The tug is now at the Government dock. The crew refuse to make any statement on the subject.

PASSAIC, N.J., March 30. -- Swindlers have been operating here for the past week, and are said to have fleeced a number of physicians. There were a man and a boy about sixteen years old working the game. The man would drive up to the residence of a physician in a buggy, and summon him hurriedly.

The American Tobacco Company, which supplies a large majority of the cigarette and tobacco firms in the United States, has issued a circular wherein formal notice is given of the abandonment of its factor agreement, which formerly existed between the company and its customers. The reasons for the change are set forth in the circular, which was mailed to tobacco jobbers in all parts of the country yesterday, and reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Representative J.D. Richardson of Tennessee provoked the curiosity of the Republicans this afternoon during the debate in the House on the Tariff bill, which now ranges so freely that any member who can obtain the floor my speak on any subject that pleases him.
PARIS, March 30. -- M. Antide Boyer, the Socialist Deputy, was arrested this morning on charges connected with the Panama scandals.

-- Philadelphia's Board of Surveyors, after working at the job for a year and a half, has succeeded in reducing the nomenclature of that city's streets from the puzzling confusion into which it had fallen to a system which will make comparatively easy the hitherto difficult task of finding any desired house or shop.

Mr. Plunket Greene, the Irish basso, has become a regular visitor to America. When he first came across the western ocean he was practically unknown here, except perhaps to a few devoted Wagnerites who had in their memories a record of the grave fact that he once sang Gurnemanz in "Parsifal."

CHICAGO, Ill., March 30. -- Following up the discovery of the headless body of a man in the sewer on the grounds of the insane asylum at Dunning and the subsequent discovery of a bicycle shoe containing one of the feet, the searchers now believe the corpse is that of William Stide, whose parents live in Brooklyn, N.Y.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- The following is a statement of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of comparative earnings for the months of February, 1897 and 1896:

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Fifteen hundred men employed by the different tanneries in the city went out on a strike to-day. This action was unanimously decided upon at a mass meeting held last night. About 200 men went out yesterday.
Senator FORAKER yesterday introduced a bill to amend the Inter-State Commerce act practically so as to permit pooling by the railways.

Stockholders of the Second Avenue Railroad Company, which last January came into the control of a syndicate with which William C. Whitney and Thomas F. Ryan were identified, received yesterday the following statement of affairs from John D. Crimmins:

TRENTON, N. J., March 30. -- The Supreme Court rendered a decision to-day in the case of the Jersey City and Newark anti-Spring election law. City Clerk O'Donnell of Jersey City is ordered to receive the certificate of nomination of Edward Hoos, Democratic candidate for Mayor of Jersey City, but the Constitutionality of the disputed act is not involved in the decision allowing this order.
MADRID, March 30. -- The Government is contemplating imposing new taxes in order to provide for the Cuban war expenses.

HAVANA, March 30. -- Great misery is being experienced at San Cristobal, Province of Pinar del Rio, owing to the prevalence of smallpox and the great mortality thereform at San Cristobal and at other places. The municipal authorities are distributing relief when they are able to do so, that is to say, when the troops succeed in driving in the cattle from the surrounding country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30. -- Frank Mueller, a German farm hand, twenty-seven years old, who has been in America about six years, and has worked since last September for John W. Miller, a farmer, near Black Lick Station, ten miles east of this city, is in the city jail charged with one of the foulest double crimes in the history of the county.

" Jack" Everhardt of New Orleans and "Kid" McPartland of this city sparred twenty rounds at the Broadway Athletic Club last night. Everhardt started in at the beginning of the bout to rush things, but McPartland managed to dodge all his vicious blows. In the seventeenth round the bout almost developed into a rough-and-tumble, in which Referee Roche played a prominent part.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Chairman Dingley and his colleagues of the Ways and Means Committee will attempt to have the duties imposed by the new tariff bill go into effect before the bill becomes a law. This novel and much-discussed policy was definitely resolved upon at a meeting of the Republican members of the committee held to-night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 30. -- The Executive Committee of the Lake Carriers' Association determined to-day to reduce wages on all of their vessels. They agreed that the outlook for business for the early part of the season was not bright, and in order to keep the boats running, expenses would have to be reduced.

The scheme of passing a law compelling all imports after April 2 to pay the duties which shall hereafter be imposed is a novel one for the United States, and we are not surprised that even the hardiest protectionists hesitate to resort to it. It is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution, though it would probably not be declared unconstitutional by the courts.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The delay occasioned yesterday by the absence of a quorum had a salutary effect on the attendance when the House met to-day. Over 150 members were in their seats. Mr. Richardson called attention to the fact that there was not a quorum present, but said he would not make the point.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma Territory, March 30. -- At 6 o'clock this evening a cyclone, followed by hail and flood, swept through the town of Chandler, forty miles east of here, completely devastating the place.

ALBANY, March 30. -- Gov. Black to-day appointed former Lieut. Gov. Charles T. Saxton of Wayne County and John F. Parkhurst of Steuben County to be Judges of the Court of Claims. They are to succeed Hugh Reilly of Albany and Wilbur F. Porter of Jefferson, respectively. Mr. Saxton's nomination was confirmed by the Senate without reference to a committee -- a compliment paid by the Senators over whose deliberations he presided last year.

A conference to arrange for concerted opposition to the Greater New York charter before the Mayor and the Governor, if need be, was held at the City Club last evening. John E. Parsons presided and James W. Pryor acted as secretary. The following clubs and organizations were represented by the gentlemen whose names are given with them:

Persons interested in making use of the public streets and sidewalks for the transaction of their private business have been much discouraged of late. The Assemblyman who introduced a bill for their relief has been deterred by the disapproval of the Mayor, and doubtless of many of his own constituents, from pushing it further.

At the headquarters of the Grant Monument inaugural celebration yesterday preparations for the strongest possible representation of the National Guard were said to be progressing favorably. The prediction was made that 95 per cent. of them would be present.
Three women and two children were suffocated yesterday afternoon by fire in an apartment house at 61 West One Hundred and Fifth Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30. -- The Ohio Safety Elevator Company of Cleveland was incorporated by the Secretary of State to-day with a capital of $500,000. The incorporators are Hugo Mattullath, H.H. Rees, Edwin C. Thurston, Albert H. Bates, and Edward B. Gilchrist. They will manufacture elevator safety appliances and hoisting machinery.

Undoubtedly the report of the Commissioners of Accounts upon the administration of the Parks under Tammany is timely and important. A good many people are looking forward, not exactly with equanimity, but with such resignation as they can command, to a triumph of Tammany, and of the affiliated Tammanys in Brooklyn and the annexed districts, as the result of the first municipal election of Greater New York.

TRENTON, N.J. March 30. -- Both the Senate and House to-day passed Senate Bill No. 263, introduced by Senator Voorhees last night, to amend the corporation act. The bill is intended to offset a bill pending in the New York Legislature designed to make stockholders of corporations operating in other States and formed in New York liable as partners in litigation.

Senator RAINES. Excise Commissioner LYMAN, and other advocates of such amendments of the liquor tax law as shall prevent evasion of the Sunday prohibition keep up the pretense that there is no way of discriminating between genuine clubs and "fake" clubs. They make that an excuse for insisting upon the amendment which would subject clubs not only to the tax, but to all the requirements and restrictions of the law, including the Sunday prohibition.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 30. -- Senator Brush introduced a bill to-day to amend the Greater New York charter by correcting an error of the printer in leaving out a whole clause of Section 695, whereby the House of Refuge for Juvenile Delinquents, the House of Detention for witnesses, and the Brooklyn Disciplinary Training School for Boys, were placed under the jurisdiction of the Commissioner of Charities.

President I.B. Potter of the League of American Wheelmen received word yesterday from Chief Consul Kireker of the New Jersey Division that the Bicycle Baggage bill had passed the Senate in that State. All that remains now is for the Governor to sign it. If he does this it will immediately become a law.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The midnight score in the six days' bicycle race follows: Shoch, 776 miles; Lawson, 687 miles; Albert, 674 miles 6 laps; Golden, 636 miles 8 laps; Cassidy, 591 miles; Rivierre, 467 miles; Ford, 401 miles 8 laps; Muller, 101 miles 8 laps.

Capt. Edward Reed of the ship T.F. Oakes was arrested yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by United States Commissioner Shields. He was taken in custody by United States Deputy Marshals Stafford and Hurley upon his appearance at the office of Shipping Commissioner Maurice J. Power, where survivors of the crew of the Oakes on her disastrous voyage who chose to apply were paid.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- E.P. Steele of the Committee on Arrangements for the Grant celebration in New York, had a conference to-day with Secretary Porter and Secretary Bliss about the visit which the President will make to New York and the part he will take in the celebration. The arrangements will be completed within a few days, and will be announced.
We do not see why President MCKINLEY should object to the description of patronage by Senator PENROSE as "rations."

Mr. John W. Doane of Chicago, well known as an experienced railroad man and as being closely in touch with business interests throughout the country, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing current conditions:
ROME, March 30. -- After the audience which Archbishop Begin of Quebec had with the Pope yesterday, he was interviewed by a representative of The Associated Press, and said:
