We do not see why President MCKINLEY should object to the description of patronage by Senator PENROSE as "rations."

Mr. John W. Doane of Chicago, well known as an experienced railroad man and as being closely in touch with business interests throughout the country, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing current conditions:

Two wards of the State asylum for the insane, on Ward's Island, were destroyed by fire early last evening. A third was partially damaged by the flames and completely wrecked by water, and nearly half the roof over the eastern wing of the main building, its prods burned away, fell to the floors and lawns below, a mass of broken, useless slate and tangled iron.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- In the executive session of the Senate to-day Senator Hoar introduced an amendment to the arbitration treaty which is intended to meet the objections which have been urged against the agreement. The new amendment is similar to that originally suggested by the Committee on Foreign Relations to the first article exempting all questions of foreign and domestic policy from the operations of the treaty.

Former Senator George F. Edmunds told a distinguished assemblage of railroad lawyers yesterday that, in his opinion, the provisions of the so-called Sherman Anti-Trust act did not invalidate the Joint Traffic Association's agreement. The act in question was drawn by Senator Edmunds, although introduced by Senator Sherman, and the author of the measure believes he understands the scope and intent of it.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Clifford's Gaiety Theatre will change hands Saturday night. The Schiller Specialty Company has taken a five years' lease of the premises, and on the afternoon of April 17 will reopen the establishment with a vaudeville attraction.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 31. -- A heavy rainfall, accompanied by a strong gale from the west, is adding to the gravity of the flood situation in the Mississippi delta. There are four breaks, and each is letting in a stream as large as the Ohio River at Cincinnati or the Hudson at Albany. This tremendous outflow has caused a fall of only one-tenth at Vicksburg, immediately below the last break.

MADRID, March 31. -- In response to the invitation of President McKinley the Government will send the Spanish cruiser Maria Theresa to represent the Queen Regent, King, and people of Spain at the ceremony of dedicating the Grant mausoleum on April 27.

In the Harlem Police Court yesterday Magistrate Kudlich was called upon to decide the ownership of a small black-and-tan dog. The rival claimants were Mrs. Pauline Auerbach of 72 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, and John Monroe of 2,013 Madison Avenue.

The battle among local Republican politicians for Federal places under President McKinley is waging fiercely both here and in Washington. The appointment of Ferdinand Eidmann as Internal Revenue Collector for the Third District is the only bit of comfort that the regular organization has yet received.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The two committees on military affairs for the Senate and Assembly took action this morning which the members say has effectually killed the attempt to arm the National Guard of the State with the Savage rifle.

A personal encounter between Mgr. Thomas J. Ducey of St. Leo's Church and Dr. Owen Jones of the Bellevue Hospital staff was averted yesterday only by the interposition of stalwart Patrolman McMahon of the West Thirtieth Street Station.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Voting on the Tariff bill did not begin until 3 o'clock this afternoon, but the galleries were crowded early to witness the manoeuvring leading up to the climax of the ten days' battle. Mr. Dingley and Mr. Bailey were in their places when Speaker Reed called the House to order at 10 o'clock.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The State Fisheries, Game and Forest Commission to-day received information of an important decision handed down by Justice Kellogg, which establishes the State's title to a number of thousands of acres of land in the Adirondacks which the State has acquired through sales for the non-payment of taxes.

LONDON, March 31. -- The annual banquet of the British Colonial Institute was given this evening, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, presiding. In the large and distinguished company were representatives of almost every colony of the empire. Among the more prominent guests were the Duke of Cambridge, the Marquis of Lorne, Baron Tweedale, Lord Loch, Sir Frederick George Milner, and other Lords and Commoners.

The first-class battleship Iowa, which left Cramps' shipyard, in Philadelphia, Monday, arrived at the Navy Yard yesterday morning. The ship anchored off Tompkinsville Tuesday evening and came up to the yard about 8 o'clock, answering salutes on the way with hoarse wails from her siren. She is on her way to Boston, where, after taking on the official board, she will make her final trial trip off the Massachusetts and Maine coast.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31. -- The proposed amendments to the Raines liquor-tax law were under consideration at the meeting of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment and the Assembly Committee on Excise, in joint session in the Senate chamber to-night. This was the first public hearing on the amendments.

ABERDEEN, S.D., March 31. -- The washout has succeeded the snow blockade in all this section. Fully one-third of the surface of the ground seems to be under water, and worse is expected. Eastern trains on the Milwaukee and Northwestern systems could not get within fifty miles of this city last night, and two hours before its departing time the regular Hastings and Dakota passenger train was abandoned.

There were rumors of robbery and incendiarism in the flats at 61 West One Hundred and Fifth Street following the fire which suffocated three women and two children there on Tuesday afternoon. All these were patiently investigated and emphatically contradicted by the Fire Marshal and the police yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the information recently requested in a Senate resolution as to the sums paid as indemnity to aliens for injuries caused by mob violence. It shows that $147,748 was paid to the Chinese Minister on April 16, 1887, as indemnity for the mob attacks on the Chinese at Rock Springs, Wyoming.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 31. -- The cyclists living in this section are rejoicing today over the completion of the special path between this place and Westhampton. Over $200 was expended in the construction of the wheelway, all of the money being obtained by popular subscription. The Ladies' Bicycle Club of Westhampton is preparing for a parade over the path in celebration of the completion of the work.

HAVANA, March 25. -- The well-authenticated reports of the Laurada's successful expedition only confirm the tenor of my advices of the 20th ult. What was then rumored from most reliable sources is now indisputable fact. The landing at Banes of Gen. Roloff with this expedition is certainly the most important event of the struggle to the Cubans.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31. -- Gov. Black's scheme to preserve the forest of the Adirondacks by having the State purchase $1,000,000 worth of woodland in that territory occupied the attention of the Senate Finance Committee in executive session for the greater part of the afternoon, and, after a most heated discussion, the committee decided to report favorably Senator Ellsworth's bill providing for the same, with some important amendments.

John Frank Short, for nearly a dozen years a trusted employe of Lane Fox, brokers at 223 Produce Exchange, has been missing from the office since March 26. His books show that he is a defaulter for nearly $7,000. The peculations have been in small amounts, spread over a long period of time, and the irregularities were discovered by accident.

The Board of Walking Delegates is not anxious to take up the challenge of the Mason Builders' Association, and seems to be quite willing to submit to arbitration the general strike which it had ordered on the Columbia University buildings against the plumbers and in favor of the steamfitters.

A public conference was held in the Mayor's office yesterday in reference to the controversy between the Dock Commissioners and some of the transatlantic steamship lines over the proposed rentals for new piers in process of construction, between Gansevoort and West Eleventh Streets, on the North River. The Dock Commissioners want to charge more than the steamship companies want to pay.

It is practically admitted by the Republican leaders in the House that the revolutionary changes in the duties on wool and woolens have been made in order to secure the votes of Senators from the sheep-growing States. We do not care now to criticise the morality of this sort of a compromise.

The public reads of some producer who has struck a good well, and envies him in his seeming possession of a comfortable and continuous income. It is assumed that he will retire from business, or at least will not allow the good things he has thus struck to get away from him; that he will store away the revenues it brings him and take things easy.

The Voorhees bill passed by the New Jersey Legislature on Tuesday, and which was immediately signed by the Governor, checkmates any probable action by the New York Legislature growing out of the Lexow investigation. The bill is acceptable to resident holders of stock in corporations that have been incorporated in New Jersey.

Jacob N. Sampson, Assistant Prosecuting Attorney of Lewanee County, Mich., was arrested yesterday in District Attorney Olcott's office after he had been indicted by the Grand Jury for conniving at the escape of Anton M. Christiansen, committed to the custody of Sheriff E.E. Ferguson of Lenawee to be taken to Michigan under extradition proceedings for trial on a charge of embezzlement.

TRENTON, March 31. -- The Senate and House adjourned to-night, after rushing through a number of bills without discussion. The Senate passed the General Appropriation bill for the fiscal year beginning next November. The total amount of the bill is $2,122,934.32, a decrease of $273,998.64 from the appropriation of the present year.

Although the Eastern trunk lines and their Western connections will continue to operate under the Joint Traffic agreement until compelled to cease from so doing by an adverse decision of the United States Supreme Court, the railroad men, almost without exception, are preparing for a vigorous campaign in favor of the passage of a pooling law by Congress.

ALBANY, N.Y., March. 31. -- The Speaker, upon assuming the gavel, was met with a hearty round of applause in honor of his birthday, and huge bunches of flowers were sent to the restrum. One was from the minority, one from the majority, and one from the Westchester and New York members.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Senate to-day began voting upon the miscellaneous amendments to the Anglo-American arbitration treaty. The proceedings were conducted in executive session, but it is understood they were confined almost exclusively to the numerous votes taken. The first roll call was upon Senator Hoar's amendment.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, March 31. -- The town of Chandler is a mass of ruins. The cyclone which at 6 o'clock last evening swept down upon the town almost wiped it from the face of the earth. Of her 1,500 inhabitants, 25 were killed outright or burned to death, and fully 170 were injured.

Alfred H. Tompkins, 206 Broadway, charges Robert E. Matthews and his wife, formerly of 100 East Seventy-sixth Street, with securing from him under false pretenses the deed for his interest in a house and lot at Bath Beach, L.I., valued at $5,000. Mr. Tompkins alleges that he gave them the deed in payment for some water color paintings that he purchased.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 31. -- Donato Spina, thirty years old, employed as watchman on the City Boulevard, was shot and slightly wounded by an unknown assailant this evening. Spina was approached by the man who fired at him with a double-barreled shotgun. Spina had time to drop behind some rocks and was but slightly wounded.

The House of Representatives now has before it a bill for a Monetary Commission. It has been introduced by Mr. HEATWOLE of Minnesota, a representative of the powerful, progressive, conservative Northwest, to which a stable and sound currency is the very condition of progress and prosperity.

B.M. Strauss Co. have sold for William R. Rose, trustee for the creditors of Ferdinand H. Mela, builder, 708 Broadway, a new ten-story mercantile structure, 25 by 137.6, and the new seven-story buildings 15 to 21 Lafayette Place, connecting in the rear on plot about 96.8 to 137.6, for about $600,000, to Gen. Alfred C. Barnes of Brooklyn.

In this week's bulletin of the Chairman of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen, issued yesterday, is contained the list of appointments of handicappers and some of the principal sanctions for race meets already granted but now published for the first time.

Mayor Strong will sit in the Councilmanic Chamber, City Hall, at 2 o'clock this afternoon to hear speakers in opposition to the Greater New York charter. The session will last until 5:30. There will be another hearing on Friday, and if the opponents of the charter find that the two days are insufficient to enable their arguments to be presented the Mayor will sit on Saturday.

SOUTHAMPTON, March 31. -- The North German Lloyd steamship Havel, which sailed to-day for New York, has on board the cabin passengers of the Konigin Luise, which, as previously reported, put back to Falmouth on the 20th, having become disabled when 600 miles west of the Scilly Islands, while bound from Bremen for New York.

Mr. Thomas Lowry of Minneapolis, prominent as a Western capitalist and street railway man, who is at present in New York, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing the Western business outlook:
JACKSON, Miss., March 31. -- The Associated Press correspondent at Greenville telegraphs:

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Cuban question came up soon after the Senate met to-day. Mr. Mills of Texas presented a concurrent resolution instructing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire what, if any, obligations the United States Government had assumed toward the people of Cuba by preventing the acquisition of that island by any European power and compelling the people of Cuba to remain subject to Spain.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 31. -- The New York Sugar Refining Company of Long Island City was incorporated to-day with a capital stock of $600,000, to manufacture and refine sugar. The Directors are Claus Doscher, A. Frederick Henre, C.H. Tiebaut, W.H. Logan, and Frederick Brommer, all of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The non-appearance to-day of the nomination of Andrew D. White to be Ambassador to Germany has led some of the impatient people about Washington to indulge in conjecture.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Mrs. Seawell and the Misses Seawell entertained at an afternoon tea Tuesday in honor of Mrs. Hobart, the wife of Vice President Hobart. Miss Seawell and Miss Henrietta Seawell, the hostesses, were assisted by Mrs. Hawley, Miss Herbert, Miss Voorhees, and Miss Dalzell.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Dingley bill went through the House this afternoon by a prodigious Republican majority, after it had been amended so as to make the rates of the bill effective from April 1. This date was the final outcome of the proposition to make the rates retroactive and of a date not later than April 15.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The executive officers' of the Western roads met to-day to consider the changes made necessary by the abrogation of the association agreements. They took no action, and will meet again to-morrow.

Annex Ferryboat No. 5 of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, a double-decked ferryboat plying between Brooklyn and Jersey City, which had just been overhauled at Lang's repair docks, in Hoboken, went down the river yesterday afternoon to Jersey City and tied up at the York Street pier, or Pier C, to be in readiness for active service this morning.

Lord SALISBURY'S defense of the action of his Government in the matter of Crete, delivered in the House of Lords in reply to Lord KIMBERLY'S arraignment, was an admirable example of its author's skill in parliamentary badinage. If there were no such things as justice and humanity in the world it would be quite conclusive.

LONDON, March 31. -- The Times will publish to-morrow a dispatch from its Paris correspondent advocating the appointment of Prince George as Governor of Crete, and emphasizing the great importance which attaches to the visit of the Dowager Czarina to Copenhagan. He says:
NEW ORLEANS, March 31, -- Weather rainy. track sloppy.

The New York Journal of Commerce of March 18 says of India and Ceylon teas: "The statistics of the trade in Great Britain and Australia are conclusive as to the strides sanitation and the desire to use only pure beverages are making in substituting clean, machine-made teas for the tainted hand-twisted teas of China and Japan.

" Dr. Murphy's refusal to introduce the proposed new stoop-line bill settles the fate of that class of legislation for the remainder of this session," said Lawyer E.M. Wight to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

Present prospects indicate that the Grant Monument celebration, to be held on April 27, will surpass anything of the kind ever attempted in this city. Military organizations from most of the States will be in line, and the civil representation promises to be on a very large scale. The Governors of fourteen States have signified that they will be present with their staffs.

At the hearing on the bill "to provide for the acquisition of land in the counties embracing the forest preserve," on Tuesday night, at Albany, Mr. WARNER MILLER declared that $30,000,000 is invested in "plants" for reducing the Adirondack forests to lumber and wood-pulp paper, and that it was one of the greatest business interests of the State, which would be ruined if this bill should become a law.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The committees did a great deal of hustling to-day and the number of important bills to be reported favorably to-morrow is in excess of any day this session. The important measures to be reported favorably in the Assembly are:

The Zoological Society ought to be strengthened and extended. The granting of its application for land in Bronx Park not only makes it a conspicuous and important organization among the many of like purposes which exist in the city, but imposes on its managers serious duties and responsibilities.

The following is from a letter from Mr. Arthur T. Lyman of Boston, Treasurer of the Lowell Manufacturing Company, the largest carpet manufacturing corporation in this country and probably in the world, to Mr. Edward D. Page of Faulkner, Page Co., woolen commission merchants of this city:

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 31. -- The preachers of Leavenworth have started a crusade against poker playing by the society women of the town. Last Sunday the Rev. Dr. Thomas of the Episcopal Church, after inveighing against gambling in general, related an instance of the robbery of a visiting young lady by a prominent lady.

ALBANY, March 31. -- To-morrow Assemblyman Forrester will move to discharge the Assembly Committee on Gas, Electricity, and Water Supply from further consideration of the bill to provide that the price for gas in Brooklyn shall not be over 90 cents per 1,000 cubic feet.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- One hundred policemen from the Desplaines Street Station laid aside their blue uniforms and brass buttons last night and donned dress suits and silk tiles. Then they went out on the streets and invited footpads to assault them.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- It took nearly an hour this morning to read the reports of committees in the Assembly.

MEADVILLE, Penn., April 1. -- Cambridge Springs, a health resort about fifteen miles from here, was almost destroyed by fire to-day. Charles Hayes lost his life, and property worth $200,000 was destroyed. Several persons were injured.

LONDON, April 1. -- There were loud cheers from the Irish benches in the House of Commons to-day when the Parliamentary Secretary for the Foreign Office, Mr. George N. Curzon, confirmed the report from Crete that a detachment of Turkish Bashibazouks at Retimo had fired upon a flag of truce subsequent to the refusal of the insurgents to accept autonomy, and upon their insisting upon annexation.

Arguments were made before Mayor Strong in the Aldermanic Chamber yesterday afternoon against his approval of the proposed Greater New York charter. This was the first public hearing on the subject, and considerable interest was manifested in the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Tariff bill passed by the House of Representatives yesterday was received by the Senate as soon as the session opened to-day. There were no formalities as to its reference and without motion or comment Mr. Hobart referred the bill to the Committee on Finance.

PARIS, April 1. -- M. Hanotaux, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Comte de Mun, the well-known Clerical Deputy, have been elected members of the French Academy, in succession to the late M. Challemel Lacour, President of the Senate, and the late M. Jules Simon, the distinguished statesman.

The original plans of the Rapid Transit Commissioners, which were presented to the Board of Aldermen on March 2, contemplated the construction of a road to begin at Park Row and Ann Street. At the various hearings on the plan before the Aldermen the extension of the road to the Battery was urged strongly.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- The following bills will be reported favorably by the Cities Committee of the Assembly to-morrow:

The Columbia freshmen and 'Varsity crews, which are making their headquarters at the Hudson Boat Clubhouse, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and the Hudson River, this week until the float of their own boathouse, at the foot of West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, is placed in position, were both out in the Hudson Wednesday afternoon for an hour's work.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Senate today in executive session concluded its consideration of all amendments to the arbitration treaty. The voting on additional amendments began at 4 o'clock, after three hours of general debate, and in the hour and a half which followed about a dozen propositions were passed upon.

Wail Street houses with London connections report that, although speculation in London is small, there is considerable confidence abroad regarding American securities. The trans-Missouri decision by the Supreme Court seems to have created very little, apprehension in- London regarding American railway stocks, and it is also said that the actual floating supply of stocks abroad is smaller than it has been for some time.

Strong words of condemnation for the Dingley Tariff bill were spoken by representative New York merchants at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. Gustav H. Schwab, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Commerce, started the discussion by offering a resolution characterizing the tariff bill just passed by the House of Representatives as "excessive and likely to invite reaction harmful to business and to the best interests of the country."

The Seventh Regiment was reviewed last night by the war veterans, the members of the Veteran Association, and former members of the regiment. The big armory was crowded, and men who served in the famous regiment before many of its present members were born were conspicuous in the throng.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- The Republican members of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment and the Assembly Committee on Excise have decided to try to make an amendment which will differentiate between "fake" and genuine clubs in the matter of taxation for the sale of liquor.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1. -- Justices Garrison and Gummere, in the Supreme Court this morning, practically declared unconstitutional the act passed by the present Legislature abolishing Spring elections in Jersey City and Newark. The Court granted a writ of mandamus directing City Clerk O'Donnell of Jersey City to go on with the printing of the tickets and the preparation for an election in Jersey City on April 13.

The Atlantic Yacht Club members are planning for a brilliant season, and are determined that it shall be even better than last year. The first race will be sailed on Saturday, June 12, and will be a special regatta for the crack racing yachts. It will be the first time that the Colonia will meet the changed Emerald, and the first race between the new Syce and the Wasp.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 1. -- The flood situation in the Mississippi Delta, above Greenville, is decidedly improved to-night. The half-dozen crevasses on the Arkansas and Mississippi shores between Helena and Greenville have drawn an immense volume of water out of the main channel, which is spreading over the lowlands, but not rapidly enough to cut off the escape of the inhabitants of the low counties.

At a hearing before the Senate Committee on Insurance at Albany yesterday a delegation of New York merchants and insurance men presented a remonstrance against Senator Cantor's Fire Insurance Restriction bill.
HAVANA, April 1. -- The Diario de la Marina prints to-day a letter from Gen. Maximo Gomez to Senor Morote, the correspondent of El Liberal of Madrid, which runs as follows:

Thirty-five families, numbering 120 persons, were yesterday evicted as squatters from the South Cove grant, owned by Jersey City, and adjoining property along the old southern boundary of the city in the neighborhood of Henderson, Grove, and Canal Streets. This property has been in the courts on a question of title under a legislative grant to the city made in 1866.

Suppose that a Board of Trustees managing the business of a number of corporations, or a Board of Directors of one large corporation controlling the business of a number of establishments, gives an order that certain shops shall be closed or that sales shall not be made to certain concerns which do not comply with the conditions laid down by the trust or the corporation, the purpose being to keep up prices and maintain profits!

The obstinacy of Senator RAINES'S fixed idea seems very remarkable. His vindictiveness against clubs appears, to people who know anything about clubs, as so gratuitous that he must have something of the spirit of a crusader. Republicans of such unquestioned "straightness" as that of LAUTERBACH and GRUBER tell him that he is ruining the party in New York and Brooklyn, and in consequence that he is endangering the State.

Aided in eloquent and convincing fashion by the American Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Mr. Sam Franko, W.J. Henderson delivered his lecture explanatory of the modern orchestra last night in Chickering Hall. The subject was "The Orchestra Explained."

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Representative Dalzell of Pennsylvania, who was a member of the Sub-Committee of the Ways and Means Committee which investigated the question of the power of Congress to provide for the enforcement of the duties of the new tariff bill before its enactment into law, has prepared an argument in support of the validity of the amendment.

-- Claims amo,ntlng to $93,138 have been filed by the crew of the ship T. F. Oakes. The amount is so newhat impressive, but the owners are doubtless worrying much less about these demands than about the big bill for towing their vessel into port, which was another result of Capt. REED'S economy.

Anti-cartoon is a misnomer for the Ellsworth bill, which says nothing about cartoons, but prohibits the publication of the portrait of any person not a fugitive from justice without his written consent. While the avowed purpose of this bill -- the protection of privacy -- is a legitimate one, it really aims at much more than that, and its constitutionality is very questionable.
LONDON, April 1. -- The Times will print to-morrow a dispatch for its Vienna correspondent, who says:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The first open and formal expressions of dissatisfaction with the pending tariff bill on the part of foreign nations have come to the State Department from Japan and Argentine.

There are evidences that the committee appointed by the Mason Builders' Association to confer with the various organizations of the United Building Trades for the purpose of making a combined attack upon the Board of Walking Delegates has been doing quiet, but effective work; and before long the board may have to make a desperate fight for its existence.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- President McKinley has extended invitations to all the members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House to dine at the Executive Mansion Friday evening.

The New York Athletic Club swimmers won both of the races contested at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club tank Wednesday night, and they were much elated over their victory. There were nine starters in the one-hundred-yard race. They were E.S. Goldstein, J.F. McMillan, A.G. Sivori, G. Van Cleaf, Knickerbocker Athletic Club; D.M. Reeder, Normandie Murray, J.M. Davis, H.N. Rawlins, F. Wenck, New York Athletic Club.

Mr. HOPKINS of the Ways and Means Committee, during the debate in the Committee of the Whole on Tuesday, inadvertently exposed the plan on which the Dingley bill was made up. West Virginia and Maryland especially, he said, had protested against the present duty of 40 cents a ton on bituminous coal, and had asked for an increase.
HAVANA, April 1. -- The Queen Regent has cabled her congratulations to Captain General Weyler on the capture of Gen. Rius Rivera and the success of the latest operations against the insurgents.
What does Mr. DINGLEY think that the Senate will do with his bill?

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 1. -- P.F. Brown of Johnstown, Penn., left a package of papers and letters in his room at the Jefferson House and went to Columbus recently, and it was the means of exposing the largest scheme the farmers of this country have ever undertaken.

The new golf links of the Crescent Athletic Club at Bay Ridge were formally opened for play yesterday afternoon. The course consists of nine holes, and was laid out during the Winter. The ground is very favorable for golf. Several members were present during the afternoon, but the playing was purely informal.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Weather Bureau to-day resumed publication of its weather crop bulletins. In a review of crop conditions during the month of March it says:

Further testimony was taken before Surrogate Arnold yesterday in the contest over the will of Dr. Alexander Buchanan, offered for probate by Mrs. Kate M. Foster and contested by Mrs. Margaret P. Buchanan, the testator's widow, and her daughters. The will gave to Mrs. Buchanan $50, and to each of the daughters $5, while the residue of the estate was left to Mrs. Foster.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Congressional contingent at the White House today was unusually large. The visitors were not confined by party lines. Mr. Bailey of Texas and a number of other Democrats were among the callers. Many of the members of the House called to leave papers at the White House and to put in final words for aspiring constituents.

WASHINGTON. April 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business yesterday the debt, less cash in the Treasury amounted to $1,003,962,200, a decrease for the month of $8,638,254. This decrease is accounted for by a corresponding increase in the amount of cash on hand.
NEW ORLEANS, La., April 1. -- Weather fine; track very heavy.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

OMAHA, Neb., April 1. -- The severest blizzard of the entire Winter prevailed for thirty-five hours in Western Nebraska and adjacent territory, but is now at an end. It completely stopped all traffic on three Omaha railroads -- the Burlington, the Union Pacific, and the Rock Island -- in that section.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Col Fred Grant of New York, the eldest son of President Grant, this morning received an offer of the position of Assistant Secretary of War by President McKinley and has the question of his acceptance under advisement.

As a result of the meeting of the local Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen, Wednesday night, it is very likely that a plan will be adopted whereby the organization will be made to include all the league members in the city. It needs strengthening, so the officials say, both as regards numbers and finances.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- "These bills will drive from this State millions of dollars' worth of capital, will cut off the living of thousands of residents, and will lower the commercial standing of the State in a large degree." So said Charles A. Collin of the New York law firm of Sheehan Collin in an argument before the Judiciary Committee to-day on the trust bills.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- The agreement regarding freight matters, which was practically adopted yesterday by the Western roads was to-day formally ratified by the executive officers and is now in effect. The General Passenger Agents some days since recommended that the Western Passenger Association be turned into a Bureau of Statistics and Information, and the recommendation was adopted by the executive officers.

If any one desires to observe how local home rule is ignored and to what extent the Legislature of the State undertakes to run the affairs of cities, let him notice for a single day the character of the bills introduced or advanced in the various stages of enactment at Albany. Take, for instance, the dispatches in yesterday's TIMES.

It is to be hoped that Col. FRED GRANT will find the place of Assistant Secretary of War, which the President has offered to him, "equally as good" as the Commissionership of Police. This latter place cannot have been a bed of roses for Col. GRANT, since his sense of duty constrained him to join with Commissioner PARKER in producing a dead-lock in all police business.

The Union College baseball team of Schenectady, N.Y., was beaten yesterday afternoon by the St. John's College team at Fordham. The Fordham boys outplayed their opponents from the first inning. During the six that were played the Fordhams scored 24 runs, while the Unions had hard work making 2.
Knox McAfee has sold for the trustees of the Reformed Presbyterian Church of North America, 146 West Eleventh Street, a three-story and basement brick dwelling, on lot 18.9 by 57.3, to W.F. Moore.

The passage by the Assembly of the Leonard bill permitting booths for truckmen on the sidewalks over Mayor Strong's veto has aroused intense indignation among persons in this city who are working for unobstructed streets. The Board of Trade and Transportation and the Real Estate Exchange will send a delegation to Albany within a few days to oppose any such action in the Senate.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The President to-day made the following nominations:

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day, Solicitor General Conrad, acting for the Government, entered a motion to advance on the docket the suit against the Joint Traffic Association, comprising the principal trunk lines of the country. In addition to setting forth the history of the proceeding in the court below the motion gives the reason for asking an advance as follows:

ALBANY, April 1. -- The bill of the Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations, reducing the price of gas in New York City 5 cents a year until the price reaches $1, was taken up in the Senate Committee of the Whole this afternoon.

If all the Christian Endeavorers in New York City should turn out in one big procession they would make quite a respectable army. The quota of nearly seven full regiments would be included in this muster, and the scene would be rendered still more picturesque if to it were added the various society and district banners and the blue and white colors of the New York City Union.

In the Supplement of last Saturday's issue, your correspondent "Q." asks for the meaning of the word "mistal" as found in Fletcher's "God's Failures." The word is purely a local or dialect one; it is pronounced similarly to the word "pistol," and is used to designate the place where the cows are kept in contrast with the stable for the horses.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The part of the public that is interested in having the Dingley bill changed before it shall become a law has begun to look up the members of the Senate Finance Committee, and they are having some trouble in getting at them. With the determination on the part of the Republicans to give no hearings except to Senators, but to consider written papers, oral argument is headed off.

LONDON, April 2. -- The Parliamentary committee which is investigating the Transvaal raid held another session to-day in the committee room, off Westminster Hall. Sir John Willoughby, the military leader of the raid, who was released from Halloway Jail on Wednesday last, where he served a sentence of ten months' imprisonment for violating the Foreign Enlistment act, was examined.

The annual meeting of the Quill Club Wheelmen of America was held at the clubrooms, 150 Nassau Street, yesterday afternoon, and the following officers were elected on the regular ticket, without opposition:

LOCKPORT, April 2. -- Niagara County is the first county in the State to adopt a bicycle tax. The new sidepath law went into effect yesterday. It taxes bicycles 50 cents annually. Up to noon to-day 1,074 licenses had been taken out.

The last public rehearsal of the Symphony Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in the presence of a large and demonstrative audience. The programme consisted of Schumann's B flat symphony, the E flat piano concerto of Beethoven, the Good Friday music from "Parsifal," and the Hungarian fantasia of Franz Liszt. Mme. Teresa Carreno was the solo performer.
LONDON, April 2. -- The Times will print to-morrow the following dispatch from its Athens correspondent: ...

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Secretary Gage has announced that hereafter he will receive visitors only between the hours of 10 to 1 o'clock on days other than Cabinet days. On Cabinet days visitors will be received from 9 until 10:30 o'clock. No visitors will be received at other hours, except on urgent official business.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The President had many callers to-day. Gen. Stewart L. Woodford of New York was one of the earliest callers, and had a few minutes with the President. He was in excellent humor when he took his departure. His name has been mentioned in connection with the mission to Spain, and he denied that he had any aspirations in this or any direction.
The City and Suburban Homes Company, which is building model tenement houses and suburban homes for the poorer classes, has just made two more important purchases of real estate.

The John Crerar Library of Chicago was opened for public use last Thursday. It will occupy temporarily the entire sixth floor of the Marshall Field Co. building, 87 Wabash Avenue. This will be for at least five and perhaps ten years, until the sum which the Directors intend to set aside each year from the income is sufficient to begin the erection of a separate building.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Right in the business district to-day a messenger employed by the wholesale woolen firm of Kuh, Nathan Fisher was robbed of $3,500 after being beaten into insensibility by two men.

The war between the Board of Aldermen and the executive departments of the city over the question of street obstructions is daily becoming more aggravated. Mayor Strong continues to veto the board's resolutions granting permits for the erection of sidewalk stands, and in taking this position he is indorsed by Corporation Counsel Scott, Col. Waring, Commissioner Collis, the press, and the courts.
Without ostentation or ceremony Major Gen. Thomas Howard Ruger, second in command of the United States Army, retired at noon yesterday after forty-three years of service.

SANTA FE, New Mexico, April 2. -- Fracisco Gonzales y Borrego, Antonio Gonzales y Borrego, Sauriano Alarid, and Patricio Valencia were hanged together at 9:10 A.M. to-day, for the murder of ex-Sheriff Chavez, who was killed from ambush on the night of May 29, 1892.

WICHITA, Kan., April 2. -- Deputy Sheriff Cunningham of Abilene, Texas, shot and mortally wounded Joseph B. McMahan, proprietor of McMahan Brothers' Show, in a duel in the office of the Manhattan Hotel this afternoon, and the officer is now a prisoner in the county jail, in a cell adjoining that of the man he came here from Texas to arrest.
New exponents of the defects of the Greater New York charter appeared before Mayor Strong yesterday at the second day's hearing in the Aldermanic Chamber.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 2. -- The trouble between the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada and the Canadian Pacific Railway about transcontinental rates continues. The Grand Trunk has announced a schedule of rates in which it meets that of the Canadian Pacific, and the Canadian Pacific announces that it will appeal to the Joint Traffic Association to compel the Grand Trunk to go back to the old rates.

Charles Volzing Son have sold 976 and 978 Third Avenue, near Fifty-eighth Street, two five-story tenements, with stores, on plot 50 by 100, to Frederick G. Zinsser for Dr. Helen Botezkes, at $115,000, and 111 East Sixtieth Street, a four-story and basement brownstone front dwelling, 20 by 50 by 100.5, for Mrs. W.K. Lantry to Dr. Louis Brucklieb, at $25,000.

It does seem ungracious thus to state it, and savoring of indolence, but the English book reviewers complain of the books they receive, which are uncut. That important person in the big newspaper office the exchange editor, never could get through his onerous labors were his journals placed on his table uncut.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 2. -- The flood situation has once more become acute from a point a few miles above Austin, Miss., as far down as the first break at Perthshire, Miss., and a crevasse in this line of levees would not be surprising. The pressure on the levee is brought about by the waters of the St. Francis basin, which are here congested between the levees in front of Helena.

The pretense'of the '" European concert that Its' Intervention tO 'drive the Greeks out of Crete and provisionally to. re-enslave the Cretans was in the interest of peace, is dally becoming more absurd; BIr. CURZON,. in the House .of Commons on FridaY'; explained, that, the Turks Would be put out of:, Crete as'-fast as possible, but that they,could not be expelled Until the powers could supply a police to take their place?.'.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 2. -- The rental was announced to-day of the George Francis Train villa, near the end of Bellevue Avenue, to Stanley Mortimer of New York, the polo player. Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer were not here last season. The Train villa is one of the most charming in Newport.

-- A statistician for whose accuracy one of the London papers has been bold enough to vouch has figured out that between thirty and forty millions sterling wilt be spent by the Queen's frantically loyal subjects in securing windows and other points of vantage from which to watch her pass in the great procession of June 22.

LONDON, April 2. -- In the House of Commons to-day Labouchere, Radical member for Northampton, moved that the House disapprove the advice of the Marquis of Salisbury to the Queen to use the British forces against the Cretans or the Greek nation.

The prospects for a settlement of the steamfitters' strike, or lockout, as the men call it, which began Monday, was more encouraging yesterday, and if the master steamfitters accept the proposal which the Board of Walking Delegates made yesterday, their men will all return to work on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Secretary Gage to-day announced that he had decided to comply with the requirements' of Section 27 of the pending Tariff bill, providing for the retention of samples of merchandise imported under orders given subsequent to April 1, and which were not purchased and directed by the owner to be shipped for import into the United States prior to April 1.

The Rev. Dr. E.E. Chivers, General Secretary of the Baptist Young People's Union of America, left New York yesterday to make Chicago his permanent home. He has been for some time District Secretary of the American Baptist Missionary Union, but recently resigned from that position to devote his entire attention to the young people's work.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment held a joint session in the Mayor's office yesterday, in reference to the selection of a site for the new Hall of Records.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 2. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee immediately after the adjournment of the Senate resumed the hearing on the anti-trust bills. Prof. Charles Collin continued his argument. He contended that the bills accomplished more than their purpose in driving from the State the business of legitimate corporations. He said that bills in correcting evils worked far greater evils on legitimate enterprises.

As the preparations for the dedication of the Grant Monument grow nearer completion, the managers express the assurance that the ceremonies will be the most imposing this country has ever known on an occasion of this kind. In some respects the celebration bids fair to rival the Columbian celebration of 1892.

In an art journal, excellent of its kind, Bradstreet's is quoted as follows: "Six hundred million pounds of pork were shipped from Chicago in 1896, as against 500,000,000 pounds in 1895." Then in juxtaposition, taking the figures again from Bradstreet's, the statement is made that "there were 2,000 portraits painted in America in 1896, as against 2,700 in 1895."

Assemblyman AUSTIN in the act of be traying the rights of his constituents in this city sneered at the motives of Mr. HUSTED of Westchester when the latter declared that the Grand Boulevard and Concourse bill was a "big political job," providing a few men with an easy berth and a big salary for an indefinite time, and that it was such measures that wreck political parties.
The weekly prayer meeting of Plymouth Church was devoted last night to a consideration and discussion or the subject, "The Old Bible Under New Lights: What It Has Been to Us."

MONTREAL, April 2. -- A bold attempt is to be made to-morrow night or Monday night to influence the Chicago wheat market for the benefit of Montreal speculators. The Metropolitan in to-night's issue sums up the situation in a nutshell as follows:

The Countess di Brazza has a winning way in clothing a scientist in fairly bright colors, as the hero of an American idyl. The archaeological romance has been attempted before, and it has failed because it was too archaeological. In the pretty story of "Amphorita," we have mixed in fair proportions the ways and habits of the Indians in Northern Mexico, their folk-lore, and a sympathetic episode of love unrequited.

If Henry Drummond was not the equal of Darwin or Huxley, it would be stupid to advance the idea that he was unprepared for scientific argument. Born at Stirling in 1851, he was bred among books, his uncle having been a publisher. Henry Drummond's father a well-to-do man, and had taken a leading part in promulgating religion.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The Republican members of the Senate Committee on Finance are continuing their work day and night on the tariff bill with the intention of reporting it to the Senate at the earliest possible day. They are not yet prepared to give out any of the results of their investigations, and say that they have not as yet reached any conclusions upon any schedules of the bill.

ST. PAUL, April 2. -- The Mississippi River here has reached a stage of 15 feet and is still rising slowly. This is the highest point reached since the great flood of 1881. The residents of the flats have had ample warning to save themselves and their property.

LONDON, April 2. -- An Oxford man, who has rowed in victorious Oxford crews at Putney and Henley and who is an acknowledged authority on university racing, writes as follows for The Associated Press relative to the prospects of to-morrow's Oxford-Cambridge race:

PROVIDENCE, April 2. -- Mrs. William Gammell of this city died at Dover, England, to-day, of heart disease. The news was received here by a cablegram to her son. Mrs. Gammell was taken ill while on her way home from the Riviera, where she had spent the Winter, as was her custom. The news of her death was a great shock to her relatives, who had supposed her to be in excellent health.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 2. -- William Tighe and John McCann, twenty-three years old, of East Metuchen, are locked up in the county jail here, and John Manson, eighteen years old, of this city, is out under $1,000 bail on a criminal charge.

The Chamber of Commerce is not a body of politicians or of partisans. Its membership includes Democrats, Republicans and Independents, and among these are many convinced and ardent protectionists. As business men, the members of the Chamber are concerned in all forms of trade and industry, foreign and domestic.

Some person with a peculiar sense of humor, or perhaps with malice, has advertised the death of a woman who is at present in excellent health, in two of the morning newspaper of this city. The victim is Mrs. Ellen Arnold, the wife of Patrick L. Arnold, of 70 West Forty-fifth Street.

Thus far only the opponents of the Greater New York charter have had an opportunity to appear before the Mayor at the hearing, and their plea has been for delay in order that the defects of the charter may be remedied before it is put into effect. Some of the speakers have incidentally expressed hostility to the whole scheme of consolidation, but that is a settled question, and its discussion is not relevant.

A dark-visaged man approached a boatman at the Battery Basin yesterday, and said that he wanted a boat. Boatmen McCormack and Delaney lost no time in casting off, and their passenger, having taken a seat in the stern, they pulled around to the Liberty Island boat, about to start on her 11 o'clock trip.

For more than half an hour last night Patrick Flannigan lay pinned under an engine before the elevated station at Eighty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, while those who would have aided him looked helplessly on and waited for a relief train. The man was ticket agent at the station, and had been knocked down as he crossed the tracks. A few minutes after the engine had been raised the man died.
{ Stock market firm.

The rules and regulations issued by the Trustees of the Carnegie art fund are well considered. That difficult matter of a jury is disposed of follows: It is to be composed of eleven persons, one of whom shall be Chairman of the Fine Arts Committee of the Board of Trustees, who shall act as President, and shall cast the deciding vote in case of a tie.

A dark-visaged man approached a boatman at the Battery Basin yesterday, and said that he wanted a boat. Boatmen McCormack and Delaney lost no time in casting off, and their passenger, having taken a seat in the stern, they pulled around to the Liberty Island boat, about to start on her 11 o'clock trip.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The visit to-day to the Treasury of Senators Platt, Quay, Penrose, and Proctor, to confer with Secretary Gage about the office of Supervising Architect, is being talked about to-night as an indication of a desire of the Senators to run things in their own way in the departments.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 2. -- Capt. Joyce of the New York Giants, who for the past two weeks has been watching the work of the new men, is beginning to weed out those whom he will not need when the championship season opens. To-day he released Charles Zeidler, a pitcher, and Dennis Houle. The latter will probably play in a minor league team this season.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- President McKinley gave a dinner to twenty-seven at the White House to-night, the guests including the present and past members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House now in Congressional life, and a few others.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 2. -- Three bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day:

BERLIN, March 23. -- At the regular Berlin stands are few pictures to chronicle. The Winter's exhibit by the "Eleven" at Gurlitt's is much like that of the year before. Skarbina shows up as usual with clever water colors, and Leistikow represents pretty much all there is hereabout suggestive of the symbolists of Paris.

Between the dates of the sale of the two parts of the Bierstadt Library at Bangs Co.'s, Messrs. Libbie of Boston will disperse another notable New York collection of first editions. This collection, comprising nearly 2,000 lots, was formed by Mr. C.P. Roos, and has long been known to bibliophiles and collectors as containing one of the most remarkable series of first editions both of English and American authors ever formed in this city.

Prof. Manatt's first thought concerning this notable volume was merely to make it a translation of the very important work in which Dr. Tsountas (the Greek archaeologist, who continued Dr. Schliemann's work at Mycenae) had in 1893 brought together the fruits of his toil for the benefit of the Greek public.

The President and Mr. GAGE have met fairly one severe test of sound administration in the Treasury. The appoint-ments of Mr. O. L. SPAULDING and Mr.W. B. HOWELL as Assistant Secretaries are in direct contrast to the politicians' methods of dealing with places not under the civil service rules.

LONDON, April 2. -- An immense crowd witnessed the annual field and track games between the Oxford and Cambridge teams to-day at the Queen's Club grounds. The Duke and Duchess of York were present, and a numerous sprinkling of the nobility. Hundreds of ladies appeared in Spring toilets and the scene was very gay.

The sixth annual meeting and banquet of the Veteran Association of the Department of the South and the South Atlantic Blockading Squadron will be held upon the thirty-sixth anniversary of the fall and the thirty-second anniversary of the formal reoccupation of Fort Sumter April 14, at the Hotel St. George, Clark Street, Brooklyn.

There was a tumultuous time in Madison Square Garden late Wednesday night, after the big Barnum Bailey parade. The torch bearers were summoned to get their pay, and, in accordance with the arrangement made in the morning, when the men were engaged, the return of a torch entitled the bearer to $1.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Senator Platt is apparently without anxieties nowadays. He seems to have come to a resolution not to expect or demand anything, and not to be disappointed if things do not turn out his way. He takes just as much interest in appointments, however, as he did when he made most strenuous efforts to secure the places to which he believed New York to be entitled.

Like other time-honored institutions the wholesome custom of Spring cleaning is gradually assuming a more modern aspect. Time was when the very word suggested to the house mother mountains of manual labor performed to an accompaniment of grumblings loud and deep, uttered by him who, deeming himself head of his household, found even a brief and temporary dethronement intensely disagreeable.

Compared with other professions in England, the municipal service is, on the whole, fairly well paid. Salaries of Town Clerks range from 300 in towns of a population of 30,000 to 1,750 paid by Manchester, which has a population of 500,000; while municipal engineers are paid all the way up from 200 in towns of 20,000 to 1,000 a year paid by each of the municipalities of Manchester, Liverpool, and Newcastle.

The production of "The Tempest" at Daly's Theatre will be the most noteworthy dramatic event of this week. Others, however, will demand and receive their share of serious attention. For instance, to-morrow night, at the Garden Theatre, Olga Nethersole will act Emma Scarli in the translation of Giuseppe Giasco's Italian domestic drama, "The Wife of Scarli," for the first time in New York.

Officers of the National Guard will learn with a great deal of satisfaction that Gov. Black has appointed. Dr. Nelson Henry an Assistant Surgeon General. Col. Henry, as Surgeon in the Twelfth Regiment some years ago, and also as Assistant Surgeon General under Gov. Flower, gave ample evidence of his value in the National Guard.

The Society of the Colonial Dames of the State of New York, which holds its annual meeting and election of officers to-morrow, will congratulate itself that the latest and largest of the many works it has undertaken since its incorporation, in 1893, is well under way in the Van Cortlandt mansion, which it is preparing for a Museum of Colonial History.

A gallery of the best paintings from the pencils of the old masters and the new upon themes appropriate to the day will occupy the pages of the Magazine Supplement issued with THE TIMES of Easter Sunday, April 18.

The Legislature of Manitoba has ratified the settlement of the school question arrived at by the present Canadian Government, and ratified it by a majority approaching unanimity. On the crucial question the vote at Winnipeg was 53 to 5, and on a subordinate question even the leader of the Opposition voted with the Government.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 3. -- The Maiden Stakes for three-year-olds was run at Newport to-day on a fast track. Ten horses went to the post with Vengeance the favorite. The winner turned up in Panchita II, a long shot, who won in a hard drive by a nose. Attendance, 5,000. Summaries:

The United States battleship Iowa, which has been in dry dock at the navy yard preparatory to her official speed trial, sailed yesterday for Boston. She steamed down to Tompkinsville, where she remained at anchor until 3 P.M., when she passed out at Sandy Hook.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 2. -- The Raines law, although perplexing and somewhat vexing to many people, does not trouble an aged veteran of the late war who lives in the little hamlet of Olive Bridge, away up in the Catskill Mountains. Up there, at the recent town election, the inhabitants voted for no license, and carried the day, although by a small majority.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Under a special order from general headquarters authorizing the formation of the separate companies of the Third Brigade into battalions, Gen. Oliver, commanding that brigade, has carried into force his plan, which brought forth the order, and under the new formation the brigade will make its first parade in New York City on the occasion of the Grant tomb dedication exercises.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 3. -- Although many cottages have been leased here for the coming season, the number is considerably below the record of a year ago. That is chargeable to the cold weather, which has kept people from coming here in all probability.

To the thousands of persons who pass up and down New York's inner harbor daily, the picturesque old "cheese-box" shaped fortress of Castle Williams, situated at the northwest point of Governors Island, is more or less an object of curiosity. Built quite beyond the remembrance of "the oldest inhabitant," the venerable walls have witnessed the rise of several generations, and are nearing the century date in point of age.

Prior to our Revolution a whipping-post stood in Philadelphia at the southeast corner of Third and Market Streets. They were also to be found in most other American cities at that time. The pillory, which usually accompanied the whipping of criminal, was regarded as a species of public entertainment.

George E. Chisolm's new house boat, built by Marvel from designs by H.C. Wintringham, is about ready for her owner. She will be put in commission about the end of April and will be used for cruising on Long Island Sound.
The two cleanest cities on the continent to-day are Toronto and New York, and they are both cleaned by direct labor.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The official orders for the participation of United States troops in the Grant Monument celebration at New York were promulgated to-day at the War Department. In a letter to the Commanding General of the Department of the East at New York, Major Gen. Miles states that Secretary Alger has designated the following troops for participation in the ceremonies:
President William Berri of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees had this to say yesterday regarding the subject of rapid transit between this city and Brooklyn:

ANNAPOLIS, April 3. -- The ancient city begins to feel the impulse of the arrival of the annual caravan of candidates for admission to the Naval Academy. Although the first entrance examinations do not take place until May, candidates are already here enrolled in one or the other of the three preparatory schools which fit them for the examinations which bridge the gulf between appointment and admission.

A recent musicale at the house of Dr. Anderson, in East Eighty-sixth Street, was made noteworthy by the reintroduction of the long-disused viola d'amore, which makes its last appearance in classical music in the scores of Bach, who wrote in the Johannis Passion an obligato accompaniment to a vocal solo for two violas d'amore.

Although the real estate business is undeniably dull, the private sales of the past week, when carefully figured out, exclusive of those that have gone on record show an aggregate investment of $8,000,000. Only once this year, four weeks ago has that amount been exceeded.

In the Register's office in Brooklyn yesterday was recorded a deed transferring a piece of property in Sixteenth Street from Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Tilton to Mortimer J. Brown for a valuable consideration. Mr. Tilton is in Paris, where he has lived ever since his suit against Henry Ward Beecher, so his signature is attested by United States Consul McLean.

The voyager, if he is not seasick, is dependent for comfort first on the table steward. To this man it seems to be the rule to give $2.50 for one, or $5 for two or three persons in a party, whether one is served in regular courses or orders what he pleases from the bill. Late suppers might increase the fee.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Senator Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to-day issued the following address:

ONE of the most interesting figures in the whole of ecclesiastical America is the Most Rev. M.A. Corrigan, Archbishop of New York, and an especial point of the interest centring upon him is that, while he is constantly an object of public attention and discussion, he never himself takes part in such discussion.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 3. -- The condition of affairs in coal-mining circles here is becoming critical. The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company has abandoned the work of putting in pumps at its Avondale Mine. This endangers the great mine of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, which adjoins the former.

HAVANA, April 3. -- At the headquarters of Captain General Weyler, in Cienfuegos, Province of Santa Clara, news has been received from Bayamo, Province of Santiago de Cuba, that three deserters from the personal escort of Gen. Maximo Gomez, the insurgent Commander in Chief, have arrived there, refusing to remain any longer with Gomez.

Cleanliness of instruments, now a prime consideration, was not so many years ago entirely ignored. Oftentimes the same instruments would be used at different times upon the dead as well as upon the living body, and a celebrated operator of that day was accustomed to hold his knife between his teeth, when his hands were temporarily employed in the wound.

Before the Wagner Institute of Philadelphia W.B. Scott, Professor of Geology at Princeton University, recently lectured about the formation and life of lakes, from which the following interesting extracts are taken:

ALBANY, April 3. -- Kings County legislators are not satisfied with the progress of legislation which affects their part of Greater New York. Some of them say that Kings County bills are "held up," while those from New York are advanced, and they have held two of three conferences to consider how they may combine to secure action on measures which they deem of importance.

It may not generally be known, but the United States copyright law is at present doing more than anything else to delay the development of spelling reform in this country. As it stands at present, in order to secure copyright on a work by an English author, the typography and presswork must be done in the United States -- this in the interests of American industries.

THE two most important art exhibitions of the year in New York, namely, the annual Spring displays of the Society of American Artists and of the National Academy of Design are now open, and will be on view until the first week in May, the first at the American Fine Arts Galleries, in West Fifty-seventh Street, and the second in the old Academy of Design Building, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

BABYLON, L.I., April 3. -- The condition of Roswell G. Rolston, the President of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New York, whose right side was paralyzed while riding in a Long Island Railroad train yesterday afternoon on his way to his home in North Babylon, remains serious. Dr. W.W. Hewlett is in attendance on him. It is not thought that Mr. Rolston will ever be able to use his side again.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 3. -- Spring weather, with mild air and only light wind, has served admirably for outdoor pleasures. Golfers, who are practicing for the tournament on April 22, 23, and 24, have made the most of the fine days. The two cups which the Laurel-in-the-Pines will present are to be made from special designs by a prominent firm of silversmiths who have submitted designs to Mr. Porter during the last few days.

BERLIN, April 3. -- Prince Bismarck's birthday was generally greeted with congratulations and eulogistic articles. Him rheumatic attack, which has been very painful during the week, having partially subsided, the former Chancellor was able to spend part of the daytime out of bed and share in the family meals, his appetite remaining good.

The recent agitation upon the subject of so-called "trusts," and of legislative attempts to check or prevent combinations of capital, has directed attention more sharply than ever before to the fact that the union of labor is not different in principle or in motive from the union of capital and is quite as apt to lead to abuse of the power of combination.
The Knickerbocker Athletic Club's team won the team championship in the cross-country race, run off under the auspices of the New York Athletic Club, yesterday afternoon at Morris Park.
The crisp, invigorating weather of the past fortnight has had visible effect in athletic circles, and candidates in the college teams have commenced their outdoor work with great activity.

ALBANY, April 2. -- By an amendment to the Brackett bill which was tacked on the other day the salary of each Railroad Commissioner is to be $8,000 a year instead of $5,000, as was proposed by Mr. Brackett when he introduced the bill two months ago.

John Howley, through his attorneys, Stern Rushmore, of 40 Wall Street, yesterday obtained from Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, an order to show cause why an injunction pendente lite should not issue enjoining the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of New York from issuing stock policies, or any other policies, other than those issued in the standard form prescribed by law.

PARIS, March 18. -- Neither the Eastern question, nor the loss of the transatlantic liner, of which the shocking details have just reached us, nor the Corbett and Fitzsimmons fight has roused anything like so much sensation as the duel on Wednesday between Chevalier Pini and M. Thomeguex, of which all Paris has been talking for the past week.

People interested in seeing everything new in this age of scientific development will surely want to pay a visit to the fourth annual exhibition of the New York Academy of Sciences, which opens in the American Museum of Natural History, Eighty-first Street and Columbus Avenue, to-morrow.

CANEA, Island of Crete, April 3. -- Admiral Canevaro, the Italian Admiral in command of the fleets of the powers, authorized the insurgents and their families to quit the Akrotiri Peninsula and proceed inland. After he had done so a party of armed Bashi-Bazouks attempted to prevent the departure of the insurgents, and a force of international troops was dispatched to disarm the Bashi-Bazouks.

It is practically decided that the Ladies' Club, which will give up the lease of its present quarters, at 28 East Twenty-second Street, on the 1st of May, will be reorganized in the Fall. A house will then be taken further up town, probably about Thirty-fourth Street, and the club will be continued.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- There was a brief session of the House to-day, followed by an adjournment to next Wednesday, in pursuance of the policy which has been determined upon. The only business transacted was the adoption of the Senate resolution providing for chartering a vessel to carry donations of food to the famine sufferers of India.
NEW ORLEANS, April 3. -- This was the sixth and last day of the New Louisiana Jockey Club's Spring meeting. Weather rainy; track heavy.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- It has come to the knowledge of the State Department that Gen. Julio Sanguily is now at Jacksonville, Fla., and that his followers have given out the impression that the General is about to head an expedition to Cuba. Secretary Sherman was asked what the United States Government would do in case this impression were well founded.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 29. -- One of the funniest hunting stories related here recently was concerning the "cattle-whipping" of a big bear by John Capo and John Andrea on Anastasia Island, just across the bay from this city.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 3. -- Millard Spencer, a middle-aged man living in the Township of Hammony, Chautauqua County, last night attacked his step-daughter and a guest. Helen Van Sickle of Union City, Penn., with a butcher knife and stove poker. The two women were beaten into insensibility and so badly cut that it is feared they will die.

A nice question in ecclesiastical law has arisen in connection with the organization of the Greater New York, whose boundaries, as now fixed by the charter for the consolidated city, contain parts of two of the most important Episcopal dioceses of the country, namely, those of New York and Long Island.
-- Mr. I. Zangwill, who wrote the "Children of the Ghetto," is going to deliver a lecture at Jerusalem on Easter Sunday.

Serious weakness among the coal stocks and continuing apprehension over what may result from the Supreme Court's ruling in the Trans-Missouri case -- these have been the depressing factors in the stock market. Some developments have been encouraging. The Tariff bill is through the House -- in its first venture, at least; its progress in the Senate is likely to linger longer and be attended by less partisan reverence.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3. -- Collis P. Huntington's attention was called last night to a dispatch from Norfolk, Va., stating that a company of American and English capitalists were to join him in establishing a large ordnance and armor-plate factory at his shipbuilding yards at Newport News, Va.

It is rather odd that Mr. HENNIKER HEATON, M.P., who has made several visits to this country, should have had the notion of challenging the House of Representatives to play chess with the House of Commons. The fact that Mr. HEATON presumably knew the "chess strength" of the House of Representatives has caused chess players upon this side to reproach him with an anxiety for a "sure thing."

Golf was formally opened for the season yesterday on Staten Island, and from now until cold weather again puts a stop to the sport devotees of the game will have matches and club tournaments every week. The Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club, which laid out fine golf links last year, played the first of the large number of matches it has arranged for the season.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- Harrison K. Caner and his brother-in-law, Tristram C. Colket, two well-known society men of this city, made the distance from New York here on horseback to-day in 5 hours and 52 minutes, arriving at 2:32 P.M. The distance is over 100 miles, and the riders went over the old turnpike. The best previous horseback record to Philadelphia is said to be 12 hours and 17 minutes.

Miss Gladys Vanderbilt, the ten-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, with the aid of her cousins, the little daughters of the Rev. Mackay-Smith of St. John's Church, Washington, is editing a paper called "Spring Blossoms." Its object is to raise money for an Easter offering for the Sunday school of St. John's Church.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Additional applications for appointments to Presidential offices under the Treasury Department have been filed as follows:

Arrangements have been completed for the dedication of the memorial monument to be erected by the employes of the Manhattan Railway Company at the grave of the late Col. Hain, at Danville, Penn. The ceremony will take place Wednesday. May 26. As many of the employes as can be spared without interfering with the service on the elevated roads will go to Danville and be present at the exercises.

Even in the field the merely physical qualities developed by athletic games and sports are of little use. The troopers who rode into the Transvaal with Dr. Jameson and Sir John Willoughby were as pretty a set of men as any officer could wish to command. Nor is there any doubt that if they had been decently led they would have achieved their immediate object.

BERLIN, April 3. -- As lald bare by the Emigration bill w.hlch the Government has submitted to [he Reichstag, it will hereafter be the settled policy of the Government to direct the stream of German emigration elsewhere thau to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Those who do not have the opportunity to watch the Congress in its varying moods are apt to get the impression that it is by habit a very heavy body, constantly in the attitude of Poor Richard, with finger to chin to indicate deep thought and a sense of intense responsibility.

When Mayor Strong entered the Aldermanio Chamber yesterday afternoon to listen to further arguments in reference to the Greater New York charter he was confronted with a much smaller audience than on the two days preceding, although it was announced that the representatives of both sides would be heard.

The Seventh Regiment games are always interesting, and whenever the soldiers compete for prizes in athletic contests the armory is always crowded with the friends of the contestants. Last night the contests were more interesting than usual, because one of the star events of the evening was a mile relay race between teams from Yale and Princeton Universities.

No disposition is shown by the supporters of the bill providing for the construction of a "grand boulevard and concourse" in this city, under the direction of a special commission, to discuss that measure. On the contrary, efforts are being made to keep the matter as quiet as possible until after the bill passes the Senate.

The purchase of over forty city lots, in one block, at First Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, for the purpose of erecting model tenements, is a transaction that has an interest for the whole community. The City and Suburban Homes Company, which has acquired the land, is an association of rich and public-spirited citizens who not only know, but care, "how the other half lives."

The Greater New York Exposition of the House and Home was to have been opened last night at the Grand Central Palace, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, and was to continue until April 28. The proceeds were to be given to a home for unfortunate women.

In behalf of Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop's work in caring for poor people afflicted with cancer, Butler Davenport has organized a benefit performance to be given in the Fifth Avenue Theatre Tuesday afternoon, April 20. Mr. Miner has given the free use of the theatre.

VIENNA, April 3. -- Johannes Brahms, the well-known musical composer, is dead. He had been ill for a long time. He suffered from jaundice last Atumn, and went to carlsbad; but the cure was ineffective, and he intended to go there again this Summer. The disease developed, into cancer of the liver.

Nobody seems to know even approximately what is the total output of Bibles at the present time. There are reckoned to be about seventy centres of production and distribution, but what is the extent of their work there are no means of ascertaining. Of distributing associations there are four principal ones -- the British and Foreign Bible Society, the American Bible Society, the Scotch, and the Dutch.
THAT music, and especially good music, is an important factor in the religious services of to-day cannot be denied.

Attorney General Frederick Maynard of Michigan had a long conversation yesterday over the telephone with District Attorney Olcott. The matters discussed were the extradition of Anton M. Chrtstiansen and the indictments found against the Lenawee officers, Sheriff Ferguson and Assistant Prosecuting Attorney Sampson.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 3. -- The town of La Grange is deeply stirred over an elopement yesterday, in which Miss Annie Hunt, the stylish and attractive daughter of Mrs. John Hunt, a wealthy widow, and Charles Ferris, a farm laborer, were the principals.

ST. LOUIS, April 3. -- Two rough-looking men are in the East St. Louis Jail, suspected of the blowing open of the safe in the City Bank at Onelda last Monday night and securing a little over $3,000. They gave their names as Joseph Riley and William Powers, but to the name of Riley are attached the aliases of Shea and Ryan.

The principal event at the Broadway Athletic Club last night was the contest, scheduled for twenty rounds, catch weights, between "Tommy" West of New York and "Jim" Ryan of Australia. West won in the eighth round, with enough viciousness to satisfy even those of the 2,000 spectators who had bought the highest-priced seats.

PUTNEY, England, April 3. -- The fifty-fourth annual boat race between crews representing the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge was rowed to-day over the usual course, from Putney to Mortlake, a distance of four and one-quarter miles, and was won by Oxford, with barely two lengths to the credit of the Dark Blues. The time was 19:12.

Good Government Club A gave a special dinner last night, at the quarters of the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue, to discuss reform work in this city. There were about eighty members and guests present. Charles Howard Strong, President of Good Government Club A, presided.

EVERY one who has strolled up Irving Place is familiar with that quaint little brick dwelling that stands at the southwest corner of East Seventeenth Street. It is the most remarkable house the entire length of Irving Place -- noticeable for many reasons.
