I know an estimable lady who keeps a handsome bit of old cloisonne shut up in a cupboard, not because she does not admire it, but because she cannot get a second to match it, and would not think of placing a single vase on her mantelpiece, writes Benjamin A. Schade in John-a-Dreams.

A National Yacht Racing League, on which the different yacht unions and clubs have been working for some time, will doubtless be organized within a few weeks. A conference of delegates from the different racing unions and from some of the clubs that are not associated with any union has been arranged to be held May 1 at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

Under this title Mr. JAMES WARING of Santa Barbara, Cal., has proposed a scheme for the accumulation of capital for co-operative industry which has much ingenuity and within certain limits may prove effective.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 8. -- Grover Cleveland was entertained to-night by the members of the Nassau Club at an informal smoker. He was recently elected a member of the club, and the purpose of to-night's smoker was to give the ex-President an opportunity to meet his clubmates. Only members of the club were present, but of these there was a large attendance.

Mayor Strong, as Chairman of the Committee on Invitations for the Grant Monument dedication parade, made public yesterday a list of all persons who have up to this time accepted invitations to be guests of the city during the celebration. All the invitations have not yet been sent out, and all those that have been sent out have not been replied to.
From St. Petersburg to Vladivostok the tracks extend for 9,000 versts, more than 6,000 miles, and about eleven times the distance from Paris to Marseilles.

BERLIN, March 25. -- The drama is much used in Germany to edify and inspire with patriotism the lower classes of the populace, but it may be doubted whether those classes from which the social democracy draws its material go to see the patriotic plays at all. At the industrial exhibition last Summer, the theatre called Alt-Berlin began with a sensation that reeked with patriotism, blood, and glory.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 3. -- The Richardson Building, the largest in Chattanooga, was destroyed by fire early this morning. The watchman was slow in turning in an alarm, and when the fire companies arrived the building was a mass of flames.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, has issued a special river bulletin, in which he says:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 3. -- This was another fine day, and the "Regulars" and "Yannigans" of the Giants had another test of their strength on the diamond this afternoon. The game was one-sided, all in favor of the "Regulars." They opened the game with hard batting, and when the side had been retired had made 6 runs from the delivery of Miles Standish.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A gleam of encouragement to the Republicans in the Senate is discovered by those who learn that there is some chance that the silver Republicans and the Populists, who were inclined to make an alliance with the Democrats, have lost patience at the continued inability of the Democrats to contrive a plan of union which commands Populistic and silver Republican confidence.

In view of the attitude of legislators in matters relating to the interests of cyclists, it is not unlikely that concerted action will be taken ere long by the voting element to show their resentment. In New Jersey, Illinois, and Wisconsin, for instance, the wheelmen have had hard times in their effort to secure the adoption of baggage bills and acts looking toward the convenience of the riders and the general public as well.

THIS is a good time to write a little history. It is a good time because the active press agent has recently been using the words "many' and "years" indiscriminately. According to him it was "many years" since "Das Rheingold" had been performed in this city before last Monday evening, and it was also "many years" since the entire Nibelung tetralogy had been offered.

Representatives from twenty-three golf clubs in New York and the vicinity met Wednesday night at Delmonico's to discuss plans for forming a metropolitan union of golf clubs which should arrange dates for tournaments, so that important events would not conflict, and in other matters pertaining to the game to bring the clubs closer together in harmonious action.

LARISSA, Thessaly, March 2. -- This spot, which we reached last night, is a picturesque little town, in the extreme east of Thessaly, semi-Oriental in its aspect, and just now filled with the sound of drums, trumpets, and the shrill songs of soldiers. The reserve "classes," which have just been called out, pour into Larissa every day, greeted with the frantic applause of the residents.

The dramatic critic is little more than human; and his lot is not so desirable that I should advise young men to aspire to his calling, or rather to his particular branch of a calling which contains no sinecures and offers few prizes. His hours are long and irregular; his work is hard; and he is continually at war with his own moods, which must not be permitted to obscure his judgment.

The passengers who were to make the mid-winter voyage across the Atlantic gathered as promptly end chatted as cheerfully as if they were about to start for the mild Caribbean Sea. The only tears shed, until the very last moment, were shed by the friends who staid behind, these numbering eight of ten to each passenger.

MR. CLAY CLEMENT now comes into view. He has a superior "press agent" -- one who is superior to modesty and veracity -- who trumpeted his advent as loudly as possible; and he has one of those old-fashioned plays or substitutes for plays such as used to be written in the late sixties and early seventies for "variety actors" who risked their savings on the dramatic stage.

-- A corespondent of The Poughkeepsie News-Press enters a solemn protest against the publication of anecdotes about blacksmiths who, at the forge, conquered thirty languages; of shoemakers who, while pounding leather, came to be philosophers; and of milliners who, while their customers were at the glass trying on Spring hats, wrote volumes of first-rate poems.

GLASGOW, March 24. -- The Defender is evidently much wanted this side the Atlantic, no doubt with the expectation that the mud banks and tides of the Solent would provide the local knowledge to circumvent the American champion. A canard started by some American "chaffer" in the Riviera explained that the Defender was coming across the Atlantic, but would have to be strengthened for the voyage.

The patter of hoofs on the race tracks at Morris Park, Gravesend, and Sheepshead Bay, growing more pronounced day by day as the lingering winds of Winter are being gradually molded into warmth by the breezes of Spring, betoken that the lethargy that has attended racing and racing interests is at an end.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The Anglo-American arbitration treaty will be temporarily side-tracked in the Senate next week. This will be done for several reasons. The principal one, given by Senator Davis, who is in charge of the treaty, is that a, number of Senators who have remained in the city in constant attendance upon the executive sessions in the belief that a vote would be reached are anxious to get away for a few days.

The general strikes on the Columbia University buildings and on the public school buildings that were ordered by the Board of Walking Delegates for the steamfitters, who claimed the right to do the thermostatic work, and against the plumbers, who were doing the work, were declared off by the board yesterday afternoon, after it received the decision of Seth Low, the arbiter in the dispute.

The election of Count DE MUN to the French Academy at the same time with M. HANOTAUX is a curious illustration of the varying impulses that control the votes of the Immortals. Neither of these gentlemen has very distinguished literary talent, and it is highly unlikely that the writings of either would have won him the coveted honor.

From the industrial standpoint, the old plantation organization was a very perfect one. Great executive ability was required to manage it, and the lordly owner of these vast estates was far from the idle, sport-loving or politics-talking spendthrift that he is commonly supposed to have been. If he kept his property together and took care of all his dependents he was a busy, hard-worked man.

The first quarter of the year 1897, just ended, has had results not fully satisfactory to the whole business community. The general improvement, which, at the beginning of the year, seemed so near at hand has been delayed, and held back by factors which, for a time, have prevented the full restoration of public confidence, deterring business men from going ahead with their enterprises.

Sixth Avenue merchants, it is said, have decided to join those of Fourteenth Street and go before the Board of Aldermen with the request that no more peddling be allowed on those thoroughfares, particularly in the shopping district. The annoyance has become so bad that many of the storekeepers find it necessary to employ a day watchman on the street to prevent the peddlers blocking the doorways.

ALBANY, April 4. -- The amendments presented by Mr. Raines to the liquor tax law are bitterly opposed by one element of the party and strongly supported by another. The dividing line is largely geographical. The country members favor and the city members oppose them.

TUNICA, Miss., April 4. -- At 8 o'clock this morning the Flower Lake levee, where it crosses Yellow Bayou, gave way under the tremendous pressure of water. The crevasse widened rapidly, and is now 130 yards wide, through which the water is rushing with a deafening sound.

Within a few months, even weeks, two arrangements have been made as to the Trans-Siberian Railway which threaten, or promise, according to the standpoint of each interested party, to revolutionize not merely the politics, but the commerce of Eastern Asia and the Western Pacific.

CLEVELAND, April 4. -- Senator Hanna spent a quiet Sunday at home, receiving only a few intimate friends. This is the first time Mr. Hanna has been in Cleveland since he left for Washington to attend the inauguration and take his oath of office as successor to Sherman in the Senate.

A correspondent writes THE NEW YORK TIMES saying the recent summary on this page of the report of "loan" accounts made by the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company is not reliable -- that, in fact, he is informed that such a report does not exist, and that there is no Pennsylvania law requiring it.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Rear Admiral Francis M. Ramsay, holding the most important office in the naval service, that of Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, will give up his post to-morrow, retiring on account of age.

The plan recommended to the merchants of Fourteenth Street and of Sixth Avenue to protect themselves against obstruction of the sidewalks through a suit for injunction on the Board of Aldermen has this merit, that the power of the Legislature under the Constitution might thus be clearly determined.

The tour around the world of the American Theosophist Crusaders, who seceded from the parent society under the leadership of the late W.Q. Judge, wound up in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last night with the vocal collapse of its esoteric leader, Mr. Katherine A. Tingley.
LONDON, April 4. -- The Times will publish a dispatch from Vienna to-morrow, which says:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 4.-- John Penn Brock of Germantown, Penn., has just been elected Captain of the Yale freshman crew.

One of the objections which medical men and associations have made to the Greater New York charter is that it provides that the President of the Board of Health shall not be a physician. The provision is copied from the present Consolidation act, which provides for only one physician on the board, while the new charter provides for two.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 4. -- The cruiser Vesuvius prevented a Cuban expedition from leaving Fernandina last night, and captured the tug Alexander Jones of Wilmington, N.C.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4. -- James Harding, aged sixty years, member of the firm of Harding Dubois, wholesale shoe dealers of this city, was found dead in bed to-day in a house of bad repute. In the same room was an unconscious unknown woman, aged about forty years. The room was filled with gas from a burner, which had been turned on full head.

Assemblyman Jeremiah J. Sullivan and other lights of the Tenth Assembly District addressed a meeting of liquor dealers that had been called at Progress Hall, 28 Avenue A, yesterday afternoon, to protest against the proposed amendments to the Raines law, to tax clubs $800 a year.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church spoke again last night on "The Spiritual History of the Bible," and next Sunday he will deliver the last of his present series, taking for his subject, "The Bible and Christ."

August Belmont, who recently returned from a Western trip and a visit to his stud farm near Lexington, spent yesterday at the "Nursery," in Babylon, where his stable now is. He appeared much pleased with the promise his yearlings on the stud farm give for future speed.

Mr. Russell Sage, in his brand-new office, will command much Wall Street attention this week. Mr. Sage a few days ago was quoted by a Wall Street news agency as making some very suggestive remarks about Western Union dividends. Practically he was credited with announcing that the next dividend would be reduced.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- The members of Gov. Tanner's staff this afternoon decided to go to New York to participate in the dedication of the Grant monument. The Governor and his staff will leave Chicago for New York April 24.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., April 4. -- The Massachusetts Cattle Commissioners have been investigating the disposition of condemned cattle in this section, and as a result, it is stated, an alarming condition of affairs is being probed into.

Many possible events may come early this week to affect the course of the stock market. Some are cheerfully anticipated; others are nervously apprehended. More than lately has been the rule, the immediate market may depend on current news developments.
The following sales are announced for to-day at 111 Broadway:
Mr. Joseph E. Heimerdinger of the Stock Exchange house of H.P. Goldschmidt Co. says regarding bond market conditions:

TOPEKA, April 4. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. Percy Daniels has succeeded in interesting most of the leading Democrat-Populist statesmen of Kansas in an organization, the object of which is to operate a bureau of information concerning his scheme to tax "inordinate" wealth, and ultimately to secure an amendment to the Federal Constitution giving Congress the power to levy such a tax.

The Rev. Gustav Gottheil of Temple Emanu-El, Forty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, criticised the "ethical movement" and the ideas of the Society for Ethical Culture, as Felix Adler, its leader, has announced them.

An aristocratic Newfoundland dog, bearing license No. 35,659, was ignominiously cast into a cell in the East Fifty-first Street Police Station last evening. The dog had committed no other offense than that of having been lost by his owner. Incidentally, he made little Willie Foley of 235 East Fifty-first Street feel uncomfortable by following him about for a couple of hours.

Not the least attractions in Major James B. Pond's illustrated lecture at the Waldorf last evening on "Memories of the Lyceum; A Manager's Anecdotes," were the lecturer's sturdy personality, his enthusiasm for his subject, and his frank confidences concerning the innumerable speakers whom he has managed.

KINCAID, Kan., April 4. -- George Miller, who was recently released from an insane asylum, shot three women neighbors this afternoon, and was himself dangerously wounded while resisting arrest. The injured women are:

The great strides made by THE NEW YORK TIMES within the last few months form a notable chapter in American Journalism. During a period of general business depression THE NEW YORK TIMES has made steady progress, having within six months nearly doubled its circulation. This growth, while indeed gratifying, serves only to stimulate the management to greater efforts.

Cries for help attracted Policeman Holland, on duty in Eighth Avenue at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. As he turned the corner of Thirty-eighth Street toward Ninth Avenue Thomas Casey of 410 West Thirty-sixth Street ran almost into his arms.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 4. -- The Journal de St. Petersburg (semi-official) says to-day:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 4. -- The annual report of the Princeton National Alumni Association sent out by Secretary William Libbey is now in the hands of all the alumni of Princeton. While the members of the National Alumni Association have no actual voice in directing the policy of the university, the annual recommendations are likely to have great weight in shaping the actions of the Board of Trustees, the real governing body of the institution.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 4. -- Mr. Terrell has again called upon the Porte to provide a military guard for the residences of the American ladies, and this fact was mentioned in the joint representations made yesterday.

The Central Labor Union talked a good deal about bills in the Legislature yesterday, and indorsed the bill providing that surface railroad employees should be worked only ten hours a day, with time for meals.
CANEA, Island of Crete, April 4. -- The actual work of disarming the Bashi Bazouks began early this morning, and has continued throughout the day.

There can be no reasonable doubt that Jesus Christ intended to found a society among men that should grow by soliciting the adhesion of all mankind, or that He intended to endow it with all the powers of organic social life. It was only natural that the transforming spirit of the new religion should first show itself in the family, the nucleus of all social life.

Over 1,000 invitations have been issued by the Union League Club to its reception in honor of President McKinley and Vice President Hobart after the ceremonies of dedication of the Grant Monument on April 27.

As the time draws near for the hearing of the case of the Joint Traffic Association before the Supreme Court, a certain number of railroad men are frankly saying that they should prefer an adverse decision in the line of that in the trans-Missouri case. It would clear the air, permit them to know where they stand, and afford a basis for future policy.

The efforts of the young German Kaiser to erect his grandfather into a national hero and saint bring up the question once more whether, in his character, the strongest point is sentimentality or calculation. Germans are likely to say sentimentality; Americans and British, calculation.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 4. -- The Rev. Dr. George F. Pentecost, who recently came here from London, preached his first sermon to-day as the pastor of the First Presbyterian Church. There was a large attendance in the church, and the pulpit was handsomely decorated with lilies and other flowers.

The fine new docks that are to be built by the city for a third of a mile above Eleventh Street on the North River will, according to present plans, add largely to the facilities for handling foreign commerce, especially through the established and extensive transatlantic lines. No one doubts that they should be constructed and disposed of in such manner as will be of the greatest service to the general interests of the city.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., April 4. -- The forest fires in the surrounding mountains are spreading at an alarming rate. All efforts to check the flames have proved futile, and unless a heavy rain sets in many thousands of acres of valuable timber will go up in smoke.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4. -- The Bay City Wheelmen to-day won the annual one-hundred-mile inter-club race. As this makes the third successive victory for the Bay Citys, the handsome silver trophy now becomes the property of that club. The annual relay race is the most important cycling event on the Pacific coast.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The foreign Embassies and legations in Washington are watching the progress of the Tariff bill with great care, as it materially affects all commercial nations. Reports are being forwarded to the various foreign offices, and these in turn are being made public abroad for the information of concerns shipping goods to the United States.

John Murray, twenty-five years old, living at 180 Prince Street, who is a hostler, went with his employer, Alexander Savage, a livery stable keeper on West Broadway, near Bleecker Street, yesterday to Pleasant Plain, at the southerly end of Staten Island, to get a horse which Savage had recently bought. They started from Pleasant Plain about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, Murray leading the horse from the wagon.

If an actual sale of the Madison Square Garden property is made under the option given by the stockholders' meeting on Saturday, its present owners will incur a loss not quite so serious as they have feared. The Garden stands upon their books at $2,600,000. The holder of the option proposes to pay $12.50 per share, or $250,000 for the 20,000 shares, and to assume the bonded debt of $2,100,000.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Bankruptcy bill has first place on the Senate programme this week, but it will give way to the appropriation bills after Tuesday if the Committee on Appropriations shall report them then, as is expected, and urge consideration of its reports.

ATHENS, April 5. -- All the preparations for the celebration to-morrow of the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence in 1821 have been completed. An important public meeting will be held here to protest against the action of the powers toward Greece, and pledge support to the Greek Government in any action it may think fit to take in the premises.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- "The Mysteious Mr. Bugle," a new farce comedy in three acts, by Madeline Lucetto Ryley, was given its first metropolitan production here to-night. It was well-received by a large audience. Annie Russell, on whom the burden of the plot falls, Joseph Holland, and Guy Standing take the principal parts. There is a flow of harmless merriment throughout the play, and the situations dovetail into each other nicely.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church, delivered an address last evening before the Jewish Alliance, in the Assembly Hall of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, on the occasion of the alliance's closing entertainment of the season. The hall was filled with an audience in which ladies largely predominated.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 5. -- The election in Cincinnati to-day was for Mayor and other city officers and members of the Board of Legislation. The Republican ticket was headed by Levi C. Goodale for Mayor, and the Democratic ticket by Gustave Tafel, the latter being elected by a plurality of 7,320.

Some satisfactory news to cyclists was received by President Potter of the League of American Wheelmen yesterday, when he got a dispatch from Chief Consul Samuel A. Boyle of the Pennsylvania Division, informing him that the Pennsylvania Railroad had just concluded arrangements to carry bicycles without charge on all its lines.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The proposed amendments to the liquor-tax law, to exempt bona fide clubs and tax the alleged "fake" clubs, are complete, and Senator Ford and Assemblyman Allds are confident that they will attain the end sought if they are adopted.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 5. -- In the Senate to-night the first matter of importance to be disposed of was the General Appropriation bill as agreed to by the conference committee and as it passed the Assembly.

LONDON, April 5. -- Replying to a question in the House of Commons as to the negotiations said to be in progress between Greece and Turkey for a settlement of the Cretan question, Mr. Curzon said the Government had not heard of any direct negotiations between Turkey and Greece on the subject of Crete.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Until the President has appointed an Assistant Secretary of the Navy it is evident that there will not be peace of mind in the New York delegation. The talk is still about Mr. Roosevelt and the attitude of Mr. Platt. The Senator is still in about the same frame of mind concerning Mr. Roosevelt that he was described as being in a day or two ago.

John O. Sheehan was at his Broadway office yesterday, having returned Sunday night from his trip to Washington and Fort Monroe. During the day almost all of the Tammany district leaders called upon him, but their talk was informal.

Mr. B. Fish, executor of the P.T. Barnum estate, has placed on view at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms a collection of 159 old and modern paintings, some of which are the property of other estates than the Barnum, and which will be sold by auction on Thursday and Friday evenings next. The collection as a whole is a heterogeneous one, and comprises examples of all schools and times.

The Board of Trustees of Columbia University held a meeting in Hamilton Hall yesterday afternoon that lasted three hours. W.C. Schermerhorn presided. Other Trustees present were President Seth Low, the Rev. Dr. Dix, S.P. Nash, Charles A. Silliman, Gerard Beekman, Edward Mitchell, Bayard Cutting, John Crosby Brown, Dr. William H. Draper, the Rev. Dr. Vincent, John B. Pine, George G. Wheelock, H.H. Cammann, the Rev. Dr. Coe, Barelay Parsons, and Frederick Bronson.

ROME, April 5. -- There were large crowds present when Parliament opened. The King was accompanied by the crown Prince Vittorio Emanuele. Prince of Naples, and his Majesty's nephews, the Duke of Aosta, the Count of Turin, and the Duke of Abbruzzi, and by the Duke of Genoa, son of Princess Elizabeth, the King's aunt.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 5. -- Harry P. Delmar of Niagara Falls, N.Y., was arrested here to-day on information from Sheriff S.L. Todhunter of Springdale, Washington County, Ark., and held to await the arrival of an officer. The telegram stated simply that Delmar is wanted for a felony, the nature of it not being given.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Political managers are looking for a falling off of nearly 80,000 votes from the poll of last Fall. This will give a vote to-morrow of about 250,000. It is conceded to-night that of this Carter Harrison will poll 100,000; Sears, (Republican,) 90,000, with Hesing, (Citizens',) and Harlan, (Independent,) dividing the balance.

The proposition to introduce a bill in the Legislature which would enable the Sinking Fund Commissioners to secure the Madison Square Garden property for the city by condemnation proceedings did not find much favor among the city officials yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Spring has come to Washington, and all over the city the early flowering shrubs are in bloom, the peach trees are following them closely, and the lawn mowers will soon be needed on the White House lawns and the Government reservations. There is no city in the northern part of the country where the Spring is lovelier than it is right here.

Yesterday's stock market was narrow, but in one part of it there was excitement, and through much the greater part of it weakness. Quotations as a rule did not decline largely, but there was a sagging tendency, without show of resiliency. Conspicuous stocks seemed to go down of their own weight.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The situation in the flooded Mississippi district is being inquired into by the President, and to-day the Arkansas Congressional delegation, headed by Senator Jones, called upon Mr. McKinley to urge upon him the advisability of sending a special message to Congress urging appropriate legislation for the relief of the flood sufferers.
E. Stern, a retired business man, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by jumping into the East River from the ferryboat Bowery Bay.

The two-masted schooner Mad Anthony of Verplancks, N.Y., was wrecked in the dense fog on the North River at 2:45 o'clock yesterday morning, in a collision with the Cornell Steamboat Company's stakeboat Isaac M. North, anchored off Forty-second Street.

There is to be an exciting municipal election in Chicago to-day. There are four candidates for Mayor, and according to signed statements published in The Times-Herald each is confident of being elected. It must be that some of them Will be disappointed.

Olga Nethersole, whose engagement at the Garden Theatre will end this week, presented there last night a sombre domestic drama, in three acts, from the Italian of Giuseppe Giacosa by "G.A. Greene," called "The Wife of Scarli." This is simple, modern, and, if not remarkably ingenious, at least in the first and second acts so natural and reasonable that the thoughtful playgoer must find it worth while.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 5. -- The break at Flower Lake, which occurred yesterday morning, has grown from a dozen feet in length to a thousand. This was the condition of the crevasse this afternoon at 4 o'clock.
The Bureau of Elections has completed the work of redistricting the city, and if the tentative scheme laid out be approved by the Police Board the annual saving will exceed $75,000.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The advocates of the bill for the Grand Concourse and Boulevard in Northern New York City are puzzled as to what course to take with that measure, in view of the request made by Gen. Henry L. Burnett that his name be taken from the list of Commissioners named in the bill.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 5. -- The annual Teachers' Institute of Westchester County, which is to last five days, commenced at Oakside school to-day Under favorable auspices. At 4 o'clock 253 teachers had registered. Others are constantly arriving, and it is expected by to-morrow morning 300 will have reported.

Messrs. Hermann Boker Co., importers of steel, iron and metals, guns, cutlery, , like all business men affected by tariff duties, have studied the Dingley Tariff bill. They find that the provisions of that bill relating to their business are calculated to lessen or prohibit importations and so reduce the revenues.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The resolution introduced in the Senate by Senator Allen protesting against the drumhead court-martial of Gen. Rivera, the Cuban leader, was passed to-day by a vote of 44 to 0, after a spirited debate. Mr. Allen called it up shortly after the opening hour, and urged its immediate adoption.

Mayor Strong gave the last of the hearings at the City Hall yesterday on the question of his approval or disapproval of the charter. Sessions had been promised to-day and to-morrow, but it was evident from the decrease of interest after the hearing last Friday that the proceedings would soon come to an end.

CHELSEA, Mass., April 5. -- A body found in the river here yesterday is that of Charles H. Overbeck of New York. Insurance papers and cards in his pockets show that he was in the grocery business with his brother at 441 Grand Street and 561 Columbus Avenue. About $90 in bills was also found in his pockets.

The sale at auction of the library of the late Edward Hale Blerstadt, Treasurer of the Grolier Club, consisting of about 3,500 volumes, began yesterday at the rooms of Bangs Co., 91 Fifth Avenue. Two weeks will be given to the sale. The dates for the second week's auction have not as yet been announced.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 5. -- Assemblyman Scherer, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly, has agreed to give a hearing on Wednesday next on Mr. Trainor's bill to create the State of Manhattan from the territory comprising the Greater City of New York.

NEWARK, N.J., April 5. -- Caledonian Hall, which had a seating capacity of over ten thousand, and which during its existence was used for most of the large gatherings of this city, was destroyed by fire early this morning. The great wooden building, which was about 200 feet long, 200 feet wide, and three stories high, burned with surprising rapidity.
MILFORD, N.H., April 5. -- The Milford Savings Bank holds $5,000 in stock of the Globe Savings Bank of Chicago. The local bank was enjoined from paying out deposits some time ago.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- In the Senate to-day Senator Lindsay of Kentucky made an elaborate speech in advocacy of the Torrey Bankruptcy bill. He said, in part:

HAVANA, April 5. -- Lieut. Col. Lacoste has defeated a party of insurgents at Santiago de Vegas, this province, killing seventeen of the enemy, and afterward capturing the camp of Juan Delgado, at Santa Barbara.
The Park Board refused yesterday to allow the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York to hold a road race on Riverside Drive.

After repeated efforts on the part of a number of trained nurses of this city to organize a society for mutual protection, the Trained Nurses' Protective Association came into existence yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting held at the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

In view of the prospect of consolidation under the Greater New York charter, there has been a singular rivalry between representatives of Brooklyn and New York at Albany to get authority for public improvements to be provided for by an issue of bonds.

Plans for the erection of two eighteen-story hotels in the Murray Hill district were filed Saturday and yesterday. One is to be built at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and East Forty-fourth Street, by the estate of Paran Stevens, and the other on West Thirty-fourth Street, next to the Manhattan Clubhouse, near Fifth Avenue, and opposite the Hotel Astoria, by Henry Clews.
J. Kensett Olyphant has sold to Mrs. Horace Chittenden 62 East Fifty-fourth Street, a four-story and basement brownstone-front dwelling, 17 by 55 by 100.5.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- President McKinley had hosts of callers to-day. The National Forestry Commission, headed by Arnold Hague and Prof. Brewer of Yale, which was summoned here to consult with the President regarding the revocation of the order of Mr. Cleveland setting aside twenty-one forest reservations in the West, were received shortly before noon, and remained with Mr. McKinley some time discussing the matter.

The general strikes on the Columbia University buildings and on two public school buildings came to an end yesterday morning, and all the men with the exception of the steamfitters, who have a general strike of their own in the shops of their employers, returned to work.

Some of the announcements that have been made of the operatic outlook for next season are at least exaggerated and premature. The fact seems to be that the owners of the Opera House require no mor than they have required heretofore, but that the managers are unable to give assurance of as much.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- According to the best information about the Tariff bill, very slow progress is being made by the Senate in the study of the work of the House, and none whatever toward revising it to meet the views of the Republicans of the Finance Committee. The committee meetings are held daily, morning and night, and to-night it is stated that the reading of the bill is not yet completed.

The Committee on Plan and Scope of the Grant monument dedication services met yesterday afternoon in the Mayor's office. The Committee on Invitations reported that it had approved the plans adopted by the Committee on Platforms and Decorations with respect to seating accommodations for the multitudes who desire to witness the ceremonies at the tomb.

While the American people are usually loud in denunciation of merely imaginary trespasses on their liberties, they are strangely indifferent to real ones. An act of the extremest character excites only a momentary consideration, mostly the effect of the sense of novelty, and is forgotten before a week's end.

Mrs. Fanny Bean Carrere insisted upon conducting her own case yesterday against R.G. Dun, to recover $350, which, she alleges, the head of the commercial agency owes her husband, William Carrere, who has assigned the debt to her. The case was tried before Justice McCarthy and a jury in Part II. of the City Court.

Sorosis yesterday held its first meeting with the new President, Mrs. Mary Dame Hall, in the chair. If Mrs. Hall felt that she was a novice in the position she die not show it, and the meeting proceeded from the opening to "The Star-Spangled Banner," sung at the close by the members themselves, without a ripple to disturb its peacefulness.

ALBANY, April 5. -- In the Assembly Senator Brush's bill to amend the election laws by providing that persons whose names are on the rolls of one political party, and who vote at a primary caucus or convention of another party, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, was on the calendar as a special order on third reading.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

The offices of the E.S. Dean Company, brokers in stock, grain, and provisions at 35 Broadway, have been closed up by Deputy Sheriff Lipsky on an attachment for $1,905 in favor of Theodore B. Thompson on assigned claims for money deposited with the company in September last by Frederick F., Joseph W.C., and Emma E. Seavey.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Senator Chandler of New Hampshire to-day introduced in the Senate a bill in the nature of an amendment to Senator Foraker's Railroad Pooling bill. It is entitled:

The full fruits of Tammany's acceptance of BRYAN'S platform and principles were 141,275 for JACOB E. BAUSCH, the labor men's candidate for Coroner, and an alliance with some of the most unmanageable political organizations known to our history. There was no other reward, actual or contingent.

BOSTON, April 5. -- Messrs. Schoeffel and Grau, who are in this city, stated today that the dispatch from New York this morning, announcing that a renewal of the Metropolitan Opera House lease had been denied his firm, took them entirely by surprise. A meeting of the stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House, it was said, is to be held in New York to-morrow.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 5. -- As soon as it was known yesterday that the Fernandina attempt to carry arms to the Bermuda had failed, the indefatigable filibusters set to work to make connections at once in another direction. The arms were hastily loaded into a car at Fernandina, almost under the nose of the United States officials, and rushed over to Trout Creek bridge, midway between this city and Fernandina.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Quite a flurry in the Senate was occasioned by a resolution from the new Senator from South Carolina, Mr. Earle, providing that at a stated hour to-morrow the Senate shall proceed "to reorganize the committees and fill all vacancies thereon."

CHICAGO, April 6. -- Despondent because his rich young wife had left him, D.G. Porter attempted to end his life by drinking an ounce of laudanum in the barroom of the Saratoga Hotel at 9:30 o'clock last night. It is thought he will recover.

Mayor Strong will give a public hearing on Assemblyman Finn's amended stoop-line bill at 1:30 to-morrow afternoon. A number of business organizations will be represented at the hearing, among them the Real Estate Exchange, the Board of Trade and Transportation, the Retail Grocers' Union, the United Business Men's Association, and the City Improvement Society. The meeting will be open to all who wish to be heard either for or against the bill.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 7. -- Since the Republican Party caucused upon the passage of the present liquor-tax law there has not been so protracted a caucus or conference as that which occurred last night, when the proposed amendments taxing clubs and remodeling the hotel feature were considered. It was only yesterday morning determined to hold a caucus, and the leaders sent word quietly to all Republican Senators to be present.

LONDON, April 6. -- The Parliamentary committee inquiring into the Transvaal raid was again in session to-day. Among those present were Lord Chelmsford, Baron Loch, formerly High Commissioner of South Africa; Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, and Sir William Vernon Harcourt, the Liberal leader in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- There is not much politics, but there is some, in the appointment of Capt. Crowninshield to be Chief of the Bureau of Navigation. Several men are disappointed. Capt. Robley D. Evans, who aspired to the place, will be disappointed. His defeat is attributed largely to the influence of Senator Chandler.

LONDON, April 6. -- Attention was called in the House of Commons to-day, by Henry Seton-Karr, Conservative, to the inadequate production of food supplies in the United Kingdom, in relation to its large and increasing population. Mr. Seton-Karr said the matter deserved the serious attention of the Government.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 6. -- In the Senate to-day Senator Gibson of Erie presented a resolution asking an investigation by a committee of the relations existing between the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey. The resolution follows:

ALBANY, April 6. -- C.A.R. Moore, counsel to the City Board of Health of Brooklyn, to-day submitted to the State Board of Health two reports concerning the water supply of Brooklyn. These reports have also been submitted to the Mayor and the Commissioner of City Works of that city. These are a special report of the Rockville Laboratory investigation and another on the repots submitted by Dr. Z. Taylor Emery, Commissioner of Health.

The Trans-Missouri Freight Association is hopeful of obtaining an opportunity during the present session of the Supreme Court to present further argument in the matter of the anti-trust decision of that tribunal which was recently given. With a view to obtaining a rehearing, ex-Judge John F. Dillon, counsel of the association, is preparing a petition, and it will probably be laid before the court in a few days.

HAVANA, April 6. -- It is understood that Senor Jose Porrua, who in February last succeeded Gen. Suarez Valdez as Civil Governor of Havana and of Western Cuba, has tendered his resignation by cable to Premier Canovas, forwarding by mail the reasons for the act. Captain General Weyler is said to oppose the resignation, because he considers Senor Porrua's presence in the island expedient for the time.

The theatre manager who, at the very fag end of a season not too richly profitable to any impresario, lavishes money and care upon such a magnificent stage production as that of "The Tempest," seen at Daly's last evening, is far removed from the grasping speculators who generally usurp the theatre manager's functions nowadays, and deserves the largest share of esteem this community can spare for one who diligently labors for its artistic welfare.
WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

Mrs. F. Bean Carrere, as sometimes she signs herself, failed to conduct her own action against R.G. Dun to success. The case did not go to the jury. Judge McCarthy dismissed it yesterday because no evidence to prove the essential point had been submitted. Mrs. Carrere declared that she would appeal. Her husband, William Carrere, supported her.

The second annual dinner of the Booksellers' League was enjoyed at the St. Denis Hotel last evening. Covers were laid for about 150 persons. There was music before the cigars and speeches. A. Growall presided in the absence of J.N. Wing, the President. C.E. Butler and Frederick D. Lacy were the committee in charge.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 6. -- The second day of the Teachers' Institute of Westchester County was quite as successful as the first. Morning and afternoon sessions were well attended, and there were many visitors from the village.

ATHENS, April 6. -- The greatest enthusiasm was manifested here to-day during the fetes organized to celebrate the anniversary of the declaration in 1821 of the independence of Greece from Turkish rule. The King and the members of the royal family here, accompanied by the Ministers and all the high Court and other officials of Athens, attended the religious ceremonies at the Cathedral, where a solemn Te Deum was sung.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The adoption of a vigorous policy to secure from the Turkish Government a settlement of the claims preferred by the United States on account of the destruction of the American missionary property and outrages to American missionaries committed during the uprising against the Armenians in the Fall of 1895 is being considered by the new Administration, and probably will be put into operation soon.
Major Gen. Grenville M. Dodge, Grand Marshal, yesterday announced the formation and route of the Grant Monument inaugural parade as follows:

Health Commissioner Emery of Brooklyn has submitted to Mayor Wurster a report showing in detail the filthy condition of the sources of Brooklyn's water supply. The report is accompanied by another, showing the work carried on at the Biological and Chemical Laboratory at Rockville Centre, which lately has had much to do with reporting nuisances along the streams and reservoirs of Queens County.
ALBANY, April 6. -- The manifest desire to hurry the work during the closing days of the session was evident this morning in the Assembly, the calendar being taken up immediately after the prayer.

The plan of Australasian federation recently adopted by the convention which has been sitting for some weeks at Adelaide, South Australia, is the result of efforts dating back to 1886. In that year a Federal Council was instituted under an act of Parliament for the five colonies in Australia, with New Zealand, Tasmania, and Fiji.

Improvements for cyclists in this city are scheduled on a large scale by the New York Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen. A majority of the changes relate to the thoroughfares, and it is very likely that the Department of Public Works will see the desirability of the proposed alterations and grant the requests of the wheelmen.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 6. -- Dr. W.G. Hunter received a majority of the votes cast in the joint session to-day, but the bolting Republicans and Blackburn Democrats demanded a recapitulation and call of absentees. In the ballot to verify the vote the result was: Hunter, 59; Blackburn, 42; Martin, 12; Boyle, 5; Stone, 1; present, 122; necessary to a choice, 62.

It is said to have been Mr. CHAUNCEY DEPEW who laid down, as the first condition of success in after-dinner speaking, the necessity of "hanging somebody's hide on the fence." Whether the attribution of this sentiment to Mr. DEPEW is correct or not, there can be no doubt that a good many after-dinner speakers and some editors habitually act upon it.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 6. -- At a conference of the general officers of the National Guard this afternoon it was decided that a provisional brigade be sent to New York to attend the unveiling of the Grant Monument. This brigade likely will be composed of five or six regiments, selected from the three brigades, together with a battery, on troop, and a portion of the naval reserves.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 6. -- The deep mystery surrounding the robberies committed in the rooms of Smith College girls during the past three or four weeks was cleared up to-day. Miss Caroline Belle Nealley, a graduate of the college last June, was arrested this morning in West Street by Chief of Police Maynard while she was on one of her customary thieving tours of the houses where Smith students room.
CHICAGO, April 6. -- The Mayoralty election to-day resulted in a decisive victory for the Democratic Party, its candidate, Carter Harrison, having more votes than all the other candidates combined.

-- "We always thought," says The Greensboro (Ala.) Watchman, "that those who pay the fiddler were entitled to the kind of tune they desired. But such was not the case with a large majority who paid their dollar to hear Remenyi play the fiddle in Greensboro last week. Most of the tunes he played were above the comprehension of the average citizen."

The suit of Bernard Schulick against Eugene V.N. Bissell to recover $566 for dresses and trimmings furnished the defendant's wife in the Spring of 1896 was tried before Justice McCarthy and a jury in Part II, of the City Court yesterday. When the court adjourned the jury had reached no decision on the question of what clothing is necessary for a woman whose husband claims an income of $3,500 a year.

At the monthly meeting yesterday of the Board of Directors of the Blooming Grove Park Association of Pike County, Penn., at the office of its President, Nathaniel S. Smith, the most encouraging reports were made on the operations and output of its hatcheries.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Iowa's representative in the list of foreign missions is likely to be Major E.H. Conger, who probably will go to Brazil. His appointment has not been decided upon, but the President has intimated to other aspirants that the Brazilian representative is to be from Iowa.

HAVANA, April 6. -- A special Commissioner will be sent to Arroya Blanco to receive the personal effects of Mr. Crosby, the correspondent of The Chicago Record, and to inquire as to the expediency of removing the body.
The fog which returned to mantle the city and waters of the harbor on Monday night lasted until after daylight yesterday morning, and a number of mishaps occurred before it lifted.

It is really unfortunate that the Superintendent of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company should have found himself under the necessity of discharging a number of women employed by that corporation as ticket sellers and of announcing that he meant to discharge many more.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6. -- Charles Morton, a negro, twenty years of age, of Jamesburg, was captured in that place last night, and had a narrow escape from lynching before he was brought to the county jail in this place.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- William J. Bryan, the late Democratic candidate for President, called, with Attorney General Smythe of Nebraska and Representative McMillin of Tennessee, to pay his respects to his successful rival. They were immediately ushered into Mr. McKinley's private office.

The Senate will have to wait at least three weeks for a chance to consider the Tariff bill. Why not pass the Bankruptcy bill in the interval and send it back to the House, where it has already once been approved?

Slawson Hobbs have sold for Mrs. Lily W., widow of Charles T. Barney, to a Mr. Lewis, the four-story brick and stone dwelling 159 West Seventy-fourth Street, 21.8 by about 56, and extension, by 102.2.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6. -- The International Trust Company of Massachusetts, as trustee of the Cleveland and Canton Railroad Company, to-day filed a cross bill, by leave, in the United States court against the Cleveland and Canton Railroad Company and the Cleveland, Canton and Southern Railroad Company, the Waynesburg and Canton Railroad Company, and the Chagrin Falls and Northern Railroad Company to foreclose certain mortgages.

ALBANY, April 6. -- Senators Ford and Stranahan had a heated dialogue at a meeting of the Senate Cities Committee to-day over Mr. Ford's bill which proposes to extend One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street through St. Nicholas Park, in New York City. Senator Ford charged that the committee was discriminating against his measures.

A French bulldog club was organized at a meeting held by dog fanciers at Delmonico's Monday evening. Messrs. H. G. Riggs, G.M. Phelps, J. L. Kernochan, Walter W. Watrous, J. R. Buchanan, F. G. Davis, and G. L. Hepton met a few days ago for the purpose of forming such a club and establishing a definite type of the breed.

We can hardly believe that Mr. GAGE has much confidence in the practical effect of the ambiguous circular he has sent out to Collectors. We cannot, indeed, resist a feeling of sympathy for a business man in public office forced to attach his name to an order so unbusinesslike and likely to be so ludicrously ineffectual.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- In making the appointment of Theodore Roosevelt for Assistant Secretary of the Navy the President has disregarded the advice of Mr. Platt. Mr. Platt did not devote himself to getting the place for some other man, but he represented to the President the inadvisability, from his point of view, of appointing Mr. Roosevelt.
ALBANY, April 6. -- Gov. Black's forestry measure, which appropriates $1,000,000 for acquiring lands in the Adirondacks, passed the Senate -- 42 to 4 -- after a hard contest.

Compared with New Yorkers, people in Brooklyn have paid little attention to the hearings before their Mayor on the Greater New York charter. Three out of four men who attended the final hearing before Mayor Wurster yesterday spoke in favor of it. Brooklyn people think that the Mayor will sign the charter, and the line of questions he has put to gentlemen who have appeared before him gives foundation for such an assumption.

Ex-President Cleveland has accepted an invitation to attend the annual dinner of the Reform Club, which will be held at the Waldorf on the evening of Saturday, April 24. Nearly all of the members of President Cleveland's Cabinet have also accepted invitations. Commissioner Seth Sprague Terry, Chairman of the sub-Committee on Arrangements of the Dinner Committee, said last night that the speakers would include ex-President Cleveland, ex-Secretary Carlisle, ex-Secretary Wilson, and ex-Secretary Carl Schurz.

The second day's sale at auction of the library of the late Edward Hale Bierstadt was conducted at Bangs Co.'s, 91 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. A number of publishers and collectors were present. Following is a list of the principal sales made:
LONDON, April 6. -- The Athens correspondent of The Daily Chronicle will say to-morrow:

District Attorney Olcott and Assistant District Attorney Lindsay denied last evening that any step had been taken to bring the transactions of the E.S. Dean Company of 35 Broadway to the attention of the Grand Jury. No one, they said, had called at the District Attorney's office with a complaint against the firm, whose office property was found to have been removed on Saturday when a Deputy Sheriff went to execute a writ of attachment.

ALBANY, April 7. -- A committee from the First Irish Volunteers of New York City, headed by Col. James Moran, and accompanied by Senators Pavey and Grady, waited on Gov. Black to-day and asked that the organization have a place in the parade connected with the dedication of the tomb of Gen. Grant.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- The Mayoralty vote complete is as follows: Carter H. Harrison, (Dem.,) 144.828; J.M. Harlan, (Ind.,) 67,072; N.C. Sears, (Rep.,) 57,566; W. Hesing, (Business Administration,) 15,116; John Glembeck, (Soc.-Lab.,) 1,226; H.L. Parmlee, (Proh.,) 852; J.I. Pearce, Jr., (Ind.,) 686; F. Howard Collier, (Ind.,) 88. Total, 287,434.
ALBANY, April 7. -- The following bills of interest to New York, Brooklyn, and vicinity passed the Assembly to-day:

LONDON, April 7. -- Mr. John K.D. Wingfield-Digby, Conservative member for the North Division of Dorsetshire, moved the second reading of the Agricultural Marks bill to-day in the House of Commons. This is a drastic measure intended to prevent the fraudulent sale of foreign meat and cheese as British products.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A meeting of representatives of the shipping interest was held to-day in the room of the Senate Committee on Commerce. Among those present were C.A. Griscom, W.P. Clyde, T.W. Hyde, A.R. Smith, C.H. Cramp, Samuel S. Sewall, H.P. Booth, E. Bliss, Aaron Vanderbilt, D.C. Mink, F.J. Firth, C.H. Keep, ex-Senator G.F. Edmunds, and Senators Frye, Elkins, Hanna, and Perkins. Mr. Griscom presided.
This is from The Boston Herald:

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Senator Chandler to-day authorized the statement that the passage of the Tariff bill might be endangered if the pressure for high duties continues. "This pressure is enormous from all parts of the country," he said, "and it is so strong there is some danger that it will be yielded to.
Yesterday was lively at both private sale and at auction in the real estate field.

When the fishing smack Becker of the fleet of L.W. Wright Co. of 105 Fulton Market pulled into her slip yesterday morning, Capt. Young and his crew were well-nigh exhausted because of the attention they were obliged to pay to a passenger that was unwillingly taken aboard forty miles off the Highlands to the southeastward.

That the musical public of this city has neared the end of its capacity for the current season has probably received no more forcible demonstration than that offered by the size of the audience which attended Mme. Lilli Lehmann's farewell song recital at the Waldorf last night. The audience room was not packed, and that was a significant condition.
NEWPORT, Ky., April 7. -- The Domino Stakes for two-year-old colts was won to-day by Bauer Co.'s two-year-old colt Van Antwerp, at 4 to 1. Summaries:
Stock market dull and irregular.
The fifty-seven passengers on board the Red Star Line steamer Friesland, Capt. Nickels, which arrived yesterday from Antwerp, had stirring tales to tell of their voyage.

ATHENS, April 7.-It is rumored here that Russia has made a proposal to the effect that if Greece will consent to withdraw her troops from the Island of Crete Russia -will agree to obtain from Turkey the withdrawal of the Turkish troops from. Crete so soon as the Greek evacuation is completed, and that Russia will further promise that Prince George of Greece shall be sent, as a Greek Prince, to organize the Cretan gendarmerie.
ALBANY, April 8. -- The Republican Senators, in caucus at 1 o'clock this morning, decided to impose a liquor tax on all clubs.

BOSTON, April 7. -- The battleship Iowa, the last of the premium built battleships of the navy, earned to-day for her builders, William Cramp Sons of Philadelphia, $200,000, by making an average of seventeen even knots an hour over the regular Government course, off the Massachusetts coast, in the four hours' speed trial required under the contract.

Senator Caffery of Louisiana has received a letter from the New Orleans Board of Trade, in which that body requests him to use his vote and influence to secure the passage of the Dingley Tariff bill. From Senator Caffery's reply, addressed to the President of the board, THE TIMES makes the following extract:

At the Custom House yesterday $498,944.78 was received for duties. For withdrawals, $136,000 was paid. Straight import duties for sugar amounted to $105,000. There were 343 withdrawal and 452 import entries.

The "Festival of Holidays" in aid of the Riverside Day Nursery, and celebrating the tenth anniversary of the founding of the nursery, was opened yesterday at the Leslie Rooms, Boulevard and West Eighty-third Street, and was greeted with a large patronage during the hours from 2 to 11, in which it was held.

The extension of Riverside Drive by a viaduct across the Manhattan Valley to a junction with the Boulevard Lafayette at One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street is now practically assured through legislation at Albany. No other public work now in contemplation could better serve the public interest or promote the public enjoyment.

President Roosevelt of the Board of Police Commissioners presided probably for the last time at yesterday's meeting of the board. Commissioner Andrews told the board he had a bundle of requisitions which Col. Grant, as Chairman of the Committee on Repairs and Supplies had refused to sign.

The Board of Education, at a meeting held yesterday, indorsed Superintendent Jasper's idea of establishing lunchrooms in the various public schools of the city to supply proper food to the children. The Committee on Instruction, to whom Superintendent Jasper's communication had been referred, made a report favoring the plan and offered the following resolution:

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission has notified most of the roads making up the Joint Traffic Association to forward to the commission by next Saturday full information about grain shipments and contracts and agreements in force between April 1, 1896, and March 1, 1897.

A Hindoo named Babee Sukhi, living at 315 West Forty-fifth Street, was bitten by a cobra yesterday afternoon in his room and may die. Sukhi has been in this country about three weeks. He is a well-educated-man, speaking English well, apparently has abundant wealth, and is supposed to be traveling for pleasure.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 7. -- Senator Cantor's Dollar Gas bill for New York City was defeated in the Senate, and the Senate passed the bill reducing the price at the rate of 5 cents per year until it is down to $1.

--- England is rapidly civilizing -- out of existence -- the tribes living back of Lagos, on the West Coast of Africa. Almost every steamer that reaches London brings the story of conflicts with the natives, in which, of course, the English forces are always successful. The last of these stories relates to a very characteristic little affair that took place last month.

HAVANA, April 7. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler arrived at Jucaro, Province of Puerto Principe, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, on board the Spanish gunboat Satelite. From that vessel he was landed in a boat at the Diego Velasquez wharf at 6 A.M. There he found Gen. Arolas, the latter's aide de camp, and the local authorities waiting to receive him.

A proposition was sent to the city authorities yesterday by H.J. Braker of 95 William Street for the purchase of the franchises of the Sixth and Eighth Avenue surface railroads. One million dollars is offered for each of the franchises, the sum to be paid in cash, and the franchises to be delivered direct to a corporation, so as to comply with the law in that respect.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7. -- Warrants were issued this evening for the arrest of Gens. Julio Sanguily and F. Lechusa, charging them with aiding and organizing a military expedition "against the peace and dignity of Spain."

Directors of the Staten Island Railway Company of the Baltimore and Ohio system elected yesterday are James J. Winants, Charles H. Bass, James M. Fitzgerald, William King, J. Frank Emmons, A. Horrmann, E.P. Goodwin, Charles F. Zentgraf, Frank H. Curry, C.H. White, L. Dejonge, Jr., K.P. Emmons, and George F. Kreischer.

We have frequent and saddening illustrations of the gullibility of mankind, but not often one quite so vivid as is furnished by the collapse of "the E.S. Dean Company," already noticed in our news columns. The "company" pretended to be brokers in stocks, grain, and provisions, although it had no representative in the Exchange of any of those objects of investment or speculation.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The President sent a special message to Congress to-day recommending that an appropriation be made for the relief of flood sufferers in the Mississippi and Red River Valleys. The message was read at length in the Senate, and Mr. Jones (Dem., Ark.) offered a joint resolution appropriating $150,000 from moneys now in the Treasury to be immediately available for the purpose of food and supplies.

An angrier set of cyclists has seldom been seen than about fifty members of the Century Wheelmen, who gathered at the clubhouse, in West Seventy-first Street last evening, preparatory to taking part in the annual Spring lantern parade.

At least eleven of the thirty-six Republican members of the Senate at Albany, representing the cities of New York, Brooklyn, Buffalo, Albany, Syracuse, and Utica, are earnestly opposed to the amendment of the Raines liquor-tax law which would put clubs on the same footing as saloons.
ALBANY, April 7. -- The second hearing on the anti-trust bills occurred this afternoon, before the Senate Committee on Judiciary.
At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, held April 1, the following preamble and resolution were adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A number of Western Republican Senators, more particularly those from the Rocky Mountain States, have united to a movement to make sure of securing certain concessions in the Tariff bill which they consider important to that section of the country. There have been several informal conferences recently, but up to date no conclusions have been reached.

The City Committee of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation held a meeting at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon to complete the programme for opposing the Finn Stoop-line bill. The hearing on this measure will be in the Mayor's office at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. The committee, to secure as large a representation of uptown business men as possible, issued a circular letter addressed to merchants and property owners.

Both dealers and collectors were well represented at the third day's sale of the library of the late Edward Hale Bierstadt at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. Among the principal sales made were:

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. Morgan continued his speech begun yesterday in support of his resolution declaring that a state of war exists in Cuba, and recognizing both parties as belligerents.

No one who knows Mr. ROOSEVELT'S character and ability can doubt that he would make an excellent Assistant Secretary of the Navy, or be surprised that Secretary LONG should desire to have such an assistant. But New York cannot be expected to like the transfer. We cannot regard it as in any sense a promotion, and we are both sorry and puzzled over Mr. ROOSEVELT'S willingness to make the change.

No one connected with the Administration seems inclined to do anything about the currency until next Winter. A bill has been introduced in the House for a commission, but the House is practically not in session. The Senate is fussing over many things, waiting for the Finance Committee to report the Tariff bill.

The debate in the House of Commons on the food supply of Great Britain was a wonderfully forcible reminder of the complexity and interdependence of modern civilization. It was pointed out and not denied that the visible supply in the British Islands of subsistence for their inhabitants never exceeded their requirements for three weeks, and often fell below their requirements for a single week.

The situation at Constantinople is about as bad as it can be. American property has been destroyed, American lives have been menaced and even taken, and demands of American officials refused. Not an apology has been rendered, not a dollar of indemnity paid. Unless the American Government is willing to withdraw entirely from the country it should send the strongest man available as Minister to Turkey.

We trust that every business man among our readers examined the table we published yesterday morning, giving the Dingley committee's estimates of revenue and rates of duty under the new bill. They have set out to increase the revenue by increasing duties, and they calmly assume that the higher duties will not check imports, but will stimulate them.

There was a thrilling scene in Part III. of General Session yesterday, when John Bradley, a witness, illustrated how "Mut" Donovan, a resident of the Ninth Ward, had cut a gash six inches long in the side of the face of Frank Ward, also a Ninth Warder. Bradley used Assistant District Attorney Lauterbach as a manikin in making his demonstration.

For many months Lawyer A. Day and Helen De Long of the National Detective Agency occupied Room 86, at 140 Nassau Street, in peace and harmony. But now Mr. Day sneaks in the office on a run and closes the door of his side of the partition in fear and trembling. He and Mrs. De Long are not on friendly terms.
The Rainy Day Club met yesterday. It met at the house of Mrs. A. Hayes Smith, 2,040 Madison Avenue, and there were four bona fide rainy day suits out.

HAVANA, April 8. -- The Gerona Battalion, while reconnoitering in the vicinity of Encrucijada, Province of Pinar del Rio, surprised the insurgent force commanded by Perico Delgado and the remainder of the force commanded by Ducassi. The enemy left eleven men killed on the field, and the troops captured eight prisoners and a quantity of arms and ammunition.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The E.S. Dean Company has been formally barred from the mails by "fraud orders" just issued by the Postmaster General. The orders are directed against the firm's offices in New York, Salt Lake City, Utah, and Vincennes, Ind., and name the following: E.S. Dean, E.S. Dean Co., the E.S. Dean Company, Myron L. Bernard, Edward F. Farrand, and Goslin Co.

The Bristol Line steamhsip Brooklyn City, which came into port yesterday, narrowly escaped being a victim to the ice that has invaded the steamship track south of the Newfoundland Banks. A fore peak full of water that came in through open plates at her bow betokened actual encounter with an iceberg.

The most interesting business of yesterday's session of the New York East Methodist Conference in St. John's Church, Bedford Avenue and Wilson Street, Brooklyn, was a discussion of this resolution, offered by Dr. Joseph Pullman:

ALBANY, April 8. -- The Senate Committee on Cities to-day reported favorably Senator Page's Street Sprinkling bill. It provides that the proper authorities of the cities of the first class, including New York, Brooklyn, and Buffalo, shall make a contract with some person or corporation to do the street sprinkling for not exceeding a period of ten years.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railroad, and who is interested largely in transportation to the Orient, has written a letter to a Senator, in which he points out the possibilities of trade in China and Japan, and suggests that tariff duties be so adjusted as not to prevent or cut off trade with the countries across the Pacific.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Senator Ellsworth's Forestry bill, appropriating $1,000,000 for the purchase of land in the Adirondack Park, passed the Assembly, 110 to 28. Those who voted against the bill were: Republicans -- Baker, B.D. Brown, C.J. Clark, Eldridge, Graves, Hanna, Harrison, Hobbs, Ives, Kavanaugh, Kelsey, Koster, Leversee, McLaughlin Miles, C.H. Miller, Pierce, Raplee, Sears, Springer, Wilson, and Zimmerman.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 8. -- The loss by to-day's fire is estimated at from $1,500,000 to $2,000,000. Some of the leading business houses in the South were consumed. The loss of life is uncertain.

There was a hunt for a mad cat on the wild and rocky slope at Ninety-fifth Street and Riverside Avenue last night. The cat was black, with very large and glassy eyes and loud voice. Ten boys, two women, and a small girl shouted loudly for the police, and when Patrolman Nethercott hurried down the street, the girl said: "Policeman, it tried to bite my brother."

The sale of the first half of the library of the late Edward Hale Bierstadt by Bangs Co., auctioneers, 91 Fifth Avenue, was concluded yesterday. Nearly 1,400 volumes were disposed of during the four days of the auction, realizing in round figures about $8,000.

Chairman Chauncey M. Depew of the Board of Control of the Joint Traffic Association presided yesterday at a meeting at the Central Building of Presidents of some of the association lines. Besides the officials there were present Commissioner G.R. Blanchard of the Joint Traffic Association, and Commissioner J.F. Goddard of the Trunk Line, Association.

SING SING, N.Y., April 8. -- At the New York Conference session in the Highland Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church to-day the Treasurer reported that $1,690 had been received in the conference fund and $1,600 expended, leaving a balance on hand of $90.

Mayor Strong yesterday announced that he would approve the Finn Stoop-line bill. He gave a public hearing on the measure at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and at the close stated that inasmuch as the bill had been amended in accordance with his suggestions, made at the former hearing, it would be returned to the Legislature with his approval.

DENVER, Col., April 8. -- The new militia law passed by the last Assembly introduces one of the most startling revolutions in modern warfare that has yet been adopted by any civilized nation. Under its provisions the Colorado National Guard may in future be composed of both men and women.

It is only once in two or three years that Nicola Tesla, the electrician, can be persuaded to give a lecture. He contributes occasionally to electrical publications, but he carefully refrains in these communications from letting his fellow-electricians know what he is driving at in his experiments.
Frederick Zittel has sold for W.W. T.M. Hall, builders, to Charles Zoller, 349 West Eighty-seventh Street, a four-story brick dwelling, 20 by 60 by 100.8.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 8. -- The first matter of importance to come up in the Senate to-day was the introduction of a bill by Senator Raines amending in various particulars the Raines election law.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Gov. Black attached his signature to the so-called "Forestry Bill" at 2:20 o'clock this afternoon, but his action was not announced until late in the day. The Governor signed the measure within five minutes after it was placed on his desk. The "time" made between its passage by the Assembly and its becoming a law has seldom been equalled.

ALBANY, April 8. -- The Republicans today completed a programme for swift action on the amendments to the Raines liquor tax law. Unless there is a break in the Assembly, they expect they will be passed by both Houses by the end of next week, precisely as they were agreed on in the Senate caucus last night.

The conservatism which has been for so many years the most pronounced feature in the councils of the National Academy of Design has again asserted itself. For some days past there has been much adverse criticism among the Academicians and Associates of the recent manifesto issued by the Fine Arts Federation, of which the Academy is a member, against the provision of the Dingley Tariff bill taxing all imported art work 25 per cent.

Officers of the Cornell Steamboat Company and William E. Cleary, agent of the Erie Boatmen's Transportation Company, yesterday discredited a rumor that an increase of rates for towing was contemplated. The rumor grew out of the appointment by the Canal Boat Owners and Commercial Association of a committee to consider the rate question.

It was a natural sequence to the election of HARRISON in Chicago that an attempt should instantly be made to repeal the civil service law of Illinois. A bill has accordingly been introduced and advanced promptly in the lower house. The Republicans in that house have a majority of twenty-one and in the Senate twenty-seven.

Cephas, with a race record of 2:11 1/4, made on a half-mile track, was the chief attraction at the sale of trotters held at the American Horse Exchange yesterday. After some brisk bidding, in which J.T. Caldwell, J.F. Gibson, J.H. Butler, and H.B. Carroll took part, he was knocked down to J.H. Butler for $4,500.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Administration proposes to lose no time in taking up the fur seal controversy. At the Cabinet meeting on Tuesday it was decided to invite John W. Foster to take charge of these matters under the direction of the Secretary of State, and to ask C.S. Hamlin, retiring Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, to cooperate on behalf of the Treasury Department.

HAVANA, April 8. -- Michael J. Dady, the Brooklyn-New York contractor, has secured an important contract to improve the sanitary condition of Havana. It is said that the contract will involve an expenditure of about $15,000,000.

The Republican organization of the City and County of New York, which is the anti-Platt or Brookfield organization, decided last night to co-operate with the Citizens' Union movement in favor of non-partisan government of the Greater New York. The Committee on Organization of the anti-Platt movement met at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street.
LONDON, April 8. -- The Times's Canea correspondent says:
LONDON, April 8. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says:
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Senate galleries were well filled again to-day in expectation of a continuance of he Cuban debate. Mr. Chandler offered a resolution, which was agreed to, us follows:

The Inter-State Commerce Commission is evidently preparing to go very thoroughly into the question of the discrimination in rates charged against the Joint Traffic Association. Its order to each of the roads constituting the association to produce all the documents and contracts, and a statement of the operation of all oral agreements affecting transportation, is very comprehensive.

The cause of reputable journalism in this country is being greatly strengthened by the efforts which the present management of THE NEW YORK TIMES is making to issue a paper that shall furnish in an attractive form all the information about the world's doings that can have any interest or value to a person of intelligence and refinement.
TRENTON, N.J., April 8. -- Ex-President and Mrs. Cleveland were the guests of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Green, at, their home here to-night.

Mr. WILLIAM J. BRYAN is bestirring himself to raise money to buy Monticello, the home and burial place of THOMAS JEFFERSON, and to maintain it as a National reservation. If Congress refuses to make an appropriation for the purpose, he will appeal to "the Democrats of the country" to subscribe the needed funds.

At a special meeting of the State Board of Regents held in Albany yesterday the consolidation of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College and the New York University Medical College was authorized by a unanimous vote. The name of the consolidated college will be the Hew York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical College, and it will be under the control of the council of the university.

The trial of a suit by Samuel H. Randall, a lawyer, against Catherine Taylor, a well-to-do widow, for $125 for professional services, occupied Judge McCarthy and a jury all day yesterday in the City Court. After the jury deliberated more than an hour without reaching a verdict, Judge McCarthy instructed them to bring in a sealed verdict.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Additional applications for appointment to Presidential offices under the Treasury Department have been filed as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Considerable pressure is being brought to bear upon the President to secure a repeal of some Consular regulations promulgated by Secretary Olney last October, which in effect largely curtail the big fees which have been received by some Consular officers. The order practically did away with the requirement in all cases of an oath to invoices by an exporter.

Gen. Collis, the Commissioner of Public Works, placed himself on record yesterday on the question of the proposed big parade of cyclists on the Boulevard on June 5. He emphatically declared the parade would not be held in that thoroughfare.

The new giant lobster caught off the Highlands on Wednesday is to be called "Cabby," and not "Sullivan," as at first decided. This was agreed to when Mr. Cabassua, the restaurateur, yesterday afternoon presented him to the Aquarium.
