SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 8. -- The Clark County Medical S0eiety, atits meeting here this afternoon, took steps to have local laws enacted oo guard as much as possible against the spread of consumption..

The great strides made by THE NEW YORK TIMES within the last few months form a notable chapter in American journalism. During a period of general business depression THE NEW YORK TIMES has made steady progress, having within six months nearly doubled its circulation. This growth, while indeed gratifying, serves only to stimulate the management to greater efforts.

MEETING OF THE BOARD. -- The Board of Street Opening and Improvement will meet at 11 A.M. to-day in the Mayor's office, and will give a hearing on the proposed widening of Ann Street, and will discuss such other matters as may come before it.

The Dock Board, at a special meeting yesterday, in conference with representatives of the White Star, Cunard, and Wilson Steamship Lines, came to an agreement on the much-discussed leases of the new piers to be built in the vicinity of Gansevoort Market.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Commenting upon Senator Chandler's statement in regard to the possible failure of the Tariff bill because of too high rates, Senator Warren of Wyoming said: "I do not consider it entirely fair and certainly not judicious to impute at this time to Western Senators a disposition to be extreme in their tariff views, or to insinuate that the Tariff bill will fail because of the radical demands of Western interests.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The reorganization of the Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Park Commission, necessitated by the recent death of the Chairman, Gen. J.S. Fullerton, was perfected by Secretary Alger to-day. Gen. Henry V. Boynton, who has assisted the commission in historical work, was transferred to full membership in the commission and appointed Chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Navy Department received to-day but one bid in answer to the advertisement calling for proposals for supplying about 8,000 tons of armor for the three battleships, Illinois, Wisconsin, and Alabama, and this one was so irregular in form as to be far wide of the advertisement.

Every year after the disastrous flood in the lower Mississippi Valley we have been wont to point to its annually increasing destructiveness as a demonstration of the costly futility of the levee system, upon which the Government has squandered so much money. Congress is voting money without Constitutional warrant to alleviate distress which has been aggravated if not actually caused by the Government works for controlling the waters of the Mississippi River.

Senator CHANDLER sends forth a cry of alarm and distress about the Dingley bill. There is danger, he says, that the "enormous pressure from all parts of the country for high duties" may kill the bill. The Republicans are not in a majority. They need help to pass the bill. If it is made too outrageously bad, they may not get this help, and the bill may fail.

Col. Frederick D. Grant called upon Gen. Grenville M. Dodge yesterday and informed him that Jesse Grant, who lives in California, will be present at the dedication of the Grant monument. Unless some unforeseen obstacle arises all the members of Gen. Grant's family will be at the ceremonies of April 27.
Charles J. Treadway, the young negro who has been on trial for several days for perjury, was convicted yesterday by a jury in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions.

The question of having grand opera in this city next season no longer depends upon funds. If the corporation of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, Limited, can secure the necessary artists, the much mooted financial difficulty will not stand in the way. Edward Lauterbach, one of the Directors, made that statement authoritatively last night.

-- When the Seaforth Highlanders were landed in Crete the other day as one of England's contributions toward the "pacification" of that island, an astonished resident of Candia is said to have exclaimed: "If the men dress like this, how do the women dress?" This anecdote has recalled one that dates from Balaklava.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8. -- The Harvard inter-class track games and field events for the Wells Cup were held on Holmes Field this afternoon. The games were successful in spite of the cold day and rather heavy track. The seniors won the games, scoring in all 50 points; '98 was second, with 35 points, and '99 and 1900 scored 30 and 11 points respectively.

At the meeting of the Committee on Organization of the anti-Platt Republicans of this city on Thursday evening the new Chairman, Gen. SWAYNE, declared that State and municipal politics were now divorced, and resolutions were adopted in favor of co-operating with the Citizens Union in the local campaign this year and doing everything possible to secure a proper administration for the Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The people of the submerged district of the Red River of the North have declined the Government aid voted them by Congress on Wednesday. When the flood came in the Red River a quarter of a million dollars' worth of property was destroyed at Fargo, N.D., and fifty miles of fertile territory was inundated.

The more the case of "E.S. Dean Company" is investigated, the deeper the abyss of gullibility it opens. Although exact figures are still lacking, it seems clear that the dupes of the swindlers were numbered by thousands and the amount extracted from them by millions. And all this was done by a series of false pretenses that one would say could not have imposed upon an intelligent child.

Cornelius W. Luyster, builder, has sold, at about $62,500, 43 West Eighty-sixth Street, the first of his row of four-story and basement brick dwellings, 25 by 62, and extension, by 100.8 1/2, completed last year.

The caucus amenament to the Raines liquor law which exempts clubs incorporated prior to March 23, 1896, under laws in effect prior to May 6, 1895, from the restrictions in regard to selling liquor after 1 o'clock at night and on Sundays and election days, will have certain effects easy to foresee.

The New York East Methodist Conference, now in session in St. John's Church, Bedford Avenue and Wilson Street, Brooklyn, is as interesting from the personality of the men engaged as from the nature of the business to be transacted. More so, in fact, for by changing the names of the speakers the report of each session of to-day might easily be made to serve as a report of any of the last thirty conferences.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 9. -- The Senate took up its third reading calendar almost immediately after the body convened, and several bills were passed, including Mr. Mathewson's providing for the construction of a bridge over the Bronx River at East One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street, in New York City.

The cultivation of taste and refinement in the public schools and the manner in which this is to be accomplished is a subject which is at present engrossing the minds of a great many teachers and public educators. Time and again it has been contended that the only means by which this may be accomplished is to foster and encourage the artistic temperament possessed in a greater or lesser degree by every child.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 9. -- Telegrams from Ozark, Ala., and Valdosta, Ga., near the ill-fated town of Arlington, Ga., show that this section was visited to-day by another cyclone, which ascended the Appalachicola Valley and swept northward with terrific force to the confluence of the Chattahoochee and the Flint Rivers, where it divided.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 9. -- There appeared in a local newspaper to-day an advertisement offering for sale, to the highest bidder among the medical colleges, the body of Henry Biesh. The advertisement was inserted by Biesh himself, and he wants some one to buy his body, the goods to be delivered upon his death.

LONDON, April 9. -- The Parliamentary committee which is investigating the Transvaal raid held its sixteenth sitting to-day in the committee room off Westminster Hall. There was a large attendance of Peers and members of parliament. Dr. Jameson arrived with Sir John Willoughby, the military commander of the raid, and the former was again placed in the witness box.

It is not surprising that would-be Consuls are complaining of the reduction in fees made by Secretary OLNEY, but it would be amazing if Secretary SHERMAN should pay the slightest attention to them. The reduction consists, to all intents, in cutting off fees that are not merely unnecessary but strictly illegal, and which have been little short of a swindle.

This volume consists of lectures delivered at Madison, Wis., "nominally to a class but really to a large audience composed of representatives of the university and of the City of Madison." In these circumstances, Prof. Trent takes a large view of what "every schoolboy knows," and usually assumes the thorough acquaintance of his audience with the facts in the careers of the statesmen of whom he treats.

Two women, one from Houston, Texas, the other from Binghamton, N.Y., will meet at the residence of a surgeon, 127 West Forty-second Street, this afternoon, for the purpose of negotiating for the sale of a living finger.

Wyoming is a State, and elects two Senators and one Representative. It has a voting population rather less than that of Chautauqua County, which enjoys an undivided one-third of one Representative and an undivided one-seventieth of two Senators. One of the Senators of the State of Wyoming is Mr. WARREN.
Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott said that he heartily approved of the course the Mayor has taken.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The Rapid Transit Underground Railroad Company of New York City was incorporated to-day, with a capital stock of $100,000. The company is to operate an underground or tunnel road in the City of New York which shall extend partly through an open cut.

-- Originality is usually enough to insure at least temporary success in literature, but mechanics is more exigent. That remarkable "bateau-rouleur" which was launched at Rouen last August and was pictured in astonished magazines and newspapers all over the world, has turned out to be a complete failure and has not revolutionized steam navigation of anything else except the inventor's bank account.

There are some differences in the prices of a Sir Thomas Lawrence. A portrait of Miss Farren, afterward Countess of Derby, which brought 79 guineas in 1860 was sold lately in London for 2,250 guineas.

At a recent meeting of the Association of Head Masters of Schools in New York and Vicinity, held at the St. Denis Hotel, George Walton Green made an address in which he spoke as follows about the way the classics have been taught:

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- Lawyers Harrity and Beck, representing the David Blakeley estate, will make application for a preliminary injunction to-morrow restraining John P. Sousa, the bandmaster, from fulfilling any more engagements except under the Blakeley management.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The committees representing respectively the Republican and Democratic sides of the Senate resumed their efforts to-day to reach an agreement on a basis of reorganizing the Senate committees. After the Republican committee adjourned, Senator McMillan said that such satisfactory progress had been made as to warrant the prediction that reorganization would be accomplished.

Is alumni representation a failure? Is the "young blood" idea for college Boards of Trustees played out? From a New England college whose alumni some years ago Trustees, and won, although the charter and the self-perpetuating board stood in the way, there come hints that the graduate body take a diminishing interest in the privilege they conquered.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- It was supposed that Wednesday's decline of 3 3/4 cents marked the bottom of the descent which has played havoc with wheat prices lately. This was proved erroneous to-day by a decline of 1 7/8 cents from yesterday's price. May closing at 64 7/3 cents, the lowest price in any months. Weak cables started the rumpus and heavy liquidation kept it going.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has had a force of men searching for the body since the day of the accident, and the recovery was due to their untiring vigilance. Immediately upon the receipt of information that the body had been found, the railroad officials sent a representative of the company, with an undertaker from Oakland, to the spot, and the remains were removed to Oakland.

Miss Alice A. Holmes, seventy-seven years old, of 242 Grove Street, Jersey City, has received a letter from Downieville, Sierra County, Cal., stating that the will of her brother, William J. Holmes, gives her a fourth of his estate. He died there on March 3. The estate is reputed to be worth from $100,000 to $150,000.

Mr. Dannat, having served so creditably during the Paris Exhibition of 1889 as a member of the jury, received his first decoration. Mr. Dannat's "Quartette" may be seen at the Metropolitan Museum, and he enjoys the high distinction of having his "Une Femme Rouge" hung at the Luxembourg.

ALBANY, April, 9. -- By a vote of 48 nays to 34 yeas, the Assembly this morning refused to adopt Mr. Barry's motion to discharge the Committee on Gas, Electricity, and Water Supply from further consideration of his bill, providing for one-dollar gas in cities of 1,500,000 or more inhabitants.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 9. -- Of the fifty-two guests who were sleeping in the Hotel Knox yesterday morning when the fire broke out, only thirty-five have been accounted for. The hotel register was destroyed, and it will perhaps never be known how many lives were lost.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Mayor Strong's private secretary, Job E. Hedges, this morning conveyed the news to the Assembly Clerk that the Mayor had vetoed the Greater New York charter. This fact, with the additional statement that a memorandum containing the Mayor's reasons had accompanied the bill on its return, was all that was officially made public, as the message was not read in the Assembly.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 9. -- Anna Dickinson, the lecturer and actress, to-night recovered a verdict of 6 1/4 cents from George B. Thompson, Allan Eggleston, John S. Heilman, Gideon Underwood, and Henry Bryden of Pittsburg on the basis of a claim that they had brought about her unwarranted incarceration in the Danville Insane Asylum in 1891.

The Tammany General Committee met at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam last night and adopted resolutions attacking the management of the Building Department and otherwise assailing the present Municipal Government of this city. Augustus W. Peters presided and there was a large gathering of the braves.

Le Chevalier de Pontgibaud was one of a gallant little band of Frenchmen who, under La Fayette, fought for our independence. Some half century after the war the chevalier wrote of his adventures. This work has been for the first time translated and annotated by Robert B. Douglas under the title of "A French Volunteer of the War of Independence," and is for sale by Mr. J.W. Bouton of New York.

Artists are aroused over the Dingley Tariff bill. The Wilson bill, allowing the importation of paintings, has been operative long enough for opinions as to its merits and drawbacks to crystallize. The consensus of opinion gathered about the studios leans to the levying of a specific duty on paintings.

The story of the Pilgrim Fathers has been told many times and with countless variations, so that one heartily welcomes Mr. Arber's volume of extracts from the original manuscripts published in this inexpensive and accessible form. Histories, as a rule, do not make men wise because of the curious tendency of the human family to build opinions upon errors rather than upon truths.

The veto of the Greater New York charter by Mayor Strong meets with the approval of all those who have identified themselves with the opposition to it in its present form, and his recommendations are generally spoken of as steps in the right direction.

Within a few years Dr. Van Dyke has measurably widened his reputation by the books he has issued. His pulpit fame in this community had been large and was fast extending when that charming and original piece of writing, "Little Rivers," came upon us to show, for one thing, where were some of the sources of that abounding freshness, sympathy, and brightness which are peculiarly his qualities.

William Osborn, who does business at 70 Broad Street, this City, and lives at Port Chester, is much incensed against members of the Westchester County Hunt Club. He criticised them severely in a letter in Wednesday's issue of The Port Chester Journal, in which he said:

The care of the home and worldly possessions of Hannah and Margery White, two maiden ladies whose birth dates back to the last century, and who are still able to be about in a Brooklyn sanitarium, came before Justice Keogh and a jury in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on a petition to have a guardian appointed to look after their interests.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- Developments to-day have brought out the fact that a far greater amount of University of Illinois funds is involved in the suspension of the Globe Savings Bank than had been supposed. Two years ago the State Legislature appropriated $423,000, of which, according to the State laws, enough was to be drawn out monthly to meet the current expenses of the university.
ALBANY, April 9. -- Assemblyman McKnight of Queens County to-day introduced a bill designed to delay any immediate action on the scheme of rapid transit in New York City. The bill provides:

I have found your paper all that you have claimed for it. It is clean, newsy, interesting, and entirely free from the new journal sensationalism, which is demoralizing the community wherever it has influence.

Lady Mary Wortley Montagu's "Letters," descriptive of Turkey, are still delightful reading, and so are Mrs. Max Muller's "Letters from Constantinople." As far as Stamboul is concerned, there may be material changes since the time of Lady Mary, a matter of 130 years ago, but the Turk is still the Turk, only he wears the fez to-day, and has put aside the turban.

From the protectionist point of view, Mr. JAMES J. HILL, President of the Great Northern Railroad, is a most narrow-minded person, to say nothing of his being selfish and un-American. He has written to a Senator practically asking that the tariff shall not make imports from China and Japan any more expensive than they now are.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- Hilaire Belloc, late scholar of Balliol College, Oxford, closed in Philadelphia last evening, with a lecture on "Napoleon," three months' work under the auspices of the American Society for the Extension of University Teaching. He has delivered during his stay in this country nearly 100 lectures, usually in courses of six each, at fifteen different university extension centres.

It would have been difficult half a century ago to appreciate the characteristics of an Oxford don -- such as was Benjamin Jowett, Master of Balliol College, Oxford. Prior to the Victorian age it was not common for heads of great English universities to be liberal in their opinions, for the least bit of dissent was likely to have brought about trouble.

ELASSONA, Macedonia, April 9. -- Bands of Greek brigands early this morning entered Turkey at Krania, in the vicinity of Grebina. The Turkish troops at once became engaged with them, and a fight began which lasted all day.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 9. -- Gov. Black today signed the following bills:
The Society of The Patriarchs, founded by Ward McAllister, was dissolved yesterday afternoon by mutual consent of its members.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 9. -- The Republican Senators who are acting as a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Finance in the preparation of the Tariff bill are inclined in their estimates now to postpone the date of its presentation to the Senate a little beyond the limit originally fixed by them.

CHICAGO, April 9. -- A.M. Palmer and Samuel E. Rork, who hold the lease of the Great Northern Theatre, have filed a bill to restrain John and Alexander Davidson and the Great Northern Hotel and Theatre Company from prosecuting any suit to enforce payment of rent. The plaintiffs also wish the partnership between themselves and the Davidsons dissolved.

The Nova Scotian brigantine L.G. Crosby, which her skipper, Capt. Perry, says is the smartest sailer along the coast, came into port yesterday with 3,840 bags of sugar from Macoris, twenty-eight days out.

A new volume, just issued in England by the Historical Manuscript Commission, is entirely derived from a collection of documents belonging to Mr. J. Eliot Hodgkin. It may be considered as an olla podrida, containing much of interest, and just such an assemblage as would have been named by, a man who had general tastes and was a historical scholar and an enthusiast.

The recent French Parliamentary discussions on the Budget of Fine Arts for this year present some points of interest. In 1896 the pay of the employes was 557,740f. This year the money required will be 611,740f. When the salaries paid in French museum were compared with those paid in England, the latter, it was stated, were very much larger.

LONDON, April 9. -- The Daily Telegraph will publish to-morrow a dispatch from its war correspondent at Elassona, the headquarters of the Turkish forces on the Macedonian frontier, confirming the reported invasion of Krania. The correspondent says:

Mayor STRONG'S refusal to accept the Greater New York charter in behalf of this city came as a surprise, but it does him credit. He was in a certain sense committed to the charter as a member of the commission which framed it, and as a signer of the report recommending its adoption in spite of certain features that he considered objectionable.
ROME, April 9. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day on the resumption of the debate raised yesterday by the interpellation of Signor Imbriani, the Socialist leader.

NEWPORT, Ky., April 9. -- This was ladies' day at the Newport track. The cold weather, however, interfered with the attendance, and the crowd did not number over 2,000. The mud was still deep on the track, and only two favorites succeeded in winning, Summaries:

Active preparations are being made by the Epworth League Society for their annual convention at Toronto, from July 16 to July 19. The different societies in this city, Brooklyn, and vicinity are giving considerable attention to the matter, and the outlook is that a large number of delegates will go from this neighborhood.

The history of magazine publication in this country prior to 1800 is an account of many worthy and hopeful attempts to launch out into the deeper sea of literary activity than occupied by the newspapers, but in every case the voyage was short and the shore soon strewn with wrecks. If the Colonial newspapers frequently had a hard struggle to win popularity and financial success, the magazines found the task still more difficult.

A work of much interest to all cyclists in this vicinity is that being performed by the Guide Board Committee of the New York Division of the League of American Wheelmen. The work mapped out for this committee has been under way for some time; it comprises the posting of sign boards on the turnpike routes of Long Island, which are the tourist's special delight in the Summer season.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The State Department continues to deny the reports that the German Government has submitted a protest against the Tariff bill, but whether it has been received or not, it is known definitely that such a protest has been forwarded by the German Ambassador, Baron von Thielmann, acting on cable instructions from Berlin.

BELLEVILLE, Ill., April 10. -- Suit has been instituted by Charles B. Carroll and John Ellspermann, Jr., against the Lansburg Brake Company for the appointment of a receiver for the corporation and an injunction to restrain the disposal of its property. It has a capital stock of $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- A meeting of the Advisory Board to the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor was held here this evening for the purpose of the universal introduction of the eight-hour workday.

ROCHESTER, April 10. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court last evening granted an important motion in the Adirondack forest dispute between Decamp, as administrator, , and the Moose River Lumber Company.

Charles M. Caughy, United States Consul at Messina, in a report to the Department of State under date of Jan. 7, 1897, declares that "the fruit trade of Sicily, as conducted last season, was rotten to the core." In explaining and giving his reasons for that assertion, he says:

Former Gov. Roswell P. Flower spoke at some length yesterday to a NEW YORK TIMES representative regarding general business conditions and the financial situation. Gov. Flower is most hopeful for the early future; believing that the country is upon the threshold of prosperity. He discerns a distinct tendency toward betterment.

The members of the Oakland Golf Club, at Bayside, L.I., had a glorious day yesterday to open their golf links for the season's play. A large number of devoted lovers of the sport took advantage of the invigorating weather to go out on the links, clad in golf costume, and do their best to go around the course in low scores.

ORANGE, N.J.; April 10. -- The Orange Wheelmen have arranged these runs for this month: April 11, 2 P.M., Nutley; April 15, 8 P.M., Brookdale; April 18, 2 P.M., Plainfield; April 22, 8 P.M., Millburn; April 25, 2 P.M., Morristown; April, 29, 8 P.M., Elizabeth.

The workrooms for unskilled women under the auspices of the Charity Organization Society are in need of $2,000, in addition to their annual subscriptions, to support them for the ensuing year. Without this they must close. The workrooms are at 47 Prospect Place, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, and First and Second Avenues.

The great strides made by THE NEW YORK TIMES within the last few months form a notable chapter in American journalism. During a period of general business depression THE NEW YORK TIMES had made steady progress, having within six months nearly doubled its circulation. This growth, while indeed gratifying, serves only to stimulate the management to greater efforts.

If the plans of the Park Department are successfully carried out, a couple of white whales will be added to the attractions of the Aquarium in Battery Park. Visitors have looked disappointedly into the large central tank, where, instead of one of the monsters of the deep, only a few skates, dogfish, and the like were to be discovered by close scrutiny.

OMAHA, Neb., April 10. -- The airship seen by the Ak-Sar-Bens members Monday night, which created such a sensation in Omaha, is now declared to be a balloon, and the men who sent it up are Roy Arnold and Jack Rogers. They are practical jokers, and they bought an enormous balloon to send up April 1, but it rained that night, so they held it for a later date.

The Giants start the season this year in better shape than they have ever been before at the beginning of any season. The team has confidence in Capt. Joyce, and the players are full of vim. The last two games at Lakewood were played in championship form.

PUNTA GORDA, Fla., April 2. -- Treasure hunting parties is one of the regular standbys in this section of the West Florida coast. The haunts of the old pirates are often pointed out, and many stories are told of their hidden hoards, supposed to be on the islands and keys hereabout, but it is very seldom that a find is made.

Of social doings in New York during the seven days which closed last night, there is little or nothing to record this morning. The gay world never looks for any particular movement or life during Passion and Holy Week, but the first half of this solemn fortnight has been unusually barren even of incident this year.

In its efforts to disseminate tariff literature in opposition to the Dingley bill the Reform Club of this city has encountered a peculiar obstruction from an unexpected source. The Democratic Editorial Association of the State of New York desires to supervise the transmission of all prepared matter on the tariff designed for the columns of Democratic newspapers in this State.

BROOKLYN Public School No. 26 was first organized in 1856 as a primary school, in a frame building at the junction of New Bushwick Lane with Ralph Street. In 1857 eight lots were bought for a school site on Gates Avenue, near Ralph. In September, 1869, the building that had been erected there was opened.

The White Star and Wilson Line of steamships, while they have yielded to the demands of the Department of Docks for rental of the new piers to be built, have filed an energetic protest. They have sent the following letter:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The State Department has received responses from eight of the maritime powers invited to send war vessels to participate in the dedicatory ceremonies at New York April 27, when the Grant Monument is to be turned over to the city. These replies are as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Lester F. Stearns of Dunkirk has decided to accept the offer of the Third Assistant Postmaster Generalship. Mr. Stearns is a leading lawyer of Dunkirk. He belongs to the New York Republican organization, and is a warm friend of both Senator Platt and Representative Hooker. He was a McKinley delegate to the St. Louis Convention.

FRANKFORT, Ky., .April 10. -- Allegations of bribery and conspiracy to bribe have been made before the Franklin County Grand Jury against Dr. W. Godfrey Hunter, the Republican nominee for the United States Senate; ex-Congressman John H. Wilson of the Eleventh District, one of Dr. Hunter's closest advisers, and E.T. Franks, one of the leading Republican politicians of the Second District.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 10. -- Trout will be fair game in all of the waters of New York State on and after April 16 until the season closes. The lakes and streams will by the opening of the season be freed from the rigors of the Winter season, and in the Catskills, as elsewhere, the trout should be alert and ravenous.

Prof. Isaac F. Russell of the New York University Law School, in a recent lecture before the Brooklyn Institute Law Department, took for his subject "The Vendetta." If any of his auditors expected to hear a discourse dealing with stories of the vendetta, such, for instance, as is treated of in "Mr. Barnes of New York," they were disappointed.

The programme for the naval parade on the day of the dedication of Grant's Tomb has finally been completed, and was given out yesterday at Gen. Dodge's headquarters. The entire water demonstration will be under the command of Admiral Francis M. Bunce, United States Navy, Commander of the North Atlantic squadron. The parade will be formed in four grand divisions, as follows:
BE COURTEOUS to everybody, warn those who ride too fast; use good judgment, but see that the laws are not disobeyed."

Spirited competitions were the rule in the second athletic meeting of the Eighth Regiment Athletic Association held last evening in the armory, at Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue. A large crowd witnessed the games. F.F. Goodman succeeded in covering a mile, unpaced, in 2:30, which beats the best previous record in the Eighth's armory, of 2:31 2-5. This was also Goodman's record.

There has been published as part of the seventeenth annual report of the United States Geological Survey an account of "The Uintaite (Gilsonite) Deposits of Utah," prepared by George Homans Eldridge. The name uintaite was given by Prof. W.P. Blake in 1885 to a variety of asphalt found in the vicinity of the Uinta Mountains in Utah.
DENVER, Col., April 10. -- For some time the following advertisement has appeared in a local paper:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- In the House to-day Mr. Simpson of Kansas found an opportunity to reiterate his denunciation of a concentration of power in the Speaker's hands. Mr. Dingley declared the Republican policy to be to do nothing but enact the tariff and left-over appropriation bills this session.

The Committee on Street Franchises of the City Club -- E.R.L. Gould, William Travers Jerome, Frank J. Goodnow, Horace E. Deming, and Albert Shaw -- has issued a statement on the application of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for permission to equip with underground trolleys the Sixth and Eighth Avenue lines. The committee says:

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 10. -- The Princeton College team and the Elizabeth Club crossed bats at the Walnut Street grounds this afternoon. There was a large attendance. Princeton outpointed Elizabeth throughout the game, but six innings being played. The score:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- About all the information that can be obtained concerning the work of the Republicans of the Senate Finance Committee on the Tariff bill has come so far from those persons who were endeavoring to shape the bill for the Senate. The members of the committee who are doing all the work are Senators Allison, Aldrich, Platt of Connecticut, and Wolcott. AIr. bIorrill has not addressed himself to this work.

The Rough Riding Club gave a tournament at Durland's Academy last night. It was the closing event of the season, and the academy was filled with the friends of the members of the club, and they thoroughly enjoyed the entertainment.

DENVER, Col., April 3. -- The recent decision of the United States Supreme Court giving E.S. Bassick of Bridgeport, Conn., possession of the famous Bassick Mine, near Rosita, Col., recalls some interesting history.

ATHENS, April 10. -- Dispatches received here to-day from Larissa give details of the invasion of Macedonia by a force of irregular Greek troops. Three thousand men, it is announced, crossed the frontier on Wednesday, the day after the celebration of the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence, in 1821.

ONE star differeth from another in glory. Lillian Russell has been the subject of so much idle newspaper talk that it really seems hardly worth while to take her seriously, yet she persists in coming before a large and substantial public and attracting its attention.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Almost everybody reads the newspapers. It is necessary to admit that all do not, for after the President had left Washington on the Dolphin, and was well on his way down the Potomac, or near Annapolis, groups of visitors went to the White House to inquire at what hour the President would receive, when he would go walking or riding, and if they might see the house.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 10. -- By the capture of William Ingliss Bloom, the incendiary, the Fire Wardens of this city may have incidentally saved Chicago the loss of sums aggregating nearly $1,000,000. Suits approaching this amount have been brought against that municipality as a result of the destruction of railroad cars and property by fire during the great railway strike of a few years ago.
The New York Baseball Club played and won an exhibition game against Yale yesterday in the presence of over 3,000 spectators. It was the Giants' first appearance this season on the home ground.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Over 2,600 policy-holders in the Chicago Guaranty Fund Life Society have been notified that a thorough investigation into the affairs of the association will be instituted in the near future.
LONDON, April 10. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times telegraphs as follows:

Agnes Sorma, who will make her first appearance in this country to-morrow night, is practically unknown here. Nothing has ever been printed about her except a few statements sent out by Mr. Conried's prejudiced agents. Mr. Conried frankly and simply declares she is a greater actress than Eleonora Duse.
In an interesting paper recently read before the Academy of Medicine by Dr. L. Duncan Bulkley, he dealt with "Relations of Diseases of the Skin to General Conditions."
If the plans of Dr. Frederick A. Cook mature, there will be an expedition leaving this city next September for exploration in the antarctic regions.

THERE are many interesting things about New York's City Hall besides its rare architectural beauty. In a quiet way it is one of the show places of the metropolis. Thousands visit it every year simply as sightseers.

LONDON, April 10. -- The final tie for the Football Association Challenge Cup, between the Arton Villa and Everton teams, was decided at the Crystal Palace today. The scene was remarkably brilliant. There were 50,000 spectators, the weather and grounds were superb, and there was intense excitement.

Dr. Wallace Wood, Professor of the History of Art in New York University, finished his course of lectures on "The Heroic in Art" at the University Building yesterday, before a good-sized audience. The lecture room was decorated with drawings of heads, entered in competition for a one-hundred-dollar prize, and sketches by several well-known artists, loaned for the occasion, all of which were intended to depict the American ideal.

We have a general sentiment among both people and legislators that distilled spirits and alcoholic preparations generally are commodities that can advantageously be made subject to any degree of taxation. If under a given rate the revenue increases, an increase in the rate is held to be desirable; if the revenue falls off, the decrease is attributed to decreased consumption, whereby any loss of revenue is correspondingly compensated by moral advantages.

St. Christopher's House, on East Eighty-eighth Street, the new home for the mission work of St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, was formally presented yesterday to the church officers. The attendant ceremonies were held in the meeting hall of the new building, and the presentation was made by William Rhinelander Stewart, on behalf of his aunt, Miss Serena Rhinelander.

SING SING, N.Y., April 10. -- The particular and interesting feature of to-day with the New York Methodist Episcopal Conference was the visit this afternoon of the clergymen to Sing Sing prison, on the invitation of Warden O.V. Sage, to listen to a concert arranged especially for them by the prison choir and orchestra.

THE career in letters of Donald G. Mitchell embraces a period of fifty years -- a longer period than his age perhaps would indicate. That first volume of his, "Fresh Gleanings; or, A New Sheaf from the Old Fields of Continental Europe," was published when Sr. Mitchell was only twenty-five.

Owen Meredith will go down to posterity as a popular writer, if for nothing but the lines just quoted and the four which precede them in "Lucile." They have been worn nearly threadbare from quotation under all sorts of possible and impossible circumstances. In reading them posterity will exclaim: "How our ancestors loved the good things of life:"

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The final agreement among Democrats, silver Republicans, and Populists, looking toward a permanent coalition, was reached at a meeting of Representatives of those parties held in Senator Gorman's committee room at the Capitol to-day.

NEW ORLEANS; La., April 10. -- Gloom hangs over the Mississippi Valley. Every where the river is rising. As the mighty weight bears upon the banks. Nerved by the appalling thought of the ruin its egress through any of the protecting levees would bring, thousands of men are at work strengthening the barriers.

The Mayor's addition of a number of women to the City Commission for the Tennessee Centennial Exposition is considered a wise move. They were appointed on Monday last. They held a meeting on Thursday and are now sending out invitations to citizens of New York prominent in business and social circles to attend a meeting at Sherry's on Saturday next.

ST. LOUIS, April 10. -- The William A. Orr Shoe Company was brought into court to-day by an application of Stockholders Louis Rouser and John S. Wilkens for a receiver. The attorney allege mismanagement and misappropriation of the company's funds. The company's capital stock is $250,000.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- According to the opinion of a gentleman who is familiar with the coal trade between the United States and Canada, the Dingley bill will inflict a great wrong upon the consumers of both countries and inevitable injury to the commerce between them, almost entirely for the benefit of a few railroad companies which hope to benefit by the imposition of the proposed duty of 75 cents a ton.

The disbandment of the Patriarchs may excite some mournful reflections on the vicissitudes of things, since the formation and maintenance of the association was the lifework of the late WARD McALLISTER. But, apart from that consideration, it is not to be regretted. Of course, the Patriarchs could and would have kept the organization going if they had considered that it continued to serve any useful or agreeable purpose.

The market at private sale has undergone no material change. The business accomplished last week showed a few hundred thousands less invested than during the previous week. That was largely due, however, to Hoffman Brothers' sale of 9 to 13 Maiden Lane for $525,000, to a buyer whose identity has not been disclosed.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- James Charlton, General Passenger Agent of the Alton Road, has submitted to the Legislature of Illinois, a statement against the two-cent-per-mile bill which is now pending before that body. Mr. Charlton says that the assertion that railroad rates have not been reduced while other things have been coming down in price is not borne out by the facts.

LONDON, April 10. -- We assume here to-night that war or the equivalent of war has begun on the Thessalian frontier. Bulletins coming in from correspondents near the scene of actual hostilities all reflect the opinion that what has happened involves formal hostilities between Turkey and Greece.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the American Line steamship St. Paul from Southampton were Alfred E. Aarons, Mrs. Patrick Collins of Boston, Henry E. Hendricks, Alexander Marshall Hay, Dan Leno and Mrs. Leno, Capt. A. Pearce, Signor Raoul Perez, Mme. Santin, George P. Brett, Charles M. Gage, William E. Wall, Blanche Ashley, and Susie Swift.

KINGSTON, April 3. -- On the night boat from Kingston to New York, a few nights ago, a little knot of young people were discussing the various methods of earning a living and the invasion of men's professions by female workers, when a well-dressed and prosperous-looking old man, who had been an interested listener, chuckled audibly and said:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 10. -- April days, with clear mornings, followed by showers later in the day, made up this week's weather. The chief interest centres now in Easter, and, with the prospect of a crowd to swell the large number already here, good weather is particularly wished for. The Lenten season has been fully as successful as the best of former times, and the late Easter finds a promising Spring season well begun.

The West Side Branch of the Public Education Association gathered Friday at the home of Percival Knauth, 302 West Seventy-sixth Street, to hear an entertaining discussion on "Conservative vs. Advanced Methods in Teaching." The Rev. Dr. August Ulmann of Trinity School advocated conservative ideas, and President Hervey of the Teachers College spoke in behalf of the advanced system.

The alumnae of Elmira College held their Spring meeting yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. A luncheon, at which covers were laid for fifty, preceded the meeting. Miss M. Katherine Jones, President of the association, acted as presiding ofticer. Dr. Alexander 1Viackenzie, President of the college, made an address explaining the needs of the institution.

No one can have watched the recent discussion in the House of Representatives and in the press of the tariff question without seeing that the idea of protection has taken an entirely new phase within the past decade. It is getting a hold on classes who were formerly indifferent or actively opposed to it.

The special committee appointed by property owners in Elm Street to confer with the Rapid Transit Commission about the proposed Elm Street route met the officers of the commission yesterday. The object in view was to ascertain the exact plan of construction, its probable effect upon adjoining property, and the legal effect of giving their consent to construction.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 10. -- The skull of C.N. Cunningham, the alleged forger of Judge Hamilton's name to a check for $75,000, was operated upon to-day. An oblong piece of bone which, had it been circular, would have been about the size of a silver dollar, was removed. The object of the operation was to show that a depression on the man's skull had caused insanity and would result in paralysis.

Since the Harlem Ship Canal was opened the advantage of having navigable waters in the Harlem Kills, in order that there may be a direct connection between the Harlem River and Long Island Sound, has appeared more plainly than ever. Senator Platt of New York has introduced a bill authorizing the Secretary of War to contract with Charles Stoughton for the construction of the Harlem Kills Canal, and appropriating $1,296,000 for the work.

An important Boston banking house, in a letter to clients during the last few days, has pointed out what, in its opinion, is a significant reason for business confidence and anticipations of betterment -- the fact that commercially and industrially failures are lessening, and that despite "hard times" talk statistics of current failures show that the business interests of the country are less critically situated than they have been in a long time past.

The statements which Mr. LAUTERBACH is reported to have made to Gov. BLACK in arguing against the Raines law amendment throw some light upon the mystery of the Republican hope of carrying the next city election in spite of the Greater New York charter and other outrages upon municipal home rule.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 10. -- This week's pleasant weather brought a number of people to the shore, some of them in search of cottages for the Summer, and some to look after their residences and to get them in readiness for the season.

A dinner in commemoration of the seventh anniversary of the establishment of the New York Free Lecture Course was given last night at the Windsor Hotel. The guest of honor was Dr. Henry M. Leipziger, Superintendent and practical executive of the courses. Covers were laid for 150. Rossiter Johnson presided.

LONDON, April 2. -- To steam through the English Channel from the Scilly Islands eastward along the coast and through the Straits of Dover into the Thames is a strong reminder of seeing a Shakespearean play for the first time. Scenes long familiar in print come to the front at every turn, though at a conservative English distance.

VIENNA, March 22. -- The elections for the fifth Parliamentary curia, which represents a quasi-universal suffrage, have just been terminated in Austria. Seventy Deputies have been returned, representing no less than seventeen different political parties. This is without exaggeration, and the list of these parties is a curiosity in itself.

Wall Street tries to be hopeful, wants to be confident, but is nervous. Hesitancy is the chief of current security market characteristics. Bad features disclosed get more attention than developments which are encouraging.

"The inconsistency of Mayor Strong in the stoop-line matter does not discourage us in the least," said Attorney E.M. Wight yesterday. "I have always thought we should have to fight the matter out before the Governor and in the courts.

WASHINGTON, April l0. -- The report of the Department of Agriculture for April makes the average condition of Winter wheat 81.4, against 99.5, on Dec. 1; 77.1 last April and 81.4 at the same date in 1895. Leading Winter wheat States show averages as follows: Pennsylvania, 96; Ohio, 83; Michigan, 85; Indiana, 65; Illinois, 40; Missouri, 60; Kansas, 80, and California, 99. The average rye condition was 88.9, against 82.9 last year.
"You see," says Jaguarina, "I don't banch."

ELASSONA, April 10. -- Edhem Pasha, the Commander in Chief of the Turkish Army, has received orders from Constantinople to cross the frontier of Greece with his forces should it be proved that Greek regular troops are among the invaders. The Turkish troops continue advancing against the invaders, who will shortly find themselves between three fires.

An unexpected, quick, and thorough police raid of the Open Board of Brokers at 46 Broad Street caused much excitement in the Wall Street region yesterday forenoon, and had the effect of closing for the time being every bucket shop in that vicinity. The raid occurred about 11 o'clock, and was carried out by a squad of Central Office detectives acting under the authority of a warrant issued by Magistrate Mott.

IN the seventh decade of the nineteenth century the condition of the English theatre, in England at least, was quite bad enough to justify the lamentations of those old stagers who had been contending, since the death of Betterton, that the drama was on its last legs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10. -- President McKinley and party came ashore this morning from the Dolphin, and were officially received at the Naval Academy. The party landed about 10 o'clock, and the Presidential salute was fired, after which the cadets were paraded as artillery and reviewed by the President.

An interested crowd of youngsters gathered in the hall of the Polytechnic Institute, with their parents and friends, yesterday afternoon, to take their first steps on the tortuous pathway of scientific investigation. Dr. Peter T. Austen, the Institute's Professor of Chemistry, was the initiator, and the mysteries explored were the simpler workings of electricity, air pressure, and gravitation.

Fragments or crosses of palm leaves were worn on the breasts and hats of many thousands of people in New York yesterday in honor of Palm Sunday. The day was observed by the Protestant Episcopal and Roman Catholic and some other churches with the special services and lessons provided.

All the newspapers have given a good deal of space to the objections made to the proposed charter of the Greater City before Mayor Strong. Your editorial of this morning as very timely, and has undoubtedly met with wide approval.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A statement relative to the agricultural interests of the submerged districts of the Mississippi Valley south of Cairo, Ill., has been issued by the Department of Agriculture. It is based upon a chart prepared under the direction of the Chief of the Weather Bureau, showing the extent of the flood on April 6.

Commissioner Waring of the Department of Street Cleaning has submitted to Mayor Strong an account of the first year's work of the Committee of Forty-one and the Board of Conference. This dual organization is the result of efforts originating with Col. Waring for the establishment of closer relations between the Commissioner and the employes of his department.

In point of patronage, the introduction of bicycle trains on the elevated railroads in this city, which was tried for the first time on the Ninth Avenue line yesterday, was not a success. From all that a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES could learn last night by a tour of the stations where the bicycle trains made stops, the total sale of tickets for the day was considerably under 300.

The Tennyson Literary Circle completed the fourth year of its existence yesterday, and celebrated the event with literary and musical exercises in the auditorium of the Educational Alliance Building, East Broadway and Jefferson Street. The hall was filled with members of the organization and their friends.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 11. -- In a communication to the Ambassadors, dated April 10, the Porte speaks of the Greek invaders of the previous day as "regular" troops, and the incursion is regarded here as the commencement of war.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 11. -- It is stated here to-night that Gen. James R. Chamberlain, an officer of the State Grand Army of the Republic, has preferred charges against Gen. John A. Reynolds, Past State Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, and an equally well-known Grand Army of the Republic man of this State and a prominent business man of this city.

We doubt the efficacy and the permanence of the reaction against immorality in Paris. Senator BERENGER is sincere, we presume, but he has mistaken his "milieu." He is an English Puritan by some accident transported to Paris. His ideas will not take root on the banks of the Seine.

The resolutions of the Tammany Executive Committee attacking the administration of the Building Department under Superintendent CONSTABLE are a mere incident in the Tammany tactics developed some time ago and likely to be kept up through the coming municipal campaign.

Yesterday was a busy day for the members of the Harlem Yacht Club, and the grounds surrounding the clubhouse, at the foot of East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street presented a lively scene. There are nearly twenty-five boats in Winter quarters there, ranging in size from eighteen to fifty feet, and the majority were being scraped, painted, and rigged in preparation for the coming yachting season, which promises to be a very interesting one.

EASTON, Conn., April 11. -- A young Swede, known as Peter Carlson, employed by an aged farmer of Easton named Hanford Lyon, suddenly went insane to-day, and while the other members of the family were at church nearly murdered the old man. The Swede was found hiding in a barn, and after a violent struggle was arrested and taken to Bridgeport by Constable Tucker.

In Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last night, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached the last of his series of sermons on "The Bible as Literature." Before closing he referred to the reports off his sermons which have appeared from time to time in certain sensational newspapers in this city in this language:
LONDON, April 11. -- The Times to-morrow will print the following Athens dispatch:
Thomas L. Greene, Auditor of the Manhattan Trust Company of this city, contributes to The London Statist a discussion of "English Audits of the American Accounts." He says:

The Intercollegiate Fencing Association held its fourth annual competition Saturday afternoon and evening at the Racquet and Tennis Club quarters, on Forty-third Street. The fencing was of excellent character, and showed a marked improvement over that of former exhibitions.

Senator Platt was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning doing his utmost to restore peace within the ranks of the Republican State organization. He returned to Washington at 3:30 o'clock over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

William C. De Witt of Brooklyn, who had so much to do with the Greater New York charter, is displeased with Mayor Strong, not only for his disapproval of that document, but for the criticisms that he has made against it.

ORANGE, N.J., April 11. -- During services in the Italian mission on Cone Street this afternoon Vencenza Masela, one of the attendants at the mission, was stabbed and badly wounded by Mary Pietsuccelli. The cause of the stabbing is uncertain, but it is known that the women have not been good friends for some time past.
A benefit performance was given last night in the Academy of Music for James Mutrie, the old-time baseball man, and one-time manager of the Giants.
For 4,200 miles the American bark Alice Reed, which arrived here yesterday from Montevideo, was navigated by a jury steering gear, creditable to the Yankee ingenuity of her master.

Bicycle "scorchers" fared ill at Yorkville Police Court yesterday. Magistrate Simms assumed charge there, and his sentiments toward the bent-back brigade are by no means friendly. Ten dollars' fine was imposed in eight cases, all of which were supplemented by the remark: "If this does not avail to stop reckless riding and give respectable riders a chance, I will try another way."

Good sparring was the rule in the four boxing bouts given Saturday evening by the Arena Athletic Club, Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. There were three preliminary bouts before the principal contest of the evening.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 11. -- North-bound Florida Special on the Southern Railway, No. 36, and local south-bound Passenger Train No. 11, collided at 11:15 o'clock this morning at Harrisburg, a small town about thirteen miles north of this city, killing three persons and injuring six.

SING SING, April 11. -- The members of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church to-day attended the churches of that denomination in this village. A Conference love feast was held in the Highland Avenue Church, the sermon being preached by the Presiding Bishop, the Rev. Dr. Stephen M. Merrill.

The Vestrymen of St. Ann's Church at a meeting Friday night passed finally upon the question of the consolidation of that church with St. Matthew's. At a meeting held several nights ago eleven out of the twelve Vestrymen were present, and consolidation was agreed upon by a vote of ten to two, the absent member voting in its favor by proxy.
ALBANY, April 11. -- It is doubtful whether the Legislature will be able to adjourn April 24 if all the promises made by the Republican leaders are to be kept.

This is the valedictory month of the oyster. In a few days the blue point will be ignored, except by a few faddists, who insist on eating him all the year round, and the little neck clam, barely big enough to meet legal requirements, will be the delicacy of the season.

Letters from Speaker Thomas B. Reed of the House of Representatives and from Senator Thomas C. Platt were received yesterday by the Central Labor Union, in reply to resolutions that had been passed by that body protesting against the proposed increase of duties on Sumatra wrappers and imported tobacco-leaf.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman preached yesterday morning in the Temple Emanu-El on "The Attitude of the Man of culture Toward Religion." He said:

An editorial article was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES June 18, 1896, calling attention to the pressing need of an express parcel service in this city. The writer said: "There are in various parts of New York and in various parts of the suburbs disappointed and melancholy persons who undertake to transport parcels to some other part of the city or to some other part of the cities.

Some three years ago I ventured to publicly advocate through the press the running of the Brooklyn elevated trains and surface cars continuously across the present tracks and roadways, respectively, of the bridge, and also across this city to the North River and back. The plan was favorably received, but until lately nothing was done in that direction.

Armed Abdallah is stranded. He shipped as a fireman on the British tramp steamship Eddie at Port Said, Feb. 17, and arrived recently in Philadelphia. He complained there to the Turkish Consul that Capt. Hewsin of the Eddie owed him $31, which he had refused to pay, and that he had sailed away again, without him, but taking his kit and dunnage.
LONDON, April 11. -- The Times to-morrow will print the following from its correspondent at Larissa:
Maurice Grau yesterday gave confirmation to the recent assurance of Edward Lauterbach that financial difficulties would not stand in the way of next season's opera in New York.

HAVANA, April 11. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler arrived at Placetas yesterday morning, accompanied by his staff. He came from Sancti Spiritus by way of Cienfuegos and Cruces. The civil and military authorities of the town immediately called upon him, and Capt. Gen. Weyler, in the course of conversation, expressed himself as well satisfied with the operations of the campaign.

LONDON, April ll. -- The money market is unusually easy, the result of the release of 6,000,000 in the form of dividends. This has compelled the Bank of England to reduce the rates, and, although the rates in the open market show only a slight decrease, a further reduction at an early date is fully expected.

ATHENS, April 11. -- Noon. -- Accounts are conflicting as to what really happened last Friday when the frontier was crossed by the insurgents, whose carefully planned invasion is accepted by the Athenians as inaugurating war. The Turks evidently share the view entertained at Athens that the movement was one of great importance.

One of the supplementary bills of the commission provides that the City Court shall be accommodated outside of the City Hall and the rooms now occupied by it shall be remodeled for the use of the Council of the Municipal Assembly. The present Chamber of Aldermen would accommodate the new second house.
We fail to discover the qualifications of a party leader in Mr. BAILEY of Texas, who is at present engaged in leading the Democrats of the House into a condition of lethargy and uselessness.

Except for an hour or two in the afternoon, the weather was a little too cold yesterday for an ideal outing day. People who were deceived by the blue sky and bright sunshine into wandering far from home without their Winter wraps discovered that they had made a mistake. The inclination of Winter to dally a little in the lap of Spring was only too apparent.
The following sales are announced for to-day at 111 Broadway:

Certainly ex-Mayor SCHIEREN and his fellow-leather dealers are perfectly right in their condemnation of the proposed duty on imported hides. That duty is absolutely without any reasonable excuse. It would simply impose a heavy burden on the manufacture of leather and leather products from the first stage to the last.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 11. -- John H. Atkinson, the seventeen-year-old son of Gov. W.Y. Atkinson of Georgia, was married again to-day to Miss Ada Byrd, the sixteen-year-old daughter of C.P. Byrd of Atlanta, Ga., the Rev. Henry McDonald, pastor of the Second Baptist Church of Atlanta officiating.

The various phases of the controversy over the sidewalks of New York have been presented to Gov. Black in the formal request that he veto the Finn Stoop-Line bill. To supplement the written arguments on the subject already laid before the Governor, a delegation of New York property owners and business men will go to Albany to-day as the representatives of the Board of Trade and Transportation.
William Rosenberg, seventeen years old, of 72 Forsyth Street, was held in default of $1,000 bail yesterday, at the Essex Market Court, on a charge of attempted suicide.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The outlook for the week in the Senate is so much befogged by the situation with reference to committee reorganization that it is impossible to forecast the proceedings with any degree of accuracy. There is a possibility that this question may consume a great deal of attention, and if it shall not be disposed of satisfactorily it may be used to prevent effort to secure action on important measures.

Greater New York will assume the city, county, town, village, and district debts of the communities it will absorb. There are indications that these debts already exceed the calculations made when the consolidation was agreed upon and that they will increase to yet more formidable sums.
In a quiet way, but very effectually, the Commissioner of Street Cleaning has practically solved the "labor question" in his department.

OMAHA, Neb., April 12. -- The Missouri River has risen rapidly here since Saturday and is higher now than at any time since 1881, the year of the great flood. At noon the Government gauge showed 14.1 feet above mean low-water mark.

The Baroness Bertha von Bulow of Dresden, Germany, gave a lecture yesterday afternoon on the life and work of her aunt, Baroness von Morenholtz-Bulow, in Assembly Hall of the Charities Building, Twenty-second street and Fourth avenue. The lecture was under the auspices of the New York Free Kindergarten Association.

Mr. DAVID B. HILL may not have any political convictions, but it is not to be denied that he has political perceptions within his own range. His range, indeed, may well have been enlarged by his experiences and the fact that he "has had lapses." At any rate, it is evident that he has reason for the exultation with which he regards the course of legislation at Albany.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The President to-night announced the appointment of Senator Edward O. Wolcott of Colorado, Charles J. Paine of Boston, and ex-Vice President Adlai E. Stevenson as Commissioners to an International Monetary Conference. These appointments are made under the act, approved March 3 last, "for the promotion of an international agreement for bimetallism," and by its provisions do not require confirmation by the Senate.
YONKERS, N.Y., April 12. -- A bold, ingenious, and successful robbery was perpetrated at the Yonkers Savings Bank, at noon to-day.
LONDON, April 12. -- The Times will print to-morrow the following dispatch from its Athens correspondent:
PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- The makeup of the cricket team which will go to England this Summer was finally fixed upon at a meeting of the Associated Cricket Clubs this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- It is said here by persons who are believed to have knowledge of the matter, that Assistant United States Treasurer Jordan, whose term of office will expire in a few days, will be reappointed by President McKinley. Mr. Jordan is a gold Democrat.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 12. -- The mighty sweep of the waters south of Vicksburg has at last had its effect upon the lower levees, and to-night a telegram from Tallelah, La., reports that the levee which protects Davis Island has given way, and the island in all probability will be flooded. Twenty-five hundred people inhabit Davis Island, which consists of about 5,000 acres of land.
In two parts of the Court of General Sessions there were placed on trial yesterday two men who are accused of establishing themselves in business on what they stole from their former employers.

There will have to be a good deal of "jamming" done at Albany this week and next if the Legislature is to adjourn on the 24th, in accordance with the joint resolution already adopted. Not that there is so much really important work to be done, but the flood of local bills, in which members have a peculiar interest, is simply appalling.

The North Side Board of Trade at a meeting held last evening in the board rooms, 278 Alexander Avenue, condemned the Greater New York charter as being crude and imperfect, and commended Mayor Strong's action in refusing to sign it. The meeting was largely attended and President James L. Wells occupied the chair.

ALBANY, April 12. -- Mayor Strong paid a visit to Gov. Black early this morning, observing great secrecy as to the object which inspired it. The Mayor came to the city last evening, and spent the night at the Kenmore Hotel. This morning he went early to the Executive Mansion, reaching the Governor while he was at breakfast.

ALBANY, April 12. -- It is to be presumed from to-night's action that the Legislature will certainly adjourn on April 24. Speaker O'Grady said: "There is no doubt about it at all. We will get through by April 24 and adjourn finally."

ST. LOUIS, April 12. -- Attorney General Crowe has set at rest the efforts to construe the stock breeders bill, signed by Gov. Stephens last week, to cover boxing matches. This idea arose from an awkward line in the bill, which reads:

LONDON, April 12. -- The Daily Chronicle's correspondent at Kalambaka says that at 2 P.M. to-day fighting was still going on a few miles west of Baltino. Many of the irregulars are returning to the frontier for food. This afternoon a Turkish Captain and his men, after heroic resistance, escaped from Baltino.
LARISSA, April 12--4 P.M.--The invaders continue to blockade Baltino. It is reported that Turkish reinforcements are now en route from Diskata.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The sweeping order of President Cleveland effecting a consolidation of pension agencies will be revoked by President McKinley, if present plans are carried out. Though it is stated that no conclusion has been reached on the matter, the President has had time to inquire into it and to hear the protests of Congressional delegations, and it is learned he has become convinced that it should never be allowed to become operative.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 12. -- Edward Farrar of Toronto has written a report on "The Bonding Privilege" addressed to the Chairman of the Committee on Inter-State Commerce of the United States. The report has been prepared at the request of the committee, and is taken from the Blue Books of the Canadian Government and the books of Canadian railways which make use of the bonding privileges.
PARIS, April 12. -The rench Government is sending the dispatch boat Fulton to represent France at the ceremonies attending the dedication of the Grant mausoleum.

Agnes Sorma, the German actress, whose coming had been heralded modestly and sensibly, portrayed Nora Helmer at the Irving Place Theatre last evening with so much facility of expression and so consistently-keeping always in harmony with the "natural" quality of the play, and never sacrificing its superficial verity for the sake of theatrical or pictorial effect -- that her American debut may be recorded as one of the best artistic triumphs of the dramatic season.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 12. -- There was a murmur of surprise when the Senate filed into the House for a joint session. The redoubtable Jack Chinn, who figured so extensively in the session last Winter, occupied a seat at the door, while Capt. Thomas Tanner, who testified before the Grand Jury against Dr. Hunter and his lieutenants, stood just behind him.
The new week at the "Greatest Show on Earth," at the Madison Square Garden, opened last evening with great eclat. The star performer of the evening was the ball-playing dog.
ALBANY, April 13. -- At 2:20 o'clock the bill amending the Raines liquor-tax law was passed by a vote of 32 to 15, Senators Wieman and Lamy voting with the minority.

D. Edgar Anthony, who has been confined in Ludlow Street Jail for nearly two years on charges of contempt and larceny, was arraigned for trial yesterday before Judge McMahon in General Sessions, but at the request of his counsel the case went over for two weeks.

ALBANY, April 12. -- The amendments to the Raines liquor-tax law, which have been adopted by the Republican Senators in caucus, and thereby made a party measure, and which will be passed without change by both branches of the Legislature during the week, have been printed, and are practically for the first time in the hands of the public.

Ella Cooper, a poor artist, died of consumption, in obscurity and want, just before noon Sunday, in her room, at 357 West Twenty-fifth Street. It was the end of a life of ambition, struggle, disappointment, and despair. She had been reared in luxury, had traveled, had studied art in Italy and France, and had come back to New York to win fame ad independence.
ALBANY, April 12. -- In the Assembly tonight Mr. Ives of St Lawrence offered the following resolution which was adopted by a rising vote:

Charles Bary of Chicago and ex-Mayor Peter J. Somers of Milwaukee, who are of counsel in the great McKee scrip litigation, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon and are staying at the Buckingham Hotel. While they have come here on business connected with the Mexican Southeastern Railroad Company, of which Mr. Bary is general counsel, they will soon go on to Washington to attend the rehearing of the McKee scrip matter.

Gen. Granville M. Dodge, Grand Marshal of the Grant Monument inaugural parade, announced yesterday his decision not to consider applications for position in the line of parade after Thursday next. After that day it will be impracticable to assign positions to newcomers, and there have already been received applications from so many and such numerous bodies that the parade threatens to be unwieldy.

The Citizens' Union took possession of its new house at 39 East Twenty-third Street yesterday. Some of the members dropped in during the day to see what the new headquarters are alike, and among these were James B. Reynolds, John C. Clark, and John B. Pine. New furniture has been bought, and in a few days the house will be ready for visitors and business.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Senator Foraker is a much sought-after man. Office seekers from his own State and from some other States are of the opinion that he has a keen scent for places, and a tenacity and power of grip upon the Administration that render him well nigh invincible. It is a very unfortunate and unwelcome reputation, and the Senator does not enjoy or attempt to justify it.

LONDON, April 12. -- Sir Charles Dilke, in the House of Commons to-day, said he believed the majority of the nation supported the Liberals in their views on the Eastern question. A blockade of the Piraeus, he contended, though it might upset the King and the Kingdom of Greece, could not restore order in Crete.

LONDON, April 12. -- The Washington correspondent of The Times says that the appointment of John W. Foster and C.S. Hamlin, the retiring Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, to co-operate on behalf of the American Treasury Department in the fur-seal controversy, seems to indicate the immediate reopening of the vexed and vexing Bering Sea question.

The Executive Committee of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company will meet Maurice Grau, Edward Lauterbach, and Jean de Reszke at the Opera House to-day at 4:15 P.M. Robert Goelet is now in Europe, but George S. Bowdoin, George G. Haven, and William C. Whitney all expect to be on hand to represent the Opera House Company.

ALBANY, April 12. -- Gov. Black to-night sent to Senator Lexow, in the Senate, and to Assemblyman Scherer, in the Assembly, a bill embodying his ideas of civil service. In the main, they are a total abrogation of the present laws, and put in the hands of the heads of each department of the State or city the examination of candidates, and require only an examination as to fitness for the office to be filled.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., April 12. -- The first step toward putting into effect the prison reform law, passed by the last General Assembly of Indiana, having for its purpose the reformation of the penal system, was taken this morning, when a train loaded with convicts serving sentences in the Jeffersonville Prison, started on its journey to Michigan City.

LONDON, April 12. -- A special dispatch from Trikhala says that the Turkish garrison of Baltino, numbering about 800 men, which was besieged by the Greek insurgents, has cut its way through the Greeks, with a loss of thirty men killed. It is added that the fighting was stubborn. It was only at the fourth attempt that the Turks were able to issue from their barracks.

Mr. GOSCHEN'S farewell to the new British Commissioner in South Africa has, it seems, created much excitement in London. No wonder. The speech of the First Lord of the Admiralty is in violent contrast with the action of the Colonial Secretary at the time of the Jameson raid.
HAVANA, April 12. -- Jose Gonzales Rogero, classed as an insurgent incendiary, was shot at Cabanas fortress this morning.
ALBANY, April 12. -- These bills have passed the Assembly:

Dr. BILLINGS addressed to the Booksellers' League the other evening a strong plea in favor of a remonstrance to Congress against that clause of the Dingley bill which taxes the importation of all books indiscriminately. He suggested that the league should endeavor to have substituted for it a clause freeing from duty all books, photographs, and engravings imported for the use of Government or public libraries.

The rain ceased yesterday, the sun shone, and finally set behind the Jersey hills, and still Miss Grace Dinsmore of "Binghamton" so far as known was in possession of her full complement of digits. The expression "so far as known" is used advisedly, because Miss Dinsmore left the Grand Union Hotel Sunday with all her luggage.
WASHINGTON, April 12. -- In the course of an interview with a representative of The Associated Press to-day Moustapha Bey, the Turkish Minister, said:

ALBANY, April 12. -- Immediately after the reading of the journal in the Senate tonight, Senator Raines, in accordance with the notice given by him last week, moved to suspend the necessary rule, so that the Senate could go into the committee of the whole and discuss the proposed amendments to the Raines liquor-tax law.

If the towns and villages which are to form the fringe of the Greater New York are making haste to provide for public improvements and to issue bonds to meet the expense, on the ground that their indebtedness is to be absorbed in that of the great municipality, they should remember also that their property is to become subject to taxation for the support of all that huge burden.

To avoid callers and escape the penalty of the notoriety that their secret marriage has caused, Mr. and Mrs. Elliott F. Shepard left the Plaza Hotel early yesterday, and did not return until late at night. It is their intention to sail for Europe this week. After a few months' absence Mr. Shepard proposes to settle down in this city and practice law.
The Rev. Alexander McKenzie of Cambridge, Mass., is to preach the baccalaureate sermon at Cornell University on Sunday, June 13.

ALBANY, April 12. -- The Amsterdam Electric Light, Heat and Power Company, organized to furnish electricity for heat, power, and lighting public streets and private buildings in the City of Brooklyn and other cities, villages, and towns within the State, filed certificates of incorporation today. Its capital stock is $500,000, divided into hundred-dollar shares. The Directors are Frank G. Writer and Edward J. Prost of New York City and Henry Keale of Brooklyn.

TAMPA, Fla., April 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. James H. Prince of Boston have been spending several weeks at the Punta Gorda Hotel, at Punta Gorda, on the west coast. They have returned to Tampa Bay and will remain for some time yet.
The Democratic Party comes for the first time clearly into view in our history in a letter of THOMAS JEFFERSON to President WASHINGTON, written Sept. 9, 1792:

PRINCETON, April 12. -- The Boston League team defeated the Princeton Tigers in a closely contested baseball game played here this afternoon. Score, 3 to 2. For Princeton, Jayne, a substitute, occupied the box during the entire game. Fewer hits were made by the Bostonians off his delivery than the Tigers secured from the three League twirlers who pitched for Boston.

At a conference held in the meeting room in Cooper Union by representatives of the sound-money Democrat in this city last night, it was decided to perfect the local organization of the National Democratic Party and to hold the first primary election on May 5. A plan of organization was adopted.

The preliminary examination in the case of Capt. Edward W. Reed of the American ship T.F. Oakes, who is charged with withholding a suitable allowance of food from his crew on a recent voyage from Hongkong, causing an epidemic of scurvy among the men, of which five are alleged to have died at sea, was resumed yesterday morning before Commissioner Shields in the Federal Building.
