At the semi-annual meeting of the New York Presbytery, in the First Church, Eleventh Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday, this letter was read by the Moderator, the Rev. Dr. W.D. Buchanan:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 12. -- C.F. Moore, alias H.J. Sanford, who was arrested at Jamestown, N.Y., on the charge of forgery, is well-known in Cleveland. He lived with his wife at 1,659 Willson Avenue. Last Summer he purchased a grocery on Woodland Avenue. Soon thereafter he sold it, and last September he entered into partnership in the insurance and real estate business.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 12. -- Miss Mellie Logan, nineteen years old, was received for treatment to-day at the hospital, well-nigh insane, and the bruises upon her person showing ill treatment of the severest sort.

LONDON, April 12. -- The Daily News will publish to-morrow the following description forwarded by its special correspondent yesterday, of the incidents attending the starting out of the Grecians who made the raid into Macedonia:

The great Irvington-Millburn handicap will be held over the course so well known to the racing men of this country, but this season's contest will undoubtedly take rank as the most important of all that have been held.

The rural forces which control the Legislature of this State are determined to force through the amendments of the Raines liquor-tax law, in spite of the strenuous objections of the people of this city, irrespective of party. In this they have the active instigation of Gov. BLACK and the acquiescence of "Boss" PLATT.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12. -- Mrs. Jennie Young, the woman who assumed the name of Mrs. D.M. Delmas, is not a Baroness after all. The man she married in Oakland on Saturday, and with whom she is now speeding across the Continent on her wedding tour, is not the Baron Robert Ludwig von Turkheim.

ELASSONA, April 12. -- The Turkish staff officer who was sent to Krania by Edhem Pasha to ascertain definitely with respect to the invasion reports that the presence of Greek regulars among the invaders has been positively proved, and that there is also good reason to believe that Greek officers of the regular army were in command.
HAVANA, April 13. -- Senor Fontanals, the public prosecutor who is to push the trial of the Government officials arrested at Cienfuegos by order of Capt. Gen. Weyler at Cienfuegos, has arrived there.

LONDON, April 13. -- A representative of the Associated Press has learned that communications are passing between Washington and London with reference to the Bering Sea. The greatest secrecy is observed here on the subject.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- William J. Bryan was the guest of honor and the principal speaker at the one hundred and fifty-fourth anniversary celebration of Jefferson's birthday at the Metropolitan Hotel under the auspices of the National Association of Democratic Clubs. The first celebration was held in the same place, which was known as the Indian Queen at the time.

The occupants of the "Steinhardt" flats, at the northwestern corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, have been burning kerosene instead of gas since March 22. The reason for it all is that the East River Gas Company will not supply gas to the building because of the unpaid bill of a former owner.

Arguments were submitted before Justice Pryor in the Supreme Court yesterday in the case brought by Simons Sons against James McCusker. Simons Sons have a store on the corner of West Broadway and Bleecker Street, and McCusker keeps a newsstand under the station of the elevated railway.

District Attorney Olcott, who has been investigating the failure of the E.S. Dean Company, brokers, of 35 Broadway, turned over to Assistant District Attorney Allen yesterday a number of complaints and other papers relating to the methods of the defunct company. Mr. Allen will sift the matter, and it will depend upon his investigation whether or not the case will be laid before the Grand Jury.

The names of Birge and Alexander Harrison have ranked high among those of younger American painters for some years past. The work of Birge Harrison first attracted public attention some fifteen years ago, and Alexander Harrison may be said to have achieved fame and reputation by his superb "La Crepuscule" -- that poetic rendering of the calm expanse of ocean at sunset which was first shown in New York about ten years ago.

The killing of a lad of sixteen on St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday evening by a bicycle rider of the expert type is another warning that the speed of wheel riding in the public streets must be much more narrowly and firmly restricted. The usual notion that the speed allowed to wagons will be safe for wheels is a delusion, since the wheel is noiseless and the bell is often rather confusing than useful.

The route of the Grant monument inaugural parade, as announced several days ago by Gen. Dodge, will not be changed. That point was settled yesterday at a conference between Gen. Dodge, Commissioner Grant, President McMillan of the Park Board, Chief of Police Conlin, President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Traction Company, and President Elias of the Third Avenue Railroad Company.

ALBANY, April 13. -- A conference of Republicans was held at the Delavan House to-night, at which thirty-five Assemblymen were present who oppose the Raines amendments. It lasted until nearly midnight.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 13. -- There was no contest here to-day, except for member at large of the Township Committee. On this office the town was divided between trolley and anti-trolley, which meant an expression by vote as to whether some of the avenues should be given over to the trolley companies.
The bill in which Gov. BLACK has "embodied his ideas" of the regulation of the civil service is likely to be very mischievous.

There will be no grand opera under the management of Maurice Grau or under that of the corporation of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, Limited, in this city next season. As the possibility of grand opera conducted by the proprietors of the Metropolitan Opera House is practically out of the question as well, the chance of having it in New York at all next Winter is slim.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., April 13. -- Ex-Vice President Stevenson said to-day, when questioned about his appointment on the commission for the promotion of an international agreement: "I appreciate the compliment paid to me by the President, and will cheerfully render what assistance I can to accomplish the object of the commission.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Treasurer Spalding of the Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois, who was expected to come before the meeting of the board and explain the disappearance of the university funds intrusted to his keeping, failed to put in an appearance. At the meeting, which was held behind closed doors, E.G. Keith was elected Treasurer in Mr. Spalding's place.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Weather Bureau in its report of weather crop conditions for the week ended April 11, says:

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Senator Chandler to-day introduced his bills empowering the Secretary of the Navy to take possession of the armor plants of the Bethlehem and Carnegie Companies. There are two of the bills, one applying to each of the institutions, the provisions being the same in both.
An officer of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad writes to a New York stockholder as follows:
ALBANY, April 13. -- Senator Grady's bill prohibiting the desecration of the American flag by using it for advertising purposes passed the Senate without debate by a vote of 29 to 15.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Gov. Black's Civil Service bill, whose main provisions were printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, is to be passed under machine orders, if the statements of the party leaders are correct. It came from Gov. Black direct to Senator Lexow and Assemblyman Scherer, the Chairmen of the Judiciary Committees of the two houses, and it is supposed to embody the Governor's idea of a "civil service with less starch."

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 13. -- A masterly graveyard insurance swindle was unearthed to-day by the arrest of C. Linford Wood, alias Charles L. Wood, on complaint of the Mutual Reserve Fund Company of New York. He confessed to having placed about $400,000 insurance on aged and decrepit men since January, with the policies all assigned to himself, either as beneficiary or as a creditor.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A letter from Secretary Gage was received by the Senate to-day, responding to the resolution of inquiry as to orders issued to customs officers to delay liquidation of entries made of merchandise arriving after April 1 last. The Secretary explains that the order is in accordance with authority conferred on him by law.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Bellamy Storer is to Senator Foraker a sort of Banquo's ghost that will not down. Before and since the incoming of the new Administration the locks of Storer have been shaken in the eyes of Foraker, who has succeeded, because of his skill and power as a politician, in dissipating the vision of greatness which appeared to have opened for the other man from Ohio.

The Board of Health yesterday adopted a resolution quarantining the House of Refuge, under the charge and care of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents in the City of New York, on Randall's Island. The effect of the quarantine resolution is to prevent the commitment of prisoners to it.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Senator Wolcott is hopeful that the International Monetary Commission, of which he is a member, will be able to bring about international bimetallism. He looks forward to hard work, but says that from what he learned abroad last year he is most sanguine of results.

ALBANY, April 13. -- There was a call of the House in the Assembly this evening at 6 o'clock on Senator Burns's bill providing for the building, operation, and maintenance of a system of sewage disposal of the Bronx River, the Hudson River, and the Westchester Creek valleys in the Counties of New York and Westchester.
" We are opposed to the free coinage of silver except by international agreement with the leading commercial nations of the world, which we pledge ourselves to promote."

ALBANY, April 13. -- The Greater New York Charter bill, with Mayor Strong's veto, was sent from the Assembly to the Senate this morning. A discussion ensued, and Senator Pavey made a heated arraignment of the measure. He said:

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld has been enjoined from disposing of his property, which is involved in the Globe Savings Bank failure. There will be a legislative investigation of the manner in which the university's funds were lost in the bank.

It is with a natural feeling of temerity that I hazard an opinion which conflicts with the able articles published by your excellent paper, while I have differed repeatedly with statements you have so lucidly published. I shall not for one moment attempt to go into a protracted denial or refutation of those statements.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Word reached the Navy Department to-day, from Commander Whiting, in charge of the Puget Sound Naval Station, Washington, that the battleship Oregon had grounded while approaching the dock into which she was about to go to have her bottom scraped and painted.

President Angell of the Brooklyn Good Roads Association has not given up all idea of securing a new path in place of the old one on the west side of the Ocean Boulevard, running from Prospect Park to the ocean.

Opponents of the Greater New York charter should make the record complete by bringing their arguments, their protests, and their remonstrances before Gov. BLACK with all their force. The Governor, so far as we know, is not committed upon the question of consolidation now or in the future, or upon the charter as it is or as it ought to be.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Louise Willis Hepner, recently of the Gaiety Theatre, went before Justice Hall this afternoon and filed a suit against Clifford's Olympia Company, owners of the Gaiety Theatre. The suit is for wages amounting to $195. It will come up for hearing April 26.

Yesterday's stock market did not show much broadening, but wherever it was even fairly active it was firm, and in some quarters it was almost buoyant. Several advances of more than a whole point were made.

SING SING, N.Y., April 13. -- The New York Conference ended its week's session to-day, Bishop Stephen M. Merrill presiding. One of the first questions was introduced by the Rev. Thomas S. Bond, who read the following:

There is little hope that we shall have regular opera next season. It is worth while pointing out that this will be our own fault -- that is to say, the fault of the opera-going public. What the manager of the opera and the Directors of the Opera House desire to do, and what they need to do, is to attract the public.

A great crowd of women attended yesterday's three sessions of the New York East Methodist Conference, in St. John's Church, Bedford Avenue and Wilson Street, Brooklyn. Every seat not reserved for the Conference members was occupied by them, and they stood a dozen deep in the aisles and at the rear of the pews.
John G.R. Lilliendahl sold to Andrew J. Shipman the three-story and basement dwelling in Audubon Park, West One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street.

A notable meeting of the Board of Control of the Joint Traffic Association was held yesterday at the Central Building. Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad and Chairman of the board, presided. Of the thirty-two roads having representation in the board only two, the Philadelphia and Reading Railway and the Terre Haute and Indianapolis Railroad, were unrepresented.

Joseph Adams, who was sentenced on Monday last to three years in Sing Sing Prison for forgery, has made a confession, in which he admits having swindled the Columbia Bank of this city out of $580. This is the crime for which Alonzo J. Whiteman was tried and acquitted last week.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 13.--"Stiff" Harper, a well-known and handsome young printer, who was "devil" in The People's Tribune shop, and Miss Afton Hauser, daughter of Mr. D.M. Hauser, who travels for a Knoxville music house and tunes pianos, are married. The girl is fourteen, the youth seventeen years of age.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 13. -- The Senate has passed Mr. Burns's bill, which is supposed to be aimed at some of the alleged "fake" insurance companies in the State, providing that organizers of mutual benefit fire insurance companies in New York and Kings Counties shall have $5,000 worth of real estate, and in other counties $2,500 worth of real estate.

ALBANY, April 13.--The State Railroad Commission to-day granted the application of the Penn Yan, Keuka Park and Branchport Electric Railroad Company for permission to build a road from Penn Yan to Branchport, in Yates County.

LONDON, April 13. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says that the commanding officers of the Greek troops in Thessaly and Epirus have been ordered to telegraph the Ministry of War next Thursday detailed reports as to the efficiency of the troops and to point out any deficiencies.

A Pinkerton detective who has had a great deal of experience in pursuing bank robbers on behalf of the American Bankers' Association came to the conclusion yesterday, after patient investigation, that the three men who robbed the Yonkers Savings Bank in broad daylight Monday were old and shrewd hands at the business.

Funeral services for Charles W. Nash, the veteran restaurant keeper, were held at his late residence, 9 East Twelfth Street, yesterday afternoon. Mr. Nash had outlived most of his old associates, and the attendance at the funeral, therefore, was confined almost wholly to intimate friends of the family and neighbors.
NEWPORT, Ky., April 13. -- A well-filled card of six races was run off at Newport to-day over a slow track. One favorite, three second choices, and a "hundred-to-one shot" won the money.

The sale of hackneys and coach horses at the American Horse Exchange yesterday, most of them from John Jacob Astor's Ferncliff Stud at Rhinebeck, N.Y., resulted satisfactorily in all but one case. The exception was in the price brought by the hackney stallion Confident Shot, the star of the sale. Four years ago Mr. Astor purchased the stallion from William Easton, who brought him to this country, for $3,000.

A few years ago an ingenious person in a Western city put an advertisement in the papers thereof offering his services, so to speak, to vivisectors in want of subjects. We are not aware that the advertisement brought any vivisectors, or that the advertiser rendered any service to the pathological branch of human knowledge.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The Japanese Legation has received advices from official sources in relation to the recent deportation from the Hawaiian Islands of a number of Japanese immigrants, which do not agree in all details with the accounts already published in this country.

Members of the Assembly from the larger cities of the State are showing a disposition to stand together regardless of party against the Raines law amendments which were jammed through the Senate at a late hour of Monday night. There is great doubt about their being able to stem the tide of rural partisanship.
MEMPHIS, April 14. -- Despite the inclement weather, a large crowd was at Montgomery Park to-day. It was cold and disagreeable. The track was heavy. Summaries:

ALBANY, N.Y., April 14. -- Controller Roberts and President of the State Board of Charities Stewart are working bard today to obtain an appropriation of $37,000 in the Supply bill for the building of a sewerage system at Randall's Island to relieve the present condition. The Assembly struck out the appropriation, but the Senate committee agreed to put it in again.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 14. -- Constable Henry Dipple this morning journeyed to Lodi to arrest Frederick Darlington. Dipple found Darlington sitting on the front stoop. He read the warrant, which recited that Darlington had been indicted for keeping and maintaining a nuisance. There are about 200 geese on his place, and the farm and house are offensive to the neighbors.
ALBANY, April 14. -- The attempt of the Republican Assemblymen to make the Raines amendments a caucus measure tonight developed the most serious break in the party that has occurred this session.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson has been inquiring into the subject of foreign markets for American products, and one conclusion he has reached is that the butter trade should be extended. In an interview to-day he says the United States last year made more good butter than the home demand required.
" GOV. BLACK'S bill does not aim to revolutionize the existing civil service law, but to abolish it."

The Metropolitan Traction Company yesterday gave out a statement intended as an answer to the request for information made to the Board of Aidermen by representatives of the Knights of Labor on Tuesday. The statement showed that during the year the Metropolitan Company paid $591,890, including the State tax, while the Third Avenue Company has paid $69,051.70. This statement
Alexander E. Orr, President of the House of Refuge on Randall's Island, which was quarantined by order of the Board of Health on Tuesday, said yesterday that the action of the board was very severe.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The President to-day sent the following message to Congress, urging it to make suitable provision for adequate representation of the United States at the Paris Exposition:

The New York Board of Trade and Transportation discussed several reports of committees presented at the monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, and passed resolutions on various matters. Darwin R. James presided.

HAVANA, (via Key West,) April 14. -- The expedition under Gen. Roloff, by the steamer Laurada, carrying 2,400 rifles, 500,000 cartridges, and several pieces of rapid-firing artillery, landed alongside the quay of Banes. Gen. Calixto Garcia, with 5,000 men, came to protect the convoy of arms and ammunition; but as Roloff had no men to arm Garcia was compelled to carry the arms into the interior.

The amendment to the anti-trust law introduced in the House yesterday by Mr. SHANNON (Rep.) of this State has one feature of prime importance. It provides that the act shall not prohibit traffic agreements between competing transportation companies, but it requires that "such agreements, before going into effect, shall be submitted to and approved by the Inter-State Commerce Commission, and that a copy of all such agreements shall be filed with said commission."

-- That airship to which all the Western papers and some of the Eastern ones are now giving the benefit of several doubts, is visible nightly to correspondents in all parts of Illinois, Wisconsin, Michigan, Indiana, and Iowa. The aerial voyager evidently is a Mahatma of high development, for he exists in a dozen places at once and has a different appearance and does different things in each of them.

Jennie Keating, aged twenty, of 68 Downing Street, this city, was the young woman who was killed in the runaway accident. Tuesday night on Ocean Boulevard, Brooklyn. Miss Keating went for a drive to Coney Island with James Cotter, of 20 Fourth Street, Brooklyn, who is an employe of Spellman, the hatter, on Broadway.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

ALBANY, N.Y., April 14. -- The Ticket Brokers' Association has prepared an amendment to the bill just passed forbidding the members to do business. It will be introduced by Senator Ford, and reads as follows:

The Assembly Committee on General Laws, to which the Ellsworth Anti-Portrait bill was referred, has made that measure quite innocuous by the simple process of making it altogether useless and practically of no effect. It might be further improved by striking out the enacting clause, but if it should become a law in its present shape it would be a still-born "letter."

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The President has decided to recommend to Congress an appropriation as indemnity for the killing by a mob of lynchers of three Italian citizens at Hahnville, La., Aug. 8 last.

Additional evidence was heard yesterday before Commissioner Shields, in the case of Capt. Edward W. Reed of the ship T. F. Oakes, who is charged with causing an epidemic of scurvy among his crew through an improper allowance of food and medicine, on a recent voyage of the vessel from Hongkong to this port.

We have already remarked upon the incongruity of the appearance of Mr. BRYAN as the chief speaker at a Jefferson birthday banquet. The incongruity was heightened by the address which the orator delivered and in which he showed himself as a kind of inverted Bourbon. Certainly he has learned nothing since last November, not even the absurdity of imputing to JEFFERSON the scheme of general repudiation which he chooses to describe as "independent bimetallism."

There was a melancholy interest in the performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It was the last performance, including the famous De Reszke brothers as Siegfried and Wotan. This, indeed, made it a sad occasion for a public which has decreed that grand opera cannot exist in the metropolis of America without these two artists.

The refunding plan of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company and the New York and Harlem Railroad Company was officially announced as decided on yesterday. At the head of the syndicate which is to convert the bonds are J. Pierpont Morgan Co. of New York and J.S. Morgan Co. of London.

That Senator FORAKER is a singularly "forthputting" statesman has long been known. There is no authentic instance of his having gone without anything that he wanted through having omitted to ask for it, and he wants a great deal. It has become a practical question for the President whether he does not want too much.

ALBANY, April 14. -- At about 7:30 o'clock to-night Republican Assemblymen who were undecided as to attending the caucus on the Raines law began gathering in the Assembly library. At 8 o'clock Assemblyman Murphy of New York called this conference to order, and was selected to act as Chairman by the twenty-seven members who were present at that time.

Gentlemen in this city who have been conspicuous in their opposition to the present form of the Greater New York charter, and who intend to fight it before the Governor in spite of the overwhelming vote in both houses of the Legislature, were a little disconcerted yesterday when they received news by wire that the Governor had fixed a public hearing on the subject for 10 o'clock Monday morning in Albany.

A case has been brought in Special Sessions to test the right of flower vendors and other peddlers to carry on their business on the sidewalks. The defendant is James Vios, a licensed peddler, who is represented by Attorney R.J. Haire. The case for the people is conducted by Attorneys Seth B. Robinson and Charles De Hart Brower, by consent of District Attorney Olcott.

BOSTON, April 14. -- Gen. Charles J. Paine, the Boston member of the International Monetary Conference Commission, said to a TIMES reporter to-day that he joined Gen. Walker's Committee of One Hundred three years ago, for the promotion of international bimetallism, and that the declaration of principles published at that time represented his views on the question to-day. The declaration is as follows:

The monthly meeting of the Board of Trustees of the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden foundations, was held at the Astor Library yesterday afternoon. The following resolutions were adopted and ordered spread on the minutes. Copies will be sent to the New York Representatives and other members of Congress:
ALBANY, April 14. -- The Good Roads question had its innings for the first time in the Legislature this year in the Senate to-day and won a signal victory.

ATHENS, April 14. -- On the reassembling of the Boule to-day, M. Delyannis, the Premier, introduced a bill granting the Government a credit of 23,000,000 drachmas for the Ministries of War and Marine.
ALBANY, April 14. -- Senator Raines today received the following telegram from Senator Piatt in Washington with reference to the Raines liquor tax amendments:

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Governor still refrains from indicating his sentiments concerning the charter. The men who have been instrumental in passing it twice through both branches of the Legislature believe there is no possibility of a veto. If Gov. Black had not intended to sign it, they say, he certainly would not have it allowed it to go thus far.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee met at 10 o'clock this morning, and after a session of an hour and a half an adjournment was taken until this afternoon, without any definite action being taken on the anti-trust bills. Several amendments were presented, with the object of making them less sweeping, but none was agreed to.

By far the most important announcement contained in the bulletin of the Racing Board this week, issued yesterday, is the notice of the League of American Wheelmen to terminate the alliance existing between that body and the Union Cycliste de France.
ALBANY, April 14. -- During the reports of committees in the Senate Senator Grady moved to discharge the Judiciary Committee from the further consideration of the anti-trust bills.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- David Martin, long the leader of the local Republican "combine" which has for years been warning with the Quay faction for political supremacy, stated to-day that he meant to retire from leadership.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 14. -- C. Linford Wood, in jail here for attempting a gigantic insurance swindle, implicates an instructor at West Point. Wood secured forty policies in his name, $200,000 of these being with the Mutual Reserve Association of New York the remainder with the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company.

The refunding plan of the New York Central Railroad Company, involving securities to the amount of $85,000,000, following the like arrangement for the Lake Shore, involving some $50,000,000, is the latest and most striking evidence of the tendency toward cheapness of loanable capital. Its tendency necessarily is to advance the market price of outstanding securities bearing a higher rate of interest and to reduce the net returns of future investments in such securities.

It is a puzzling thing to many people that the Republican politicians in control of legislation at Albany should insist upon "jamming through" the Greater New York charter and the Raines law amendments, and otherwise proceeding in a manner to alienate support from their party in this city, when the inevitable result must be the defeat of that party in all this part of the State.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The House was in session but ten minutes to-day and then adjourned until Saturday. As soon as the Journal had been read Mr. Dingley made a motion that when the House adjourns it be until Saturday. Mr. De Armond of Missouri and Mr. Simpson of Kansas immediately demanded a division. The vote on the motion was 131 to 38.

The lady who has brought suit for certain injuries arising from the brutal behavior of a conductor on a Broadway car has set an example of public spirit which deserves to be commended. The conductors of cable cars are much like other people in being very unlike each other. Some are good-natured and desirous of promoting the comfort of their passengers.

LONDON, April 14. -- The book written by Mrs. John Hays Hammond, wife of the American engineer, who was a member of the Johannesburg Reform Committee, and who was sentenced to death and subsequently liberated upon the payment of a heavy fine, was published to-day. It is entitled "A Woman's Part in the Revolution," and consists mainly in personal experiences.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The committee appointed by the Republican caucus of the Senate to arrange with the opposition a plan for the reorganization of the Senate committees to-day decided to reject the proposition made yesterday by the committee representing the alliance of the Democrats, Populists, and Silver Republicans and to ask for another conference with a view of reaching a more satisfactory understanding.

Somebody stole a pocketbook from Mrs. Mary Green of 170 Perry Street yesterday while she was attending the funeral of a relative at St. Veronica's Church, in Christopher Street. She accused John Donohue, sixty-three years old, and insisted on searching him as soon as the services were concluded.

If Judge PECKHAM could get a crack at the Dingley bill, he might find plenty of chances for a ringing condemnation of many of its provisions as being in "restraint of trade." We should like very much to see him apply the anti-trust law of 1890, for instance, to the agreement between the manufacturers of tin plate and the Dingley committee.

Lovers of fine show and harness horses as well as a large number of dealers were attracted to the American Horse Exchange, Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday afternoon by the sale of the first consignment of show and other harness horses, the property of M.H. Tichenor Co. of Chicago, Ill.

ALBANY, April 14. -- The Assembly passed two important prison bills. One compels the marking of all prison-made goods from other States sold in this State, and the other abrogates the last year bill providing that only persons sentenced for less than one year can be sent to county penitentiaries by making it read five years.

The revised returns of the election in Jersey City, which were completed yesterday, show that Edward Hoos, Democrat, for Mayor, received 15,264 votes, and J. Herbert Potts, Republican, 12,018 votes, giving Hoos a majority of 3,246. The new Board of Aldermen, which will convene on the first Tuesday in May, will comprise twenty Democrats and five Republicans, a Democratic gain of one.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 14. -- Ben L. Carpenter, whose trial, conviction, and sentence to hang for the murder of J.E. Hannibel, a farmer of Ashley County, this State, in 1895, is well known to the reading public, was to-day granted a full pardon by Gov. Jones.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 14. -- Saratoga has been selected for the New York State Division bicycle meet, which will continue two days during the week beginning June 21. The local arrangements will be made under the charge of the Good Roads Association.

SING SING, N.Y., April 14. -- One of the last acts of the New York Methodist Episcopal Conference last night before adjourning sine die was the reading of a letter from the leader of the Sing Sing Prison choir, thanking the conference, on behalf of the choir, for attending the concert last Saturday.
In talking yesterday of bond market conditions and investment sentiment, Mr. Henry S. Kerr of Redmond, Kerr Co. said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:
PASCOGA, R.I., April 14. -- A horrible tragedy was enacted early this morning at the home of Edward Reynolds, on the Eliza Matthewson place, near Sweethill, in the town of Oakland.

Joseph Adams, who pleaded guilty to forgery last Thursday, and who on Tuesday was alleged to have made a confession taking upon himself the crime of which Alonzo J. Whiteman was acquitted, denied yesterday that he had made any such confession. Whiteman had been accused of swindling the Columbia Bank, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, by means of a forged draft on the National City Bank of Brooklyn.

The sale of 19,500 packages of domestic cotton goods, by order of Catlin Co., commission agents, which was held yesterday in the auction room of Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, 64 and 66 White Street, proved to be the largest sale of its kind that has taken place in this city within the last two years.
Faulkner, the veteran trainer who looked after Titus, Cabanne, and Ziegler when they were in winning form, contemplates taking a team of American riders to Europe this season.

Ex-Controller Theodore W. Myers declined yesterday to talk about the charges entertained by The Governors of the Stock Exchange against Charles Neukirch, Exchange member of Theodore Myers Co. of 32 New Street, or of the affairs of this firm. Mr. Myers is not a member of the firm, but is often in its offices and regarded as identified with its interests.

Just before the New York East Conference of Methodist ministers adjourned yesterday in St. John's Church. Williamsburg, a resolution was adopted by which the Conference placed itself on record as being against the use of the bicycle or trolley cars or cable cars on the Sabbath. An effort to debate the resolution was shut off.

Because of a combination of unforseen circumstances, the annual parade of the New York Coaching Club on May 1 has been abandoned for this season. It will be the first time in the history of the club, which was organized in 1870, that the club has failed to give its annual turnout.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Navy Department is much exercised over an order to Lieut. Peary, the arctic explorer, to leave the New York navy yard and go to Mare Island, California. Lieut. Peary's friends and persons actively interested in polar explorations are raising a fund in New York to defray the expense of another expedition to be conducted by Lieut. Peary into the far north.

NEW ORLEANS, April 15. -- The Moresque Building, on Camp Street, between Poindras and North Streets, occupied by the B.J. Montgomery Furniture Company and John Gauches's Sons, crockery, caught fire last night. The Moresque Building, with its contents, was entirely destroyed.

-- What seemed in its inception to be a most promising social and economic experiment has just come to a disappointing end in Baltimore. Twenty-six years ago Mr. ROSS WINANS was led by his interest in the condition of workingmen to spend $500,000 in the erection of 104 four-story brick houses on land which he owned.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Senate, on motion of Mr. Gorman of Maryland, agreed that in consideration of to-morrow being Good Friday, the adjournment to-day be until next Monday. The Senate at 12:15 went into executive session on the arbitration treaty. The open session was resumed at 1:50 P.M., and the Indian Appropriation bill taken up.

HAVANA, April 15. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler has ordered the erection of an infirmary on the trocha and the extension of the military hospitals, in view of the approach of the rainy season. New hospitals will be constructed under the supervision of the Sanitary Inspector General at Trinidad, Casilda, Isabella, and Sagua.
George R. Read has sold for Mrs. C. Berger, to Ambrose K. Ely, the four-story brick tenement, with store, 96 Gold Street, 23.5 by 96.
It is reported that the chemical laboratory at Dartmouth College was broken into last Sunday night and much damage done to the apparatus, especially to many of the finer instruments.

RICHMOND, April 15. -- The Supreme Court to-day rendered a decision affecting bequests made for the benefit of religious denominations, in which an interesting principle was laid down. The case was that of the executors of Mrs. Lenora Van Wyck, and involves $75,000. This lady was a resident of New York, and died last December in Norfolk, Va., where her will was probated.

OMAHA, Neb., April 15. -- The flood situation to-night is grave. All day torrents poured from the Missouri across the North Omaha gardens into Florence and cut-off lakes. The former has lost its identity in the general flood, and the latter may soon.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 15. -- The new laws went into force at midnight by the Governor's proclamation. Chief interest here attaches to the three-cent street car fare. The Citizens' Street Railroad Company gave no instructions to conductors, and declines to consider the law until a decision is reached in the Federal Court, where a test case is under argument.

LARISSA, April 15. -- In all, the Greeks have about 80,000 regulars and some 20,000 irregulars on the frontier, but they count a great deal on reinforcements to their armies through risings in Epirus, Albania, and Macedonia.

In view of the suit brought by Mrs. S.J. Hassett-Choate against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, for damages for alleged brutal treatment by the conductor of a Broadway cable car, a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday asked President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Company about his instructions to conductors as to their treatment of passengers.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The passage by the Assembly of the liquor tax amendments in precisely the same form as they passed the Senate now sends them to the Governor. Their passage was not unmarked by dramatic effect. Until the bill was finally put upon passage, Assemblyman Eldridge, ill with a high fever, sat in an ante-room until the house generously allowed his vote to be recorded in the affirmative.

Secretary of Agriculture WILSON is showing much zeal for the promotion of the export trade in butter. It does not seem exactly a proper function of the Government to organize a corps of buyers and drummers, to collect, ship, distribute, sell, and report on specimens of butter for foreign markets.

George H. Richmond, who was arrested on March 4 upon the complaint of Anthony Comstock for selling Gabriele D'Annunzio's book, "The Triumph of Death," is offended at some words of City Magistrate Leroy B. Crane, who committed him for trial. He may call the attention of the Supreme Court to the matter.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Senator Marlin has introduced a measure like that which lately passed the Legislature of Illinois, to regulate department stores by providing a graded system and classification of selling merchandise.
George E. Hardy, Professor of the English Language and Literature in the College of the City of New York, died at Roselle, N.J., yesterday morning.

A meeting for the purpose of arousing interest in the approaching Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition in Nashville will be held at Sherry's to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock. Mayor Strong is expected to preside, and the speakers will include Theodore Roosevelt, Alexander S. Webb, and John S. Wise.
Ladies who suffer from poor health may gain valuable information by reading of the astonishing discovery recently made by The London World.
CHICAGO, April 15. -- Many distinguished Presbyterian ministers are in Chicago to consider methods of bringing various Presbyterian church organizations of the world into closer harmony.

Before the work of the Tariff Commission of 1882 the duty on imported barley was 15 cents a bushel. That commission, after a careful inquiry, reported that ample protection and a fair revenue could be got from a duty of 10 cents a bushel, and that rate was adopted in the law of 1883.

At sundown this evening the Feast of Passover will begin, and will continue for seven days, ending at sundown on April 22. The feast is celebrated generally by the Jews, with services in the synagogues on the first and last days, and the evenings preceding those days. The "matzoth," or unleavened bread, is used in place of the usual bread during the week.

Paralysis, on Tuesday evening, caused the death of Mrs. Elizabeth R. Tilton at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Pelton, in Pacific Street, Brooklyn. She had a paralytic stroke in March, but partially recovered until April 7, when she was again stricken and remained unconscious until her death. Her children were at her bedside when she died.

Mr. Jacob H. Schiff, head of the banking house of Kuhn, Loeb Co., returned to this city yesterday from a short stay in Europe, arriving on the Teutonic. When asked last night by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES as to financial matters abroad and as to the foreign opinion of the financial situation in the United States, Mr. Schiff made the following interesting remarks:

The announcement yesterday morning that the Park Board had decided to grant permits for the erection of stands on Park property on the easterly side of Riverside Drive, prices of seats on such stands to be limited to 50 cents each, had two effects. It brought a multitude of seekers after such permits, and it created something of a panic among speculators in seats along the line of parade.

We have tried to understand the conduct of the political majority in the Legislature at Albany in its treatment of matters affecting the cities of the State, and especially the cities on the East River, which contain about two-fifths of the population of the whole Commonwealth, and to that end we have sought for some rational motive of the kind which is supposed to guide the action of politicians.

-- Prof. JAMES of Harvard and a number of other Cambridge notabilities, including CHARLES ELLIOT NORTON, Prof. ROYCE, Dr. EVERETT, Prof. PEABODY, Dean BRIGGS, and Prof. DOLBEAR, devoted the greater part of a forenoon this week to investigating the relative intelligence of two monkeys from the Boston "Zoo."

ALBANY, N.Y., April 15. -- The Ticket Brokers' Association, which is opposing the Anti-Scalpers' bill, has issued a statement to the effect that if the bill is passed it will cause the imprisonment of the news-dealers under the stairways of the elevated stations for selling tickets in connection with the sale of newspapers.
LONDON, April 15. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says:...

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 15. -- A sensation was caused in the Police Court in this city yesterday afternoon when the case of The People against George Silas Terwilliger for abandonment on complaint of his wife came before the Recorder. For a long time Terwilliger has lived with his wife, or, rather, with the woman who he thought was his wife, on the old Wilbur Road, in this city.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Delegations from New York City, Buffalo, Albany, and Rochester protested against Gov. Black's Civil Service bill at the hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee this afternoon.

Superintendent of Incumbrances Henkel admits that he has totally failed in his efforts to clear Ann and Vesey Streets of push carts and stoop-line stands. He set out on this mission two weeks ago, and notified all the owners of outdoor showcases and stands to remove these incumbrances. It was his intention to widen the sidewalks on these streets to the extent of the obstructed stoop lines.

GEORGETOWN, Del., April 15. -- James M. Gordy was to-night convicted of murder in the first degree for killing his wife, formerly Mrs. Mary Estelle Lewis of New York, by throwing her into the Broadkill Creek, at Milton, Del., on March 11.

Good Government Club A gave a farewell reception to Theodore Roosevelt last night at its headquarters, 722 Lexington Avenue. After the speaking the members crowded about the Commissioner and congratulated him upon his work on the Police Board, and upon his appointment as Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

The Bridge Trustees met in Brooklyn yesterday and finally adopted the report of the sub-committee appointed several weeks ago to consider the proposition of the elevated and surface railroad companies to cross the bridge. The full board was present. The prices fixed for the privilege of crossing are 5 cents per round trip per car for the surface lines and 12 1/2 cents per car for the two elevated railroads.

The corporation of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, Limited, yesterday settled the question of giving Grand Opera next season definitely and adversely at the meeting of the Board of Directors, held in the Metropolitan Opera House. The entire board, Robert Dunlap, President; Edward Lauterbach, Thomas P. Fowler, Maurice Grau, and John B. Schoeffel, were present.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15. -- At a private meeting of Cubans and Cuban sympathizers held in this city to-night it was decided to take steps to frustrate what the Cubans claim is the real object of Major Juno Sandoval's visit to this city. This is said to be the arrest of the members of the Cuban Junta in this country.

The appointment to Annapolis of a colored boy from Cincinnati has naturally agitated the Naval Academy. It is some years since such an appointment was made, and there is no colored man now an officer of the navy, although there is one colored graduate of West Point now in the army.
ATHENS, April 15. -- The British first-class battleship Nile has arrived at Phalerum, near the Piraeus.

We do not know how much attention Gov. BLACK paid to the arguments and protests against the Civil Service bill yesterday. They were made by officials and by leading friends of good government from this city and Brooklyn, from Buffalo, Rochester, Albany, and other cities of the State, while strong letters were submitted by such citizens as President LOW of Columbia and such organizations as the City Club.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 15. -- The Assembly to-night passed these bills:
NEWPORT, April 15. -- W. Fitzhugh Whitehouse has rented his villa on the easterly side of Rhode Island Avenue, known as Eastbourne Lodge, to Mr. A. Cass Canfield of New York, for the coming season.

ALBANY, April 15. -- On Jan. 26 Senator Page introduced a bill, numbered 245, which amended Section 484 of Chapter 410 of the Laws of 1882 of the Consolidated act, the effect of which was to raise the limit above which all buildings in the City of New York should be fire-proof from 70 feet to 75 feet.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 15. -- The reports published in the United States that the Mexican Government intends, in case of the passage of the Dingley Tariff bill, instituting retaliatory measures, will be denounced authoritatively by The Mexican Herald tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Republican sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance held an all day session at the Capitol to-day to afford an opportunity to other Senators to make suggestions on the Tariff bill. Among the Senators who called and had conferences with the committee were Messrs. Quay, Sewell, Elkins, Wellington, Perkins, Shoup, Pritchard, Baker, and Harris of Kansas.

CHICAGO, April 15. -- Charles E. Churchill, cashier of the broken Globe Savings Bank, has made a statement of the failure, which, if true, implicates George R. Hayden, the State bank examiner under Gov. Altgeld.

Mayor Strong was outvoted yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on the adoption of a new southerly approach to the new Third Avenue Bridge. Two of the many plans that have been submitted for a change in the approach were before the board yesterday for final determination.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Assemblyman William Cary Sanger of Oneida, who has always favored extensions in the merit system in the civil service, is opposed to the Governor's bill. He said to-day that he believed it tended to break down the merit system of making appointments.

Justice Keogh of Brooklyn called before him yesterday Gen. James McLeer of the Department of Assessments and Taxes, and Assistant Corporation Counsel R.A. Breckenridge, and read them a lecture on the lax methods prevailing in the collection of personal taxes. Briefly, he told them that unless a speedy revolution in their departments took place, criminal proceedings would be instituted against them.

A meeting will be held at SHERRY'S tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the interest of New York representation at the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition at Nashville. It ought to be well attended. There is no question whatever that the exposition will be an extensive and varied one, of great attraction and value.

Mme. Calve had certainly recovered completely from her recent indisposition before the curtain rose last night on the performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera House. If the public had known that beforehand, the audience would undoubtedly have been much larger. The house was not full by any means, but the performance aroused much enthusiasm, which was fairly earned.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 15. -- In the Senate to-day the bill giving the President of the Park Board of Rochester a salary was passed over the veto of the Mayor of that city after Senators Cantor and Grady had protested against such action on the ground that it violated the home-rule provision of the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Assistant Treasurer Jordan may remain in office for some time, unless Secretary Gage shall become convinced that, for the good of the service, it will be better to appoint Ellis H. Roberts.

DENVER, Col., April 16. -- Samuel New-house, who represents the Rothschilds in the famous Newhouse tunnel enterprise, has returned from a two months' visit to Europe. Speaking of the European situation to-night he said:

As the time approaches for the opponents of the Greater New York charter to appear before the Governor and make their arguments against its provisions, it becomes more and more evident that it is the intention of the united organizations to impress Gov. Black with a full knowledge of the glaring defects of the measure as it has reached him, and also of the distinguished character of the opposition to his signing it.

LONDON, April 16. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says that the Russian Minister of War publishes in the Russkij Invalid an order of the Czar providing that hereafter all criminals condemned to imprisonment in Siberia shall be conveyed there by railway instead of being compelled to make the march by way of Tomsk and skutsk, which has caused so many deaths and such terrible suffering to thousands.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Republican Committee on Committees of the Senate to-day agreed unanimously to accept, so far as it is empowered to do so, the proposition made by the Democrats for the organization of the Senate committees. It was also decided to report this conclusion to the Republican Senatorial caucus.
CHICAGO, April 16. -- Oliver Pike, the supposed victim of the Salt Lake City, Utah, trunk mystery, has written to his mother and friends at Fayette, Ohio, that he is alive.

The Board of Managers of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Criminals, under the auspices of which the Refuge on Randall's Island is conducted, held a special meeting at the Refuge yesterday afternoon. The meeting was called to consider the quarantine put upon the institution by the Board of Health.

The observance of Good Friday in this city was in many respects more general yesterday than usual. Business in all of the Exchanges and in some of the large business establishments and banks was suspended for the whole or at least part of the day. With the closing of the Stock and Produce Exchanges and the partial suspension of the banking business, there was an unusual desertion of down-town business offices.

The arrest of four applicants for a position on the police force accused of robbing the Civil Service Bureau to obtain lists of questions is overshadowed for the moment by the row in the department caused by the refusal of Chief Conlin and Capt. O'Brien to take individual orders from Police Commissioner Andrews as a Commissioner, although perfectly willing to oblige him as a private citizen.

PARIS, April 16. -- The Dingley Tariff bill has aroused considerable antagonism in French mercantile circles, where it is pointed out that the measure may lead to a policy disastrous in its effects on certain French industries.

TROY, N.Y., April 16. -- Officers are closely watching Central Vermont trains for suspicious-looking passengers, whom closer examination may prove to be Chinamen being smuggled across the border. That their suspicions are well founded is shown by a recent experience of a reporter, who, while on one of the south-bound trains, had his attention called to a mysterious-looking couple, occupying a front seat.

ALBANY, April 16. -- The Senate Canal Committee recently voted adversely on the Parshall bill. The failure to report the bill, thus withholding from the Legislature an opportunity to determine the policy of the State in relation to restriction of canal commerce, has provoked numerous protests in the shape of telegrams and communications from various parts of the country.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 16. -- Ex-President Harrison appeared in the United States District Court to-day, as counsel for the Central Trust Company of New York, in an action to prevent the enforcement of the recently enacted fare law.

The ability of Jersey City to place its thirty-year 4 1/2 per cent. bonds at 107.53 is, of course, gratifying to the taxpayers of that city, and the more so as the new bonds replace an issue that bore 7 per cent. The net interest to the city will be a little under 4.2 per cent. and the annual charge will be reduced by about 40 per cent.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 16. -- Advices from Natchez and others points below Vicksburg indicate that the supreme test in the flood situation is near. The swift current is rising steadily and beating against the levees with such force as to cause the gravest apprehension at many places. At Natchez the river is near the top of the levee.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- There were comparatively few callers at the White House to-day before the Cabinet meeting. The friends of Herbert Bowen of Brooklyn, now Consul at Barcelona, Spain, have resumed their efforts to have him appointed to succeed Minister Taylor at Madrid. Representative Walker of Massachusetts saw the President in his behalf to-day.

Dealers in drugs and chemicals and importers and manufacturers of perfumes, are taking great interest in the proposed duties of the Dingley bill. There is wide diversity of opinion as to the effects of that measure upon individual articles, but most of the dealers, importers, and manufacturers agree that the bill, as it now stands, will injure many departments of their business.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 16. -- Mrs. Wilber Crouch and Miss May Daly were shot and killed and George Allen, a private in the Ninth United States Infantry, was wounded, fatally it is believed, while out driving this morning at Sackett's Harbor. Wilber Crouch, Mrs. Crouch's husband, is under arrest, having been accused of the crime by Allen.

ELASSONA, Headquarters of the Turkish Army in Macedonia, Thursday Evening, April 15, (Delayed in transmission.) -- The representative of The Associated Press at the Turkish Headquarters has just seen a prisoner who was captured by the Turks in their fight at Krania with the Greek irregulars.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- The Chicago Packing and Provision Company proposes to temporarily cut its semi-annual dividend of 4 per cent. to 2, and to abolish its London office. At a meeting in the Board of Trade Building it was decided to suggest these measures to the meeting of English stockholders to be held in London next week.

The Executive Board of the Master Steamfitters' Association and delegates from the journeymen steamfitters' and helpers' unions held another long conference yesterday afternoon at the Wool Exchange Building. The unions' representatives submitted an agreement which they claimed to contain important concessions to the employers.

There was such a display of brook trout at Blackford's, in Fulton Market, yesterday as awakened enthusiasm in the breasts of disciples of the rod and line, and of epicures as well. The occasion was the annual opening of the trout season. Attractively arranged on mosses and swimming in aquariums of fresh, clear water were several hundreds of the choicest specimens of the trout family, dead and alive.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Secretary of the Navy has just made the annual allotment of the fund of $50,000 appropriated by Congress for the naval militia of the States. Deducting $2,000 reserved for the purchase of text books, the remainder of the appropriation is allotted among the States having naval-militia organizations in proportion to the number of uniformed petty officers and men they had on their rolls on the 1st of January.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16. -- For the present, at least, the Citizens' Street Railroad Company has decided to give up its fight against the three-cent fare law. A.L. Mason, President of the company, says that until the case is settled in the courts 3 cents will be accepted as a fare.

" If Commissioner Collis and Superintendent Henkel cannot carry out the law which they are employed and sworn to enforce, the Bureau of Incumbrances ought to be abolished," said Lawrence J. Callanan, the Vesey Street merchant, yesterday. Mr. Callanan had been reading in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Superintendent Henkel's confessed failure in the attempt to remove the sidewalk obstructions in Nassau, Vesey, and Ann Streets.

CHICAGO, April 16. -- The new agreement of the Western Passenger Association is, in the opinion of the members of the committee which formulated it, the best and strongest agreement the Western lines have ever had in connection with their passenger business. The leading roads are positive that there is nothing in the agreement that will in any manner conflict with the law.

The amendments to the Raines law embrace a large number of changes, great and small. Here and there a single word is omitted or inserted or changed, to make its meaning more comprehensive. Certain clauses are condensed and others are amplified without any change in their general effect. A few unimportant clauses have been eliminated and several entirely new clauses have been added.
CLAYTON, N.Y., April 16. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the bill appropriating $30,000 for the purchase of lands in the State reservation at the Thousand Islands.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Secretary Long has revoked the orders by which Lieut. Robert E. Peary, the Arctic explorer, now on duty at the New York Navy Yard, was detailed to the Mare Island Yard, California.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--The French Embassy here is actively assisting the French Telegraphic Cable Company in efforts it is making to lay a new cable from Brest, France, to Cape Cod, Mass. The cable is intended to take the place of the one laid eighteen years ago. For this purpose the attention of Senators has been called to the restrictions which a pending Senate bill will place upon the French company.

LARISSA, headquarters of the Greek Army in Thessaly, April 16. -- Severe fighting has occurred in Macedonia between the Greek irregulars and the Turkish forces. The column of irregulars sent to the right from Pigavitza, after having invested and captured Sitovon, continued its advance toward Kritudes, Plisia, and Kourduzi, with orders to hold the latter place at all costs, as it commands the right approach to Grevena, the objective point.

Prominent officers of the Citizens' Union and men who have allied themselves with that movement said yesterday that they are very much gratified by the utterances of Edward Lauterbach in his speech Thursday night before the Republican County Committee.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Black's Civil Service bill will have another hearing before the Assembly Judiciary Committee next Tuesday. This announcement is made to-night. Precisely why this committee should go through the motions of a hearing is not apparent, inasmuch as it cannot report a bill at this stage of the session, except through the Committee on Rules.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., April 16. -- While resisting the entry of two desperate and determined robbers, and during a heroic but futile struggle to protect $150,000 or more in money and securities which were in the compartments of the open vault of the Great Falls National Bank of Somesworth this afternoon, Cashier Joseph A. Stickney was truck down and brutally murdered near the desk which he had occupied for years.

ALBANY, April 16. -- In the Senate to-day, Senator White's Syracuse Subway bill, which was accepted by the Mayor of that city, but not accepted by the Common Council, was repassed, notwithstanding the disapproval of that body.
BOSTON, April 16. -- Judge Morton of the Suffolk Superior Court has decided that Adah Richmond has not established her rights as widow to contest the will of John Stetson.
LONDON, April 16. -- The Larissa correspondent of The Times says:

Cyclists who have planned to take runs to-morrow will be pleased at the prospect for good roads. The reports received at the headquarters of the State Division of the League of American Wheelmen up to last evening are encouraging, generally speaking. They embrace all the country within a radius of thirty miles of the metropolis -- in fact, all the roads over which the riders of the metropolitan district are fond of pedaling.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16. -- George A. Taylor, the former cashier of the defunct Argentine bank, who disappeared a month ago, returned home yesterday, and to-day voluntarily submitted to arrest on a warrant charging him with illegal banking.

How full of the fragrance of Spring is this lesson! The seed which we recently saw scattered by the wind in Jerusalem is now springing up not only in Jewish soil, but in Gentile soil as well. It is not only springing up, but it is budding and blossoming all through the land, even to "Phenice and Cyprus and Antioch."

The eighteenth semi-annual convention of the Luther League of New York City will be held on Thursday, April 29, in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 49 West Twenty-first Street, near Sixth Avenue, the Rev. C. Armand Miller, pastor. The speakers will be the Rev. Alfred B. Moldenke, Ph. D.; Mr. I.S. Runyon, and Mr. H.J. Kaltenbach.

A Whitehead torpedo, launched from the battleship Indiana during target practice off Stapleton, S.I., on Wednesday morning last, has gone astray. It is not loaded, and can, therefore, do no harm, but as these engines of destruction cost $2,500, the Navy Department and the officers of the battleship are anxious to recover the missing machine.

Nor do we expect very much effect from the clearly hostile investigation of the service by a sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Civil Service. This sub-committee consists of Senators PRITCHARD, Chairman; ELKINS, and CHILTON. They are not experienced legislators, and they are not conspicuous civil service reformers.

Mr. LAUTERBACH, speaking as Chairman of the Republican County Committee, has issued the challenge to a partisan contest for the control of the Government of the Greater New York. The battle is to be fought by his forces "under the banner of partisan Republicanism," and the man they will seek to elevate to the office of Mayor must be a "tried and true Republican."

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 16. -- This afternoon about 3 o'clock an unknown German walked out on the high bridge of the West Shore Railroad, which spans the Rondout Creek at Wilbur, and with a string of hair beads and an ivory crucifix in his hands leaped from the bridge, which is 154 feet high to the waters of the creek below.

Senator Thomas C. Platt arrived from Washington, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, last night, without letting the politicians know that he was coming. Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the Republicans State Committee, who has been in the South since March 1, came with the Senator.

We exposed in our news columns yesterday a scheme for the construction by a private contractor of a canal connecting the Harlem and East Rivers by way of the Harlem Kills above Randall's Island, which cannot be explained except as a job for the benefit of private interests of some kind.

Yesterday was a holiday so far as stock markets went in all financial circles throughout the country, and in most of those abroad. In Wall Street very few brokers' offices showed any life. The banks were open, but the Street itself was, to all intents and purposes, dead.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- According to information received from trustworthy sources here the withdrawal of at least a part of the great army that Spain has maintained in the Island of Cuba will begin when the rainy season sets in, within a few days.

-- In his second lecture, on "MOLIERE as a Philosopher," M. BRUNTIERE told the Bostonians that MOLIERE deserves this title because he saw the world and humanity through his own spectacles and drew pictures of them unlike those made by his literary rivals. SCRIBE, BEAUMARCHAIS, REGNARD, and other second-rate men, on the contrary, had no conception of life except the one common to their contemporaries.

The Reform Club's Committee on Tariff Reform held an important conference last night with a number of importing and manufacturing concerns of this city. It was held in the clubhouse, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, and was attended by men representing most of the important trade interests that were sought to be reached.

ALBANY, April 16. -- Mr. Harrison's bill amending the game law, by providing that Justices of the Peace may issue warrants for the arrest of persons violating the game laws, was a special order. After considerable debate the bill was amended so as to provide that a person arrested for violation of the game laws must be tried in the town in which he is arrested or an adjoining town.

WADLEY, Ga., April 16. -- Prof. Lovett Brookins, the colored murderer of Leila McCrary, his mistress, and Sanders Oliphant, colored, met his death on the gallows to-day without displaying a shadow of fear. Before the execution he smoked cigarettes and chatted pleasantly with all who met him. He had his picture taken twice.

The decision of the Park Board to permit the erection of stands on public land on the easterly side of Riverside Drive, from which to view the Grant Monument parade, will result in a much greater accommodation to the public than was supposed when that decision was made.
ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the following bills:

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 16. -- The Equitable Aid Union, a Western Pennsylvania fraternal benefit concern, to-day formally notified its many certificate holders in different parts of the country that it was in the hands of a receiver and had suspended. This ends the life of an organization which has fought most bitterly for life, and by its final dissolution over 30,000 policy holders will suffer.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 16. -- The Rawson twins have not been indicted by the Grand Jury, despite the many charges made against them. The failure to indict was a surprise to every one. The constables asserted they had proof that the boys were guilty of many crimes. For gathering this evidence they put in bills covering months of alleged investigation, and the Freeholders had to pay them.

The Easter number of the Sunday Magazine Supplement of THE NEW YORK TIMES, to be published to-morrow, will rival in richness of illustrations and interest of reading matter the superb number published last Christmas. Many of the prominent clergymen of this city have written signed articles for it.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 16. -- At a meeting of the creditors of the Bennett and Columbia Mill corporations to-day it appeared that not only have notes of the corporations, aggregating $2,500,000, been issued, of which no account has been made, as required by the statutes, but also that notes of the Lambeth Rope Company, to the amount of $10,000, have long been car-cried.

The letter of the chief of the prisoners' choir at Sing Sing to the Methodist Conference, the members of which had been present at a concert in the jail, which we published on Thursday, was a sensible production. He thanked the clergymen for their attendance, for the lack of "morbid curiosity" on their part, and for the praise given at the conclusion of the performance.

The bill against ticket scalping in this State, which has passed the Assembly and was advanced to the order of third reading in the Senate yesterday, provides in substance and effect that no person shall sell tickets for passage or conveyance on any vessel or railroad train, "unless he is the authorized agent of the owners or consignees of such vessel, or of the company running such train."

The spelling of words in ie and ei causes a great deal of trouble in the world, and I have thought it would be useful if a formula could be got up which should cover all such words in an easily remembered jingle. Such a rule would perform the same sort of service as the ever useful "Thirty days hath September."

The farewell given to Mr. ROOSEVELT on Thursday evening by Good Government Club A was noteworthy for the earnestness that was shown on all hands. There was nothing in the least perfunctory about it. The note of sincerity in the speaking was unmistakable, and so was that of cordiality in the audience.

Russia has shown her hand even more plainly since the collisions on the Macedonian frontier than before. She had already induced the concert to declare that the aggressor in a war between Greece and Turkey should not be allowed to profit by his aggression. This meant, among other things, that Greece should not be allowed to take possession of the territory awarded to her by the Berlin Conference.

Inclosed with the checks for the regular quarterly dividends sent out by the H.B. Claflin Company to its stockholders, was the following note, dated April 15, and signed by John Clafiin, President of the company:

In determining the value of an old book, age is surely one point in its favor, but just here the mistake is often made by novices in bibliography that because certain books printed a century or more ago are valued in the hundreds of dollars, so anything of a corresponding date must possess something like a proportionate value.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, April 16. -- The Lowell Observatory, which was transferred from Flagstaff, Arizona, to Mexico early in December last for the purpose of observing the apposition of Mars and for the measurements of Southern double stars, has been dismounted and shipped back to its original location after three months' remarkable service.
WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Western Senators, after several conferences, have reached an agreement to stand together for important changes in the wool schedule of the Dingley bill.

RAHWAY, N.J., April 16. -- The Rev. J.H. Christmas, pastor of the Ebenezer Methodist Episcopal Church, came to the office of Police Justice Frazee to-day for a warrant for the arrest of his daughter Amelie, sixteen years old. He alleged she was wayward, and had not been home since Monday night.
DERBY, Conn., April 17. -- "Denny's Angels," the Derby team, of the Connecticut State League, was defeated by the Portland, Me., team this afternoon, 8 to 3. The game was fast and clean.
When Chief of Police Conlin was asked yesterday to make a statement regarding his difficulty with Commissioner Andrews, he replied:

LONDON, April 10. -- How well we Americans know the London lodging house, or think we do, front reading English fiction! To let the British novelist tell the story, the lodging-house system is the easiest and most comfortable in the world for a man living alone.

MONTREAL, April 17. -- The Dominion Parliament has adjourned over the Easter holidays without the Government having brought down its long-expected tariff measure, but it has promised to do so next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 12, -- The question of taxed or free hides will evidently have to be met by the Senate Finance Committee, and by the Republican members of it first. The advocates of free hides have no reason yet to complain except at reports, for hides were free in the Dingley bill, and the influence of Mr. Dingley will be exerted on the Finance Committee to keep them free.

Lovers of the wild and exciting scenes in which a "Wild West" exhibition abounds, and particularly the Wild West so naturally and faithfully presented by Buffalo Bill, will have an opportunity to witness many new and interesting features on the advent of Buffalo Bill to this city to-morrow week.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 17. -- To-day was the busiest day of the season thus far for Cornell's track athletes. A number of both old and new men appeared for the first time, and the general practice was satisfactory. Trainer Connors has the track and takeoffs in excellent condition, and from now on, with good weather, nothing but hard, steady training is needed to turn out a creditable team.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Dr. Elmer E. Prescott, son of the physician of the same name who was the victim of a murder that developed one of the most famous mysteries in the history of the city, made a determined attempt to kill himself at his home last night. The attending physician says his recovery is impossible.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- During the past six months evidence has accumulated at a rapid rate to show that John P. Altgeld, the recent Governor of Illinois, has juggled with State funds in such a manner as to put upon the Commonwealth a loss of nearly a million dollars. At present the State stands fair to lose at least the following:

LONDON, April 17. -- A dispatch to The Times from Paris says that the secret of the withdrawal of the Princess Chimay Caraman, nee Ward, of Detroit, Mich., from the Folies Bergere, is found in the fact that the friends of the family had resolved to place her children in the front row of the theatre.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 27. -- On Saturday last the six Ambassadors, through the medium of their dragomans, warned the Turkish Government of the danger which would result from any further massacres in Sivas or other districts of Anatolia. If the latest reports be correct, the Mussulmans are preparing to make another murderous assault on the Armenians of these Anatolian provinces.

It is possible that the New York Association of Sewing Schools may become a National organization. The organization has made no movement yet, but the request has been made and the association is growing so rapidly that it is possible that action in the matter will soon be taken.

Entries for the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club's fifth annual Horse Show, April 28 to May 1, have closed, with about 240 nominations. This number does not include the exhibits in special contests, which will make the total over 270. If that number be reached, it will exceed the record of any of the club's previous Horse Shows.

This year's outlook for racing in the East is more promising than it has been for a number of years, and if the expectations of those interested in the sport are fulfilled, the racing season of 1897 will possibly go down to history as the starting point in a new epoch of racing, grander, broader, and cleaner than any previously known in this country.

Special Customs Inspectors Donohue, Murray, and Brown yesterday noticed J. Dyson, a passenger who arrived on the steamship Campania, transferring a package to Henry Rothwell, who had gone to the Cunard pier to meet him. The Inspectors at once subjected the two men to a search.

MALONE, N.Y., April 17. -- Miss Louisa Wiess, a young German, who came to Malone with Dr. Edwin T. Osbaldeston about two years ago as an assistant in his massage treatment, and who, with the doctor, was arrested in Montreal last Fall and extradited, charged with having stolen goods from Fay Brothers of this place, escaped from the Malone Jail this morning and took the early train for Canada.

HONOLULU, Hawaiian Islands, April 5. -- The suspicious and somewhat alarming fact has come to light that the Japanese immigrants, who have been pouring into these islands under the guise of "students," are in reality trained soldiers. Suspicion of this fact was first aroused by their soldierly bearing and their military gait and movements, especially when passing through the streets in groups.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A petition for a rehearing of the Trans-Missouri Freight Association ease was fled in the United States Supreme Court to-day by Attorney John F. Dillon, counsel for the Union Pacific, St. Joseph and Grand Island, and Missouri Pacific Railroad Companies. The petition asks a rehearing on the ground that the exact effect of the recent decision is doubtful as to these particulars:

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- As anticipated in the Weather Bureau bulletins of March 28 and April 3 and 15, the levee in Northeastern Louisiana just below Vicksburg, unable to bear the strain of the immense volume of water returning to the Mississippi through the Yazoo, has given way, and the river parishes in Northern Louisiana, and probably all the regions in Louisiana overflowed in previous years, are on the eve of a disastrous flood.

The remarks of the Secretary of Agriculture in regard to the encouragement by the Government of the export of butter were read by many merchants in the butter and cheese trade. The manufacture of butter in this country has largely increased only during the past few wears, and is growing steadily.

" What should a young housekeeper learn in order to understand marketing?" said Mr. Simmons. "Well, I think the best thing she could do would be to take a cookbook which has a chart of the different animals and study it. The parts are numbered and explained, and she will learn all she wishes to know.

MARK, x., 9, 10: "And as they came down from the mountain, he charged them that they should tell no man what things they had seen till the Son of Man were risen from the dead. And they kept that saying within themselves, wondering what the resurrection from the dead should mean."

Dissatisfaction on the part of some of the stockholders of the American Grocery Company with the management of President Marsalis has led to the filing of a petition for the appointment of a temporary receiver for that concern. H. Applington, attorney for David Hunt of 84 Hudson Street, and other stockholders of the American Grocery Company, called upon President Marsalis several days ago and asked for his resignation.
