The public still stays out of Wall Street. A few traders have all to themselves what is by courtesy still described as the stock market.
The April advance sheets of Consular reports issued from the Bureau of Statistics of the State Department contain much interesting and curious information.

There is nothing fraudulent about Miss Ella Ewing, who is announced at Barnum Bailey's "Greatest Show" as the "tallest woman on earth." Miss Ewing looks tall as she stands in the ring with little Peter, the midget, gamboling around, and She looks tall as she sits on the big chair, where she stays during the time the circus is in progress, but to realize her height the ordinary mortal must stand beside her.

ALBANY, April 17. -- A new company, known as the Merchants' Union, has been incorporated under the laws of this State, with a paid up capital of $50,000. Arrangements have already been effected by the company to lease the "Liebmann Arcade," in Brooklyn, for its varied enterprises.

This morning, if tradition is to be relied upon, the sun dances in the heavens and the sons and daughters of men should follow his example and dance upon the earth. Fasterday, so long expected, has at last arrived and pips the shell of Lent. Now succeeds joy to gloom and mirth to the miserere.

Two young men -- Robert J. Finley of 101 West Fortieth Street and Alfred Lopez of 130 West Fifty-third Street -- were arraigned yesterday morning in Jefferson Market Police Court charged with having stolen a watch, valued at $100, from Mrs. Florence Stone, an actress, who was staying at the Metropolitan Hotel.
There is a glaring inconsistency in the final treatment of clubs in the amended Raines law, and it is also a flagrant instance of class legislation.

VICKSBURG, Miss., April 17. -- The United States steamer Meigs arrived at 1 P.M. from the Biggs crevasse with Mr. Maxwell and Assistant Engineer H.B. Thompson. They report the break 500 feet wide. The State convicts, 380 in number, were all safely put on the steamer' Natchez this morning for Baton Rouge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17. -- The Harvard 'Varsity crew rowed a two-mile trial on the Charles this afternoon in record time, the official watch giving the time as a minutes and 18 seconds. This is 10 seconds better than the fastest time ever made over this course. The personnel of the crew remains unchanged.

-- So weak was the evidence connecting the steamer Dauntless with filibustering expeditions that, after it had all been presented in court at Jacksonville on Friday, her owners did not think it worth while to make any defense, and the Judge dismissed the case with a promptitude that may or may not have surprised the prosecuting Federal officials.

EASTER naturally turns our thoughts to the life beyond the grave. The natural curiosity which loves to hover round the mysteries of the future state is a natural and pardonable curiosity and has its source in our innate love of life and our consciousness of immortality.

Professional Wall Street has been devoting much time recently to attacking St. Paul Railroad shares, for the apparent reason that the stock has not declined as much as they have wanted it to. They have talked bad earnings, poor prospects, and other hopeless stuff. One of their particular contentions has been the poor condition of the road and the bad outlook for crops in the Northwest.

Ransom Botsford, nineteen years old, who has gained some little notoriety as a private detective, was removed from his mother's apartments, 141 West Thirty-fifth Street, last evening, to the New York Hospital suffering from laudanum poisoning. His relatives deny that he attempted to kill himself, but nevertheless an empty two-ounce phial which contained laudanum was found in his pocket, and he will be arraigned in Jefferson Market Court to-day charged with attempting suicide.

A half hour's sail up the river from New York brings the tourist in view of the battlemented keep and tower of Fonthill, rising above the treetops on the summit of Mount St. Vincent. The castle is built of stone, in imitation of the Norman-Gothic structures of the Middle Ages, and lacks but the moat and the drawbridge to present a perfect picture of an old feudal stronghold.

The contests for the junior team championship were finished at the Fencers' Club last night. The New York Athletic Club team -- W. Lyons. C.C. Curran, and A. Schroeder -- won, and W. Lyons won the prize for the best individual score. The summaries follow:
HIGHLAND, N.Y., April 17. -- The outlook for an abundant yield of all sorts of fruit grown in the southern Ulster fruit belt is said to be better this Spring than it has been before since 1890.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 17. -- Cornell's real boating season opened this week with the commencement of lake practice. As yet the freshmen have been confined principally to the less perilous and safer waters of the inlet. But the three 'Varsities have been taken over the long stretches on the west shore of the lake every afternoon for the last four days.

LENOX, Mass., April 17. -- Several New York people who have country places in Lenox have been up this week, looking them over and planning to occupy them early this season. The weather for the past fortnight has been favorable for the shrubbery in the gardens, and on the whole the season is considerably earlier than it was last year.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Representative Grosvenor of Ohio, who made a vigorous attack on the civil service laws in the last Congress, to-day introduced a bill to declare the true intent and scope of the Civil Service act.

IF a man die, shall he live again? It is the old question, and I suppose there is no question that interests more human hearts, and interests them more deeply. I doubt whether to-day, in this nineteenth century, there are as many men and women perplexed by and interested in the question of a personal God as are perplexed by and interested in the question of the immortality of the soul.

YEAR ago the celebration of Easter was invariably accompanied by many very quaint and interesting observances; but few of these customs have been brought down unimpaired to the close of the essentially practical nineteenth century, and are, therefore, little known to the present generation.

Riders of the bicycle should take warning at the narrow escape of a wheelman on the dangerous Gorge Road last Sunday, and equip their machines with brakes. The number of unthinking pedalers who have lost control of their wheels, and been dashed to death down steep and treacherous hills is already too large and growing, when a brake might check it.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17. -- Weather clear, track good. Summaries:

The fact that ninety-four yacht clubs have responded to the invitation to take part in the convention that is to be held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel on Saturday, May 1, shows that yachtsmen are agreed that the time has come when some effort should be made to have a uniform set of racing rules and unite in some way on the troublesome question of measurement.
Among the plans filed yesterday with the Building Department were those for an eighteen-story hotel on the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue.

PARIS, April 6. -- The Meline Ministry has managed to retain possession of office for a much longer period than was at one time thought possible, and the prevailing opinion is that it has passed the rubicon, and will, as the phrase goes. "make the elections"; that is to say, will be in office when the general election takes place next Spring.

The market is, and has been during the week, a sort of two per cent. affair, which goes up or goes down within that limit, and turns back when it most looks like going on. It was so strong on Tuesday that the Street became brightly confident of a further advance Wednesday morning, which was just the occasion selected by some one to dump a lot of Chicago Gas and Sugar.

-- Though the late DANIEL WESLEY VOORHEES had been in office since early manhood, and since 1861 had represented Indiana almost continuously in one or the other branch of Congress, he had only a few hundred dollars when he left the Senate on the 3d of last month. He had, of course, numberless opportunities in his long career to advance his personal interests in a financial way, but he took advantage of none of them.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 17. -- The Franklin County Grand Jury has returned true bills against Dr. W. Godfrey Hunter, the Republican nominee for the United States Senate; ex-Congressman John Henry Wilson of the Eleventh District, the Hon. E.T. Franks of the Second District, Capt. Noel Gaines, and his brother-in-law, Thomas Tanner of Frankfort.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The House met to-day for the second time this week. The President's message urging Congress to take action for representation of the United States in the forthcoming international exposition at Paris, which had been sent to the Senate Wednesday, was read. Then Mr. Bailey of Texas rose to a question of personal privilege and had read an editorial in a Washington paper headed "From Maker to Wearer."

BERLIN, April 17. -- Prince Hohenlohe, the Imperial Chancellor, the correspondent of The Associated Press understands, in a letter dated from Baden-Baden, April 13, forwarded his resignation to Emperor William. A brisk exchange of telegraphic messages followed. His Majesty insisted upon the Chancellor retaining office for the present, in spite of the cogent reasons cited in Prince Hohenlohe's letter, urging that his resignation at this juncture would most seriously embarrass the Emperor.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 17. -- The first break in the Louisiana line has come, and, owing to the rapid widening of the Biggs Crevasse, it may do great good in aiding to hold the rest of the line. All along the State line the river has been rising so fast that men have been working day and night to avert a disaster, which seemed almost certain. The day was full of alarms.

Much of the paper of the Bennett and Columbia Mill Corporations of New Bedford, Mass, which is said to amount to $2,500,000, is said to be held in this city. Catlin Co. of 216 Church Street are the selling agents of the mills, the accounts having been transferred to them from O. H. Sampson Co. of 5S Worth Street some time ago.

Members of the New York City Commission to the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition, and other interested persons, held a meeting at Sherry's yesterday afternoon to awaken interest in the exposition among New York City residents and to secure for New York City a representation compatible with its dignity and wealth.

CHRIST'S resurrection stands out as the great, majestic, and sublime fact of Christianity. The cornerstone of the Christian Church is laid in His empty grave. On the glad Easter morning we hail Him as the Conqueror of sin, the Vanquisher of death, and the Ransomer from the grave.

NOR feast nor festival of the whole year comes to us heralded with joy so genuine or with so cheering a gladness as the Anniversary of the Resurrection. Not merely our human hearts and affections seem to expand and to second the desire of our souls toward a higher sphere, but we would have even inanimate nature reflect a portion of our happy exuberance of spirit.

ALBANY, April 17. -- The first Saturday session of the Senate was a dismal failure so far as the transaction of business was concerned. Senator Ellsworth yesterday refused to excuse Senators from attendance to-day, but notwithstanding that fact, there was not a quorum present at 10 o'clock, when the body convened.

President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Department, who will become Assistant Secretary of the Navy to-morrow, sent his letter of resignation as Police Commissioner to Mayor Strong yesterday. The Mayor said that he had selected the man whom he desired to appoint to succeed Mr. Roosevelt as Police Commissioner, but that he should not announce the appointment until the gentleman selected had accepted.

All the details in connection with the mobilization of the troops from the Third and Fourth Brigades in this city on April 27, to take part in the Grant parade, are practically completed. Most of the troops up the State are to assemble at Albany, and from there will be transported to New York City on the Drew, Kaaterskill, and other steamers.

Additional financial held is needed by the "Little Mothers'" Aid Association. For several years this philanthropic organization has been dispensing help to a class of beneficiaries who otherwise would receive scant attention. The "Little Mothers" are the young girls who are left in charge of their homes and younger children while their mothers are at work.

LONDON, April 17. -- The Prince of Wales has returned from the Riviera, and spent Thursday morning overlooking the arrangements for the celebration of the Queen's diamond jubilee. He went to Sandringham on Thursday afternoon, and it is reported he was disgusted at finding the whole route in the hands of syndicates of speculators, and the Queen's jubilee practically put up for auction.

The mounted tournament at Durland's Riding Academy, in Fifty-ninth Street, last night for the benefit of the instructors brought together one of the most fashionable audiences seen at a riding academy this Spring, and the display of horsemanship in the tanbark circle was the most interesting seen in this vicinity of late.

THE Easter festival coming in the time of "the tender crops and the young sun" represents to the modern world the anniversary of Christ's resurrection; and the pictures reproduced in THE TIMES Supplement today show the ways in which painters, from the fifteenth century down to the present day, have approached that culminating moment of the Christian history.

WASHINGTON, April I7. -- The Washington Jockey Club opened the legitimate season of racing in the East to-day with five well-run races between a good class of horses. The Lenten season, which is strictly observed by the smart set in Washington, had its effect upon the attendance, especially as to ladies. But the force of regulars seemed to be well represented, and the familiar faces of racing men from the East were numerous.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 17. -- The Council of Ministers, after a session at the palace to-day, declared that war had broken out on the frontier owing to the incursion by the Greeks on Turkish territory, and Edhem Pasha, the Turkish military commander, was ordered to assume the offensive.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The resolution introduced by Mr. Bland of Missouri, and which he tried to have considered by the House to-day, follows:

IF, then, ye were raised together with Christ, seek the things that are above where Christ is." The ambitions of the risen life, springing from a sense of the dignity of life in God's sight, as redeemed in Christ to a great fellowship with God, and springing, too, from a keen sense of Christ as Master and Example, are chiefly occupied with the uses of life.

LONDON, April 17. -- Sir Alfred Milner, the newly appointed High Commissioner for South Africa, started for his post to-day, hastening his departure by a fortnight owing to the gravity of the situation.

JAMAICA, L.I., April 17. -- The property owners of Springfield along the line of the brook from which the City of Brooklyn gets its water supply, are going to fight the Brooklyn city authorities. There being no sewers, drains from cesspools and houses run into the brook, which is practically a sewer. This, Commissioner Willis of Public Works of Brooklyn is stopping.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Andrew D. White, the new Ambassador to Germany, had a chat with the President about the duties of his post to-day. Mr. White will leave for Germany in a short time.

The Boston Journal has devised a quite elaborate scheme to make the acquaintance of its readers -- a privilege which it complains that it does not now enjoy. Apart from information more particularly useful to the business office the paper asks for "views" on its character as a whole, on its special departments, and on the readers' preferences as between these departments, that the favorite parts may be developed and improved.

YONKERS, April 17. -- The account of the murder of Treasurer Joseph A. Stickney and the robbery of the Great Falls National Bank, at Somersworth, N. H., on Friday at noon, was closely read in this city this morning, because there were many things in connection with the robbery identical with the theft at the Yonkers Savings Bank here last Monday.

The Giants have finished the first week of exhibition games that were to be played on the home grounds before the regular season began, and the general verdict touching their work has been favorable. There will be two more exhibition games, which should put the team in top-notch condition, to face the Philadelphia team, at Philadelphia, in the opening championship game on Thursday.

The real estate market experienced a decided slump last week, and the indications are that the recovery will be very slow and business throughout the Spring will be the dullest known for years. Odd sales were made here and there, as they always are, and the most prominent factor of the week was the speculator.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- It is probable that the Tariff bill will be considered by the Republican caucus before it is submitted to the Democratic members of the Finance Committee. This course was not pursued when the McKinley bill was considered, but the Democrats adopted this plan when the Wilson bill was in the Committee on Finance.

At this season the attention of every enthusiastic golfer is turned toward his own and other club links, and he rejoices that he can again don his brightly checked golf costume, pick up his bag of oddly shaped clubs, and, securing the services of a four-teen-year-old caddie to keep a sharp eye on his ball, go forth to lower his last year's record.

She was a little woman just home from school, with a big appetite and a never-satisfied craving for sweets. The dinner was very good as dinners go, and she watched with great interest as the dessert was brought upon the table. That also was very good, as desserts go, but it was not the kind of dessert that this particular little woman had written upon the list of her special delights.

NO doctrine has shed such a light and happiness over the world as that of the resurrection. No other has so contributed to its emancipation from the evils of sin and to its moral and material progress. The resurrection restored the moral equilibrium of the world.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 17. -- The Governor has signed Senator Ford's bill forbidding the distribution of advertising matter in mail boxes in New York City.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Judge Dunne to-day issued a bench warrant for the arrest of Charles W. Spalding, ex-Treasurer of the University of Illinois, on the charge of embezzlement. The warrant was issued on complaint of George N. Morgan, President of the Chicago Club of the University of Illinois. Bail was fixed by Judge Dunne at $25,000.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 17. -- The Governor has signed these bills:

CINCINNATI, April 17. -- The crowd at Newport to-day was the largest of the meeting. The betting was very brisk, and the day's event brought enjoyable sport. A great surprise was sprung in the third race, the Kentucky Stakes, by the defeat of the favorite, Lizzie Cavalier, who was played at the track and all over the country, Claret Cup winning the race by six lengths.

DENVER, Col., April 5. -- With the exception of Leadville and Cripple Creek, the Red River mining district, lying at the foot of "old Baldy," and along the Moreno Valley in Taos County, New Mexico, is at present attracting more attention than any other in the West. The Red River district is by no means a new one.

LONDON, April 17. -- Mr. Gladstone's famous explanation that he was not at war, but merely conducting military operations, fits to a nicety the present curious state of affairs on the frontier. Battles are being fought, truly Oriental reports of the dead and wounded are being circulated, but constructively Peace still reigns.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 17. -- At a special term of the Supreme Court, held here today, Judge Chase of Catskill presiding, the adjourned case of Hardenbergh against Whitaker came up, and was referred to a lawyer here to take evidence and decide.

IT seems hard in times like these to swing Christianity into the consciousness of the ordinary man miracle end to. The age is dominated by the scientific spirit, and it is not strange that people should want miracle to take itself off. Skepticism is not in itself sinful.

That begging is a profesison, art, or vocation is testified to by the fact that there are in this city more than 100,000 persons who are regular beggars or who make begging their chief means of obtaining a livelihood. At the head of this army of mostly voluntary paupers there are about 200 adepts in the calling who have plied their trade with varying success for a dozen or more years.

BERLIN, April 17. -- The United States tariff bill is just now the favorite theme of the German press, with the exception of the Agrarian press, and especially The Kreuz Zeitung and Deutsche Tages-Zeitung. The temper of these articles, however, has cooled, and a tariff war is being strongly discouraged by the entire Liberal and commercial press.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 17. -- Dull weather and church going have marked the last week in Lent. If good weather sets in Lakewood will celebrate a bright Easter, the hotels having the usual number of guests who spend the Spring holidays here, and many of the cottagers having visitors. At the churches special programmes of Easter music have been prepared, and the leaders of the hotel orchestras have rehearsed Easter music for to-morrow night's concerts.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Asphalt roads will cost more money after the passage of the Tariff bill, unless the Senate and the House shall hereafter agree not to put on the duty imposed by the Dingley bill. It is now free, but the Dingley bill proposes to impose a duty of from $1.50 to $3 per ton, depending upon whether the asphalt be crude or advanced in manufacture.
ALBANY, April 17. -- The Rules Committee of the Assembly has decided to report favorably Senator Martin's bill fixing the penalty for arson.

We have received from the Social, Labor, and Colonization Committee of the Central Labor Union a list of fifteen questions, with the request that we aid its investigations by answering them. It is the intention of the committee, which was appointed under resolutions adopted by the Central Labor Union on Feb. 21, to prepare a printed report upon the problems that confront workingmen, together with drafts of remedial laws.

LONDON, April 17. -- column article in The Times points to the perils in prospect for the British iron and steel industries, based on the Duke of Devonshire's address at the annual meeting of a steel company at Barrow-in-Furness, which is causing much talk and is interesting reading to Americans.

Those who live along the banks or in the extensive Valley of the Mississippi River are in constant dread of its capricious waters. The mighty river has no peer among the streams of the world. Through its channel flows a volume of water drained from half a continent, and even its tributaries are larger than the greatest rivers of most other countries.

PASADENA, Cal., April 10. -- When the mountain-making era ended in Southern California, one of the results was a number of short ranges, from five to twenty-five miles in length, projecting from the ocean from ten to sixty miles off shore. These to-day have the appearance of parts of mountain ranges which have wandered off shore, lying in the blue ocean like some strange marine animal.

THE actual effect produced by a belief in future existence falls absurdly short of what one might naturally expect such a startling belief to produce. Men do believe in the fact, but, for some strange reason, it does not affect either their imagination or their conduct.

WHETHER it is the seed or the tree, the bud or the blossom, the flower or the fruit we are most to admire, it is hard to say, or better said, we admire the one when we admire the other; and so with Easter and Christmas, the heart refuses to separate them in paying the tribute of its love.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 17. -- A golf club has been organized in this city, with fifty-one members and the following officers: President -- John E. Adriance; Governors -- John E. Adriance, W.A. Adriance, William H. Young, Hiram Wiltsie, Robert M. Ferris, and Dr. W.G. Dobson.

CARDINAL JOHN HENRY NEWNAN, whose words are known in all religious circles throughout the civilized world, preached many beautiful sermons on the subject of Easter, and the one given here is a portion of an Easter discourse having for its text the first three verses of the third chapter of Colossians: "If ye then be risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God.

HAVANA, April 17. -- As a result of the reconnoitering and fighting which has recently taken place, Capt. Gen. Weyler infers that it can be considered that the Province of Santa Clara and part of the Province of Puerto Principe, west of the military line, have been pacified.

The body of Gen. Grant was removed yesterday afternoon from the little brick tomb that has sheltered it for the past twelve years to the imposing mausoleum erected in honor of the dead hero. The transfer, which wa:s accomplished with no ceremonies beyond the attendance of a guard of honor composed of members of U.S. Grant Post, No. 327, G.A.R., was witnessed by thousands of persons.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 17. -- Two burglaries were committed in Fanwood early this morning. Mrs. Charles Hamilton, who resides near the depot, was awakened at o'clock by some one in her room. She saw a man, and was too much frightened to make an outcry. The thief took nine diamonds, valued at $250; a gold wach and chain, worth $50, and about $50 in cash.

A Cedar Street incident yesterday suggested the experiences of pioneers with bad, miry roads. One of Edward Joyce's mammoth trucks loaded with the steel frames of the door of Harvey Fisk Son's bank vault, whose weight was eighteen tons, turned into Cedar Street from Broadway. This portion of the street is badly cut up at present.

GLASGOW, April 7. -- Col. A. Paget of the Scots Guard is the owner of the Samphire, twenty-rater; the Sirls, 2.9 rating, and the Flying Scud, 0.98 rating, all by Sibbick, and all winners in the Riviera regattas. Their victories are over French-built boats, some of which are difficult to beat, and over French crews, which are easily beaten.
ALBANY, April 17. -- The session of the Assembly this morning was called for 10 o'clock, but the body did not come to order until 10:30.

One right which the Manhattan Elevated Company has stubbornly ignored or violated has at last been clearly defined and established by the Appellate Court of the Second Division. It is specifically the right of a passenger on a platform not to be crowded off from it, and generally the right to have his safely guarded in all reasonable ways.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 17. -- Two burglaries were committed in Fanwood early this morning. Mrs. Charles Hamilton, who resides near the depot, was awakened at o'clock by some one in her room. She saw a man, and was too much frightened to make an outcry. The thief took nine diamonds, valued at $250; a gold wach and chain, worth $50, and about $50 in cash.

A Cedar Street incident yesterday suggested the experiences of pioneers with bad, miry roads. One of Edward Joyce's mammoth trucks loaded with the steel frames of the door of Harvey Fisk Son's bank vault, whose weight was eighteen tons, turned into Cedar Street from Broadway. This portion of the street is badly cut up at present.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Senate will conclude its consideration of the appropriation bills this week. It is expected the Indian bill will pass early to-morrow, and the Sundry Civil and Agricultural bills will follow in the order named. There is no expectation that there will be any prolonged debate upon any of the bills.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 18. -- A double burglary, evidently the work of experts, occurred here last night. A safe in the large millinery store of F.J. West was broken open and $1,000 in cash was taken. Small change, checks, and drafts were thrown aside.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TURKISH ARMY IN MACEDONIA, ELASSONA, April 18. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press returned last night from Karya, on the Greek frontier, north of Tyrnavos, and three hours' ride from here. A fierce battle between the Turks and Greeks was then raging at Karya. The fighting had been in progress all day.
FALL RIVER, Mass., April 18. -- Thomas E. Barrett, clerk for the New York and Boston Dispatch Company, was the victim of an atrocious assault to-night, from which a fatal result is expected.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was crowded with thousands of worshippers and visitors at the pontifical mass yesterday morning. Not only were there the attractions of the vocal and instrumental music of Easter Day, but Archbishop Corrigan was celebrant, and the Rev. Dr. Thomas Shahan of the Catholic University of America was to preach.

If John Y. McKane had been transported to Coney Island yesterday he would, despite all the announcements of great changes and reforms to be effected, have found no difficulty in recognizing his old stamping grounds. He would have found more "hotels" than ever before, and fewer gambling places, more concert and dance halls, and, if possible, worse music, longer dresses on the women performers, and older women performing.

Fifteen years ago Butler H. Bixby, then a Police Justice, committed Columbus Heppenstall of 151 Eighth Avenue for examination as to his sanity. Heppenstall was found insane after an examination, and formally committed to the Ward's Island Lunatic Asylum. He remained there nineteen months, and then escaped. He had vowed to be revenged upon all who were instrumental in having him confined.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 18. -- Tewfik Pasha, the Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs, visited the foreign envoys yesterday and informed them that the Turkish frontier had been crossed on Friday night by fresh bands of Greeks, among whom were a number of Greek regulars.

A squad from the Old Slip Station, led by Policeman Flannery, raided the pushcart peddlers in Fulton Street on Saturday afternoon, and arrested eight of them. In Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning, Magistrate Mott fined them $3 each without trouble until he reached Thomas Carmery, who demanded his right under the Constitution to be confronted with his accuser.

FOOT OF MILOUNA PASS, April 18. -- A fierce battle raged in the pass all night long. The Greeks who entered and descended toward the valley encountered four battalions of Turks, who drove them back, and at the point of the bayonet rescued the force garrisoning the Turkish blockhouse, which the Greeks had encircled before entering the pass.

TACOMA, Washington, April 18. -- A huge devil fish yesterday afternoon attacked a boat containing Dr. W.T. Warren, Miss Katie Herbruck, and Lillian McKeehan, who were out searching for sea urchins and starfishes. The octopus made his appearance while the party were rowing along the short of Lemons Beach.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 18. -- A man about twenty-one years of age accosted a hackman on the American side and asked to be driven to the Canadian side.

There was some good sport on the Harlem River yesterday, as the oarsmen are anxious to get in racing form for the Decoration Day Regatta, and all took advantage of the fine weather. Every club on the river had crews out, both morning and afternoon, and as a consequence there were many impromptu races.

Trinity Church was far too small to accommodate the great throngs of people who congregated there yesterday morning and afternoon to attend the Easter services. Every seat in the edifice was occupied some time before the opening hour of both services, and those who came a few minutes late were hardly able to secure standing room in the rear of the church.
PARIS, April 18. -- The Temps calls upon the powers to intervene by force of arms to stop Turkey and Greece from further fighting.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, April 9. -- Whoever has not visited Germany for ten years cannot deny that in many respects this country has undergone wonderful changes during that time, and that business appears to be prosperous and the people happy and contented. The cities have made many striking improvements.

The perplexed Government of Great Britain might be excused for wishing of Mr. GLADSTONE that he would return to political life or -- something. In his last letter, addressed to a Macedonian leader, he says:

ATHENS, April 18 -- 11 A.M. -- The Turkish batteries at Preveza, on the north shore of the entrance of the Gulf of Arta, where, according to the treaty of Berlin, the Turks had no right to erect fortifications, fired on and sunk a Greek steamer, the Macedonia, this morning while the latter was attempting to leave the Gulf of Ambracia.

Of all the promises made by either political party during the last twenty-five years, promises which certainly were intended to appeal to the confidence of the people, none have so signally failed, nor revealed the utter lack of intention or want of ability to redeem, than those made by the present Administration at the time they appealed to the voters for their support.

The subject discussed by the Brooklyn Philosophical Society at its meeting in the Long Island Business College, South Ninth Street, Williamsburg, yesterday afternoon, was that of "Christianity and the Higher Criticism." The principal speaker was Henry Rowland of Brooklyn. Mr. Rowland said that the ultimate result of the attacks of the critics on the Bible will be its destruction.

VICKSBURG, Miss., April 18. -- At 6 P.M. the river was 51.8 feet, a fall of three-tenths of a foot in the past twenty-four hours, and a total of six-tenths of a foot since the crevasse was made at Biggs Levee at 10 o'clock Friday night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 18. -- An application has been made to Surrogate Dorland for the removal of F.W. Pugsley as executor of the estate of Margaret J. Myers, deceased, by the American Tract Society and the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church of the United States, the legatees under the will.

ATHENS, April 18. -- A late special sitting of the Legislative Assembly was held to-day. The public galleries were crowded. Amid intense excitement M. Delyannis, the Premier, announced that the Turkish Government had to-day notified Greece of the rupture of diplomatic relations, on the ground of the aggressive attitude of the Greek Government.

Like everything else in New York not immediately concerned in the earning and trading of the nimble dollar, the Easter after-church parade moves further up town each year. Fashion follows the new mansions of the very rich. Madison Square used to be the centre of the showy throng Yesterday it was almost a mile away from the beginning of it.

Some saloon keepers fancy they see a way of supplying their patrons with drink on Sundays and during the prohibited hours. There are a great many old club charters in this city, and a number of saloon proprietors have gone so far as to negotiate for these. Such as were granted previous to March, 1895, have in consequence borrowed a speculative value.
The information we get from Washington is that a proposition for a currency commission, if sent in promptly by the President and vigorously supported, would be adopted.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 18. -- The German General sent by the Emperor William to inspect the armies on the frontier has returned from Elassona. He reports favorably as to the Turkish Army, except in the matter of transport service. The Greeks he considers inferior in armament and less capable of standing fatigue and exposure.

ELASSONA, April 18. -- The Greeks from all their positions in the Karya district began the advance toward the frontier at 7 o'clock on Friday evening. The fighting lasted all that night, and extended on Saturday to within ten miles of the frontier. It is estimated that 15,000 Greeks were engaged. The battle continued with great vigor throughout Friday night and Saturday, when altogether 50,000 were engaged.
LONDON, April 18. -- The Times's correspondent at Elassona will say to-morrow:

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 18. -- Seth L. Milliken, representing in the House of Representatives, the Third District of Maine, died to-night at 9:30 o'clock. For some time Mr. Milliken had suffered from a serious affection of the bronchial tubes, which refused to yield to treatment.

GIRARD, Kan., April 18. -- The committee of the National Reform Press Association has decided to wage war on Marion Butler, Chairman of the Populist National Committee and also to reorganize the Populist Party.
The following sales are announced for to-day at 111 Broadway:

ALBANY, April 18. -- It is the general opinion of the leaders that adjournment of the legislative session can be had finally on Saturday of this week, but there is yet a possibility of delay if the fighting over important matters continues.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Henry W. Cramp, Vice President of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, to-day denied the report that a bill for $138,000 had been sent to Secretary of the Navy Long for repairing the cruiser Brooklyn. He said the Navy Department has not received any bill at all from the Cramps, and that the bill, when it should be sent to Washington, would not foot up $138,000 nor anything like that sum.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 18. -- President John S. Rively of the Monongahela Street Railway Company, has, it is thought, solved the storage battery problem. Mr. Rively is an inventor of no mean accomplishment, and he has been working on the present idea for six years. He has just returned from New York and Philadelphia, where he has interested capitalists in the idea, it is said, to the extent of $5,000,000.

It is interesting to remark that the supporters of good municipal government are much cheered by Mr. LAUTERBACH'S avowed preference for a Tammany triumph in the local election over the triumph of a non-partisan ticket. Mr. LAUTERBACH'S own confederated "boys" are correspondingly depressed.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton, pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, preached on the subject of "Universalism and Immortality" last night.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., April 18. -- The police of Somersworth believe that "Joe" Kelley, whose arrest they are trying to accomplish, is the man who killed Cashier Joseph A. Stickney of the Great Falls National Bank of Somersworth last Friday and robbed the bank. Additional evidence pointing to his guilt has been discovered.

Mr. GROSVENOR of Ohio has given birth to a new civil service bill. It has, substantially, two purposes. One is bad, to exempt from the law the employes of the Printing Office and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, and all persons employed as workmen or laborers. This last provision is meant to open the navy yards to the politicians.

The dropping of the free-lunch provision in the amendment of the Raines law affords a fine illustration of the motives that prevail in that kind of legislation. When the original law was passed the prohibition of giving away food in saloons and barrooms was justified on the ground that free lunch attracted customers and led to much drinking and was extremely bad for the habits of the people.
LONDON, April 18. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says:

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The grave situation in the East was the topic of discussion in diplomatic and official circles here to-day. The possibility of war between Turkey and Greece has been thought probable for some time, but the official announcement that a state of war exists served to quicken the interest with which the troubles between the two countries has been watched.

The local Greek colony is all agog with the news from the seat of action, but is not at all alarmed by the seeming victories of Edhem Pasha, who has moved with 10,000 men on Larissa. They say that his move is a foolhardy one, and is liable to be his doom.

The Metropolitan Opera House was crowded to the doors last evening, the occasion being the last concert of the season, with an audience eager to hear Calve sing. But they were doomed to disappointment. Calve did not appear. It was after 8 o'clock when word was received at the Opera House that the diva was indisposed and could not sing.

The Central Labor Union listened yesterday to protests by its delegates against what they said were the steady restrictions being made by the State Legislature and the Municipal Government upon the liberty of the citizens.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 18. -- The Australian baseball team made its first appearance here in a game to-day and suffered defeat by the Olympics. Score, 20 to 9.

" Supply and demand, logical cause and effect, the natural laws of trade, have been superseded by the arbitrary proclamations of the Executive, the folly of Legislatures and Congress, and the revolutionary decisions of courts."
Former Excise Commissioner Julius Harburger addressed the members of the Brighton Literary Association yesterday at Odd Fellows Hall, discussing the Raines law. He said in part:

A young girl, weak and pale, staggered into the East Twenty-second Street Police Station early yesterday morning and mutely held a dead baby out to the Sergeant in charge. Then she would have fallen had not a policeman caught her and led her to a chair.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 18. -- The Australian baseball team made its first appearance here in a game to-day and suffered defeat by the Olympics. Score, 20 to 9.

" Supply and demand, logical cause and effect, the natural laws of trade, have been superseded by the arbitrary proclamations of the Executive, the folly of Legislatures and Congress, and the revolutionary decisions of courts."

Francis Donchue pleaded guilty to larceny in the second degree yesterday before Judge Newburger in Part I. of General Sessions, and asked that his former good character be considered by the Court before passing sentence. He asserted that it was his first offense.

BALTIMORE, April 19. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has decided to inaugurate on May 1 the tonnage system for handling its freight trains. For the last eight or nine months General Manager Greene has been experimenting along this line, and has arrived at the conclusion that the cost of operation may be decreased, to some extent, by using this plan.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The attendance on the floor and in the galleries of the Senate to-day was unusually large. A resolution for a committee of five Senators to inquire into the issuance of land patents to the Pacific railroads and to the California and Oregon Railroad, and the amounts of subsidies paid to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was favorably reported, but on the suggestion of Mr. Stewart of Nevada, went over.

During the last month the Ministries of Athens and Constantinople have been "manoeuvring for position." War has been inevitable ever since the Greek Government dispatched its battalions to Crete, in obedience to an overwhelming popular demand. If this demand had not been promptly complied with, there would, according to the accounts of all observers, have been a revolution in Greece itself.
A children's matinee will be given at Wallack's Theatre Thursday afternoon for the benefit of the Chapel Hill Fresh Air Mission.

Mrs. Anne Gilbert owns $60,000 worth of property on Emmons Avenue, Sheepshead Bay, and keeps a hotel for Summer boarders on a portion of it. She has steadily opposed the construction of a trolley line along that avenue, asserting that it would lessen the value of her holdings.

LONDON, April 19. -- The news of the outbreak of hostilities on the Greek frontier has caused but little sensation here. The permanent officials and the Turkish Embassy have received no information beyond the fact that war has been declared. The correspondent of The Associated Press understands that Turkey has no idea of territorial conquest because she is aware that the powers would not sanction an advance to Athens.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 19. -- The work on the new fortifications at New Castle has been begun, and the contractors have a gang of men, supposed to be Austrians, employed in preparing the ground for the masonry. These men sleep and are fed in the old commissary building at Fort Constitution. Visitors are excluded from the site of the fortifications except by pass, as a huge board fence has been erected around the new fort.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 19. -- The fourteen National and State banks and banking companies in Louisville have filed a suit in the United States court asking that the State of Kentucky be enjoined from making an effort to collect any tax on their capital stock. The case will be carried into the highest courts for a speedy settlement.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Secretary of Agriculture to-day sent to the Senate a report by the Chief of the Forestry Division of the Department on the amounts of white pine and other coniferous timber standing and its consumption in the United States, in response to a resolution by Senator Chandler.
The sale of the second section of the library of the late Edward Hale Bierstadt, Treasurer of the Grolier Club, began at Bangs's auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- After much effort, owing probably to some confusion in wire transmission, the State Department officials have succeeded in translating the cipher cable dispatch received by Secretary Sherman last night from United States Min ister Terrell at Constantinople. The result was the following official statement:

SALT LAKE, Utah, April 19. -- The conference which has been held here for several days between the officials of the Union Pacific and Oregon Short Line Railways has closed. The Union Pacific officials went east to-day. It is understood the conference was for the purpose of agreeing upon traffic arrangements between the two roads, but that no definite results were reached.

Mayor Strong did not announce the appointment of Theodore Roosevelt's successor as Police Commissioner yesterday, although Mr. Roosevelt had gone to Washington and taken his place as Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., April 19. -- At the Great Falls National Bank this morning, what is thought to be a most significant clue was discovered, establishing beyond a doubt that "Joe" Kelley, who it is believed killed Cashier Stickney last Friday, was in the bank the day of the murder. On the counter was found a paper requesting that a package of postage stamps be delivered to the bearer. The document was signed Frank E. Stone.

A failure on the part of the officers of the railroads in Brooklyn to agree as to the arrangements for running their cars over the bridge, the opposition of some of the principal shareholders of the Brooklyn Heights Company and the probable sale of one of the elevated roads are all serious obstacles to the project to extend the traffic over the structure.

ATHENS, April 19. -- While the incidents of the day along the eastern portion of the frontier have not been of notable importance, the situation at the Gulf of Arta and in the vicinity of the Albanian frontier has become more favorable for the Greeks. The bombardment of Preveza was resumed at daybreak, with but feeble replies from the Turkish batteries at Hamidieh and Pantocratoros.

A suit for slander with damages placed at $10,000 is the result of the litigation by which Mrs. Nellie R. Kurtz sought to restrain the Riverside Wheelmen from occupying the residence on the southeast corner of Ninty-ninth Street and West End Avenue as a clubhouse.

ALBANY, April 19. -- At the session of the Assembly to-night a resolution offered by Mr. Smith of Westchester, providing that the widow of the late Assemblyman Richard S. Emmet, who died during the current session of the Legislature, be paid the balance of his salary, which was not due until after his death, was passed unanimously.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 19. -- The Supreme Court has rendered an important decision in reference to contempt proceedings in this State. Several months ago the Palmetto Brewery in Charleston got into financial troubles.

The uctuations in contract wheat, the May and July futures, made the professional market at the Produce Exchange, without European quotations to guide, very lively for the first two hours of speculation yesterday. That "Joe." McMahon, who receives the Chicago quotations, blackboards them, and attends to the dials, was for a time the busiest man in New York, is an assertion it would not be easy to dispute.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Patriots' Day opened clear and bright to-day with the booming of cannon and the ringing of bells at sunrise and a general display of National flags from all National, State, and municipal buildings, and many private residences.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The President is taking an active interest in the struggle between the Greeks and the Turks, and is being constantly advised by the Department of State as to the latest developments in the war. He wishes to insure the adoption of all proper and usual precautions for the protection of all American interests in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- After a very exciting opening to-day at an exceptionally great advance in its price, wheat simmered down to about its usual subdued nervousness. The final outcome was that May closed worth 75 cents and July 74 7/8@75 cents, as compared with 73 3/4 cents and 73 1/2 cents, respectively, Saturday afternoon.
ATHENS, April 19. -- The Greek Minister for Foreign Affairs has sent a reply to the note which Assim Bey, the retiring Turkish Minister, handed to M. Skouzes. The Turkish note was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- The immediate dismissal of Albert E. Conti, one of the Immigration Inspectors at this port, was ordered to-day by Secretary Gage. It is alleged that Conti eloped Sunday from Washington with the wife of F. Grimm, a veteran Treasury Department clerk. Conti is thirty-three years old and the woman is thirty.

Next Saturday has been fixed by joint resolution of the Senate and Assembly for the final adjournment of the Legislature, and we witness the same old familiar spectacle of a perfect "jam" of accumulated bills to be disposed of in the last few days of the session. Many of them will be slaughtered with little or no regard for their merits, and many more will remain unacted upon when the adjournment comes.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 19. -- The enormous amount of work to be accomplished by the Senate this week is evidenced by the size of the calendar which was presented for consideration to-night. It consisted of 64 pages, on which there were 321 bills ready for final passage and 27 for consideration in general orders.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- President McKinley informed member of Congress to-day that he would not be ready to take up the applications for Consulships before three or four weeks. By that time he hopes to see the tariff debate in the Senate will under way.
John Davis has sold for Builder Robert J. Blake, to an investor, for about $80,000, the two four-story business buildings, 31 and 33 East Twenty-fourth Street, 33.6 by 100.
Easter elections in the Protestant Episcopal churches held yesterday in this city and at neighboring points resulted in the following selections of officers:

NEW ORLEANS, April 19. -- The Carrollton levee, about which a great deal of anxiety is felt, stands at the head of the finest residence avenue in the city. A person stationed at the top of this levee looks upon the roofs of mansions while almost wetting his feet in the mighty river that is now eager to break its banks.

Easter offerings in at least two of Brooklyn's churches were unusually lavish last Sunday. By their generosity, the members of the Church of the Holy Trinity assured the building of the memorial house in honor of the late Dr. Charles Henry Hall, who served as rector of that parish for twenty-five years.

BOSTON, April 19. -- The Marathon games under the management of the Boston Athletic Association, and patterned after the games at Athens, Greece, in the Spring of 1896, were held this afternoon, and were witnessed by thousands of people. They included a twenty-five-mile road race from Ashland, Mass., to Boston and athletic games at Irvington Oval while the road race was in progress.

This map shows the territory between the thirty-eighth and fortieth parallels, embracing the northern portion of Greece and the southern portion of Turkey. The boundary line between the two countries is formed by the River Arta and a strip of territory north of the River Salamvria, and extends from the Ionian Sea on the west to the Aegean Sea on the east.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TURKISH ARMY IN MACEDONIA, ELASSON, April 19, (Evening.) -- The Turkish forces continue to hold the Milouna Pass, though it is reported that the Greeks are advancing or making ready to advance to reoccupy the positions from which they were dislodged on Sunday.

EXETER, N.H., April 19. -- Frank Wentworth, the sixteen-year-old boy who was arrested Saturday and lodged in Exeter jail on the charge of having attempted to poison his father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. George H. Wentworth, of Newton, N.H., has made a confession, stating that he put paris green in the tea while getting breakfast.

One of the notable events with which society opened the season of Easter gayeties yesterday was a unique entertainment called "The Egyptian Tea," given in the Waldorf banquet room, in aid of the Sunday Kindergarten on East Broadway, for the little Polish and Russian children of the tenement houses and the street waifs.

New York's Easter gift to the Barnum Bailey Circus managers was a little camel calf, which was born on Sunday in the menagerie quarters in Madison Square Garden. Mother and infant were both "doing fine," according to report, late last night.

The effect upon the markets yesterday of the declarations of war exchanged between Greece and Turkey seems to have been based upon the expectation that the war could not be prevented from spreading. Stocks and cotton fell. Wheat rose in even a more marked manner.

The anti-trust bills, so called, are expected to come up for action in the Senate at Albany to-day. We do not believe that anybody would be greatly grieved if they should be defeated, whereas their passage will cause some uneasiness and uncertainty.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Supreme Court to-day refused the application for a writ of certiorari and habeas corpus asked by Elverton R. Chapman, the broker, who refused to testify in the sugar speculation investigation whether Senators had speculated in sugar stocks while the Wilson tariff bill was before that body.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- There seems to be no diminution of the crowds which besiege the White House.

Assemblyman TRAINOR admits that his bills looking to the creation of the State of Manhattan are dead, but he says that their subject will be made a "war cry" by Tammany next Fall, and the bills will be introduced again next Winter. We doubt if that would be a very telling war cry for Tammany.

Col. Jenyns C. Battersby's suit for libel to recover $25,000 from Peter Fenelon Collier, owner of Once a Week, was continued yesterday in Part IV. of the Supreme Court before Justice Bischoff and a jury. In the Christmas number of the periodical for 1892 there was published a story by Edith Sessions Tupper, called "The Colonel's Christmas."

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Republican Senators were in caucus to-day nearly two hours, and adjourned when the Senate met, without reaching any agreement. The entire time was consumed in a discussion of committee organization, with incidental mention of the tariff. The proposition which had been submitted by the Democratic managers to the Republican committee was opposed by many Senators, more especially by Senators Chandler, Baker, and Elkins.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 19. -- Ex-Minister to Greece Snowden stated to-day that he had recently received the following reply to a message sent to King George, approving the attitude assumed by that monarch:

The factional trouble in the Trinity Methodist Protestant Church, Williamsburg, reached a climax at the annual meeting of its members last night for the election of Trustees. A platoon of police from the Bedford Avenue Station was finally called in to preserve order, and after a stormy session there was a division of the members, resulting in two separate meetings and the election of different officials.

There was an air of solemnity over Sorosis yesterday. The table at which sat the President and chief speakers of the day was decorated with Easter lilies and other white flowers. Sorosis was celebrating her third annual memorial day.

What are President McKINLEY'S three Bimetallic Conference Commissioners going to say to the European friends of the double standard? In sending them over the ocean, the United States takes the initiative. They must convince the bimetallists of Germany, France, and England that the time is ripe for another conference.

LONDON, April 19 -- Gen. Smolenitz, ex-Minister of War, is in command of 14,000 Greeks at Reveni, not far from Tyrnavo, northwest of Larissa. At this point Edhem Pasha, closely pressed, was nearly taken prisoner. His plan was to force the Pass of Reveni, to enter the Plain of Larissa, to cut off the retreat of the Greek Army with his cavalry, and thus to take Larissa without resistance.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Gov. Black gave a hearing on the Greater New York Charter to-day. The opponents of the charter made a strong showing, both as regards numbers and argument. The delegation from New York City, which arrived here on the Empire State Express shortly after 11 o'clock, comprised over sixty persons who are closely allied with and students of municipal government.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TURKISH ARMY IN MACEDONIA, ELASSONA, April 19. -- After a most fatiguing day with the headquarters staff in the Milouna Pass, the correspondent of The Associated Press has returned here. The battle on Sunday, resulting in giving the Turks possession of Milouna Pass, was waged with the most admirable courage and determination on both sides.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 19. -- A joint legislative committee has been investigating the wretched condition of the miners in the Pittsburg district. According to the evidence of the miners they have been cheated at every turn.

The officers at the Brooklyn Navy Yard are taking a deep interest in the warlike developments on the Grecian and Turkish frontiers, although no orders of any kind have been received in regard to a strengthening of our naval forces in the Levant.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The War Department officials are regarding the outlook in the lower Mississippi Valley with the greatest anxiety, fearing that the levee system there will prove unable to withstand the terrible strain.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Turkish Minister, Mustapha Bey, has communicated with Secretary Sherman on the status of the Turko-Grecian conflict. He officially informed the American Secretary of State of the termination of diplomatic relations between Turkey and Greece, and of the attitude of offense which Turkey had been compelled to take by reason of the aggressive course of Greece.

DUBLIN, April 19. -- The Parnellite Convention summoned by John Redmond to meet to-morrow in this city will be the most important event of its kind since the death of Charles Stewart Parnell. In an interview with the representative of The Associated Press to-day Mr. Redmond said:
" Present Issues in This Campaign" was the subject of an informal address last night by the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Church, before the Men's Club of the Church.
The Tammany Society or Columbian Order held its annual meeting and election of Sachems and officers in the main hall of the Wigwam last night.

The St. Nicholas Society celebrated "Pass," or Easter, last night, by a dinner at Delmonico's, smoking long Dutch pipes, and a half dozen speeches on all sorts of subjects from New Amsterdam customs to street cleaning in New York.

The feeling that dominates the Greeks in this city is a profound regret that they are able to do so litle for the mother country in her emergency. Taken as a whole they are a very patriotic people, but few of them have more than money enough to carry them along from day to day.

In the Easter holiday theatrical bills there are no fewer than three plays new to this city. Two of these, farces by Madeline Lucette Ryley and H. A. du Souchet, were very well received by the audiences at the Lyceum and Hoyt's Theatre, respectively, last night. The other, "Dr. Belgraff," by Charles Klein, presented at the Garden Theatre, had a less favorable reception.

It is not at all to be wondered at that the Mayor finds difficulty in filling the Police Commissionership vacated by the resignation of Mr. ROOSEVELT. It is not, under the existing conditions, an attractive place to anybody who is fit to fill it.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- If the Populist Party or any portion of it assembles in convention at Nashville on the Fourth of July, as is now proposed, Senator Butler, the National Chairman, will not be present.

HAVANA, April 19. -- A band of Spanish guerrillas was entrapped by the Cubans at a small town near Palacios, in Pinar del Rio, last week, and a fearful vengeance was inflicted upon them for the many recent murders of pacificos. This band is accused of the murders at Mangas last week, when forty people were killed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- The General Society of the Sons of the Revolution met in special session to-day to consider the proposition of consolidating with the Sons of the American Revolution. The subject was debated behind closed doors. Thirty-two States were represented, and the vote upon the question of consolidation stood 16 for and 14 against.

Your leader in yesterday's issue is timely and encouraging. The absurdity of the business part of our opera scheme is, I believe, without precedent. The thoroughly ridiculous prices, which could easily be calculated at so much per note, were never paid elsewhere.
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 19. -- The Imperial Ottoman Bank has offered the Government to establish at Elassona and maintain at its own expense a hospital for the wounded.

HAVANA, April 19. -- A detachment of the Aragon Battalion, it is announced, has captured the five remaining members of the insurgent force commanded by Zarraga. It is not known whether Zarraga has surrendered or not.

At the hearing before the Governor on the Greater New York charter Mr. CHARLES STEWART SMITH asked that the people of this city have the opportunity to study the charter for a year. "Scarcely a person," he said, "is opposed to consolidation, but they would like to have something to say as to the manner in which they will be governed."
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The annual egg rolling festival in the White House grounds, which always occurs on the Monday following Easter, took place to-day. It was an Ideal Spring day, warm and balmy.

Operators in the wheat pit at the Produce Exchange were excited yesterday over the decline in the May future. On Monday they were frantic over its rise. At the opening of trading the speculators were fully informed of the temper of the European markets, which reflected confidence in the shortness of the struggle between Greece and Turkey and the ability or determination of the onlooking nations not to be dragged into the squabble.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

The hearing before the Governor on the Greater New York charter brought out the most remarkable demonstration ever made against a proposed act of legislation in this State. There was a delegation of about sixty citizens, representing all the great commercial, professional, and civic interests of the community most deeply concerned, and all shades of political opinion, demanding with one voice that final action be postponed upon a scheme of government involving such momentous consequences.

With the Turks mendacity is a serious occupation. With the Greeks it is merely a popular pastime. We must expect, therefore, that in the dispatches the victories will go to Turkey and the heavy losses to Greece somewhat in excess of the apportionment which fate and the facts may actually ordain.

The Hamburg-American Line steamer Bohemia arrived at her dock in Hoboken yesterday afternoon, eighteen days out from Hamburg, with a damaged bow, resulting from an encounter with an enormous ice field in the North Atlantic.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 20. -- John Joseph Nouri has been crowned Patriarch at the Chaldean Pontifical Cathedral at Trichur, Malalar, and is ruler over the Syrian Chaldeans.

MONTREAL, April 20. -- Joseph E. Kelly, arrested here last night on suspicion of being the murderer of Joseph A. Stickney, cashier of the Great Falls National Bank of Somersworth, N.H., has confessed. When he was arrested Kelly admitted that he figured in the crime, but said that the murder was committed by an accomplice while he remained outside the bank and watched.

Jacob A. King has sold to Louis M. Cohn the three-story stone-front dwelling, 157 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 17 by 99; also, for Augusta Wunsch, to Bernard Galewski, the four-story brick building, 67, Market Street, 25 by 60.

A membership of 50,000 is what Chief Consul Potter believes New York State will alone provide for the League of American Wheelmen before the year ends. The number of persons in this State already belonging to the organization is over 20,000, or nearly twice that of any other division.
Consul General Botassi Forwards a Formal Notification from His Minister of Foreign Affairs to Secretary Sherman -- Greek Mass Meeting To-night.

The cold weather that has been hanging around New York and vicinity all this month reached a climax early yesterday morning, when the thermometer dropped to 24 above zero at 7 o'clock, and broke all records for the month of April. There had been nothing to compare with it since 1875, when the mercury got down as far as the freezing point.

There should be a universal compliance throughout the city on Tuesday next with the request of Mayor STRONG, officially proclaimed, not only that the buildings along the route of the parade to the monument of Gen. GRANT be decorated with the National colors, but that the American flag be displayed "wherever possible."

One of the most brilliant of the weddings arranged for the Easter season was solemnized in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the presence of an eminently fashionable congregation, nearly 3,000 in number. It was the marriage of Miss Lillian May Stokes, daughter of Thomas Stokes, of 8 West Fifty-third Street, and Robert McMaster Gillespie, son of Col. George L. Gillespie of the United States Army.
ALBANY, April 20. -- The Assembly passed Mr. Nixon's bill appropriating $1,250,000 for continuing work on the Capitol building, $800,000 of which is available at once.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Out of a batch of four nominations sent to the Senate by the President this afternoon three met with the unqualified approval of Senator Platt. One did not receive his prior sanction, but it may not encounter his opposition in the Senate. Mr. Platt had signified his desire to have Mr. Van Cott appointed to succeed Mr. Dayton as Postmaster.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and their household returned to New York to-day, after having spent three delightful months in Washington. The Vanderbilts occupied the Lowery mansion at K Street and Vermont Avenue, and their coming caused quite a flutter in fashionable circles.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 20. -- A second Turkish squadron left the Golden Horn this afternoon for the Dardanelles. It consists of the ironclad Orhanion, the monitor Hifsirahman, the corvette Mansoura, five torpedo boats, and four steamers which have been converted into cruisers.

Dr. RAINSFORD'S vigorous address on municipal issues before the Men's Club of St. George's Church illustrates one marked advantage that has already been gained by the formation of the Citizens' Union. A clergyman who "preaches politics" or who talks politics in public necessarily impairs his influence as a clergyman unless his congregation is all of one way of political thinking.

The last of the series of monthly conferences, which were arranged by the Charity Organization Society, was held yesterday morning at 11 o'clock in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building. The attendance was good, and great interest was manifested in the charity work of the different societies and organizations. Mrs. J.F. Tapley presided, in the absence of Miss Kate Bond, Chairman of the Central Auxiliary Committee of Women.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- In the Senate to-day a resolution by Mr. Hoar (Rep., Mass.,) was agreed to requesting the Secretary of State for comprehensive information as to the machinery of Government of all foreign nations with which we have diplomatic relations, the taxes or excises, and methods of collection, imports and exports, method of aiding the merchant marine, discriminations against American merchant vessels, public indebtedness,

ALBANY, April 20. -- Some new points were brought out this afternoon in opposition to Gov. Black's Civil Service bill, at a hearing before the Assembly Judiciary Committee. A large delegation from Buffalo, headed by Charles B. Wheeler, Chairman of the Civil Service Commission of that city, was present, as were representatives of the boards from Albany and Rochester.

The Bijou Theatre was closed last night, and will surely not reopen until to-morrow evening, May Irwin has been suffering for some time past from nervous chills, and on Monday night, while the performance of "Courted Into Court" was going on, she became so ill that her physician was summoned.

ALBANY, April 20. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided the Manhattan Elevated railroad tax case in favor of the company. The order of the Appellate Division is reversed, and that of the Special Term is so modified as to vacate the assessment and order a new assessment by the Commissioner without costs to either party.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:
Col. Jenyns C. Battersby won his libel suit against Peter Fenelon Collier, proprietor of the paper which was "Once a Week, but is at present Collier's Weekly.

The meetings of the National League magnates held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last week to devise some plan to bring back Amos Rusie to the New York ball team this year have been successful. The big Hoosier pitcher, who is at present in Indianapolis, has signed the contract which President Freedman sent, and will leave Indianapolis to-day or to-morrow to report for duty. The signed contract is now on the way to New York.

ATHENS, April 20. -- Midnight. -- News has just reached here that the Greeks, after a desperate battle, have captured and burned Damasi. Viglia is still resisting. But another division of the Greek troops, it is reported, has traversed the Reveni Pass and captured three blockhouses. This division has almost reached Damasi, where it will effect a union with the force that captured the town. The 20,000 troops under Gen. Smolenitz displayed the greatest bravery.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Members of the Ways and Means Committee of the House are at a loss to understand the report given out to-day as coming from the Senate Finance Committee, that the Republicans of that committee will make many reductions in the tariff bill. They do not regard it as probable.
The decision of the Supreme Court that witnesses who refused to answer in the Senate sugar inquiry were rightfully sentenced is a very important one and will certainly be sustained by public opinion.

The eminent citizens who have represented the varied interests and associations of this city in opposing the Greater New York charter are not subject to reproach for being so late with their protest, for the opportunity was not given for making it sooner.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 20. -- Superintendent of Insurance Payn to-day made public the report of Deputy Superintendent of Insurance R.H. Hunter and Chief Examiner Isaac Vanderpoel of their examination of the United States Casualty Company of the City of New York. The report says:
The stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company met in the Mutual Life Insurance Building yesterday and discussed the problem, what to do with the Opera House next year.

Evidence of the magnitude of the preparations for the proper celebration of Grant Day began appearing yesterday all over the city. Along the Boulevard, above Fifty-ninth Street, up to Seventy-second Street, the sound of hammer and saw is continually heard, while the skeletons of stands arise as if by magic.

DUBLIN, April 20. -- There was a large attendance of prominent Parnellites present at the Parnellite convention summoned to meet in this city to-day by Mr. John Redmond, the Parnellite leader. The meeting was private.

The adjourned examination of Capt. Reed of the ship T.F. Oakes on the criminal charge of having withheld suitable food from the crew of the vessel on the celebrated two-hundred-and-fifty-nine-day passage from Hongkong, was resumed yesterday afternoon before Commissioner Shields in the Federal Building.

HAVANA, April 20. -- The Spanish gunboat Delgado Parejo left here on Wednesday last for the mouth of the San Juan River, Province of Santa Clara, to protect the landing of detachments of troops, shipped there on board the steamship Gloria, under Gen. Pratts.
The decision of the Court of Appeals reversing the Appellate Court of the Second Division in the Brooklyn civil service case is a surprise and a disappointment.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 20. -- Another fruitless ballot for United States Senator was taken in the Legislature to-day. It is settled now that Dr. Hunter, who has been the Republican candidate, will withdraw. He announced to-day that he should not prolong his fight for the Senatorship "beyond a reasonable time." It is believed he will be out of the race to-morrow.

The second day's sale of the second part of the Bierstadt library at Bangs's auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, attracted a good-sized crowd. The authors whose works brought out the keenest competition were Sheridan, Pope, Rossetti, Shakespeare, Shelley, and Shirley, a playwright and poet of the seventeenth century.
ALBANY, April 20. -- The Senate five-cent graduated reduction in price gas bill came up on final passage in the Assembly today and caused long discussion.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The presence on the floor of the Senate to-day of the members of the Republican sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee which is engaged in preparing the Tariff bill was made the basis of much speculation. The members of the committee were closeted for a time with Senator Vest of the Democratic side of the Finance Committee, and afterward held individual conferences with other Senators on both sides of the Chamber.

The population of the Island of Crete, earnestly desiring to be free from Turkish rule, rose up against it, killed certain of its agents, and laid siege to some of its strongholds. The contest, however, was too unequal. The islanders made no secret of their intention, if they should win their independence, of joining themselves to the Kingdom of Greece, to which geographically and ethnologically they belonged.

CANTON, Ohio, April 21. -- Albert Winger, George Gifford, and John Barber, three prisoners in the Stark County Workhouse, escaped from that place. They were with others in line going from a meal. The Superintendent of the institution called a man from the rank of prisoners to speak to him. This act distracted the attention of the guards momentarily, and the three prisoners made a dash for liberty.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 21. -- The Assembly began work this morning by overriding the vetoes of Mayors.

FOOT OF MILOUNA PASS, April 20. -- Afternoon -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- The last height commanding Tyrnavo has just been captured by the Turks. The infantry advance was supported by cavalry, the soldiers cheering lustily as they began the attack.

The Richard Arnold String Sextet is the name of a new chamber music organization, of which Richard Arnold, concert master of the Philharmonic Society, is the leader. From the character of some of the music performed at its first concert in the Mendelssohn Glee Club Hall last night it is natural to draw the conclusion that the sextet was organized with designs upon the Summer resorts.
The Governor's signature has given effect to the amended Raines law. Will it be rigidly enforced where public opinion is opposed to its restrictions?
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Fourth-class Postmasters for New York offices were appointed to-day as follows: Hartfield, M.W. Scofield; West Berns, P.H. Clow.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 21. -- This afternoon at 3 o'clock the Senate Committee on Railroads gave a hearing on the bill introduced by Senator Ford enabling the City of New York to issue bonds sufficient to purchase the Sixth and Eighth Avenue railroads, according to the terms of the contract existing between the city and the said two corporations.

Trainers and their charges were out early yesterday morning at the Morris Park and Gravesend race tracks, for the air was crisp and invigorating, and the tracks were in perfect shape. Deerslayer, Walter Rollins's candidate for the Washington Handicap, to be run at the Bennings track on Saturday, received his final preparation for the race, at Morris Park early in the morning.

An audience of nearly 1,000 persons greeted Ferdinand Brunetire, the editor of the Revue des Deux Mondes, at the Lenox Lyceum, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon, when he delivered the first of a series of lectures in French on "La Litterature Francaise Contemporaine."

The Turkish forces under Edhem Pasha have been checked in their effort to seize Larissa by the Greek Army under Crown Prince Constantine. The first real battle of the war was fought near Larissa last night with varying fortune. Edhem Pasha has sent to Constantinople for 40,000 more troops. The Greeks are mustering every available man into service, and are massing their forces around Larissa.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 21. -- There seems to be no question that the college boat races will be held on the Poughkeepsie course if satisfactory quarters can be secured by all the crews. This was evidenced by the presence in this city to-day of representatives of Columbia and Yale in quest of quarters for their crews.

The last day but one of the sale of the Bierstadt library by Bangs Co., auctioneers, 91 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, brought out spirited bidding. This was especially the case as regarded Swinburne's, in which the collection was rich; Symond's, Waller's, and Tennyson's. Many of the latter, being first editions, were keenly competed for. Conspicuous among the sales made were:
