-- Seeing that the phrase "white squadron" lost all definite meaning a good many years ago, it would seem to be judicious no longer to set it hard at work whenever a few United States vessels make their appearance here or elsewhere. When the Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, and New York made their first trip to Europe they were a squadron, they were white, and no other warships were of that color.

In view of the general interest taken in a suit which has been recently brought against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, a "modern instance" of personal experience with the methods of this corporation appears significant.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Correspondence is still in progress between Representative Pearson and the Hon. Henniker Heaton, M.P., upon the details of the international chess match between the American Congress and the British Parliament. The games will not begin for two weeks or more, however.
LONDON, April 21. -- The lacrosse team of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn, N.Y., to-day defeated a picked team of the Surrey Lacrosse Clubs by a score of 7 to 3.

Mayor Strong again offered the Police Commissionership to ex-United States District Attorney Edward Mitchell yesterday. The latter, it was said, took the matter under consideration, and is strongly urged by friends of the Mayor to accept. Mr. Mitchell will probably give the Mayor a definite answer to-day.

The monthly meeting of the local consulate of the League of American Wheelmen last evening developed a tempest in a teapot. It was all the result of the refusal of the Membership Committee to report favorably upon the application of Malcolm L. Bridgman, which Mrs. E.S. Merry secured and turned in six months ago.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Turkish Legation received an official dispatch sent from Constantinople at an early hour this morning, as follows:
When the State of Kentucky permitted a majority of its Court of Appeals to be made up of silverites it made a bad bargain.
President Charles G. Wilson of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange in discussing financial conditions said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ALBANY, April 21. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad was held to-day at the Union Station in this city. About $63,000,000 of stock was voted. The English proxies were voted by Mr. Robert Bacon of J. Pierpont Morgan Co.

Judge, in its latest issue, has a cartoon at the expense of President McKINLEY and his party which is even more stinging than it was intended to be. It represents "Uncle Sam" in a very ragged suit scolding Boss Tailor McKINLEY because the "protection clothes" ordered in November for March are not yet even cut out.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 21. -- The first work in the Senate to-day was the repassing of Mr. Bondy's bill creating a police pension fund for the City of Syracuse over the veto of the Mayor of that city.
ATHENS, April 21 -- Midnight -- The Crown Prince Constantine telegraphs from Larissa, the headquarters of the Greek forces in Thessaly:

Now that the amendments to the Raines law have been signed by the Governor and so become a part of that law, the question of their interpretation and enforcement is one of present importance to every person in any way engaged in the liquor traffic.
James Kyle Sons have sold for Dr. Francis Valk, the three-story-and-basement private dwelling 146 East Thirty-seventh Street, 14 by 98.9.

Court do not move very rapidly at best. The famous hat-trimmings case, which has just reached a verdict in the United States Circuit Court in Philadelphia, has been pending for three years. It involved duties of over $20,000,000 collected by the United States Government on importations of trimmings which the importers claimed were hat trimmings, taxable at 20 per cent., and the Government claimed were dress trimmings, taxable at 50 per cent.

We mean no disrespect to the court of last resort in the State of New York when we say that its decision in the Brooklyn civil service cases is a most unsatisfactory and inadequate piece of judicial work.

An unsuccessful attempt at safe cracking by two burglars in the building occupied by Burt's shoe store and the S.S. White Dental Supply Company at Hoyt and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn, at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning resulted in the capture of a man known as James Lynch and the narrow escape of Officer Carroll of the First Precinct from being shot.

Turkey and Greece are at present somewhat in the position of two dogs engaged in ferociously biting each other's tail. EDHEM Pasha has invaded Thessaly in the east, marching south at the head of a Turkish army, and Col. MANOS, in the west, has invaded Epirus with a Greek army, marching north. Both are victorious and both are pressing forward into the enemy's country.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Mrs. E. Frances Hyde and Mr. Eugene De Kieffer, who left New York this morning on horseback, arrived at their destination, the Hotel Stratford, this city, at 4:42 o'clock, having made the trip in 8 1/2 hours.

If the remarks of Dr. AUSTIN FLINT, in a discussion of "Disease and Crime," are correctly reported, he declared against capital punishment in the sweeping assertion that "the physician should never countenance a judicial murder, for it is a murder to take a human life." Though we find the statement in marks of quotation, we call hardly believe that a man of such eminent ability and undoubted reasoning power could so "beg the question."

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The large batch of nominations sent to the Senate yesterday seems to have whetted the appetite of the office seekers and there was a greater crowd at the White House to-day than for ten days past. Senator Lodge and Congressman Barrett of Massachusetts presented Arthur D. Breed of Lynn, who has been indorsed by the Bay State delegation for Consul General to Montreal.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Republican members of the Finance Committee of the Senate have reached an agreement either to strike out the retroactive provision of the Dingley Tariff bill or to so amend it as to pave the way for its being stricken out in conference, and have so notified the Democratic members of the committee.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Wheat was as bad as a woman to-day in the variety of its moods and the suddenness of its changes. It started very strong, sold for a time at an advance of 2 1/2c over yesterday, and closed at a net loss of 1/4c. Strong cables and heavy realizing were the factors.

PARIS, April 21. -- The correspondent of Le Journal at Athens had an interview with King George of Greece at the palace yesterday. His Majesty is quoted as saying he believed to the last moment that peace would be maintained and did his utmost to bring about a pacific solution of the matters in dispute.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department has made the following report of the damage caused to agricultural interests on the Mississippi River by the flood:

Dock Commissioner O'Brien was not one of the guests at the shipwarming on the new North German Lloyd's steamship Friedrich der Grosse Tuesday night, and he had no opportunity to hear Collector Kilbreth's speech, in which he said that New York should give the steamship lines their wharf-room free.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- United States Consul General Lee has advised the State Department that the Spanish authorities at Havana have released one consignment of Cuban tobacco for shipment to a New York firm. This tobacco has been held in Havana since May last, when Captain General Weyler, by a decree, forbade the further exportation of tobacco from the island.

A paper on "The Synchronograph, A New Method of Rapidly Transmitting Intelligence by the Alternating Current," was read last evening before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, in New York and Chicago. In this city the paper was read before a good-sized audience at 12 West Thirty-first Street by its authors, Lieut. George Owen Squier and Albert Cushing Crehore.

Before the present session of the Legislature began much interest was awakened in this city over a reduction in the price of gas, caused in part by reports of a consolidation of companies with more watering of already diluted stock and increase of profits, and in part by an agitation of the question of municipal ownership of all "plants" supplying light.

Eight stocks were traded in yesterday to the extent of over 10,000 shares apiece, one of them -- Sugar Trust -- aggregating over 26,000. Out of a total of less than 180,000 shares dealt in throughout the whole list these eight contributed about 130,000 shares.

TACOMA, Washington, April 22. -- News received to-day from Hongkong absolutely contradicts stories from Madrid that the Philippine rebellion is practically stamped out. On the contrary, two important engagements have been fought, in both of which the insurgents were victorious.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Every man, woman, and child who has been moved by the exhibitions of such domestic pictures as "The Old Homestead," "The Cricket on the Hearth," or "Shore Acres," will have an opportunity to discover anew their capacity for being touched if they chance to see "The Hoosier Doctor."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 22. -- Ever since the Troy Conference convened in this city yesterday morning there have been ugly rumors that one of the prominent members of the body was to be tried on grave charges.
POUGHKEEPSIE, April 22. -- Ex-Sheriff George Lamoree and his wife, an aged couple, were robbed and tied in bed by masked robbers in their home at Salt Point, Dutchess County, last night.
ALBANY, April 22. -- The Assembly repassed over the veto of the Mayor of New York Mr. Roche's Ward's Island Bridge bill.

Bicycle insurance is not always what it is claimed to be. The experience of the League of American Wheelmen in prosecuting the claims of its members against a Chicago concern to recover for loss of wheels insured by the company is interesting. President Potter of the league received a letter yesterday from the attorney who handles these cases in behalf of the organization. It reads as follows:
ALBANY, N.Y., April 22. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast has issued the general orders for the National Guard of the State during the Grant memorial parade in New York next week. The order reads:
ALBANY, April 22. -- At 2:45 o'clock this afternoon the rules of the Senate were suspended for the purpose of taking up the Civil Service bill of the Governor.
ALBANY, April 22. -- In the Senate this morning the President named Senators Krum, Higgins, White, Stewart, and Koehler as the special committee to investigate the Department of Public Buildings.

We doubt if many of our readers understand the scope and effect of the bill which has passed the Legislature and now awaits the Governor's approval, providing for a "graduated transfer tax." Most of them probably do not know how that which started as a "collateral inheritance" tax and afterward became a general "inheritance" tax got transformed into a "transfer" tax.

LONDON, April 22. -- The United States Ambassador Col. John Hay, accompanied by the Secretary of the United States Embassy, Mr. Henry White, called at the Foreign Office this afternoon and saw the permanent officials of that department of the Government.

The weather and track conditions yesterday at Gravesend and Morris Park, where the trainers have been most active during the past two weeks in getting their charges in trim for the racing season, which will open in this vicinity at Aqueduct on Tuesday, were all that could be desired. As a result the horses were forced to do some lively work.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 22. -- James B. Angell, President of the University of Michigan and President McKinley's appointee as Minister to Turkey, spent yesterday and last night here, en route to Ann Arbor, Mich., where he goes to confer with the Trustees of the university in regard to his acceptance of the position tendered him.
WASHINGTON, April. 22. -- The first reference in Congress to the Turko-Grecian war came soon after the Senate opened to-day, when Mr. Allen of Nebraska introduced the following resolution:

The first annual dinner of the New York Credit Men's Association was eaten last evening in the Colonial Room of the St. Denis Hotel. Covers were laid for more than 150 persons. The table decorations were lilies, roses, pinks, and tulips. A Hungarian band played while the dinner was in progress. Charles Biggs, President of the association, presided and was toastmaster.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE GREEK ARMY, LARISSA, April 22. -- The latest advices as to the situation at Damasi show that on Sunday the Turks made a sortie from the town and attacked the Greek position at Boughasi Pass and Sideropoluki. After severe fighting the Greeks drove the Turks back across the frontier, with a loss of five guns.

Spirited songs of war time and stories of bravery on the battlefield gave cheer to companions of the Loyal Legion at Delmonico's last night, when the Commandery of the State of New York gave a farewell dinner to Gen. Horace Porter, who is retiring from the leadership of the Commandery to become Ambassador of the United States to France.

ROME, April 22. -- At 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, while King Humbert was on his way to the races, a man named Pietro Acciarito, an ironworker out of employment, attempted to stab his Majesty with a dagger. The man was seized before he could carry out his purpose, and the King proceeded to the Campanelle race course, seemingly unmoved.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The following memorial was to-day presented to the President and members of the Cabinet by the Executive Council of the Federation of Labor:

Quite a commotion was produced in the Senate at Albany yesterday by the announcement by the Lieutenant Governor of his appointment of the Committee of Five to investigate the management of the State Department of Public Buildings which had been authorized the day before by a resolution unanimously adopted.

A Frenchman, whose name was not made public, brought five bars of metal to the United States Assay Office on Tuesday, and asked Superintendent Mason to have the bars assayed. Mr. Mason looked askance at the bars, but complied with the Frenchman's request. Yesterday the owner of the bars was informed that he was the possessor of a very excellent mass of brass.

The reception and ball of the ladies of the Ohio Society of New York was held at the Waldorf last night. About 250 were present. The reception was held from 9 to 10:30 o'clock, and the stream of guests was received by Mrs. Henry L. Burnett, Mrs. William L. Strong, and Mrs. Calvin S. Brice. Dancing began immediately after the reception.
Mandelbaum Lewine have sold to Frinberg Freedman the four-story front and rear tenements 15 Monroe Street, 25 by 100.

HAVANA, April 22. -- It turns out that Kelley, the American who disappeared from Havana a fortnight ago, went to the insurgent lines representing himself as an expert in the use of dynamite, and alleging that the New York Junta had sent him. The insurgents distrusting his story, and considering him a spy, hanged him, after having stripped him of his clothing.

Otis E. Bullock of Haverhill, Mass., twenty-one years old, a passenger on the steamship Finance, which arrived yesterday from Colon, was removed, on the vessel's arrival at Quarantine, to Swinburne Island, suffering from yellow fever of a most malignant type. He died soon afterward. He had been sick for several days, and had been attended by the ship's physician, but grew steadily worse.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Representative Holman of Indiana died at his home here at 2:05 P.M., after an illness of some weeks. Spinal meningitis was the cause.

Senator MASON'S first appearance in the Senate must be acclaimed as a success. There was something truly comic in his explanation that, as he would presently be subdued to what he worked in, it behooved him to express his opinion about the body to which he belonged before he was disabled from doing so by degeneration to its level.

A vigorous protest against the change of motive power by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company on the Fourth Avenue and Madison Avenue Line without liberal compensation to the city was presented before the State Railroad Commission, in the Chamber of Commerce, yesterday. The railway company proposes to adopt the underground trolley system.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Ambassador Pauncefote has been made the subject of some statements concerning himself that appear to have been without foundation, otherwise than in the minds of those who wrote them. He has been made to appear to be very dictatorial and disagreeable in insisting upon his place in the Grant Monument ceremonies.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 22. -- Opening day here was a success. The weather was delightful, and the attendance numbered 17,074. The players paraded across the field company front, and then raised the new flag, while the band played "The Star-Spangled Banner."

BALTIMORE, April 22. -- Argument was begun this morning in the United States Circuit Court in this city in the suit of the Johns Hopkins University against the receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, in which it is sought to establish that the 6 per cent. dividend on the preferred stock of the company is a prior lien over all other outstanding obligations.
Mr. W.L. Stow of the Stock Exchange said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in talking of the outlook for the stock market:

SAN JOSE, Cal., April 22. -- Frank Evans, a pugilist, died this morning of concussion of the brain, caused by a blow on the chin delivered by "Matt" Semichy in a fight before the San Jose Athletic Club. Semichy is in jail, charged with manslaughter.

Our neighbor, the Staats-Zeitung, speaks its mind with unusual bluntness about local politics. "The Republican Party," it declares, "is the party of bigots and temperance cranks. An independent municipal organization must be open-minded and tolerant; if it is so it can be master of the situation."

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The Republican tariff sub-committee of the Senate Finance Committee is working now with its eyes fixed upon next Tuesday as the day to report the Tariff bill to the full committee, but without feeling at all confident that this result can be accomplished. All will depend upon the interruptions that may take place, the persistence and influence of those who seek changes, and the demands of other Senators.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Another contest over committees came up in the Senate to-day, when Mr. Butler (Pop., N.C.,) called up his resolution directing the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads to inquire and report on the establishment of postal savings banks. Mr. Pettus (Dem., Ala.,) promptly objected, stating that no directions should be given to the Post Office Committee in its present disorganized condition.

We are sorry to say it, but the Mayor has made a wretched appointment to the Police Board in place of Mr. ROOSEVELT. What perverse spirit of the air could have guided his mind in selecting Mr. FRANK MOSS, counsel to the Parkhurst Society, as a fit person to be Police Commissioner?

It is a forlorn hope to appeal to the Governor to check bad legislation, but if ever there can be a case in which he shall see his duty clear to do that, it exists in the so-called Anti-Trust bills, which in effect are and must be anti-business bills.

ATHENS, April 23 -- 1 A.M. -- The Ministers held a prolonged conference at the war offices to-day and then went to the Royal Palace for a council, at which King George presided. It is said that very important decisions were taken.

With the issuing of Gen. Dodge's general order, the last important task connected with the Grant Day parade was finished. Nothing remains to be done now but to modify orders when necessary, and to see that all plans are carefully executed. Upon she aides and commanders the success of the parade has now devolved. Nearly 60,000 men will be in line.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Mabel R. Haines, an actress who was with one of Hoyt's companies, obtained a verdict of $10,000 to-day from a jury in Judge Bunn's Federal Court against Lyman E. Crandall, the owner of the Normandie Hotel, at Michigan Avenue and Twelfth Street.

The most conflicting news comes from the seat of war. Furious fighting continues in the passes leading to the plain of Thessaly, with the success apparently on the side of the Greeks, who still hold Larissa and Tyrnavo, and have driven the Turks back across the frontier in the direction of Elassona, captured Viglia, and forced the Turks behind the ramparts of Damasi during a sortie.

LONDON, April 22. -- The war news received from the special correspondents of the London morning papers for publication to-morrow is meagre and somewhat conflicting. The only certainty seems to be that Tyrnavo has not yet fallen, but Nezeros is in the hands of the Turks. The Chronicle's Athens correspondent says that the Greeks have retreated from Mati.

John E. Parsons, President of the City Club, who has recently spoken before Mayor Strong and Gov. Black in opposition to the Greater New York charter, last night addressed the Union Settlement Workingmen's Club, at 1,894 Third Avenue, on the same subject.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- When the House met at noon to-day, Mr. Dalzell of Pennsylvania presented a special order for the consideration of the Senate amendments to the Indian Appropriation bill. The rule provided that until the final disposition of the four Appropriation bills, it should be in order to consider Senate amendments in committee of the whole without reference of consideration by any committee.

Frank Moss, Director, member of the Executive Committee, and counsel of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, better known, perhaps, as the Parkhurst society, yesterday took the oath of office as Police Commissioner, to succeed Theodore Roosevelt. He was appointed by Mayor Strong just before 3 o'clock.

Once upon a time, and the time was within the current quarter of the current century, a semi-naturalized Briton took a Briton not in the least naturalized to a frontier town. The unnaturalized Briton was a man of large possessions and still larger influence, and was expected to make large investments and to direct still larger investments in the "boom town" in question.

Joseph Jefferson, the actor, was the guest of honor at a reception given by the young ladies of the Association of Collegiate Alumnae, at the school of Mlle. Veltin, 160 West Seventy-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon, and the occasion was marked by an address by the distinguished visitor. The young women, in bright Easter costumes, crowded the schoolroom to the doors.
ALBANY, April 22. -- When the Assembly this afternoon reached a bill introduced by Mr. Murphy of New York, amending the railroad law, Speaker O'Grady announced:
ALBANY, April 22. -- Gov. Black to-day issued the following proclamation relating to Grant's birthday:

STAMFORD, Conn., April 23. -- Samuel Scoville, Jr., a New York lawyer, was shot and wounded at his home, in South Street, this city, this morning by a burglar. Mr. Scoville is well known as an athlete, and live with his father, the Rev. Samuel Scoville. He is a grandson of the late Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, and is the law partner of his cousin, William T. Beecher, at 273 Broadway, New York.
CHICAGO, April 23. -- The Quincy, Omaha and Kansas City Road was sold to-day at foreclosure to a committee representing the bondholders, for $300,000.

A bill was introduced in the Senate at Albany yesterday authorizing Controller FITCH to ascertain what bonds of the various communities consolidated under the Greater New York charter are to fall due Jan. 1, 1898, and to sign warrants for their payment in advance of that date. It is a necessary measure if the charter is to take effect.

Up to a late hour yesterday there was not in New York City a certified copy of the Raines liquor tax law as recently amended. Nor had there been received at the office of George Hilliard, Deputy Commissioner of Excise, blanks for applications for certificates. In the absence of a certified copy of the new law, many of the multitude of inquiries addressed to Mr. Hilliard's assistant yet remain unanswered.

The war of extermination against bucket shops now being conducted in this city received fresh impetus yesterday, when three establishments in New Street were raided by the police and eleven persons connected with them were arrested. The establishments raided were the Standard Company of 53 New Street, the Manhattan Commission Company of 49 New Street, and J. Willard Woodruff Co. of 51 New Street.

-- In Sweden, where the telephone system is owned and operated by the Government, the cost to each subscriber is $10 a year. This includes the installation of the instruments, and there is no extra charge for communication between any cities to which the wires extend. In other countries where the telephone is also under public control, the cost of service is as follows:

LONDON, April 23. -- A dispatch to The Daily News from Larissa, dated Wednesday, says the Greeks are about to assume the offensive against Vigla and Salonica; that the Greeks have occupied Karya, and that the Turks have suffered unexpectedly severe reverses.

Mr. LANHAM of Texas has a good scheme. He proposes "to reduce the expenditures of the Government, to decrease Federal salaries, and to discourage the office-seeking industry," by reducing all salaries one-third.

First editions have been attracting all the auction interest in the book world recently. The two parts of the Bierstadt sales in this city have given both collectors and dealers many surprises in the way of record-breaking prices, and the sale in Boston last week of the fine library of Christian P. Roos of this city has shown that there as well the fever for first editions is leading to greatly advanced prices.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 23. -- Fire started in some unknown manner at Whitney's Point, twenty miles north of this city, about 3:30 o'clock this morning, and destroyed property valued at $250,000. The insurance is estimated at $80,000.

Col. George E. Waring Jr., addressed a meeting last night in the lecture hall of the Marble Collegiate Church, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, on "The Interest Good Citizens Should Have In Clean Streets." The meeting was held under the auspices of the Good Citizenship Committee of the Christian Endeavor Society.
" Let Us Have Peace" will be the subject of Dr. Silverman's Grant memorial sermon at Temple Emanu-El this morning.

The Bible and almanacs, it has been said, formed the chief reading material of our Colonial ancestors, and if with the Bible might be included sermons, religious tracts, and dissertations, the statement contains a large measure of truth. The popularity of the almanac for 150 years was undiminished. Beginning with 1639, the great almanac period continued up to the Revolution.

The International Young Men's Christian Association Committee gives out some interesting figures concerning work during the last two years. Of 1,429 associations in North America, an aggregate membership of nearly 249,000 is reported, more than one-half being active members -- a growth of 2 per cent.

CAPE TOWN, April 23. -- In the Cape Parliament the debate on the so-called "peace motion," adjourned on April 16, was resumed to-day. The motion referred to urged the adoption of a policy of moderation and conciliation in the settlement of differences in the interpretation of treaties and conventions.

Ferdinand Brunetiere, the French critic, delivered the second of his series of lectures on French contemporary literature at the Lenox Lyceum yesterday afternoon, before a large audience. His subject was "History," and as he proceeded with his theme it became evident that what he said came from a feeling of deep conviction.
ALBANY, April 23. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the following new laws:

The funeral of "Billy" Birch was conducted according to the rites of the Benevolent Protective Order of Elks, at the rooms of Lodge No. 1 of the order, at 19 West Twenty-seventh Street, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 23. -- It is now definitely announced that Osman Pasha, the hero of Plevna, has been appointed Commander in Chief of the Turkish Army, with headquarters at Elassona. Edhem Pasha has been recalled.

Police Commissioner Moss yesterday took possession of the offices at Police Headquarters lately vacated by Theodore Roosevelt. The offices are usually assigned to the President of the board, but Mr. Moss will occupy them until the expiration of his term of office, unless the present dead-lock as to the election of a President is sooner broken.

HAVANA, April 23. -- Michael J. Kelley, the Philadelphian who disappeared suddenly from Havana a fortnight ago, who went to the insurgent camp, and was strung up on the charge of being a spy, but finally managed to escape and to reach the Spanish authorities at Punta Brava, was interviewed by the correspondent of The Associated Press on his arrival at the Consulate General here to-day.

Seven days, crowded with interesting religious, historical, and musical features, will constitute the formal and official celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the incorporation of Trinity Church. The exercises will begin on Sunday, May 2 and will continue through the week, ending with the following Sunday.

Macaulay has somewhere noted the fact that no man has ever written well in any language save the one that he learned from his mother's lips. For a writer to weave a romance about other times than his own is almost as difficult. George Eliot said she began "Romola" a young woman and finished it an old one.

The French Minister of Finance has adopted the design of Mr. Roty for the new five-franc piece. In the medallic art as far as coin is presented, there are difficulties which only the expert knows. You may not raise your design, and so be effective, because if you did you could not pile one piece on another.

There is a pleasant and judicious mingling of figure works and landscapes in the East Gallery of the Academy of Design this Spring. Henry Mosler's large and important subject picture "Invoking God's Blessing," William H. Lippincott's "Pleasant Reflections," Louis Moeller's excellent genre, "The Will, which was deservedly awarded one of the Hallgarten prizes, and Harry Roseland's figure work, "Parish Gossip," that excellent study of negro character, are among the most important works in the display.

Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for T. Quincy Brown, for over $91,000, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 18 West Fifty-fourth Street, 25 by 100.5; also for James Stillman, the lot running through from Fifty-fourth to Fifty-fifth Street, 175 feet west of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 200.10. This lot is similar to and adjoins the one recently sold by the same brokers in connection with Charles S. Brown for William Rockefeller to George Sherman.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 23. -- The Assembly passed the Governor's Civil Service bill by a vote of 110 yeas to 29 nays, and it now goes to the Governor.

Not jealous of the loan exhibition in Boston proper, but emulating it, Brookline has now its own exhibit, and The Boston Transcript declares that the 107 works shown there are quite as good as -- even in some ways a trifle better than -- those in Boston. Taking the moderns, there are the works of Diaz, Millet, Couture, Daubigny, Monet, Boudin, Eduard Frere Clays, Chaplin, Dupre.

The American Numismatic and Archaeological Society last evening presented to Gen. Horace Porter the only copy struck in gold of its Grant Monument Memorial Medal. The presentation was made in the lecture room of the Academy of Medicine Building, 17 West Forty-third Street, where the society's collection of war medals was on view during the evening.

Two men were run down by a cable car yesterday afternoon at the curve at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. One, who has not been identified, died soon after his removal to Roosevelt Hospital. The other is James Hughes of 453 Bergen Street, Brooklyn. His skull is fractured, but hopes of his recovery are entertained by the Roosevelt Hospital physicians.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 23. -- The Governor General has received the following from the Colonial Office: "The Government of his Majesty the King of Sweden and Norway purposes sending in the Summer of this current year a balloon expedition toward the north pole for exploration in the interests of science.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The attendance at the Bennings race track was large to-day. The weather was beautiful, the track was fast , and there was a fine card, with good-sized fields, in came out ahead. Summaries:

A pilgrimage to Epworth, the native place of John Wesley, is to be one of the great events of the present year in the Epworth League. The pilgrimage is undertaken with the sanction of the Epworth League officers, its prime motives being to give a wider acquaintance among young people of this birthplace of Methodism. Epworth is in Lincolnshire, England.

The American Authors' Guild is about to move into larger and more comfortable quarters in Carnegie Hall. Possession will be taken next week of the new rooms, which consist of a large main room or hall, where the customary meetings and social gatherings of the guild will be held, and two or three or three smaller rooms to be used for the library and as reading and writing rooms.

In 1895 THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed its obligation to Hamdy Bey, the Director of the Imperial Museum at Constantinople, for catalogues published under his supervision giving full descriptions of Himyarilic and Palmyrian objects. In Mr. Max Muller's letters from Constantinople, (see THE NEW YORK TIMES's Saturday Supplement of Books and Art of last week,) the interesting quality of these catalogues was described.
The Appellate Court of the Second Division has just decided a case which shows very clearly how the sweeping Lexow bills would work if they became law.

Not the least picturesque figure in the Grant Day parade is likely to be that of Chief JOSEPH, the head of the remnant of the Nez Perces. Twenty years ago his name was very familiar throughout the country. He was driven into fighting the Government by what he sincerely regarded as its injustice toward his people.

An amusing story of the Abyssinian taste in art comes from Rome. Before the late conflict between Italy and the African country, a commission was sent to Rome and pictures were ordered for the decoration of the cathedral Adis Abeba, within whose sacred precincts the Emperor Menelik dwells -- that is to say, when he is not fighting.

Greece has ordered Col. Vassos to attack the Turks in Crete. The insurgents have attacked the international troops and Turkish garrison in Fort Izzedin. This, with the threat of Bulgaria to mobilize her troops unless Turkey complies with her demands, adds to the seriousness of the situation in Europe.

Several wasted efforts have been made In these columns to call attention to the neglect of the arragut Statue in Xqadlson Scluaxe. Standing now on the sidewalk, near the Twenty-sixth Street side, you may look right through the stones of the curved base arid catch a view of the opposite side of the square.

The retired statesmen of Europe are making things extremely unpleasant for the active statesmen, "and justly so." The British public has not yet recovered from the pleasure, nor Lord SALISBURY and Mr. BALFOUR from the indignation, with which they respectively viewed the recent manifesto of Mr. GLADSTONE on the European concert.

Two new lives of Gen. Grant are nearly ready for publication. Each belongs to a series of books already well known to the public. For the Heroes of the Nation Series of Messrs. G.P. Putnam's Sons, Col. William C. Church has Written a volume, and Gen. James Grant Wilson has written one for the Great Commanders Series of the Messrs. D. Appleton Co.
LAKEWOOD, April 23. -- The second and third rounds in the tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club for the Laurel-in-the- Pines Cup and the Consolation Cup were played to-day.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 23. -- Demosthenes Parlidis, Greek Consul at San Francisco, passed through Union Station on his way to Washington. Mr. Parlidis said:

In former times in England, when to the review of a book was given the price of it, the journal had to pay a tax, because it was held that the printing of the cost of the book was all advertisement. That is the reason why to-day, so says The Academy, prices of books are not given, though the law taxing advertisements is no longer in existence.

What a fine thing it would be to bring together all the Stuarts in the United States, and to make a grand exhibition of them, with the final purpose of erecting memorial in honor of this great American artist. According to The Boston Evening Transcript, just such a measure has been proposed.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES'S Review of Books and Art of Saturday last were published the names of those who, living in the Province of New York in the Colonial period, took the abjuration oath in the young Pretender's time, swearing allegiance to King George. What is curious is to find out that in England, Jacobitism is not exactly dead.

Greater New York cyclists will pedal to all points of the compass to-morrow if the weather is propitious. Runs have been scheduled to every point of interest, and the prospect for fine roads is very encouraging.

Greater New York will be the greatest Lutheran city in the world. The figures are as follows: New York, churches 34, communicants 15,994. Sunday school members 13,683, value of property $2,040,000: Brooklyn, churches 39, communicants, 16,169, Sunday school members 13,093, value of property $1,705,000; Staten Island, churches 4, communicants 749, Sunday school members 410, value of property $50,000; Long Island, churches 9, communicants 1,361, Sunday school members 1,058, value of property $100,000:

Democrats in this city and visitors from other counties are predicting with much confidence that the Democratic candidate for Judge of the Court of Appeals will be elected this year. A Judge of the Court of Appeals is the only official to be elected on the State ticket, and it is likely that there will be several candidates in the field.

We have it on Republican authority that for the year ending Sept. 30, 1896, it cost the State for the care of the public buildings at Albany $353,204.37, while the annual cost to the United States Government for the maintenance of public buildings at Washington is about $200,000. It is said that $186,912.31 was for services of employes of Superintendent EASTON.

Mr. Nahan Franko, being about to depart for foreign shores to exhibit himself to the admiring multitudes which there await his coming, gave a farewell concert last night in Carnegie Hall. His undertaking was an ambitious one, embracing orchestral numbers and solo performances by himself, Charles Gregorowitsch, the Russian violinist, and Rafael Joseffy, the eminent pianist.

This board is to consist of seven persons, and is to be made up as follows:

Chief Joseph, accompanied by Sub-Chief Olocut, an interpreter, and Major Burke, called on Mayor Strong yesterday afternoon. They were ushered into the reception room, where, after shaking hands, the Mayor invited them to sit down. Several seconds of silence followed, and Mayor Strong asked Chief Joseph how he was.

Secretary of State Sherman, in a letter to Mayor Strong, has squarely contradicted the published rumor as to dissensions in the Diplomatic Corps over the question of precedence in the Grant Day parade. The matter has not been seriously considered at committee headquarters from the first. But the space devoted to it by some newspapers has led to some discussion.

The author of this volume asks: "Has hypnotism any actual standing either in science or common sense? What of clairvoyance, planchette, trance, and trance utterance, crystal gazing, and apparitions?" The hard-headed materialist will say: "We know what the laws of nature are, and alleged occurrences which go beyond or contravene these laws are upon their face illusions and frauds."

ARTA, April 23. -- During the fighting on Tuesday the Turks, at daybreak, attempted to rush the bridge and capture Arta by assault. Turkish artillery as secretly brought up during the night and placed in position on commanding elevations opposite the town. Under cover of a furious cannonade the Turks advanced upon the bridge and they were received with a murderous rifle fire from the Greeks.
LONDON, April 23. -- A dispatch to The Times from Milouna Pass, dated to-day, says:

More than 500 persons will sit down at the dinner to be given by the Reform Club at the Waldorf to-night in honor of Mr. Cleveland. Among these there will be thirty-eight distinguished guests, including the ex-President, ex-Secretary Carlisle, W.L. Wilson, W.D. Bynum, ex-Secretary Herbert, and fifteen members of the National Committee of the National Democratic Party.

It is a curious incident that Mr. Paul Leicester Ford works up in his little story. "The Great K. A. Robbery." There are road agents and road agents, but, whether these bandits are intent on robbing a safe or stealing letters out of a mail car, there is little difference between the two acts.

Whatever may be mysterious about a great show, such as the Barnum Bailey one, is all made clear by Mr. Charles Theodore Murray in his "A Modern Gypsy: A Romance of Circus Life." Then, in addition to the realities of the business, there is introduced a goodly modicum of fiction. Here are your actual "acrobats, clowns, women riders, grooms, trainers, jugglers, canvas men, razorbacks, trainmen, ringmasters, trapezists, musicians."

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- President McKinley has decided to nominate William R. Day of Canton, Ohio, to be First Assistant Secretary of State and ex-Representative Bellamy Storer of Cincinnati, Ohio, to be Minister to Belgium. These nominations were to be sent to the Senate to-day, but owing to that body's adjournment over until Monday will not go until next week.

The will of Andrew Jeffries, Garvey, the Tweed informer, who died in Southampton, England, a few weeks ago, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday for probate. The amount of the estate is not given. Mr. Garvey left no children.

When Major J.R.L. Macdonald was in Bombay in 1891, he was on the point of embarking for England on leave, having seen seven years' service in India. Just before starting for home he received a telegram offering him the post of Chief Engineer of "the proposed railway survey from Mombasa to the Victoria Nyanza." The Major accepted the post, and then went to England in order to understand the details.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 23. -- In the Senate to-day Senator Grady moved to suspend the rules for the immediate consideration of Mr. Tupper's bill to allow the New York and Brooklyn Railroad Tunnel Company to construct its tunnel upon the authority of the Department of Public Works of Brooklyn. This was carried, and the bill was placed on final passage.

A man of one idea in an office that demands a multitude of ideas is out of place. That is the disqualification of Mr. FRANK MOSS, counsel to the Parkhurst Society, in the office of Police Commissioner.

It may be asked, "Why do painters so often make portraits of themselves?" And pray may not an artist do that much? Is he to be deprived of such satisfaction as may arise from looking at himself in a mirror? It is, however, noticeable that the tyro in art, just as soon as he "can catch a likeness," invariably labors over a representation of himself.

Pearson's Magazine has been trying to gauge the number of words that authors can write per diem. We have Trollope's average, which was about 10,000 words a week, and when pushed he could increase that some 150 per cent. Mr. W.L. Alden, the "sixth-column man" of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who is now visiting in England, was good for 4,000 words per day, and when put to it his average was even higher.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 23. -- By a decision in the United States Court of Appeals at New Orleans, Major Hugh Carlisle of Guntersville, Ala., was to-day put into possession of 100,000 acres of the best farm and timber land in Alabama, lying in the Counties of Blount, Cullman, Marshall, Etowah, and De Kalb.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- Philadelphia to-day again defeated New York in a game which had a most exciting finish. The score was 7 to 6 against the Phillies in the last inning. Gettig started the trouble by hitting Nash' with a pitched ball. Geier was then sent in to bat in place of Orth and got a base on balls.

None of the portraits or busts of William Shakespeare gives one a satisfactory idea of the great dramatist and poet, except the recently acquired Davenant bust, now in the library of the Shakespearean Memorial at Strut-ford-on-Avon. It is the most striking thing that meets one's eye in that quiet little room which is filled with pictures, books, and manuscripts, all pertaining in some way to the Bard of Avon.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Final arrangements for the Presidential trip to New York were completed to-day. The Presidential party will go by special train over the Pennsylvania Road, leaving Washington on Monday next at 10:30 A.M. The first car will be occupied by the President and family and Secretary Porter. The private car of President Frank Thomson of the Pennsylvania Company has been made available for the President's use on this occasion.

WEST POINT, April 23. -- The programme for the dedication of Battle Monument on May 31 on Trophy Point was completed to-day. The ceremonies will commence at 11:30 A.M. with prayer by Chaplain Shipman. The monument will then be presented to the army by Gen. John W. Wilson and received by Gen. Nelson A. Miles, who will in turn present it to the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- A resolution was adopted in the House to-day by which a committee of twenty-five, of which the Speaker, by the terms of the resolution, was Chairman, was appointed to attend the dedication of the Grant Tomb in New York on Tuesday.
ALBANY, April 23. -- The annual report of the State Racing Commission was handed to the Legislature to-day. It says:

Some of the answers received by The Boston Journal to its request for comments on the qualities and features of the paper are extremely interesting and varied. They are uniform, for the most part, only in one thing, in warm admiration for cleanliness. This prevails in all classes, and not less among mechanics and tradesmen than among professional men, teachers, and clergymen.

Vice Chancellor Reed of Jersey City was asked yesterday to interpret the will of John Zabriskie, who died at Hackensack, N.J., in 1853 He gave his wife a life interest in the property. In the event of her death or should she remarry the estate was to be divided between the three children. One of the children died two days before her father. She was the wife of Judge Banta.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 24. -- The shooting at the Elkwood Park traps this afternoon consisted of five events. J. Elmer Applegate of Morgan, N.J., who finished second in the grand American handicap, was defeated in a fifty-bird match, $50 aside, by Phil Daly, Jr. Daly killed 47, Applegate 41.
