TRENTON, N.J., April 24. -- The Court of Errors and Appeals in special session today, after a secret conference of about an hour, declined to take up the case which was designed to bring before that tribunal the question of the constitutionality of the Jersey City and Newark anti-Spring election bill.
BAY CITY, Mich., April 24. -- Omer, a small village about twenty miles north of Bay City, was swept by a cyclone this afternoon.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., April 24. -- Joseph E. Kelley, charged with the murder of Cashier Joseph A. Stickney of the Great Falls National Bank of this city, pleaded guilty in the Municipal Court before Judge Knapp this morning.

With Johanna, the chimpanzee, in the van, the circus parade took up its march from Madison Square Garden shortly before midnight last night. The performance closed at 10:05, and at midnight, just 1 hour and 55 minutes later, the last man and the last piece of circus property was out of the Garden, and the Wild Wrest Show was moving in.

The continuance of the "vacant lot scheme," throwing open unoccupied land to the poor of New York City for cultivation, has been assured for this year, and will be extended far beyond what has been attempted in and around New York since the project was introduced into this country. Two organizations are furthering the enterprise, and both have been progressing rapidly until their plans are nearing completion.
Police Commissioners Parker and Grant gave out statements last evening concerning Police Board affairs and their trouble with the Mayor. Mr. Parker made this statement:

Stagnation stupefies Wall Street. No activity appears anywhere. It is fashionable to be blue. Quotations are featureless. Commission houses are without customers. Only the littlest of the professional traders make any show whatever of interest in the security market, and they are about evenly divided between bears utterly despondent and bulls prepared for the millennium.

LONG BRANCH, April 24. -- Many preparations are being made to render the place attractive to Summer guests. Those who summered here last year will long remember the enjoyment that was afforded them at Pleasure Bay, in the way of fireworks, balloon ascensions, and other entertainments, which were witnessed by thousands of people.
Bare Corridors Have No Terrors for His Family, but They Have Lace Curtains and Flowers and Pets in Their Living Rooms.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 24. -- The process of crew making is now under full swing, and graduates begin to flock back daily to assist Coach Courtney. Promptly at 5 o'clock yesterday the two university boats were lowered into the water. A signal to the launch house, and the beautiful new coaching launch Cornell was backing water for her dock to take on the coach and his party.

Who has not heard of the Persian jewels: their glory, their number, their priceless worth? When the doors were unlocked and I was taken into the Peacock Throne-Room, I found myself surrounded by a mass of wealth unequaled in the world. Nowhere are such treasures. But nowhere also, is there such an accumulation of rubbish.

A good-looking man, about twenty-five years old, dressed in the height of fashion, strolled into the Yorkville Court yesterday morning, and, escaping the vigilance of the court officers, managed to present himself before Magistrate Simms without first removing his high hat or throwing away a lighted cigar, which he held between his teeth.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 24. -- The baseball game with the University of North Carolina on Wednesday closed the annual Southern trip of the Princeton team. The members of the team returned to Princeton on Thursday and received an enthusiastic welcome by their college mates.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 24. -- The tax rate for the year is 2 67-100 mills. This includes the following -- each item being expressed in mills:

IN 1880 the Board of Trustees of the Tenth Ward purchased lots in Norfolk Street, near Grand, and on this site was built Grammar School No. 75, which now eaters to the intellectual wants of what is probably the most densely populated section of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Acting Secretary Roosevelt has authorized the commandant of the New York Navy Yard to grant leave of absence, without pay, to all veterans employed in the New York Navy Yard on Tuesday next who may desire to participate in the Grant parade.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 24. -- The marriage of John Van Nostrand Dorr of Deadwood, S.D., to Miss Sally Harmon Doughty of Englewood was solemnized in the Presbyterian Church to-day. The bridgegroom is a nephew of R.E.A. Dorr of The Mail and Express, who, with Mrs. Dorr, and a number of relatives and guests from New York, Orange, Wilmington, and Brooklyn, attended the wedding.

Vernon M. Davis, who resigned his position as an Assistant District Attorney last Monday, was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon at a luncheon given at the Astor House by Judges of the Court of General Sessions, former Assistant District Attorneys, and attaches of that court.

Standard Oil shares took another Jump yesterday, selling during the day at 0.95. No new talk is heard regarding the stock. Rumors of new stock to be issued to present holders and the establishment of a 16 per cent. dividend rate are still current.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 24. -- Much alarm is felt here over the continued absence of William D. Howland, Treasurer of the New Bedford Manufacturing Corporation, Rotch Spinning Company, and the Howland Cotton Mills, which, as announced last night, are in financial difficulties, due principally to the placing of the Bennett and Columbia Corporations in the hands of receivers and the revelation of the true condition of the accounts in the latter two mills.

LONDON, April 24. -- The reception accorded to Col. John Hay, the new United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, has been most cordial on all sides. The newspapers have been most eulogistic, and it is emphatically a case of "Le Roi est Mort. Vive le Roi!" There have been many allusions to Col. Hay's dignified reticence, compared with the volubility of his predecessor, Mr. Thomas F. Bayard.

THE week which has just come to an end was one of the busiest of the entire musical season. That statement has an especial significance because so many persons are of the opinion that there is not any music when the opera, is at an end.

Of my three days in Olympia, I had one morning to myself. No Pindar, no Pausanias, no lecture. The faithful Baedeker was thrust into a side pocket. It was a lovely April day. The sky had the azure hue to which I was born, and the earth was tapestried with wild flowers, blue and yellow and purple.

GLASCOW, April 10. -- Mr. Watson's career as a designer of steam yachts is quite phenomenal. During the last twelve months he has designed over a dozen steam yachts, besides some steamers engaged in commerce. His more recent steam yachts are increasing in tonnage up to 2,000 tons, and Clyde shipbuilders, who at one time were unwilling to meddle with such troublesome vessels as steam yachts, are glad to compete for Mr. Watson's orders.

Reports from brokers and agents for office buildings indicate that there is fair activity in May rentals. Despite the fact that half a dozen skyscrapers have been erected during the last year, almost within a stone's throw of Broad and Wall Streets, there still seems to be a supply of tenants almost, if not quite, equal to the demand.

THERE are fans and fans. The real season for fans, when they are considered merely as an accessory to the toilet, is the Fall and early Winter. That is the time in the year when fans are purchased most largely for the part they are to play in fashionable New York society or society all over the country.

Chauncey M. Depew's birthday was celebrated at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn last night, with Mr. Depew as the guest of honor and the principal speaker of the evening. Covers were laid for 250 members and guests and 229 were present when the President, Charles A. Moore, introduced Mr. Depew.

President McKinley intends to follow the precedent established by former Presidents Harrison and Cleveland in signifying his approval of military drill in the public schools. The First Battalion of the American Guard, from this city, will pay him a visit at the White House Saturday, May 15, march before him in review, and listen to a brief speech of commendation.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Great opposition is manifested all along the Western roads to granting the request of the Nashville Exposition managers for a one-cent-a-mile rate to Nashville from May 1 until the end of the exposition. Not even a round-trip rate of one fare is likely to be made for that event, except for special days when large crowds are expected to go.

In the publication containing the report of the Commissioner of Parks of Brooklyn for the year 1896 much interesting information is given regarding the growth of the park system in Kings County. There are now 32 parks in the care of the Park Department, with more than 25 miles of parkways, covering over 1,500 acres of ground.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 24. -- As previously announced in these dispatches, the Turkish Government, some days ago, called upon Bulgaria, as the vassal of Turkey, to break off diplomatic relations with Greece and to expel the Greek Consuls and Greeks from Bulgarian territory. The Bulgarian Government took the matter into consideration, and, it is now announced, has declined to do so declaring that she will observe neutrality during the war between Turkey and Greece.

In a material sense the carnival at Madrid is the harvest of hundreds of shopkeepers, milliners, flower-sellers, fancy shoe dealers, and cafes, and gives more than a crust of bread to the crowd of the half-starved class of the unemployed as sellers of confetti, paper serpentines, chocolates, and false noses.

FREEPORT, L.I., April 24. -- Miss Mary Isabel Smith, daughter of Mrs. Isabel M. Smith of this village, was married here to-day in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, to William John Curtis, also of this place. The ushers were Edward Mayland and Albert Bedell. George Elcock of Brooklyn, uncle of the bride, gave her away.

LONDON, April 24. -- The forthcoming trial of Dr. John Watson, "Ian Maclaren," on the charge of heresy is attracting great attention. Dr. Watson, who was in London yesterday, said to a representative of The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Republican members of the Finance Committee of the Senate have decided to appeal to their Democratic colleagues on the committee to allow the Tariff bill to be reported to the Senate without passing through the hands of the full committee, or, in default of this, to agree to a report after one formal session.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 24. -- Heavy rains have swollen the Des Moines, Skunk, and Iowa Rivers, whose waters eventually flow into the Mississippi River, and, as a result, at Warsaw, Ill., the outlook is the worst so far this season. Major Meigs of the Government engineers is acting in conjunction with the Commissioners of that drainage district in protecting the levees.

SUPERIOR, Wis., April 17. -- The strange adventure of Paul Parsons while hunting deer in the pine forest near Gordon a few days ago has developed the theory that a portion of one of the best deer sections in Northern Wisconsin is being protected against game-law violators by some mysterious agency other than the Game Warden.

ALBANY, April 24. -- The uniform charter for cities of the second class, including Rochester, Syracuse, Albany, and Troy, was passed by the Assembly this morning. It now goes to the Governer, being a general city law, and therefore not coming within the requirements of Section 2 of Article XII. of the Constitution.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., April 24. -- Dr. John H. Gillett, a physician of Sloatsburg was so badly poisoned by handling wild ivy a few days ago that it was thought he would die from its effects. Last week the doctor decided to add several hundred feet of unreclaimed land to his garden. With spade and rake he started to clear the vines that formed a network over the place.

MONTREAL, April 24. -- The chief feature of the new Canadian tariff, which was brought down in the House of Commons Thursday night by Finance Minister Fielding, is its preferential feature, the decision to reduce immediately the duties upon goods imported from Great Britain by one-eighth, and after July 1, 1898, by one-quarter, of the duties of the new tariff as they apply to less favored countries.

Rudolph Babst, forty-eight years old, a retired Recruiting Sergeant of the United States Army, who lived at 178 Greene Street, Williamsburg, dropped dead while boxing with a young friend in that city last night. His antagonist, Peter Langtry, of 152 Franklin Street, was locked up in the Greenpoint Avenue Station on a charge of homicide.

LONDON, April 24. -- The Associated Press special dispatches from Larissa, dated April 18, April 19, and April 20, delayed in transmission owing to the enormous congestion of the wires with official communications to Athens, received in London up to midnight, confirm the previous advices from Larissa, more complete details of the conflicts being given.

THE family of Raines of Canandaigua must have had a natural liking for politics of the old school. Thomas, or, as he is still spoken of in Albany and in the "Amen corner" of the Fifth Avenue Hotel corridor, "Tom" Raines, was State Treasurer in the early seventies.
ALBANY, April 24. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners held a session to-day for the examination of Assessors from the County of Herkimer.

BERLIN, April 24. -- The indictment of Dr. Peters, the German African Commissioner, whose trial on charges of ill treating African natives has commenced, in private, before the Disciplinary Court for German Protectorates, charges him, firstly, with arbitrarily hanging a negro boy in 1891 and with hanging a girl in 1892; secondly, with unjustly making war upon Chief Malalia in November, 1891, and thirdly, with furnishing incorrect reports to the superior authorities.

It is the last thing in the world one would expect to set a thoughtful man to thinking, but it did. It did more than that; it set him, to use his own words, to "moralizing or philosophizing." And he put his words in print.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Save for the presence of flowers and the absence of the huge files of bills which have almost hidden the Senators from view, the scenes in the Senate Chamber this morning at the closing session were the same as they have been at every session this week.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 24. -- A profound sensation was created to-day by the announcement that Harry W. Cassin, cashier of the Georgia Loan, Savings, and Banking Company, had misappropriated about $45,000 of the funds of that institution. He has always been known as a young man of exemplary habits and fine business Qualifications.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 24. -- Lakewood is once more given over to golf. The three days' Spring tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club was to-night adding another to the successful tournaments held under the auspices of the club. The good weather that marked Easter Sunday continues to the satisfaction of the forty-six players who represent twenty-three clubs, many of them at a distance.

In a recent number of the bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club Prof. Byron D. Halsted points out that the pods of the well-known Chinese wistaria are most effective catapults, expelling their seeds with a pistol-like explosion and scattering them far and wide. Every one knows that our common witch-hazel (Hamamelis virginica) acts similarly.

Tears were as plentiful as cheers among several hundred Greeks who went to the French line pier to see La Champagne start for Havre yesterday morning. The cheers were from 300 or more Greeks who were fortunate enough to get sleeping room before the steamer hauled in her gang-plank and backed into the stream.

A lawyer in high standing, and a thoughtful father, says that whenever he can give a simple explanation he does so; that if he cannot he confesses frankly that the matter is too difficult for him to explain and too hard for the child to understand. If he does not know he admits his ignorance promptly, but adds that he will try to find out.

Those who engage this year in prosecuting a campaign for non-partisanship in the administration of municipal affairs will need to avoid running on a narrow track. They must remember that the main purpose of their contest is good city government -- not political or moral reform, but just plain honesty and efficiency in the management of the public business of the city and the maintenance of law and order for the safety of the community.

LONDON, April 24. -- The comments on the war are becoming more or less heated. Two letters from Mr. Gladstone since Monday have added fuel to the fire. He says that the six powers "with the incomparable mal-adroitness which has distinguished them throughout, have said, in acts, to the Greeks, 'You shan't carry on your work in Crete.

There were a great many men eminent in National, State, and municipal politics at the annual dinner of the Reform Club in the Waldorf last night, but supreme above them all was former President Grover Cleveland. The reception, the dinner, and the speeches that followed were transformed into a personal ovation to him.

MATAWAN, N.J., April 24. -- The Rev. Dr. Thomas Gallaudet of New York City had a narrow escape from death, or at least serious injury, near this place this afternoon. He came here this morning to conduct the funeral service of Mrs. N.M. Totten, who taught the deaf and dumb for years under his direction.

ATHENS, April 24, (6 P.M.) -- All telegraphic communications with Larissa are interrupted, but it is understood that the retreat of the Greek Army was conducted with the best of order. The excitement and disquiet at Athens because of the sudden abandonment of Larissa continues, but the tranquillity of the city is unbroken as yet.

The Accras, who are employed right down the whole West Coast of Africa, thanks to the valuable education given them by the Basel Mission, as cooks, carpenters, and coopers, cannot resist fishing, let their other avocations be what they may. A friend of mine the other day had a new Accra cook. The man cooked well, and my friend vaunted himself, and was content for the first week.

The bells in all the steeples rung almost continuously from Monday morning until Thursday night last, and a small army of brides and bridegrooms have joined the matrimonial procession. Sunshine has fortunately blessed the brides of Eastertide this year, although those of the early days of the week were married during the most unseasonable and untimely of cold waves.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 24. -- Sir Archibald Geike, Director General of the Geological Survey of Great Britain and Ireland, is in Baltimore delivering a course of lectures before the Johns Hopkins University, upon the founders of geology. He spent the first part of the day at Annapolis observing the geological formations of the Severn River.

It is significant that Mr. Cleveland won his unprecedented triumph (his second election) without possessing what are commonly supposed to be the elements of popularity. He did not fascinate people by the charm of extraordinary eloquence. He did not win their friendship by any magic of "personal magnetism."

The absorbing topic among military men at the present time is the parade in connection with the dedication of the tomb of Gen. Grant next Tuesday. Among the military who will participate will be a number of historical organizations, and ,the following are among the most noted: First Company of Governor's Foot Guard of Hartford, Conn., commanded by Major E.H. Hyde, Jr.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 24. -- J.H. Simpson, stroke of the Yale crew during all the preliminary training this year till the present time, and bow last year at Henley, has dropped out of the boat, has stopped training, and left the training table. Mr. Simpson frankly states that his action is taken because of dissatisfaction with the present system.

CARLYLE, after describing the public funeral of MIRABEAU, observes that "in those days of convulsion and dissection not even the dust of the dead could be permitted to rest," and he goes on to tell how soon MIRABEAU'S body was removed in obscurity from the place to which it had been publicly consigned amid the mourning of all France.

Men often wore the himation alone, without chiton. The chlamys, another rectangular garment, shorter than the himation, weighted at the corners, and fastened by a brooch so that one corner hung down in front, was worn by men, with or without the chiton. It is especially well shown in the horsemen on the frieze of the Parthenon.

Bronx Park is the paradise of birds, for here birds, as well as children, enjoy "police protection." In this wild-wood park, the most romantic and picturesque of all our parks, the crows are as tame as pigeons, and the cuckoo, shyest of all known birds, sings its mournful song unmolested.
It was in attempting a definite presentation of his ideal of justice that PLATO, in "The Republic," conceived the ideal State.

The war flurry in the market being over for the time being, it has returned to normal conditions, which are not inspiring. They mean dullness most of the time, with activity confined to a few stocks, and the bear cliques more active and aggressive than any others. Nevertheless, long stock comes out only slowly and in driblets.

WHEN one recalls the vast extent of the literature pertaining to Nelson already before the public, the appearance of Capt. Mahan's two octavo volumes, "The Life of Nelson: the Embodiment of the Sea Power of Great Britain," (Little, Brown Co.,) might lead one to inquire into the need for its appearance; but this inquiry would not result in any conclusion hazardous to the welcome which the book will receive.
NEW YORK. Because the people of that city befriended me in my need," so wrote the dying hero, in discussing the places from which he wished the choice of a burial place to be made.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Spring meeting of the Washington Jockey Club closed to-day. The attendance was larger than on any preced ing day, and a good card pleased the crowd. The meeting has been a fair success. While the cards have not been well filled, the sport has been excellent, the average attendance fair, and there has been an entire absence of unpleasant features.

With a remarkably spirited and entertaining performance of "Much Ado About Nothing" the regular season at Daly's Theatre was closed last evening. Miss Rehan's facile, intelligible, and powerful portrayal of Beatrice was the centre of interest, and Mrs. Gilbert's nimble and sagacious embodiment of Ursula was seen again with pleasure.

Harry Wentworth is a clown at the pig Barnum Bailey show. Which clown he is It would be difficult to tell, for in the course of an evening he is a great many different clowns. But it is always Harry Wentworth who conducts the educated pigs of the show around the ring.

If signs point aright, next Tuesday will be a day unprecedented in the history of this city. Never before were preparations made on such a scale to do honor to the memory of one man. The city streets are gay with the National colors, and decorations may be seen on the smallest buildings as well as on sky scrapers, while in some thoroughfares banners make of them a veritable avenue of patriotic colors.

Larissa has been abandoned by the main Greek army under Crown Prince Constantine, who was defeated by the Turks at Mati, in Thessaly, after a stubborn resistance, the Greeks no doubt having been outnumbered and thoroughly exhausted.

The Balkan States have their own several interests to serve and their own respective prejudices and preferences to consider. But upon one point they are all united, and that is in detestation of the Turk. They are also united in the conviction that Turkey's difficulty is their opportunity.

LONDON, April 24. -- The developments in South Africa are creating much excitement here, especially in the case of the sudden dispatch of the Cape of Good Hope squadron of British warships to Delagoa Bay. It is the general impression that Great Britain is preparing for some important move. According to one statement, the Government learned that several German warships had been ordered to Delagoa Bay, and consequently it was determined to forestall the Germans.

Mickle, gaff in hand, was hopping around behind me, more like a wild Indian with a tomahawk than an experienced Irish water bailiff about to impale a salmon. Sport, too, joined in the infectious excitement and jumped at my feet and barked at every splash that the big fish made. Down along the river bank the cute old bailiff glided, and crept out behind a projecting rock.

LONDON, April 24. -- Albert Chevalier has completed the book and lyrics of his two-act musical comedy, "The Land of Nod." In it Mr. Chevalier will play Prof. Peter Pinder, changing later to a cockney butler, in which character he will sing more of his ditties. The music, which was composed by Alfred H. West, is of a catchy character.

A prominent optician has invented a form of binocular that will enable its user to see the performance on the stage though a lady with a hat a foot high is seated directly in front of him. -- Morning Paper.
ALBANY, April 24. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the following bills:

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The Philadelphias to-day again defeated the New Yorks hands down. Their record was 17 hits, with total of 26. The game was an ordinary one, and, outside of the local club's hitting, the only noteworthy feature was Lajoie's individual batting. He had two singles, a double, and two triple-baggers. Carsey pitched a good game, the visitors' hits being scattered.

No systematic researches had been undertaken by any explorer within New York City prior to the Spring of 1890, when the accidental finding of the fragments of a beautiful jar at Inwood suggested the possibility of other specimens of aboriginal handiwork in that vicinity. The vessel was found in an excavation made near the present Dyckman Street, at its junction with the proposed Sherman Avenue.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 24. -- The Morristown Golf Club opened its fine links for general use to-day. Some changes have been made since last year, and the new greens, will not be used until later in the season. A number of informal matches were played, and in the afternoon the la dies served tea to the members and their friends.

WE who cherish illusions are always to be pitied, because our disenchantments are frequent and bitter. I have clung to many illusions about the drama, and acting as an art, rather than a trade, and the possibilities of the stage.

At an alumni dinner the President of one of our great universities recently said: "We won the baseball championship, the championship in the Olympian games, the football championship, and we celebrated the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of our founding."
Any method which is productive of lasting and beneficial results is a good method. "Reasoning," says Locke, "is the facility of deducing unknown truths from principles already familiar."

One effect of the Constitutional requirement that all bills shall be printed in their final form and laid on the desks of members of the Legislature three days before the vote can be taken on their passage has been to put an end to the old scenes of rushing through a mass of measures at the very end of the session.

ATHENS, April 24. -- The Holy Friday procession here yesterday evening was one of the most dramatic incidents of the war, moving vast crowds of Athenians on an overwhelming wave of emotion. The processions, all carrying lighted candles, converged at about 10 o'clock on Constitution Square. As seen from a balcony above the sea of heads the spectacle was fairylike.
Forty out of every hundred people who die of disease lose their lives by some form of throat or lung complaint.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Grant Monument dedication ceremonies in New York promise to turn Washington into a rather dull town for a week. Up to the last day or two the interest manifested here was divided by the accounts of the Turco-Grecian war and the inscrutable business of the Finance Committee with the Tariff bill.

Though the total population of the world is now put down as 1,500 millions, we have to bear in mind that it is to some extent founded on rough estimates. Some would doubt whether the number of heathen is really so large as it is sometimes thought to be, or that the pagan population increases at the rate supposed to be the case.

SAYVILLE, L.I., April 24. -- During the closed season deer are said to have increased in large numbers in the woods in this vicinity. The deer are reported to have become very bold. Fields of wheat and rye, belonging to Joseph Sebek and Louis Hurbal, near Bohemia, have been destroyed by the deer.

There is great activity at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union at 39 East Twenty-third Street. The Committee of Enrollment and District Organization is making rapid progress in its work, and the enrollment is assuming gratifying proportions, though the present early work is of a voluntary character.

NEWTOWN, L.I., April 24. -- Frederick Cromberger, aged fourteen years, a scholar in the East Williamsburg public school, is laid-up at the residence of his aunt, on Columbia Avenue, Maspeth, suffering from injuries which he says were inflicted on him by his teacher, Miss Schroeder, of the East Williamsburg public school.

LONDON, April 10. -- To write about the remarkable London cockney dialect is to open up a train of subjects that hardly has a beginning and certainly has no ending. The cockney naturally suggests Bow bells, within whose sound every cockney is supposed to have been born; and the Church of Saint-Mary-le-Bow leads easily on to the other, old churches of London.

The defeat of the Good Roads bill in the Legislature at Albany last week by the small margin of three votes was a big disappointment to the cyclists. The bill was instigated by Chief Consul Porter of the New York Division of the League of American Wheelmen, and had the support of every one of the 20,000 members in the State.
ATHENS, April 24. -- A dispatch received from the Greek commander in Epirus, Col. Manes, announces that the Greeks have occupied Kumusades, near Strevina.

A little king and a tiny queen, the royal family of fairyland, sat in state in their chairs of royal purple in the smaller Waldorf ballroom yesterday afternoon and demeaned themselves majestically while their fairy subjects entertained them with dancing and singing.

The Lawyers' Club gave its annual reception yesterday afternoon from 2 to 5 o'clock, in its handsome quarters in the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, when luncheon and punch were served in the club's new dining room, at the Pine and Nassau Street corner of the building. All of the clubrooms were tastefully decorated with flowers.

ALBANY, April 24. -- When the Assembly was called to order at 9:30 o'clock this morning but few members were in the chamber, and less than a hundred visitors were present. The chamber, however, filled up rapidly during the morning, while the House rushed through the long calendar before it.

The trainers at the Morris Park, Sheepshead Bay, and Gravesend race tracks were kept busy yesterday giving final preparations to those of their strings which will be shipped to Aqueduct to-morrow and exercising those who will not be set to racing until the Morris Park or Gravesend meetings open.

Riding back we met the holy Mahant or Abbot of the shrine of the Marble Rocks, a fair boy of fourteen, the disciple nominated his successor by the lately deceased priest. He wore a purple velvet coat, and a white silk cap, both profusely embroidered with gold, and took little interest in the people on the relief works.

ANNAPOLIS, April 24. -- A score of years ago the first intimation the naval cadets had that the annual examination was approaching was the appearance on the sward of the academy grounds of Old Whitey, the old gray horse that for three decades had been in the service of the institution, driven by George Washington Brown, his colored groom.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24. -- The great intercollegiate and interscholastic relay races, which the college world has been anticipating for so long, were run at Franklin Field to-day under the auspices of the University of Pennsylvania. The track was four laps to the mile. While but one record was broken, the intercollegiate on-mile walk, the events were most successful both in attendance and good, heavy work on the part of the contestants.

Considerably over a tenth of all the stock market trading last week was in Sugar Trust shares, no other stock except St. Paul reaching the 100,000 share mark which it passed. Wall Street is filled with conflicting rumors of what is going on in Sugar Trust affairs. Some reports are full of rosy suggestions, and others suggest dreadful things about to be disclosed.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Senate Committee on Civil Service, of which Senator Pritchard of North Carolina is Chairman, began its investigation of the civil service to-day.
Easter, according to the calendar of the Greek Orthodox Church, was celebrated yesterday, and the day was ushered in with special impressive Easter services that began before midnight on Saturday.
The third annual Spring century run of the Century Wheelmen, made yesterday to Patchogue, L.I., and return, was the largest and most successful ever made out of New York.
LONDON, April 25. -- The Daily Chronicle's Athens correspondent will say to-morrow:

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Mr. Maurice L. Muhleman, Deputy Assistant United States Treasurer, recently published a paper on "The Source of Our Financial Discontent," in which he stated that "the unequal distribution of capital and of money, and the consequent gross inequality in interest rates, is the chief cause of the inability to carry on the important business of agriculture profitably."

A beautiful ceremony, which it is hoped may become an annual custom, was performed in Trinity Church by the New York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, yesterday. Memorial services were held in the church in honor of the men who died during the Revolution, and around and about the dusty and crumbling monuments of such heroes as lie in the old church yard were placed clusters of lilies and garlands of ferns.

We observe that the State Commissioner of Excise takes the ground substantially that it is the business of his department, that is, of himself, his deputies, and his special agents, to attend to the enforcement of the liquor tax law only in its relation to the collection of the taxes.

The adverse decision of the Court of Appeals in the suit of Simeon B. Chittenden and others, taxpayers, against F.W. Wurster, Mayor, the fiscal officers and eleven appointees in the various departments of the Brooklyn City Government is far reaching. Counsel for the plaintiffs purpose attempting to accomplish their object of enforcing civil service reform by suing in different form.

Equally discreditable, though perhaps not so important, is the sending of the younger SEWALL to Hawaii. Whatever trouble it is possible to have with Hawaii must come from the selfish schemes of American residents there in the direction of annexation. The American people have no desire for the annexation of the islands.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Dr. F.W. Gunsaulus will leave Plymouth Church. He wants his labors lightened, and his retirement from the Michigan Avenue pulpit is in pursuance of his desire. He wired from New York that he was not a candidate for Broadway Tabernacle. "Whatever haphazard opinions may be," said P.D. Armour this evening, "it is certain that Dr. Gunsaulus will not leave Chicago.

Chancellor of the Belgian Consulate Roemaet was at the French Line pier when the steamship La Gascogne, from Havre, arrived yesterday, to welcome five representatives of the Belgian Government. who are going, by way of Chicago and Vancouver, to China and Japan. It was said that they were sent on a commercial mission.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The belief that William R. Day soon would be the Secretary of State was formed by many persons here Friday when the announcement was made at the White House, in advance of the nomination to the Senate, that Judge Day was to be made Assistant Secretary of State.

John T. Clokey, forty-three years old, a real estate broker of 160 Broadway, and who lived with his wife and daughter at 726 East One Hundred and Fortieth Street, died suddenly of apoplexy yesterday morning at the Alexander Avenue Police Station.

In honor of the approaching Grant Memorial exercises, Prof. Felix Adler's discourse before the Society for Ethical Culture, yesterday, in Carnegie Hall, was on "The Debt of the American People to Ulysses S. Grant." He briefly reviewed the history of the illustrious soldier's early life, and then spoke of the National importance of the honors that will be done to-morrow to the memory of a man who ranks among the first characters in American history.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- There is in process of formation here a syndicate which expects to control the patent and enameled leather business of the country. This city manufactures practically all of these kinds of leather made in the United States. Outside of Newark there are three concerns in the business.

Dwight L. Moody returned to Carnegie Hall yesterday after his trip to the West, and he preached in the afternoon and again at night to audiences that filled the hall. His subject on both occasions was "The Prophet Daniel." Mr. Sankey was there also, and his singing of "Eye Hath Not Seen" and "Dare to be a Daniel" showed that his vacation in the South had enriched and strengthened his voice.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Love, not locks, has made Charles Warren Spalding, disgraced banker and defaulting Treasurer of public moneys, a prisoner in the county jail. He would have kept out of the jail if he had renounced Sarah Louise Ervin. He refused liberty at that price.

I notice in THE TIMES of April 16 an article concerning what is there termed the economic experiment of Mr. Ross Winans of Baltimore, who erected 104 model tenement houses twenty-six years ago, which are now given up as a failure.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The promised statement from the Department of State touching the report on the French wine trade by United States Consul Chancellor at Havre will appear in the May number of the United States Consular Reports.
It is in a theatre of old wars and amid scenes made familiar to all the world through classic story that the Turk and the Greek are contending.

BOSTON, April 25. -- The military exodus for New York set in fairly with the pulling out of the 3 o'clock afternoon train from Park Square Station. There were four drawing room and four day coaches, all of them well filled.

Charles Baldwin Fosdick, President of the Second National Bank, and one of the wealthiest and best-known leather merchants in the city, is lying at the point of death at his home, 31 West Thirty-sixth Street. He is suffering from a complication of diseases -- kidney trouble and heart failure. He is seventy-three years old and has been in failing health since the death of his only son about two years ago.

Central Office detectives arrested Edward S. Farrow, forty-two years old, formerly a Lieutenant in the United States Army, at the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon on the charge of conspiracy to defraud the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association. Mr. Farrow gave out a statement for publication, in which he makes direct and detailed charges against the management of the association, and especially against F.A. Burnham, the President.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 25. -- This has been a rainy and threatening Sabbath in the lower Delta country, and the Louisiana levees are being taxed to their utmost. At Natchez, the river gauge shows a rise during the last twenty-four hours of one-tenth of a foot. Showers have prevailed in this section all day, and to-night a steady downpour is reported.

While several of the larger posts in the Diplomatic Service have been filled by Mr. MCKINLEY with care and sound judgment, he has made some appointments which it is mere charity to call mistakes. Of these the most conspicuous and unfortunate is that of POWELL CLAYTON as Minister to Mexico.

The tariff bill will probably reach the full Finance Committee of the Senate this week. Nominally it has been before that committee nearly four weeks. In reality it has been wholly in the hands of a few of the Republican members. The Democratic members have not known anything that has been done or proposed except so far as the individual Republicans have chosen unofficially to consult them.
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 25. -- The triumphant success of the Turkish arms has caused the liveliest satisfaction here. The following telegram from Edhem Pasha is posted everywhere:

The Harlem River was alive with racing and pleasure craft all day yesterday. The majority of the crews that are in training for the Harlem regatta took advantage of the fine weather and took spins over the mile course, both morning and afternoon.

MONTREAL, April 25. -- Senators T.E. Ellsworth, L.H. Humphrey, F.W. Higgins, and N.M. Stranahan; Joseph Mullin, Bank Superintendent F. Kilburn, and Assemblyman C.G. Austin of New York have arrived in the city from Albany. The party is en route for Ottawa, to accompany the Governor General to New York to the dedication of Gen. Grant's tomb.
LONDON, April 25. -- The Athens correspondent of The Daily Telegraph will say to-morrow:

-- If The Hartford Courant is to be trusted, women, as a class, are less courteous when riding about in street cars than are men as a class. Indeed, The Courant doesn't say "less courteous," but "more boorish," which is a very harsh and dreadful phrase, and one which nobody out of Connecticut would dare to use.

Antonio Maximo Mora, a native of Cuba, but a citizen of the United States, whose claims of indemnity for loss during the former Cuban rebellion were the subject of national contention between Spain and this country, and in settlement of which nearly $1,000,000 was paid in 1895, died at his apartments, in the Hotel Grenoble, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 25. -- The United States cruiser Brooklyn, as sound as before she struck on schooner Ledge, will lift her anchor from the Delaware River to-morrow morning and pass down to the sea. She will undergo her final trial trip under the supervision of the Naval Board of Inspection, after which she will be assigned to her station.
WASHINGTON, D.C., April 25. -- Chief Willis L. Moore of the Weather Bureau, has issued the following special weather forecast for Grant Day in New York:

Hosts of visitors from out of town swelled the usual Sunday throng on Riverside Drive yesterday, until the broad avenue and all its tributary streets were literally blocked. It is certainly a conservative estimate to say that more than a quarter of a million sight seers made their way to Grant's tomb during the afternoon, awheel and afoot.

ATHENS, April 25. -- It is useless to deny that a very gloomy view of the war prospects is taken here by the better informed. There are, however, no signs of panic. The city exhibits an attitude of dignified endurance, while many still show an unabated enthusiasm for fight. This symptom is particularly noticeable among the wounded now in Athens.

A mournful laxity marked the enforcement of the liquor law in the so-called "Raines hotels" throughout the city yesterday. While the new amendments virtually abolishing these institutions have been signed by Gov. Black and are now law, the interpretation of the enactments will require time.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 25. -- A series of games between the classes of Vassar for the college championship was commenced yesterday. The class of 1900 defeated Class '98 by a score of 3 to 2, and '97 defeated '98 by a score of 3 to 1. The games were spirited. They will be continued for several weeks.

M. Ardigo, thirty-nine years old and living at 108 West Twenty-ninth Street, either jumped or fell yesterday afternoon from a window on the eighth floor of Carnegie Hall, to the roof of Frank Briggs's stable, which adjoins Carnegie Hall, and was instantly killed. The affair happened while 8,000 persons were in the hall attending the Moody meeting.
LONDON, April 25. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times will say to-morrow:

All informal conference of National Democrats was held at the Reform Club, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon. It was arranged for at the dinner of the Reform Club the evening before, when some of the New York men, after brief consultation, passed the word quietly around the tables among members of the National Committee of the party and a few of the guests.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 25. -- More interest than ever was manifested in the Legislature by the public yesterday in consequence of the possibility of a Senator being elected. The temper of the Legislature was tested by ballot, showing 66 for Deboe out of 69 present, exclusive of the gold and silver Democrats, none of whom arrived at roll call.
LONDON, April 25. -- What seems likely to be the last week of the war is entered upon to-day. It is difficult from the tangle of conflicting telegrams to understand the exact position of affairs.

Consecration ceremonies of the English Evangelical Church of the Redeemer, in Cumberland Street, near Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, were begun yesterday afternoon. The services were opened with a musical programme, rendered by a choir of forty voices, under the direction of Walter Haas, the organist and choirmaster.
CORNING, N.Y., April 26. -- The trial of Floyd Meyers for murder opened in the Trial Term of the Supreme Court before Nash of Avon this afternoon. The prosecution's story is as follows:

The people of this city should understand just what enrollment in the Citizens' Union means and how important it is that it should be as large as possible. It should be understood that it involves no pledge to support any ticket, though of course it implies an intention to vote for the candidates of the Union if they shall prove satisfactory to the voter.

The language used by Mr. Cleveland and his Democratic friends respecting the Republican Party could only be excused if there had been held out to him or to them distinct assurances that the Republican Party, if successful, would dishonorably abandon the principles and pledges which had caused the nomination of President McKinley and which brought him a great share of his support.
Hoffmann Brothers and Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for L.J. Seaman the five-story brick building, 313 Washington Street, 24.9 feet front, leased at an annual rental of $3,400.

Theodore A. Havemeyer, Vice President of the American Sugar Refineries Company, died from a complication of stomach troubles at his home, 244 Madison Avenue, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. The last illness of the deceased capitalist was of only about two weeks' duration, and on last Sunday his attending physicians informed him, in reply to a question, that his end was very near.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 26. -- There was a riot to-day on Long Branch Avenue, where the elevation of the railroad tracks is being altered to allow the Atlantic Coast Electric Railroad to pass under it. This morning when the men reported for work ninety were laid off. Among those laid off were fourteen Italians living at Long Branch.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- Since the dissension in the Yale crew was brought to a head last Saturday by the refusal of J.H. Simpson, stroke, to continue training until, as he alleges, Coach Robert J. Cook settled down to a definite system of stroke and training, scores of letters and telegrams have poured in upon Captain Bailey and Manager Wheelwright of the Yale Navy.
The Southern troops in the parade to-day come from Virginia, Maryland, and the District of Columbia.

The dead-lock in the Police Board on the election of a President was not broken at the meeting held yesterday. Commissioners Andrews and Moss voted together on every proposition in that regard against Commissioners Parker and Grant. The matter was brought up as soon as the four Commissioners had taken their seats.

The suggestion that the Powers should intervene to put a stop to the war, now that it is plain that Greece is beaten, is natural, proper, and humane. But it does not follow that it will be adopted. In fact the course of the Powers before the beginning of the war, and equally since, has been evidently unnatural, improper, and inhumane.

The Greeks are not giving up in the war with Turkey, and the indications are that more energy will be put into their operations. They are massing their forces at Pharsalos, on the southeastern side of the plain of Thessaly. There a stout resistance will be maintained, if the present intentions are carried out.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Democratic members of the Finance Committee will not accept the proposition made by their Republican colleagues to allow the Tariff bill to be reported direct to the Stnate without passing through the hands of the full committee, and have so notified the Republican members.

Mayor Strong had a large number of grand stand tickets to distribute yesterday. He probably will never want to distribute tickets again during his official career. His office was not wrecked yesterday. It is still intact, but there is good police protection in the City Hall.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 26. -- A few days ago Postmaster General Gary announced to a delegation of colored citizens in Georgia, who visited him at Washington, that it was the intention of President McKinley to appoint to the office of Postmaster of Augusta the leading Republican candidate, whose name is Henry Lyons, and who is one of the most prominent negro leaders of Georgia.

Spring housecleaning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was completed Saturday. Yesterday there was a reception for invited guests, and to-day its doors will be thrown open to the public for the first time in two weeks.

We observe that some of our esteemed free-silver contemporaries are a good deal disturbed by the fact that the dinner of the Reform Club on Saturday evening cost $12 a plate. It is perhaps natural that the journals which are opposed to the politics that were talked after dinner should endeavor to divert public attention from the post-prandial to the prandial part of the occasion.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- In the case of the Long Island Water Supply Company versus the City of Brooklyn, Justice Brewer handed down the decision of the court, sustaining the city's contention. The case involved the city's right to abrogate a contract to supply water to a portion of the city.
The twenty-round fight between George Dixon and Johnny Griffin, at the Broadway Athletic Club last night, was one of the fiercest contests ever seen at that club.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
CUMBERLAND FALLS, Ky., April 26. -News was brought here from Parks Mills, ten miles distant, in the mountains, of the drowning of four young people, who were out in a skiff.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The State Department has been informed that the Government of Roumania has prohibited the entry of Jews into that country.
Even Mr. BRYAN feels called upon to defend the Republican Party against the charge that by its tariff policy it has broken faith with the sound-money Democrats who elected its President.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- The bulls had the worst of it in the wheat market to-day. The market started at a decline of nearly 3 cents. and still the bottom had not been reached. Corn and oats were also radically weak, closing at declines of 7/8c and 3/4c respectively. Provisions declined 2 1/2 7 1/2c.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 26. -- Sir Richard Cartwright, who had more to do with the framing of the new Canadian tariff than the Minister of Finance had, replied to the criticism of Mr. Foster, the opposition financial critic in the House of Commons, this afternoon.
LONDON, April 26. -- The correspondent of The Times at Larissa, telegraphing from that point Sunday evening, says:

The violent ringing of the alarm bell in Louisville arouses a lethargic people, too late, probably, to a full sense of their danger. WATTERSON is at the rope, and the belfry rocks with the vehemence of his exertions. But it is easy to see that he despairs of the Republic. "Mr. CLEVELAND can never again be President of the United States," he rages.

LONDON, April 26. -- The Proia, in a special edition at Athens this evening, announces that Gen. Smolenski has been appointed Chief of Staff of the army in Thessaly, with power to choose the members of his staff. It is reported here that Trikkala has been evacuated and that the Turks are constructing temporary forts at Larissa.

Muller, Schall Co. will to-day ship on the steamship Trave the 200,000, or about $977,000, in gold bars which they obtained from the Assay Office yesterday. Kidder, Peabody Co. of Boston will on Thursday ship by the steamship Normannia 100,000, or about $488,500 in gold bars. In each case the gold will be shipped on the basis of $4.88 1/8 for demand bills of sterling exchange.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 26. -- The mills of the three Howland corporations are running to-day as if nothing had happened, and, as far as is now known, will continue to run until a greater necessity develops for stopping them.

The Tammany leaders are reported to be already parceling out territorially the candidates for office in the Greater New York on the assumption that the election will be held this year under the new charter. They are said to be claiming the Mayor and Controller for the Borough of Manhattan.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE GREEK ARMY, LARISSA, April 23 -- Night -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- The development of the Greek position in front of Tyrnavo continues. Col. Audononitz, with a brigade of the Second Division, arrived from the West yesterday evening and took up a position south of Deliler, with the right wing, which is now 8,000 strong and commanded by Gen. Mavromichaelis.

Sixteen young men disobeyed the speed ordinance on the Coney Island cycle path in Brooklyn on Sunday, to the danger of life and limb of hundreds of others. There were more violators, but the number referred to were caught, and in Justice Steers's court yesterday were lectured and fined $5 each.

This splendid city never appeared in finer array to the eye of the sight-seer than yesterday. The tens of thousands of citizens and soldiers who have come here from the four quarters of the Nation to see what manner of monument shall mark the final resting spot of their beloved hero, found New York in the flower of its glory.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- A carefully planned expedition left for Cuba last night from near Sea Isle City, N.J. The supply of arms and ammunition left New York on Saturday on lighters, and was placed on a tug between Barnegat and Long Branch. The tug came steadily down the coast, and was soon joined by another boat.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 26. -- The United States cruiser Brooklyn sailed from League Island Navy Yard at 6:30 o'clock this morning for her forty-eight-hour sea trial.

The British purchase of Delagoa Bay is evidently an effective means of putting pressure upon the Boers, according to the immoral programme, to which there seems to be no longer any substantial objection in Great Britain. It is to be deplored upon that account, but apart from that it is a natural and commendable stroke of policy.

John De Lucca, aged thirteen, is an orphan who resides with his aunt at 61 Fourth Street, Long Island City. He was recently released from the House of Refuge through the efforts of Principal Quigley of the First Ward Grammar School, where the boy is one of the pupils under Teacher Miss Sarah E. Crawson.

LONDON, April 26. -- The House of Commons reassembled to-day, after the Easter recess. The Liberal leader, Sir William Vernon Harcourt, asked the Government leader, Mr. A.J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, whether the Government would make a statement in relation to the Greco-Turk war and the policy of the Government relations thereto, and whether a British force was still engaged in the blockade of the Island of Crete.

NEWPORT, Ky., April 26. -- The sport at Newport to-day was marred by a number of serious accidents. The fifth event, a hurdle race, resulted in the death of imp. Sauteur, and Jockey Kidd was taken to the hospital in a critical condition. In the opening race Jockey Dickerson was thrown from invitation and rendered unconscious. He is not thought to be badly hurt.

A rumor was current last night to the effect that a Mrs. Dennison of 230 West Twenty-first Street had been robbed of jewelry to the amount of about $2,000. It is said that the pawnbrokers had been notified to be on the watch for the stolen property.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day decided a case involving a claim for damages for killing a dog, which had made its way from the lower courts of New Orleans through the various phases of litigation, to be finally decided here in opposition to the claim.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Though hampered by the failure of Congress to make any appropriation for the expense of the International Postal Congress, the Post Office Department is exerting every effort to provide for a proper entertainment of the distinguished guests who will come here as delegates from between sixty and sixty-five of the principal countries and provinces of the world.

The reading of H.C. Bunner's "Grant -- the Hero," the leading feature of a programme by Miss Amy Baker and others, attracted many society people to Sherry's yesterday afternoon. The tribute to the dead leader was received in almost a profound silence. Miss Baker also read other selections in a lighter vein. There were also musical selections by Emilio de Gogorza, Mile. Alice Verlet, and Orton Bradley.

Present problems? Goodness gracious! there is nothing contemporaneous about these old, once-familiar phrasings of self-consciousness and pessimism, this laborious perversion of the English language, this elephantine effort to be impressive without distinct ideas.

The New York baseball team played the first championship game of the season on the home grounds yesterday with Washington. Before 2 o'clock the crowds began pouring into the grounds, and when the game began at 4 o'clock, fully 12,500 persons were in the grounds. Ladies and visiting militiamen were scattered throughout the grand stand, adding to the brightness of the scene.

LONDON, April 26. -- The most serious feature in the Graeco-Turkish emergency is the revolutionary feeling displayed at Athens. Ex-Minister Ralli, leader of the principal Opposition group in the legislative assembly, threatened that unless the military staff was changed he would issue a proclamation to the people.

LONDON, April 26. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press in Athens has just received from a colleague who is with the Turkish Army near Tyrnavo the substance of an interview which the latter had with Edhem Pasha, in confirmation of the disorderly retreat of the Greeks, as follows:

NEW ROCHELLE, April 26. -- Richard S. Emmet of the law firm of Emmet Robinson of Wall Street is dangerously ill at his home, on Pelham road, of pneumonia. He is almost seventy-eight years of age. He caught cold several days ago, and on Saturday it developed into pneumonia. Dr. Neilson was summoned, but as Mr. Emmet grew worse he summoned Dr. Janeway from New York.

In some parts his speech approached the commonplace level, in others it was strongly partisan, but in no respect does it show depth or breadth of thought, nor is it calculated to inspire to activity; it is not clear enough in the advocacy of a defined policy to lead to intelligent action in the direction of organized effort.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee to-day followed up their refusal of yesterday to allow the Tariff bill to be reported directly to the Senate with the announcement that they would expect to have an opportunity for a thorough examination of all the schedules of the bill as amended before it is reported to the Senate.
LONDON, April 28. -- All the morning papers contain long telegrams with elaborate descriptions of the ceremonies yesterday at the Grant Monument in New York, and editorials based upon them.

LONDON, April 27. -- Popular feeling in Athens points to a revolution in favor of a republic. The citizens are greatly excited at the revelations made by former Minister Ralli as to the conduct of the campaign. To-day large meetings have been held in Constitution Square and other places of public resort, and fiery harangues have been delivered by well-known orators in denunciation of "those who would betray Greece."

LONDON, April 27. -- Sir William Vernon Harcourt, leader of the Liberal Party in the House of Commons, addressed a large and important meeting of Welsh Liberal electors this evening at Abertillery. Discussing Cretan affairs, he declared that Great Britain had never before occupied a position of which she had so much reason to be ashamed.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 27. -- All the financial institutions with which Harry A. Cassin, the defaulting cashier of the Georgia Loan, Savings, and Banking Company was connected seem to have been marked out by fate. The management of both the banking company and the United States Bond Company are closely related to the Washington Loan and Investment Company, and to-day a receiver was granted for that corporation.

On the statute books of this State there is a law authorizing the establishment and operation of "traveling libraries." This law was passed at the suggestion of public-spirited citizens for the purpose of enabling the residents of remote and secluded communities to enjoy opportunities of obtaining fresh reading matter at stated periods.

Lowering clouds and a cold blast from out the northwest were not conducive to an entirely satisfactory marine demonstration. When the war vessels at anchor off Riverside Park dressed ship at sunrise yesterday, in accordance with the programme, no sunburst gave the signal. Not an edging of silver was there to the banked-up masses of clouds, not a rift for a glimpse of blue, not a tinge of fair promise in the elements.

The Athenian populace, led by M. Ralli, chief of the Opposition in the Boule, is turning its resentment for the abandonment of the frontier line of defense at Larissa against King George and his Ministers, headed by Premier Delyannis.

Henry T. Munson, a member of the firm of Philipp, Munson Phelps, patent attorneys at 7 Beekman Street, lies critically ill at his home, 37 West Twenty-first Street, and his death is expected at any moment.
The city formally took into its keeping yesterday the memorial tomb and monument of Gen. Grant, erected at Claremont in Riverside Park by the subscriptions of ninety thousand persons.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 27. -- The close of the defense in the court-martial of Capt. Henry Romeyn of the Fifth Infantry, at Fort McPherson, to-day, was marked by a long, straightforward, and dignified statement from the accused, made under oath, reasserting the position he had taken in the beginning and recounting again in plain terms the allegations he had made derogatory to the character of the wife of Lieut. O'Brien.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 27. -- Train wreckers last night threw the switch at Fairbanks, on the Houston and Texas Central Railroad, twenty miles north of here, and the south-bound passenger train ran into it, causing a smash-up of the forward coaches and the derailment of the others.

The official ceremonies at the tomb were simple enough to have satisfied Jefferson or Lincoln. They were almost austere, and were such as Gen. Grant himself might have chosen as befitting the simplicity and directness of his own life.

LONDON, April 27. -- The newspapers are paying much attention to the Canadian tariff debate. They indorse the proposals of the Premier, Mr. Wilfred Laurier, and denounce those of the Opposition, especially Sir Charles Tripper's. The St. James's Gazette says:

As we have before suggested, we are at a disadvantage in the organization of great public pageants with countries which maintain large standing armies. That is a disadvantage with which we can afford to put up very cheerfully, and which the people, if not the rulers of the countries concerned, would be very glad to partake. But as a matter of fact, it is for this specific purpose a disadvantage.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Additional applications for appointments to Presidential offices under the Treasury Department have been filed as follows: E.K. Hart of Philadelphia, Assistant Secretary; H. De B. Clay, Collector of Customs at Newport News, Va.; J.S. Shaw of Montgomery. Ala., Commissioner General of Immigration; L. Freund, Commissioner of Immigration at New York.

Nearly 1,000 invited guests and members attended the reception given last night by the Union League Club to the President and Vice President of the United States, the members of the Cabinet, and the Diplomatic Corps at its clubhouse, on the corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. The galaxy of light and color presented on this occasion was unprecedented in the long array of the club's brilliant events.

LONDON, April 27. -- According to a special dispatch received here this afternoon from Constantinople the Turkish fleet has started for Salonica, where a naval battle between the Greeks and Turks is imminent.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 27. -- Fire which started in the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad Company's pier No. 5 at an early hour this morning caused a loss of $2,000,000 and injuries to eight persons, one of whom is so badly hurt that he may die.
LONDON, April 27. -- The correspondent of The Times at Volo will say to-morrow:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 27. -- It can now be asserted on the highest authority that the Yale Navy management will not accept the offer of the English coach to take charge of the Yale 'Varsity crew for the rest of this season. The offer was never seriously considered by the Yale management, and a discouraging answer was immediately returned to the coach who proffered his services.
CHADRON, Neb., April 27. -- A riot occurred at Crawford in which Arthur Morrison, once City Marshal was beaten almost to death and several others seriously injured.

It is the rule, for instance, in the parks of this city and Brooklyn and on the streets most convenient for cycling that the maximum speed shall be eight miles an hour.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 27. -- The flood situation to-night throughout the neighboring Mississippi and Missouri River territory is one of gravest danger. At several points the swollen streams have overlapped their banks and burst through the levees. Already several lives have been lost, and many people are imperiled by the rapidly rising waters.

HAMPTON, Va., April 26. -- Hampton Institute celebrated last week its twenty-ninth anniversary. The occasion takes place a month earlier than usual this year. Heretofore the anniversary and commencement have occurred together, in the third week of May. Now the two events are separate, and commencement this year will take place June 10.
