Before the departure of the Grant family, from the Fifth Avenue Hotel, to take their place at the reviewing stand, and after the official breakfast served to the guests Mrs. Grant held an informal reception. Colonel Grant was at first fearful that his mother would be unequal to the strain, but so many old friends claimed the privilege of seeing her, and as she appeared willing to gratify them he yielded his judgment to hers.

MONTREAL, Quebec, April 27. -- Considerable doubt is being expressed as to the success of the effort of the new Liberal Government to establish preferential trade with Great Britain. The latter country now has "most favored nation" treaties with Germany, Belgium, and other countries, which expressly provide that in none of the colonies of Great Britain shall the produce of these countries be subject to higher import duties than the produce of the United Kingdom.
NORFOLK, Va., April 27. -- Business circles were startled to-night by the news of the assignment of N. Burruss, Son Co., one of the most prominent and widely known firms in the South.

-- Though there is no such number of millions "in chancery" as would lend any semblance of truth to the myths by which American claimants are inspired with hopes, yet the sums which pass through the hands of the High Lord Chancellor are by no means unimpressive, and even those for which he fails to find heirs make a decidedly pretty showing.

KISSIMMEE, Fla., April 27. -- Some of the old engineers on the South Florida Railroad tell funny stories of adventure. "Uncle Dave" Kennedy, the oldest engineer on the road, is the acknowledged leader in this line. Last night when he came into the hotel he found fifteen or twenty tourists and others in the sitting room.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 27. -- The Imperial train, having on board Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria, Archduke Otto, Count Goluchowski, the Austrian Minister for Foreign Affairs, and their suites, arrived here to-day.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- President E.G. Mason of the Chicago Historical Society, learned by a catalogue of some historical curios in Paris of the existence of an old manuscript which tells about what are presumably the first cannon ever brought to the State of Illinois.

The land parade, in point of numbers, surpassed the general expectation. There were fully 60,000 men in line. The scene was beautiful as well as imposing. Taken in its entirety, it was a well-organized and harmonious body, and appealed strongly to the patriotic impulses of the hundreds of thousands who viewed the procession.

President McKinley was a little late in leaving the Windsor Hotel to make the start to the tomb. The schedule time was 8:45 o'clock. Mayor Strong and Gen. Horace Porter arrived a few minutes before that time and went at once to the President's parlor.
There are several bills pending in Congress bearing on the offices embraced under Mr. CLEVELAND'S extension of the rules, but which were not filled either by promotion or competitive examination.

Booker T. Washington of Tuskegee, Ala., who is now lecturing in this city, is one of the Trustees of the Calhoun School for Plantation Negroes at Calhoun, Lowndes County, Ala. For five years the negroes of this county have prided themselves on the work done in this institution. In addition to the school there is an agricultural and social settlement.

The result of Amos Rusie's return to New York was shown yesterday in the largest attendance of the year and a winning game of ball. The grounds began to fill up early in the afternoon, and by 4 o'clock, when the game began, there were fully 13,000 persons in the various stands. The exciting tie game of yesterday and the fact that Rusie was to pitch combined to draw them.
LONDON, April 27. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Larissa, by way of Elassona, dated Sunday evening, eulogizes Edhem Pasha's conduct of the campaign. The correspondent says:

Four persons lost their lives in a tenement house fire which started shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning in the four-story brick building at Third Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn. They were Mrs. Carrie Newell, thirty-eight, her two sons, John, aged seven, and Lewis, aged eighteen months, and Mrs. Celia Burnett, a widow of fifty-five years.

-- American bridge builders are much interested in the proposed widening of the Victoria Bridge, at Montreal, and representatives of half a dozen companies are now examining the great structure with a view to bidding for the contract. The task will be an expensive and difficult one, and it will be undertaken only after careful consideration of the conditions to be met.

Although it was nearly 1 o'clock yesterday morning when President McKinley returned from the reception of the Union League Club, he arose early, and at 9 o'clock took breakfast with Mrs. McKinley and Mr. and Mrs. Abner McKinley in the private dinning-room of the Windsor Hotel.

Judge Newburger, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday dismissed five indictments charging Police Inspector William W. McLaughlin with bribery and extortion. McLaughlin was indicted in 1894 as a result of the Lexow investigation. He was convicted once and sentenced, but the Court of Appeals overruled the conviction.

LONDON, April 28. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Paris says that M. Hanotaux, the French Foreign Minister, had a five hours' interview to-day with the Turkish Ambassador. It is understood that the subject under discussion was the terms upon which the powers are to base their intervention between Greece and Turkey.

An editorial in THE TIMES of Friday last upon the local situation is full of excellent suggestions, and points out the great danger which threatens the success of the independent, or non-partisan, movement in this city. The defeat of the Republican machine in the City of New York this Fall may be predicted with as much certainty as can be reasonably assumed of any future political event.

JOHANNESBURG, April 28. -- A joint meeting was held to-day of the Chamber and the Association of Mines with respect to mining operations on the Rand, and a resolution was adopted to make a 30 per cent. reduction in wages paid to native miners.

City Magistrate Charles E. Simms, Jr., has been asked to referee the ninth annual Irvington-Millburn handicap road race, which is scheduled to take place on Memorial Day over the famous course in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Representatives of leading railroads of the South met here to-day and concluded the formation of a new passenger traffic association, to be known as the Southeastern Passenger Association, and elected officers for the ensuing year. The articles of association were tentatively formed at a recent meeting at Atlanta, subject to the concurrence of four absent members.

District Attorney Olcott has decided to remove a number of subpoena servers and other employes of his office who have been retained because of the claim that they were protected by the civil service laws. This determination of Mr. Olcott was caused by the decision of Justice Smyth on Monday in the case of James Riley, a subpoena server, whose pay was withheld by Controller Fitch.

Brooklyn's annual society affair, the horse show, was opened last night at the Riding and Driving Club, with a large attendance of horse-loving members of society and entries for almost innumerable events. Nearly all the boxes were filled, and while the crowd was not so large as on the first night a year ago, the opening augured well for a successful week.

Trade in the dry-goods district yesterday was extremely lively all day. Although this is the slack season, all the firms were kept busy waiting on customers and opening new accounts. This activity is attributed largely to the success of the Wholesale Merchants' Association, which has been endeavoring to secure from the railroads entering New York lower rates, with a view to attracting buyers to the city, and thereby increasing their trade.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, April 28. -- At sunrise this morning a mighty wall of water from six to eight feet high and a mile wide broke upon West Guthrie without warning, crushing houses, sweeping away property, and drowning many people. Every movable thing was swept before the wave, which passed on into the Canadian Valley with resistless force, wreaking terrible destruction to life and property.

A larger crowd greeted Ferdinand Brunetiere yesterday afternoon at the Lenox Lyceum than on his previous appearances here. He delivered the third of a series of lectures on French literature, his subject this time being "The Drama," and fully 1,500 persons gathered to hear his views upon this interesting subject.

A wedding ceremony in the Church of the Transfiguration, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday, marked the culmination of a romantic love story. The contracting parties were L. H. Hyde, a lawyer c of this city, and Airs. IVIary Stevens, widow of John Stevens Of Hoboken.
RICHMOND, Va., April 28. -- Col. John S. Mosby, the famous Confederate ranger commander, who was so terribly hurt at Charlottesville, returned to consciousness to-day.
Charles Neukirch, the floor member of Theodore W. Myers Co., 32 New Street, was last night expelled from the Stock Exchange by the Governing Committee. The vote was unanimous.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 28. -- Adlai E. Stevenson, former Vice President of the United States, was in Atlanta last night, one of a party of capitalists who are on their way to Dahlonega to see the gold properties owned by the Appalachian Gold Mining Company. This company owns and controls twenty gold mines in Lumpkin County and is capitalized for $2,000,000.

WATTERSON is no luckier with history than with prophecy. In 1892 he staked his reputation on the gruesome prediction that if Mr. CLEVELAND were nominated the Democratic Party would "march through a slaughterhouse to an open grave." That was a pretty bad break in futures.

LONDON, April 28. -- Herbert Beerbohm Tree's new theatre, Her Majesty's, was opened to-night under circumstances of great social brilliancy. The general verdict is that it is the finest play house in London. So much interest centred in the opening that applicants for seat in the pit waited at the pit doors from early morning until 7 o'clock this evening. Great crowds watched the arrivals.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- The general officials of the Rock Island road deny the story sent out from Santa Fe, N.M., that the road is contemplating the building of a line from the Missouri River via El Paso through to the Gulf of California.

In spite of the fact that they had been invited as honored guests to take part in the festivities at the Waldorf last evening, only a few of the visiting Governors remained in town. Among the first to depart yesterday was Gov. Lowndes of Maryland, who left the Waldorf Hotel at 10 o'clock in the morning.

American publishers have devoted themselves to many enterprises which have brought reputation and profit. Seldom, however, has more enterprise been shown in recent years than in the undertaking of the Werner Company of New York, Chicago, and Akron, Ohio, to bring down to date the ninth edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 28. -- W.J. Deboe was elected United States Senator to-day. He was the caucus candidate of the Republicans, who indorsed him upon the withdrawal of Dr. Hunter. The ballot on which Deboe was elected Senator, the one hundred and twelfth ballot taken this session, was: Deboe, 71; Blackburn, 46; Martin, 12; Stone, 1.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 28. -- Lieut. Col. Denison, President of the United Empire League, at the annual meeting here to-day, said that Canadians were in favor of preferential trade with England. Canada was interested in the safety and permanence of the British Empire. England did not realize the dangerous position she was in.

During most of yesterday Stock Exchange tickers stood almost still. Transactions were insignificant. In two or three quarters weakness developed, and to some extent in specialties it seemed significant; but for the most part the market showed firmness, and the average of net changes for the day is not on the side of material declines.

ATHENS, April 28. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press at Larissa, who was with the retreating Greeks after the battle of Mati, has arrived here. When he overtook the Greek infantry the latter were in straggling order, footsore and grimy from four days in the trenches and long exposure to shells enough to unnerve veterans.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Mayor Harrison swung his newly sharpened axe this morning and severed every department head in the City Hall, with one exception. It was the reopening of hostilities with the Civil Service Commission. The list of those he has removed is headed by John P. Barrett, Superintendent of City Telegraph, and in the employ of the city for thirty-five years.

The journeyman plumbers of Chicago are threatening a strike on the 1st of May because, as they allege, agreements between them and the master plumbers have been violated by the latter. These agreements had two objects -- the maintenance of certain rates of wages in the plumbing trade and a limitation of the number of helpers or apprentices to be employed in the shops.

The Grant Day parade should have had a very important use. It was the most extensive competitive display that has been had since the civil war of the National Guard of different States. The Governors and their staffs could hardly have failed to derive from it important lessons in the means of securing the efficiency of the militia which the Constitution and common sense tell us are necessary to the security of a free State.

That the New York team defeated Washington yesterday by a score of 11 to 3 is due to young "Cy" Seymour's excellent pitching and the good team work of the rest of the team. Seymour's work in the box was of a high-class order, and the Washington team found it difficult to connect with his speedy curves, shoots, and drops.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The representatives of both the Dawes Indian Commission and the Choctaw and Chickasaw tribes, who five days ago at Anoka, Indian Territory, jointly executed an agreement, or treaty, for abolishing tribal organization and allotting lands in severalty, have reached here, and have announced formally the results of their conferences.

Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, reserved decision on an application for an injunction to restrain Commissioner of Public Works Collis from issuing a permit to the Metropolitan Street Railway to tear up the Sixth and Eighth Avenue pavements to substitute electricity for horse power for cars on those streets.
LONDON, April 28. -- The following semiofficial announcement was issued in Paris this afternoon:

As a graceful method of winding up the ceremonial exercises in honor of Gen. Grant, the City of New York gave a reception and ball at the Waldorf Hotel last evening to the officers of the warships that took part in the naval parade. Four foreign nations were represented in that parade, and the whole foreign diplomatic corps was present at the exercises about the tomb.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The election of Deboe in Kentucky does not change the political complexion of the Senate, but on some party questions might give the Republicans a majority if Senator Kyle of South Dakota voted with them, together with the vote of the Vice President. The election of Deboe makes the total membership of the Senate 88, composed of 43 Republicans, 33 Democrats, and 12 Populists and Silver Republicans.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 28. -- Harry A. Cassin, defaulting cashier of the Georgia Loan and Savings Bank Company, was a large stockholder and one of the officers of the Hartman Colony Company, which owns about 20,000 acres of land in South Carolina, and which is now facing an application for a receiver.

LONDON, April 28. -- Matters at Athens are likely to remain unchanged until the Ministerial crisis is settled, when overtures from the powers to intervene are expected. The Sultan is said to be willing to listen to terms.

It appears that it is not for nothing that mankind owes to Greece the adjective which in more than one modern language has been transposed into a noun to express general and a causeless terror. It seems clear from the only intelligible accounts that we have had of the overwhelming disaster of the Greeks that it was due to "panic."

Mr. LORIN A. THURSTON, the special Commissioner at Washington of the alleged Republic of Hawaii, seems to be in a constant state of worriment which nothing will allay but the annexation of the United States of the Pacific dominion and of its Government, including the special Commissioner.
Albert Sokoiskoi has sold for Abraham Lichtenstein to Israel Moskowitz the five-story building with store, northeast corner of Ludlow and Rivington Streets.

LONDON, April 28. -- A special dispatch from Volo, the port of Thessaly, announces that the Turkish advance forces have attacked the Greeks at Vlestino, about eight miles west of Volo, and on the railroad connecting the latter place with Larissa and Pharsalos. The Turks, however, the dispatch says, were repulsed with heavy loss and driven back as far as Teherlis.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 28. -- The first definite information of the losses of the three Howland corporations, with figures as the basis, is contained in a letter to creditors, which has just been issued. From this letter it appears that the total indebtedness will reach possibly $2,250,000, although it may fall slightly below this figure.

It is a pure coincidence, but a striking one, that the splendid tribute to the memory of Gen. GRANT fell on the eve of the anniversary of one of his greatest victories, not won in war, but in profound peace, which was in its day a priceless service to the Nation, and which to-day should be an inspiration to every honest citizen.
LONDON, April 28. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Patras, dated Tuesday evening, says:

At a meeting of the Citizens' Union held yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Union, 39 East Twenty-third Street, Prof. Nicholas Murray Butler spoke on the public school system and the policy of the Citizens' Union in that regard. Prof. Butler said:
BOSTON, April 29. -- Col. Jeremiah W. Coveney, Postmaster of this city, died at 11 o'clock to-night.

James Meisinger, a guard on the Kings County Elevated Railroad, has submitted a written report to W.T. Goundie, General Manager of the road, which will probably form the basis of a complaint against Major George G. Cochran of the Thirteenth Regiment, National Guard, in Brooklyn.

The Good Roads Association of Hudson County, N.J., is obtaining a reputation for activity equal to that possessed by its sister organization in Brooklyn. Its latest move for the benefit of cyclists and drivers will be made on Sunday, when the Executive and Road Committees will critically inspect the Hudson County Boulevard with the view of having its defects obliterated at once.

" I don't want to talk with you at all. If you have anything to say to me, say it in writing and send it through the mails. You are the only Commissioner appointed by me who has insulted me. Yes, Sir, by heavens, you have insulted me, Sir, I would remove you to-morrow if I had the power. I don't want to see you in this office again during my term."
LONDON, April 29. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Athens had an interview with M. Ralli this afternoon, during which this ambitious Greek statesman outlined his policy. M. Ralli said:

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 29. -- The victories of the Turkish troops have enormously raised the military spirit of the Turks, and the confidence thus inspired in Turkey's vitality is removing the dissatisfaction felt with the present regime, while at the same time rendering the powers' scheme of reforms for the Ottoman Empire harder of realization.

TACOMA, Washington, April 29. -- A riot occurred in Shanghai, China, April 5, in which thousands of striking coolies crossed the Yank King Pang River from the French Concession into the Anglo-American settlement, and fought the police at close quarters.
VIENNA, April 29. -- It is officially announced that Greece has assured the British and French Ministers at Athens that the Greek fleet will not bombard Salonica.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Judge Chase of Catskill has denied the application of W.H.D. Sweet, a former Special Excise Agent, for a writ of mandamus to compel the State Excise Commissioner to reinstate him. Sweet, who is a veteran, was appointed a Special Excise Agent from the civil service eligible list for a probationary term.

Fourteen additional delegates from foreign countries to the International Postal Congress, to be held in Washington next month, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd steamship Lahn and the Holland-American steamship Spaarndam.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 29. -- The Americus Club banquet was almost prevented to-night by a fire in the dining room of the Monongahela House. Covers had been laid for 324 members and guests. The banquet was given to honor the memory of Gen. Grant, and among the speakers were Senators George L. Wellington of Maryland and William E. Mason of Illinois.

Lead every day criticisms by members of the Stock Exchange, bankers and brokers, as to the causes of the business depression and the unwillingness of the public to invest in the goods (or bads) in which they wish to deal. They propose to secure business by abolishing bucket shops, suppressing tickers, and enforcing commission laws.

In the American Presbyterian Mission at Alexandria, Egypt, Jan. 26 last, Harrlet E. Beach, a widow of this city, contracted a "spiritually inspired" marriage with a spiritualistic medium, who sometimes calls himself Rogers and at others Richardson. Mrs. Beach is sixty-nine years old.

NASHUA, N.H., April 29. -- The New Hampshire Banking Company suspended this afternoon. Solomon Spalding, father of Charles W. Spalding of the broken Globe Savings Bank of Chicago, is President of the institution.

ATHENS, April 29. -- The King summoned M. Delyannis, the Premier, this morning, and called upon him to tender his resignation. His Majesty subsequently intrusted the Opposition leaders with the task of forming a new Cabinet.

With each succeeding lecture M. Brunetire's popularity seems to increase. Yesterday he delivered the fourth of his series on French contemporary literature at the Lenox Lyceum, and the audience was perhaps larger than on the previous day, when it was estimated at 1,500. The subject was "Criticism," virtually the lecturer's sole field, and his definitions were looked forward to with a great deal of interest.

A large importation of Kathleens, Eileens, Delias, and Norahs reached this port yesterday on the steamships Majestic and Servia. There were more than 1,100 immigrants in the steerage of these two ships alone, and nearly 200 more came in the Anchoria, from the northern part of the Emerald Isle.

For the German-speaking public in New York, or that comparatively small portion of it interested in modern art development, the first performance, at the Irving Place Theatre last night of Gerhart Hauptmann's latest fantastical drama was a notable event. The house was crowded. There was no evidence, however, in the frequent and vociferous applause, that the play made a very profound impression.

The block bounded by Broadway, Prince, Houston, and Crosby Streets will soon be the handsomest business block in the city. It will by January, 1898, if present plans are carried out, contain no building lower than twelve stories, and none that will not be worthy of any business quarter in any metropolis of the globe.

Among the April brides of yesterday was iiss Biay Ella Robinson, whose marriage to George Elliotte Little took place last eventng, in the Old First Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street. The bride is the granddaughter of the late Charles Knox, a daughter of Irs. WIary Knox-Robinson, and a member of the Daughters of 181_o,

A home wedding was celebrated yesterday afternoon when iVf2-s Julia L. Bedford, daughter of the late P, Wendover Bedford, Professor Emeritus of the College of Pharmacy, amd niece of %Yarner Van Norden,President ;of the Bank of North America, became the wife of E. Tomilson Gill of I-Iaddonfield, N. J., at the home of lr. %ran Norden, 16 ;Vest Forty-eighth Street.

Kent W. Ford, of "Ford Co.," 60 Broadway, was last night expelled from the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange by the Board of Directors for having been found guilty on a charge of "obvious fraud."
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Postmaster General Gary has appointed the following named delegates to represent the United States at the International Postal Congress to be held in this city next month:

" Mr. CLEVELAND is the logical leader of the Democracy, and before the present Administration is concluded I believe that almost the unanimous voice of the people will call upon him again to take the reins of the Government." -- Ambassador BAYARD, as reported in The Journal.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Some of the far-Western Senators, seeing the disadvantage under which the Republicans are suffering in not being able to induce the minority of the committee to permit the tariff bill to be reported as the Republicans have framed it, are encouraging the Democrats to resist the Republican programme and to afford the mountain State Republicans opportunity to compromise in rates.

The Commissioners of Rapid Transit met yesterday afternoon for the first time since April 6. There were present the President, Alexander E. Orr; Commissioners John H. Starin, John Claflin, George L. Rives, and Charles Stewart Smith, Secretary Delafield, and Albert B. Boardman and Edward M. Shepard, counsel.

As the result of a dinner given in his honor by Assistant Treasurer Conrad N. Jordan at the Lawyers' Club last night, Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage goes back to Washington with the cordial and united support of the financial interests of New York. Sixteen men were at table, and all of them besides the host and the guest of honor represented the leading banks of the city.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The House was in session seven minutes to-day. The Journal was not read. The objection that there was no quorum present was interposed by Mr. Simpson, (Pop., Kan.,) whereupon Mr. Payne (Rep., N.Y.,) made a motion to adjourn C.W. Stone, (Rep., Penn.,) who was in the chair, held that an adjournment under the order of the House made last Friday would be until Monday next.

Capt. MAHAN, with his accustomed force and lucidity, has set forth naval reasons for the annexation of Hawaii. In the possession of a maritime enemy these islands would afford coaling-station facilities and a basis of attack only 2,100 miles from San Francisco and less than 2,500 miles from any point on our western coast.

The action of the Stock Exchange in expelling Charles Neukirch from membership, and thus incidentally putting the firm of T.W. Myers Co. off the floor of the Stock Exchange, was one of the most generally discussed of Wall Street topics yesterday.

In the presence of fully 3,000 persons, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, impressive funeral services for Theodore A. Havemeyer were held yesterday forenoon. The sanctuary and pulpit were elaborately decorated with giant palms and ascension lilies, and near the Archbishop's throne stood a large broken column of white roses and purple immortelles.
LONDON, April 29. -- The Times correspondent at St. Petersburg has had an interview with a high official who accompanied the Emperor Francis Joseph on his visit to the Czar.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Mr. Vest (Dem., Mo.,) offered a resolution in the Senate to-day for a comprehensive inquiry by the Commerce Committee of the Senate into the causes and remedies for the Mississippi floods and said he would call it up at the next meeting of the Senate.

By Judge SMYTH'S decision and by his own interpretation of the recent decision of the Court of Appeals, District Attorney OLCOTT feels himself permitted -- so he says, in substance -- to discharge some fifty subordinates, chiefly subpoena servers.

The racing at Aqueduct yesterday was not of the highest order, but the five events furnished exciting contests, and ample opportunities for speculation. The weather was pleasant, and the narrow track was in excellent condition. A large crowd put in an appearance, and many of the "regulars" witnessed a horse-race for the first time this season.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Senate Finance Committee was in session for an hour to-day, four Republicans and four Democrats being present. The absentees were Platt, (Rep., Conn.,) Jones, (Dem., Ark.,) and Jones, (Sil. Rep., Nev.) No conclusion of any kind regarding the Tariff bill was reached, although the Republicans said they hoped to be able to report the bill to the full committee on Monday.

There was quite a noticeable increase in attendance over that of the opening night at the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club's horse show last evening. The society element turned out in full force, filling nearly all the boxes, and showing more interest in the goings on in the arena than in the boxes around the gallerits.

President McKinley and his party left the city yesterday, their departure being characterized by the utmost simplicity. There was no demonstration, no escorts, and, with the exception of a small crowd that gathered around the Windsor Hotel shortly before noon, not a soul knew that the plain carriage furnished by the hotel contained the Chief Executive of the United States.

Edwin W. Winter, President of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, laid his resignation, to take effect on the appointment of a successor, before the Directors of the company yesterday. They did not act on it.

Miss ]Belle Nellson, daughter of Airs. Belle Neilson, was married to Arthur Kemp yesterday at her home, 100 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by _Archbishop Corrigan, Archbishop Farley and the Rev. t'ather Van Rensselaer assisting. Only a few relatives wvere present. The bride was given away by her brother, J. B. Nellson.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 29. -- Weather cold, track heavy. Bannockburn opened favorite, at 1 to 3, for the third race, the Memphis Stakes, at five furlongs. Rumor spread that the colt was very lame, and the odds receded to even money. Isabey being backed to 4 to 5. Mc Guigan was refused permission to withdraw Bannockburn.

LONDON, April 29. -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, read the budget statement in the House of Commons to-day. The balanced account for 1896-7 shows the Exchequer revenue to be 103,950,000 ($519,750,000) and the expenditures 101,477,000, ($507,385,000,) leaving a surplus of 2,473,000, ($12,365,000.)
LONDON, April 29. -- The Athens correspondent of The Standard says:
The following bulletin, referring to Whisky Trust affairs, was issued in Wall Street yesterday by the financial news agency of Dow, Jones Co.:

LONDON, April 29. -- All the talk now, says The Daily Mail's Berlin correspondent, is of the intervention of the powers. Even Germany wishes to save Greece from the consequences of defeat, and it is stated in Berlin official circles that the powers will intervene of their own initiative if Greece does not invite them.

What ever became of that committee to investigate the charges against Mr. EASTON, State Superintendent of Public Buildings at Albany? The Senate adopted a resolution directing an inquiry to be made by a special committee of five, which was to have the rest of the year for its work and to report at the next session.

Slawson Hobbs have sold for Dr. William E. Diller, the four-story stone and brick dwelling, with smoking room, butler's pantry, bath and laundry extension, 16 West Sixty-ninth Street, 25 by 100.5. This is one of the two houses just completed by Dr. Diller.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29. -- According to advices by steamer this morning the Japanese Government is aroused over the refusal of the Hawaiian Government to permit Shinshou Marou emigrants to land there, and has ordered warships to Honolulu to enforce what the Japanese emigrants consider their rights.

LONDON, April 29. -- The log of the Mayflower was formally handed over to Mr. Thomas F. Bayard, the former United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, at 2:30 P.M. to-day, in the dingy dining room of the Bishop of London's official residence.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The announcement from Madrid that the Queen Regent has signed a decree applying the reform laws to Cuba is considered by officials here as a realization of the plans under negotiation for many months to give Cuba an autonomous form of government or home rule.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, April 29. -- In the devastated valley of the Cottonwood River to-day there has been one heroic effort towards the rescue of those unfortunates whose lives were still endangered, and for the relief of the hundreds of destitute and hungry. To-night it seems a certainly that the loss of life in yesterday's deluge will not exceed twenty.

LONDON, April 29. -- Volo is almost completely evacuated by the Greeks. The women and children have been taken away en masse by sea. The foreign Consulates have hoisted their flags. British and Italian iron-clads are at anchor in the harbor.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Former Gov. Altgeld to-night issued a statement concerning his connection with the defunct Globe Savings Bank, in which he said: "I have never received any benefit, directly or indirectly, from the bank."

Of interest to the Spanish residents of this country and he social world was the wedding of Miss Marquita Serrano, daughter of 1Vfrs. Mary J. Serrano, and Harold Q. Villard, son of iVir. and iVirs. Henry Viilard, which was celebrated yesterday in All Souls Church, Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, 1efore a large represerLtation of friends of the bride and groom.

Dr. Leo Ross, twenty-four years old, senior assistant house surgeon in the Women's Hospital, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, and August S. Wolf, thirty years old, druggist for the same institution, were badly burned yesterday in the chemical laboratory of the hospital by the explosion of alcohol which they were using.

SING SING, N.Y., April 29. -- William Kelley, the bicyclist, who lives at 166 East One Hundred and Eighth Street, New York, who met with an accident while coasting down Bacon's Hill, in South Highland Avenue, Tuesday by being thrown from his wheel, striking on his head and causing concussion of the brain, was reported to-day as likely to recover.

There was a conference of artists and architects last night in the council rooms of the Academy of Design, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue, over the arrangement and appointments of the new home for the academy, which is to be built at Morningside Heights.

It has been customary with some New Yorkers in the past to look with good-natured superiority on the efforts of provincial cities to draw trade. The attitude was dignified, but not profitable. When it became certain that the ceremonies of "Grant Day" would attract large bodies of strangers to the city some of our merchants determined to make an organized movement to stimulate the attraction and make the occasion as serviceable to trade as possible.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- At to-day's session of the Women's Whist League officers were elected for the ensuing year, as follows:

-- Manufacturers of chewing gum are in a state of great excitement because the new tariff, unless radically amended, will hit them not one blow, but half a dozen, each serious and several so vigorous as to leave no chance of survival. The chief constituent of chewing gum, it seems, is chicle, a vegetable resin or wax, produced by a tree that grows only in tropical America.
Gem John B, Gordon of Georgia, who fought with great gallantry throughout the eh-ll war, and led the forlorn hope at Appomattox, is writing a book Of war reminiscences.

BOSTON, Mass., April 30. -- The third annual banquet of the People's Party of Massachusetts took place at Arcade Hall to-night. Senator Butler made the principal address, in the course of which he said:

The first practical result of the donation of nearly $2,000,000 by the Baroness de Hirsch for the relief of the Russian Jews in America is made manifest by the establishment of the "Clara de Hirsch Home for Working Girls." It has been a cherished idea of the Baroness to assist the working girls, with whom she has always had great sympathy.

A young lady in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, whose first name is Laura is probably wondering to-day how in the world her sweetheart is going to take her to a New York theatre to-night, and how he will manage to take tea with her this afternoon.

The battle for the lightweight championship of the world between George Lavigne of Saginaw, Mich., and Eddie Connolly of St. John, New Brunswick, was decided at the Broadway Athletic Club last night in favor of Eavigne. The fight was scheduled for twenty-five rounds, but only eleven rounds were fought before a decision was reached.
MADISON, Wis., April 30. -- At a meeting of the University of Wisconsin students to-day it was decided to send a crew East to row Yale.

With the leafing of the trees now observable in this section, the country will posess added attractions for the cycling tourists who go exploring to-morrow. Every club in the metropolitan district has a run scheduled, and every good road leading away from the metropolis will be a route for some rider.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 30. -- The distress in Mayford and Shamong townships, where the forest fires are burning, is increasing. The fires burned all day, and are still burning to-night with great fierceness. Much valuable timber has been destroyed.

According to the statements of Tax Commissioner Barker yesterday, New York is no longer a city in which rich men can afford to live. The poor people who do not have to go to him and swear off personal taxes can worry along all right. Yesterday was the last day for the rich men to do this, and Mr. Barker said that the number of them exceeded anything in his experience with the office.

The Central Park menagerie has been enriched by the addition of two antelopes of the species oryx and a kangaroo. The animals have been loaned for an indefinite period by Mr. Bailey of the Barnum and Bailey circus. The antelopes are of a silver gray color, and somewhat shorter than yearling calves.

ALBANY, April 30. -- A novel question has arisen under the new liquor tax law which, if it is deemed a violation of the law, will be exceedingly hard to cope with. A party of men in Troy purchased a cask of liquor, and they wrote to the Excise Commissioner to find out whether they could distribute it among themselves without a liquor tax certificate.

Some bibulous wags of Troy have been preparing a poser for the Excise Commissioner as to the operation of the Raines law. A party of them, it is reported, bought a cask of liquor, and then sent a solemn communication to Mr. LYMAN inquiring if they could distribute it among themselves without a liquor tax certificate.
LONDON, April 30. -- The Standard's correspondent at Athens will say to-morrow:

The causes that bring about gold exports are very complex, and the most expert dealer is compelled to "take short views" on the subject, which are sometimes mistaken. The engagements for shipment yesterday were heavy, bringing the total for to-day to $4,000,000 and for the week to $6,477,000.

LONDON, April 30. -- La Patrie of Paris publishes a dispatch from Rome saying that Admiral Canevaro, the Italian commander in Cretan waters, has been ordered to consider Col. Vassos, who commands the Greek Army of occupation in Crete, as a belligerent and to no longer oppose Greek attacks on the Turkish troops there.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The United States Consul at Guadeloupe Island, West Indies, has telegraphed the State Department, under date April 29, from Point-a-Pitre, as follows: "Severe earthquake; loss heavy; many injuries."

CHICAGO, Ill., April 30. -- Sarah Louise Ervin, the young woman who was so closely connected with Banker Spalding and the downfall of the Globe Savings Bank, was put on the stand to-day in the legislative investigation of the loss of the State University funds. She admitted having received $75,000 from Spalding, and said she was to have married him in case he got a divorce.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Letters from the members of the diplomatic corps, through the dean, Sir Julian Pauncefote, are about to be sent to Mayor Strong and Gen. Horace Porter of New York, expressing the appreciation of the foreign representatives for the many courtesies shown them during the recent Grant ceremonies in New York.

The Rev. John McNeill, who arrived in this country on Wednesday, preached in the Hanson Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, last night, before an audience which crowded the old-fashioned edifice to the doors. This is Dr. McNeill's first appearance in the United States since the World's Fair, where he was a prominent figure in the World's Parliament of Religions. He is a Scotchman, and in his native land he is often called the Scottish Spurgeon.

Inquiries at various places in the downtown dry goods district, among wholesale dealers in millinery goods and among wholesale grocers yesterday, disclosed the fact that trade has been perceptibly stimulated by the influx of people for Grant Day ceremonies. Many buyers are said to be here from localities that have not taken the trouble to send to New York for goods for some time.

LONDON, April 30. -- To-day's news from the seat of war indicates the continuous advance of the Turks in both Thessaly and Epirus; but Edhem Pasha is carefully concealing the time and place of his principal attack.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 30. -- President James J. Hill of the Great Northern Railroad returned home to-day, having spent several days in New York on his arrival from Europe.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, April 30. -- Four hundred Greek volunteers sailed to-day for Athens, and 1,000 more will leave for the Greek capital to-morrow by a special steamer.

Some important developments came out of the recent International Young Men's Christian Association Convention at Mobile. One was the making of the Bible study department of equal grade with the educational and physical culture departments, and in getting $3,000 pledged toward its support.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 30. -- To-morrow will mark the formal opening of the Tennessee Centennial. All day crowds have been arriving, and dawn will find Nashville streets crowded. The people who populate this rich and prosperous section of the South will be here in fine force, all dressed in holiday attire.

Disappointment was very freely expressed among the crowds that saw the Grant Day parade at the inability of the spectators to pick out Gov. BLACK among the paraders. It is a great many years since the State has had a Governor who, at the time of his inauguration, was known by sight to so small a proportion of the population as our present Chief Magistrate.

Only one or two stocks advanced in the whole Stock Exchange list yesterday. Pacific Mail rose a point on transactions aggregating less than 1,000 shares, with reports current that an official statement of the company's affairs, soon to be issued, will make an especially favorable showing. Almost the only other stock showing a gain was Sugar Trust. In that transactions were beyond 12,000 shares.

The will of Charles B. Fosdick, the banker and leather merchant, was filed for probate yesterday. The value of the property is not given. The will is dated Dec. 28, 1895. The late William P. St. John, who was Treasurer of the Democratic National Committee during the Presidential campaign, is named as one of the executors.

WEST BUCKSTON, Me., April 30. -- News was received this morning of a double murder and suicide at Bonny Eagle, a small village two miles from here. The bodies of John C. Lane, a resident of the village, and his wife and infant child were found in bed at their home, a bullet from a revolver having ended the lives of each.

ATHENS, April 30. -- During the last twenty-four hours the Turks have almost been forgotten. Nothing is thought of but the Cabinet crisis. M. Delyannis has countersigned the decree dismissing his Ministry. The new Cabinet is composed equally of members of M. Ralli's party and of followers of the late M. Tricoupis, the latter holding the most important portfolios -- War, Foreign Affairs, Finance, and the Interior.

The banking house of John H. Davis Co. will to-day issue their financial circular for May. Messrs. Davis Co.'s monthly circulars have become widely known for their scholarly reviews of the financial situation and of current conditions and for their pertinent comments upon the various factors which from time to time influence the security markets. In their circular to-day Messrs. Davis Co. will say:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 30. -- Justice Lambden in this village to-day held Grosvenor W. Barry, a well-dressed young man, who was arrested yesterday in the Home Life Building, at 557 Broadway, New York, on a charge of check swindling, in $2,000 bail to await the action of the Westchester County Grand Jury. Barry was brought here late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- It is probable that the Secretary of the Treasury will recommend to Congress a material reduction of the internal revenue tax on distilled spirits and an increase in the tax on beer. This action will be taken on the ground that the present tax of $1.10 per gallon is at about the revenue-producing point.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 30. -- A case of National interest, from the fact that principles applying to the conduct of National banks throughout the country are involved, was submitted last evening to Judge John A. Williams of the United States District Court, after an exhaustive argument by counsel.

Commodore Sicard yesterday became Rear Admiral Sicard, and at 10 o'clock in the morning the Commodore's broad pennant, with its single star and swallow tail, gave way at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to a Rear Admiral's flag and two white stars. Although the Senate confirmed Admiral Sicard in his new grade some weeks ago.
LONDON, April 30. -- The Daily Mail publishes a dispatch from Larissa, dated Wednesday, which says:

The record for one day's customs receipts, established March 15 last at $2,667,979.51, was nearly equaled yesterday, when the amount taken in at the Custom House reached $2,408,829.12. The record for the month ending yesterday was $17,711,562.97. It was a short month, too, having only twenty-five business days.
LONDON, April 30. -- The Times correspondent at Athens will say to-morrow:

Four million dollars in gold coin, gold assay bars, and other bar gold will be sent to Europe to-day on the French steamer La Gascogne. The shippers are L. Von Hoffmann Co., $750,0oo in assay bars and $750,000 gold coin; Lazard Freres, $750,000 assay bars and $750,000 gold coin; Kuhn, Loeb Co., $500,000 assay bars, and Heldelbach, Ickelheimer Co., $350,000 assay bars and $150,000 bar gold.

The saloon keeper's new year began last night at 12 o'clock. A number of them observed the day by standing in line for hours at the Excise Department, awaiting their turn to pay $800 for a certificate to do business for the next twelve months.

There has been a patient at Bellevue Hospital since March 23 who is anxious to find out who he may be. On that day he walked into the reception office, and his symptoms were "sized up" as the result of too much drink. As "Charles Ernest Kaufman" he was committed to the alcoholic ward.

Maclay Davies have sold for George W. Bashford the five-story hotel, northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 25.11 by 100, with addition fronting on One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 20 by 100; also, to Gordon Norrie the four-story and basement stone-front dwelling, 9 East Eighty-fourth Street, 25 by 100.2.

Mayor Strong said yesterday that he proposed to call a conference of representative New York manufacturers early next week for the purpose of devising ways and means for the entertainment of the South American merchants who will be here on June 9.

Another important step has been reached in the preparation for the Elm Street improvement. The Commissioners of Estimate and Assessment have made their report upon the value of the property to be taken, and the amount of damage to be paid, by the city. This amounts to something over $5,000,000 in the aggregate.

BALTIMORE, April 30. -- The champions took the second game of the series from the Giants to-day, although the game at times looked close. In the fourth inning Keeler made a phenomenal catch of Beckley's long hit. The next ball that went into Keeler's field was from Seymour's bat. It bounded over the fence, and Seymour scored the only home run made here this season. Score:

The subject of library furniture is one which from time to time forces itself upon the attention of every owner and lover of books. All plans for the preservation and convenient arrangement of books may properly be classed under the head of library furniture. The better the collection the more important and interesting the topic becomes.

Gen. Joseph Wheeler, Democratic Representative from the Eighth Alabama Congressional District and a member of the Ways and Means Committee, who is on a visit to this city, brings encouraging reports from the South, both as to the political and the business situation.

It is gratifying to note that Mayor STRONG virtually retracts the statement that he would remove Superintendent CONSTABLE from office if he had the power on account of his personal resentment or irritation. He was reported as making that statement at the heated interview of Thursday, but yesterday he took it back, admitting that he had "nothing against Mr. CONSTABLE officially."

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- Testimony was taken in the Orphans' Court to-day in the contested will case of Mrs. Anna Bennett, who died in East Orange about a year ago. She made a number of personal bequests to relatives and friends and to charitable organizations.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 30. -- Steps for the union of the Sons of the American Revolution with the Sons of the Revolution were taken here to-day. This matter has been favorably considered by members of both societies for several years, and at the meeting of the National Congress of Sons of the American Revolution to-day a committee consisting of James M. Richardson of Ohio, E.J. Hill of Connecticut.
It would be a curious event if Mr. GRACE should be compelled by his party's policy as to revenue and taxation to come upon the market with an issue of bonds. But it is no means impossible.

It must now be as plain at Athens as it is at every other capital that the failure of Greece in an undertaking of which the chivalry was Quixotic is complete and hopeless. She is, indeed, at the mercy of Turkey. But she is not upon that account much worse off than she was before, except by the actual losses of life and treasure already incurred.

Charles J. Toppin, twenty-three years old, who gives the St. Cloud Hotel as his New York address but claims St. Louis as his home, was held in $1,500 bond yesterday, in Jefferson Market Court, to answer to a charge of robbery.

The bi-centenary celebration of Trinity Parish will begin to-morrow with special services in every church and chapel in the parish. The principal exercises will be in the parish church proper, Trinity. The floral decorations in this church will be elaborate. The vicars of each chapel will read from the pulpit a pastoral letter for the rector of Trinity, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 30. -- The thirteen army officers constituting the court-martial before which Capt. Henry Romeyn is now on trial at Fort McPherson have received orders from the War Department to the effect that upon conclusion of the present trial they shall remain in Atlanta to await further instructions.

The Building Department deserves a particular word of praise for its work in connection with the Grant Day parade. It is one of the misfortunes of that department that it cannot attract the confidence of the public by any positive achievements. Its value is shown only by the disasters it averts.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Japanese Foreign Office has gazetted the promotion of the present Japanese Consul General at Hawaii to the rank of Minister Resident. This gives him larger authority in dealing with displomatic affairs between Japan and Hawaii, and the legation here has no further jurisdiction of the subject except as it may affect the relations of the United States and Japan.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Gov. Tanner returned from New York to-day and said: "We had no trouble in New York, While, of course, the committees saw fit to slight Illinois as to a position in the parade, we are not making much of a fuss. You know it may have been a mistake. Of course that is very plausible, as the New Yorkers, I suppose, do not know that Grant came from Illinois.

THE TIMES meets my approval, and I believe it an ideal newspaper, barring one fault. No other daily is taken to my home. While I do not subscribe to all the doctrines THE TIMES advocates, yet I read it with a great deal of pleasure, except when it speaks of Mr. BRYAN in a dastardly and contemptible manner, classing him with Anarchists and Socialists.

In a recent speech upon the reciprocity of protection delivered by the Hon. J.L. McLaurin of this State in Congress, he is reported to have said that while the laboring men of the Northeast were making bank accounts, those of his section were making store accounts, the majority of which they were unable to pay.

It will be interesting news to Christian Endeavorers in this country to learn that the Continental tour of Dr. Clark, President of the United Society, is nearly finished. He has traveled many thousand miles with his wife during the Winter, having gone as far east as India, and south to Cape Colony, in Africa.

LONDON, April 30. -- Mr. A. Cohen's Greenlawn won the Asher Stakes at the second day's racing of the Sandown Park meeting to-day. The Lorillard-Beresford's Drace and Mr. Richard Croker's Santa Anita did not start. Eleven horses ran. The Asher Stakes is a handicap of 1,000 sovereigns, the second horse to receive 100 sovereigns, and the third 50 sovereigns, out of the race; distance, one mile.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Col. E.C. Bainbridge of the Third Artillery, stationed at Angell's Island, San Francisco Harbor, was to-day placed on the retired list, having reached the age of sixty-two years. This is the second compulsory retirement in the army within the present year.

The House Tariff bill proposes to tax wood pulp one-twelfth of a cent per pound. This is equivalent at present prices to $1.66 per ton, as against the present duty of about $l per ton. The total revenue involved in this increase would not at the utmost amount to more than $60,000 to $70,000 a year.

The Insurance firm of Fleming Kell of 271 Broadway began suit on April 1 in the United States Circuit Court of the District of Connecticut against the National Life Association of Hartford for $100,000, and attached property of the association in the First National Bank of Hartford -- money, stock, and securities -- valued at $50,000.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Minister Dupuy De Lome has received an official dispatch from Madrid confirming the press cable that the Queen has applied the reform laws to Cuba. The dispatch says:

I heard nearly all the great speeches made by both the men in that Parliamentary duel which lasted for so many years. My own observation and judgment gave the superiority to Mr. Gladstone all through, but I quite admit that Disraeli stood up well to his great opponent, and that it was not always easy to award the prize of victory.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14. -- The Connecticut Historical Society in this city has received from Miss Helen E. Smith of New York, the granddaughter of Gov. John Cotton Smith, the personal and official correspondence of the Governor during the five years that he was at the head of the State Government. There are 1,700 letters and official documents in the collection, the bulk of them covering the war period of 1812.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The Senate committee which has undertaken the investigation of the workings of the civil service laws held its second meeting to-day. Senators Pritchard, Lodge, and Chilton conducted the investigation. The Civil Service Commission was represented by President Procter and George R. Wales.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 1. -- The combined report of Col. Robert H. Hall, United States Army, and Capt. James B. Burbank, United States Army, to the War Department of the United States, on the condition of the National Guard in this State, was made public to-day. Capt. Burbank is detailed by the War Department to observe the workings of the State Militia, and is stationed at the Adjutant General's office.

"There is a practical element in this desired reform, and it is this: Anybody who has given even the most cursory attention or study to botany knows that all forms of life have their origin in plant life. Every animal which exists either lives directly on some plants, or on insects which destroy plants.

It cannot truthfully be said that the week which closed last night was either a gay or enjoyable one in the society world of New York. It had been anticipated both pleasantly and eagerly, for the average man and woman likes a brillint military and naval spectacle, and numberless were the parties and countless were the plans formed to make Tuesday last an enjoyable day.

Former Mayor William R. Grace is heartily in favor of the principle of taxation embodied in the Dudley Graduated Inheritance Tax bill. "I have not read that particular measure," he said, "but I am in favor of a progressive, graduated system of taxation on large estates. I believe that the rich should pay taxes according to their means.

ATHENS, May 1. -- The Legislative Chamber finally secured a quorum, and held a sitting this afternoon, great crowds surrounding the building. The public galleries were thronged. The new Ministers were seated on the Government bench. M. Ralli, the new Premier, without delay addressed the House.

There was a runaway on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock which created a great amount of excitement, and which ended with a miraculous escape from serious injury of the several parties in the affair. David T. Merritt, who is the Collector of Customs at New Brunswick Canada, is a guest with his wife at the Grand Union Hotel.

BOSTON, May 1. -- The first of this season's new twenty-one-foot knockabouts is in the water, and has had a trial under sail. The boat is the Cockatoo, built by the Herreshoffs for C.S. Eaton of the Marblehead Corinthians, to replace last year's champion, Cock Robin. She was launched last Tuesday, tried under sail Wednesday, and was delivered to her owner Friday morning, ready either to race or cruise.

LONDON, May 1. -- Last week ended in chaotic doubt as to the meaning of the contradictory stories creeping in from various points in the Levant. There had been such a striking series of Greek successes that the Sultan exhibited his fright by sending Osman Ghazi to the front and hastily calling out a huge class of reserves.

ATHENS, April 20. -- So much has been written in prose and verse about the splendid position of Athens, backed by her glorious mountains and lying, as it were, beneath the protection of her magnificent Acropolis, that, instead of going into fresh raptures about it, it will be more timely to give some idea of its more modern side.

Harlem River oarsmen are training faithfully for the Memorial Day regatta, and every evening, between 6 and 8 o'clock, the river is dotted with all kinds of racing craft. The junior eight of the First Bohemians seems at present to be the best crew on the river. Their frequent brushes with the senior eight of their own club have proved them very fast.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 1. -- Just now Lakewood rejoices in Spring verdure. New foliage, fragrant fruit blossoms, and green lawns welcome Spring guests who, having a memory of other Springs at this resort, have returned to find no shadow of disappointment, for the village has never been more attractive.

Australia claims the largest auto-mobile carriage ever constructed for actual service. This car utilizes seventy-five horse power, an unheard-of amount for any such vehicle. The car travels from Coolgardia to the coast for the transportation of merchandise to the mines. Besides the load on the car itself, it drags two "trailers" over a distance of 400 miles.

Pleasure and benefit from cycling depend upon two things, namely, upon the proper physical condition of the rider and upon having a suitable bicycle. "The cyclist who lives a simple life and rides judiciously," says Joseph Goodman, the well-known Hartford student of cycling, "will create and hold a goodly supply of that reserve force which is to a great extent synonymous with perfect health and a consciousness of well-being and contentment.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1. -- The annual YalePrinceton debate will be held in the College Street Hall, Yale, next Friday evening, May 7, at 7 o'clock.

LONDON, May 1. -- Profiting by the temporary presence in England of a leading member of one of the oldest and largest Victorian sealing houses, a representative of The Associated Press called upon that gentleman to ascertain the views held by the Canadian or pelagic sealers on the latest phase of the sealing question. He said:

THE regular musical season in this city is at an end, yet there are some very interesting musical entertainments still to come. The week which has just closed has been given over to the celebration of the memory of Gen. Grant, and musical projectors wisely declined to undertake the uncertainty of offering any calling for serious consideration.

The war between Greece and Turkey will have marked effect on the importation of high-grade sponges. The finest in the world, particularly the costly cup sponges, come from Greece. Several hundred divers who make a living the year round at their trade have quit work and joined the army.

ONE of the most attractive of all the many interesting homes in this city is the house of Chauncey M. Depew. The house is 43 West Fifty-fourth Street, midway in the block between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. It is the most noticeable house in the row, for it has a very wide stoop, with big lamps of brightly polished glass.

It is a great thing for an American city to possess an institution with two centuries of authentic history behind it. And to-day Trinity Church celebrates its arrival at that respectable antiquity. There may be other institutions even older, but there is none that has attained and kept the same dignity as a civic monument.

The centennial celebration of the admission of the State of Tennessee into the Union has been belated by a year, but it is very well worth waiting for. Without doubt the State has very much to celebrate. And most worth celebration of all the history of the century is that of the last third of it. Before that Tennessee had had many famous names.
They talk in Washington of building a new Executive Mansion. It is a proposition to be most carefully considered before it is carried out.

VIENNA, April 18. -- The crisis at the Macedonian frontier has brought the question of Macedonia's future more than ever to the front, and here in Vienna it is the predominating subject of interest to Austrian diplomacy. Of all the problems in the vexed Eastern question it is by far the most difficult to solve.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Consul Germaine, at Zurich, Switzerland, writing to the Department of State March 28, says that if the manufacturers of picture molding, wire, and hooks will send him samples, prices, and terms of their product, he thinks he can help to introduce these articles in his district, Zurich being the distributing centre for Switzerland, and, for that matter, of the whole Swiss territory.

The elemental costume of the Arab woman consists of a shirt and a pair of trousers, the former worn outside and of varying length, and a kerchief for the head. There may be many a variant, much elaboration and adornment; stockings may or may not be worn, a profusion of jewelry always, such as necklaces, bracelets, and tinkling anklets; the kerchief may be replaced by a cap, and around the waist a rich girdle drawn.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Lieut. Gibbons, charged with the arrangements for the Summer drills of the Naval Militia, is now busy in completing the programmes for each State. The department has encouraged the encampment of the militia from adjacent States in groups, and the States have fallen in with the idea in most instances, though some of the State organizations will act alone this Summer, either by preference or from lack of a near-by neighbor.

Trinity Church will be in festive array this morning, this being the bi-centennial anniversary of the foundation of Trinity Parish. In honor of the occasion a celebration has been arranged for to last all week, and it will commence this morning at 10:30 o'clock with high services. In the afternoon at 3:30 an evensong will be rendered, and special services will be held in the evening at 8 o'clock.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1. -- The eighth annual handicap field and track athletic games, open to all amateurs under the intercollegiate rules, were held here this afternoon under the auspices of the Princeton University Track Athletic Association. There was a very liberal list of entries from Harvard, Yale, Pennsylvania, and Columbia ,Universities, and a large number of spectators watched the contests.

Cloudy skies and damp weather that drifted into showers late in the afternoon spoiled the usual May Day festival for the children in Central Park yesterday. In spite of it at least 1,000 boys and girls in gay-colored caps took possession of the meadows wherever the blue flag assured them that the ground was dry enough.

The indifferent citizen is not a good citizen. The man we call a good citizen is a good man, an upright man, honored and respected in the community, but a perfect cipher in the State. He contributes nothing, unless it be money in taxes, and this the law forces from him. His voice is never heard in council.

It is a serious question -- a more serious question than many people think -- this of manners, or, to use a broader and more appropriate word, courtesy. If more consideration was given to it there would be more of it and the world would be infinitely better. It is very possible it would be a more virtuous world; certainly it would be happier.

The first Spring meeting of the Meadowbrook Steeplechase Association was held yesterday afternoon, and there were some very exciting races over the picturesque Wheatley Hills. The success of the initial meeting, held last Autumn, was surpassed, not only in the matter of attendance, but also in the number and character of the entries, and the general interest in the programme.

"Our country is certainly more democratic than the United States," the Crown Prince of Greece once said to me, in the midst of a conversation about the political institutions of his country. He was surely right, if the remark be applied to the social and political instincts of the Greek people. No more naturally and unaffectedly democratic people exists under the sun than the Greek.

NEWTOWN, L.I., May 1. -- Frederick Cromberger, the fourteen-year-old boy who came home ill from school three weeks ago and complained then and afterward that his teacher, Miss Scouler, had hit him on the head with a ruler, died last night. Physicians who held an autopsy to-day said that death resulted from virulent pleuropneumonia.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 1. -- Philadelphia won from Brooklyn to-day in a teninning game, the latter half played in the rain. The noteworthy feature of the game ,Yes the great number of men left on bases.

The Rev. Edward Ernest Matthews, assistant to the Rev. E. Walpole Warren, rector of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, was complainant in Yorkville Police Court yesterday against his brother, Percy H. Matthews, whom he accused of persistently annoying and threatening him. He succeeded in having the prisoner sentenced to either to give bail in $500 or go to jail for six months.

LONDON, April 17. -- "Take the yellow 'bus down to Oxford Street, and there change to the blue 'bus. Be sure you don't take the green one, for that is three ha'-pence, and the blue is only a penny. Then from Charing Cross take the pink 'bus down to Fenchurch Street, and you'll not have more than half a mile to walk. Bear along to the left, and take the third turning."

CHICAGO, May 1. -- Charles W. Spalding, former President of the defunct Globe Savings Bank, told the Senate Committee this morning that he never gave any money to Miss Ervin; that he merely invested her money for her, but admitted that her savings did not amount to more than a few hundreds of dollars.

One day while du Maurier was taking his favorite walk about the Heath he saw a gathering of people on the borders of the shallow pond which is a particular attraction to Hampstead. A thin coating of ice covered the water, excepting where a little dog had broken through and was ineffectually struggling to get out again.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 1. -- The State Board of Railway Commissioners took preliminary steps toward securing a general conference of Kansas railways on freight rates by sending out a letter to all the lines. The Commissioners say they will name a date at Topeka within thirty days when they ascertain the convenience of the companies.

The plans of the men who hold the immediate future of New York grand opera in their hands assumed definite form with the incorporation of the Maurice Grau Opera Company of New York City, at Albany yesterday.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 1. -- Ten days ago Judge Smith granted to George E. Waller and others a temporary injunction restraining the Rev. David T. Howell, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church of Monticello, from placing the word "lapsed" after the names of Mr. and Mrs. Waller, Mrs. Johnston, and Mrs. Bush, with a dozen other persons.

The threatening weather did not deter half-holiday racegoers yesterday, and the large army of "regulars" was considerably augmented at Aqueduct yesterday. Visitors who were thoughtful enough to bring heavy overcoats found they were needed, for a fierce blast blew across the track from Jamaica Bay and made the waits between races anything but comfortable.

Louis XIV.'s famous saying, "I am the State," is not far from being applicable to Wesley, however he would have revolted from saying, "I am the Church." But unquestionably the prolongation of his life as both the apostle and lawgiver of his Church throughout the whole of its adolescent and formative period, during which it was plastic to his organizing and guiding hand, secured to it both its stable basis and its symmetrical development.

"Congress first assembled in the new Capitol on Nov. 17, 1800, and John Adams, then President, took up his abode in the Executive Mansion. Neither the Capitol nor the Executive Mansion was fully completed. The proportions of the house seemed to Mrs. Adams as 'grand and superb.' The plan was taken from the palace of the Duke of Leinster in Dublin.

LONDON, May 1. -- It is semi-officially announced that the Marquis of Salisbury has proposed to the powers that a conference be soon held in Paris to discuss measures with the view of ending the war between Turkey and Greece. The powers, it is further stated, are discussing the proposal; but its acceptance is regarded as doubtful.

ATLANTA, Ga., .May 1. -- The order from headquarters commanding an indefinite sitting of the present court-martial convened to try Capt. Romeyn for conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman, together with the sensational developments of to-day's hearing, have given rise to the belief that three other trials will result, as follows:

For people who like vegetable dishes there is nothing more delicious, the mycologist says, than the mushroom. There are mushrooms and mushrooms, but to the mushroom eater all mushrooms -- of the edible variety -- are good mushrooms.

The starting of the customary Spring export of gold has had its also customary effect of dampening the stock market, which, however, did not need dampening. General estimates of the total amount which will go vary rather widely, but they average about $30,000,000. With the full supply in the Treasury and the amount held in the banks, the loss of this amount will not cause trouble, but will doubtless stiffen money rates.

A meeting of women was held last night in the Twenty-fifth Assembly District, at the home of Mrs. N.M. Butler, 119 East Thirtieth Street, for the purpose of forming an organization to study political methods. The women learned a good deal more at the first lesson than they expected, and one of the speakers succeeded in doing a good piece of electioneering for the Citizens' Union and non-partisan movements in politics.

-- Seeing an account in a paper recently of the arrest of the "Cheyenne Kid" reminds me of five years ago, when I was in Casper, Wyoming, and assisted at a trial of the "Kid." The court was held in the front room, one of two, in the log cabin which was the home of the Judge.

LONDON, May 1. -- Hifiz Pasha, Commander of the Turks at Janina, yesterday telegraphed a report to the effect that the troops had occupied, after a fight, the heights commanding Caravansera. The Greeks fled, according to the official Turkish accounts, by way of Kunuzados.

Several of the twenty-footers that are to furnish so much of this season's yacht racing are now approaching completion, and in the course of the next few days one or two will be launched and tried. Dr. Clarke's boat is already in the water, and in her trials has given general satisfaction to her owner and to her builder, Larry Huntington.

With the stroke of midnight last night the police of the city began the enforcement of the new amendments to the Raines liquor tax law, according to instructions given by Chief Conlin to the Inspectors, Captains, and precinct commanders yesterday afternoon.

The passage at the very end of the session of the Legislature of the uniform charter for second-class cities was almost an accident. The bill had been through the Senate and was pending in the Assembly with no expectation that it would pass, when a sudden pressure from the outside carried it through.
HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., May 1. -- The biggest kind of a sensation was created here to-day by the unexpected appearance of James Crosby, who it was thought had been murdered thirty years ago.

LONDON, May 1. -- The following is the full text of the petition presented by Dr. W. Kennedy Moore to the Presbyterian Synod last Thursday in the charges of the erroneous views held by Dr. John Watson, "Ian Maclaren," and rejected by that body:

There are no more expensive gifts made through the year than at Easter, considering the evanescent quality of the floral offerings in connection with the price. Easter lilies and azaleas form a large proportion of these gifts, and they range in price from a fraction of a dollar to hundreds of dollars, according to the quality of the plant and the place in which it is purchased.

The first set of games between Berkeley School and St. Paul's School of Garden City, L.I., were held yesterday afternoon at Berkeley Oval. The grounds were soggy, owing to the recent rains, and a damp east wind did much to chill the enthusiasm. The following is a summary of the events:

May Day was celebrated last evening by the Socialist trade and labor unions of this city by a grand parade and demonstration. Notwithstanding the threatening weather the Socialists turned out in force, with music and Chinese lanterns, banners and transparencies, and when paraders and curiosity seekers assembled in front of the cottage in Union Square there were between 6,000 and 7,000 persons.

The golf season in the vicinity of New York was actively opened last week, and the sport will now be continued with tournaments and team matches every week throughout the Summer. The next big event which will attract more than ordinary interest will be the intercollegiate golf tournament at Ardsley Casino, on the Hudson, near Dobbs Ferry, May 13 and 14.

HAVANA, May 1. -- It is announced here that the Spaniards have succeeded in recapturing the Port of Banes. The insurgents have retreated to the interior of the island, official reports announcing their loss as considerable.

-- From the Year Book just issued by the Church of England it appears that the income which comes to it from property owned, ancient endowments, and regular Government grants amounts annually to something over 5,750,000, yet the expenses of the Church amounted last year to more than twice that sum, the difference having been made up by voluntary contributions. In commenting on this state of affairs, one of the London papers says:

The Montauk Club of Brooklyn last evening gave a farewell dinner to Gen. Horace Porter, Ambassador from the United States to France, in its handsome clubhouse, 17 Eighth Avenue, that city. Covers were laid for about 140 persons, who were seated at four tables.

BOSTON, May 1. -- Edward S. Taber, Thomas B. Tripp, and Morgan Rotch were appointed receivers of the Rotch Spinning Corporation, the Howland Mills Corporation, and the New Bedford Manufacturing Company, all of New Bedford, by Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Senator Jones of Nevada, the independent member of the Senate Committee on Finance, spent several hours with Senators Allison and Aldrich, representing the Republican sub-committee on tariff, to-day. He went over the bill with them and suggested changes when he was not satisfied with the existing provision.

ALBANY, April 24. -- George Rogers Howell, State Archivist, before the New York Society of Founders and Patriots, recently overthrew the credited authorities on the date of the first colonization of the State of New York in modern history. In opening his remarks, which are shortly to be printed in pamphlet form, Mr. Howell says:

The women of the Richmond County Country Club, on Staten Island, yesterday competed for the handsome silver prizes offered by James Park, Captain of the Richmond County golf team. It was the last regular tournament that will be played over the old links, and a large number of golfers turned out to witness the farewell match.

District Attorney Olcott held a civil service examination of his own yesterday afternoon. The various applicants for positions as subpoena servers were interrogated in his office. There will be nine vacancies to-morrow ready to be filled.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 1. -- The Tennessee Centennial Exposition was opened at noon to-day with appropriate ceremonies in the presence of many thousands of people. The weather was bright and cool, and at an early hour the streets were thronged with people, assembled to witness the parade of the Essenic Orders and other societies.
