MUCH more important as a topic than Gerhart Hauptmann's "Sunken Bell," an original, whimsical, mystical, and sad German drama, is "The Circus Girl," which, in spite of a certain "slowness" that condensation of text and "business" cannot altogether remove and a strong effusion of rank silliness that the prettiest music and the brightest pictorial effects can barely palliate, is bound to be a great "go."

ANNAPOLIS, May 1. -- The Naval Academy every afternoon from 5:30 to 7 is a scene of interesting activity with the large preparation to make the annual meet on May 8 a decided success. The Superintendent of the academy, Capt. Cooper, wisely forbade any cadet from taking part in the meet unless he had had three weeks' previous training.

It can be positively stated that, according to the decision of the Directors of the Manhattan Railway Company, the road will not be equipped with electricity, all consideration of the matter having been dropped by the Manhattan Company.

BERLIN, May 1. -- Emperor William's cutting remarks about men without patriotism which were used not only in a telegram to his brother, Prince Henry of Prussia, but also in a public address delivered at Carisruhe this week in reply to the greetings of the municipal officers of that place, have created a sensation.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1. -- An unusually large number of the members of the university Faculty will leave for Europe for the purpose of pursuing their studies at the prominent Continental universities during the Summer months. Some of the professors have received permission to stay abroad for long terms.

"Cap'n Pete" -- hundreds of New Yorkers who know him and visit his North River swimming school every year have forgotten that his last name is Hunt -- sat on the bulkhead of a pier and watched with mingled pity and sorrow two men in a boat extract a dozen struggling shad from the meshes of a net.

May, the latest and loveliest of the Spring months, holds in turn its celestial festival in which we find almost all of our familiar actors in their favorite roles. The May evenings are soft and serene, inviting to open-air life. As the twilight fades and the shadows darken no study is more ennobling and elevating than that of the starlit heavens, with its myriad hosts of suns peopling the star depths.

It is not alone by obstinate ill-doing that the Senate has forfeited the public respect. In what it refuses to do, or does grudgingly under the lash of compulsion, it is unbearably exasperating. The mulish stubbornness with which it has resisted the will of the people in respect to the treaty of arbitration is a flagrant example of degenerate practices.

BEGINNING with scant numbers and in comparative poverty the founders of Trinity Parish established, just two hundred years ago, a church organization, the growth and development of which is an essential part of the history of the City of New York.

The steamship Bertie, which arrived yesterday from Hamburg and Hartlepool, had a rough encounter with the elements. She came in with a hole in her bow, her fore peak filled with water, one boat missing and another smashed, while Chief Officer Wolford suffered from two broken ribs.

LONDON, May 1. -- The fifth member of the House of Commons' chess team, which will compete with a corresponding number of chess players of the United States House of Representatives, will be Mr. F.W. Wilson, Member of Parliament for the Middle Division of Norfolk. He is the author of "Our National Debt," and was President of the Newspaper Society of the United Kingdom in 1894.

Mayor Strong has received a letter from Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador at Washington, complimenting him on behalf of the Diplomatic Corps upon the conduct of the Grant Day ceremonies, and thanking him and the municipal committee for the attentions bestowed. Mayor Strong is very proud of this and other letters he has received which compliment those who managed the ceremonies.

Gold is going abroad more largely than anybody in Wall Street has foreseen. Over $1,000,000 per day has been the average export engagement during the week just closed. In high banking circles there is hesitancy in making forecasts as to how far the outgo may reach, but it is not difficult to find bankers of consequence who are willing to put the estimate beyond $25,000,000. Any measuring figures, however, depend upon guesswork.

At Edmonton, England, where Charles Lamb once lived, Mrs. Humphry Ward, about two weeks ago, laid the foundation-stone of a public free library. The Urban District Council has provided the site, while the building, which is estimated to cost 3,000, will be the gift of Passmore Edwards, whose name it will bear.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 28. -- Capt. W.C. Champlin, who is the instructor of the Young Men's Christian Association military company of this city, a few days ago delivered an address to the company in which he discussed the organization of the United States Army. In the course of his lecture he said:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 1. -- Never before in the history of Morristown has society appeared so openly to the public as it did to-night in a three-part entertainment given in Lyceum Hall by the members of the Morristown Field Club, to raise funds for the extension of the golf course. After six weeks' rehearsal twenty-eight handsome maidens and youths gave the finest amateur entertainment ever given in this city.

Eleanor Penrose, who says she lives in Plainfield, Conn., and declares she is a law student, got into trouble at Coney Island Saturday night. She dressed up as a man and, with a male companion, visited the various resorts. Miss Penrose, which is probably not her right name, attracted a large crowd of men and boys, and wherever she and her companion went the crowd followed.

The hour was 7 in the evening. The scene Arno Muller's dancing pavilion at Coney Island. The time yesterday. The floor was crowded with promenaders. A man and a woman sat quietly at a table, drinking. Suddenly there was a commotion, and a young man broke roughly through the promenaders and stood before the table.
LONDON, May 2. -- The Duchess of Teck has undergone a critical operation, but is progressing favorably toward recovery.

With imposing display of gilded heraldry, silk banners, National flags, and flowers, with special services of song and historical addresses, that dwelt on a long and honorable service in the cause of Christianity, Trinity Parish celebrated its two hundredth birthday yesterday.
Gov. BLACK will give a hearing on the Civil Service bill on Thursday next at 11:30 A.M. A strong delegation from this city will undoubtedly be present, and other cities will be heard from.

The arrival of English mails explains an incident which, when it occurred, was most mysterious here. It will be remembered that the appointment of Messrs. FOSTER and HAMLIN to arrange with England some method to prevent the extinction of Alaskan seals passed in the United States almost without comment. But suddenly the cable was laden with British denunciations of us.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2. -- Mrs. Margaret Rennie, a widow, living with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Rogers at Bonhamtown, three miles from this city, was drowned in a peculiar manner this afternoon. The bridge over Mill Creek, a small stream, had recently been widened. The work was completed on Friday, and on that day the false work was removed and the new bridge depended upon itself for support.

The first twenty-four hours of the sway of the amended Raines liquor tax law, so far as this city was concerned, which ended at midnight last night, did not make the quest of a thirsty soul for refreshment any more difficult than was usual on Sunday. There was absolutely no trouble to buy all the liquor one wanted to drink with no other formality than to suffer stock sandwich to remain on the table.

The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was comfortably filled yesterday afternoon when the Rev. Dr. John Hall and the Rev. John McNeill ascended the platform. Mr. McNeill was announced to preach. He is a Scotchman, and has been for a few years past engaged in evangelistic work. Prior to that he was pastor of the Regent's Square Presbyterian Church, in London.

Gong Shen, twenty years old; Chin Gin, twenty-one years old, and Chin Pawn, twenty-three years old, were baptized by Dr. Samuel A. Virgin in the Pilgrim Congregational Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, yesterday morning. Gong Shen alone wore the costume of his native land. After the baptism the sacrament of the Lord's Supper was administered.

" We may reasonably expect that the public schools shall keep in constant view the betterment of the physical, mental, and moral condition of pupils," said W.H. Maxwell, Superintendent of the public schools of Brooklyn, before the Public Education Association at 64 Madison Avenue.

Impressive exercises were held yesterday morning by the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall. Nearly 1,000 members of the People's Choral Union and of the People's Singing Classes, under the leadership of Frank Damrosch, furnished the music, and the platform had to be extended half way into the auditorium to accommodate the singers.

Once upon a time a wise old King sent his son upon a traveling tour to complete his education, and Laid to him as he was about to depart: "Go, my son, and see with what little wisdom the world is governed. If Adolphus of Sweden had survived to our time and sent his inquiring son to the United States of America, he would have received object lessons of the most impressive character.

Perhaps the young women who attended M. BRUNETIERE'S lectures have learned as much as it is well for them to know about French literature. It is just as well, too, that they should adopt his point of view and not question his authority -- unless they really wish to make a serious study of the subject.
LONDON, May 2. -- The Athens correspondent of The Daily Mail will say to-morrow:

A man about thirty years old, who had registered as "Peter C. Burke, Philadelphia," at the Hotel Bartholdi, Broadway and Twenty-third Street, Thursday night, was found dead in his apartment on the third floor yesterday morning at 7:30 o'clock.
PITTSBURG, May 2. -- The immense wholesale grocery house of T.C. Jenkins Co., on Liberty Avenue, was destroyed by fire this evening and will be a total loss.

Notwithstanding the recent movement to remove the intercollegiate championship athletic games to Philadelphia, the contests will take place this season at Berkeley Oval May 28 and 29. The meeting this year promises to surpass any ever held. Colleges from the North, South, East, and West are sending strong delegations, and the events promise to be stubbornly contested.

Policeman McGlynn of the Leonard Avenue Police Station, Williamsburg, found Matali Ciscao, a nineteen-year-old Italian boy of 28 Throop Avenue, half crawling and staggering across a vacant lot near Bedford Avenue and Park Street last night. The boy held his hands across his abdomen, and was moaning as he went.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Mrs. George M. Pullman has in view an entertainment to raise money for charitable purposes. She has invited the members of the Milwaukee Board of Trade, who recently gave a minstrel performance in that city, to come to Chicago and repeat the entertainment at the theatre in her Prairie Avenue residence.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The postal operations of the world will pass in review before one of the most distinguished bodies that ever met in this country when the Universal Postal Congress convenes in this city next Wednesday. It is the first time that the Universal Postal Union, now comprising and controlling, so far as the mails are concerned, every organized Government save three -- China.

PITTSBURG, May 2. -- Before leaving Pittsburg on Saturday night, "Bob" Fitzsimmons let fall a few remarks about the sixth round of the battle at Carson, which plainly show that the new champion did in this particular round consider himself beaten. After the show on Saturday night, "Jimmy" McKnight and several other well-known people about town tendered the champion a little banquet at the Victoria.
PATERSON, N.J., May 2. -- Richard Darmstadt, a trolley car conductor, and the wife of Ernest Parteboeuf of Haledon are in the County Jail, each on a charge of bigamy.

Two scuttle thieves entered the residence of Samuel Jacobsen, at 54 East Sixty-fourth Street, on the afternoon of April 12, secured jewelry valued at $2,000, and escaped. The police have not made public the robbery, nor have they been able to capture the marauders, although they have been watching three suspected men ever since.

A fight is probable between the tile layers' helpers on one side and the tile layers and the employers on the other. The helpers asked for an advance of 25 cents a day, which has been refused, and for the restoration of the "improver" system, by which the helpers are allowed to do the work of cutting and laying tiles, as well as helping.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- During the past year Mr. Burke had been engaged as professor of Latin and philosophy in Georgetown College, Washington, where he had, up to a few weeks ago, acquitted himself with much credit and earned the respect and esteem of all who came in contact with him.

LONDON, May 2. -- There are numerous indications that the Ralli Ministry intends to assume greater direct military and naval control, and no longer to divide responsibility between the Ministry and the Court.

LONDON, May 2. -- A dispatch to The Times from Pentepigadia, dated Thursday, says that the Greeks are arming the population of the district, and have occupied Turkish territory, many villagers escaping through the Turkish line and joining the ranks of the Greeks.

The People's Choral Union and Singing Classes gave a concert last evening at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Frank Damrosch. They were assisted by two soloists, Heinrich Meyn, baritone; David Mannes, violin, and the New York Symphony Orchestra.

The congregation of the Church of Divine Paternity met yesterday morning for the first time in the Carnegie Lyceum, at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Charles E. Eaton's sermon was a reply to some recent criticisms on Universalism, uttered by Dr. Parkhurst. Dr. Eaton paid a compliment to the civic services of the critic, but said that his theology was not that of the advancedly intelligent.

At a recent meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at the Academy of Music, Dr. H.J. Boldt made an interesting address on the question of "State Intereference in the Administration of Anesthetics." After briefly reviewing the history of the use of anesthetics, especially of ether and chloroform, Dr. Boldt continued:
The stormy weather which set in Saturday continued yesterday, and with the fog and rain and a cold wind from the ocean Sunday was made miserably dreary.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 2. -- Mrs. Dwyer Jaycox of Jersey City was cut to pieces by a train last Monday night on the Hudson River Railroad at Barnegat. There was no suspicion of foul play at the time, but it has developed that Mrs. Jaycox had quite a sum of money with her, and her pocketbook has not been found.

Mayor Strong has appointed an advisory committee of citizens to co-operate with the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, in the work of the cultivation of vacant lots by the unemployed. This work will be continued this year on a wider scale than ever before.

The Wolcott Commissioners expect to sail this week. We do not agree with those who charge President MCKINLEY with duplicity in sending these Commissioners abroad to promote an international bimetallic agreement. We do not believe such an agreement to be possible. We regard it as a chimera. Mr. McKINLEY may differ from us on that, or he may be in accord with us.

ST. LOUIS, May 2. -- To-day's game was Contested brilliantly. It was witnessed by over 8,000 persons, A wild throw by Hartman gave Cleveland two runs. Hart and McDermott pitched splendid ball, but four hits being made off each delivery.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Senator Aldrich said this evening, just before the Finance Committee began what was expected to be an all-night session, that he hoped the Tariff bill would be reported to the whole committee by Tuesday. To one inquirer who talked with him in the afternoon, he expressed the hope that the bill would be under discussion in the Senate by May 17.

Only a few of the more venturesome oarsmen went out on the Harlem River yesterday, as the water was rough and choppy all day. Club members whiled away the hours in discussing the coming regatta and criticising the work of crews.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Senate will resume business in earnest Monday, and the week bids fair to be one of important results. According to agreement, a vote will be taken on the arbitration treaty on Wednesday. It is also quite probable that the committee vacancies will be filled and that the tariff bill will be reported to the committee.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 2. -- Particulars reached here to-day of a pitched battle near Eufaula, I.T., between cattle thieves and farmers residing in that vicinity. The cow punchers are said to be running off the farmers' stock at an alarming rate, and early this morning a drove was intercepted by the farmers, and an effort made to kill the five men in charge of the stock.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 2. -- Englewood now has two Board of Education. Both organized yesterday. The new board consists of Miss A.W. Sterling, Chairman; Charles Huckin, Secretary, and Joseph M. Cooper and Robert B. Taylor. The old board consists of Frank M. Demarest, President; Huyler Bogert, Secretary; Robert B. Taylor and Edward O'Hara. Both boards claim Mr. Taylor.

Controller ROBERTS has an article in the May number of The Forum in defense of the graduated, or progressive, tax upon the transfer of property by inheritance or by donation in anticipation of death, which has been provided for upon his recommendation in a bill now awaiting the approval of the Governor.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 2. -- Ex-Gov. Albert G. Porter is fatally ill at his residence in this city. Two years ago the venerable man sustained a severe fall, and since then he has been confined to his room almost constantly. Gov. Porter at the zenith of his career was a big factor in Republican politics in Indiana.
BUFFALO, May 2. -- John C. Sheehan, just before starting for New York to-night, made the prediction that Tammany Hall would elect its ticket in New York next Fall by 75,000 plurality.

A mass for the repose of the soul of Theodore A. Havemeyer was said yesterday in the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, Wythe Avenue and South Second Street, Williamsburg. The Rev. Sylvester Malone, pastor of the church, spoke of his dead friend, who had been a contributor to the church fund for the last thirty-two years.

GIBSON CITY, Ill., May 3. -- Another sensation, rivaling the H.H. Holmes butchery, has been developed in the conviction of Fred Hallmann for the murder of Mrs. Fred Geddes. It is believed, that this man is responsible for the death of six women, all of whom were strangled with a rope. Hallmann's supposed victims have all been Germans.
GALLUP, New Mexico, May 3. -- The foreclosure sale of the Atlantic and Pacific Railway Company took place here to-day, O.N. Marron, the Special Master, acting as auctioneer.

BERLIN, May 3. -- In the Reichstag to-day Count von Kanitz, the Agrarian leader, interpellated the Government on the subject of the new United States tariff. He asked if the Government wished to continue the agreement of 1891, and said the Dingley, bill implied less the increase of the American customs revenue than the successive expulsion of European imports from American markets.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

After attending a professional matinee of "My Friend from India" March 16, Walter A. Loeb suggested to Mabel Power, who was with him, that they get married. He was secretary to the firm of Zucker, Levett Loeb, manufacturers of electrical instruments on West Twenty-fifth Street. His father is a member of the firm, with a residence at the Hotel Endicott.

Senator JOHN P. JONES is a protectionist of the right stamp. He demands enormously high duties on the low-grade wools, the borax and the fruits of the Pacific slope States. Carpet men of the East, the fruit importers of New York and his associates on the Senate Finance Committee denounce his propositions as monstrous, and protest that his duties would be prohibitory and would ruin many established industries.

Dean W. Richmond, thirty-four years old, grandson of Dean Richmond, who was once President of the New York Central Railroad Company, died early yesterday in the St. Charles Hotel, 777 Sixth Avenue, presumably from injuries received by falling.
LONDON, May 3. -- The Times will print the following dispatch to-morrow from Velestino:

RICHMOND, Va., May 3. -- Jesse W. Clark, a well-known business man here, to-day had a narrow escape from death by hanging. He was on the free bridge between here and Manchester, watching some fishermen. An electric street car passed at the time. At the sound of the ringing of the motorman's gong Clark stepped to one side of the track.
" It's a pity to let the devil have all the good tunes," remarked the practical-minded parson as the choir finished a dull and droning hymn.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Possibly it was from noticing the unsuccessful attempts made by the would-be rainmakers in the United States to bring down showers when wanted that an ingenious Austrian grape-grower was induced to reverse the American practice. An account of his experiment is given by United States Consul Stephan, at Annaberg, in a report to the State Department.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 3. -- The Indianapolis Bar Association made another effort to-day to discipline Judge Baker of the Federal Court for peppery language used by him to ex-Attorney General Miller during the trial of the street railway receivership case, and because of words in connection with the defendants in the case, in which he was quoted as saying:

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- President McKinley informed Representative Northway of Ohio to-day that further Consular appointments, as a rule, would be postponed until after the adjournment of Congress. There may be appointments in exceptional cases from time to time, but the general policy of the President will be to defer this class of appointments until after the Tariff bill is passed and Congress has adjourned.
ALBANY, May 3. -- The first of the series of hearings to be held by Gov. Black on the bills under his consideration was given this morning at 11:30 o'clock.

A so-called "Exhibition of Fine Arts," comprising some 600 exhibits, oil paintings, water colors, black and whites, engravings, etchings, carved wood, decorated china, tapestries, statuary, , was opened last evening in the Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House. There was music by the Mexican National Band and a fair attendance.

If the Citizens' Union, which thus far shows rather a lagging disposition, will only get under way with a vigorous campaign, in advance of the other forces, the chances are that the fight this year will be between that independent body and Tammany. Then we shall have a real non-partisan contest for the control of the City Government.

A banquet was given to Gen. Horace Porter, President of the Union League Club, by his fellow-members, at Delmonico's last evening. Covers for about 240 persons were laid in the large dining room, which had for its decorations only the French and American flags, these referring to the guest's departure to-day as American Ambassador to France.

Representatives of the West End Association and the West Side Taxpayers' Association appeared before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday to oppose Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring's project of erecting a department stable on Eighty-ninth Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.
PITTSBURG, May 3. -- Fire last night destroyed $3,000,000 worth of property and caused the death of one fireman and injuries to four more.

The first championship game of the season in Brooklyn was played yesterday on grounds sticky with mud and under threatening skies. When the game started a drizzling rain was falling. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the 8,000 persons who filed into the grounds were not sorry they had braved the weather.

We regard the provisions of the Raines liquor-tax law with reference to liquor selling on Sunday as oppressive, discriminating, and outrageous, and as forced unjustly and unwisely upon the cities of the State by rural legislators who had no adequate conception of the effect of what they were doing.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Black has 783 bills left by the Legislature to dispose of in twenty days, and the morning and afternoon of two weeks of this time will be devoted to hearings on the most important of them, so that the Governor will of necessity be a very busy man until May 24, considering the aftermath of the Legislature.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 3. -- The opening day at Cumberland Park was bleak, cold, dreary, and forbidding, with rain threatening every hour- But these drawbacks did not prevent the attendance of a good crowd, exceeding 2,500 in number, notwithstanding the counter attraction of the exposition. The track was good and fast, the racing good and fully up to expectations in every respect.

In an editorial of May 2 you review the interesting article by Gen. Schofield in the May Century on his secret mission to France for the purpose of inducing the Emperor Louis Napoleon to evacuate Mexico. Gen. Schofield's article affords an apt illustration of the undisclosed means whereby important events are sometimes shaped.

Miss Nettie Wickham, a well-known teacher of elocution, was found dead yesterday morning in a room adjoining her studio, at 18 East Twenty-first Street. She was found by Mrs. Mills, an artist with a studio on an upper floor in the same house. Miss Wickham was fifty-three years old, and had been under medical care for kidney troubls for more than two years.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- President McKinley to-day sent to Congress a message concerning the lynching of three Italians at Hahnville, La., on the night of Aug. 8, 1896, named Salvatore Arena, Giuseppe Venturella, and Lorenso Solaridino. He recommends an appropriation for the heirs of the persons without admitting the liability of the United States in the premises.

Three services were held in Trinity Church yesterday. It was the second day of the bi-centenary exercises of the parish. All day the church was open to visitors, who lingered in the aisles to admire the decorations.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3. -- A Hindoo calling himself the Brahmacharin Bobhabhiskshu, nearly created a riot at the meeting of the Women's Congress by denouncing the women of the West as savages, and declaring that he had been insulted.

Never before had such a commotion been raised in this church. A cat did it; a long yellow, gaunt cat, a little dog, helped, and hysterical women and children, too, so that the services were badly disorganized and the excitement considerable.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 3. -- The assembly hall of the Woman's Building was the scene of a brilliant gathering to-day, it being the day set apart for the formal opening of the Woman's Building, which is one of the chief features of the Exposition.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The resignation of W. M. Aiken, Supervising Architect of the Treasury, has been asked for by Secretary Gage. No official announcement has yet been made.

Certainly the attitude of the Cretan insurgents is calculated to exasperate the Admirals who have the immediate responsibility of dealing with them. Considering that Greece has already been beaten, the proposition made on behalf of the powers is as liberal as could be expected, and would doubtless have been accepted at the outbreak of the rebellion.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- After a recess covering practically ten days, the Senate met to-day with a large accumulation of routine business and several important questions, including the Morgan Cuban resolution, awaiting attention. The attendance was unusually large, including Mr. Allison and other members of the Finance Tariff Sub-Committee.

The American Society of Civil Engineers has sold to Henry Steeger, for about $60,000, the four-story brownstone building 127 East Twenty-third Street. The society paid $30,000 for this house in 1881 and has used it as a clubhouse ever since. Mr. Steeger paid $46,000 in 1888 for the adjoining property, No. 129.
ATHENS, via Brindisi, Italy, May 3. -- The following dispatch to The Associated Press has been sent from Athens by way of Brindisi, in order to escape the censor:

PRETORIA, May 3. -- At the opening of the Raad to-day, after the adjournment, President Kruger, in a speech prepared evidently with great care, asked the Raad, as a token of sympathy with Queen Victoria and appreciation of her long and glorious reign, to declare June 22 Diamond Jubilee Day, an official holiday in the Transvaal.

LONDON, May 3. -- The chief points of interest in the situation to-night are: First, that the decision of the Ministers who have returned from the Greek frontier seems to be in favor of a continuance of the war; and, second, that fighting continued almost incessantly at Velestino from last Tuesday until Sunday, with the result that Gen. Smolenski has been prevented from actually assuming his new duties as Chief of Staff.

The Park Commissioners yesterday received, smiled at, and ordered placed on file a communication from President Hubbell of the Board of Education. Mr. Hubbell suggested that the Park Board set aside a plot of ground in Central Park on which the schoolboys might plant oats, wheat, barley, , and otherwise obtain a knowledge of the various seeds.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- In the House to-day Joseph B. Showalter, who was recently elected to represent the Twenty-fifth Pennsylvania District, to fill the place of the late James J. Davidson, took the oath of office.

It has been a satisfaction to me, as a constant reader of your columns, to note the invariable accuracy of detail that belongs to your notes of passing events. It is on that ground, and feeling also that you should not be accidentally misled while I can prevent it, that I offer to you a slight correction to your note under the above heading in your issue of Saturday last.

The police authorities are generally satisfied with the manner in which the excise law was enforced from midnight Saturday until yesterday morning. Deputy Chief Cortwright, who is in command in the absence of Chief Conlin, who is visiting Mrs. Conlin in the Adarondacks, said he considered the law had been properly observed.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The Republicans of the Finance Committee may not have a good Tariff bill to report to the Democrats of the committee, but whatever it is, they have so far kept it pretty well to themselves.

A very interesting programme was given at the meeting of Sorosis yesterday afternoon, in the Waldorf. Miss Antoinette B. Taylor sang. Mrs. Alice C. Hall gave an original recitation, after which Miss Myrta French sang "Chansen d'Avril," by Goring Thomas, and "A Dream," by J.C. Bartlett. Miss Henrietta C. Tuthill was accompanist.

A north-bound cable car -- No. 689 of the Columbus Avenue line -- struck a repair wagon belonging to the Metropolitan Traction Company about 8:30 o'clock last evening, about thirty feet north of the curve at Fifty-third Street and Ninth Avenue. The car was filled with passengers at the time, and many of them were thrown to the floor and more or less injured.

Directors of the newly incorporated Maurice Grau Opera Company met yesterday afternoon in the office of Edward Lauterbach, 22 William Street, for organization, election of officers, and discussion of the prospects of opera in America. Mr. Lauterbach, Robert Dunlap, Roland Knoedler, Henry Dazian, Charles Frazier, and B. Franklin de Frece were present, Maurice Grau being the only one of the incorporators absent.
Mayor Wanser of Jersey City yesterday vacated his office under protest, and was succeeded by Edward Hoos.

OSHKOSH, Wis., May 3. -- The Gleaner, winner of the pennant of the Massachusetts Yacht Racing Association in 1896, and with a record of fifty-one first prizes out of sixty-four starts, was placed aboard a train at Boston to-day, billed to L. Frank Gates, Oshkosh, Wis. This simply means that Mr. Gates has purchased a yacht which he thinks will be as invincible on Lake Winnebago as his iceboat, the Strus, proved last Winter.

The feature of the day's sport at Aqueduct yesterday was the succession of winnings on long shots of Jockey Powers. The boy has acquired a reputation for bringing in winners at long prices on the smaller tracks, and those of his followers who were faithful yesterday were well rewarded for their constancy.

The real trouble with tea and coffee drinking is not generally understood. It is common knowledge with every one that physicians advise the discontinuance of both tea and coffee when a person is sick, particularly when the digestive machinery is affected. Any person with a slight knowledge of chemistry can make the following experiments, securing the results as given.
The Citizens' Union is ready to put its ticket in the field as soon as Gov. Black signs or vetoes the Greater New York charter.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- The services in St. Mark's Episcopal Church Sunday morning were interrupted by sounds of revelry from the basement. The janitor, who went to investigate was greeted by a carrot and loud ha-has from seven tramps, who, unwashed, unshaved, and in rags, were dining on the chicken and the vegetables in season, using for a table the church communion table.

As our London correspondent has several times pointed out, it is quite impossible to explain the apathy with which Europe has regarded the recent procedures of Turkey without reference to "the Bourses." Turkey owes about $650,000,000, of which about $550,000,000 is in securities quoted on the European Exchanges. Greece owes about $130,000,000.

The Board of Walking Delegates yesterday passed a resolution stating that strikes were costly and detrimental to both employers and men, and requesting the Mason Builders' Association and the Building Trades to appoint a committee to meet a committee of the board, with a view of bringing about harmonious action between the employers and the building trades unions.

LONDON, May 3. -- The Standard's correspondent at Volo will say to-morrow that the Greek fleet is taking position to shell the heights of the defile leading to Macrinitza, in case the Turks succeed in turning the Greek flank and marching to Volo.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- The estimated gross earnings of the entire system of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company for the month of April, 1897, are $1,120,714, a decrease as compared with estimated earnings of April, 1896, of $40,337.

The Justices of Special Sessions decided yesterday, in disregard of the Raines law amendments, that they have no jurisdiction over cases of simple intoxication, and remanded a prisoner charged with that offense and committed to them for trial back to the City Magistrate's court.
There were more relic hunters at the Mayor's office yesterday looking for souvenir bricks from the temporary tomb of Gen. Grant.
CONSTANTINOPLE, May 4. -- Capt. Scriven of the American Embassy at Rome, has arrived here, en route for Thessaly to watch the operations.

President KRUEGER'S speech at the opening of the legislative session in the South African Republic was so studiously mild and conciliatory that the English followers of CECIL RHODES must be greatly disgusted with it. The suggestion to make a public holiday on the sixtieth anniversary of the Queen's accession must be especially repulsive to them.
The Journal of Commerce of to-day has a very elaborate editorial on "The Relative Returns of Labor and Capital." I wish to call particular attention to its summary in this paragraph:

Mayor Strong yesterday held public hearings on several bills. One was the bill legalizing the appointment of Isaac Tyson as park keeper and Roundsman on the park police force. Controller Fitch has held back Tyson's pay for some time because of alleged false statements in his civil service examination papers.

BERKELEY, Cal., May 4. -- A clock garden, whose flowers will tell the time of day, is being planned by Instructor H.A. Ouisterhout of the botanical division of the university. He proposes to cultivate such a garden on the university grounds, arranging the plants in dial form. The hours and half hours are to be indicated by the successive opening and closing of buds.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- In a day or two Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, will submit for inspection the summary of the imports and exports of the United States for the month of March, and for the nine months ending March 31, together with comparisons of the imports and exports of part of this year with last year and of March, 1896, with March, 1897.

PARIS, May 4. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press has had an interview with Miss Elsie Bushbeck of Philadelphia, who, with the Misses Hawthorn and Druer, was one of the few who escaped, although not unscathed. Miss Bushbeck said:

A story was told yesterday by a lawyer in the big Equitable Building of an experience that a brother of his, a blind man, had a few days since, while he was in the city from a small town in Jersey, where he resides. On the day mentioned, the blind man was without a guide and stood on the corner of Twenty-third Street and Broadway, wishing to cross the street.

The removal of Messrs. CLARK and HOTZ, Civil Service Commissioners, in Chicago by Mayor HARRISON is an act of vandalism. This is not a figure of speech; it is a moderate statement of plain truth. The ruling passion of the Vandal was greed of plunder, and that is Mayor HARRISON'S motive.

It is not only natural but just that proof should be demanded by the public for every statement or claim that is made to the public. When, therefore, it is asserted that a certain article is not only pure and palatable, and a most delightful beverage, but also that it possesses qualities almost invaluable for the human system, people are right in demanding the proof.
The Senate Finance Committee has made marked changes in the bill of which Mr. DINGLEY'S committee was so childishly proud.

WASHINGTON, My 4. -- The Tariff bill was reported to the Senate to-day, to the surprise of Senators and the public. When the Senate Finance Committee met to-day the idea prevailed that the bill would be held in committee for two days. All the members of the committee were present.

James R. Keene's colors were seen in front at Aqueduct yesterday for the first time this season, when Honeydew, the daughter of Kallicrates and Helena, spread-eagled her field in the fourth race, and galloped home a winner by two lengths. There were only four other starters, and none of them gave Honeydew any trouble at any stage of the four-and-a-half-furlong dash.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- The Tariff bill reported to the Senate to-day by the Finance Committee differs in many important respects from the bill which the House passed and sent to the Senate.

DENVER, Col., May 4. -- Articles of corporation of the Denver, Cripple Creek and Southern Railroad Company have been filed in the office of the Secretary of State, the incorporators being Charles T. Case and George S. Freeman of Colorado, Charles E. Funk of Chicago, Samuel L. Blake of Detroit, and Frank W. Corrigan of St. Louis.

STETTIN, May 4. -- The new twin-screw express steamer Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, sister ship of the Friedrich der Grosse, of the North German Lloyd Line, was launched here to-day in the presence of Emperor William of Germany.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- An absolute and positive refusal has been returned by the Canadian Pacific Road to the invitation extended it to become a member of the reorganized Western Passenger Association. The Canadian Pacific was a member of the old Transcontinental Association, and by virtue of its becoming a member, secured from the western roads a recognition of its differentials, via its Port Arthur route.

It does not now seem likely that the old cycle path on the Ocean Boulevard, leading from Prospect Park to Coney Island, will be repaired this year, as the Brooklyn wheelmen had fondly hoped. The path needs a new foundation very much, a fact which is indisputably attested to after a rain. Then it is that the wheels cut into the crust and disclose its weakness.

Influential representatives of wholesale houses in various lines of trade in this city met in the Merchants' Club, New York Life Building, yesterday, to effect a permanent organization for the purpose of attracting trade to New York. William F. King of Calhoun, Robbins Co. presided, and at his suggestion several merchants made statements regarding the business effects of Grant Day.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 4. -- Frederick W. Havemeyer has leased the "Old Brick Farm," the residence of Mrs. S.P. Taberwillets, about a mile from Roslyn Railroad Station, for a term of twelve years. With the lease goes the large colonial mansion and about twenty acres of ground. Mr. Havemeyer, it is understood, has the privilege of purchasing at the end of that period.

A. Bumiller lives at 20 First Avenue. Two years ago he took a trip to Florida, sailing on the Clyde Line steamship Cherokee. When off Charleston he dropped a sealed bottle overboard containing the following note:

The stockholders of the corporation of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, Limited, held a meeting yesterday afternoon and decided to give up all idea of operatic business for the future, to release Maurice Grau and John B. Schoeffel from their obligation not to enter the business on their own account, and to concentrate "the energies of the company toward managing and eventually making the best possible disposition of the Tremont Theatre, in Boston."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 4. -- The cellar of a house inhabited by human beings is a strange place for wild beasts to make their home, but it has happened far back in the hills near Sunol, Alameda County, where Antonio Nunez, a farmer, lives with his family.

OLEAN, N.Y., May 4. -- In accordance with a resolution introduced by Senator Quay, the investigation of the manner in which leases for oil well operations were obtained from the Seneca tribe of Indians has been begun here. P.E. McCormack, a representative of the Interior Department, by shrewd examination of witnesses elicited the information that irregular methods were employed.

The Baltimore team defeated the Brooklyn yesterday at Eastern Park in the second game of the series. With the closely played tie game of Monday in mind, the enthusiasts were early at the grounds. There were about 5,000 spectators on the grounds when the game began, at 4 o'clock.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Everett F. Martin, son of Police Commissioner A.P. Martin, and the one who figured prominently in the recent investigation by Gov. Wolcott into the alleged irregularities of Gen. Martin in being engaged in business while holding the office of Police Commissioner, has filed a voluntary petition in insolvency in the Suffolk Registry.

It was the talk in Wall Street yesterday that Jerome B. Wheeler must have had some intimation that the highest court in Colorado would sustain the judgment of $750,000 obtained against him in litigation about the possession of the Aspen Mine, and which resulted, Monday, in the closing of two banks owned by him -- one in Aspen and the other at Manitou, Col.

MACON, Ga., May 4. -- Elijah Morton will be executed at McRae, Ga., on the 21st of this month for killing four persons near that place. These are only a few of his victims. He is now in the Bibb County Jail for safe keeping.

Barney McDonald, an iron molder, of 15 Second Street, who is employed by the Manhattan Rolling Company, 362 Avenue A, was taken to Bellevue Hospital shortly after noon yesterday, suffering from burns received in a fight at the mill with Richard Garretty, thirty years old, of 442 East Twenty-first Street, a fellow-workman.

An outward bound steamship, the name of which could not be learned, crashed into a Brooklyn Wharf and Terminal Company's float and a tug off Robbins Reef last night. One of the tugboat men was drowned. The float and tug were badly damaged, and two box cars were demolished.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union decided unanimously at its meeting on Monday night that a ticket should be put in the field as soon as practicable after the Greater New York charter has been either signed or vetoed, so that it may be definitely known what nominations are to be made.
The Ladies' Health Protective Association met yesterday in the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street. Owing to the absence of the President, Mrs. Henry J. Newton presided.

In yesterday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES you make mention of the curious fact that "the kingfisher bores holes six feet deep in the levees of the Mississippi River and builds nests therein," contributing in this way to the crevasses and destructive floods.

The Gilbert Manufacturing Company, wholesale dealer in cotton goods at 380 Broadway, corner of White Street, made an assignment yesterday to Sidney Sargent, without preference to any one. The deed of assignment was signed by Orlando P. Dorman, President, and Frank H. Gilbert, Secretary-Treasurer.

Paymaster L.G. Boggs of the navy yard yesterday opened the sealed bids for the purchase of an immense quantity of condemned stores belonging to the department. The proposals were opened in the presence of a large number of persons, most of whom were junk dealers who had entered bids for the stores.

PARIS, May 4. -- Fire broke out at 4 o'clock this afternoon in a crowded charitable bazaar in the Rue Jean-Goujon, at which the Duchess d'Uzes and other well-known patronesses were in charge. Fifteen hundred people were present. Many were burned to death, and there was a terrible panic, during which a large number of persons were injured.

The City Magistrates have decided to disregard the provision of the amended Raines law which makes intoxication in a public place a misdemeanor which must be tried before the Court of Special Sessions. The reason given is that to carry out the law would be "against public policy," as it would be "manifestly unjust" to compel a person arraigned for intoxication to furnish bail or be kept in the Tombs awaiting trial.

PARIS, May 4. -- Another version of the origin of the fire is as follows: There was a nun at the stall of the Duchess d'Uzes, who lighted a spirit lamp under a toy balloon, which took fire, the flames then speedily connecting with the drapery. The first terrible fact realized was the absence of water.

An interesting topic which will come before the approaching International Postal Congress is that of a universal postage stamp, or at least a stamp that can be used in common by the leading commercial nations. Such a postage stamp would be a great convenience for making small remittances abroad and for inclosing to prepay return letters.

Yesterday's stock market was more active than has been the rule for some time past, though even with the increased transactions shown the volume of business did not reach totals indicative of the improvement for which Wall Street has been so much hoping. The extension of business was, very apparently, for professional account. Public interest was not displayed more than lately has been the rule.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 4. -- William Moore is the name given by a man locked up here to-night. Three months ago William Moore, a wealthy shoe dealer of Rochester, N.Y., disappeared and took with him about $5,000 of his own money. He is a well-known Mason, but has not yet been located.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 4. -- Capt. Henry Romeyn of the Fifth Infantry, whose court-martial on serious charges has just been concluded at Fort McPherson, has accepted a post under the Chilean Government. Its exact nature is not known. The Captain said this afternoon:

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 4. -- Louis Vatt, three years old, living with his parents at 33 Washington Avenue, found a box of matches this afternoon and carried them into the yard back of his home to play with. He set his clothes on fire. His mother, Ellen Vatt, and Mrs. Lena Cass, a neighbor, ran to his assistance in response to his screams.

On the one excursion north of MASON and DIXON'S line which JOHN RANDOLPH of Roanoke permitted himself in the course of a reasonably long and unreasonably cantankerous existence he ordered the waiter at a tavern to "change his cup." The minion inquired whether he desired tea or coffee.
Judge Wauhope Lynn, sitting in the First District Civil Court, has rendered a decision in the case of John A. Stewart against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4. -- The Directors of the Glen Mary Coal Mining Company, which operates extensive mines at Glen Mary, Tenn., met here at 4 o'clock this afternoon and decided on a general reduction of 10 per cent. in salaries and wages, including everybody employed by the company from the President down.

" You think the clergy don't amount to much!" exclaimed the Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford before a great congregation in Trinity Church at noon yesterday, the third day of the bi-centennial exercises of Trinity Parish.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- In the Senate to-day a resolution by Mr. Allen of Nebraska was agreed to asking the President for information as to the work accomplished by the Venezuelan Commission.

LONDON, May 5. -- The Paris correspondent of The Daily News says: "The flames licked most of those who escaped, and the dresses were burned off the backs of their wearers, who tore off their blazing hats as they rushed for the street, their heads singed to the roots of their hair. The clothing not burned off was literally torn off.

If the West End Association does not look out it will become known as the representative of "incivism" in New York. It is really necessary to the permanent efficacy of a body of holders of real estate interested in "booming" a particular part of the town that their counsels should be animated or at least restrained by common sense.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4. -- The second day at the Kentucky Association course found a larger attendance, but wretched weather and a sloppy track. Arcturus was the only favorite to win. The starts were all good, except in the second race.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 4. -- Gov. Black started his task of signing the thirty-day bills to-day, and as a result of his labors three new laws were created, only one of which is of general importance. This one is Mr. Nixon's bill providing that railroad companies shall not mortgage their property without the consent of stockholders owning two-thirds of the stock.

Senator CHANDLER has the sense to propose that the Secretary of the Treasury shall be authorized to borrow, up to $50,000,000, on 3 per cent. three-year certificates, at any time to meet a temporary deficiency.

F.M. Hoyt's racing sloop yacht Syce, which was built at Wood's Yard, City Island, from designs by Gardner Cox, was successfully launched yesterday afternoon. The Syce is the first of the new boats that are to race in the fifty-one-foot class during the coming season. The dimensions of the yacht are 69 feet length over all, 45 feet on the water line, 12 feet 6 inches extreme beam, and 10 feet 3 inches draught.

BARCELONA, May 4. -- Five of the Anarchists convicted of participation in the bomb outrage of June 7 last at the feast of Corpus Christi were shot this morning outside Fort Montjuich. They shouted "Long live Anarchyi" just before the order to fire was given.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 5. -- The racing at Cumberland Park to-day was attended by 2,500 people. The contest in the handicap was one of the most brilliant events ever seen in this city. Buck Massie won in a driving fininsh by a head. The track was fast, and the weather was good. Summaries:
PARIS, May 5. -- The following is a list of the dead and injured by the fire in the Grand Bazar de Charite.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5. -- At the annual meeting of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern stockholders, held this morning, the Board of Directors submitted its twenty-seventh annual report. The report included the operations during the fiscal year which ended Dec. 31, 1896.

The final game of the series between Baltimore and Brooklyn was played yesterday. From the Brooklyn rooters' viewpoint it was the best of the three. Superb pitching by Kennedy, brilliant work by the fielders, and an ability to hit Pond at opportune moments contributed to a victory for the Brooklyn team.

The New Bedford Line steamship City of Fitchburg, which arrived yesterday, brought in four seamen and a boy who had been taken from the schooner yacht Telfer, which the City of Fitchburg raw down and sank at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning off Faulkner's Island, near the Connecticut coast.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 5. -- Contrary to expectations no dispensary arrests were made to-day, the Attorney General holding back, it is understood, until some more necessary affidavits are obtained. He had a number of sworn statements in hand this morning, which, when he was prevailed upon to give them out for publication, went to show that shocking, irregularities have been practiced.

The Yale University golfers yesterday wiped out their defeat of last Saturday by the Staten Island Cricket Club by an excellent victory over the team of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club of Brooklyn. The match was the last the Yale boys will play until they meet four other colleges next week on the links of Ardsley Casino, near Dobbs Ferry.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 5. -- In a box car on a north-bound freight train on the Hudson River Railroad Detectives Furlong and Albertson to-night arrested three tramps, who were armed with the worst looking collection of murderous instruments ever exposed in Police Headquarters. They had between them two loaded pistols, a bright, new axe, ground to an edge; a dirk, sharp as a razor, and a new leather cigar case filled with pepper.

HAVANA, May 5. -- Captain General Weyler arrived yesterday at Cienfuegos, Province of Santa Clara, coming by rail from Ysabela, where he landed from the Spanish cruiser Pizarro on Monday, going thence by train to Sagua. He only remained there three hours, and then pushed on by rail to Cienfuegos.
There are two ways of increasing the profit of manufactures -- to raise the selling price or to lower the cost.

The Rainy Day Club devoted itself yesterday to the pleasant task of appeasing "the press" and the consideration of missionary work along club lines. The meeting was held at the Murray Hill Hotel, and although the skies smiled, there were the average number of rainy-day gowns out -- about half a dozen.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Universal Postal Congress met to-day in the old Corcoran Art Gallery. Fifty-five countries, comprising most of those in the Postal Union, were represented. Korea, China, and the Orange Free State, which are now outside the pale of the union, had delegates present. It is expected that the work of the congress will extend over about six weeks.

Almost in the first sentence of his address in commemoration of Jubilee Day at "Old Trinity" yesterday, Bishop Potter, who was the orator of the occasion, touched the keynote of the celebration. He said that it was a remarkable illustration of the "pace" of New York.
PARIS, May 5. -- M. Dieudonne, the secretary of Baron Mickau, the President of the bazaar, during the course of an interview is quoted as saying:
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The President has announced the following nominations to the Senate to-day:
WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Republican Senators held a caucus to-day and adopted the report of the Committee on Committees. The important changes are as follows:
LONDON, May 5. -- Mrs. George Linnaeus Banks, poet and novelist, is dead.

At an executive meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners, held after the regular meeting had adjourned, Commissioner Frank Moss was yesterday made President of the board. His election was made possible by the action of Col. Grant, who withdrew his own name as a candidate, and, after an explanatory statement in which he declared the present condition of affairs in the board intolerable, moved that Mr. Moss be elected.

Compared with the activity displayed on Tuesday, yesterday was a disappointment to Stock Exchange interests. The boom which seemed approaching withdrew of a sudden. Buoyancy disappeared; in place of Tuesday's firmness, Wednesday's transactions were by contrast surprisingly weak. Operators conspicuously identified with what was hoped might develop into permanent improvement do not hesitate to express their feeling of disappointment, though many of them still insist that the market's most substantial tendencies are upward.

TRENTON, April 24. -- Rancocas has a population of a little more than 300 people. The population varies little from year to year, for few die and few move away. For over three years the undertaker has had nothing to do in the line of his calling.

Frank Damrosch was appointed Supervisor of Music to the public schools at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education. The Board of Superintendents preferred another name, but the Committee on Instruction disregarded its report and selected Mr. Damrosch. The salary of the place is $4,000.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The new Senator from Kentucky, W.J. Deboe, was on the floor of the Senate to-day. Accompanied by Senator Lindsay, he entered the Chamber and held an improptu levee in the rear of the Republican side, afterward taking the oath of office. A towering bouquet was placed on his desk, which adjoins that of Mr. Hanna.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5. -- W.B. McConville, a jeweler, doing business of 372 Broad Street, notified the police this evening that burglars had entered his apartments on the second floor of the building at that address, his store being located on the street floor, and stolen jewelry valued at $25,000.

Machinery and the way the capitalist looks down upon those who labor for him, says Bishop POTTER, "are the great causes of the general ill feeling and uneasiness among the laboring classes." The chief of these two is machinery, says the Bishop:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 5. -- The Arkansas State Senate at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon, by a vote of 16 to 14 defeated the Jones-Amacker Railroad Commission bill. Their action has surprise Gov. Jones, who convened the Legislature in extraordinary session April 26 for the express purpose of passing the very bill which the Senate today killed. When asked to-night what he thought of the action of the Senate Gov. Jones said:

There was a decided falling off in the attendance at Aqueduct yesterday, as compared with the first two days of the week. The weather and track conditions were all that could be desired but the fields in the majority of the races were rather small, and did not promise good chances for speculation.

The Greater New York charter has been signed by the Governor, and its going into effect is now as inevitable as the flight of time. The beginning of the year 1898 will witness the consolidation into one municipality under a single government of the commercial community on the Bay of New York, which numbers three millions of people and will become the second city in the world in population and wealth.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Driving Club of New York held yesterday at the Commercial Club, it was decided to hold the opening meeting at Fleetwood Park on May 22. The classes will be as follows: 2:15 trotting, amateur class, open to members, road wagons, bicycle wheels barred, best two in three, for a silver cup.
As you are probably aware, there is to be a general meeting of the International Postal Union at Washington in May next.

Owing to alleged misunderstanding of signals the steam yacht Penelope yesterday came in collision with the monitor Terror. The yacht lost her foretopmast and a considerable section of her starboard bulwarks. The monitor sustained slight injuries.

PARIS, May 5. -- A sombre feeling pervades every class of society. The newspapers, without exception, describe the disaster in the sober and simple terms befitting so appalling an event. The catastrophe will always be remembered as one of the most fearful that ever befell a European city.

Throughout Wall Street no name is better known than of S.V. White. As one of the veteran financiers of the Street his opinion is widely respected. At the present time Mr. White is bullish as to the eventual outcome of the situation. For the moment, however, he does not look for any substantial upward movement. In talking with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, Mr. White said:

ATLANTA, Ga., May 5. -- At the trial of the thirteen physicians charged with the serious offense of having their names and pictures in the newspapers, a change in the interpretation of the rules governing professional actions and ethics was practically agreed upon.
LONDON, May 6. -- The Athens correspondent of The Daily Mail says:
BERLIN, May 5. -- It is semi-officially denied that the Imperial Chancellor, Prince Hohenlohe, has resigned. The Prince was received in audience this morning by Emperor William.

Attention is called in this week's bulletin of the Racing Board to the by-law relating to college meets. Owing to the application for sanctions from many colleges the Chairman of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen deemed it best to call special attention to the rule relating to the conduct of tournaments and competitors.

M. L. Hess have sold for Elias Kempner, for $55,000, the lot, with old building, 7 Great Jones Street, about 175 feet east of Broadway, 25 by 100. The buyer is a builder who will immediately improve the property by the erection of an eight-story manufacturing building.

The State Railroad Commissioners met in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday morning and gave a public hearing in the matter of the application of the New York and Harlem Railroad Company and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for the approval by the board of the substitution for horse power of an underground current of electricity as a motive power on the Fourth and Madison Avenue Street Railroad.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

We observe with interest that some of our esteemed contemporaries and their correspondents are pained because, in decorating Trinity Church for the two-hundredth anniversary of the parish, use has been made of "coats of arms."

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 5. -- Robert M. Fulton of 416 Marshal Street was buried Sunday afternoon. At 1 o'clock the Rev. Father J. J. Smith, pastor of the Holy Rosary Church, conducted services according to Catholic rites. An hour later the Rev. M. Trout of the Methodist Church conducted services over the body.

Joseph Pesek and a number of companions were playing "tag" on the dock at the foot of East Seventieth Street yesterday afternoon. In his eagerness the eight-year-old lad stumbled over the string-piece and fell into the water.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Prof. Edouard Von Holst of the Chicago University, says his friend Prof. Von Schroen of Naples University has discovered that life exists in crystals heretofore supposed to be inorganic. Prof. Von Hoist says Herbert Spencer has investigated the theory and pronounced it sound.

ALBANY, May 5. -- Gov. Black signed the Greater New York charter at 9 o'clock this morning. The charter takes effect on Jan. 1, 1898, and the officers to have charge of the greater municipality will be elected in November this year.

The Senators from Havemeyer are always at the post of duty. Their names change, and their politics. Three years ago they were Democrats. Now the great sugar principality's chief representative is a Republican.

One of the best-known landmarks of the vicinity of New Rochelle, the old Col. Lathers mansion, in Winyah Park, took fire in some unknown manner and was burned to the ground, with its contents, early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The Senate today by the vote of 43 to 26 refused to ratify the general arbitration treaty between the United States and Great Britain negotiated by Secretary Olney and Sir Julian Pauncefote. The two-thirds vote prevails in the Senate as to the ratification of treaties. Hence four more affirmative votes would have been required to secure a favorable result. The vote in detail was as follows:

The legislative committee that has been investigating the affairs of Philadelphia with special reference to charges of corrupt doings in the City Council has just rendered a report to the Senate at Harrisburg. It contains some points of interest to people in New York.

LONDON, May 6. -- The Daily Chronicle publishes an interview which its Paris correspondent has had with William L. Hogan, whose sister, Margaret Hogan, was one of the four ladies assisting at the stall of the Duchesse d'Alencon, and the only one who escaped. Miss Hogan is a niece of Mayor Strong of New York.

ATHENS, May 6. -- A collective note will be handed to the Greek and Turkish Governments this evening or to-morrow, calling upon them to cease hostilities, on the distinct assurance that the powers will undertake the final solution of pending difficulties.

HAVANA, May,6. The Spanish cruiser Maria Cristina has captured, at the mouth of the Mosquito River, four lighters of American construction. They had apparently been used in the landing of a filibustering expedition. The troops ashore captured sixty-three boxes of cartridges belonging to the filibusters.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners held a conference yesterday with residents and property owners of the Boulevard at the office of the Commissioners. All members of the board were present except John H. Starin and the Mayor and Controller.
Bishop Potter will sail for Europe to-morrow on the Cunard liner Lucania. He will remain abroad until the month of August, spending most of his time in England.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 6. -- Excise Commissioner Lyman to-day ruled that an all-night certificate, issued to the holder of a liquor-tax certificate only authorizes traffic in the place specified in the existing certificate, or in a place to which such certificate has been lawfully transferred.
Your editorial comment upon Col. Grant's action in breaking the "deadlock" over the election of a President for the Police Board strikes a jarring note that it is to be hoped was not intended.

Several of our leading architects are in simultaneous trouble for two unrelated if not actually contradictory reasons. One is that there was a competition for a Court House at Paterson, and the other is that there was not a competition for the Hall of Records in this city.

District Attorney Olcott paid his respects to Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring in a very lively way at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Col. Waring was in the Mayor's office at the opening of the meeting, but left before Mr. Olcott began to hurl criticisms at him.

The Council of the Archaeological Institute of America will hold its annual meeting to-morrow morning at Columbia University. The members of the council are chosen by the affiliated societies of the institute, and come from Boston, New York, Chicago, and other cities of the United States. Prof. John William White of Harvard is the President of the institute.

On several occasions recently the electric lights on the Hudson Boulevard in Jersey City have gone out at unexpected times. Once the dynamos at Snake Hill were burned out, and the road was in darkness for several nights. An investigation was made, the result of which was announced yesterday.

Those were very interesting as well as very vigorous remarks which Dr. RAINSFORD made from the pulpit of Old Trinity on Tuesday. The gist of them we take to be, not merely that Trinity is fortunate in having an endowment which dispenses her ministry from paying overmuch attention to "the pews," but also that it would be fortunate for the community if a like system prevailed generally.

Chief Conlin yesterday assigned Inspector W.W. McLaughlin, restored to active service by the Police Board Wednesday after more than two years' suspension, to take charge of the Fifth Inspection District. Acting Inspector Walter Thompson, who has had charge there for the past five months, was sent to the First District, replacing Acting Inspector O'Keefe, who, on the advice of his friends, applied to be sent to the command of a precinct.

One of the largest annual meetings of the New York Chamber of Commerce of recent years was held yesterday afternoon in the Chamber of Commerce at 32 Nassau Street. Over 300 members, it is estimated, were present. The cause of the large assemblage was the proposal for a permanent home for the Chamber and the election of officers for the ensuing year.

Miss Frances E. Willard, President of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, was to speak last night on "A White Life for Two," but she utilized her feminine privilege of changing her mind at the last moment, and talked about the defeat of the arbitration treaty and the Senators who cast the votes against confirmation.

There was a long controversy in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon over the bill abolishing the Board of Examiners in the Building Department and substituting in its place a board of appeal, to consist of seven persons. Ex-Judge Henry E. Howland favored the bill and led the fight for it, and Gen. Wager Swayne, representing the present Board of Examiners, led the fight against it.

Trinity's bi-centennial celebration was continued yesterday. The church was well filled by 9 o'clock, when morning prayer was offered. Hundreds of those who were then present remained awhile around the old churchyard, until the noonday services were about to begin. Then they swelled the throng within the doors of Trinity again.

Yesterday saw the completion of the building of the first caisson to be used in the building of the New York pier of the new East River bridge. Its launching may be delayed for several days, and meanwhile preparations are making for the proper celebration of the event.
As the result of a meeting of the Standing Committee of the diocese, yesterday, two plans for the consolidation of Episcopal parishes in this city have been blocked.

One fireman was suffocated last night and nearly fifty of his comrades were more or less seriously affected by smoke in attempting to effect his rescue from the cellar of burning building in Chambers Street.

CHICAGO, May 6. -- George S. Thomas, Chief of the Banking Department of the State office, told the special Grand Jury some facts about the report on the Globe Savings Bank, which were held back for two months by ex-Bank Examiner Hayden. Mr. Thomas's story placed the latter in a very bad light, and evidently impressed the jury.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- T.S. Sharretts, President of the Board of United States General Appraisers at New York, who has been summoned to Washington to advise the Senate Committee on Finance in relation to the Tariff bill, was asked to-day for an opinion in regard to the merits of the amended bill as a revenue producer, and in reply said:
SAN FRANCISCO, May 6. -Monroe Salisbury, the well-known horsemen, has been declared insolvent by the Superior Court of Alameda County.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 6. -- The annual meeting of the Elyton Company which founded Birmingham was held here to-day. James T. Woodward, President of the Hanover National Bank of New York; Dr. B.J. Baldwin, W.M. Bolling of Montgomery, J.K. McDonald, and Alexander T. London of Birmingham were elected Directors, the number of which was reduced from seven to five.

LONDON, May 6. -- The annual meeting of the Primrose League took place to-day at Mbert Hall. There was a large attendance of members and the galleries were crowded. rhe platform was handsomely decorated xviLh flags and flowers. .qmong those present were the Dukes of Marlborough, Leeds, and Norfolk. and many eminent peers and members of the House of Commons.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 6. -- L.J. Williams, a member of the Slate Board of Control, to-night swore out warrants against S.W. Scruggs, Chief Clerk of the dispensary, and Col. John T. Gaston; ex-Commissioner of the dispensary. This is the result of investigations by the Attorney General, the testimony showing that Scruggs had taken from a trunk which was seized by constables four boxes of cigars and several cans of peaches.
J.B. Ketcham has sold for the Hawkins estate, for $60,000, the two three-story brownstone front flats, with stores, 50 and 52 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, each 15.7 1/2 by 60 by 100.11.

DETROIT, Mich., May 6. -- The annual meeting of the Michigan Central Railroad Company held to-day was attended by Cornelius Vanderbilt, William K. Vanderbilt, Henry B. Ledyard, E.D. Worcester, Dr. Seward Webb, H. McK. Twombley, and others. Secretary Worcester had the usual proxies, and the Directors and officers were re-elected.

That the way of the transgressor is hard was impressed upon John Ryan of 345 East Twenty-sixth Street yesterday. He met Mrs. Rosa Meyer in her flat at 1,328 First Avenue. He had been engaged in robbing the place when she came in, and it was his experience with her which has converted him.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 6. -- James McCrea, First Vice President of the Pennsylvania Company, denies the story that he is after the old Northern Pacific Railroad, and to-day says:

PARIS, May 6. -- The question of responsibility for the fire in the Grand Charity Bazaar In the Rue Jean Goujon is engaging the attention of public officials and the newspapers. Some very rigid Investigations will be instituted, and nothing will be left undone to place the blame. That such a ctastrophe could happen in any other large city in the world seems quite impossible, and Paris feels keenly her reproach and shame.

The admirable address of Mr. SCHURZ on the Civil Service bill made to Gov. BLACK yesterday was full of the highest respect for the office of Governor; in the actual occupant of that office it must have inspired conflicting feelings.

Scratches from the events originally carded reduced the fields at Aqueduct to such an extent yesterday that it did not seem to be a hard matter to pick at least a couple of winners. The scratching was accounted for by the fact that to-morrow the scene of racing will shift to Morris Park, and the trainers are anxious to have their charges safely quartered at the Westchester track before the opening day.
The Senate Finance Committee has made the crockery and china schedule of the tariff a deliberate and cruel imposition on the poorer classes.

I The Metropolitan Handicap, the first of the important Spring: handicaps, which will be decided at the opening of the Westchester Racing Association meeting at Morris Park to-morrow, has been the all-absorbing topic r of conversation in racing circles during the j past lew weeks. Under the present coridii tions of the contest, the race should prove much more interesting than heretofore.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 6. -- The National Festival of the North American Gymnastic Union (Turnerbund,) which is held quadrennially, opened here to-day. August H. Megge acted as Grand Marshal of the parade, which was escorted by a platoon of mounted police.

The Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island held a ladies' meeting last night at the Hotel Savoy, which was devoted to a discussion of local political questions. A reception and business meeting were followed by a dinner at 7 o'clock, and after the dinner several speeches were made upon municipal politics, "bossism," and the Citizens' Union.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In the Senate to-day a resolution by Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts was agreed to requesting the President to furnish information relative to outrages on Italians in Louisiana, for which compensation had been suggested by the Executive.

Steps were taken yesterday by the Board of Fire Commissioners of Long Island City toward abolishing tile present paid Fire Department and adopting the Buffalo system, which is practically a volunteer department. The expenses of the Long Island force has for some time been in excess of the appropriation, and the Common Council, which is in opposition to .Mayor Gleason, has refused to aid him in his efforts to meet the deficiency.

After litigation lasting since early in 1893, the American Surety Company of 100 Broadway yesterday received notice of a decision by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, affirming a judgment in its favor of $323,909.99, with accumulated interest since July 1, 1893. The total amount involved is in round figures $375,000.

PARIS, May 6. -- The remains of the Duehesse d'Alengon was placed in a coffin this afternoon in the presence of 'Prince Louis and Prince Ferdinand of Bavaria, Baron Lambert and Col. de Percival, who signed their names on the sealed coffin. The Duc de Vendome, son of the deceased Duchesse, was also present.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 6. -- Mrs. Theodore Lemke of 13 Chestnut Street, Montclair, died yesterday, without medical attendance, and it is alleged that the woman deliberately starved herself to death. For the last two weeks, it is alleged, she had refused to touch a morsel of food. Mrs. Lemke's husband is engaged in business in New York. It is believed the woman was not in her right mind.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- President McKinley, according to good authority, cherishes the belief entertained by the Ways and Means Committee that the Senate Tariff bill will be amended greatly before it becomes law. Mr. Dingley visited the President to-day and had a long talk with him, and since then a number of Republican members of the House have talked with more positiveness than ever about the inadmissibility of the Senate bill in many particulars.
The vote of Greater New York consists of the vote of the present Cities of New York and Brooklyn, about three-fifths of that of Queens County, and all that of the County of Richmond.
We judge that the arbitration treaty was beaten because England is a gold standard country and because it was negotiated by GROVER CLEVELAND and RICHARD OLNEY.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In the House to-day Chaplain Couden gave thanks for "the good tidings from our Iowa brother," referring to Gen. Henderson, whose recovery from a serious illness is reported.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 6. -- Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn signed his approval of the Greater New York charter and returned it to the Assembly. That signature becomes a part of the certified record in connection with the bill, but, strange to say, when the measure, with Gov. Black's signature, was filed to-day, it was discovered at the Secretary of State's office that Mayor Wurster's signature of approval was missing.
DURHA.%{, AIay 6. -- Eleven men have been drowned through an inflow of water into the ICclloe Colliery.

LONDON, May 6. -- The afternoon newspapers are bitter at the rejection of the arbitration treaty by the United States Senate. The St. James's Gazette publishes a long article headed "Free Trade and Brotherly Love," during which it says:
