WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Senator Platt's dissatisfaction with the make-up of the Senate committees is not so deep as the dispatches sent from here yesterday indicated. He has five committee places. He is Chairman of the Committee on Transportation Routes to the Seaboard, this place giving him the services of a clerk and a good committee room in which to attend to his correspondence.

The selection and care of a library constitute a subject that always interests a large class. The original cost is not the main consideration with the average person. A man who wants books for the gratification of his tastes, or one who needs what may be called a working library, be he rich or poor, accumulates slowly, and the question of expense does not appear to be a serious one.

LONDON, May 7. -- At to-day's racing of the Newmarket Spring meeting, Lord Rosebery's bay filly Chelandry won the One Thousand Guineas Stakes by two lengths, a length and one-half separating the second and third horses. The event is of 100 sovereigns each for three-year-old fillies, the owner of the second filly to receive 200 sovereigns out of the stakes, and the third horse to save his stakes.

One sees the fervor of the archaeologist when Prof. Mahaffy, considering the chances of finding remnants of former greatness, writes: "A splendid chance of searching underground Alexandria occurred after the bombardment of 1884, when numbers of houses were ruined, and when pits and trenches could have been dug without any protest or difficulty." The professor adds, deploringly: "But, as usual, the admirable opportunity was neglected."

The Synod of the Holland Reformed Church, in session at Jamaica, has undertaken to read out of existence a nominal congregation of that church at 279 West Eleventh Street. The building looks like an ordinary dwelling, but a stone set into the well over the front door describes it in Dutch as a church of the Holland Reformed Church, founded in 1876.

As C.F. Merriss lay dead in his room, on the third floor of 680. Broadway, yesterday morning, his only son, a married man, looked on his face with interest and curiosity. The young man had never before seen his father, to know him, although one of them had been living in Brooklyn and the other in New York for years.

-- Rarely has an appeal to American intelligence had a more unsatisfactory result than that which has come from the request made some weeks ago by The Little Rock Gazette for an answer to the question "What is news?" The inquiry was addressed to students in the public and private schools, colleges, and universities of Arkansas, and The Gazette offered a fivedollar gold piece for the best reply.

Thomas H. Stout, who fled from this city five years ago after committing forgeries aggregating about $40,000, gave himself up yesterday morning at the District Attorney's office. He was kept in the detectives' room during the afternoon, while indictments were being found and bail was being arranged for, and late in the evening the bail not being forthcoming, he was taken to Police Headquarters and locked up for the night.

ATHENS, May 7. -- The Greek fleet at Volo has been instructed not to hinder the entrance of the Turks, in order to save the town from destruction. The Consuls have decided to ask the foreign warships to land detachments, and have promised to protect the town.

Mayor Strong was very much astonished yesterday afternoon to learn that telegrams just received from Albany stated that Gov. Black had signed the graded reduction Gas bill. He had arranged for a public hearing on the bill, holding that it is a local law, at 2:30 P.M., and was sitting in front of about thirty empty chairs, awaiting arguments pro and con.

LEROY, N.Y., May 7. -- The will of William Lampson was presented for probate to-day by Butler Ward, one of the executors, in the Surrogate's Court at Batavia. Judge North appointed June 28 as the day for probate. The amount of the estate is not known.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners are making strenuous efforts to secure the consent of the requisite proportion of property owners to the construction of the underground railroad upon the routes and according to the plans heretofore adopted. In order to expedite the process it has called upon the property owners on various portions of the line to hold meetings and agree to give their consent so as to avoid the long and tedious process of canvassing.

PARIS, April 27. -- The dominant tone in the annual exhibition of the works of French artists in the Champ de Mars resembles that of the rival salon in the Champs Elysees in one respect, and that is an unexpressed and half-formed conviction on the part of exhibitors that no great effort of genius is necessary in a salon doomed to demolition.

PARIS, May 7. -- The Duc d'Aumale expired at 2 o'clock this morning in his villa at Zucco, Sicily, of cardiac apoplexy. Death was caused by hearing of the death of the Duchesse d'Alencon, one of the victims of the Charity Bazaar fire.

ST. LOUIS, May 7. -- The second day of the National Turnfest began early. At 7 o'clock the different Turner societies marched to the infield of the race track at the fair grounds. Until noon the time was taken up with class competition of the three active groups.

I read somewhere an extract from one of your editorials saying that you are always glad to receive and to publish well written letters on matters of public interest. I am glad to know this, as there is a matter of great interest -- a matter of very grave import to the people -- that I would like to say something about, and that I will try to treat intelligibly.

The meeting of the Managing Committee of the American School of Classical Study at Athens, which is part of the Archaeological Institute of America, was held in the Trustees' room at Columbia University yesterday morning and afternoon. The Chairman, Prof. T.D. Seymour of Yale University presided. Reports from Director R.B. Richardson and the Faculty of the school were presented.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7. -- The business of the third annual convention of the National Municipal League was finished this morning. The league was called to order in the Exchange Hall of the Board of Trade by Chairman George W. Ochs of Chattanooga. Several papers were read, dealing with municipal affairs in Philadelphia, New Orleans, Providence, and St. Louis.

John E. Searles, Secretary of the American Sugar Refining Company, appeared in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, as defendant in a suit brought by Mrs. Eliza Tierney, his former housekeeper, for a claimed balance of $200 salary. Mrs. Tierney's connection with the Searles family, she says, began in May, 1896, when Mr. Searles engaged her to take charge of his country residence at Buzzard's Bay, for six monrhs, at a salary of $50 a month.

That was rather a pitiable spectacle which some of the Senators from the far West made of themselves in the debate on the forest reserves. It is necessary to recall, as was recalled by Senator GRAY, that it was by the act of Congress that a scientific investigation was made of the condition of the Western forests and of what needed to be done in order to prevent the destruction of the Western forests.

" Now, just as soon as the election is over and the future position of the United States is assured, both as to money and to the employment of our people, capital is ready to come to us from abroad and from our own people, and we shall again be prosperous." -- From Speaker REED's speech at Alfred, Me., July 29, 1896.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 7. -- There was a lively and very largely attended hearing before Gov. Black this morning when the ticket brokers of the State made their last fight against the so-called "anti-scalpers" bill, which prohibits offices not under the authority of a railroad from selling tickets.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7. -- Rufus P. Vassal, said to be a descendant of one of the Vassars who endowed Vassar College, at Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is under arrest here, charged with embezzlement. The complainant, Maud Essington Stewart Mitchell Duggan of Chicago, alleges that she intrusted him with a two-hundred-dollar diamond ring and $80 in coin, and that he appropriated the same to his own use.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 7. -- The Governor has signed the Lexow Anti-Trust bills. One of these acts provides that every contract, agreement, arrangement, or combination whereby a monopoly in the manufacture, production, or sale of any article or commodity of common use is created is hereby declared to be against public policy, illegal, and void.

We detect no sign of conscious humor in Senator SHELBY M. CULLOM's approval of the tariff commission idea. "I believe," he writes to the Secretary of a tariff commission league, "that through the judicious agency of a permanent tariff commission, composed of experts, statisticians, and business men, such changes could be made from year to year by Congress as might be indicated and clearly shown to be wise.

This year the Governor of the State of New York will exercise a far greater power of legislation than the so-called representatives of the people constituting the two branches of the Legislature. So far as we can recall Gov. BLACK did not veto a single measure during the late session, but it was only necessary for him to intimate his objection to a pending bill and it was not passed.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- In reply to inquiries as to his views on a permanent Tariff Commission, Senator Cullom has written the following letter:

Li Hung Chang, Viceroy of the Chinese Empire, yesterday afternoon planted a tree in commemoration of his friend. Gen. Grant. Yang Yu, who until a few days ago was Chinese Minister at Washington, acted for the Viceroy, and did the actual planting, and the tree now stands above the spot where Gen. Grant's body lay until removed to the mausoleum.

During Lord Rosebery's term as Foreign Secretary in Mr. Gladstone's last administration, he was often annoyed by an elderly female who paid him daily visits to get his opinion on matters of no importance to him whatever. Finally, becoming exasperated at the woman, he gave the doorkeepers orders not to admit her under any circumstances.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 7. -- Mrs. Fannie Scott, seventy years old, of Yonkers, N.Y., and her five-year-old grandnephew, George McKenzie, whose parents live at Mott Haven, New York City, were found asphyxiated this morning in a room in Mrs. Scott's Summer cottage, 413 Sixth Avenue, this city. Death occurred probably early on Wednesday night.

Tammany berated the Republican Legislature at its General Committee meeting in the Wigwam last night, and in so doing outlined the State issues which it will make use of in its fight for the control of the Greater New York. It was practically the opening of Tammany's campaign. John C. Sheenan and most of the local leaders were on hand, and the main floor of Tammany Hall was crowded.

ALBANY, May 7. -- The entire system of State canals will be opened for traffic tomorrow, and those portions embraced in the $9,000,000 improvement that have been under way are either completed or have been left in such condition that the canals can be safely opened for the boatmen without interfering in any way with the contractors.

All day yesterday two engines pumped water on the ruins of the building 163 Chambers Street, destroyed by fire Thursday night. There was no sign of any fire, but the firemen were taking no chances of a second outbreaw. Owing to the style of construction of the building, the destruction was confined almost entirely to the section in which the fire started.

It is a proverb of ancient Greece that has just been verified by modern Greece. It is the saying that a herd of deer led by a lion is more formidable than a herd of lions led by a deer. It was not the cowardice of the Greek troops, but their just lack of confidence in their leaders, that led to the disgraceful flight at Larissa.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 7. -- A female sneakthief, who, judging by the nerve she displayed, must have been a professional, created some excitement among the students at Vassar College on Thursday afternoon. The woman was about twenty-five years old and was well dressed. She entered the college about 3 P.M., and passing the reception room as if she belonged there knocked at the door of a student and asked where Miss Nolan's room was located.

The New York Hospital is about to purchase from Mrs. Marianna De Peyster the three-story house 23 West Fifteenth Street, adjoining the hospital, for $50,000. Mrs. De Peyster has owned the property for many years and still resides there. She is at present out of the city.
By waiting long enough to study them Gov. Black makes himself fully responsible for the so-called anti-Trust bills which he signed yesterday.

ELKINS, West Va., May 7. -- The Rev. Anthony Mustoe and Christopher Tausig were arrested to-day for arson and attempted murder and an alleged plot on the part of the reverend gentleman to murder his son, C.L. Mustoe, and family, was unearthed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 7. -- A letter received here from Chicago indicates that a colored candidate from Chicago will come here to be examined for admission to the Naval Academy at the same time that Bundy, the colored candidate from Ohio, is examined.

A trade paper published in this city takes up a cry of warning started by The London Times, that the supply of natural rubber is running short, owing to the increasing demand for pneumatic bicycle tires and the decreasing exports of rubber from India. An artificial substitute for rubber is therefore said to be an imperative necessity.

New York won yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park the second game in the intercity series against Brooklyn. The work of both teams was decidedly off color, and each team made an extravagant number of errors.

The Tribune has recovered from its spasm of discontent with the Senate committee's tariff. What alterative dose has been administered, or by whom, we do not pretend to know, but the effect is rapid and marked.

Senator Thomas C. Platt has given out a statement, declaring the position of the Republican machine with respect to the Citizens' Union. He announces that the only way to defeat Tammany Hall in the coming municipal campaign is "under the leadership of the Republican organization."
LONDON, May 8. -- The Times prints the following dispatch from Velestino, via Athens:

An English translation of Sardou's threeact comic play, "Divorcons," which was written at the time of the agitation in France over the pending divorce bill, was acted with spirit at the Fifth Avenue Theatre yesterday afternoon. The performance had a charitable object -- to aid the Maternity Free Bed Fund of the Hahnemann Hospital -- and the house was well filled.

MILWAUKEE, May 7. -- A double, and what may yet prove a quadruple murder, occurred at the farmhouse of Alexander Harris, about five miles south of Waukesha, early this morning. The dead and wounded are: Alexander Harris, aged about forty-five years, killed outright; Mrs. Harris, aged forty-four years, killed; Helen Vesbach, hired girl, fatally wounded; Nelson McHolt, hired man, probably fatally wounded.

From such indications as may be had from the illustrations which have reached us, including photogravures, of the pictures at the Salon, some appreciation of the originals may be obtained. "Les Funerailles de Pasteur" of Ed. Detaille shows the work of a really great artist, laboring with the restrictions of his subject.

CHICAGO, May 7. -- The lines of the Western Passenger Association and of the Central Passenger Committee have reached an amicable agreement regarding the arrangements for the sale of the Christian Endeavor tickets. A round trip form of tickets will be used up to the eastern gateways of the Western roads and from there a one-way ticket will be used.

NEW HAVEN, May 7. -- By the unanimous official opinion of the judges Princeton won the annual debate held with Yale in this city to-night. It was a sharp forensic contest, however, despite the unanimity of the arbiters of the debate, but the Yale men had the wrong side of the question and undertook to prove too much.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 7. -- Thomas Hitchcock, the well-known society man, member of the Meadowbrook Country Club, and noted polo player, was seriously injured on the polo field this afternoon, and is now at the clubhouse suffering great agony. Just how serious his injuries are could not be ascertained at a late hour to-night.

LONDON, May 7. -- In the House of Commons to-day, in Committee of Supply, on the Foreign Office vote, William S. Robson, Liberal, moved to reduce the salary of the Marquis of Salisbury, the Premier and Minister for Foreign Affairs, by 500. His object was to raise a debate on the Eastern question.

Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for Jackson Stern to John Kehoe the building until recently occupied by the Dutch Reformed Protestant Church, 147 to 153 Norfolk Street, 80 by 100; also, for the same sellers to the same buyer, the three-story and basement private dwelling 155 Norfolk Street, 20 by 100.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 7. -- R. Marpole, who has for many years filled the position of Superintendent of the Pacific Division of the Canadian Pacific Railway, has been appointed General Superintendent in succession to H. Abbott, resigned.

A reader of this page hands me the bulletin of a small library somewhere in the State of Washington. It is printed at Seattle, and makes an extraordinary revelation of the possibilities of the printing offices of that wide-awake city; for in the first issue, containing the library's catalogue in full, I find some names and titles that have undergone a sea-change at the hands of the compositor.

The fiftieth anniversary of the organization of Plymouth Church and the call and settlement of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher as its first pastor, had its first celebration at the prayer meeting in the lecture room of the church last evening. The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, in opening the meeting, spoke of the call and acceptance of Mr. Beecher, and gave several reminiscences of the great preacher.

There is every indication that the art season in the metropolis is nearing its end. The Society of American Artists has closed its exhibition in the Fine Arts Building and the Academy exhibition will close on Saturday next. Only a few minor displays in the dealers' galleries and the remarkable exhibit of bad art at the Metropolitan Opera House Assembly Rooms have interested the art public during the week.

The feature of the racing at Aqueduct yesterday was the persistency with which "good things" managed to win. It was the closing day of the Spring meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, and as "get-away" day at the smaller tracks is usually marked by surprises, the winning of Loch Glyn and Blue Beard did not cause much comment.

A letter appeared in The London Times of the middle of April which excited a great deal of interest. The writer of the communication, who signed himself Philip Kerney, his address being Dublin, declared that he had found what was "the supposed lost or destroyed MS. of the history which Swift, in 1713, undertook to write of the negotiations which ended in the peace of Utrecht.

At the annual election of the Stock Exchange, the official ticket to-morrow will be elected without opposition, though it is not improbable that some of the candidates may poll less votes than others.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Committee on Civil Service of the Senate to-day resumed the investigation of the operation of the law which was undertaken some time ago. Senators Pritchard of North Carolina and Chilton of Texas, and President Proctor and George R. Wales of the Civil Service Commission, conducted the proceedings.

James M. Harris is a patrolman attached to the West Sixty-eighth Street Station. He is from the country, and often tells how he left his plow to join the police force. He wandered a block off his post last night, and gave his excuse in the following report:
The Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League held its third annual athletic games yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, May 8. -- Throughout the week the entire press has been full of rumors of a Cabinet crisis, and the wildest and most conflicting statements have been published on the subject. The correspondent of The Associated Press here learns on reliable authority that the facts in the case are as follows:

Spain must have a genuine belief in her ability to thrash out the Cuban rebellion at no distant date, for her finances are hardly in a condition to maintain a struggle of many years' further duration. It is true that the recent national loan of 400,000,000 pesetas (say 13,300,000) was raised at once, and, indeed, subscribed to nearly twice over, but how was it effected?
Henry W. McCord, son of Henry D. McCord, President of the Produce Exchange, died suddenly yesterday morning in the lavatory of the Boulevard Hotel, Sixty-seventh Street and the Boulevard.

One of the most amazing omissions from Senator PLATT'S letter is that of any reference to the fact that what he calls "the political campaign now shaping" is to result in a local election. The "best citizens" at whom he sneers are trying to confine it to local questions, and to restrict the issues involved in it to questions of what may be called municipal housekeeping.

New York won yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds the third and last game of the opening intercity series against Brooklyn. The game was marked by the fastest kind of team work and splendid fielding. The New York team seemed imbued with new life and put up a magnificent game. Their work was marked by none of the errors and misplays that characterized it in Friday's contest.

Such doorways have their histories unquestionably, but they are lost in the dust of the past. Who designed the well-proportioned panels, who fashioned the brass knocker, and whose taste devised the simple decorations will never be divulged. The owner has likewise passed into oblivion, leaving only the speechless door behind to awaken the curiosity and stimulate the emulation of newer generations.

This is the hey-day of the early morning prowler after street scenes that vanish with the dew. To the majority of people in this and every other city they are a closed book. But there are early morning prowlers here as elsewhere, and one of the places to find them at this time of the year is in the vegetable and fruit district around Washington Market.

-- Miss Frances E. Willard, having been the guest of Mrs. Frederick Douglass in Washington, is trying to awaken a new interest in Douglass's home. She wants it made "a Mecca for humanity, a beacon of hope, a historic shrine."

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TURKISH ARMY IN THESSALY, PHARSALOS, May 7 -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- Early to-day, as briefly bulletined to The Associated Press, there was an engagement, lasting several hours, between the Turks and Greeks at Velestino. The latter were beaten.

Drivers of trucks and other vehicles who persistently endeavor to run down cyclists without provocation are to be brought up with a sharp turn. A particularly aggravating case came to the surface on Thursday, when Theodore Housechildt, a member of the Century Wheelmen, was run over in Eighth Avenue by James Jones, the driver of an express wagon.

The most interesting event in the golfing world this week will be the intercollegiate tournament on the links of Ardsley Casino, near Dobbs Ferry, overlooking the Hudson. The recent team matches of the Yale golfers have shown that the lads from New Haven are in excellent trim, and the team that proposes to beat them will have to put up a wonderfully fine game of golf.
ATHENS, May 8. -- The report that the Turks have occupied Volo is confirmed. The Turkish troops entered that place this morning.

Following a period of several weeks almost unparalleled for its lack of activity, the last few days have produced some transactions in the real estate market which, to say the least, are encouraging, and are, in the opinion of many brokers, the forerunner of a time of increased dealings.

BOSTON, May 1. -- Massachusetts's Assembly has lately made its annual appropriation for carrying on the work of destroying the Gypsy moth. The sum is $150,000, but not large enough by $50,000 to satisfy the Entomological Board, which has charge of the active management of the work, and which alleges that a vast deal depends upon effective fighting of the pest for the coming year.

The great strides made by THE NEW YORK TIMES within the last few months form a notable chapter in American journalism. During a period of general business depression THE NEW YORK TIMES has made steady progress, having within six months nearly doubled its circulation. This growth, while indeed gratifying, serves only to stimulate the management to greater efforts.

" The Senate Tariff bill as a whole," said John De Witt Warner yesterday, "is a notice to Eastern manufacturers of what they may hereafter expect. Hitherto they have considered 'protection' as a sort of Providential arrangement by which they were enabled to feed on the rest of the country.

LONDON, May 15. -- The rejection of the arbitration treaty by the United States Senate Committee has been received with much disappointment here, and many hard things are being said about American politicians The weekly newspapers indulge in caustic comments on the subject. The Saturday Review says:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 8. -- Notwithstanding that Lakewood is in the full beauty of Spring, and the hotels have quite the usual number of Spring guests, among whom are many honeymoon people, it is essentially a Winter resort, and the annual exodus of cottagers has begun.

The Ladies' Auxiliary of the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund will hold a tea sale at the Waldorf, next Tuesday afternoon and evening, from 2 until 6, and from 8 until 10 o'clock. The proceeds are to be devoted to the erection of a new building for the destitute sick.
A person desiring to journey around Greater New York would be obliged to go nearly four-fifths of the way by water.

A new element has entered into the religious life of the West, as interesting as it is suggestive of the push and enterprise of that section of the country. It is the utilization of railroad coaches for missionary work on the frontier, writes W.S. Harwood in The Illustrated American.
The Platt Republicans are delighted with the Senator's Republican ticket manifesto. Their views were voiced last night by Chairman Edward Lauterbach of the County Committee. He said:

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Republican members of the Senate Committee on Finance to-day furnished the Democratic members of the committee with estimates of the revenue to be derived from the Tariff bill, as prepared by them and as compared with the House bill and the McKinley and Wilson laws, together with statements showing a comparison of rates of duty reduced to ad valorem figures.

KINGSTON, May 8. -- The town of Esopus, especially the northern slope of Snake Hill, has long been known as one of the most heavily loaded snake dens in the Hudson River counties. Many snake stories have come out of this locality, but none richer in the quantity of snakes than that old by two quarrymen, "Josh" Freer and "Garry" Halsey.
The outgoing transatlantic steamships yesterday had their passenger accommodations taxed to the fullest, and the names of many prominent persons appeared on the passenger lists.

BERLIN, May 8. -- The Emperor's recent decree to minimize duels in the army has just been enforced for the first time in the case of Landrath and von Roell, in Posen, and the two officers settled their dispute amicably by a Council of Honor.

DENVER, Col., April 24. -- The existing difference between the mining stock market and the real value of the mines is astonishing to every one. Prices have steadily declined for three weeks, until to-day stock in dividend-paying properties in Cripple Creek and Leadville can be bought at a price much less than the ground would bring at public auction.
THE portrait of Mr. Robert Fulton Cutting is presented to the readers of THE TIMES today, solely because he is the Chairman of the Citizens' Union.

Perched upon a low section of the wall separating the premises of the Post Office Building from Mail Street, on a recent sunshiny afternoon was a well-dressed young man, busily plying his pencil as a portrait artist. His subject was a little "newsie," and a crowd composed of other newsboys, employes of Uncle Sam, City Hall Park loungers, and casual passers-by watched the scene.

There are in the Southern States nearly 100 endowed schools and colleges devoted to negro education. These institutions represent an investment of nearly ten millions of dollars, and are maintained at an annual expense of about four millions of dollars.

Stitched to the back of their tunic collars, the officers and Sergeants of the Royal Welsh Fusiliers wear the "flash," a black silk bow, which is a relic of the old pigtail days in the army. In Cannon's "Historical Records of the Twenty-third Regiment," printed in 1847, there is a plate showing a group containing an officer whose back is turned to the spectator, thus affording a good view of the "flash" as then worn.

The nineteenth annual commencement of zhe New York College of Music was held lagt night in the college hall, which was crowded to its utmost capacity with the friends of the otudents. The college has had over 600 pupils in the year which has just come to a close, and its work has maintained the standard set for it years ago by its Director, Alexander Lambert.
In the various changes in church music plans for the current year there is one that promises to be a source of much satisfaction to the members of the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, in West

Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn yesterday approved the bill for the improvement of Atlantic Avenue, that city. The bill provides for a partly elevated and partly depressed system of railway to take the place of the present grade tracks of the Long Island Railroad Company.

PASADENA, Cal., April 25. -- A curious implement attracted the attention of the tourists at Avalon recently. It was about 10 feet in width and 30 in length, being a beam of wood girded with iron from which extended an enormous bag net. The apparatus, which lay on the sand surrounded by fishermen, was a deep sea dragnet and the owners were about to make the first trial.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 8. -- The resignation of Eliphalet Nott Potter as President of Hobart College last December has led to much speculation and to the circulation of a number of newspaper reports regarding the appointment of his successor and the future of the college that have been either without foundation or based upon a distortion of the facts.

No new play will be offered this week, but there is still plenty to choose from in the current theatrical programme, and the theatres are not all closed yet, by any means. The two musical "reviews," at the Casino and the Knickerbocker Theatre, both promised for May 24, may be expected to run well into the Summer, as will also "The Circus Girl," at Daly's, and some of the farces now on view.

Governors Island, with its sixty-eight acres, is a small social world in itself. As the season in New York proper draws to a close the festivities on the island -- hops, teas, bicycle meets, and dress parade promenades -- begin to take on their most earnest social phases.

The fad, if it may be called a fad, for pretty and artistic pieces of jewelry, antiques, and curios from other countries for personal adornment has increased greatly in New York in the last few years. The change has come in the development of the people from the chromo stage to an appreciation of true art, and this taste has grown with the increasing cultivation of the people.

Among the musical instruments used on the Congo we notice the long and short drum. Some drums are used to beat the time of the dance. Some other drums are used as telephones for the transmission of messages to neighboring villages. The stringed instruments represent the African harp.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 8. -- As the opening of the Summer season draws near every hotel proprietor and cottage owner is using his efforts toward getting in readiness. Some of the cottage people who generally make it a custom to arrive here as early as possible have already taken their cottages for the Summer, and from now on there will not be a week but will see new arrivals.

In seeking rural homes, whether for a few months of Summer recreation or for permanent residence, the New Yorker enjoys exceptional advantages. Within a radius of thirty miles he has the seaside and the brookside, the mountains and the valleys, the banks of the picturesque Hudson and the undulating verdure-clad plains to select from.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 8. -- At the annual field day sports of the United States Naval Academy, held here to-day, Cadet Henderson, a third-year man, ran 220 yards in 21 1-5 seconds, equalling the inter-collegiate and amateur records, held by Bernard Wefers of Georgetown University. Five academy records in all were broken during the games.

BOSTON, May 8. -- The annual meeting of the New England Free Trade League, this afternoon, was marked by a cropping out of the feud over the currency question, which has been growing ever since last Autumn.

THE Union Club, the oldest and most exclusive of the leading clubs of New York, was organized in 1836, when there were not many more than 350,000 inhabitants in the city. Houston, (then North Street,) Bleecker, and Bond Streets were away up town and thoroughfares of fashion and aristocracy.

Henry F. Gillig, the promoter of financial schemes, is still in Ludlow Street Jail, to which he was committed on Monday by Justice Beeekman of the Supreme Court, in a civil action instituted by Raymond W. Kenney, furrier, of 24 East Twenty-third Street.

CORNELIUS VAN COTT, whose candidacy for the Postmastership of this city was favorably passed on by President McKinley on April 19 last, comes of an old New York family, of Dutch descent. He was born in the Fifteenth Ward in 1838, and attended the public schools until, he was fourteen years of age.

A stiff little breeze yesterday morning and in the latter part of the afternoon played havoc with the efforts of some of the aspirants for marksmanship honors at Creedmoor, but otherwise it was an ideal day for shooting. Not a cloud dimmed the bright azure of the May sky, nor were the rays of the sun too piercing to make it at all uncomfortable for the boys in blue.

Clarence W. Meade and Col. Joseph Pool were appointed City Magistrates yesterday forenoon by Mayor Strong under the new taw, which authorizes the Mayor to name three additional Magistrates for a term of ten years at a salary of $7,000 a year. The third Magistrate was not appointed because the Mayor wants his private secretary, Job E. Hedges, to accept the office.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., May 8. -- M.M Davis, an intimate friend of Judge Goff of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, says there is no question as to the future of the Judge. He has been offered, and has accepted, the place which Justice Field of the Supreme Court will vacate within a few months.

LONDON, May 8. -- Our week closes this time with the spectacle of unbroken masses of the victorious Turks, Kurds, and Circassians advancing toward the oldest capital of civilized Europe, shouting "Allah! Allah!" as they go, in deep-chested and exultant unison, with the noise described as like the roar of the tempest in a forest.

PARIS, May 8. -- A requiem mass for the repose of the souls of the victims of the fire on Tuesday last at the Charity Bazaar in the Rue Jean Goujon was celebrated at the Cathedral of Notre Dame to-day with extreme solemnity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 8. -- John Myers is in the county jail charged with assault in the second degree for holding up Fred Bostwick on Thursday with a double-barreled shotgun loaded with buckshot, and threatening to shoot his head off. The incident took place in front of Myers's home, near Halcyon Lake, in Pine Plains.

Favored by excellent conditions of weather and field, the Spring games of Columbia University Union held yesterday afternoon at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge, were a great success. The events went off smoothly without loss of time, and the meet, which began at 3:15 o'clock, was all over before 6 o'clock.

The announcement of the camp dates from general headquarters has been received with a great deal of satisfaction by the members of commands who are scheduled to go under canvas this season at the military post on the Hudson, as they will now be able to make their business arrangements with a proper notification.

LONDON, May 9. -- A dispatch to The Observer from Athens dated Saturday says that the officials and Consuls of Salonica report that the Turkish losses in killed, wounded, and sick during the recent campaign will reach 38,000.
I was sitting on the veranda of a cocoanut plantation in Mosquito with Mr. Schultz one evening, when Benancio, his assistant and general overseer, came running up.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Lawrenceville Academy won the handsome silver trophy cup offered by the Princeton alumni to the school securing the greatest number of points in the first annual Princeton interscholastic games held here to-day. The New York schools which competed made a good showing, Berkeley, Pingry, Bernard, and Trinity securing points in the order named.

A current news item gives the results of an investigation carried out by Dr. G. Stanley Hall, President of Clark University, on the things that most excite fear in people. Of the 298 classes of objects of fear to which 1,707 persons confessed, thunder and lightning lead all the rest, although in certain localities, as, for instance, those subject to cyclones, , the fear of the latter predominates.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 8. -- Cornell defeated Syracuse in their dual meet here this afternoon. The final score standing: Cornell, 67 points; Syracuse, 45 points. The work of the local collegians was much better than was expected, but they were weak in the hurdles and in the weight events, and the result was at no time in question.
" If he had had me that way he would have made me guess," said John Franz.

GLASGOW, April 28. -- Between the Clyde, Southampton waters, the Solent, the Thames, and the Colne there are peculiarities at this fitting-out season which American yachtsmen may be puzzled with. In the Clyde, when a yacht is launched and fitted out for the season, she is afloat and in deep water as soon as she leaves the launching slip.

We passed a dollmaker's shop, in which sat a couple of girls manufacturing little puppets that to the life resembled the ridiculous little boys who were eagerly looking on, and who probably served as unconscious models to the busy artists, who turned the toys off so rapidly. I strolled over the way to where a crowd of children were breathlessly bending over a man who was busy at something among them.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 8. -- Articles of incorporation were filed to-day of the Southern Illinois Coal Railroad. It is proposed to build a railroad from a point on the Illinois Central Railroad, in Williamson County, through the counties of Williamson, Alexander, and Union to a point on the Mississippi River, in Alexander County, with branches to coal fields in Jackson, Williamson, and Johnson Counties.

Sanford Burton and F.G. Robinson shot a match at 200 birds each for $750 a side at Larchmont yesterday. The match has been talked of in yachting and shooting circles for some time, and there was quite a large attendance at the traps yesterday. Mr. Burton won, killing 175 birds altogether, while Mr. Robinson could only kill 163.

NYACK, May 8 -- In the Spring election held in March, the people of Ramapo Township, in the County of Rockland, voted no license on all the propositions, and now the liquor sellers are going to try through the courts to have the election set aside and a new one ordered.

My father was one of the village doctors, and had sent me with a package of medicine for Mrs. Hawthorne when Una was born at the Old Manse. I remember standing tiptoe before the ancient door at the end of the long avenue of half dead ash trees, and just managing to reach the ponderous iron knocker.

As the United States is soon to launch a submarine torpedo boat that can be driven either on the surface by steam like an ordinary boat, or when circumstances require her to work under the water, be driven by electricity at a fair rate of speed, it might, while waiting for her advent, be as well to see what has been done in this line by other naval powers.

It was a good day for the Chairman and Vice Chairman of The Jockey Club at Morris Park yesterday. August Belmont, Chairman, won the Juvenile Stake, for two-year-olds, with Firearm, a colt of his own breeding, out of the speedy race mare Fides, who was a particular pet of Mr. Belmont's father.

THERE was a musical entertainment on Monday night, and it was one worthy of some comment. Mr. Frank Damrosch's organization, called The People's Choral Union, gave a performance of "The Messiah" at Carnegie Hall. Only a few years ago such a performance would have been deemed impossible.

The golfing members of Ardsley Casino, on the Hudson, above Dobbs Ferry, held their second Saturday handicap yesterday for Class A and Class B players. The Class A match for a silver cup was won by H.S. Brooks, who played a very even game, turning in a net score of 90 strokes. The Class B contest was won by Dr. Holbrook Curtiss in the net score of 88.

The members of the New York Association of Teachers of Cookery and their guests, members of the New York Mycological Club, held a mushroom bee at the College of Pharmacy yesterday afternoon at which Mrs. Anna Pauline Doughty presided. The festivities really began Friday night, when a goodly number of those who gathered at the college yesterday took dinner in Chinatown and ate mushrooms in all the various ways which Chinese ingenuity could devise.

IN SUDA BAY, Mediterranean, April 21. -- Four days from Marseilles, fifteen from New York, finds us in Suda Bay, the centre of the great naval armament. We have stopped on our way to Constantinople to leave the mall for the war vessels, with some special instructions and packages for the French fleet.

The ladies of the Health Protective Association do not restrict themselves entirely to the work which their name implies. There is nothing which calls for public spirit or the promotion of the best interests of mankind to which they are not equal. Miss Theresa Barkalow, one of the most characteristic members of the association, gave an illustration of this last week.
The wreck of a freight train on the New York and New Haven Railroad yesterday afternoon delayed traffic for nearly two hours. Nobody was hurt.

THE indebtedness that New York and Brooklyn owe to the progressiveness of the men who first concluded that the Brooklyn Bridge could be built, and then persisted in their determination despite all the discouragements that were placed in their way until the bridge became a reality, is great, very great.

Patrick Jerome Gleason, the famous fighting Mayor of Long Island City, said last night, with a chord of pathos in his voice and a shade of sadness over his face, that he will fight no more. He has heart disease, he says, and Dr. Janewey has warned him not in any circumstances to allow himself to become excited or agitated, lest he pay for it with his life.

And yet the Italian colony in France is made up chiefly of immigrants, more or less transient, who scarcely ever learn to speak the language of the country they inhabit.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 8. -- James Phillips, the original of Jeems Phillips in Edward Eggleston's "Hoosier Schoolmaster," has been stricken with paralysis at his home, in Vevay. As he is seventy-six years of age, it is not expected that he will recover. It has been said that his was the only character in the book drawn, from life.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- "Interesting? Why, the story of New Sweden is as interesting as the tale of Robinson Crusoe," said William Widgery Thomas, a former United States Minister to Sweden, in his hearty, earnest manner as he took one of the great cushioned chairs in the Arlington drawing room.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 8. -- In all probability, Prince's Southern circuit project is dead, a score of disaffected riders having checked their baggage for other points -- and all because a game of grab has followed fast upon the success of the past four weeks.

As the result of an autopsy held yesterday by Coroner's Physician Donlin at the Harlem Hospital on the body of Jacquin Granna, the police arrested Anthony Grogon of 119 East One Hundred and Fifth Street and John Gillespie of 170 East One Hundredth Street. Granna and the other two men had a fight on March 18, and Granna was taken to the Harlem Hospital, with a broken jaw.

Oettinger, the work of the celebrated Viennese medalist, A. Scharff; his pupil, Prof. S. Schwartz; Tautenhayn, Radnitzky, F.K. Pawlik, Janner, and other Austrian artists.

In a recent public lecture at the American Museum of Natural History, Dr. E.G. Love set forth, with the assistance of stereopticon slides, some features of insect life that are not very widely known. His subject was "Study of Insects; Their Structure and Transformation."

There is a story in Plutarch which must convince every reader that one myth at least relates to an alteration made in the Egyptian calendar, to extend the length of the year from 360 days to 365. A year of 360 days existed in Egypt at an early period, and may possibly have been arrived at in the way suggested by Mr. F.L. Griffith.

Animals which loved the cold and those of a torrid land were curiously mingled. Troops of mastodons wandered over the land and gorged themselves on the soft twigs of spruce and fir. The slow, lumbering, woolly rhinoceros wallowed in the muddy streams and lakes. Moose and reindeer ranged the woods; perhaps the Indian story of the Great White Moose is a survival transmitted from paleolithic days, when this animal was actually larger than now.

There were three or four of these small urchins going up one of the streets in Brooklyn the other day, in which each house had a small front yard and a greater or lesser number of flowers.

LONDON, May 8. -- The war monopolizes attention, and there are but few other topics of interest. The powers are now anxious that hostilities be ended. Turkey, however, does not seem disposed to arrest her army in the midst of its triumphs. The war party at the Yildiz Kicsk is very strong and wishes to humble Greece completely.

Merchants engaged in the retail trades in this city are watching the course of tariff legislation in Washington with much interest, but with different sentiments. The effect upon business of the enactment of either of the measures pending in Congress is the subject of some frank expression of opinion which are presented herewith.
LENOX, Mass., May 8. -- Few of those who own country places here have arrived, but those who are here are having delightful weather.

In pro-slavery times the white man could imitate the negro and it was considered proper fun. But with emancipation and placing the colored man on a political plane with his white brother, negro minstrelsy began to decline. Other causes may have been factors in the decay of the Black Troubadours, but the fact remains that burlesquing the darky seemed to be on the decline from the hour Lincoln struck the shackles from the slave.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8. -- Pennsylvania and Harvard fought each other to a tie this afternoon on Holmes Field in their annual dual athletic games, each team scoring a total of 56 points. Although there were no records broken, the marks were fast almost without exception, and every event was very closely contested.

Out of the twenty-five amusement advertisements in your newspaper, in only nine (9) cases is the address given; leaving sixteen (16) to be hunted out by the visitor to New York. It seems to me that those managers who give an address must profit largely by the stupidity of those who don't, as, all things being equal, one usually does the easiest thing, especially where amusement is concerned.

THE season wanes, and the output of new theatrical merchandise last week was limited to an adaptation of the famous German vaudeville, or schwank, "Drei Paar Schuhe," which had, seemingly, been made in the dark by some person or persons not very familiar with approved methods of "adaptation."

It is not often that an unlisted stock engages the attention of Wall Street, but the past week Standard Oil, which the Rockefellers would never allow to be listed, has been as much talked about as any stock dealt in on the Exchange. This is due to its great rise, and the big dividends paid upon it which have caused the rise.

Indeed, among the Bechuanas and Basutos at the present moment, married women carry dolls until they are supplanted by real children. There is for its possessor a curious individuality about a doll, altogether unaccountable to other people.

THE books we have had about Russia have seldom been inspiring. The reader lays them down with a feeling of sadness. Part of Europe that Russia is, she exhibits little that is European. Modern in name though she be, there is little save architecture, clothes, and household comforts in cities that is to be called modern.

NEWARK, N.J., May 8. -- Miss Florence Harriet Joy and George Randall Swain were married to-day at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. Luther Joy, 994 Broad Street. The bridegroom is a son of State Treasurer George B. Swain. The officiating clergyman was the Rev. Dr. Henry Baker of Wilmington, Del., formerly of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, this city.

BERLIN, April 28. -- One of the most attractive, central, and comfortable theatres in Berlin is the Theater Unter den Linden; yet it has never been able to hold its own in the severe struggle for existence that goes on. A certain repute for frivolity attaches to it. People have an idea that persons with shady connections frequent it, and respectable Berlin will not support it.

An interesting golf match was played on the Morristown Golf Club links yesterday afternoon, between members of the Princeton team that will play in the intercollegiate tournament this coming week and a picked team from the home club. Seven men played on a side. The result was a victory for the Morristown golfers, and they felt particularly jubilant, because it is the first match they have played this season.

In all the refreshing brightness of a perfect Spring day, the bicentennial celebration of Trinity Parish was brought to a close yesterday. For eight days the two-hundredth anniversary of the parish's birth has been observed with impressive ceremonies and in the presence of great throngs. The glorious weather and impressive ceremonials of yesterday served to bring out a crowd equal to the largest of any day of the week.
MANCHESTER, May 9. -- Reports for the last week are more uniformly gloomy than hitherto, the decline in silver exchange spoiling the chances of Eastern orders.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -The interests of United States citizens at Puerto Cortez, the seat of the revolution now in prooTess in Honduras, will be looked after by the United States cruiser iVfarblehead. The vessel is now on her way there from Key WeSt, orders having been given her commander late yesterday afternoon t( proceed at once.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- As the result of an injury sustained in the athletic games yesterday, "Jimmy" Roche, Harvard's sprinter, will be unable to compete again this year. It was in the second trial heat of the 100-yard dash that the accident occurred.

Richard F. Price, twenty-eight years of age, a lawyer of 243 Broadway, who lives at 15 East Eleventh Street, is once more under arrest. He was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning, charged with grand larceny by Jacob Dux, a printer, of 315 West Forty-second Street.

ALBANY, May 9. -- The commander of the river steamer Kaaterskill claims $60 in settlement of damage to his boat, which he alleges was done by members of the National Guard while he was transporting troops to and from the Grant Monument ceremonies. He has made his demand for $60 to the Tenth Battalion, located in this city.

CLEVELAND, May 9. -- Senator Marcus A. Hanna arrived home this morning from the National capital for a week's rest. Mr. Hanna is not in his usual health, and hopes to recuperate before going back to Washington.

Tales of adventure often record feats of supreme daring in remote regions that are perhaps intensified in interest by the glamour of distance; but last week a young professional naturalist in the employ of leading scientific institutions accomplished a most difficult undertaking almost in the suburbs of New York that will compare well with many of that nature among the alpine snows.

Ten steerage passengers -- men, women, and children -- and three men of the steward's crew lost their lives in a fire on board the Mallory Line steamer Leona, bound for Key West and Galveston, soon after 1 o'clock yesterday morning. The ship steamed back to her dock late last night, and tied up at her pier, with the dead bodies aboard.

More than 300 names are attached to a petition which the members of the congregation of the Chapel of the Transfiguration, on West Sixty-ninth Street, near the Western Boulevard, have been presented to the authorities of the diocese for permission to set up a parish for themselves, with the Rev. Lawson Carter Rich, vicar of the chapel, for their permanent rector.

The Trustees of the Capitol, consisting of Gov. BLACK, Lieut. Gov. WOODRUFF, and Speaker O'GRADY, are investigating the charges against Superintendent EASTON in a manner to minimize as much as possible the political effect of any disclosures that may be made. They are making no public inquiry and will examine no witnesses who may go out and tell what was said.

CHICAGO, May 9. -- Griffith was in old-time form to-day, pitching a remarkably steady game, not issuing a free pass, and striking out Miller, Vaughn, and the old reliable McPhee twice. Pfeffer's misplays were responsible for the Reds' two runs. Owing to the spectators overflowing into the held, ground rules were made allowing three bases for hits into the crowd. Dahlen's helding was a feature.

Bishop Potter's remarks about trades unions and the workingmen, at the annual supper of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor, last Monday, were a subject of discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union.

A battle royal between two huge snakes and an attempt on the part of the surviving reptile to count a woman among its victims were the cause of a great deal of excitement yesterday afternoon among the visitors to the "Grand Spring Show," otherwise the miniature German County Fair, now being held at Sulzer's Harlem River Park, at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Second Avenue.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 9. -- William Haggerty of 24 Easton Avenue last night saw a tramp about to be arrested for being a tramp, and his sympathy was aroused. He pleaded for the man, and his life came very near paying the penalty for his successful pleading.

TRENTON, N.J., May 9. -- Commander E.C. Stahl of the New Jersey Grand Army of the Republic has gone to Washington for the purpose of seeing President McKinley and persuading him to attend the encampment of the division in June at Atlantic City.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 9. -- The prospective duty on Mexican cattle, as proposed in the pending Tariff bill, has resulted in unprecedented run of Mexican cattle into the United States.
We have noted the fact that the only possible excuse for Gov. BLACK'S signature to the Lexow anti-business bills is the belief that they would never be enforced.

ST. LOUIS, May 9. -- The twenty-seventh National festival of the North American Gymnastic Union, or Turnerbund, to-day, closed a most successful meeting of four days, and prizes were awarded to the victors. Like those given by King George of Greece to the successful competitors in the Olympian games at Athens last year, they consisted of laurel wreaths.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- There is no certainty as to the line of proceeding in the Senate this week. The Morgan Cuban resolution probably will be taken up Monday, and it may led to a prolonged debate. Senator Morgan is quite determined to press the resolution to an issue, and Senator Hale is just as determined to prevent its passage.

To-day's annual Stock Exchange election can proceed without disturbing anything like business transactions. Some miracle may, of course, happen to make business activity -- but apparently nothing short of a miracle can work that wonder. There is ample warrant for Wall Street brokers, depending on commissions, to show dolefulness.

A Mayoralty boom was launched yesterday, and the launching was done by Insurance Commissioner "Lou" Payn. The candidate he declared for was Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss. Whether Mr. Bliss is willing to be thus introduced is still a matter of conjecture, as he has not been heard from.

Harlem River oarsmen made good use of the fine weather yesterday and were on the water early and late in all kinds of racing craft. The water was smooth, and what wind there was did not tend to make it choppy, so that the work of the crews in training for the Harlem River regatta on Memorial Day could be judged accurately.

It is reported from Athens this morning that the Greek Government has applied in writing to the Ministers of the European powers in that city for mediation. It is significant that all the representatives except the German have promised to use their best offices. The Sultan is said to be ready to accept "a reasonable indemnity" with the cession of several strategic points which would give his army greater command of the Thessalian frontier.

The twenty-first anniversary of the founding of the Society for Ethical Culture in this city occurred yesterday, and in honor of the occasion an exceptionally fine musical programme was provided at the morning exercises of the society, in Carnegie Music Hall. Prof. Felix Adler's discourse was on "The Reconciliation Between Man and Man and Man and Fate."

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., May 9. -- The tug Paoli, Capt. Harding, brought the news here this afternoon of the collision with and the sinking of the schooner Annie E. Rudolph of Camden, N.J., off the Nauset Light, early this morning, and the loss of her skipper, Capt. Gardiner, Mate Snell, and a Norwegian seaman called Bob.

DULUTH, Minn., May 8. -- A young woman, plainly dressed, and with a plain, intelligent face, strode briskly into the lobby of the Merchants' Hotel yesterday morning, and giving the register the well-known "drummers' twist," proceeded to write thereon the following: "Mary Hartopp, National Organizer for the American Servant Girls' Association."

The Rev. Charles L. Thompson, in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-third Street and Madison Avenue, took for the theme of his yesterday morning's sermon, "Theological Tendencies of To-day."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 9. -- A sensational shooting affray, in which a woman shot and seriously wounded four men, occurred at Lowell, Ark., this morning. The shooting was done by Mrs. Durling, the young but erratic wife of a merchant of Lowell, and the wounded men are E. Bryant of Lowell and three prominent citizens of Springdale, whose names are not yet known.

One thing the Republican politicians profess to dread if Tammany obtains control of the City Government is that the present excellent force of employes will be replaced, after the old fashion, by Tammany appointees.

T.C. PLATT'S defense of the primary against the unscrupulous usurpers of the Citizens' Union would evoke a guffaw from a graven image. Do you suppose, he asks, that the freemen of New York will surrender to you their primary rights to take part in the business of making platforms and naming candidates?

Although the Raines law amendments, as the police interpreted them, were very generally observed yesterday, there was no lack of drinkables in any section of the city. The regular out-and-out saloons that made no pretense of being anything else were closed and closed tightly, but there was no precinct but afforded several places of refuge for the thirsty.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 9. -- The semi-annual trip of the receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will begin to-morrow morning at 8:30 o'clock, when the special train will leave Camden Station for the West.
VOLO, May 9. -- Before the Turkish troops entered Volo yesterday Edhem Pasha sent a flag of truce with a proclamation that he would protect all inhabitants remaining in the town.

A movement was started in Princeton about a month ago by resident graduates to revive rowing at the university. They succeeded in interesting several wealthy Princeton alumni in this city, with the result that these gentlemen have bought several rowing shells, and will present them to the undergraduates.

The suit against the Metropolitan Building and Loan Association of Newark was continued before Vice Chancellor Pitney, in Jersey City yesterday, on a motion by Col. E.L. Price that the court should appoint a competent person to make an examination of the company's books.

James Dalton, one of the men who robbed a collector for the George Ringler Brewery last September, made a confession to Assistant District Attorney D. Frank Lloyd yesterday all which he implicates three other men in the robbery.

We have had one Sunday's experience of the working of the amended Raines law and it looks as though the small and tortuous loopholes of the original act had been converted into a wide open breach, except for the saloon and the restaurant which are not appurtenant to a hotel or a club.

Another mystery of the Morgue is likely to remain unsolved until some person produces one-half of a letter that was missing from the body of a woman found in the Central Park Reservoir early yesterday morning. Her death was undoubtedly a case of deliberate suicide.

LONDON, May 10. -- Jeannine von Turkheim, nee Young of San Francisco, is in this city, and in great distress. She says that she is the victim of a conspiracy which has grown out of the Fair will contest at San Francisco. She charges her husband with a knowledge of the conspiracy, and is anxious to return to California in order to expose it.

All fears concerning the possible collapse of the new dry dock at the Navy Yard, which sprang a leak on Saturday morning and continued to leak throughout Saturday and Sunday, were allayed yesterday afternoon when the dock was flooded and the Massachusetts floated out and tied up at the Cob dock.

ROME, May 10. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Minister of Finance, Senor Luzzatti, replying to Count Della Rocca, said it would be a serious error to retaliate against the United States, since the Dingley bill permits a new convention. Italy, the Minister added, will open negotiations to protect her exports, which include nearly all agricultural products.
LONDON, May 11. -- The Daily Mail's correspondent at Volo says:

The North Side Board of Trade held a well-attended meeting last evening at its rooms, 278 Alexander Avenue. Louis Eckwort offered a resolution earnestly requesting the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company to furnish without delay to the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards additional rapid-transit facilities, particularly the extension of its line from Tremont to Bedford Park, and an increase in the number of through trains.
POUGHKEEPSIE, May 10. -- Three burglars last night entered the house of John Rohan, a farmer at Hyde Park, and encountered Rohan in the hall down stairs.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Gov. Black signed twenty-three bills to-day, making the total number of laws created to date 411. Among the bills signed were eight making appropriations as follows:

What is a cough? It is an irritation of the throat and lungs. What causes it? Congestion. Stop the congestion, the irritation ceases, and the cough iscured. But how to stop the congestion! Ah, there is where the physicians have always been puzzled. Some doctors give cod liver oil, others cough syrups, but the most advanced prescribe stimulants. Nature must be assisted. Pure whiskey will do it. See what physicians say:

The charred and blackened remnants of thirteen human bodies, the victims of the fatal fire on the Mallory Line steamer Leona, were lowered in rough pine boxes from the deck of the vessel at 5 o'clock yesterday morning and taken to the Morgue.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Considerable surprise has been expressed at the withdrawal by Gen. Wesley Merritt of his application for leave of absence to go abroad, it is suggested that the reason is that Gen. Miles, his superior officer, having been sent to watch the Greco-Turkish war by the Government, would leave the army without a responsible head, and Gen. Merritt stays home in consequence.

LONDON, May 10. -- The Spring season of French and Italian grand opera opened this evening at Covent Garden with the most flattering prospects. Mr. Grau and the new management will have the same brilliant array of supporters as brought prosperity and eclat under the direction of the late Sir Augustus Harris.

The shifting population of the east side was the theme of an address by the Rev. Adolphus F. Schauffier, Superintendent of the New York City Mission and Tract Society, at a meeting of the Congregational ministers of the city, held in the Bible House yesterday afternoon. "City Missions" was the subject of the address.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 10. -- The State encampment, Grand Army of the Republic, which began here to-day, was the most remarkable ever held in Kentucky, from the fact that ex-Confederates took the leading part in the exercises, and only one Union soldier made a set speech.
HONOLULU, May 4. -- The Japanese cruiser Nanaiwai should soon arrive here, having left Yokokasuka on April 20, four days before the steamer China sailed.

The first annual exhibition of the New York School of Applied Design for Women will open to the public at 6 o'clock this evening in the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, 268 Fifth Avenue. There will be a reception to the friends and patrons of the school and a number of specially invited guests at the galleries between 3 and 6 o'clock this afternoon.
I read with interest the article from C.H. Ward, published in your paper of April 17, regarding rules for the use of "ei" and "ie" in the different words of the English language.

It was the fault of the Patent Office, not of the telephone company; the patent is sustained, the monopoly continues. That is the answer of the Supreme Court to the Government's application to annul the Berliner patent, granted in 1891, under which the Bell Company will be able to control the telephone business until 1908.

The Seventh Regiment of the National Guard was represented at Creedmoor yesterday by Companies B, C, D, and K. Until quite late in the afternoon the weather was perfect, and a mild breeze helped the boys so well that only a baker's dozen or so failed to qualify.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 10. -- In an address before the City Ministers' Union, Judge C.W. Noble, who recently retired from the Common Pleas bench, severely arraigned the present tendency of divorces. He said:

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, in the United States Circuit Court rooms here, resumed its hearing on the subject of differential freight rates. A preliminary hearing was given in New York in March last, and a postponement was then taken, with the agreement that the commission continue the hearing in this city to-day.

A trouble of some kind is disturbing the Chinese colony here, and Ong Yung, the new Chinese Minister, is trying to settle it. He arrived here yesterday morning. Some Chinese merchants called on him in carriages at the consular residence, 26 West Ninth Street, while others, including many important men, carefully stayed away.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 10. -- The third-rail system, which President Clark of the Consolidated Road asserts is to be an important factor in the development of railroad traffic, and which, it is predicted, will undoubtedly at an early day largely supersede steam power in railroad travel, had a satisfactory test to-day.

I am surprised to see so much space taken up again in your valuable paper quoting the sayings of the latest arrival here in the form of an evangelist. Don't you think it is becoming a little aggravating and tiring, not to say uncomplimentary, to our own ministers of the Gospel for these so-called evangelists forever to make these tirades against well-to-do churches and rich people?

Commissioner PARKER'S belated explanation of the dead-lock in the Police Board over the Inspectorship promotions makes it look as if the other Commissioners were evading their own civil service regulations for the purpose of giving the promotions to two officers whom they regarded as most capable and deserving.

PARIS, May 10. -- It is not known yet who gave the 937,500f. ($187,500) received by the committee of the Charity Bazaar, the scene of the terrible fire last Tuesday. It was reported to-day that the gift was from Baroness Hirsch, and that she had made it in commemoration of the anniversary of the death of her husband, which took place April 21, 1896.

Would hepatic colic and ginger ale form a combination more acceptable to Mr. ARMSTRONG'S enlightened and fastidious taste? Or nephritis and champagne, rum and rheumatism, pleurisy and hackmatack beer, nervous prostration and cheap claret? When Labor steps into the field of politics with such a well-reasoned exposition of its preferences, the nominating power should offer if a comprehensive range of choice.

Yesterday morning's papers contained an affecting tale of two serpents, measuring, respectively, 10 and 8 1/2 feet, and of a female snake charmer weighing 296 pounds. The snakes were carefully distinguished from each other, to the confusion of herpetologists, the one as an "anaconda" and the other as a "boa-constrictor."

LONDON, May 10. -- The Earl of Kimberley, the Liberal leader, in the House of Lords to-day asked whether Greece had announced her willingness to withdraw her troops from Crete, and whether she had requested the powers to mediate with Turkey.

A dispatch from Duluth, published in yesterday's TIMES, must have excited almost to infuriation a number of mothers of families. The notion that there is any need in these United States of an "Association for the Protection of Servant Girls" is what has wrought this condition of mind, and we must admit that it is well adapted to attain that object.

ATHENS, May 10. -- The conditions insisted upon by Germany, the chief of which is that Greece shall give her formal consent to the principle of autonomy for Crete, will be accepted by the Greek Government.
LONDON May 10. -- In its weekly review of the grain market to-day, The Mark Lane Epress comments upon the unfavorable cereal weather in England, and adds:

Frank Moss, President of the Board of Police Commissioners, declined yesterday to discuss or make any comment upon Commissioner Parker's contention that the eligible list of police officers qualified for promotion to the post of Inspector is illegal. He said:

Only a few property owners were represented at the special meeting which the Rapid Transit Commissioners held yesterday afternoon at 256 Broadway. The members of the commission present were Alexander E. Orr, who presided; Charles Stewart Smith, John Claflin, Woodbury Langdon, and George L. Rives. Albert B. Boardman and Edward M. Shepard appeared as counsel to the board, and Mr. Sooysmith represented Engineer Parsons, who is now abroad studying foreign underground systems.

LONDON, May 10. -- Apart from the peace negotiations the principal feature of the situation is that Turkey is pressing reinforcements forward and preparing for a rapid advance. Unless the powers succeed in quickly arranging a settlement the Greeks are likely to suffer further disasters.
