Jacob Worth, County Clerk of Kings County and Republican leader of that county, yesterday gave out a typewritten interview with himself. He propounds the question: "What is your opinion of the Citizens' Union and the proposition made by one of its officers in relation to the Mayoralty of Greater New York?" and answers it as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Morgan Cuban resolution was discussed at considerable length in the Senate to-day. The discussion was opened by Mr. Hale, (Rep., Me.,) who spoke in opposition to the resolution. Mr. Hale said there always would be a genuine and heartfelt sympathy throughout this country for every struggle in behalf of human liberty.

FRIEDRICHSRUH, May 10. -- Three thousand men were in line in a torchlight parade given this evening in honor of Prince Bismarck. A heavy rain was falling, but in spite of this Prince Bismarck appeared upon the balcony and witnessed the march past. The crowd then gathered in front of him and listened to a brief address by Dr. Semler congratulating him upon his recovery from his recent illness.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 10. -- Klobedanz to-day told some of the Fall River players that he would leave here Wednesday and join the team at Cleveland on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- There were two significant features of to-day's developments of the Universal Postal Congress. The first was the positive announcement from the Corean Minister here, Mr. Chin Pom Ye, that the little kingdom would join the union, and the second a decision that was reached after a long discussion to reduce the rates of international postal orders on a sliding scale basis after reaching a certain amount.

Blakesiee Barnes has sold to Louis Lese six lots, southwest corner of One Hundred and Thirty-second Street and Malison Avenue, 120 by 100. These lots were purchased last month from the Hemenway estate of Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The House today took up the consideration of the Senate amendments to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill under a special order providing for a recess each day until disposed of.

The Grand Jury yesterday dismissed eleven homicide and manslaughter cases out of a lot that have accumulated since 1892. The dismissals were mainly on the grounds of absence of witnesses or lack of legal proof. The cases dismissed were as follows:

We do not understand that the Hon. LOUIS F. PAYN expects to be paid for advising the Republicans of New York to nominate CORNELIUS N. BLISS for Mayor. Since the right to grumble is correlative to the duty to pay, we should have felt freer to criticise Mr. PAYN'S counsel had he been professionally consulted and asked to render a bill.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Athens correspondent of The Standard says that almost the whole population of Thessaly, numbering 350,000, has fled to the mountains in the west. Refugees from Volo, Pharsalos, and the villages around Mount Pelion have been transported to the Islands Skiathos, Skopelos, and Euboea. Forty-five thousand refugees from villages along the coast are clamoring for food at Almyros.

Leonora M. O'Rourke, in May, 1894, with Mr. and Mrs. Charles Barrett, was walking in Central Park at 9 o'clock in the evening northerly upon the path which surrounds the upper Croton reservoir, and on the westerly side. It was a clear night, but the moon was not out. They came to three stone steps extending across the whole path, which was thirteen feet wide.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Bell Telephone Company has won the case brought against it by the United States to annul the last Berliner patent. This decision has the effect of continuing the control of the telephone by the Bell Company for seventeen years from the date of the last patent, which was granted in 1891.

Notwithstanding the favorable judgment obtained recently by the Brooklyn office holders appointed under Schedule A of the civil service classes in the appeal taken to Albany by Mayor Wurster against the affirmance by the Appellate Division of the decision rendered originally by Justice Keogh as to the legality of their appointment, the legal contentions are not yet disposed of.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 10. -- The Circuit Court to-day rendered a decision in the contempt case of Editor Louis F. Post of The Recorder, and formerly of New York City. Post was arrested by order of Judge Lamson of the Common Pleas Court, and fined $200, costs, and sentenced to ten days in jail.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The question of reorganizing the Senate committees was settled to-day, the Senate adopting a resolution offered by Mr. Carter of Montana, that the committees as arranged by the respective caucuses go into effect to-morrow. The resolution was agreed to without comment or division.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 10. -- It is out of the ordinary to have the rector of a church, the Trustee of a college, and a Doctor of Divinity appear as defendant in a criminal prosecution, and yet the Rev. Dr. George D. Silliman, rector of Grace Church of this city, stood in that position to-day when the charge was dismissed by the County Judge of Dutchess County.

The woman who drowned herself in Central Park Reservoir and left a lot of poetry signed "Titania" was identified by two people yesterday as Mrs. Ethel Marie Reis, thirty years old, who had lived at 42 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

" I desire it to be understood that I have made no statement as to the amount of the estate left by Mr. Havemeyer, except to say that there is no reason to believe that the estate is any less than might have been expected. What opinion I have is merely surmise."
ATHENS, May 11. -- The note of the powers was presented at 4:30 A. M. to-day by M. Onou to M. Skouloudis, who waited up until that hour. The following is the text of the document:...

Cyclists are always interested in the work of improving the public thoroughfares, and those not associated with the Road Committee of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York will find much pleasant information in what the committee has done during the last week and what it hopes to accomplish.

The Citizens' Union is conducting a vigorous campaign all along the line. Some of its members had planned an attempt to capture the Union League Club; but a premature announcement has interfered with, if not defeated, the attempt. Charles Stewart Smith, it was reported, had charge of the movement on the League.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 11. -- The stockholders of the three crippled Howland corporations this morning listened to a report of a committee as to the best course to pursue in rehabilitating the concerns. In the case of the New Bedford Manufacturing Company, the assets and liabilities can be briefly stated as follows:

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 11. -- Receivers John K. Cowan and Oscar G. Murray, General Manager W.M. Greene, Chief Engineer W.T. Manning, Manager of Passenger Traffic D.B. Martin, General Superintendent Thomas Fitzgerald, Assistant General Superintendent William Gibson, Superintendents Cutter and F.A. Husted, Superintendent of Transportation D.F. Maroney, E.D. Smith and J.H. Maddy of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, had a thrilling experience this afternoon at Hazelwood, during a storm.
HAVANA, May 11. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler has left Sancti Spiritus, Province of Santa Clara, for the field. Before leaving he offered to build a railroad from Placetas to Sancti Spiritus.

The proposed method of the Citizens' Union for nominating candidates for municipal offices has been subject to some criticism, but it is only a question how to secure nominations which shall be most completely representative of those who constitute and are to constitute the union during the present campaign, and which will give the best assurance of carrying out the objects of the union.

The Waldorf ballroom was crowded yesterday afternoon and evening at the tea given by the Ladies' Auxiliary of the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund to raise money to construct additions to the present hospital, on Twelfth Street, near Seventh Avenue.

A good many facts are coming out which tend to explain why the generous and gallant impulse which led Greece to declare war against Turkey and to defy all Europe has come to nothing. We have seen, to quote once more a remark of ROSCOE CONKLING'S which used to be a familiar quotation, "the bright beginning and the bitter end of a halcyon and vociferous proceeding."

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- One Democratic Senator and one Republican Senator to-day expressed the opinion that the Tariff bill may get through earlier than common report is leading anxious business men to believe. The Republican expectation is that Republican desire to get the bill through will hurry its passage.

ALBANY, May 11. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the property situated on docks leased by the City of New York is not taxable. The decision is the result of litigation on the part of the International Navigation Company vs. the New York City Tax Commissioners, and is an affirmation of the decisions of the lower courts.

There is a good prospect that Madison Square Garden will not be sold, but that, on the other hand, a reorganization of the present company will be effected, with such changes as are deemed necessary to put the big enterprise on a sound financial basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 11. -- The hearing before the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the freight differentials case in which the New York Produce Exchange charges that the existing differential freight rates on grain, flour, and provisions from the West are disadvantageous to New York and unduly favor Baltimore, Philadelphia, Norfolk, and Newport News, was resumed this morning.

NEW ORLEANS, May 11. -- The steamer Rover; plying between this port and the ports of Spanish Honduras, was fired on by a Nicaraguan man-of-war May 6, while four miles from Puerto Cortez, and narrowly escaped being hit amidships.

Wilburn Lawton is a dignified lad of eleven years, who wears the uniform of the Barnard School, in Harlem. He lives at 107 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street. His father is a publisher on Fifth Avenue. Harry Show, eleven years old, of 121 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, and Arthur Bellew, eight years old, son of Frank Bellew, the artist, are his playmates.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Queen's drawing room at Buckingham Palace to-day was a most imposing function. Half a dozen Duchesses were present, in addition to hosts of other distinguished people. There was a large attendance of Ministers and members of the Diplomatic Corps. The show of jewels was remarkable, many of the dresses being decorated with diamonds and pearls, in addition to costly ornaments.

The Governor has signed the bill authorizing the raising of $2,500,000 by an issue of bonds to establish four high schools in this city, and the Mayor has certified the acceptance of the bill for an issue of $10,000,000 of city bonds to provide additional buildings for the existing grades of schools.

The Quebec Line steamship St. Madiana, Capt. Frazer, arrived yesterday, bearing news of the series of earthquakes which occurred on the Islands of Montserrat and Guadaloupe during April. These earthquakes, while not so severe as those of six months ago in the same place, have occasioned much damage to plantations and resulted in the loss of over sixty lives.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The House to-day took up the subject of forest reservations, and Mr. Underwood (Dem., Ala.,) and Mr. Ellis (Rep., Oregon,) advocated the restoration of the reservations made by President Cleveland to the people.

BOSTON, May 11. -- The market has displayed more buoyant and broader characteristics than for many days. The rise in Bell Telephone yesterday is maintained well. Yesterday's highest was 232 1/2, closing 229; to-day's highest was 232 and the lowest 230, the price steadying at 230 in the afternoon.

The unidentified bodies of the victims of the fire on the Mallory Line steamship Leona remained at the Morgue yesterday. George Lange of 720 Washington Street, Hoboken, called, but was unable to identify the body of his brother Alfred.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- During the debate in the Senate on the Morgan Cuban resolution to-day, a strong plea was made for its reference to the Committee on Foreign Relations, on the ground that the State Department is in possession of recent official information on the Cuban question, which, it is considered, should be consulted before action is taken by the Senate.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

B.M. Strauss Co. have sold for the Walker estate to an investor the three five-story buildings 54, 56, and 58 East Ninth Street. The buildings will be torn down at once and a new six-story structure erected on the site. The proposed building has already been leased for a term of ten years.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Chairman Dingley of the House Ways and Means Committee, made the following statement to-night regarding the Tariff bill pending in the Senate:

The Bar Association held a largely attended meeting last night in its house in West Forty-fourth Street, James C. Carter in the chair. Its most important business was the consideration of the following amendment to By-law XIV., notice of which was given on March 20:

At times yesterday there was almost a show of old-time activity in the stock market. But for the most part it was an increase of business at the expense of quotations. Generally prices were lower at the closing than at the opening, though no losses of special importance were recorded.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 11. -- Mancher F. Glidewell of this city has conveyed to the Church of Christ in North Indianapolis valuable real estate conditioned that the Trustees never permit the introduction of an organ or choir musical instrument inside the church walls, and that fairs, festivals, and all other gatherings not enumerated in the New Testament be interdicted.

LONDON, May 11. -- The Parliamentary committee appointed to inquire into the Transvaal raid held another meeting today, in the committee room off Westminster Hall. The examination of the Duke of Abercorn, Chairman of the Chartered Company of British South Africa, was continued.
Surrogate Arnold resumed taking testimony yesterday in the contest over the will of the late William Ivison, the eccentric millionaire publisher, who died last May.

The Woman's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church, in America held its twenty-third anniversary yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Collegiate Church. The church was crowded. The President, Mrs. Paul D. Van Cleef, was in the chair.

Edward Lauterbach was in consultation with Senator Thomas C. Piatt twice yesterday. The first conference was at Mr. Piatt's office.at 49 Broadway, and the second was in Mr. Piatt's room in the fifth Avenue Hotel. Mr lauterbach told Mr Piatt that he desired to resign as chairman of the Republican County Committee, owing to the ill health of Mrs. Lauterback.

The Washington correspondent of The National Review of London -- a periodical of the stiffest conservative views -- under date of April 15, makes some complicated remarks concerning the decision of the Supreme Court in the Trans-Missouri case, and the reception thereof by public opinion. Among other things, he says:

Noticing an article in your issue of yesterday signed by Alfred de Cordova, giving his reasons for an optimistic view as to the immediate future of speculation in Wall Street, permit me to answer his article upon the subject in as few words as the limit of your columns will permit. The cry among the commission brokers at the present is: "What is the matter with Wall Street?"

The Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic yesterday served upon each of the Police Commissioners a protest against the promotion of Acting Inspectors Brooks and McCullagh to full Inspectorships. This is the protest:

A large number of citizens who reside and do business on the west side of this city called upon President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company at his office, in the Cable Building, 621 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, to ascertain why work was not begun on the long-promised rapid-transit improvements in Sixth and Eighth Avenues.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- There was no feature of noteworthy importance to the trading in the local market to-day. Prices continued firm, in some cases above those ruling yesterday, on a comparatively small volume of business. The sentiment on the Street is encouraging to higher range of values, and brokers generally look for increased activity in the market within a short time.

The new armored cruiser Brooklyn steamed up the North River yesterday morning and came to anchor off Thirty-seventh Street. The Brooklyn passed through the Narrows Monday afternoon during the squall, and her commander, Capt. Francis A. Cook, thought it safer, in view of the darkness and mist, to anchor off Tompkinsville, S.I., for the night.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Senator Burrows, for Mr. Platt of New York, has presented some amendments to the Tariff bill, which the New York Senator will offer at the proper time. One is to make chloroform dutiable at 25 cents per pound instead of 15 cents as in the Senate bill and 20 cents in the House bill.

Nearly seventy merchants, representing the Boards of Trade of almost every Central and South American country will arrive in this city on the evening of June 8. They come to the United States to make a thorough investigation of its business methods.

The appearance of Mayor PAT GLEASON of Long Island City as a candidate for the Mayoralty of Greater New York is decidedly the most comic development of municipal politics since the signing of the charter. About the candidacy of PAT there can be no question. He is bringing it into clearer evidence every day.

ALBANY, May 12. -- State Commissioner of Excise Lyman to-day made the following ruling in the matter of filling prescriptions by regular pharmacists, where the same contains alcohol or other liquor, viz.:

Company H of the Seventh Regiment carried off the honors at yesterday's shooting at Creedmoor, beating its old-time rival, Company F, the "Big Six" of the regiment, by 1 3/4 per cent, in the general merit mark and by 3 1/2 per cent. in the volley firing. With this victory, the H boys also wrest the Donohue Trophy from Company F, which has held it for the last six years.

The will of John W. Patterson of 222 Washington Street, Brooklyn, who died Dec. 23 last, was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate Abbott after a brief hearing on a contest brought by his son, John H. Patterson of Chicago. Mr. Patterson was eighty-three years old. He left an estate valued at $80,000.

Assistant Secretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt will begin his investigations at the navy yard this morning. It is understood that during his visit Mr. Roosevelt will investigate all the charges that have been brought against the various department heads by the workmen at the yard, and it is said that the departments of construction and steam engineering will receive the closest attention.
The meeting of the American Authors' Guild, called last evening to nominate officers for the year, did not turn out as had been expected by the conservative element of the Guild.

At the end of the present academic year, July 1, Thomas Egleston, Professor of Metallurgy and Mineralogy at the Columbia School of Mines, will be retired at his own request, on account of failing health, and be made professor emeritus. His chair will be divided, Henry Marion Howe of Boston will thereafter be Professor of Metallurgy and Alfred J. Moses, who has been for some time adjunct professor, will become Professor of Mineralogy.

Senator ALLEN'S appeal to the President not to pardon CHAPMAN till CHAPMAN has purged himself of his contempt has served one not very important purpose. It has shown that none of the Sugar Trust's money is in the pocket of the Senator from Nebraska. But, then, nobody ever supposed it was.
