Funeral services for Cornelius Corson -- once a noted and politically potent factor in this community -- were held according to the ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the family residence, 110 East Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon. A number of old New Yorkers were present, including many of Mr. Corson's business associates.

Melville E. Ingalls, President of the Chesapeake and Ohio and Big Four Railroads, accompanied by Mrs. Ingalls, arrived on the White Star steamship Teutonic from Liverpool last night and registered at the Waldorf.

The weights for the Crotona High-Weight Handicap, to be run over the last six furlongs of the Withers mile on Saturday, have been announced by Handicapper W.S. Vosburgh. The probable starters and their weights are as follows:

BERLIN, May 12. -- In the Reichstag today, before the discussion of the motion of Herr Auer, Socialist, to repeal the clause of the Penal Code dealing with lese majeste. Herr Singer, Socialist, said that a number of officers of the Criminal Department were in the galleries of the House, and he expressed the hope that visitors would abstain from making remarks which might bring them into trouble.

JAMAICA, L.I., May 12. -- President Philip M. Wood of the Jamaica Board of Sewer Commissioners was arrested here last night for riding his bicycle without a lantern. President Wood is a physician, and he stated that he had been summoned to attend a patient and expected to be home before dark, but was detained. Sentence was suspended.

The Press Committee of the Citizens' Union has completed its statement or address. It is to be incidentally a reply to Senator Thomas C. Platt and to all other attacks that have been made upon the movement by partisan leaders, as well as a restatement of the principles and aims of the organization.

LONDON, May 13. -- A dispatch to The Standard from Constantinople, says: "In Thessaly the official reports are not favorable. The Turkish reconnoissance in force at Domokos has been repulsed, and the attack on Arta, which promised to be successful, has also resulted in a cheek. It is believed that Edhem Pasha is developing an outflanking movement with the right and left wings, with a view of rendering the Greek position at Domokos untenable."

Princeton carried off the golf championship honor at the Ardsley Casino, on the Hudson, above Dobbs Ferry, yesterday, The Intercollegiate Golf Association is holding its first regular tournament, the contest being divided into an event for the individual golf championship of the colleges and a team championship.

The annual meeting of the National Academy of Design was held in the council room of the Academy building, yesterday afternoon. The meeting was called to order at 2 P.M. by the President, T.W. Wood. Fifty-two academicians were present.

A long step toward breaking the dead-lock that has stopped all police promotions for the past year was taken at yesterday's meeting when the Police Board abolished the eligible list for Sergeants, one of the subjects of contention, and appointed a committee to devise a system of promotion from future eligible lists. The eligible list for Inspectors was referred to the Corporation Counsel for an opinion as to the legality of its formation.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The President to-day nominated Brig. Gen. James W. Forsyth to be Major General. The nomination was made to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Gen. Wheaton.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12. -- The twenty-third Kentucky Derby was won by Typhoon II., contrary to the expectations of the racing people, who confidently believed that the winner of the race would be the chestnut colt Ornament. Typhoon won easily, showing the way to Ornament the entire distance of one mile and a quarter.

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 12. -- The Ambassadors of the powers held a prolonged conference to-day, at the close of which they presented to The Turkish Government a collective memorandum proposing an armistice between Turkey and Greece on the basis of negotiations for peace now in progress through the powers.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Senate sugar investigation and the conviction of Elverton R. Chapman for refusing to testify was recalled when Mr. Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) a member of the investigating committee, offered a resolution in the Senate to-day requiring Chapman to appear at the bar of the Senate and purge himself of contumacy as a preliminary to Executive clemency.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 12. -- Mercer County is in a state of siege to-night, resulting from the raids of Monday night, in which four toll gates were destroyed. It is conceded that Monday night's raid was made for the purpose of defying the Circuit Court, which began its session that day, and the boldness of the raider has caused leading citizens to begin work in earnest in trying to bring the raiders to justice.

The Tammany Society met last night and installed the Sachems who were elected at the April meeting. The braves were out in large numbers. Former Police Justice Thomas L. Feitner acted as installing officer. All of the Sachems were installed with the exception of Nathan Straus, who was detained by a prior engagement.

According to some of the dispatches from Washington to the Western papers, the "steering committee" of the House is inclined to make a special order for the Senate Bankruptcy bill, known as the Nelson bill. Its friends say that they have hopes of its passage at the present session.

It was a happy thought of The Independent to invite Mr. NELSON DINGLEY, Jr., to give "an explanation and defense of those schedules and clauses of the House Tariff bill which have been specially subjected to assault." In reply, Mr. DINGLEY has written a page and a half to The Independent, but what he has found to say of "schedules and clauses" "specially subjected to assault" could be put in one-fifth of the space.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 12. -- Major Gen. Merritt's decision in the Romeyn case was received at Fort McPherson to-day, and Major Charles Porter, who is commanding the Fifth Infantry in the absence of Col. Cook, to-day made public that portion which refers to the charges brought by Capt. Romeyn against Lieuts. O'Brien and Bamford.
Natural grains, meat, and fruit will make good blood if the digestive machinery of the body is not interfered with.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 12. -- To-night at the Star Theatre the "Widow Goldstein," a three-act comedy, had its first production. There was a good-sized audience, and for a first performance the presentation was a remarkably smooth one.

A special meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday, much important business being transacted at it. The necessary steps were taken to acquire $1,500,000 worth of property for the erection of new schools and the enlargement of some of those now in operation. Two of the three Principals for the new high schools were chosen.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The cases of President Havemeyer and Secretary Searles of the American Sugar Refining Company were selected for trial on May 17 for refusal to answer questions put by the Senate Sugar Trust Investigation Committee.

What is supposed to be sought for in a convention to nominate candidates for office is representative character. Theoretically the delegates to a political convention are fairly representative of the party holding the convention, but practically it does not always prove to be the case.

The Grand Jury yesterday indicted Commander Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army, for maintaining a common nuisance at the Army Headquarters, 124 West Fourteenth Street. The complainant is Phineas Smith, who lives at 131 West Thirteenth Street, immediately in the rear of the headquarters. On his complaint Commander Tucker was arrested a month ago and held in $500 bail in Jefferson Market Police Court.

The Hotel Waldorf is new to Chang Yen Hoon, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Chinese Empire, head of the Imperial Treasury and Special Ambassador to represent his country during the jubilee celebration of Queen Victoria, but New York is not. He arrived here yesterday morning with a suite of eight young lords and gentlemen and a staff of attendants, and all were taken in carriages from the Grand Central Station to the hotel.

Richard V. Harnett Co. have sold for the New York Realty Company to Charles T. Harbeck the four-story office building, 15 Maiden Lane, 23 by 94, and the five-story building, 80 Nassau Street, 34.9 by 101.5. In exchange Mr. Harbeck gives 260 Fifth Avenue, 49.4 by 100.

The members of the Real Estate Board of Brokers met last night for the first time in social enjoyment, when they dined in Parlor B of the Hotel Marlborough. The dinner was an informal affair, and jollity had full reign. William Henry Folsom, President of the Board, was in the chair.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. Morgan of Alabama made a statement relative to his resolution on Cuba. He said the Committee on Foreign Relations at a meeting to-day had considered the question of referring the resolution to the committee, and had not reached an agreement.

The Board of Health has investigated two cases of children reported to have died from the effects of vaccinations performed by the board's doctors. The first of these was that of James J. McLaughlin, an infant son of John McLaughlin of 527 West Fortieth Street. Dr. Benedict said yesterday that this case had been carefully inquired into, and that death was caused by purpura hemorrhage. The symptoms following the vaccination were as usual.

The man who is elected the first Mayor of New York City under the new charter will be confronted with such a task as no public officer has ever had to deal with in this country. A new and complicated government will have to be put into operation over an area hitherto occupied by three cities and a large number of towns and villages, with a diversity of interests and conditions.

-- Apparently the censor at Havana is becoming cautious, and has acquired a knowledge of arithmetic which he did not possess during the early part of the revolution. Last year he would not have bothered to insert in an official dispatch about the capture of forty-six prisoners a parenthetical explanation that this number does not include the seventy-one rebels whose taking was reported a few days ago.

DENVER, Col., May 13. -- The Colorado Equal Suffrage Association and the Civic Federation of Denver make a public statement regarding the results of woman suffrage in Colorado, in the course of which they say:
J.B. Ketcham has sold, for Michael T. Daly, for $22,000, the three-story brown-stone-front dwelling 46 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, 15.7 by 50 by 100.11.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Gov. Black this afternoon signed a bill affecting every village in the State, and which has been two years in preparation. It is a general revision of village laws, and provides that an enumeration of the inhabitants of each village shall be taken under the direction of the Board of Trustees in the month of January, 1898, and in the same month each fourth year thereafter.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The effort to secure the adoption of a universal postal stamp by the Postal Congress has collapsed. There were too many difficulties (the chief being that of currency fluctuations) in the way of adopting such a stamp, and the General Committee, after considering the subject briefly, abandoned it as impracticable, and will make an adverse report to the congress.
After the calm of a long and dispassionate discussion of municipal affairs, the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday ended in a short and sharp debate that was somewhat like a storm.
The Board of Control of the Joint Traffic Association held a long meeting yesterday at its offices at 143 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Senate Committee on Finance reached an understanding to-day by which it was practically agreed that the debate on the Tariff bill should begin on Monday the 24th inst. In accordance with this understanding Mr. Aldrich (Rep., R. I.,) this afternoon announced to the Senate that he hoped to call up the Tariff bill on Thursday, at least for a preliminary statement.
The report of the Board of Consulting Engineers of the Dock Department upon the improvements of the North and East River water fronts was read at a meeting of the Dock Board yesterday.

The city ordinances relating to the use of bicycles may be revised in the near future. The local Board of Consuls of the League of American Wheelmen has been requested to suggest any changes deemed desirable from the experince of the members, and the work is now under consideration.

The order of the Founders and Patriots of America held a meeting in the Governor's Room at the City Hall yesterday afternoon to commemorate the two hundred and ninetieth anniversary of the settlement of Jamestown, Va., in 1607. It was the first annual meeting of the General Committee, and Col. Frederick D. Grant, Governor General, presided. Representatives from several State societies attended.

NYACK, N.Y., May 13. -- Lightning did considerable damage in Rockland County last night. Part of the vestibule of St. Ann's Catholic Church was shattered, and the Rev. Father Crosby was badly shocked. Miss Kate Cooke, a young lady of Upper Nyack, had an arm rendered useless by the lightning. Many electric-light poles and trees were shattered.

The Sinking Fund Commissioners met yesterday and transacted a large amount of routine business. Lawyer De Forest, counsel for the Central Railroad of New Jersey, which operates the Liberty Street Ferry, asked the board to strike out a provision in the proposed franchise for the ferry, giving the successful competitor the right to purchase the boats, buildings, and terminal property in case the franchise was not bought by the present company.

Many members of Good Government Club B met at the San Remo Hotel last night, where they dined and listened to a number of speeches respecting the pending campaign for the control of the government of the Greater New York.
There is no getting around it. The way the eligible list for promotion to Inspectorships in the Police Department was dealt with by a majority of the Commissioners was an evasion and a bad example.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 13. -- Reports from Havana to-day indicate that the Spanish officials are beginning a war against the American correspondents again for their reports sent out regarding the Spanish atrocities and the many cruelties inflicted by the Spanish troops throughout the island.

There is much careful investigation and discussion of the pending tariff measures in Congress now going on among the retail merchants of this city. Aside from the general disturbing effect of uncertainty, the proposed changes in the tariff schedules affect almost every branch of the retail trade, and each merchant is watching his own interests very closely.

ALBANY, May 13. -- Among the billss signed by Gov. Black to-day were the bills of the Statutory Revision Commission codifying and revising the existing statutes of the State relating to mechanic' liens; finance, personal property, and partnerships.

LONDON, May 13. -- The Graeco-Turkish news received to-day does not change the situation. Everything is facing on the Porte's action. There is no confirmation of the report, printed by the Journal of Paris, that an armistice has been arranged, but, the silence from the seat of war seems to indicate that Edhem Pasha's advance upon Domokos may have been countermanded.

The New York Sun abandons its plea that the President and his party have not promised to adopt the measures needed to preserve the gold standard. It presents what it considers "sufficient reasons" why no measure should be undertaken now, and especially why the creation of a Currency Commission is at present "impracticable" and why it would be "indecent" for Mr. MCKINLEY to ask for it.

About the worst weather imaginable for rifle practice prevailed at Creedmoor yesterday. It rained hard all day, and for the greater part of the time a gray mist hung over the targets, rendering them hardly visible. There were to have been five companies of the Thirteenth Regiment and four companies of the Sixty-ninth on the grounds, but only the men of the Sixty-ninth got there.

War on the Methodist Book Concern has been declared by the American Protective Association, better known as the A.P.A. The plan of campaign is to disseminate throughout the entire United States by means of the A.P.A. newspaper organs the report that the Methodist Book Concern in this city is in the hands of a clique, which is running it in the interest of Roman Catholics.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 13. -- Forty-nine years ago the nucleus of the present Chamber of Commerce was formed, and this evening the anniversary dinner of Cleveland's honored commercial organization was held at the Hollende Hotel. About 300 guests were present, and the guests of honor were Archbishop Ireland and United States Senator M.A. Hanna.

It is part of the belated political development of Germany that members of the Reichstag cannot express themselves freely about measures which personally affect their "dread sovereign." The very gingerly manner in which the members of the Reichstag were reduced to expressing themselves about the proceedings taken to punish the offense of "lese-majeste" does no sort of justice to German public opinion.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 13. -- A Council-manic scrap occurred here this afternoon in the City Clerk's office, in which the smallest man came out best. The fight was the result of the charges preferred against Director J.O. Brown, for having been extravagant in erecting the public safety building.
Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt paid his first official visit to the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday morning.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., May 13. -- I.V. Baker carried everything before him at the Republican County Convention here to-day. Rumors were rife that Burleigh had manipulated enough of the delegates to give him a majority of the convention, but the result showed that Baker had a clean sweep of twenty-five, and used his power with telling effect.

When the first round was started yesterday on the Ardsley Casino golf links, near Dobbs Ferry, in the intercollegiate golf team championship tournament the weather conditions were extremely unfavorable for the enjoyable features of golf, although the college lads showed that they could make low scores even if they had to play over soggy grounds and damp, heavy greens.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day had the Cuban question under consideration on the basis of the report of the sub-committee appointed yesterday to confer with the President and Secretary Sherman. The report was prepared by Senators Davis and Foraker, the Republican members of the sub-committee; Senator Morgan, the Democratic member, declining to participate in it.

The Board of Consulting Engineers for the Dock Department, which has been studying our water-front problem during the past two years, has just submitted a third report, which deals with the facilities of transshipment at the docks. The practical isolation of our wharves from the great lines of land communication has its advantages and its disadvantages, chief among the latter being the difficulty and expense of transshipment between railroads and vessels.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 13. -- The Cincinnatis defeated the New Yorks easily in an uninteresting game to-day. Both Dammann of the Cincinnati team and Doheny, who pitched for New York, were wild. Dammann gave nine men their bases on balls.

Isn't it about time for the courts to put an end to the long-drawn-out farce between the Third Avenue Railroad and the Metropolitan Traction Company? The rivalries and contentions of these two companies are of no possible interest to the public. They block the way to projected improvements in equipment and service, and hold out no promise of advantage to the public.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 13. -- The dramatic and artistic possibilities of Milton's "Comus" were strongly emphasized this evening in a performance of the masque given at Helicon Hall, the residence of the Rev. John W. Craig.

Regarding a dispatch from Buenos Ayres to the effect that anxiety was felt for the members of the gold hunting expedition of Moses Y. Ransome to Terra del Feugo, H. Demorest of 15 West Fourteenth Street said yesterday that the party had reached its destination, and was safely settled in the field of its work.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Trouble for Charles L. Schar and Franz Koch, the Halsted Street bankers, who suspended some time ago, has been commenced in a Justice's court, and Koch has been arrested and a Constable is said to be searching for Schar. It is thought that Schar has gone to California.

HAVANA, May 13 -- There is no truth in the report that the city is excited by rumors of an intended attack by Gen. Maximo Gomez. There is no truth in the report that the forts have been regarrisoned and that new earthworks have been thrown up. No attack by Gen. Gomez is expected. He is now in the eastern part of the Province of Puerto Principe and has not been able to come westward.

Commander BOOTH-TUCKER is very indignant because the headquarters of the Salvation Army have been indicted as a disorderly house. And yet the specification of the indictment is hard to controvert. It sets forth that the defendant maintains a disorderly house, which men and women frequent nightly in large numbers, singing and playing on musical instruments, making a great noise, and disturbing the comfort and repose of the people of the neighborhood.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters held its thirty-fifth annual meeting yesterday at the rooms of the local board, at 32 Nassau Street. The meeting was regarded as one of considerable importance by insurance men, as about 110 companies were represented, among them being several English and Canadian ones.

ALBANY, May 13. -- In the Court of Appeals to-day a motion was made to reopen the Brooklyn Civil Service case in the decision of which Judge Haight wrote an opinion making more open the confidential non-competitive class. Such a motion as this to-day is not a calendar case, but leave to make the motion is usually granted by consent of the Judges who concurred in the prevailing opinion.

Miss Eleanor Scheuter is a Brooklyn girl of nerve and courage. Incidentally she is twenty-two years old and good looking. She is ticket agent for the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad Company at its Myrtle and Franklin Avenue station. About noon yesterday she was robbed of a bag containing $14, but the thief was unsuccessful in getting far away.

HANOVER, N. H., May 13. -- Dartmouth won the second annual debate from Williams to-night. The question was: "Resolved, that it is desirable that Municipalities in the United States having a population of 25,000 or more own and operate all plants for supplying light, water, and surface transportation." Dartmouth's side was the affirmative.

-----All the anti-vaccinationists are leaping up and down in a frenzy of glee at the death in this city of two children upon whom the Jennerian operation had recently been performed. Membranous croup caused one of the fatalities, and the other resulted from the malady known as purpura hemorrhagica.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Several additional gambling associations having reopened under the impression that the new city administration was to proceed upon "wide-open" lines, Chief of Police Kipley announced to-day that he would permit no gambling houses to be maintained in the city.

The thirty-eighth annual exhibition of the work of the pupils of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, at Mechanics' Institute, closed last night. The attendance was good and the instructors and officers are much gratified. The pupils are all men and boys engaged in the various trades, who are seeking to advance themselves by devoting their evenings to systematic study.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- In the Senate to-day the Allen resolution relative to bringing Elverton R. Chapman to the bar of the Senate was taken up as soon as the routine business was out of the way. Mr. Allen said the Senate should, in justice to itself, take this matter in hand and deal with it promptly.

Senator ALDRICH is both cynical and impertinent in his comment on the favors he has granted to the Sugar Trust. "Possibly," he says, "the sugar schedule is condemned in the newspapers." "Most of the complaints have come from newspapers that were expected to object to the schedules and the rates."

The International Stock and Grain Company of 53 New Street was raided by Detective Sergeant Wade of the Central Office and four detectives yesterday afternoon. The policemen were in plain clothes, and when they entered the company's office on the ground floor of the building about 2:30 o'clock were not noticed by the crowd present.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13. -- The college championship baseball season will open here Saturday with the first game in the Harvard-Princeton series. Both teams are in fine condition after their two months' preparation, and an interesting contest is expected. The batting order of the teams will be as follows:

Capts. Petrie and Barrett of the local Board of United States Inspectors of Steam Vessels held an investigation yesterday as to the fire on the Mallory Line steamship Leona, in which thirteen persons were burned to death last Sunday morning.

Michael Duggan, ten years old; David Crandall, nine years old, and James Ahearn, nine years old, all Harlem boys, were held for trial in the Harlem Court yesterday on charges of larceny. The boys, it is alleged, robbed the cash drawer of Mrs. Tillie Gerschiet's grocery store last Tuesday, securing $1.60.

Secretary SHERMAN does well to lay before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations all the facts in the possession of the Department of State relating to Cuba. It is true that some of the members of that committee are malignant, and some of them feather headed, and these may not respect the confidential nature of such communications.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Judge Jere Wilson and Senator Elkins called on the President to-day. The former is the counsel of Broker Chapman, the recalcitrant sugar witness, and the presumption was that he called in behalf of his client. Judge Wilson insisted, however, that such was not the case.

To no one but the wildest racing enthusiast or to him who won a pot of money by guessing the names of the winners of the races was yesterday a good racing day. There was rain and murkiness and discomfort, and forerunners of rheumatism and pneumonia in the air at the hour when people started for the track.

YONKERS, N. Y., May 13. -- Wally O'Connor, who was arrested in New York on Wednesday, was brought here to-day and arraigned before City Judge Kellogg. O'Connor was positively identified by Lyman G. Cobb, the Cashier of the Yonkers Savings Bank, as one of the three men who participated in the robbery of that institution.
RICHMOND, N.S., May 14. -- The boiler of a locomotive of the Inter-Colonial Railroad, in the roadhouse at this place, exploded this morning and caused a heavy damage to property.

Many of the prominent librarians throughout the United States are preparing for an enjoyable Summer vacation to Europe, arranged under peculiarly interesting circumstances. This European tour is the direct result of an important International Library Conference to be held in London during the middle of July.

The Committee on Labor and Social Reform of the Citizens' Union met last night at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, and made preliminary arrangements for the labor conference which will be held in connection with the work of the Union at the Cooper Institute on the evening of May 25.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 14. -- "The fastest vessel of her class in the world," was the verdict recorded by the officers of the trial board at the conclusion of the speed trial of the new gunboat Nashville today on Long Island Sound.

PROVIDENCE, May 14. -- When the young and attractive wife of Charles H. Fuller, a well-known manufacturing jeweler residing in Pawtucket, returned from a European journey yesterday morning and drove to her elegant home, on Broadway, she was astounded to find the doors locked and the servants, who were on duty, refusing her admittance.

Max Maretzek, the well-known operatic manager, died yesterday at his-home, at Pleasant Plains, S.I. He is survived by his wife, sis son, Max, and two daughters, Mrs. Charles Welber and Mrs. Carrie Lindsay. The funeral will take place on Monday.

The question of acquirement by the city of the franchises of the Sixth and Eighth Avenue railroads came up at the public hearing yesterday by the Aldermanic Committee on Railroads. Aldermen Parker, Hall, and Goodman were present when the hearing began, and later President Jeroloman apeared.

NEWARK, May 14. -- Eastern Star Council, No. 50, Daughters of Liberty, refused this week to attend the funeral of Mrs. Hannah S. Schofield, an officer, principally because, the funeral service being held in an Episcopal church, the purple pall prescribed by the ritual would cover the American flag which was to be placed upon the coffin, in accordance with the rules of the organization.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 14. -- Four thousand people saw the Reds again defeat the Giants in an interesting game of eleven innings. Sullivan was substituted for Meekin in the fourth. The Reds could do very little with his delivery. The feature of the game was the playing of both Davis and Gleason.

The inexorable age limit is this year to deprive the Court of Appeals of the further services of Chief Judge Andrews. In him the sole survivor of the original members of this tribunal will retire, and a new Chief Judge is to be elected. It is to be regretted that this selection is to be made through political nominating machinery.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Elverton R. Chapman, a broker, of New York City, will surrender himself to United States Marshal Wilson at 3 o'clock Monday afternoon. Positive assurance to this effect was given District Attorney Davis to-day by Chapman's counsel. Chapman will then be escorted immediately to the District Jail and begin to serve his sentence for thirty days for refusing to answer the Senate Sugar Trust Investigating Committee's questions.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 14. -- A wild scene occurred in the Senate to-day over an attempt of the fused gold Democrats and Republicans to force through a bill providing for putting one name under two different devices on the State election ballots. The silver Democrats, though in the minority, outgeneraled the opposition, got one of their number, Senator Goebel, in the chair, pending an appeal, and adjourned the Senate.
There was a divorce in Ludlow Street Jail yesterday, the granting of a separation by a husband, who was locked up, to his wife, as the only alternative for his release.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The meeting of the Cabinet to-day was devoted almost entirely to the consideration of the Cuban situation. The meeting occurred an hour earlier than usual, owing to the importance of the question to be discussed and the fact that the President and the Cabinet were to leave for Philadelphia at 12:45.

LAKEPORT, Cal., May 14. -- Emelie Charlotte Langtry, better known throughout two hemispheres as "the Jersey Lay," has secured a divorce from her English husband. The decree that gives her her much-sought freedom from matrimonial fetters was signed by Judge R.W. Crump yesterday. It was all done very quietly, a default being entered against the foreign defendant, who had failed to file a defense in the time allowed by the California code.

The University Corporation, which is the governing body of the University of New York, held a meeting yesterday afternoon to complete the consolidation of the University of New York Medical College and the Bellevue Hospital Medical College. The first steps toward the union of the two institutions were taken some time ago by the Regents of the University.

Prof. Felix Adler made a characteristic speech last night on the Citizens' Union at the meeting of the Young Men's Union of the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. There was a large attendance. Emil W. Kohn, former President of the union, presided.

BALTIMORE, May 14. -- A large increase in the value of exports from South Atlantic and Gulf cities for the nine months ending March of this year compared with the same period of 1895-6 is announced in a statement compiled from statistics of the principal ports.

LONDON, May 14. -- Advices from Constantinople to-day say that the Turkish Government, in its reply to the note of the Ambassadors of the powers offering mediation between Turkey and Greece, says the Sultan will be in a position to discuss mediation after the Greater Bairam Festival, which began yesterday and ends on Sunday night.

The New York State Household Economics Association, which was formed on March 19, met in the rooms of Mrs. Eliza Newcomb Alexander, its First Vice President, 128 West Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon, and made arrangements for the work of the organization this coming Winter.

On Tuesday last the Administration appeared to be without hostile designs upon Spain, and its policy toward that nation and toward Cuba was substantially the policy that had been pursued by the Administration of President CLEVELAND. The treaty obligations of the United States were observed by preventing, as far as possible, the fitting out from the United States of military expeditions designed to injure Spain.

When the Sundry Civil bill was before the Senate it was said that President CLEVELAND had been satisfied, after he had made the order creating the forest reservation, that it was too sweeping, and that he would have modified it if he had been clear about his power to do so. However that may be, the question presented by the Senate's amendment is not at all the question whether the order ought to be modified.
LONDON, May 15. -- The correspondent of The Times at Athens says:

Interest has been aroused in artistic and social circles, and in the congregation of Trinity Church especially, by the question between Frederick Wilson, who designed and superintended the decoration of Trinity Church for the bi-centenary celebration, and Wilfred Buckland, who did a large share of the work.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- President McKinley, Vice President Hobart, and the members of the Cabinet, with the exception of Secretaries Sherman and Long, arrived in this city late this afternoon to take part in the ceremonies incident to the unveiling of the Washington Monument. Representative Bailey of Texas and Secretary Porter accompanied them.

-- Evidence that when Canadian editors come here they indulge in conduct which it will be charitable to call eccentric is to be found in this statement by The Toronto Globe: "In New York a stranger cannot walk long in a public park without being surrounded by policemen, who rush up to 'order' him here or there, in accordance with some absurd ordinance."
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 14. -- Fire broke out in an attic of the Court House here at 9:45 this morning, and in a few minutes the upper story and come were all in flames.
Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt resumed his investigation into alleged violations of the Civil Service rules at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

The negotiations that have been going on for several weeks among the leaders of the regular Democratic organizations in the counties included in the territory of the Greater New York, looking to united action in the big municipal contest of this year, are now so nearly completed that it is probable that conference committees from the various organizations will be appointed within the next two weeks.
There has been a good deal of interviewing of public men of late with reference to the municipal contest, and there is much interest in the gradual shaping of the situation in men's minds.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The record of the court-martial in the case of Capt. Henry Romeyn, recently tried at Fort McPherson, Ga., on charges founded on a personal assault upon Lieut. M.J. O'Brien of his regiment, reached the War Department to-day from Gen. Merritt at New York.

There was an exciting time yesterday before Justice Roesch in the Fourth Judicial District Court. The suit brought by the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, formerly of the Baptist Tabernacle, in Second Avenue, and Miss Julia Ross, his landlady, against the Baptist City Mission Society, demanding to be reinstated in the building at 162 Second Avenue, from which they had been ejected by the society, came up for trial.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14. -- Harvard defeated the University of Pennsylvania at cricket to-day, 109 to 108, after a close and interesting contest. Harvard played loosely in the field, while Pennsylvania's agile fielding was in sharp contrast.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:
ST. JOHN'S, May 14. -- A serious encounter has taken place in Fortune Bay between a band of smugglers and the crew of the revenue cruiser Fiona.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- There is some difference of opinion among the Democratic members of the Senate Committee on Finance as to the policy to be pursued in regard to the Tariff bill. Some of them, notably Senator Gorman, are of the opinion that the Democrats should prepare a substitute bill and introduce it.

The river-front railway, in West Street, proposed by the consulting engineers of the Dock Department appears to be a device for substituting roundabout and costly transportation by land for cheap and direct transportation by water. What is the use of a marginal freight railway with spur tracks to the ship's side, when lighters and car floats have now free and convenient access to the ship's side in the slip?
LONDON, May 15. -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Daily Telegraph says:
Why does the Sugar Trust get more advantage by the Dingley bill than it already has in the present Gorman tariff, and why does it get still more by the Aldrich Senate Committee bill?

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- There is some difference of opinion among the Democratic members of the Senate Committee on Finance as to the policy to be pursued in regard to the Tariff bill. Some of them, notably Senator Gorman, are of the opinion that the Democrats should prepare a substitute bill and introduce it.

Yale won the honor, yesterday, of possessing the championship college golf team in the United States. Her team beat its Harvard opponents on the links of the Ardsley Golf Club, in the final round for the intercollegiate team championship and the silver cup given by the Ardsley Club. The score was 24 holes to 4.

In the Review of Books and Art of Feb. 6 THE TIMES describes at much length the sale at Bangs Co. of a collection of the original manuscript records of Drury Lane Theatre. As will be recalled, the records were in 174 volumes, and in date ranged from 1766 to 1852. Their character was various, as ledgers, journals, cash books, property books, and the like were comprised.

As a club the Senate of the United States cannot be said to be altogether successful. The House of Commons used to be called "the pleasantest club in London," and it may be doubted whether the Senate has ever been the pleasantest club even in Washington. For one thing, its members continue to be chosen, or to choose themselves, on other grounds than clubbability.

I was deeply pained by the "attack" on the Rev. John McNeill -- the mighty evangelist now in our midst -- by a person who did not comprehend the words he wrote when signing himself "A Lover of Truth and Justice," the heading of his letter being, "Tired of Evangelists." An evangelist is "a preacher of the Gospel."

The soldiers who practiced at Creedmoor yesterday were more fortunate than their comrades on the day before in having a nice, clear day. Four companies of the Sixty-ninth and a like number of the Forty-seventh Regiment held the ranges. A few men detailed from other companies also went up for qualification.

J.A. Willard, President of the Standard Fibre Ware Company of Duluth, Minn., and of the Mankato Knitting Company of Mankato, Minn., was arraigned before Magistrate Mott, in Jefferson Market Court, yesterday morning, on a technical charge of intoxication.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The State Department has received the following copy of the decree promulgated last month suspending silver coinage in Peru: ...
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The State Department has received the following copy of the decree promulgated last month suspending silver coinage in Peru: ...
LONDON, May 15. -- The Athens correspondent of The Daily Chronicle says:

Favored by ideal weather, the nineteenth annual Spring games of the Interscholastic Athletic Association attracted large numbers of young students to picturesque Berkeley Oval yesterday. The grounds never appeared to better advantage, and the fringe of dog carts, drags, and other fashionable turnouts on both sides of the grand stand tended to complete the pretty picture.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 15. -- Z.D. Green, colored, Probate Judge of Georgetown County, was to-day sentenced to six months' imprisonment in the penitentiary and to pay a fine of $500 for official misconduct. Green's offense consisted in failure to make the required annual report as public guardian, and the unlawful investment of funds in his hands.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- The bronze equestrian statue of Washington was unveiled to-day by President McKinley, with the accompaniments of speeches, a parade, a salute from warships, and a banquet.

During September I visited several of the reformatory institutions to see what was being done for the younger boys in regard to manual training. I found very little systematic instruction. The principal occupations were caning chairs, knitting stockings by machinery and other purely mechanical work.

LONDON, May 15. -- The Adelphi Theatre, long devoted to English melodrama, gave an enthusiastic reception to Gillette's "Secret Service," produced to-night with the same cast as in America. The house was crowded. Among those in attendance were Col. John Hay, the United States Ambassador; Mrs. Hay, and Miss Hay; Miss Davis of Washington, and many other Americans.

BOSTON, May 15. -- Some very interesting racing is promised in the twenty-one-foot restricted cruiser class, which the Beverly Yacht Club has established in Buzzard's Bay. Lawley has three boats in hand, Herreshoff has at least one, and B.B. Crowninshield has designed another for Alfred Winsor of this city, which Sheldon will build.

RICHMOND, Va., May 15. -- Policeman Percy G. Miner was shot down on the street about 1:30 o'clock this morning by a negro whom he stopped to question about his suspicious movements. The ball struck the officer in the face, and caused the loss of the sight of one eye, and he may lose the sight of the other.

ANNAPOLIS, May 15. -- For ten days preceding the closing scene of the annual examinations at the Naval Academy the city and academy are in a state of feverish excitement, in anticipation of the grand ball that sends the new class away with sentiments of appreciation from their friends and the country.

That is a pretty and interesting quarrel which has been stirred up in Chatham, Mass., by a student of the Harvard Law School. It does not appear from the dispatches whether he is a graduate of the university. But it does appear that he is deeply impressed with the advantages of the methods employed in the university for the study of English composition.

The last public hearing on the Civil Service bill was held in Albany, May 6. Carl Schurz, at the head of a delegation, spoke against the measure. The exhortation of his speech, to which the Governor makes reply, was as follows:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -- The athletic games between Yale and Harvard to-day closed with the victory of Yale, which gained points to Harvard's 24.

"Widow Goldstein," the new and presumably comic play, to be produced at the Fourteenth Street Theatre to-morrow night, is in three acts. The scene is laid in this city, in the Wall Street neighborhood. A man and a woman, well-known in the daily life of that neighborhood are said to be the living originals of two of the personages.

The report that comes from Colorado of the good work done by the women of the State during the three years they have been enfranchised may give a boom to woman suffrage in the East. One of the difficulties upon which great stress has been laid by the anti-woman suffragists here seems to have been answered in Colorado.

It is a happy family aboard the British bark Snowdon, which lies at anchor off Liberty Island. She arrived Friday, 133 days out from Honolulu, whence she brought a cargo of sugar. Capt. Rowlands is a happy man for the master of a sailer, and the men in the forecastle are happy. They are the best-agreed lot of men that ever went before the mast, bay boatmen say.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 15. -- During the week a number of families have arrived at this place and taken possession of their cottages.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., May 15. -- There is a dead-lock in the Board of Trustees of this place. The Trustees are M.L. Morgan, George E. Helm, and J.H. Ficken, who held over, and F.C. Lowe. The village should have five Trustees, but at the election in March C.W. Reinhart and J.L. Oberg each tied, with 157 votes.
ORANGE, N.J., May 15. -- At the links of the Essex County Country Club this afternoon there were a number of interesting matches, and some good scores were made in the competition for the May Cup.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 15. -- Since the departure of the Annapolis crew on Wednesday training by the first university and freshman squads has continued under the direction of Capt. Spillman. When Courtney returns it is predicted that there will be a sensational shake-up in the university squad.

NEARLY half a century has elapsed since Catherine Sinclair Forrest passed out through the portals of a wide-fronted brick mansion in West Twenty-second Street, and the brief married life of one of the greatest actors to whom America has given birth was ended.

In signing the Lexow Civil Service bill Gov. BLACK speaks the true sentiments of his heart with a frank indecency characteristic of himself and perfectly appropriate to the occasion. We remarked of his inaugural address that no previous Governor of New York had ever so far forgotten the dignity of his great office as to employ in a State paper the language of ribaldry and slang to express his political ideas.

Do the people of the Greater New York yet realize the stupendous change to be wrought by the election of the present year? In the mere matter of offices to be filled by election and by appointment as the result of the election of a Mayor, it is without parallel in the history of popular government. Every important term of office will expire with the year.

Thomas F. Bayard, former Ambassador of the United States at the Court of St. James's, arrived in this city yesterday by the steamship Paris from Southampton. He was accompanied by his wife and daughter. Mr. Bayard was met at the Quarantine station by Henry Bryan, his former private secretary.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- The proposed ordinance of the Chicago Subterranean Railroad Company, it is said, will be revived in the City Council on Monday night. The measure was introduced by Alderman Finkler in June, 1896. Since then it has slumbered in the files of the Council. The defeat of the Humphrey bills is seized by the promoters as an occasion to revive it.

This big town has been taken in and done for by a cracker from the remote wilds of Florida in the person of Sheriff Owen Huggins Deshong of De Soto County, that State. The Sheriff arrived here on Friday, having James Fullerton, a fugitive from Elmira Reformatory, who had gone to Florida on a bicycle and been arrested there for robbery, in tow.

Three alarms were rung in shortly before 9 o'clock last night for a fire in the recently erected building at 50 and 52 West Third Street. Patrolman Crittenden saw flames and smoke issuing from the basement grating and the roof at the same time, while dense black smoke poured out of almost every window in the front.

Another Republican growl over the Aldrich tariff comes from The Sandusky (Ohio) Register, a strong advocate of the re-election of Mr. HANNA. It is directed to the clause which exempts from duty foreign machinery for the manufacture of beet sugar, if erected and in use before July 1, 1899. The Register points out that no such favor is shown to the makers of cane sugar.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 15. -- Gov. Black has signed the bill of Senator Page, which changes the Code of Civil Procedure relative to the awarding of counsel fees by courts by including compensation fees for final appeals from judgments of lower courts and by placing a maximum of $500 where now no maximum exists, except in the pleasure of the Judge.

James A. Tyng, the amateur champion golfer of the Morristown Golf Club, gave another evidence yesterday, at the Meadowbrook Club, that he is a decidedly dangerous golfer. He won the big open tournament which has been going on at the Meadowbrook Club links since Thursday, beating his opponent, Oliver W. Bird, for the Meadowbrook Cup, by five holes and four to play.

Personal appeals to the devil are held by popular belief to be at least as efficacious as imprecations uttered by another. The latter has already received illustration; two German tales will confirm the force of the former. In one of these a girl, who was dancing at some village festival, boasted that no partner could tire her at the sport, not even the devil himself, and she only wished he would come and try her.

Louise Eltoff, private detective in a Sixth Avenue dry goods store, saw a well-dressed woman drop something in her umbrella on Friday afternoon. When the woman left the store the detective followed and stopped her. The woman on being threatened with arrest returned to the store.

The Jews of Germany and of other Continental States (Poland and Russia excepted) may be divided into two classes -- those that do and those that do not observe the ritual or the ceremonies of their religion. Very few of the richer classes belong to the former; most of the poorer classes belong to the latter.

Although the past week has not been marked by large transactions or other special features, there has been a general activity, indicating that the real estate market is in anything but a demoralized condition. In fact, if the statements of several of the largest brokers can be believed, the market is characterized by a remarkable firmness.

Dr. Albert Shaw, the writer on municipal government, has made a statement of his views regarding the outlook for efficient government of the Greater New York. He says the charter has created eighteen or twenty distinct and independent bureaucracies, which it will be the business of the Mayor to launch in the first six months of his administration.

Prof. McCall, for many years Principal of the Glasgow Veterinary College, said: "I have heard the evidence of Prof. Walley, and I agree with him that the operation is one of extreme torture at the time and afterward. There must be more or less pain until the wound is entirely healed. Under the most favorable circumstances it must be painful for ten days.

LONDON, May 15. -- Of all the peculiar institutions which barbarian Osmanli brought with him into Europe none serves him now so admirably in his latter-day straits as his calendar. He has a splendid lot of fasts, feasts, and festivals with which to clog unpleasant diplomatic action.

The Huguenot Yacht Club had an interesting regatta yesterday afternoon off its clubhouse at New Rochelle. The regatta was the first of the season, and brought together fifteen yachts belonging to the small sloop and all the catboat classes. The wind was not favorable for good racing. At the start it was blowing lightly from east by south.

LONDON, May 15. -- The inquiry into the fire at the Charity Bazaar, Paris, on May 4 last, has been followed with the most keen interest in aristocratic circles at the French capital. This has been especially the case with the evidence throwing light upon the cowardly conduct of many of the men.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- The monument, which is the design of Prof. Rudolph Siemering of Berlin, is about 40 feet high. From an oblong platform, reached on four sides by thirteen steps, symbolical of the thirteen original States, rises a pedestal bearing an equestrian statue in bronze of Gen. Washington.

There was a special meeting of the Woman's Health Protective Association yesterday afternoon at the house of Miss Mary Phillips, 19 West Thirty-eighth Street. It had been called to hear a report of the committee which attended the Philadelphia meetings on May 3, 4, and 5.

LONDON, May 15. -- The first week of the opera season has been marked by light attendance. Maurice Grau is silent on the subject of the reincorporation of his American firm, but he says positively he has no intention of doing anything in America the present year, and as yet has no plans for 1898.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Unless the temper of the Senate shall undergo a complete and speedy change, it begins to look as though Broker Chapman would be obliged to spend about a month as an inmate of the District of Columbia Jail, and that by turns Mr. Havemeyer, Mr. Searles, E.J. Edwards, and John S. Shriver would realize what it is to dwell in that abode chiefly of black offenders at the Nation's capital.

HAVANA, May 15. -- Mr. G.W. Fishback, the secretary of Mr. W.J. Calhoun, the Special Commissioner sent by the United States Government to investigate the death of Dr. Ricardo Ruiz, a naturalized American citizen, and other cases in which Americans are believed to have suffered outrageous treatment at the hands of the Spaniards, arrived here to-day.
PAXTON, Ill., May 15. -- Three men of science are here to study the case of Friederich Wilhelm Hoellman, who was executed yesterday.

The cat Angora, owned by ex-Commodore Connolly and belonging to the Huguenot Yacht Club, narrowly escaped being run down by the tug Pottsville of New York last Tuesday afternoon off Captain's Island. The pilot of the tug made no effort to clear the yacht, until right on top, although repeatedly warned of her presence by hand on the foredeck.
In the latest bulletin of the Racing Board is contained the following information of general interest to cyclists and promoters of race tournaments:

BERLIN, May 4. -- Labor Day, which the opponents of the Social Democracy always profess to regard as a day big with republican terrors, has passed as quietly as a British Sunday. The annual exhibition of the fine arts was opened with less pomp than ever before, perhaps because it leaked out that the Emperor would not be present, after all.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 15. -- It was a typical day for golfing. There was no wind and the course was just damp enough to make the playing pleasant. The day was evidently appreciated, for from sunrise to sunset the links were crowded, and Prof. Weir had his hands full helping his long list of novices.

Quite the most successful opening programme during the five years' existence of the Parkway Driving Club of Brooklyn was that run off yesterday afternoon. There was a goodly assemblage of members with their wives and friends, and an orchestra on the upper balcony helped to entertain between the races.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Gov. Black at noon to-day announced that he had signed the Civil Service bill prepared under his direction late in the legislative session. The bill provides that Civil Service Commissioners shall only examine for 50 per cent. ratings for candidates for office, and that the head of a department may examine as to practicability and rate the other 50 per cent.

Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast has been authorized by the Commander in Chief to grant permission to the Sixty-fifth Regiment of Buffalo to go on a practice march of eight days' duration this season. The expenses, outside of pay, it is ordered, shall not exceed the expense of the regiment to the Peekskill Camp.

The backward Spring and the rainy and dull days of the past week made even the suburbs, where the members of the New York society world are now for the most part assembled, anything but lively, and the social doldrums into which the world of New York society has seemingly drifted this Spring still continue.

OF the Justices of the Supreme Court who are rendering important services in this county is Judge Leslie W. Russell of the Fourth Judicial District. From January, 1884, to January, 1892, he was a member of the bar of New York City in active practice, and is consequently well acquainted with its lawyers.

Jean Ingelow's familiar lines embody a call to cows in the fields prevalent in Scotland; it also obtained in Lincolnshire as early as 1571. It is sometimes used in combination as cushy-cow, and has given rise to a term of endearment, cush-love. It is found in England as cushie, and in Ulster County, N.Y., as cush, (pronounced koosh.)
"Infantile Athletics" wag the subject of a paper read at a recent meeting of the Section on Pediatrics of the New York Academy of Medicine, at 17 West Fortythird Street, by Dr. Henry Ling Taylor.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 15. -- The Princeton-track athletic management is now bending every energy to get the Tiger team in condition for the annual dual meet with Columbia, which will take place at the Columbia Oval next Saturday. The performances of the Princeton athletes in this meet will also furnish a criterion of the strength of the Tiger team for the intercollegiate meet, to be held a week later in New York.

Abraham Abraham of the dry goods firm of Abraham Straus has presented to the Brooklyn Institute Ridgeway Knight's picture of "The Shepherdess," which was exhibited in the Paris Salon of last year. Mr. Abraham wrote to the institute May 10 offering the gift, and at the meeting of the Board of Trustees Friday it was formally accepted.

The young girls of the Packer Institute, Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, gave an entertainment in the chapel of the institute yesterday afternoon, when they sang an operetta, for which the words and music were written by James Truslow Adams of the class of '98. Polytechnic Institute.

When the May dance was over in Central Park yesterday afternoon the Queen lost herself. Toward 6 o'clock in the evening she stood at Sixty-eighth Street and the Boulevard when Patrolman Stephen got around that way.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The announcement was made at the Capitol to-day that a message on the Cuban situation will be sent to Congress by the President Monday. It will deal specifically with the question of the deprivations to which citizens are subjected in Cuba, and it is understood that it will recommend an appropriation for their relief.

NEWPORT, May 15. -- A week of delightfully warm weather has had a marked effect upon the foliage and Newport's famous lawns. The cottage grounds are beautiful with their rich greens, dotted here and there with beds of tulips, hyacinths, and other Spring flowers. A number of Summer residences have been opened in the last few days, and it is estimated that as many as twoscore prominent families already are located here for the season.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 15. -- Leo and Frank Stevens, aeronauts, of 361 West Twenty-fifth Street, New York Cty, who, it was believed were drowned while making a balloon ascension, were brought to this place this evening on the schooner Mary Jane, Capt. Conroy. They were picked up Wednesday night, ten miles off Highland Light, below Sandy Hook.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 15. -- For the first time in the history of the city, street cars will run in Toronto to-morrow. The question of Sunday cars is one that has agitated this city for the past ten years. Under the charter of the street railway company, a vote of the citizens was allowable every third year as to whether cars should run on the Sabbath or not.

Some idea of the growing popularity of cycle racing may be obtained from the increasing number of sanctions for tournaments issued by the Chairman of the Racing Board. A list is announced weekly. The largest of the year appeared in the bulletin of the Racing Board last week. It indicates that this will doubtless be the busiest season the sport has ever known.

Street improvements and the running down of cyclists in the public thoroughfares are two questions which the enthusiasts in wheeling talked about last week. The most interesting piece of news relating to the first mentioned matter was made known on Thursday. It was that the agitation for asphalt strips in streets leading to the ferries had at last been rewarded by the awarding of a contract for the work in East Twenty-third Street.

The fourteenth annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club, to be sailed on Long Island Sound on May 31, bids fair to surpass all previous regattas of the club in number of entries. The Regatta Committee, composed of H.B. McAllister, P.H. Leary, J. Wimmer, W.T. Hyde, and William A. Towner, Chairman, has invited the following clubs to participate and enter yachts: New York, Larchmont, Brooklyn, Pavonia, Yonkers, Corinthian, and Jersey City.

ANNAPOLIS, May 15. -- Contrary to expectations the weather to-day was all that could be desired for the race between the rival boat crews of Cornell and the Naval Academy. The boys appeared early and took a trial spin over the course, but did not attempt to make anything like speed, contenting themselves with just enough pulling to limber up a bit for the struggle that came later in the day.

The discovery of a new source of Lagos rubber, from a tree known to the natives as the "Ire," or "Ireh," has given a great impetus to the trade of the West Coast of Africa in a rubber of extremely good quality. The Kicksia africana forms a tree 50 to 60 feet high, with a trunk averaging 12 to 14 inches in diameter.

NEW HAVEN, May 15. -- W.R. Clinton of West Haven was arrested to-day by Police Captain Cowles because of a threat of assassination which Clinton sent by mail this afternoon to the Rev. Dr. Newman Smyth, pastor of Center Church, the most ancient and aristocratic of New Haven's churches, and of which Clinton is a member.

The return of Mr. BAYARD will be welcomed by all his old admirers and by the new ones he has made by his representation of his country abroad. It has been a representation in the line of the best traditions of the office he has held and in the incumbency of which very few mistakes have been made. But the ex-Ambassador is quite as urgently needed at home as he could have been needed abroad.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Supt. Skinner of the Department of Public Instruction handed down to-day his decision in the appeal of Samuel Kennedy and others from the action of the Board of Education of the City of Watervliet, in refusing to require six teachers in one of the public schools of such city, held in the St. Bridget's Parochial School Building, to distinctive dress or order of which they are members.

There is a most ingenious young woman in the domestic science department of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, and she has a most ingenious cooking apparatus. Miss Alberta Thomas is the young woman, and her stove is in the nature of an Aladdin oven, one difference being that, while the regular stove costs some $35, hers cost $5, and it will do everything she desires it to do in the most satisfactory manner.

VIENNA, May 3. -- The Emperor Francis Joseph is back in Vienna from his visit to the Czar at St. Petersburg, and the Austrian capital is full of rumors concerning the results of the imperial meeting. Nothing more is heard now about a reconstruction of the three Emperors' alliance so much discussed in the past ten days.

Three organizations practiced yesterday at Creedmoor, the Second Signal Corps and Troop C of Brooklyn and Separate Company No. 17 of Flushing, L.I. The weather was all that could be desired, and there were hardly any traces left of the inclement weather prevailing during the earlier part of the week.
The New Jersey road book for 1897 will be issued about June 1. It will, it is said, be a great improvement over the book of last year.

The man himself is of less than average height, thin, nervous, sick-faced, with great and exposed forehead, hair habitually short, beard of frosted chestnut. His eyes are almost level with his face. His eagle-beak would have excited the admiration of Sir Charles Napier, who once exclaimed, "Give me a man with plenty of nose."

The great caisson intended for the new East River bridge, which on Thursday withstood all attempts to move it, was successfully launched yesterday from the yards at the foot of North Second Street, Williamsburg. There was a large gathering of engineers and contractors present to witness the launch.

THE choir of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin was organized in 1870 and sang at the first service in the church on Dec. 8 of that year. It consisted of about twenty boys and six men. The English communion services were rendered at the high celebrations on Sundays, and the solo parts were taken by boys.

Let us now examine into some of the conditions surrounding domestic wells and springs in the larger towns and villages, conditions which also prevail sometimes even about rural homes. We shall then be better able to understand how a well, like a Nevada silver mine, may have "millions in it," and how "the old oaken bucket" may bring from the depths elements of disease with the same draught that refreshes the thirsty throat.
NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- There will be no further court proceedings to have a receiver appointed for the Metropolitan Savings and Loan Association of this city.

A table of relative heights and weights given by Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders in the May number of What to Eat is worth repeating. The weight of ordinary clothing is included in the table. The woman who reaches the minimum or maximum weight for her height is recommended to look carefully after her diet, not only that her figure may be what it should be, but for the sake of her general health.

The molecules of the Democratic Party are slowly settling into place after the disturbances and disruptions of the Bryan campaign. Not all of them have much cohesive affinity for their neighbors, but arrogant and reckless misuse of power by the Republicans rekindles the old party spirit and impels them to come together.

The war in the Levant has evidently wrought great changes. Before it broke out, Turkey was in the hands of the powers, and Greece was acting upon her own account. Now that Greece has been beaten, she has been induced to put herself into the hands of the powers unreservedly. But now it is Turkey which takes airs of independence, and discloses an intention of using her victory to suit herself.

A great many proofs, now more or less familiar to most people, show quite clearly that the decay of animal or vegetable matter is not a simple chemical change, inevitable in the nature of things, but a violent interference with the natural course on the part of hostile organisms. The bacteria which produce decomposition are very minute plants, which grow, like mushrooms, or molds, upon organic matter, and which reproduce their like with incredible rapidity.

CINCINNATI, May 15. -- A large crowd saw some excellent sport at Newport to-day. The weather was rather cool, but the track fast. The surprise of the day was the defeat of Gid Law by Winker in the third race, a mile handicap. Summaries:

Golf was not lacking in activity last week, for the college boys and the big tournament at the Meadowbrook Club kept the sport in an unusually live condition. This coming week the activity will be continued by a four-day open tournament at the Knollwood Country Club, near Elmsford, Westchester County.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 15. -- The 1st of June will bring the end of the Lakewood season. The hotel managers cannot but regard it as a successful time upon the whole, with a remarkably prosperous business for the Spring months. Of the leading hotels the Laurel House alone remains open, with rather more than the usual number of Spring people, many of whom will remain until the house closes, on the 1st of June.

Despite all her apparent advances of friendship, Russia was ever and is yet looked upon with suspicion and antipathy in Greece. There is too great a difference between the rude and despotic character of the Muscovites and the refined and liberal nature of the Hellenes. Moreover, the latter are still caressing their ideas of Pan-Hellenism and their dream of again possessing Constantinople, which is coveted by Russia herself.

AN unassuming man of small stature and slight physique, courteous in his manner and quiet in his speech, sits at a desk in a handsomely furnished office at Police Headquarters, in Mulberry Street, and controls and directs the operations of the largest police force on this continent.

Owners and trainers who have been complaining that three days' racing a week does not afford them sufficient opportunity for earning enough money to keep themselves and their charges, will find some consolation in the fact that there will be an extra day's racing at Morris Park on Wednesday.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 15. -- Darius W. Hover, the father of fifteen-year-old May Hover, who ran away from her home in Brodheads Bridge in Catskill Mountains the early part of the present week, is happy tonight because he has found his daughter, for whom he has been searching ever since she ran away.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Society was astounded by the information that George Mair, a well known and wealthy man, whose stormy and second engagement finally resulted in his wedding last month to Florence McLaughlin, daughter of the millionaire coffee man, had cut short his honeymoon and was on the way home.

IT is a good thing for the curled darlings of the opera to "go on the road." New York worships them so utterly, so estatically, that it is no wonder they become distended as to their occiputs and fancy they are going about like Virgil's Dame Rumor, with their feet upon the earth and their sublime heads knocking the stars out of the sky.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 15. -- The Cornell athletes were snowed under to-day by the University of Pennsylvania boys in their dual track and field events. In the event, the mile walk, W.B. Fetterman, Pennsylvania, lowered the intercollegiate record for a mile by 5 seconds, going the distance in 6 minutes and 47 seconds.

John R. Gentry, 2:00 1/2 and Robert J., 2:01 1/2, won their titles as "Kings of the Turf," by making the marks recorded behind their names. Since their purchase by Lewis G. Tewksbury, he has seen to it that they have had as much care and attention as if they were rulers of a nation.

AMONG the few dramatic topics of a dull week at the fag end of the season none seems to me of more importance than the rumored change of management of the American Theatre. I am afraid I have fallen into the habit of expecting a great deal from that nobly proportioned and well-appointed playhouse, and of proclaiming my expectations or expressing my regret when they are not fulfilled.
The following excerpts are taken from a lecture delivered by Dr. Emily G. Hunt before the Wagner Institute, at Philadelphia, recently:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 15. -- A large crowd saw Williams defeat Syracuse here to-day. The weather was fine and the track fast. The score was 65 1/2 to 46 1/2. New college records were made by Syracuse in the broad jump and the high hurdles. These were the events:

GLASGOW, May 5. -- The Marquis of Dufferin and Ava is the Commodore of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, which he assisted in founding, and occupied the chair at the recent dinner of the Royal Ulster in Belfast. Lord Londonderry and several baronets were present, which is more than the Clyde clubs can boast of at their festivities.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The Senate committee investigating the condition of the civil service resumed its session to-day, Senators Pritchard, Chilton, Elkins, Lodge, and Harris of Kansas and Civil Service Commissioner Procter being present.

A Shakespeare garden party in aid of the New York Kindergarten Association caused an exodus of several hundred society people from this city to Bronxville yesterday afternoon. The invitations were in the language of Jaques in "As You Like It":
