In the Counties of Fermanagh and Monaghan; in the Carmelite Convent, New Ross; the Ursuline Convent, Blackrock, County Cork; the Mercy Convent, Kinsale, and other places in the South, the "Irish crochet lace" is produced. This fabric, known in France as "Pointe d'Irlande," durable and decorative in its two chief varieties of "relieved" work and "guipure," has already acquired a large Parisian sale.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 15.-The Cincinnati team defeated the New York team in the last game of the present series easily to-day. In the third inning joyce was put out of the game by Umpire Ernslie for questioning a, decision. W. Clark went to third baae in his place. Attendance. 4,000. Score:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16. -- The police made good their promise to prevent Sunday ball in Cleveland if an attempt was made to play to-day. At the end of the first inning between the Cleveland and Washington teams, all the players on both sides and Umpire Tim Hurst were arrested and taken to the Central Police Station, four miles distant, where President Robison gave bail for the prisoners, and they were released.

Four ruffians attacked, robbed, and nearly murdered a passenger on the ferryboat Manhattan Beach of the Long Island City and Thirty-fourth Street line a little after 7 o'clock last night. The crime was committed while the boat was crossing from Long Island City just before reaching the dock, and was witnessed by hundreds of persons who, on account of the desperate appearance of the robbers, were afraid to interfere.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A private letter dated at Sancti Spiritus May 7, received in this city yesterday morning from an American resident in Sancti Spiritus, gives the following details of the death of Col. Carlos Aguirre, a Cuban officer, resident of New York for twenty years, whose family is well known in this city.

The Progressive Democratic League, which claims to be a combination of trades unions, Knights of Labor, silver clubs, and Democratic organizations, held its regular meeting yesterday afternoon at 420 Hudson Street. By some coincidence a communication from this organization was received by the Central Labor Union, asking it to send delegates to the league. The Committee on Outside Communications of the union recommended that the communication should not be read.

Strangely the strains of "Old Hundred" sounded to the ears of excursionists on passing craft. Sung my manly voices, in which were mingled the accents of many nationalities, the familiar hymn was heard midst unfamiliar environment. For a fact it is that from the deck of a merchant sailing vessel the hymn of praise but rarely jibes with the "heave ho" of the sailor man.

A better day for riding and driving than yesterday could not have been wished for by the thousands who were on the Central Park drives and bridle paths and on the Riverside and other drives outside of the park. The muddy roads of Saturday had dried out sufficiently to make the going excellent, and the light breeze and somewhat cloudy skies which did not bring the rain they portended made outdoor exercise delightful.

New York's share of the export trade shows no sign of improvement. The Bureau of Statistics has just issued its bulletin for May 10, showing exports of principal articles for the ten months ending April 30. Here are some interesting comparisons:...

NEWARK, May 16. -- The 3 o'clock train from New York on the Central Railroad of New Jersey jumped the track on the bridge over the Hackensack River this afternoon and narrowly escaped a terrible disaster. As it was no damage was done further than delaying traffic for an hour and the shaking up of the passengers.

Many and various are the reasons ascribed for the existing stagnation in Wall Street, and the lack of speculative spirit which has for some time past been a matter of serious consideration among Stock Exchange houses. Mr. F.J. Lisman, the well-known bond expert, has some views on the question with which he is frank and outspoken.

The dissension among the members of the Ninth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., took shape and substance yesterday afternoon by the absence of Capt. Simeon S. O'Connor and most of Company A, his command, from the annual sermon, which was delivered by the Rev. Dr. Madison C. Peters at the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street.

YONKERS, May 16. -- The examination of "Wally" O'Connor, the alleged bank burglar, arrested on suspicion of being one of the three men who robbed the Yonkers Savings Bank here on April 12 last, was begun yesterday.

For the first time, so far as is known, the birth, enlightenment, and Nirvani of Sakya Muni, the Buddha, of Gautama, was celebrated in public in this country last night. The ceremony took place in the Pouch Mansion, 345 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, and some 400 believers and curious persons were present.
PARIS, May 16. -- Mme. de Laume and her daughter have succumbed to the injuries they received at the Charite Bazaar fire.

-- It begins to look as though, through a justice higher than poetic, Turkey would prove to be an instrument for the punishment of the recent crimes of the European powers, They united in permitting the humiliation of the defiant Greeks, but it is more than douotful if they can unite in driving the Moslem wolf they unchained away from the prey they allowed him to strangle.

While looking over your valued paper today, I became very much interested in an article headed "West Side Rapid Transit," noting the reply of President Albert J. Elias to President Vreeland. I would say that, representing one of the associations which Mr. Elias says the Metropolitan Traction Company is trying to hoodwink, I cannot agree with him in his statements.

W.G. Steele of Portland, Ore., Consul of "Mazamas," a company of mountain climbers of that city, is at present in New York, the guest of Col. E.B. Crane of 35 Broadway. Mr. Steele is here for the purpose of perfecting arrangements for his mountain climbing club to ascend snowcapped Mount Ranier, 14,525 feet in height.
HIGHLAND PALLS, N. Y., A,Iay 16.-A handsome new pipe organ costing $5,000 was dedicated in the Episcopal Church here to-day, Archdeacon W. R. Thomas officiating.
CHICAGO, May 16. -- Capt. E. Green of the Sacramento police was robbed of $1,500 by two colored women to-day.

DURHAM, N.J., May 16. -- The Rev. I.W. Gowen, pastor of the Grove Reformed Church of this place, to-night again paid his respects to the alleged poolroom which has been flourishing in West New York, delivering a sermon on "What I Saw at Little Monte Carlo."

Elverton R. Chapman, broker and capitalist, left yesterday afternoon for Washington, where he will to-day begin serving a sentence of thirty days in jail for refusing to answer certain questions put to him two years ago by the Senatorial committee which was investigating the sugar scandal.
EAST BRIDGEWATER, Mass., May 16. -- Lewis B. Hayward, a Grand Army veteran, was found hanging to a tree in the woods between here and Elmwood this afternoon.

HALIFAX N.S., May 16. -- The steamer Diana, which will carry the Canadian Government expedition to Hudson Bay, arrived here to-day from St. John's, N.F., and will be provisioned at once for her long sojourn in the North. The Diana is a fine steamer for ice work. The scientific party and the ship's crew will make the number on board fifty.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 16. -- The Porte has replied officially to the note of the powers, and declines to agree to an armistice until the following conditions are accepted: The annexation of Thessaly, an indemnity of 10,000,000, (Turkish,) and the abolition of the capitulations.

Walter H. Barney, President of the American Whist League, paid a visit to this city Saturday, coming from his home in Providence, R.I. He had a consultation with R.H. Weems of Brooklyn, Corresponding Secretary of the league, regarding the seventh annual congress, which is to be held at Put-in-Bay, Ohio, early in July.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 3. -- No sooner had it become apparent that a Republican Administration would succeed the Democratic in the United States than a rumor went abroad here that the Government here had determined to reimpose the schedule of import duties that had been remitted in 1892 with a view of securing reciprocity with the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The tariff question will be taken up in the Senate this week, but it is not certain that it will occupy the Senate's attention for any considerable time.

Henry Ward Beecher preached his first sermon in Brooklyn fifty years ago yesterday, on the site of what is now Plymouth Church, on Orange Street. Commemorating the event, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, pastor of Plymouth Church, in the morning service yesterday, preached on "The Church and the Preacher" before a large congregation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- The one hundred and ninth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America will meet at Winona Assembly Grounds, Eagle Lake, Kosciusko County, Ind., May 20, and probably will continue in session until May 31. The assembly will be composed of about 600 delegates, one-half of them ministers and the other half ruling elders.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton of the Church of the Divine Paternity preached on "Divine Love and Divine Wrath," at Carnegie Lyceum yesterday morning. He discussed the apparent inconsistencies of the New Testament, and by a series of logical deductions showed that instead of contradictions, "Divine Love and Divine Wrath" were both necessary in the work of establishing righteousness in the world. Dr. Eaton said in part:

An in interesting variety of facts relative to coal production, prices, and transportation, at home and abroad, is contained in a compact red-book entitled "The Coal Trade," compiled and published by Frederick E. Saward, editor of The Coal Trade Journal. One of the most significant facts brought out in this compilation is that the United States is rapidly gaining on Great Britain as a coal-producing nation.

DENVER, Col., May 16. -- The famous law suits of Popejoy et al vs. Stratton, involving $25,000,000 of mining property on Battle Mountain, in the very heart of the Cripple Creek district, came to an end last week at Colorado Springs by a voluntary settlement on the part of W.S. Stratton.

LONDON, May 17. -- The Times's correspondent at Kephalosis, under date of Friday, reports an interview with Gen. Smolenski, whose headquarters are at that point and close to the hills south of Almyros, a position exceedingly difficult to take by assault.

ARDMORE, Indian Territory, May 16. -- A south-bound passenger train on the Santa Fe Road, known as the Chicago and Galveston express, went through a trestle sixteen miles south of here at 5 o'clock this morning. Fifteen persons, passengers and train men, were injured. Several of these are seriously hurt, and it is believed that two will die.

After all the swashbucklers of spoils politics have broken their heads against the stone wall that civil service reform has built around the public business comes Gov. BLACK and tries to undermine while professing to mend it. If his attempt were as skillful as it is base, it might permanently overthrow the safeguard.

TURNWOOD, N.Y., May 16. -- Here is the central point of what is left of trout angling on the once famous Beaverkill. Out of Ulster County, on this stream one has to fish for this delightful water sprite, and half a dozen small trout is about the daily reward of most patient manipulation of the "garden hackle" or kindred abominations.

ALBANY, May 16. -- The reports of County Treasurers to Excise Commissioner Lyman, pursuant to an order for reports of excise receipts for the first ten days in May, show increases in the sums received from cities and slight decreases in small counties where no license was voted in many towns.

The pleasant weather of yesterday, combined with the fact that crews preparing for the Harlem River Regatta on Memorial Day have only two more Sundays on which to train, had the effect of bringing out an unusually large number of oarsmen on the Harlem River. The water was smooth most of the day.

It is the opinion of WILLIAM J. BRYAN that "the adoption of the gold standard by Japan and Peru has increased the strain upon gold and emphasized the warnings uttered by the advocates of free silver during the campaign." The adoption of the silver standard by us would relieve the "strain upon gold" to the extent of the entire store of that metal now in our possession.
LONDON, May 17. -- The correspondent of The Daily Chronicle at Arta, telegraphing Saturday at noon, says:

The Rev. Minot J. Savage answered in the negative the question, "Is the world getting worse?" in a sermon which he preached yesterday at the Church of the Messiah. He said that people who argued that the world was growing worse did not know what they were talking about. Civilization is gradually advancing, and the cry that "the rich are growing richer and the poor poorer" is based on false reasoning.

Bernhard Cohen, one of the oldest Jewish residents of this city died at his home, 20 East Forty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon. He had lived in almost perfect health until four days ago, when he was seized with a sudden attack of pneumonia, which confined him to his bed, and eventually caused his death.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- "The months of March and April were busy times for our force of Inspectors," said Col. Wheeler, Chief Post Office Inspector, to-day. "In fact, during the past six months our men have had more work on hand than would seem possible for such a limited number to handle.

Except in Washington there is a general awakening to the blunders and the perils of the Administration and the Republican Party. It is a subject of men's speech in private and in public that in beating off one set of unsound and dangerous aspirants for power the Nation has committed itself into the hands of another set scarcely more heedful of its welfare and equally bent on their own selfish and harmful ends.
BALTIMORE, May 16. -- The Very Rev. Dr. Edward P. Allen, recently appointed Bishop of Mobile, Ala., was consecrated at the cathedral here this morning.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company promises to confer a real boon upon New York in giving it a cheap cab service. There has from time immemorial been a superstition that a cheap cab service was out of the question in New York. There was some peculiarity in the climate which made horses eat more and cabs wear out faster than in other large cities.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- No sooner had the journal of the last session been read in the House to-day than Mr. Simpson (Pop., Kan.,) and Mr. Wheeler (Dem., Ala.,) shouted objections. Mr. Wheeler was trying to repeat his Constitutional objections raised last week amid the objections of several Republicans, when the President's secretary, Mr. Pruden, appeared with a large document and announced: "A message from the President."
Companies A, C, F, and H of the Eighth Regiment occupied the range at Creedmoor yesterday. The weather was perfect, though a trifle cool, and the wind was rather favorable to the shooters.

An unexpectedly large list of entries has been received for the race meet of the Quill Club Wheelmen, which will take place Saturday at Manhattan Beach. In the amateur division there will be over 175 riders, while in the cash-prize contests will figure twenty-five of the fastest speed men in the country.

JAMAICA, L.I., May 17. -- The officials of the towns of Hempstead and North Hempstead have commenced to build a road which will run from Rockaway Park to Far Rockaway, Lawrence, Cedarhurst, Woodsburg, across the Merrick Road between Lynbrook and Valley Stream, through Hempstead Gardens to Hempstead, to Mineola, to Roslyn, to Manhanset Avenue, Port Washington.

The following letter has been sent within the last few days to a large number of local dry goods retailers by an importing house of this city. A similar letter was sent to the same dealers some time ago by another importing house:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17. -- The bookmakers did a good business again to-day, for in the six events only two of the public's choices were first under the wire. The track was fast, the best time of the meeting being made. There were about 3,000 people in attendance. In the Corncracker Stakes Paul Griggs won over George Rose, the favorite.

LONDON, May 17. -- H.B. Chamberlin, formerly of Denver, Col., was killed yesterday at Staines in Middlesex, by a fall from his bicycle. He was the London agent for a New York life insurance company, and was organizer of the American Society in London.

Section 3 of Article XII. of the Constitution of the State of New York, drawn with great care, discussed thoroughly by the people, and adopted by them with full understanding, provides that elections for local officers in the City of New York shall fall in years when important elections to political offices are not held.

HAVANA, May 17. -- During a number of small skirmishes which have taken place recently in the Province of Santa Clara the insurgents left thirty men killed on the field, an insurgent Major and sub-prefect surrendered, and sixty-five armed insurgents were captured.

-- "Abolition of the capitulations," which Turkey demands as part payment for sparing the remnants of Greece, is a phrase with much meaning. By "capitulations" is meant the old concessions of extraterritorial rights to foreigners residing in Turkey. Such rights are granted -- under compulsion -- by barbarous and semi-civilized nations, and their existence is a constant humiliation.

Newell Bliss, who was for years a merchant of this city and a prominent member of Calvary Baptist Church, died Saturday at his home in Chambersburg, Penn. For the last year he had been suffering from heart trouble, complicated by occasional hemorrhages. A recent hemorrhage was the immediate cause of his death.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 17. -- To-day's game as a mixed affair. In the second inning the Clevelands knocked McJames out of the box. In the next six innings they failed to get a run off Swain. In the ninth McGuire was put in to bat for Swain. His hit tied the score, and he was sent home by De Montreville's single, putting the Senators one ahead.

PARIS, May 17. -- A memorial service for the repose of the soul of the late Duc d'Aumale was held this afternoon in the Church of the Madeleine. The ceremonies, which were most imposing, were attended by all the French Ministers, the members of the French Institute, and a great number of public officials, all in uniform.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Elverton R. Chapman, the Sugar Trust witness who refused to answer a Senate committee's questions as to whether he had acted as a broker for any Senators in speculations in Sugar Trust, occupies a cell at the District Jail to-night, and will continue therein for twenty-five days.

Congressman John Murray Mitchell of the Eighth New York District and John R. Dos Passos talked yesterday of the charges made by Col. J.E. Bloom, Chairman of the Committee on Organization of the Democratic Honest-Money League, and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, that Mr. Mitchell had violated confidence and that Mr. Dos Passos was a plagiarist.

The officers and Directors of the City and Suburban Homes Company, whose aim it is to provide model homes for working people, held their first annual meeting in the small hall of Cooper Union yesterday afternoon. D.O. Mills, R. Fulton Cutting, Adrian Iselin, Jr., and Elgin R.L. Gould were elected to succeed themselves as Directors to serve three years.

Crowds of striking tailors began to assemble in and about Walhalia Hall quite early yesterday morning, some enthusiastic over the fight which, they felt sure would result in a great victory for them, and others anxious to learn whether the contractors had shown any signs of weakening.

NEWPORT, Ky., May 17. -- Virgie Cook was claimed out of a selling race at Newport to-day, but her owner, H.M. Jones, refused to give her up to Turner Co., who put in the claim. After investigation, the judges ruled Jones and the filly off the turf. Summaries of to-day's races:

When the meeting to hear further arguments against the continuation of the franchises on Sixth and Eighth Avenues to the Metropolitan Traction Company was called to order yesterday Chairman Parker of the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen announced that no further hearings will be held until after the courts have rendered their decision in the matter.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A number of silver Republican members of the Senate and House met at Senator Pettigrew's house last night and decided to support a proposition providing for an export bounty on agricultural products. They take the position that by this system only can the farmer secure benefit to compensate him for import duties on other articles, and will support a proposition for an amendment to the Tariff bill providing for the bounties.

On Sunday, the 16th inst., I was a passenger on a train of the New York and Putnam Branch of the New York Central Railroad. Arriving ten minutes before the time of the departure of the train, I found all the seats occupied and some passengers already standing. Inquiry made of a trainman elicited the information that no additional coach would be attached, and a vigorous protest produced no change in the situation.
There is to be an important conference of Greater New York Republican politicians in Washington with Senator Thomas C. Platt to-day.

" The Widow Goldstein," produced after no large expenditure of either money or preparatory labor at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night, is described on the bill as a "farcical character sketch." For this time of the year, this is an example of unusual modesty on the part of the authors, Lillian Lewis and Lawrence Marston, for the piece has a "serious interest," and one would naturally expect it to be described as a comedy.

The Commercial Travelers' Club gave an informal smoker last night at the club rooms in West Thirty-eighth Street, at which Col. Fred D. Grant, Job E. Hedges, and a number of railroad and steamship men were present as guests.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Col. John Tracey, Superintendent of Charities for the District of Columbia and brother of ex-Congressman Tracey of New York, died at Providence Hospital last night of Bright's disease.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 17. -- This State witnessed the spectacle this morning of two separate bodies sitting in session in the same hall, and each claiming to be the Senate of Kentucky. The right over the Stephenson Fusion bill was renewed, and the advocates of the bill were confident of its passage.

The "fake hotels" have to some extent been got rid of by enforcing the amendments to the Raines law respecting the accommodations that such edifices shall offer. It is necessary that a hotel for the purpose of selling liquor shall be a hotel in its capacity for entertaining guests.

A Coroner's jury yesterday decided that the fire on the Mallory Line steamer Leona on the night of May 8, whereby thirteen persons came to their death, was accidental. The verdict exonerated from all blame the Captain of the vessel, James Wilder, the crew, and the management of the Mallory Line.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- A bill providing for an appropriation of $50,000 for the relief of Americans suffering in Cuba went through the Senate to-day, receiving a unanimous vote. An objection raised by Mr. Bailey of Texas, the Democratic leader, prevented similar action by the House. Mr. Bailey objected to the consideration of the relief measure because the Republicans would not consent to embody in it a clause granting belligerent rights to the Cubans.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met at the headquarters, 39 West Twenty-third Street, last night and transacted routine business. James B. Reynolds presided. The following selection of additional Assembly District Chairmen was announced.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 17. -- At 11 o'clock this morning the Government Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition was formally opened in the presence of the representatives of the Government, Senators and Congressmen from Tennessee, the Centennial Exposition management, the State and city officials, foreign representatives at the Exposition, and leading citizens of the State.

The Congregational Club held its last meeting before the Summer vacation at the St. Denis Hotel last night. The President, John H. Washburn, presided. The Rev. Frank Goodwin, the Rev. Dr. William Hays Ward, and Mr. S.S. Marple were elected members of the Executive Committee, to serve three years.

Corporation Counsel SCOTT has made the way of the spoils transgressor hard and most unpleasant by designating the present City Civil Service Commission as a board to conduct all examinations to determine the fitness of applicants for places in the Law Department.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Pettigrew (Pop., S.D.,) called up the resolution for the appointment of a committee of five Senators to investigate the issue of patents for lands to the Pacific railroads and to the California and Oregon Railroad.

The United States cruiser Detroit, after a two years' and a half absence, in which she has been attached to the Asiatic station, returned yesterday, coming into port gayly flying homeward bound flag, jack, and pennant.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Two correspondents -- one for an Eastern and Democratic newspaper, and the other representing a Western and Republican paper -- have recently returned here from Cuba, where both writers have been spending some months. Each had ample opportunity to learn the situation.

It is inconceivable that Turkey should have assumed the insolent and defiant attitude she assumed toward Europe without a recent assurance of powerful support. "The Last of the Caliphs" takes a tone that would not have misbecome the Mohammedan conqueror of Constantinople four hundred years ago or his successors of a century later, who were still the terror of all Europe.

It was purely a message of humanity, not of politics or of jingoism, that the President sent to Congress yesterday. The American Consul General reports that some 800 Americans are in Cuba without means of support. The President asks an appropriation of $50,000 for their relief.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, May 17. -Mrs. Charles Luzler and Mrs. Jay Smith, wives of two of the most extensive stock raisers in Ohio, were arrested to-day on the charge of shoplifting. The families are among the oldest and most prominent in this part of the State.

The Chicago Times-Herald takes it upon itself to remind the gold Democrats that tariffs are at most but a passing ailment, while repudiation is permanent disability. Therefore, it complacently reasons, the Democrats who are for sound money must come into alliance with the Republican Party.

LONDON, May 17. -- The Prince of Wales held a levee at St. James's Palace to-day in behalf of the Queen. The weather was brilliant, and there was an unusually large attendance of Ministers and members of the Diplomatic Corps.
D.B. Dearborn, the agent here of Arthur Sewall Co.'s big steel ship Dirigo, said yesterday that he had no fears for the vessel's safety.

PITTSBURG, May 17. -- The New York team lost the game to-day by costly errors. The combined errors of Joyce and Davis let Pittsburg score two men. Rusie pitched a splendid game, but Killen of Pittsburg pitched a still better one. He made a record that has not been equaled by any pitcher this year.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- A.M. Palmer will continue in control of the Great Northern Roof Garden and the Great Northern Theatre. This condition was made possible to-day when Judge Ewing placed the case of the Great Northern Theatre and Hotel Company vs. A.M. Palmer at the end of the regular call.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Promptly at 2 o'clock to-day the Morgan Cuban resolution was taken up in the Senate. At that time the galleries were filled to overflowing. The Morgan resolution declares that a condition of public war exists in Cuba and that strict neutrality shall be maintained by the United States.

ALBANY, May 17. -- The Executive Department this morning announced through Private Secretary Griffith that thirty-one bills in the hands of Mayors of various cities had not been returned in time, and so are as dead as if they were vetoed either by the Mayor or the Governor.
No gold was engaged for export at the Sub-Treasury yesterday. Rumors of intention to ship from $1,500,000 to $3,000,000 in coin and bars during the week were current, but were not substantiated.
Gov. Black's personal attack on Carl Schurz in an official document continues to excite unfavorable comment.
LONDON, May 18. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Vienna says the following was received there late last night from a correspondent with the Turkish forces in Thessaly:...
LONDON, May 17. -- All the powers have agreed, through their Ambassadors at Constantinople, to protest against the cession of Thessaly to Turkey, and the abolition of the capitulations.

It is not necessary to look far for evidence that somewhere near the foundation of human nature lies a deep and abiding thirst. The brutes are fond of drinking, but it does not yet appear that they have a thirst for beverages that confuse their brains and diffuse their locomotive powers.
LONDON, May 18. -- Speaking to-night at the Junior Constitutional Club, Lord Salisbury touched briefly on the complications in Southeastern Europe.

An attempt was made to kill John R. McPherson, formerly United States Senator from New Jersey, yesterday in his office in the Aldridge Building, 149 Church Street. The assailant was William Van Aken, once a prominent contractor and builder in New Jersey, but now living at the Adams House, 15 Tenth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- The children's coat and jacket makers of this city to the number of 375 went on strike to-day for an increase of 25 per cent. in wages. The strikers include all of that class of garment workers in the city, excepting thirty who are employed in one shop. These have also declared their intention of joining the strikers.

-- What on earth are those "desperate and extreme measures" which the Greek Government threatens to take unless the powers come instantly to its rescue? By putting MANOS or SMOLENSKI in command of the army and letting them win a few battles, the holders of Turkish securities might be seriously annoyed, but that would involve financial losses to King GEORGE, and therefore is not even to be considered.

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 18. -- The Sultan has ordered two hospitals of 600 and 100 beds, respectively, to be erected near the Yildiz Kiosk, in order to enable him to visit the Turkish soldiers who have been wounded in the campaign against the Greeks.

Three hundred prominent business men and firms representing millions of capital, much of which is dependent upon Cuban trade for its profitable employment, have addressed a memorial to the Secretary of State praying the Government to consider the expediency of taking measures to end the war in Cuba. They speak in the name of commerce with the great authority of prominent merchants, bankers, manufacturers, and owners and agents of steamship lines throughout the country.

President Angell of the Good Roads Association of Brooklyn paid his compliments to Park Commissioner Dettmer at the semi-annual meeting of the organization, held last evening in the Common Council chamber of the City Hall.

On one of the cots of Harlem Hospital Emily Johnson lay last night close to death. Early in the evening she was fearfully burned while in a flat at 1,883 First Avenue, and she insists that she tried to kill herself by pourning kerosene over her clothing and then setting fire to it.
PARIS, May 18. -- The retiring United States Ambassador, James B. Eustis, gave a luncheon to-day to his successor, Gen. Horace Porter.

Michael Hughes, seventy years old, of 352 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, met his death yesterday afternoon under peculiar circumstances. Late in the afternoon Hughes, who was an expressman, was riding with Patrick Lynch of 149 Brook Avenue in his single wagon on Second Avenue. Lynch was driving and occupied the driver's place on the right-hand side.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Representative Wilber of New York is actively pushing a movement in conjunction with W.A. McKnight, a member of the Liverpool and Manchester Chambers of Commerce, who came to America for this special purpose, whereby it is hoped to extend the market for American cheese abroad by rendering impossible fraudulent practices that have affected injuriously the standing of American cheese with the foreign consumer.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18. -- There was something of a sensation in the stockholders' meeting of the United States Rubber Company, held in the local factory of the company, on Burnett Street, to-day. There was a large attendance of stockholders. Joseph A. Bannigan, formerly President of the company, but who not long ago withdrew as a Director, caused the trouble.

Racing Commissioner and former Congressman John Sanford and his wife were at Morris Park yesterday to see the contest for the Laureate Stake, an event named for the imported English horse owned by Mr. Sanford. It was the second running of the stake, the first event, a year ago, having fallen to the Messrs. Thompson of the Brookdale Stud with their colt Bastion.
PLATT is trying to keep Bryanism alive among the Democrats of New York and to make it the controlling force. All the trumpets of his policy proclaim this purpose, and he confesses it himself.
LOUISVILLE, May 18. -- Three favorites and two outsiders divided the money at Churchill Downs this afternoon. Track fast. Attendance, 6,000. Summaries:...
The houses that Quinn built in Harlem are likely to become part of the history of law in New York and to settle a legal problem which has been long, frequently, and copiously discussed.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Great pressure has been brought to bear on the President for a reform in certain branches of the civil service, especially since the meetings of the Senate committee investigating the workings of the civil service. The main propositions in the reforms demanded are briefly as follows:

PITTSBURG, May 18. -- The trial of Lieut. Edward S. Farrow on the charge of conspiring with C. Linford Woods to defraud the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association was continued to-day before Judge S.A. McClung. The taking of testimony was concluded and the addresses of the defense to the jury were begun.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The arrest of Adolph Luetgert, President of the Luetgert Sausage and Packing Company, for the murder of his wife has recalled, and may lead to the investigation of a murder which took place eighteen years ago. At that time Luetgert was a saloon keeper and had a place of business at Clybourn and Webster Avenues.

The tailors' strike for an advance of wages and the abolition of the day task system was continued yesterday, and according to the statement of the Executive Committee it was extended. By evening it was said that 20,000 people were out, and that 4,000 tailors in Newark were also on the point of striking.

CLAYTON, N.Y., May 18. -- A twenty-foot yacht of the rater class has just been completed by L.E. Fry of this place for William Willard Howard of New York, to compete in the Seawanhaka Yacht Club's international trial races at Oyster Bay, L.I., July 12, 13, and 14, for the selection of a boat to sail for the Seawanhaka Yacht Club International Challenge Cup at Montreal, in August.

ALBANY, May 18. -- Gov. Black this morning signed the General Tax Rate bill and the Insane Tax Rate bill, which, together with the Canal Tax bill, heretofore signed, completes the financial measures. The tax rate for the year is 2.67 mills. This includes the following, each item being expressed in mills:

The annual meeting of the Alumni Association of the Union Theological Seminary was held in the Adams Chapel yesterday morning. Dr. William A. Patten, '77, of Wayne, Penn., who was elected President of the Alumni Association for the ensuing year, was in the chair.

The Constitution of New York contains this language: "Appointments and promotions in the civil service of the State and all the civil divisions thereof, including cities and villages, shall be made according to merit and fitness, to be ascertained, so far as practicable, by examinations, which, so far as practicable, shall be competitive."

During a congestion of traffic on the East River yesterday morning the ferryboat Wyoming, bound from the foot of Roosevelt Street for Williamsburg, ran against the Sound steamer City of Worcester of the Norwich Line, which was just arriving from New London.

For the sixty-first time the Union Theological Seminary held commencement exercises last night in the Adams Chapel, at the seminary buildings, Park Avenue and Seventieth Street, graduating a class of thirty-three members. The Rev. Dr. Thomas S. Hastings, the retiring President, presided, and at his right and left sat the members of the Faculty attired in their academic robes.

A scrubby little skeleton -- being without arms or legs, and having a dwarfed appearance -- perched on a brand-new, red-ribbon-tied bicycle gave the text for part of an interesting talk on the subject of "The Human Machine and How to Use It" by Miss E. Marguerite Lindley at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The conference of prominent New York Republicans with Senator Platt at his rooms in the Arlington Hotel was practically without result. The purpose of the conference was to talk over the coming campaign for Mayor of Greater New York and decide on some preliminary matters.
The attitude of the Society of Beaux Arts in regard to competition is clearly set forth in the recommendations adopted at the regular meeting, held Monday night. These recommendations are as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Gen. John W. Foster, the special agent of the Department of State, charged with the negotiations concerning the seal fisheries, left Washington to-night for New York, whence he will sail Wednesday on the Paris for England.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day heard an argument by Attorney C.E.S. Woods of Portland, Ore., in support of the claim of H.W. Corbett to a seat in the Senate to succeed Senator Mitchell under the appointment of the Governor of Oregon, but the committee took no action.

For a long time Gem Collis, Commissioner of Public Works, has been anxious to have Mayor Strong and the other heads of the Municipal Government inspect the progress of the work in the Croton Watershed. Now that the proposed new system has assumed form, he wished all in whose department city question as to the water supply of this city might come to inspect and contrast the coming system with that at present in use.
ALBANY, May 18. -- The following bills of interest to New York City and Brooklyn were signed by Governor Black to-day:

CHICAGO, May 18. -- The Bostons earned two runs in the first, were presented with three in the second, after which they were unable to connect with Briggs. Lewis was batted off the rubber in the first, Stivetts pitched the next two innings, and the Bostons's new giant, Mahoney, the last innings, both being hit hard. Connor, at second for the locals, made a good impression. Score:

TRENTON, May 18. -- Gov. Griggs to-day signed the Lloyd Marriage License bill passed by the recent Legislature. The bill was considerably amended in the two houses, so that it differs very much from the bill, as it was introduced.

NEWARK, May 18. -- The twenty-third annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey was opened at 10 o'clock this morning at Trinity Church, this city. The annual address of Bishop Starkey touched upon the Pope's encyclical, in which the Pope pronounced the orders of the Protestant Episcopal Church invalid. In referring to the encyclical Bishop Sharkey spoke of the Pope always as the Bishop of Rome.
The Quill Club, at its seventh annual meeting last night, at the Windsor Hotel, discussed "The New Charter of the City of New York."

The protest of the 3,000 practicing physicians who are members of the County Medical Association and the County Medical Society against the present methods of appointing the visiting surgeons and physicians of the city hospitals was again developed at the regular monthly meeting of the County Medical Association Monday evening.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 9. -- A matter which is creating a considerable amount of interest here just at present is the situation of the Jamaica Railway. Prior to 1889 this railroad was owned by the Government of Jamaica, but toward the close of that year it was purchased by an American syndicate, of which Fred Wesson and Leo Franks are President and Vice President, respectively.

HAVANA, May 18. -- W.J. Calhoun, the Special Commissioner of the United States, who is investigating the death of Dr. Ricardo Ruiz, a naturalized American citizen, visited the Spanish Casino last night, which was decorated and illuminated in honor of the eleventh birthday of King Alfonso. Mr. Calhoun was accompanied by the Spanish Consul at Philadelphia, Dr. Jose Congosto, the Mayor of Havana; Senor Michael Diaz, and Dr. Jover, who acted as interpreter.

The disclosures of yesterday furnish the key at once to the contumacious defiance of the concert by Turkey and of her final yielding. It plainly appears that Germany is the only power which had given Turkey any assurance that she might defy the powers with impunity, as she is the only power that abstains from taking part in the pressure which the rest have united in bringing to bear upon the victorious Turks.

LONDON, May 18. -- The Princess of Wales held a drawing room at Buckingham Palace to-day in behalf of the Queen. The weather was Summerlike and there were enormous crowds on the Mall. The showing of equipages, toilets, and flowers was of the best. The dresses, as a whole, were exceptionally brilliant, and there was a lavish use of jewels and embroidery, which were the features of the display.
Gov. BLACK finds his notion of what an appointing officer should do under his bill repudiated by such officials as Corporation Counsel SCOTT, Commissioner WARING, and Commissioner COLLIS.
D.H. Scully has sold for a Mrs. Ludeke to Mrs. T.T. Lynch the five-story brownstone-front flat 320 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, 25 by 100.

The cause of the leak in Dry Dock No. 3 was discovered by the navy yard diver yesterday, who found a hole in the apron just outside of the caisson. The hole is at least ten feet square at the top and extends to a depth of from four to eight feet below the layer of concrete which forms the bed of he dock, and which was laid on the spongy, filled-in ground of Wallabout.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Promptly at 2 o'clock the presiding officer laid the Morgan Cuban resolution before the Senate, and Mr. Mason of Illinois was recognized.

ALBANY, May 18. -- In the interest of thousands of poor people, the Superintendent of Banks of the State announces that the sums undistributed by savings banks which have gone into voluntary liquidation and such of the dividends declared by receivers of failed savings banks as were not called for by the depositors are deposited with the State Banking Department in Albany and now aggregate something more than $75,000.

According to The Venezuelan Herald of May 8, the concessions for the working of the Government's telegraph system, which were granted to J. Schwed of this city, have been rejected by the Venezuelan Congress. The Herald says that when Mr. Schwed obtained the concession he arranged for a deposit with the United States Legation on April 13 of $25,000.

-- The conference was a failure on account of too many advance notices. The conference was held for the purpose of getting needed advice, and as the needed advice was given, it was a complete success. There was no conference. With all this information from prominent and truthful participants in the conference, public curiosity ought to be sated so far as the conference is concerned.

Edward L. Stoddard, a convict who is serveing a term for forgery in the New Jersey State Prison at Trenton, and whose achievements with the pen have been many, has again attracted attention to himself. A few days ago he wrote a letter to the American Tract Society, in which he asserted the existence of a will, executed in 1889 by Andrew J. Davis of Butte, Montana, who died in 1890.
One point in the peculiar proceedings begun by the Attorney General against the coal companies was the place where the proceedings were to take place.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 19.-John Smith, the colored candidate for the Naval Academy, has failed in three- out of four branches of the English examination. He passed in spelling, but did not reach the mark in grammar, geography, and history. Under the rules of the Academy he will be allowed a re*-examination.

President Hubbell of the Board of Education characterized yesterday's meeting of that body as the shortest regular meeting that had been held in ten years. There was less than the usual amount of speechmaking from the members of the board, and the business of the day was put through with rush.

NEWPORT, May 19. -- Samuel M. Blatchford, Special Deputy Surveyor and Auditor of the Surveyor's office of the New York Custom House to-day rented the Weaver cottage, Berkeley Avenue, for the season. He arrived here yesterday, and Mrs. Blatchford joined him here this evening. Mr. Blatchford is in poor health.
The press of the United States has it within its power to give to the people of Cuba not only national independence, but also relief from the horrors which now oppress them.

There is, of course, the keenest interest as to whether retail prices will advance in consequence of the higher duties proposed in the Tariff bill now before the Senate. Whatever changes are made in this bill before its passage, the rates are sure to be much higher than at present and higher even than under the McKinley act of 1890.

Almost all of the political pilgrims who went to Washington on Tuesday to confer with Senator Platt returned yesterday, and immediately there was a great boom for a union ticket against Tammany this year. None of the pilgrims were in a very communicative mood, but on all sides could be heard hints and suggestions of a union on "the lines laid down by Senator Platt."

The sale, at auction, of a collection of standard and rare books, comprising copies of choice and limited editions of well-known authors in various departments of literature, was begun yesterday at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue.

Samuel M. Blatchford, Auditor and Special Deputy Surveyor in charge of the First Division of the Surveyor's Department of the Custom House, has placed his resignation in the hands of Surveyor John C. McGuire. It will take effect when his successor is appointed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 19. -- Arthur E. Foote, formerly intercollegiate tennis champion, has cabled to his parents in this city that he will not enter the tournament for the New England, championship. It is scheduled to begin on the grounds of the New Haven Lawn Club next Tuesday. Mr. Foote has won the New England Trophy Cup, valued at $400, for two consecutive years, and needed but one more victory to hold it permanently.

It has been understood, from the start, that the Tariff bill could pass the Senate only on such terms as could be arranged with the so-called silver Republicans. So far the monstrous tax on carpet wools and the tax on hides -- each laying a heavy burden on the industries of the East -- have been supposed to be the price the Republicans were to pay for support from the Rocky Mountain contingent.

Five companies each of the Seventy-first and Fourteenth Regiments occupied the ranges at Creedmoor yesterday. An unfavorable north wind blew all day and interfered with the shooting in some measure, though otherwise the weather was perfect.

ORANGE, May 19. -- The silver anniversary of the Woman's Club of Orange was celebrated this afternoon. Women prominent in club and literary circles in New York and New Jersey were present to aid the local club in its celebration. The exercises were held in Music Hall. Potted plants and flowers decorated the hall.

BOSTON, May 19. -- Albert M. King, the nineteen-year-old messenger of the Boylston National Bank, at Washington and Essex Streets, is missing, together with nearly $20,000 in cash and a ten-thousand-dollar United States certificate, not negotiable except between banks.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19. -- Shortly before the close of the annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island this afternoon, there was a scene which might have become more stormy had not Bishop Littlejohn interfered.

Some 2,000 more tailors were reported yesterday as having gone out to swell the ranks of the strikers. Besides the coat tailors there are now on strike the jacket makers, vest makers, sailors' jacket makers, overcoat makers, and sack coat makers.
MADRID, May 19. -- At a meeting of Liberal Senators and Deputies to-day Senor Segasta former Premier, made an important speech, in the course of which he said:

Handicapper W. S. Vosburg-h has announced the weights for the Claremont Highweig-ht Handicap for three-year-olds and upward at six and one-half furlongs, owhich is to be run. at Morris Park on Saturday, as follows:

NEWPORT, May 19. -- Newport's Tax Assessors have completed their duties, and have made the rate $11 on each one thousand dollars of assessed valuation. This is one-half per cent. higher than last year, and, in fact, the highest tax ever levied in the history of Newport. The continued withdrawal of personal property has necessitated the advanced rate, the decrease in personal property valuation having been $446,200 since the last assessment.

According to appointment with Controller Fitch, who had agreed to hear a statement by Lawyer Charles H. Butler, counsel for Henry J. Braker, who has made the city an offer for the franchises of the Sixth and Eighth Avenue Railroads, Mr. Butler attended yesterday afternoon in the Controller's office.
Senator MORGAN'S belligerency resolution is intended to bring on a war with Spain.
ATHENS, May 19. -- An official bulletin just issued says:

CHICAGO, May 19. -- The big steel schooner Amazon, the largest sailing or towing vessel on the lakes, will be launched at the yard of the Chicago Shipbuilding Company on the Calumet River May 29. The Amazon is owned by Corrigan of Cleveland.

That part of the Irvington-Millburn course, between Hilton and the starting point, about three-quarters of a mile, was reported to be in very bad shape yesterday at the meeting of the committee having the annual handicap in charge. Repairs will be made at once, and it is expected that every rod of the way will be in fine condition by the day of the great contest.

The bondholders of the Northern Pacific Trminal Company and the officials of the Northern Pacific and the Oregon Railroad and Navigation Company held a meeting in the oiTices of the 1N'ew York Life Insurance Corrpany yesterday afternoon. The object of the meeting was to arrange for a reduction in the rate of interest on the bonds.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Speaker Reed has called a meeting of the Committee on Rules for to-morrow morning for the purpose of framing a rule under which the House will consider the resolution passed by the Senate appropriating $50,000 for the relief of American citizens in Cuba. The Republican leaders have decided practically that the House shall adopt the Senate resolution to-morrow, and ignore the question of recognition of belligerency.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 19. -- William B. Van Aken, who yesterday attempted to murder former Senator John R. McPherson in his office in New York City, was at one time a resident of this city, and is well remembered by many persons, notably lawyers, who reside here.

Six houses were destroyed, eleven badly damaged, and seventy families rendered homeless by fire in Jersey City yesterday morning. The fire started in Frederick W. Payne's furniture store, 245 and 247 Newark Avenue. The flames were discovered at 1:20 A.M., and in half an hour the interior of both buildings were a mass of flames. The buildings were surrounded on three sides by frame tenements, and a general alarm was sounded at once.

LONDON, May 19. -- To avoid probable demonstrations Oscar Wilde, who on May 25, 1895, was sentenced to two years' imprisonment with hard labor, was not released from Reading Jail, where he has served out his sentence, but was transferred last night to Holloway Prison, London, under special arrangement made by the Home Secretary.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 19. -- Judge Chester declined to-day to vacate the order granted May 11 with reference to changing the place of taking testimony in the proceedings against the alleged Coal Trust. This he refused to do upon an ex parte application, but he did grant an order to show cause, returnable Thursday, May 27, at 11:30 o'clock at the Chambers in Albany.

LOUISVILLE, May 19. -- Nearly 9,000 persons to-day saw Ornament win the Clarke Stakes. Without being touched and with an even, steady stride, in which he showed the way from wire to wire, Ornament earned the stakes in the good time of 1:55, only one second slower than the track record for the mile and one-eighth. Summaries:

CHICAGO, May 19. -- A suit in forcible entry and detainer has been begun in the Superior Court by the Great Northern Theatre and Hotel Company, against A.M. Palmer, Samuel E. Rorke. and John A. and Alexander Davidson. The cause of the difficulty between the parties is a dispute in regard to the terms of the partnership agreement, by which the theatre was operated.
ALBANY, May 19. -- The Governor has declined to sign the bill providing for an additional Railroad Commissioner, and has filed a memorandum stating his views. Gov. Black says:

Terrace Garden has long been a popular resort for Germans who love operetta of the Summery kind and for Americans who are fond of light music with accompaniment of fluent and luminous beer. Under the direction of Messrs. Philipp and Von Raven a season of operetta began there last night with every evidence of popular favor.
Francis B. Roberts has sold for W.C. Wood, to William W. Johnson, for $80,000 cash, the new seven-story business building, 64 University Place, 25 by 100.

It is a necessity for the cause of good government in the Greater New York that the Citizens' Union shall make no serious mistakes. It is a necessity because those who believe in managing the affairs of the greater city as a mere matter of municipal housekeeping, without reference to party politics, have nowhere else to go.

There is a patient in one of the medical wards of Bellevue Hospital whose ailment puzzles all the doctors who have seen him. Apparently hale and strong, with all his faculties seemingly normal, he can neither talk nor indicate by signs who he is or where he comes from. The doctors have diagnosed his disease as aphasia, and are awaiting a natural cure or some fortunate accident to reveal the man's identity.

The Democrats are making complaint over the information they have received about the way in which the reapportionment of the election districts in this city has been made by the Police Commissioners. Under the law the Commissioners have reduced the number of election districts from 1,392 to less than that.
BERLIN, May 19. -- The Reichstag to-day passed the Emigration bill. It becomes operative on April 1, 1898.

A report from the committee appointed to consider some scheme of promotion from the eligible lists that will obviate the danger of future deadlocks, and a discussion on President Moss's "practical plan for enforcing the new law," were the only matters of importance outside department routine considered at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Many things about the so-called conference held, last night in the room of Senator Platt have caused comment to-day. Last night everybody who had attended it was reticent, and while all the participants generally agreed in saying that nothing was done, not one of the conferrees would explain how it had taken three hours to do absolutely nothing.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- It was expected that Senator Burrows of Michigan would open the Cuban debate when the Morgan resolution was taken up at 2 o'clock today, but he told his friends on entering the Senate that he felt indisposed, and would not go on to-day. Mr. Hoar of Massachusetts moved that when the Senate adjourns to-morrow it be until Monday next.

We think Mr. JACOB WORTH made a mistake in missing the Washington express on Tuesday. If he differs from PLATT or resents his attempt to be the boss of all the boroughs, the better plan would have been to go to the conference and fight it out.
The signing by Gov. Black of the so-called Lexow Civil Service bill continues to excite comment. Following are interviews on the subject:

It has been remarked by those who knew, that it is a good thing for brethren to dwell together in harmony, and also that a house divided against itself cannot stand. There are evidences that some of our esteemed neighbors of the new journalistic brand have not taken these truths to heart.

Elkin Lloyd, about thirty years old, who recently came to this city from New Hampshire, made a desperate attempt early yesterday morning to kill Florence Eyfield, a concert hall singer, and her husband, Harry Eyfield, on the Grand Street station platform of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad.

William C. De Witt, a member of the commission which drafted the Greater New York charter, delivered an address on that instrument before the Brooklyn Democratic Club, at Historical Hall, Brooklyn, last night. He said, in part:

Good golf and several close finishes were the features of the second day in the open club tournament yesterday, on the Knollwood Country Club links, near Elmsford, Westchester County. Two hole play rounds of the Worthington Whitehouse tournament were finished and one of the consolation match. Both will end to-day, and to-morrow the big handicap will be played.

Edward Lauterbach's resignation as President of the Republican County Committee was received at the meeting of the committee in Murray Hill Lyceum, in East Thirty-fourth Street, last night, was laid over for action until next Tuesday night and led to a revolt among some of the Assembly district leaders against the proposition to elect Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg President in Mr. Lauterbach's place.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Secretary of State to-day sent to the Senate a protest from the German Ambassador against the provision for a discriminating duty on sugar. The original protest is dated April 5, and is directed against the provision of the House bill for a differential duty on sugars from countries paying an export bounty.

The auction sale of old and rare books was continued yesterday at Bangs Co.'s, 91 Fifth Avenue. The books included a number of first editions, some of them very rare; about twenty Grolier Club publications, some French books, and quite a large number of miscellaneous volumes. The most valuable of the entire collection was a superb Latin manuscript, written on 125 leaves of fine vellum, and entitled "Horae Beatae Mariae Virginis cum Calendario."

The undergraduates of Cambridge University in England who are making a vulgar fuss over the proposition of sensible and broad-minded persons to give degrees to women are probably "jays." We all have known, for a long time, that there are "jays" in our own Cambridge, and Mr. HOWELLS has recently portrayed a typical Harvard "jay" and minutely analyzed his character.
There's many a true word spoken in a jingo debate.

The pupils of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, both present and past, the nuns of that order, and nearly 100 priests joined in the first day's celebration of the semi-centennial jubilee of that institution at Manhattanville yesterday. The arrangements for the three days' observance of this fiftieth anniversary have been in the hands of a committee of former pupils of this convent, most of them now women of social distinction in this city.

Jersey Central led all the rest of the Stock Exchange list yesterday. About 36,000 shares were traded in, only Chicago Gas anything like approaching it, the Jersey Central total being practically a dozen times as big as that of Sugar Trust, the usual leader. The other coal stocks were fairly active, Delaware and Hudson being traded in to the extent of about 10,000 shares, which is far above the stock's usual average.

WAKEFIELD, May 20. -- Mrs. S.A. Barnes of New York, who is visiting at the home of her son, George Harrington, in Wakefield Park, reported to the police yesterday that diamonds, other jewelry, and money to the value of $2,250 had been stolen from her room. She said the valuables were done up in a handkerchief and were kept concealed between the mattresses of her bed.

Some of the striking clothing makers met with a little success yesterday. Secretary Adolph Rotter of the overcoat and sack-coat makers announced that Contractor Abraham Cohen of 320 East Broadway, who employs 250 hands, has agreed to settle with the union. It was also said that eighteen contractors had signified their willingness to make a reasonable agreement.

The work of dismantling that part of the Tombs which is to make way for the new city prison was virtually completed yesterday, and the tearing down the Centre Street part of the structure will begin next Monday. About everything movable in the old Tombs and Special Sessions Court rooms has been taken out.

When Mayor PEENE of Yonkers distinctly says that he does not play cards, that, in fact, he never played cards in his life, we are bound to believe him. All the same, we have known gentlemen who could not be truthfully called "card-players" to "sit in" a game of poker.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The hearing on freight differentia.Is between iew York and Philadelphia, Ialtimore, llorfoik, and other cities from Western points (the ease instituted by the New York Produce Exchange against the Pennsylvania Railroal and others) was concluded at the InterState Commerce Commission to-day.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Senate to-day, by a vote of 41 to 14, passed the Morgan Cuban resolution, which is as follows:
LONDON, May 21. -- A dispatch to The Standard from Athens says that 500 Greek volunteers from America arrived there yesterday.

Somebody has been dropping strychnine wrapped in bits of meat along West Ninety-fourth Street, near the Boulevard, and has succeeded in poisoning several valuable dogs. The street has an asphalt roadway and public grass plots along the outer edge of the sidewalks. These make a series of miniature parks, and every pet dog in that part of town enjoys a run over them daily.

The railway ticket brokers, commonly known as scalpers, are quite within their rights when they decide to disregard the law -- and take the consequences. According to the statement of the leading brokers in this city they do not fear the consequences. In the first place, they are confident that the law forbidding them to sell railway tickets except as authorized agents of the companies issuing the tickets is unconstitutional.

ALBANY, May 20. -- County Clerk Jacob Worth was one of the Brooklynites who called upon the Governor this afternoon in relation to pending legislation. Mr. Worth has been either in Saratoga or Albany for over a week, and neither he nor any of the Kings County Republican leaders were at the conference in Washington which Senator Platt called to discuss the question of this Fall's election in Greater New York.

The Commencement exercises of the male and female departments of the free schools of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, established in 1785, were held in Chickering Hall last night. The diplomas were awarded to the class of women by Charles E. Bogart, and to the men by William H. Oliver, as follows:
The problem of relieving the condition of the poor of New York City by allowing them to cultivate the vacant lots was discussed at a public meeting held in the Aldermen's Chamber yesterday afternoon.

TACOMA, Washington, May 20. -- Oriental news received to-day tells of famine in the Chinese Provinces of Sze-Chuen and Hu-Pehin. The authorities are sending grain to destitute people, but inland districts away from rivers have not been reached. Leading merchants in Sze-Chuen have appealed to foreigners for help.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The House to-day, without a dissenting vote, passed the Senate's resolution appropriating $50,000 for the relief of Americans suffering in Cuba.

Promises are made by the Quill Club Wheelmen that their race tournament at the Manhattan Beach track to-morrow afternoon will make the biggest opening meet ever held in this section. The entry list for the various races shows 65 novices scheduled to appear in the half-mile scramble, 61 cracks in the mile open, and 112 in the mile handicap.

If Mr. "JAKEY" WORTH is really determined to pit his machine against that of Mr. PLATT, there is no room for doubt as to his motive. He is after the spoils which he believes can be had from the administration of the greater city. It is only by spoils that such a machine as his can be run.

LONDON, May 21. -- The armistice between the Greek and Turkish armies is for seventeen days. The agreement stipulates that a mixed commission of officers of superior rank shall establish a neutral zone between the two armies and that no advance on either flank shall be permitted. It is understood that Turkey wants the commission to be constituted of the foreign military attachee with the two armies.

The visitors to Morris Park yesterday were treated to a race which set their blood a-tingling through their veins. The race was the sixth on the card, and had as starters Volley, Bastion, Sir Walter, and Savarin. The mile journey was started from the chute, and the pace from the start was a hot one.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 20. -- Mayor Peene, Jr., of this city to-day related the details of his loss of money on the day before. He said: "I left home to go to Greenfield, Mass., to purchase some cattle for my stock farm at Tarrytown. I had $1,000 with me when I left Greenfield at 5:18 last evening in order to connect with the train leaving Springfield for New York at 6:31.
The quickest and the easiest way to free Cuba and to end the suffering and oppression is to strengthen the hands of the insurgents.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Twice within as many days it has been announced in Congress that the policy of the Administration is to secure independence for Cuba. Senator Foraker asserted it plainly Wednesday, and to-day Representative Hitt pointedly, in response to an inquiry by Representative Livingston of Georgia, said the President's purpose was to bring about Cuban independence.

Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down his decision in the suits brought to restrain the Eighth Avenue Railroad from changing its motive power from horse power to electricity. He denies the injunctions asked.

ST. LOUIS, May 20. -- George A. Taylor, who has been in the banking business in St. Louis for thirteen years, and who was known as a man of integrity, was found dead in bed at the Normandie Hotel to-day. An empty bottle labelled "Hydrocyanic acid," and a number of letters, showed that he had committed suicide in a most deliberate and dramatic manner.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 20. -- The death of Senator Earle as caused serious political complications in the State. Elected as a protest against Tillmanism and the character of Tillman's candidate, it was hoped he would retain his seat until that faction should be thing of the past.

NEW HAVEN, May 20. -- "A Round of Pleasure," Klaw and Erlanger's extravaganza, was produced at the Hyperion Theatre to-night. The verdict of the large audience that included William H. Crane, Joseph Brooks, "Sam" Nixon, George W. Lederer, William Harris, C.G. Spaulding, and Harry Mann was distinctly favorable.

Hoboken was visited by the largest fire in her history last night. It was rather a series of three fires, one growing out of the other. One Hundred and twenty-eight families were made homeless, and the loss is estimated at about $650,000.

What will the President do with the Morgan resolution if it is passed by the Senate and House? Obey it and issue a proclamation of neutrality? Or will he have the courage to inform Congress that the recognition of belligerency, like the recognition of independence, is properly a matter within the discretion of the Executive, and ask it to withdraw its resolution?
Following is the record in the Police Department of Jacob Worth, a nephew of the Republican leader of that name, who has just been made by Albany legislation a Captain of the Brooklyn police force:

The counsel of the coal road companies base their petition for an order to show cause why the Attorney General's proceedings should not be vacated upon a fact of great interest. It is that the Lexow law, providing for an entirely novel method of procedure as to alleged offenses not heretofore defined, must be most carefully examined and reviewed by competent courts before its exact meaning and scope can be determined.
Charles Buermann Co. have sold for Joseph Kugler, to John Luhrs, for $18,500, the four-story front and rear buildings 96 Columbia Street, 25 by 100.

The Emigration bill passed by the Reichstag seems to be an endeavor to revive the scheme of German colonization. This project was taken up with characteristic energy by BISMARCK, who made some ambitious beginnings in the Cameroons and elsewhere. Since his retirement it has not seemed to interest the Government and has been allowed to languish.

BOSTON, May 20. -- The Transcript publishes an interview with Congressman Barrows, in which he corrects, from official data, the impression that the United States consented to the blockade of Crete by the powers. The reply of Secretary Sherman to the notice of the blockade, which was served upon him by Sir Julian Pauncefote March 21, bears date of March 26, and is as follows, the copy having been made from the official files to-day:

WINONA ASSEMBLY, EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 20. -- Alternate rain and sunshine to-day greeted the opening of the one hundred and ninth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. At the hour appointed for the opening session the platform was occupied by a long line of Commissioners waiting to be assigned to permanent seats.

The Emigration bill passed by the Reichstag seems to be an endeavor to revive the scheme of German colonization. This project was taken up with characteristic energy by BISMARCK, who made some ambitious beginnings in the Cameroons and elsewhere. Since his retirement it has not seemed to interest the Government and has been allowed to languish.
