The reply of Secretary Sherman to the notice of the blockade, which was served upon him by Sir Julian Pauncefote March 21, bears date of March 26, and is as follows, the copy having been made from the official files to-day:

WINONA ASSEMBLY, EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 20. -- Alternate rain and sunshine to-day greeted the opening of the one hundred and ninth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. At the hour appointed for the opening session the platform was occupied by a long line of Commissioners waiting to be assigned to permanent seats.

The Sheik-ul-Islam seems to have been a trifle subsequent in his expert opinion, delivered to the Sultan at his request, that it was the will of ALLAH that Thessaly should revert to the Ottoman Empire. A week ago such an opinion from the spiritual adviser of the Sultan would have carried much weight.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Speaker Reed and a considerable body of members of the House have been looking at the Cuban question with the eyes of men who recently have been observing the difficulty of getting through Congress a bill to supply the amount of revenue necessary to maintain the Government on a peace basis.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment sat in the Mayor's office yesterday for nearly two hours and a half, and according to the oldest member of the board more money was spent by it, or ordered to be spent, in that time than at any other meeting during his experience.

LONDON, May 20. -- At the third day's racing of the Newmarket second Spring meeting, Mr. August Belmont's chestnut cold Bridegroom II. finished second, and the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's bay colt Elfin was third in the race for The Breeders' Plate of 500 sovereigns, (400 sovereigns to the owner and 100 sovereigns to the nominator of the winner,) added to a sweepstakes of 10 sovereigns each for starters.

Some excellent shooting was witnessed yesterday at Creedmoor, where three companies -- A, B, and K -- of the Twenty-third Regiment occupied the ranges. In spite of the fitful gusts of wind that kept blowing all day from every direction, some good scores were made, and two companies -- A and B -- succeeded in having every one of their men qualify.

About sixty men met last night at the headquarters of the Democratic Club, 617 Fifth Avenue, and perfected the organization of the Democratic Union of the City of New York, and declared it to be their purpose "to rescue the fortress of Democracy from the raids of Republican masqueraders in the guise of reformers."

The recent discoveries at Glastonbury, in Worcestershire, England, of dwellings of the Neolithic period are not to be called lacustrine, as are the finds in the Swiss lakes. The site was in a marsh, and piles were used, as in Switzerland, but these seemed to have served as foundations for clay and stone heaped on the timbers.

BOSTON, May 21. -- There may yet be legal interference with the pleasant programme arranged by Gov. Wolcott, former Ambassador Bayard, and Senator Hoar for the formal reception by the Commonwealth of the famous Bradford manuscript, "Historie of the Plymouth Plantation, Containing an Account of the Voyage of the Mayflower."
Summer plans of leading New York and Brooklyn pastors and churches are now about complete. With few exceptions churches are to be kept open, and in one case evangelistic work is to be inaugurated.

Some six years ago the military service institution at Governors Island, New York Harbor, addressed a circular, through its Publication Committee, asking the co-operation of officers so that a series of historical sketches of the regiments, Staff Corps and Staff Departments of the United States Army might be procurable.

The seemingly vicious slur upon the American dog by the British Board of Agriculture, which has stirred our kennel clubs to action, will be treated by none so wisely as by the American dog himself. Insinuations that he is subject to rabies will not affect him so long as his health is good, and the supply of dog-cake and bones holds out.

The report of the Aguilar Free Library Society for 1896 shows wonderful progress. The society's main East Broadway library is now supplemented by three other branch libraries -- at 616 Fifth Street, at 113 East Fifty-ninth Street, and at 176 East One Hundred and Tenth Street. This last library was opened for business about a year ago.

MADRID, May 21. -- The Duke of Tetuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has resigned as a result of the incident to-day, when he boxed the ears of Senator Comas during a dispute in the lobbies of the Senate, following the heated and tumultuous debate on the Morgan resolution passed by the United States Senate.

Chief of Police Conlin yesterday denied the statement made by Frank Moss, President of the Police Commission, before Good Government Club A on Thursday night that the Chief's action in refusing to aid in making promotions from the eligible list was governed by signals from a Commissioner.

ALBANY, May 21. -- The State prisons are now employing convicts in manufacturing street brooms, and the New York City Street Cleaning Department has made a requisition on the Superintendent of Prisons for 1,000 of them.

In the general condemnation pronounced by honest men against the new civil service law it seems that the civil service of the Police Department ought to be included. Is it not the practical application of the present civil service measure? As far as romotions in the department are concerned, it certainly is. The maximum percentage for the mental examination is 35.

Arthur H. Fenn carried off the big trophy -- the Worthington Whitehouse Silver Cup -- at the Knollwood Country Club, Westchester County, yesterday. The consolation prize, given by Paul Gibert Thebaud, was won by Lawrence E. Van Etten, one of the best and steadiest players in the Knollwood Club.

The expenditures authorized by the Board of Estimate on Thursday are said to have reached the largest aggregate passed at any meeting of the board within the past decade, if not since its formation. They amounted to something over $2,000,000, and they did not include the largest pending projects of municipal expenditure.

PARIS, May 21. -- The Fourth Chamber of the Civil Tribunal began to-day the trial of the cross divorce suit brought by Antonio Terry, who is reported to be the affianced husband of Sybil Sanderson, the prima donna, against his wife, the Terry-Sanderson marriage being contingent upon the success of this action.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission has sent to Senator Cullom of Illinois the following letter in response to a request for suggestions regarding the Pooling bill:

LONDON, May 21. -- The Prince and Princess of Wales and the Duke and Duchess of York witnessed the performance of "Secret Service" at the Adelphi Theatre this evening. All expressed themselves as delighted.

DENVER, Col., May 21. -- Probably the most important case brought before the Supreme Court of the State during recent years is that in which David H. Moffat, President of the First National Bank of this city, and other Colorado millionaires are pitted against John E. Searles, Secretary of the Sugar Trust, and other New York capitalists, combined as the Great Plains Water Storage Company.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Republican Senators will hold a caucus Monday after the adjournment of the Senate to consider various questions in connection with the Tariff bill. The first effort will be to devise plans to expedite the consideration of the bill, and there will also be an attempt to reconcile differences of opinion as to the merits of some features of the bill.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21. -- A will declared to be a forgery and discovered in the urn containing the ashes of the testator's dead wife is one of the sensational features that will be presented in the contest over the estate of the late Jacob Z. Davis, the San Francisco millionaire, philanthropist, and patron of arts and sciences.

When the arbitration treaty failed in the Senate there were thirty Senators who voted or were paired against it. Of these twenty-two voted or were paired for the Morgan Cuban resolution. Their names and politics were as follows: ...

TACOMA, May 22. -- Five miles out of the city this afternoon a car on the Steilacoom Electric Line was halted by a masked robber, who pointed a revolver at the motorman and Superintendent Dame and ordered them to the rear of the car.

Justice Chase, in the Supreme Court, resumed yesterday taking testimony regarding the will of the late John Augustus Pell. The will leaves the entire estate to Mr. Pell's daughter, Eleanor Livingston Phelps, on condition that she live and travel only in Europe. Mrs. Phelps is an American citizen, and claims that this clause prohibits her from exercising her rights, and asks the court to construe it.

LONDON May 21. -- The Duke of Buccleuch unveiled at Westminster Abbey this afternoon a memorial bust of Sir Walter Scott, in the presence of a distinguished assemblage. The bust is by Mr. Hutchinson, R.S.A., and is a copy of Sir Francis Chantrey's well-known portrait. Previous of the ceremony speeches were delivered in the Chapter House of the Abbey by Mr. A.J. Balfour and by Col. Hay, the United States Ambassador, who said, in par:

What, it is charged, was a daring conspiracy to blackmail Samuel Willard Bridgham, a wealthy clubman, came to light yesterday through the news that the Grand Jury had found three indictments against the alleged conspirators. The indictments were returned Thursday, and Recorder Goff issued bench warrants for Lee Hawley, alias "Big" Hawley, alias Woodward; James Ward, and Eugenia Ward.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The full correspondence between the United States and Spain relative to Secretary Olney's offer of mediation on the Cuban question is gradually coming to light. Mr. Olney's letter was made public Wednesday, with a brief extract from the Spanish Minister's reply. Today the full reply of Minister Dupuy de Lome became available.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21. -- Both teams made the same number of hits and errors to-day, but the Brooklyns' hits were made timely, and the Louisville team's two misplays were costly. Griffin, Jones, and Shindle did great work with the stick. Dexter took Pickering's place in the eighth inning. Attendance, 2,000.

At a time when Greece is again threatened with annihilation and when the eyes of a sympathizing world are more eagerly than hopefully watching to see whether her people can display to-day that dauntless and stubborn courage which in ancient times so often kept the outnumbering barbarians at bay, Mr. Hogarth's two essays upon Philip and Alexander of Macedon must find a wide and appreciative audience.

The Second Battalion of the Seventy-first Regiment, consisting of Companies B, E, F, H, and K, under command of Major C.H. Smith, occupied the range at Creedmoor yesterday. In spite of the disagreeable weather, the men did some good shooting. It rained so hard at times that the targets were almost totally obscured.

Under the head of "Heavy Excise Receipts," your Albany dispatch of yesterday says that the total collected from the State up to May 10 was $9,153,648, of which New York City contributed $5,171,075, Kings County $2,206,335, and goes on to say:

There was no indication at the Third National Bank yesterday that it was in the course of voluntary liquidation in entire solvency, and that its business is to be absorbed by the National City Bank. The Usual transactions occurred at the Bank Clearing House, checks were cashed, and deposits were received from some customers.

It was reported yesterday that the savings banks of this city intend to reduce the rate of interest they are now paying on deposits. It was also reported that this reduction would be made from June 1. When asked about this rumor last night, Merritt Trimble, President of the Bank for Savings, 280 Fourth Avenue, said:

The Hoboken Land and Improvement Company carried insurances amounting to $140,000. None of the firms carried much insurance, and no information could be obtained on the subject. The Hoboken Land and Improvement Company on Thursday paid off a mortgage of $180,000 on the buildings, which was held by the Mutual Life Insurance Company.
It is a good thing, upon occasion, to have a Czar. We have one in the Speaker's chair, and the eyes of the country are upon him.

The fourth installment of Prof. Max Muller's "Literary Recollections" in Cosmopolis for May, is full of interest to us, inasmuch as he gives his reminiscences of Emerson, Oliver Wendell Holmes, and Lowell. Max Muller complains, but in a humorous manner, of the large number of letters and visits received by him "from unknown friends and distant admirers."

ALBANY, May 21. -- Gov. Black at 1 o'clock to-day gave out a memorandum giving his reasons for his refusal to approve of the Graduated Inheritance Tax bill, in which he says, after calling attention to the present inheritance tax law and citing the provisions of the bill which he has disapproved of:

For the ritualistically inclined this book will doubtless have its attractions, but the general reader will hardly flutter about its light. Dr. Tucker lived a quiet life, very unselfishly and humbly, devoting his superior gifts and his fine capacity for taking pains to a comparatively obscure rectorship at Troy.

To begin at the beginning noticing these six new volumes of native fiction, we naturally begin with Mr. Howells. We can say fairly that clever and interesting as some of the other are, in their various ways, not one of them, not even Mr. Stockton, quite equals Mr. Howells as a story teller.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Cabinet meeting to-day was not of long duration, but it was interesting, because the principal subject of discussion was Cuba.

It is to be hoped that in making the appointments of American Commissioners for the Paris Exhibition of 1900 the President will keep in view some considerations which his predecessors have not always kept in view upon similar occasion. One of these is the necessity of appointing upon the commission somebody whose expert knowledge is such as to command the confidence and enlist the interest of American artists in all specialties.

So far as the cable permits us to judge of it, Col. HAY'S tribute to WALTER SCOTT in Westminster Abbey deserved the praise bestowed upon it by the Dean of Westminster. It was "wise, eloquent, and truthful," and seems to have been a propitious opening for the career of celebrating the glories of our common tongue, which is an important part of the functions of an American Ambassador in England.

Among the many interesting American manuscripts and autograph letters in the Frederickson library to be sold the latter part of this month is a curious Indian petition. Unfortunately it bears no date, but it is evidently of this century. It is from the Chippewa and Muncey Indians of Canada, addressed to the Legislature, begging that the sale of liquor may be prohibited.

The auction sale of standard and rare books was concluded yesterday at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue. Among the books disposed of yesterday were a number treating of Napoleon and the French Revolution, while among the miscellaneous volumes were some fine first editions of the works of Algernon Charles Swinburne. Some of the books disposed of were:
The chances for the success of the striking tailors were yesterday reported to be improving. Four more contractors offered to signs the union agreement to get their men back again to work.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for John Hickey to a Mr. McGinn for investment the five-story brick and stone flats, with stores, southeast corner of One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Fifth Avenue, 25.2 by S3.

In an early number of Fraser (1832) there is a merry skit entitled: "The Great and Celebrated Hogg Dinner," in which many literary characters are represented as feasting at the Freemasons' Tavern. Hock is quoted as having improvised "for the occasion" certain lines which begin:

It is hardly necessary to say that a succinct and comprehensive life of Gen. Grant, adapted to the needs of the general reader, was wanted. Gen. James Grant Wilson's volume fairly fills that want. It is a straightforward, clearly written, untechnical story of the achievements which made Grant one of the greatest commanders of all history.

The third annual art exhibition under the auspices of the Educational Alliance is now on view at the Assembly Hall of the Institute, corner of East Broadway and Jefferson Street. The collection, consisting of ninety-one pictures, is an excellent one, having been selected with fine judgment by the Committee of Artists, Messrs. Carroll Beckwith, J. Wells Champney, Francis C. Jones, Dora Wheeler Keith, J.G. Brown, Joe Evans, I.A. Josephi, and H. Siddons Mowbray.

The editorial in this morning's TIMES on "The Citizens' Union" points the way -- and, I am profoundly convinced, the only way -- by which that organization may hope to accomplish its great purpose. The key to the situation is this:

Capt. O'Brien received a communication from the Scotland Yard authorities yesterday telling of the arrest and conviction for shop breaking in London of a man who gave his name as Edward Simpson, and was sentenced six months at hard labor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 21. -- H.S. Van Duzer, representing Cornell, Harvard, and Yale, with Dr. Walter Peet, formerly Columbia's coach, and Assistant Manager White of the Cornell Navy, arrived at Highland to-day on a special train. In the party was General Passenger Agent Lambert and Superintendent Bradley of the West Shore Railroad.

NEWPORT, May 21. -- Gouverneur Kortright, the yachtsman of New York, to-day rented Mrs. Gertrude V.C. Hamilton's villa on Harrison Avenue, known as the Moorings. The place had been taken by Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Rutherford, but they decided to remain in Europe.

In cudgeling the Republican Party for its sins, the new Democratic Union makes a good beginning. Puritanical laws, invasions of the liberties of the citizen, and the delivery of the city into the hands of the up-country banditti are consequences of Republican rule that have provoked the people of New York to wrath and a keen desire to put that party out.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- Former Senator George F. Edmunds of Vermont to-day discussed the action of the United States Senate with reference to the passing of the resolution recognizing Cuban belligerency.

In the Spring of last year Mr. J. Rendel Harris, accompanied by his wife, visited Armenia, not the outskirts of the country, but traveled into the interior of it. The volume under notice, which has the commendation of Mr. Gladstone, is made up of letters addressed to friends in England. The book commends itself to readers, especially by its mildness of expression and its naturalness.

MADRID, May 21. -- Senor Moret y Prendergast, former Minister, asked the Government, on behalf of the Liberals in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, to submit all the papers relating to the rebellion in Cuba, and to the diplomatic relations of Spain with the powers.

ALBANY, May 21. -- Gov. Black this morning affixed his signature to the important codification of the "commercial paper law" of the State. The bill goes into effect on Oct. 1. There are many changes and provisions of importance. The first seven sections are new. Section 1 provides that "this chapter shall be known as the commercial paper law."

PORT HURON, Mich., May 21. -- The steamer Florida of the Lackawanna Line, bound from Chicago to Buffalo with grain and general merchandise, was sent to the bottom of Lake Huron by collision with the steamer George W. Roby yesterday morning between Middle Island and Presque Isle.

LONDON, May 21. -- The First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader, Mr. A.J. Balfour, made an important statement in the House of Commons to-day regarding the Government's policy, which will be carried out next session, the object of which is to give Ireland an equivalent for the relief in agricultural rates given to England.
The Citizens' Union of Brooklyn, of which W.G. Low is President, and of whose Executive Committee George H. Fletcher is Chairman, has issued the following address to the public:

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Clerical errors and mistakes will no longer be considered good and sufficient by the Sugar Trust as a defense for those who make a lower bid than the schedule allows. A letter has been secured which was sent out by the Ohio Wholesale Grocers' Association Company addressed to all bidders for sugar at the Dayton Soldiers' Home in Ohio.

Something more than a year ago, at a juncture in the discussion of Cuban affairs by our National legislators very similar to the present one, a distinguished American scholar and thinker, explaining, according to his view, the causes of the general detericration that has taken place in the character of our Representatives, uttered a note of warning which the American people would do well now to recall and to heed.

The tariff on books now and for some time past has worked harm to the booksellers through the exemption from payment of the tariff made in favor of libraries and educational institutions. The Macmillan Company, of which George P. Brett is President, has this week forwarded to the Committee on Tariff Revision of the Senate the following letter on the subject:

LONDON, May 22. -- A dispatch to The Daily Chronicle from Paris says that Father Kneipp, well known throughout the world through his water cure, is dead. He had been suffering for some days from inflammation of the lungs, and received the last sacrament of the church a week ago at Worishofen, Suabia.

PARIS, May 21. -- The announcement of the award of medals of the Champs Elysees Salon of 1897, section of paintings, was made to-day. The Medaille d'Honneur is given to Henri Harpignies for his picture, "Solitude." M. Harpignies is a pupil of Acard; he also exhibited "Bords du Rhone."

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., May 21. -- James Fleming, a New York youth, who is at the Preparatory School here getting ready to enter the Military Academy at West Point, got into trouble to-day with Lieut. Braden, manager of the school. Lieut. Braden telegraphed to New York for the boy's father, who shortly arrived.

The First Brigade of National Guard of New York City, according to information from the most authentic source, will shortly have a new commander. Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, who has been in command for the past eleven years, it is stated by those in close relations with him, will resign the first week in June, or immediately following his return from Boston with the Seventh Regiment on May 31.

The granddaughters of Peter Cooper have founded, after years of patient effort, a Museum for the Arts of Decoration. The museum is established "in memory of the great and constant interest he always evinced in the education and welfare of artisans"; and their collections for it are appropriately placed in Cooper Union.

BERLIN, May 22. -- Paul Potter, representing the heirs of the late George Du Maurier, has arrived in Berlin to take the proceeds of the unauthorized use of his play and other versions of "Trilby," now being performed, four of them in Berlin and many at the provincial theatres.

It is given out in high military circles that there is to be a radical change in conducting the State camp at Peekskill this year, inasmuch as the Adjutant General, it is said, will not command the camp in person, as has been done for some years past, but intends to turn over the direction of the military post to the several brigade commanders.

The most important feature of local aquatics at present is the Memorial Day regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association. This will mark the formal opening of the rowing season, and for the past six weeks strict attention has been paid to crews training for the various events. There is little doubt that this year's regatta will surpass all previous ones both in interest and number of entries.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22. -- Receiver E. Hopkins of the Peoria, Decatur and Evansville Railroad has filed his annual report for 1896. The report shows total receipts for the year of $1,365,337.23, divided as follows: Receiver's accounts, $1,350,522.60; Peoria, Decatur and Evansville account, $14,814.63.

A meeting of importers, manufacturers, and wholesale dealers in millinery was held yesterday afternoon in the Broadway Central Hotel to protest against an order issued by the Treasury Department at Washington, directing customs officials to collect duty at the rate of 35 per cent. on crude ostrich feathers.

Now that the cold light of science has thrown its ray upon the most remote parts of our globe, there is no longer room for legendary creatures -- save the sea serpent, and we are told that the mermaid is nothing more than a dugong, a unicorn either a rhinoceros or a Tibetan antelope, while the cockatrice, the phoenix, and the roc appear to be pure imaginations.

LONDON, May 22. -- The Graeco-Turkish trouble is now fairly entered upon its diplomatic bargaining stage, and the negotiations are expected to last for some time. Many important differences have to be settled, and the Sultan of Turkey may be counted upon to drag the affair along as much as possible, with the view of bringing out the latent jealousies of the powers.

In the high country the great pines sing and moan in the wind at night and morning. The pinons and cedars on the lower levels murmur fitfully to the passing breeze. Small lizards rustle in the dried grass as they whisk from your presence. Prairie dogs here and there chatter and whistle at you as you pass.

BUDA-PESTH, May 12. -- Hungarian public opinion has undergone a complete change in its attitude toward Russia since the Emperor Francis Joseph's recent visit to St. Petersburg. The friendship displayed between the two monarchs in the Russian capital was greeted with great enthusiasm in Buda-Pesth, which proves once more what an essentially peaceable people the Hungarians are.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Democratic Senators held a caucus to-day and decided to begin their fight upon the Tariff bill as soon as the bill is taken up in the Senate by a motion to strike out the internal revenue features of the bill relating to beer and tobacco.

Four hundred delegates and members from all parts of the State were in attendance at the fourth annual New York State Convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, which met in St. Luke's Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, and half as many more are expected at the services to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Civil Service Committee of the Senate continued its sessions to-day. Several letters were received from chiefs of bureaus, among them one from Mr. Miller, Acting Commissioner of Internal Revenue, who suggested the propriety of amendments to the civil service rules.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 22. -- A unique enterprise in the heart of the mountainous region of North Alabama is the Indian Head Cotton Mill, located by Harcourt Amory and associates of Boston, Mass., near the site of the town of Cordova, in Walker County, thirty miles west of Birmingham, on the main lines of the Southern and the Kansas City, Memphis and Birmingham Railroads.
A handsome silver service was presented yesterday to the new United States cruiser Brooklyn. It was a gift of the people of Brooklyn, the city whence the warship got her name.

Wall Street is still awaiting some sign which will warrant a renewal of general business confidence. And, apparently, it is disposed to keep on waiting till that sign is unmistakable. Ordinary observers do not anticipate its appearance so long as Congress is in eruption.

The Brooklyn Handicap of 1897, which will mark the opening of the Spring meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club at the Gravesend track on Memorial Day, Monday, May 31, should furnish one of the best contests ever fought out for the famous stake. To begin with, the field, from present indications, will be a large one, with probably twelve and possibly sixteen starters.

Commissioner of City Works Willis has come out in an interview with himself favoring the candidacy of Seth Low for Mayor of the Greater New York. Mr. Willis claims to be the original Low advocate in Brooklyn, and now that Jacob Worth, the real leader of the Republican machine in Kings County, has announced his willingness to support Low, Mr. Willis says that the combination of Republicans and Democrats is very gratifying to him.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Information was obtained to-day that Rome has just transmitted to the Catholic Church in the United States the most significant ruling of recent years, bearing on ecclesiastical matters in America.

The Hamburg-American Line will this week celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of its existence. The occasion will be marked here by dinners -- one to be given on the steamship Furst Bismarck at her pier, in Hoboken, on Tuesday evening, and the other on the steamship Pennsylvania, on Thursday evening. The company was established May 27, 1847, and from small beginnings it has come to possess the largest tonnage in the world.

Gifts of the aggregate value of nearly half a million dollars are shortly to be presented to the Society of Friends at Pawling, Dutchess County, this State, by one of its members. Albert J. Aiken, the proprietor of the Mizzen Top Hotel, who in spite of his ninety-four years is still an active man, is the benefactor.

-- An armistice, as defined by the Turks, seems to be an opportunity for capturing easily places they would have to fight for if the war were still going on. Naturally, the Greeks object to this definition, but the only way open to them for demonstrating their dislike of it is to take an occasional snap shot, not photographic, at that heroic warrior, the Crown Prince.

LOS ANGELES, May 2. -- This is the season of the annual flower carnivals and floral pageants in Southern California. The roses, lilies, poppies, daisies, carnations, marguerites, and scores of other varieties in the floral kingdom that have made California unique, are at their best for three or four weeks after the early part of April.

Wall Street found much interest yesterday in a letter made public purporting to have been addressed on Friday to an unnamed stockholder in the Central Railroad of New Jersey by President J. Rogers Maxwell of that company. In a variety of particulars it was surprising, statements in it being apparently very much at variance with official figures as hitherto generally understood in Wall Street.

Androw D. White, at the dinner given in his honor by German-Americans at Liederkranz Hall last night, must have felt for the moment as if he were going as Ambassador from a German colony to the German fatherland.
The monument to the Confederate dead, built by Charles Broadway Rouss in Mount Hope Cemetery, was formally presented to the New York Camp of Confederate Veterans yesterday.

The most conspicuous fact about the general market the past week is, that it withstood unmoved the shock of a demoralizing break in Jersey Central. When this stock suddenly collapsed, dropping about eight points in two days, the balance of the list only lost fractions. This may be assumed to indicate inherent strength, viewed from one standpoint; or, from another, that it simply shows the market to be narrow and professional.

AS the traveler passes along the fine turnpike road leading from Madison to "old historic Morristown" he cannot help but notice the beautiful residences that line the road. Far off to the right in a beautiful valley he sees the former residence of H. McK.

FARMINGTON, Me., May 22. -- Albert M. King, the Boston bank messenger, who disappeared Tuesday with about $31,000 of the Boyiston National Bank's money, was arrested here just before noon to-day. King reached here on a train from the Rangeley Lake region, at 11:15. Deputy Sheriff Dyer, who in also keeper of the Franklin County jail, met him at the station.

BERLIN, May 8. -- The average American who visits the Continent of Europe leaves his ship in England or France, coming to Germany by way of Belgium and Cologne. He takes a trip up the Rhine, goes to Switzerland, then spends a large part of his time in France, and never visits Berlin, the capital and most important city of the German Empire.

LONDON, May 22. -- Tuesday's drawing room at Buckingham Palace was by far the smartest of the year. The weather was beautiful, and enormous crowds of people lined the streets in the neighborhood of the palace and the Mall. A striking feature of the day was the many State carriages in line.

Talk in Wall Street yesterday of banks preparing to follow the example of the Third National in liquidating and turning its business over to another bank was purely speculative. No banker knew of any bank that was prepared either to absorb another or to transfer its patronage and wind up business.

Col. Aldace F. Walker, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, has returned from California with R. Somers Hayes and Victor Morawetz, composing the Atlantic and Pacific Purchasing Committee. Their mission was satisfactorily carried out.

The season of cycle racing in this vicinity began under very auspicious circumstances at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon, when the Quill Club Wheelmen promoted what was practically a National Circuit tournament. Some of the best of the circuit fliers were there,and a big and demonstrative crowd was present in holiday attire, the ladies in Summer finery, which gave the impression of rushing the season a bit, since overcoats and wraps were desirable.

There is an amusing story told of the husband of a clever New York literary woman, a well-known writer of many books which have been translated into many languages. Before her marriage to her present husband, she was what is called a "fascinating widow."

Commodore George J. Gould's prizes this year will be for the special races which are to be sailed on Saturday, June 12, and for the squadron runs during the cruise. The races on June 12, under the auspices of the Atlantic Yacht Club, are for schooners and sloops in racing trim. The schooner cup is worth $300 and the sloop cup $200.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22. -- With the college championship baseball season now fairly under way, and the first game with Harvard won, Princeton students are figuring on the probability of retaining the championship for another year. The uniform success of the Tiger team so far this season has inspired confidence in their ability to repeat last year's brilliant record.

No biography of Thackeray, in the true sense of the word, has been written -- Thackeray wished that none should be. When Anthony Trollope produced his sketch in the English Men of Letters Series the volume was found to be a biography only in so far as Trollope could make one when hampered by a dearth of material.

LONDON, May 22. -- The forthcoming suit brought by John Frazer in an endeavor to recover from the present holder the title and estates of Lord Lovate, promises some decidedly theatrical evidence. It introduces jewelry discovered in an old London building, documents found in coffins, tombstone inscriptions, and a secret vault in a house at Kirk Hall.

NEWARK, May 22. -- Esther Meisel, the four-and-a-half-year-old daughter of Frederick Meisel of 71 Prince Street, burned herself to death to-day by igniting matches in the bedroom. When her parents heard the cry of fire they rushed to the street, having no idea that the child was in the bedroom.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 22. -- New York and Cleveland played two games here to-day, and broke even. The fact that two games were to be played attracted a splendid crowd.

The Kentucky Court of Appeals has just decided that the death of a man as a result of a mosquito bite is an accidental death, within the meaning of an accident insurance policy, and that the representatives of the deceased are entitled to recover accordingly.

On they go through the streets, over the rough cobbled roads, for nearly two miles, till they come to the flight of steps leading to the church. Up these steps, sixty-four in number, they dance forward and back, ever with the same motion. Right up to the church door do they dance. Into the church, up the gospel aisle, through the sanctuary the dancers, go.

One of the most conspicuous features of the present financial situation, and one of the most important, is the great abundance and cheapness of money. Everywhere funds lie idle, piled up in the vaults of banks and trust companies. Everywhere rates for money are so low that lenders are bitterly complaining.

The work of Hartley House, 413 West Forty-sixth Street, the headquarters of the first industrial settlement established by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, is progressing with energy and zest.

The earliest mention of tea by an Englishman is probably that contained in a letter from Mr. Wickham, an agent of the East India Company, written from Firando in Japan on the 27th of June, 1615, to Mr. Eaton, another officer of the company, resident at Macao, asking him to send "a pot of the best chaw."

She was a matron with a comfortably rounded figure, and she looked very "nice" as she started out by herself upon a little shopping expedition. That was what her pretty, grown daughter had told her as she kissed her good-bye that morning.

The meeting of Good Government Club C at 677 Fifth Avenue last night was interesting from beginning to end. The club is in active rebellion against the Citizens' Union, because no nominations have been made, and is unalterably opposed to any deal of any kind with either political party.

Day by day the villagers, men, women, and children, left their thatch huts and visited the tombs of the local saints, crying: "God have mercy upon us; God have mercy upon us!" And there on the hills, where some clumps of palmetto and a few whited stones mark the last resting place of a saint, they stood and prayed. But no rain came.

WERE phrenology an exact science, the phrenologist would find his ideal in Robert Bonner. His head tells much of the man as he actually is. The bulging forehead and deely set eyes are backed by a head so plainly a region of phrenological bumps as to make itch the fingers of him who has ever dabbled in that fad.

On the 6th of May of last year I had journeyed, perhaps for the twentieth time, to the distant river station, and recommenced the weary routine of another launch, with very moderate expectation indeed; and when, on that, to me, memorable afternoon the signal was given and the aerodrome sprang into the air, I watched it from the shore with hardly a hope that the long series of accidents had come to a close.
It is the customary thing in Wall Street to meet with people who have advance information of coming events.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 22. -- Tables were turned upon the Newark Academy at Bayonne this afternoon by the Pingry School of Elizabeth, which won the second annual championships of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association in points scored.

ALBANY, May 22. -- Senator McCarren's bill, supplemental to the Greater New York charter, allowing slaughter houses in Brooklyn to remain where they are, instead of being moved to the river front, as provided for in the charter, was signed by Gov. Black to-day, as was Mr. Austin's bill, authorizing the Mayor, Aldermen, and commonalty of the City of New York to acquire land by condemnation whenever it is deemed necessary for public purposes.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 22. -- Sheriff Deshong of De Soto stepped off the Clyde steamer here this noon with a most complacent smile on his features.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 22. -- After their return from Annapolis the second university crew were given a rest until Wednesday in order to catch up with their university work. On Wednesday Courtney had the three college crews and the freshmen out on the lake. A long practice spin was taken, and then the four were lined up at the three-mile mark for a race to the foot of the lake.

THERE will be sold at Antwerp on June 1 a collection of old Dutch and Flemish pictures, formed and owned by Mr. Gijsbert de Clercq, a distinguished citizen of Holland and a descendant of a family which has always been noted for its love of art and the ownership of fine pictures.

LONDON, May 11. -- A tremendous desire for green fields or salt water seizes the whole of London when the Easter holidays come. Everybody feels that his system needs a change, and strains his mind trying to determine whether the little journey he certainly intends to make shall be to Brighton, to Eastbourne, up the river, or out into the open country.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- There was a bold attempt at robbery in the Rand-McNally Building this forenoon, outside the doors of the Sub-Treasury. Patrick Broderick, the confidential messenger for William Skakel, stopped out of the Sub-Treasury into the corridor, carrying a canvas bag containing 170 silver dollars.

PARIS, May 22. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day when M. Gautier interpollated the Government on Eastern affairs. In so doing the Deputy expressed the hope that France would not permit Thessaly to be taken from Greece or permit a European control of Greek finances. He also expressed regret at the fact that German influence at Constantinople had superseded French influence there.

A fair amount of dealing in dwellings and smaller properties has continued through the past week, but there has been no transaction of sufficient size or importance to command special attention. The possibility of any noteworthy activity grows less from day to day, and with the 1st of June only a week away brokers generally express little hope of any revival before Fall.

Without doubt the manifestation of British conservatism in the opposition of the conferring upon women of degrees which they have earned is ridiculous, as such manifestations are apt to be. But this was also more than a little brutal, which is especially deplorable, as the opposition is said to have been mainly clerical.

BERLIN, May 10. -- Spring is peculiarly gracious to Berlin, owing to her many parks, and to the climate, which does not hurry out the leaves as April and May hasten forward the foliage at home. Hail, sleet, and snow are by no means rare, even in May, when the cherry blossoms are nearly gone and the roses are beginning to bloom.

LONDON, May 22. -- The scheme of the Government for the relief of Ireland, as outlined in the House of Commons yesterday by the First Lord of the Treasury, A. J. Balfour, was sprung as a surprise upon most of the members, and is the leading topic for discussion in the political world to-day.

While no one would ever have thought of calling the hansom cab the "Gondola of New York," it has been rather picturesquely conspicuous here for fifteen years or more, and Americans have been gradually getting used to it. The cab habit is not common in New York, though, and the hansoms have not multiplied as rapidly as the sparrows, music halls, and other things imported for various economic reasons from England.

"Walley" O'Connor and Patrick Flannigan, the two men who were held on Thursday for robbing the Yonkers Savings Bank of $4,400 at the point of a pistol on April 12 last while Cashier Lyman Cobb, Jr., was alone, were received at the Queens County jail on Friday afternoon. That evening a "trusty" informed the Deputy Sheriff and keeper of a plot to break jail.

Senator Platt's visit to this city enabled him to ascertain that the Republican machine affairs are in unusually bad condition, both in New York and Kings County. So curious has the mix-up in Republican circles become that Senator Platt will hold an important conference with the big leaders who are still loyal to him at the Fifth Avenue Hotel this morning.

In nearly all the churches or in the monastic chapels hereabout I find swarms of Greek soldiers. They come in, cross themselves, stand listening while the priest reads from the holy books in the peculiar quavering sing-song which makes the words quite incomprehensible even to Greeks, and then they kiss the pictures.

"Andromaniacs" is a word the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst has coined to express the "passionate aping of everything that is mannish," which he apparently believes to be characteristic of many women of the present generation. The doctor has been saying some interesting things upon the so-called woman question. He emphasized the superiority of womanhood, and is emphatic in regard to the way and the purpose for which it should be developed.

Sakhalin is, for administrative purposes, divided into three districts, viz.: Korsakovsky Post in the south, Tymovsk in the north, and Alexandrovsky Post on the western coast. The latter, which is situated in the centre of the coal district, is a picturesque, straggling town of about 7,000 inhabitants, consisting almost entirely of officials and convicts.

Perfect weather and a good track was the reward for those who attended the twenty-seventh annual opening of Fleetwood Park by the Driving Club of New York yesterday. The races were good for thus early in the season and gained additional interest because the drivers were for the most part friends and acquaintances of the onlookers. A large number of women saw the races from the upper balcony of the clubhouse.

The family live handsomely, but as we were not invited, only tolerated, guests we only took off our outside wraps in the anteroom, where a man was in waiting to remove them, leaving our hats on. We passed up stairs and through a room where a son was playing delightfully on a piano when we went in and bowed to us as we went through.

Two policemen on duty in plain clothes were shot last evening while arresting a woman who had sold them whisky in violation of the excise law. The woman's husband did the shooting. Neither policeman was seriously injured, although both were hurt sufficiently to necessitate the attendance of a surgeon.

The twenty-second annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association of America will be held at the Berkeley Oval next Friday and Saturday afternoons. The contests will decide which college is entitled to the championship for 1897, and, judging from the preparations in all quarters, the struggle is bound to eclipse anything of its kind in the history of college sport.
BUFFALO, May 22. -- Asked by an Associated Press correspondent for an opinion as to Gov. Black's veto of the Graded Inheritance Tax bill to-day, Controller Roberts said:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 22. -- In the face of a waning season nature has succeeded admirably in the effort to make those last days pleasant ones. The lakes are beautiful with their clear reflections and surrounding woodland, the roads are hard and smooth, and an abundance of wild flowers may be had for the picking.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Whatever complaint of lack of hospitality the delegates to the Postal Union Congress may have felt disposed to make a week ago ought to have been silenced by this time. There was some grumbling, soon after the congress began its sessions, for it would not be accurate to describe the congress as "opening" its sessions, because the visitors were not being invited to meet Americans.

LENOX, Mass., May 22. -- Cottagers have been coming in large numbers this week. John Sloane and family arrived Tuesday and will remain through the entire season. Mr. Sloane drives out every pleasant day. His health has improved steadily since he came here.

THE world of music has transferred its chief activities to the other side of the Atlantic, where London's season has begun with its customary blare of trumpets. Already the cable has begun to seethe under the briny deep with the fiery flashes of the press agent's blazing fancy, and we are like to have our very souls dazzled with the visions of the world beyond the waves.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22. -- The approach of the month when Yale will match her brawn and skill at the oar with that of Harvard and Cornell induces a survey of the prospects as indicated by the condition of the Yale eight. The return to contests with Harvard has furnished a special and particular cause for hoping that Yale would have a strong crew to represent her at Poughkeepsie.

THE Wall Street play has had its day, and no American playwright with his wits about him will waste his time sentimentalizing over the rise and fall of stocks until financial speculation again becomes a popular theatrical topic.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 22. -- Judge Van Syckle, in the Supreme Court at this place, has granted non suit in the case of Elmer Runyon of this city against the Central Railroad of New Jersey for $25,000 damages because he was not allowed to board a train of the company in Communipaw on Dec. 30 last with some bundles.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22. -- The ninth Indiana Music Festival drew an enormous audience this afternoon, to hear 1,000 school children sing Benoit's cantata, "Into Life," and some famous soloists. The festival was the most successful in the history of these enterprises here. It concluded to-night with a grand concert, in which Mme. Emma Calve appeared.

One of the subjects brought to the attention of the Savings Banks' Association at its annual meeting in this city Thursday, and emphasized as of special interest to officers of savings banks, is the tendency of municipalities in this State to create debts. J. Harsen Rhoades, President of the association, called attention to the matter because a very large proportion of these debts are held and carried by the banks.

Fifty enthusiastic golfers from nearly twenty prominent clubs in the vicinity of New York were the starters yesterday in the big thirty-six-hole handicap contest at the Knollwood Country Club, Westchester County. This event closed the open tournament of the club. Which has been in progress since Wednesday morning, and a finer golfing day could not have been desired.

Two poolrooms are running openly in Hoboken within a hundred yards of Police Headquarters, and with the full knowledge and acquiescence if not with the consent of the city authorities. No pretense at concealment is made, despite the fact that the New Jersey State law defines poolselling as gambling, punishable with five years in prison.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 22. -- At the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day the regular order of the morning was the report of the Board of Ministerial Relief, from which it appears that the receipts last year were $160,856, and the expenditures $182,264.

The Washington lawn party of the Daughters and Sons of the American Revolution held at Earle Cliff, Washington Heights, yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Washington Heights Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, was in every way successful.

A fire which broke out in the hotel stables of McCauley McLaughlin, at Flatbush Avenue and Malbone Street, Brooklyn, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning, ended the life of Ralph Malbone, whose father at one time was one of the wealthiest citizens of Flatbush.

The padrone in the strict sense of the world was a man who engaged laborers or whole families to come to this country, rented their services, and then paid them a mere pittance. They were virtually his bondsmen.
King, Alward Co. -- The people who started Union Pacific last week will help Reading along. There has been a pool formed, and it will work not only on this side, but likewise in London.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 22. -- Cottage owners as well as the business fraternity at this place, have experienced a very busy week of it. Many people have arrived and taken possession of their cottages for the Summer, much to the surprise of the owners, who do not look for their tenants much before the 10th of June, but those cottagers who own their places have been getting in readiness for some time.

BAYBERRY POINT is the name of a sandy stretch of beach down on Great South Bay near West Islip, which a year ago was about as barren and uninviting a place as one could find. At high tide a good part of it was submerged, and there was nothing to commend it as a place for human habitation.

There are very few people of the farming class who, if properly approached, will decline to take you in for the night, provided you are reasonably well dressed, a gentlemanly looking personage, and are not traveling in a company of more than two, including yourself. You ride along through the day, and toward evening come upon some attractive looking farm house.

MADRID, May 22. -- The newspapers here consider the adoption by the United States Senate of Senator Morgan's belligerency resolution to be a very grave step. They say it will tend to strengthen the Premier, Senor Canovas del Castillo, in checking the proposed Liberal attack on the Ministry.

Local fishermen have been forced to forego their sport this week on account of the cold and disagreeable weather. All of the fishermen, however, who braved the weather and went in pursuit of the wily bass, that gamest of deep-sea fish, or cod, or ling, report good catches.

Fresh figs are not known or appreciated in Northern markets, and consequently the demand is too limited to encourage shipments. It seems doubtful if the distant shipment of fresh figs will ever become to a profitable business The fruit is more perishable than any other that is generally marketed.
BERLIN, May 22. -- The whole internal political situation in Germany is such that important surprises may he expected at any moment.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 22. -- The new Republican Common Council was organized last night. City Clerk Ayres, in calling the roll, omitted the name of Alderman Reed, from the Second Ward. The omission caused the Alderman to inquire why his name had been passed. Clerk Ayres said that, as the Alderman had not taken the oath of office, his name had not been added to the new roll call.
In his regular weekly financial review in London Truth (just received here) Mr. Henry Labouchere says of the American market:

An Englishman, bent on mastering the mysteries of their code of worship, attended Hindu debates where the orthodox and the advanced school met together in discussion. "Can you tell me," he inquired at last, confused by the arguments and counterarguments tossed like shuttlecocks from one to another, "of one single article of your creed which you all hold in common?"

WITH the marriage of the late Baron de Hirsch were united two remarkable figures in the world's history of philanthropists. The wife, no less than the husband, was a master of the art of money making, and under the skilled guidance of this unique couple, their individual fortunes grew to colossal proportions.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Assistant Secretary Spaulding has gone to New York. Gen. Spaulding will look into the personnel of the Ellis Island force, with a view to making any necessary changes. He will also examine the new improvements on the island, and probably will give some consideration to the question of the establishment of a so-called clearing house for the benefit of immigrants.

Founded by Henry B. Plant, the millionaire railroader, who is President of the Plant system of railways, steamship lines, and hotels, and holding its site at the crossing point of two of the railroads of this system, the little Florida village is fast growing into the proportions of a pretentious town; and, strangely enough, its prosperity dates back no further than when it was given the name of Trilby.

The divergencies between BOSS WORTH of Brooklyn and BOSS LAUTERBACH of New York upon the subject of fusion in municipal politics are interesting and refreshing. The mere fact of a divergency would be full of promise, without reference to the specific merits of the dispute, upon the principle of the old adage.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Careful consideration of the recent decision of the Supreme Court in the suit of the United States vs. the American Bell Telephone Company indicates to the persons who are interested in breaking the patent that it cannot be considered as overwhelming a victory for the American Bell Telephone Company as at first announced.
The Second Battalion of the Twenty-second Regiment, composed of companies A, D, E, I, and K, and four companies of the Twenty-third -- C, E, H, and I -- practiced yesterday at the Creedmoor range.

BOSTON, May 22. -- This is to be a great season for the boats in the Yacht Racing Association classes of twenty-nine feet and under. Not only are there new boats in all the classes, but through the association's influence there is harmony in the matter of racing dates, rules, and measurements. Fixtures for the season have been announced by all the clubs affiliated with the association, and by the Corinthian and Beverly Clubs.

At a dinner last week I sat beside an eminent Frenchman who graduated at the Polytechnic with M. Carnot. The severe discipline -- a military discipline -- and the fearful mathematical grind there weld the pupils into a close brotherhood. They are out of touch with every one else. Carnot was generally amiable, but only expanded with Polytechnicians.
NEWPORT, May 22. -- The real rush to Newport appears to have begun this week. At least a dozen more Summer villas were opened, including several of the larger ones.

There is a very charming family in New York where the subject of an income for the son and daughter is arranged most satisfactorily for all concerned. The two young people have inherited, or have acquired from their environment, many delightful characteristics, and perhaps may be called unusually clever and well-bred specimens of young manhood and womanhood. That is what the parents consider them, at any rate.

To advise the Republicans in Congress to drop the Dingley-Aldrich Tariff bill and say no more about it is to give a counsel of unattainable perfection. The Republican Party exists for tariff making and cannot in reason be expected to abandon the object of its being.

Sandwiched between the days of touring and parades, the cyclist who is interested in exhibitions of speed on track and road will find plenty to amuse him during the remainder of the season. Such a plethoric programme as the list of sanctions foreshadows was never before contemplated in a single Summer.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 22. -- The feature of to-day's programme at the Fair Grounds was the Debutante, Stakes for two-year-olds, at four and one-half furlongs. The stake is worth $1,200 to the winner. Good Friend won with odds of 60 to 1 against him. The winner is owned by James Whitten, and is by Ealua, out of Ruth. The weather was pleasant and the track fast.

Fire occurred late yesterday afternoon on the third floor of 396 and 398 Broadway. The building is on the corner of Walker Street and extends 150 feet to Courtland Alley. It belongs to an estate, and Solomon Blumenthal is the agent. The basement store and fourth floors are occupied by J.S. Lesser Co., importers and manufacturers of lace and lace goods.

LONDON, May 22. -- The period of marking time while the powers extend their delicate balancing act, to cover all new phases of the Eastern question, has now just begun. There be rumors enough, and even circumstantial reports, that the job will be finished, and the whole matter settled within the next week or two, but these rumors are to be taken with much more than the conventional pinch of salt.

ORANGE, N.J., May 23. -- Some 5,000 people saw the game of baseball at the Orange Oval yesterday between the Orange Athletic Club and Yale University. It was a pretty game, and Yale won by the narrow margin of one run, because of sharp and clean field work. The home team made a few errors, but most of them were excusable.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Col. George Hilton, aged and sightless, was led into the County Court Saturday to prove his sanity. He charged that relatives had declared him insane in order to get his pension. He had come from the Soldiers' Home at Dayton.

Richard M. Scruggs, the St. Louis millionaire merchant and philanthropist, who arrived Saturday on the steamship St. Paul and whose failure to make declaration to the customs officials of jewelry which he had purchased in Europe, led to its confiscation and the arrest of himself and his friend, Edmond S. Langhorne, was at the Waldorf yesterday.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- The Spring meeting of the Queen City Jockey Club ended yesterday. A special card of seven races furnished good sport. The track was fast and the betting very lively. In the sixth race, a hurdle handicap, Jockey C. Clayton was crushed by his horse falling on him. Clayton was on Wingfield, and while attempting to clear the second hurdle, the horse fell.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 23. -- The recently reorganized New York State Intercollegiate Association held its annual meet on University Field yesterday. Syracuse and Rochester were the only colleges competing. Syracuse swamped Rochester by a score of 87 to 39. The track was fast and the day fair.

PASSAIC, May 23. -- The cornerstone of St. Mary's Hospital Building was laid this afternoon with much ceremony and in the presence of what was probably the largest crowd ever gathered in Passaic. There was a big parade participated in by all the Roman Catholic societies of this and neighboring places.

NEWARK, May 23. -- Mayor James M. Seymour yesterday named two Police Justices. They are Democrats, and succeed Republicans, whose terms expired. The men chosen were George H. Lambert of the Eleventh Ward, to succeed Wilbur A. Mott in the First Criminal Court, and Herman Schalk of the Ninth Ward, in place of August F. Eggers, in the Second Criminal Court.

Rowing in the Harlem River yesterday was more like hard work than play, from the fact that the high wind which prevailed all day was not only difficult to row against, but it kicked up a choppy sea that threatened to swamp every boat out and did swamp two. Not a boat returned to a float without being half full of water, and many narrow escapes from a swim were recorded.

The Rev. Merle St. Croix Wright, pastor of the Lenox Avenue Unitarian Church, preached yesterday morning on "Nature and the Supernatural." He said in advance that he was not going to speak of the occult, or give an account of strange and extraordinary happenings, but would ask the question whether nature and the supernatural, as we know them, were to stand forever antagonistic.

The launching of the Holland submarine torpedo boat may prove to have been an event of historical importance, but it is wise to postpone rejoicings until certain demonstrations have been made. Indeed it may be questioned whether the solution of the problem of submarine navigation would be a cause for unalloyed joy.

The report in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Monday of the initial performance of Buddhistic rites in Brooklyn, in which novices, many of them members of the Brooklyn Ethical Society, took part, deserves some consideration as indicating a possible example of that "variation from the type" in the sense in which that term is used in Mr. Miller's article in the current Forum discussing the question of the degeneracy of the Senate.

A lecture and concert were held at the Montauk Theatre, Brooklyn, last evening for the benefit of the building fund of the new Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, in process of construction at Broadway and Hull Street, Williamsburg. A good sum was realized.

There was more than Summer force behind the wind that worried the sea around Coney Island yesterday, and played havoc with the pleasure craft anchored in Gravesend Bay and along the Bath Beach and Bensonhurst water fronts.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- After being twice chased by Spanish gunboats and passing through a storm of shot, which splashed in the water across her bows, the British fruit steamer Ethelred arrived at this port to-night after a five days' run from Port Antonio, Jamaica.

Special services were held in the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday morning, afternoon, and evening to celebrate the seventy-second anniversary of the establishment of the American Tract Society. The Sunday school, Bible class, and Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor participated in the various exercises.

There was a conference of Republican leaders in Senator Platt's apartments in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. It was more of a wordy battle than a conference, and bitter personalities were exchanged. As a result, Congressman Quigg, who is Senator Platt's choice for Chairman of the Republican County Committee, was triumphant, while Insurance Commissioner Payn was "turned down" and left the city with a resolve to be revenged firmly rooted in his mind.

The Central Labor Union was yesterday asked to vote in favor of the Government paying the farmers bounties on agricultural products exported. Several delegates expressed themselves as opposed to both a protective tariff on imports and to the payment of any bounties on exports.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Those whose business has called them to the Executive Chamber during the pendency of the thirty-day bills at the conclusion of the sessions of the Legislature for a number of years past compare the present system employed by the Governor and his private secretary unfavorably with those of the past, especially those in vogue in the times of Govs. Flower and Morton.

Gov. JOSEPH F. JOHNSON of Alabama is earning the title his admiring constituents give him -- " the business Governor." In a recent interview with a correspondent of The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore the Governor declared: "We should make and enforce such laws as will cause those who have money to invest to feel that it is safer in the South than in either New York or New England."

WORCESTER, Mass., May 23. -- The eleventh annual games of the New England Intercollegiate Athletic Association took place at Worcester Oval yesterday in the presence of about 1,500 spectators. Dartmouth won the championship for the third successive year. The scores were: Dartmouth, 29; Brown, 26; Bowdoin, 19; Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 11 1/2; Wesleyan, 11; Amherst, 9; Williams, 7; Trinity, 5 1/2; Tufts, 5; Worcester Polytechnic Institute, 3.

Edward L'Estrange Phipps, a real estate dealer of 102 South Sixth Avenue, Mount Vernon, was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday, accused by Gaetano Tagliabue of grand larceny. He pleaded not guilty, and gave bail in $1,500 for examination Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The arrangements for the international chess match between selected teams from the British House of Commons and the House of Representatives are practically completed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The golden jubilee meeting of the American Medical Association, which will be held in Philadelphia June 1, 2, 3, and 4, promises to be not only the most important meeting ever held by this great organization, but also the largest gathering of noted medical men ever before brought together in this city.

-- Even in the vicinity of New York, the country roads are at last in a condition that almost satisfies those severe critics, the bicyclists. They are grateful only to the weather, however, for they know that to it alone is the present smoothness of the highways due. And the excellence will be of short duration.

GEORGETOWN, Del., May 23. -- It was reported to-day that Lawyer Cullen, the chief attorney for the defense in the Gordy case, had in his possession a letter which says that the writer and a companion had plotted the murder of Mrs. Lewis, for whose death James M. Gordy is sentenced to be hanged on June 11.

DALLAS, Texas, May 23. -- At 4 o'clock this morning a mob of 500 white farmers from the Counties of Cass, Wood, and Smith stormed the jail at Tyler, Smith County, and shot William Jones, a well-known white man, to death in his cell.

CINCINNATI, May 23. -- The Brooklyn team made its first appearance this season in Cincinnati to-day, and succeeded in defeating the Cincinnatis in an exciting and hard-fought game. The feature of the game was the playing of Shindle and Anderson of the Brooklyns. Though the Cincinnatis piled up ten hits on Daub's delivery, excellent fielding on the part of the Brooklyn team won it the game.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- United States Consul General Lee yesterday cabled the State Department from Havana that the Spanish officials there have released Frenando Govin, an American citizen, who has been under arrest, and he will leave the island.
The Rev. F.M. Goodchild, pastor of the Central Baptist Church, preached the fourth of his series of sermons on popular frivolities and vices last night. Swearing was the vice denounced last night.

Mr. BYNUM'S tour through the South is arousing much interest. His recent speech in Winston, N.C., was very fairly reported in both the local papers, The Journal and The Sentinel. And, though these are both connected with the free-silver Democratic organization, their comments on the speech were candid.

The thirteenth annual report of the City Civil Service Commission, submitted to Mayor Strong, by Everett P. Wheeler, Charles W. Watson, J. Van Vechten Olcott, W. Bayard Cutting, and William Jay Schieffelin, has been published. A perusal of its contents reveals to the friend of the merit system of selection and promotion many facts to strengthen him in his confidence in the methods of these Commissioners.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, to members of Winchester Post, G.A.R. The sermon was an appeal for an exercise of true patriotism in the discharge of civic duties, and the preacher discussed the problem arising out of the creation of Greater New York.

Confederate veterans joined those of the Federal forces to honor the memory of Admiral David Glasgow Farragut with simple services of impressive character yesterday afternoon. It was the annual memorial service of the Farragut Association of Naval Veterans of the Port of New York, held to commemorate the anniversary of the opening of the Mississippi in 1862.

William Glennon of 812 Second Avenue was knocked down by a bicycle at Forty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue yesterday morning, and his right wrist was broken. He was taken to Flower Hospital. George A. Feavers of 844 Ninth Avenue, who was riding the wheel, was arrested.

The four days of racing at Morris Park this week, which will end the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association, should prove to be the most attractive of any since the season opened, for besides the famous stakes to be contested, among them the rich Eclipse, there are a number of events in which the gentleman jockey will have an opportunity of showing his skill.

As far as the possibility of obtaining liquor is concerned yesterday was much the same as the other Sundays have been since the amendments to the Raines law went into effect. There was no lack of drinks to be had, and there were few sections of the city where the thirsty man had to walk many blocks to satisfy his appetite.

ST. LOUIS, May 23. -- Not for a generation has a greater sensation been created in religious, social, and business circles here than was caused by the announcement that Richard M. Scruggs and Edward G. Langhorne had been arrested in New York on a charge of smuggling diamonds.

ALBANY, May 23. -- The annual report for 1896 of State Superintendent of insurance Payn, upon life, casualty, and assessment insurance companies, just made public, exhibits an interesting array of figures.

Fire in the four-story and basement brownstone building at 149 West Twenty-third Street yesterday caused the loss of two lives and the fatal injury of one person. Several were slightly injured, and many had narrow escapes from death. The lives of at least five persons were saved through the coolness and heroism of a woman, who paid for her valor with her life.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- "President McKinley is an opportunist," said a Democratic Senator to-day, in speaking about the promised Administration policy toward Cuba. "He does not take a broad view of the situation. He has no plan for anything but to-day.

If genius were really the faculty for taking infinite pains, Mr. THOMAS L. GREENE, auditor of the Manhattan Trust Company, should be credited with genius. But as a matter of fact the capacity for such intelligent painstaking as he shows in his little book on "Corporation Finance" is nearly as rare as genius and more useful in the field that he has entered and may almost be said to have opened.
WOODBURY, N.J., May 23. -- At Almonesson this afternoon a trolley car loaded with fully a hundred excursionists jumped the track while going at full speed. There was a panic.

Preaching to the New York State Convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew and a congregation that crowded St. Luke's Church, Brooklyn, last evening, the Right Rev. J. Philip Du Moulin, Lord Bishop of Niagara, appealed for the better keeping of Sunday and outlined his views about bicycling and when it might and might not be enjoyed on the Sabbath.
LONDON, May 24. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Times says:

Perhaps the Diamond Jubilee will turn out to be a disastrous speculation. Of course, the procession will be fine and memorable and many thousands of her subjects will see the Queen, as will many Americans. The Americans who are going to the jubilee are willing to spend their money and expect to pay extravagant prices for all they get.

BOSTON, May 23. -- An interesting point was ruled on by Judge Fitz, in the Chelsea Police Court yesterday in the case of Jerome Cronin, who was arrested in Revere a few nights ago. He was arraigned on two complaints, of illegal liquor selling and assaulting a policeman while in the performance of his duty. The latter was Patrolman De Laite of Revere, who made the arrest.

The bill which has been approved by Gov. Black in reference to the construction of a new library building on the site of the reservoir at Forty-second Street empowers the city authorities to erect such a building in accordance with plans to be made by the Trustees of the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations, and having the approval of the Board of Estimate.

MONTREAL, May 23. -- It is announced that the Standard Oil Company is about to erect extensive warehouses at Montreal and at Toronto, with the expectation of considerably increasing its Canadian business. This is a direct result of the new Canadian tariff.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 23. -- Though the General Assembly has not been in session to-day, it has not been a time of idleness. Many ministers have preached in neighboring towns, but most of the commissioners and visitors have remained here. Consequently, the meetings held in the large auditorium have been very fully attended.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Mgr. Martinelli was the guest of honor at the celebration here to-day of the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the Catholic diocese of Albany. Pontifical mass was celebrated, the Archbishop presiding, assisted by Bishop Burke of Albany and Bishop Ludden of Syracuse.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 23. -- Fast birds and good scores characterized the shooting at Elkwood Park traps yesterday. Phil Daly, Jr., won seven of the ten events. Although not scheduled events, the shooting was attractive. Daly captured the three first ten bird matches with straight kills and defeated "Walters" in a twenty-five-bird match, killing twenty-three.
LONDON, May 24. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says:

CHICAGO, May 23. -- The Saddle and Cycle Club celebrated the opening of its new clubhouse yesterday with a programme of entertainment such as visitors to county fairs are familiar with. The golf-stockined members chased a greased pig, which saved its bacon by running into the lake; rolled down hill in barrels, had potato races, and other games not usually played in society.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Tuesday, ten weeks and a day after the beginning of the session, the Senate will take up the Tariff bill, for the passage of which the session was called. The bill was to have been called up Monday, but the death of Senator Earle of South Carolina will render necessary an adjournment for a day.

When I clipped my coupon from your advertisement setting out the superiority and merit of your 1897 or tenth edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica I did not for a moment imagine that you had any attending features connected with the work which rendered the same doubly valuable as a time saver and educator.

FARMINGTON, Me., May 23. -- Albert M. King, the messenger of the Boylston National Bank of Boston, who disappeared with $30,000 of the bank's money, and was captured here yesterday, was a sad-looking young man to-day.

A warm discussion arose at the meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York at the Academy of Medicine last night as to the fate of a certain bill which had been advocated by the society and passed by the Assembly and Senate, but which apparently had been lost in the multitude of measures still left over for the consideration of the Governor.

DENVER, May 24. -- One man was killed and another fatally wounded at Joe Lowe's roadhouse, about five miles south of the city, last night. Lowe has had trouble with a neighbor, Jacob Kisthard, over the water in an irrigating ditch in which both are interested. Kisthard and his two sons were working on the ditch when some of Lowe's employes went to the ditch to protect his interests.
WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 24. -- During a thunderstorm at 10 o'clock to-night lightning struck the lumber yard of W.N. Clayton, at South River. The fire which followed destroyed the lumber and sheds in the yard. A hardware and shipping material store which joined the yard was also burned. The loss on the lumber yard and store is estimated at $17,500.

PITTSBURG, May 24. -- The session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church this morning was enlivened by a heated discussion over the use of tobacco. The question arose over the report of the committee having in charge the bequest of the Rev. Dr. Francis Land for the education of young men for the ministry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- President Thomson of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company has returned from an inspection trip over the lines between Philadelphia and Pittsburg and the Pennsylvania Company's lines west of the latter city. In an interview to-day with a reporter for The Associated Press Mr. Thomson said:

Within the sombre walls of the meeting house at Rutherfurd Place and Fifteenth Street the Hicksite Friends yesterday spent the third day of their annual convention, or "yearly meeting," as they term it. In public worship the men and women Friends assemble together, but at the business meetings, or "meetings for discipline," the men use one hall and the women use another, holding separate but harmonious sessions.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 24. -- The sessions of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church were opened to-day with devotional exercises led by Elder Kiliaen Van Rensselaer of New York. By general consent, reference to the parliamentary tangle on Saturday regarding the Presbyterian Building was omitted from the minutes.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- A very small crowd huddled shiveringly together in the grand stand and saw the New York team defeat the Chicagos to-day. It was a pitchers' battle from start to finish -- Meekin and Sullivan against Griffith. The visitors won the game in the fourth inning. A base on balls and three hits did the business.
