CHICAGO, May 24. -- A morning newspaper says steps looking to the formation of a powerful alliance in opposition to the Bell Telephone Company are to be taken in Chicago this week. The main things contemplated are:

The effete sportsmen of the Meadow-brook Hunt must look to their laurels. No doubt they think that when they pursue the elusive anise-seed bag "across country" to the detriment of the crops and the morals of the Long Island farmer, they are giving a life-like imitation of the real Englishmen who are fond of doing a fast twenty minutes up wind and killing in the open.

BERLIN, May 24. -- The trial of Herr von Tausch, the former Commissioner of the Secret Political Police, who was arrested on Dec. 8 last, at the close of the sensational Luetzow-Leckert trial, during which the Imperial Chancellor, Prince Hohenlohe; the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, and the German Ambassador to Austria, Count Philip von Eulenberg, were among the witnesses, commenced to-day, and will probably last a week.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- A bill amending and revising the inter-State commerce law has been forwarded to Senator Culiom in Washington by a committee representing the National Business League, Board of Trade, and the Chicago Freight Bureau. The bill has been approved by the Executive Committees of these three organizations, and a comprehensive brief, analyzing the proposed changes in the law, accompanies the document.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day, Justice Peckham handed down the opinion of the court in the case of L.E. Parsons, late District Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama, appealed from the Court of Claims. The decision was averse to Parsons's claim that he was entitled under Section 769 of the Revised Statutes to hold his office for four years, notwithstanding the President's order of removal.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Chief Justice Fuller of the Supreme Court to-day announced the dismissal of the writ of error in the case of Henry T. Blythe and others versus Florence Blythe Hinckley. This decision sustains the Supreme Court of California in its disposal of the fortune left by Thomas H. Blythe, the eccentric California millionaire, and ends one of the longest and most famous legal fights ever waged in this country.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 24. -- At the opening of the afternoon session of the Presbyterian General Assembly John Wanamaker was recognized, and said: "Mr. Moderator, I rise to a question of privilege, believing that this assembly would like to be reminded that to-day is the anniversary of that most noble woman who reigns over the British Kingdom.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., May 24. -- Archibald R. Henry, for fourteen years prominent as a Seventh Day Adventist, and lately General Manager of the Publishing Association of the order, has brought suit against the Adventists for $50,000 for alleged defamation of character.

Voters who approve the principle of non-partisan government for the city have an opportunity to participate in the nomination of a candidate for Mayor by indicating their choice to the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union. The committee is only an agent. It acts for the mass of citizens who want to be rid of party politics in local administration.

The word having gone forth on Sunday that Senator Thomas C. Platt wanted Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg made Chair-night's meeting of the County Committee, to succeed Edward Lauterbach, there was comparative peace in the Republican local camp yesterday. There was some quiet talking among the opponents of Mr. Quigg in the County Committee, but it was carried on in subdued tones.

While there is a disappointment in the number of entries received for the Irvington-Millburn handicap road race, the list only footing up to about 120, it is thought that the high class of the candidates will more than atone for the lack in the size of the field. All things considered, the race of this year will probably rank as high as any in the history of the great contest.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 24. -- President Henry O. Havemeyer of the American Sugar Refining Company will be placed on trial in the Criminal Court to-morrow morning on an indictment charging him with having refused to answer questions put to him by the Senate Committee investigating the Sugar Trust.

It looked early yesterday morning as though the soldiers at Creedmoor would have a wet day of it, but fortunately the weather cleared, and in consequence some good shooting was done. Five companies each of the Ninth and Thirteenth Regiments occupied the range under command of Cols. William Seward and W.L. Watson, respectively.
ALBANY, May 24. -- Gov. Black used his veto power with a surprising lavishness on the Supply and Supplemental Supply bill to-day. Here are the vetoed items, with the Governor's reasons:

BOSTON, Mass., May 24. -- At the annual meeting of the Handel and Haydn Society to-night President A. Parker Browne, who has had office ten years, resigned, and Vice President Eugene B. Hagar was chosen in his stead.
This is the most dangerous season of the year. It may be pleasant, may often seem attractive, but back of all the pleasant atmosphere there is danger! This danger comes in some form of sickness.

DOVER, Del., May 24. -- The House of Representatives this afternoon, by a vote of 8 to 6, passed the bill divorcing Mrs. Laura Crocker Acklan from her husband, William H. Acklan of Washington. The bill recently passed the Senate.

The Lord Bishop of Niagara, the Right Rev. J. PHILIP DU MOULIN, is a wise clergyman and deserves to be an extraordinarily influential one. His remarks on the observance of the Sabbath in St. Luke's Church, Brooklyn, last Sunday, ought to be heeded by certain narrow-minded preachers of the Gospel here in this progressive city, where liberal views are supposed to prevail, and by the majority of ministers elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The nomination to-day of Brig. Gen. John R. Brooke, commanding the Department of the Missouri, to be a Major General, was prevented by the early adjournment of the Senate. It is expected it will be made to-morrow.

LONDON, May 24. -- The birthday of Queen Victoria, who was born May 24, 1819, was observed to-day with the usual artillery salutes, the ringing of church bells, and reviews at the different naval and military stations.

PITTSBURG, May 24. -- The eighty-third anniversary meeting of the American Baptist Missionary Union, which was opened in the Fourth Avenue Baptist Church this morning, was enlivened for a short while by an unlooked-for incident. The report of the Executive Committee recommended that the appropriations for the coming year be made on a scale $60,000 below those of the present year, without making any concealment of the disastrous effects of such enforced economy.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The questions whether the statutes relating to National banks, prohibiting them from purchasing or subscribing to the stock of another corporation, and whether the want of authority can be urged by the bank to defeat an attempt to enforce against it the liability of a stockholder, were passed on by the Supreme Court to-day in the case of the California National Bank, plaintiff in error, vs. Nat Kennedy.

President Charles G. Wilson of the Board of Health sent a letter to Corporation Counsel Scott on May 21 asking his construction of Section 3 of the new civil service law, which seems to indicate that when the eligible list has been made by adding the ratings by merit and fitness, appointments must be made absolutely in the order of their standing on that list.

The evidence given in the trial of Commander Booth-Tucker before Judge Newburger and a jury in Part II. of General Sessions yesterday for keeping a disorderly house at the Salvation Army Barracks in West Fourteenth Street was the cause of considerable merriment in the courtroom, and several times the Judge rapped sternly for order. But, notwithstanding the judicial solemnity, it was apparent that the Court was as much amused as any of the spectators.

The sale at auction of the library of Charles W. Frederickson, who died Jan. 29 last, was begun yesterday at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms. Many dealers were in attendance. The library is in some respects the most remarkable ever offered in America. It illustrates to a splendid degree the effectiveness and use of pursuing one aim.

President Moss of the Police Board visited Walhalla Hall, the headquarters of the striking tailors, yesterday afternoon. Escorted by the Executive Committee he was conducted through the crowd to the platform, and Leader Schoenfeld introduced him to the strikers and assured the men that the police were not against them.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- In response to an application by Secretary Alger, the Attorney General has rendered an opinion as to the power of the War Department to issue licenses for the erection of religious chapels on military reservations. The opinion was called forth by an application for a license for the erection at West Point of a Roman Catholic chapel.

Dr. NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER made a pregnant suggestion the other day in a public address, in which he said that the schoolhouses ought to be the centres of neighborhood life, and should be permitted to be used for all gatherings which were not political or religious.

Referring to the recent and pending creation of indebtedness by the smaller villages and towns within the Greater New York territory, I would respectfully suggest that on this subject there is a point of view opposite to that formulated by the President of the Savings Banks Association, and which is at least as plausible as his, with its insinuations of recklessness and dishonesty.

-- Georgia, Massachusetts, Ohio, and North Carolina each win reflected glory this year by supplying one of the class leaders at Annapolis. The showing is a pleasant one, as it indicates that no single part of the country has a monopoly of brains, though three of these bright boys do come from an Atlantic coast State, and the fourth from what is now well in the East.
Lowenfeld Prager have sold to Weil Mayer the old front and rear tenements 9 Pitts Street, 23 by 100. The buyers will improve the property by the erection of a six-story tenement.

We look upon Mr. DAVID LUBIN of California as a benefactor of his country. He is going about getting bodies of grangers and labor unions to pass resolutions demanding that the Government pay bounties to farmers on exports of agricultural products. Bounties are in their nature compensatory and corrective.
Stock market strong.

SHANDAKEN, N.Y., May 24. -- While riding his wheel Sunday Charles Brownlee of this village met a fierce dog with his jaws covered with foam on the road from Allaben to Shandaken, and quickly decided that he had best ride fast and furiously if he wished to escape. He had heard of the dog's being fierce and a terror to wheelmen.

The body of Oscar Garrettson, a well-known resident of Grasmere, S.I., and a member of the Mercantile Exchange of New York, who has been missing from his home since the 14th inst., was found drowned in the bay yesterday and removed to an undertaking establishment. The body was identified by his nephew, Louis Garrettson, a Staten Island lawyer.

ALBANY, May 24. -- The Executive Chamber was besieged to-day from early in the morning until late to-night with those who were interested in bills still in the Governor's hands. This was the last day, and all were anxious to know the fate of some one of the 325 bills left. It was 4 o'clock when the Governor made his first announcement that he had signed the Buffalo Armory bill.

Not alone every inhabitant of the Borough of Manhattan, but every citizen of New York, has an interest in the proposed building for the Public Library. It will not be merely the home of a library to which every New Yorker of any intellectual curiosity will have occasion at some time to resort.

PARIS, May 24. -- The retiring United States Ambassador, Mr. James B. Eustis, drove to the Elysee Palace to-day and presented his letters of recall to President Faure. After the ceremony Mr. Eustis granted an interview to a representative of The Associated Press and gave the latter his impressions of France, and expressed his admiration of the French people and his opinion of the rejected arbitration treaty. Mr. Eustis said:

ALBANY, May 24. -- The statement of pardons and commutations granted in 1896 by Gov. Morton, just issued, shows that 29 pardons were granted, as compared with 34 in 1895. He granted 82 commutations, as compared with 53 in 1895. Of the pardons none were of those convicted of murder or manslaughter.
MADRID, May 24. -- The political situation here seems to be as follows:

ST. PETERSBURG, May 24. -- The Odessky Listok of Odessa announces the coming arrival there of one of the Vanderbilts, who, according to that newspaper, is about to start big naphtha works at Baku, Russian Transcaucasia.

ST. PAUL, May 24. -- The Grand Jury this afternoon returned an indictment against Congressman F.C. Stevens, charging him with an overdraft of $2,200 in his account with the Minnesota Savings Bank at the time when he was a Trustee and Acting President of the bank.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- The Stock Exchange was unusually quiet to-day, and only a small business was done. None of the local securities showed the difference of a point between opening and closing, and those stocks which furnished the recent activity had fallen into their former sluggishness.

" A Round of Pleasure" had a noisy welcome at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, and most of the spectators, if not all of them, remained to see the quadrille d'honneur transformed into a wild can-can under the influence of Dr. Edison Beaten's brain wafers, which had been flying about and exploding all through the piece.

Peter F. Vanderveer, principal owner of Vanderveer Park, in Flatbush, and one of the wealthiest representatives of the old-time families in that suburb, has been sued by Dr. William H. Nans, a Flatbush physician, for services alleged to have been rendered Miss Kate Hoffman at the instance of the defendant.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The President has remitted the sentence of dismissal imposed by court-martial on Capt. Romeyn, Fifth Infantry, who, after a sensational trial, was convicted recently of assault on Lieut. O'Brien of the same regiment at Fort McPherson, Ga. In view of the fact that Capt. Romeyn will retire by operation of law on June 1, the President believes that the ends of justice will be secured by his severe reprimand.

DUBLIN, May 24. -- It is believed to be certain that many, perhaps all, of the political prisoners, including the Invincibles James Fitzharris, Larry Hanlon, and Joe Mullett, will be pardoned early in June, in commemoration of the sixtieth year of the reign of Queen Victoria.

Cornelius Van Cott took actual charge of the Post Office and the Federal Building yesterday morning, when he entered the Postmaster's room at 9 o'clock and announced himself ready for business. He has been, however, Postmaster and custodian of the Federal Building since Saturday midnight, for his commission dates from then.

After weeks of brooding and deliberation, Charles Kemble Hillyard of 212 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, shot and killed his thirteen-year-old son, William Kemble Hillyard, whom he idolized, and himself on Monday night. The double crime was not discovered until yesterday afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 25. -- May Campbell, a variety actress, who came here from Cincinnati, hid in a closet in Maud Devere's room to-day and listened while her husband and Miss Devere arranged for an elopement. Then Mrs. Campbell emerged with a revolver and put five bullets into her husband and one into Maud Devere. She then walked to the Four Courts and gave herself up.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Miss Susan St. John, a New York portrait painter, has won her suit for $25,000 damages against the North Chicago Street Railway Company. In 1895 she was visiting Chicago, and Aug. 30, while dismounting from a North State Street electric car, the motorman started the car before she had reached the ground, and she was thrown to the stone curbing.

The City of New York and the Dock Commission are to be Congratulated on the addition of over five miles of possible wharfage room on the North River and of 900,000 square feet of area available for handling freight and passengers. This is an addition equivalent to about 15 per cent. of the total wharfage room of Liverpool and Birkenhead, the second largest port in this regard in the world, New York being the first.
Lemuel Ely Quigg was elected President of the Republican County Committee, to succeed Edward Lauterbach, last night. Frank H. Platt, son of the Senator, placed Mr. Quigg in nomination.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 25. -- Gov. Ellerbe to-day appointed Congressman John L. McLaurin United States Senator to succeed the late Senator Earle, although it had been understood that the appointment would not be announced until to-morrow.

The Board of Health yesterday decided a Harlem dog case, which has been pending nearly a year, and which seems to have divided a neighborhood in East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street into opposing factions.

CINCINNATI, May 25. -- The Brooklyns made it three straight to-day, defeating the Cincinnatis easily in an uninteresting game. Payne went in the box for the visitors, but was relieved by Fisher after the first inning, only one hit being made off Fisher in eight innings. Attendance, 800. Score:
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Senator Cannon of Utah to-day offered the following as an amendment to the Tariff bill:

LONDON, May 25. -- When the Parliamentary Committee inquiring into the Transvaal raid resumed business to-day in the committee room off Westminster Hall, the Chairman, Mr. William L. Jackson, Conservative, Member for North Leeds, and Chairman of the Great Northern Railway Company, read a long letter from Mr. Henry Labouchere.

The powers of the Inter-State Commerce Commission fare badly at the hands of the courts. This, of course, is but another way of saying that the law under which the commission was created and operates was badly drawn for its purpose.

S. Van Rensselaer Cruger Co. have sold for the Taylor estate the five-story brownstone-front flat 279 Seventh Street, 24 by 73.2. The same brokers sold 281 Seventh Street to same purchaser a few days ago.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 25. -- W.S. Fielding, Minister of Finance, advanced in the House of Commons this afternoon a statement of the changes he intended making in the tariff resolutions. The most important is that in regard to tobacco. In his budget speech Mr. Fielding made an excise duty on tobacco of 10 cents per pound on the raw leaf unstemmed and 11 cents on stemmed.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- The New York team administered another defeat to Chicago to-day, giving them their first shut-out of the season. The home team was outplayed at every point, and only one of them reached second. The visitors played a fast, snappy, errorless game, took quick advantage of every misply, stole bases almost at will, and won easily with but four safe hits to their credit.

The Second Battalion of the Ninth Regiment, consisting of Companies A, B, F, I, and K, a few stragglers from Company C, the Fourth Separate Company of Yonkers, and the First Separate Company of Mount Vernon, practiced at Creedmoor yesterday. While the weather was perfect, the breeze that blew all day was not favorable to the marksmen.

MARGARET DELAND, who is a moralist as well as a story-teller, and neatly combines the two functions in her books, (though her morals are apt to be "modern," complex, and vague,) tells the story in her "Wisdom of Fools" of a meek but firm woman who preferred poverty and hard work for her children and herself to accepting the bounty of her brother, who was a "capitalist" at war with "labor."

As an innovation on early Quaker customs, the men and women of the Society of Friends held joint business sessions yesterday in the fourth day of their yearly meeting, at Fifteenth Street and Rutherfurd Place. For generations since the time of William Penn, the men Friends transacted their business apart from the session held by the women Friends to consider the same items of business.

Two brothers, lost to each other for more than thirty years, were reunited last Saturday night under peculiar circumstances. Samuel Frazer, one of the crew of the ship T.F. Oakes, and the principal witness against Capt. Reed, who is on trial in the United States District Court for alleged ill-treatment of his crew during a recent voyage from Hongkong to this port, has been detained for several weeks in Ludlow Street Jail.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Assistant Secretary Day, who is charged with the execution of the President's wishes respecting the Cuban relief measures, had a long interview with President McKinley at the White House this afternoon just after the Cabinet meeting. The conclusion was reached that, having advanced Consul General Lee funds to meet all probable immediate necessities, there was no opportunity for the adoption of further steps until he had been heard from.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The trial of H.O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, for refusing to answer the questions of the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee in the Spring of 1894 began in Criminal Court No. 1 at the City Hall this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Pasco of Florida presented the credentials of the new Senator from Florida, Stephen R. Mallory, and the latter was duly sworn in. He was assigned to a desk in the front row of the extreme right of the Democratic side. A handsome bouquet of roses was on his desk.

A conference of the Committee on Wage Earners of the Citizens' Union, with prominent labor men, was held last night at Cooper Union. It was the first of a series of conferences held for the purpose of effecting an organization of workingmen in harmony with the Citizens' Union.

An anonymous appeal to LEMUEL ELY QUIGG to turn his back on PLATT, repudiate LAUTERBACH, and come out as the Hercules of the righteous government cause would at once be set down as the work of a political wag. Such an appeal is made by our serious Republican contemporary, The Mail and Express.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The Permanent Committee on Arbitration appointed by the National Conference held in Washington in April, 1896, with special reference to a permanent system of arbitration between the United States and Great Britain, have made public the following statement:

ALBANY, May 25. -- Gov. Black's private secretary announced this morning that the case of Police Commissioner Parker will not be taken up by the Governor until next week. It will not be a public hearing, but merely a review of the case by the Governor, with a decision.

The unusual spectacle of a policeman taking a Roundsman to the police station under arrest was witnessed early yesterday morning in the Nineteenth Precinct. Michael Gannon was the policeman, and his prisoner was Roundsman Elmer Dixon. Gannon's post extends along Broadway, from Twenty-third to Twenty-ninth Street.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 25. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly to-day settled two important questions. The first was not to sell its building in New York and the second to have only one Secretary of home missions. The latest echo of the controversy over Dr. Briggs and the Union Seminary came up in the report of the Judicial Committee, which extended to all Presbyteries the order to exclude students of that seminary from their care.

" Those Thompson boys" had a sort of gala day of it at Morris Park yesterday. Horses belonging in their stable won just half the races, and their two-year-old fillies L'Alouette and Sagacity ran first and second, respectively, in the Fashion Stakes for the young misses, thus putting to the credit of their owners $2,750 of the $3,000 stake.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 25. -- Some time ago C.P. Huntington made an offer of $1,000,000 in 4 per cent. gold-bearing bonds for the Galveston, Laporte and Houston Railway, a terminal line from Galveston to Houston, now in the hands of receivers. Saturday a meeting of a committee of the creditors was held, and it was agreed that the bonds should be accepted.

Sooner or later every cyclist experiences the difficulty of keeping clear of children playing in the street. And if he is unfortunate enough to run down one of them, there is sure to be a great cry against his alleged recklessness. Such was the result of an accident in which Walter Cummings, Captain of the Glenmore Wheelmen, of Brooklyn, figured last week.

With the aid of two brass bands, which marched through the Bowery, Third Avenue, and intersecting streets, the Independence Hall Democracy drew a large crowd into the main hall of Cooper Union last night, where a meeting was held to protest against the Raines law. Police Captain O'Keefe and a squad of bluecoats were on hand to preserve order.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., May 25. -- Of the nineteen men of this town who sailed last week on the schooner Joseph E. Johnson for the fishing ground, on the Western Bank, so-called, which lies off Sable Island and about 200 miles off the Nova Scotia coast, only three came back on the schooner when she rounded the point this morning with her flag at half mast.
Several fights and an attempt at suicide were features of the tailors' strike yesterday.

Mr. ALDRICH'S explanation of his sugar schedule is cautious but not convincing. It leaves unchanged the complicated rates which have called out severe criticisms from his own party and have excited the alarm of those Republicans who are just now peculiarly apprehensive of the political effect of tariff favors to great trusts.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- The special session of the one hundred and twenty-first Legislature, after being in session seven hours, adjourned sine die, without having accomplished anything except the correction of the error which made the session necessary and the confirmation of some nominations sent to the Senate by the Governor.

LONDON, May 26. -- The aspect of Eastern affairs is less peaceful. Turkey is sending 7,000 more troops to Thessaly, and it is said that the Sultan has promised his Ministers not to relax his hold upon that province.

MADRID, May 25. -- The President of the Chamber of Deputies, Senor Pidal, in the name of the majority, has begged Senor Sagasta, the Liberal leader, to persuade the Liberals to reattend the sittings of the Cortes. Senor Sagasta replied that the question was between the Government and the Liberals, and not between the Liberals and the majority.

The decision of Corporation Counsel Scott that under the new civil service law appointments must be made absolutely in the order of the eligible list is exactly in accord with Commissioner Andrews's contention on the subject of promotions. He was seen at his home last night and expressed himself as pleased that Mr. Scott had so perfectly voiced his opinion.

It is not very creditable to our civilization perhaps that that achievement of what is now called the "veriscope" that has attracted and will attract the widest attention should be the representation of a prizefight. Moralists may deplore this fact, and the kindred fact that the fight in question "sold more extras" than would be sold by a Presidential election.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The tariff bill was taken up in the Senate at 2 o'clock on motion of Mr. Aldrich, (Rep., R.I.) The motion prevailed without opposition.
LONDON, May 26. -- The correspondent of The Times at Athens says:

The State of New Jersey is shy one martial son. Her National Guard has been depleted to the extent of Private Harry McClurg of Company A, First Battalion, Fourth Regiment, and the hunting of him interested Jersey City yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Senator Aldrich on behalf of the Republican members of the Senate Committee on Finance to-day gave notice of thirty-two additional amendments to the Tariff bill which will be offered as the bill progresses, as follows:
NEWPORT, May 25. -- Elisha Dyer of Providence was inaugurated to-day "Governor, Captain General, and Commander in Chief of the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations for the year ensuing."
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Mr. Aldrich closed his tariff speech at 3:10 o'clock, having spoken a little over an hour.

A house warming marked the opening of the new home of the New York Tenement House Chapter of the International Order of the King's Daughters and Sons yesterday afternoon at 48 Henry Street. Daintily attired young women picked their way through the swarms of children on the sidewalks to the chapter's new home, and enjoyed a pleasant social event in the heart of the slum district.
LONDON, May 25. -- A brilliant audience witnessed the first performance at the Alhambra Music Hall this evening of the new national ballet by Sir Arthur Sullivan, "Victoria and Merrie England."
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

-- By deciding, as he has, to let Capt. ROMEYN off with a reprimand, President MCKINLEY shows that, though once a soldier himself, he now shares the inability of ordinary civilians to regard a cuff on the ear as the episode in that Atlanta scandal which best deserved investigation and punishment. A court-martial however, was a somewhat complicated means of reaching the conclusion that it's injudicious for a grown-up man to lose his temper.

The sale at auction of the library of Charles W. Frederickson was continued yesterday at Bangs Co.'s auction rooms, 91 Fifth Avenue. A number of important and interesting volumes were disposed of. There were two sales yesterday, one beginning at 10:30 o'clock, and one at 3 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Representatives of practically all the tobacco manufacturers in the United States, with the exception of the cigar manufacturers, met here to-day to protest against the proposed advance of two cents a pound in the tax on tobacco contemplated in the Senate amendments to the Tariff bill.

Senator MORGAN was rather more absurd than usual on Tuesday. Especially was he comic when he became pathetic. This was when he deplored the "calamity and humiliation" to which the country was subjected in having to send its wheat for the relief of the starving people of India in foreign bottoms. To avert this grievous thing he proposed to naturalize two foreign-built ships for the occasion.

The report of the conference committee upon the Sundry Civil bill establishes a much more reasonable regulation than at one time seemed possible of the question of forest reserves. It illustrates once more how the House of Representatives acts in the manner in which the framers of the Constitution hardly expected the Senate to act -- as a check, that is to say, upon the turbulent and irresponsible "other house" bulent and irresponsible "other house."

DANVILLE, Penn., May 26. -- There was dedicated here to-day a granite monument to the memory of Col. F.K. Hain, who held important positions on the Philadelphia and Reading, the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, and other railroads before he became General Manager of the Manhattan Railway Company, in New York.

Former Police Captain Patrick H. Pickett was appointed Warden of the Ludlow Street Jail yesterday morning to succeed William J. Roe, removed. The new Warden immediately filed, with the County Clerk a bond of $50,000, with Patrick McMorrow and James Fay as sureties.

At the conclusion of the usual routine business of the Police Board yesterday President Moss referred to the recent raid on the Clarendon Concert Hall, in Thirteenth Street. He said his attention had been called to the place by a personal letter from the Mayor, and that he had investigated before referring the matter to the Chief for action.
PARIS, May 26. -- President Faure formally received the new United States Ambassador, Gen. Horace Porter, to-day. The reception took place at 5:10 P.M., and the General presented his credentials.

BOSTON, May 26. -- The Bradford manuscript history of the New Plymouth Colony, for the possession of which Massachusetts had long been anxious, and had made many overtures to those in England in whose custody it had been, was formally presented to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts by Thomas F. Bayard, former United States Ambassador to England, before a joint convention of the Legislature to-day.
HAVANA, May 26. -- El Diario de la Marina, in a leading editorial to-day, says:

Quakers young and old, some in the poke bonnet and dull garb of the early Friends, others attired in the gayest of this season's millinery, crowded the quiet meeting house of the Hicksite Society of Friends, in Rutherfurd Place, yesterday to attend the "Fourth Day" meeting for public worship. It was a joint session of men and women, the women being in the majority.

The sale of the late Charles W. Frederickson's library was continued yesterday morning in the auction rooms of Bangs Co. The bidding was quite lively, and a number of important books were sold. The chief sales of the forenoon were:

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 26. -- Gen. Nelson A. Miles, United States Army, who left the United States with the intention of witnessing the Turko-Greek war, started yesterday for Athens with his suite. The General has abandoned his proposed visit to Thessaly.

EDINBURGH, May 26. -- The second and third round of the ladies' golf championship games were played this afternoon at Gullane. The weather was favorable. In the third round Mrs. Murray beat Miss Issette Pearson, the Secretary of the Golf Union.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, May 26. -- The fate of the whaling schooner Gen. Siglin, which sailed from San Francisco several weeks ago for Wood Island, Alaska, is no longer uncertain. The steamer City of Topeka, from Alaska, brings information that the derelict schooner was sighted by the revenue cutter Perry while on her way north to Bering Sea.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- When the Tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day, Mr. White of California, in behalf of the Democratic members of the Finance Committee, submitted a number of tables showing the articles on which the duties were from 50 to 75 per cent., from 75 to 100 per cent., and over 100 per cent.

Andrew D. White was the guest of honor last night at the Authors' Club in the Carnegie Building, where a reception was given in his honor prior to his departure next Saturday to assume his duties as Ambassador to Germany. A distinguished party of literary men were present to welcome their fellow-member and wish him godspeed.

" When the mariner has been tossed for many days in thick weather and on an unknown sea," said Mr. WEBSTER, as he rose to reply to HAYNE, "he naturally avails himself of the first pause in the storm and the earliest glance of the sun to take his latitude and ascertain how far the elements have driven him from his true course."

After many attempts, ranging over two years' time, the cyclists of Mexico have formed an organization on the lines of the League of American Wheelmen. It is called the Union de Ciclistas Mexicanos, and it bids fair to become a useful and thriving organization.

Blanche Card, the young woman who swallowed bichloride of mercury on Monday upon being told that the man she was to have married was already married and the father of three children, died yesterday at the home of her grandfather, Oscar M. Hurlburt, at 171 East One Hundred and Third Street.

The Executive Committee of the New York State Bankers' Association met yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce. There were present Judge Seymour Dexter, President of the Second National Bank, Elmira; John A. Kennedy, Niagara Bank, Buffalo, Secretary; Charles F. Van Inwegen, First National Bank, Port Jervis, Treasurer; James G. Cannon, Fourth National Bank, New York, ex-President; and these Presidents of the nine groups, respectively:

John Claflin, President of the H.B. Claflin Company, dry goods, 224 Church Street, will be arrested to-day, if he can be found, and required to answer concerning his alleged derelictions in the matter of jury duty.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Civil Engineer R.E. Peary has been detached from duty at the New York Navy Yard and five years' leave of absence granted him.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 26. -- The Connecticut Senate passed a resolution to-day which provides that every person shall be able to read in the English language any article of the Constitution or any section of the statutes of this State before being admitted as an elector. The House previously passed the resolution.

Jacob Worth appeared at his office in Brooklyn yesterday morning for the first time since his defiance of the orders of Senator Platt, and after a three weeks' absence up the State. It proved to be a busy day with Mr. Worth, for politicians of all degrees of prominence called to congratulate him upon the stand he dad taken in reference to Greater New York politics.

PITTSBURG, May 26. -- Umpire Hurst was in the hands of a mob after to-day's game and was saved serious injury by the Pittsburg players dragging him into the clubhouse. The general sentiment after yesterday's game was that Hurst's favors gave the Orioles the victory, and a repetition to-day capped the climax in the minds of the crowd, and after the game about 500 persons waited around the clubhouse for the umpire.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The trial of Henry O. Havemeyer, the President of the American Sugar Refining Company, indicted for refusing to answer questions propounded by the Senate Sugar Investigation in June, 1894, was resumed this morning. The attendance was almost as large as on yesterday.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., May 26. -- The latest sensation here is the mysterious disappearance of Mrs. Tandy, the fifteen-year-old five-day bride of Henry Tandy. The couple eloped last week, and came back here Saturday night, after much trouble in getting out of the Sheriff's way, he having a warrant for Tandy's arrest for enticing a girl under fifteen from home, which is a serious offense here.
Louis W. Dinkelspiel has sold to H.C. Ohlckers the triple flat, with stores, 2,115 Eighth Avenue, 25 by 88 by 100.11.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Consul General Lee cabled the State Department to-day from Havana that the amount of supplies he has now on hand there for the relief of American citizens in distress is abundant, and will last for some time. Presumably this statement applies generally to all the Consulates, for the Consul General has been in consultation with his subordinate Consuls on this very matter, by direction of the Secretary of State.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 26. -- The devotional exercises of the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day were led by Dr. Ray Ewing of Indiana. John Wanamaker occupied the Moderator's chair. A report was presented by Dr. John A. Liggett, Chairman on reception and licensure of candidates for the Gospel ministry.

Alfred G. Stokes, forty-two years old, of 26 West Nineteenth Street, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night on the charge of burglary. The complainant was Mrs. Louisa Selonova, his sister.

LONDON, May 26. -- The official celebration of the Queen's birthday was observed to-day in London with the usual closing of the courts and Government offices, the ringing of the church bells, a display of flags, artillery salutes, and the ceremony of trooping the colors, on the Horse Guards' Parade, in which the colonial troops now in London took part.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- There has been some gossip about a probable revolt in the Senate against the Tariff bill reported by the Finance Committee, but the vote of to-day on the first item disposed of in Committee of the Whole shakes the confidence of the dissatisfied in their expectation of amendment.
LONDON, May 27. -- The correspondent of The Standard at Constantinople says:

Commander Frederick de la Tour Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army, who was on trial for three days in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions, before Judge New-burger, on the charge of maintaining a disorderly house at the headquarters of the army in West Fourteenth Street, was found guilty yesterday afternoon.

CINCINNATI, May 26. -- The opening of the fifteenth Spring meeting of the Latonia Jockey Club to-day was one of the most brilliant in the history of that famous association. The weather was perfect, the track fast, the attendance reached the highest limit of the most successful seasons, and the racing was first-class. Seventeen books were in line, and the betting suggested flush times. Summaries:
LONDON, May 27. -- The Athens correspondent of The Times says:

Seldom has the City of Brooklyn been so deeply stirred as by the tragic death of Charles Kemble Hillyard and his son Willie. All day yesterday crowds of curious people thronged about 212 Greene Avenue, where the suicide and murder occurred, and a detachment of police was required to keep the street before the house open.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Justice Chester will hear in chambers to-morrow morning the application of the various railroad Presidents summoned in the anti-trust investigation to dismiss the proceedings on the grounds of unconstitutionality. It is understood here to-night that the attorney of the various railroads will ask for an adjournment, but the Attorney General says that any such request will be combated by him.

The best shooting of the season, that of the Seventh Regiment excepted, was done yesterday at Creedmoor by the First Naval Battalion of New York, under Commander J.W. Miller. In the volley firing the battalion as a whole surpassed even the Seventh, but the general figure of merit was materially reduced by the comparatively large number of absentees, especially in the Fourth Division.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The approach of the Victorian jubilee served to-day as the theme for an eloquent invocation by the blind Chaplain of the Senate, the Rev. Dr. Milburn. In his prayer at the opening of the Senate he said:
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senator Chandler has prepared the following amendment to the Tariff bill, which he proposes to add to the anti-trust amendment proposed by Senator Pettigrew yesterday:

Less than 200,000 shares were traded in yesterday, and much more than half of the total was contributed by half a dozen stocks in which is centred at the moment what speculative interest Wall Street is exhibiting. With hardly a noteworthy exception the whole list advanced. Practically all expressions of sentiment now heard in Wall Street are on the bull side.

Tatm -- la$ el-. A lagely attended wedding of yesterday was that of Miss lary Louise ajor, daughter of Air. and lrs. %Villiam Kevan Major, of 9 East Seventy-third Street, and Albert Holmes ratum, son of Charles .4_ Tutus, which was solemnized before 1,200 nvlted guests, at the Church of the HevenY' Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

Lizzie Lawrence, who has a suit pending in the City Court against Levi Samuels for damages for personal injuries, was directed by an order obtained at the instance of the defendant to appear for examination before trial and at the same time to submit to physical examination. On her appeal the order was modified so as to require the appointing of a female examining physician.

SHORT HILLS, N. J., May 27. -- No golf tournament this season has been opened with so fine an array of first-class players and under such excellent conditions for superior golf as was the case to-day, when the open tournament of the Baltusrol Golf Club began.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27. -- Yale's new cedar shell got here to-day. It was shipped from Cambridge by M.F. Davy, the Harvard boat builder, who constructed it, and was taken to Lake Saltonstall, where it was used by the 'varsity for light practice this morning. The shell is built on almost exactly the same lines as the Harvard boat of this year, and the new shell for the Wisconsiners, which came last Friday.

Unusual circumstances attended the erection of a trolley pole at the corner of Washington and First Streets, Hoboken, by the North Hudson County Railway Company. The determined opposition of Mrs. Mary Quirk, the owner of the property, was overcome after a series of hostilities that almost resulted in the interment of three or four persons.

The standard of Japan floated in front of the Waldorf Hotel yesterday to indicate the arrival and presence there of the Marquis Ito, former Premier of Japan, and his party, who are on their way to join Prince Arasugawa in Paris to go with him to London to represent this country at the Queen's Jubilee celebration.

MANKATO, Kan., May 27. -- Two thousand Populists held an indignation meeting here yesterday to discuss railroad freight rates, and the meeting afforded Gov. Leedy an opportunity to spring a surprise upon the people of Kansas.

The First Battalion of the Twelfth Regiment, consisting of Companies A, B, C, E and K, and the Second Battalion of the Thirteenth Regiment, consisting of Companies B, D, G, and I, with a few stragglers from other companies, occupied the range at Creedmoor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- There was an attempt to bring forward the Cuban question in the House to-day as soon as the Journal had been read. Mr. Lewis (Dem., Washington,) shouted "A question of privilege!" and sent to the Clerk's desk a resolution relating to recognition of the belligerency of the Cubans.

Warrants were sworn out in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Miles for the arrest of Henry S. Davis, former Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, and George Williamson, Clerk in Judge Nostrand's court in Coney Island, charged with bribery and compounding a felony.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., May 27. -- The statue of Agnes Gilkerson was destroyed to-day. The work was done by the men employed in the mills at Smithville under the direction of Capt. Elton J. Smith, son of Hezekiah B. Smith, who erected the statue in memory of the woman who was his companion for many years.

" Every suit of clothes, every yard of cloth, every pair of gloves, every piece of furniture, or any other article which is bought abroad because of the exemption from duty of tourists' effects, means the deprivation to Americans of a certain amount of work, wages, and profit."

William M. Ryan has sold for the heirs of the late Thomas Moore to the Grace Institute, for $32,000, the old three-story stone mansion, 153 West Sixtieth Street, 100 by 100.5. Additional facts in regard to the transaction will be found in another column.

Former Senator David B. Hill arrived at the Hotel Normandie yesterday morning. He had been at his old home in Elmira for a day or two and came to this city from there. He will probably return to Albany to-day. Mr. Hill said last night that he had not come here on political matters, and that he had no political conferences in view.

The Mayor, Controller, and Corporation Counsel yesterday held a consultation with Chief Engineer Greene of the Dock Department relative to the plans for the proposed dock improvements. The Dock Department now has at its disposition $5,000,000 a year for the next three years for water-front improvement. No action was taken at the conference.

NEWARK, May 27. -- James Coley of West Arlington started to walk across the Midland Railroad Bridge over the Passaic River yesterday afternoon. His big Newfoundland dog Rex persisted in following him. There is no foot path on the bridge, and the only means of crossing is by walking on the ties which are about two feet apart.

William Waldorf Astor's gift to the Children's Aid Society -- the new home of the Avenue B School at 537 East Sixteenth Street -- was formally opened yesterday afternoon with addresses by members of the Board of Trustees and exercises on the part of the little pupils. In memory of Mrs. Astor, who was much interested in the school, Mr. Astor donated to the society $50,000, to be expended in acquiring and equipping the home.

The Trustees of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge have decided to provide in some manner for cyclists when the trolley roads have tracks in the roadways. This information was imparted yesterday to a committee from the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island, which called upon the Trustees to request a hearing when plans are considered.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- D. McFarlan Moore gave a demonstration here to-night of results obtained by him in vacuum tube lighting since his exhibitions before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the convention held in New York City, in May of last year. A limited number of persons were invited to witness the demonstration, owing to the smallness of the room in which it was made.

The fourth day's installment of the library collection of the late Charles W. Frederickson was offered for sale yesterday by Bangs Co. It was an interesting array of rare literature, and the sales brought prices in excess of those of the preceding days. Various curiosities, portraits, and engravings were also disposed of. The bidding was no so lively on subjects of ordinary literary interest, but special features called forth keen and earnest competition.

Concluding the yearly meeting of Hicksite Friends, the exercises of yesterday faintly recalled the worship of the early Quakers who had formerly tenanted the plain brick meeting house on Rutherfurd Place. In a meeting house more pretentious, and yet sombre and modest, on East Twentieth Street, opposite Gramercy Park, the orthodox Friends began their yearly meeting yesterday with a gathering of ministers and elders for worship.

Features of yesterday's racing at Morris Park were to have been the run for the Eclipse Stake of $10,000 for two-year-olds and the Hunt Steeplechase, at two miles and a half, in which only horses owned by hunt club members and ridden by gentlemen riders were to have participated.

In the linen-goods trade there is a strong sentiment that the proposed increase in the tariff on manufactured linens is plainly prohibitory. The Tariff bill prepared by the Senate Finance Committee doubles the present duty in most instances, and in the case of table damask the duty is increased from 35 per cent. to 109 1-3 per cent. ad valorem.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 27. -- "Johnny" Kosk, a two-year-old child, is lying in a critical condition as the result of an attack by a vicious cow. The child was playing in the street near his home, when a vicious cow owned by a neighbor attempted to enter the gate which led to the stable. The gate was closed, and the angry cow turned and made for the child with a bellow of rage.

Alluding to your late editorial commending the Right Rev. Bishop of Niagara, Canada, for his liberal address at St. Luke's, Brooklyn, before the convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, will you permit a churchman to comment?

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 27. -- An unusual legal proceeding is about to be instituted in this city. When Gov. Stephens on Sunday last extended Executive clemency to Cashier Slattery of the defunct Kansas City Safe Deposit and Savings Bank, after he had served less than half of his four years' sentence for complicity in the forgeries which wrecked the bank, a storm of protests arose.

POCATELLO, Idaho, May 27. -- A head-end collision between a freight and a passenger train at American Falls, twenty-five miles west of here, at 4:30 o'clock this morning, caused the death so far as known of nine men and the injury of eight others. Two of the latter will die. This is the worst wreck that has occurred on the Short Line in many years.
LONDON, May 28. -- In an editorial on Prof. Darcy Thompson's report as to the Bering Sea seal fisheries The Times says this morning:

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Senate today agreed to the final conference report on the Sundry Civil bill. The main questions involved in the report related to the suspension until March 1 next of President Cleveland's proclamation embracing large areas as forest reserves; making immediately available $2,933,333 for contract work on the Mississippi River, and the proposed appropriation of $10,000 for the improvement of Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Senator Tillman promises to ask the Senate to-morrow to command Henry O. Havemeyer to appear before the bar of the Senate to purge himself of the charge of contempt lodged against him in spite of Judge Bradley's decision. This course of Senator Tillman will create some excitement, no matter what may be the outcome of it.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- In the trial of Henry O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, for contumacy of the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee, Judge Bradley sustained the motion of the defense for a dismissal of the case, and instructed the jury to bring in a verdict of not guilty, which it accordingly did.

The Attorney General's counsel at Albany yesterday sneered at the counsel of the coal companies for asking time to study the Lexow law under which he was proceeding. But he could not deny that at the time when the Attorney General began his operations the text of the law was as inaccessible, not only to the general public, but to the legal profession, as the Sibylline books.

Gov. BLACK'S heads of State departments are in what they would call, if they dared to speak frankly, a "hole," and the Governors civil service law has put them there. The purpose of that law was to enable a head of a department to conduct an examination for "fitness" so as to bring the man he wanted to appoint out at the head and give him the appointment.

The project of which the completion was marked by the picturesque and interesting exercises at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday is one of real value. The establishment of a Colonial museum in a Colonial mansion to be kept for the enjoyment and instruction of the people is a real public service.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 27. -- The interests of the American Sabbath Union occupied the time of the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day during the first half hour, usually devoted to devotional exercises. Dr. J.W. Hathaway, President of the Union, presided and made remarks, during which he said that the desecration of the Sabbath in America had no parallel in Europe.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- The National Republican League has served notice upon the Leagues in the Western silver States that delegates to the National Republican League Convention, in Detroit, in July, must be in accord with the party platform. The Executive Committee of the League met at the Auditorium to-day to make arrangements for the coming convention.
BLOOMSBURG, Penn., May 27. -- The trial of L.S. Wintersteen for conspiracy to murder Levi E. Waller by blowing up his residence with dynamite continued to-day.

There are in the United States at least two dozen Brooklyns. There are also an equal number of Brooklins, Brooklines, and other variants, besides towns galore which are proud to be known by some compound name containing Brooklyn, or something "equally as good." There must be over fifty towns any of which may contain any street in our sister city.

The first big gathering of the Salvation Army since the conviction of Commander Booth-Tucker of maintaining a disorderly house was held last night at the army headquarters in West Fourteenth Street. The keynotes were submission to the law and forgiveness and prayer for opponents, and all the proceedings were in harmony with them.
The parade of the Street Cleaning Department last year was a surprising success. This year it was even a greater success, but not surprising, because every one knew that it would be successful.

The second annual parade of the Street Cleaning Department of the City of New York took place yesterday afternoon. Twenty-five hundred men, attired in spotless white, each with a flower in his coat lapel, marched to the strains of martial music, and in alignment as perfect as that maintained by any regiment of soldiers.

The Coat Contractors Mutual Protective Association has decided to make a hard fight against the striking tailors, and yesterday Benjamin Witkowski, Secretary of the association, sent a circular letter to all contractors, in which he said that the present strike was called for the purpose of advancing the condition of certain leaders only, and to the detriment of all others in the trade.

FERNANDINA, Fla., May 27. -- Within the past few months $45,000 have been unearthed on Amelia Island, near this city, consisting of two finds of gold doubloons of the Spanish Government. They have created a sensation. In both instances the searches were conducted very secretly and the money was taken away before the truth was made known.

About 500 persons attended the first night bicycle racing in this vicinity at the Olympia track, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Lenox Avenue, last night. The cool air caused the light attendance, as the sport was all that could be desired.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President McKinley had under consideration a report submitted by Commissioner of Pensions Evans on the consolidation of pension agencies ordered by President Cleveland shortly before the change of Administration. The report recommends revocation of the order. Sept. 1 was fixed as the date for President Cleveland's order to take effect.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerec practically agreed to-day upon the final amendments to the Foraker pooling bill, which there will be an effort to have reported at the next meeting of the committee, a week from to-day. The votes taken on amendments to-day leave little doubt that the committee's recommendation will be favorable to the measure when reported.

Lord BYRON, in one of those letters which some connoisseurs of literature esteem as equal to his poems, said, "The Troad is a fine field for conjecture and snipe shooting." If the noble lord had lived to travel in America in the year of grace 1897, he would probably have written, "Chicago is a fine field for fiction and hunting."

We have heretofore pointed out upon how different a footing was the case of HAVEMEYER from that of CHAPMAN. In the latter there was no doubt that the question put related to a matter within the jurisdiction of the investigating committee and was "pertinent to the inquiry," as the statute under which CHAPMAN was convicted requires that it should be.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day at 2 o'clock, and the formal consideration of the measure by paragraphs proceeded.

BERLIN, May 28. -- In anticipation of the second reading of the bill amending the law of association, the lower house of the Prussian Diet was crowded to-day. After a brief discussion, the motion of Count Limberg-Stirum. Conservative, to insert a clause allowing the police to prohibit meetings which might be expected to endanger the security of the State or public order was rejected.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 28. -- The oldest person in Connecticut, Manuel Oliver Levy, died in Stonington, Conn., yesterday, aged one hundred and four years and seventeen days. The birthday records in Lisbon, Portugal, say that Levy was born there May 10, 1793. He has been in fairly good health up to a few weeks ago. He retained his senses and faculties to the last.

It looks now as if the success of the scheme of underground rapid transit, as far as the construction of the road is concerned, is assured. The Commissioners have completed plans, satisfactory to themselves and to the engineers, which have been approved by the Board of Aldermen, for the construction of the road at an approximate cost of $30,000,000, more than $20,000,000 less than the amount required for the plans presented last year.

LONDON, May 28. -- John Redmond, the Parnellite leader, was suspended in the House of Commons to-day, owing to his persisting in an irregular discussion of the financial relations between Great Britain and Ireland. John J. Clancey, Member for the North Division of Dublin County; William Redmond, Member for West Claire, and William Field, Member for the St. Patrick's Division of Dublin, for similar conduct, were removed from the House by the Sergeant at Arms.

Prompt action on the part of two drug clerks yesterday morning probably saved the lives of two children whose mother tried to poison them with paris green, and then sought to end her own life with a draught of the same poison.

After Requital had made such an utter and unexpected collapse in his race at Morris Park last Wednesday, the Thompson brothers, who own him, had him taken to Sheepshead Bay at once, and their trainer, James Rowe, was given instructions to "try him out and see what is the matter with him."

Amateur philatelists and stamp dealers who have in their collections United States newspaper and periodical stamps of the issues from 1865 to 1894 are anxiously inquiring of their attorneys whether the National Government has a better right to the stamps than they have.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Insiders in street car circles profess to have information that the enactment of the Allen bill will be immediately followed by an entirely new course by President Yerkes and his associates in the financial handling of the North and West Side companies.

David C. Robinson, indicted on the charge of having obtained $30,000 under false pretenses from the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, was released yesterday under $10,000 bail. Thomas Cleary, Superintendent of the Equitable Building, furnished the bail, giving as surety the property 117 Cedar Street, which is valued at $25,000, without incumbrances.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The Tariff bill was before the Senate again to-day.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28. -- Princeton students had their first opportunity to meet former President Cleveland and Mrs. Cleveland to-day. Since their arrival in Princeton three months ago, several receptions have been given in honor of the Clevelands, and they in turn have received the society set of the town and university at their Bayard Avenue home.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 28. -- Luther H. Beals, a large whip manufacturer of Westfield, this afternoon filed a voluntary petition in insolvency at the Court House in this city, application having previously been made for his adjudgment as a bankrupt by the First National Bank of East Hampton.

Senator Thomas C. Platt and Mrs. Platt arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel from Washington last night. They came to remain over Memorial Day, and Senator Platt says that politics has nothing to do with his visit. While the Senator is in town, however, there will doubtless be some informal conferences.
For years past the collection of personal taxes in Brooklyn has been a farce, and the law relating to it has been considered a dead letter.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 28. -- A clash occurred this afternoon between local militia and students of South Carolina College, on the latter's athletic grounds, and several persons were badly injured. Permission had been granted the militia to undergo their inspection upon the grounds, and the Governor's Guards and Richland Volunteers were drawn up for parade while a game of ball by the students was going on.

There were not many developments in the garment workers' strikes yesterday. Sixteen manufacturers and contractors were reported as having signed the agreement with the Brotherhood of Tailors, and the Boston Garment Workers' Union telegraphed an expression of sympathy and encouragement.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 28. -- At a lecture this week in the Broadway Congregational Church, Norwich, Mrs. Forbes, President of the State Women's Christian Temperance Union, raised her voice in wrath against the State Legislative Committee on Woman's Suffrage. She had recently been in Hartford, and knew whereof she spoke.

The last day allotted for rifle practice at Creedmoor came yesterday. The Second Brigade staff, headed by Gen. J. McLeer, and the Second Battalion of the Twelfth Regiment, under command of Major W. Content, took advantage of the fine weather and practiced with good results.

The vogue of the French bulldog, an exceedingly intelligent and picturesque member of the mastiff race, is not likely to be lessened by the sneers of narrow-minded Englishmen. The right little, tight little island has always been proud of its own bulldog, which, for ferocity and courage, has rarely been excelled, and which has served quite as well as the overrated lion as a symbol of national character.

CINCINNATI, May 28. -- Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage made an important speech here to-night at the Commercial Club's banquet. After a few felicitous words addressed to the club and its guests from Chicago and Boston, Mr. Gage said:

It was a day of subdued excitement yesterday at the gray old Friends' Meeting House, in Gramercy Park. Matters of vital moment were discussed and decided, for at the meeting -- the two hundred and second annual session of the New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends -- a wound of fifty-one years' standing was torn open afresh.

Capt. Hinde's volume tells an interesting story, and will, in the future, when Central Africa is occupied by a modern civilization, be a valuable contribution to the history of its savage period. There are no startling revelations in the book, because it tells of a territory whose nature had already been made known by its explorers.

It is altogether probable that the majority of the residents of this city will not agree with the excited comments of one minister on the verdict against the Salvation Army for making too much noise. He said: "All lovers of GOD and humanity are with you. Last night 7,000 people witnessed a brutal prizefight watched by the police; that was all right, judged by the devil.

PARIS, May 28. -- There were 400 delegates present to-day at the annual meeting of the National Bimetallic League. Deputy Fougeirol presided. M. Thery, Secretary of the League, read the report. It set forth that the leading event of the year was the election of President McKinley, which, the report added, gave great satisfaction to bimetallists.

It is not a bad thing to have in the Senate at least one social pariah who is tacitly excluded from the courtesy of the Senate. For it is the courtesy of the Senate which prevents any Senator from making a real investigation of charges affecting the integrity of Senators or from making any unpleasant remarks about their lapses from honor and honesty.

The four hundredth anniversary, this year, of Cabot, the American discoverer, gives interest to the origin of his name. Having "Cabot" for a middle name, the honorable Senator from Massachusetts, Henry Cabot Lodge, is naturally interested in Cabot, and particularly in John Cabot. It is to Harrisse that is due such present light as has been thrown on that bold adventurer who sailed from Bristol for an almost unknown continent some 400 years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The Senate Finance Committee is considering a proposition to amend the Tariff bill by substituting for the proposed tax on tea and increase of tax on beer a tax on bank checks, deeds, mortgages, and other conveyances which would compensate for the loss of revenue which the proposed taxes on tea and beer would produce.

Suppose it were possible to build a railroad from Central Nebraska, through Kansas, Oklahoma, the Indian Territory, and Texas, to the Gulf for $45,000,000, and that the builders were sure that when completed these various States would pay in $55,000,000 to the capital of the company and take over the road and run it.

Dr. Carl Beck, Professor of Surgery in the New York School of Clinical Medicine, last night gave an X-ray demonstration to about 100 physicians and surgeons at his residence, 37 East Thirty-first Street. He demonstrated that several theories relative to the effect of modern bullets on the human body are without foundation.
The principle of Home Rule is asserted in the Citizens' Union declaration, the first article of which is here quoted:

Ray Dawson is the champion cyclist of Columbia University. He won the coveted title at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon in the tournament promoted by the wheeling enthusiasts of the college. The honor went with the winning of the mile race, in which appeared such favorably known riders as W.H. Fearing, Jr., Irwin A. Powell, H.K. Bird, W.H. Hayes, and J.T. Williams.

Principal among the features of this, the last day's racing at Morris Park, will be thirty-first renewal of the Belmont Stakes. Of the thirty-four three-year-olds eligible to start, probably the eight named below will be the only starters. The race will bring about another meeting between August Belmont's Octagon and Marcus Daly's crack colt, the Futurity winner, Ogden, and it should settle definitely the question of superiority between the two.

EAGLE LAKE, Ind., May 28. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly to-day had a sharp debate on the report as to the use of wine at the Alumni banquet, at the sesquicentennial anniversary of Princeton University. The committee recommended that, as the institution was not under the control of the General Assembly, no action be taken on four overtures received from certain Presbyteries.

In the fierce competition for the world's trade it is now recognized and insisted upon that one indispensable condition to success is the cheapest possible material of manufacture. This is as true for nations as for individuals or corporations. What, then, must be thought of a Government which deliberately shapes its legislation to increase the cost of this material?

Frederick Southack Co. have sold for Flake Dowling to Henry Corn, for $400,000, the old Charles H. Harbeck mansion, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 258 and 260 Fifth Avenue, 49.4 by 100. The buyer will improve the property by the erection of an eight-story business building.

Notice was read from the rostrum of the Stock Exchange yesterday that the Board of Governors had appointed a committee of five to consider and receive suggestions in regard to the "ticker" service to be adopted after June 30, when the contract with the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company will end.

The competition for the autograph letters and manuscripts from the library of the late Charles W. Frederickson brought out some spirited bidding yesterday afternoon in the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 91 Fifth Avenue. The sale, which has been going on since Monday last, was finished. A feature of the proceedings was the presence of the private purchaser in greater force.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- In the Senate this morning, Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C.) rose to a question of privilege and presented a resolution for another sugar investigation. The resolution quotes the Senate resolution of May 17, 1894, authorizing the original inquiry, and then proceeds as follows:

This afternoon and to-morrow many cyclists will start on tours lasting over Memorial Day. The condition of the roads is important, and information on this point has been supplied by Secretary Bull of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, from reports received up to late yesterday afternoon. The territory embraced is within a radius of forty miles of this city.
The New York baseball team returned from its Western trip yesterday and played the St. Louis team at the Polo Grounds in the afternoon. About 2,000 persons were present.

The schedule for the Memorial Day parade was completed yesterday by Gen. James R. O'Beirne, the Grand Marshal. Contrary to the custom of recent years, the militia will not take part, but there will be about 3,500 men and boys in line. The regular army and navy will be represented, as will the Grand Army of the Republic and the American Guard, composed of schoolboys.

New York City Christian Endeavorers are to have the largest and most interesting rally at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. June 18, that has been held in this city since the Christian Endeavor Convention a few years ago. Dr. Francis E. Clark, the founder of this young people's organization and President of the United Society, is expected to arrive in the city on that day from Europe on the Britannic.

Persons who walked in Fifth Avenue near One Hundred and Thirtieth Street late yesterday afternoon stopped to look at a tiny boy who rode a nickel-plated tricycle. His neat-fitting bicycle suit, his brown cap and shoes but made him look smaller than he really was. He bent over the handlebars in true scorcher fashion, and seemed to think he was moving like the wind.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 28. -- The open golf tournament held on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club to-day was noteworthy owing to the defeat of the picked three of the contestants, Harry P. Toler, James A. Tyng, and Arthur H. Fenn, by three young players who won their honors by superb play.

" Oh, they have no House over there anyway; they have one man running it," said Senator TILLMAN on Thursday. Yes, but doesn't he run it well? How innocucus is the condition of desuetude to which he has reduced the cranks, March hares, incoherent Populists, moonstruck howlers, fanatical mischief-makers, and loquacious ignoramuses of the House!

President CLEVELAND'S attempt to preserve some of the forests of the Western country from the timber chopper who would strip the whole land without regard to consequences of any kind has been thwarted by the Congress, and President McKINLEY has been relieved from the unpleasant necessity of doing anything in the matter except to sign the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill.

Sunday school children of Brooklyn practically owned the streets of that quiet town yesterday afternoon. It was the day of their sixty-eighth annual parade, and to keep up with the custom handed down by other generations of Sunday school children, over 80,000 happy youngsters with their teachers turned out and marched through the various routes laid out for them.

George Eliot says that it is easy to begin things with a new person, "even to begin to be a better man." Very likely the same is true of a new country, which would in part account for the moral charm that surrounds the Colonial and Revolutionary men and women, to whom public honor was a matter of burning interest, and by whom the necessity of establishing a worthy precedent was keenly felt.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Senator Jones of Nevada, Chairman of the Committee on Contingent Expenses of the Senate, has not yet called a meeting of his committee for the purpose of considering the Tillman Sugar Trust resolution.
LONDON, May 28. -- The prospectus has been issued for the new Japanese loan of 43,000,000 yen (about $21,947,916) at five per cent., repayable in gold. The issue price is 101 1/2 per cent.

-- It is impossible to conjecture why a sion of X-ray photographs as evidence. Of Chicago court has rules against the admis-course the value of such pictures as testimony depends entirely on the good faith of the man who makes them, but that is true of any photograph. The camera has an undeserved reputation for veracity, and yet, when properly guarded, it will tell the truth, and prove it.

The preliminary events of the twenty-second annual field and track sports of the Intercollegiae Association of Amateur Athletes of America were held on Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. The semi-finals and finals will be decided this afternoon.

ALBANY, May 28. -- Announcement is made here that proceedings are likely to be undertaken shortly to recover for the State some 200,000 acres of valuable Adirondack lands, title to which has been lost through the cancellation by former State Controllers of tax sales, on which the State's title to the lands was based.

The blue and white burgee of the Larchmont Yacht Club was hoisted on the tall flagstaff in front of the clubhouse yesterday afternoon, and it will fly there each day until the end of the yachting season. It is a conspicuous mark to sailors going up and down the Sound, and a standing signal to all yachtsmen who are looking for races that they can be accommodated at Larchmont.

Some efforts seem to have been undertaken abroad to urge objections to the Union Pacific reorganization scheme. The London Economist recites some of the points made by anonymous objectors. They do not show frankness or familiarity with the Union Pacific situation.

Nine young men sat in trepidation in the lecture room of the Department of Physics, Hamilton Hall, Columbia University, yesterday awaiting the ordeal through which they had to pass to attain their degrees as Doctors of Philosophy.

The one hundred and sixteenth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York will be opened in the Masonic Hall, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, next Tuesday afternoon, more than 700 lodges, with a membership of nearly 100,000 Masons in good standing, will be represented by the Masters of the lodges or by their authorized proxies.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 29. -- The stockholders of the Lambeth Rope Company to-day voted to wind up the company's affairs at once, and to petition into insolvency. This action followed the consideration of the report made by the committee of stockholders appointed at the last session to examine into the affairs of the company.

In the second game "Dad" Clarke relieved Meekin in the box. He redeemed his reputation by holding the visitors down to seven scattering hits and striking out six men. The New York team piled up four runs in the second inning, and were never headed. The game was marked by heavy batting on the part of the home team.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The details of the Presidential trip to the Nashville Exposition have been practically completed, and they were announced to-day at the White House. A special train will be provided by the Chesapeake and Ohio, consisting of a private car for the President and Mrs. McKinley, one for the Cabinet members who attend and their families, a car for the newspaper men, and dining and smoking cars.

Her Majest being now ready to receive us, we were ushered into her presenece one at a time. My turn was the twelfth; hence one of my friends has dubbed me the Twelfth Knight. The equerry took me to the door of the apartment, and then left me. It was a lofty room, but not very large, being perhaps forty feet long and of a corresponding width.

In contemplating the alternative which will be forced upon the railway companies if the Supreme Court decision be maintained, it is proper to say that while pooling has been commended and resorted to abroad, was recommended by the Cullom committee, and has been indorsed by the most eminent railway experts of this and other countries, it remains forbidden here by law.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 29. -- Playing at the Morris County Golf Club to-day was in foursomes. Mrs. Dean and Mr. Beckwith tied with Miss Day and Mr. Shippen for first place, the score being 99. Summary:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 29. -- Notwithstanding that the end of the season is at hand on June 1, the beauty of the village is still attractive to the cottagers who remain. The wide lawn in front of Edgemere, the residence of Francis P. Freeman, which is a fine example of successful transplanting of the native laurel, is particularly beautiful.

SUMMER theatricals have always been risky commercial enterprises in New York, but they have frequently been rather edifying in an aesthetic way. Long before the era of roof gardens (which are, by the way, already going out of fashion) the Summer months at certain theatres used to be given over to melodrama, burlesque, and farce.
