First, as to oral and written, column and sentence spelling, I shall say only this, that the wise teacher will acquaint herself with as many methods and devices as possible, and change from one to the other, in order to relieve the tedium and to meet the needs of individual children. Before all, she will beware of running off at a tangent with any particular method, because none yet discovered has proved a panacea.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 29. -- There is a leper at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, this city. A woman was taken to the institution several weeks ago, suffering from what was supposed to be a skin eruption. After a careful diagnosis of her case by the physicians at the hospital it was discovered that the woman was a victim of leprosy.

The Canarsie Yacht Club formally opened the season yesterday afternoon. The club members and their friends, including many ladies, were out in force to witness the review of the fleet at Sands Point, Canarsie Landing. The yachts were mustered at 2:30 P.M. by Fleet Captain McEvoy and made a creditable showing.

BOONTON, N.J., May 29. -- The Boonton Athletic Club's pretty bicycle track, with its fringe of elm and chestnut trees, decked in brightest green, was the scene this afternoon of an interesting tourney of wheel races. All the best riders in this part of New Jersey, together with a sprinkling off well-known amateurs from the metropolitan district, formed an attractive card, and this, coupled with excellent management, made the sport doubly enjoyable.

ST. LOUIS, May 29. -- The Mississippi Valley Stakes, worth $1,500, was the feature of to-day's card at the fair grounds. Macy went to the post favorite and was played heavily. David was the second choice, opening at 5 to 1 and remaining at that figure until post time, when a heavy plunge was made on him. Linda was in an ugly mood and delayed the start twenty minutes.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Representative Richardson of Tennessee appeared before the Senate Committee on Civil Service today. He had been attracted by the statement made by Harold Benedict that during the latter part of Mr. Palmer's former administration of the Government Printing Office seventy-five persons had been appointed there at his instance, while he (Richardson) was Chairman of the House Committee on Printing.

What are the qualities which bring men to the front in public life? The question is suggested by the personality of two men who have been somewhat prominently in evidence during the week, but whose natural qualifications for conspicuous eminence may be held to be debatable. The one is A. Oakey Hall and the other Lemuel Ely Quigg.

The sports of the turf were growing in popularity in the United States. The contest lay principally between the Messengers and the Bashaws, though for a time the Stars in their courses had prevailed against both. Probably all were of original Arabian stock. The Stars were slight of limb, and had a tendency to contraction of the feet.
LONDON, May 29. -- The Duc d'Alencon, whose wife lost her life during the Charity Bazaar in Paris on May 4 last, will, it is said, take Holy Orders and retire to a monastery.

For a long time admirers of Coroner Hoeber have been casting about in their minds for some way to express their appreciation of the way he has administered his office for the last two years. One thing and then another was suggested and rejected, and finally a dinner was proposed. That was approved, and last night 123 of his friends entertained him in the gold ballroom of the Hotel Savoy.

OPERA is a subject about which the general public thinks it knows more than it really does. However, that is not the text to-day. But it is always admissible to speak of opera to a public which is serenely satisfied that it knows quite as much about the matter as you do yourself.
The statue which was unveiled yesterday in the little park before the Cooper Institute is a noble monument to a noble man.

The small urchins of New York, those with whom people wandering the streets come in contact, as a general rule have good manners. They may not be exactly polished, but they have the politeness that comes from the heart.

The Right Rev. Ellison Capers, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of South Carolina, who is fulfilling Bishop Potter's engagements for ordination and confirmation in this diocese, is the only Bishop in this country with a distinguished military career preceding his church work.

The condition of Max Schmittberger, who is lying at the Mount Sinai Hospital with a bullet in his brain, was the same yesterday as it has been since he was shot at St. Vincent's Church fair Wednesday night. There is a chance for his recovery, but it is a very slight one, and the physicians in charge have held out no hope.

Yachtsmen will have a busy day to-morrow, when all those clubs that have not opened for the season will formally hoist their burgees. Some of these clubs will simply have opening ceremonies, while others will celebrate the day with a regatta. At all the clubhouses in this vicinity there will be some entertainment for the members an their friends.

SO merrily hummed the Colonel on a recent fair Sunday morning as the members of the Cycle Touring Club met on the ferryboat which runs from the foot of East Ninety-ninth Street, New York, to College Point, on their way to Oyster Bay, Long Island.

NEWPORT, May 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harold Payne Whitney are here for the Summer. They will entertain a good deal during the season. Their guests will include Mr. and Mrs. William C. Whitney, Mr. and Mrs. Almeric Hugh Paget, and Payne Whitney. It at one time was believed that ex-Secretary Whitney would take a cottage here, but it is understood he has abandoned that idea.

Prince Luigi Amadeo of Savoy, Duca degn Abruzzi and nephew of King Humbert arrived in this city yesterday from Liverpool on board the Lucania. He left Rome about two weeks ago on a journey whose objective point is Alaska, where the Prince and his party will attempt the ascent of Mount St. Elias.

The sacred thread of the Brahmins is well known; it is a caste distinction assumed at an early age, and never parted with. It must be made by a Brahmin, and should consist of three strands, each of a different color, forty-eight yards in length, doubled and twisted together twice, the ends tied in knots. It must be worn next the skin, over the left shoulder, hanging down to the thigh on the right side.

Upon the whole it may almost be said that the sculptors appear in the library to greater advantage than the painters. Not, of course, that the art of sculpture is so successfully cultivated in America as the art of painting, but that the library presents a more adequate exposition of what we can do in sculpture than in painting.

With simple but impressive ceremonies, the monument to Peter Cooper, erected by popular subscription on the little triangular park south of the Cooper Union, was unveiled yesterday afternoon. It stands now in the little bare plot, and consists of a pedestal of granite, at the north end of which rises a solid block of pink granite.

At the rsik of her life, Mrs. Elizabeth Schneider of 233 West Twenty-sixth Street saved her three children from being burned to death in a fire which broke out in her bedroom early yesterday morning. Mrs. Schneider, whose husband works at night, slept with her three children in two small bedrooms in their apartments, on the fifth floor of the building.

ANNAPOLIS, May 29. -- The dress parades of the cadets this week at the Naval Academy, which drew large crowds of spectators to the parade grounds, were advance guards of the brilliant array of events that troop upon each other in graduating week.

A friend of mine tells me he was present in a neighboring city where an architect presented a plan for a new schoolhouse, notes a writer in The Sanitarian. He had a fine elevation, and it was a very pretty picture on paper. He was asked where the fresh air was admitted to the rooms? He replied, "Through this flue," pointing to it on the plan.

The "Coronation Roll" is wonderfully and curiously complete. It sets down every detail with minuteness and elaboration. The "Coronation Roll" of Queen Victoria is like the rolls of all her predecessors since the time of Richard II. -- a huge, bulky roll of parchment. It is what the lawyers would call a deed poll as distinguished from an indenture.

LOWELL, Mass., May 20. -- The bodies of Maria and Frances Butler, unmarried and middle-aged, who had lived in this city for about sixteen years, were found on the kitchen floor of their home this morning. They apparently had been dead for several hours from asphyxiation by gas, and it is believed they committed suicide because of heavy financial losses due to the failure of several banks in Nashua.

Night Ticket Agent, Portus F. Peterson, who is stationed at the up-town station of the elevated railroad at Cortlandt Street, was bunkoed by a bogus telegram last night out of 6,500 tickets and $22 in cash by a clever scheme, which, however, was only partially carried out, as $525 in cash, which had been in the safe, was left in the ticket seller's desk in a hand-bag.

The stock market for the week past has been narrow, almost inanimate. Yet as a rule yesterday's quotations, compared with those of a week ago, show substantial advances. These better prices extend throughout nearly the whole list. In two or three quarters there are exceptions to the rule of strength, but in each case special influences have been at work.

The most important of June's astronomical happenings is the arrival of the sun at the extreme northerly point in its course. Ever since it left the southern solstice, in December, it has been journeying in this direction. This movement is, of course, apparent only, being caused by the actual movement of the earth in the opposite direction.

Those who watch the records of the time in the press may have noted that they show a large and interesting development of athletic sports in schools. These preparatory institutions have naturally followed the lead of the colleges, and now most of them have the whole apparatus -- football and track teams, baseball nines and tennis players, tracks, gymnasiums, and directors of physical culture.

ALBANY, May 29. -- State Fish Culturist A.N. Cheney has just returned from an inspection of the shad hatchery at Catskill. The work, he says, is progressing nicely. "The shad seen, however," he says, "are light this year, and the fishermen attribute this condition to the small plant, comparatively, of fry three years ago.

LONDON, May 29. -- Sometimes the expectd happens. One has always been saying that sooner or later the German Emperor, with his insatiable passion for being thought the great man of his time, and his congenital incapacity to keep his finger out of any pie in sight, would come to grief. It is more than suspected, these past two days, that this is what has occurred.

NEW HAVEN, May 29. -- Yale won the two-mile boat race from the University of Wisconsin on Lake Saltonstall this afternoon by about three lengths, in the time of 10 minutes 54 seconds, with the Wisconsin eight finishing ten seconds behind.

BERLIN, May 29. -- There was another sensational trial this week, the prisoners being charged with treasonable acts in favor of Russia and committed at Thorn, the most important Prussian fortress on the Russian border. Fahrin, a "Fortification Master," and a Court official named Albrecht were the principal defendants. Several Russian go-betweens fled the country in time to escape arrest.

Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast has announced officially the officers to be detailed at the Camp of Instruction this season, as well as the several organizations who are to perform a tour of service. The camp is not to be under the direction of the several brigade commanders, as the scheme fell through, it is said, because only one Brigadier General of the four cared to accept the offer.

Our grandmothers, when they braved a rainy day wore waterproofs of cloth, in which the only waterproof virtue lay in the peculiar weave, in a measure similar to the thatching on a primitive roof. It was simply easier for the water to run from one thread to another than to work between, but in an exposure of even half an hour, this "waterproof" would be as wet inside as out.

My friend had vanished into the dressing room, and at first glance I entirely failed to recognize him in the padded monster that now staggered clumsily into the room, supported on each side by his second and sword-bearer. The thick armour of leather and wadding with which he was bolstered entirely protected his body and limbs.

Carl H. Schultz died yesterday morning in his home at Murray Hill, N.J., after a short illness. Up to Tuesday last he was apparently in robust health for a man of his years, and, although close to the allotted period of threescore years and ten, he attended to every detail of his immense mineral water business at First Avenue and Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets.

LONDON, May 29. -- The news that Mr. Whitelaw Reid is coming here as Special Envoy of the United States upon the occasion of the Queen's Jubilee is received with satisfaction on all sides. A larger delegation, as was intended, would have been embarrassing, as her Majesty had intimated that she could personally receive only one Special Envoy from each country.

LONDON, May 29. -- The manuscript of a new comedy by W.S. Gilbert is in the hands of Miss Fortescue, who is waiting for a favorable opportunity to produce it. If she is unable to find a suitable London theatre she will play it during her next provincial tour.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Pennsylvania University defeated Cornell to-day in an interesting and well-played game. The feature of the game was the extraordinarily good fielding of the two pitchers from their positions in the box. Dickson having eight assists and Bole seven. Affeld, Cornell's short stop, was severely injured by a swiftly-thrown ball striking him in the forearm while running to second base. Score:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 29. -- The Harold stakes for two-year-old colts was run at Latonia to-day over a fast track. Pink Coat, a colt by Leonatus-Alice Brand, won the race after long delay at the post. Pink Coat got off in front and was never overtaken, winning in impressive fashion from MacIver. Summaries:

The paid Fire Department of Long Island City has been disbanded by the Fire Commissioners. The Buffalo system will take its place, and will go into effect immediately. The Fire Department of Long Island City comprised 36 men, 6 engines and tenders, 2 trucks, and 26 horses. Now the department will be made up of 12 paid firemen as a nucleus for expected volunteers, 3 engines and tenders, and 1 truck.

The rural dooryard of Greater New York is now in full bloom. Apple blossoms, budding vines, and the many-hued flower beds give a rich color to the landscape, while the fragrant country odors exercise their tempting spell upon the city folk. Many New Yorkers have already gone to their Summer homes, and others are preparing for the exodus.

Ornament, who had no difficulty in winning the Latonia Derby a few days ago, arrived at Sheepshead Bay yesterday with the other horses in the stable of C.T. Patterson. He is in excellent condition, and was brought here to fill his stake engagements, chief of which is that for the rich Realization, which is to be run at Sheepshead Bay on July 10.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day, on motion of Mr. Aldrich, who called up the paragraphs relating to china, crockery, porcelain, , which had been passed over. Mr. Aldrich, in behalf of the committee, withdrew the Senate amendments to Paragraphs 90 and 91, and stated that the House rates would be allowed to stand.

Nearly everybody in Brooklyn who is interested in golf went out to the Dyker Meadow Golf Club's links, near Fort Hamilton, yesterday. It was a big day, and women practically held possession of the clubhouse in the afternoon, the occasion being the annual ladies day and club reception to members and guests.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 29. -- Further particulars from the scene of the Indian trouble near Prince Albert show that affairs are growing more serious. It appears that Napoleon Venne, a rancher, and his brother, Bruno, a scout and interpreter, were looking for some lost cattle near a bluff in the Manichmass Hills.

HAVANA, May 29. -- The commission conducting the inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the death of Dr. Ruiz closed its labors at an early hour to-day. A mysterious messenger from Washington came from Tampa on the steamer Mascotte this morning, but did not land.

MONTPELIER, Vt., May 29. -- Miss Mildred Brewster, eighteen years old, the daughter of a wealthy farmer of Huntington, to-day shot Miss Annie Wheeler, of whom she is alleged to have been jealous, inflicting wounds, from which she died.
Thus spoke the Secretary of the Treasury at Cincinnati on Friday evening to the business men of that city. They are welcome words to the business men of the whole country.

GOLF has opened this season with unusual energy and activity. Its popularity is now unquestioned, and one of the pleasantest features is that this popularity is not confined to any one class, but extends to all, the young as well as the old, the rich, and those not overburdened with the wealth of the world, but who find in this fascinating Scotch game opportunities which may be easily acquired for health, exercise, and recreation.

George F. Kunz, the mineralogist and diamond expert, recently gave a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES an account of the Imperial diamond, which, it is reported, has lately been stolen from the Nizam of Hyderabad, India, who intended to present it to Queen Victoria.

WEST POINT, May 29. -- The dedication of the Battle Monument in memory of the officers and men of the regular army of the United States who fell in battle during the civil war, and which was erected by their surviving comrades, will take place here on Monday morning next at 11:30 o'clock. The following is the order of exercises:

Unless the heirs-at-law of ALFRED NOBEL, the Scandinavian inventor, succeed in their effort to break his will, a number of eminent men of Norway and Sweden have a task before them which will inevitably bring to them more trouble than glory. NOBEL'S will sets aside a large sum of money, of which the annual income will probably exceed $240,000, as a fund for the advancement of science, literature, and humane ideas.

The past week has been one of great activity among Harlem River oarsmen, who are training for the Memorial Day regatta, and every spare moment has been devoted to training. A few of the most enthusiastic have made a practice of taking a spin every morning before going to business, besides the regular evening practice spin.

HANOVER, N.H., May 29. -- J.F. Moody, the best two-mile runner in Dartmouth College, lies in the Hitchcock Hospital in a critical condition, with one side paralyzed and a blood vessel in the brain broken.

Mrs. Nellie Davis and Clarence Davis, her husband, are under arrest in Buffalo, N.Y., on the charge of having swindled several persons in Jersey City. Sergt. Archibald and Detective Clarke went to Buffalo yesterday to bring the couple back, and it is expected that they will arrive in Jersey City next Wednesday.

PARIS, May 21. -- In spite of his infirmities, M. Alphonse Daudet is indefatigable. The cruel tortures he suffers have no effect upon his mind. His genius triumphs over the excruciating nervous rheumatism which has crippled his lower limbs, and even the opiates to which he is obliged to have continual recourse leave his brain as clear and effulgent as ever.

Playthings are improvised by the Indian youngster with no small play of invention. Fine war bonnets are made from corn husks, at the expense of much time and labor, and everything that children see is modeled in clay: dishes, pipes, ponies, whole villages, show their imitative faculty, while coffins with a bit of glass set in the lid, covering a pinched-up baby, indicate their keen observation of new customs.

DENVER, May 29. -- James A. Roberts, Controller of the State of New York, and Henry Koons, a capitalist of Buffalo, stockholders in the Colorado Land and Water Company, are perfecting arrangements for an irrigation project which will be worth many millions of dollars to the State of Colorado.

LONDON, May 17. -- "What is that object on the flagstaff on top of the church?" I asked a resident of Kew the other day, looking across the street at the old Church of St. Ann, otherwise the Kew Parish Church.

-- It is "O Those Golden Slippers!" and silver slippers as well, now, for any one who cares to invest a not very large sum of money. The slippers are not entirely of gold or silver, but have little adjustable tips, about as large as the tip of any shoe. They are of filigree work, and are bought separately and can be adjusted to any slipper.

The New York baseball team played two games yesterday with the St. Louis team, and succeeded in adding two more defeats to the Western club's long string. But the local men had to play a good game to do it, and both games were better played and far more interesting than the contest of Friday.

Yet the word "gleeman" seems to change that conclusion somewhat, for this name, given to their bards, signifies "joy-man," or one who sung of joys. Doubtless the gleeman's "musical wood" rang through the scale of both joy and sorrow.

VIENNA, May 18. -- The great event of the month was the Emperor's visit to St. Petersburg, originally intended and generally taken as a visit of courtesy. The Emperor of Austria was the first potentate whom the Czar visited last Autumn, when, with his young consort, he made the round of the courts of Europe. Naturally the visit had to be returned.

BOSTON, May 29. -- Although the seventeen-footers, the fourth-class Yacht Racing Association boats, had a race in Dorchester Bay last Saturday afternoon, the racing season really opens Monday with the open race of the South Boston Yacht Club off City Point, when all the association classes will be represented.

LONDON, May 29. -- The Associated Press has been requested to give publicity to the fact that the dedication of the John Robinson Memorial Church, at Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, will take place on June 9. This event is of special interest to Americans of old New England stock for the reason that it was at Gainsborough that the Puritan movement took shape by the formation, in 1602, of the first Separatist Community.

ANNAPOLIS, May 29. -- Every cadet in the Naval Academy feels like an Admiral tonight because the cadet crew to-day defeated the Pennsylvania University crew in a two-mile race, crossing the line seven lengths ahead of the Quakers in 13 minutes and 47 seconds. The visitors came in 28 seconds later, in 14 minutes and 15 seconds.

LONDON, May 29. -- Prince Luigi has a cutter yacht on the stocks of Messrs. Henderson, at Meadowside. The dimensions of the new boat, which will probably be launched next week, are: Length, 75 feet; beam, 18 feet, and draught, 14 feet. Her mainmast is an Oregon pine of 80 feet, and, with the topmast, the truck will be about 100 feet from the deck.
What is known as the "Waitress Course," at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, is one of the most interesting courses given in the domestic science department of the institute.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 29. -- The annual auction of the seniors was held at Vassar College to-day. Two class rooms on the second corridor were devoted to it, and a great variety of articles were offered to the highest bidder, ranging from the autographs of famous persons down through the whole list of room furnishings and decorations.

LONDON, May 29. -- An international motor-vehicle race from London to Birmingham and back has been arranged for next Tuesday by the proprietors of The Engineer, who have offered prizes amounting to 1,100 guineas. It is expected that about fifty motor carriages will take part in the contest, and the conditions require that they must complete the race, which begins and ends at the Crystal Palace, within forty hours, the distance being about 115 miles.
The closing exercises of the thirty-eighth annual commencement of Cooper Union last night were made memorable by the report of the Trustees submitted by Abram S. Hewitt, Secretary.

THERE are half a dozen uncommonly taking songs in "The Circus Girl" at Daly's, and one of them is "The Wet, Wet Day," sung by Cyril Scott and eight comely young women with much graceful illustrative "business.'' This song grows on one who drops in occasionally to see and hear the performance or part of it, as indeed "The Circus Girl," taken as a whole, improves on acquaintance.

EL PASO, Texas, May 20. -- Nine of ten people who come back from tour through "old Mexico," as our sister republic is called in the West, to distinguish it from the Territory of New Mexico in our own country, are full of wonder at the wonderful dexterity and strength of the burden bearers of the old land.

The Kings County Electric Light and Power Company is preparing to compete with the Edison Electric Light Company by erecting an underground system of subways, thirty-seven miles in length. The statement is made on the authority of Charles Cooper, who says that he controls the Tesla patents for Brooklyn, and that he will be able to furnish light and heat at a very low rate.

Louis F. Haffen, Commissioner of Street Improvements in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, which, together with the recently annexed portion of Westchester County, comprises the borough of the Bronx, predicts that in a very few years that territory will not only be the garden spot of the metropolis, but will be a vigorous rival, in commercial supremacy, of that part of the city within the confines of Manhattan Island.

The facts in connection with the gift of the bronze figure of Bacchante to the Boston Public Library and the withdrawal of it on Friday, as learned yesterday at the offices of McKim, Mead White, are as follows:

BERLIN, May 29. -- When the trial of Major von Tausch, the former Chief of the Secret Political Police, charged with perjury, treason, and forgery, was resumed to-day the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, was examined by the prosecution. He explained the relations which formerly existed between the Foreign Office and the Political Police, but which were broken off.

In the long arctic nights there is considerable difficulty in keeping awake; while, contrariwise, the perpetual day of Summer indisposes to sleep. At one time I worked thirty-six hours without realizing that the time had passed, until I discovered the fact by my journal. I had no sense of sleepiness during this time. Last Summer the sun set about 11 o'clock, and nobody seemed to be sleepy until it commenced to get dark.

NEW HAVEN, May 28. -- At a regular meeting of the corporation of Yale University, held Tuesday, the resignation of Dr. C.A. Lindsley, as Professor in the Medical School, dated June, 1896, was accepted. Mr. Lindsley having remained in office for the current year by request of his colleagues, he was now, in view of his long and faithful service, appointed professor emeritus in the school.

The situation in Cuba to-day is perfectly clear and simple. In the western provinces we find between 300,000 and 400,000 people penned up in starvation stations, and a prey to all kinds of epidemic disease. They are without means and without food, and with only the shelter that the dried palm leaves of their hastily erected bohios afford, and in the rainy season that is now upon them that is no shelter at all.

THE public-spirited citizen who named J.S.T. Stranahan "Brooklyn's Grand Old Man" made no error of judgment. He but expressed the sentiment of over a million people. But it is by the title "Brooklyn's first citizen" that Mr. Stranahan is better known.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 29. -- Salem Rhoades, a peddler living in the town of Plattekill, in the lower part of Ulster County, has a phenomenal fear of snakes. The very mention of a snake makes him shudder.

It was reported in Long Island City last evening that there would be a strike inaugurated to-day on the five lines of the New York and Queens County Electric Railroad. The terminal of the road is in Long Island City. One line runs to Flushing, another to Maspeth, one through Ravenswood, another to Calvary Cemetery, and the fifth to Newtown and Middle Village.

The final events in the intercollegiate athletic games were decided at Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon before a large and enthusiastic crowd of spectators. The University of Pennsylvania won over the rest of the colleges represented, with thirty-four points to her credit. Yale secured second place with a record of twenty-four and one-twelfth points.

UNTIL within a few years Mr. Gilder was widely known in the United States and abroad only as the editor of The Century Magazine. He was also but less widely known as a writer of verse with a distinct charm and of a feeling at once strong, delicate, and individual.

That Russia will, under any circumstances likely to arise attempt forcibly to capture the Turkish capital is not probable. But that all Russians look for the future possession of Constantinople is certain, and they will never, as a Nation, allow England without protest to retain permanent possession of Egypt, unless they are permitted to annex the greater part of Asia Minor and the shores of the Bosphorus.

ORANGE, N.J., May 29. -- There was some interesting golf at the Essex County Country Club links in Hutton Park, West Orange, this afternoon, when the record for the May Trophy Cup was lowered twice and a new record established for the course. W.J. Kingsland's record of 87 strokes for the eighteen holes, made two weeks ago, was brought down by Charles F. Watson, he doing the round in 85.

Heavy was the dew on the sod of Gramercy Park, and the neighborhood had scarcely awoke for the day when the Friends gathered yesterday morning in the meeting house on East Twentieth Street, opposite the park, for devotional exercises before proceeding to the business of the third day of the yearly meeting of the Orthodox Friends.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Certain inquiries that have been propounded by the Turkish Government as to the record of Dr. Angell, who has been appointed successor to Mr. Terrell as Minister to Turkey, have led to the erroneous conclusion that formal objection has been made to the Minister, or, in other words, that our Government has been informed that Dr. Angell is persona non grata.

The formal opening of the North Shore Tennis Club took place yesterday, on the club grounds, on Davis Avenue, at Livingston, S.I. The feature of the day was a progressive tournament, in which sixteen gentlemen and sixteen ladies line up at the nets when the play was called, at 3:30 o'clock. Miss Marie Kobe won the first prize for ladies W. Pembleton Johnson the first prize for the gentlemen.

GLASGOW, May 19. -- The Duke d'Abruzzi's new cutter Bona has been hurried forward by Messrs. Henderson at their Meadowside Yard, Glasgow, so rapidly that it is expected she will be launched quite in time to take part in the Clyde Jubilee regatta, in June. Capt. Sycamore and his Brightlingsea crew of twenty are getting the standing rigging set up and the running gear in order.

JAMAICA, L. I., May 29. -- Justice Wood last night held H. Livingston, George Gass, Henry Stevens, George Brown, William Harris, George Smith, and Thomas Harper under $2,000 each to appear for trial on Thursday. They were arrested yesterday in a raid on Paul MacCarthy's American House. at Palmetto Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, Ridgewood.
LONG BRANCH, May 27. -- Mrs. Charles F. Hoffman, widow of the Rev. Dr. Hoffman of New York, with her family, arrived at her mansion, Castle-Wall-on-the-Hill, Thursday.

SAN BERNARDINO, Cal., May 22. -- "Yes, there's gold all over Southern California, plenty of it, but only a greaser can make his salt mining it." That is the terse way a grizzled old miner put the case in the course of a half hour's talk I had with him yesterday. He had just come down from the Mojave "Rand," and things did not particularly look roseate from his viewpoint.

Park Row newsboys have a new plan to sell papers, and the confidential ones claim it is better than the "last paper" scheme and "sleeping game." It is worked by a large boy and a small one, and can be best illustrated by an instance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29. -- Harvard is jubilant to-night over the victory which her ball nine achieved over the Princeton Tigers this afternoon in a hard-fought and interesting game. Paine pitched strongly and the visitors could do nothing with him outside of the sixth and seventh innings, when they got five of their nine hits. The Harvard nine easily outplayed Princeton in the field, and made the best of every opportunity for run-getting.

ALBANY, May 29. -- For several years back fishermen have opened the legal season on May 30 -- or Memorial Day. Some of them followed with great interest the fate of an amendment to the game code which was finally signed by the Governor this year as Chapter 628. This law makes the bass season open on June 15, while it closes on the same date as before, Dec. 31.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29. -- Pittsburg took two straight from the Brooklyns to-day. The morning game was won by good hitting in the sixth. Killen pitched a good game in spite of the many errors behind him. The afternoon game was a slugging contest, and some nice plays were made on both sides. The feature was a triple play by Griffin and Smith.

DECORATION DAY marks the opening of the yachting season, and to-morrow will be a busy day at the yacht clubhouses. At every house in this vicinity there will be some sort of entertainment for the benefit of the members.

MONTREAL, May 27. -- Five boats of the one-raters building in this city, Toronto, and Kingston, from which a Canadian defender of the Seawanhaka Cup is to be picked, have been launched during the past ten days, and a preliminary series of trial races has already begun. As fast as the boats are completed they are sent to Lake St. Louis, near Montreal, where the international races will be held in August.

The Real Estate Exchange itself furnished the most interesting topic of discussion during the last week. It is felt by many that the institution will soon become a thing of the past, to be replaced by another one formed on different lines. The members of the Real Estate Board of Brokers very generally feel that their body will take its place with good chances for ultimate success and usefulness.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senator Jones of Arkansas comes pretty near to agreeing with some of his Gold Democratic friends who last November helped to elect McKinley. He does not rejoice that Bryan was defeated, nor does he believe that Bryan's election would have justified many of the alarming notions that took possession of the voters and made Bryan's election impossible.

It was delivered not far from the site of the present Christ Church, Savannah, of which Wesley subsequently, was the third rector, and was addressed to a mixed assemblage. His congregation hardly exceeded 400 persons, including children and adults, reinforced, however, by 100 or more of the neighboring Indians. Wesley discussed in a most eloquent manner the principles of Christian charity as argued by St. Paul in the thirteenth chapter of First Corinthians.

SHARPSBURG, Md., May 29. -- With appropriate ceremonies, and in the presence of a distinguished assemblage of war veterans and ladies, the Hawkins Zouave Association, composed of the survivors of the Ninth New York Volunteers, dedicated this morning, on Antietam battlefield, a monument to the men of their regiment who fell there in action.

Harlem River oarsmen spent a busy day yesterday making final preparations for today's big regatta. With the exception of the college crews, about every crew entered was on the water once, and sometimes twice, during the day, putting the finishing touches to their training and timing themselves over the regular mile course, between Madison Avenue and Central Bridges, where to-day's races will be rowed.

It was given out on Saturday that Mr. Platt, who had returned to this city from Washington with the avowed purpose of bringing about harmony in the local Republican ranks, even if he had to use a scalping knife to do it, would go back to his Senatorial duties yesterday. He did not go, and it is doubtful if he will go before Tuesday afternoon or evening.

WILMINGTON, N.C., May 30. -- The Messenger to-day prints a detailed account of the loading of the tug Alexander Jones and her departure, with the schooner John D. Long, on a Cuban filibustering expedition. The facts were obtained from a member of the crew of the Alexander Jones, which returned to port several days ago.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., May 30. -- John Lennaker of Fiatlands was drowned Jamaica Bay, off Rockaway Park, this afternoon through the upsetting of a catboat in which he and four other men from Brooklyn had gone fishing. Through the efforts of the owner of the boat the other three men were saved. Lennaker was caught beneath the sail and could not be rescued.

That the sensational press has added new terrors to suicide is shown in the letter explaining his act left by VON ENTRESS, the last words of which deserve to be preserved forever among notable "last words." "Let me down softly," he wrote, and died. He was hopelessly sick and poor, and believed he was right in taking his own life.

The Central Labor Union yesterday entered a protest against the special jury law that has just come under its notice by the appointment of H.B. Claflin on the special jury, and it charged the newspapers with conspiracy for having withheld the knowledge of the existence of the law from the public. It will call a mass meeting to demand the repeal of the law.

PISA, Italy, May 30. -- The official report of the disaster at the cathedral yesterday, upon the occasion of the unveiling of an image of the Virgin, when a candle fell, setting fire to the building and causing a panic, shows that nine were killed and twenty-one others seriously injured. Most of the victims are women and all of them resident of Pisa.

A reasonable time will elapse, we suppose, before the President names, another Minister to Turkey in place of Dr. ANGELL. The right of the Turkish Government to declare him unacceptable cannot be questioned, but when a Minister, appointed and confirmed, is found to be person non grata by the sovereign to whom he is accredited it is not customary to be in a hurry about the choice of another Minister to send in his place.

Mr. EUGENE G. BLACKFORD is a coolheaded, sound business man of wide experience. When he declares that the tunnel under the East River is bound to be a success his statement may be relied on with very great confidence.

Memorial services were held in Brooklyn yesterday by a large number of Grand Army of the Republic posts. The weather was all that could be desired, and at an early hour the veterans and thousands of citizens gathered at the graves in the various cemeteries and covered them with flowers.

DUCK LAKE, N.W.T., May 30. -- The transport party which left for the scene of the Indian trouble at 6:15 this morning reports that Capt. Gagnon, with a seven-pounder field gun, arrived at the bluff where the Indians are intrenched, before dark last night, and fired seven shells into the bluff. At dusk, when everything had quieted down, Almighty Voice yelled to the police that they were doing well, but would have to do better.

Not later than 4:30 P.M. to-day the Brooklyn Handicap problem, which for the past month or more has monopolized the thought of the racegoing members of New York and its vicinity, shall have been solved. If weather conditions do not ordain otherwise, there will be a crowd at the Gravesend track such as it would be hard to find at any other place in the world.

Three Raines law clubs were entered by the police yesterday, and their proprietors, or supposed proprietors, arrested. The men were subsequently arraigned before City Magistrates and gave bail for further examination. Then they went back to their clubs and continued business as before. The same condition of affairs will doubtless follow every such arrest.

Mr. HENRY D. PURROY has never been able to inspire any part of his fellow-citizens with the belief that his political action was governed by considerations of the general welfare. He is in fact one of our most private-spirited citizens, and whatever he may ostensibly be for, we may always be sure that he is really for PURROY.

BUTLER, N.J., May 30. -- This small village, which is eleven miles from the nearest railroad station, in the heart of the forest land of this State, and can only be reached by a stage route from Paterson, was the scene of the gathering of several thousand Catholics from various parts of the United States to-day.

The most serious danger that besets the Citizens' Union is the enticement to abandon its fundamental principle and make up its ticket by a "deal." Its declarations pledge it to keep tree of political and party entanglements. If it yields that principle, it strikes its colors and becomes indistinguishable from the half dozen citizens' movements that have from year to year been called into brief existence to beat Tammany.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30. -- The riotous convicts in the San Quentin penitentiary caused no serious trouble to-day, but they are still defiant and vaguely threaten that they will yet compel the authorities to yield to their demands.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The policy of the Post Office Department as to the appointment of minors in the Post Offices has been definitely fixed. Minors will be debarred from Chief Clerkships and Deputy Postmasterships, except in a few of the third-class offices where circumstances urge their peculiar fitness.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., May 30. -- A negro boy in this county, only five years old, is credited with three murders and great cruelty and torture. His parents live at Lacrosse, and have kept his deeds quiet until now. They say he is conjured and cannot help it.
VIENNA, May 30. -- The Austrian Derby was run to-day and won by Baron Oppenheim's Saphir.

A memorial asking the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund to take some action tending to induce or force the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to provide better transit facilities for the west side was sent to the commission on Saturday. It is as follows: To the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund of the City of New York:

That must have been an insensible spectator at the last day of the May meeting at Morris Park on Saturday who did not enjoy the spectacle. It was a perfect day, as Morris Park is a perfect place for the sport. Not since Jerome Park was in its glory in the days of its founders has there been a prettier race meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Some time was spent to-day by Manager Marean of the Western Union Telegraph Company in perfecting arrangements for the transmission and receipt of messages to and from the London office in connection with the international chess games between the picked teams of the House of Representatives and the British House of Commons, which will begin to-morrow at 2 o'clock, Washington time.

Summer sent a little, fragrant Summer breeze to play about the city yesterday morning, and thousands of happy people yielded willingly to its soft caresses. It was a good little breeze, too, for it didn't keep on the broad avenues or in the parks up town, but wandered down in and out dark, narrow alleys and crooked streets, where warmth and light mean much.
LONDON, May 31. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily Mail says to-day:

In honor of Memorial Day, impressive services were held last evening in the Church of the Paulist Fathers, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, which were attended by several hundred veterans of the war of the rebellion and over 2,000 other people. The veterans present represented twenty-sex posts of the Grand Army of the Republic.

HAVANA, May 30. -- In a leading article this morning El Diario de la Marina makes a scathing, indirect attack upon Commissioner Calhoun by criticising articles which have appeared in a Washington newspaper over the signature of Mr. Pepper, who, it is said, accompanied Mr. Calhoun to Cuba in the guise of an intimate friend of President McKinley and Mr. Calhoun.

BOSTON, May 30. -- A reception in the cadets' new armory, on Columbus Avenue, this evening brought to a close the Seventh Regiment's Sunday in Boston. The function was attended by some 400 people, and was unusually distinguished for a Sunday evening in this Puritan city.
I have read the slashing letter of your correspondent, John Lincoln Blauss, on "Dropping into Buddhism" in your issue of May 24, and wish to submit the following in reply.

Laying aside the worry of business, the Orthodox Friends rejoiced their souls with a whole day of devotion and worship yesterday, at the fourth day of the yearly meeting in the sombre edifice on East Twentieth Street. As early as 9 o'clock, while the ordinary citizen was sipping his coffee and reading his Sunday paper, the followers of William Penn wended their way soberly to the devotional service with which the day of worship opened.

The Carnegie Lyceum was well filled yesterday morning, for the Rev. Charles H. Eaton was to make reply to interviews of other clergymen regarding his views on future punishment and the scheme of salvation. Dr. Eaton took as his text the passage from the Gospel of St. John, "Except ye be born again, ye cannot see the Kingdom of Heaven."

A novel marriage ceremony will take place this evening in the old Brooklyn Savings Bank Building, corner of Concord and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn. A Captain in the ranks of the American Volunteers has been taken prisoner by a gentle recruit and the regiment will halt and ground arms that he may have his revenge.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 30. -- George W. Aldridge, Superintendent of Public Works, under whose supervision the Capitol is being finished, and who on Saturday, with the approval of Gov. Black, let the contract to the Hallowell Granite Company of Maine for $259,000, denied to-day that they had been forced to accept the bid of the Hallowell Company against their wishes.

A boys' industrial settlement was opened on Saturday last near the village of Gardiner, Ulster County, N.Y., by which it is to be determined how far the taking away of city waifs from urban environment may effect a reformation in their habits and an improvement, in their condition. The project is a novel one, and it will be conducted under the auspices of New York and Brooklyn Christian workers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30. -- A mass meeting of nearly 5,000 people was held in the Alhambra in this city this evening, to protest against Sunday ball playing. The platform was filled with prominent business and professional citizens. The audience was an enthusiastic one.

PARIS, May 30. -- The Prix du Jockey Club, the French Derby, second only to the Grand Prix de Paris in social and racing interests, was run to-day at Chantilly, and won easily by Palmiste II., Baron de Schickler's three-year-old, trained by Webb.

When Senator MORGAN'S voice "quivers," what is it a sign of? On Saturday he was called to order by Senator HALE, and the Chairman, Senator GALLINGER, sustained the point of order. He was criticising and even denouncing the action of the House, which is as clearly disorderly in the Senate as it would be to appear in a state of intoxication in the Chamber.

Walter Damrosch, who returned from Europe on Saturday morning, has completed all arrangements for an extensive opera season in French, Italian, and German next Winter in New York and elsewhere. Charles A. Ellis will be associated with him. The New York season will begin on Jan. 17, and will continue for at least five weeks.

It is a pity that the Irish members should have prejudiced by their behavior a case which, if it be not wholly meritorious, at all events deserves the most serious examination. The claim that Ireland has for many years been overtaxed and that the contributions to the imperial revenue that have been exacted from her are out of proportion to her ability to pay does not rest upon conjecture or declamation.

PITTSBURG, May 30. -- Jean Baptiste Le Blanc, or Dr. Hamilton Griffin, who obtained some notoriety by his financial operations in New York and on the Pacific coast, has been living in seclusion in Pittsburg since April 27. He is practicing medicine at 177 Wylie Avenue, in a poor section of the city.

The third annual chess match between the Manhattan Chess Club of this city and the Franklin Chess Club of Philadelphia was played by telegraph yesterday. The Manhattan team, with M. De Visser as Captain, sat at two rows of tables in their club room at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Forty-seven yachts raced in the annual regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club yesterday. The start was made off the clubhouse at Belden Point at 1:35 o'clock, in a light southwesterly breeze. Yachts over thirty feet in length were sent off first, and sailed to Matinnecock Point and back -- twenty nautical miles.

Medical reports continue to furnish conclusive proofs of the efficacy of the antitoxin treatment of diphtheria. In laryngeal diphtheria, the severest form of the disease, commonly calling for operative interference by intubation or tracheotomy or both, in which the mortality was formerly 70 per cent., antitoxin treatment yields 70 per cent. of recoveries and only 30 per cent. of deaths.
" And you might bring me a cup of weak coffee, too," a busy man said to a restaurant waiter, when giving an order.

The thirty-first annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association of Amateur Oarsmen, held yesterday on the Harlem River, was by far the most successful and interesting event of its kind held in this part of the country for years. Tide, wind, and weather favored the oarsmen, and, without a single exception, every crew entered put in an appearance at the starting line and rowed its race.

CLIFTON, N.J., May 31. -- The two-mile multicycle handicap was the feature of the bicycle meet held at the old race track here this afternoon, under the auspices of the Excelsion Boat Club of Paterson. The event was won from the seventy-yard mark by a triplet team comprising William Slavin, W. Cane, Jr., and M.R. Brown. A tandem team finished second, a single third, and a "quad" fourth. The summaries:

With placidity unruffled by the observance of the holiday about them, the members of the Orthodox branch of the Society of Friends met yesterday morning to continue their two hundred and second yearly meeting. So far were Memorial Day and its sentiments removed from the mild brethren and sisters that no mention was made of it at any of the sessions of the day.

TACOMA, Washington, May 31. -- The Makah Indians of Neah Bay had a whale hunt Friday which they will long remember. They started out forty-eight strong to secure their season's supply of meat and oil. Their party was rigged out in warlike fashion, filling six big canoes. At daylight Friday, when fifteen miles west of Cape Flattery, they sighted a school of between fifty and sixty whales.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 31. -- Judge Simonton of the United States Circuit Court to-day filed a decision in the case of the Vandercook Company against the State of South Carolina, restraining the State from preventing the sale of liquors brought into the State. This decision, if sustained on appeal, it is said will have the effect of rendering nugatory the State dispensary law.
The New York team defeated Pittsburg yesterday afternoon by a score of 10 to 2. The home team outbatted, outfielded, and outplayed their opponents every point.

BERLIN, May 31. -- The trial of Herr Von Tausch, the former Chief of the Secret Political Police, charged with perjury, treason and forgery, was resumed this morning. Herr Friedheim, representing the Chief of Police, testified that Von Tausch, during the course of his investigation into the origin of an article in the Welt-Am-Montag, intimated that it emanated from the Foreign Office.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- While no definite announcement of a policy toward Cuba by the Administration can be expected until after the return here of Mr. Calhoun, some intimations from the White House favor the assumption that the President will not resist the passage by the House of the Senate resolution declaring the belligerent rights of the Cubans.

ORANGE, N.J., May 31. -- Play was begun to-day on the links of the Essex County Country Club for the Governor's Cup and the May Cup, and was won by T.H. Powers Farr. A large number of players were out on the links, but few cards were turned in. There was considerable informal play. The players, with scores in the contest for the Governor's Cup, were as follows:

HELENA, Mon., May 31. -- The Cheyenne Indians are reported on the war path, and are said to have killed almost a dozen men, including five United States soldiers. The Indians have no reservation of their own, but roam over the southern part of the State near the Crow Reservation. The white settlers are in arms, and the women and children are being sent into the northern towns for safety.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., May 31. -- Receivers Robert W. De Forrest and Samuel E. Kilner of New York met William B. Banks to-day, and made known the plan of reorganization of the Land and Rivers Improvement Company, which failed in September, 1896. This company organized the town site of West Superior, being incorporated in 1883, with a capital of $1,400,000.

When the report of a public address has to be condensed into a few paragraphs it is, of course, not reasonable to look for close discriminations; but when a speaker is reported to have said about another man the precise thing he tried disprove, it is fair to make a disclaimer.
MONTREAL, May 31. -- Baroness Von Turkheim, formerly Miss J.M. Delimas of San Francisco, reached here to-night. She is on the way to San Francisco.

The business week, beginning after what has been practically a three days' holiday, promises to be rather an active one in Wall Street -- particularly in the industrial stocks. Tariff news is likely to play an important part as a stock market factor. Both bulls and bears will be quick to turn every new development into an argument for or against prices.

It was a day of rain, fog, sunshine, and wind for the Atlantic yachtsmen yesterday, and they experienced these various changes of weather in the order named. The rain fell long enough to mar the ceremony of putting the club in commission. Then the fog lasted so that the races were postponed until late in the day.
LONDON, May 31. -- The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the crop situation, says:

The games of the New Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne yesterday were attended by about 5,000 persons. There was great disappointment when B.J. Wefers failed to appear for the special race arranged for him with J.H. Colfert of Princeton, who defeated him Saturday. Colfert won the 300-yard special race by a neck, defeating two University of Pennsylvania men.

The Cleveland team, including Sockalexis, the Indian, were made to bite the dust at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon by the Brooklyn team. There was no morning game, owing to the rain, but the management were not out of pocket as a result. An hour before the afternoon game was scheduled there was not a vacant seat in the stands.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Memorial Day was generally observed in Washington. The Senate adjourned over for the day, and the House held only a fifteen-minute session. All the departments and the business houses were closed. At 10 o'clock there was an impressive parade of the Grand Army and other patriotic organizations, which at 11 o'clock broke up, the several posts holding memorial exercises in the various cemeteries.
POUGHKEEPSIE, May 31. -- The bicycle races held by Crockett's Wheelmen, at the Hudson River Driving Park, this afternoon, were attended by over 5,000 persons.

WEST POINT, May 31. -- In the presence of 5,000 people, the Secretary of War, Lieut. Gen. Schofield, and many high officers of the army, the battle monument, erected by their comrades in honor of the officers and soldiers of the regular army who fell in battle in the civil war, was dedicated to-day.

NEWARK, May 31. -- The Passaic River Amateur Rowing Association held its twenty-third annual regatta on the famous Passaic course to-day. With few exceptions, the events were highly enjoyable. The course was one mile in all except the eight-oared races, in which it was one and a half miles. Summary:

A bright-eyed lad of nineteen, slight of frame, but with muscles as strong as steel, won the honors in the Irvington-Millburn handicap yesterday. There were over 100 others opposed to him, most of the number tried and seasoned old road riders, yet this youth of Newark crossed the finish line an easy winner, a smile playing upon his lips, while the spectators cheered him.

The Indians will get their clothes from Uncle Sam two months later this year than usual. Their Summer suits will reach them about the time that the snow-cooled breezes from the Rockies and from the wintry plains where rolls the Oregon make it necessary for even the Indian to think of something warmer than war paint and seersuckers.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The international chess match between the teams of the House of Representatives and the House of Commons was the only matter of real interest to-day at the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Two of the five chess games between the teams of the House of Representatives and the House of Commons were decided to-day. The three others were unfinished when the time for adjournment arrived, at 7 o'clock. The first game completed was won by Plunkett of the English team.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Indian trouble in Southern Montana reported from Helena was made known to the authorities of the War Department last week, and in the opinion of the officials is not likely to be followed by serious results. The first news of the affair came to the department in a telegram from Col. Sheridan, the Adjutant General of the Department at St. Paul.

Cricketers woke up yesterday morning in dismay as they heard the rain pattering down. The afternoon sun brought joy to their hearts, but many games were spoiled, either by absentees from the team or by a dead wicket.

The old Athenian dramatists showed a peculiarly vivid contempt for the folly acid fickleness of the populace. Though there is no longer any Greek drama to which the world pays any attention, the modern Athenian populace continues to justify the sentiment with which its remote predecessor was regarded.

It is over a century since BURKE wrote, "the age of chivalry is gone." He wrote it, too, in reference to the treatment of women in France, in particular to the treatment of the Queen, who had already been insulted and imprisoned, though not yet sent to the guillotine.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Speaker Reed does not regard as probable the reported intention to test the constitutionality of the order of the House to adjourn for periods of three days at a time. The denunciations of the course of the House do not at all alarm him. This afternoon, when the subject was referred to, he wore one of his most comfortable smiles as he soliloquized:

Members of the alumni society of the American Academy of the Dramatic Arts performed a new three-act farce by A.E. Lancaster, called "A Wise Child," at Carnegie Lyceum last night. Some years ago Mr. Lancaster was thought to be a promising dramatist. "A Wise Child," however, is not a promising work. It is an incoherent, improbable, and hysterical sort of piece, in which the author's intentions are probably not always realized.

NEWARK, May 31. -- The new board track of the Century Cyclers at Vailsburg was opened to-day. The turnout to see the several events exceeded the anticipations of the promoters of the scheme and the result was a good afternoon's sport. One of the features was A.A. Zimmerman's half-mile against time paced by a quad.
" Pittsburg Phil has scratched The Winner and decided to start Howard Mann instead. It's a question whether it is a tip or a blunder."
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- There was a good attendance on the floor of the House and in the galleries to-day, notwithstanding the outside attractions of Memorial Day.

Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg, the new Chairman of the Republican County Committee, took charge of the committee's headquarters at 1 Madison Avenue yesterday. Senator Platt went back to Washington yesterday afternoon after having another talk with Mr. Quigg. It is understood that the plan of campaign which Mr. Quigg is to pursue has been roughly mapped out, and that the plan is for him to harmonize in every possible direction.

WAVERLY, N.J., May 31. -- The Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark never promoted so successful a tournament as that held here this afternoon on the track at the fair grounds. The attendance numbered about 5,000.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 31. -- The first semi-annual tournaments for the women's and men's championships of the Morris County Golf Club were played to-day on the club links. Miss Helen Shelton won the silver cup presented by the club. For the ownership it must be won three times. Mrs. Shippen formerly held the cup, which she has won twice.

Educators of prominence gave their views yesterday at the conference of professors and teachers held in the rooms of the Law School of the New York University, as to the present methods of teaching English and whether any modifications should be made in the system of examinations adopted at the last conference.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Secretary Gage has returned to the city from Cincinnati, where he was a guest at the banquet given last Friday by the Commercial Club of that city to the visiting clubs from Chicago, Boston, and St. Louis. Mr. Gage said today that a feeling of impatience seemed to be general among the people at the delay in the passage of a tariff bill.
Among the many demerits of Senator ALDRICH'S Tariff bill these specific vices are conspicuous:

WINDSOR, Ga., May 31. -- The body of Edward J. Wright was found on the public road near this place yesterday afternoon, pierced by two bullets and badly hacked by a blunt instrument. Wright was the choir leader in the church here, and led a service yesterday of much public interest.

A frightful accident occurred shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the crossing of the Merrick Road and the Hempstead Branch of the Long Island Railroad, near Valley Stream. A passenger train going at the rate of thirty miles an hour crashed into a tally-ho coach containing twenty-four persons, all from Brooklyn, midway between the front and hind wheels.

HOLLIDAYSBURG, Penn., May 31. -- While Joseph Spencer, Chief of the Volunteer Fire Department at Roaring Springs, Penn., near here, was helping to extinguish flames that had started in a dwelling house to-day, a chimney fell and buried him under its ruins. He died soon after.

A cable dispatch received last night from Cuba said it was rumored that the steamship Valencia of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company (Ward Line) had been wrecked off the south coast of Cuba.

BOSTON, May 31. -- Memorial Day of this year was of particular significance on account of the unveiling and dedication of the elaborate memorial structure on Boston Common, erected in honor of Col. Robert Gould Shaw of the Fifty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment and the brave black men who comprised his followers and who fell, with their Colonel, in the assault upon Fort Wagner, S.C., July 18, 1863.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 31. -- Because a woman twice his age refused to marry him, Robert J. Hlbbard, a young machinist, twenty-two years old, shot and seriously wounded her to-day.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 31. -- President D.D. Woodmansee and Secretary M.J. Dowling have issued a call for the tenth annual convention of the National Republican League at Detroit, July 13. Each State and territorial league is entitled to four delegates from each congressional district, and six delegates at large.

The scheme of the coat contractors to cause a stampede among the striking tailors yesterday by opening their shops and saying that they were willing to take back all who wished to return to work at the old terms did not succeed, although they promised the men to give them enough work to enable them to earn 50 per cent. more money.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 31. -- There was an attendance of about 8,000 people at the fifth annual meeting of the Associated Cycling Clubs, at the Waltham bicycle track, to-day. The track itself was in fair condition. The greatest interest centered in the professional events, in which Cooper, Bald, and Kiser took part. In the one-mile professional, Bald and Cooper were brought together for the first time, and Bald won.

St. Andrew's Club golfers had the largest and most interesting competition of the season yesterday. The annual Decoration Day event for the Governors' prizes was held, a first for the winner in both classes, A. and B, and a second for the former. John B. Upham won the Class A prize from handicap of 6 and a net score of 83, and S.D. Bowers took second in 85 strokes, from scratch.

If madness possesses them, and an insatiable craving for another defeat, the Democrats of the new great city will affirm the principles of the Chicago platform in the municipal contest this Fall -- otherwise not.

If the success which attended the opening of the regular campaign for the harness racers in this State at Parkway track, Brooklyn, can be traced directly to the reduction of the penalty for pool selling, the new law bids fair to revive a sport which has languished for two seasons under stringent legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- At 2:10 P.M. play was resumed in the international chess games between Congress and the House of Commons. The greatest interest was manifested in the play at the fourth table, where it was thought a few moves would indicate the result to be expected.

Thirty-three members of the Baltusrol Golf Club at Short Hills, N.J., yesterday finished the special tournament arranged for members of the club on Memorial Day. It was not concluded until late in the day, and the scores of the leaders were very close. Handicaps were limited to 18 strokes, and Grier Campbell, with a handicap of 12, won the prize and first place with a net score of 84 strokes.
HAVANA, (via Key West, Fla.,) June 1. -In its last issue, El Comercio, the organ of the retail grocers, violently attacks the United States. It says in part:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- Princeton won the Baseball series from Harvard this afternoon, meeting the Crimson at Yale Field in the third and deciding game.

It has been said a great many times that cyclists are a selfish lot, and not desirous of according any special privileges to the non-riding public, when their (the riders') convenience is in any way encroached upon. This popular belief will now have to take a back seat, at least so far as the New York City Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen is concerned.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The trial of John E. Searles, Secretary of the Sugar Trust, for recusancy before the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee, was resumed this morning. Judge Bradley sustained the motion of the defense and ordered the jury to bring a verdict of acquittal, holding that the questions asked the witness by the Senate committee were not pertinent, and, if so, were not within the jurisdiction of the committee.

LONDON, June 1. -- The scene to-night in Room No. 12 of the House of Commons, where the British chess team played, was a repetition, in the main, of that of the previous night. The chief difference was in the increasing excitement at the approaching termination of the contest. But the anxiety was more felt than seen, and not an echo of it was allowed to ranch the players themselves.

The New York and New Jersey Bridge Company has been aroused to greater activity by the reports from Washington that it may have forfeited its right to construct a bridge across the Hudson. The stockholders held their annual meeting yesterday, and Treasurer Charles H. Swan submitted a report showing what work was done last year.

Miss Adelaide R. Hasse, who comes from Washington to catalogue the political documents in the Astor Library, was at her post of duty yesterday. But those who have the vast array of pamphlets and monographs in their charge were not ready for her, and so she spent her time assisting in other work in the Catalogue Department.

Some time since THE TIMES had occasion to comment upon the efficient and judicious policy of the Governor of one of the Southern States, who happens to have been elected, by an overwhelming majority, by the pay whose views on finance THE TIMES has vigorously opposed.

By diligent application to business the Orthodox Friends finished their two hundred and second Yearly Meeting yesterday afternoon a day before they had expected. Clerk James Wood, as the twilight darkened, read the minute he had prepared announcing the adjournment, "Having considered with a continued and lively interest the business that has come before us, it has been concluded in delightful harmony."
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

LONDON, June 1. -- When the inquiry of the Parliamentary committee into the Transvaal raid was resumed to-day, Mr. Alfred Beit, a former Director of the British Chartered South Africa Company, read a statement denying the charges of Mr. Henry Labouchere to the effect that he had "rigged the market," and offered the books of his firm to prove the truth of his denial.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Heavy frosts occurred the past two mornings over the greater part of the Northwest. Snow and freezing weather are reported from Northern Wisconsin and Minnesota, with much damage to vegetables and small fruits. The Wisconsin strawberry crop may be a total loss. Tobacco in Southern Wisconsin is reported slightly injured, and in Northern Illinois badly damaged.
CINCINNATI, June 1. -- Only two out of six favorites succeeded in getting first money to-day. The track was' fast and the weather' was fine. but ,the betting, was. light. , Snmmai'y-:

The frame of mind in which Mr. Secretary GAGE comes back from Cincinnati as significant. He went there, as his speech showed, to quiet the impatience of business men on the currency question by the assurance that the Administration had not forgotten its mandate, and in due time would take decisive steps to establish a sound and enduring currency basis.

The long-pending resolution of Alderman Hall that the Corporation Counsel be instructed by the Board of Aldermen to acquire for the city the Sixth and Eighth Avenue railroad franchises was acted on yesterday by the full board after the Railroad Committee had presented a majority and a minority report.

LONDON, June 1. -- The friends of Mr. Samuel L. Clemens, "Mark Twain," ask The Associated Press to deny the stories in circulation regarding his ill health and impoverished condition. As cabled exclusively to The Associated Press on May 8, when Mr. Clemens was reported to have died suddenly, the great American humorist is now in better health and spirits than for years past.

The Columbian Line steamer Allianca, which arrived yesterday morning from Colon, is detained at Quarantine. During the voyage to this port Angus McLellan of Pictou, N.S., aged thirty-three years, died of yellow fever. He was taken sick on May 26 and died at 7 o'clock Monday morning and was buried at noon. McLellan was a second cabin passenger and by profession was a mining engineer.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day immediately after the disposal of the routine business. Mr. Aldrich, in charge of the bill, returned to Paragraph 90, relating to china, porcelain, , and withdrew the proposed committee amendments, leaving the rates as reported by the House, viz.: Decorated, 60 per cent. ad valorem; undecorated, 55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- When the House met to-day, it was still the legislative day of yesterday, a recess having been taken until to-day. A large pile of authorities was heaped up on the desks of Representative Richardson (Dam., Tenn.,) and Mr. Lewis (Dem., Washington,) and there was every indication that the minority intended to make the path of the majority as thorny as possible.

-- A correspondent of The Mobile Register is another person who questions the originality of the "siss-boom-ah," or "skyrocket," part of the Princeton cheer. Mr. ALEXANDER'S article in this month's Scribner's inclines toward the theory that this cheerful sound was first made when the Seventh Regiment started for the war, and that it was then heard and afterward adopted by the Princeton boys.

The first set of open junior interscholastic games ever held in this vicinity took place yesterday at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge, under the auspices of the Cutler School Junior Athletic Association. The entries included youngsters from nearly every school in this city, and the competition for first honors was quite interesting.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The international chess match between members of the House of Representatives and the English House of Commons to-day resulted in a draw, each side having won and lost two games and one being drawn.

Judge BRADLEY has decided: 1. That the Senate committee's inquiry as to contributions by the Sugar Trust to State or local election funds was not pertinent. 2. That if it were pertinent, it was beyond the jurisdiction of the Senate as too remote from the subject of investigation and an unwarranted prying into the private affairs of the company.

The killing and maiming of a coachload of human beings at the Merrick Road crossing of the Long Island Railroad Monday may lead in time to the abandonment of grade crossings by that railroad. "Pressure" to that end will be brought to bear upon its officers now that the worst has happened.

Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday appointed Samuel Sanders temporary receiver in a suit brought for dissolution of partnership by Michael Wineburgh against his brothers, Henry, Abraham, and Jesse. Dissensions impossible to subdue were the reasons given by Michael Wineburgh for his action in his application to be appointed receiver.

It has long been known as the "Merry Month of May." But there is such a thing as being too merry, and if Winter persists in lingering in the lap of Spring as he is doing this year, it will be in order for the Roof Garden Managers' Protective Association and Coney Island outing societies to join hands in a movement to have him indicted for disorderly conduct.

PITTSBURG, June 1. -- The annual meeting of stockholders of the Pennsylvania Company, operating the lines of the Northwest system, was held to-day. The annual report was submitted, showing results in the proprietary department: Total revenue for 1896, $2,399,623, out of which was paid for interest on bonds, general expenses, taxes, $2,161.356, leaving profit $238,266, a decrease as compared with 1895 of $708,767.

Benjamin Aaronson, twenty-seven years old, a salesman, who refused to give his residence, but whose wife lives at 118 East Eighty-seventh Street, and John Brickwedel, thirty years old, of 1,370 Fifth Avenue, who was formerly in the employ of the Manhattan Railway Company, are prisoners at Police Headquarters on the charge of having committed the robbery of money and tickets from the Cortlandt Street station of the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad Saturday night.

An air of indescribable sadness hovered over the entire neighborhood of the Greene Avenue Baptist Church, in Brooklyn, all day yesterday. The terrible accident at Valley Stream, which cast a shadow over the homes of twenty of the most popular members of the church, was discussed in hushed tones by the many friends of the dead and wounded.
The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union will hold its regular weekly meeting at the headquarters, 39 West Twenty-third Street, to-night.

The young men of the Twenty-third Street branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, after a heated debate last night, decided by a good round majority that "the Citizens' Union movement merits our heartiest support."
CHICAGO, June 1. -- The latest convert to cycling is former Gov. John P. Altgeld. He mounted a wheel to-day for the first time, and conquered it in a short period.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- The American Medical Association began the celebration of its golden jubilee to-day in the Academy of Music by convention, which will continue for four days. In connection with the sessions of the main body, the various sections of the association also held separate sessions, at which papers bearing on each particular section were read.
Cooper Institute was packed last evening with the striking tailors, and hundreds were unable to gain admittance.

These are trying times for conscientious musicians held to service in the army or navy of the United States and subject to the Articles of War. The latest conflict between the artistic conscience and military discipline is reported from Washington. The leader of the Marine Band played music displeasing to a Lieutenant of the Marine Corps in charge of the parade.

The polo season at the Westchester Country Club was opened yesterday afternoon, when the Meadowbrook team administered a severe defeat to the home players. Something was radically wrong with the handicaps of the Polo Association, for the best the Country Club men could do was to score three goals, which, with their handicap of two goals and one received by penalty against their opponents, gave them a total of six.

In spite of the fact that almost all of the really good carriage horses that have been bought up at auction in this city recently have been shipped to Europe on orders given months ago, the purchase of this class of animals for shipment continues. Yesterday, at the American Horse Exchange, some excellent carriage stock was disposed of, and most of it will go to the other side.

The New York-Pittsburg game played yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds ended in a most disgraceful squabble in the latter half of the sixth inning and was awarded by Umpire McDermott to New York with a score of 9 to 0, because the Pittsburgs refused to play ball. The game had been marked by the kicking of Killen and Donovan on points about which they did not agree with Umpire McDermott.

The annual parade of the Police Department of the City of New York took place yesterday afternoon. It was the last parade under the present organization of the force, and, although handicapped at the beginning by the elements, Chief Conlin and his men gave one of the finest parades in the history of the department.

The last name mentioned conspicuously as a Tammany Mayoralty candidate is that of Supreme Court Justice Morgan J. O'Brien. While Justice O'Brien has in no way intimated that he is a candidate, some of his closest friends have been quietly urging his selection upon many politicians. Supreme Court Justices Dugro and Giegerich have already been mentioned in connection with the Mayoralty.
