The Atlantic Transport Line steamship Mississippi, from London, arrived in port yesterday with a hole in her port quarter suggestive of a rough encounter with something more solid than water. She had been in collision during a fog on May 27 with the Thingvalla Line steamship Hekla, which left New York May 22 for Christiansand.

John N. Golding has sold for C. Grayson Martin of Martin Brother to J.T. Tower of Poughkeepsie for about $410,000 the southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, 50 by 100. This is half of a plot sold recently by the Church of the Divine Paternity to Martin Brother. Mr. Tower will immediately improve the property by the erection of a ten-story office and studio building.

While the two spoils organizations are thus laboring to hold their own forces and to win outside adherents by striking conciliatory attitudes, the Citizens' Union has arrived at a critical period in its career. So far it has merely put forth its programme of non-partisan municipal government, with a few more commendable pledges, and upon the strength of this it has asked good citizens to enroll themselves under its auspices.

We have now had an experience of some weeks, which is practically to say of some Sundays, with the Raines law as amended by its author. The amended law was enacted by the assembled wisdom of the rural districts, paying no regard whatever to the opinion of the representatives of the people chiefly concerned.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Senate has disposed of two schedules of the Tariff bill in Committee of the Whole, in one week. The two schedules -- chemicals and earth, earthenware and glassware -- cover about as many pages as the next two schedules, metals and wood and manufactures of wood, which promise to be debated as carefully by the opposition as the schedules already passed upon.

MUNICH, June 1. -- The International Art Exhibition was opened to-day by Prince Regent Luitp01d in the presence of the Court dignitaries, l%linisters, members of the Diplomatic Corps, and the civil and military authorities. There are many American exhibits.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 2. -- Judge Taft, in United States Court Chambers, at Cincinnati, yesterday, on motion of the Mercantile Trust Company, placed the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railroad in the hands of Samuel M. Felton as receiver. Mr. Felton is President and receiver of the Queen and Crescent Route.

BALTIMORE, June 2. -- Edgar Harris, a letter carrier, thirty-two years of age, living at 1,724 Ashland Avenue, this morning shot and killed his twelve-year-old son George and his six-year-old daughter Ada, wounded his daughter Ella, aged fourteen, and then turned the pistol on himself. He is now lying at the point of death in Johns Hopkins Hospital.

The Citizens' Union, desiring to do a new thing, has set out to do it in a new way. Whereupon warning voices cry out that if it does not stick to the old ways it is lost. The politicians mostly prefer a short canvass. Sometimes it is the candidate, sometimes it is the party principles that will not bear prolonged scrutiny and discussion.

CLEVELAND, June 2. -- Major C.W.F. Dick, Secretary of the Republican National Committee, has arrived in the city to take personal charge of Mr. Hanna's campaign for the Senatorship. Major Dick will remain in the city until the State Convention, and, contrary to rumors, it is not expected that Mr. Hanna will arrive in the State until the week of the convention in Toledo.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- President McKinley dropped into the second day's session of the golden jubilee of the American Medical Association on his way to address the Commercial Congress. He was introduced by the President of the Association, Dr. Senn, and spoke as follows:

FRANKFORT, Ky., June 2. -- Harmony characterized to-day's sessions of the silver Democratic State Convention on all issues except whenever any point came up involving the interests of one of the six candidates for Appellate Court Clerk. The convention nearly divided when the election of permanent Chairman came up over the question upon which ballot the last candidate should be dropped. The platform adopted in part was as follows:

The American Line steamship St. Louis, for Southampton, and the White Star Liner Majestic, for Liverpool, left their piers yesterday loaded down with celebrities. Among those on the first-named vessel were Chauncey M. Depew, Andrew Carnegie, George J. Gould, Charles H. Cramp, and several other Americans who do not have to rely on charity for means of subsistence.
The Naval Court of Inquiry which is investigating the complaints made by Switz Conde against Ensign Stone resumed its labors yesterday afternoon on board the United States battleship Maine.

The discovery of an airship farm in the wilderness of Illinois (whether within or without the municipal boundaries of Chicago is not specified) will surprise no one except a few having some knowledge of the etymology of the word "farm." It has not been generally used hitherto to describe a place where artisans are employed in manufacturing.

We observe with interest that Mr. JOHN SWINTON made an address to the striking tailors in which he told them that they ought every one to receive not leas than $5 for not more than eight hours' work. This statement must have been received with enthusiasm tempered by incredulity by men who have difficulty in getting a fifth of the money for twice the work.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- The International Commercial Conference, which had its inception in the Philadelphia Commercial Museum, under the auspices of which institution the conference is held, was formally opened this afternoon at the Academy of Music with an address by President McKinley. On the stage of the Academy sat the delegates to the conference, members of President McKinley's Cabinet, and quite a number of Ministers and other representatives of foreign countries.

Every sensible person had to own that the Ellsworth bill, in the shape in which it came up for discussion and decision, was not fit to be enacted. The original purpose of it, the protection of privacy, was excellent. But that purpose was so overlaid with projects of foolish persons and of persons who desired to avoid political criticism by caricature as to be almost lost sight of in the completed measure.
Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for the A.B. Cox estate to F. Reinert for $10,000 the irregular plot Sixty-fifth Street, south side, 100 feet west of Second Avenue, about 25 by 100.

Any West Point cadet knows that the whole art of war consists in not doing what your enemy wishes. "Abroad" is our enemy in trade, and there is no protectionist, from our own Napoleon down to the merest office boy, who does not know that the more Europe protests the better is the proof of how the tariff makes them suffer.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, last night. Chairman James B. Reynolds presided, and there were present R. Fulton Cutting, John C. Clark, William B. Hornblower, Edward A. Drake, Henry R. Kunhardt, James Loeb, George Tombleson, John Frankenheimer, Charles C. Nadal, John B. Pine, James W. Pryor, Joseph Larocque, Henry White, Richard Watson Gilder, William M. Kingsley, and William Jay Schieffelin.

Commissioner of Public Works Collis sent a letter to the Mayor yesterday, in which he proposed a plan for the construction of a grand plaza in the southern part of Central Park. His scheme is to lay out the plaza so that it will include the area between Fifty-ninth and Sixty-second Streets and Fifth and Eighth Avenues.

The Spanish Ministry, with Senor CANOVAS at its head, has been obliged to give up. There were enough of the Liberals and the dissident Conservatives who would not attend the sessions of the Cortes to prevent all action. There are not enough of them, however, to make a majority for a new Ministry.

Thomas M. Early of Highland Falls, N.Y., and Marx Bernstein, a junk dealer, at 30 Hester Street, were arraigned before Untied States Commissioner Shields yesterday afternoon on the charge of stealing cannon from West Point. The guns are relics of the Mexican war, and are prized on account of historical connections.
CINCINNATI, June 2 -- Three favorites, two "second choices," and a "long shot" won to-day at Latonia The track was fast. Attendance, 2,000. Summaries:

On the authority of the engineer in charge of street openings Gen. COLLIS informs the Mayor that it would cost only $1,250,000 to convert the lower end of Central Park, from Fifty-ninth Street to Sixty-second Street, into a treeless and asphalted place d'armes, plaza, or parade ground, with raised stone platforms upon which no end of bad statues could in future ages be erected.

NEWPORT, June 2. -- The Naval War College was formally opened to-day with an address by Theodore Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy. The address was delivered in the lecture room of the college. Among those present were Commodore Wallace and officers of the naval station, Col. Pennington, commander of Fort Adams, and Commander McGowan of the naval training station.

The so-called Nelson Bankruptcy bill which has passed the Senate and gone to the House is in some important features a mischievous bill. It has yet to be passed upon by the House. There is, therefore, an opportunity to get from that body a better bill, which should be improved to the utmost.

A business man in John Street courteously informs THE TIMES of the amusement he has felt at our mention of white lead as a "raw material." He says urbanely: "Perhaps you will write another funny article, and with the brilliancy of your imagination be able to show how an article that has been through about five processes and taken three months to corrode is still an article which can be called raw material."

DENVER, June 2. -- Three men will start out from Denver to-morrow in a wagon on which are painted the words "Co-operative Commonwealth Van," to preach revolutionary Socialism in every part of Colorado and prepare the way for the inauguration of Eugene V. Debs's Co-operative Commonwealth.

All Saints' Church, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, presented a brilliant scene at noon yesterday, when Miss Frances E. Gilroy, daughter of ex-Mayor and Mrs. Thomas F. Gilroy, became the bride of Mr. Edward A. Maher, Jr., son of ex-Mayor of Albany Edward A. Maher, now a resident of Harlem.

MADRID, June 2. -- The Premier, Senor Canovas del Castillo, has tendered to the Queen Regent the resignation of the Cabinet, owing to the difficulty the Ministers experienced in carrying on the Government in view of the Parliamentary situation caused by the refusal of the Liberals to take part in the deliberations of the Cortes.

John C. Sheehan's statements, published yesterday morning, that "places have been made for friends and relatives of reformers"; that there are "6,000 more employes on the city's pay rolls than when the Democratic administration went out," and that there have been extravagant expenditures under the "reform administration," were emphatically denied by officials of different departments.

MANCHESTER, England, June 2. -- The annual meeting of the Bimetallic League opened here this morning. There was a large attendance, including over fifty delegates from labor associations, mostly Lancashire spinners and weavers. The Lord Mayor of Manchester presided and welcomed the delegates.
ROCHESTER, June 2. -- At a meeting of the Cuban Hospital Relief Association yesterday the following letter from Senator Morgan of Alabama was read:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 2. -Up to noon to-day no report had been received here of the Hekla, which was in collision off the Banks on Thursday last with the Atlaxitic Transport Liner Mississippi, bound from London to New York. It Is thought she may be making .slowly for St. John's.

Contrary to general expectation, the first chess match between the House of Commons and the House of Representatives has resulted in a draw. This is a result extremely creditable to our side, seeing that chess has for a long time been the favorite diversion of the M.P.'s and habitually played within the precincts of Westminster Palace itself.
In a country like this necessity exists for two kinds of capital -- which may be broadly designated as commercial and productive.

On Tuesday Chris Yon der Ahe swapped Tommy Dowd a~ud a jackknife for Harley and Hallman ou the PhHadelphias, and he played them yesterday against the Brooklyns, and still he could not win. In the fifth inning, Hart, the visitors' Ditcher, "went up." He gave three bases on balls, allowed three hits, and this, coupled with Cross's error, gave the home talent five runs, more than enough to score the victory.

Two long reports from Chief Conlin were received and read at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board. One referred to the resolution of the board adopted at the previous meeting calling on the Chief to take action to suppress the fake clubs in precincts where the commanders had failed and to report what legal proceedings had been taken against a certain alleged disorderly house.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Mr. Aldrich being slightly ill to-day, Mr. Allison of Iowa and Mr. Platt of Connecticut assumed management in the Senate of the Tariff bill.

Although considerable speculation is being indulged in regarding the movements of the steamship Hekla of the Thingvalla Line, which met the Atlantic Transport liner Mississippi in collision in mid-ocean May 27, no anxiety is felt for her safety by the local officers of the line. It is believed she will proceed cautiously to Christiansand, her original destination, and will probably arrive there Sunday or Monday.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Evanston business men are now fighting the Davis Street meetings of the Salvation Army through the City Council. A petition is in the hands of Mayor Dyche, signed by the patrons of the public library and nearly all the merchants along Davis Street asking that the meetings be stopped.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 2. -- The members of the Yale crew, with their manager and coach, "Bob" Cook, arrived here late this afternoon, to take up their training quarters at Gale's Ferry.

Warrants are out for the arrest of Maurice Meyer, proprietor, and H.S. Loewenthal, manager, of the Union Bicycle Supply Company, 68 Murray Street, which was closed up last week. They have disappeared, and the police and detectives are trying to find them. After the business was closed last week it was stated that outstanding accounts had been transferred to creditors for money borrowed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- A great banquet was given this evening by the managers of the International Commercial Congress, in which nearly 1,500 persons participated, including President McKinley, Secretary of Agriculture Wilson, Attorney General McKenna, Congressmen Dingley, Dalzell, Grosvenor, Heatwole, and Tawney; the Ministers from Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, and other South American Governments, the Chinese Minister, and Mayor Strong of New York.

There were no interruptions for the battles of the light-harness steppers yesterday, and the Spring meeting of the Parkway Driving Club brought a profitable crowd to the pretty grounds at Gravesend, notwithstanding the greater attraction at the running track near by. The picking of the winner in either of the two classes proved too much for even the best judges, and both events went to outsiders.

-- New York politicians will smile superior at the news than an Illinois Mayor is to be tried under the law which regulates and limits the expenditures of candidates for office. We have here a similar law, but such care was taken to make it of no practical effect that the very idea of a prosecution based upon it is amusing.

Justice Andrews, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday denied the application made by the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Railroad Company to continue the temporary injunction granted recently in its suit against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and others.

Adjt. J.C. Ludgate of the Salvation Army last night broke his own record of fifty-one hymns in sixty minutes, but failed in an attempt to make it sixty hymns in sixty minutes. All the queer people and remarkable events of the world get to New York sooner or later. Adjt. Ludgate came here from Chicago and announced himself as the "champion long-distance singer of the world."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 2. -- Princeton defeated Brown University in a baseball game to-day by a score of 23 to 10. The game was interesting chiefly by reason of the Tigers' heavy hitting and clever base running. Both teams made frequent errors, but the Brown's were more costly. The Tigers knocked Brown's three strongest pitchers out of the box before the sixth, when Third Baseman Lander was tried, and held Princeton down well.
LONDON, June 3. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Times says:
VIENNA, June 2. -- By order of Emperor Francis Joseph, Count Badeni, the Austrian Premier and Minister of the Interior, has declared the session of the Lower House of the Diet to be closed.

Mr. LABOUCHERE probably means well in respect to the British proceedings in South Africa; but he does not do very well. The other day he was compelled to retract charges which he had published against one of the witnesses, for the reason that he could produce no evidence to sustain them.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 2. -- The old blue laws of this State were invoked yesterday in Justice Collins's court in a case of a suit for damages. The case was that of Crane against Hetfield. Both were riding bicycles. Hetfield, it was asserted, ran into Crane and damaged his bicycle to the extent of $25. Crane asked damages for that amount.

Little Helen Wheatley, or "Fairy," as she was called by every one who knew her, was the light of the neighborhood. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wheatley, had lived at 513 West One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Street for only three weeks, but that was long enough for the golden-curled girl of six to enshrine herself in the hearts of every one in the neighborhood.

The five victims of the Valley Stream disaster will be buried to-day. The funeral services for Leslie J. Roberts, George F. Pashley, Jr., and Winslow W. Lewis will be held at the Greene Avenue Baptist Church at 2 o'clock. The Rev. Dr. D.C. Hughes, pastor of the Pilgrim Baptist Church, and the Rev. Dr. Frank M. Ellis, pastor of the Washington Avenue Baptist Church, will officiate.

People at the Brooklyn race track yesterday who were looking for a sensation found it when Sir Vassar won the handicap at a mile and an eighth. It was only on Monday last that this same Sir Vassar gave all the racegoers a surprise by winning a hurdle stakes at a mile and three-quarters, beating a fine field of jumpers with the greatest of ease.

The Executive Committee of the United States Casualty Company, which two weeks ago declined to accept further burglary risks, met yesterday and decided finally to withdraw from the burglary insurance business.

The election of officers was the principal business at yesterday's session of the Grand Lodge of Freemasons of the State, now holding its one hundred and sixteenth annual communication at the Masonic Temple. It was expected that, with the exception of the contest on the Deputy Grand Mastership between Wright D. Pownall and James B. Gillie, the regular ticket would be elected.

The Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club is making golf a leading feature this season. The game has become so popular with the members that additional facilities were found necessary. The lease of the Clove Road links makes it the only club in the country possessing two golf courses. The club now has facilities for Sunday golf.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- When the Tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day, Paragraph No. 149 relating to penknives, razors, , was the subject of immediate consideration.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 3. -- The June crop report issued to-day by the Board of Agriculture shows that the condition of growing wheat has advanced four points to the good since May. Clover and timothy meadows are overrun with white top, and potatoes are rotting in the ground.

Probably the strongest anti-Bryan force now at work in the country is Mr. BRYAN himself. Common stories about him are in the air. Some of the most curious come from Ohio, where the Democrats have been trying to organize and unite for the Fall campaign against HANNA.

A house warming of the new rooms of the West Side Republican Club of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District was had last night at 1,047 Sixth Avenue. Speeches were made by Mayor Strong, Senator Pavey, City Chamberlain McCook, Assistant Corporation Counsel Clark, John Sabine Smith, and Lucius E. Chittenden.

In view of the explicit statements and promises made by the leaders of the Citizens' Union at the first meeting of its Committee of Organization some months ago, it seems strange that at this date THE TIMES should feel obliged to utter warnings against deals and submit the arguments in favor of immediate and independent nominations.

The two great complaints against the reform administration in this city are: First, that the taxes are higher than they were under Tammany administration; and, second, the interference by the Legislature and the police with the rights of the people. The former in passing the Raines law, and the police for arresting persons without cause and for stooping to low cunning to obtain evidence against saloon keepers and others.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Mr. Terry (Dem., Arkansas,) rose to a question of privilege as soon as the journal had been approved in the House to-day. His question of privilege, he said, vitally affected the rights and privileges of the House.

It would be a good thing if the Music Teachers' National Association, which is soon to convene in this city, would seriously consider the so-called record set up by Adjt. LUDGATE of the Salvation Army. It does not seem that there is any other body competent to decide on a matter of this kind, and it does seem that this record is open to question.

The following letter on the subject of tariff on linens has been addressed to Chairman Aldrich of the Finance Committee of the United States Senate by Mr. Mark Finlay of the linen importing house of Lamb, Finlay Co., this city:
The crowd had increased to about 4,000 persons when the second game began. Umpire McDermott came on the field just as the two teams were about to line up for play.

Three coffins, each covered with lilies, roses, and smilax, were borne into the Greene Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, a little before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and placed reverently in front of the flower-laden pulpit platform. These coffins contained the bodies of Leslie J. Roberts, Winslow W. Lewis, and George F. Pashley, Jr., victims of the tally-ho calamity at Valley Stream.

Yesterday was "Cy" Seymour's day to shine at the Polo Grounds. The erratic young left hander has not had a chance in the box since the poor showing he made in the two games he pitched on the club's Western trip. He had a task yesterday that would have bothered any pitcher.
LONDON, June 3. -- A case of much interest to trades unions has taken another step in the wearisome path of legal solution.

John George of 2,155 Third Avenue was driving behind a fast horse in Jerome Avenue yesterday afternoon. At 6 o'clock he alighted and tethered his animal in front of Joseph Murphy's saloon, at One Hundred and Seventy-third Street and Jerome Avenue. A few moments later a rain squall came on, driving down the avenue a large party of cyclists.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- The estimated gross earnings of the Rock Island for the month of May are $1,202,490, an increase of $1,247 over the estimated earnings of the system for the same month of last year.

Two men were killed in the collapse of a factory building at Fifty-first Street and Twelfth Avenue yesterday morning. The victims are William Frazer of 456 Van Buren Street, Brooklyn, employed by the Otis Elevator Company of 38 Park Row, and Jacob Jacobson, a millwright, of 568 Columbus Avenue.
The Brazilian Minister made a noteworthy speech at Philadelphia on Wednesday evening at the banquet of the International Commercial Conference.

Five persons were painfully, but not seriously, injured in a somewhat peculiar accident to cable car No. 720 of the Lexington Avenue line yesterday morning at the foot of Duffy's Hill, One Hundred and First Street and Lexington Avenue. Several accidents have recently occurred at this point, and every precaution is taken in going up and down the hill, which is very steep.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- The Medical Congress, under the auspices of the American Medical Association, began the third day of its session this morning, during which the formal jubilee exercises commemorating the semi-centennial of the association were held. After some preliminary business had been disposed of Dr. Horner of Philadelphia reported in favor of the establishment of a relief association for poor and disabled physicians.

Samuel L. Post, Jr., was stricken by sudden illness on the floor of the Stock Exchange yesterday morning in the presence of several hundred fellow-brokers. He died in a quarter of an hour in the smoking room on the fourth floor of the Broad Street building. The sudden taking away created a profound impression, both among the members of the Exchange and in the Street.

A meeting of the Academy of Medicine was held last night at 17 West Forty-third Street. Dr. E.G. Janeway, President of the academy, presided, and about forty members were present. The resolution offered at the last meeting by Dr. S. Baruch -to appoint a committee to urge on the city authorities the erection of public baths -- was brought up, and evoked considerable discussion.

WASHINGTON June 3. -- The final consideration of the Railroad Pooling bill was again postponed by the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce to-day. Senator Chandler moved a postponement until Dec. 1, but the motion was not voted upon, and a compromise was agreed upon postponing the measure until the next weekly meeting.
BALTIMORE, June 3. -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage this evening made a short speech at the banquet of the Maryland Bankers' Association, in the course of which he said:

Two Brooklyn men, G.W. Hunt of 1,244 Fulton Street and Charles E. Arms of 1,368 Pacific Street, were arrested yesterday on a charge of attempted larceny and thereby, according to their account, put in a false position. Mr. Hunt presented a check on the National Shoe and Leather Bank at the bank itself, and it was pronounced worthless.
The Modry-Friedman fence feud is making history for the residents of Arverne, Long Island.

CINCINNATI, June 3. -- Afamada, a "ten-to-one shot," won the Clipsetta Stakes for two-year-old fillies at Latonia in a hard drive. Mary Black, the favorite, failed to finish in the first three. Umbrella was the only one of the six favorites that crossed the wire winner. Summaries:

Ricardo de Requsens of 66 Fourth Street, Long Island City, and Mrs. Eugenia Reineman of 158 West Fourteenth Street, partners in the Spanish-American Printing Company at 126 Maiden Lane, were arrested yesterday by secret service agents, accused of passing "forged and counterfeited notes for 100 pesos on the Bank of Costa Rica Feb. 27, 1897." They were arraigned before Commissioner Shields and held for examination June 16 in $3,000 bail each.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3. -- The International Commercial Conference held its session this morning in the Philadelphia Commercial Museum Hall. A number of addresses were delivered by foreign delegates, all of which related to the commercial, banking, and industrial conditions prevailing in the respective countries represented by the speakers, and in all of which suggestions were embodied looking to the increase of trade with the United States.

It is a peculiarly Spanish trait that the Government should he brought to a dead-lock because one of the Ministers slapped the face of one of the members of the minority in the lobby. M. CONSTANS had occasion a few years ago to slap the face of a French Deputy, and that not in the lobby, but in the Chamber itself.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3. -- The police are avowedly mystified regarding the death of Isaac Hoffman, the wholesale clothing dealer, in his Battery Street office, but as the investigation proceeds, the circumstantial evidence against Theodore A. Figel, the bookkeeper, has become so strong that he has been placed under surveillance.

We trust that the Hon. EDWARD MURPHY, Jr., whom some of our readers may recall as a Senator of the United States from New York, has received his copy of the letter of Mr. MARK FINLAY, which we publish this morning, and which has been sent to each of the Senators. If not, we would call his attention to it in print.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 3. -- In his annual report State Insurance Superintendent McNall declares that the foreign insurance companies doing business in Kansas during the past twenty-five years have taken out or the State and invested elsewhere over $22,000,000 over and above losses. He advises the enactment of laws that will compel investment of this money in Kansas securities.

Lowenfeld Prager have sold to George W. Eggers the plot northwest corner of Second Avenue and Ninety-fifth Street, 100 by 100. The buyer will improve the property by the erection of five flats. The same firm has purchased from Mary A. Bowe the old buildings 386 East Fourth Street, on a plot 17 by 98 by 27 by 90.

Many of the college racing men entered for the championship bicycle meet which takes place at the Manhattan Beach track to-morrow are expected to arrive at the course this afternoon. A majority of them may take trial spins before darkness sets in, in which case there is sure to be a crowd to watch their movements.

J. Edward Simmons, Vice President of the Chamber of Commerce, presided at its monthly meeting yesterday in the absence of President Orr, who is visiting the Yellowstone Park, and Vice President Jesup, who is in Europe.

The armored cruiser Brooklyn sailed yesterday for England, where she is to represent the United States in the naval demonstration attending the Queen's Jubilee celebration. The Brooklyn carries the flag of Rear Admiral Miller, and was chosen to represent our Government as being the finest vessel of the armored cruiser type afloat.

HONOLULU, May 24. -- The Government announced to-day that its answer to Japan's demands had been sent to the Japanese Minister. Minister Shimamura is not at all satisfied with the reply made by the Hawaiian Foreign Office. In an interview upon the subject he said:

DOVER, Del., June 3. -- William N. Boggs, paying teller of the First National Bank of this town, is a defaulter in the sum of $38,000. The peculations have extended over a period of ten years, but the shortage has been covered up by false entries that escaped the eyes of the Bank Examiner.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Postmaster General has awarded to the Starin Transportation Line of New York the contract for performing the newly instituted New York harbor mail service. This provides for a vessel to carry the mails from Quarantine station to the Government pier near the Battery, to the Pennsylvania Railroad station at Jersey City, and to a point adjacent to the Grand Central Station in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C.,) made a motion in the Senate to-day to discharge the Committee on Contingent Expenses from further consideration of the resolution recently offered by him to investigate the relations between the Senate and the Sugar Trust.
DENVER, Col., June 3. -- The Rev. Myron W. Reed, President of the National Brotherhood of Co-operative Commonwealth, of which E.V. Debs and Henry D. Lloyd are the chief promoters, said to-day:

MADRID, June 3. -- A Cabinet council was held to-day. The Queen Regent presided. The retiring Premier, Senor Canovas del Castillo, made a long statement regarding Cuba, the Philippine Islands, the internal situation, and the relations between Spain and the United States, which led to his resignation.

Two hundred delegates to the International League of Press Clubs were at the Gravesend race track yesterday afternoon as guests of the Brooklyn Jockey Club. They will go away from town with a queer idea as to the sort of weather that is dished up for the inhabitants of Greater New York. When they left the city on Manhattan Island it was hot, muggy, sticky, and enervating.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 3. -- Fire destroyed Bryan's Fertilizing Mill on the river front shortly after midnight, and raged with great fury for about eight hours, causing a total damage of from $450,000 to $500,000, partly insured. The entire block, bounded by the Strand, Duke, Union, and Prince Streets, was almost completely wiped out, only one warehouse with its contents being saved.

ALBANY, June 3. -- Inspector Gatchell of the State Railroad Commission, who was detailed to investigate the fatal tally-ho coach accident on the Long Island Railroad, has returned here, and will submit his report in a few days.

The college bicycle races at the Manhattan Beach track this afternoon will form he most important contests a-wheel that have even been managed by the Intercollegiate Athletic Association. This is the second year in which the riders have had a tournament apart from the at'hletic events which annually attract thousands of college men and their families.

Capt. Burton was a voluminous writer, and in the intervals of his long wandering up and down on the face of the earth he found time to produce something like fifty books, several of them too large for a single pair of covers, and one requiring ten for its accommodation. His death was far from putting an end to the tide of Burton literature.

John Vincent Brown, fifty-two years old, of 227 High Street, Brooklyn, and William Harrigan, forty-seven years old, of 130 Prospect Avenue, also of Brooklyn, both keepers of the Kings County Penitentiary, were badly injured in an open trolley car accident which occurred on the Flushing Avenue line, near Fulton Street, yesterday morning, at 6:15 o'clock.

The decision of Justice Andrews, that the defendant in an excise case before the Court of Special Sessions may apply for a transfer of his case to the Court of General Sessions and secure trial by jury, has caused a great deal of comment among court officials, the police, the Excise Department, and the liquor dealers.

There are reminiscences of Prof. Drummond to be found in the United States, and many letters of his. Prof. George Adam Smith is to write Drummond's biography. Any persons having letters of Prof. Drummond or other matters of interest connected with his work are invited to send the same to Prof. Smith, 22 Sardinia Terrace, Glasgow.
WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

Henry James's latest volume is written in that exquisite English of which he is master. His material is scant, and he spins with his usual fineness. A mother, a son and two young women of the "upper middle class" appear in this tale. The study of character is Mr. James's single aim, and the result is pleasing to one's finer senses, intangible though it all be.

For the first time in the history of the real Columbia University Library, its splendid and varied collection of books will not be available to students and others engaged in special literary research this coming Summer. This will be a serious loss to many who have found the spacious Columbia Library reading room a delightfully cool and convenient place in which to do literary work or perfect one's information in some particular subject.

Mr. GAGE has repeated and emphasized at Baltimore, before the Maryland Bankers' Association, the "prophecy that both sides of Congress would soon put through an adequate tariff and the promise that the Administration would be faithful to the task imposed upon it of putting the currency of the country on a sound, enduring, and solid basis."

URBANA, Ohio, June 4. -- Two men were killed and two fatally wounded and seven others less seriously injured at 2:30 o'clock this morning by shots fired by a company of the Ohio National Guard in defense of Charles Mitchell, a negro in jail at this place. In spite of the militia the mob finally entered the jail and lynched the prisoner.

If the people of this community believed in the Raines law as a proper method of regulating the liquor traffic they would deplore and might resent the construction which Judge ANDREWS has given to it. Because, manifestly, the effect of that decision is to render to a considerable extent inoperative some of the sections of that law to which its authors attached the greatest importance.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- J.C. Dennison, Secretary and Treasurer of the Union Stock Yards and Transit Company, blocked the investigation of the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday by refusing to produce before the commission the books and records of his corporation.
The New York Baseball Team, with the assistance of Umpire McDermott, wrested a victory of what was about to prove a defeat in the last half of the ninth inning yesterday.

This romance, by an annonymous writer, is strongly put together. It deals somewhat with the vexed subject of heredity. The hero comes of an unknown origin, and is at outs with the world and his surroundings. He achieves success, indifferent somewhat as to the means, and then, broken by his troubles, succumbs, cared for by the woman he had forgotten.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Senator Allison, who, in the absence of Senator Aldrich, has charge of the Tariff bill, expressed the opinion to-day that the sugar schedule would be reached in its order on Monday, and that it would be taken up then if Senator Aldrich, by that time, should have so far recovered as to be able lo take charge of the schedule on behalf of the Republicans.

Tammany concluded its series of monthly meetings for the Summer season last night by issuing a long statement, setting forth the issues it is going to make its fight on this Fall and roundly denouncing the Republican Legislature and the present Municipal Government. Its General Committee met in the main hall of the Wigwam. There was only a fair attendance of the members.
The seven-story building at 155-157 Broadway, occupied by a number of important insurance agencies and other business offices, was in very serious danger for a few minutes yesterday morning.

Louis Blum, sixty-five years old, of 112 Suffolk Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Mott in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of violating the bottling law. Blum is a sexton in a Jewish synagogue, and was instructed to erect a canopy for ritualistic purposes.

That is a very instructive contrast which the dispatches report from Ohio and from Virginia. The lightness with which the violent taking of human life is regarded in the South has been, time out of mind, a theme for Northern moralists. It has been the rule in particular that negroes plausibly accused of criminal assaults upon white women have not been suffered to undergo a legal trial for their offense.

John K. Cowen, one of the receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, arrived at the Waldorf last evening and talked vigorously concerning the published reports that at a meeting, held Tuesday, President Thomson of the Pennsylvania, and Mr. Depew forced the Baltimore and Ohio to maintain rates. Mr. Cowen said:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 4. -- The proceedings of the Lower House of Arkansas Legislature this afternoon partook more of the nature of the secession convention held in this vicinity in 1861 than of the ordinary transaction of business by a body of lawmakers of the people of a great State.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Senate had a period of speechmaking to-day, and as a result little progress was made on the Tariff bill. The advance covered about two pages or seven paragraphs, and brought the Senate up to the wood schedule, the first item of which was considered, but not completed.

ALBANY, June 4. -- The Civil Service Commissioners announce to-day that they have completed the revision of the civil service rules to make them accord with the new law, and the revised rules were presented to the Governor to-day for his consideration. The details of the rules will not be made public until after the Governor takes action on them.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- A morning newspaper to-day says Chicago will fight the gas companies' consolidation and frontage laws at home. The citizens' committee of 100 is preparing to ask the Council to pass an ordinance before July 1, when the Frontage and Consolidation bills become laws, granting to the Citizens' Gas Company a franchise for electric and gas lighting in every street and alley of the city.

May we not use Mr. Howells's application of Rudyard Kipling's poems as catching the keynote of them? "His is the lustiest voice now lifted in the world, the cleanest, the bravest, with the fewest false notes in it." As to the false notes, you want them in the Kipling verse, just as a discord or a clang helps music at times.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- The International Commercial Conference, begun here on Tuesday last, held its final business session this morning. The report of the committee on nominations, which was as follows, was unanimously adopted:

Anna Eva Churchill, three years old, who lived at Rockaway Avenue and Avenue L. in Canarsie, died yesterday morning from an attack of convulsions, into which the sight of an unknown man sleeping in the kitchen of her parents' home threw her. The man is a painter of the name of Edward Mason, who lives at 4 Rivington Street, in this city.

Frederick M. Cutler, who was one of the organizers of the Columbia University Young Men's Christian Association and for two years its General Secretary, has resigned and been succeeded by George D. Orner, class of '99. Mr. Cutler is now studying theology in the Union Theological Seminary, and is also pursuing a graduate course in political science at Columbia.

Miss Pool has her marked individuality, never more conspicuously shown than in "Mrs. Gerald." Judith sprang from degenerates. Her father was without principle and her mother silly, but the girl possessed those stronger and better traits which her parents lacked. One thing the author shows is a nice sense of humor.
Corporation Counsel Scott delivered to the Sinking Fund Commission, at its meeting yesterday, an opinion on the right of the city to acquire the Sixth and Eighth Avenue Railroads.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4. -- The final exercises at the Naval Academy incident to the graduation of the class of '97 took place to-day. The battalion marched to the chapel at 10:30 o'clock, where an address was delivered by President Wilkes of the Board of Visitors, who gave some excellent advice to the graduates.

Her are short stories pertaining to a land Mr. Roberts knows as well as, if not better than, any other that now writes. He takes us to the lumber camp of the far Canadian frontier. He is not only familiar with outdoor life, but with the rude, toiling men who people sparsely those wild forest places.

We all know that a woman can build a bonnet, that she can adorn and decorate a house inside, but it has rarely occurred to us that she could build the largest house in New York! We are slow to believe in woman architects, we were slow in an effort to try to educate them; had we been more enlightened we might have had as many architects as we have milliners and dressmakers.

The Republican Conference Committees from the four organizations in the counties included in the Greater New York territory have been called to meet at 8 o'clock Monday night at the New York Republican County Committee's headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Attorney General has directed suit to be brought against the Traders' Live Stock Exchange of Kansas City, Mo., under the act of Congress of July 2, 1890, known as the antitrust law.

Senor CANOVAS is reported to have expressed himself as deeply disappointed at the failure of his overtures of conciliation and reform to secure response from the people of Cuba. His chagrin is not based upon reason. Spain has made not only offers, but solemn pledges, to Cuba before, and has failed to keep them.

-- Instinctive appreciation of the incongruity of "Senator" when placed before "HANNA" is what must be the explanation of the reluctance manifested by many papers to give the Ohio man the designation of his official rank. It takes something more than an election or an appointment to make a title really stick, and it is not entirely a matter of record, ability, or character.

Another extended work, of fiction from Mrs. Harrison is sure to be awaited with interest. Her "Sweet Bells Out of Tune," "A Bachelor Maid," and "An Errant Wooing" made impressions that were real The present story Mrs. Harrison has had in mind for several years, but has been actually writing it only during the year just past. It is a Colonial tale, historical in its coloring and its incidents.

BOSTON, June 4. -- Dr. Samuel J. Allen, who is under arrest at White River Junction, charged with shooting H.M. Duffer of Montpelier, was found guilty of killing Dell Hansel in a saloon on Howard Street, in this city, and on Feb. 4, 1885, was sentenced to serve five years in prison. The deed was committed during the previous May.

The reader of to-day whose knowledge of books goes back twenty years must often have been surprised with the change that has come over books intended for Summer reading. This is true not only of their literary quality, but of the printing and binding.

To those who study history through biography, the record or Mrs. Gibbons's long, industrious, and eventful life will prove a treasure. See represents to posterity the spirit of a large number of woman who, according their varying characters and temperaments, lived plain lives, practised homely arts, and gave themselves to public duties with energy and cheerful good sense.

A maximum temperature of S1 degrees placed yesterday on record as the hottest day thus far in 1897. There has been no warmer day on June 4 since 1890, when the mercury rose as high as 88. The contrast with the cool weather of the early week made the heat more felt, while the humidity, varying from 85 per cent, to 95 per cent., was well nigh overpowering.

More churches in New York and Brooklyn are to maintain services uninterrupted by hot weather than heretofore. In some cases clergy from country pulpits or from cities in the West have a chance for a New York hearing while the regular occupants go either to these country or Western pulpits or to seashore and mountain region churches that are kept open only during the Summer.

Fifty men -- being members of the Citizens' Union's Committee on Labor and Social Reform, and labor leaders of Brooklyn and New York -- met in Room 22, Cooper Union, last night for a secret conference. They placed a guard at the door, and stationed several policemen on the outside.
Regarding exchange market conditions and gold export prospects, Mr. Charles Schumacher of C. Schumacher Co. said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:
The surviving victims of the Merrick Road tally-ho accident were all reported doing well yesterday morning.

The author of the "Reveries of a Bachelor" and of "Dream Life" long ago made himself dear to many minds. What he once said of Irving is measurably true of him also -- he has taught a nation to love him. Those volumes of his are among the best known works in our literature. Mr. Mitchell's present work is something more than a history of our early literature.

There is a suspicion of hyperbole in the statement telegraphed from Chicago that the soldiers at Fort Sheridan have been fed on beef hearts and beef liver 365 consecutive days. The men have now placed themselves in the position of Arthur Clennam in the eyes of Mr. F.'s aunt. They have shown their proud stomachs and refused to eat any more beef hearts or liver.

The applause accorded "The Red Badge of Courage" is still ringing in the public's ears. The high quality of Mr. Crane's literary work has been universally conceded. "The Third Violet" is a departure from scenes of camp and strife, and is a study of artistic life, the theme carried out with not alone originality and force, but with much humor.

The foregoing lists have been prepared with special reference to their adaptability as Summer reading. Many works of much popularity and special utility have been necessarily excluded; the purpose in making the selection was not so much to provide instructive books as to provide those which would entertain.

The Rockaway second polo team defeated the Meadowbrook team yesterday at the Westchester Country Club, thus winning the Country Club tournament and the cups awarded by the club. The Country Club men had already been severely beaten on Tuesday at the hands of the Meadowbrook players.

The Academy of Medicine was actuated by the right spirit when it adopted the resolution urging the erection of public baths in this city. Such baths are not only a luxury, but a necessity. Of course there are obstacles in the way of the full accomplishment of their usefulness, for it is generally conceded that those who need bathing most are least fond of it.
The Ways and Means Committee of the Massachusetts House of Representatives has reported a bill for a State tax of $1,750,000, of which the City of Boston is expected to contribute $628,740.

M. Boissier's book is a substantial contribution to our understanding of the history of Rome and the condition of Roman society in the days of Marcus Tullius Cicero. The French Academician plainly found his task a genuine labor of love, for in every line of the book there glows a genial spirit, which makes its scholarship an easy grace and its adroit collation of facts a cheering pastime.
Hoffman Brothers and J.N. Kalley Son have sold for Warren E. Dennis, for about $100,000, the new seven-story building, 39 Great Jones Street, 27 by 100.

One may not rattle along with Ernst Grosse's "The Beginnings of Art." To appreciate the learned professor of the University of Freiburg on acquaintance you must be something of an archaeologist and an ethnologist.

It is reported that the Citizens' Union has decided to nominate SETH Low for Mayor. It is reported, too, that President Low wishes the Union to hold off until assurances can be had that he will also be nominated by Mr. PLATT'S Republican Convention. The first report has good authority, the other has seemingly no authority at all, and we do not believe it.

In this volume Mr. Wise relates some of his hunting experiences. But the book purports to give the observations, traits, and experiences of an English setter a written by himself. His entire career from birth until death, a period of twelve years, is unfolded. After his early education has been completed the dog tells of rabbit hunting, quail shooting, and sport with grouse, snipe, woodcocks, prairie chickens, and turkeys.

The cable has already given to the public an outline of the ceremony attending the unveiling of the monument to Sir Walter Scott in Westminster --Abbey. English papers to hand a few days since contain full reports, and readers will be glad of these, and especially glad to read the several speeches in full. The bust immediately adjoins the florid monument of the Duke of Argyll and is in sight of the monument to Shakespeare.

MADRID, June 4. -- Senor Sagasta, the Liberal leader, after conferring with the Queen Regent at the palace to-day, said he had told her Majesty that the Liberals were prepared to deal with all pending questions. Public opinion continues to favor a Sagasta Cabinet.
Twice a year the question what books to buy assumes formidable proportions in every reading community -- once when the Winter holidays are at hand, and again when the Summer season begins.

WHEN "Secret Service" was modestly brought into town last Fall no one imagined that it would run all Winter, become the most talked-of play of the year, and create a furor in London in the Spring. There was a vague idea that the play had failed somewhere before its advent here, and naturally no one expected an "epochmaker."

John Brooks Leavitt yesterday specified the charges of being controlled by political "pulls" which he made, in a general way, about the Department of Buildings and Superintendent Stevenson Constable in a speech before the Citizens' Union of the Fourth District on Friday evening.
The State Suffrage Association is sending out circulars to the women of New York, of which the following is the substance:

A BUSY man is Ernest Neyer, the leader of the Seventh Regiment Band. He is a New Yorker by birth and could therefore qualify as a member of Mr. Franko's American Symphony Orchestra. But he has not time in these days to be a member of any other person's orchestra.

THE "chappies" in "The Whirl of the Town" at the Casino are the devoted admirers of one Evangeline Earlybird, a sprightly and melodious but utterly irresponsible young woman, who proclaims herself Queen of Gay Broadway.

BERLIN, June 5. -- Several unusual features occurred during the great Spring parade on the Tempelhof Grounds last Tuesday. By the rigorous police measures barring all traffic from the streets leading to the Tempelhof, the public was virtually excluded from this sight, which for many years has been a popular diversion.

THE Brooklyn Institute made a valuable acquisition to its art department when it received the large painting known as "The Shepherdess," the gift of Abraham Abraham, at a meeting of the Board of Trustees held Friday, May 14.

MONTREAL, June 5. -- A hitch has occurred in connection with the coming local celebration of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee on June 22, which may have the most serious consequences, and which, in any event, will arouse a bitter feeling between the English Protestant and French Catholic sections of the city.

Nothing has happened for a long time calculated to give a more vivid notion at once of the wealth and of the public spirit of New York than the progress of the subscription for a new building for the Chamber of Commerce. There is some form of returning the subscribers bonds for their subscriptions, but that must be a mere form.

The absolutely essential examinations for a degree at Oxford are Responsions, Moderations, and Final Schools, colloquially termed Smalls, Mods, and Greats. The first of these is the only examination that is the same for all, for the man who will have difficulty in scraping a Pass degree, and for the future winner of the Hertford or Ireland, the blue ribbons of Oxford scholarship.

BERLIN, June 5. -- A new and important political office has been created, that of Political Commissioner, whose province is to watch and influence by all possible means political feeling in disaffected districts, such as the Polish provinces, the Reichsland, and Northern Schleswig-Holstein. Four such Commissioners have been appointed, at Dantsic, Konigsburg, Posch, and Breslau.

Charles W. Frederickson for many years -- at least twenty -- was one of the most familiar figures, as he was the most picturesque figure, in the book auction rooms of this city. Having retired from business, he became a devoted collector of rare books, and the auction rooms were his camping grounds.

The examination in the case in which Richard M. Scruggs, seventy-six years old, member of the St. Louis dry goods firm of Scruggs, Vandervoort Barney, and Edmund G. Langhorne, his private secretary, are charged with smuggling jewelry and other articles into this port, was continued yesterday morning before United States Commissioner Shields. Assistant United States District Attorney Hinman appeared to prosecute, and the defendants were represented by Gen. A. P. Ketchum.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- The soldiers at Fort Sheridan are complaining bitterly of their food. Beef hearts and livers might be endured occasionally, they say, but when they constitute the bill of fare 305 days in the year they insist it is time to protest. Consequently, the troops at the garrison are in a state of open revolt.
Farming is not profitable.

Walter Stewart, a negro, nineteen years old, of 40 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, was shot in the left breast about midnight Friday, and died shortly afterward. He also received a severe cut on the head, caused by falling against the stone steps.
Our newspaper must be truthful, clean, and wholesome.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 5. -- Justice Wilmot M. Smith of the Supreme Court has fixed June 19 at Patchogue as the time and place to hear arguments in the demurrer in the suit of the Montauk Indians, through their Chief, King. Wyandank Pharaoh, against the Long Island Railroad to recover the Peninsula of Montauk, the end of Long Island.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5. -- By making the most exciting finish ever witnessed at a baseball game in this city, Yale managed to land the game from Princeton this afternoon. Camp tied the score for Yale after two men were out in the ninth, sending in Fincke ahead of him by a long home run.

John B. Doris will open the Casino Roof Garden to-morrow with a bill composed of burlesque, ballet, and other specialties, said to be sufficiently good of its kind to attract the theatregoers that want variety.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- There was more trading on the Exchange to-day than for months past. The cables were especially strong. West Chicago was the most active. Good buying orders from investors and also from parties willing to take a flier, as well as the room traders' speculation, made a lively market. Account was 3/4 under regular, showing the speculation.

W.L. Stow -- The market has at last started on the upward tack. Get the Cuban matter out of the way and the situation will be cleared of almost every depressing factor. We may have some little reaction from today's level of prices, but the tendency is, and will remain, upward. Things generally are better, railroad earnings are improving, general trade is improving, the feeling among manufacturers and merchants is improving.
PITTSBURG, June 5. -- It is more than probable that the big strike at Jones Laughlin's south side mills will be broken on Monday morning, as it is announced that the mill will then start up.

Inspector General of Rifle Practice Kirby, after getting the opinions of Regimental Inspectors of Rifle Practice, has decided upon some radical changes. The annual Fall matches at Creedmoor will not take place until after the annual contests under the auspices of the New Jersey' State Rifle Association, at Sea Girt.

Columbia University's racing cyclists swept everything before them in the second annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes, held at the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon. In every event except one her representatives captured first and second, and in the half-mile race Columbia's riders finished, one, two, three.
The unexpected happened again yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds. But this time it was the visitors and not the New York who pulled out a victory in the ninth inning.

With the exception of a slightly soft track and turf, the rain of yesterday morning did not affect the Spring games of the New York Athletic Club, at Travers Island, yesterday afternoon. Fully 5,000 invited guests swarmed on the grand stands, over the terraces, and on the clubhouse verandas.

Undoubtedly more mothers than fathers have proved kind and faithful, but the fact remains that millions of loving, honest fathers have gone down to their graves unsung and almost unnoticed, while the universal paean to the mother has filled the ears of the world. Thus, in one of the largest modern collections of quotations there are thirty-six which glorify the mother, while not a single one is dedicated to the father.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 5. -- Many of the prominent manufacturers of Cleveland were interviewed yesterday on the condition of business. The interrogations developed that there is a very noticeable improvement in the business situation. While business has not reached the volume of output or given employment to as many as before the last three years of depression, there is nevertheless an improvement.
LOWELL, Mass., June 5. -- A heavy track prevented fast time at the third meet of the Spindle City Wheelmen at the Fair Grounds this afternoon.

About the end of January, or when the sun again appears above the horizon, many families at the two Eskimo villages near Point Barrow, in Alaska, leave their Winter houses and travel inland seventy-five or one hundred miles to hunt reindeer along the upper waters of the large rivers that flow into the Arctic Ocean east of the point.

LONDON, June 5. -- Conflicting news is published about the progress of the peace negotiations at Constantinople. On one side the Sultan is said to have adopted a most unyielding attitude, and on the other hand he is declared to be showing a conciliatory disposition, and that the settlement of the questions in dispute is only a matter of a few days.

Central Park, in the vicinity of the Ramble, was the scene of great excitement shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Hundreds of children were playing near the lake, and one of them fell in. Women screamed, and men looked on helplessly, until a passer-by jumped in, and after struggling with the drowning boy, managed to pull him ashore.

Senator Thomas C. Platt came over from Washington last night to talk with President Quigg of the Republican County Committee and other lieutenants over the local political situation. Mr. Quigg spent two or three hours with the Senator, and he will have another long talk with him this morning.

The specific charges against the present municipal administration in the Tammany address are amplifications of those already made by SHEEHAN in his individual manifesto. These have been answered by the heads of some of the departments chiefly concerned. No doubt a comprehensive and candid examination of the whole body of them by disinterested experts is desirable. The result of

Here is Jules Lemaitre's latest explanation of the doctrine of Henrik Ibsen: "What Ibsen preaches is love of truth and hatred of falsehood, the rights of individual conscience as opposed to written laws, and a great human morality as distinguished from the pharisaism of the middle classes.

The work of the American Museum of Natural History for the past year is reviewed in the twenty-eighth annual report recently submitted by President Morris K. Jesup to the Trustees of the Museum. The report tells of the great interest taken in the Saturday morning lectures to public school teachers and in the evening lectures given by Columbia University in co-operation with the Museum.

The acquittal of VON TAUSCH would be startling enough in itself. But it is made more startling by the simultaneous conviction, for a second time, of his tool, VON LUETZOW. The coincidence cannot fail to excite suspicions of the administration of justice in Germany. Considering that VON TAUSCH was committed for manifest perjury on the order of the court, the acquittal is astonishing.

Crossing the Delaware River below Port Jervis, the tourist comes to a point of land upon which a rude stone monument marks the spot where the States of New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania join. Some years ago official representatives of the three States attended the ceremony of erecting this stone, which is suitably inscribed and is known as the Tri-States Monument.
UTICA, June 5. -- The State Intercollegiate Athletic Union is formed by Colgate, Hamilton, Hobart, and Union Colleges. The final score was: Union, 57 1/2; Hamilton, 36 1/2; Colgate, 10; Hobart, 9.

Fire burned out the three upper floors of the five-story brick building 161 Pearl Street shortly before noon yesterday, doing about $18,000 damage to the building and stocks of different tenants. The blaze started in the rear of the third floor, where two women employed by the Lion Polish Company were mixing the ingredients used in the manufacture of russet polish.

A new President of the United States Golf Association will be elected this coming week at the Executive Committee meeting to be held Thursday. Laurence Curtis, now the First Vice President, will probably be elected. He is a Boston man, a member of the Stock Exchange in that city, and a member of the Brookline Country Club and the Essex County Country Club, at Manchester, Mass.

I once spent some months on a cotton plantation down in Mississippi. Fastened to the top of the gin house was a large bell. It had been the custom on this plantation, even before war and up to the present time, for all hands to go to work and quit work by the sound of this bell. The bell rang at 6 A.M., 12 M., 1 P.M., and 6 P.M.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- Florence Clark is in a cell in the County Jail, charged with the larceny of a $1,000 bond of the Union Traction Company. Her accuser is Mrs. John Hatrick of 229 Walnut Street, and the arrest is a sequel to the domestic troubles of Mrs. Hatrick and her husband, who is also in jail.

AMONG other things that have been changed in order to keep abreast of the times is the nomenclature of the clouds. While there has not been much difference in the appearance, a necessity has for a long time been felt for a better designation of the different kinds.

THE last commencement exercises that are to be held in the old Columbia University buildings will begin this week. The senior classes in the different departments of the university will graduate, the commencement examinations will be held, and then preparations will be made for moving to the new university buildings, which are fast approaching completion on the upper west side of the city.

Two "killers" and a huge swordfish, (Xiphias,) desperate with hunger, had combined their forces and ventured to attack a half-grown bull cachalot. Nothing, I am persuaded, but the direct necessity and pressure of want could have prompted them to undertake so grave a conflict, although it must needs be confessed that their combination was a powerful one.
LONG BRANCH, June 5. -- The Shaw cottage on Chelsea Avenue will be occupied this season by Jacques Guttman of New York.

THE graduating class of naval cadets, Naval Academy, the members of which will receive their diplomas from "the greatest naval school in the world," is a markedly interesting body of young men. Five of its fifty-one members are "star" cadets, and several others look this honorable position almost squarely in the face.

Sensational charges are made in connection with a suit brought in the Supreme Court by Cornelia B. Granget, the nineteen-year-old granddaughter of Mrs. Barbara Sigrist, to compel her grandmother to account for the rents and income of a considerable amount of real estate in this city and in Brooklyn, left by her grandfather, Theodore Sigrist, who died intestate on Nov. 10, 1875.
" I am so sorry to leave, and I shall miss it so much," said a young Normal College girl of the graduating class one day last week to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 5. -- President Ashley W. Cole of the State Railroad Commission said this morning: "The statement that the Long Island Railroad is exonerated from all blame in the matter of the accident at the Merrick Road crossing is entirely without foundation. Mr. Gatchell's report as Inspector has not yet been given the commission.

" Mamma wants two quarts of your best liquid air, and she says that the last you sent had too much carbonic acid gas." It is not impossible that before many years the corner grocer will hear such requests as this, writes George B. Waldron in The Illustrated American, and, what is more, be able to supply them.

LONDON, June 5. -- Sydney Grundy's new play, "A Marriage of Convenience," will be produced at the Haymarket this evening with the following cast: Comte de Candale, William Terriss; Chevalier de Valelos, Cyril Maude; the General, Sydney Valentine; Jasmin, Holman Clark; an officer, Clarence Blackiston; Comtesse de Candale, Winifred Emery; Marton, Adrienne Dairolles.

Probably self-distrust is one of the readiest causes of failure. A man who, however much he conceals the fact from observation, feels in his heart of hearts that he is not capable of doing the work that he has undertaken, is almost sure to fail. Ordinary diffidence as to one's powers is quite another matter, and by no means a necessary impediment to success.

ST. AUGUSTINE, June 5. -- Much excitement exists to-night over the report of the lynching of a negro named Isaac Barrett, near Orange Dale, in this county, early yesterday. Barrett worked for a man named Hewson, and, according to reports, he attempted to murder the family and assault the daughter. Hewson's family consisted of himself, wife, two young children, and a girl of eighteen, named Maggie.

That tally sticks were at one time pretty general may be concluded from the derivation of the word score. In its original signification, a "score" is a "scar," a cut made in a counting stick. So also a "tally" is derived from the French taille.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- On the opening of the Senate to-day a letter from the Secretary of State was received transmitting a letter from the Minister of Austria-Hungary, Baron von Hengelmuller, protesting in behalf of his Government against the discriminations of the sugar schedule in the pending Tariff bill against bountied sugar.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Senate Committee on Civil Service to-day resumed its nearings, Capt. Pratt, Superintendent of the Carlisle Indian School, continuing his testimony. He criticised the civil service system in the Indian Service, saying that, long as he had been in the work, he doubted whether he could pass an examination.

As "good phrases are surely, and ever were, very commendable," perhaps we ought to be thankful for "zoophilous women." It is certainly not a "vile phrase," as Polonius said of "beautified," and it means something. Moreover, the definition given of it in the address of the Medical Congress to the United States Senate is not without some sort of authority.

Martha Stiritzo, the three-year-old and only child of Pietro Stiritzo of 123 Chrystie Street, was run over and killed last night while playing in front of 184 Chrystie Street. With several other children the little girl was playing in the street, as it is the only place they have.

Thomas C. Smith, the proprietor of a large porcelain establishment in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a charge of unlawfully receiving public moneys.
In his regular weekly financial review in London Truth (just received here) Mr. Henry Labouchere says:

The chief symbol of Russian religion is the universal icon, that unique sacred picture which is everywhere in evidence. Artistically, the icon is unlike anything familiar in other lands. It is a picture containing no painting whatever, except the face and hands. These are painted either rudely, or with fair skill, or exquisitely, as the case may be.

The Citizens' Union Committee on Labor and Social Reform needs looking after by somebody of sense and sober judgment. Its first conference with the labor leaders was so badly managed that the men it wished to placate went away in a huff, and in the discussions and the resolutions of the conference of Friday night there was a somewhat rank flavor of Socialism.

An instructive comparison of the method and influence of direct and indirect taxation may be instituted by supposing the two systems to be put into practical operation under similar circumstances, for effecting a purpose which all are willing to admit is most desirable or necessary. For example, a town meeting is held to provide means for building a bridge.

DENVER, Col., June 4. -- Enormously rich strikes of silver ore in the famous Mollie Gibson and Argentum-Juniata mines, at Aspen, have been the features in Colorado mining circles for ten days past. In consequence of these discoveries, the shares of these mines have advanced enormously.

Nicola Tesla, the electrician, says that he has practically perfected an apparatus by which telegraphic messages can be transmitted without the use of wires. After experimenting with this object in view for several years, Mr. Tesla now believes that he has found a way of sending messages in any direction, and to any distance, with no other medium that the electrical currents.

Had they been men they would not have met. But as they were girls, they did meet, and had a just too lovely time, hugging, kissing, and telling each other what they had seen since they parted, tearfully, yet joyfully, in America.

Crowds are expected at the Aquarium to-day to see the whales "spout." Whales do not really "spout." They simply blow, or breathe out through the blow hole, and if they happen to be submerged at the time, the water is blown up like a spout.

LENOX, Mass., June 5. -- June in Lenox will be a most interesting month for out-of-door sports. While golf will be the leading sport for a great number of the people, considerable attention is being given to boating and trout fishing. Trout-fishing parties are common, and some of the young women are becoming quite proficient with the rod and line.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Next to their liking for a President who makes himself popular here in the capital, the people of Washington like a President who goes abroad with cheerfulness and frequency. The people of the National capital are exacting about the conduct of the occupant of the White House, but the occupant who yields to the more reasonable of the exactions of his neighbors, will not have a very difficult task.

" Chand d'Habits," the wordless play Beerbohm Tree has imported from France and produced, with no great effect, seemingly, at his theatre in London, is not original with Catulle Mendes, whose name is announced as its author. Pierrot was first imported from the Italian stage to the French by an actor of the name of Gaspard Duboureau, about the beginning of the century.

A branch of the work of the League of American Wheelmen in which every cyclist takes an interest is the erction of guide signs. If this is pushed systematically, says an observing admirer of the league, it will do as much toward strengthening the already powerful organization as any other one thing that can be thought of.

PARIS, May 25. -- Society in Paris seems doomed to remain for an Indefinite time in mourning. The Prince de Sagan has just had an apoplectic stroke, and his recovery is despaired of. This grievous event, following so closely upon the catastrophe at the Charity Bazaar and the death of the Duc d'Aumale, puts a final extinguisher upon the season's gayeties.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 5. -- In a dissenting opinion rendered by Chief Justice Doster, holding that a legislative "boodle" investigating committee had power to compel witnesses to answer questions, he said: "Government by injunction and government by habeas corpus and government by the courts are really losing these contemptuous and protesting significations with which the terms were first used, and are rapidly passing into accepted theories of municipal sovereignty.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

Sir John Drummond Hay was a fine horseman, and on one occasion, having been to interview the Moorish Foreign Minister at El Araish, sixty miles from Tangier, he desired to catch the outgoing steamer which left next morning. He had arranged that four relays of horses should be in readiness for his return. On obtaining his reply he rode off.

Mrs. McLean of Brooklyn, N.Y., was a short, slight woman, and when she reached the Crystal Palace on the day of the opening the crowd completely hemmed her in. She could not catch a glimpse of a single royalty or celebrity. Tears of chagrin sprang to her eyes as she realized her disappointment and the price of it.

Despite the complaint of dullness, made almost universally by brokers, there continues to be a scattered dealing in smaller properties which, taken in the aggregate, makes a creditable showing. The only transaction of the week involving a large amount was the purchase of the southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue by J.T. Tower of Poughkeepsie for $410,000.

FORT DUCHESNE, Utah, June 5. -- Dispatches from Washington announcing the selection of Capt. William H. Beck, Tenth Cavalry, as Acting Indian Agent of Uintah and Uncompahgre Ute Indians, has created more than ordinary interest here, for the reason that other army officers who were available candidates for the position to succeed Col. Randlett, recently retired, declined the appointment of Acting Indian Agent.

On the whole, the most interesting figure in the public life of the United States to-day is Thomas B. Reed. The Speaker will hardly go down to posterity as a great American statesman. He has originated nothing; there is no great question germane to the home or foreign policy of the country which he can be said to have mastered.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 5. -- The case of Bly E. Witthaus against Prof. Rudolph A. Witthaus of New York was before Judge M.H. Hirschberg, in Supreme Court, Special Term, here to-day. Mrs. Witthaus's counsel moved for increase of alimony and counsel fees.

YANKTON, S.D., June 5. -- Mrs. Mary Sinnott, nee Vanderpool, is here seeking a divorce from her husband, who is a son of Judge James Sinnott of New York State. She charge non-support, and asks for the custody of her two children.

The official programme for the entertainment of the visiting delegation of Mexican, South and Central American merchants has been arranged by the joint committee representing New York and Brooklyn. The visitors will arrive Tuesday at 11:10 P.M., and will be escorted to the Hotel Waldorf, which will be their headquarters during their stay here.

ALBANY, June 5. -- The administrators of Mary S. Van Beuren of New York have appealed to the Court of Appeals against the denial of the lower courts to grant a mandamus to reduce to $34,000 the asessment of the personal property valued at $409,000 made by the New York Tax Commissioners.

The golf team from the Philadelphia Country Club, which paid the first visit of the year to this locality yesterday, played a spirited team match with the Staten Island Cricket Club, on the links at Livingston, but, unfortunately for the visitors, the game was practically all on the side of Staten Island, for the latter team won by the heavy score of 39 holes.

ALBANY, June 6. -- Ex-State Controller Frank Campbell, who is a member of the Democratic National Committee, arrived here to-day fresh from a conference with prominent New York Democrats. Speaking of the local elections this Fall, he said:

BERLIN, May 26. -- The boycott which the German sporting papers have been ordered by the makers of bicycles to announce against all advertisements of American wheels has already begun to react upon the manufacturers. American wheels are more than ever in demand. Columbias, Hartfords, Clevelands, Victors, and Monarchs go off like hot cakes; the local agents cannot obtain enough. Seizure of unprotected trade-marks is of no avail.
