The Commissioner of Public Works, who is not a New Yorker by birth, training, or long residence, expresses in his plan to ruin Central Park by converting the lower end of it into a treeless, asphalted waste, the cheap utilitarian "practicality" that is always in vulgar opposition to the park idea in large cities.

The baccalaureate sermon of the New York University, on Morris Heights, was delivered yesterday afternoon in the gymnasium of the university by the Rev. F.S. Schenck. D.D., pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of University Heights. The platform, which was draped with American flags and the university colors, was shared by the Faculty and the preacher. A large audience was present, largely composed of students.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- While the tariff will be the general topic of discussion in the Senate this week, what portions of it will receive attention it is impossible to predict. This uncertainty is due largely to the difficulty of determining when the sugar schedule will be taken up.

HAVANA, June 6. -- In an interview Gov. Gen. Weyler, upon his return to Havana from the scene of military operations, said the war would be ended in a short time, but just how soon he could not say, as its termination depended entirely on circumstances.

We are told by an authority whom it were unwise to dispute that "peace hath her victories." We have also been warned repeatedly that in time of peace we must prepare for war. For some years past we have been preparing for war -- or perhaps for the prevention of that stern arbitrament -- by building a modern navy.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The House has no work ahead of it this week, and it is the intention of the majority leaders to ad-journ to-morrow until Thursday and from Thursday until Monday.

The white whales at the Aquarium proved to be an attraction greater than any display which there has been heretofore at the Aquarium. The attendance yesterday was far in excess of that of any day since the place was opened in December last. On March 21 there were 17,372, and that remained the record till yesterday.

WEST POINT, June 6. -- The chapel of the West Point Military Academy was filled this morning by the cadets, the Board of Visitors, the officers and their families, and the friends of the cadets, assembled to listen to the farewell discourse of the Rev. Herbert Shipman to the graduating class, Mr. Shipman took for his text St. Matthew, xxviii., 20: "And lo I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 6. -- Edward Long, aged eighteen, a hack driver, died at his home here this morning from a bullet wound in the head, received in a brawl last night. Long was unconscious when found and expired without being able to give any information as to the cause of the shooting.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- "Pass the Tariff bill" is the word that is being passed about here just now with much greater urgency than has been observed at any time since Mr. Dingley introduced his bill at the beginning of the session. The anxiety on the part of business men to have it and the Congress out of the way is being hammered into Congress by letter and by message from day to day.
Edgar F. Hicks and John E. Lisk, Deputy Game Inspectors for Richmond County, yesterday arrested Constant Gamble and Pionani Primus, both of New York, for violating the game law.

Thirty-four members of the Midnight Sun Assembly, No. 193, a Swedish secret society having headquarters at 1,071 Home Street, in the annexed district, are busily engaged in an effort to discover the present address of a Paternal Alliance, formerly of Baltimore.

Cries of "Stop thief!" proceeding from the basement store at 27 Union Square, attracted the attention of everybody within bearing distance a few minutes before 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A moment later a tall, well-dressed young man darted up the two steps from the area to the sidewalk and ran down Union Square.

Senator Platt, Secretary of the Interior C.N. Bliss, Congressman Quigg, Commissioner of Public Works Collis, and State Insurance Commissioner Louis F. Payn were in consultation at various times and places most of yesterday, and the Citizens' movement for non-partisan municipal government was the chief matter of consideration.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 6. -- Anniversary week at Andover Theological Seminary opened to-day with the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class by the Rev. Dr. William H. Ryder. He said that the right activities of the Church consist of the inculcation of the great truths and making, them vital in Christian living. Ministers ought to be shy of the present tendency of administering churches as complicated evangelical and social machines.

If the police and special agents have made any headway in their fight against the fake hotels and the fake clubs, there were no signs of their success to be found yesterday. The places that were opened when the amendments to the Raines law made their existence possible by putting control of them beyond the power of the police were still open.

LONDON, June 6. -- The steamers Bittern and Ystroom, both bound for Amsterdam, came into collision in the Thames early this morning. The Ystroom foundered, two of her passengers being drowned. The remainder of her passengers and her crew were taken on board the Bittern, which was damaged.

Gen. James R. O'Beirne, Commissioner of Charities, delivered a lecture on "Ireland in America's Struggles," under the auspices of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul for the benefit of the Catholic Boys' Association, at the Grand Central Palace last evening. The hall was filled with a very enthusiastic audience.

The efforts of the dissolute to swear off and get out of bad company are always creditable even though weak and unconvincing. They indicate a remnant of right feeling. In protesting against the retention of Thessaly by the Turk England, France, and Italy show that they have not become wholly and hopelessly. debauched by consorting with the Czar and the Kaiser in the European concert.
LONDON, June 7. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says:

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 6. -- Daniel Mann of this city and William Mackenzie of Toronto have secured from the Canadian Pacific Railway Company the contract for the building of the Crow's Nest Pass Railway from Lethbridge. Northwest Territory, to Robson, B.C., a distance of 300 miles. It is said the work will cost from $25,000 to $29,000 a mile.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Gustave Higgins, a Swedish newspaper man and artist, offers for the sum of $5,000 to dress in a suit of Casimir Zeglen's bullet-proof cloth and allow himself, to be shot at with revolver or gun.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Cuthbert Hall of the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, preached his last sermon yesterday as pastor of the church, previous to entering upon his duties as President of the Union Theological Seminary. The occasion was also the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of the church building and its consecration to public worship. In referring to the anniversary, Dr. Hall said:

URBANA, Ohio, June 6. -- Mrs. T.M. Gaumer, who was assaulted by Mitchell, the negro lynched by the mob last Friday, to-day issued a card of thanks to her friends for their sympathy during her affliction. After speaking of the messages of sympathy she has received from many parts of the country, she concludes as follows:

NASHVILLE, June 6. -- The event at the exposition this week will be the visit of President McKinley on Ohio and Cincinnati Days. Preparations are being made to give the President a hearty and enthusiastic welcome, and all parts of the State will be represented.

This week's racing outlook at Gravesend is a particularly bright one, for, aside from the good fields which the fixed events will probably insure, the conditions of most of the over-night events are such that they should bring together horses quite evenly matched, and weighted so that good finishes should result.

ALBANY, June 6. -- Dr. James Hall, Geologist of the State of New York, will sail on June 24, in company with his daughter, Mrs. Bishop, and her two sons, for Europe to represent the geology of this State at the International Geological Congress which is to be held in London early in July.

Charles P. Scribner, fifty-six years old, of 56 Morton Street, fell from the fifth floor down an elevator shaft in 244 West Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon and was almost instantly killed. Mr. Scribner was the Secretary and bookkeeper of the Veriscope Company, which is now exhibiting the pictures of the Corbett-Fitzsimmons fight in the Academy of Music.

The protest of the Austrian Government against an import duty as an offset to an export bounty on sugar is specious, but not, we think, well founded. It pleads a violation of the most-favored-nation clause in its treaty with this country.

Alexander Rosenthal of the law firm of Hayman Rosenthal appeared before Magistrate Mott in Essex Market Court yesterday on behalf of Thomas Murphy, sixty-one years old, of 89 First Avenue, who was accused of intoxication.
OXFORD, June 6. -- The Philadelphia cricketers who are to play here to-morrow arrived about noon to-day. No one met them. They spent the afternoon quietly.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Representative Joseph W. Bailey of Texas has been hearing some talk from time to time that put him in the attitude of a candidate for Speaker of the next House of Representatives, if there shall be a majority of Democrats in the Fifty-sixth Congress, and a candidate for President in 1900.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The President has been represented incorrectly as having so fully decided upon a Cuban policy that is to be aggressive that he has prepared a message to Congress on the subject, and only awaits the return of Mr. Calhoun, his Commissioner, to communicate his policy to Congress in a special message.

LONDON, June 7. -- The Premier of Hyderabad telegraphs to the London papers this morning that the story, widely circulated, to the effect that the imperial diamond, the property of the Nizam of Hyderabad, had been stolen, is a pure fiction.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- The delegates from cities and towns of Mexico and of the Central and South American States, forty-nine in number, who came here to the Pan-American Trade Congress, which closed Friday, will leave this city to-morrow morning for their six weeks' sight-seeing tour of the United States.

PARIS, June 6. -- Samuel E. Moses, who has just completed a service of about four years as United States Consul Generai in Paris, was asked to give his impressions of the Consular Service of the United States; to say how, in his opinion, it compared with that of other leading commercial nations, such as Great Britain, France, and Germany, and what measures were in his judgment desirable for its improvement.

The Harlem River was alive with pleasure craft of every description early and late yesterday, and oarsmen in their racing shells and gigs found it somewhat difficult to pick their way along without getting into trouble.
The New York Mycological Club indulged its mycological proclivities Saturday afternoon and went away on a grand mushroom excursion.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 6. -- Paymaster Corwine, United States Navy, who has been charged with misappropriating funds of the Government, was seen to-night relative to the arrest of Thomas C. Smith, his father-in-law, at Brooklyn, N.Y., Saturday, and a charge of receiving $3,353.48 of public money unlawfully from John Corwine.

Before the Senate has finished the consideration of the Tariff bill in Committee of the Whole, and in anticipation of any effort that may be made in the later stages of consideration to exclude new matter, the Finance Committee may be directed to weigh the proposition to protect the American producer of news that is a strictly American production, advanced by labor and American ingenuity beyond the condition of raw material.

DENVER, Col., June 6. -- A dispatch from El Paso, Texas, says that Francis Schlatter, who professed to perform miraculous cures by Divine power, was found dead recently in the foothills of Sierra Madre, thirty-five miles southwest of Casa Grande, in the State of Chihuahua, Mexico.

Brian G. Hughes, a manufacturer of paper boxes at 242 Centre Street, was held yesterday by Magistrate Flammer in the Centre Street Police Court in $1,000 bail for further examination next Friday afternoon on the charge of attempting, on April 9, to bribe an Assistant Examiner in the office of the Commissioner of Accounts. He was ar-

The United States torpedo boat Porter came out of dry dock Saturday with new paint on her steel bottom, swept bare three weeks after her first trial by friction occasioned by her remarkable speed. Her final trial, it is said, will be made to-morrow, and yesterday she went to Communipaw to coal. Incidentally, to ascertain if all else were in proper form, Lieut. J.C. Fremont, in command, took her around Scotland Lightship and back.

While the Central Labor Union does not, and probably will not, take any direct political action during the coming campaign, many or most delegates are already taking sides with one party or another or with the Citizens' Union.
The stripes of the Tammany tiger are as unchangeable as the leopard's spots.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 6. -- A fire in the southeastern part of the city at noon to-day cost three firemen their lives and entailed a property loss of $100,000.
Your able leader on "Baths in the Parks" is based upon a misconception of the views and aims of the committee recently appointed by the Academy of Medicine, which I ask to be permitted to correct.
NEWARK, June 6. -- Three-year-old Mamie Mahon, the daughter of Charles Mahon, was burned so that she died in three hours at her home, 10 McWhorten Street, to-day.
" Monsteur Tonson, come again," was ejaculated Saturday by Special Deputy Collector Joseph J. Couch as he affixed his signature to a document at the Custom House.

The advertisement of a house which sells musical instruments is full of suggestions for those who desire to dream away the hot Summer in eating of the lotus that blooms in the land. This advertisement presents an alluring list of guitars, mandolins, banjos, zithers, music boxes, flutes, clarinets, violins, and cornets.

The review and drill of the Second Battery, N.G.N.Y., which went into camp at Van Cortlandt Park Saturday evening, attracted about 10,000 visitors to the park parade ground yesterday. The battery will have its annual inspection drill to-day at 10:30 o'clock by Brig. Gen. E.M. Hoffman, Inspector General of the National Guard of the State.

In one of the damage suits growing out of the Merrick Road disaster, the owner of the coach has been impleaded with the Long Island Railroad Company as one of the defendants. The degree of responsibility attaching to the owner of the coach can be determined only by the courts, but the lay mind is irresistibly forced to the conclusion that the driver of it was guilty of amazing recklessness.

The American Sportsman of Cleveland, Ohio, is only doing its duty as an advocate of the turf and the trotting track in asserting and maintaining the superiority of the horse to the bicycle. It is, perhaps, only natural, in the circumstances, that it should say cruel things about the bicycle, accusing it of immorality and other deplorable faults.

After a period of appeals to the courts and the legislative bodies of Staten Island the rival electric railroad companies of that island again met in violent conflict yesterday. As a result there was a collision between cars, the General Manager and the Superintendent of the Midland Company were arrested, a woman was shocked by a current, and a warrant is out for the Superintendent of the Staten Island Electric Railroad Company's lines.
Stephen O'Brien, a brother of former Sheriff James O'Brien, died suddenly at his home, 110 East Forty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon of heart failure.

The collapse last week of a factory in course of construction up town was attributed to the overloading of a floor by way of testing the water tanks. They were subjected to a "proof-charge" greater, very likely, than any load they would have been required to sustain after the completion of the building.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The consideration of the Tariff bill was resumed in the Senate soon after the session opened, and the discussion proceeded on the paragraph placing a duty of $2 a 1,000 feet on lumber.

Nicholson Co. have sold for the Payne-Withers estate the five-story stone-front business building 9 Murray Street, 25 by 100. The three adjoining buildings, 11, 13, and 15, are now being torn down, and it is understood that the owner of the latter site is the buyer of No. 9. On the entire plot, 100 by 100, an eight-story business building, with stores and lofts, will be erected.

It was class day yesterday at Columbia College, and the students who have just finished their course of studies entertained their friends in the Library Hall. It was the last class day celebration that will be held in the old building, and it will probably be remembered as one of the pleasantest ever held in the college.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- In the House to-day, on motion of Mr. Dinsmore, (Dem., Ark.,) the Senate resolution to permit Carlos Guttierrez of Salvador to be received as a cadet at West Point was adopted, and on motion of Mr. Morris, (Minn.,) the Senate bill to amend the act to authorize the construction of a steel bridge across the St. Louis River was passed.
A Wall Street news agency issued yesterday the following bulletin as a special dispatch from Philadelphia:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jude 7. -- The sixth of the graduating exercises of the Class of '97, United States Military Academy, took place at 5 o'clock this afternoon. It was an infantry drill, school of the battalion, before the Board of Visitors. The entire corps of 300 men were put through numerous military manoeuvres under the command of the commandant of cadets, Col. S.M. Mills.

The high schools for New York City, authorized by recent legislation, will open on Sept. 20, fully equipped, and, it is hoped, with pupils for every class. There will be one for boys in Thirteenth Street, one for girls in Twelfth Street, and one for boys and girls at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street.

It was a famous Frenchman who said, "No generalization is quite true, not even this one." The minister who on Sunday uttered a spirited protest against novel reading may have had this saying in mind when he put a saving word at the beginning of his most vigorous assertion, "Perhaps ninety-nine out of a hundred are baleful, an outrage on decency and common sense."

OXFORD, England, June 7. -- When the umpire ordered the stumps drawn for the day, on Christ Church College cricket ground, at 6:45 P.M., because of increasing darkness, Oxford was all out but 363 runs. Baily and Ralston of the Philadelphia team were still at the bat, the former having scored 5 runs and the latter 1, and neither being out.

We printed yesterday an elaborate defense by Mr. MORSS, the retiring Consul General at Paris, not of our Consular system, but of the character of our Consular representatives. It is no doubt true that the luck of the United States of America has been very largely with us in this matter.

The possibility that the "divine healer," SCHLATTER, will come to life gain, and exert more influence than he possessed before he went to seek Nirvana in the wilds of Chihuahua, must occur to every moderately ingenious person who reads carefully the account of the finding of the whitened and glistening bones near Casa Grande.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7. -- The commencement exercises of Evelyn College began yesterday with the baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Baker of Princeton. To-day was class day, the programme including the usual class day exercises, meeting of the Alumnae Association and the commencement concert.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 7. -- The State intends, through Adjt. Gen. Axline, in vindication of the militia of the State, to arrest the ringleaders of the Urbana mob and the fifty Deputy Sheriffs who withdrew from the support of Sheriff McLain. This information came this afternoon from the Third Regiment Armory here, the regiment the Urbana company belongs to.

An interesting golf event at the Ardsley Club, near Dobbs Ferry, is scheduled for to-day, the first semi-annual contest for the women's championship of the club. The match will he eighteen holes, medal play, and the winner will receive a handsome trophy.

CINCINNATI, June 7. -- Tigirene ran away with Jockey Clerico to-day and jumped over the grandstand fence. Neither horse nor jockey was hurt. The horse was scratched and a new book was made for the fourth race. Summaries:

LONDON, June 7. -- The Micronesia, a nitrate steamer, bound from Iquique for Antwerp, took fire off the Goodwin Sands from overheating and was beached near Deal. The crew were saved. The hull of the vessel became red hot; the flames of the burning material took on a singular appearance and were visible for miles.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 7. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judge Allen appointed C.M. Foreman of Nashville, Ill., receiver of the Centralia and Chester Railroad, running from Salem. Marion County, to Evansville, Randolph County, Ill., a distance of eighty-six miles.

-- When statesmen from Washington and Albany are making their weekly visits to this city, and do not care to explain what they are doing or have done, their favorite formula for refusing information is to say that they are here "on personal business." This is generally regarded as a harmless equivocation of the "not at home" order.

The Race Committee having charge of the Irvington-Millburn road race, held on Memorial Day, decided yesterday that R.M. Alexander of Hartford, Conn., against whom a charge of unfair riding had been made, was guiltless.

A freight elevator on the Park Row side of the Post Office Building fell four stories into the sub-basement yesterday morning, seriously injuring six men -- one of them, perhaps mortally. Overloading is given as the cause of the accident, for in addition to the passengers were eight bags of cement weighing 140 pounds each.

Coroner M.C. Coombs of Queens County yesterday evening began an investigation of the tragedy which occurred on Decoration Day at the Valley Stream crossing of the Long Island Railroad, where the tallyho coach, containing a picnic party, was run into by a passenger train, five of the occupants of the coach being almost instantly killed and a dozen others wounded.

Under threatening and lowering skies, and before a rather small crowd, the New Yorks defeated the Chicagos in the second game of the series yesterday afternoon. The game was not an exciting one, though both teams played good ball, and very few errors were made. Only about 900 persons were on the grounds when the game began.

The Populists have all the courage and the candor of the silver party. They have the honesty to fight under their own flag and their own name. The silver Republicans and silver Democrats make unauthorized and dishonest use of the old party names. They parade in stolen clothes.
Seth Low last night sent the following letter to the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union:...

The striking tailors held a mass meeting last evening at Cooper Institute, and the leaders seemed to be apprehensive of a stampede in their ranks to-day when the contractors will open their shops for work, and they did their utmost by persuasion and scolding to keep the men together for another week at least.

The London Times recurs to the Alaskan question in a more amenable spirit. The information it received from New York having been supplemented by the official report of Prof. THOMPSON, the British expert, it now thinks our proposal to revise the sealing regulations is "ungracious," and that acquiescence on the part of England would not be "business," inasmuch as England is under no "obligation" to amend the regulations.

ST. LOUIS, June 7. -- Three murders and several affrays were recorded here yesterday. John O'Connell and James Patten, roofers, killed each other in a controversy about religion, on Chouteau Avenue. At a party Charles Leonard shot and killed William Sherman, and motrally wounded Henry Chappell. Maud De Vere, who was shot on May 25 by Mrs. May Campbell for enticing her husband died yesterday.

" My, I'd have missed half my life before I would have given up seeing it!" said one open-eyed, open-mouthed woman at the Empire Grove, some fifty miles up the Hudson, yesterday afternoon. "I left my bread in the oven to come."

NEWARK, N.J., June 7. -- Henry Kohl, who twice stood within twenty-four hours of dying on the gallows, was released today from custody. There was a big crowd at the Court House to see the young man who for three years has stood under conviction of murder in the first degree.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 7. -- The Harvard oarsmen gave a goodly portion of their waking time to-day to their examinations, and these, with the work on the river, made the day a hard one for the men from Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The throng of Government clerks and others hurrying up Pennsylvania Avenue about 8:50 o'clock this morning were startled by the attempted murder of Miss Dorothy E. Squires and the suicide of Charles Barber, a patent attorney who had gained much notoriety of late by his eccentric actions.

PARIS, June 7. -- The latest details from Grenoble, in the Department of Isere, show that the desolation wrought by the cloudburst which caused the River Morge to overflow its banks, is far more extended than was at first supposed. The deluge of water caused enormous landslides of trees and sand from the mountains into the valley, overwhelming houses, burying cattle, and destroying other property.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The leaders of the Silver Republicans are gathering in the city for a committee meeting Tuesday. Among those already here are ex-Congressman Charles A. Towne of Minnesota, ex-Senator Fred T. Dubois of Idaho, Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota, Congressman Charles S. Hartman of Montana, Congress-M.U. Jones of Washington, and Gov. J.P. Lee of South Dakota.

LONDON, June 8. -- The Daily News recently sent a special correspondent to investigate the circumstances of the dreadful immuring tragedy near Tiraspol, Southern Russia, where the police recently discovered the bodies of six persons, members of the fanatical sect known as the Raskolniki, who had been walled up alive by Feodore Kovaleff that they might secure salvation by self-immolation.

The representatives of commercial and industrial interests in South and Central America, who have begun a tour of the industrial and mercantile centres of the United States, will be handsomely received at the Produce Exchange to-morrow. Henry D. McCord, the retiring President of the Exchange, will receive them, and several cordial addresses of welcome will be made.

The embarrassment of the Republican leaders over the plans of the Citizens' Union arises from the widely different nature and aims of the two organizations. The Republicans are manoeuvring to secure a party victory. The Citizens' Union proposes to do away with party altogether and to elect its non-partisan candidates on non-political issues.

A pretty plaintiff's suit to recover $5,000 damages from her dentist, who, she claims, injured her appearance by extracting the wrong tooth, and caused her great pain by breaking another, occupied the attention of Judge Bookstaver and a jury in the Supreme Court yesterday. The action was brought by Miss Mary Hughes of 254 West Thirty-eighth Street against the New York College of Dentistry.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 7. -- An entire section of the plant of the Standard Oil Works in this city shut down at noon to-day for an indefinite period.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Another crush of those who were anxious to see the President before his departure on the Nashville trip occurred at the White House to-day. In consequence, the President was very busy. Among the callers were Attorney General McKenna and Secretary Gage, the former to confer on a New Mexican pardon case and the latter concerning a prospective appointment in his department.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The report was heard here this afternoon that the President had been considering the form of a message to Congress asking for authority to appoint a Currency Commission, and that he would send the message to Congress June 22. The report was so definite, even to the number of members of the commission to be named, being from eleven to fifteen, as to give it the appearance of plausibility.

Breeders of thoroughbreds, who use the New York market for the disposal of their yearling stock, realized last night, at the American Horse Exchange, for the first time in several years, an adequate return for the money they laid out to raise their yearlings.
In this day's TIMES I find a communication about baths in the parks and a report on labor opposed to Waring.
LONDON, June 8. -- The Times, commenting editorially this morning, in a rather sarcastic vein, upon Secretary Gage's recent declarations as to the currency, says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 7. -- President Taylor's baccalaureate address at Vassar College yesterday is being generally commented upon here to-day. In the condensed report sent out yesterday several strong points were omitted. Following is the important part of his talk to the students:

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Ex-Congressman Frank Aldrich of Chicago is in the city. His purpose in visiting Washington at this time is to consult with Special Commissioner Calhoun respecting affairs in the Island of Cuba.

DOVER, Del., June 7. -- The First National Bank opened as usual this morning, prepared to meet a run, but the run did not occur. The Farmers' Bank here has pledged assistance, as has also the National Bank of Philadelphia through which the local institution transacts its business.

The members of the Actors' Fund of America met yesterday at Hoyt's Theatre and held their sixteenth annual meeting and election of officers. In the afternoon anniversary exercises were held at the Garrick Theatre. The following officers were elected unanimously:

LONDON, June 9. -- A dispatch to The Times from its Constantinople correspondent says that the powers, to whom Greece has intrusted her interests, show no sign of yielding either of the three points in the Turkish demand, the annexation of Thessaly, the abolition of the capitulations in the case of Greek subjects in the Ottoman Empire, or an exorbitant indemnity.

American shares were weaker in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- Illinois Central 1 1/8, to 98 3/4; Louisville and Nashville, 3/4, to 49 1/2; Canadian Pacific, 3/4, to 62 1/2; St. Paul, 6/8, to 79 1/8; Atchison, 1/2 to 11 7/8; New York Central, 1/2, to 102 3/4; Reading, 1/2, to 10 1/4, and Erie, 1/4, to 13 1/2. Erie first preferred sold at 32 1/2 and Pennsylvania at 53 3/4.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- Fred V. Vr. Pugsley, formerly a lawyer of this city, who is now said to be somewhere in New Jersey, was removed from t,he position of executor of the estate of the late Margaret J. Myers by Surrogate Dorland to-day.

The trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company upon an indictment for conspiracy, found in May of last year, was begun before Judge Fitzgerald, in Part I., General Sessions, yesterday morning, and when court adjourned for the day four men were in the jury box provisionally.
The Board of Health yesterday passed an ordinance requiring all street railways to run at least one closed car to every three open cars.

The members of the bar yesterday afternoon presented to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the First Judicial Department a portrait of Presiding Justice Charles H. Van Brunt. The portrait was painted in oils by Alfred Q. Collins. It represents Justice Van Brunt seated in judicial robes, and is beautifully framed.

ALBANY, June 8. -- The Court of Appall, in Saratoga, to-day handed down a decision dismissing the motion made to reopen the Brooklyn civil service case in the decision of which Judge Haight wrote the prevailing opinion, making more open the confidential non-competitive class.

The seventy-ninth commencement exercises of the New York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb were held yesterday morning in the chapel of the institution, One Hundred and Sixty-second Street and Eleventh Avenue. Despite the storm fully 1,200 parents and friends of the pupils attended.

BOSTON, June 8. -- The invitations were sent out last night for the great society event of the year at Harvard, and the most decidedly exclusive event of a social sort which can be found in the catalogue of happenings, the "Beck Hall Spread," as it is called.

Mr. Brundage, in his letter to The Dry Goods Chronicle of June 5, under the caption, "Some Statements Contradicted," makes a most extraordinary misstatement when he says, "The average ad valorem equivalents of the linen cloth paragraph are lower in the Senate bill than those of the House bill.
I do not speak of the general excellence of THE TIMES as a good newspaper -- this is known to all who read it.

Rain prevented ball games in all of the League cities yesterday, except Boston. Boston strengthened her hold on second place, and sent Pittsburg down another notch, to sixth place, by defeating the latter club by a score of 9 to 5.

The letter which President Seth Low of Columbia University sent to the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union Monday night attracted wide attention yesterday, not only from the members of the Union, who believe that the letter plainly means that Mr. Low will run for Mayor, but from the practical Republican politicians. When President Quigg of the Republican County Committee was asked, yesterday, what he had to say about Mr. Low's letter, he replied:

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Thirty-two states were represented at the first meeting of the Provisional Committee of the National Silver Republican Party, which met in executive session at the Leland Hotel to-day. Besides the committeemen of the various States represented, over a hundred silver Republicans were present from all parts of the country.

Mayor STRONG, in his just tribute to the police, remarks that their excellent discipline and bearing are "especially noteworthy in a body of men nearly 3,000 strong, of whom quite 70 per cent, had not been one year on the force." With this proof of the way in which good administration assimilates and perfects new material must be linked another proof of the way in which like administration can change old material.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 8. -- Judge John F. Parkhurst of Bath handed down an important decision yesterday, as referee in the five actions brought by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York against David C. Robinson and Emma A. Robinson of this city, and others, to foreclose mortgages aggregating nearly $500,000.
The annual exhibition of the work of the students in the School of Architecture, Columbia University, was opened in the rooms of the school yesterday morning, to continue throughout the week.

Sugar Trust stock provided the feature in yesterday's market. Nearly 92,000 shares of it were dealt in, one-third of the entire trading of the day. The stock advanced to 122 3/4 and closed at a net gain for the day of 3 5/8 points. There was liberal buying for all accounts; Washington shorts and room traders all scrambled to get on the long side of Sugar.

It is a shame that the delegates to the International Postal Congress, which was recently in session in Washington, are now sightseeing, not at the expense of their host, the United States Government, but of certain magnanimous citizens. It seems that Congress was asked by the Post Office Department to appropriate $200,000 to pay the expenses of the sessions in Washington and the delegates' sightseeing, and that the appropriation was cut down to $50,000.

-- Though it is one thing for the Supreme Court of Kansas to order a repudiating township to pay its bonds, and another to get the money, yet the decision itself is reassuring in that it evidences the survival in that State of a regard for honesty which Populistic antics had made a matter of some doubt.

The full report of M. BRUNETIERE'S speech at the banquet in Paris of the American University Dinner Club shows that the orator kept his eyes open during his brief sojourn in the United States. It is a pity that comparatively so few eminent Frenchmen visit this country, and that of these so few take the trouble to publish their impressions.

ALBANY, June 8. -- By its decision in the cases of Clinst and Beckman against the Third Avenue Railroad of New York the Court of Appeals to-day decided six questions of very great importance, practically making void the King's Bridge extension of the Third Avenue Railroad, upon which it claims to have spent $2,000,000.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- A fifty-million-dollar mortgage executed by the Lake Shore Railroad Company recently for extension and improvement purposes was filed here to-day. It evidences the issuance of $50,000,000 gold mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent., interest bearing, and maturing 1997.

James Whittaker, thirty-six years old, and Englishman, attempted to commit suicide by jumping from the Brooklyn Bridge early yesterday morning. While repairs were being made on the bridge promenade Monday night the north roadway was thrown open to pedestrians. Shortly before 2 o'clock Whittaker paused near the middle of the bridge and after slight hesitation climbed over the railing and started across the car track, stepping carefully over the electric rail.

The facts published in THE TIMES concerning the rebuilding of the superstructure of the Victoria Bridge at Montreal show in a striking fashion the progress of the world in such matters in the last half century. The old bridge carried a single-track railway. The new one will carry double tracks for the steam road, a double trolley track, and two footways.

HAVANA, Via KEY WEST, Fla., June 8. -- After months passed in compiling data, which is confirmed by competent, well-in-formed, impartial parties, the correspondent of The Associated Press is able to announce that in the country comprised between Cape San Antonio, Pinar del Rio, and the Jucaro-Moron military line of the Province of Puerto Principe, there are 8,000 insurgents well armed with rifles and sub-divided into small bands.

ALBANY, June 8. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided the Murray Hill Bank case, involving the rights of two sets of receivers who were appointed by different courts to wind up the affairs of the bank. Edward H. Hobbs of Newburg and Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., of Newburg, the receivers appointed by a final order of the court on Jan. 9, 1897, made the appeal together with a committee of depositors of the bank.

Thirty-five members of the Executive Committee of the Democratic Union met at its headquarters, 617 Fifth Avenue, last night and passed resolutions which were intended, a member said, as an answer to Seth Low's candidacy, to Mayor Strong's Republican speech of some days ago, and to the entire anti-Tammany programme.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Republican caucus to-day was devoted to consideration of the sugar schedule of the tariff; other features where there are differences were not reached.

The golf team of the knollwood Country Club, near White Plains, which played its first team match last week against the Tuxedo Golf Club, coming off victorious, met the Fairfield County Golf Club of Greenwich yesterday, on the Knollwood links, and won a second victory. The Fairfield team was beaten by three holes, the scores standing 20 holes for Knollwood and 17 for the visitors.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 8. -- On Monday last it was officially announced at Athens that the Turks in Epirus were guilty of abusing women, defiling churches, and engaging in general pillage, and it was further announced that the Turkish irregulars had committed similar excesses in the villages around Larissa.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- W.J. Calhoun of Illinois, the Special Commissioner sent to Cuba by President McKinley, arrived from New York this afternoon at 4 o'clock. He went immediately to the State Department, where Judge Day, the Assistant Secretary of State, was awaiting him, and together they proceeded to the White House.

Miss Ida Dent Wright, once the affianced bride of Gen. Antonio Ezeta, at the time he was Vice President of Salvador, was quietly married to Dr. Walter E. Seymour, a young physician of Boston, in St. Chrysostom's Chapel, Seventh Avenue and West Thirty-ninth Street, at high noon Monday. The Rev. Canon John Harris Knowles of St. Chrysostom's conducted the ceremony, which was very simple.

An article appeared in your issue of June 5 giving an account of an action brought by Lawrence M. Kortright, in which the facts are so incorrectly stated that they apparently reflect upon the latter gentleman. Therefore, as his attorneys, we would be obliged if you would publish a correct statement of the facts, which are briefly as follows:

At a meeting of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund held yesterday Controller Fitch presented a report on the plan of the Dock Department for the improvement of the North River water front north of Gansevoort Street. The estimate of the cost of the work as proposed by the Dock Department was $11,327,640.

Joseph Richardson, a wealthy and eccentric capitalist and contractor, died shortly after noon yesterday at his home, at Eighty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, after a period of unconsciousness lasting forty-eight hours. He was attacked by heart disease some weeks ago, and this disease, with complications following, proved fatal.

JOLIET, Ill., June 8. -- The citizens are divided in two factions over the action of the Council in ordering that all vagrants found about Joliet be shackeled with ball and chain and put to work cleaning the public streets. The Chief of Police obeyed the order, and yesterday a "chain gang" was the attraction all day on Jefferson Street.

Theodore Lindner Schulte, the Swiss passenger on the steamship Veendam, which arrived Sunday, who disappeared from the Holland-America Line dock in Hoboken at about the moment. Inspectors Coffee and Kennedy discovered that his trunk had a false bottom containing 7,000 glass eyes, appeared at the Barge Office yesterday and demanded his trunk.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 8. -- At the annual diocesan convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church the Rev. Chauncey Brewster of Brooklyn, N.Y., was elected Bishop Coadjutor by the clerical delegates on the eleventh ballot. The lay delegates are now holding an election, and it is thought they will confirm the choice of the clergymen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- Rain seriously interfered with the class day programme at Vassar College to-day, compelling the use of the college chapel for the exercises instead of the lawn east of the college, as was intended. The largest attendance of friends of the students in the history of the college is here this year, and the chapel was thronged.

PONTIAC, Ill., June 8. -- A serious labor riot occurred at Minonk to-day. The coal miners there have been on a strike since May 1. During last week a few men have been working against the wishes of the majority.

In addition to the specific statements of Secretary GAGE, which have been so encouraging, our dispatches and others from Washington, authorized at the White House, show that the Administration is aroused to its duty in the matter of the currency.

Company E of the Eighth Regiment, the only bicycle company in the National Guard, have planned to make a trip of 500 miles on their wheels. They want to demonstrate that they are able to stand as much fatigue as the regular army. All the men in this company are expert riders, and capable of standing a long journey. They have won every prize in the last two years for which they have competed.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- A match carelessly dropped by one of the workmen in the fireworks factory of M. Shure, at West Van Buren and Halstead Streets, caused a terrible explosion a few minutes after 6 o'clock to-night.

The Republican caucus sugar schedule is a slap full in the face at Senator ALDRICH. He it was who took this important part of the tariff scheme into his own hands and so changed its terms and the rates as to frighten, disgust, and madden several of his Republican associates.

The meetings of the Brooklyn Jockey Club have been noted in past years for the bad racing weather which attended them, so when the 2,000 "regulars" who braved yesterday's storm arrived at the Gravesend track and found it as uncomfortable a place to be as one could find in a month's search, and the track ankle-deep in mud, they said nothing, but accepted the condition of things as a matter of course.

PATERSON, N.J., June 8. -- Dr. Edgar A. Keeler died at his home, in Little Falls, last night, after a long illness that interested physicians in all parts of the country. His troubles began about five years ago. He was able to be about his duties until January, 1895. Up to that time the nature of his trouble had not been determined.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- As soon as the consideration of the Tariff bill was resumed in the Senate to-day, Mr. Allison (Rep., Iowa,) requested that the sugar schedule be passed over.

A correspondent yesterday called attention to the frivolity and absurdity of the charges made by some members of the Central Labor Union against Col. WARING. According to one of them, "organized labor would be opposed to Col. WARING" as a candidate for Mayor, and for this opposition two reasons were given.

It was upon a most inhospitable night that the merchants from Mexico and Central and South America, who are visiting the United States as delegates from the leading commercial bodies of their countries, were welcomed to the metropolis of North America. Seldom has such a dreary night as that of yesterday been known here at this season of the year, with its cold, misty rain and wind.

On Friday last 225 graduates of the grammar schools were examined at the Teachers College for the ten scholarships annually offered by Mr. Joseph Pulitzer. The subjects included in the examination, which was in writing, were grammar, dictation, reading, composition, American history, geography, and arithmetic.

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 8. -- It was long after dark again to-night when the Yale crew finished their row on the Thames, and the work was fully as hard as yesterday's, although the crew did not cover the four-mile course. An improvement in the form was noticeable though slight.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8. -- The Brooks, Butler Co. banking corporation has gone into voluntary liquidation, and Herbert Brooks has established an office from which all depositors will be paid in full.

The sale of thoroughbred yearlings, the produce of the Woodburn, Runnymede, Hartland, McGrathiana, Dixiana, and Larchmont Stock Farms last night was not productive of the big prices, nor did such a high average obtain as at the sale of Monday night. The weather was, in a measure, responsible for this, for few of the turfmen cared to travel from their headquarters, near to race tracks to the city, in the mud and rain.

Mr. Low's letter is a demand for more light. The pith of it lies in this sentence: "I must have much more evidence than I now have of the popular desire to make it seem to me to be a public duty to become a candidate." If he were convinced of the popular desire for his nomination and that his candidacy would unite the friends of good government in the city, he would accept.

We have no desire to influence in any way the course of Judge CHESTER in regard to the case now before him under the Lexow law, commonly called the anti-trust law. But certain points were brought out by counsel touching the constitutionality of that law which are of general public interest quite apart from the merits of the charges against the coal companies.

OXFORD, England, June 8. -- At the close of the second day's play of the cricket match on Christ Church grounds, between the visiting team of Philadelphia cricketers and an eleven representing Oxford University, the Americans had scored 163 runs for seven wickets. Lester, with a well-played 72 runs to his credit, was not out, and King was not out for 6 runs.

OXFORD, England, June 9. -- Rain fell all last night, and this morning the pitch was swamped. A conference was held between Capt. F.H.E. Cunliffe of the Oxford University eleven and Capt. George S. Patterson of the Philadelphia eleven, with the result that they decided not to resume the cricket match between the two teams.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Senate Committee on Finance has agreed upon a number of additional amendments to the agricultural schedule, the most important of them relating to fish, as follows:

In the coldest and most disagreeable weather ever recorded for June in this vicinity, the representatives of the commercial organizations of Mexico and South and Central America received their first impressions of New York City. Some of them remarked, as they felt the first touch of the cold, raw air yesterday morning, that they had no idea New York was so far north.

MATAWAN, N.J., June 9. -- The annual commencement exercises of Glenwood Collegiate Institute were concluded last evening in Glenwood Hall. On Monday evening the primary oratorical contest took place. A committee of judges awarded the first medal to Miss Ann Avery and the second medal to Miss Mary Bushnell.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 9. -- One of the largest and most influential delegations, representing many millions of money that ever waited upon any Government met Sir Richard Cartwright, the Hon. W.S. Fielding, and the Hon. William Patterson this evening. The delegates represented the combined lumber interest of the Dominion, as well as all the leading Canadian banks.

The present attitude of our lawmakers toward capital is one of the great causes of the business depression in all parts of the country. The business world has been and is being paralyzed by legislation. Legislators are pressing down upon the business community with the iron fetters temporarily in their possession.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Senate Committee on Territories to-day after a somewhat prolonged investigation agreed to report back the nomination, of M. H. McCord to be Governor of Arizona, with a favorable recommendation. The committee did not divide on the vote, but two or three members reserved the right to oppose confirmation in the Senate if so disposed after further investigation.

LONDON, June 9. -- William Waldorf Astor gave his second reception at his home in Carlton House Terrace this evening. It was preceded by a dinner party, at which forty guests were present, including Prince Alexander of Teck, Ambassador Hay, Mrs. Hay, and Miss Hay.

ANNAPOLIS, June 9. -- Gov. Lowndes was in long and serious consultation with Secretary of State Dallam and Gen. Wilmer this evening, after hearing of the lynching to-day of Andrews at Princess Anne. He was much incensed at the conduct of the mob, and the injury such acts give to the good name of our State.

When Judge Fitzgerald adjourned his court, Part I., General Sessions, yesterday afternoon, eleven men had been accepted provisionally as jurors to try the case against the American Tobacco Company's officers and Directors, who are under indictment for conspiracy. It is expected that a jury will be sworn this morning, and the case opened.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Mr. Calhoun, the President's special Commissioner to Cuba, had another conference with the President this morning. Owing to the fact that Mr. McKinley was to leave at noon on the trip to Nashville, Mr. Calhoun went to the White House at 9:30 by appointment. He was accompanied by his secretary, Mr. Fishback. They remained with the President about three-quarters of an hour.

The General Council of the Reformed Episcopal Church, the highest legislative body of the Church in the United States and Canada, met yesterday in the First Reformed Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, of which the Rev. W.T. Sabine is pastor.
We have a suggestion for ex-Mayor SCHIEREN, who is in charge of the visiting merchants from Mexico, Central and South America.
Stock market strong.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., June 9. -- William Andrews, the young negro, accused of felonious assault upon Mrs. William D. Kelley, was taken from the Sheriff here today and beaten into insensibility, then hanged to a tree by an infuriated mob, immediately after having been arraigned in court and sentenced to death for his crime.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 9. -- Notwithstanding the rain, the session of the Reformed Church Synod here was well attended to-day. The work was finished, and the Synod adjourned permanently until next year.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

LONDON, June 9. -- The election yesterday in the East, or Petersfield, Division of Hampshire for a successor in Parliament to the late W. Wickham, Conservative, who was returned without opposition at the last election, resulted in the election of the Conservative candidate, W.G. Nicholson.

Hall J. How Co. have sold, for Francis M. Weeks to John O'Connor, two lots on the north side of One Hundred and Ninth Street, 150 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue, each 25 by 100. The buyer will improve the property.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 9. -- George M. Davie, State Chairman of the National Democratic Party, to-night issued an address calling a State Convention of gold Democrats to be held in Louisville July 14 to nominate a candidate for Clerk of the Court of Appeals, the only State office to be filled in November, and for which the Populists and silver Democrats have already made nominations.

ALBANY, June 9. -- Superintendent of Public Works G.W. Aldridge within the next few weeks will take active steps in establishing a system of telephonic communication on the canals for which purpose the Legislature has appropriated $100,000.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., June 9. -- There is a brilliant array of legal talent gathered before Judge Forbes to try the contested will case of Catherine Ellerson against Dr. Elizabeth Pope-Westcott. The action involves the disposition of an estate valued at $100,000, which formerly belonged to Munroe Westcott of Oneonta, who died in 1891.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- The demoralization in passenger rates between Chicago and St. Paul shows signs of increasing, and if a atop is not put to it in a short time there will be a regular rate war between the roads. Some of the most conservative lines in the West have determined that the demoralizing tactics of the small lines must cease or a war in passenger rates will be the result.

It is a very good thing that the contempt of the fashionable women of Paris for the fashionable poltroons who, at the burning of the Charity Bazaar, saved their own lives at the expense of the women, should have found an effective expression. Two women so openly showed their contempt for one of the chevaliers, Count ROBERT DE MONTESQUIOU by name and title, as to sting him into "doing something."

ALBANY, June 9. -- A decision was handed down by the State Railroad Commission today dismissing the application of Joseph Goulden, President of the Taxpayers' Alliance of the North Side of New York City, requesting the commission to compel the New York Central to provide better freight accommodations on its Harlem Division in that part of the Twenty-fourth Ward of New York City which embraces Tremont, Claremont, Mount Hope, and West Farms.

The second session of the Coroner's inquest in the case of the deaths of George F. Pashley, Jr., Winslow W. Lewis, William Gilchrist, Dora Bertsch, and Leslie J. Roberts, who were killed in the tally-ho accident at the Merrick Road crossing on May 31, was held yesterday in Odd Fellows' Hall, Inwood, L.I., by Coroner M.C. Coombs of Queens County, beginning at 9:30 A.M.
Instead of advising the Citizens' Union to "go slow," why not call upon the Republicans to hurry up?

The one hundred and forty-third commencement of Columbia would be an event of local interest and importance even if Columbia were of no more account as a place of education than it was half a century or even a quarter of a century ago. But the most interesting fact about the institution is the surprising advance and the surprising expansion which it has taken within the last few years.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 9. -- To-day has been commencement day in Peekskill for its largest three schools. First, the Ladies' Seminary of St. Gabriel's, under the Sisters of St. Mary; second, the Mohegan Lake Military School, and third, the Peekskill Military Academy.

PARIS, June 9. -- All Paris is talking tonight of the duel with swords fought this afternoon between two members of the old nobility, Count Robert de Montesquieu and Henri de Regnier, at Neuilly le Vallois, growing out of a remark made by Mlle. Heredia, the sister-in-law-of de Regnier, a few days ago in the salon of the Baroness Alphonse de Rothschild.

CONSTANTINOPLE, June 9. -- It is expected that strong pressure will be needed to overcome the resistance of the Turkish Government to the retrocession of Thessaly. Reports that Great Britain is opposing on religious grounds Turkey's retention of Thessaly are being circulated here with the view of exciting Mussulman fanaticism.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union was in session at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, until nearly midnight last night, working on the report which it will make to the Committee on Organization of 250 to be held next Tuesday night. Fifteen out of twenty-five members of the Executive Committee were present at last night's meeting.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange had a three hours' session last evening. Much of the time was occupied in discussing the report of the special committee, of which President Eames was Chairman, appointed to receive suggestions in regard to the "ticker" service. The committee was appointed because the present contract by which the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company receives the quotations on the payment of $30,000 a years ends June 30.

The decision of the Court of Appeals declaring void the franchise granted to the Third Avenue Railroad Company by the Board of Aldermen leaves the matter exactly where it was two years ago. The decision is based on the grounds that the franchise was practically for more than one railroad or extension, and the law ordains that each extension be built under a separate franchise.

The Exploration Fund of England and the United States, which I have formerly presented to your readers for support, must now earnestly appeal to an interested public. Under Prof. Petrie we closed another successful season in May; discovering the uniquely valuable remains of an edifice of the remote fifth dynasty, with furniture, implements, ornaments, , to illustrate that era.
The Republican Senate caucus on Tuesday as called to arrange for a solid party vote on the tariff, and the leaders say that it succeeded.
LONDON, June 10. -- The latest advices from Constantinople deny that the powers are advocating direct negotiations between Turkey and Greece.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Consideration of the Tariff bill was resumed in the Senate to-day at 12:15 P.M. No mention was made as to the time of taking up the sugar schedule, and the debate proceeded on the agricultural schedule.

It is doubtless true that a great many Cubans have obtained American certificates of naturalization under false pretenses. They have not in good faith meant to become residents and citizens of the United States. They have meant to provide themselves with other protection than their status of Spanish subjects gave them in case their activity in Cuban politics should get them into trouble.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9. -- Mining men are discussing the strange stories which come down from Hawthorne, Nevada, about the arrest for housebreaking there of Mining Experts Hague and Alexander Womble. They have been held to answer, released on bonds, and their trial set for July 7.

At the American Horse Exchange last night W.B. Fasig Co. began a sale of harness-racing stock that will continue every evening this week. There was quite a crowd present when the lot from Cloverdell Farm, at Colmar, Penn., came first under the hammer. Some of the undersized yearlings went cheap, but the infant steppers that had size and substance caused some spirited competition.

LONDON, June 9. -- The agent of Lloyds at Swansea telegraphs that the story told by the crew of the French schooner which has arrived there is untrue and originated in the schooner picking up an empty rowboat having no name upon it.

The first volume of the romance of GEORGE L.P. STONE, Ensign, United States Navy, seems to have ended in a manner not wholly unsatisfactory to the hero and heroine. The means taken by the "heavy father" of all romance to crush the hero and his sympathetic friend, Ensign OSBORNE, have failed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9. -- New actors in the persons of thirty sturdy oarsmen from the University of Pennsylvania appeared on the scene to-day, to share the stage with the Harvard crews, who have for the past week held the centre. Great difficulty was found in getting the shell into the boathouse, owing to the latter being built at right angles to the boardwalk that leads from the shore.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 9. -- The writ of quo warranto issued by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court yesterday at the solicitation of Lawyer R.T. Stout, who represents twenty-five business men of this city who contend that the recently adopted license ordinance is inoperative because of the unconstitutionality of the act incorporating Asbury Park, will, it is thought by many, prove a boomerang to the investigators.

AUSTIN, June 9. -- The introduction in the House to-day of a resolution providing for the appointment of a committee to investigate the management of the State University in this city created much excitement.

Filled with hopes for fair weather, after the last few days of chill and rain, the committee having charge of the Long Island Associated Cycling Clubs' twenty-fivemile handicap is looking forward to a record-breaking contest Saturday. This can be realized only in the matter of time, for the entry list comprises but seventy names.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- It is reported that the Illinois Central has completed negotiations for the sale of $7,500,000 of stock to an English syndicate. At a special meeting the company was authorized to issue $10,000,000 of additional shares, making the capital stock of the road $60,000,000.
HONOLULU, May 24. -- The Hawaiian Government on the 3d inst. formally refused to renew the exclusive cable contract, awarded to Z.S. Spaulding eighteen months ago, and which expired June 1.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 9. -- This is the most completely deadlocked and tied-up city in the United States. It does not know "where it is at," what its legal status is, or how it must appear before the Supreme Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9. -- The attorneys for Hoffman, Rothschild Co., who assert that Isaac Hoffman was murdered, have engaged, among other experts, Daniel T. Ames, who has given a written opinion that the signature of Isaac Hoffman on a receipt for $9,500, an important document in the case, was forged.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 9. -- Rosinante, one of the most formidable candidates for the Latonia Oaks, was cut down in the fourth race at Latonia to-day, and win not be able to race for some time.
J. Pierpont Morgan was among the passengers on the White Star Liner Teutonic, which reached port just before noon yesterday. He was accompanied by Mrs. J.B. Morgan and Miss Ursula and two servants.

HAVANA, (via Key West,) June 9. -- The passenger train which leaves Havana for Matanzas daily at 6 A.M. was blown up with dynamite this morning about twelve miles from the city by a party of insurgents. According to the official account, the object was plunder, as about $6,000 was in the express car.

Columbia University held its one hundred and forty-third annual commencement in Carnegie Hall last night in the presence of the Trustees, Faculty, and students of the university, friends of learning prominent in educational circles, and several thousand invited guests. Simple and impressive exercises were observed.

WEST POINT, June 9. -- Following is the standing in general merit of the graduating class and the branch of service to which the members will be respectively assigned as announced by the Academy Board tonight:

The healing of the breach which has existed between Philip J. Dwyer, President of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, and David Gideon since the running of the famous dead heat between Banquet and Ramapo at the Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club in 1894 was the chief topic of conversation among the thousand people who made their way through the heavy rain to the Gravesend track yesterday.

Forty-eight hours of idleness was not enough to curb the ambition of the harness racers that are at Fleetwood Park this week. When the Spring meeting was finally started yesterday the horses went at their long-delayed engagements with such vim that after fourteen heats only two of the three classes were decided.

WEST POINT, June 10. -- At dress parade to-night, which was the last one for the graduating class, there were some impressive incidents. One was the weird playing by the band of the familiar air "Home, Sweet Home," and concluding with "The Girl I Left Behind Me."

The lynching of a negro in Maryland on Wednesday adds complications to the problem which such acts of lawlessness set before the country. Lynch law usually becomes the resort of people who believe that properly enacted laws do not adequately punish malefactors. These people are generally a minority in the community to which they belong.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- James T. Loyd, who was recently elected to succeed the late Representative Giles of the First Missouri District, took the oath at the opening of the session of the House to-day. The Democrats applauded Mr. Loyd.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., June 10. -- President McKinley's journey toward Nashville, where he will arrive to-morrow, has been a comfortable one for himself and the party invited to accompany him. Excepting one brief speech by the President at Staunton on Wednesday afternoon, there have been no formalities more fatiguing than handshaking and bowing.
LONDON, June 10. -- The fourth biennial sale of the Prince of Wales's hackneys and harness horses was held this afternoon at the Prince's stud farm at Wolferton, near Sandringham, Norfolk.

" Commencement days" have come in spite of the unseasonable weather, and there was a time when the impulse to hail the "sweet girl graduates" and the young men standing on the threshold of their careers was rarely resisted, and quotation of KINGSLEY'S irritating quatrain was as common in the daily newspapers at this time of year as in the spoken addresses of the experienced to the girl students about to lay aside their books.

We should greatly like to know what JOHN SHERMAN in the remoteness and quiet of the State Department thinks of the attitude of his party toward the Trusts which he used to denounce so savagely and against which he aimed the blank cartridges of his anti-Trust law.

BOSTON, June 10. -- New England was visited by a storm last night which, from the amount of damage done, has become one of the worst in many years, although, according to official records, the actual amount of rain was not unusual. Most of the rain which fell came down with great violence at intervals between the hours of 4 o'clock P.M. and midnight.

Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Commissioner of the Department of Public Works, is quite willing to accept the bronze figure of the god Pan which has been rejected by the Park Board because an appropriate place could not be found for it in Central Park.
E.H. Ludlow Co. have sold for L. Napoleon Levy to John R. Suydam the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 12 East Forty-first Street, 20.10 by 98.9.

Lexington Avenue cable car No. 30, in charge of Gripman Curtis Stevens of 1,119 First Avenue, coming down town on Lexington Avenue at 6 o'clock last night came to an abrupt stop between One Hundred and Fourth and One Hundred and Fifth Streets, owing to the wedging of the grip in the slot, and three women were thrown from the car to the pavement and seriously injured.

JACKSONVILLE, June 10. -- A big colored camp meeting near St. Nicholas, below here, was thrown into a panic the other night by the flashing in the sky of the searchlights of the cruisers Wilmington and Vesuvius. The latter was at Mayport, at the mouth of the river, and the other here. The negroes, when they saw the light, fell prostrate and began confessing their sins, crying out that the Angel Gabriel was coming.

ALBANY, June 10. -- Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn to-day made public the report of Chief Examiner Isaac Vanderpoel, of an examination made by him of the Norwood Insurance Company of New York, which showed the condition of the company on April 30, 1897, to be as follows:
Gen. Tomas Estrada Palma, head of the Cuban Junta, received a letter yesterday containing news of a character highly satisfactory to the patriots.
I read at the close of your leader of the 8th, under the subject heading "Unsafe Elevators," "In what except Providence does a passenger put his trust when he enters an elevator?"

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- Prof. Hinton's patent baseball pitching gun was a decided success to-day. Eight strike outs, one base on ball, one wild pitch, and four safe hits are the record in three innings to-day in the first fair test of the machine's practicability in an actual game.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- It is Senator Pettigrew's intention to offer his anti-Trust amendment to the Tariff bill at the end of the sugar schedule, and the manner of its acceptance is beginning to be a matter of speculation among Senators.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Mr. Calhoun was at the State Department again to-day and had another long conference with Assistant Secretary Day. This being Diplomatic Day, the Spanish Minister, Senor Dupuy de Lome, was among the callers, and had an opportunity to exchange views with the special counsel in the presence of Judge Day.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 10. -- The following gifts have been made to Vassar College:

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The Senate to-day emphatically refused to adopt the amendment to the Tariff bill offered by Mr. Cannon of Utah, providing for an export bounty on agricultural products. Mr. Tillman of South Carolina made the proposed amendment the subject of a speech, in which he pleaded for the farmers of the country in characteristic fashion.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 10. -- Gov. Johnston received a telegram this morning from Sheriff Fulghum of Huntsville, Ala., saying that a mob of 200 men had captured a freight train at Decatur last night and started to Huntsville to lynch the two Decatur negroes, Lewis Moore and Claude Neville, who are charged with criminally assaulting Nellie Lawton, white, age thirteen, and who were sent to Huntsville for safe keeping.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 10. -- The Board of Trustees of Hobart College met this afternoon in Library Hall, with a full attendance. The committee from the board appointed last January to nominate a candidate for the Presidency of the college presented the name of the Rev. Robert Ellis Jones, rector of All Angels' Church, New York, to succeed former President Potter, resigned.

The Engineering Record has instituted an investigation on its own account into the failure of the iron framework of the unfinished building at Fifty-first Street and Twelfth Avenue. It finds that only cast-iron columns were used, and that the connections of them at the floor lines were very imperfect and dangerous.

The United States torpedo boat Porter on Sunday made the record of a mile in less than two minutes, and forty-two miles in one hour and fifty minutes with scarcely an eort. Yesterday she made the circuit of Long Island in faster time than it has ever been made before, and successfully passed the most severe tests that had ever been given a boat in her class.

-- In the country it is considered almost criminal not to be on terms of friendly intimacy with one's neighbors, simply because they are neighbors and without any reference to congeniality of tastes, habits, or education. New York has outgrown this village trait, and associates are selected here for other reasons than mere propinquity.
Mr. Samuel R. Shipley, President of the Provident Life and Trust Company of Philadelphia, said yesterday to a representative of The New York Times in discussing business conditions and prospects:

The County Committee of the Purroy or Home Rule Democracy held a meeting at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street, last night, to define the attitude of the organization in the pending municipal campaign. The meeting, which was surprisingly large and fairly bubbling with enthusiasm, unanimously committed the Home Rule Democracy to support Seth Low for Mayor, without, however, mentioning him by name.

NEWPORT, June 10. -- G.W. Garrison of New York to-day rented Mrs. George Tiffany's cottage on Clay Street and Narragansett Avenue. Mrs. and Miss Garrison will arrive soon for the season. The Tiffany villa is one of the largest and best known of Newport houses.

I read your editorial yesterday on "Col. Waring and Labor," and I am really surprised that you should dignify the utterances of a few delegates to the Central Labor Union as reported in a paper favorable to Tammany with such attention. I am a union man myself, and the persons quoted surely do not represent the sentiments of union men generally.

KANSAS CITY, June 10. -- An address of great interest was delivered to-day before the National Association of Credit Men by James G. Cannon, Vice President of the Fourth National Bank of New York. The subject of Mr. Cannon's address was "Individual Credits." In the course of the address he said:

MANCHESTER, England, June 10. -- The cricket match between the visiting Philadelphia eleven and an eleven of Lancashire began here to-day. The weather was fine and there was a good attendance of people on the Old Trafford Grounds. The Americans won the toss and went to the bat. They were all out for their first inning with 123 runs.
LONDON, June 11. -- The Times gives this morning the official programme of the procession for June 22, the occasion of the diamond jubilee.

BOSTON, June 10 -- Larz Anderson, until recently a member of the United States Diplomatic Corps at Rome, Italy, and Miss Isabelle Perkins of Boston, heiress to $17,000,000, were united in marriage in this city to-day.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 10. -- Commander Jacob W. Miller of the First Battalion of the New York Naval Militia, has resigned, and June 15 has been set as the date for the election of his successor.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Charles N. Cunningham was found guilty in the Criminal Court to-day of forging the name of Judge E.T. Hamilton to a check for $75,000. Strenuous efforts were made to prove that he was insane at the time he committed the crime.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association was held yesterday at the office of the Treasurer, Samuel L. Parrish, 44 Broadway. Lawrence Curtis of Boston was elected President to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Theodore A. Havemeyer.

The Commencement exercises of the New York Law School were held at Lenox Lyceum last evening. There was a large audience present who greatly enjoyed the exercises and applauded their friends when the degrees were conferred.
John De Witt Warner said yesterday that the sugar schedule, which is being approached in the tariff debate in the Senate, is the most interesting and important item in the Dingley-Aldrich bill.

August Belmont was at the Gravesend track yesterday for the first time since his return from Kentucky, and he had the satisfaction of seeing his good, but somewhat inconsistent colt Octagon capture the feature of the day's programme, the rich Brooklyn Derby. Mr. Belmont's horses came within a short head of running first and second, but as it was, his colors finished in first and third places.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 10. -- A court of inquiry to investigate the charges preferred by the Faculty of the South Carolina College against Adjutant and Inspector General J.G. Watts convened here to-day. The charges laid before the court are, in substance, as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10. -- S.M. Felton, receiver of the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railroad, has notified the Big Four -- Baltimore and Ohio, Monon, Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern, and the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Roads -- that he will not redeem interchangeable mileage issued by the road which he represents, and the conductors have been advised not to accept such transportations.

Judge BENEDICT of the United States Court for the Eastern District of New York, who has just resigned from the bench, carries with him in his retirement an enviable and highly honorable reputation. For more than the average life of a generation of men he has discharged the duties of his high office in a manner to add constantly to the prestige of the Federal judiciary.

Contrary to the expectation of all connected with the case, a jury was not sworn yesterday before Judge Fitzgerald in Part I., General Sessions, to try the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company. The attention of the court was taken up for an hour in the morning with other business, and after that counsel for both sides proceeded with care and deliberation in the work of securing jurymen.
WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The Senate to-day began consideration of the sugar schedule. There was no indication in the proceedings as to the time when a vote would be reached.

Mr. HORTON of Wayne County is a statesman much in view at the present moment, though his vogue proceeds from his action as a legislator a year ago last Winter. "HORTON'S law" may not be of as much permanent importance to mankind as KEPLER'S or GRIMM'S or GRESHAM'S, but it is of a good deal more present interest to a large body of malefactors and their instigators.
BUFFALO, June 10. -- The convention of the brewers of the United States concluded its work this afternoon with the election of the following officers:

The course of events in the Bureau of Water Register of this city does not always run as smoothly as does Croton water. The payment of water taxes, which is now progressing on the ground floor of the American Tract Society Building, is usually marked by more or less friction, in which the Registrar and his clerks are forced to hear expressions of opinion of unstudied frankness from irate taxpayers.

The uprising in New York this Fall threatens to be directed against the Republican Party, not against Tammany. "The union of all the elements that oppose Tammany" is a fine stock phrase for the speeches of Mr. QUIGG and a convenient shibboleth for the literature of the Citizens' Union and the organs of reform.

The New York University last night held its sixty-fifth annual commencement in Carnegie Hall, conferring degrees on the graduates of the university.
