Several days prior to the exercises of last night, the commencements of the Department of Medicine and the Department of Law were held, and large classes graduated.
Col. Waring last night gave out the following letter, relative to the recent address issued by Tammany Hall:

ITHACA, N.Y., June 10. -- The Cornell 'Varsity had a significant shake up this afternoon. At 3 o'clock the 'varsity crew went out on the inlet in their usual order, as did also the freshman crew. Courtney, however, soon called the 'varsity crew in and sent the shell out again, but manned as follows: Stroke, Briggs; 7, Savage; 6, Spillman; 5, O'Dell; 4, King; 3, Moore; 2, Bentley; bow, Wakeman; coxswain, Colson.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., June 10. -- The Ellerson-Westcott will contest, before Judge Forbes, is rapidly developing some startling evidence.
CINCINNATI, June 10. -- Taluca, at 15 to 1, surprised the crowd at Latonia to-day by winning the Milldale Stakes from a great field. Summaries:

PORT TOWNSEND, Wash., June 10. -- The steamer City of Topeka arrived here this morning from Alaska with the news that while she was at Sitka the revenue cutter Corwin towed in the derelict schooner General Siglin, which was wrecked while en route from San Francisco to Unalaska, and all on board were lost.

" JESHURUN waxed fat, and kicked." That Scriptural statement exactly expresses the present temper of the Turk and accounts for the lofty airs he is taking before the congress of Europe. Of course, the Turkish soldiers and politicians were quite confident beforehand that they could defeat Greece, provided no other power or powers intervened in behalf of Greece.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 10. -- Mrs. Nancy E. Clem is dead. She was the central figure in Indiana's most famous criminal case. She was tried five times for murder, twice sentenced to be hanged, and finally escaped on a technicality. She was finally convicted of perjury and served four years in the State Female Reformatory.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 10. -- A terrible disaster that resembles the Paris fire in all its details, is reported from Tien-tsin, China, where over a hundred people lost their lives in an attempt to escape from a burning death trap. A festival was in progress in a temple dedicated to the Queen of Heaven. All around the building hung awnings and inflammable materials were strung about.

TROY, N.Y., June 10. -- The commencement exercises of Emma Willard Seminary opened this morning and were attended by many relatives and friends of the graduates and pupils of the school. Mrs. Russell Sage of New York arrived in the city yesterday and became the guest of Miss Knox, Principal of the seminary. Mr. Sage was unable to accompany her.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 10. -- To the great disappointment of hundreds of yachtsmen, and especially to those who wished to see what she could do sailing with other American cracks, Royal Phelps Carroll gave out to-night that he would not race the Navahoe this season. He may sail her in the annual cruise of the New York Yacht Club, however, but in none of the contests for cups.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The Navy Department officials were singularly reserved about the movements of the New York, and showed a reluctance to answer any questions. Secretary Long, in answer to a direct interrogation, replied: "The New York is not going to Cuba; she will next be heard from at some point on the Atlantic coast well north of Cuba."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 10. -- Bunting, gay colors, flags, and decorations are already in evidence, and the line of march of the procession escorting President and Mrs. McKinley and party to the Exposition grounds to-morrow will be between handsome residences lavishly bedecked. Already hotel registers show long lists of names, and the railroads have prepared special trains to accommodate the incoming thousands.

The Summer amusement course of the Young Women's Christian Association will be begun this evening at the Association Hall, 7 East Fifteenth Street. The Minnie Marshall Smith company will give a concert. It is free to all women.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The indications here warrant the belief that the details of a scheme for the annexation of Hawaii will soon be submitted to Congress. These plans have been under consideration for a long while, and the persistent work of former Minister Lorin A. Thurston and Mr. Castle, the present Minister, has met with great encouragement, in spite of the fact that Congress has been so largely occupied with Cuba.

The determination to retain possessions which are no longer of national use or ornament is as marked in the Portuguese as in the Spanish part of the Iberian peninsula. Portugal has even fewer left of her ancestral glories of the seventeenth century than has Spain, but she hangs on to them with the same obstinacy.

The bust of Scott having been unveiled in Westminster Abbey, plans for memorials to three other writers are now under way and subscriptions are solicited. The authors whom it is proposed thus to recognize are Robert Louis Stevenson, James Russell Lowell, and Mrs. Hemans. It is announced in London that the Stevenson Memorial, through its Chairman,Prof. David Masson, has issued its appeal for subscriptions and will include all lovers of Stevenson's works.
LATONIA, Ky., June 11. -- There was a big crowd at the track to-day in spite of the hot weather. The track was fast, but the sport was tame. Summaries:

Mr. Taylor, in Puck, has made the most telling of cartoons, it shows a gentleman in his own garden (locality Princeton) under the shade of his own fig or apple tree, dancing a baby on his foot, while his two other children are amusing themselves. Then there is a quiet lady telling her little girl the story she has just been reading.

LYLE, Minn., June 11. -- The cyclone which struck this vicinity last night laid waste a track about 200 yards wide and ten miles long. Thousands of dollars' worth of property is in waste. The barn on the Funda farm was the first to suffer; J.C. Owens's fine residence, barn, and granaries are destroyed.

It is pleasant to read that Mr. JOHN W. FOSTER has been well received in St. Petersburg, and that his mission commends itself to the Russian officials. Because his mission is in fact to establish literally a "modus vivendi" for the fur seals, which are in danger of speedy extermination unless something is done for their protection.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 11. -- The ceremonies connected with the graduation of the class of '97 from the Military Academy were held this morning. There were about 5,000 persons in attendance. The ceremony took place under a canvas tent, in front of the library building. Seats were provided for the corps of cadets and 500 guests.

The English Government still claims her own, for a part of "treasure trove," it seems, belongs to her. In making certain alterations in an old church at Crediton, in England, a buckskin bag full of old money was found. The Crown seized it, taking the best specimens. There were 1,885 coins of the reigns of Edward VI., Philip and Mary, Elizabeth, James I., Charles I., and Charles II.

While Mr. WILLIAM WALDORF ASTOR'S London newspaper is "pessimistic" and foreboding about the future of the United States, good Americans, who take its utterances to heart, may find some consolation in the reflection that America, as the place of his origin, and the Americans, as his fellow-countrymen, will not be wholly without glory as long as Mr. WILLIAM WALDORF ASTOR keeps himself so conspicuously in evidence.

The process of finding a jury for the trial of the men indicted for conspiracy to keep up the price of cigarettes has been tedious. But it ought to be instructive. It has seemed at times that the object of counsel was to keep off the jury every man who was reasonably well informed upon current affairs.
The delegates from Mexico and Central and South America spent yesterday in examining various industries in Newark, Harrison, and Elizabethport, N.J.

The United States Church Army, a Protestant Episcopal adaptation of Salvation Army methods, has been thrown out of all official standing in the Church. The action was taken by the Parochial Missions Society at its last meeting, and is to take effect on Sept. 28. The chief reason for this summary course is said to be "Col." Henry H. Hadley, a lay evangelist, who is at the head of the Eastern Department.
The Brooklyns again took the Pittsburg Pirates into camp at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon after another "Garrison finish."

The readers of THE TIMES who followed the very full discussion in its columns two years ago of the progress and final success of the movement for the separation of the charitable institutions of this city from its correctional institutions will be pleased to hear that the example set by New York has already been followed by Boston.
LONDON, June 11. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Pall Mall Gazette says:

PARIS, June 4. -- For the past two weeks Mr. Oscar Wilde, who was recently released from prison, has been staying in France under an assumed name, and considerable curiosity has been evinced as to his whereabouts. I am in a position to inform the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES that nearly all the details that have been published about the present doings and plans of the famous author are incorrect.

MONTEVIDEO, June 11. -- Dr. Sanarelli, in a lecture delivered before the delegates from all parts of South America, members of the Diplomatic Corps, and others, announced yesterday that he had discovered the cause of yellow fever to be a bacillus, which he had named "Icteroid," and which was very rare.
The following twelve men were accepted yesterday and sworn as the jury to try the Directors and officers of the American Tobacco Company who are accused of conspiracy:

Yesterday was the three thousand and forty-first birthday of Quon Gung, a great Chinese Emperor. He was a fighter and a unionist, and succeeded in uniting the people and the provinces of China in one nation and country for the first time. The day was celebrated in Chinatown by the flying of big silk flags over the joss houses, while a steady stream of Chinamen filed in to say their prayers.

It is many a long year since the essay that gives to this volume its name was first printed in The Atlantic Monthly. Col. Higginson has done some stern work for his country in the intervening time, and has continued to write and lecture, withdrawing somewhat from nature and leaning more and more upon books and men.

Ever since 1890 excavations have been made southwest of Reading. England, in the parish of Silchester, and the remains of the old Roman settlement of Callera Attrebatum have been brought to light. There have been found the indications of public edifices, temples, forum, residences, shops, traces of trades, and other evidences of the former existence of a purely civil community.

J. Clarence Davies Co. have sold for the Countess de Montsatnin of Paris, through her attorney, Henry Lewis Morris, to E.B. Levy, for about $200,000, 250 lots on One Hundred and Sixty-ninth, One Hundred and Seventieth, One Hundred and Seventy-first, and One Hundred and Seventy-second Streets, and Clay, Teller, Findlay, College, and Morris Avenues, fronting on Claremont Park, on the south and west sides.
The Cincinnati team defeated the New Yorks yesterday by a single run in one of the cleanest, fastest, snappiest ball games seen at the Polo Grounds this year.
Apparently the only check on debate in the Senate of the United States is a sense of guilt.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- The Pullman Car Manufacturing Works are now running at two-thirds of their capacity, and it is probable the force of employes will be increased still further in the next few days. Three thousand men are now working full time, the largest force that has been on the pay roll within the year.

At a recent sale in London was an excessively rare genuine first quarto edition of Shakespeare's "Excellent History of the Merchant of Venice," printed by J. Roberts in 1600. It measures 7 1/8 inches by 5 1/2 inches. It is without question the best copy known, and the price paid for it, 315, the highest yet obtained for this play.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The first test vote on the sugar schedule was taken in the Senate late to-day, resulting in the adoption of the Republican caucus amendment, changing the House rate on sugars above No. 16 Dutch standard to 1.95 cents per pound, by the close vote of: Yeas, 32; nays, 30.

The more accurately we gauge the history of Assyria, not speculatively, but in a material way, by handling potsherds, the more convinced we are of the remoteness of certain civilizations. "The Threshold of History" becomes removed further and further back. Before Babylon waxed great there must have been culture.

In the June Lippincott attention is called to Jacob Steendam, who, as far as can be ascertained, made the first attempt at versification in that part of the continent now known as New York. Jacob Steendam, who was born in 1616 in North Holland, when of mature age came to the New Netherlands and was the purchaser of a house and lot in Pearl Street and of another on Broadway, in the so-called New Amsterdam.
Were there any Republicans who have any influence in their party organization at the banquet to the Southern merchants on Thursday evening?

-- Now that a machine to do the work of the baseball pitcher has been invented and has been found to work successfully, there is room for hope that mechanical substitutes for catchers, basemen, fielders, batsmen, and umpires will also be built. In time perfectly satisfactory automata may replace even the spectators.

Certain considerations not easily solved have to do with the status of the Turk. Taking him on the physical side, the purely material one, the man himself has not deteriorated by his residence in Europe. Polygamy has not lowered his standard. There are certain characteristics, such as of courage, which make him just as redoubtable a foe to-day as he was when he captured Constantinople.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., June 11. -- A diabolical attempt was made upon the life of Gov. Andrew J. Smith of the National Soldiers' Home and his wife and daughter, between 4 and 5 A.M. to-day, by some person who is as yet unknown. Dynamite was employed, and the explosion wrecked the Governor's beautiful residence.

A boy who was recently sent to St. Paul's School, Garden City, said when he returned home for his first vacation: "That's the meanest school I ever saw. They put you on your honor there, and then you can't do anything." Perhaps no more eloquent comment on the honor system, now so much favored by educators, was ever uttered.

COOPERSTOWN, June 11. -- There was a big legal quibble over the admissibility of the evidence of Thomas W. Cantwell of Albany, a handwriting expert, in the trial of the Ellerson-Westcott one-hundred-thousand-dollar will case, which was continued before Judge Forbes to-day. It is charged that Mrs. Dr. Pope-Westcott caused the death of Westcott by giving him poison.

"Inside of the next ten years this country will see the biggest and most awful revolution that has for many years astounded the world. That is my view, that is my opinion, based upon more than one visit to the United States, of the condition of the country to-day."

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- Frederick Miller, eighteen years old, died this afternoon in the City Hospital from a wound caused by a pistol bullet fired into his head in a joke. Charles Zebulka is locked up for having fired the shot.

For the last sixteen years the author of "Wild Norway" has often visited Scandinavia, and, in the enjoyment of special advantages, has taken a wider field than that possessed by the usual Anglo-Norseman sportsman. He has been afield with rod, gun, rifle, and in this most interesting volume tells of the reindeer, the elk, and all the winged game to be found in Norway, or in the divide between that country and Sweden.

GEORGETOWN, Del., June 11. -- James M. Gordy was hanged in the Sussex County jail at 10:26 o'clock this morning for the murder of his wife. Gordy displayed very little nervousness, and protested his innocence to the last.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 11. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill responded to the toast, "The United States," on the occasion of the Niagara Falls excursion of the Rochester Chamber of Commerce. He said in part:

Unusual public and neighborly interest was awakened by the funeral of Joseph Richardson, the venerable and eccentric millionaire, which occurred yesterday forenoon. Several hundred persons assembled near the unique home of the dead man -- the noted five-foot-wide "spite house" -- at Lexington Avenue and Eighty-second Street, a little before 10 o'clock, and watched with much curiosity for the appearance of the funeral party.

That Sphinx is always propounding her riddles -- and there was but one Oedipus ever born. Old Time, with his posers, always is pumblechooking you, and like Pip, your answers are halting or insufficient. Try to be overprompt, and you are pretty sure to blunder.
In talking of the general outlook yesterday, Mr. Benjamin Graham of the Stock Exchange house of Cuyler, Morgan Co. said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

It may have been noticed lately by persons whose attention has not been wholly taken up by the many more important matters in the newspapers that the English press has been at its old and favorite job of predicting the downfall of this Republic. There may be a few very sensitive Americans who will be somewhat affected by its gloomy prognostications.

Everything was favorable for good sport with the light-harness cracks at Fleetwood yesterday, but the fields were so badly matched that the entire card was cleared in straight heats. The old track was all the better for the thorough wetting it received earlier in the week, but only one of the successful horses had to take a lower record.

After a warm, and at some points a bitter, discussion yesterday in the General Council of the Reformed Episcopal Church of the question of vestments, the adherents of the black gown carried the day, and passed a resolution against the introduction of white surplices in the service in any parish where they are not now used.

The indications for good roads and fine weather for to-day and to-morrow are promising. The heavy rajahs of the last few days have tended to improve the macadam roads, and the dirt roads will very likely be dry by to-morrow.

The announcement that a Parisian publisher is shortly to bring out an edition of 500 copies of "Le Mangeur d'Opium par Alfred de Musset" will be hailed with astonishment by literary people in general, and with no little enthusiasm by bibliophiles. And there will be many incredulous ones.

In a recent number of The Forum, F.W. Farrar, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, writes of the tombs of great writers and rulers which have been opened since the time of burial, and among other interesting statements makes the following:

A notable collection was the one sold recently in London, made up of pamphlets, prints, engraved portraits, caricatures, and documents all pertaining to the famous South Sea Bubble and other schemes. The man who brought together this material must have been enamored with his object, and was the most painstaking and erudite of faddists.

Attachments were issued yesterday against the United States Guide and Information Company of 114 West Thirty-fourth Street and Ernest V. Marschall, its General Superintendent. These troubles may lead to criminal proceedings, as it is claimed that stock in the company has been issued illegally.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Final arrangements have been made for the great Yale-Princeton baseball game here to-morrow. A tremendous crowd is expected to attend the game. Manager Thompson has disposed of all the grandstand and open stand seats, and the rush for the bleachers promises to be very warm.

In England, Canada, and Newfoundland there will be celebrations, held on the 24th of this month, to commemorate the voyage of John Cabot to the coast of North America 400 years ago. In the June Forum, that great authority, Mr. Henry Harrisse, in an interesting paper, "When Did Cabot Discover North America?" remarks: "But it is well to recollect that we do not know exactly when and where be first sighted the New World.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment was reviewed and congratulated in its armory last night by Mayor Strong. The men made a splendid showing in their bright uniforms. The Mayor presented badges won during 1896 to the marksmen. Considering the disability under which the members of the regiment labor from the fact that they have no facilities for armory practice, the number qualifying in the work at Creedmoor during the season of 1896 is creditable.

William J. Bryan, the silver Democratic candidate for President in the last campaign, is due to arrive in this city over the New York Central Railroad either this morning or early this afternoon. Rooms have been secured for him at the Bartholdi Hotel, where he stopped when he was in this city during the campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Elverton R. Chapman, the New York broker, spent the final night of his term in the District Jail last night. His sentence expired at midnight, but according to custom he was "allowed to remain" till this morning. He accepted the final courtesy at the hands of Warden Leonard laughingly, saying he should be sorry to requite the hospitality he had received by seeming to hurry off precipitately.

DENVER, June 11. -- Four railway washouts, a twenty-five-thousand-dollar fire, and a host of minor losses epitomizes the evil results of the storm which prevailed in Denver and the southeastern section of the State generally from near 7 o'clock last evening until a little after midnight. A cloudburst on the slope of Pike's Peak shut off traffic on the Rio Grande and Midland lines between Manitoba and Colorado Springs.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 11. -- The centennial city was early astir this morning with preparations to greet the distinguished party which was to be its guest. At 5 o'clock the streets were crowded, and the booming of cannon awakened those whose enthusiasm was not sufficient to make them forsake their beds.

The retirement of Commander J.W. MILLER from the command of the First Naval Battalion implies the speedy promotion of that gentleman to the rank of Captain of the Naval Militia force of the entire State. The man well deserves the honor, and no one is more fitted for the assumption of the responsibility.

The Latin-American delegates spent yesterday, which was the last active day of their visit, in examining a number of manufactories in Brooklyn, in a boat excursion on East River and the upper Bay, and in driving through Greenwood Cemetery and Prospect Park.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 12. -- Parties from Mayport report an exciting chase yesterday afternoon, in which the cruiser Vesuvius attempted to capture a strange-looking craft which appeared off the Bar and hove to late in the afternoon. The result of the chase had not been learned up to a late hour to-night.

SUPERIOR, Wis., June 12. -- In tearing down the ruins of the old Nicollet House a few days ago three workmen made a discovery which has startled the community. While removing the debris of an ancient furnace in the cellar of the building, which had crumbled to earth long before the destruction of the hotel by fire, two years ago, the workmen found a rusty iron box about two and a half feet square.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 12. -- President McKinley left Nashville to-night for Chattanooga after a stay very brief and fully occupied, in spite of the intensely hot weather and the fatigue incidental to much unavoidable exertion and exposure to the sun. He and Mrs. Mckinley have benefited by the visit as much as their hosts.

Ensign G.L.P. Stone of the United States Navy returned to duty on board the Puritan at 12 o'clock last night. The Conde family, it is said, will soon sail for Europe. Ensign Stone is still in love with Miss Conde, and Miss Conde's feelings are of course a matter of conjecture.

Salty air, cool and bracing; smooth, hard beaches, washed by a wild and restless surf; commanding bluffs, rich in verdure and in shade; beautiful drives, comfortable hotels, and elegant cottages constitute some of the reasons why the seagirt coast of New Jersey is a favorite resort of Summer pleasure seekers.

The habit of not paying, which seems to have been spreading in this country, was treated of in a masterly way by Mr. JAMES G. CANNON in his address on "Individual Credits" at Kansas City the other day. Mr. CANNON'S purpose was practical; it was also scientific and philosophical.

That was a suggestive item of news which told the other day that the "Grand Street Board of Trade" had held a meeting to urge the erection of a roof garden on a new pier in the East River. The name of the association seemed to some readers to indicate that it was the merchants of Grand Street in this city who had associated for the purpose of securing public improvements in their neighborhood.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Ten thousand people, the largest crowd that ever attended a Princeton baseball game, crowded into the university field to-day to see the Tigers lower the colors of old Eli in the second game of their championship series.

Abraham Lincoln, colored, twenty-three years old, of Stevens and Rose Avenues, Jersey City, was arrested yesterday by Police Captain Thomas P. Nugent and Sergt. Reardon, after a desperate resistance, on a charge of robbing Richard Wood at Ocean Avenue and Bartholdi Place, where Lincoln was formerly employed.

BOSTON, June 12. -- The wretched weather of this week put a damper on yachting, and it will take several days of sunshine to make the yachtsmen feel that they are in the game again. The fitting out and furnishing of new boats has been badly delayed, and some of them will go into the racing of the coming week with very little in the way of preparatory tuning up.

WHEN, in 1869, the Board of Education consisting of twenty-one Commissioners elected by the people, was legislated out of office, a new board of twelve, appointed by the Mayor, was installed in its place. This board, on account of its number, or, perhaps, its character, was nicknamed "Mayor Hall's Twelve Apostles."

As a general rule, all waters coming directly, or, rather, indirectly from near the surface of the ground, must be avoided. Recourse must be had either to deep wells or the drinking water must be boiled. The experience of the town of Hawkinsville, Ga., will well illustrate this point. This thrifty little manufacturing city was located unfortunately in a malarial section.

ORANGE, N.J., June 12. -- Finals in men's singles in the junior tournament and the semi-finals in the doubles of the tournament begun on Memorial Day were played this afternoon on the courts of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. In the contest for the silver loving cup offered for the Memorial Day tournament, P. Parmly Paret beat Edward Lynian, 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12. -- Harry Whallen, known as "the human ostrich," was operated on at the German Hospital, in this city, to-day, as a final means of saving his life.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the steamship Valencia was Dr. H.W. Danforth, physician to President Salvador Cisneros of the Cuban Republic. The doctor, who embarked at Nassau, N.P., is on a six months' leave of absence, and is bound for his home, in Milwaukee. He was dressed in his Cuban rig of white trousers, leather belt, dark gray coat, and straw hat, and had with him his campaign outfit.

An interesting case which concerns the legality of certain dealings in stocks has been brought to Magistrate Kudlich to solve. The parties are Herman Tappen, a wholesale dealer in perfumes at 112 Greene Street and 70 Reade Street, and whose residence is at 206 West End Avenue, the complainant, and Edward H. Myers and Charles Neukirch, members of the firm of T.W. Myers Co., brokers, of 47 New Street, the defendants.

That a religious denomination should be in danger of disruption through the settlement, one way or the other, of so trifling a question as the adoption of a black or a white robe by its ministers seems barely credible. Yet we must believe that the delegates who asserted their fear of so disastrous a result from the passage of Dr. ASHURST'S resolution in the Reformed Episcopal General Council spoke from conviction.

Superintendent McKelvey of Brooklyn called his Captains together yesterday morning and delivered a lecture on the evils of gambling, and upon the sins of bicycle riders who use the sidewalks. Both, he said, must be stopped, and he ordered the Captains to instruct the patrolmen to arrest all persons violating the bicycle ordinance.

Meetings of the General Council of the Reformed Episcopal Church were held yesterday morning and afternoon at the First Church, Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. The early part of the morning session was devoted to reports on missionary work and the obtaining of pledges for the missionary fund for the next three years.

In mining for gold in Siberia the ground is kept clear of snow, so as to permit the cold to penetrate as deeply as possible, after which the surface is thawed by fires until a shallow layer of earth can be removed. The freezing is then allowed to proceed, and the thawing operation repeated, and this is continued as long as the cold weather lasts.

The dealings of the past week have shown a desirable increase and the feeling among brokers is correspondingly improved. Some of them, discouraged beyond recovery by the ups and downs of the past few months, are not quickly moved by the temporary improvement, but the verdict of the more optimistic is: "Pretty good for the middle of June."
The eighteenth annual regatta of the Canarsie Yacht Club was held on Jamaica Bay yesterday afternoon. Thirteen boats started over the course, but at the finish there were only four.

John Weldon, an ironworker, thirty-nine years old, of 60 North Moore Street, met with a serious accident yesterday while at work erecting scaffolding on the site of the old Arcade Building, on the corner of Broadway and Rector Street. Weldon was standing on a stringpiece fourteen inches wide and twenty feet above the excavation, when he made a misstep and fell to the bottom.

" The most subtle and deceitful hope which ever existed, and one which wrecks the happiness of many a young girl's life," writes Evangelist Dwight L. Moody in the June Ladies' Home Journal, "is the common delusion that a woman can best reform a man by marrying him.

The rainy weather has seriously interfered with the sport of the yachtsman. Rain will not usually prevent a race, but the rain, fog, and wind spoiled the special regatta of the Riverside Club, which was to have been sailed last Wednesday. The yachts could not get up to the clubhouse.

LATONIA, Ky., June 12. -- The Latonia Oaks was the star event on the Latonia track to-day, and resulted in an easy victory for Lou Bramble. White Frost was the favorite, at 6 to 5, but she tired in the stretch. The track was fast, the distance -- a mile and a quarter -- being covered in 2:08 3/4.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., June 12. -Owing to the recent heavy falls of rain only minor skirmishes have occurred between the Government troops and insurgents during the last few days. According to official reports ten armed insurgents have surrendered to the authorities.

This year's crop of three-year-olds seems now to be about the worst the Eastern turf has had in a number of years, judged by the recent running of those the public has supposed to be the best. While some of the speculators are grumbling against their inconsistent running, the fact is that there is really no class among this season's three-year-olds, in the East at least.

LONDON, June 12. -- The past week has seen the arrival of numerous military detachments from the colonies to take part in the jubilee festivities. A splendid body of Maori police are the latest arrivals. They reached here yesterday evening from New Zealand, and composed an ode to the Queen while on their way here. They hope to chant it before her Majesty and expect her to join in it.

Daniel Kandelhardt considers himself the luckiest man that ever rode a bicycle. He is a carpenter, living with his family at 634 East One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, and usually rides his wheel to and from work.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 12. -- Bergen County seems to have been picked out by a gang of burglars, believed to be experts from the city, as a good field to work in during the Summer. Reports received from the different villages show that thieves have been more or less successful in looting them in the last week or two.

William J. Bryan came to New York yesterday, and during the day managed to see and talk with most of those who were associated with him in the last Presidential campaign. He arrived in this city at 6:30 o'clock from Troy and took breakfast at the Grand Union Hotel With James Oliver, Sergeant at Arms of the National Committee.
One day, while many people stood about the statue, enjoying it as usual, a person broke into the circle and cried out:

LONDON, June 12. -- M. Jean de Reszke's sudden absence from the opera on two occasions when billed to appear at Covent Garden has raised a crop of rumors as to differences between himself and the management, in spite of the official announcement that his retirement was due to indisposition.

It will be safe to wait for what Mr. MCKINLEY has to say about a treaty for the annexation of Hawaii. The gentlemen who have concocted the latest scheme have every motive for declaring that the President favors it. The President, so far as now appears, has every reason for putting his foot on it and through it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12. -- Pennsylvania went down to-day before Charley Paine's great pitching, and Harvard won out easily by the score of 8 to 0. Only one little single was secured off Paine's delivery, and in the last six innings only three men came to the bat for the visitors each time.

GLASGOW, June 2. -- The Yachting and Fisher Exhibition, opened in the Imperial Institute, London, to commemorate Queen Victoria's jubilee, has not created the surprise expected. In the yachting department an extensive assortment of sliver cups, vases, and other trophies won in yacht races have been collected and exhibited, and this department is exceptionally popular, of course, among the ladies.

New Grammar School, No. 108, is to be erected on the east side of Avenue A, between Seventy-seventh and Seventy-eighth Streets, to relieve the dearth of school accommodations in that district, which were made more apparent than ever by the manner in which Grammar School, No. 96, Eighty-first Street and Avenue A, was filled to overflowing when opened, in 1895.

One of the most interesting figures in the delegation of South American merchants now visiting this country is Col. Fernando Mendes de Almeida, LL. D., of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He is professor on the Free Faculty of Juridic and Social Sciences, commander of the Second Infantry Brigade of the National Guard of Brazil, editor in chief of the Jornal do Brasil, and a Commissioner of the Brazilian Government.

The formative influences which have gone to make up the individuality of the President of the Franklin Bank, Ellis H. Roberts, would be interesting and profitable to contemplate in detail. Successively he has been a pedagogue, a journalist, a politician, (in the broad Latin sense of the word,) a financial economist, and a lecturer on financial themes, and as each he has achieved more than a passing eminence.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 12. -- The Dominion Government has at last taken a stand which shows unmistakably that it is determined to have every means at hand to retaliate against the United States should the increased duties of $2 per thousand on lumber be put in force against Canada.

BOSTON, June 12. -- At Wellesley College this afternoon the Shakespearean comedy "Love's Labor's Lost" was played by the Shakespearean Society, in the presence of an audience of about 500, made up mostly of friends of the students. There was nothing at all vexatious save the busy mosquito. The stage was an almost level stretch about the size of the stage of an average theatre.

LONDON, June 12. -- There is serious alarm in all circles of the French capital at the avowed intention of the parliamentary committee which is now dealing with the Beranger bill to restrict not only the sale, but the possession, of certain classes of literature and works of art. Acknowledged works such as are exhibited in the Louvre and some classical literature will be placed on the blacklist.

The persecution of the Stundists and Mennonites, who are in reality the Baptists of Russia, and of many other minor sects, is not excusable. Its genesis is, however, easily accounted for. It is simply a case in the nineteenth century of the intolerance which prevailed in the rest of Europe in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. Russia sustains alone the mediaeval uniformity which allowed no Nonconformity.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, June 12. -- At the afternoon session of the Lutheran Synod to-day the report of the Board of Trustees of the Tressler Orphan Home, at Loysville, was submitted by the President, the Rev. Dr. W.M. Dunbar of Baltimore.

LONDON, June 12. -- An extraordinary murder story comes from Philippopolis, Bulgaria, where a Capt. Boitcheff, Prefect of Police Novitich, and a gendarme have been arrested on the charge of murdering Anna Szimon, a beautiful public singer. Boitcheff, it appears, became tired of Anna, and determined to get rid of her.

Dr. William Thompson Lusk, President of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College, died yesterday at his residence, 47 East Thirty-fourth Street, of apoplexy. He was born May 23, 1838, in Norwich, Conn., where he received his preliminary education. In 1859 he entered Yale University, remaining there only one year, when he enlisted in the Second New York Volunteers as a private, rising to the rank of Assistant Adjutant General in 1863.

DRESDEN, May 30. -- The pleasant Saxon capital on the Elbe is offering her citizens and the many American, Scotch, English, and Russian sojourners within her gates an international exhibition of the fine arts which is a model of arrangement and remarkable for the quality of the works that are shown.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Until recently Chicagoans have been in the habit of flattering themselves that they knew an Anarchist when they saw one. Admiring visitors were formerly introduced by local cicerones to various gentlemen whose superabundance of hairy locks, ferocity of language, and large capacity for beer left no doubt of the faith that was in them.

Fleetwood's Spring meeting ended yesterday, but the horses are not entitled to any credit for that They were still engaged in the contest when darkness came, and out for sensible provision in trotting rules made last year the 2:30 trot would have to be resumed on Monday.

When the American bark Justin H. Ingersoll, Capt. Peterson, from Montevideo, arrived yesterday at Quarantine, three Deputy United States Marshals arrested her acting first mate, Albert Ammon, and two seamen, Louis Larsen and Thomas Nickales, They will be detained as witnesses in the trial of Paul Blanchard, who is charged with the murder in November last of John Christensen, who was mate of the Ingersoll when she left this port for Montevideo.

" France has opened her eyes to the menace exercised toward her and her sister republic, the United States of America, by what is practically a British monopoly of submarine cables," said J.B. Depelley to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Waldorf Friday.

The Ward Line steamship Valencia, which was fired upon off the Cuban port of Guantanamo May 29 by the Spanish cruiser Reina Mercedes, arrived here yesterday. Capt. John F. Skillings, her commander, made a report to the officials of the Ward Line, to which the Valencia is under charter, and to Boulton, Bliss Dallett of the Red D Line, her owners.

The recent speed trial of the torpedo boat Porter over a long course gave results which should make her builders feel very proud and which ought to gratify every person who has any pride in the mechanical achievements of his country. The little vessel was sent around Long Island, a distance of 300 sea miles, and she performed the journey in 12 hours and 45 minutes.

Sir Henry Irving made an amusing speech at the one hundred and fifty-ninth anniversary dinner of the Royal Society of Musicians in London a few days ago. He took for his topic music in the theatre, and his words are reported thus:

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The sugar schedule was again the subject of Democratic assaults to-day in the Senate. Practically no progress was made in disposing of the schedule. Only one amendment was voted upon, and that was defeated. When the Senate adjourned the amendment of Mr. Lindsay of Kentucky to strike out the differential on refined sugar was still pending.
LONDON, June 12. -- The Czar's baby is to receive a singular name, Tatiana.

The professional handling of the market shows that the talent is fully engaged on the bull side. The big houses which so long remained inactive and apparently indifferent; the professional operators who but recently would do nothing save to bear some special stock; and with these, the rank and file of the Street, are all working to advance prices.

McCullough did not carry the actor into everyday life, as Forrest did. Forrest was always "the great tragedian," and after his divorce, generally moody and silent, but when he spoke it was in deep, tragic tones and with shakings of his black, curly locks that impressed the listener with unbounded awe.

WHEN the Brooklyn Board of Education was organized, May 2, 1843, there were but five schools in the city. Within the space of fifty-four years the city's school system has increased from these five district schools to 138, including the Evening High, Special, and Societies' School, all contained in 121 distinct buildings. The board came into existence under a law passed by the efforts of Joseph Sprague, then Mayor of Brooklyn.

The Emerald, J. Rogers Maxwell's schooner, won the race yesterday for the handsome cup given by Commodore George J. Gould, beating the Colonia and Amorita. H.F. Lippitt's sloop Wasp won the Commodore's Cup for Sloops, beating the Syce, Norots, Eidolon, Hera, Acushla, and Akista. The special race for the thirty-footers was won by the Vaquero, and the catboat race was won by the Dorothy.

The Brooklyn Provisional Naval Battalion will be mustered into the service of the State of New York Monday evening. It will be known as the Second Battalion, Naval Militia of New York, the First Battalion being in this city. The ceremony will take place at the armory of the Twenty-third Regiment, at Bedford and Atlantic Avenues.
It was evident he was sinking fast, and the physician told his sorrowing relatives to prepare for the worst.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., June 12. -- During the heavy thunder shower this afternoon the steeple of the Second Congregational Church was struck by lightning and badly damaged. The church was filled with children at the time, but no one was injured. The Fire Department was called out to remove the debris of the shattered steeple.

Eighty-five years ago a young man from Anne Arundel County, Maryland, came to Baltimore to seek his fortune. When he arrived in the city, which sixty years later he was to endow so munificently, he had only seventy-five cents in his pocket. In those early days the opportunities for obtaining an education were very limited even in cities, but in the country there were scarcely any advantages in this respect.

Lillie Feron, a little slender, pale-faced girl, the oldest child of Arthur Feron, a French decorator living at 205 West Twentieth Street, was arrested in a Sixth Avenue store yesterday afternoon by Special Policeman Wund, on a charge of shoplifting. The little girl was sent by her mother on an errand early in the afternoon, and she failed to return.
A London journal boldly prints an interview with a theatrical costumer, who says he "padded" Sir Henry Irving for the role of Napoleon in "Mme. Sans Gene." Says this communicative person:

HARVARD, Mass., June 12. -- This community was aroused to an unprecedented pitch of excitement last night by an assault upon Estelle Stratton, the fifteen-year-old daughter of a well-known citizen, by an unknown tramp, who was traced as far as Concord, Mass., but who has thus far escaped arrest. The tramp got away on a woman's bicycle, which he stole in his flight.

TORONTO, June 12. -- The premises of the Royal Toronto Sailing Skiff Club and several adjoining boathouses at the foot of Sherbourne Street were totally destroyed by fire early this morning. A large number of small boats were destroyed. The loss will exceed $10,000.

The reception of President MCKINLEY on his Journey to Nashville and at that city has been cordial, as it was bound to be. There is no section of our big country in which honor is more sincerely rendered to the representatives of the National Government, without regard to the party to which they belong, and it is to be said of Mr. MCKINLEY that he invites the heartiest expression of that feeling.

LONG BRANCH, June 12. -- Among the arvals at Elberon this week was a woman who will be 100 years old this Summer. She is Mrs. Dullas of Philadelphia, and is occupying the Thompson cottage. Mrs. Dullas spent many seasons at Long Branch. Before President Garfield died at the Franklyn cottage she frequently made it her Summer home.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, June 9. -- A remarkable combination of circumstances tending to illustrate the fatality of the number 13 is developed by the suicide here of Charles Drynan of the Sandusky News Company and the recent death of his sister, Mrs. Maxima Stenzel.

Bronze was very extensively used by the Swiss lake dwellers in the manufacture of a great variety of things useful and ornamental, such as words, knives, fish hooks, javelin heads, pins, needles, bracelets, Their bronze swords were similar to those found in other parts of Europe of the same era, rather short, broad, and thick; some plain, others highly ornamented.

A man employed in one of the railway offices in Washington has for years been collecting newspaper accounts of railway accidents of all kinds. He now has thousands of these narratives, and from an attentive study of them he has come to the conclusion that no locomotive engineer ever came alive out of his third disaster.

" Canadian pirates" is what the music dealers call publishing houses across the line who are flooding this country, they say, with spurious editions of the latest copyrighted popular songs. They use the mails to reach purchasers, so members of the American Music Publishers' Association assert, and as a result the legitimate music publishing business of the United States has fallen off 50 per cent. in the past twelve months.

Socrates is reported to have said that, although no man undertakes a trade he has not learned, even the meanest, yet every one thinks himself sufficiently qualified for the hardest of all trades, that of government. It was the opinion of Burnout that if a hundred persons were stopped at haphazard in the streets of Paris and a proposal were made to them to take charge of the Government, ninety-nine would accept it.

One of the greatest advances of the times is in the use of a wise philanthropy in place of the so-called charity, which, students of human nature are now coming to believe, frequently does more harm than good. This advance is shown in many ways, and in none more prominently than in the efforts of the uniformed workers in the different churches.
Such instances as the following carry with them their own moral:

THE one hundred and fiftieth annual commencement of Princeton and the first commencement since the title of the institution was changed from the chartered name of the College of New Jersey to the more appropriate name of Princeton University will be celebrated at that ancient seat of learning next Wednesday.

It is a racing day in Moscow. The course is swept free from snow, and follows the wooded shores with red-painted railings on each side. On one side is a stand, with seating room for several thousand people, and a special box, with tent hangings, for the Governor General, surmounted by the imperial eagle in gold.

The near approach of the one hundred and fifty-second anniversary of the capture of Louisbourg, Cape Breton, by the English and its capitulation, June 17, 1745, makes interesting this somewhat unique history of the siege. It was written 150 years ago by "a military gentleman in his Majesties service" who is anonymous.

LONDON, June 12. -- The rather conscienceless system of flaring posters employed by the London evening papers threw the Street into excitement yesterday, which, if fleeting, was very intense while it lasted. The bills burst forth in big lettered lines about treachery in India and the massacre of British troops.

Thomas F. Bayard, recently United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, was the guest of the National Civic Club of Brooklyn last evening at the clubhouse in Montague Street. The reception was informal, and there were no speeches, except a brief one by Frederic W. Hinrichs, President of the club, who welcomed the guest and introduced him to the company, and Mr. Bayard's response.

Neither riot nor bloodshed followed yesterday when the Seventh Regiment Band played "God Save the Queen" on the Crowded Central Park Mall. There was a slight demonstration. Some fervid admirers of her Britannic Majesty cheered, while opponents of the hated Saxon rule hissed. But the police were in the majority over all disturbers, and no blow was struck for the Emerald Isle.

LONDON, June 4. -- The English "booking" system extends even to the sale of seats for the Jubilee procession. In all the business streets through which the procession is to pass half the shop windows bear the sign, "Jubilee Procession. Seats Booked Inside for This Wind." The prices paid for seats are so high that the ordinary shopkeeper cannot afford to keep his show window for the use of his family and friends.

DENVER, Col., June 12. -- The death of William Korn of Leadville, Col., from yellow fever, in Quarantine at New York, yesterday, marks the total extinction of one party of prospectors who left Colorado last March to dig for gold in Bolivia. The other members of the party.

WILLIAM A. SUTHERLAND, the newly elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons, is a resident of Rochester and is one of the best-known men in the western part of the State. He is an eminent member of the Rochester bar and is prominent in the councils of the Republican Party. He is a public-spirited and progressive gentleman, and his administration will undoubtedly be a successful one.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- There were frequent references to the probability of a new treaty for the annexation of Hawaii during the caucus of the Republican Senators on the Hawaiian reciprocity treaty in connection with the sugar schedule of the new Tariff bill. It seemed to be generally understood that such a treaty was included among the possibilities for the near future.

BOSTON, June 12. -- Business men of the Hub are finding some claims that the commercial situation is looking up from the fact that building projects are actually increasing. It has been a long time since such widespread energy in this line has existed as there has the past year and is indicated for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Ohio is getting its share of diplomatic work under the present Administration, and if success shall wait upon the policy to be generally followed, the Buckeye State will have abundant satisfaction. The relations of the United States with Spain appear to be in the care of Ohio, with the prospect that they may be more completely so.

The week just closed has worked material changes in Wall Street's stock market. We have had activity and we have had strength. We have had confidence become enthusiasm. We have had opposing influences brushed carelessly aside. The sensation of a Cuban incident, which every bear a week ago was counting on, has not appeared.

A clothesline, which caught fire on the outside of the tenement at 536 West Fifty-sixth Street yesterday, caused a good deal of excitement among the tenants of the house. The clothesline is supposed to have caught fire from sparks from the big chimney of the Benedict Iron Foundry, which is on the same block.

A single shot rang through the vaulted arches of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Three minutes later a chance visitor found lying face downward in the vestibule of the church, just in front of the swinging doors leading to the middle aisle, a woman with a great hole in her right temple, dead.

Enthusiastic and hearty approval of the game of golf was given yesterday by the members of the Stock Exchange. Never have the beautiful links of the Knollwood Country Club witnessed such an outpouring of the bulls and bears of Wall Street as tramped over them under the broiling sun yesterday afternoon.
" Under the Red Robe" continues at the Empire.

Thiers's great achievement at AIX was in winning a prize offered by the Academy for an essay on Vauvenargues. The way in which this prize was secured was characteristic of Thiers. He wrote one essay which would have been successful but for the fact that it was known to be his. The essays were sent anonymously, but Thiers had been unable to refrain from reading his to a literary society.

Of the efficacy of physic Queen Elizabeth had always been skeptical. Now ten or twelve physicians came to the palace, each promising, "with all manner of asseveration," "her perfect and easy recovery" if she would follow a simple course of treatment. But they spoke in vain. Nor could the protests of Councilors, divines, and waiting women induce her to accept medical assistance.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 12. -- A very cool burglar got into the house of John Francis, at 50 Bartlett Street, late last night by removing a wire screen from the kitchen window. The thief secured about $100 worth of booty. He was heard in the house by James Teneson, father of Mrs. Francis. Mr. Teneson thought it was some member of the family, and, being sick, requested a drink of water.

SIMLA, June 12. -- A Punjab infantry regiment has been ordered to proceed to the Tochi Valley, where a British force of 200 men escorting a political officer, Mr. Gee, was recently attacked by an overwhelming force of insurgent natives, instigated by the Mullah of Powindah, a notorious fanatical priest.

THE accompanying Illustration shows the memorial window which, according to the prevailing custom of classes in the colleges, the graduating class of '85 presented to Wells College, at Aurora, N.Y. To this class Mrs. Cleveland belonged, and the photograph from which the reproduction has been made was taken at her request by Mr. John La Farge, who designed the memorial.

Play is no longer the exclusive occupation of the young American. His father and his grandfather beat him at golf, his mother and his grandmother ride with him on the wheel. The old people have disappeared. The lines which in the old time divided youth from maturity and maturity from age have been obliterated.

Sydney Grundy's new comedy at the Haymarket Theatre, in London, "A Marriage of Convenience," (scarcely a correct translation of the French form, "Un Mariage de Convenance,") is an adaptation of "Un Mariage sous Louis XV.," the origin of which is amusingly traced by an English critic. The forts et origo of the tale is to be found much higher up.

Yesterday's game between the New Yorks and St. Louis was not close enough at any time to be exciting. Had it not been for Gleason's wild throw in the seventh inning to Clark, Cross would not have tallied, and a single run would have been the visitors' portion.

BANGOR, Me., June 12. -- Mrs. Addle W. Buzzell of Clinton is attracting much attention in Eastern Maine. Although only thirty-four years of age, she has been married and divorced five times. In each case she has been the complainant.

THE roof garden season has begun, but the roof garden is not such an important factor in Summer amusements as it was expected to be a few years ago. The principal New York roof garden is still that of the Casino, planned by Rudolph Aronson, very profitable at first because of its novelty, and not unprofitable now, it is likely, although the entertainment is always a secondary consideration.

The remark of KOCH, the truck driver, as he ran down a bicycle rider the other day, "Say, streets weren't made for bicycles," revealed his belief, which is shared by many others of his calling, that the streets were made for trucks. No person who knows well the crowded thoroughfares of New York in business hours can doubt that the loaded truck occupies much more space than its relative importance entitles it to.

The police of the West Twentieth Street Station found an unconscious old man on the sidewalk at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street last night. He had just fallen to the ground when he was surrounded by passers-by, who attracted the attention of some policemen, and an ambulance was sent for. The surgeon from the New York Hospital said that he thought the man was suffering from alcoholic coma.
NEWPORT, June 12. -- There are now fully a hundred villas and cottages open, and Newport's gay season seems about to blossom.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- President Gompers and the other members of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor have sent a greeting on the immigration question to affiliated unions, in order by this means to obtain the sense of organized labor on the immigration question in its several phases. The greeting says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12. -- An important meeting of boat race officials was held at the Nelson House this noon. There were present H.S. Van Duzer, general manager of the Yale-Harvard-Cornell race; J.S. Wheelwright, Commodore of the Yale Navy; S.C. White, assistant manager of the Cornell crew; William Woodward, manager of Harvard, and Chairman William F. Booth, Treasurer William H. Frank, and Secretary Harris S. Reynolds of the local committee.

Right in the midst of their Summer cruising seafaring men will have to make changes in the number and arrangement of lights carried. The new Rules of the Road go into effect on July 1, and a careful perusal of them is necessary to prevent confusion, particularly in thick and foggy weather.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., June 12. -- As a result of a ruling by Judge Forbes in the Ellerson-Westcott will contest case to-day, the plaintiffs may be prevented from presenting testimony as to the manner of the death of Munro Westcott, the testator.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The Indian Office has received from Capt. Stouch, the agent of the Tongue River Reservation, a detailed report of the recent trouble at the post, resulting from the arrest of the Indian Stanley for the murder of Settler Hoover.

Treasure trove interests everybody. Mr. Robinson tells of eleven crowns of gold, set with precious stones, found in 1858 by some Spanish peasants near Toledo. One of the crowns has the Gothic name of Suinthila, who reigned from 621 to 631. Who buried them? We shall never know. The Brooch of Tara, Irish work of the seventh century, was picked up by a child on the seashore in 1850.

One of the attractive features of golf, which will be far more noticeable this Summer than it was last year, is the growing popularity of the game in purely Summer resorts. Besides the various clubs in such localities which have been organized by the residents themselves, the hotel proprietors in many cases have laid out golf links for the use of their guests.

The leading articles, which look so imposing, and which express the policy of a paper on important subjects, are not troublesome from the point of view of organization. The editor decides comparatively early in the evening what subjects shall be written about, and he, of course, also directs the lines which the articles shall follow.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 12. -- The cotton spinners of the Southeast met here Thursday. The purpose of the meeting was to perfect the organization of the Southern Cotton Spinners' Association. J.T. Anthony of this city is President of the association.

" There is nothing so unfortunate for a child or so disagreeable to older people as the child who is made precocious by being constantly put forward;" says a careful mother, "and yet I am trying in every way to train my children to be entertaining. I have had them commit to memory many beautiful poems, they begin to study music when they are very young, and dancing is a part of their physical education.

There is little doubt that the influence of the Turkish victory over Greece has been felt beyond the confines of the Ottoman Empire, and indeed to the ends of the Mohammedan world. The Mohammedan world does not enjoy the advantage of the press, but the mosques serve something the same purpose to Islam as the newspapers to Christendom, both for the dissemination of news and the inculcation of opinion.

BERLIN, June 12. -- The health of Mr. Edwin F. Uhl, the former United States Ambassador to Germany, has failed lately, and he has gone to Gasten with his family for a cure. Mr. Uhl will return to the United States in July, but the members of his family will remain abroad until the Autumn.
Somebody wrote: "To the Dutch the ladies of all nations are indebted for the invention of the thimble. The Dutch achieved this great invention about the year 1690."

CHICAGO, June 12. -- The traffic officials of the Eastern roads were thrown into a panic this afternoon by the report that a tariff had been filed with the Inter-State Commerce Commission making a cut on packing-house products and provisions from Chicago to the Atlantic seaboard of 12 cents.

It was a happy idea, when the women of the South were considering their contribution to the exposition at Nashville, that they should have decided to make their Woman's Building as artistic and important as possible.

NEW ORLEANS, June 12. -- Archbishop Francis Jannsens died at sea on the steamer Creole on Thursday. His body was transferred at sea from the Creole to the Hudson of the same line, and was brought back to New Orleans.

There is little doubt that the influence of the Turkish victory over Greece has been felt beyond the confines of the Ottoman Empire, and indeed to the ends of the Mohammedan world. The Mohammedan world does not enjoy the advantage of the press, but the mosques serve something the same purpose to Islam as the newspapers to Christendom, both for the dissemination of news and the inculcation of opinion.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 13. -- The local Police Department has solved to its satisfaction the problem of affording protection to the thousands of visitors who will be here at the races.

-- While the educators of Chicago are trying to produce a work on elementary mathematics which shall develop the reasoning power of children, instead of their ability to learn and apply rules, would it not be well for them to abolish the present absurd distinction between arithmetic and algebra?
PARIS, June 13. -- An attempt was made to-day to assassinate Felix Faure, the President of the French Republic, while he was on his way to Longchamps to witness the Grand Prix.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13. -- The baccalaureate sermon in connection with the one hundred and thirty-first commencement exercises at Rutgers College was delivered to-night in the First Reformed Church by the Rev. Dr. Roderick Terry pastor of the South Reformed Church of New York.
When Mr. ALLISON, pressed beyond all endurance by the attacks on the sugar schedule, finally ventured a defense, it was a very flimsy one.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The sugar schedule of the Tariff bill will be the subject of consideration in the Senate to-morrow, and maybe a day or two longer. The treaty and anti-trust amendments are still to be disposed of, and both will excite considerable debate. With the sugar question settled, the agricultural schedule, a portion of which has already been considered, will be taken up again.

PROVIDENCE, June 13. -- Dr. William H.P. Faunce of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church of New York City delivered the annual baccalaureate sermon before the graduating class of Brown University this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Indian Office has received from Capt. Stouch of the Tongue River (Mon.) Agency a detailed report of the recent trouble there arising from the murder of Settler John Hoover by David Stanley, a Cheyenne brave. After much diplomacy on the part of the agent, Stanley and his two accomplices, Sam Crow and Yellow Hair, are now lodged in jail at Miles City and will be tried by the civil courts.

If we were to judge from appearances, we should say that the United States would within a measurable period be without serious organized political opposition to the doctrine of protection. It is our judgment, on the contrary, that a reaction toward commercial and industrial freedom is bound to come, and that if the protective tariff shall ever again be made a distinct political issue, the popular verdict will be against it.

It is not surprising that The London Chronicle should protest against the refusal to give a place of honor in the jubilee procession to Mr. GLADSTONE and to the Speaker of the House of Commons. The Chronicle is the organ of advanced Liberal opinion in England, often verging on extreme radicalism, but in this matter it must represent the great body of thoughtful Englishmen.

ALBANY, June 13. -- There promises to be an exciting time at the meeting of the State Printing Board Tuesday, when the contract will be let for doing the legislative printing for two years. The present State printers, Wynkoop-Hallenbeck-Crawford Company of New York City, have been the subject of attack for some time by other printing concerns formerly doing State printing.

Harlem River oarsmen were out in full force yesterday afternoon. It was by far the liveliest day on the river this season. High Bridge was the destination of the majority of the crews. The tide was high and the water was in excellent condition, being exceptionally clear of driftwood, usually a serious menace to the oarsmen.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 13. -- Edward S. Edwards, better known as "Teddy" Edwards, the Welsh rider of the Century Wheelmen of New York City, has raised the American record for twenty-four hours' road riding to 349 2-5 miles. The best previous record, 314 miles, was made by Smith at Baltimore several weeks ago.

When the last heat was trotted at Fleetwood Park in the dusk of Saturday evening, the harness racers that are making the usual Summer trip bade farewell to the metropolis for some months. When they reappear for the Grand Circuit meeting, in September, their numbers will be larger, and it is expected the speed shown will be much greater than at the meeting just closed.
LONDON, June 14. -- The Paris correspondent of The Daily News says:

On this point the most authoritative of the visiting delegates speak with perfect plainness. They recognize the politeness with which they have been treated personally, but that only throws into stronger relief the essential hostility of our legislation to them. Col. FERNANDO MENDES DE ALMEIDA of Brazil, referring to the pending tariff, says: "Can we buy goods from a country that treats us in this manner?
Elverton R. Chapman, who spent twenty-five days in the Washington Jail for refusing to answer certain questions asked him by the Senatorial committee, returned home yesterday afternoon.

David Johnson Jackson, sixty-five years old, of 1,860 Boston Avenue, a retired policeman, who draws a seven-hundred-dollar pension from the Police Department for thirty years' service and a pension of $12.50 a month from the Government for services as a soldier during the late war, has been mysteriously missing from his home since May 21.
PARIS, June 13. -- The Grand Prix de Paris, the chief event of the French racing and social year, was won to-day by Dogo, owned by M.J. Arnaud. The animal is a brown colt, by Fricandeau-Dogarosso.

LONDON, June 13. -- All the morning papers comment upon the speeches of the Duke of Devonshire and Wilfred Laurier, the Canadian Premier, at the banquet given Saturday evening at Liverpool by the Chamber of Commerce. Most of these comments are in a tone of lively satisfaction. The Times says:

During the absence of the manager or Saturday night $595 disappeared from the safe in the Regal Shoe Company's branch store on Fulton Street, near Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn. At 10 o'clock Charles M. Hodson, the manager, in company with E.B. Marshall, manager of a Nassau Street branch store of the same company, left the Fulton Street store and went to a near-by billiard room, where they played pool.

Children's Day was observed in a number of Brooklyn churches yesterday. One of the most unique and interesting exercises was held in the New England Congregational Church, South Ninth Street, near Driggs Avenue, where the morning service began with the baptism of several babies.

There was but a slim attendance at Senator Platt's Sunday school, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, but the pupils made up in earnestness what was lacking in numbers. The notable ones were Chairman Hackett and Chief Clerk Fox of the Republican State Committee and Chairman Quigg of the County Committee.

The venerable ex-President of the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. William Alexander Smith, talked at length yesterday with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the stock market outlook and the prospects for general business throughout the country.

The Staats-Zeitung warns Mr. Low not to deceive himself about the difficulties of the canvass he may be called to undertake. The reputation he gained as Mayor of Brooklyn will count for little, it declares. The German vote will be a highly important factor in the election, and the Staats-Zeitung adduces reasons for German distrust of Mr. Low.

New York is to have a bicycle palace. It will be in the nature of a club, and will be something entirely unique. The direction of its affairs for the first year will be vested in a Board of Control selected from among the following prominent men, who have either given their sanction to the plan or have subscribed to the stock of the club:

What appears to have been a deliberate attempt to wreck a train loaded with returning pleasure seekers was made last night on the Sea Beach Railroad in Brooklyn. Owing to the fact that the train was heavily loaded, and running slowly because of trouble with the weight of the passengers, no serious damage was done.

-- It is a little curious that President MCKINLEY, in searching for "heroes of distinguished deeds" to use as illustrations of the greatness to which sons of Tennessee have risen, should fix upon JACKSON, POLK, and JOHNSON, every one of whom was born in North Carolina. Possibly other grounds for surprise might be found in the little list, if a person looked long enough.

St. Francis Xavier's Roman Catholic Church, West Sixteenth Street, was crowded yesterday at the celebration of Trinity Sunday, many people being turned away from the high mass. Father O'Connor preached the sermon, taking for his text Romans, xi., 33: "O the depth of the riches, both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!" He said:

A touching scene was witnessed yesterday afternoon on Blackwell's Island when confirmation services were held in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd connected with the almshouse. The class presented for confirmation consisted not of children, but of forty men and women, most of them aged and feeble.

The Kentucky Colonels are up in arms. The next gale that sweeps from the South will bring to our ears the clash of resounding bottles. In the words of PATRICK HENRY, "Gentlemen may cry 'Peace! Peace!' but there is no peace!" There is wind in the Blue Grass region, and the tempest thunders with the sound of many oaths.

PRINCETON, June 13. -- Dr. Francis Landey Patton, President of Princeton University, chose as his text for the baccalaureate sermon, which he preached to the members of the graduating class to-day, Luke, Tenth Chapter, Verse 23: "Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself." By way of illustration he read the parable of the Good Samaritan.

ITHACA, June 13. -- The exercises of the twenty-ninth annual commencement at Cornell University began this afternoon, the Rev. Dr. Alexander McKenzie of Cambridge, Mass., preaching the baccalaureate sermon. The text was "God give us good speed."

There is a probability that the Australian team which has come here to play baseball and cricket will be seen in New York. A special meeting of the Executive Committee of the Metropolitan League was held to conside the matter, and the Secretary was instructed to put himself in communication with the Australians' manager regarding a match.

The Church Army has established a new post in Jersey City, and Gen. Hadley, who is at the head of the work, is making his plans to carry on the movement regardless of the recent action of the Parochial Missions Society, looking to the withdrawal of its support next September. Gen. Hadley opened the new post yesterday, assisted by his staff.

One of the older members of the New York Stock Exchange has figured out that there are 289 members who have been in the board twenty-five years and over. He says that stock brokers are a long-lived race. All but twenty-one of this large number have been in the Stock Exchange for periods ranging from twenty-six to fifty-four years.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 13. -- After almost a week of travel, sightseeing, speechmaking, and social duties somewhat onerous, though pleasant in performance, the Presidential party had a Sunday of rest. The heat, while intense, was more or less tempered by a northwesterly breeze, which, however, was not much in evidence in the railroad station into which the train pulled from Nashville just as day was breaking.

If republicanism is a principle derived from nature's immutable laws, and, as such, has been adopted as fundamental or basic in our system of government, then its workings and its potency should always be paramount in whatever may occur, particularly on occasions important enough to materially affect the welfare of the people at large.

The delegates to the Central Labor Union appear to be taking just as much interest in Politics as they are in trades union affairs, and caucuses of delegates were held in side rooms yesterday while the general meeting of the body was going on in the main hall. When any important question was to be voted on the politicians hurried in and voted, and then went aside again and resumed their political deliberations.

Lord Kelvin yesterday gave an interesting turn to the old-standing dispute between geologists and physicists as to the age of the earth. As soon as the theory of Natural Selection -- at first hazarded as an audacious speculation -- had been adopted as an article of scientific faith, it became evident that we must revise all our ideas of chronology.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The treaty for the annexation of Hawaii to the United States, which was referred to in THE TIMES on Saturday last, will, it is understood, be sent to the Senate soon after the return of the President, unless present plans are altered. The treaty has been written, and all its details were fully agreed upon before the President and Secretary Sherman left for the South.

Apropos of Count Vorontzoff Dashkoff's resignation of the post of Minister of the Imperial Court and Appanages, and Director of the Imperial Stud, the St. Petersburg correspondent of The London Times telegraphs as follows:

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road has placed on sale in St. Paul a round-trip ticket unlimited in all respects, save dates, which is via Chicago to New York, for the price of $30.50.

At an adjourned meeting of the New Jersey Congregational Council yesterday afternoon, in Bible House, Astor Place, the Rev. Dr. A.H. Bradford presiding, it was decided to recommend to the First Congregational Church of Asbury Park, N.J., that the Rev. W.T. Widdemer should be installed. This places Mr. Widdemer in Congregational standing and disposes of the charges preferred against him.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 14. -- The President and party arrived here from Chattanooga in beautiful weather, warm, but tempered by a delightful breeze, at 11:40 o'clock. They were met at the station by a local Reception Committee and the Asheville Light Infantry. The President was received by Mayor Rankin and E.P. McKissick, manager of the Battery Park Hotel, to which all of the party went for luncheon.

At Bridgnorth, within a stone's throw of the home of Bishop Percy, whose "Reliques" have justified the preservation of his house, for nearly four months past women have been weaving with deft fingers the magnificent fabric which will, during the present month, be offered for her Majesty's acceptance.

Still only disappointment is reaped by the group of speculators who from day to day try to bring about a reaction in the stock market. At the beginning of business yesterday they were more confident than usual. They backed up their theories with substantial sales of short stock. Instead, however, of any recessions there were advances, some of them substantial.

C.S. Sargent, Thomas Hastings, John C. Olmsted, and Samuel Parsons, Jr., a special committee appointed by the Park Board to examine the plans for the proposed botanical garden in Bronx Park, have made their report. They do not agree with the plans of the Directors of the botanical garden, and have asked the Directors to meet them this week, probably on Thursday, in order that the differences may be adjusted.

St. Louis lost the second game of the series against New York yesterday afternoon by the score of 7 to 4. It was an uninteresting game and rather listlessly played. The New Yorks won because they were lucky enough to hit the ball when men were on bases.

The popularity of the Manhattan Beach track among local clubs appears to increase, if anything, as the season progresses. Its accessibility has always been a taking feature with New York and Brooklyn wheelmen, and even New Jersey riders prefer to cross over. The Excelsior Boat Club, an organization of Paterson, has chosen the track for its big racing tournament of July 3 and 5.

CAMBRIDGE, England, June 14. -- The Gentlemen of Philadelphia began a cricket match here to-day with an eleven representing Cambridge University. The visitors won the toss and went to the bat. The Philadelphians were all out in their first innings for 149 runs. Wood, who went in first, appeared to be the only man who was able to resist the good bowling of the Cambridge men.

NORFOLK, Va., June 14. -- William Jennings Bryan arrived here this morning from Washington, accompanied by Arthur Sewall of Maine. He was met at the boat by two committees of citizens, and after breakfast at the hotel was taken with his party in a special car to Virginia Beach, where he spent several hours.
