Duff Rusher have sold, for Paul Euell to J. Allen Townsend, eight lots on the south side of One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 225 feet east of Lenox Avenue. In exchange, the buyer gives the fire-story double flat 69 West One Hundred and Fifth Street, 32 by 90 by 100. The total value of the properties involved is reported at $125,000.

LONDON, June 14 -- Midnight. -- A special dispatch from Funchal, Island of Madeira, off the west coast of Morocco, says that on the arrival there to-day of the British steamship Scot, which left Table Bay, Cape Town, on June 2 for Southampton, it was announced that Barney Barnato, the South African "Diamond King," who was among the passengers, had committed suicide by leaping overboard.

A new form of gas burner, the invention of Mr. Thomas Rowan, is not very happily termed the "mantleless incandescent gas light." It has, indeed, no mantle, but since the introduction of the Welsbach light the term incandescent, as applied to gas burners, generally connotes the presence of some foreign substance in addition to the ordinary products of combustion, which, by being heated to incandescence, increases the illuminating power of the flame.
WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The final ratification of the boundary treaty between Great Britain and Venezuela was exchanged at the State Department at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

Fire broke out in the main building of the United States Immigration Station, on Ellis Island, shortly after midnight. It was first discovered from this city, when the flames began to shoot out from the northwest tower. This was at 12:30.

The red letter call, or summons, to members of four district assemblies of the Knights of Labor to attend a mass meeting in Union Square, last evening, to demand the municipal ownership of franchises, drew a crowd of about 2,000 people, which dwindled toward the end of the meeting.

Four hundred pounds of trout was the record for one day's fishing at Schoodic Lake, on the Bangor and Aroostook Railroad. This immense amount of fish comprised lakers and square tails. During the past week over 600 brook trout were taken there, together with 200 pickerel, 400 white perch, and 30 bass.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union held a meeting yesterday afternoon at 3:30, in the office of its Chairman, R. Fulton Cutting, 32 Nassau Street. A report of the sub-committee of five appointed last Wednesday night was received. This was the only business of the meeting that was announced after it was over.
PRINCETON, June 14. -- The class day exercises of Princeton's one hundred and fiftieth annual commencement were held today. Nearly 4,000 persons attended the exercises.

BUNKER HILL, Ill., June 14. -- The funeral of Mayor John R. Richards, who was shot last week by Editor Hedley, was held to-day, and was attended by nearly all the citizens of the town. The cause of the tragedy was Alice Brown, Richards's cousin, who had been his and Hedley's stenographer at different times. Both loved her, and were political rivals besides.

An old Frenchman namel Martin Hurel, who arrived in the steerage of the steamship La Bourgogne in September last, exhibited two paintings, one of which he declared was a genuine Raphael, and the other an original Rubens. Hurel wanted a large price for the paintings which, according to documents brought by him from France, were all that he said they were.

Once upon a time, and not so very long ago, either, calf and kid were practically the only "lightweight" leathers in use for shoe tops, gloves, pocketbooks, and the thousand and one articles made up of this material. To-day there are a bewildering number of kinds, some shining with their own light, while others are profiting by the popularity of another by assuming its name and appearance.

D.L. Russell, Chairman of the Southeast Missouri Swamp Commission, is in the city. This commission is composed of fourteen members from as many counties in the southeastern portion of the State, and its object is to formulate a bill to reclaim a very large body of land subject to overflow and present the measure to the next General Assembly.

A letter in your issue of yesterday, by Mr. de Cordova, and headed "The Curse of Legislation," seems to me to call for a re ply from this section. I can readily see how a man in Mr. de Cordova's environment could sincerely hold such views on the subject of trusts as he there advances, and it is my purpose simply to try to show something of the other side of the picture.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 14. -- There is only one case of sickness in the entire rowing colony here. The exception is young Kellogg, stroke of the Columbia freshmen crew, who was taken down with a fever to-day. He had been feeling poorly for several days before the crew left New York, but his sickness is not serious, and he will undoubtedly be in the boat again in a day or two.

Fortunately Congress cannot legislate for all time. The senseless barriers it is erecting against the commerce of the country will yield when public opinion is informed as to our real interests, and on public opinion facts must steadily tell.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The Republican Senators were in caucus for more than three hours to-night. Three propositions only were under consideration. These were: The question what to do with the Hawaiian reciprocity treaty, the advisability of giving a bounty on best sugar, and the matter of an anti-trust amendment.

Old Glory had a day brilliant in sunshine for its one hundred and twentieth anniversary, and a fresh breeze rippled the Stars and Stripes that were floated from housetops and window ledges. Flag Day was more generally observed than it was last year, or at any time since its observance was mooted five years ago, and the entire city was resplendent in red, white, and blue.

The Larchmont Yacht Club began a golf contest yesterday, which will continue through the week, the contestants playing any day they please and handing in a properly attested score. The lowest score turned in after Saturday's play will win. The club offers a silver cup as first prize. The Larchmont course consists of nine holes, and many improvements have been made since last year.

The steamship Vigilancia of the Ward Line, which arrived yesterday from Havana, was detained at Quarantine for disinfection because of the death of Bock Lem Jung, a Chinese second-cabin passenger. He died on Friday last, and his body was buried at sea. The vessel carried no physician. It was thought that the Chinaman died from heart failure.

TACOMA, Washington, June 14. -- China has two serious rebellions on hand, one in the extreme southern and one in the northern provinces. Mail advices received to-day state that the greatest rebellion the empire has known in recent years has broken out in the Prefectures of Lem, Loi Kin, and Kucheow, situated in the mountains north of Canton.

The fifteenth annual convention of the National Association of Master Plumbers of the United States will open this morning in the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street. It will be the largest in the history of the association. Between 550 and 600 delegates from all over the United States are expected to respond to the roll call.

-- An appropriate and useful decoration for the front halls of suburban residences is a neatly designed and framed tablet bearing the words "Have you forgotten your commutation ticket?" In some villages it is hung above, and in some under, the ever-popular request for a blessing upon home, but it is not considered good form to let the newer legend conceal the old one entirely from sight. Still, it's sometimes done.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- When the Tariff bill was taken up this morning Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) reverted to the colloquy of Saturday, in which he held that it was the right and duty of the Government to take legal steps to dissolve the Sugar Trust.

The Anarchists have been so quiet of late in France that it has seemed the promptness with which their predecessors of "the party of action" were dealt with had produced its effect. It requires an effort to recall the names of the Anarchist murderers whose names were in all the newspapers a few years ago, and who died expecting that they would be immortal.

The appeal reported to have been made by the Sultan to Russia and Germany to support his demand for Thessaly is also reported to have incensed the representatives of the other powers. It is natural that this should be so. An endeavor to detach any power or powers from the European concert is a distinct offense to the powers which remain in the concert.

WEST KINGSTON, R.I., June 15. -- Great excitement was caused here to-day when it became known that William Brown, colored, had surrendered to Policeman Joseph T. Northup and confessed that he murdered "Aunt" Martha Watson, also colored, Oct. 5, 1885.

We have not heard much of the Steckler organization since it was "recognized" in the distribution of offices by Mayor STRONG in the early part of his term. The Mayor knows more now, and he must look back upon his recognition of the Stecklers and their alleged "vote" with amusement not unmingled with chagrin.

TAMPA, Fla., June 15. -- A vessel supposed to be the Dauntless came into Hillsborough Bay last night, and took on a cargo of arms and ammunition from a schooner lying at anchor off the mouth of the Alafia River and then sailed away.

Further strenuous efforts are made to bring about a reaction in the stock market. Yesterday practically all the talent on the Stock Exchange seemed working to accomplish that result. The measure of success attained was small. A little nervousness was occasioned in two or three quarters, but no setback of any consequence was produced.

-- People who pay attention to the varying usage of words have noted within the past few weeks an inclination to substitute "former" for the prefix "ex." All of a sudden a vast number of writers have taken to "former President," "former Senator," "former Governor," and the like, while only a few have had the strength of mind to cling to "ex-President," "ex-Senator," and "ex-Governor."

CHICAGO, June 15. -- The Union Pacific today pulled out of the Western Passenger Association by giving the thirty days' notice of withdrawal called for in the association agreement. The cause of the withdrawal was the old fight over the divisions to be allowed the Oregon Short Line.

Argument will be made to-morrow morning before Attorney General Hancock, in Albany, on the petition filed by Philander B. Armstrong, an organizer and former President of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of 45 Cedar Street, seeking to have the officers of the company removed for misconduct.

The Brooklyns started off well in their game with Chicago at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon, but could not stand the pace. The visitors tied the score in the seventh inning, and in the ninth they made more than enough runs to win, through good hitting, coupled with some poor playing on the part of the home team.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Universal Postal Congress, the fifth convention of its kind in the world, closed to-day after a closed session, lasting several hours. The next of the congresses, the sixth sextennial one, will he held in Rome, Italy, in February, 1899.

AMSTERDAM, June 15. -- The results of the election to the Second Chamber of the States-General of the Netherlands are, so far as known, the return of twenty Catholics, twenty-two Liberals, and thirteen orthodox Protestants. At least forty-five second ballotings will be necessary.

LONDON, June 15. -- The officials of the Union Steamship Company, to which the steamer Scot belongs, confirm the announcement made last night in a special dispatch from Funchal, Island of Madeira, that Barney Barnato, the South African "Diamond King," committed suicide by jumping overboard while that vessel was on her way from Cape Town, which port she left on June 2, for Southampton, via Funchal.

There can be no doubt that Congressman WHITE of Chicago looks upon himself as a friend of the colored race in this country. He appointed JOHN W. SMITH, a colored youth, a cadet at Annapolis, and the candidate failed to pass the examination. It is not denied that the prospect of having a colored associate stirred up considerable feeling among the embryo naval officers at the academy.
New York took her third successive game from St. Louis yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds after a very one-sided contest.

Mr. F.T. Adams of the New York Stock Exchange and head of the well-known house bearing his name, talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the outlook for prices in the stock market. Mr. Adams is inclined to look for substantial reaction in the market, believing that stocks have advanced too rapidly in the past few weeks.

If we annex the Hawaiian Islands, we shall hold them by a tainted title. In the political and legal sense the Dole Government, being in recognized control of the islands, has full authority to make a treaty of cession. But the Dole Government in its origin is a rank usurper, for which we are morally responsible.

The Social Reform Club at its meeting last night discussed the action of the Corporation Counsel and of the city in the recent suit of Potter versus Collis. This case was tried before Jusice Beach, and was brought by an application for injunction forbidding a change of motive power on the Sixth and Eighth Avenue roads.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- It was the expectation that the Hawaiian annexation treaty would receive this afternoon the formal signatures of the negotiators, Secretary Sherman, for the United States Government, and either Minister Hatch or Lorin Thurston, as a Special Commissioner, for the Hawaiian Government. The document itself had been prepared and everything was in readiness when it was taken again to the White House for the President's final inspection and review.

The cigar manufacturing firm of Kerbs, Wertheim Schiffer has secured control of the Straiton Storm Company. The consolidation of the firms was completed yesterday. Both firms are prominent in the cigar trade.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- The fourth day of Princeton's one hundred and fiftieth annual commencement, alumni day, is one of intermission. No exercises of commencement proper have been held and many visit ors have taken the opportunity to inspect laboratories, museums, and halls of interest.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Charles F. Dietrich the four-story stone-front dwelling 142 West Eighty-second Street, 20 by 56 by 100.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15. -- The college crews had quite a variety of weather to-day. The sun, which shone fiercely upon the unprotected heads of the oarsmen during the morning practice, passed behind a heavy bank of clouds which floated down from the northwest shortly after noon and hung ominously over the river.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- Graduation exercises of Bulkeley High School occurred to-night in the Lyceum Theatre. The young men who competed for the gold medal prize acquitted themselves in true oratorical style. Among the subjects treated upon was an essay by Andrew L. Gard on "The Signs of Promise in the Crusade Against Yellow Journalism."

The city is showing a very wholesome disposition to take expert advice upon subjects upon which its own officers are not "charged with knowledge" of the expert kind. The Board of Estimate has shown its intention not to repeat, in the new Hall of Records, so grievous an architectural blunder as the Criminal Courts Building.

The destruction of the Government buildings on Ellis Island, used for the reception and inspection of immigrants, will cause inconvenience, but no serious loss, except to the Government. Arrangements have already been made under which it is believed that the immigration machinery will work smoothly and rapidly.

Some time since, The Gazette learned that an old gentleman named Wagner, living on a little farm up in Crawford County, was the possessor of an original letter from Gen. Andrew Jackson, written in the plain, vigorous style for which "Old Hickory" was famous. The Gazette wrote the Hon. Samuel R. Chew of Van Buren, commissioning him to secure for publication a copy of this letter.

The Friar stirred things up in the three-year-old situation at the Brooklyn Jockey Club track yesterday, when he defeated Voter in the race for the Broadway Stakes, a run of a mile and a sixteenth, also defeating Buddha, Don de Oro, and Ogden. These were all the starters, and they represented the best of a commonplace lot of horses of their age.
CAPE TOWN, June 15. -- The Cape Parliament has adjourned out of respect for the late Barney Barnato.

The Committee on Organization of the Citizens' Union, known also as the Committee of Two Hundred and Fifty, met last night at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, and, while no candidate for Mayor was placed in nomination, it was resolved to invite all voters of the Greater New York to give public expression of their desire that Seth Low should be named for Mayor.

The Atlantic Yacht Club's regatta, which was sailed yesterday, was very interesting tram a spectacular point of view, but hardly a success as a fair trial of the speed of the yachts that took part in the different contests. Luck entered largely into the races, and there was not a yacht that could be credited with having won on her merits.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- A delegation of office seekers from the Sixteenth Ward called on Mayor Harrison to-day. They had bolted the late Democratic judicial nominees. It was easily seen that Mayor Harrison would not yield an inch.
No doubt there is truth in the reports of thorns in the path of the tariff managers of the Republican Party.

In your issue of yesterday, Dr. Danforth, a passenger from Havana, who has been acting as physician to the so-called "President of the Cuban Republic," is reported as placing the number of the insurgents now in arms at about 30,000.

CHARLOTTEVILLE, Ga., June 15. -- The address of William J. Bryan before the Washington and Jefferson Literary Societies at the University of Virginia to-day drew an immense crowd. This morning five special trains entered Charlotteville, each loaded with visitors to its fullest capacity.
LONDON, June 15. -- All the afternoon newspapers discuss the Hawaiian question and the proposition to annex those islands to the United States. The Globe says:

CAMBRIDGE, England, June 15. -- The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and an eleven of Cambridge University, which was commenced yesterday, was resumed this morning. On Monday the American players, in their first innings, scored 149 runs, and when play was stopped yesterday evening the university men had 268 runs to their credit, with three wickets down.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15. -- Everything and everybody wore an old English air here to-night; even the atmosphere was English. The occasion was the presentation of "An Old English Fantasy" under the direction of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Greenough, on the spacious grounds of Franklin W. Dorman, in aid of the building fund of the Congregational Church of Upper Montclair.
LATONIA, Ky., June 15. -- Followers of favorites had another bad day of it. Only one favorite won. Weather hot; track fast, and attendance very large. Summaries:

ASCOT HEATH, England, June 15. -- Fine weather prevailed here to-day, the first day's racing of the Ascot Heath Meeting. There was a rich programme and big fields. The feature of the day was the victory of the Irish colt Galtee More, Mr. J. Gubins's Derby winner, in the Prince of Wales's Stakes. Galtee More also this year won the Two Thousand Guineas and the New-market Stakes.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Although it is assumed that the President is in favor of annexation, some persons, who heard the President's address in his inauguration, are confident that he is not. The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has proceeded upon the notion that the President will not oppose a proposition sustained by the Senate.

Former City Chamberlain William M. Ivins was arrested last night and taken to the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station, on a charge of disorderly conduct preferred by Conductor John Rieve of Columbus Avenue Cable Car No. 191. Policemen Dobbins and Hall of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station noticed a blockade on the Columbus Avenue line about 8 o'clock last night near the corner of Sixty-fifth Street.

Wall Street houses with London connections report that from their advices, London sentiment as to American securities is decidedly bullish, although the London speculator is showing a disposition to take quick profits on his ventures in Americans. In London yesterday the American stocks all showed strength, being, in fact, the features of that market.

A thousand obvious things to say about the life and death of BARNEY BARNATO suggest themselves. The temptation to moralize over the shocking end of his career is strong, of course, and there will be much more of moralizing than of explanation in the countless obituary notices inspired by the singularity, audacity, and picturesqueness of his life.
LONDON, June 17. -- Most of the morning papers contain editorials on the proposed annexation of Hawaii.

Affairs in the Immigration Bureau were running along smoothly yesterday despite the fact that the department has been deprived of its quarters at Ellis Island and of a great bulk of its records and other paraphernalia for the carrying on of its business. Fortunately for the officials, but few immigrants arrived yesterday -- only 170 on the Friesland and 455 on the Ems, so that the clearance was easily effected.

The Californian fruitmakers are advancing with rapid strides. They were always very successful in simulating the appearance of the natured fruit. Their pears and peaches were even larger and handsomer than those of nature and lacked only flavor to make them equally acceptable. But they were "Dead Sea fruits, that tempt the eye, but turn to ashes on the lips."

American shares were lower in the London market. The principal changes were: Declined -- Canadian Pacific, 1, to 62 1/4; Atchison, 1/4, to 12 1/2; St. Paul, to 1/4; to 80 1/4; Erie, 1/4, to 14 1/2; Illinois Central, 1/3, to 99 1/4; New York Central, 1/8, to 103, 1/4, and Reading, 1/8, to 11 1/8. Louisville and Nashville sold at 51. Erie firs preferred at 33 3/4, and Pennsylvania at 54 1/4.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 16. -- Over the canvas tents of Forepaugh Sells's circus to-day flags floated at half mast out of respect for Mr. Young.

BUFFALO, June 16. -- Ashley W. Cole, President of the State Railroad Commission, was asked to-day when Inspector Gatchell would make his report on the Valley Stream disaster. Col. Cole said that Mr. Gatchell's findings will not be made known until after the Long Island City Coroner has concluded his investigation regarding the disaster.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16. -- The auxiliary steam yacht Wild Duck, owned by J. Malcom Forbes, and the schooner yacht Elsemarie, owned by J. Barry King, arrived and sailed to-day, the former for New York.

The scheme of co-operative colonization in some Western State or Territory of the unemployed and the unfortunate, which is fathered by EUGENE V. DEBS, the agitator, and to which the author of that vastly overrated book, "Looking Backward," stands as a sort of irresponsible sponsor, does not seem to be either coherent or sensible.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 16. -- In the House of Commons last night Mr. Fielding, Minister of Finance, referred to a statement previously made by him in which he had said that in the event of the United States duty on coal being increased to 75 cents per ton, as proposed in the Dingley bill, it would be necessary for Canada to impose a duty on both bituminous and anthracite coal.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- Joseph Devoe, three years and four months old, died at the Institution of Mercy, conducted by the Sisters of Mercy at Pocantico Hills, yesterday from a dose of laudanum given him in mistake for cough mixture by one of the attendants. The boy's father, Frederick Devoe, lives in New York.

CALCUTTA June 16. -- Further reports of the destruction caused by the earthquake of last Saturday show that great damage was done at Dacca, Jamaltur, and Murshidabad. At the latter place the Nawab had a miraculous escape.

Whitehouse Porter have sold, for A.M. Hoyt, to L.V. Harkness, for about $275,000, the lot, southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, 57.2 by 120. It is probable that Mr. Harkness will erect a residence for his own occupancy on the site.

In compliance with a request recently made by representatives of the Wholesale Merchants' Association of this city the Board of Managers of the Joint Traffic Association yesterday adopted a reduced rate of fares for out-of-town merchants. The reduced rate will take effect upon advice of the completion of the merchants' organization and other definite details as to special sales of dry goods and similar merchandise.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16. -- All the fancy stores in Poughkeepsie did a rushing trade in red and white ribbon today, for the Cornell oarsmen arrived here this afternoon, and the people of Poughkeepsie, who are almost to a man stanch supporters of the Ithacans, wanted to show their colors.

At the American Horse Exchange yesterday W.D. Grand disposed of several consignments of horses, getting fair prices for all the stock that possessed merit. The sale took in animals suitable for heavy harness or riding, and began with seven head from Springhurst Farm, at Lexington, Ky., from which C.L. Railey has been supplying the metropolitan market for a score of years.

Suit will shortly be brought by Lawyer William M. Ivins, formerly City Chamberlain, against the Metropolitan Traction Company as a result of his forcible ejection from one of its cars and subsequent arrest Tuesday night as told in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Me., June 16. -- At a meeting of the Directors of the Dexter and Newport Railroad Company to-day a semi-annual dividend of 3 per cent, was declared, and arrangements with the Maine Central Railroad were announced for taking up bonds amounting to $175,000, issued thirty years ago by the Dexter and Newport Railroad.
A certificate of organization was filed yesterday in the office of the Secretary of the Interior at Washington creating a new corporation under the name of the Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company.

Miss Fanny Archbold did the winning golf playing yesterday on the Ardsley Club links in the second day's contest for the handsome silver cup given by Mrs. W.H. Granbery. The third and final round will be played to-day, and some close scoring and exciting play are expected, as the scores of the leading women are now very even.

UTICA, N.Y., June 16. -- At a meeting of the Board of Trustees of Colgate University yesterday afternoon, President George W. Smith handed in his resignation, owing to ill health. Mr. Smith was inaugurated President of Colgate on Nov. 14, 1895.

ST. LOUIS, June 16. -- C.D. Collins, a wealthy Tennesseean, was lured to probable death Tuesday night by a man he has known since boyhood and with whom he had been on terms of intimate friendship for six years. His assailant is Martin Ensley of Memphis, whose father, Col. Enoch Ensley, was one of the most prominent mine owners and planters of the South.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Congress has had its way in the annexation business, and if the treaty in annexation which has been sent to the Senate by the President with some reluctance shall be ratified, it will be because the President has obeyed what he believes is the desire of the majority in Congress, representing a National demand that Hawaii shall be accepted from the hands of the Dole Government.

Too much prizefight and too much religion are the causes for the increase of the population of the Bellevue Hospital insane pavilion by two last night. Edward R. Morgan, thirty-one years old, a plasterer, of 320 East Forty-second Street, is the victim of his devotion to the prize ring. John Leonard, thirty years old, a cook, living on South Fourth Street, Brooklyn, has religious mania.

The examination of the case against Ricardo de Requesens and Mrs. Eugenia Reineman, accused of sending to Costa Rica nearly 1,000,0O0 pesos in counterfeit notes of 100 pesos each on the Bank of Costa Rica, was begun yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields. Friend House appeared for Mrs. Reineman and R.S. Durrant of Howe Hummel for de Requesens. Assistant United States District Attorney Hinman presented the case for the Government.

A man of good appearance, who gave his name as John R. Stuart and described himself as an M.B.C.M. of the University of Aberdeen, Scotland, was arraigned before Police Justice Nevin, in Jersey City, yesterday, charged with trying to swindle by fictitious appeals for aid.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- It required the combined efforts of Mayor Harrison and big "Steve" Rowan to handle the mob of place hunters which crowded into the Chief Executive's office this forenoon.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- Princeton's one hundred and fiftieth Commencement Day exercises were held this morning. At 10:30 o'clock the university Trustees, Faculty, and members of the graduating class, in academic costume, formed in procession in front of old North Hall, and, led by the Annapolis Cadet Band, marched to the auditorium of Alexander Hall, where the exercises took place.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16. -- In the recent engagement between the Japanese troops and rebels against the rulers in Northern Formosa, the former, besides securing large quantities of Mauser rifles, succeeded in capturing the famous rebel chief, Sen Sin, (Tan Shin,) who had succeeded in evading capture ever since the arrival of the Japanese.

The Rev. Dr. John Hall of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church is authority for the statement that Miss Conde, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Swits Conde, has availed herself of the prerogative of her sex and changed her mind, and no longer loves -- if indeed she ever did love -- her sailor lover, Ensign G.L.P. Stone of the United States Navy.

Police Captain Donald Grant of the Old Slip Precinct will to-day prefer charges of absence from duty against William F. Annand of his command. There are other charges against the policeman, but they are not to be officially presented to the Police Commissioners at this time.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The President has nominated Stewart L. Woodford of New York to be Minister to Spain. Mr. Woodford is an old friend of Senator Platt, and the two have been on intimate terms since they were colleagues in Congress a score of years ago. Senator Platt vigorously urged him for a Cabinet position, trying to have him made Secretary of the Interior.

Wall Street bears got yesterday the reaction they have been so strenuously striving for. It wasn't a very large one. In no way was it significant of weakness in the financial situation; in no way was it consequential enough to disturb any interests that lately have been identified with the long side of the stock market.

The trial of the conspiracy charges against the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company made slow progress yesterday although some testimony of public interest was given. Counsel for the defense fought every inch of the way and interposed objections almost without number. Most of these objections were overruled and exceptions noted. The trial promises to be a protracted one, and counsel tables are piled high with portentous-looking legal documents.

The first business of the Board of Education at the meeting yesterday was the adoption of a resolution suggested by the Board of School Superintendents ordering the public schools to be closed June 30 and July 1, 2, and 3, during the meeting of the Teachers' Association, of which there are 6,000 members in this city and Brooklyn and 60,000 in the State.

The Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday, incidentally took up the matter of prize fighting, and decided that there should be no more of it in this city. The matter was brought up by a letter received from Mayor Strong inclosing a set of resolutions adopted by the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church, which denounced the fights at the Palace Athletic Club.

An open letter on the wearing apparel and personal effects features of the Tariff bill has just been addressed to Senator Thomas C. Platt by C.C. Shayne, President of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 16. -- The famous Charter Oak piano, which has been owned by the Stuart family, in this city, during the past forty years, will be removed to New York next week, having been secured by President H.W. Greene of the Music Teachers' National Association, which will hold its annual convention in the metropolis, beginning June 25.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Judge Dittenhoefer this morning resumed his argument on the motion to order an acquittal in the trial of John S. Shriver, Washington correspondent of The New York Mall and Express, charged with recusancy, before the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee of 1894.
The Clevelands proved themselves quite a different proposition from the St. Louis men by easily defeating the New Yorks yesterday by the score of 7 to 2.

If the Citizens' Union were a political machine controlled by a big boss and supported by a disciplined and obedient party it might make a deal with Mr. PLATT and the Republican organization without appreciably diminishing its vote. But the leaders of the Citizens' Union have a following made up altogether of men who do their own thinking and are as independent of control as the winds of heaven.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16. -- An investigation of the poor showing made by the torpedo boat Cushing in her recent run to Newport from New York results in the discovery that her overhauling at the Norfolk Navy Yard recently was very carelessly done, and a report to that effect was made to the department.

The first official demand on the part of the city that the officials of the Metropolitan Railway Company prepare to pay to the city something in return for the granting of the privilege of changing the motive power on the Sixth and Eighth Avenue Railroads was made by Mayor Strong yesterday at the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- A north-bound suburban train on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road ran into the Chicago River to-night at Kinzie Street. Six men were hurt, but it is not expected that any of them will die.
There is no possible good reason for the annexation of Hawaii. What are the bad ones?
John H. Comer, who is opposed to the consolidation of St. Ann's and St. Matthew's Churches, made the following statement yesterday:

BERLIN, June 17. -- The Emperor William gave an audience this morning to Dr. von Boetticher, Minister of the Department of the Interior and Vice President of the Prussian Ministry, and then started for Cologne to unveil the statue of the Emperor William L. Dr. von Boetticher will also be present at the ceremony.

LONDON, June 18. -- The Daily News announces that Mrs. Joseph Chamberlain, wife of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, will entertain the Prince and Princess of Wales on Wednesday, the 30th.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The House was in session an hour and a half to-day, most of the time being taken up with roll calls. Mr. Sulzer (Dem., N.Y.,) succeeded in injecting into the proceedings a brief speech in favor of Cuba.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The following, made public by vote of the Senate, is the full text of the Hawaiian treaty sent to the Senate yesterday:

BALTIMORE, June 17. -- The Lyceum theatre of this city is no longer in the Nixon Zimmerman Syndicate. John W. Albaugh, Jr., to-day signed a lease for the theatre with his father, John W. Albaugh, Sr. Mr. Albaugh said to-day:

The railroad world was much interested yesterday in the result of the annual meeting of the Ogdensburg and Lake Champlain Railroad Company, held at Ogdensburg, N.Y., on Wednesday. The Central Vermont Railroad Company's interests favored a postponement of the customary elections until February, 1898.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17. -- Coach Courtney ordered his three crews into their boats to-night to do an exhibition mile for Dr. Walter Peet, the well-known coach and rowing expert, and the mile proved to be a magnificent exhibition of speed, indicating that the crew which beats Cornell must be a remarkably fast one.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The results of the first shipment of butter ever made by this Gevernment to foreign markets, this time to England, have been communicated to Secretary of Agriculture Wilson in an official report from the experts, who managed the experimental exportation.

Residents of the Twenty-sixth Ward, Brooklyn, at the Brooklyn Music Hall, Alabama Avenue and Fulton Street, last evening celebrated the recent passage by the Legislature of the bill for the improvement of Atlantic Avenue. Edward F. Linton, the Secretary of the Atlantic Avenue Commission, introduced Mayor Wurster as the speaker of the evening.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Amid catcalls and hisses Vice President Lyon of the Board of Trade adjourned the meeting of the members interested in the proposed warehouse amendment in the call room this afternoon.

PARIS, June 17. -- At the garden party at the British Embassy here to-day in honor of Queen Victoria's Jubilee, the United States Ambassador to France, Gen. Horace Porter, the staff of the United States Embassy, the leading members of the American Colony of Paris, Senator Edward O. Wolcott of Colorado and Mrs. Wolcott, ex-Vice President Adlai E. Stevenson and Miss Stevenson, and Gen. Charles Jackson Paine of Massachusetts were present.

Acting for the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York, Charles E. Simms, President of the association, and W.H. Kay, representing the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island, decided to form an association to include the cycling clubs of the entire metropolitan district at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the office of P. Anthony Brock, 14 Desbrosses Street.

The Mayor has acted hastily and injudiciously in urging the Park Commissioners to adopt the plans for the Botanical Garden recommended by the Trustees of that institution. The Park Commissioners, on the other hand, have acted with deliberation and judgment in taking expert advice upon the plans from the point of view of a landscape architect, that point of view having apparently not been taken by the Trustees.

Cloudy weather combined with frequent threatenings of rain produced no deterrent effects upon golf enthusiasm yesterday on the links of the Ardsley Club. The third and last day's competition for the handsome silver cup given by Mrs. W.H. Granbery for a women's handicap tournament was played amid greater interest than was noticeable on the previous days.

-- Day by day comes new proof -- for everybody except the Senators and Representatives -- that the remarkable Tariff bill now under what a humorist might call "consideration" will be equally effective in the restraint of importations or exportations. It is a double-acting engine, moving two ways at once, and under its provisions producers are likely to be crushed as flat as consumers will surely be.

The plan of a new industrial empire in the Far West, which has been rather vaguely formulated by Mr. EUGENE V. DEBS, seems to have attracted the favorable notice of a tolerably large number of men who are anxious to go anywhere, free of expense, and to have somewhat pleased the President of a small railroad company who, doubtless, is much bothered by applications for work from the unemployed.

LATONIA, Ky., June 17. -- The Himyar Stakes, which is the next in importance to the Derby, was run at Latonia this afternoon. Ornament and Boanerges were the only starters. The track was slow, but sloppy going did not interfere with Ornament's chances, as he won in the same easy manner in which he captured the Latonia Derby. The summary:
About 250,000 shares were dealt in yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and the raction of Wednesday disappeared; quotations were almost unanimously at advances.
The Yorkville Wheelmen, who are now well settled in their new clubhouse, at 215 East Eighty-seventh Street, will take a run to White Plains Sunday, and on the following Sunday to to Livingston, S. I.

Any exception to the American rule of "criminal good nature" in submitting to small grievances, slights, and abuses ought to be acclaimed as a public service. Mr. W.M. IVINS has performed such a service in announcing that he will bring suit against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for the wrongful and brutal behavior of some of its agents.
Permit an old reader of your admirable paper to thank you for your vigorous editorial on the Hawaiian question, published in your issue of this morning under the caption of "Consult the People."
WASHINGTON, D.C., June 17. -- Accompanying the message was the following report from Secretary Sherman:

MINEOLA, L.I., June 17. -- About 5,000 people attended the second and last day of the June fair of the Queens County Agricultural Society, held here to-day. Some excellent specimens of Long Island strawberries and flowers were shown in the exhibition hall.

ASCOT HEATH, England, June 17. -- The weather upon this the third day's racing was fine and breezy. The royal procession was brilliant, and included the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, the Duke of Cambridge, the Duke and Duchess of York, Princess Victoria of Wales, Prince and Princess Charles of Denmark, Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, Grand Duke Sergius of Russia, and Grand Duke Cyril of Russia.

A long letter from Gen. Gomez, received yesterday, was the source of much joy and satisfaction to the Cubans at the Junta. It was dated May 16, at .the headquarters of the Cuban Army, La Gloria, Sancti Spiritu, and was addressed to Gen. Tomas Estrada Palma, the Cuban delegate.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Opposition to the Hawaiian annexation project has broken out much more violently than was anticipated by the Administration, and the treaty will be roughly handled when it comes up in the Senate for ratification. Whether the opposition will be able to muster sufficient strength in that body to defeat ratification is a speculative problem.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 17. -- As an outgrowth of the action of the Charleston Cotton Mill in displacing 300 white operatives with blacks upon resuming operations a few days ago, there is much suppressed excitement in the City of Charleston, where the mill it situated.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The following is the full text of the message sent to the Senate yesterday by President McKinley to accompany the Hawaiian treaty:

WINDSOR, England, June 17. -- Queen Victoria arrived here from Balmoral at 9 o'clock this morning. Thousands of people lined the route from the railroad station to the castle. Her Majesty looked the picture of health, and repeatedly bowed to the cheering of her subjects.

BALTIMORE, June 17. -- The Baltimore Consolidated Railway Company was organized to-day, the stockholders of the Baltimore Traction Company and the City and Suburban Company voting almost unanimously to consolidate the roads. The capital stock is $10,000,000, consisting of 400,000 shares at a par value of $25 a share.

Francis T. Underhill and H. Archie Pell have sold for Herman Wronkow, for about $75,000, the five-story apartment house, southwest corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 50 by 75.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The Senate made greater progress to-day on the Tariff bill than had been made any previous day since the debate opened. Two entire schedules, covering twenty pages, were gone over -- Schedule H, spirits, wines, and beverages, and Schedule 1, manufactured cotton goods.
Section No. 209 of the Revised City Ordinances says:

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17. -- The twenty-ninth annual commencement of Cornell University was held in Armory Hall this morning. Four hundred and thirty-two degrees were conferred -- 388 first degrees and 44 advanced. The procession of trustees, officers of instruction, alumni, and candidates for degrees formed in front of Morrill Hall at 9:45 o'clock, under the direction of Walter S. Schuyler, Commandant, and marched to Armory Hall, where the degrees were conferred.

The striking tailors were surprised yesterday morning by a committee from the Contractors' Association calling at the office of the Settlement Committee of the brotherhood, at 50 Essex Street, and offering to capitulate. The contractors' committee said the Contractors' Association would sign the agreement in a body, and offered real estate as security, or $1,000 in cash.

The Citizens' Union will begin to-day the work of securing such an expression of the popular desire as Seth Low said would determine him in accepting the nomination for Mayor by the union. In his letter of June 7, Mr. Low wrote:

BOSTON, June 17. -- One of the features of the celebration of "Bunker Hill Day" in Boston was the formal presentation to the officers and crew of the battle ship Massachusetts of a trophy from the Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- About 3 o'clock this afternoon ex-Queen Liliuokalani filed the following protest in the office of the Secretary of State. It was delivered into the hands of Secretary John Sherman by Mr. Joseph Heleluhe, representing the native Hawaiians, duly commissioned by two of their patriotic leagues.

Jacob L. Kahn, a retail tobacco dealer, and one of the District Attorney's witnesses in the case against the Tobacco Trust, was assaulted early yesterday morning by two men, who knocked him senseless. Mr. Kahn has owned two tobacco shops at 94 and 98 East Houston Street for nearly twenty years.

ST. LOUIS, June 17. -- E.P. Garner, car accountant of the Wabash Railway, with offices in East St. Louis, brought to this city to-day details of the attempt to wreck and rob a Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern passenger train on a culvert between Odin and Salem, Ill., about sixty-five miles cast of St. Louis.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- The Executive Committee of the Western Passenger Association met to-day for the purpose of considering the rate situation in the West. Representatives of the Denver and Rio Grande and of the Oregon Short Line were present to see that the interests of their roads were properly protected.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Among other statements circulated since the signing of the treaty of annexation with Hawaii calculated to give the impression that the Administration is not fully convinced of the wisdom of the convention was one that Secretary Sherman told the Portuguese Minister -- that, while he had signed the treaty, he was opposed to it.

That is an excellent suggestion, from every point of view, which the Mayor has made to the Board of Education, urging that body to acquire for the use of the College of the City of New York the buildings that are about to be abandoned by Columbia.

The Hoboken Turtle Club gave its first outing of the year yesterday at the King's Bridge Hotel. One hundred and twenty-eight members and friends enjoyed the breakfast and at the dinner the number was increased to 149. President H.H. Brockway made the opening address at the dinner and Hosea B. Perkins responded with a review of the history of the club, which is now 101 years old.

President Quigg of the Republican County Committee exploded what many of his associates describe as a "bomb" at last night's meeting of the County Committee in the Murray Hill Lyceum on East Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue. After the routine business of the meeting had been disposed of Mr. Quigg asked George R. Bidwell to take the chair, and going upon the floor, Mr. Quigg then offered the following resolution:

The National Civil Service Reform League has addressed a letter to members of Congress protesting against the report of the Senate committee on civil service and retrenchment on Senator Gallinger's amendment to the Deficiency Appropriation bill, removing from the classified civil service mechanics and workmen of every class.

LONDON, June 17. -- The Pall Mall Gazette this afternoon says that the Marquis Ito, the Japanese statesman, who was interviewed yesterday in Paris on the Hawaiian question, has declared that Japan will not create international difficulties in connection with Hawaii, and that certainly no other country will object to the annexation of Hawaii by the United States.

There was what turfmen call a surprising reversal of form yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The Clevelands, who had found it so easy to defeat the New Yorks the day before, were defeated by the score of 5 to 0. The Clevelands suffered the first shut-out made on the local grounds this year.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Representative Evans of Kentucky to-day introduced in the House a joint resolution authorizing the President to alter, modify, amend, or revoke the classifications and rules regulating the classified civil service. The resolution recites that there are " grave doubts" whether "certain recent extensions were made in good faith to promote selections on account of merit, or were in harmony with the intention of Congress in enacting the civil service law."
CHICAGO, June 17. -- "I will not allow any one to take away my Christian liberty. That is what the Council of the Church at the New York meeting attempted to do."

It is time for Brooklyn, Queens, and Richmond to join in the work of the Citizens' Union. It was appropriate that the movement should have its origin in New York, where more than half the vote will be cast. The New York organization has laid a solid foundation. It has awakened the people.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Senator Davis, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, said to-day that he would not make an effort to press the Hawaiian treaty to final consideration in the Senate during the present session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The advocates in the Senate of an increase in the duty on wool held a meeting to-day, and decided upon the following as the rates which they will ask the committee to fix on wool:
The Mayor's letter to the Board of Education would indicate that this conscientious and public-spirited magistrate has been misinformed on this subject.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 18.--George H. Jackson, who became famous In the Pearl Bryan murder trial by testifying that he drove the c@rriage in which Scott Jackson and Alonzo Walllng conveyed their victim to the Kentucky }{ighla.nds, where her body was found, to-day was found guilty of perjury in a case where he had given testimony in a criminal trial in Springfield. Sentence has not been pronounced.

NYACK, N.Y., June 18. -- The Ellide, a steam launch Built for E. Burgess Warren of Philadelphia, made a sensational run here this afternoon. She was speeded over the mile course, and made the distance in about a minute and a half. The yacht was slowed down near the end of the run through a mistake, and so the time was really faster than the watches showed.
J. Clarence Davies Co. have sold, for J.B Lorge, to C.H. Thornton, for $6,800, four lots, One Hundred and Eightieth Street, south side, 100 feet east of Webster Avenue, each 25 by 100.
LINCOLN, Ill., June 18. -- Five persons were killed and several injured in a cyclone that visited this section this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock. The names of the dead are:

Throughout the old Eastern District of Brooklyn no officer was so popular and beloved by the school children as Policeman William A. Fields. For years he was stationed at the crossing of Broadway and Gates Avenue, and the number of children's lives he has saved, and the thousand and one ways he has endeared himself to the tots and to their elders, is a part of the history of that portion of the town.

A monument for Heine's neglected grave in the cemetery of Montmarches, Paris, has been prepared in Rome by the Danish sculptor, Hessebru. It has not been ordered, however, and whether or not it will be erected over the grave seems to be a matter for future decision. A correspondent of The Pall Mall Gazette in Rome thus describes the circumstances in which the work was produced:

Policeman John Carroll, six feet tall and strong, patrolled his beat, along Manhattan Avenue yesterday afternoon, at peace with the world and himself. His state of contentment was rudely disturbed, however, by a mob of men shouting "Mad dog!" and by the sight of a small dog coming up the avenue, yelping with all his might and dragging six feet of rope behind him.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The Senate to-day disposed of only one page of the Tariff bill, almost the entire session being taken up in partisan debate, in the course of which some of the Democratic Senators exchanged somewhat caustic remarks.

LONDON, June 18. -- The Winnipegs, who have just arrived at Henley in order to compete at the regatta which begins on July 14, are in good form. They have recovered from the effects of the voyage from Canada, and are established in comfortable quarters.

OAKLAND, Cal., June 18. -- Fred Holturn, who lives in Berkeley, denies the story told by the sister of Barney Barnato that her brother never played in a circus. Holturn says that he and Barney Barnato performed together in the same ring in London many years ago.

The longest drive on record, in the game of golf, was until recently 288 yards. That drive was executed in Scotland, we believe, or in some other remote and frequently untruthful land, by some person quite unknown to the ladies and gentlemen who play golf in this neighborhood.

A remarkable volume about this country, written by an Englishman, "The Land of the Dollar," by G.W. Steevens, was noticed in The Review of Books and Art of Feb. 13. Mr. Steevens is a newspaper correspondent, who approached his subject, not with a view to criticise it because so wholly unlike England, but to understand it.

Many interesting golf contests will be played on many links to-day, and the players in nearly all the clubs around New York will be out in force. Ardsley and Baltusrol will command particular interest. At the former club the Edwin Gould Cup tournament will be played off by the six winners of the six monthly contests last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 18. -- The investigation into the management of the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children and the charges of cruelty on the part of Superintendent J.W. Pierce, had another inning to-day before Referee Daniel W. Guersey.

M. Arsene Alexandre in the Figaro pays a merited tribute to Louis Francais, whose death has been already recorded. There are a few of Francais's landscapes in the United States. In former days he was classed with Corot and Theodore Rousseau, and there may have been a certain resemblance in his works to both these artists.

PARIS, June 18. -- A cyclone swept over the villages of Bezons and Colombes, near this city, this afternoon. Houses collapsed, trees were torn up, telegraph wires were broken, several people were injured, and much general damage was done.

One of the greatest benefits from the reform of the Federal civil service has been the almost complete banishment of politics from the employment of labor, skilled and unskilled. The change is very great since the days when political clubs marched through the streets with transparencies inscribed, "One more rally and the navy yard is ours."

The trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company was resumed yesterday after an adjournment of one day, and Judge Fitzgerald sat in Part IV., General Sessions, having ordered the case transferred from Part I., because of the noise made by workmen who are tearing down the Tombs Building, and also because of the wretched acoustics of that court room.

New York again defeated Cleveland by the splendid score of 5 to 0 yesterday, in the most interesting and exciting game of ball played at the Polo Grounds this season. And to that erratic young left-handed dispenser of wild, tortuous, and speedy curves, "Cy" Seymour, is the greater part of the credit due.
LONDON, June 18. -- At the fourth day's racing of the Ascot Heath Meeting to-day Mr. Leonard Brassey's bay colt Bay Ronald, four years old, won the Hardwick Stakes.

LONDON, June 19. -- The correspondent of The Times at St. Petersburg, referring to the alleged jealousy existing in England because John W. Foster, the American Special Commissioner in the sealing controversy, visited Russia first, explains that Mr. Foster went to Russia when he did simply because the Eastern crisis and the jubilee preparations made the time univorable for a serious discussion of the question in London. He adds:

One of the most interesting features in the educational development of this country is the steady growth of the library movement. Within recent years this interest has shown marked progress, and not only have scores of small town libraries been established, but the literary standard of readers has been raised to a higher level.

Ex-Mayor HEWITT'S explanation of the position of the Trustees of the Cooper Union, which was published yesterday, puts in a new light the suggestion made by the Mayor to the Board of Education that Cooper Union should be used for a high school, in which use of it he understood the Trustees of it to acquiesce.

-- Bishop CHENEY of Chicago shows singular vehemence in denouncing the action of his church council in regard to the color of clerical vestments, which he describes as "such a childish thing, so small, so insignificant,'' and singular inconsistency in calling that action an attempt to take away his Christian liberty.

A seventh edition has been called for of "Authors and Publishers," that familiar manual of suggestions for beginners in literature which has been issued for many years by the Messrs. Putnam. It is compiled by two members of the firm, who scarcely conceal their names by the use of their initials only on the title page.

It is well that a prophet should be honored in his own country when proper occasion arises. The present occasion, however, is one of retrospect rather than of prophecy. Some of our contemporaries have been commenting upon Lord KELVIN'S recent address upon "The Age of the Earth" at the annual meeting of the Victoria Institute in London.

Messrs. Houghton. Mifflin Co. offer a new edition at a popular price of Lieut. Col. T.A. Dodge's "A Bird's Eye View of the Civil War." All the important campaigns and the leading characteristics of army commanders are contrasted. In this new edition, the latest War Department publications have been carefully studied, and there are not less than forty-seven maps and battle charts, with a glossary of military terms.

But little attention ever is given to the man of pure science, who, when investigating natural phenomena, risks his life. Take the bacteriologist, who handles the most dangerous of microbes. Is it supposable that he leads a charmed life or is ignorant of the risk be run? How many narrow escapes did Pasteur have?

Very much has been written about book plates in the sense of regarding them as bits of paper to be stuck into volumes, their adhesiveness as proprietary labels being dwelt upon to the entire exclusion of their artistic quality. A man having library is supposably endowed with some literary taste.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Senator Nelson of Minnesota has prepared an anti-trust amendment, which he will offer to the Tariff bill, and which, he thinks, will meet the objections that have been made to other amendments of a similar character. It follows:

Mr. QUIGG profoundly misconceives the spirit and purpose of the Citizens' Union. He charges the Union with attempting to "overreach or humiliate" the Republican organization. Pray, tell us, Mr. QUIGG, what the Union would gain, by overreaching and humiliating the Republicans.

The old Police Justices used to furnish abundant food for speculation and frequently for amusement. The men who gather news for daily journals found them a source of supply. But the Magistrates who succeeded them have not failed to preserve the interest of the situation.

Two months ago the New York Stock Exchange notified the Western Union Telegraph Company that after June 30 the contract under which the Western Union's auxiliary, the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, has for years been collecting and distributing stock market quotations, would terminate.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- John S. Shriver, the correspondent of The New York Mail and Express, to-day was declared not guilty of contempt in refusing to answer questions of the Senate committee in relation to the Sugar Trust investigation. E.J. Edwards, the New York correspondent of The Philadelphia Press, was put on trial this afternoon, and a verdict of acquittal was entered by direction of Judge Bradley.

After several hours' session yesterday afternoon the Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen decided to send the set of rules governing the use of city streets by vehicles, drawn up by the Board of Consuls of the New York City Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen, as their own report to the Board of Aldermen at the next meeting, which is set for Monday.

Communications regarding differential rates and their effect on the business of this city have been sent to the Board of Trade and Transportation and to the Chamber of Commerce by the Executive Committee of the Special Committee on Freight Rate Discrimination of the New York Produce Exchange, which consists of Henry B. Hebert, John Valiant, Charles P. Sumner, John P. Truesdell, O.M. Mitchel, and S.S. Marples. Like communications will be sent to other commercial bodies.

The work of sending out blanks for signatures of voters who desire the renomination of Seth Low is being pushed along rapidly at the Citizens' Union headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street. One of the members of the Union said yesterday that at least 50,000 signatures would be obtained.

Two children were abducted from Public School No. 13 and a third child from Public School No. 22 in Jersey City on Wednesday afternoon, but no report of the affair was made to the police, because it was supposed that the children had been taken by order of Judge James S. Erwin of the Second District Court.
LONDON, June 18. -- The Prince of Wales, as President of the Imperial Institute, presided over a banquet given by the Institute this evening to the Colonial Premiers.
Mayor Strong said yesterday that the story that he bad pledged himself to Seth Low or to any other man whose name has been mentioned in connection with the Mayoralty nomination was not true.

A large tomcat wandered into the crockery store of M.J. Lynch, 937 Eighth Avenue, Thursday night, and made himself at home. Three young women who are employed as clerks there, resented his intrusion, but after an hour's vain endeavor to chase the animal out, concluded to allow him to remain all night.

LATONIA, Ky., June 18. -- Favorites were beaten to-day in four out of six events. The surprise of the day was Kris Kringle's "win" in the fifth race at 50 to 1. Weather fine, track good, attendance 2,000. Summaries:

HAZARDVILLE, Conn., June 18. -- The "barn" cracker, a small building attached to the plant of the Hazard Powder Company, was blown to pieces this afternoon by the explosion of a quantity of powder. In the building at the time were three men, all of whom were instantly killed, and near by stood a horse, owned by one of the victims, and he, too, was torn to pieces.

-- Apparently it was not inadequate means but unintelligent methods of transportation that reduced the profit which the Georgia farmers used to derive from raising watermelons, and yet, instead of improving their system of distribution, they have to a great extent abandoned the raising of a crop that for years brought them returns much larger than those from products less dependent on special conditions of soil and climate.

It is not often than any of the States of the Union has called one man to its Governor's chair for three successive administrations, and it is rather a singular coincidence that the three years' administration as Governor of Massachusetts of the lamented William E. Russell should have been immediately followed by the incumbency for two years of the same office of Gov. Greenhalge, and by his election to the post for the third time.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- Coach Courtney was angered and prevented from giving the Varsity and freshmen Cornell crews the trial race of two miles be intended. Swells from passing steamers and several newspaper boats that hovered about impeded him.

It would have been quite as well had President McKINLEY sent the Hawaiian annexation treaty to the Senate without a word. Neither his message nor the report of the Secretary of State gives any ground for approval of the treaty. Both confirm its futility and recklessness.

The assemblage that gathered in Carnegle Hall last night to greet the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Francis E. Clark upon their return from a year's travel recalled the great political mass meetings that have made the hall famous. The suggestion was strengthened by the drapery of banners, the blare of trumpets, the full-tide of oratory, the exultant chanting of hymns of victory, and the fiery enthusiasm of the audience.
The "Merchants' Association," which has just been incorporated in this city, is an organization of quite a novel character, with a field of great usefulness open before it.

Judge Addison Brown, James A. Scrymser, William E. Dodge, and Prof. H.L. Brittan, the committee of the Directors of the Botanical Gardens to arrange for a site for the museums in Bronx Park, met the Park Commissioners yesterday. The conference lasted for several hours, and during that time numerous locations and plans were considered.

A young woman clerk in the office of the Secretary of the Faculty of New York Homeopathic Medical Colleges by an error of figures cost that institution much trouble and $150 in cash and promoted an indefinite quantity of discord and ill-feeling.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., June 18. -- After deliberating nine hours the jury in the United States District Court returned a verdict last night finding George Wilson guilty of manslaughter.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- At the request of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade the Treasury Department has made an investigation at New York as to the value of personal effects which returning passengers have brought to this country when returning from abroad.

Eight stories of "society." told with a graceful lightness of touch, and with a proper appreciation of the desirability of being of correct form, well connected, and "well stacked up," (which is a new Londonese phrase of great merit,) are bound together in this plump and pretty book. But Mrs. Burton Harrison is ever and suitably awake to the faults and dangers of good society.

LONDON, June 19. -- The Washington correspondent of The Daily Chronicle declares that President McKinley has instructed Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, the Minister-elect to Spain, to demand reparation and indemnity for the death of the late Dr. Ruiz and to intimate to Spain that if she refuses to grant freedom to Cuba she must be prepared to yield it to force, which would mean large sacrifices of men and money.

ATHOL, Mass., June 18. -- Gilbert Peters, a teamster, at South Royalston, yesterday afternoon made an attack upon Belle Rollins, seven years old. While he was being tried at Athol to-day, word came that the girl was dead. He was placed under $5,000 bonds, and the hearing was adjourned until June 25.

H.H. Hanna of Indianapolis, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Indianapolis Monetary Conference, is spending a few days in this city. He is deeply interested in the effort to secure Congressional authorities for the appointment of a commission to examine into and report upon the currency and banking system of the United States.

The Board of Street Opening, at its meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday, practically decided on the laying out of a small park at Seventy-sixth Street and the East River. The map of the park was accepted and the board voted to assess one-fourth of the cost to the surrounding property holders and three-fourths upon the city.

EASTON, Penn., June 18. -- The Easton, Palmer and Bethlehem Street Railway Company, with a capital stock of $150,000, has been granted a charter for a road between Easton and Bethlehem. W.B. Ferguson of Boston is the President and Charles F. Barnes of Plymouth, Mass., Treasurer. Among the Directors is C.A. Richardson of Boston.

TRENTON, N.J., June 18. -- The body of a woman was found in the canal near Morrisville this evening. It had been in the water about two days. The woman appears to have been drowned. Tied in a handkerchief which was placed next to her breast was a letter, which cannot be deciphered. On her wrist, fastened to it by a leather band, was a small tintype.

LONDON, June 18. -- The Hon. Whitelaw Reid, Gen. Nelson A. Miles, and Mr. Ogden Mills were the guests of Col. Henry Harlan Parr, special equerry to Mr. Reid during his stay here as Special Ambassador, at luncheon to-day at the Naval and Military Club. Among the company were Major Gen. Methuen and Gen. Sir Redvers Buller.

The idea of taking a polar holiday seems almost impossible, and yet that was the scheme Sir Martin Conway proposed and most successfully carried out. Spitzbergen was the objective pleasure domain. In his final chapter Sir Martin elaborates this fancy, and writes of Spitzbergen as a Summer resort:

Of all bookish fads, that of extra illustrating is the most interesting, and, it must be admitted, the most expensive. For to extra illustrate a book adequately it is necessary for the collector to go to enormous expense, and to give to the building up of the work the spare moments of many years.

There were a poor entire fool, (though Sir Robert Peel calls him "a bit" of one,) two great rascals, and three exceedingly wicked women, who compose all the Important personages in this story. The history of a silly young chap, ("a mug," or a "Johnnie,") is not uncommon in romance literature.

Detectives are the only people, except, perhaps, theologians, who find it professionally necessary to have a "theory" for everything that happens. The consequences, in the detective line, are sometimes very curious, as all readers of newspapers know. The epidemic of suicides by drowning in the Thames is certainly extensive enough and peculiar enough to excite curiosity.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A significant report on this country's trade with Cuba from 1887 to 1897, prepared by Chief Hitchcock of the foreign markets section of the Agricultural Department, has been promulgated by Secretary of Agriculture Wilson. The statistics show clearly the effect of present hostilities in Cuba upon the commercial intercourse of the United States with that island.

ELMHURST, L.I., June 19. -- Deputy Sheriff Kenling has not yet been able to find and arrest ten-year-old William Schneider, the school boy who is charged with setting fire to Josephine Miller, a schoolmate, on Monday.

FOR three years a few of the leading Jewish citizens of Philadelphia, led by Rabbi Joseph Krauskopf of that city, have been working and planning to found a Farm School in the neighborhood. This afternoon the farm and buildings will be dedicated with fitting ceremonies. But it stands to-day as the result of no local movement, and its name, National Farm School, well indicates the National character of the undertaking.

The new Hotel Astoria at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, has received its baptism of fire. It was just enough to create intense excitement in the vicinity for a time and to prove that the place is, to a great degree, at least, fire-proof. The structure adjoins the Waldorf, and it is by many considered an addition to that house.

BURR McINTOSH and his sister Nancy were unusually conspicuous on the New York stage last season. Both are popular and both have lately had opportunities out of the common. Miss McIntosh had sung in operetta in London and New York, but had never had an important role in the spoken drama, before she appeared at Daly's Theatre as Hero in "Much Ado About Nothing."

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 19.--Rear Admiral George Brown, until within the last few weeks in command of the Norfolk Navy Yard, which he was largely instrumental in building up to its present standard, was placed on the retired list to-day on account of age.

Oliver Adams is the owner of the new yawl Sakana, and yesterday he sailed her in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club to see what he could do with such boats as the Pawnee and Fidelio. The Sakana is smaller than the other boats, and she was sailing very well, and seemed to have the race almost won, when an incident happened that caused Mr. Adams to forget all about cups and victory.

Nearly all of the members of the German Liederkranz of this city have signified their intention to attend the eighteenth National saengerfest in Philadelphia this week. The Liederkranz will leave here early to-morrow morning on a special Pennsylvania train, and it will be one of the chief participants in the saengerfest.

NASHVILLE, June 19. -- This city and the State of Tennessee are entitled to be proud of the Centennial Exposition, which has now been in operation a month and a half, and is to last four and one-half months more before its gates are closed, its valuable, instructive, and entertaining collections dispersed and its buildings cleared away from the places they now occupy.

The result of the regatta of the New York Yacht Club, which was sailed on Thursday and a part of Friday morning, is another argument in favor of having time limits put on races. When the Goelet cups were sailed for in 1893 the Colonia won the cup for sloops, but it took her fourteen hours to go over the course, and some of the schooners were out twenty hours.

Edward Bellamy, the author of "Looking Backward,'' one of the most widely read books of the decade, in this new work introduces us again to his character, Julian West, who may be called the modern Rip Van Winkle, going to sleep as he did in 1887, and waking up some 113 years later. So ample was Mr. Bellamy's material, so rich is his imaginative power, that "Looking Backward" scarcely gave him room to turn in.

BERLIN, June 19. -- In spite of semi-official denials, there is no doubt that a new shuffling of the Cabinet has been decided upon by the Emperor, Dr. von Boetticher, the Vice President of the Council of Ministers and Imperial Secretary of State for the Interior, the Vice Chancellor, and Prince Holenlohe's mouthpiece in the Reichstag and Diet, has intensely dissatisfied his Majesty by repeated recent failures to vigorously represent the Government during important debates.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- When a Secretary of State says a thing, it is assumed that it is true. When a Minister makes a positive assertion about a matter, particularly if the matter is one of international interest, politeness compels the hearer to assume that he has spoken the truth as a diplomatic officer understands it. Thursday was diplomatic day at the Department of State.

ERIE, Penn., June 19. -- George Lytle, an Empire Line clerk, was fatally shot to-night by his father-in-law, John Honocker. Lytle had just returned for his supper, and while his father-in-law was showing him how he had missed a rat, the gun he had in his hand was accidentally discharged.

Golfers were out in force all day yesterday on the picturesque links of the Ardsley Club, near Dobbs Ferry. More contests were on the programme than has been the case during any other day of the season. The usual handicap tournament for Class A and Class B players brought out a fine contingent of enthusiasts.

One of the pleasantest and creepiest experiments of the Society for Psychical Research has been all but ruined by an extremely unpsychical and unimaginative person who is permitted to reveal his dullness and lack of all the qualities that go to make a man interesting in three columns of The London Times.

BERLIN, June 19. -- At the banquet held in the Guezenich Saal, at Cologne, yesterday, after the unveiling there of a statue to Emperor William I., the Emperor, replying to the Burgomaster's toast, said he remembered "the glorious time when the tall forms of my grandfather and father were seen among the citizens of Cologne." His Majesty added:

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The protest made by the Japanese Government against the pending Tariff bill is formally embodied in a note from Minister Toru Hoshi of date as late as the 3d of the present month. The note is couched in the most courteous language, but there is a firmness of tone observable that indicates the remonstrance may be followed by acts of retaliation if disregarded.

On the arrival of the American Line steamship St. Louis, from Southampton yesterday morning, Customs Inspector Wilson and Deputy Surveyor Daniel Dowling made a seizure of goods belonging to August Weil, senior member of the firm of Weil, Haskell Co., importers of and wholesale dealers in furnishing goods at 483 Broadway.

In the parish house of St. Andrew's Church, Richmond, S.I., there was a unique gathering on Tuesday of last week. Every religious body of importance on the island was represented, in most instances by their pastors, and they were there to do honor to the Rev. Dr. Thomas S. Yocom on the twenty-first anniversary of his installment as pastor of St. Andrew's Church.

GLASGOW, June 9. -- The Duke D'Abruzzi's new cutter, built in the Meadowside Yard of Messrs. Henderson of the Anchor Line, at Glasgow, has been launched. The cutter is from the design of G.L. Watson, and has been designed in conformity with our new girth rule as amended by the Yacht Racing Association.

The industrious CREELMAN has been interviewing the preposterous DEBS, and after reading the rhapsodies of the founder of the new Social Democracy about his yet unbuilt Arcadia on the Pacific coast we are not surprised to learn that DEBS'S ears "stand out straight from the head."
Curse, anything worthless. Corruption of the old English word kerse, a small sour wild cherry; French, cerise; German, kirsch.

Some of the best amateur riders of the metropolitan district were entered in the race meet of the Atalanta Wheelmen on the Waverly Park track yesterday afternoon. A card of twelve events was run off smoothly before some 2,500 spectators, most of them from New Jersey. The track was a little dusty, but this feature was not noticeable until a slight wind arose in the latter part of the afternoon.

The so-called Gresham law is founded upon axl enunciation by Sir Thomas Gresham In a letter to Queen /Elizabeth of /England in the year 1560, in which he pointed out that the debased coin of Henry VIII. was driving th'e good coin out of the country; that good and bad coin could not circulate together.

PARIS, June 8. -- The Parisians have just been covering themselves with flowers. The last echoes of the dire catastrophe in the Rue Jean Goujon have died away. The last medals have been conferred on the gallant rescuers at that terrible tire, the last banquets have been eaten in their honor, the last speeches to their glory delivered; and now Paris is almost herself again.

LONDON, June 19. -- F.E.
