Bacon, the English champion long-distance runner, to-day ran against the one-hour record of 11 miles 970 yards, made over thirty years ago, which he succeeded in breaking, covering 11 miles and 1,234 yards. The event, which took place at Rochdale, England, was witnesed by 30,000 persons, who greeted Bacon at the completion of his task with great enthusiasm. There was a steady downpour of rain throughout the race.
Mr. Secretary SHERMAN has permitted a formal and authoritative statement that while he is in favor of the annexation of Hawaii he is opposed to its admission as a State.

IT may be noted that what I have to say relates not at all to these showy and frivolous pictures that accompany it; but that cannot be helped. For what could I say, that might not better be left unsaid, of reprehensible and impossible mermaids and unblushing but comely dancing girls? As a matter of fact, in the close-season for theatricals the choice of theatrical subjects for illustration is small.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 19. -- One of the best team golf matches that has been held this season was played to-day on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club. The home club and the Richmond County Country Club of Staten Island were the opponents, and before the finish some of the finest golfing that has ever been seen over the Baltusrol links had been played.

LENOX, Mass., June 19. -- Mr. William C. Whitney and his son, Harry Payne Whitney, came up to Lenox this week to look over their 7,000 acres on October Mountain. They found the thirty-five elk looking finely, and they enjoyed seeing the many pheasants that Mr. Whitney has had put on the place. Deer and larger game from the Rocky Mountains are expected some time this season.

STOCKBRIDGE, June 19. -- Nearly every Summer residence in town is now occupied, and the new inn is very well filled with guests, so that the Stockbridge season has had as early an opening as that of Lenox. Mrs. Joseph H. Choate and family are at their home here. This week they have been entertaining Joseph Choate, Jr., George Choate, and Mr. Choate's nephew, George De Gerstorff of New York.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 19. -- As the days for the big intercollegiate boat races approach, the experts are comparing notes and trying to foretell the result of the struggles. The figures from which the experts are drawing conclusions show this work on the part of the different 'varsity crews engaged next Friday:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 19. -- By far the most general subject of conversation among rowing men and others interested in the intercollegiate race here, is the question of stroke. English and American are the titles of the strokes used, and both titles are absolutely misnomers. Harvard, with an English coach, is supposed to exemplify the first, and Yale the other. Cornell is concededly a half-breed.

Mrs. Russell Sage was indulging in reminiscences one day last week. Mrs. Sage has been through an experience recently which would tend to make any one less fond of the people and the days that are gone reminiscent. It was only the week before that she had stood before the graduating class of the Emma Willard School to tell its members how she had been graduated from that same school fifty years before.

There have been great banquets given in this city to celebrate the triumph of some political leader, the achievement of some cherished public design, or the yearly return of the birthday of the Nation. But last night the unique spectacle was presented of a banquet given in honor of a politician out of office, by former employes who are now serving under the banner of another party.

One of the principal legends connected with St. Patrick's altar stone, according to a writer in Donahoe's Magazine, is called the "Legend of the Leper and the Flagstone." This story runs as follows: When St. Patrick was embarking for Ireland to enter upon his mission, a poor leper came to the seashore just as the ship was about to weigh anchor, and earnestly begged to be taken on board.

BABYLON, L.I., June 19. -- The barn, carriage shed, and other small buildings on the property of R.I. Nicholas, in Deer Park Avenue, were destroyed by fire this morning. Mr. Nicholas is senior member of the firm of Nicholas Co. of 11 Wall Street, New York. The damage will amount to about $3,500.

Two Sisters of Charity connected with the New York Foundling Asylum, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, returned from Chicago yesterday. Robert Curran, the out-door agent of the asylum, against whom charges have been made that he has been carrying on a traffic in little children, selling them at $6 apiece is said to be still in that city.

Brighter and more seasonable weather, with the hot wave generally to be expected at this time of the year still happily deferred, has made the past week much more lively in the suburbs, and even in the city, where more well-known people still linger in consequence of the continued cool weather than usual at this season.

The tenants of the Grenoble Apartment House, at 210 West Fifty-seventh Street, received a number of severe shocks last night. A cry of "Fire:" caused them to rush for the fire escapes, staircases, and the elevator. The repeated and insistent ringing of the elevator bell brought forth no response to the agitated men and women, who, with blanched faces and beating hearts, awaited the arrival of the car to carry them to safety.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 19. -- The Franklin County Republican Convention, held at the City Hall to-day, expressed as the practically unanimous sense of the delegates that civil service is a fraud, and they instructed the delegates chosen to represent the county at Toledo to vote a plank favoring the utter abrogation of President Cleveland's civil service orders.

Mayor Strong's two suggestions to the Board of Education made to it at its last meeting, it is believed, will not be accepted or acted upon. These were, first, to secure the old site and buildings of Columbia University for the City College, and, second, that an arrangement be made with the Trustees of Cooper Union whereby the building and its facilities may be used as a manual training high school.

LONDON, June 19. -- A matinee for the benefit of the Queen's Commemoration Fund will be given at the Lyceum Theatre June 29 under the management of Edward Terry. A veritable galaxy of dramatic talent has promised to take part, including Sir Henry Irving, Sarah Bernhardt, Mme. Rejane, Mr. and Mrs. Baneroft, Beerbohm Tree, George Alexander, Edward Terry, Cyril Maude, Charles Wyndham, and Jone Hare, all of whom will be supported by their respective companies.

LONDON, June 19. -- The Queen is resting quietly to-night at Windsor, in excellent health and spirits considering the work of the past month, settling and debating the whole dictionary of details connected to the arduous historical work to come, for every arrangement, however trifling, in the programme of the next seven days has received royal sanction and consideration.

SISTERSVILLI, West Va., June 19. -- Some fishermen caught the badly decomposed body of a middle-aged man about a mile north of this city a week age. The body was anchored until morning, and then brought here for identification and burial. There was absolutely no mark giving a clue to the name or residence of the dead man, and he was buried.

GUELPH, Ontario, June 19. -- William Bell, the millionaire piano and organ manufacturer of this city, was stricken with a paralytic stroke while traveling on a train from Detroit last night. Mr Bell's illness was not noticed till the porter of the Pullman car went to call him this morning. He was removed to his home, where he now lies in a precarious condition.

The Tiger walked all over Eli yesterday afternoon at Manhattan Field, jumped on him, chewed him, and then wiped up the ground with the remains. In other words the Princeton baseball team defeated the Yale team by a score of 22 to 8. This makes the Sons of Nassau the college champions and leaves Yale without a single championship won this college year.

LONDON, June 12. -- If the English people were constructed and conducted more on the American plan -- that is, if the workman knew as much of history as the millionaire, like our American workmen, and some times a little more -- there would be considerable disappointment here, I think, over the pageant on Jubilee day.

LONDON, June 19. -- We are now definitely in the grasp of the Jubilee maelstrom, and are moving round with such a perceptible increase of speed that the weaker souls are already dizzy. What Tuesday's climax will be like it requires a robust mind to contemplate with calmness.

Queen VICTORIA'S reign has been exceeded in length, in modern history, only by that of Louis XIV of France. From his accession May 14, 1643, in his fifth year, to his death, in 1715, his reign occupied within three and a half months of seventy-two years. VICTORIA'S reign began June 20, 1837, exactly sixty years ago to-day.

VIENNA, June 9. -- Political complications of various descriptions developed to such an alarming extent within the Austrian Reichsrath in the past few weeks that the only possible solution left to Count Badeni was to prorogue the Assembly. At the rate the Deputies have been going of late the country was marching on the straight road to civil war.
" I say plainly, if we are to have this stealing, I want my share for South Carolina."

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 19. -- At 11:40 this morning Park Avenue. New York City, at Sixty-seventh Street, looked deserted, with only a few pedestrians and an occasional straggling vehicle, moving rather languidly in the hot sunshine. At 11:41 the guard of the Seventh Regiment appeared from the armory, under command of Lieuts. Wilson and McGreevy.

The golf tournament which has been in progress during the entire week on the links of the Larchmont Yacht Club was nearly finished yesterday. The committee extended the time for two extra days this week so as to benefit four members who were unable to play. Fourteen scores were turned in last night, and the leading man was George E. Ide, with a net score of 98.

The sale of a large tract in the Hunt's Point section of the Twenty-third Ward, to which reference was made in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, is practically closed. Although the deeds have not been recorded, it has become known that the buyer is George Crocker, the California millionaire, and that the price is in the neighborhood of $650,000.

For the past two or three years Lawson N. Fuller has been diligently striving to accomplish something out of the ordinary in the line of a public trotting performance. Last season he put six horses together, driving them a mile several seconds faster than three minutes. This Spring Mr. Fuller added two more to his team, and has been schooling the eight-in-hand for a mile worth talking about.
Dr. Benjamin Sharpe, Corresponding Secretary of the Academy of Natural Sciences, recently delivered at that institution in Philadelphia a lecture from which the following excerpts are taken:

CHICAGO, June 19. -- The trouble between the Chicago-St. Paul Roads over the low rates made by the Milwaukee and St. Paul Road from St. Paul to the Atlantic seaboard via Chicago have not yet been settled. It was announced that the Omaha Road had decided to meet the rate of $30.50 made by the Soo Line from Duluth and West Superior for the round trip between these points and Chicago.

SARATOGA, June 19. -- There is no sympathy nor good cheer in this famous village for the person who says that the popularity of Saratoga is waning. Although last season was commercially unsatisfactory, the shrewd Saratogian, who is an adept at observation and calculation, says that now the prospects are roseate.

BOSTON, June 19. -- The rattling good race of the Massachusetts Yacht Club off Nahant June 17 and the way the Cock Robin beat all the new boats in the knockabout class have given yachtsmen enough to talk about for a month, and now every one is anxious for further meetings of the boats in the hope that Cock Robin can at last be beaten.

REDLANDS, Cal., June 19. -- "The most funerals per capita in the most healthful town in America." That is the unique distinction accorded to Redlands by a New York physician, resident in this neighborhood a year. The doctor had shortly before been reading in THE NEW YORK TIMES about the Loomis Home for Consumptives, erected by J. Pierpont Morgan.

LONDON, June 19. -- The list of notabilities, guests of the Queen, who are gathered in London to-night to offer congratulations from the nations of the earth, is long and imposing. It includes on behalf of the United States, Mr. Whitelaw Reid, with Gen. Nelson A. Miles to represent the army, and Rear Admiral J.N. Miller, the navy, with their aides.
A MUSICAL EVENT of the utmost importance will be the Eighteenth National Singing Festival of the Northeastern Saengerbund of America, to be held in Philadelphia this week.

Wholesale merchants in an branches of trade in this city are gratified at the action of the Joint Traffic Association in granting reduced rates to merchants coming to this market for their supplies. There is a feeling among a good many of those interested that the reduction is not quite as large as it might be and should be in order to benefit both the local dealers and the railroads.

THE sailing of one of those great modern steamships -- the liner -- is an event to be seen, admired, and remembered. Within her capacious sides of steel the ingenuity of man has deposited the secret of eclipsing time and of annihilating space.

James Gayler, First Assistant Postmaster of this city, died Friday night at his home, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. He had been in bad health for about a year, and seriously ill for a week. Up to Saturday, June 12, he went daily to his office and performed his accustomed duties there.

NEWPORT, June 19. -- There has been considerable evidence of life among the cottagers this week, a half dozen entertainments of various kinds, including one or two pretty luncheons and dinners, having been given.
New plans are in progress by which the Stock Exchange may be able to obtain evidence showing connections between members of the Stock Exchange and bucket-shop principals.

ORANGE, N.J., June 19. -- Hilton, in the township of South Orange, is justly famous for its strawberries, and this year the crop is fully equal in size and quality to any of previous seasons. Henry Jerolamon, one of the principal growers, has a strawberry on exhibition in Newark which measures 12 inches in circumference, with a tape measure fastened around it, to prove his claim.

Two accidents occurred last night on Park Row within two blocks of each other and only ten minutes apart. The ambulance from the Home of Relief was no sooner laden with the hapless victim of one than it was summoned for the other.

LIVERPOOL, May 29.--The overhead railway here is one of the strongest reminders of New York that one sees in England. It is an elevated railroad, pure and simple, with electric engines instead of steam; and it runs up and down the street nearest the docks, close enough to give the passenger a good view of those structures, which are justly called "the pride of Liverpool."
Our neighbor The Sun strips the mask off the Citizens' Union and exposes what it calls the "real purpose" of that intriguing and subterranean organization:

THE new gunboat Helena, which is now receiving her battery and other finishing touches at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, is one of several small cruisers designed to meet the requirements of service in places where shallow harbors must be entered or rivers ascended. Such conditions confront naval officers on foreign stations very often, and for this service the larger and more powerful vessels of our navy are, of course, not available.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Senate Civil Service Committee resumed its hearings to-day. A letter was read from William B. Prescott, President of the International Typographical Union, in which he stated that the Typographical Union was not friendly to the application of the civil service rules to the Government Printing Office, as had been represented.

A great deal of interest has been manifested among golfers and throughout golf clubs over the new interpretations of golf rules which have just been announced by the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association, through the report of Charles B. Macdonald and Laurence Curtis, the sub-committee appointed last year to revise the rules.

The perfume of a thousand varieties of flowers filled the City Hall yesterday, and throughout the afternoon hundreds of children and grown persons crowded into the Aldermanic Chamber to feast their eyes on the wealth of floral beauty supplied by the second annual free exhibition of the New York Gardeners' Society.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 19. -- A test of the new etheric engine was made yesterday at Inventor Keely's laboratory in this city. A number of gentlemen were present, including General Manager Fransioli of the Manhattan Elevated Railway, New York: Mechanical Engineer Pierson of the same company, Chief Electrical Engineer Brown of the Western Union Telegraph Company, and Mr. Sterritt of the Metropolitan Traction Company, New York.

The names of most places suffer little change through the Latinization. An educated man would recognize the original through the disguise. For example, the Archbishop of Boston is "Archiepiscopus Bostonensis"; the Bishop of Belleville is "Episcopus Bellevinensis." But some of the Latinized names are not so easy.
WASHINGTON, June 19.--President McKinley has determined to revive the abandoned treaty of general arbitration between, the United States and Great Britain.

He was a Japanese student, Shasuka, fellow in chemistry of the Imperial University of Tokio, who came to this kitchen to learn general housework. He answered all questions, as to his capabilities with "I do not know, but I wish to learn." His interest in the culinary processes was great, his wan cheek flushed, and his languid eye kindled as the mistress initiated him into the applied principles of food chemistry.

Dr. Francis E. Clark, President of the Christian Endeavorers, who returned Friday morning on the Britannic from a year's tour of work and travel, had some interesting experiences among the Boers of South Africa.

LONDON, June 19. -- Two questions are agitating London. The prospective weather on Jubilee days, the procession day -- Tuesday -- especially, and how to get to the seats from which to view the procession. The weather recently has been cold, boisterous, and rainy, and the latest reports show that the cyclonic system is passing away eastward.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, June 19. -The two grand mountains which form the mighty chasm of the Gap have been fittingly arranged. The one on the Pennsylvania side is Minsi, in memory of the Indians who made the Minisink their hunting grounds. The opposite, more rugged and rocky cliff in New Jersey, has a name of Tammany, the chief of chiefs, who clasped hands in solemn covenant with William Penn under the elm tree of Shackmaxon.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer of the Army, for the last five weeks has been suffering intensely with necrosis of the middle finger of the right hand, resulting from freezing while on duty in the arctic regions.

Jenkins Van Schaick: "It certainly looks as though we have seen the beginning of a real old-fashioned bull market. The strength which stocks are exhibiting and the way in which the market stands liquidation show that there is a wonderful buying power in the Street.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- In the Senate to-day the Finance Committee suffered defeat on our important paragraphs in the flax, hemp, and jute schedule of the Tariff bill. These were the paragraphs relating to floor matting, plain jute fabrics, burlaps, and cotton bagging.

" Doctor," said the woman with the lonely, hollow expression around her lips denoting a physical lack of some kind, "I am going out of town now and I can't possibly wait to have a set prepared, and you will have to give me some ready made."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19. -- Awards of prizes are officially announced at Yale College this morning as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 19. -- The Republican County Convention to-day was clearly in the control of Hanna. A resolution ringing in its tone was adopted, indorsing Hanna for re-election to the United States Senate.

This is another mushroom story. The young women implicated in it are not members of a mycological club, and are only interested in the mushroom as it furnishes a valuable addition to the family table. But the story goes to show how the mushroom, like the fish, has a tendency to bring out the inherent depravity of the human animal.

PACHOGUE, LI., June 19. -- Supreme Court Justice Wilmot W. Smith gave a hearing to-day on the demurrer put in by the Long Island Railroad in the suit of the Montauk Indians against the railroad to recover the peninsula of Montauk. The land consists of 6,000 acres and is now very valuable.

WICHITA, Kan., June 19. -- The little village of Emet, Indian Territory, is greatly excited over the killing of the Rev. J.T. Evans, pastor of the Baptist Church, by Elisha Bradburn, one of the Deacons. The men met by appointment to settle a financial difficulty concerning a crop contract.

The members of the Columbia Yacht Club could not have wished for a more propitious day than yesterday to hold their thirteenth annual regatta. It was sailed on the Hudson River, off Eighty-sixth Street.

COOPERSTOWN, June 19. -- After many years of dilapidation and lack of care the five-acre plot of ground in this village where stood Otsego Hall, the home of James Fenimore Cooper, will be turned into a park, and will be known as the Cooper Grounds. The grounds will remain the private property of the Edward and Alfred Corning Clark estate, but will be open to the public.

We do not yet appreciate the tailless cavy as an article of human food. In France they sell them for rabbits; and there are three farms in this country where they are reared, and which export them to France, one farmer alone exporting over 150,000 of the little beasts. The flavor of the meat is said to be identical with that of rabbit meat.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- William A. Kinney, one of Hawaii's special Commissioners, in answer to Queen Liliuokalani's protest, said to-day:

Fontainebleau has no conspicuous charm. There are few nobles trees; the one of any excellence has a refreshment bar to celebrate it, and finger pots for miles around guide you to the giant "Jupiter." "Jupiter" is indeed a splendid relic, a straight column towering above the puny moderns, twelve paces round the swelling roots, six yards in girth at the height of a tall man.

" It is a pleasure," says The Wheel, "to announce that under the new administration those who ride bicycles are not only to be treated courteously by the Long Island Railroad, but cycling patronage is actually to be sought for. To this end a bicycle agent has been appointed whose sole duties are to look after wheeling traffic.

An application is now in the Surrogate's office, awaiting action on Tuesday, to compel Alonzo C. Monson of 14 East Sixty-third Street to render a complete account as executor of the estate of the late Daniel Dunham Withers, who died in the Brevoort House, Feb. 18, 1892. The applicants are Augustus Clason of 322 West One Hundred and Fourth Street and William P. Clason, his brother, of Annapolis, Md., nephews of the testator.

The banquet over which the Prince of WALES presided on Friday at the Imperial Institute was undoubtedly an assemblage very impressive to those who formed part of it and to those who witnessed it. But it is far more impressive to the imagination than it can have been to the sight.

Gen. WOODFORD returns from Washington happy and communicative. We all know his extreme reluctance to take office. Nothing but the entreaties of the President, the urgent advice of Mr. PLATT, and, above all, the repeated and loud calls of his country would induce him to exchange that privacy which is so dear to him for the odious publicity of the United States Legation at Madrid.

Not long since your correspondent "A.B." in reviewing an article written by me, discussed the differences between the Democratic and Republican systems of government. His idea that the Res publica -- the "Public Thing." or, in other words, "the Government," was the supreme motive of all political action, was the keynote of the whole question.

-- Stupidity or carelessness may account for the fact that the Populists of Kansas included among the "obsolete, inoperative, and redundant" laws which they have just repealed, the statute providing for sessions of the district courts, but one has to be of an unusually charitable mind to be quite sure of it.
Senator MORGAN has broken loose again and renewed his scolding of the House.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 20. -- The cornerstone of the new Roman Catholic Church of St. Dominic, in this village, was laid by Bishop McDonnell of the Diocese of Long Island at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Nearly 3,000 persons of this and the adjacent villages witnessed the ceremonies. The Bishop was accompanied by his secretary, the Rev. Father Barrett; Vicar General McNamara, and Chancellor James H. Mitchell.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 20. -- The first day of the Williams College commencement dawned very pleasantly this morning, but shortly after sunrise dark clouds floated through the sky and big raindrops began to fall. This lasted but a short time, however, and the sun came out for a second time, to remain.

LONDON, June 20. -- Queen Victoria began the celebration of her jubilee to-day, as was befitting her entire career, before the altar of her faith, while throughout London, the United Kingdom and the Empire, in every cathedral, church or chapel of the Established Church of England were held services similar to those at St. George's Chapel, Windsor, where her Majesty paid her devotions and offered solemn thanksgiving.

Senator NELSON of Minnesota proposes an anti-trust amendment to the Tariff bill which will do no good and no harm. The Sugar Trust would be hampered by it no more than the sturdy Norwegian would be by a cobweb across his path.

The coming jubilee of the Queen's coronation in England carries my memory back sixty years, when I sat on the wall of the Duke of Devonshire's palace, in Piccadilly, and saw the fair young Victoria as she was proceeding to Westminster Abbey to be crowned Queen. At that time I was the second mate of the ship Globe of Philadelphia, recently arrived at Liverpool with a cargo of cotton from New Orleans.

The mustering into the State service of the Second Naval Battalion of Brooklyn and the election of a new commander for the First Naval Battalion of this city are steps in the development of a militia force which promises to be in the near future of great value to the country. These steps go toward setting at rest the rumors of dissension in the naval militia which were rife only a few weeks ago.

The Nassau Boat Club's Board of Trustees will meet this week, when a date for the senior single-shell race for the Abeel Perpetual Challenge Cup, to be rowed over the regulation one-mile course, will be fixed. The cup, which is silver, with stag-horn handles, is held by the winner, while the gold medal which accompanies it becomes his personal property.

Clergymen of the Episcopal faith in this city are puzzled to determine whether ecclesiastical law demands the reconsecration of the building of Calvary Church, at Fourth Avenue and East Twenty-first Street, within whose walls a woman commited suicide Saturday, June 12. It is likely that nothing will be done in the matter, at least until the return of Bishop Potter, in the latter part of the Summer.

Protestant Episcopal churches all over the world held special services yesterday to commemorate the sixtieth anniversary of the accession of Queen Victoria to the British throne. In this city the services were especially impressive. Trinity Church announced a service of thanksgiving to begin at 4 o'clock, but long before that hour the pews were filled with a fashionable audience, and when services commenced there was hardly standing room anywhere in the church.

Believing as I do that you are interested in the awful condition of the colored brother South, I write asking space through your journal to say a few words in behalf of the little negro orphans in Charleston. It is fatal doom and ingratitude to God to let the little colored orphans suffer as they do to day for the sake of not having bread and proper medical attention.

The Sandy Hook pilots' new steam station boat New York arrived yesterday and tied up at the Atlantic Docks, where she was inspected by many of the pilots and their wives and friends. She received an ovation from harbor craft as she came into port.

COLUMBUS, June 20. -- The prospect of a "warm time" at the Republican State Convention at Toledo Tuesday and Wednesday has greatly agitated the conservatives of the party. There no longer is any doubt of the nomination of Bushnell for Governor and the indorsement of Hanna for Senator. The last of the County Conventions was held yesterday, and the eighty-eight counties, with one or two exceptions, accepted these two propositions.

Another of the down-town church landmarks is to go. The final religious service was held in the old Norfolk Street Dutch Reformed Church yesterday afternoon, and this week it will be turned over to a contractor, who will tear it down, and soon a big tenement building will be erected on the site.

DULUTH, Minn., June 20. -- John Haney, a section boss on the Wisconsin Central Railway, who is known along the road by the name "Little Humphy," was made rich a few days ago by the bequest of a miserly old uncle, who died in Philadelphia after willing to his far-away nephew the bulk of an estate valued at $150,000.

Many women, well known in church circles, and who are members of the Chiropean Society, have been interesting themselves in trying to obtain Mayor Wurster's consent to establish small parks in the neighborhood of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Nineteenth Wards of Brooklyn. The Mayor's wife, Mrs. Bernard Peters, and Mrs. James H. Darlington have been appointed a committee by Catherine D. Burnett, M.D., President of the society, to push the project.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- The monument erected to the memory of Harry Wright, the "Father of Baseball," was unveiled in West Laurel Hill Cemetery this afternoon in the presence of a large crowd of persons. It was expected that the National League would be represented at the unveiling by a number of the officials of the various clubs, but Messrs. Reach and Rogers of the Philadelphia Club were the only League representatives present.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 20. -- The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class at Smith College was preached by President L. Clark Seelye this afternoon. The service was held at the First Church, which was finely decorated. Music was furnished by the college Glee Club.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- Trinity commencement week began to-day with morning prayer and holy communion in the chapel. The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class was delivered in Christ Church this evening by the Rev. Dr. W.W. Battersball of Albany, N.Y.

Your dispatch stating that Liliuokalani of Hawaii, or any person whomsoever representing her, was at the White House yesterday, can only be explained on the supposition that some one was guilty of a practical joke on the servants. Neither the Queen nor any of her attendants has ever been there, nor does she go out with other ladies, although often invited.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 20. -- Because a deputation from the local Queen Victoria Jubilee Association called upon Bishops Glennon and Hogan recently and asked them to order prayers in their churches for Queen Victoria and did not wait upon the dignitaries of the Episcopal Church with a similar request, the Rev. P.F. Duffy of the Episcopal Church of Kansas City, Kan., deeply incensed, resigned from the association.

The New Yorks will open to-day in Baltimore, where four games will be played. The team then will go to Washington for three games. If the team plays the kind of ball it has been putting up for two weeks at the Polo Grounds, it should win at the very least four out of the seven games.

The very able editorials on the Hawaiian question, headed "Consult the People" and "Open the Doors of the Senate." published respectively in your issues of yesterday and to-day, entitle THE TIMES to the thanks of the American people as a watchful guardian of their interests and a stanch defender of their rights.

When James Wickham, fourteen years old, of 4 First Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Hedges, in the Essex Market Court, yesterday, to answer a charge of sending out a false alarm of fire, fifteen-year-old Oscar Werner of 32 First Street asked to be heard.

As so many cyclists cross the English Channel at this season of the year, and often wish to speak a word of French to a cycle agent or repairer, I append a little vocabulary of useful words, which has been communicated by a member of that energetic cycling organization, the Catford Cycling Club:

LONDON, June 20. -- High mass at the Brompton Oratory was made the occasion of a thanksgiving for the Queen's jubilee on the part of her Roman Catholic subjects, a special Te Deum being sung. The Oratory was richly decorated for the occasion, the marble columns inside the edifice being draped with crimson and the chancel with cloth of gold.

Secretary W.C. Allen of the Parkway Driving Club has compiled the list of candidates for the trotting and pacing events to be contested at the Fall meeting of the club on Sept. 14, 15, 16, and 17. A 2:33 trot and a 2:16 pacing class did not fill, and additional class races will be opened instead of them for entries on or before Aug. 1.

TACOMA, Washington, June 20. -- Chinese rebels in Formosa on May 15 made a second attack on Twatutia, the capital, hoping to drive the Japanese out and secure the large quantity of silver stored there by merchants, who will use it in buying tea.
LONDON, June 20. -- There were two services at St. Paul's Cathedral at 11 A.M. and at 3 P.M.

QUOGUE, L.I., June 20. -- Those old-time patriots of Speonk who still adhere to the name given their village two and a half centuries ago in preference to the newfangled and more easily pronounced Remsenburg which has been foisted upon them marked another point in their opposition to-day by holding services of worship in a tent in place of the handsome new church building which caused the name of the village to be changed.

Archbishop Martinelli, the Papal Delegate, drove down to the little Italian Church of Our Lady of the Rosary at Pompei, in Sullivan Street, near West Third Street, yesterday afternoon and participated in the unveiling of a beautiful picture of the saint in whose honor the little edifice is named.

A report recently made to the Department of Agriculture by Statistician Henry A. Robinson treats exhaustively of local taxation as affecting farms. It is understood to be the first report of its kind that has been prepared.

The records of the local cricketers who engage in the contests of both the Metropolitan League and the New York Cricket Association have been made up. The New Jersey Athletic Club leads for the championship in the league, and in the contests of the association Paterson has also an unbeaten record.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Republican Senators in charge of the tariff bill begin to feel that the end is almost in sight. They do not hope to conclude the consideration of the bill by the close of the present week, but they expect by that time to be able to say when they can complete the work.

Everything is now in readiness for the Surburban of 1897, and, if the day is a clear one, the cozy, homelike track at Sheepshead Bay should be teeming with life and activity to-morrow. The racegoing public will welcome the change of scene, for at Sheepshead Bay the surroundings are pleasing to the eye as well as comfortable, and in the intervals between races Lander's Band will furnish lively music.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20. -- Yale is here and the blue floats over the boat house and training quarters and the boating colony has a score more added to its already large numbers. The arrival of the brawny giants will now make it possible for the collegiate experts who have picked winners and condemned methods to change their opinions.

Fire in the three-story and basement house at 142 West Thirty-second Street late yesterday afternoon caused a panic among the tenants, in which Ella Duncans, a colored woman, jumped from the third-story window and received injuries that may prove fatal. Three other women were badly hurt.

RAHWAY, N.J., June 20. -- Interesting exercises were held in Woodbridge to-day to commemorate the two hundred and twenty-eighth anniversary of the Old Presbyterian Church, supposed to be the oldest in this section.

John M. Haneals, two years old, of 652 East Twelfth Street was badly burned at his home last night by the explosion of a giant firecracker. Mrs. Haneals was setting the table for supper, and little John had been placed in his high chair at his accustomed part of the table.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 20. -- The local militia company was called out this morning to search the town for some drunken Italians who had inflicted probably fatal injuries on one of the town policemen.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- The eighteenth National Saengerfest of the Northeastern Saengerbund will open in this city to-morrow, and there are indications that in respect to attendance it will be a greater musical event than ever has been held in this country.

HAVANA, June 20. -- According to an official report from Manzanillo, the insurgents continue to surrender. Gen. Calixto Garcia has caused to be placarded on trees, posters threatening to hang guerrillas and native volunteers.

Under the many Ministers who have served her Majesty in the sixty years of her reign the foreign policy of England has exhibited a remarkable steadiness and fidelity to the settled traditions of the empire. Probably no other power in the world has in the same period been so little affected by the changing views of its rulers in respect to foreign relations.

" I guess the Knights of Labor will get out of this," remarked Delegate William McNair, who belongs to District Assembly No. 49, when yesterday's meeting of the Progressive Democratic League, at 420 Hudson Street, was drawing to a close.

Dr. Peter A.E. Boetzkes, a physician at Bensonhurst-by-the-Sea and socially well known there, threw the settlement into a fever of excitement early yesterday morning by making two attempts to murder his family with a rifle.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, near Peekskill, June 20. -- The Seventh Regiment broke its own record and all other regimental encampment records this morning, having in camp 904 men of an enrollment of 1,050. This is rank and file and exclusive of the band of 97 men. Company K leads every other company, both in number and proportion of men present to enrollment.

At intervals enlisted men in the army or navy, but more frequently in the former, attempt to get redress for their supposed wrongs by appealing to the civil laws. This process, it may be noted, seldom meets with encouragement, because the civil courts usually possess sufficient intelligence to understand that military law is founded on the requirements of a service in which the ordinary relations of civil life are of secondary importance.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 20. -- Near 100 moneyed men scattered over Illinois have been made defendants in what are likely to prove the most notable suits concerning a National bank ever instituted in the West. It is another chapter in the famous case in which Charles Mosper, Treasurer of the defunct Capitol National Bank of this city, figured to the extent of stealing something over $1,000,000, and serving five years in the penitentiary.
Wall Street believes that we are at the end of hard times, and has been discounting hopefulness and confidence in an advancing stock market. Are the facts warranting this sentiment?

ATLANTA, June 21. -- The Northeastern Railway was not sold to-day, as advertised. The roacl is owned by the State, and the Governor did not get a bid, the upset price, which is $287,000, being regarded as too high.

It would be a very good thing indeed if some of those alarming patriots who fill the halls of Congress with the flame and thunder of their eloquence would sit down and read carefully Lieut. Commander J.D. JERROLD KELLEY'S article on "The American Fleet" in Harper's Weekly for June 19.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 21. -- Following is the make-up of the 'Varsity and Freshman crews of Harvard, Cornell, and Yale:
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

Commissioner STILES represented the cause of reason and civilization at yesterday's meeting of the Park Board. The board invoked expert advice upon the question whether the plan for the botanical garden reconciled, in the most complete manner possible, the claims of that institution with the claims of Bronx Park as a park, and received an authoritative opinion that it did not.

Horsemen, who are always anxious to add new vigorous racing blood to their stable strings, were out in force yesterday at the sale of the Rancho del Paso yearlings at the Easton Paddocks, near the gate of the Sheepshead Bay Race Track. The youngsters offered were a choice lot, and the bidding on the best of them was spirited.

John Meahlie, an alleged lunatic, living in an attic at 500 Washington Street, is said to be responsible for a fire which started in that building early yesterday morning. A Mrs. O'Brien, who lives on the first floor of that house, heard a noise up stairs in the attic, and being aware of Meahlie's condition, went out and called Roundsman Dougherty.

Once more we are compelled to ask, what do the Republicans want? What is the mysterious influence that holds them back from that prompt and hearty acceptance of Mr. Low's candidacy which would seem to be natural and inevitable if good city government is what they are after and not something else?
LONDON, June 21. -- The Times this morning publishes a jubilee ode from the pen of Sir Lewis Morris. It begins:
LONDON, June 21. -- The following is the text of the personal letter to Queen Victoria which was delivered to Her Majesty to-day by Mr. Whitelaw Reid, the Special Envoy of the United States:

BALTIMORE, June 21. -- The champions lost both games to New York to-day through their inability to hit Rusie and Meekin, particularly Rusie, who in the first game held the Orioles down to five scattered hits. The big Hoosier's support was faultless.

LONDON, June 21. -- Queen Victoria left Windsor Castle at noon by the Sovereign's entrance, facing the Long Walk, and traversed part of the high, Thames streets of Windsor on her way to the railroad station. Her Majesty's carriage was drawn by a pair of grays, with postilions and outriders.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Judge Bradley this morning instructed the jury to acquit Broker Allen L. Seymour of New York, on trial for alleged contempt of the Senate Sugar Trust Investigating Committee.

BATAVIA, N.Y., June 21. -- The trial of Howard Curtis Benham, charged with the murder of his young wife last January, opened here this morning. At 10:15 o'clock Benham was brought into court by Deputy Sheriff Dyer. He looked pale and haggard after 160 days confinement in jail.

The new steam pilotboat New York of the Sandy Hook pilot station made its trial trip yesterday, starting from Pier A North River. The course was down the ship channel, around the Southwest Spit, and through Gedney's Channel to the Sandy Hook Lightship, and return, a distance of about fifty miles.

He would be a very apathetic or a very misanthropic person who would not be really grieved if any untoward event should happen to mar the success of the jubilee celebration in London. The subjects of the Queen who has ruled through the longest reign in British history constitute something like a fourth part of the inhabitants of this planet.

Nearly 1,500 candidates entered the entrance examinations for the Normal College and 628 passed with the required 79 per cent. average. The rate was increased this examination from 75 to 79 on account of the crowded condition of the college. There were 870 who reached 75 per cent. In addition to what the Grammar schools furnished, a large number of candidates came from private schools and the Normal College training department.
LONDON, June 22. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Standard says: ...

-- There have been earthquakes in most continents and countries in the past few weeks, but none of them has yet tried its powers on really tall buildings constructed in the modern fashion. People who pass several hours a day in such buildings hardly know whether to rejoice or lament over this discrimination.

WALTHAM, Mass., Jun 21. -- Malone I. Wilson of this city shot and dangerously wounded Maggie Hines, a servant employed in the boarding house of Mrs. Moulton, Wilson's mother, at about 7 o'clock this morning. Wilson then went into his own room and, placing the revolver at his head, discharged the weapon, killing himself instantly.

HALIFAX, June 21. -- The annual meeting of the Royal Society of Canada opened here to-day. Among the delegates in attendance are Mayor John Boyd Thacher of Albany, N.Y.; Prof. Libby of Princeton University, H.L. Bridgman of the Brooklyn Art and Science Institute, Prof. Tyler of Princeton University, and Prof. F.S. Coop of the American Historical Society.

-- Considerably more mysterious than the Keely motor is the success with which, every year or two, he claims the attention of practical scientists and men of affairs for one of his so-called exhibitions. He never showed anything except a few wheels set in revolution by a force possibly unknown, but certainly concealed, and he is always as particular about "conditions" as a materializing medium.
William Fischer has sold for H. Weber to 'rnk Afeyer, the five-story fiat, 3 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, 7 by 100.1L

CHICAGO, June 21. -- At a meeting of the Directors of the Social Democracy of America, the following officers were elected: Chairman -- E.V. Debs; Secretary -- Sylvester Keliher; Vice President -- James Hogan; General Organizer -- William E. Burns. The Directors who chose these officers and were themselves elected at the meeting in the afternoon are E.V. Debs, Sylvester Keliher, James Hogan, William E. Burns and Leroy Goodwin.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 21. -- S.B. Comstock, who over thirty years ago located one of the richest mines in Nevada, died about thirty years ago, leaving no kin known here. S.F. Comstock and his sister, Mrs. Susan Farral of Independence, Ohio, knew of the facts, but never investigated, for the purpose of learning who S.B. Comstock was and whether they were related.

ALBANY, June 21. -- Another case of the petticoat in politics has come to light in Rensselaer County. It seems that a year ago one of the leading Republican candidates for Assembly in the Third District was Harry Bates. He was called to Troy early in the campaign by the then Congressman Black, and asked to step aside for one year, that George W. Anderson of Schodack might be selected to represent the Third District.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 21. -- Gov. Bushnell and other State officers and Chairman Kurtz arrived to-night and immediately took up the fight for the State campaign Chairmanship. Gov. Bushnell said it had always been the custom for the candidate for Governor to name the Chairman, and that he would insist on the continuance of Chairman Kurtz, who had made an excellent record in the last two campaigns.

In an editorial published in your issue of June 19 you stated: "There ought to be an ordinance forbidding bicyclists from riding on sidewalks. They have no business there, and they know it. The police should at once be empowered by a proper ordinance to keep them on the road." All reasonable bicyclists would subscribe to these views if there were also an ordinance requiring the proper authorities to keep roads in good condition.

CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, near Peekskill, June 21. -- Everybody who saw the evening parade of yesterday is busy talking of it this morning, and everybody agrees that it was the most beautiful in all the long and varied life of the Seventh Regiment. The conditions were perfect. Light and air, sky and ground, time and temperature were right, and the men were fit.
LONDON, June 21. -- This afternoon at 4 o'clock, in the Bow Drawing Room of Buckingham Palace, her Majesty received the imperial, royal, and other envoys.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 21. -- Sheriff Kirk to-day sold the organ of Grace Episcopal Church and all its other unattached personal property at auction. Craig A. Marsh, attorney for the judgment creditors, was the purchaser in every instance. Sheriff Kirk will sell the church property at the Court House in Elizabeth on Wednesday.

An audience that filled Carnegie Hall last night witnessed the closing ceremonies of the Golden Jubilee of St. Xavier College. The stage was decorated in the college colors and the Stars and Stripes. On the platform, besides the graduates and faculty, were Archbishop Martinelli, the Papal Delegate; Archbishop Corrigan, Bishops Wigger, Farley, Hotan, McDonnell, and McFaul, President Richards of Georgetown University, Falkers, Murphy, Duffey, and many other church dignitaries.

Mrs. Herman Warszawiak, who was led out of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Sunday after she had denounced the statement read in the church announcing the suspension of her husband, the Rev. Herman Warszawiak, was yesterday said to be confined to her room with nervous prostration as the result of shock caused by being put out.

LONDON, June 21. -- At Lord's Cricket Ground to-day, the Gentlemen of Philadelphia began a match against an eleven of Middlesex. The latter won the toss and went to the bat. The first wicket of the home team went down for 26 runs, when Stoddart was bowled by Baily for 8 runs. The second wicket of the Middlesex players went down for no runs, when Rawlin was bowled by Baily.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Senate Finance Committee has practically reached a conclusion on the wool schedule of the Tariff bill, but it will not be officially announced until to-morrow. It was on this account that the wool schedule was passed over when reached in the Senate to-day.

NEWPORT, June 21. -- These yachts sailed to-day: Steamer Formosa, owned by W.H. Fabyan; schooners Varuna, owned by George L. Rives; Harbinger, owned by W. N. Russell; sloops Sharon and Beatrice, of the New York Yacht Club, and yawl Monticito, owned by W.L. Tompkins. The arrivals include: Sloop Mystery of the New York Yacht Club and Xara, owned by W. Van Wart.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Christian K. Ross, the father of Charles Ross, whose abduction on July 1, 1874, from his parents' home became a matter of world-wide interest and still remains largely an unsolved mystery, died early this morning at his residence in Germantown, aged seventy-four years.

The usual peace of the Brooklyn Navy Yard was disturbed by a fire which started shortly after 9:30 o'clock last night in the Ordnance Building, known as No. 13. The flames spread with great rapidity, and before the firemen gained control the building was completely gutted, with a total loss estimated at about $80,000 to $100,000.

The menace to wheelmen at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Fourteenth Street in the shape of a watering trough, to which wagon drivers turn without warning, with dangerous results to the many wheelmen constantly using that route, has not been removed, despite the fight the League of American Wheelmen Consuls of the city have been making over the matter.

It is curious that the names of the few reigning Queens of England should have become associated with periods of English history the most famous and memorable. There has been no English King within historical times whose name calls up to Englishmen such proud associations as those which belong to "the spacious times of great ELIZABETH."

A score of barefooted urchins romped on the dock at the foot of East Seventieth Street yesterday afternoon. None laughed louder than did little, red-headed Joseph Christie, aged seven, who had come from his home at 232 East Seventieth Street to play. He wore a new straw hat, and was proud of it, for he was the only one in the crowd that had a new one.

When men or women feel depressed or debilitated at the present day it is common to say, "I think I have malaria." What is malaria? It is only germs that get into the body; germs that thrive and increase unless they are killed; germs that worm themselves all through the system; germs that ruin the health and undermine the life.

Being possessed of certain facts not known to the general public, in the matter of the trial of Herman Warszawiak, by the Session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, and noting the great attention this matter has attracted throughout the press, I deem it my duty to publish some of the injustices practised upon the accused during the trial.

A strikingly ingenious and original article in your paper on the 20th inst., copied from The Memphis Commercial, and entitled "Astronomy a Dead Science," affords me an occasion which I have long desired of thanking you for the interesting and instructive articles that have appeared in your paper every month for years giving your readers a monthly horoscope of the heavens.

The Board of Managers of the New York Botanical Garden appeared before the Park Commissioners at their meeting at the Arsenal yesterday afternoon and submitted revised plans for the Botanical Garden in Bronx Park.

LONDON, June 21. -- The Queen at 8:45 this evening entertained at dinner ninety of her most distinguished guests in the State supper room at Buckingham Palace. Among those present were the Prince and Princess of Wales, with all the members of the royal family; the royal guests, the envoys of States with the rank of Ambassador, and the great Officers of the Household, who wore full Court dress.

LONDON, June 21. -- In the House of Lords to-day the Government benches were crowded, though there were fewer Peers present on the Opposition benches. There were many Peeresses present in the galleries set apart for them, and the Archbishop of Finland and a number of Iidian Princes were in the other galleries.

It was an eventful day for the Merchants' Association of New York yesterday. The Directors of the corporation held a meeting in the morning and elected officers and adopted a constitution; the newly elected officers immediately engaged rooms for the association, arranged for a meeting with the Joint Traffic managers to-day, and during their spare moments attended to the numerous applications for membership.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The Senate made great progress to-day on the Tariff bill. It is now believed that the consideration of the measure will be completed within a few days.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 21. -- Yale's crews have been seen here, and everyone now agrees that there will be a boat race on Friday. The victors will have to work for their victory, and the defeated crews will not be disgraced. The Yale men have created a very favorable impression, and the experts are all at sea trying to pick the winners of this week's races.
LONDON, June 21. -- The death is announced in County Mayo, Ireland, of Capt. Boycott. He was about fifty-five years of age.

Our neighbor The Sun is one of the defenders of Hawaiian annexation. It attempts to show that the absorption of this island two thousand miles distant from our coast is merely a continuation of the policy of expansion which prompted the Louisiana purchase and the acquisition of California and New Mexico, and the buying of Alaska.
The Bostons found it comparatively easy yesterday to add another to their long string of continuous victories, and defeated the Brooklyns at Eastern Park by the score of 11 to 6.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- After the approval of the Journal in the House to-day a special order was adopted providing for the consideration of a bill appropriating $100,000 for the repair of Dry Dock No. 3 at the New York Navy Yard.

The third week of the trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company for conspiracy began yesterday. No one is bold enough to attempt to predict when it will end. The trial has settled down into a stubborn legal contest. Scarcely a question is asked of any witness that objection is not made and argued pro and con.
LONDON, June 22. -- Chauncey M. Depew has kindly written for The Associated Press his impressions of the jubilee. They are as fellows:

ALBANY, June 22. -- The Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day informed former State Engineer and Surveyor Sweet, receiver of the Lebanon Springs Railroad Company, that if he did not begin to repair the road by July 15 they would begin an action in the Supreme Court to stop the operation of the road, on the ground that it is a menace to public safety and endangers the lives of persons traveling on it.

The Bostons stood at the head of the percentage list of League clubs just twenty-four hours. After winning seventeen straight victories, they were defeated by the Brooklyns yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park by the score of 7 to 4.

The famous Stewart collection of paintings and water colors, embracing over 100 masterpieces by French and Spanish artists, has arrived in this city from Paris, and will be sold at public auction some time next Fall. This is virtually the outcome of the visit to this country a short time ago of Jules Stewart, son of the late William H Stewart, the former owner of the collection.

Old arguments were heard again yesterday, when the counsel engaged by the parties to the legal controversy in regard to the right of the Metropolitan Traction Company to construct an electric road, and also in respect to the determination of the legal status of the City of New York as a controller of franchises for operation of a new motive power, appeared before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to sustain their briefs.

When Bunthorne in GILBERT'S "Patience" bursts into one of his flights of fancy, he reassures the alarmed heroine by confidentially telling her, "That's poetry." Whereupon she promptly answers: "If that's poetry, I don't like poetry." But although it is officially announced that Mr. ALFRED AUSTIN'S thirty stanzas on "Victoria" are poetry, we must not dismiss them with a similar comment.

While counting a package of money handed in for deposit yesterday Receiving Teller Harmer of the Nassau Bank found a queer-looking note. It was a silver certificate of the latest issue, with the figure "5" in each corner, but with the animated group that the Government prints only on two-dollar silver notes in its centre.

SEATTLE, Washington, June 22. -- A report was received to-day from Capt. Munger of the United States revenue cutter Grant, stationed in Alaskan waters, in which it was stated that the bark Gay Head, Capt. Foler, after encountering whale, had sent out two boats, which had been lost, and the crews of which were finally found by the cutter.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 22. -- Bamberg, the county seat of Bamberg County, this State, was the scene to-day of killing of highly dramatic nature growing out of the famous Murphy-Copes murder trial of two years ago.

We learn from a Chicago dispatch to The Journal that Mr. E.V. DEBS, the organizer of the great Chicago strike of 1894 and of the new Social Democracy Commonwealth, has received the following letter from the Rev. Dr. W.S. RAINSFORD of St. George's Church, in this city:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 22. -- The representatives of Yale, Harvard, and Cornell held a protracted meeting this evening, to decide upon rules and other preliminaries as well as to choose courses for to-morrow's race. In this ceremony the proverbial "Yale luck" asserted itself.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- The differences between the citizens of Evanston and the Salvation Army are becoming intensified. Brig. Gen. Brewer says $10,000 has been pledged to pay the expenses of determining what legal rights the army has in the town.

" To criticise the Supreme Court for its decision in the income tax case was reckoned last Summer to be a most treasonable proceeding by some of the very men who have kept up for the last few months a running fire of attack on the same august tribunal, for its decision in the Trans-Missouri Freight Association case." -- The Journal.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Judge Bradley to-day sustained the motion of the defense in the case of John W. Macartney, the Washington broker, charged with refusing to testify before the Senate Sugar Trust investigating committee, and ordered the jury to return a verdict of acquittal.

The Mayor declared himself unalterably opposed to the raising of salaries of city employes at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. Col. Waring's request to allow a part of the appropriation for his department to be used for raising the salaries of some of his foremen and Superintendents occasioned the remarks by the Mayor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 22. -- Yale's freshmen gave their coaches, trainers, and followers a bad scare for a time to-day. Some of the men drank some milk last night which did not agree with them. At least it was supposed that it was the milk. Anyhow, to-day some of the men were troubled with nausea and stomach trouble, and "Bob" Cock had to give them medicine.

ALBANY, Juno 22.--Carrie A. W. Vilas of Evanston, Ill.. has se,rved notice on the Attorney General and the Eames Vacuum Brake Company that as ast ockholder she will make application to the Supreme Court at Watertown on June 26 for permission to begin an action for the dissolution of the company on the ground that it has not tJerformed its corporate functions for a year past.

A.L. Mordecai Son, together with Frank Hughes, have sold, for Leopold Kahn, to Charles B. Barkley, the five-story apartment house, with store, southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 46 by 100; also, for Leopold Kahn, the five-story single flat, 156 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 25 by 99.11.

LONDON, June 22. -- The procession was practically in three sections as far as St. Paul's, though the two last en route to the Cathedral were consolidated as they moved into Piccadilly. The first to take up position was the Colonial procession, formed on the Embankment and moved via the Mall, thence past the palace, where her Majesty viewed it from a window over the route to St. Paul's.

STATE CAMP OF INSPECTION, Near Peekskill, June 22. -- The remaining days of the week of the encampment of the Seventh will be even more crowded with business than the beginning. To-morrow four companies are to be suddenly called up into the mountains to be given a taste of skirmish drill in actual woods and fighting; advancing, sharpshooting, and bushwhacking.

Last Monday's TIMES contained a report of a Trinitarian sermon delivered at a local Evangelical Lutheran Church, wherein it was stated that "the distinction of the persons in the Godhead is traced from passages of Genesis, from the plural form of the name 'God,'"

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A dozen tired young men riding bicycles stopped in front of the War Department Building this afternoon, and the leader, Major R.P. Davidson, dismounting, entered the department and presented to Secretary Alger a message which had been delivered to him just fourteen days and six hours before in Chicago by Gen. Brooke, commanding the Department of the Missouri.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 22. -- Many special trains arrived to-day with ex-Confederate soldiers and friends who had come for the purpose of attending the annual reunion of the noted Confederate veterans.

Our esteemed farce-and-freak contemporaries have been illustrating their usual enterprise of late in unusually startling ways. One of them the other day went to the trouble and expense of having cabled from London an anecdote about the sale of the Queen's signature by young BATTENBERG which it might have saved money by cutting out of the '"Topics of the Times" in this journal, where it had appeared some days before.

One of the most brilliant weddings of the season was that of Miss Lorena Langdon Barber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amzi Lorenzo Barber, who was married yesterday to Samuel Todd Davis, Jr. The marriage was solemnized at Ardsley Towers, Ardsley-on-the-Hudson, the residence of the bride's parents.
The "Gallant Twenty-first " -- meaning the Assembly district and not any regiment that ever bore the brunt of battle -- took its yearly outing yesterday.
Brooklyn was the birthplace and cradle of home rule for cities.

One of the most important golfing events next Saturday will be the opening of the new links of the Richmond County Country Club at Garretsons, S.I. The members took possession of their fine new clubhouse and grounds June 1, but it has taken some time to put the golf course in first-rate playing condition.

Michael F. Dwyer yesterday saw the accomplishment of one of the chief ambitions of his racing career. His colt Ben Brush won the rich Suburban, and proved pretty conclusively that he was not a "gold brick" when he was purchased by M. Dwyer.

Yesterday was a day of accidents on the Broadway cable line, and the unreliability of cable service as applied to metropolitan transit was clearly demonstrated. The most serious accident occurred shortly before 6 o'clock last evening at the Fourteenth Street curve, when the grip of a car caught in some loose strands of the cable and was carried along with a momentum that baffled all the efforts of the gripman to stop the car.

BALTIMORE, June 22. -- The champions took to-day's game from the New Yorks in a hot contest. It was a pitchers' battle throughout, in which Corbett had decidedly the best of the argument. The fielding on both sides was full of snap, and fast double plays were the features. Score:

LONDON, June 22. -- With the coming of night the crowds which had filtered out of the processional streets after the great show wedged back again, to view London alight. The sight was worth the trouble and risk, both considerable. The illuminations were achieved more artistically than the decorations by day.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 22. -- The Republican State Convention, which met here to-day to nominate a full State ticket and indorse a candidate for United States Senator, is completely dominated by Senator Marcus A. Hanna. The only matter of difference among the delegates was the choice of a Chairman of the State Committee.
LONDON, June 22. -- The Queen breakfasted at 9 o'clock, and informed her physician that she was not fatigued by yesterday's ceremonies.

A monster century run, probably the largest on record, is being projected by the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York for the first week of August. More strictly speaking, there will be two century runs within the week under the same auspices, but one run will probably be made in divisions. The second run is expected to have between 2,000 and 2,500 participants, mostly from the uniformed clubs of this city.
LONDON, June 22 -- Midnight. -- The jubilee was celebrated in almost all parts of Ireland with enthusiasm by public official fetes, decorations, illuminations, and bonfires.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- An exciting debate marked the consideration of the wool schedule which began in the Senate to-day. It developed the first open disagreement on the Republican side of the chamber and led to a warm personal exchange between Senators Carter of Montana and Foraker of Ohio on the one hand, and Mr. Allison of Iowa, in charge of the bill, on the other.

Frederick de la Tour Booth-Tucker, Commander of the Salvation Army in the United States, who was convicted of maintaining a public nuisance, will not be punished. Judge Newburger, in General Sessions, before whom he was convicted, suspended sentence yesterday and permitted him to go free.

LONDON, June 22. -- The last stroke of 12 had not died away in the midnight air when from some metropolitan belfries a tumultuous peal of bells announced Diamond Jubilee Day. The vast crowd that filled the miles of streets and squares answered with ringing cheers, and here and there the singing of "God Save the Queen."

LATONIA, Ky., June 22. -- Tillo, Turner Brothers' three-year old, added one more victory to his credit by winning the Spring prize at Latonia to-day. The second race on the card was declared off on account of the large number of scratches. Weather fair, track fast, and attendance good. Summaries:
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

The prosecution sprang a surprise toward the close of the afternoon session of Judge Fitzgerald's court yesterday, by calling Senator Clarence Lexow of Nyack as a witness in the trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company. The defense objected to his testimony, and the Court reserved decision until this morning.

Merely as a spectacle, the royal procession that moved yesterday through the shouting streets of London was no doubt very well worth seeing, but it was by no means unique or supreme. In all points of military display, in numbers, in gorgeousness and nicety of uniforms, in precision of arrangement and movement other countries, making parade of their affliction of huge standing armies, could surpass what England had to show.

President Duncan D. Parmly of the Phenix National Bank, and member of the Stock Exchange house of Marquand Parmly, said yesterday regarding the business outlook in talking to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

About seventy-five women prominent in Episcopal circles of this and neighboring cities left yesterday afternoon over the New York Central for Peekskill-on-the-Hudson. They were bound for the annual retreat of the Associate Sisters of the Order of St. Mary, the Anglican order of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, at St. Gabriel's, the mother convent of the order.
You cannot strengthen an infant by withholding or diluting its food. You cannot "foster" an industry by increasing the cost of its material.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Yale lost the game with Harvard to-day by a score of 7 to 5, before the largest crowd which has assembled on Holmes Field in years. Harvard was the favorite at the start, but the Elis were expected to make a stiff battle. The stands, with their huge class-day crowds, were a mass of waving colors and brilliancy, and the enthusiasm throughout the contest was unbounded.

The special committee of the Trustees of the College of the City of New York, to whom was referred the letter of Mayor Strong, suggesting the adoption of the buildings about to be abandoned by Columbia University as the new home for the City College, reported yesterday at a regularly called meeting.

The assertions we have reiterated almost daily about the candidacy of Mr. Low are sustained and justified by the speech of Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD to the Gold Democrats of Brooklyn. The important thing is not that Mr. SHEPARD agrees with THE TIMES. In many things he said he is not in agreement with it.

" Seeking a text on which to hang, rather than base, some remarks of its own relative to the political situation in this city, our neighbor, THE NEW YORK TIMES, made an injudicious selection from our columns, and in yesterday's issue attributed to The Tribune a purpose which it has never expressed nor entertained.
LONDON, June 23. -- To-night was a gala night at Covent Garden Opera House, where the whole programme and performance reflected the greatest credit on Manager Maurice Grau.

The Democratic conference committees named to consult as to plans for the Greater New York campaign will meet at the Hoffman House at 8 o'clock to-morrow night. They will agree upon a basis of representation that will make the Democratic City Convention three or four times as large as the Republican City Convention.

The last of the lot of yearlings from J.B. Haggin's Rancho del Paso Stock Farm were disposed of yesterday at auction in the Easton Paddocks outside of the Sheepshead Bay race track, but the prices they brought were not up to those of Monday and Tuesday. Pierre Lorillard bought a chestnut, brother to Dr. Hasbrouck and Dr. Helmuth, for $4,000, and Jack Joyner got a half sister to Nanki Pooh for $800.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23. -- The Rev. David H. Greer of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, who was yesterday elected Bishop Coadjutor of the Rhode Island Protestant Episcopal Diocese, was seen at his Summer residence here by a representative of The Associated Press, and, when asked whether he would accept the election, spoke substantially as follows:
RUTLAND, Vt., June 23. -- News reaches this city of a peculiar accident among the Grand Islands, in Lake Champlain, to a prominent man who lost his life at the age of seventy-three.

The event of the day, and one of the most important of the year from a military Standpoint, was the bifurcated expedition through the woods and wilds of Westchester County. It started at 7:45. One-half turned to the left in leaving the encampment and made toward the Hudson River. The other half took the right-hand way into a country of forest and hill.

At the close of proceedings in the trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company yesterday afternoon, District Attorney Olcott announced that the case for the prosecution had practically been made and that only a short time this morning would be consumed in examining one or two witnesses.

The four four-story brownstone-front dwellings 463 to 469 Fifth Avenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets, on a plot 66 by 100, have been sold for about $300,000. It is said that Martin Brother are the buyers. The transaction may prove to be a trade involving the southern half of the Church of the Divine Paternity property, 50 by 100, at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

LONDON, June 23. -- This day was one of the most fatiguing of the week for the Queen. The chief event of the day was the reception of several distinguished bodies of official personages. After this elaborate ceremonial the Queen returned from Buckingham Palace to Windsor, stopping en route at Slough, Eton College, and at the castle gates at Windsor to receive addresses.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The quick growth of the street-car mail service which within a short period has become established in a number of the large cities has created a curious complication at the Post Office Department.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 23. -- Yale's freshmen won to-day in a very pretty race. They finished with a full length of open water between their shell and Harvard's, and Cornell was nearly a length further behind. Yale's time was 9:19 1/2, Harvard's 9:26 1/2, and Cornell's 9:29 1/2, so that all three crews beat the record for this course, and the New London course, which was 9:41.

The annual report of Mr. HENRY M. LEIPZIGER, supervisor of the free lectures to the people given under the auspices of the Board of Education, has just been issued, and is of high interest. It is to the devotion and industry of Mr. LEIPZIGER himself that the public mainly owes the opportunities for instruction and entertainment which these lectures afford.

SUFFIELD, Conn., June 23. -- The Selectmen of this town have accepted the plan of route for the Springfield and Southwestern Street Railway Company, the petition for the same being approved and the papers filed late yesterday afternoon. The officers of the company give positive assurance that the work of construction will be started immediately.

As the result of the issue of a "News Bulletin of the Zoological Society," containing an invitation to all parties interested to become members, applications for membership in the society are now coming to Secretary Grant at the rate of ten per day. At its meeting yesterday the Executive Committee elected Levi P. Morton and W.K. Vanderbilt to the class of Founders, six persons were elected life members, and seventy-nine persons were elected annual members.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Referring to the recent dispatch from Lewiston, Me., wherein L.C. Bateman charged Congressman Freeman Knowles of South Dakota with saying that "Mr. Bryan's gift of $1,500 to the Populist committee was made with the distinct understanding that no action against fusion should be taken by the People's Party before the next National Convention," Mr. Knowles says:

Some of the reported talk about Recorder GOFF'S decision in the Van Aken case is both ill-advised and alarming. It seems to be the opinion of a number of lawyers versed in criminal procedure and at least of one Judge of a criminal court that if a man who is talking angrily to you suddenly puts his right hand into the hip pocket of his pantaloons you may with impunity kill him on the spot.

NEWARK, June 23. -- There was a fashionable gathering to-day in the Chancery Court, this city, of witnesses and spectators in the case of Mrs. Lillian Endicott of Plainfield, who seeks legal separation from her husband, Dr. George W. Endicott, the leading physician of Plainfield.

ORANGE, N.J., June 23. -- Governor Griggs and a team of golf players from Paterson were badly beaten this afternoon on the Hutton Park links, West Orange, by a team of players from the Essex County Country Club, the local golfers winning by sixteen holes up. Good scores were made by the players on both sides, but the visitors got into difficulty at several of the bad parts of the links.
BALTIMORE, June 23. -- The receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-day filed their report of receipts and expenditures for the month of April.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- At the eightieth annual commencement of Georgetown University to-day President McKinley was present at the invitation of the Faculty and presented the diplomas to the graduates.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The consideration of the wool schedule of the Tariff bill was resumed in the Senate to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- An eloquent tribute to the long and illustrious reign of Queen Victoria was a feature of the opening prayer before the Senate to-day by the acting Chaplain, the Rev. Hugh Johnson.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Hawaiian annexation treaty formed the principal topic of consideration by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations at its brief session to-day. The treaty and accompanying papers were read and referred to a subcommittee consisting of Senator Foraker, Davis, and Morgan, with instructions to investigate the entire question and report to the full committee.

A slender coil of white smoke issuing from a third-story window of the massive brick structure at the northeast corner of Laight and Greenwich Streets a little after 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon led to the prompt sounding of a fire alarm and to the giving of sufficient warning to enable 150 persons to escape from a doomed building.

Squire BANCROFT BANCROFT, to whom the honor of Knighthood has fallen in Jubilee year, is the second actor in the history of England to be thus distinguished for his services to his calling alone.
