The late Sir AUGUSTUS HARRIS, who was some sort of an actor as well as a daring and successful showman, was knighted in due course simply because he was for a term Sheriff of London.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23. -- Six of the leading grocers of this city have been arrested, and nearly all have been indicted, for selling molasses adulterated with glucose. The arrests and indictments are made under the new law against adulterations.

-- Of course, it is all right for the Seventh Regiment to make no distinction between richer and poorer members in the assignment of regimental duties at the State Camp or elsewhere, but somehow there is an element of the unpleasant in the frequency with which they call attention to this display of what is after all but very elemental common sense.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 23. -- Considerable anxiety is felt here at the non-arrival at this port, to take part in the great naval review, of the British training brig Sealark. She was due here last Thursday, but has not been seen since she left Devonport. It is believed the brig experienced the full force of the recent gale, and, being under sail, some mishap is feared.
PITTSBURG, June 23. -- J. Painter Sons, proprietors of the largest cotton-tie and hoop mill in the world, informed their employes to-day that a reduction in wages would be made.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 23. -- Collector of the Port James T. Kilbreth died at 6:30 this evening. He passed a poor night last night, and this morning rallied for a short time. He then began to sink again, and at 6 o'clock hope was abandoned. He died thirty minutes later.
SCHENECTADY, June 23. -- The one hundred and third Commencement exercises of Union College were held this morning. The graduating class numbers forty-five members.

LONDON, June 23. -- In the afternoon the Queen returned to Windsor Castle, and her progress was a triumphal processional. On the route the royal party made stops at Slough, Eton College, and Windsor, where they were received by the local authorities with impressive formalities and most enthusiastically welcomed by the populace.

Candidates in the recent examinations for entrance to the College of the City of New York found themselves working on unusually hard papers, and only 42 per cent. of them went successfully through the ordeal.

Mr. F.J. Lisman of the New York Stock Exchange, whose views recently expressed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on corporation mismanagement attracted much attention, pointed out yesterday a striking feature of the present railroad situation. Mr. Lisman said:

TOLEDO, June 23. -- The Republican State Convention completed its work to-day in a session of less than four hours. While there had been a hard fight for two days for the control of the State Central Committee, there was every appearance of harmony and enthusiasm to-day, The two contested districts were decided in favor of the Dick candidates, and this showed that the State Committee stood 17 for Dick and 4 for Kurtz.

A stench which it is claimed arises from factory conducted by T. Carter Bell and G. Curtis Smith, where a substitute for rubber is manufactured, in Palmetto Street, Brooklyn, was aired before Justice Lemon in the Ewen Street Police Court yesterday, where Health Commissioner Emery had the proprietors arraigned for maintaining a nuisance.

The occasion which a great nation takes of celebrating itself is not commonly an occasion for cementing its good relations with other nations. The demonstration is in the nature of the case exclusive, and as it is almost necessarily a demonstration of military power, it evokes rather the jealous scrutiny than the cordial sympathy of other powers.

Charles M. Fegenbush, alias C.M. F-Bush, thirty-eight years old, a mining operator, was arrested in this city yesterday by the Central Office police, on an indictment charging him with being a fugitive from justice from Denver, Col., from which city he fled five years ago, after having been released on bail on an indictment for forgery.
HOLYOKE, Mass., June 23. -- Commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke were held this morning at 10 o'clock, the Rev. Dr. Charles Cuthbert Hall delivering the address to the class.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 23. -- The champions to-day lost the last of the present series to the Giants in a loosely played game. Pond took the box in the sixth and proved more effective than his predecessor. Manager Hanlon to-day signed George Blackburn of Dallas, Texas, as an addition to the pitching department. Score:

Ohio is the first State to hold a Republican Convention since the inauguration of Mr. MCKINLEY. Mr. GROSVENOR'S speech as temporary Chairman is the "first gun" fired in behalf and under the direction of the Administration. It is not a cheerful salute.

Lieut. Peary returned from Washington yesterday after completing arrangements to get leave of absence from the Government service of five years in order to continue his attempts to reach the North Pole.

Edward M. Shepard said yesterday that the speech he made Tuesday night before the National Democratic County Committee in Brooklyn, in which he referred to Seth Low and his probable nomination by the Citizens' Union, has been entirely misconstrued.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 23. -- Walter B. Humphreys, a well-known real estate agent, made an attempt this afternoon to shoot Martin V. Bergen, a leading lawyer and City Superintendent of Schools. The assault was made in Mr. Bergen's office.

Indications point to a successful day of sport at the sixteenth annual race meet of the Kings County Wheelmen on the Manhattan Beach track to-morrow afternoon. Two hundred riders have already entered, which means over 400 entries, and among the number are nearly all the best amateurs of New York State.

A magnificent looking yearling, a full brother to the Latonia Derby winner, Ornament, was the star of the sale of the Beaumont Stud yearlings at the Easton Paddocks, Sheepshead Bay, yesterday. Because of his relationship to Ornament, as well as his trim, racy appearance, no surprise was shown by the spectators when the bidding for him reached $10,000.

Frank Wild, whose wife says that he is insane, was in charge of their home yesterday at One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street and Stebbins Avenue. He had barricaded himself in and with a loaded revolver had succeeded in keeping two policemen and a citizen off the grounds. Mrs. Wild went to the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning to get a warrant for the arrest of her husband.

-- It was inevitable that there would be protests against the acceptance and exhibition by this city of the statue rejected by Boston. Not all residents of New York are New Yorkers, and there are villagers enough among them to get up an amusing demonstration at every opportunity of this kind.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Republican Senators decided in caucus to-night by a vote of 22 to 11, to sustain the action of the Finance Committee in placing a duty upon hides, but did not pass upon the question of the amount of the duty to be imposed.

COLUMBUS, June 24. -- The Detroit and Lima Northern Railroad Company was incorporated to-day with a nominal capital stock of $10,000 by Waiter B. Ritchie, C.H. Roser, W.H. Leete, and E.B. Hathaway. The road will extend from Columbus Grove to Ottawa.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hale (Maine) came forward with a surprise in the form of a proposed amendment to the Senate rules admitting to the privileges of the floor of the Senate only ex-Senators "who are not interested in any claim or in the prosecution of the same, or directly in any bill pending before Congress."

The death of Collector KILBRETH removes an excellent and faithful public servant. His efficiency was for a long time much more conspicuous than it ought to have been, because he was the one member of the Board of Police Justices who was fit for the employment. By character, breeding, education, and learning in the law he was a model Magistrate, while his colleagues were grossly deficient in some of these requirements or in all.

Something of a sensation was created among the wholesale grocers of this city yesterday by the publication of a dispatch from New London, Conn., stating that six of the leading grocers of that city had been arrested, and nearly all indicted, for selling molasses adulterated with glucose. The arrests and indictments were made under the new law against adulterations. Each grocer gave a bond of $100.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Ferdinand Gottschalk, one of the leading men of Charles Frohman's company, now playing "Never Again" here, is compelled to give up his work and return to England on account of his health.

The Philadelphias played their first game this season on the Brooklyn grounds yesterday, and were defeated by a score of 7 to 5. The visitors are very welcome guests to the Brooklyns, for from them the home team expect to win enough games to regain the ground lost during the Boston series.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, who was arrested yesterday as a fugitive from justice, from New York, where he is wanted to answer a charge of assaulting his wife with a deadly weapon, was given his preliminary examination today. The prisoner appeared, greatly depressed.

LONDON, June 24. -- The Princess of Wales's Jubilee dinners to the poor to-day were very successful. About 300,000 denizens of the slums were sumptuously entertained at the various centres. The Princess, accompanied by the Prince of Wales, Princess Victoria of Wales, and Prince and Princess Charles of Denmark, visited the principal halls where the feasts were given.

Although the contract will not be signed until to-day, it was learned positively yesterday that Martin Brother are the buyers of the four-story brownstone-front dwellings, 463 to 469 Fifth Avenue, 66 by 100, for about $300,000. It is a purely cash transaction, and the Church of the Divine Paternity property at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street is not involved.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- A daily paper says: "The long-cherished plan of Charles T. Yerkes, the street railway magnate, to manufacture all machinery needed by street railroads in Chicago, New York, Philadelphia, and Pittsburg has at last been realized.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- A stubborn contest over the duties on manufactured woolen goods went on in the Senate throughout the session to-day. It was a day of roll calls and cross-fire debate on the effect of advancing rates. Many amendments were proposed to reduce the rates, but these were rejected by decisive majorities. Less than five pages of the tariff bill were disposed of during the day.

LONDON, June 24. -- In the House of Commons, to-day the Parliamentary Secretary for the Foreign Office, Mr. George N. Curzon, replied to the question of Mr. Ernest William Beckett, Conservative, member for the Whitby Division of the North Riding of Yorkshire, regarding Hawaii and annexation.

The Music Teachers' National Association assembled in this city yesterday for its nineteenth annual convention. The subjects which the teachers from various parts of the country have convened to consider are of considerably greater importance than they may seem to casual observers to be.

The Coroner's jury which has been investigating the deaths of the victims of the Merrick Road disaster, which occurred at a Long Island Railroad crossing in Valley Stream, L.I., on May 31, heard the last of the evidence in the case yesterday, and, after a consideration lasting one and three-quarter hours, brought in a verdict finding the railroad company guilty of criminal negligence, on the ground that its electric gong failed to convey warning.
SENECA, FALLS, N.Y., June 24. -- The worst rain and hail storm that has visited this vicinity in years did great damage today to crops. Trees, smokestacks, and telegraph wires were blown down.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Open war has broken out between Senators Mason and Cullom. The former opposed three of the latter's appointees whose names are now before the Senate by telegraphing from here to Senator Hoar to postpone action till his, Mason's, return.

KEY WEST, June 24. -- Great excitement exists here over an assault made upon Mrs. Maggie Atwell last night by a negro named Sylvanus Johnson and the efforts of the negroes to save him from being lynched.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 24. -- Already there is a big assemblage of yachts in the Solent to witness the great naval review of Saturday next. Practically all the warships, British and foreign, are in line, and they present a most imposing sight. The American Line steamships will carry a full complement of passengers to the review.

Gen. N.M. Curtis, whose close relations with National politics is known throughout New York, was asked yesterday by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES about the progress of tariff legislation and the general outlook for business prosperity.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Senator Hale has set the Senators talking about his resolution to exclude from the floor of the Senate ex-members of that body who resort to it to prosecute claims or promote other matters under consideration by the Senate.

WHITESTONE, L.I., June 24. -- There were free threats of lynching here this afternoon, and to-night the street corners are still alive with excited groups, discussing the details of what may prove to be a fatal tragedy.

The committees of the Progressive Democratic League held a long and boisterous meeting last evening at the Bartholdi Hotel, and after midnight they were still calling each other liars and other such frank terms. The delegates from the Twenty-first District Progressive Club had said that unless the grip of Tammany was completely thrown off at last night's meeting the club would secede from the league.

RICHMOND HILL, L.I., June 24. -- Albert C. Bunn, Jr., son of the Chaplain of Brooklyn Church Charity Foundation, this morning saved an elderly German woman named Mrs. Yennow, living on Elm Street, from being killed while attempting to cross the track in front of an express train which was making up lost time. She became frightened and stood bewildered in front of the approaching train.

LEWISTON, Me., June 24. -- The speech of Senator Allen in the United States Senate denying Prof. Bateman's charges against Bryan, and Mr. Bryan's explanation as to why he added Bateman's name to Allen's letter of notification in the last campaign, have attracted much attention in this city, where Bateman is well known.

The prosecution rested yesterday afternoon, and W.W. Fuller opened for the defense in the trial of the American Tobacco Company's officers and Directors. Mr. Fuller concluded his address to the jury by a statement that the defense will call this morning a few expert witnesses. Privately he said that, unless the prosecution subjected these witnesses to a protracted cross-examination, they would not be upon the stand for more than an hour end a half.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 24. -- Harvard College Class Day, the time-honored anniversary, the crimson letter day of every senior at Harvard, dawned for the class of '97 this morning with a splendor of sunshine. The programme of the day varied only slightly from that of the last fifty years or more.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Elkins and Widener of Philadelphia are both back in the Directorate of the West Chicago Street Railway. To make a place for Mr. Yerkes's Philadelphia friends, George A. Yeuelle and W.F. Furbeck handed in their resignations at a meeting of the Directors of the company this afternoon.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 24. -- The Confederate Veterans' reunion closed to-day with a parade of the veterans and their auxiliary bodies. Ten thousand persons were in line, and fully 100,000 persons packed the line of march, and the enthusiasm broke out in thunders of applause as the men of the gray and their old leaders swept by.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 24. -- There is only one topic discussed here to-day, and that is the relative merits of the three crews which will meet in the 'Varsity race tomorrow. It is doubtful if there was ever so much enthusiasm over a rowing contest as there is over this year's race between Yale, Harvard, and Cornell, and many who never saw a crew row discuss the merits of the oarsmen like veterans.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- The Clevelands played here to-day for the first time this season and won a well-contested game from the Chicagos. Both teams bunched their hits in the second, each side tallying twice, the score remaining so until the sixth, when the only error of the game, a wide throw by Callahan, resulted in three runs for the visitors.
TOPEKA, Kan., June 24. -- The worst hailstorm known in the history of Kansas struck this city shortly after 6 o'clock tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24. -- The Newark special, the fastest seashore train on the Central Railroad of New Jersey, met with an accident this morning which might have cost many lives had it not been for the coolness and courage of Engineer William E. Bennett of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The prizes in the singing contests of the Northeastern Saengerbund were awarded to-night as follows: City Federations: First class societies -- Won by United Singers of Brooklyn: (only one prize in this class;) second class societies, United Singers, Hudson County, N.J., first; United Singers of Trenton, second.

Senator Thomas C. Platt is expected in this city early this evening. When he arrives the local politicians will talk with him over the chances of the candidates of the Republican organization for Federal places in this city.

Carnegie Hall was crowded last evening with the students, alumni and those interested in the College of the City of New York to witness the exercises incident to its forty-fifth annual commencement. The hall was decorated with the Stars and Stripes and a few fraternity banners.

The Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works and the Superintendent of Gas and Lamps have united in a report to their chief, the Commissioner, which ought to arrest his attention and that of the public. The question upon which they were instructed to report was the best means of obviating the numerous complaints made about the mischievous effects of the underground steam pipes on other systems of subterranean communication.

It is not very easy to apprehend the point of view of the American Sculpture Society, which is by no means to be confounded with the National Sculpture Society. The former society is indeed supposed to be composed of sculptors whose professional qualifications have not commended them to the older body as suitable for its membership.
LONDON, June 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chamberlain will accompany the Colonial Premiers to the naval review at Spithead.

Nearly 2,000 music teachers, representing thirty-six States of the Union, assembled yesterday morning in the auditorium of the Grand Central Palace for the opening of the nineteenth annual convention of the Music Teachers' National Association. The convention is to last four days.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The United States Court of Claims to-day rendered a decision in the famous La Abra case, holding, in effect, that the award rendered against Mexico by Sir. Edward Thornton, acting as umpire under the treaty of 1868, with Mexico, was obtained by testimony of a corrupt character.
SALINA, Kan., June 24. -- A tornado passed fifteen miles northwest of this city about 10:30 o'clock last night. Three persons were killed and a number dangerously injured.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, June 24. -- Archbishop Hennessey made an attack on the public-school system to-day in his address to the graduates at St. Clara's Academy at Sinsinawa Mound, Wis. His theme was "Religion and Science." He said: "To-day in the United States we have from twelve to fourteen million children who are being educated without religion.

Your editorial of the 18th inst. denouncing the outrage perpetrated by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company against one of its patrons (Mr. Ivins) is a much-needed comment on the practices of that organization.

THE TIMES of Wednesday contained a criticism of a statement quoted in Monday's edition of your valuable paper from a sermon preached by me on Trinity Sunday. I am disposed to give a few words in reply.

HAVANA, June 24. -- Col. Aguileras, with a column of troops and acting in conjunction with the local guerrilla force and garrison of Madruga, has been engaged with an insurgent force, under the leadership of Aranguren, which was intrenched in the Sierra de Grillo, near Madruga, in this provence.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 24. -- The class of '97 from Bowdoin College was formally liberated from its active duties in the college by the commencement exercises to-day. It was the ninety-second commencement, and the programme was a delightful one.

Thomas C. Smith, ex-President of the Seventeenth Ward National Bank of Brooklyn, who was arrested several weeks ago on the technical charge of illegally receiving money belonging to the Government, had a hearing yesterday before United States Commissioner Morle, in the Federal Building, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, June 24. -- Boston won a decided victory over Baltimore to-day, but the crowd of spectators was so dense that the outfielders were greatly hampered, and the ground rules that were put in force detracted largely from the interest in the game. Bergen split his finger in the seventh inning, and was replaced by Ganzel.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The gist of the protest of Japan to Hawaiian annexation, which was read to the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations yesterday, is as follows:

BOSTON, June 24. -- A surprise was created on the Street this morning when it was announced that the' firm nf F. R. Cordley Co., stock brokers, of 66 State Street, had assigned to Chaxles K. Cobb of the firm of Nichols F ,Cobb. The firm is composed of F. R. Cordley, H. C. Young, and G. N. Notter.

An explosion of naphtha at 418 Fourth Avenue, yesterday morning, killed a woman and a dog, severely injured a man, and slightly injured a boy, wrecked the lower part of the building, and smashed windows and frightened residents and passers-by for a distance of three blocks in all directions.
BRUSSELS, June 24. -- The Reforme says it learns from a good source that the entire Dhanis expedition to the headwaters of the Nile, including Baron Dhanis himself, has been massacred.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24. -- Capt. W.H. Whiting, late commander of the naval station at Puget Sound, has assumed command of the monitor Monadnock, relieving Capt. George W. Sumner. After the customary ceremonies, the senior officer's pennant, which had been displayed by the Monadnock, was hauled down and flown from the Monterey's peak, Capt. C.E. Clark of that vessel being next senior-officer.

Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD'S speech is wholly unsatisfactory to the Republicans. The Mail and Express is shocked that he should be willing "to stultify his courageous opposition to free silver in 1896 by surrendering to the Popocratic forces in 1897." It censures him for his plainspoken criticisms of Republican misdoing at Washington, and evidently cannot under stand how an intelligent and upright man can have so poor an opinion of the Republican Party.

The chapel of the Normal College, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, was crowded yesterday at the twenty-eighth annual commencement exercises. The hall was decorated with flowers and bunting and a large floral piece of pink and white carnations banked against the reading desk bore the class mottoes, "Strength in Action" and "Always Ready."

A recent issue of The London Times contained a long account of the results of the gunnery practice in the English Navy in 1896. Americans may find some interest in its demonstration that the marksmanship of our transatlantic brethren does not appear to have greatly improved since we met them in the war of 1812, when our brilliant series of victories was attributed in a considerable measure to the superiority of our gunnery practice.

BOSTON, June 24. -- It is learned here that a big gas transaction, by which the Standard Oil Company secures absolute control of the Bay State Gas Company of Delaware, was consummated in New York yesterday. J. Edward Addicks accepted the Standard Oil proposition that he should refund about $2,000,000 in cash, or its equivalent, to the company, in consideration of which all litigation is to be ended.
Entries to the following fixtures, which will be decided at the Fall meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, which opens on Aug. 24, will close on Thursday, July 15:

The words "Gdje su Turci tu su i Vuci" mean in Bosnian "Where the Turks are, there will also be wolves." We need not pin our faith to popular sayings, born of race prejudices, but from a reading of Mr. H.C. Thomson's "The Outgoing Turk," we should say that the vulpine genus existed appreciably in the countries the author describes.

A woman, dressed in black, who said that she represented a church society which sent boys under ten years old to the country for a ten days' outing, went among the children of East Seventy-sixth Street Wednesday looking for little boys who seemed to need the country air. Children are very numerous in that part of the street between First and Second Avenues.

Wall Street bear speculators make much of the claim that the only prosperity which can anywhere be discovered in this country is lodged on the Stock Exchange tape. There is, they contend, neither business activity nor prospect of business activity discernible anywhere else. Some of these bear speculators talk as if they really believe what they say.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 25. -- Courtney and his boys were overwhelmed by telegrams of congratulation from all parts of the country this evening. One of the most characteristic of these dispatches came from Hi Haskin, an Ithaca druggist, who said: "God bless your old soul, the town is crazy."

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Senate Committee on Pacific Railroads to-day agreed to report favorably the resolution introduced by Senator Harris of Kansas expressing the sense of the Senate that the United States should redeem the Union Pacific Railroad from prior liens and take steps to foreclose the Government mortgage.

The Baptist Boys' Brigade camp will be held at Asbury Park this season. The encampment is situated upon a beautiful tract of land skirting the shores of Musquash Bay. The grounds are admirably adapted for the purpose. There is an abundance of pure water, and a neighboring wood furnishes ample shade. The first detachment will leave for camp July 6. One thousand boys will attend camp during the season.

KEY WEST, June 25. -- There is every indication to-night that the town is on the eve of another riot, as the result of the attempt to lynch Sylvanus Johnson, the negro assailant of Mrs. Margaret Atwell yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, June 25. -- The crew of the torpedo boat Admiral Foote presented a pitiable appearance when the vessel arrived at the Naval Academy this afternoon from the second test of the Foote's ability to come up to the Government's requirement of twenty-four and a half knots, (twenty-seven miles,) sustained for two hours.

Judge Fitzgerald said yesterday that the trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company would not extend beyond Monday. The defense rested yesterday shortly after noon, and the prosecution at once did the same. At the request of counsel for both sides, the court adjourned the case until Monday morning, after having allowed each side two hours in which to sum up.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Mercer lost the first game to-day, and Swaim went in the box in the second inning. Rusie was almost invincible in pitching, but errors by himself and Warner aided the Senators in getting runs. In the second game McJames did masterly work, while Meekin was hit hard. Score:

Many roads should be in good condition for to-day and to-morrow, according to the report received from correspondents at the headquarters of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen yesterday. In this city considerable road repairing is being done and many roads should be avoided on that account.

The Democratic conferrees of the Greater New York met last night at the Hoffman House and made the preliminary arrangements for the local campaign. The meeting was harmonious, and, curiously enough, there were no typewritten resolutions and no speeches. Although there was some hesitancy in the work of the meeting, it passed off with the usual machinelike precision.

Six thousand Republicans assembled in Durland's Riding Academy last night to receive orders and instructions from Congressman Quigg, the new President of their County Committee. It was intensely hot, and there was little or no fresh air, but the zealous partisans who had risked discomfort in a crowded hall sat through the meeting, listened to a long speech of instructions, cheered vociferously, and passed resolutions with unquenched enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Judge Advocate General Lieber of the army has submitted the following report to Secretary Alger on the Hudson River bridge case:

The very title of this recent book of travel through a comparatively near, but almost unknown, country will doubtless be a surprise to the average reader, for people in general are under the indefinite impression that Finland is either continually covered with snow and ice or consists of nothing but marshes and waterways.

There was recently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article referring to two paintings brought to New York a short time ago by M. Armand Flurel, a Parisian collector and connoisseur. M. Flurel questions some of the opinions of an expert, who figured in the article in question, and sends the following letter:

Paradox worked up with intense dramatic effect is the salient feature of "The Gadfly." Mr. E.L. Voynich's start in the establishment of his principal character is not a pleasant one, because Arthur, the half English half Italian lad, has for father the priest Montanelli, and the boy's mother was a married woman. Montanelli is canon, a Father Director of a school in Pisa, where Arthur is receiving his education.

The German-American Reform Union's primaries were held last night in all of the Assembly Districts. The vote was not so large in some places as had been expected. Officers of the district organizations and members of the General Committee were chosen. There were some contests.

Protests against the proposed widening of Ann Street, from Broadway to Gold Street, were heard by the Board of Street Opening and Improvement in the Mayor's office yesterday. Fully twoscore of property owners and lawyers interested in the matter were present. Mayor Strong presided, and all of the members of the board were in their places.

Jospeh J. O'Donohue died at his home, 5 East Sixty-ninth Street, at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Until a short time before the end Mr. O'Donohue's symptoms were no worse than they had been for two weeks, and the members of his family had no expectation of his immediate demise. His exhausted vitality, however, brought about a sudden change for the worse about noon, and members of the family were hastily summoned to his bedside.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 25. -- Everything is in readiness for to-morrow's great naval spectacle. Portsmouth, Southsea, and their environs are quite repeating London's jubilee fever. Decorations are universal, profuse, and distinctly naval, notably at the gateway of the gun wharf, where brass cannon are mounted in two turrets and in charge of pickets in full armor.

The opening of the Summer season of work at the State Camp was fortunately in the hands of the Seventh Regiment. This may be said without disparagement of any of the other excellent organizations which belong to the National Guard in this State. It is not saying that others fall short of a high standard of excellence to award the Seventh the first place.

-- If the negroes of Key West had made any attempt to prevent the trial of one of their number who is accused of a heinous crime, or if they had tried to remove him by force from the custody of the county officials, there would have been complete justification for the angry excitement that prevails among the town's white population.

Mr. SHEPARD said in his speech that the candidacy of SETH LOW would be doomed to defeat if his nomination came in such a way that it would "become a prop for the legislative corruption we have known" and "a bulwark for the crude savagery represented by Gov. BLACK'S civil service message."

ALBANY, June 25. -- Articles of incorporation of the Pan-American Exposition Company were filed here and in Buffalo to-day. A meeting of the Board of Directors will be held at the Transportation Club, in New York, this afternoon, to effect an organization.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25. -- It was freely asserted about the Chamber of Commerce to-day that C.A. Pillsbury has under his control about all the cash wheat in the visible supply of the United States. It should, however, be understood that there are some long lines of wheat held in Chicago, St. Louis, and Duluth, but not enough to prevent the preceding statement from being true.

BOSTON, June 25. -- The Oregon Short Line reorganization committee announces that the new securities, the consolidated first mortgage bonds, the income A bonds, and the stock, will be ready for delivery July 1, and that later announcement will be made as to the date the income B bond will be ready for delivery.

The elevated railroad is putting up at some of its stations turnstiles. This may effect an economy for the road by dispensing with a "ticket chopper," but the inconvenience to the public is too high a price to pay for the saving. On Saturday morning last three other persons and myself lost a train at Eighth Street that all of us could have caught except for the stile.

ST. LOUIS, June 25. -- It is announced that an immense traction company, with a capital stock of $7,500,000 will shortly be organized to take in the Lindell and Missouri Street Railway systems. The consolidation will occur as soon as the necessary legal steps can be taken, and an interchangeable transfer system probably will be inaugurated.

We have almost an embarrassment of riches in the line of popularizing books about birds, but they are always welcome if they are good. Mr. Chapman has received much praise for his "Handbook," and does not lower his standard in speaking to amateurs alone.

At the annual meeting of the London Diocesan Church Reading Union recently the Bishop of London presided, and, after distributing the certificates won by members of the union in its sixty-one branches, gave an address on reading. He said:
The three pitchers who played in yesterday's Brooklyn-Philadelphia game were ineffective, because both teams appeared to have on a batting streak.
LONDON, June 25. -- The sixth round of the international women's chess tournament was played in this city this evening, with the following results:

David Stewart has sold for John E. Schorsmith, for about $70,000, the five three-story American basement dwellings, 179, 181, 183, 185, and 189 Convent Avenue, 16 and 18 feet frontages, and 98.9 feet in depth.

The library of Columbia University, comprising some 260,000 books and pamphlets, which is shortly to be installed in the splendid new library building on University Heights, is now being prepared to take the journey from East Forty-ninth Street under the direction of George H. Baker, the librarian. The library was collected mainly under his supervision.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 25. -- The following statements were made to-night by leading representatives of the Cornell crew:

The Academy tells of a surprise. Somebody asked to see a Shakespeare folio in the British Museum, and, obtaining it, when turning over the flyleaf there was "writ bold" William Shakespeare. His Booke, 1597." Had the visitor made a startling discovery? Breathless he called on the librarian and told him of his find.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 25. -- Cornell's 'Varsity crew won the college boat race this afternoon, finishing three lengths ahead of Yale. Yale was seven lengths ahead of Harvard. The times were: Cornell, 20:34; Yale, 20:44; Harvard, 21:00.

The Music Teachers' Convention at the Grand Central Palace opened yesterday with a business meeting in the Auditorium. The plans for a new constitution, as outlined by President Greene, were favorably received, and final action will be taken this morning. The remainder of the morning at the auditorium was taken up by a lecture on "A Theory of Interpretation," by A.J. Goodrich, and illustrated on the piano by W.H. Sherwood.

LONDON, June 25. -- The Lord Mayor, Sir George Faudel-Philips, gave a luncheon at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the Mansion House to all the Princes and Princesses, home and foreign, who were in the jubilee procession, to most of the special envoys with the rank of Ambassador, and to part of the Diplomatic Corps.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 25. -- The crew and the Cubans who were on board the Dauntless and who were yesterday arrested were to-day discharged by United States Commissioner Julius Otto, on the ground that there was no evidence to show they were a military organization or intending to commit acts hostile to Spain.

PARIS, June 11. -- The artistic event of the week has been the exhibition opened to-day to the public of Mme. Rosa Bonheur's pastels. They are four in number, and they reveal a totally new and unexpected side to this aged paintress's extraordinary talent, for she has never before worked in the medium of chalk.

J.J. McCafferty owner, trainer, and rider of the two-year-old filly Kitefoot, proved to the satisfaction of many who surmised as much before that he has a first-class race horse in that animal. She won the seventeenth running of the Foam Stakes for two-year-olds at Sheepshead Bay, yesterday, defeating some of the best two-year-olds of the year, among them Handball, Great Bend, Varus, and Archduke.

While Moses Scherdnyck of 49 Eldridge Street, who acts as janitor and officiating rabbi of the Russian-Jewish Synagogue Ansche Minsk, at 47 and 49 Pike Street, was sweeping out the synagogue at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, he discovered six bundles of gun cotton under a bench. Upon further investigation, he found a barrel containing about forty pounds of the same material in a second-floor rear room, which is used for the children's meetings.
LONDON, June 25. -- A set of the works of Aristotle, the Greek philosopher, printed on vellum, and of the date 1483, brought 800 at the Ashburnham sale to-day.

Once more the weak things have been chosen to confound the mighty and the wise have been put to shame by the simple. All persons learned in rowing were agreed yesterday morning that, though they could not with any confidence pick the winner, they could pick the loser, and that the loser would be Cornell.

When QUIGG gets through with the Republican organization its orthodoxy will be beyond question. Some time ago he decreed the purging of the rolls, the Platt enrollment which had been denounced as fraudulent and rotten by twenty-five of the most prominent Republicans in town, being too heavy a load to carry in a moral campaign.

HELIGOLAND, June 25. -- Of the thirteen yachts which started from Dover, England, on Wednesday last, in a race for the cup presented by Emperor William of Germany in commemoration of the sixtieth year of the reign of Queen Victoria, to be raced for by yachts belonging to any royal or recognized British yacht club, the Cetonia, schooner, 203 tons, owned by Lord Iveagh, arrived first, at 7:34 o'clock this morning.

The Horseman, newspaper, of Chicago, has been calling for "missionary work" in behalf of the American trotting horse in England. It gravely asserts that wealthy Americans who make their homes in England, "fired by the ambition to be as British as possible," reject American horses altogether.

In 1895 THE NEW YORK TIMES recorded Mr. Flinders Petrie's discovery of worked flints in Egypt, and now Prof. Mahaffy's assertion that a people with cannibalistic tendencies existed there has been confirmed.
Regarding the prospects of the International Christian Endeavor Convention in San Francisco next month, General Secretary J. Willis Baer said yesterday:

It was a red-letter day in the public schools yesterday. In all parts of the city school commencement exercises were held. There were many prominent people in attendance, and hearty applause greeted the efforts both of the graduates and the little ones who contributed to the general entertainment.

The astonishing spectacle we have just witnessed of a Congress of South American States, invited to travel in this country with reference to devising some plan to give us the benefit of trade with them, and a Washington Congress putting up a tariff higher than the Eiffel Tower against them and the rest of the world, ought to convulse with laughter a graven image.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- It is reported the traction lines of Chicago are about to be consolidated under the name of the Chicago Traction Company. The sponsors of the plan are J.P. Morgan, Charles T. Yerkes, P.A.B. Widener, and W.L. Elkins.

Notices will soon be sent out by Controller Fitch to the heads of the various city departments calling for the estimates of each department for the running expenses for 1898, so that the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in its arrangement of the provisional budget for next year may be ready to proceed with its work when the time comes.

The Queen's jubilee celebration is not wholly devoid of a feature distinctly literary, for it is attended by one of the greatest book sales London has known in this generation. Part I. of Lord Ashburnham's library has been advertised to be sold in London this week and next, beginning yesterday and ending on July 3.

Certain rare and curious objects in porcelain, with pictures, were sold in London recently at these prices: A Louis XV. oblong gold box, engraved with trellis ornament and enameled with groups of flowers, , 40; eighteen Chelsea plates, painted with sprays of flowers, and white and gold scroll borders, gold anchor mark, 68 guineas, and an old French bronze figure of an undraped woman plaiting her hair, 7 1/4 inches high, 120 guineas.

Five men went for a sail on the upper bay yesterday afternoon in a sloop yacht, leaving Communipaw at 2:30 P.M. They were all painters of this city out of work -- John French of 610 West Sixty-fourth Street; Paul Hackle of 345 West Eleventh Street; Edward Hackle, his brother, who owned the boat; Samuel Albert, formerly a mate on the steamboat General Slocum, and a man known to his companions only as "John."

William Aragall, thirty-three years old, one of the three yellow-fever patients removed from the Colon steamship Finance at Quarantine on Friday of last week, died yesterday morning in the Swinburne Island Hospital. Hargon and Costello, the other patients, were reported by Health Officer Dr. Doty yesterday as doing well.

Criticisms on his official conduct apparently do not affect Police Captain Chapman, in charge of the "Tenderloin" Police Precinct. He says he is doing what he has been ordered to do, and until directed to desist will continue in the same line.

This work, planned many years ago by Max Miller, and finally carried out, has to do with language mythology, religion, and thought, and has for its aim the elucidation of the study of mythology, the whole "sphere of activity of the human mind from the earliest period" to within the reach of our knowledge of the present day.

Mr. Charles H. Haswell's interesting "Reminiscences of an Octogenarian of the City of New York" (Harper's) was included in the Summer reading lists printed in the "Review of Books and Art" on June 5. The price given was $2, but it should have been $3. The volume is a crown octavo, bound in ornamental cloth and profusely illustrated.

BOSTON, June 25. -- Hoffer pitched great ball for Baltimore to-day up to the ninth inning, when the score stood 9 to 7 in the visitors' favor. In the ninth, with two men out, and none on bases, Collins made a hit, and then Hoffer went completely to pieces, making a wretched exhibition, giving three men bases on balls succession, and forcing in one run.

JACKSON, Miss., June 25. -- A negro named John Moses, who killed farmer John Strong near Crystal Springs, Miss., a few days ago, and who was arrested at that place yesterday, and confined in jail, was hanged by a mob there at 9:50 o'clock this morning.

The protest of the Novoe Vremya of St. Petersburg against the annexation of Hawaii by the United States has considerable significance. Of course, it has no official character, but every expression of a Russian newspaper has passed the Russian censorship. Every expression, therefore, which has any international bearing must be regarded as semi-official.

Whitaker is a solid name, and attached heretofore to the most matter-of-fact of publications, which was an almanac. Whitaker now blossoms in a new and luxuriant field, and before us is his "Directory of Titled Persons for the Year 1897." On the first page, not used in the sense of a reclame, however, we find that the book is "designed as a companion to Whitaker's Almanack," though wherein lies the connection meteorological we cannot see.
BOSTON, June 26. -- The Traveler to-day, quoting from the Boston News Bureau, says:

In common with all beings human, cyclists show a craving for something new, and have taken gladly to a number of novelties in cycle sport this year. The pursuit race is always an interesting diversion at race meets where it is included, and generally incites more enthusiasm than the hard contests of the fast ones.

Under one heading we may consider several groups of foodstuffs, which, while different in composition, are alike in the form of adulteration which is resorted to. These groups include the varieties of canned vegetables, fruit butters, jellies, preserves, and catsups. The forms of adulterations, common to all of these, consist in the use of coloring matter, of imperfect vegetables or fruits, of other fruits and vegetables than those called or, of preservatives.

The week which closed yesterday was one of such perfect Summer weather that it will not be soon forgotten. It almost seemed indeed as if Nature had determined to make compensation for the unseasonable chill and the gloomy skies and rain of the first part of June, and it dowered the land more richly than ever before with the richest verdure, a wealth of sunlight, and the balmiest of warm airs.

If the support given the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday in their attempts to encourage racing for amateur riders is a sample of the sort of thing this club and others may expect in the future, the gentlemen riders who have been clamoring for a chance to sport silk will clamor in vain after this meeting.

AKRON, Ohio, June 26. -- A Cleveland, Akron and Columbus excursion train, having on board the employes of the Goodrich Rubber Company, the Diamond Rubber Company, and the Akron India Rubber Company, was run into by a Baltimore and Ohio passenger train at Millersburg this morning.

The conspicuous absence from the Jubilee celebration of the greatest English statesman of her Majesty's reign was calculated to recall the part which the personal antipathies of the Queen have played in the British politics of the last sixty years. To do Victoria justice, her individual preferences have never affected her official relations with her Ministers, and are hardly worth chronicling beside those of her royal uncles and grandfather.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 26. -- Apropos of the talk of displacing him for Gen. James Longstreet of Georgia, among the many stories related of United States Railroad Commissioner Wade Hampton, formerly Governor and United States Senator from Sooth Carolina, there are three stories in connection with his war history that richly deserve preservation, the first two as affording rare examples of devotion to duty and the last as an instance of astonishing yet heroic generosity.

Up to the year 1877, if a Japanese gentleman was asked to name his best friend he would significantly touch his sword. From time immemorial it has been the custom to wear side arms in Japan, and when an edict was issued in 1877, a flood of useless swords was thrown upon the market; weapons which represented a peculiar art, at once aesthetic and surrounded by a glamour of romance and chivalry.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., June 26. -- A stage coach bound from Havana for San Jose de las Lajas, a near-by settlement, was stopped on the road by a large band of insurgents, who killed with their machetes the eighteen scouts who were escorting the coach; six guerrillas, one Spanish officer a doctor, a carpenter, and three other passengers who attempted to save their lives by flight.

-- MM. Mourtier and Granier have reported to the Paris Academie de Medicine that by setting a singer upon an isolated stool coupled to a negative pole of a static machine and making her breathe the atmosphere, which was electrified by means of a brush electrode, they caused her voice to become full and clear, and its quality much more agreeable. The Voice also tired less rapidly.

No reaction worth mentioning has been permitted in the market since the bull movement started in May. There have been pauses, and dull spells; but they have been no more than temporary halts. The leaders of the movement had their programme, which was to make the granger stocks the solid moving force, and they have steadily adhered to this policy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- Funeral services over the remains of the late Collector James Kilbreth were held to-day. The services began after the arrivel of the city train, which got here at 11:30.
Much bull talk on Erie is to be heard in Wall Street, but during the whole of last week only 100 shares of the stock were traded in.

A small army of messenger boys were utilized yesterday by the National Civic Club of Brooklyn for collecting the straw vote by which they hope to test public sentiment upon the most popular Mayoralty possibility.

It was reserved for an aristocrat, however, to produce an even more startling innovation. Up to a few years ago the yellow boot was unknown in England outside the annual visit to the seaside, and even there many people would have been disposed to look upon it as the uniform of what is called in onomatopoetic fashion, the "bounder."

Eighteen yearlings from August Belmont's famous nursery stud were sold at auction yesterday morning in the Easton Paddocks, near the Sheepshead Bay race track. The yearlings were a choice-looking lot, but the bidding on them was not spirited, and low prices ruled. The highest price paid for any of the lot was $1,050, for Yule Tide, a racy-looking colt by Badge.

Since this morning this camp has changed its colors and grown larger and stronger. The gray and white of the Seventh Regiment has been changed to the regulation blue of the Twelfth Regiment, the Tenth Battalion from Albany, and a small detail from the Third Battery. The population of the camp has increased also from less than 900 this morning to 1,100 to-night.

One of the largest and most successful outdoor social features ever held on Staten Island took place yesterday afternoon on the picturesque grounds of the new Richmond County Country Club, near Garretsons, Staten Island. The golf links there were used yesterday for the first time in a regular tournament, the contest being a mixed foursome, men and women playing as partners.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- July and September wheat changed places to-day in point of speculative interest. July started out with the usual "corner" scare, but before the session was half over, September was commanding the attention of most of the traders, and was much the stronger at the close. Final prices showed a 1/2c advance in July and 1 1/4@1 3/8c rise in September.

There is one Spring or early Summer fever which the physicians called upon to cure say is incurable. It is a fever which lasts throughout the year, but makes itself most prominent about this season and a little earlier. It is the stage fever, and the patients are usually warranted -- not to die of it, but to live and grow on it.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The Republican tariff managers are very hopeful of being able to complete the consideration of the Tariff bill in the Senate by next Wednesday night, a result which would bring the end in the Senate within the present month. They are led to this conclusion because the Republicans have adjusted most of their differences and see their way clear to the settlement of others.

To persons who seek the cool, bracing air of the mountains, and enjoy the seclusion which the balsamic wilderness affords, the Adirondack region extends a tempting invitation at this season of the year. Its varied resorts -- some primitive and rugged, others luxurious and fashionable -- are now ready to receive visitors, and from present indications the next three months will be busy ones for the mountain entertainers.

BOSTON, June 26. -- New York yachtsmen will have a chance the coming week to see two of the three Seawanhaka 20-footers designed by C.H. Crane, who last year designed and sailed El Helrie. The Al-Anka and the Momo were shipped by rail from Lawley's Friday, and should be sailing at Oyster Bay within a few days.

TRENTON, June 26. -- The application of Edward S. Hewitt for a limited divorce from his wife, Annie, on the ground of extreme cruelty has been denied by Vice Chancellor Grey. In his complaint Hewitt said the cruelty consisted of displays of temper on the part of Mrs. Hewitt on three or four occasions when he sided against her in disputes which she had with his children by a former wife.

THE class of '97 of the United States Military Academy, at West Point, is superior in some respects to many of its predecessors. The average percentage of its members in studies and discipline is high. In athletic sports the class has always taken a leading part, and the prize banners which '97 teams have won will from their places of honor in the gymnasium tell future generations of the prowess of this year's class.

Col. McCoskry Butt of the Twelfth Regiment, whose command went to the State camp yesterday, relieving the Seventh Regiment, has compiled some brief instructions for "the soldier on guard" from the latest official works, which will be found of value to Guardsmen, especially those who have, still to undergo a tour of duty at the camp.

He is probably the youngest newsboy in the business, not even excepting the babies who are regular professionals and ply their trade in the vicinity of Printing House Square. He is not more than four or five years old, and he has probably only one customer, a gentleman who is spending the early part of the Summer in the vicinity of Bay Ridge.

WHITESTONE, L.I., June 26. -- Thaddeus Norsleet, who killed Policeman Wendelstorf, was arraigned before Judge McKenna here this evening charged with murder in the first degree. He pleaded not guilty and claimed self-defense. He said he did not know the officer, and thought he was one of the crowd about to commit violence on him. He admitted the blow.

THE best-appointed bowling alley in this country is that recently built by Miss Helen M. Gould at her home, Lyndhurst, Irvington-on-Hudson. The cost was not far from $10,000. Bowling is the only game Miss Gould cares for, and at this she is quite expert, having many high scores to her credit.

A great deal of interest, mingled perhaps with consternation, has been excited by the announcement of Scotland Yard's latest discovery -- a kit of "electric burglar's tools." One of the implements described was an electric drill, the power for which was carried in a case like an opera glass receptacle, slung over the shoulder when not in use, and giving the safe breaker the appearance of a gentleman who frequents the race course.

The second series of races for the cups given by Vice Commodore F.T. Adams of the Atlantic Yacht Club was sailed yesterday off the clubhouse at Bay Ridge. The wind was strong from the northwest all the afternoon, and the races were very interesting. Vice Commodore and Mrs. Adams entertained on the Sachem Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Ceballos, Mr. and Mrs. W.E. Pearl, and Miss Roe.

Agurai is a small town, surrounded with walls of from 40 to 50 feet in height, and built of "tabia," or consolidated rubble. It owes its existence to Mulai Ismail, who held the throne of Morocco from 1722-1757. One gate alone gives entrance to the place, and in this respect, as well as in its architecture within and without, it much resembles the "ksor" of the Sahara described in the writer's "Tafilet."

There was a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Commercial Travelers' National League held at the Ashland House last evening. W.W. Gibbs was elected Secretary of the organization, and considerable other routine business was transacted.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 19. -- The Hudson River counties, particularly Ulster, and more particularly that neighborhood in and adjacent to this city, have always been noted for their small fruit and flower gardens. Every householder who had a front yard -- and in a city where there are few brick blocks, but thousands of little cottages, very few residents lack front yards -- had a miniature nursery of flowers and shrubbery.

It is well to point out the injurious effects of alcohol taken in excess, and this, of course, only applies to those who take it, not as an adjunct to the enjoyment of life or to the pleasures of the table, but who take it at all times and under all circumstances. Taken in moderation it can do no more harm than any other luxury -- it increases appetite and stimulates digestion.

LOUISVILLE, June 26. -- Companies A and B of the Second Regiment, K.S.G., will be in arms to-morrow night. Tuesday morning they will escort from the jail to the Court House at Franklin William Dinning, a negro who is in danger of death at the hands of a mob. These companies, which are located at Winchester and Frankfort, respectively, are in command of Col. E.H. Gaither of the Second Regiment.

Buddhism and Christianity are at one in this: that they perceive our life here is but for a moment and if rightly lived it must be lived in view of an eternal life or a life hereafter. Life does not cease with our departure; it continues still beyond, and that life beyond will be shaped by the life here. Indeed, no discrimination can be made on grounds of time.
Everything is a little different on the other side of the water, even so universal a practice as cycling. A few notes taken from The Lady Cyclist, an English wheelwoman's paper, are interesting.

MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass., June 25. -- During the months of March, April, May, and June shoals of herring, driven by the scarcity of food and attracted by the approach of warmer weather, leave the ocean and seek their breeding grounds at the head waters of the principal rivers of the New England and Middle Atlantic States.

The first monthly golf handicap tournament at the Ardsley Club, on the Hudson, yesterday, brought out a good number of contestants. The Class A contest resulted in a tie -- M.S. Paton and H.S. Brooks each finishing in S1 strokes, net. The Class B event was won by F.F. Chrystie at 80 net. The tie for first in Class A will be played off this week.

It is more than twenty years since the music lovers of New York have been able to enjoy a Summer season of high-class concerts. It is true that Mr. SEIDL has in the interval given a good many seasons of entertaining and more or less instructive Summer concerts at Brighton Beach.

Two young women were endeavoring to find places on a Columbus Avenue cable car. It was an open car, and the fact that the entrance to each row of seats was barred by the outstretched limbs of a male passenger made the task of boarding car laborious and a trifle slow, "Step lively!"

LONDON, June 26. -- The Marquis of Tweeddale, as Chairman of the committee having in charge the international submarine telegraph memorial to the late Sir John Pender, announces that the committee has decided to proceed during the present year with its work. The memorial is intended to commemorate the leading part taken by Sir John Pander in the establishment and development of submarine telegraphy, and its extension throughout the world.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- The sturgeon fishermen from this place to Montauk are making immense catches daily and the scenes along the shore where the fish are shipped to market are busy ones. The Westhampton fishermen are assisted by their wives and families in preparing the fish for market.

The Rev. Walter E. Bentley, the new vicar of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, comes from Sheffield, in England, and is thirty-seven years of age. He tried clerking in a music store, apprenticeship to a firm of silversmiths, and the manufacture of brass goods. Not liking any of them, he entered the theatrical profession, and played Adam in "As You Like It," touring the country with several companies.

The Valencia Boat Club's twenty-third annual regatta, held over the one-mile Guttenberg course on the Hudson River yesterday afternoon, was a pronounced success. Tugboats, carrying delegations from the Dauntless, Hudson, and Nameless Boat Clubs, were present, as well as craft of all kinds, from the small catboat to the big steam yacht.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 26. -- Coach Charles E. Courtney of the successful Cornell crew was asked this evening whether, since his crew had defeated Yale and Harvard, he believed that it could be possible for Pennsylvania or Columbia to outrow them next week.

There is one distinctly Dutch sport, the Hardriverij. This delightful word (pronounced "hard drivery") is Dutch for a trotting match. It was from Holland, through the old Dutch settlers of the colony, before New Amsterdam was taken by the fleets of Charles II. and renamed New York, that our American cousins got their taste for trotting horses.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 26. -- At Buffalo, forty miles north of here, last night, Frank Taylor was killed and his brother, John, badly wounded while attempting to rob the wood mill.

The seven weeks' strike of the east side tailors, supposed to be amicably settled, took a new turn late yesterday afternoon. Some dissatisfied contractors began to make threats, intimating an intention to lock out their employes in the settled shops. They assert that they cannot live up to the terms of the new agreement, and indications point to the precipitation of another tedious conflict between the Brotherhood of Tailors and the Contractors' Association.

AMONG the lesser church choirs in this city, that of St. John's Chapel has for many years occupied a prominent position. This is due in a large measure to the excellence of the music which has characterized the services ever since its organization, twenty-one years ago last May.

The ceremonies in celebration of the supposed four hundredth anniversary of the landing of JOHN CABOT and his fellow-voyagers on the Matthew, in Bristol, England, Halifax, N.S., and St. John's, N.F., last Thursday, were all as appropriate and interesting as they possibly could have been if the exact time and place of CABOT'S landing had been positively agreed upon by the historians.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, June 26. -- Lieut. Henry McCrea, the navigator of the United States cruiser Brooklyn, flagship of Rear Admiral J.N. Miller, at the request of The Associated Press has written the following account of to-day's picture from an American officer's point of view:

The graduating exercises of the sixth class of the Baron de Hirsch Trade Schools were held last evening at the school building 225 and 227 East Ninth Street. These exercises were simple, and to the point. Myer S. Isaacs, President of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, and A.S. Solomons and Milton Schnaier of the Advisory Committee of the schools, made addresses.

While conducting a series of investigations into the industries and customs of Japan, in the interest of the National Association of Manufacturers of America, Robert P. Porter made some interesting discoveries about the personal expenditures of Japanese people as compared with the expenditures of Americans, both at home and abroad.

With expressions of astonishment 5,000 spectators saw the wall-known speedy men of Greater New York go down before two dark horses at the big race meet of the Kings County Wheelmen at Manhattan Beach yesterday afternoon. R.A. Miller of the Greenwich Wheelmen and O.V. Babcock of New York had not been picked out as winners by the many, but they showed a pace that passed the favorites.

PORTSMOUTH, June 26. -- After a threatening morning, the weather brightened and a brilliant day for the great naval review was ushered in. The streets were thronged with people at an early hour, and on all sides were to be seen bewildering masses of glittering uniforms, multitudes of gay civilians, military bands, and sailors of all ranks and nationalities.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Circular No. 79, recently issued by the Navy Department as a guide to officers in matters relating to proposed changes in their uniform, has given rise to much heated discussion and unfavorable comment. In fact, only here and there has an officer been found who has anything to say in favor of all the proposed changes.

Thomas Croswell, a land surveyor, who lives at Merriam Park, got back Sunday from an absence of three months in the rainy lake country, where he has been surveying six townships of Government land on the ceded Red Lake reservation. These townships lie on Rapid River, and though it will be a year or two before they are thrown open to settlement, squatters are already picking out the best claims.

The great yellow water lily occurs at Wocus Bay and a few other places on Klamath Lake, and in endless amount in Klamath Marsh. The large mucilaginous seed pods are gathered in boats, the seeds extracted after some process of drying the pods, and then stored for use during the year.

PORTSMOUTH, June 26. -- One of the prettiest sights of the day was when the royal yacht had come to anchor, the various foreign Admirals, with their staffs, put off to pay their respects to the Prince of Wales. As they passed the different warships, the bugles sounded, the bands played, and the marines presented arms. All the Admirals, with the exception of Rear Admiral Miller, went in their steam pinnaces.

Prices are not to be controlled by conditions entirely within our power to modify; the price of wheat rose last Fall because the demand upon us for it from other nations was greater than before, owing to their reduced supply. A crop failure in India or a war in Europe immediately affects general prices here.

Prof. Lincoln of Brown University, whose death occurred a few years ago, used to tell amusing anecdotes of Neander, the great professor and historian of the Christian Church of the Berlin University, under whom he studied for some time.

GLASGOW, June 15. -- The Emperor of Germany is determined that his jubilee yacht race shall be a great success. Not contented with his five-hundred-pound gold cup as the first prize for a yacht race from Dover to Helgotand, he has signified his intention of giving three other prizes, prompted by the big entry of twenty-one yachts which it is intended to start.

Under the laws of the Brooklyn Board of Education, the terms of fifteen of the forty-five members expire July 1 of each year. The term of Edward Rowe, who died three weeks ago, was among those which are about to expire. Of the other fourteen time-expiring members, Mayor Wurster reappointed thirteen to succeed themselves.

Fall River has more than one-sixth of all the spindles in the country, over one-fifth of those in New England, and manufactures over three-fourths of all the print cloths made in the country. It has more spindles than any State in the United States except Massachusetts, nearly as many as all the Southern States combined, and more than twice as many as any other city in the country.

ISLIP, L.I., June 26. -- As a memento to the late Rev. Reuben Riley and the late Rev. W.E. Ringwalt, two memorial windows have been placed in the Church of the Messiah in Central Islip. The Rev. Mr. Riley was the founder of the Church of the Messiah. The Rev. W.E. Ringwalt was a deacon in charge of the missions of the church.

The New York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution has prepared a set of resolutions to be forwarded to Queen Victoria, congratulating her on her Jubilee. They will be engrossed on vellum and inclosed in a white kid case, with silver trimmings. The resolutions read as follows:

The subject is unpleasant, but we beg to call the attention of moralists and social reformers to the remarkable statements made by Capt. CHAPMAN in an interview reported in THE TIMES of yesterday. The impression has of late become very general that vice is at the present time unusually obtrusive and conspicuous in the streets of New York.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Down a long, steep hill at Lakeside eight persons were dragged in an open wagon behind a maddened runaway horse this noon. At the bottom of the hill is a deep ditch and into this the party was thrown beneath the overturned wagon. They were members of the First Presbyterian Church of Evanston, and were on their way to attend the annual picnic of the Sunday school given in Hubbard's Woods.
BERLIN, June 26. -- The Reichstag has adjourned for the Summer, but the Prussian Diet will remain in session until late in July.
