It is the People's Institute, and what it proposes to do is told in the second clause in its charter, which reads as follows:

LENOX, June 26. -- The most distinguished guest of the week among the cottagers is the Comte des Garets-Quiros, who has been the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos de Heredia at Wheatleigh, the H.H. Cooke country place. This is the first time the Count has ever seen the hills of Lenox, and he is greatly charmed with the country round about.

BOSTON, June 26. -- The Boston-Baltimore game to-day was a great pitcher's contest, both being remarkably effectives Nichols only allowed one hit in the last five innings, and that was in the ninth. With two men out, Stenzel hit the ball to right field over the low fence near the bleachers, and it netted a home run, the only score made during the entire game.

BUENOS AYRES, June 26. -- It is announced that the Argentine Government will assume the debt of the Province of Buenos Ayres, taking as a guarantee for its repayment the customs receipts at the port of La Plate.

VIENNA, June 14. -- The Austrian Court has gone into mourning for Princess Sophia d'Alencon, sister of the Empress Elizabeth, who met with such a tragic fate in the recent fire at Paris. Sad recollections attach to the life of that remarkable lady. It was she who was the first cause of King Ludwig of Bavaria's tragedy. He, perfectly mad, drowned himself in Lake Starhenberg; she was burned to death.

President Alexander E. Orr of the New York Chamber of Commerce has just returned from an extended trip throughout the West. He went away uncertain as to the business outlook; he comes back not merely hopeful but confident to the point of enthusiasm. Mr. Orr gives a most glowing account of prospects for prosperity in the West; he found that there was already material increase in the business of that section.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Johannes Gelert's bronze bust of Beethoven made on the order of Prof. Carl Wolfsohn, and presented by him to the city, was dedicated with appropriate ceremonies last Saturday afternoon at Lincoln Park. To the relief of the artistic, the bust has turned out a beautiful piece of work, saving Chicago from the addition of another to its collection of bronze and marble freaks.
The very first song Du Maurier ever heard, in his later life he loved to recall. In the second part of "The Martian" he writes of it in the most touching manner:

Gen. Roy Stone, Director of Road Inquiry in the United States Department of Agriculture, has sent to Secretary James L. Wilson an elaborate paper, prepared by C.L. Whittle, or the "Forces Which Operate to Destroy Roads." This paper goes into the subject of the construction and care of roads, from a scientific, as well as a practical point of view, and Mr. Whittle submits some original and interesting notes on road stones.

July is always noted for one very important thing, so far as the earth is concerned, for it is in that month that our planet is in aphelion, or at its greatest distance from the sun. This event takes place on the first day of the month, when the fierce heat of Summer is mercifully tempered in the north temperate zone by the sun's 3,000,000 miles of extra distance.

HARTLEY HOUSE is a social and industrial settlement in the heart of the Fifteenth Assembly District of New York. Its object is the broad one of doing all it can in various ways to improve the condition of the poor. Before proceeding to describe the methods of its work I must say a few words as to how it happened to be started.
The peculiar way in which several boys of Yorkville disappeared from their homes last Wednesday has been explained. The boys, fifteen or twenty of them, were sent to a fresh-air home at Nyack.

In an unpublished history of the public improvements in "The Great North Side," Louis F. Haffen, Commissioner of Street Improvements for the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, points out the great extent and varied character of that section of the present City of New York which lies east of the Bronx River.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26. -- A mortgage for $1,000,000 has been filed with County Register Riker. It is given by the Passaic and Newark Electric Railway Company to the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company to cover bonds for the amount of the mortgage, which are to draw 5 per cent. interest and mature in June, 1937.

The subjoined lines, written a short time prior to the decease of King William IV. of England, (June 20, 1837,) addressed to the then Princess Victoria of Kent, were recited by Marc Antony Lawer, Esq., at the Mechanics' Institute in my native town of Lewes, Sussex County, England, a few days only before the death of England's Sailor King.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 26. -- John H. Bass and Charles T. Strawbridge were to-day appointed receivers of the Bass Foundry and Machine Works. The embarrassment, it is said, is only temporary, and has been caused by the depressed times for the past few years, and it is thought wise to place the works in the hands of receivers so as to keep the concern going and the 800 men employed.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 10. -- By a strange irony of fate, while the Governments of Europe are trying to effect a peaceable solution of the Eastern imbroglio there is a general awakening of race conflicts, national antipathies, and rivalry all over Europe. In the East the imperious veto of the great powers alone prevents the Greeks, Turks, Bulgarians, Servians, and Armenians from butchering one another in a merciless war of extermination.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 25. -- The following epitaph is copied from a stone in an old burying ground in Mystic, Conn.:

LONDON, June 26. -- A pleasant feature of the week was the Americans' complete success. The Special Embassy of the United States, headed by Whitelaw Reid, and the manner in which the British of all sides recognized the splendid and lavish manner in which he carried out the mission of the United States, have attracted considerable attention.

KOENIGSBERG, June 14. -- The old coronation city of the Prussian Kings, which lies well up toward the Russian frontier in the ancient Land of Amber, is just now bubbling over with suppressed excitement. A bomb has burst; a political revenge has been achieved. The Social Democrats have elected their man to the Reichstag, the Conservatives, Liberals, and Jew-baiters notwithstanding.

As with Samson of old, the Indians' wildness lay in their long hair, which the returned, educated Indians wore because, as they boasted, "it made them wild." All energies were bent to compel the adult males to cut their hoar and adopt civilized attire in vain. Even the police would not wear their uniforms.

Fairy stories are not entirely out of date. There is a little thirteen-year-old Brooklyn schoolgirl who writes them "out of her own head." The following is one of them as it was handed, very neatly written, to her teacher:

The first "recreation pier" provided for the public of New York City and the first of its kind in the world was formally opened yesterday at 4 P.M. The pier is at the foot of East Third Street, and its opening marks the first completed step in the work of erecting pleasure structures along the water front.

A public clock was erected at Ocean and Linden Avenues, Jersey City, a year ago by the residents of the vicinity. It kept good time until Thursday, when its face was found filled with buckshot that had been fired into it during the night. It was still running, though it was a little slow.
BERLIN, June 26. -- The Socialists are to hold a convention at Hamburg on Oct. 3. The principal point for discussion will be the participation of the Socialist Party in the Prussian Diet elections.

No doubt it seems curious to many casual observers that the United States, which at times has led the world in the construction of vessels, should have had only a few years ago a navy which was a mortification to its officers and a source of amusement to other nations.

Wall Street's present enthusiasm has much of its foundation in the excellent prospects for improvement in railroad earnings, the crop outlook giving every promise of wonderful betterment in that direction, and in the outlook for vast savings in fixed charges through bond-refunding schemes of which many of the important railroads are able to avail themselves.

The announcement made by President Quigg of the Republican County Committee at the meeting of the election district officers on Friday night, that no enrolled member of the Citizens' Union could properly be an enrolled Republican as well, it is claimed, will keep many Republicans off the rolls in the revision which will take place next Tuesday night.

PORTSMOUTH, June 26. -- A heavy fall of rain, accompanied by thunder and lightning, occurred at Portsmouth this evening. The storm lasted an hour but did not in any degree mar the effect of the illumination of the fleet. The night was pleasantly dark, no moon dimmed the effect of mortal creation, the waters of the Solent were reposefully quiet, everything contributed to enhance the success of the programme.

THE class of 1897. Harvard College, is the largest yet graduated by that celebrated institution, numbering within a half dozen of 400. Indeed, the result of the "exams" may be that quite that number will be granted sheepskins.

MY Aunt Mona, if her own words might be believed, had hardly been well for a day throughout her life, certainly not for one during the last twenty years She walked the earth a bundle of unstrung nerves, an incarnation of aches and pains, a living sufferer of all the disorders that poor mortals are liable to, a specimen of utter misery and living martyrdom.

The clouds that for so long a time threatened the racing of the thoroughbred as a sport seem to have passed away, and the men who have worked so unselfishly in the face of sometimes fanatical opposition to place racing where it properly belongs -- at the head of all sports of the field -- now bask in the encouraging and invigorating sunshine of prosperity.

The continuation of steady dealing and a succession of large transactions, which under the most favorable market conditions would be worthy of notice, have not only been most gratifying to the interested brokers, but also a source of confidence among real estate men generally, and sufficient reason for congratulation that the supposedly indispensable and much heralded "Summer dullness" is as yet in the background.

The annual regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club was sailed on the Sound yesterday in a brisk northwest wind. The chief feature of the races was the defeat of the Wasp by the Carmita, which is now owned by W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., and the contests for the Rouse Cups for schooners and sloops under a new system of measurement by which boats of excessive draught, overhang, or sail area were taxed.

Letters have been received in this city from members of the crew of the United State flagship New York, now lying in Hampton Roads, giving details of a new and heretofore unheard of order recently issued by Capt. Silas Casey, relating to the use of the ship's boats. The new order compels all enlisted men going on shore leave to pay their way on a shore boat.
BOSTON, June 26. -- Coach Lehmann of Harvard reached Boston to-night from Poughkeepsie and was interviewed by a reporter on the race of yesterday. He said:

Col. Jesse E. Peyton, one of the most remarkable men in this country, died at his home, in Haddonfield, N.J., a short time ago. He was known as the "Father of Centennials," from the fact that he had originated nearly all the great National and historical celebrations which have taken place in this country during the last thirty years.

IF the statement, of which so much has been made, (in the lack of other theatrical topics,) that Charles Frohman intends to remain in London and conduct his future operations from there, could be gravely considered at all, it could be considered only as a severe blow to the American theatre in a very critical period.

LONDON, June 26. -- The Winnipeg oarsmen who are to take part in the Henley regatta viewed the procession from the Cambridge inclosure and returned to Henley in time to take a spin over the course. They have taken quarters at the Manor Farm, and are delighted with the hospitality shown to them on all sides.

Justice Dickey, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday enjoined the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad Company from mortgaging its property for $1,500,000 to the Brooklyn Trust Company or issuing bonds within a term of fifty years. The application was made by ex-Corporation Counsel Jenks on behalf of Patrick H. Flynn, who is the owner of a large block of stock of the company.

Mr. QUIGG'S official ruling and his instructions to his captains put a large number of old-time Republicans upon the list of "hostiles" who cannot be permitted to enroll as members of the Republican Party.

BOSTON, June 26. -- With infinite slowness, but at the same time infinite perseverance, the work of adding to and improving the Massachusetts State House has advanced until within a comparatively short time "the new building" will be a completed reality. At least, this will be true so far as the structural labors are concerned.

THE scheme of furnishing additional breathing space for the people of this city by means of utilizing some of the piers has been in process of agitation for some years, but it remained for the present Dock Commissioners to take hold and develop the project.

The Cuban Junta, which has its offices on the second and third floors of 36 New Street, yesterday opened an additional office on the ground floor, just off the main entrance to the building. This office is being fitted up for Jose Zayas, Special Financial Commissioner of the Republic of Cuba.
The Brooklyns turned the tables on the Philadelphias yesterday, and defeated them in the third and last game of the series by the score of five to 3.

The third day of the Music Teachers' Convention, at the Grand Central Palace, began yesterday with a business session in the concert hall. Prof. G.C. Gow of Vassar College read the new constitution, as drafted by the Committee on Revision, of which he was Chairman, and after considerable discussion it was adopted.

HAVANA, June 26. -- Rumors have been afloat here yesterday morning, probably emanating from official circles, that Gen. Maximo Gomez, the insurgent Commander-in-Chief, has been killed in a fight near the military line, in the Province of Puerto Principe, extending from Jucaro to Moron. The reports have not been confirmed.

THE NEW YORK TIMES takes pleasure in announcing that it secured, at great cost, the monopoly for the United States of photographing the Queen's Jubilee procession, the greatest pageant of modern times, as it passed in front of St. Paul's Cathedral, the great point of vantage.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The Senate started to-day on its second passage through the Tariff bull, the purpose being to dispose of all items previously passed over. The paragraphs considered were in the chemical and earthenware schedule, and failed to elicit more than technical debate, except in the discussion relating to fuller's earth, which practically was terminated by the sudden illness of Mr. Pettigrew.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The Senate Civil Service Committee resumed its inquiry to-day under the Allen resolution, William M. Butcher of Philadelphia being the first witness. He represented eighty-two Philadelphia letter carriers who were in 1895 under Postmaster General Wilson reduced to the position of substitutes.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- An abrupt and startling halt in the tariff debate occurred in the Senate at 2:30 o'clock to-day, when, in the midst of a passionate speech, Senator Pettigrew, silver Republican of South Dakota, was stricken with paralysis of the vocal organs, which brought his vehement speech to a close with a sentence half uttered.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- Seymour and Sullivan had the Senators at their mercy to-day, but eleven hits being made in the two games. In the second game O'Brien's hand was injured, and he retired. Brown going into the game. King pitched well, but Mercer was hit hard. The score:

Tobacco Trust stock advanced five points during the week on what insiders are frank enough to declare is the discounting of a favorable decision from the Criminal Court in which the trust's Directors are being tried. Generally insiders talk bullish on the stock, but one Virginia stockholder is known to have sold out a large block of trust just before the present advance set in.

Ex-Congressman William Bourke Cockr n arrived home yesterday from Europe, where he has been traveling for several months. He came in on the Paris, and early in the day he visited his new offices in the Bank of Commerce Building. Mr. Tomlinson, his law partner, had moved the firm's offices during Mr. Cockran's absence, and the distinguished orator had to ask the janitor of the building where his own offices were.

The second company of little girls from the schools of the Children's Aid Society went to Bath Beach Monday. The excursionists numbered between 300 and 400, and will remain at the Home for a week. Before the new detachment arrived at the grounds, those whose vacation had just expired were well on their way to the city.

The Lord Denman this generation knew would be harshly described if he were said to be insane, for he was not violent, and never offended any more than he hurt anybody; but he was certainly of weak, or at least eccentric, intellect. He attended every sitting of the House of Lords quite conscientiously, and no sitting passed without his rising to speak.

LONDON, June 19. -- The overpowering dullness of the London Sunday is so well understood that a large percentage of the population makes it a point to be out of town on that day; and this very fact makes a Sunday excursion undesirable, for all the conveyances to suburban resorts are crowded with people who have no other day for enjoyment.

THE HAGUE, June 14. -- Mounting the somewhat steep path that leads up to the Burg in the midst of the City of Leyden one stops to take breath, then to gaze, then to bow the head in reverence, as the eye falls over this ancient city, small but power holding, which has played and still plays an important part in the fortunes and lives of men.
LONDON, June 26. -- Mrs. Margaret Oliphant, the authoress, died last evening of cancer. Mrs. Oliphant was unconscious for several days previous to her death.

The Board of Mississippi River Commission, which has been in session since Thursday in the Army Building, on Whitehall Street, in this city, finished its work yesterday, and the outside members started for their homes in the West and the South. They had left the apportionment for the last thing, and it was for this matter that delegates came from all parts of the Mississippi River States.

THE general public never sees the men of the Naval Militia except when they turn out for parade. As sailors do not necessarily form a marching organization, it is hardly to be expected that the amateur tars of the First Naval Battalion should march as well as the Seventh Regiment.
