Now that the Victorian Jubilee has passed, with its engrossing splendor and significance, the attention of Europe is again turned to the still unsettled and still perilous situation in Thessaly. All reports agree that up to the present time the acts of the Government of Turkey have been in direct conflict with the Sultan's professed desire to satisfy the powers.

-- Claiming and possessing, as it does, certain elements of superiority that, having nothing to do with military excellence, might easily detract from it, the Seventh Regiment is constantly regarded by the public, and especially by other members of the National Guard, with a closeness of attention not exactly loving, and readier to criticise than to admire.

The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa preached on the "Diamond Jubilee," at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, Waverley Place and West Eleventh Street, last night, taking, as his text Exodus xii., 26: "What mean ye by this service?"

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27, -- Miss Minnie Levinson, eighteen years old, pretty and accomplished, a daughter of Jacob Levinson, a wealthy resident of South River, and Bray Martin, twenty-five years old, a well-known young man of the same place, are missing. They have not been seen in South River since Friday evening.

Toward the close of the Senate's first overhauling of the Tariff bill, when the silk schedule came up for what is called "consideration," Senator JONES of Arkansas denounced the rates as ranging from 70 per cent. to 700 per cent. This was warmly denied by Senator PLATT of Connecticut, who said that the rates did not "average more than 75 per cent."
At the lowest estimate 100,000 persons visited Coney Island yesterday, and the streets were crowded from early morn.

August Cheron, twenty-seven years old, of 413 Paterson Avenue, West Hoboken, John Weidner of Summit Avenue, and William Gurns of 86 Spring Street, West Hoboken, went fishing on the Hackensack River yesterday afternoon in a rowboat.

COLUMBUS, June 27. -- A feature of the Republican campaign this Fall will be the oratory of Mr. Hanna. The Senator evidently recognizes the fact that he has a fight before him. He also recognizes the fact that the rural and working population are prejudiced against him because of his wealth and alleged unfriendly attitude toward organized labor.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 27. -- The Pan-American tourists went over into Kentucky to-day, and had an outing. The commercial men of the Queen City decided that the foreign visitors would be grateful for a little time away from mills and foundries, so the events arranged for the three days' stay here are entirely in the way of entertainment.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, June 27. -- The most exacting person could not ask for any more charming weather than Sunday brought with it to the soldiers in camp. The heat from the cloudless sky was tempered just enough by a delightful breeze that swept up from the river and across the wooded hills, making it a lazy, dreamy day.

Harlem River oarsmen were out in full force yesterday, as it was an ideal day for rowing. The Union Boat Club men were in the water as early as 10 A.M., when Capt. Cassidy started the intermediate eight-oared crew, which is training for the Springfield regatta, at work. They rowed about six miles in good form.

Charles Wreta, ten years old, is lying in a critical condition at the home of his parents, 697 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, with a fractured skull, which he received by being run down with a bicycle ridden by Charles G. Apitzsph, twenty-nine years old, of 1,200 Bushwick Avenue. The accident to the boy occurred on Friday while in company with another brother they were playing ball in the street.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- President Cleveland on May 6, 1896, Issued an order including certain officers and employes of the War Department within the provisions of the civil service law and rules, arranging those employes in eleven classes, the order placing within the classified service all persons receiving from less than $720 a year to those with a salary at the rate of $2,500 a year.

George R. Bidwell will be the next Collector of the Port of New York. This has been definitely decided upon among the Republican leaders, and there is ample reason for saying that assurances of the appointment have already been received from President McKinley.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The Republican tariff managers are hopeful this will be the last week of the tariff debate in the Senate, but they do not feel sure of it. Many of the differences among the Republicans have been adjusted, but the Democrats naturally will take advantage of their knowledge of the feeling existing among their opponents to debate some of the questions at length.

TACOMA, Washington, June 27. -- The Philippine rebellion is not ended. A large band of insurgents, which left Cavite, has reached the neighborhood of Manila, and on May 18 it was within one hour's drive of the capital. This was after the Commander in Chief, Captain General Primo de Rivera, had published his latest proclamation declaring the rebellion ended and offering pardon to the insurgents.

There was considerable amusement in Jefferson Market Court yesterday when Policeman Regan of the Macdougal Street Station arraigned Lily Morret on a charge of disorderly conduct. Lily wore a bicycle cap, a silk waist, and a gray skirt. In appearance she looked like the tough girl in "The Bowery."

" This man lost his feet, your Honor, and could not navigate," said Patrolman Henschel of the Eldridge Street Station, who arraigned John Meyer, thirty-one years old, residing at 56 Stanton Street, on a charge of intoxication before Magistrate Brann, in the Essex Market Court, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Senator Pettigrew has recovered rapidly from his illness of Saturday. He had so far recovered his voice to-night as to be able to articulate quite distinctly, and he expressed great confidence in his speedy restoration to health.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 27. -- There is every indication that the Gold Democrats of Ohio are going to make trouble for their friends who are now gathering at Columbus to nominate a State ticket.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Mrs. Annie Besant was cheered when she expressed hope of a reunion with the faction of Theosophists in this country in her address at the annual convention of the American Section of the Theosophical Society held to-day at the rooms of the Chicago branch, in the Athenaeum Building. An additional interest was imparted to the occasion by the presence of the Countess Wachtmeister and Miss Wilson.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 27. -- None of the college crews went upon the water to-day.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27. -- Deputy United States Marshals attached to the Fort Smith court have captured three men whose arrest, it is believed, has effectually broken up the once-famous band of counterfeiters known to secret service operators all over the United States as the Bullfrog Valley Gang.

John Smith, a boy of sixteen, living at 247 West Sixteenth Street, was run over by a Boulevard horse ear at 7:30 o'clock last night and received injuries from the effects of which he will probably die.
LONDON, June 27. -- A dispatch from Santiago de Chile says that President Errazuriz has accepted the following Cabinet, to succeed Senor Carlos Antunez, which resigned on June 22:
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 27.--The annual sermon to the graduating class of Wesleyan was preached this morning in the Methodist Church by the Rev. Bishop W.X. Ninde of Detroit, Mich.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 27. -- The United States cruiser Marblehead, lying in the harbor, was open to visitors this afternoon between the hours of 1 and 5. During this time she was visited by over 3,000 persons, and there were fully 15,000 strangers in the town. The steam ferry, with every conceivable kind of craft, was pressed into service, and the owners reaped a rich harvest.
" Oh, look at the little dogs! Wouldn't you like to have one?"

AMHERST, Mass., June 27. -- The baccalaureate sermon at Amherst College was preached to-day by the Rev. Dr. A.H. Bradford. His subject was "Puritanism." There was a demand, he said, in the modern world for the essential principles of Puritanism. In the course of his sermon, he said:
The late Collector KILBRETH, when he first took the Collectorship, remarked to the writer that it would have been an impossible place had he not been protected by the civil service rules.

In a suit for divorce that is now pending in Plainfield, N.J., and is a topic of absorbing interest to the polite society of that town of beautiful shade trees and frequently agreeable people, some of the testimony excites interest of a purely literary character and may, therefore, be commented upon without prejudice or injustice to either plaintiff or defendant.

At the convention of the Music Teachers' National Association a lady read a paper on woman's work in musical composition. She was wise enough to confine most of her paper to the safe field of prophecy. She told her hearers what woman would do in the future in musical creation.

The annual festival of the Hudson County Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein began yesterday in the Union Hall Schuetzen Park. The park was thronged with thousands of happy Germans, young and old, and the affair proved to be a grand success.

Dr. T.H. Bean, Superintendent of the Aquarium, returned yesterday on the steamer Orinoco from a three weeks' trip through the Bermudas and brought with him some interesting specimens of fish peculiar to the waters in and near the Gulf Stream. The most beautiful specimens were four angel fish.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27. -- Although the Democratic State Convention does not meet till Wednesday, a half dozen of the candidates for the nomination for Governor opened their headquarters here to-day. The delegates will meet by Congressional districts Tuesday afternoon and the committees Tuesday night, and most of the preliminary work will be done to-morrow night.

He [Mr. Low] does not wish to be a candidate unless all the friends of good government unite in his support. This means that the Republican organization may, if it so desires, nominate him, and that the Citizens' Union may, if it chooses, follow suit. But he will not be the candidate of a clique of political amateurs who would have no potency in a campaign.
MILWAUKEE, June 27. -- The ambitions of ex-Gov. W.D. Hoard and ex-Congressman Robert M. La Follette to succeed Senator Mitchell is causing trouble in the anti-machine ranks of the Republican Party.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27. -- The recent complete temporary overthrow of the Foraker-Kurtz-Bushnell dynasty is the saddest fact in local political chronicles. A year ago these three men were in absolute control. The worst of all has been the passing of Kurtz, who was turned down "good and plenty," to appropriate an uncopyrighted Ohio idiom.

With the regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, which was sailed Saturday, the yacht-racing circuit on the Sound was begun. There will be racing now every day until July 7, and then the yachts of the Atlantic Club will start on their cruise to the eastward.

NEWPORT, June 27. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Conqueror, owned by F.W. Vanderbilt; steamer Intrepid, owned by Lloyd Phenix; schooner Sea Fox, owned by A. Tucker; schooner Quickstep, owned by F. Grinnell.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 27. -- Seven coffins were forwarded to St. Louis to-day from Missouri City. They contained the remains of the following victims of last night's wreck on the Wabash Road:
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 27. -- Fine weather marked the opening event of the Ocean Grove religious services for the season of 1897, which occurred to-day. All the meetings were largely attended.
HAVANA, June 27. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler has arrived at Manzanillo. Heavy rains are falling in the interior of the island.

Now that the trotting campaign is in active progress, there are few horses left for the dress parade at Fleetwood and Parkway, which is held at the opening of each week. The fliers in training are too busy with their regular work to furnish diversion for the road drivers, who are always ready with a match to catch a trial, and the amateur reinsmen have the field pretty much to themselves.
The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome, which arrived yesterday on her second trip out from Glasgow this season, came perilously near disaster almost at the close of the voyage.

Detectives Higgins and Bennett of the Elizabeth Street Station arrested two young colored men on Saturday night who they believe will turn out to be desperate burglars. It is suspected that they robbed the Pelham Manor railroad station. They gave their names as Louis Hayden, twenty-two years old, no home, and Charles Johnson, alias Taylor, of Rondout, N.Y., but late of Long Branch, N.J.

" Our Greater City" was the subject of the sermon delivered last night in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Charles L. Thompson. The preacher took for his text Acts xxi., 39 -- "A citizen of no mean city." He said:
CINCINNATI, June 28. -- An important utterance on the tariff question was made by the Pan-American commercial men, who are here on their tour, to-day.

The business session, with which the last day of the Music Teachers' Convention at the Grand Central Place began, was held in the Lyceum yesterday morning and furnished a good deal of excitement. It was a case of the West arrayed against the East, and the East came out victorious, but not until after a hard struggle for the supremacy.

Senator ELKINS of West Virginia has been "reading the riot act" to Senator ALLISON. According to the Washington dispatch of The Brooklyn Eagle, Mr. ELKINS sought Mr. ALLISON in his committee room and demanded an explanation in detail of how sufficient revenue was to be got out of the Tariff bill.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Senate Committee on Finance to-day settled several vexed questions in connection with the tariff, including lead ore and iron ore.

There was a rather sensational hearing yesterday before Referee Rastus S. Ransom in the contest over the estate of William L. Blanchard, or "Doc" Blanchard, as he was better known in sporting circles in this city, who died last year leaving an estate valued at $60,000. Letters of administration were granted to Fannie Blanchard, or Belkeiser, a negress, housekeeper for Blanchard for twenty years, and claiming to be his wife.

The arrest yesterday afternoon of Frederick McHenry Kitching, a swell-appearing young man of New Brighton, S.I., in the Centre Street Court, at the instance of Andrew L. Taylor, a broker at 256 Broadway, reveals a complicated set of financial deals in which a number of people are more or less involved.

The Indian Right Association, through its Washington agent, Mr. FRANCIS E. LEUPP, has issued a statement of an outrage on the Navajo Indians, in January last, which is not pleasant reading for the citizens of a Republic whose professed policy is to "civilize" the remnants of the Indian tribes.

TRENTON, N.J., June 28. -- In the United States court to-day Justice Kirkpatrick made an order for the receivers of the Erie Railroad to show cause on July 12 why the court should not dissolve an injunction granted by the late Judge Green, restraining the New Jersey Electric Company from building a trolley road in Passaic City.

The behavior of the passengers, both cabin and steerage, and of the officers and crew of the City of Rome during the thirty-two hours after the discovery of fire on board was praiseworthy, and whatever loss the steamship company may incur through the damage to the ship and cargo will surely be more than compensated for, in a practical way, by the increased confidence of the public in its methods of management.

HAZLETON, Penn., June 23. -- John Broadt, indicted for murder, but later released on a writ of habeas corpus, and whose case was to have come up in court to-day, shot and killed himself a few yards from his home this morning.
The annual regatta of the Stamford Yacht Club was sailed yesterday in a good sailing breeze from the southwest. Twenty-three yachts started and all but two finished.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- It was intended that as soon as the Tariff bill should be taken up to-day, the paragraphs relating to hides should be considered. On account of the absence and slight indisposition of Mr. Smith of New Jersey, who desired to make a speech on hides, Mr. Allison consented to let the subject go over until Mr. Smith should appear.

Golfing interest this week will be centered chiefly in Seabright, where a three days' open tournament will be held over the new eighteen-hole course of the Seabright Golf Club. The contest will begin Friday morning, and will be continued Saturday and Monday.

There are many reasons for believing that the explanation of the mystery of the fragments of a dismembered body found part in the East River and part at Undercliff Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-sixth Street can be found in the disappearance of two men from the State Lunatic Asylum at King's Park, L. I., reported on June 9.

The investigation into the legitimacy of the so-called Raines clubs and their right to sell liquor was continued before Referee Edward D. O'Brien in the St. Paul Building yesterday. The Plymouth Social Club, with headquarters at the Broadway Garden, was the subject of inquiry. A charge of keeping a disorderly place is pending against the proprietor, Bruno Bretschneider, and the present action is taken for the purpose of revoking its liquor license.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 28. -- The New York and New Haven Railroad is having much trouble with train wreckers. During the past few months the Stonington division has had three attempts at train wrecking. The last was on Sunday, when rails were piled high on the track near Wood River Junction, to throw the fast mail from the track.

HAVANA, June 28. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler, after a stormy passage on a coasting steamer from Manzanillo, arrived at Santiago de Cuba yesterday afternoon. The steamer was met by a number of tugs, having on board the municipal authorities, provincial authorities, and Gen. Linares, the Military Commander of the district.

The New Yorks returned from their victorious Southern trip Sunday. Yesterday afternoon they appeared in bran-new white uniforms at the Polo Grounds and demonstrated conclusively, in a game with the Baltimores, both by the score and the form they displayed, that their winning streak is likely to last for some time. Baltimore was defeated by the score of 4 to 2.

Surrogate Arnold yesterday began the hearing of the contest over the will of De Witt C. Lawrence, at one time a well-known Wall Street banker. The testator was married twice. By the will submitted for probate, he left Louisa, his second wife, the income for life of $50,000, and divided the residue of his estate, amounting to about $20,000, between his five daughters by his first marriage.

Vice Chancellor GREY of New Jersey has been compelled, against his sympathies, perhaps, but in strict accord with his duty as a Judge, to extend the protection of his court to a cruel stepmother who, from his own words, seems to be a fit companion of all the cruel stepmothers of fiction.

HAVANA, June 28. -- The coasting steamer Triton, which has arrived here from ports in the Province of Pinar del Rio, brought eleven officers and twenty-five sick soldiers, in addition to fourteen prisoners of war.

The specifications for the new wing of the Museum of Natural History were approved by the Park Board yesterday, and the contract for building it will be awarded after advertisement to the most advantageous bidder. The wing is to cost $1,000,000.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 28. -- The Pennsylvania 'Varsity crew, under the same conditions that prevailed during the 'Varsity race of last Friday, so far as concerns wind and tide, has gone over the four-mile course in 19 minutes and 48 seconds, 46 seconds faster than Cornell made it and 56 seconds faster than Yale did. This time row was made in competition with the second 'Varsity and freshman crews, all rowing their best.

Slawson Hobbs have sold, for Theodore K. Pembrook, to Dr. George W. Jarman, for about $40,000, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, with extension, 54 West Seventy-sixth Street, 18 by 56 by 1022.

CLEVELAND, June 28. -- For some time past Mrs. Mary Obermiller, who resides in Lakewood, has been troubled by burglars. Two of her neighbors, Edward Ratcliffe and William Beneke, suggested to her that she obtain a tin horn and blow it when the burglars came again.

PEEKSKILL, June 28. Work began in earnest for the soldiers this morning, and to-night they feel very little like skylarking. From the time reveille sounded until mess call for dinner there was nothing but drills, company and battalion.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Col. William J. Lyster, commanding the Ninth Infantry at Sackett's Harbor, N.Y., was placed on the retired list of the army to-day by operation of law on account of age. He was a volunteer officer during the war, serving in a Michigan regiment, and was subsequently transferred to the regulars.

NEW HAVEN, June 28. -- The academic seniors held their class-day exercises to-day, their programme being the principal feature of commencement week at the university. The class formed in line on the campus at 10:30, marched in a body to Battell Chapel, where the presentation exercises took place. President Dwight presided, and introduced the class representatives.

BERLIN, June 28. -- A the health of Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, is in no way impaired, the semi-official announcement of his retirement from the Foreign Office, which comes from Kiel to-day, is regarded as a virtual dismissal.

In speaking of business conditions and prospects in the Northwest, Mr. Thomas Lowry, the well-known Minneapolis capitalist, who has just arrived in New York, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIME:

PORTSMOUTH, June 28. -- Much disappointment is felt among the British naval officers at the fact that the Queen did not review the fleet in person on Saturday, especially as she goes to Aldershot on Thursday in order to review the troops there.
When is Gov. BLACK going to have his starchless civil service rules ready?

The case of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company was given to the jury at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At 12:30 o'clock this morning the jury had not agreed upon a verdict and was locked up for the night. There was the usual speculation as to what a failure to agree in that time meant. Some said that it naturally pointed to a disagreement, while others thought it meant a conviction.

THE TIMES of June 25 contained a communication from the Reg. C. Armand Miller regarding the use of the name "Elohim," the Hebrew plural form of "God." While admitting that the writer in Genesis is not to be credited with a knowledge or prescience of the doctrine of the Trinity, he believes that the word was, nevertheless, divinely inspired, being a "suggestive foreshadowing" of this great Christian dogma.

It is evidently necessary to take cautionary salt freely with the dispatches from Honolulu. The "English-speaking people" of that capital, having obtained possession of the Government, are largely engaged in the undertaking to saddle the destinies of Hawaii upon the United States.

PORTLAND, Me., June 28. -- The will of the late John B. Curtis, the chewing gum manufacturer, was filed for probate today. The testator's entire property, amounting to about half a million dollars, is left to the care of trustees, to be named by the court.

ALBANY, June 28. -- Representatives of the educational institutions embraced within the University of the State of New York gathered in this city to-night in their thirty-fifth annual convocation. The sessions, which will continue until Wednesday, are being held in the Senate Chamber at the Capitol.
LONDON, June 28. -- At the Ashburnham Library sale to-day the famous Mazarin or Gutenberg Bible, on vellum, fetched 4,000 ($20,000.)

THE TIMES has held, these many years, that protectionism, by the law of its nature, must go on from bad to worse until it becomes intolerable and the people finally throw it off. No one can tell at what point the people's patience will be exhausted, but it looks now as if the present Tariff bill will fill the measure of what can be borne.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 28. -- Col. F.D. Mussey, the well-known Washington correspondent, died here suddenly last night of Bright's disease. He had been ill for some time.

Tradition has it that polo was played by the Persians as early as the beginning of the Christian Era, and that the riders were wild and fierce at the play. They could scarcely have been harder riders or fiercer players than the eight society men who circled and whirled and drove the ball up and down the field yesterday afternoon at the opening game of the polo tournament for the Meadow Brook Cups.

A part from the interior view it affords of the workings of Canadian polities, the dispatch THE TIMES published yesterday from Montreal has a special interest for American readers. It shows one of the consequences that naturally follow from the State ownership or control of railways, and a consequence to which not much attention has been paid in the discussion of the subject in this country.

Judge Coxe of the United States Circuit Court handed down a decision yesterday sustaining the demurrer entered in the suit brought by George C. Carey, as trustee, for the benefit of the creditors of the National Express and Transportation Company against John E. Roosevelt and others, as trustees, legatees, and beneficiaries of Amos Cotting's will, founded upon a judgment for $6,221.90 recovered against his administrators.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, Peekskill, June 29. -- For a time late last night a clash between the military and civil authorities of Peekskill appeared imminent, but so far as the soldiers are concerned it blew over with nothing more serious than some remarks concerning the mental calibre of a Peekskill constable.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- When the tariff bill was taken up in the Senate to-day attention was given immediately to Paragraph 189, relating to watch movements, clocks, , the same being the House paragraph amended by striking out the clauses on watches and on jewels used in the making of watches and confining the paragraph to those articles not made of china, porcelain,

William F. Hoey, known to every theatregoer in the United States as "Old Hoss" Hoey, died yesterday morning at his home, 201 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, of paresis. His final Illness was as brief as it was violent, having developed only last week at Mount Clemens, Mich., where he was seeking relief from an attack of sciatic rheumatism.
LONDON, June 29. -- The Pall Mall Gazette this afternoon prints the following dispatch from its correspondent at Madrid:

Dr. Thomas A. Conaty, rector of the Catholic University at Washington, has been elevated by the Pope. He is now Mgr. Conaty, Domestic Prelate to the Holy See, with the title of Right Reverend. The announcement was made last night for the first time by Archbishop Martinelli, the Papal Delegate, at a dinner given in his honor by Brother Justin, President of the Manhattan College, in the De La Salle Institute, 108 West Fifty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

TACOMA, Washington, June 29.--Capt. Curtis of the British wheat ship Eurydice, which has just sailed for Europe, told a story just before leaving which sounds much like a sailor's yarn, but which he vered to be strictly true.

The Baltimores had another opportunity yesterday to check New York's stride in the race for the pennant. They couldn't do it, and received a worse drubbing than they did on Monday. The score stood 8 to 2 in favor of the home team at the end of the game. The game was not so interesting as that of Monday; it was too one-sided.

Gov. BLACK is not cheerful as to the present and future value of the scholar in public affairs. He thinks it is already decidedly less than in the "earlier days of the Republic." Then "the statesman, the politician, and the scholar were the same." Now he fears that there is a tendency in the scholar not to "grow to the size of a statesman," but to "shrink to the crippled stature of a critic."

ADEN, June 29. -- The Indian Government's steamer Mayo, sent out in search of the missing steamer Aden, from Yokohama on April 28, via Colombo and Aden for London, which was last heard of when leaving Colombo on June 1 for this port, has returned here and reports that the Aden was totally lost off the Island of Socotra, at the eastern extremity of Africa, during the morning of June 9.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Three hundred Bannock Indians have broken away from the Fort Hall Reservation, in Idaho, and their actions have alarmed the settlers in the adjacent territory.
Philip Jeselson has sold for James B. Harris to Max Marx the two three-story American basement dwellings 516 and 518 West One Hundred and Fortieth Street, each 15 by 80 by 100.

Aboard the trim yacht Viking, snugly anchored a full mile off the shore of Larchmont in Long Island Sound, with the water scarcely rippled by the salt sea zephyrs that languidly tossed the folds of her bridal veil, Miss Helen Woodruff Smith was united in marriage to Homer Stille Cummings yesterday morning.
BERLIN, June 29. -- The local press teems with comment upon the changes in the Cabinet, which are regarded as a triumph for Prince Bismarck and the Agrarians.

Further testimony was taken yesterday before Referee O'Brien in the proceedings to revoke the charter of the Plymouth Social Club. Royal R. Scott, N.N. Stranahan, and Alfred R. Page represented the prosecution, and Lawyers Neuberger and Barnes. Bruno Bretschneider, the defendant.

It seems odd that the Board of Health should be invoked to stop the slaughter of foot passengers at the corner of Broadway and Fourteenth Street. But in fact there could be no more legitimate occasion for the interference of that body, and the large powers bestowed upon that body enable it to interfere to some purpose.

Chief Conlin returned to duty at Police Headquarters yesterday after a twelve days' sojourn in the Adirondacks. He was at once beset by reporters, who questioned him about the story that Capt. Chapman was to be transferred from the West Thirtieth Street Station. The Chief said:

BALTIMORE, June 29. -- S. Weinkrantz of 909 East Baltimore Street says he believes the headless trunk found in New York to be that of his uncle, S. Weinkrantz. He says that since the finding of the remains he has made numerous attempts to communicate with his uncle, who resides at 119 Park Row, New York, but has received no response.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 29. -- A dynamite plosion early this morning in South Scranton blew up the business block of Leon Olchefski, a double dwelling block owned by him, and a single house owned by Michael O'Hara. The business block, a two-story building, was torn to pieces. Twenty other houses had all the windows blown out, and plaster torn from the walls. The shock was felt all over the city.

LONDON, June 29. -- At the Newmarket first July meeting to-day, the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's bay colt Elfin won a selling plate of 103 sovereigns for two-year-olds. The same stable's bay gelding Glaring won a Trial Plate of 200 sovereigns, for three years old and upward. The Bottisham Plate, of 200 sovereigns, was won by Lord Wolverton's five-year-old bay horse Ugly, the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's chestnut gelding Draco being second.

The freak journals, those startling and irrepressible caterers to the gross and savage side of human nature, are having a particularly fine time with their new "murder mystery." Not content with doing "detective work" themselves, and putting all the celebrated detectives of fact and fiction to shame with their owlish wisdom, they are also pressing their readers into service to help ferret out the mystery.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 29. -- The preliminary work of the Democratic State Convention showed to-day that it was almost unanimous for free silver and John R. McLean for Senator. There was, however, a continuation of the contests for the different places on the State ticket.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Acting Secretary Roosevelt held a conference to-day for an hour with Admiral Sicard, commanding the North Atlantic Squadron; Capt. Crowninshield, Chief of the Navigation Bureau, and Capt. Jewell of the Ordnance Bureau, respecting the disposition of the vessels of the North Atlantic Squadron this Summer and next Fall.
So far as can now be told, Mr. QUIGG'S new enrollment, made last night, is very much like the old enrollment. Why not?

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 29. -- W.F. Herbert was relieved of the receivership of the Carolina, Cumberland Gap and Chicago Railway by Judge C.H. Simonton, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, here to-day. This action is taken without prejudice to any of the claimants against the road now before the courts.

The "art departments" of such of our esteemed daily contemporaries as still maintain those curious appendages are liable to get them into grievous trouble. One of them yesterday presented its readers with what purported to be a portrait of Baron VON BULOW, the new German Minister for Foreign Affairs, but was in fact a recognizable likeness of the late HANS VON BULOW, the pianist.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- Yale's Commencement is nearing its close. The alumni had their celebration to-day. In the morning the first exercise was the annual alumni reunion in Alumni Hall. Thomas Hooker of this city called the meeting to order and said that the Executive Committee had selected A.F. Judd, Chief Justice of the Hawaiian Republic, '62, to preside.

BOSTON, June 29. -- Brooklyn earned more runs than Boston to-day, yet lost the game, 8 to 7, errors and chance hits giving Boston the victory. Boston played an errorless game. Klobedanz was batted pretty freely, ten hits being made off him up to the eighth inning. Nichols was then substituted and held the visitors down to one hit for the remainder of the game.

In time of plague or war I suppose the leisure fancies of any building legislation would not be literally carried out, so far as the temporary hospitals would be concerned, which would be put in readiness for the sick or wounded. My idea about the immediate help needed for certain sick poor seems to me to resemble the plans for aid which the above unusual circumstances would necessitate.
WASHINGTON, June 29.--Acting Secretary Roosevelt has practically completed the programme for the Summer drills of the Naval Militia, so far as the Navy Department is connected with the movements.

An exceptionally large number of people bound their way to the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday and had a pleasant afternoon's sport, even though there was no ansational feature on the card to draw a crowd or cause any unusual excitement. But there was all the business that the layers in the ring cared for, and Lander's musicians had the pleasure of playing in their inimitable fashion to an exceptionally appreciable lot of listeners.

Although it is now nearly four days since a portion of the body of a murdered man was found in the East River, and three since a second part of the same headless trunk was picked up in the woods in Harlem, the mystery of his identity and of that of his slayer, is apparently as far from solution as at first.

Walking delegates have induced workmen in the building trades to do some wonderful things in vindication of the right of the walking delegate to live without labor. But they have never succeeded in committing a body of workmen to a more preposterous proposition than that in defense of which the plasterers are now striking.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- When Yale lost her commencement day ball game to Princeton here a year ago, the alumni held up their hands aghast. Such a thing had never happened in the memory of the oldest Yale enthusiast. But this afternoon Harvard did just what Princeton did a year ago -- defeated the blue on the grounds of the latter university, the final score standing 10 to 8.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Several hundred pension bills were reported to the Senate to-day as the result of the first meeting of the Pension Committee since the present Congress assembled.
LONDON, June 29. -- The eleventh and twelfth rounds of the women's international chess tournament were played to-day. Appended are the scores up to date:

Lovers of cycle racing will find it hard to decide where to visit next Saturday and the following Monday by reason of the many race meets arranged for those two days within the Metropolitan district. Choice need not be limited to track events, as several road races are projected for the two days.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Senor Andrade, the Venezuelan Minister, has received no confirmation of the cable report that President Crespo's Ministry resigned yesterday. If it should prove to be true, the Minister thinks, it will be found that the reasons assigned are incorrect. He says there are no differences in the Cabinet growing out of the provisions of the Guiana boundary line arbitration treaty.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 29. -- Arthur Gardiner of Chicago in to-day's races of the National Circuit bicycle meet, held at the State Fair Grounds, broke the world's one-mile handicap record. There were eighteen starters in the race, Gardiner, Mertens, and Will Coburn being the scratch men.
LONDON, June 30. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Aden, Arabia, says:

In the adjustment of the business relations between the New York Central and Harlem railroad companies, incident to the general refunding scheme now under way, a formal suit has been brought by the first-named corporation to compel the Harlem to execute a mortgage on its property and franchises to the Central and to issue bonds under the mortgage for $12,000,000 payable in gold on May 1, 2000.

Discussing business and financial conditions and the outlook for Stock-market prices, Mr. John Greenough of the Stock Exchange firm of poor Greenough said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:...

The protracted trial of the officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company on an indictment charging them with conspiracy to restrain trade and commerce came to an end yesterday afternoon at 3:25 o'clock, when the foreman of the jury, W.W. Dixon, announced to Judge Fitzgerald that the jurors could not agree upon a verdict.

The Tribune is inclined to make ponderous fun of those who resist the latest Tariff bill. It calls them Bourbons and says that they are "fatuous worshippers of British theories" and that they "represent half a century ago and not the brilliant closing of the nineteenth century."

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Information has reached the Treasury Department that large numbers of Chinese admitted into this country as participants in the Tennessee Exposition were clandestinely leaving Nashville for San Francisco, Sacramento, St. Louis, New York, and other cities, thus evading the spirit and letter of the law authorizing their admittance.

CANTON, N.Y., June 29. -- St. Lawrence University is in the midst of its thirty-seventh annual commencement. The town is filled with old students, including Foster L. Backus, H.H. Gunnison, and W.B. Gunnison of Brooklyn; C.S. Russell of New York, and many others. Last night the Latin students presented the "Mostellaria" of Plautus in the Latin.

Cable car accidents and the risks to public at the dangerous curves on the Metropolitan line traction road at Fourteenth and at Fifty-third Street, occupied the attention of the Board of Health at its meeting yesterday. Sanitary Superintendent Charles F. Roberts submitted a long report on the subject.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The report by Senator Hoar in the case of H.W. Corbett, claiming a seat from Oregon by appointment of the Governor has been printed for the use of the Committee on Privileges and Elections. After reviewing the situation in the Oregon Legislature, the report continues:

Some further gains were yesterday made by stock market reactionists. They worked hard and accomplished some material results in a few quarters. The market was soft all day long, but an appearance of weakness given to it was hardly borne out by the record of final net changes. Only two railroad stocks are down for the day as much as a whole point.

American shares were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced-Erie first preferred, 1/2, to 35; Canadian Pacific, 1/4, to 65 3/4, and Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 52 1/8. Declined -- New York Central, 1/2, to 105; Reading, 1/4, to 11 5/8; Erie, 1/4, to 15 1/8; Atchison, 1/4, to 12 5/8, and St. Paul, 1/8, to 84 3/8.
Baltimore took the last game of the series against New York yesterday by the score of 8 to 3.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 30. -- Colby University to-day conferred the following honorary degrees: Master of Arts -- Dr. E.E. Holt, Portland; the Rev. J.A. Ford, Eastport. Doctor of Laws -- Alfred A. Buck, Atlanta, Ga.; Llewellyn Powers, Houlton. Doctor of Divinity -- The Rev. George B. Illsley, Bangor; the Rev. Charles H. Spaulding, Boston.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 30. -- Train No. 11 on the Vandalia Railroad, which left this city at 7 o'clock last evening, containing a large number of Christian Endeavorers, was in collision with Train No. 6, bound east from St. Louis, at 8:25 o'clock, near Vandalia. J.J. Turner, General Manager of the Vandalia, telegraphed the following facts to this city.

We are not surprised that the Treasury officials should accept with a large grain of salt the glowing prophecy of The National Review of London as to what England will do for bimetallism. The National Review is a sensational publication with no great amount of intelligence to guide it.

The Park Commissioners met in executive session Monday and enacted an ordinance regulating the use of vehicles, especially bicycles, in Central Park. This has been promulgated to the Police Board and will go into force to-day. The Park police have been directed to be vigilant in enforcing the rules.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 30. -- Two exciting games of polo for the Meadowbrook Cup were played here this afternoon. The contestants in the first game were the second team of the Rockaway Hunt Club and the second team of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club. The Rockaways won by 1 goal.

BALTIMORE, June 30. -- President and Receiver S.M. Felton of the Queen and Crescent Route, has returned from his tour of inspection over the Baltimore and Ohio system, and is now on his way to New York to report the result of his investigations to J.P. Morgan Co., in whose interest he made the trip.

Target practice with the new big guns is doubtless an essential part of the service at the newly fortified posts near the westerly end of Long Island Sound; but the people who live in Larchmont and New Rochelle and other places near Fort Slocum, and the residents of Long Island near the works at Willet's Point feel that it might be conducted in a manner less disagreeable to them.
HAVANA, June 30. -- Gen. Rius Rivera has been removed from Cabanas Fortress to the military hospital of San Ambrosio, in this city. He is comfortably quartered in the room of an officer.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Congressman Quigg, President of the New York County Republican Committee, had a consultation with President McKinley this afternoon, at which Mr. Quigg explained the New York Mayoralty situation and the necessity for Federal recognition of the "regulars."

Fastidious New Yorkers are to be congratulated. Yellow journalism's latest subject for brisk, wide-awake, "new" treatment is already nearly worn out. The junior yellow journal has almost solved the mystery, and whether or not anybody gets the $1,000 offered as a prize for clues, the four-page illustrated accounts of what happens at the Morgue when some mutilated portions of a corpse are on view there will soon lose their interest.

Sir WILFRED LAURIER'S speech at the Canadian banquet in London seems to have evoked more excitement than intrinsically it was adapted to create. He merely spoke very pleasantly about the United States and assured his hearers that he believed the American sentiment toward Great Britain was in reality very friendly.

Fully 3,000 persons assembled last night at the chapel of the Normal College, Sixty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, for the opening session of the New York State Teachers' Association's fifty-second annual convention, which is to last four days. This is the first time the convention was ever held in this city.

Patrick Cook, thirty-five years old, of 302 Second Avenue, who says he is an inventor and will startle the world with a perfect flying machine, was found at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning hanging by the left leg from the second arch of High Bridge. He had been experimenting with his flying machine, and went there at 3 o'clock in the morning so that he would not be disturbed.

Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court yesterday, heard argument and reserved decision on a motion on behalf of William Dehon King and others to compel Eugenia A. Webster Ross, the claimant to the estate, real and personal, left by William Henry King in this and other States, to file a bill of particulars in a suit brought against her to compel the determination of her claim to the real estate in New York City.

Edward N. Crosby and Eugene S. Willard have sold for the Courtlandt Palmer estate the plot on the east side of the Boulevard, 27 feet south of One Hundred and Sixth Street, 136 by 69 by 125 by 16. It is said that a large apartment house will be erected on this site.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met last night at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, and transacted routine business. W. Bayard Cutting was elected a member of the committee. R. Fulton Cutting, Chairman of the Union, has gone to Europe, and W. Bayard Cutting will sit in the Executive Committee at ting will sit in the Executive Committee at
" The Citizens' Union," says The World, "needs the Republican vote; the Republican vote needs the Citizens' Union. Now, what is the use of bickering about trifles?"

Nine men, seven of them positively, have identified the mutilated and dismembered corpse at the Morgue as that of William Guldensuppe, a masseur at the Murray Hill Turkish Baths in Forty-second Street. Five fellow employes had known him for years and had seen him almost daily nearly naked at his work in the baths.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Under date of June 19 Secretary Gage addressed the following letter to Senator Burrows concerning the proposed tax on distilled spirits: Hon. J.C. Burrows, United States Senate:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30. -- The Democratic State Convention here to-day was one of the most memorable in the history of Ohio. It was a convention of unanimity on principles and of differences on men, and especially on those who were candidates for places on the State ticket.

LONDON, June 30. -- The Pan-Anglican, or, as it is officially called, the Lambeth Conference, began to-day with a private devotional service in the chapel of Lambeth Palace, the official residence of the Archbishop of Canterbury.

PROVIDENCE, June 29. -- It was stated here to-night by a prominent Episcopal clergyman of this diocese that Rev. Dr. David H. Greer of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, who was last week elected Bishop Coadjutor, has some hesitancy about accepting.

HAVANA, via Key West, June 30. -- There are 1,500 sick soldiers in the hospitals at Manzanilio, and sickness prevails at a high ratio through the entire Province of Santiago de Cuba, where at least two-fifths of the troops are incapacitated by fever and other disorders. Beds and other nursing facilities are being forwarded from Havana.

BERLIN, June 30. -- The German Cabinet crisis has made further progress. Dr. Buchenberger, Minister of Finance in the Grand Duchy of Baden, has declined the Secretaryship of the Imperial Treasury, vacated by Count Posadowsky-Wehner, probably fearing the fate of Baron Marschall von Bieberstein.

ORANGE, N. J., June 30. -- E. P. Merwin was to-day declared winner of the June Handicap Cup tournament at the links of the Essex County Country Club. Mr. Merwin played with a handicap of 25, his net score being 76. T. H. Powers Farr, who played from scratch, made a score of 83 in the tournament, the lowest gross score played on the course this season.

The upward movement of stocks in the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, which comprises the Brooklyn Heights system, was accounted for yesterday, when it became known that D.O. Mills purchased last Monday $1,000,000 of the company's bonds.

In response to a call for a conference to urge the nomination of Seth Low for Mayor of the greater city many prominent business men of all shades of political belief met last night in the Criterion Theatre, on Fulton Street, near Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, and after considerable expression of views of a harmonious nature, the appended resolutions offered by James McKeen were unanimously adopted.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- The hearing in the Endicott divorce case was resumed before Vice Chancellor Stevens to-day. After some fencing by counsel Mrs. Endicott was permitted to give from memory the contents of a letter which she had previously sworn she intercepted, and which, she testified, was addressed to Dr. Endicott by Miss Louise M. Wells, a co-respondent in this case.

Dissatisfied at the distribution of patronage, or, rather, the lack of distribution, among their members, the Executive Committee of the Colored Republican County Organization held a meeting last night to protest against it, and to demand recognition for the services of their race in the last campaign.

The Norota ran into the twenty-footer Kenu during the regatta of the Corinthian fleet of New Rochelle yesterday and cut the boat so badly that she may not be able to race again. The accident happened at the West Buoy, off Execution Reef.

HAVANA, June 30. -- La Lucha publishes an interview which its correspondent at Santiago de Cuba has had with Captain General Weyler, regarding the latter's plans for the pacification of that province. The General is quoted as saying:

There was something more than ordinarily significant in the immense pride shown by the British in the display of their naval force at Spithead on Saturday. It was the pride of a people which realized that its greatness, reared by the old-time walls of oak, would be preserved by these new walls of steel.

AMHERST, Mass., June 30. -- The excitement at Amherst College over the resignation of Prof. Morse was to-day allayed by the announcement that the professor had withdrawn his resignation. During the commencement exercises in College Hall President Gates made the following statement:

LONDON, June 30. -- Joseph Chamberlain, Imperial Secretary of State for the Colonies, capped the climax of his social attentions to the Colonial Premiers by entertaining them this evening at dinner. As his town house is too small for such a reception as followed the banquet, both were given at the residence of the late Sir Julian Goldsmid, in Piccadilly.

In the meeting of Police Commissioners yesterday the crusade against women in the Tenderloin Precinct was brought up for consideration by a letter from Bolton Hall, a lawyer of 111 Broadway, charging that policemen have sworn to the commission of crimes they did not see, and that, in the case of Eva McMonagle, Magistrate Kudlich had said a policeman swore to an allegation which he had no reason to believe was true.

NEW HAVEN, June 30. -- Nearly 700 young men received diplomas from Yale this morning. The approximate numbers of the various departments follow: Academic, 290; scientific, 240; law, 80; divinity, 30; medical, 30. Besides these, there were many special degrees given for work in the music, art, graduate, and other departments.
President MCKINLEY'S course as to New York City politics is very bad.

The "ticker" service of the Western Union Telegraph Company will continue to-day on, practically, the contract which expired yesterday between the New York Stock Exchange and the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company and the lines indicated long ago in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 30. -- The race between Cornell, Columbia, and Pennsylvania freshmen crews in the intercollegiate boat races here to-day was won by Cornell, after a close and exciting struggle. The official time for the two miles was 9:21 1-5. Columbia was second, three-fourths of a length behind Cornell and one-third of a length ahead of Pennsylvania.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 30. -- There was no new feature in to-day's commencement exercises at Harvard. The weather was rainy and otherwise disagreeable. The graduating class was a large one. At 9:45 o'clock the seniors and other candidates for degrees assembled in front of Holworthy Hall.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Three persons were killed outright and about twenty or thirty persons injured in a rear end collision on the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad at 12:45 o'clock this morning at West Chicago, thirty miles out of Chicago on the Galena Division.

ALDERSHOT CAMP, England, July 1. -The great jubilee review of troops took place to-day. Queen's weather prevailed. The town of Aldershot was gaily decorated with flags and festoons of flowers. Crowds of people flocked toward the camp from very early morning.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- It is understood that the President has selected W.W. Rockhill, late Assistant Secretary of State, for the post of United States Minister to Greece, and that his nomination is likely to go to the Senate to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Spooner (Rep., Wis.,) gave notice of the following amendment to the Tariff bill.

Allow me to correct an erroneous impression that your renders might derive from the article in this day's TIMES, referring to our forthcoming City Directory. There has been no unusual elimination of names from the Directory this year, the necessary we ding out process having been conducted on the same lines as in former years.

The headquarters of the National Democratic Committee have been established at 62 and 64 William Street, this city. William D. Bynum, as Chairman of the committee, occupies Rooms 33 and 34 of the Germania Fire Insurance Company's Building, and from those quarters will direct the forces of the National Democracy in the State campaigns this Autumn.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Mr. Settle, (Dem., Ky.,) after the Journal had been read in the House to-day, raised a question as to the truth of the Journal of last Monday's proceedings by offering an amendment to correct the Journal so as to make it show that "the Speaker, in pursuance of the rule heretofore adopted, declared the House adjourned until Thursday."

There was rejoicing in the rooms of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, 111 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, over the success of the efforts to raise $236,000 by general contributions from Baptists. Much more than this sum had been pledged up to yesterday noon, thus complying with the condition upon which John D. Rockefeller agreed to give $250,000 toward paying the debts of the Baptist Home Mission Society and the American Baptist Missionary Society.

The new rules of the road at sea, which went into effect yesterday, contain some novelties worthy of special note. The first of these which will strike the maritime observer is the provision that a steam vessel "under way may carry an additional white light." This additional light must be abaft the steamer's headlight, and at least fifteen feet higher than it.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, Peekskill, July 1. -- The spectacle of soldiers at the point of the bayonet compelling an excursion barge Captain to give drinking water to hundreds of excursionists, was one of the episodes of the Company G excursion late last night. Further, a detail a fourteen men was put on board the boat, and rode to New York, to see that the passengers were not further abused.

NEWARK, July 1. -- Mrs. Carrie Wadsworth resumed the stand this morning when the suit of Mrs. G.W. Endicott for a divorce from her husband, Dr. E.W. Endicott of Plainfield, was resumed before Vice Chancellor Stevens. She was on the stand all day yesterday denying in detail the charges made against her by Mrs. Endicott.

By far the largest gathering the Normal College ever contained within its walls assembled there yesterday for the first morning session of the New York Teachers' Convention. The chapel where the main body met was filled to overflowing, the classrooms where the several sections and sub-sections discussed educational topics had every seat occupied, and in the aisles, containing the school exhibits, a constant stream of sweltering humanity pushed its way hither and thither.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1. -- Provisional Chairman S.H. Holding of Cleveland and Executive Chairman James Caren of Columbus have called a meeting of the State Central Committee of the Gold Democratic Party, to be held in this city July 8, at which the expediency of putting a separate State ticket in the field will be discussed.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 1. -- A majority of the cigarmakers of El Modelo Cigar Manufacturing Company of this city voted to-night to discontinue the practice of deducting 10 per cent. of the wages of the individuals of that factory for the purpose of prosecuting the Cuban war.

President Colvin of the New York State League of Republican Clubs has received the official call from President Woodmansee for the tenth annual convention of the National Republican League. It will meet at the Auditorium Building, Detroit, at 10 o'clock Tuesday morning, July 13.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 1. -- When the trial of Howard C. Benham, for the murder of his wife, was resumed to-day, Leo Wells of Akron testified that Benham went to his hotel last November with a young woman and engaged a room.

The death of Auguste Cherons of West Hoboken, who was drowned last Sunday while fishing on the Hackensack River, has developed the fact that for years he had been deceiving both his wife and his mother. Cherons had always told his wife that his mother was dead. He also kept secret from his mother the fact that he was married.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The near approach of the completion of the tariff bill was referred to in the opening prayer to the Senate to-day by the Rev. Hugh Johnson who said:

The Ohio Democratic Convention has proved over again that the party in that State is utterly worthless in opposition. It has proclaimed vociferously its undying attachment to the crazy doctrine of independent silver free coinage, and every speech in the convention has added emphasis to the proclamation.

The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court yesterday reversed a judgment recovered in a district court by John A. Stewart against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, for a penalty of $50, under the railroad law, for charging fares in excess of the legal rate.

PARIS, July 1. -- M. Leon Lecestre, Curator of the French Archives, will issue during the present week the first volume of 300 letters, which were suppressed by the editor's of Napoleon's correspondence, issued in 1869, as not calculated to increase the glory of the great French Emperor. The volume includes some heated family letters and some rigorously worded epistles to Fouche and Dubois, the Ministers of Police and War.

Fire started in the forward hold of the twin-screw steamboat Tourist, which plies between the foot of Whitehall Street and Bath Beach, when she was making her down trip last evening. It was the trip in which business men return from the city to their homes and women return from shopping.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- W.D. Ryan, Secretary of the United Mine Workers of Illinois, has written an open letter to United States Senator Mason, in which he says: "The stand taken by you in behalf of the patriots of Cuba deserves the commendation of all liberty-loving people, but let me call your attention to the condition of 40,000 of your constituents, the coal miners of Illinois.
In the telegraphic report of the tariff debate in the Senate, published in Wednesday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was the following paragraph:

PITTSBURG, July 1. -- As the result of the failure of the joint wage conference of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers and the manufacturers to agree upon the scale at the Youngstown conference yesterday, all the union mills are closed down to-day, and between 75,000 and 85,000 men are idle.

If the story told last night by Constantine Keehn, a barber working for Conrad Vogel, at 836 Sixth Avenue, is true and the mangled and mutilated body at the Morgue is that of William Guldensuppe, the mystery of the case is solved and there is nothing left for the police but to find and arrest Martin Thorn, known in the Guldensuppe-Nack household, at 439 Ninth Avenue, as "Fred."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 1. -- There was another large gathering of New York's society on the Polo Grounds of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club, near Hempstead, to-day to witness the sixth match of the series now being played for the Meadowbrook Cup.

The splendid and significant ceremonies of Queen Victoria's diamond jubilee have been pictured by pen and pencil, and are now passing into history, literature, and art, as forming one of the grandest pageants of the world. No description of these ceremonies, however, can do justice to the magnificent succession of scenes and tableaus that will be memorable as long as England shall endure.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The president to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Secretary Gage is said to have written a letter to Senator Pritchard, in which he recommends that all Deputy Collectors and cashiers in both the customs and revenue services shall no longer be amenable to civil service rules. The result will be that the civil service fence, which now surrounds about 2,000 offices, will be thrown down.

Capt. James Aikman of the British steamship Bretwalda, which arrived Wednesday night, yesterday wrote to the Metropolitan Museum of Art offering to give to the museum the mummified falcon and petrified loaf of bread presented to him at Alexandria by the American shipping man and antiquarian, S. Cummings.

County Clerk Jacob Worth, who is down from Saratoga for a day or two, gave his opinion yesterday in reference to Chairman Quigg's edict debarring members of the Citizens' Union from enrollment in the Republican Party. He said that he was amazed at the propositions laid down, both from the standpoint of justice and political expediency.
SAVANNAH, Ga., July 1. -- This has been the hottest July 1 ever known in Savannah. The maximum temperature at 2:45 o'clock this afternoon was 102. No prostrations.

If demonstrative, noisy, earnest "rooting" won ball games, the New Yorks would have won yesterday, instead of having been defeated by the narrowest kind of a margin. But Nichols's pitching proved more effective than the noisy encouragement of the grand stand and bleachers, and Boston won.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Republican Senators held what they decided should be their last caucus on the Tariff bill to-night. The meeting continued for more than three hours, and was productive of important results, which were not reached without the display of considerable feeling.

The Rev. Mr. JOHNSON'S prayer in the Senate Chamber yesterday was an extraordinary effort. "We recognize Thy hand in this work of commercial legislation," he exclaimed, and the pronoun signified no powerful manufacturing interest, but the Almighty. Without a suspicion of irony, he thanked GOD for "the disinterestedness and the generosity exhibited by the Senators and Representatives."

Yesterday's was the first really poor day's racing at the Coney Island Jockey Club track this year. There was no class among the horses, and save for the field in the handicap at a mile and an eighth, the whole batch was hardly worth the amount that was given away in the single stake and the six purses.

Among the big clubs which will spend the holidays out of town are the Harlem Wheelmen, who have arranged for three busy days. To-morrow they will start for Bridgeport, Conn., and on their arrival will be hospitably received by one of the leading wheeling clubs of the own.

There was a great time at Gifford's, S.I., yesterday, that having been selected as the scene of the third annual outing of the Joseph Schilling Association. The organization was named in honor of Alderman Joseph Schilling, and exists to do him credit. He was elected as an Alderman, but is now part of Tammany, and consequently his following includes representatives of several elements in politics, all practical.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The President to-day transmitted to Congress, with his indorsement, a letter from Secretary Gage, urging the immediate appropriation of $600,000 for rebuilding the immigrant station at Ellis Island. After reciting the destruction of the station by fire on June 15, the Secretary says:

CLEVELAND, July 1. -- Judge T.K. Dissette of the Common Pleas Court to-day decided the Smith lynch law invalid. The law, more properly speaking, is a riot law permitting persons injured in riots to recover from the county. It went before the courts in the form of a damage suit brought by J.W. Caldwell against the county, to recover damages for injury received at the Brown Hoisting and Conveying Machine Company's strike.

-- Even those who are most inclined to regard the solution of murder mysteries as an incidental, not the chief, aim of journalism, need not be utterly cast down by the adoption in certain quarters of views exactly contrary to theirs. It will at least give that hard-worked phrase "our esteemed contemporary" a chance to get a little rest, for now one can occasionally substitute "our esteemed detective agency."

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 1. -- To-day Capt. John Bartlett completed negotiations with her owner for the hire of the steamer Hope to convey Lieut. Peary on his Arctic expedition. She will go into dry dock immediately, will receive a thorough overhauling, and sail for Boston on Wednesday next.

HAVANA, July 1. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press has had an interview with Gen. Rius Rivera in the San Ambrosio Hospital, to which he was removed from Cabanas Fortress by the advice of the attending surgeons.

HAVANA, July 1. -- Felix Perez, a local insurgent leader, and twelve of his followers have surrendered to the Spanish authorities at Naranjo, Province of Pinar del Rio, delivering up their arms and ammunition and 232 pounds of dynamite.
ALBANY, July 1. -- Gov. Black informed the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES Monday that he had taken up the matter of the complaint against Police Commissioner Parker.

Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold for Henry E. Woodward, to James Livingston, the eight-story apartment house, Orienta, 153 and 155 East Seventy-second Street, 40 by 100. In part payment, Mr. Livingston gives the three three-story and basement dwellings, 520, 522, and 524 West One Hunderd and Fortith Street, each 20 by 100.11.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 1. -- Seventeen Curators of Kentucky University met here this morning to elect a successor to President Charles Louis Loos, who resigned. There were three prominent candidates, all ministers of the Christian denomination -- Elder James C. Keith of Irvington, Cal.; the Rev. Reuben Lindsay Cave of Nashville, Tenn., and Elder Mark Collis of this city.

Among the reports of early catches of big fish is that made by Timothy Flynn, proprietor of the billiard rooms at 117 Nassau Street. Mr. Flynn, who has a badly sunburned face to show for proof, says that he made a visit to Shippan Point, near Stamford, Conn., on Sunday last, and while there he tried his luck fishing.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Count Posadowsky-Wehner, the Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, has been gazetted as the successor of Dr. von Boetticher, the Vice President of the Council of Ministers and Imperial Secretary of State for the Interior, taking, however, only the portfolio of Minister of the Interior. Dr. Miquel, the Minister of Finance, is gazetted Vice President of the Council of Ministers, in succession to Dr. von Boetticher.

ALBANY, July 1. -- The rules to carry into effect the provisions of the new civil service law were adopted by the Civil Service Commission at its meeting to-day, after a consultation with the Governor, and the rules as revised by the commission in accordance with the ideas of the Governor were formally approved by him, and they take effect immediately.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 1. -- Senator Mark A. Hanna has lent his aid in securing a law favored by the miners of the bituminous region. Last week a bill was passed at Harrisburg which, if it becomes a law, will compel the mine operators to weigh the coal before screening it, and pay the miners full weight. At present the miner is only paid for the coal passing over an inch and a half screen.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- When the Tariff bill reaches the House after it has passed the Senate it is not probable that there will be any attempt to oppose the motion which will be made either directly by Chairman Dingley or by the operation of a special order to disagree to the Senate amendments and send the bill to conference.

Louis Lafair, ten years old, of 330 West Twenty-first Street, will probably lose his eyesight as the result of an explosion of some cheap fireworks in front of his home last night. A crowd of the little fellow's playmates were out in front of his home shooting firecrackers in great glee. Louis could not join in the fun, as he was one of the unfortunates that had neither money nor fireworks.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business on June 30 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $988,656,086, a decrease for the month of $10,027,966 which is accounted for by a corresponding increase in the amount of cash on hand. The debt, independent of the cash, was reduced $4,152.

" In every speech Mr. Laurier makes he seems to take pains to emphasize the individuality and independence of Canada." This is what THE NEW YORK TIMES says, and THE TIMES has caught the spirit of the jubilee speeches. In Mr. Laurier's first speech at Liverpool this characteristic was quite striking, and at Edinburgh and Manchester he seemed to even go out of his way to make it more apparent.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Senators are unusually reticent to-day about the proceedings of last night's caucus. But there is general surprise at the decision to put a stamp tax on all dealings in stocks and bonds.

Seventy-five girls from Grammar School 6S opened the exercises of the second morning session of the New York State Teachers' Convention at the Normal College yesterday, singing the chorus to Abt's "Ave Maria," Miss Belle Van Riper being the soloist. A chorus of fifty boys from Grammar Schools 20 and 79, led by Dr. Philip H. Grunenthal, followed with a rendition of Weber's "Prayer" and other songs.

That is an astonishing announcement which comes from Constantinople. Nothing in the negotiations which have preceded it could have prepared us for it. The concert of Europe has seemed for many days to be complete. Even the erratic and capricious discords interjected into it by the willfulness of the German Kaiser have ceased to be heard.

ALBANY, July 2. -- Many applications from heads of State departments are on file with the Civil Service Commission for the certification of candidates for appointment, and as soon as possible the commission will make arrangements to hold examinations for fitness, so that the appointments can be made in accordance with the new law.

CALCUTTA, July 2. -- In the fighting which took place yesterday in the suburb of Chitpore between the police and the rioters, during which the former were compelled to fire on the latter, many policemen were injured. A party of twenty-four members of the native police was surrounded by a mob and so roughly handled that all of them are expected to die of the injuries they received.

I The statue erected on Paddington Green, In London, to the memory, of Mrs. Siddons, the famous tragedienne, was unveiled by Sir Henry Irving a few weeks since. Tho statue is within a hundred yards of the grave of the actress, has been hewn out of a. solid block of marble, and stands upon a. pedestal of Portland stone.

The growth of public interest in golf and the increase in the number of golf clubs and golfers will make this year memorable in the history of the game in this country. Whether or not golf will ever become a fad here, and a veritable golfing fever will rage for a short time, it would be rash to conjecture.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 2. -- At 6:45 o'clock this afternoon the welcome five blasts from the referee's boat called the crews of Cornell, Columbia, and Pennsylvania to get into their shells. Cornell was first to obey, her launch going to the float quickly. The crew executed a fancy "get in," all dropping from the float simultaneously, which drew a general and hearty cheer from the observation train.

The book world, not only in this country, but throughout Europe, has recently been thrown into a keen state of interest over the record-breaking price of $20,000 paid last week in London for the famous Gutenberg Bible at the sale of Lord Ashburnham's library. The book was purchased by the former owner in 1873 at the Parkins sale in London for u3,400, about $17,000.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Senator Lodge to-day prepared a draft of an amendment to the Tariff bill providing for a stamp tax on stocks and bonds in accordance with the action of the Republican Senatorial caucus of last night, and submitted it to the Finance Committee.

Yesterday's stock market was not particularly active, but there was strength shown throughout it. Market values had to stand rather pronounced tests. In some stocks there was pressure of an extraordinary sort. Yet in no part of the market was there anything that looked like significant liquidation or any indication that sentiment was changing from its recent optimistic character.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Some interesting statements and words of warning to American farmers are given in a report on pure-seed investigations submitted to Secretary Wilson. It says thousands of pounds, probably tons, of grass and clover seed are shipped annually into the United States which contain all sorts of vile weed seeds.
The accident at the Brooklyn Navy yard to the boilers of the monitor Puritan, which were seriously damaged on Thursday, is not the first one that has happened in the fireroom of that vessel.

In The Century for July, conspicuous for a distinction of the highest order, are the two engravings after Hogarth. One is "The Marriage Contract," the other "The Portrait of Hogarth," by himself. So far we have only known one side of Mr. Cole's art, which was the wonderful copies made by him of the Italian, Spanish, and Flemish schools.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 2. -- The trial of Howard Curtiss Benham for the murder of his wife developed a new feature to-day. It is believed that an attempt has been made to poison Mrs. Mary Farrant, wife of Peter Farrant of Byron, and the sad-hearted mother of Florence Tout Benham, for whose murder her husband is on trial.
