The fourth volume of the revised edition of Dr. Chambers's large and exhaustive work on the Scotch singer contains an ambitious essay entitled "The Character and Genius of Burns." It is to this essay that especial attention is now invited. Judging by it, biography and character-study of great men have not yet acquired the dignity of art.
Mr. DAVID LUBIN of Sacramento, Cal., has started a movement among the ministers which the protectionist managers may well "view with alarm."

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Reciprocity and retaliation were the two phases of the Tariff bill to occupy the attention of the Senate to-day, to the exclusion of all other subjects. Both provisions were agreed to, although the debate on the reciprocity clause was protracted to 6 o'clock.

It is very interesting to observe the respective attitudes of our esteemed freak contemporaries over the "scoop" which one of them has obtained over the other. The Journal, as we believe it has itself mentioned, alone followed the clue which led from a square of oilcloth and some disjected fragments of a human body to a German midwife.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Senator Wellington (Rep., Md.,) rose to a question of personal privilege soon after the opening of the Senate to-day, and in vehement voice referred to a publication concerning a conflict said to have taken place yesterday before the Committee on Commerce in relation to the appointment of A.B.H. Warner, Jr., as Consul to Leipsic.

The "Rules for a Wife," which we extract below from the "Romance of Isabel Lady Burton," and which are the rules she literally made herself, wrote out, and laid down for her own guidance with her own somewhat erratic and wayward husband, will be read with interest by a good many people of both sexes.

DENVER, July 2. -- Ramsey C. Bogy, President of the Colorado Mining Stock Exchange, believes that the proposition of the Republican Senate caucus to tax the sale of stocks and bonds will never be enacted into a law. He said:

Mr.WORTH condemns Mr. QUIGG'S effort to keep his machine compact and manageable, on the grounds of both justice and expediency, and his condemnation is perfectly sound. Mr. QUIGG cannot promote good government in Greater New York by his course, and he cannot promote the permanent interests of the Republican Party.

LONDON, July 2. -- At the resumption to-day of the sittings of the Parliamentary committee appointed to inquire into the Transvaal raid, four telegrams exchanged between Miss Flora Shaw, the Colonial editor of The Times, and Mr. Cecil Rhodes, then Premier of Cape Colony, were produced.

On Sept. 22, 1896, at their rooms in Fifth Avenue, Bangs Co. opened the book auction season of 1896-7, and on June 25 they had their last sale of the year. Between the two dates three great collections and several of less importance were dispersed, and the season that begun inauspiciously was one of the most prominent and successful known to those who follow, the fortunes of the auction mart.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Senator Thurston to-day introduced as a bill the provision prepared as an amendment to the Tariff bill by the Judiciary Committee to prohibit trusts. The amendment was based upon a suggestion made by Senator Nelson, but was perfected by a sub-committee consisting of Senators Thurston, Davis, and Spooner.

BOSTON, Mass., July 2. -- Two weeks ago a dapper young man, giving the name of A.G. Blair, was arrested at the Union Station for the larceny of a dress suit case. Since his incarceration he has told a number of entertaining yarns about his crooked career in Boston and elsewhere, and to-day he made a clean breast of his case, saying, among other things:

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 2. -- There has never been a more decisive or a more honestly earned triumph than that with which the Cornell 'Varsity crew to-day completed its series of victories, while no men ever rowed a braver or more stubborn race than the Columbia men rowed, and no crew ever went to pieces more thoroughly or unanimously than did the Pennsylvania crew.

There was astonishment, consternation, and indignation among the working girls in Henry Wallner's hat factory yesterday when they learned that "Becky" Feingold, whom they had worked and joked with for seven years, was not a girl at all, but a "horrid" man.

Verdi, the musical grand old man of Italy, is evidently of opinion that a man in his eighties is in the golden prime of life. Two or three years ago he gave to the world his delightful opera of " Falstaff," just to show how copiously the fount of inspiration may flow in the soul of an octogenarian. At Genoa he rides the bicycle.

Aiany events of interest to pleasure seekers are announced for the holiday spell before and after the Fourth. Lovers of sport, music, and the camping ground will fred, in addition to specially organized excursions, a variety of opportunities to enjoy pleasant outings. The conjunction of the Saturday holiday or half-holiday, Sunday, and the _National holiday, makes a three-day period destined by a l?.rge portion of the community Go b devoted to recreation.
Mr. Felix Moscheles, the artist, author of that interesting volume, "In Bohemia with du Maurier," (Harper brothers.) has written for the June Cosmopolis his reminiscences of Giuseppe Mazzini.

In The Atlantic Monthly for July will be found an article by Edward Waldo Emerson, entitled " Correspondence Between John Sterling and Emerson." This correspondence is of exceeding interest, and can but increase our admiration for Sterling and Emerson.

English book collectors are very prone to pay good prices for supposed unique copies without making adequate investigations. A few years ago the British Museum desired very much to possess an original copy of "The Power of Sympathy," believed to be the first American novel, by Mrs. Perez Morton, published in Boston in 1787.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- At least seven of the Chicago banks passed their dividends Thursday. Some of the banking institutions whose Directors decided there should be no dividends for the last half year have been in the habit of paying 6 per cent, annually to the stockholders, and others from 4 to 8 per cent, annually.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2. -- An attempt was made early this morning to rob the safe in the Bedford Branch of the Produce Exchange Banking Company of Cleveland. The same methods were used by the gang as were employed a few nights ago to enter the safe of the bank at Chagrin Falls, when electricity was brought into play.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The question whether the President will send a special message to Congress recommending the creation of a currency commission will be definitely decided next week.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 2. -- Golf was never received in so enthusiastic a manner in Seabright as was the case to-day, and the pretty links of the Seabright Golf Club were fairly alive with the social and golfing element of the town. Many prominent golfers from other clubs came down to compete with the home talent in the opening rounds of the three-day tournament of the club.

PARIS, June 18. -- Francais, the landscape painter, who died recently, was a member of the Institute, and in artistic circles the question who shall be nominated as his successor is now being debated.

LONDON, July 2. -- The Duke of Connaught presided at a banquet given this evening by the Colonial Institute to the Colonial Premiers at the Hotel Cecil. Covers were laid for 600. Among those present were Lord Halsbury, the Lord Chancellor; the Earl of Selborne, the Earl of Jersey, Lord Loch, Mr. Goschen, the First Lord of the Admiralty; Sir George Faudel-Phillips, the Lord Mayor, and most of the Consular Agents General.

In the Contemporary there will be found under the signature of " Germanicus" a bitter attack on Wilhelm II. In the United States this phrase relating to the Kaiser is often heard: "God Knows everything, but the Emperor William knows everything better." This saying has been disseminated by the Germans in the United States:

A heavy thunderstorm passed over New York and vicinity yesterday in the mid-afternoon of what was not the hottest, but, on account of excessive humidity, the most unbearable day of the season. Lightning struck in several places, and in the upper part of the city and across the river in New Jersey hailstones of considerable size fell during the storm.

In none of the elaborate and interesting articles descriptive of the ceremonies attending the opening of the people's new "Pier Pavilion," located at the foot of East "Third Street, do I find any credit given to the originator of this splendid yet practical idea for public comfort and recreation, namely, ex- Assemblyman William H. Walker of the old Ninth District.

The Bookman's reports of the best-selling books for May give James Lane Allen's "Choir Invisible" the first place in the following cities: New York, (both up town and down town,) Baltimore, Boston, (one report out of two,) Chicago, (one report out of two, (Indianapolis, Louisville, Salt Lake City, and St. Paul.

Passengers who arrived last evening on the steamship Allianca, from Colon, told stories of the ravages of yellow fever on the Isthmus, and of the experiences of passengers on a recent trip of the Pacific Mail steamship City of Para, from Panama to San Francisco. They say that the report made at San Francisco by the officers of the steamship suppressed the facts, and that at least ten deaths occurred during the trip.

PATERSON, N. J., July 2. -- Constable Crowley is searching for Simon Gostvert and a young woman. They are charged with obtaining money under false pretenses. Samuel Goldstein, twenty-four years old, of 84 Prospect Street, makes the complaint.

ATLANTA, July 2. -- The contest between the city authorities and the Consolidated Street Railway Company, which has been in progress since the incoming of the present administration, took a sensational turn to-day when it was learned that Mayor Collier will take steps to declare the company's charter void and the corporation illegal.

The Associated Cycling Clubs of New York have decided to have the two century runs to Philadelphia and return which have been under consideration for some time. According to the expectations of the officers of the association, the return run will be the biggest event of the kind that ever finished in these parts, and perhaps the biggest ever held in this or any other country.

LONDON, July 2. -- The Associated Press is informed on reliable authority that Richard Croker assures his friends here that he has virtually made up his mind to return to New York in time to manage the Tammany campaign for next Autumn's election. He is in constant cable communication with the Tammany leaders, and taking an active part in arranging the preliminaries.

Under the auspices of the University of Pennsylvania an archaeological association was founded some years ago, and a group of public-spirited gentlemen in Philadelphia gave without stint time and money "for explorations in Babylonia, Egypt, Central America, Italy, and Greece." Among the first important work undertaken was the Babylonian expedition.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2. -- A general strike of members of the United Mine Workers of America has been ordered for July 4 by the National Executive Board, whose headquarters are in this city, and also by the District Presidents, as the result of the meeting held here June 24, 25, and 26.

Mr. McCarthy's conclusion of his extremely interesting "History of Our Times," made by the present volume, has almost the interest that one finds in reading a daily newspaper's story of events or incidents in or of which the reader has been a participant or spectator. One turns the leaves with continued curiosity, if not mild excitement, to note just how the author will treat events which are not yet sufficiently long past to be forgotten.

The Roy. Rev. Chamberlain has evidently found his task of setting down his opinions of Puritan life in conjunction with extracts from Judge Sewall's diary a pleasant one. He has apparently lingered long over it, for the style and the ideas expressed suggest the little boy's criticism upon a dwarf, that it has "grown old a-bornin'."

Three important new churches are now under construction or are about to be begun in Greater New York. Perhaps the most important of these is the Washington Heights Baptist Church, the Rev. B.B. Bosworth, pastor, until recently Known as the Twenty-third Street Baptist Church. This congregation long worshipped in Twenty-third Street, but most of its members moved up town.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTI0N, PEEKSKILL, July 2. -- With most uncomfortable inconsistency, the weather for the last day in camp for the Twelfth Regiment has veered from broiling heat to thunder-storms. But withal the soldiers say there is method in it, for not one drill or military ceremony to-day has been interrupted, while nearly all the recreation hours have been spent in tents.

In Harper's Magazine for July the opportunity is given to compare the work of Mr. W.T. Smedley and of Mr. Albert B. Sterner, the first Illustrating Mr. Fox's "The Kentuckians," the second Mr. Myers's short story, "A Portrait by Cahanel." Perhaps the distinguishing trait Mr. Smedley possesses is that in his portraiture he adheres more closely to the American type than does Mr. Sterner.

BRIG. GEN. GEORGE MILLER Sternberg, Surgeon General of the United States Army, who has just been elected to be President of the American Medical Association, at the semi-annual meeting in Philadelphia, stands not only at the head of the medical corps of the army, but is one of the foremost men in his profession in this country.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 3. -- Blossburg, a mining town twenty miles from Birmingham, is in a state of excitement to-night. The whites and blacks, of an evenly divided population, are heavily armed and stand in a threatening attitude despite the fact that Sheriff O'Brien and twenty men guard the place and have ordered all assemblages to disperse.

THE schooner yacht Sachem is this year the flagship of the Atlantic Yacht Club, her owner, Vice Commodore Frederick T. Adams, acting as Commodore in the absence of Commodore Gould, who is now in Europe. The Sachem is one of the handsomest schooners afloat, and is well known in every harbor where yachts frequent.

A STATESMAN is a politician who is dead," is an epigram so characteristic of Thomas Brackett Reed, the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Ffty-fifth Congress, that the sentiment is not likely to be attributed to any other living public man.

With exercises of a religious and patriotic character, the new armory of the Sixth New Jersey Regiment, in Camden, will be opened to-day. The Rev. J. Madison Hare of Burlington, Chaplain of the regiment, will have charge of the dedicatory programme. The pastors of all of the Camden churches are expected to be present, and a combination of church choirs, supplemented by a large chorus of school children, will render patriotic songs.

The growth of the German Navy since 1872 has been extraordinary. According to figures quoted in the Reichstag, the increase in naval expenditure since that date has been 527 per cent. The outlay of the North German Confederation in 1870 was only 1,201,000; in 1885 that of the German Empire stood at 2,119,000; while at the date of the Emperor William II's accession it was 2,700,000, which by last year had risen to 4,315,000.

SQUIRE BANCROFT BANCROFT, recently knighted by Queen Victoria, was a mere stripling when he was engaged as a member of H.J. Byron and Marie Wilton's company at the Prince of Wales's Theatre, London, in 1865. A little trivial comedy by Byron and a burlesque in which pretty Miss Wilton was "Principal Boy" formed the first bill.

Sixteen thoroughbred yearlings, the produce of James R. and Foxhall P. Keene's Castleton stud, were sold yesterday at the Easton Paddocks, near the Sheepshead Bay race track. The only Hindoo colt in the lot brought $2,500, the highest price of the sale, and went to P.J. Dwyer, the former owner of the great sire. The lot of sixteen brought an average of $594 per head.

One of the old, old stories is the tale that the frugal housewife tells about her troubles with help. "It is almost impossible to keep a girl," is the set phrase, and it is heard often repeated in the market place, and in the fashionable store; in the cable car, on the elevated road, and more frequently still in the intelligence office.

INCLUDED in the membership of the Brooklyn Club are the best representatives of social life in that city. It is also the senior club, having been incorporated April 24, 1865, by the following gentlemen, all of whom have closely been identified with all that is progressive in the City of Churches.
MONMOUTH BEACH, July 3. -- The clubhouse of the Country Club is open now, and is thronged all the time with members and their families.

The police have sent out a general alarm for the arrest of Martin Thorn, whom they accuse of the murder of William Guldensuppe. The District Attorney's office has communicated with the State Department at Washington, and the department has cabled the Consuls in Europe to see that all ships which left from Eastern American and Canadian ports since last Tuesday are searched for a man answering the description of Thorn.

We take particular pleasure in presenting to our readers, in to-day's Magazine Supplement, Speaker REED'S short Fourth of July address upon this topic. Like most of the Speaker's deliberate utterances, it both evinces and provokes reflection. Mr. REED is intellectually of a much "larger discourse" than most of his colleagues in Congress.

LONDON, July 3. -- The sensational stories circulated by a New York newspaper regarding Queen Victoria's alleged blindness and her alleged intention to abdicate in favor of the Prince of Wales after the jubilee festivities, which have just reached here by mail, are exciting great derision among the few newspapers which have deigned to notice the cruel and utterly unfounded reports.
BOSTON, July 3. -- The Globe to-morrow will say:

THE half dozen pages which begin the first volume of the Journal of the Continental Congress show beyond a peradventure that the colonists, assailed in their dearest rights and privileges, had no wish to separate themselves from the mother country.

The Tammany Society's celebration of the Fourth of July to-morrow is likely to produce a variety of Democratic opinion. As already told in THE NEW YORK TIMES, gold as well as silver Democrats have been invited, and there will be plenty of speakers on hand, with more or less divergent views.

Of society in 1840, let me speak only of the wealthier city class -- the people who lived in big houses in Bloomsbury or in the suburbs. They had "evening's" with a little music: they were very decorous; the young men stood round the wall or in the doorways; the little music included those songs of the affections already mentioned; there was a little refreshment handed about or set out in the dining room.

LONDON, June 26. -- There is no end to the noise a man can make in London streets, or a woman either, provided something is to be gained by the racket. It must be a commercial din, not a mere pastime. A gentleman and a magnum of champagne leaning collectively against a lamppost and singing in concert would soon attract the attention of a "bobby."

What is it that enables an operative today to produce so much more, in a less number of hours, than he could thirty or forty years ago? It is simply invention, as embodied in the improved machines, tools, processes, and appliances that American inventors are constantly furnishing to American manufacturers.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago the suggestion came from this side of the Atlantic, from the Provincial Synod of the Canadian Church, that all Bishops of the Anglican communion throughout the world meet in conference for consultation under the Presidency of the Bishop of their eldest See, the Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of All England and Metropolitan.

The temporary revival which has been evident during the month of June has come to an abrupt end during the past week, and even those brokers who are inclined to scout the "Summer dullness" theory and look for a big deal to turn up most any day seem ready to admit that they don't expect much for the next six or eight weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Secretary Long has received a note of thanks for his action in sending the Massachusetts to Newfoundland to be present during the jubilee celebration in St. John's. The note is from Her Majesty's Diamond Jubilee and Cabot Celebration Committee, and begins:

It is well known to-day that salicylic acid is a powerful antiseptic. As such it retards the action of organized ferments like the yeast plant and putrefactive bacteria. It hinders and prevents fermentation, the souring of milk and the putrefaction of milk. Its action upon unorganized ferments is even more powerful.

IT has been truthfully said that of all games, golf is the most beneficial and enjoyable for women. Tennis, while an exceptionally excellent sport, still numbers among its devotees only a limited number of the younger women, for it requires continued and violent exercise to play well, so that few women care to practice it to the extent of becoming first-class players.

LENOX, Mass., July 3. -- With fitting ceremonies the cornerstone of the beautiful memorial building which John E. Parsons of New York gives to Trinity Parish was laid this afternoon. The building is given to the parish by Mr. Parsons in memory of his wife, who spent many years of her life at Stoneover, the beautiful country place of the Parsons family here.

Reporting upon the Valley Stream tally-ho accident, by which five persons were killed and sixteen injured, on Memorial Day, the Grand Jury of Queens County yesterday brought in a presentment censuring the driver of the coach and calling on the authorities to require gates or flagmen to be stationed at all dangerous railway crossings.

The two hospitals in this city which make a specialty of treating cancer are very much interested in the efforts of Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop to establish another hospital at Corlears Park and Front Street. The Superintendents of both say that, while another hospital is not needed, a home for incurable cases, where patients could get an abundance of fresh air and have their cases treated daily, would be a great charity and great blessing.

If the Postal Congress adopted no important measures, it at least took no steps backward; and the postal experts inform us that good work in various practical directions was accomplished which will make for enhanced efficiency both in international postal service and also in the internal system of various countries.

The trolley roads are rapidly covering Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut with a network that is slowly and surely redistributing the population; it seems almost inevitable that a great part of the present rural area of these three States will ultimately be included in the suburbs of their numerous and widely scattered industrial centres and of their dozen or more larger cities.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 3. -- S.D. Bowers of the Otsego Golf Club, and one of the most promising younger members in the St. Andrew's Golf Club, furnished the surprises in the second day's contest of the Seabright Golf Club's open tournament to-day. In the morning he beat H.P. Toler, the Baltusrol champion, by two holes, after an unusually hot game, each taking the same number of strokes for the course.

CANTON, Ohio, July 3. -- President McKinley and party reached this city on the 10:30 train this morning and were met at the station by the people of the city en masse. A large proportion of the population marched in a parade to receive and escort the presidential party, bands, military companies, old soldier's, and the campaign organizations of last Fall being conspicuous in the line.

There was an interesting exhibition of guns, big and little and rapid-fire guns, mortars, and gun carriages, and gun firing at Sandy Hook yesterday, incident to the visit of inspection made by Secretary of War Alger.

LENOX, Mass., July 3. -- The season at Lenox is progressing merrily, and there are now many distinguished arrivals each day whose first care is to get into their golf clothes and proceed at once to the links of the Lenox Golf Club, where Caretaker Nichols has been breaking records during last week, getting the best score for the nine holes down to 33.

The late John M. Francis of Troy and former Postmaster General Thomas L. James were old-time friends, both being of Welsh descent. A few days ago Gen. James related the following incident of how John M. Francis's father called on George Washington, in quest of an appointment in the American Navy.

All medical men of large experience have frequently met with cases in which patients have placed a bottle of medicine to their lips and taken a draught of its contents in a dark room, under the impression that there was "only one bottle upon that shelf," when in reality some other member of the family had placed other bottles there.

The locomotive has been a faithful old friend. Locomotive Engineering goes so far as to say it "was always kept equal to any speed requirements put upon it," and that the only obstacles to fast trains a half century ago were the tracks and the lack of signals, and the absence of efficient means of stopping the trains.
ROME, July 3. -- The Messagero says that Menotti Garibaldi, son of the famous Italian patriot, has decided to go to America and take up farming.

As I am at present in an out-of-the-way part of the country it was only by accident I saw your editorial in your issue of the 23d of June, I must characterize it as inexcusably unjust and misleading. The writer evidently did not take the trouble to read the proposition made by Mr. DEBS to the workingmen, which proposition the letter of mine you quote referred to.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Significant action in the grave question of the ejectment of "intruders" from the lands of the Cherokee Indian Nation has been taken by the Secretary of the Interior, who has authorized the removal of twenty-eight heads of families who have received the amount of reimbursement awarded them by the Board of Appraisers of intruders' improvements, and who afterward refused to move.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3. -- The General Hocking Coal Company expected a rush of orders from the railroads as soon as the United Mine Workers' strike was ordered, or before, but it failed to develop, which would seem to indicate that a great deal of coal is in stock. There will be no trouble so far as the mines in this pool are concerned. Everything will be shut and a friendly feeling maintained.

The current number of the Annales de l'Institut Pasteur contains M. Pottevin's annual report for 1886 on the anti-rabic inoculations conducted during the past year at the Paris Pasteur Institute. The number of persons treated was 1,308, less than in any previous year since the institute was opened.

MONTREAL, July 3. -- The Allan Steamship Line people have announced that a man resembling Martin Thorn bought a ticket for a second-class passage on the steamer State of California, which left last night.

With favorable conditions of track and weather, an interesting card of amateur and professional races was run off yesterday afternoon in the first half of the two days' tournament of the Excelsior Boat Club of Paterson, at the Manhattan Beach track. In all, about 100 riders of the two classes were entered, and the races in the main were hotly contested.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 3. -- The two rolling mills here and at Gate City have closed down, pending the signing of the scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers. The miners are still at work, and the companies operating them have asked the men to accept a small reduction. Indications point to their acquiescing.
LONDON, July 3. -- The Prince of Wales to-day inspected the Colonial troops at Buckingham Palace and bestowed a medal commemorative of the jubilee upon each man present.

An average shade temperature of 85 during about ten months of the year in Bangkok is accompanied, for at least six or seven of these, by damp so depressing that for many hours of each day the grasshopper is a burden and sustained thought almost impossible. The Siamese recognize the drawbacks of their climate, and they seldom attempt to do anything through the hottest hours of the day.

LONDON, July 3. -- The opera season at Covent Garden has been extended to July 28. With the non-arrival of Mme. Calve, and the illness of M. Jean de Reszke and other of his artists, Mr. Maurice Grau has thus far not been overfortunate with his first London season as Managing Director. Last Tuesday "Der Evangelium" was produced for the first time in London, with Vandyck in the leading role.

The race between the 20-footers Alanka, Momo, and Shark was the feature of the regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday. It was the first meeting of these boats, and they made a very pretty race. The Momo won and the Shark was last. The wind at the start of the regatta was east. It shifted a little to the southward later on.

DULUTH, Minn., July 3. -- The worst rain, wind, and electrical storm in the history of Duluth raged here last night. It was a cloudburst, and the damage in Duluth and surrounding towns will be in the neighborhood of $500,000. In Duluth the damage to city property is extremely large.

With regard to tigers, the expectation of the animal's appearance, the waiting, and watching during the brief period of the beat, formed the most interesting and stirring part of the performance. The transverse rush of a tiger, scolding the elephants, and throwing the whole line into confusion, is one of the finest sights in India.

It was not until the Autumn of 1539 that the final steps were taken toward the destruction of Glastonbury. On Sept. 19 the Royal Commissioners arrived and commenced the work of search. Among the Abbot's papers were discovered a book of arguments against the King's divorce and a counterfeit life of Thomas a Becket.
LONDON, July 3. -- At the Hurst Park Summer meeting to-day the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's four-year-old bay colt Diakka won the Duchess of York Stakes.

The five open events at the annual athletic games of the Alfred Benjamin Co. Mutual Benefit Society held at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday afternoon attracted nearly all the crack athletes of the metropolitan district.

LONDON, July 3. -- An interesting account of a conversation between Emperor William and a French dragoon officer, M. de Noailles, nephew of the French Ambassador at Berlin, the Marquis de Noailles, is published in the Gaulois of Paris.

That Saturday is a half-holiday proved a godsend yesterday to tens of thousands of New Yorkers, and that to-day is one of rest and to-morrow a holiday will be esteemed equally a boon. With a trifle less humidity in the air than on Friday, the temperature remained at a high point, and New Yorkers suffered from the intolerable heat.

CAPE MAY, July 3. -- Life at this resort has assumed its usual activity. A number of musicales have been given, together with card parties, dances, and dinners. This week ended with three full-dress balls tonight at leading hostelries.

For some unknown reason the Fourth of July has come to be in the social world the dividing line between the early Summer, or suburban, and the Summer or watering place season, and in obedience to this unwritten law there has been all during the past week a movement from the suburbs to Newport, Narragansett, Southampton, Bar Harbor, Richfield, and even the less noted seaside and inland resorts.

Because he tried to stop a runaway team of horses that was madly tearing along First Avenue last night, H.J. Freyhalter, nineteen years old of 323 East Forty-fifth Street, a picture-frame maker, is now in the Presbyterian Hospital, with both legs broken. The driver of the team, which was attached to a heavy charcoal wagon, was George Frink of 401 East Fiftieth Street.

In journeying through this beautiful land it is impossible not to be struck with the absence of begging, and the general honesty of the people with whom one has to deal. Extortion, which has poisoned the pure air of many a mountain village in other countries, is here unknown. An urbanity, which reaches the elevation of kindness, characterizes the manners of the native to the stranger whom he welcomes to his cottage.

LONDON, July 3. -- Though the Home authorities and Indian Government are showing the greatest reticence and an outward confident calmness as regards the investigation of the murder of Lieut. Ayerst and the other outrages between Poonah and Bombay, it will be found that, as foreshadowed in my last week's dispatch, they are about to take strong and straight measures with the Bombay Presidency native press.

It is an error to suppose that the Tito Barnacle family is an exclusive product of monarchical institutions. The tribe flourishes under all forms of government just as parasites are found under all climes in the world of nature. We have several varieties domiciled among us, the common characteristic of all being their unalterable conviction that the Government, National, State, or municipal, owes them a living.

Now that the intercollegiate boat races at Poughkeepsie are over, it is time for the "experts" to sit down and figure out how much they do not know about rowing. An "expert," judging not by dictionary definitions but by common usage, is a young man who is hired by a newspaper to make prophecies which are never fulfilled and to express opinions which are ultimately proved to have been all wrong.

The Pilgrim Trust Company (Limited) was founded in London, England, July 4, 1618, with a capital of $500,000,000 in gold. One hundred million of this was in gold coin and bullion, and the balance in gold certificates and Treasury notes. This is the historical origin of the $100,000,000 gold reserve.

Justice Beekman, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, refused a preliminary injunction to the New York City and Westchester Railroad Company in its suit brought against the Port Chester Street Railway Company to restrain the defendant from encroaching upon certain righrs of way of which the plaintiff claimed to be owner.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 3. -- This being Fourth of July week, and with the hot weather that prevailed during the past few days, it has brought crowds of people to this watering place, the hotel proprietors have been busily engaged getting their guests placed in their rooms, and the cottagers have about all arrived that are expected for the season.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- When the Tariff bill was taken up this morning, Mr. Allison (Rep., Iowa,) presented several amendments, not for immediate action, he said, but in order that they might be printed speedily.

PITTSBURG, July 3. -- The largest convention of coal miners ever held in the Pittsburg district began here at 10 o'clock this morning to take action on the strike circular sent out by the general officers of the United Mine Workers a few days ago. A resolution ordering a strike in this district was unanimously adopted this afternoon, and a general suspension will be ordered at once.

The week on the Stock Exchange opened width a rush; it closes calmly enough. While activity slackened somewhat, there was not much diminution of strength. In many ways the market has stood rather unusual tests; while bulls may not have scored many visible gains, the bear contingent has met influences to discourage it.

H.J. Whigham of Chicago, the amateur golf champion of the United States, has written a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES endeavoring to explain some of the troublesome points in the new interpretation of golf rules recently adopted by the United States Golf Association. Some criticism has been made of that clause regarding the playing of a ball when it lies upon turf in a hazard.

It it were not for the fact that the horses racing in the East this year, two and three year olds, as well as those in the older division, are a notoriously poor lot, the June meeting, of the Coney Island Jockey Club which will end on Saturday, would go down in the annals of turf history as one of the best ever held in this country.

While patrolling his beat on King's Highway yesterday Mounted Policeman Daly was attracted by a woman's screams in the Van Sicklen station of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad. He found her standing on a box an the station, in one corner of which was a rattlesnake nearly 8 feet long, sounding its rattles.

NEWPORT, July 3. -- The yacht racing season of the thirty-footers in Narragansett Bay will begin next week. Last year the boats of Herman B. Duryea and Bayard Thayer of Boston were the largest winners. This season the interest will be centred in the Dorothy and the Veda, owned by Harry Payne Whitney and Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr.

Charming weather, a good card, and a half holiday combined to bring together a big crowd at the Sheepshead Bay races yesterday afternoon. There was only one thing that happened to mar the pleasure of the day, and that was the ignominious defeat of The Friar, who was the favorite for the Spindrift Stakes.

The yacht racing season is upon us, and lovers of the most picturesque and expensive of outdoor sports will find plenty to interest them in the racing of this season, although there are no famous new yachts afloat and some famous old ones are not to race. The season, however, will not be without one element of novelty.

The New York State Teachers' Convention was brought to a close yesterday morning, with a short session in the chapel of the Normal College. The attendance was rather small, as many of the visiting teachers were preparing to leave for home.

LONDON, June 23. -- The Queen came smiling out of Buckingham Palace yesterday morning, but before many minutes had passed her eyes were moist. She would have been more than Queen, more than woman, if she could have received such a tremendous ovation without emotion. She soon controlled herself, however, and rode calmly through the six miles of crowded streets, bowing on every hand with a "God bless you, my children" air.
PITTSBURG, July 3. -- Two deaths and a number of prostrations from heat were reported to-day. This was the hottest day of the year, the thermometer registering 91 3-10 at noon.

LONDON, July 3. -- A curious story is told in connection with the approaching visit of President Faure to Russia. It is, in substance, that Emperor William of Germany wished to meet the President at St. Petersburg, and wrote the Czar to that effect.

The Fugios were the earliest coins issued by authority of the United States, and the coin pictured in the accompanying illustrations was one of the common issues of the first American cent. This particular coin is now in the possession of Maurice Kaufmann, Superintendent of the Freund-schaft Verein of this city.

If Meekin had received support yesterday the Bostons would have been shut out. Four inexcusable errors lost the New Yorks the game. Meekin did not give a single base on balls. The three hits made by the visitors were widely scattered, and all of them counted for naught.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 3. -- Nearly fifty contestants played on the Morris County Golf Clug links to-day beneath the broiling sun in the first competition for the three handsome prizes offered by Mr. Robert F. Ballantine.

The condemnation by writers who earn their bread and butter by trying to please the multitude, which Prof. HARRY THURSTON PECK'S article on education in the July Cosmopolitan has received, is probably the best evidence that the article has made the "hit" editors of wide-awake monthlies expect everything they print to make.
ITHACA, July 3. -- All Ithaca turned out to welcome the Cornell crews home tonight. The victorious oarsmen arrived at Ithaca at 8:40 o'clock.

Yachtsmen will combine racing with cruising this week. There will be three days' racing on the Sound, and then the Atlantic Yacht Club will cruise to Shelter Island. The Atlantic fleet will rendezvous at Larchmont to-morrow morning, and after taking part in the big regatta of the Larchmont Club, the Captains will meet on board the flagship Sachem.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- There will be little except the unusual quiet of the Government offices and the temporary racket from pistols and firecrackers to note the coming of Independence Day in Washington. Instead of being celebrated with tumult and enthusiastic observance, it will be just a disorderly "day off," with some incidental noise that will be regarded as a nuisance.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- There is a remarkable traveling Japanese watch to be seen in Washington, the origin, cost, significance, and importance of which, as an illustration of the necessity of compelling the people of this country to pay more for watches than they would naturally be worth, are considerations that have had weight with the Ways and Means Committee and with the almost equally willing Finance Committee of the Senate.
When the President returns from Canton this week a decision will be reached as to sending a special message to Congress asking for a Currency Commission.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 4. -- Donald Fergueson, eighty years of age, was found dead in bed this morning. The gas was turned on and in one of his hands was a half-burned match that had scorched his fingers. It is supposed he was in the act of lighting the gas in the room when he either fainted or was stricken with apoplexy and fell back in the bed.
Ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois arrived last night at Manhattan Beach from Chicago, and was welcomed by James J. Martin, James O'Brien, and Police Commissioner Andrew D. Parker.

The exhibition of school work, which has been one of the main features of the New York State Teachers' Convention at the Normal College, will be thrown open tomorrow, and the public will have an opportunity of comparing the results obtained in the New York public schools with those elsewhere.

Senator Thomas C. Platt, Chairman Lemuel E. Quigg, of the Republican County Committee, and Frederick S. Gibbs held an extended conference yesterday at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach. Political affairs pertaining to the coming election this Fall were thoroughly gone over, but nothing definite could be learned as to the result of the conference.

The class of '72 at Dartmouth College, which has just had a reunion at Hanover in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of its graduation, inclines strongly to the opinion that this earth is a congenial and satisfactory abode. Out of sixty-nine members graduated twenty-five years ago only two have died. This remarkable record of vitality sets statistics at defiance and upsets the insurance tables.

Under the auspices of the Evangelical Alliance for the United States, a campaign in behalf of social reform has been begun in the mining communities and towns of Pennsylvania by the Rev. Dr. Josiah Strong. After working two months Dr. Strong is now on his way to San Francisco to present the scheme before the convention of Christian Endeavorers.

Henry Gerard, fifteen years old, of Patchogue, L.I., was sentenced to sixty days' imprisonment in the County Jail by Justice Conklin at Patchogue on Saturday. He was charged with stealing a bicycle belonging to Arthur Green.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 4. -- The coal miners' strike will be on to-morrow. The success of the struggle for higher wages in five States depends on the miners in the Pittsburg district. If they fail to refrain from working the movement will be a failure.

The Rev. John Balcom Shaw, D.D., pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, One Hundred and Fourth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, delivered two interesting sermons yesterday, his morning subject being "The United States and Great Britain; Their Rightful Relations."

One of the liveliest and most disastrous fires that the firemen of the north side have had to fight in many a day broke out at 11:40 o'clock yesterday morning in the two-story iron and brick building on the northwest corner of One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street and Third Avenue. Two of the largest dry goods and department stores in the vicinity went up in smoke, and the loss is fixed at about $100,000.

NEWPORT, July 4. -- The yachts arriving to-day were the following: Steamer Admiral, owned by Mr. Comstock; steamer Satanella, owned by W. Bliss; steamer Black Pearl, owned by B. Sheldon; steamer Stella, owned by J. Beckwith; steamer Eugenie, owned by J. Gardner Cassett; schooner Coronet, owned by W.B. James; yawl Montecito, owned by W.L. Tompkins; sloop Surf owned by W. Titcomb; sloop Minerva, owned by M. Fletcher.

The silver jubilee in honor of the Rev. Father Duffy, pastor of St. Agnes's Church, in Brooklyn, was, brought to a close yesterday in an elaborate ceremonial in the church. Cardinal Gibbons preached, and Bishop Charles E. McDonnell of the diocese of Long Island was present, and many dignitaries from this city and Long Island.

The new scheme for making up the deficit bound to come from the Tariff bill was formally introduced in the Senate on Saturday. It will probably be adopted to-day, though we doubt if it goes through the House.

The little boy who said he would be contented if he had "what he most couldn't get" was not a bad type of nations as well as men. In the United States we have been grumbling long because the Executive has no direct voice in Congress and because we cannot consult the people and put their judgment in operation until the end of a Congressional term.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 4. -- At a meeting to-day of the committee appointed at Memphis to call the conference of the People's Party, which begins here to-morrow, the following were present: W.S. Morgan, F.D.W. Mays, J.S. Coxey, Alexander Steinberger, J.H. Ferris, Milton Parks, and Joe A. Parker. Mr. Mays presided and Mr. Parker acted as Secretary.

Kate Freeman, an attractive-looking girl, eighteen years old, who was poorly, but neatly, dressed, walked into the Bedford Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning and asked for shelter and protection. She said she was homeless and without a cent, and had no friends.
Kindly decide a bet as to numerical strength of the respective standing armies of Germany and Russia by responding through your Sunday edition.

SANFORD, Florida, July 4. -- A funny story was related here yesterday by a party of fishermen from up the river, relating to the attack made upon a party of negro baptizers by an alligator while the minister was immersing his converts.

In view of the fact that yesterday was the "Glorious Fourth," the day was a remarkable quiet one. The sharp crackle of young patriots' torpedoes and firecrackers was to be heard occasionally, but it was not the continuous bombardment timid residents afflicted with nerves had apprehended. The small boy was reserving his powder and enthusiasm for the official celebration of independence to-day. Serious accidents reported were comparatively few.

With the exception of the announcement of the finding of a bundle of blood-stained clothes, that may or may not have anything To do with the case, floating in the East River near the Astoria Ferry, nothing startlingly new or important developed yesterday in the Guldensuppe murder mystery, as it has come to be called.

Mr. PLATT'S is most unwilling to farm out his large and somewhat hungry party for the election of a Mayor who would refuse to recognize the demands of the Republican appetite. He desires a distinctly partisan triumph, and the length and depth of the public trough. He has been sanguine that the conditions of last year would be repeated and the hope within him dies hard.

Rumors of a large shortage in a Wall Street banking house were afloat late Saturday afternoon, and when two detectives started for Boston late at night the rumors took on a more substantial character. It is now known that the Sheldon Detective Agency in West Forty-second Street was employed to start a detective in pursuit of two men who were either partners or employes of the firm, and whose accounts are said to be short.

COLUMBUS, July 4.--Telegrams received by President Ratchford of the United Mine Workers to-day indicate that the order for a general strike of the miners has been complied with generally throughout the mining districts of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, and Western Pennsylvania, and in sections of West Virginia and Kentucky.

PATERSON, N.J., July 4. -- The family of Dr. Wessler, consisting of himself, his wife, and three young children, of 53 Bridge Street, are suffering from arsenical poisoning. They were taken sick to-day after drinking milk which had been left on their back porch early this morning by their milkman. It is supposed that some enemy put arsenic in the milk before the family arose.

The Rev. A.C. Dixon, pastor of the Hanson Place Baptist Church, yesterday preached a sermon denouncing the moral shortcomings of Coney Island. He began by telling of a banquet at the island at which he said a Brooklyn city official had assured the dive keepers and toughs of that resort that the law would not be strictly enforced against them.

The Organization Committee of the Workmen's Political League of the County of New York has sent out a statement giving the reasons why it exists. It says that labor is steadily receiving less political and social consideration, and unless it is careful of its own interests it will be reduced to serfdom, with all its horrors.

Mr. DAVID LUBIN and his farmer and preacher friends will please take note of the little farce played in the Senate on Saturday over the so-called amendment providing for a bounty on beet sugar. They have warned the Republican Party that there must be substantial protection for the farmer or none for anybody.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 4. -- Policeman McIndoo is the bicycle policeman of the Fiftieth Street Station, and his mission in life is the pursuit and sometimes the capture of the elusive scorcher.

MONTREAL, July 4. -- The passengers aboard the steamer Vancouver, which arrived here to-day, celebrated Dominion Day on the high seas by firing cannon and holding a concert. Judge Kisbery of Dublin presided, and many Americans took part. Coming up the river to-day, the Canadians returned the compliment, and at 12 noon, Capt. Jones had "Old Glory" hoisted and a salute fired, the crowd cheering for Uncle Sam.
Unless the so-called anti-trust bill is put into the Tariff bill, it is not likely to pass.

The New Yorker is essentially a parasite who feasts and waxes fat off the rest of the country. He collects his tolls on everything that comes in from other countries and another toll on what goes out to foreign markets through that port. He imagines that the rest of the country is in perpetual vassalage to him and he only tolerates, for business purposes, the peons with which his fancy peoples the country.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 4. -- The Sunday services in Ocean Grove to-day opened with the usual young people's meeting in the Temple, led by Evangelist Yatman. The Auditorium service at 10:30 was attended by at least 5,000 persons. The usual half hour's song service was conducted by John R. Sweeny.

Harlem River oarsmen were not very active yesterday, as many rowing men were out of town and others were in Philadelphia to witness the races on the Schuylkill River, in which several Harlem crews are entered.

While delirious from the effects of the grip yesterday afternoon John Smith, a laborer, fifty years old, threw himself from the front window of his apartments on the third floor of 165 Stanhope Street, Brooklyn. He received severe injuries and was removed to St. Mary's Hospital, where he died shortly afterward.

WEIR CITY, Kan., July 4. -- No strike has been ordered among the miners of this district. Should the men be ordered out many would refuse to strike, it is said, although most of them are union men. They have no serious grievance except scarcity of work: In 1893 they were out on a long and disastrous strike, and since then they have remained at work regardless of Eastern disturbances.

" Capt." William C. Keeble of 196 Chrystie Street, an employe in a Fourteenth Street restaurant, but who claimed to be a professional bridge jumper, jumped from the central span of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday morning. He met the fate of some of those who have made that attempt. His body made two revolutions in the descent and struck the water, 135 feet below, on the side and back.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 4. -- President Knight of the United Mine Workers for Indiana, says he is convinced that practically all of the miners in the State will join in the strike. He thinks the block men will strike from the fact that those at the meeting yesterday were representative men from every part of the country.

The Rev. Dr. John Hall preached his farewell sermon for the season to the congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. The church will be closed for repairs and cleaning for the next two months.

CINCINNATI, July 4. -- About 10,000 people saw the Cincinnatis defeat the Baltimores in a slow and tiresome game. Both teams played a bad fielding game and were constantly kicking with Umpire Hurst. In the fifth inning Jennings singled and Kelley hit to Corcoran, Ritchey covered second, and Jennings was put out, but stopped Ritchey from making a double play by holding his arm. Umpire Hurst called Kelley out at first. The score:

To-day in Brooklyn will be celebrated by many athletic events, and the usual number of picnics and family gatherings. Some of the more important events are the Old Mill Yacht Club's annual regatta at Jamaica Bay; Bayswater Yacht Club, Far Rockaway; model yachting, and the South Brooklyn, American Model, and Wave Crest Yacht Clubs.

William Carney of Chicago met James Fitzgerald of Tralee, County Kerry, Ireland, at Phil Casey's handball court, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in the final half of the rubber of fifteen games, which decided the world's championship at handball. Carney won after an exciting contest.

PITTSBURG, July 4. -- An important opinion was handed down yesterday in the United States Circuit Court in an anti-discrimination case brought by independent oil refiners against the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad. The opinion is on a demurre filed by the defendant company against a petition of the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

The arrny corps carrying dispatches from Chicago to army headquarters, Washington on bicycles, to demonstrate the practicability of the rapid movement of troops over long distances on wheels, traited for their run on Postum Cereal in place of ordinary coffee and Postum was used on the entire trip.

PARIS, July 4. -- Twenty thousand spectators witnessed a splendid race between "Tom" Linton and J.W. Stocks, the bicyclists, at the Velodrome de la Sere today. The distance was fifty kilometres (about thirty-one miles.) Linton passed Stocks at the fifteenth kilometre, kept the lead, and won by a half lap in 1:01:24 3-5.

ST. PAUL, July 4. -- Cole Younger, who, with his brother "Jim," is serving a life sentence at Stillwater for the Northfield bank raid, and who, it is believed, will be pardoned this month, has made a statement giving a story of the crime, After describing the trip to Northfield, and the beginning of the raid, he says:

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson has received a report from a veteran horticulturist whom he sent recently to investigate the tea farming industry carried on at Summerville, S.C., with a view to ascertaining the prospects of profitable growth of the tea plant in this country, should it be decided to introduce it here as an industry.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 5. -- Henry B. Stone, ex-Vice President of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, and ex-President of the Chicago Telephone Company, was killed at Nonquitt this morning by an explosion.
Minister Hoshi then submitted Japan's formal protest, as follows:
There was good sport at the Independence Day meet of the Atalanta Wheelmen at the Waverly Park track yesterday.

The mates and the crew of the ill-fated American ship Belle of Bath, which was burned at sea, and who, as before reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES, reached Barbados in the ship's boats, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Sardinian Prince. There were fifteen seamen and Chief Officer T. Cox and Second Officer George Harris.
LONDON, July 5. -- ft. Higgins; the oarsman, is dead.

In the philosophic calm which it secures by isolating itself from the excitements incidental to getting the news, THE NEW YORK TIMES engages in an academic discussion of the ethics of journalism. It notes that while the police and other newspapers which do not think sleep and dignity synonymous were endeavoring to clear up a mystery that intensely interested the community, The Journal alone succeeded where the rest failed. The Journal.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- All conditions were favorable for the Fourth of July regatta which took place this afternoon on the Schuylkill River. There was scarcely a ripple on the surface of the water, and there was just enough breeze to temper the rays of the sun.
The annual races of the Hudson Boat Club were held yesterday afternoon off the clubhouse, at the foot of West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street. Wind and tide were favorable to the events.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 5. -- Championship honors for 1897 of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States in the all-round events were carried off this afternoon, at the New Jersey Athletic Club's grounds, by Ellery H. Clark, Boston Athletic Association. Clark scored a percentage of 6244 1/2. He was about 550 ahead of Cosgrave. L.P. Sheldon of Yale was the winner last year, with a percentage of 5380.

A good many confusing stories of the speed of steam vessels appear in the public prints from time to time. Some of the statements are correct and some are not, but it would puzzle a mathematician to get at the truth. The cause of confusion is the employment of two different kinds of miles in the records of speed.

There was abundant excitement for the 13,000 enthusiasts who attended the afternoon game between the New York and Brooklyn teams yesterday, and, while the New York element was disappointed by the result, it saw a slashing finish, full of hope and interest to the fall of the last man.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5. -- This city is a sea of color, the decorative ribbons of the Christian Endeavor Societies, the Stars and Stripes, and the bunting hung in honor of the National holiday floating in the breeze in mingling waves of blue and gold, purple and white, with the motto of the Young People's organization displayed on every hand.

ORANGE, July 5. -- The Middle States championship tennis tournament opened this afternoon on the grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Montrose, with a brilliant assemblage of fashionable people. There were thirty-six entries in the men's singles, the largest in the history of the club.

" There's quite a gang of blackmailers and horse poisoners about here," said Selig Lavinsky, a fruit dealer at 29 Ludlow Street, yesterday afternoon. He and his partner, Louis Singer, had their two horses poisoned some time on Sunday night, and the animals died yesterday morning.

LONDON, July 5. -- Three hundred citizens of the United States, residents of London and visitors, sat down to the annual dinner of the American Society in London this evening to celebrate Independence Day.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 5. -- The largest crowd that ever assembled at Charter Oak Park was present to-day at the reopening of this famous track, the attendance being estimated at from 25,000 to 30,000.

HAVANA, July 5. -- It is officially announced that Major Moscoso's column of Spanish troops has had a skirmish at Lamita with the insurgents commanded by Rego and Carrillo. The Government force is reported to have captured a quantity of arms and medicines.

William Bodey of 242 West Thirty-fifth Street, while riding a wheel, last evening, ran over and severely hurt Elmira Schore, seventy-six years old, of 221 West Twenty-first Street. Miss Annie May of 363 Ninth Avenue, who was with Bodey, gave $500 bail for him at the Twentieth Street Station, and said she would give $50,000 if necessary, as she is to be married to him next Sunday.
The Jersey City Athletic Association held its annual athletic games at Baldwin Park yesterday. Five handicap events were on the programme. Following is the summary:

Americans have a notion that the use of torture as a means of compelling confession is obsolete by several centuries, and has never been employed in the United States. Certainly it has never been legalized. There is nothing better settled in our jurisprudence than the principle that no accused person can be compelled to criminate himself.

The Central Wheelmen held their regular series of club races at Irvington yesterday morning. The track was in fine condition. Following is the summary: Quarter Mile. -- H.J. Bartholomew, first; second, J.W. Dickson, Jr.; third, M.J. Demarest. Time -- 0:55. Half Mile. -- Arthur Demarest, first; second, J.W. Dickson Jr.; third, E. McCann.

LINCOLN, N.J., July 5. -- This place was a town yesterday, is a city to-day, and expects to be a metropolis to-morrow. It is not as old a place as it might be, but it is not too young to know a thing or two. Last Spring, after a brief existence as a railway station and as a village, Lincoln blossomed into a town.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- As soon as the Journal was read and approved in the House to-day, Mr. Dingley, the floor leader of the majority, moved a recess until Wednesday noon.

HAVANA, July 5. -- The exclusion of American newspaper correspondents from the Fourth of July celebrations over which Consul General Lee presided at the United States Consulate, is commented upon in local Spanish circles.
OSWEGO, July 5. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill delivered an address at the Fourth of July celebration here to-day, in the course of which he said:
PARIS, July 5. -- The American Chamber of Commerce gave its third annual banquet at the Grand Hotel this evening. Covers were laid for 500, and the company included many ladies.

MAMMOTH HOT SPRINGS, Wyo., July 5. -- As the Summer advances, travel through the Yellowstone National Park increases, and things generally are assuming a very lively aspect. The weather is growing warm and pleasant, permitting outdoor sports, such as fishing, boat riding on the Yellowstone Lake, and mountain climbing.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The formal protest of Japan against the annexation of Hawaii to the United States became available to-day.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 5.--The second annual bicycle carnival of the Patchogue Wheelmen was held here to-day. Fully 10,000 cyclists were in town.

A remarkable story of the mental affliction of Theodore Krause, who tried to kill his wife with a razor, at 470 Union Street, Brooklyn, last Saturday night, and then cut his own throat, dying in a few minutes, is developed by the police.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 3. -- "This is the city of vitiated tastes."

CHICAGO, July 5. -- The New York Oriental Operatic Company of the Thalia Theatre, New York, began a three weeks' engagement at the Academy of Music Sunday night. The historical opera of "Bar Chochba," or "The Face of Jerusalem," was given.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A patriotic celebration was held to-day at the Grand Opera House under the joint auspices of the National Association of Democratic Clubs and the Democracy of the District of Columbia and contiguous sections. Addresses were delivered by Senator John W. Daniel of Virginia and Joseph C. Sibley of Pennsylvania.

-- England has reasons enough to regard with apprehension the possibility that the incidents of 1857 may be duplicated in India this year, but the very certainty that those incidents would be duplicated would seem to be a sufficient reason to prevent the natives from putting their threats in just this form.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A caucus of Republican Senators has been called for 10 o'clock to-morrow to consider the advisability of reintroducing the beet sugar bounty amendment.

Patriotism, so far as it could find vent in noise, was practically unrestrained in New York yesterday. Liberal tolerance of the small boy and his explosives almost bordered on free license. The rattle of firecrackers, the snap of the torpedo, and the bang of the pistol and the bomb constituted the music of the day, and there was scarcely a city block that did not join with more or less zest in Young America's serenade.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Senate continued work on the Tariff bill to-day, although the National holiday was generally observed in the executive and departmental branches of the Government. The usual gallery attendance was considerably augmented by the presence of many holiday visitors.

That British sailor who lately touched at Tacoma with an account of his adventures in the Caroline Islands seems to be of considerable promise as a composer of fiction, though distinctly an old-fashioned romancer rather than a modern realist. An inventor whose invention is worthy of transmission across the country by The Associated Press has acquired thereby a certain standing in his profession.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- The one hundred and twenty-first anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence was celebrated to-day in front of Independence Hall. The celebration was under the auspices of the Society of the War of 1812 of Pennsylvania.

The Philanthropist is a journal published by the American Purity Alliance for the purpose of furthering its aim to make mankind morally pure. Its latest number, for July, contains the full text of an address delivered at the National Purity Congress, in Baltimore, by the Rev. Dr. WILLIAM T. SABINE, on "SOCIAL Vice and National Decay."

The Tammany Society's celebration of the Fourth of July in the Wigwam yesterday was marked by an almost absolute absence of any free silver talk. The Chicago platform was not referred to, except in the letter sent by William J. Bryan.

The Larchmont yachtsmen had a glorious regatta yesterday. It was fully up to the standard of Larchmont yacht races, and in nearly every class there was a hot contest. It was the eighteenth regatta of the club, fifty-five yachts went to the line, and a fine fresh breeze from the southwest blew all day, all of which helped to make the regatta a success.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- The Bostons beat the Phillies out in the ninth inning this morning on hits by Duffy and Stahl, a double steal, and Lowe's single. The game was prettily played and interesting throughout. The pitching of both Lewis and Orth was of a high order. Attendance, 6,611. Score:

CHICAGO, July 5. -- The second annual road race of the South Side Cycling Clubs was run to-day over the Pullman course, the start being made at the corner of Michigan Avenue and Jackson Street, out through Washington Park, down the Midway Plaisance, and through Jackson Park, then south to the village of Pullman, a distance of about eighteen miles.

HEMPSTEAD, July 5. -- The Rockaway, Essex, and Staten Island huntng colonies were well represented in the large gathering of well-known society people who assembled on the picturesque polo field of the Rockaway Hunt Club to-day to witness the first of the polo tournaments that will be held at Cedarhurst during the next two weeks.

After the "long talks" had been disposed of, John B. McGoldrick read some of the most conspicuous letters received from prominent men. There was one letter that was not read yesterday, nor was it printed on the slips furnished to the press. It came from ex-Senator David B. Hill. Mr. McGoldrick gave it out to the reporters toward the end of the meeting.

The familiar doctrines of Democracy were set forth by the speakers at the Tammany celebration yesterday, but free silver coinage found no place in their discourse. In his colorless letter Mr. BRYAN mentioned, the Chicago platform. No other writer or speaker alluded to it. One speaker made a reference to "the money of the Constitution."

In the second half of the two days' tournament of the Excelsior Boat Club of Paterson yesterday afternoor on the Manhattan Beach track the racing was spirited, and interested 2,000 spectators. A card of four amateur and two professional events was offered. Weather conditions were favorable, and a brisk breeze that blew from the sea helped on the off side without materially hindering on the homestretch.
At the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday essentially a holiday crowd gathered, probably the largest seen on a track this season. Most of them backed Sloane's mounts and sorrowed toward evening.

Inquiries yesterday at the Oriental Hotel, Coney Island, for United States Senator Thomas C. Platt obtained the information that he had gone to New York on business and that he would not return to the hotel until to-day. This answer was reconciled with the absence from the east end of Coney Island of certain politicians who have Mr. Platt's ear. There are, however, some prominent in politics in one way or another at the hotel.

The second batch of yearlings from James R. and Foxhall P. Keene's Castleton Stud, at the Easton Paddocks, yesterday, was not productive of the fair prices of Saturday. The highest price of the sale was $900, which was paid by A. Taylor for a chestnut colt by Hyderabad-Ocean Queen.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 5. -- Wesley Robinson and John Dresher, two enthusiastic wheelmen from Orange, N.J., rolled into Atlanta Friday afternoon, being out on the road only ten days. They came by way of Philadelphia, Washington. Charlottesville, Va., and Greenville, S.C., and carried with them an entire traveling outfit, consisting of bicycle repair goods, tool bags, wearing apparel, tent, and a number of other articles incident to a bicycle outing.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- The question of holding a Pan-American Exposition was raised by a party of men during an entertainment given to the Pan-American delegation at the Union League Club to-night. During the discussion Col. Dickinson, ex-Secretary of the World's Fair, and President of the Coliseum Building, said:
TROY, July 6. -- James McCaugharn of Watervliet committed suicide by jumping into the canal at that place last night. It is though that the excessive heat unbalanced his mind.
" Honesty is the best policy," observed the reformed adventurer; "I know it, for I have tried them both."

LOUISVILLE, July 6. -- The Sinking Fund Commissioners this afternoon opened bids for the sale of $499,000 of 4 per cent. forty-year gold city bonds. There were many bidders. C.H. White Co. of New York bid $499,000 for $458,600 worth of bonds, which was the largest bid.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 6. -- All is now in readiness for the Christian Endeavor Convention. About 6,000 delegates arrived to-day, and as many more are expected to-morrow.

The new ordinances as drawn up by the New York Council of the League of American Wheelmen were again submitted to the Board of Aldermen at the meeting held yesterday. As was the case at a recent meeting, the matter was laid over until next week. At the last meeting no action was taken because several members of the board claimed that they had not yet read the new restrictions.

BALTIMORE, July 6. -- Friends of Miss Margaret Douglas Stewart of Easton, Md., and of H. Skipwith Gordon of this city were surprised to learn of the marriage of the couple this morning at the Cardinal's residence. The engagement between Miss Stewart and Mr. Gordon was an open secret, but the closest friends had no idea that the marriage would take place so soon.

The burden of Gov. ALTGELD'S Fourth of July speech in Brooklyn was that all the great movements of mankind had proceeded from the bottom to the top. The Christian religion -- not that ALTGELD attaches much importance to that -- the movement for American independence, the demand for free silver and free riot, all these things had proceeded upward from the poor and lowly.

KINGSTON, July 6. -- The huckleberry harvest promises this year to amount to many thousands of bushels from the bushes which cover the mountain tops of Ulster, Orange, Sullivan, and Greene Counties. The berries now coming to market sell at 15 cents a quart, but in a week or so the markets will be flooded with berries, and 6 cents a quart will be considered a good price.
Temperature, 88, the highest reached this year.

More than 1,000 letters have been received by the President and Secretary of the Merchants' Association of New York from out-of-town tradesmen approving the purposes of that organization and expressing a desire to become non-resident members. These letters comprise only the near-by replies to the many thousands of circulars recently sent out by President King and his assistants.
Americans would read the Japanese correspondence with greater pride if JOHN SHERMAN'S name were signed to TORU HOSHI'S notes and Minister HOSHI'S name to Secretary SHERMAN'S.

A Republican committee, appointed to confer with the National (sound-money) Democrats of Kentucky on the subject of fusion, is to meet representatives of the party this week in Louisville. The Courier-Journal says that the committee will get a hearing, but the fusion proposition will be declined.

The reappearance of two of the ninety-foot sloops at the Fourth of July regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was an interesting feature of the day's sport. The Vigilant and the Navahoe, which competed on Monday, are the only large sloops now in commission, and that meeting was their first.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 6. --Baron Ernest von Thielmann, the Imperial German Ambassador, who is stopping at his fine Summer home in Lenox, this afternoon confirmed the report that he has been recalled to Germany to become the Minister of the Treasury in the new Government now forming.

Exports of general merchandise from the Port of New York for the week were valued at 5,407,221, against $9,612,634 in the preceding week and $7,369,063 in the corresponding week of last year. Total exports since Jan. 1, $204,912,763, against $194,179,172 in the corresponding period one year ago.

There was nothing particularly exciting about the New York-Brooklyn game at Eastern Park yesterday until the ninth inning. The local team had played a listless, careless sort of game, as if they felt they had no chance, and had scored but once when the visitors were out in the ninth, with seven runs to their credit.

The excessive heat told on Wall Street's speculative spirit, and yesterday's transactions represented a considerable shrinkage compared with corresponding days in recent weeks. Very generally the market reacted somewhat, and the list of changes in a great majority of cases showed declines. Yet in only two or three cases were the losses as much as 1 per cent. Measured either by activity or fluctuations it was a small day.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 4. -- Atlantic City boasts 23,000 regular inhabitants and accommodations for 175,000. There were 170,000 of that number of people in bathing this morning, while the remaining 5,000 occupied chairs and pavilions and indulged in the unlimited opportunities offered for the study of humanity and anatomy.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 6. -- Four people were fatally injured and eighteen or twenty others were more or less hurt in a street car wreck to-night on the Forbes Street line of the Consolidated Traction Company. The names of those seriously injured are:

ORANGE, July 6. -- The second day's play in the Middle States Championship Tennis Tournament opened late on account of the excessive heat. In the men's singles the contest is likely to narrow down to W.A. Larned and Richard Stevens. The consolation singles were started to-day, as well as the handicap singles. The doubles will be opened to-morrow afternoon.

Capt. William Fowler died suddenly of apoplexy at 7 o'clock yesterday morning at his home in Claremont Avenue, between Bergen and Jackson Streets, Jersey City. He was apparently in splendid health when he retired Monday night at 9 o'clock, but when called yesterday morning he was unconscious, and died soon after.

The efforts of Daniel Hennessy, son of ex-Superintendent of the Poor Hennessy of Richmond County, and Miss Jennie Fenley of Tompkinsville, S.I., to be married have been prosecuted amid interesting and exciting circumstances.

An interesting golf team match will be played to-day on the links of the Morristown Field Club, New Jersey, between that club and St. Paul's School, New Hampshire. All the players will be of the younger element, and on this account the match is of particular interest, as it is the only one of the season, except the intercollegiate championships, in which all the contestants will practically be young fellows.
PARIS, July 6. -- Henri Meilhac, the noted dramatic author and member of the French Academy, is dead.

BATAVIA, N. Y., July 6. -- The third week of the Howard C. Benham trial for the murder of his wife opened this morning. The cross-examination of Dr. Showerman was resumed by Attorney Mackey. There are at least six physicians yet to be sworn by the people, aside from Chemist Vandenburg, and this testimony will be likely to take up the entire week.

MILWAUKEE, July 6. -- At the meeting of the National Educational Association of the United States in this city to-day the President of the association, Charles R. Skinner of New York, State Superintendent of Instruction, delivered the principal address. His subject was "The Best Education for the Masses." He spoke in part as follows:

ELIZABETH, July 6. -- Although the fact has only just become known outside of his immediate friends and relatives, "Jack" Bissell, the well-known broker connected with the New York Produce Exchange and the leader and instigator of all social doings in the best set here, has for some time been suffering from nervous trouble. He has been in the hands of friends for some time.

WASHINGTON, JULY 6. -- S.P. Williams, a young man whose home is in Bismarck, N.D., but who formerly held a clerkship in the Treasury Department in this city, was arrested to-day on a charge of forging the name of Senator William E. Mason of Illinois to an application to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for two round-trip passes from Washington to New York.

The Democratic Senators made a bad mistake in opposing Senator SPOONER'S amendment providing for a permanent commission of appraisers to study and report from time to time on the operation of the tariff. Doubtless Mr. SPOONER'S plan might be improved, but its general scope was sound, and nothing would tend more to sanity and decency in tariff legislation than such a commission.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 6. -- A quarter of a century ago no whale would have had the audacity to have shown his head within fifty miles of this port. Had one been foolhardy enough to thus appear his capture would surely and speedily have followed. Conditions have changed with the present generation of leviathans, for they are seen in schools of 50 to 200 now off Long Island.

DENVER, July 6. -- Private information received from New York says that the management of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad is now in New York negotiating with the Reorganization Committee of the Colorado Midland with the object of placing the Midland under the same management as the Denver and Rio Grande.
