" The President is in good health, but I don't see how he stands up against the raids of the candidates. If a few appointments are made a new lot of applicants will rush to Washington and pounce upon the President, demanding instant recognition. He patiently hears them all."

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Republican Senatorial caucus to-day decided to not again present a beet sugar bounty amendment to the Tariff bill, and Senator Allison was authorized to move to have the amendment offered by Senator Allen tabled. There was also a general agreement to take up the Thurston beet sugar bounty bill as an independent measure, the first thing after Congress meets next December.

Creditors of S. Goldstein Co., wholesale dealers in woolens at 246 Canal Street, whose store was closed by the Sheriff Saturday, were still actively at work yesterday trying to find their goods. It is estimated that the firm bought from $40,000 to $50,000 worth of goods since June 20, and now the stock in the store is believed to be worth only atbout $6,000.

H.H. Cammann Co. have sold for John E. Hubbard the block front on the east side of the Boulevard between Ninety-sixth and Ninety-seventh Streets, 201.10 by 112.8 by 203.6 by 86.8. The rest of the block, bounded on the east by Amsterdam Avenue, is owned by the Church of the Holy Name.

ALBANY, July 6. -- The fourth annual convention of the New York State Bankers' Association will be held in Saratoga Springs July 15 and 16 at the Grand Union Hotel. The opening session, at 11 o'clock, will be called to order by the President, Seymour Dexter. The forenoon session will consist of the reports of committees and officers and the annual message of the President.

CLEVEDON, Wis., July 6. -- If Eugene V. Debs should visit this town he could take a few notes which might serve him well in the promotion of his Social Democracy scheme, Mr. Debs probably expects that his associates will be compelled to perform a certain amount of manual labor in order to gain the object sought for.

Unusually large bookings for July on the transatlantic ferry are reported at all of the steamship offices. The St. Paul, Germanic, and Westernland, which sail to-day, will have their full capacity taxed. The Servia sailed yesterday as an extra boat on the Cunard Line service.

Gov. FLOWER argues in the July Forum that party government is best for great cities. "The untried, unknown candidates" of non-partisan movements and citizens' unions "sometimes exhibit excellent qualifications in office, but are more often administrative failures, if not actual disgraces." He continues:

The efforts of Mrs. Sarah Ann Angell, a resident of Michigan, to establish her claim as the widow of the late Jay Gould, in a suit against Edwin and Helen Gould, to recover her dower in the premises 1 East Forty-seventh Street and 579 Fifth Avenue, were recalled yesterday, when the deposition of Mrs. Susan J. Fillmore, a witness in behalf of the claimant, was filed in the Supreme Court.
The Senate caucus has decided not to put the sugar bounty into the Tariff bill.
A tedious, desperate fight for a man's life continued more than three hours in Henry Street yesterday, and during that time kept crowds of intensely excited people packed against the police lines.

Undoubtedly it is a great many years since the Turks have been so uplifted in spirit as they have shown themselves to be since their victories over the Greeks. Certainly not since the Crimean war, probably not since the battle of Navarino, has the Sultan ventured on so bold a tone to the powers as he is taking now.

The extreme heat was perhaps responsible for the smallness of the crowd that attended the sale of the Fairview yearlings at the American Horse Exchange last night. The yearlings were in excellent condition after their journey from Tennessee, and they were an excellent-looking lot of embryo racing material, but prices ruled low, with a few exceptions.

BRAINERD, Minn., July 6. -- A short time ago Alfred Maxwell was a penniless, seedy-looking tramp, without prospects, without a friend, and without a pillow to lay his head on. To-day he is a well-dressed, handsome man, with a good home, a prosperous business, and, best of all, a loving wife.

New York City's tax rate for this year will not be less than 2:05 cents on the dollar, and will not go more than one or two points higher. The tax rate fixed last year was 2.14, so there will be a considerable reduction in the number of points. The tax books were turned over to the Board of Aldermen yesterday and by them referred to the Financial Committee.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., July 6. -- One of the severest rainstorms in years swept through this section this afternoon. It was accompanied by hail, which did damage to tobacco, corn, and other crops. The houses of E.E. Stockwell and F.E. Young were struck by lightning, but only slightly damaged. Several horses owned by Mr. Stockwell were knocked down, and four men near his house were affected by the shock.

The members of the American Yacht Club entertained the Atlantic Club yachtsmen at their clubhouse at Milton Point last night. The Atlantic Club is on its annual cruise to the eastward, and accepted the invitation of the American club members to pay them a visit. Fortunately for the visitors, Commodore Charles A. Gould did not have anything to do with the reception or they would not have had the pleasant time they did.

ALBANY, July 6. -- State Commissioner of Excise Henry H. Lyman has appointed the first Board of Examiners to conduct "fitness" examinations, under the new civil service rules for the Excise Department.

TRENTON, N.J., July 6. -- The New Jersey Supreme Court has been invoked to decide as to which of two sets of Directors of the Suburban Construction Company of Chicago has been legally elected. The two sets are at present attempting to act, and as a result the concern is in the hands of a receiver.

Steps have been taken to relieve the citizens of Wakefield and William's Bridge, in the Annexed District, who have recently been practically without any water supply, and who had begun to regard their condition as desperate. Before annexation the people of the villages made contracts with the New York and Westchester Water Company to supply them with water.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The final vote on the Tariff bill will be taken in the Senate before adjournment to-morrow, a definite agreement to that effect, assented to by all parties, having been reached at the close of debate to-day. The announcement by the Vice President that the agreement was perfected led to a general exchange of congratulations among Senators.

PITTSBURG, July 6. -- The general strike order issued from the United Mine Workers' headquarters at Columbus has not been obeyed by all the miners of the Pittsburg district. From definite reports received it is known that fully 5,000 men went to work this morning, and it is believed many more will return to-morrow morning.

The New York Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen met at the Oriental Hotel last night and listened to several reports on the overcrowding of ferryboats. The matter was first called to the attention of the consulate through the news columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the members saw the importance of the matter and will take immediate steps to wipe out the evil.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The Court of Arbitration appointed in June or last year to settle the disputed Lippe succession has decided in favor of the claims of Prince Ernst Lippe-Biesterfeld. The court was composed of the King of Saxony, as President, and six Judges of the Imperial Court.

From The Jacksonville (Fla.) Times-Union. Every man in the United States is supposed to know what the "Governor of North Carolina said to the Governor of South Carolina," but perhaps some do not know when and under what circumstances the famous remark was made. Nearly a century ago a man prominent in political affairs in North Carolina moved across the border and settled in South Carolina.

To-day President McKINLEY will ask Congress before it adjourns to give him authority to appoint a commission to examine and report on the measures required to put the currency on a sound and stable basis.

There is no swallowing on the programme. It is not called for. The Citizens' Union, we suppose, will nominate Mr. Low for Mayor, because he is the best man they can find and they have asked him to run.

The activity of Russia in behalf of Greece has been rather noteworthy of late. It was manifested the other day in putting "pressure" publicly on the Porte. It was manifested again yesterday in a note to the powers urging what in undiplomatic language would be called the prodding of Turkey.

ORANGE, N.J., July 7. -- Good progress was made to-day in the tennis tournament at Montrose, the championship singles reaching the semi-final round. There was a surprise in the handicap singles when D.W. Davis beat Stephen C. Millett after a sharp struggle by the score of 6 -- 2, 10 -- 8.

Ex-Gov. James E. Campbell of Ohio arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. In an interview with a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES he predicted success for the Democratic ticket in Ohio this Fall.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 7. -- When court convened this morning for the trial of Howard C. Benham for the murder of his wife, Dr, Tozier resumed his testimony. On Jan. 24, he said, he again visited Benham in the jail.

Martin Thorn, who is suspected of being the accomplice of Mrs. Augusta Nack in the murder and dismemberment of William Guldensuppe, the ex-rubber in the Murray Hill Baths, and whose arrest was announced yesterday morning, is alleged to have made a confession to somebody whose identity the police are carefully concealing.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- It is understood that Secretary Gage has suggested that a provision like the following might properly be incorporated in the new Tariff bill:

PUTNAM, Conn., July 7. -- Word reached here to-day from Woodstock to the effect that the Rev. Dr. Stephen H. Camp, pastor of the Church of the Unity, Brooklyn, who is at his Summer residence, The Pines, in Woodstock, was stricken with paralysis Monday. The report adds that the lower part of the body is paralyzed, and the patient is said to be growing more feeble.

One man who is always well informed concerning business conditions in this country is ex-Governor Thomas M. Walled of Connecticut, Consul General at London during President Cleveland's first Administration. Ex-Gov. Waller is now practicing law in New York, and represents many important corporations. In talking with a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday concerning the outlook, ex-Gov. Waller had this to say:
LONDON, July 8 -- 1 A.M. -- Mme. Nordica's condition has grown rapidly worse during the night, and now occasions her friends the greatest anxiety. Her physicians are in constant attendance.
LONDON, July 7. -- Greco-Turkish affairs appear to be re-entering an interesting stage.

Pontifical high mass was celebrated yesterday morning at St. Paul's Church, Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue, over the body of the Very Rev. Dr. Augustine F. Hewit, and the dead Superior General of the Paulist Community was buried in the crypt by the side of Father Hecker, his colaborer in the founding of the order.

The British Socialist is of his own kind and has very small affinity with the Continental "Red," He takes his Socialism very much to heart, but it is not of the brand that can be exported. Mr. H.M. HYNDMAN among educated Englishmen is probably the leading Socialist, now that WILLIAM MORRIS is no more.

BAY CITY, Mich., July 7. -- An inter-urban electric car, bound for Saginaw from this city, crashed through the open draw of the high iron bridge two miles south of this city at 11 o'clock to-day, and the seven passengers were carried down into the river. Mrs. William McClelland and three children from this city were drowned.

A man rushed into Perry's drug store, on Park Row, about noon yesterday, and cried out that he was poisoned. Two clerks, who were making up prescriptions, ran to him, and, seeing that he was apparently in great agony, asked what was the matter.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 7. -- About 200 National Democrats met in State Convention to-day to nominate a State ticket. Judge Nathaniel French of Davenport was temporary Chairman. When in his address Grover Cleveland was referred to in connection with the Pullman strike there was the wildest enthusiasm.

The fourth day of the great heat wave passed yesterday, with little diminution of temperature and five deaths were reported from its effects. The night before was the hottest of the season. The minimum temperature, reached shortly after midnight, was 71 degrees, which is the highest recorded this season at night.

The will of Joseph F. Babcock, who died June 12 last at 326 West Thirty-second Street, was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Office. By its provisions, Mrs. Laura Babcock, wife of the deceased; his two daughters, Mrs. Lillian Stevenson and Mary E. Babcock, and two sisters, Mrs. Ida James and Mrs. Mary Dezendorf, are cut off with bequests of $1 each.
Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for Fay Stacom to John Kafka the five-story tenement, with stores, 112 Hester Street, 25 by 100.

It was a pretty commonplace sort of sport that was provided at the Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club yesterday. There were no stakes on the card, the races being for the commoners of the stables. Thorpe carried off the honors of the afternoon by winning three of the four races in which he had mounts, with Murillo, Lincoln II, and Flying Dutchman.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Senator Pettigrew to-day presented in the Senate a statement prepared by himself, giving Japan's reasons for adopting the gold standard, together with translations of the new currency law of that country, the speech of Minister of Finance Matsukata in presenting this measure, and the report of the Japanese Currency Commission.

The continued sale of the Fairview yearlings at the American Horse Exchange last night was not productive of the fair prices of Tuesday night. The lot of fourteen sold went for an average of $366 a head, and it was noticeable that almost all the fillies offered were passed out.

The Board of Education, at its meeting yesterday, received from the Corporation Counsel an opinion sustaining the legality of the appointments of John T. Buchanan, John G. Wright, and E.J. Goodwin as Principals of the high schools that are to be opened in September. Mr. Scott said the board's Finance Committee might properly audit and the Controller pay the salaries of these teachers.

CINCINNATI, July 7 -- Racing at Oakley to-day was confined to large fields of inferior quality. Three out of six favorites succeeded in getting first past the wire. Gov. Boies, the odds-on choice in the second race, was easily beaten by Asaph, who won all the way. Camperdown, very heavily backed, finished outside of the money in the third race, which was won by Ed Farrell, a good-looking son of imp. Order.
HAVANA, July 7. -- The reports that Gen. Maximo Gomez has made his appearance in the Province of Matanzas with 6,000 men are said in Spanish official circles to be absolutely untrue.

PITTSBURG, July 7. -- Conservative estimates place the number of miners now striking in this district from 16,000 to 18,000 men, an increase of about 5,000 over yesterday's record. This leaves but from 3,000 to 5,000 men still working.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The House met to-day at noon, after the recess taken on Monday in anticipation of the possibility that the Senate might have passed the Tariff bill to-day.

Credulous persons who were alarmed by Prof. HARRY THURSTON PECK'S recent statements of the dangerous increase of college education and polite learning in this country will take comfort in the "figures" quoted by CHARLES R. SKINNER, Superintendent of Instruction of this State, in his address at the meeting of the National Educational Association in Milwaukee.
ORANGE, July 7. -- The New York League baseball team had to play ten innings at the Orange Oval this afternoon to defeat the Orange Athletic Club in the most interesting game played here this season.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Tariff bill was passed by the Senate at 4:55 P.M. today by a vote of 38 to 28.

LONG BRANCH, July 7.--Five golfers from the Englewood Golf Club came down to the Norwood Field Club links to-day and played a team match with the home club. It was a hot game, but the Norwood golfers finally won by two holes, scoring 9 to Englewood's 7. John W. Albaugh, Jr., rolled up the largest number of holes of the players, scoring 6 against his Englewood opponent, A.T. Enos.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day, through Senator Lodge, reported a resolution authorizing the President to "take such measures as he may deem necessary to obtain indemnity from the Spanish Government for the wrongs and injuries suffered by August Bolten and Gustav Richelieu, two naturalized American citizens, by reason of their wrongful arrest by Spanish authorities at Santiago de Cuba in the year 1895."

CEDARHURST, N.Y., July 7.--Another large crowd of society people gathered to-day on the polo fields of the Rockaway Hunt Club at Cedarhurst to witness the third polo match for the Blizzard Cups. The contesting teams were the third team of the Rockaway Hunt Club and the crack team of the Essex County Country Club.

The tug Henry A. Crawford, owned by the Dailey Towing Company of One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Third Avenue, was burned to the water's edge early yesterday morning. The tug was towing a dirt scow through the Harlem Canal about 4 A.M., when the fire was discovered. So rapidly did the flames spread that the men on board had to spring into the canal and swim ashore.

BUFFALO, July 7. -- Buffalo has already received notice of the effect which the great miners' strike in the Pittsburg coal region will have upon this city. Among the first to be affected by the strike are the railroads, and the Lake Shore Railroad Company has notified the local gas companies and the shippers that it would confiscate all the coal coming over its line in case it becomes necessary.

A fast awakening interest in the efforts of the Merchants' Association to build up the trade of New York is shown in the daily reports received at the office of the association, at Broadway and Leonard Street. At a meeting of the Directors yesterday much enthusiasm was manifested. All the members of the board were present, including President William F. King, First Vice President John C. Juhring, and Second Vice President Meyer Jonasson

There was some great cricket at Staten Island yesterday, where the home club played the New York Nomads, and were defeated by 49 runs and 5 wickets. It was a great day for batting, and the record of New York centuries was broken by J.F. Curran scoring 103, which makes the fifth hundred of the year.
The Medical School Inspectors of the Health Department have made their report to Dr. Blauvelt, Chief of the division, for the quarter ended June 30.

The Department of Taxes and Assessments has just filed its annual demonstration of the injustice and stupidity of our system of taxation. The total assessed valuation of the city, real and personal, is $2,168,635,856. Of this total $1,787,186,791 is real estate, and only $381,449,065 is personal property.

LOUISVILLE, July 7. -- Dr. A.D. James, the new Republican United States Marshal, this afternoon appointed two colored Deputy United States Marshals for Kentucky. They are P.H. Kennedy of Henderson and Walker Blackburn of Louisville. This is the first time Kentucky ever had a colored Deputy Marshal.

It was reported in Jersey City yesterday that the Northern Railroad of New Jersey, which has heretofore been controlled by the Erie, had passed into the hands of a New York syndicate. John W. Heck, counsel for the company, said that a majority of the stock had been transferred to New York capitalists, He could give no particulars.

Everybody has been connecting ex-Senator Edmunds's name with a special mission to be performed at the request of President McKinley, whereby a treaty satisfactory to all the contending factions in this country, and one that might be admitted in the English Foreign Office, could be speedily prepared in time for presentation before the present session of Congress ends.

Mr. FOSTER'S report that the arrangement he had arrived at with Russia is satisfactory was to be expected. Russia has, in fact, the same interest that we ourselves have touching the protection of the seals, and so has Japan. So, for that matter, has England, seeing that London is the great fur market of the world, and that the considerable industry of preparing the skins for sale is English.

NEWARK, N.J., July 7. -- The Endicott divorce case was resumed before Vice Chancellor Stevens to-day. R.H. McCarter, counsel for Mrs. Endicott, at once moved for a further assignment of counsel fees. Counsel for Dr. Endicott presented affidavits in objection, but none of the papers were read.

The next ship in interest is also a cruiser, but represents the United States. The Brooklyn is about the same size as the Blake, but she is a much more modern and powerful ship. She has a very curious appearance, since her masts are lower than usual, while her funnels are of unprecedented height, rising 100 feet from the furnace floors below.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President McKinley called a special meeting of the Cabinet to-day. The regular meeting would not have occurred until Friday, but there were some matters it was desired to give early consideration.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 7. -- A string of flags fluttered from the flagstaff of the Riverside Yacht Club all day to-day. They were signal code flags, and interpreted meant "You are very welcome." This signal fluttered for the Atlantic Yachtsmen, who sailed up in a squadron from Milton Point early in the morning.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 8. -- A most remarkable golf tournament was played at the Essex County Club's links this afternoon, in the mixed foursomes handicap competition. There were four ties for first place, something heretofore unheard of, and it is pronounced by R.C. Hooper, Chairman of the Golf Committee, as the most wonderful game on record.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 8. -There was a reception of the Epworth League at the Jrard House, P.oint o' Woods. last night_ _a_bout 500 members of the league from the Brooklyn South District attended. The Rev. Dr. Inglehart of Brooklyn delivered an address.

M.L. C. Ernst have sold to William S. Rosenfeld 101 East One Hundred and Third Street, northeast corner of Park Avenue, and 112, 116, 118, and 120 East One Hundred and Third Street, each 16 by 100. There are five of thirty-five three-story dwellings built on either side of this block by Frederick Gebhardt and sold to the Ernsts and others in 1896. The average price in the last transaction is $8,250.

LONDON, July 8 -- This evening at the Hotel Cecil, the Cordwainers' Company gave a banquet to the colonial Premiers and their wives. Sir Wilfrid Laurier and Lady Laurier sat on the right and left, respectively, of the master of the company, and covers were laid for 300 guests.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The first meeting of the conferrees of the Senate and House on the Tariff bill began at 2:40 P.M. to-day in the room of the Senate Committee on Finance. The meeting was attended by both the Republicans and the Democrats constituting the committee from each of the houses.

ORANGE, N.J., July 8. -- In the Middle States Tennis Tournament at Montrose today Richard Stevens found no difficulty in defeating J.P. Paret in the semi-final round. Clifford A. Gould, Secretary of the club, received a letter from Clarence Hobart, holder of the Challenge Cup, to-day, in which he formally defaulted.
NEWARK, July 8. -- At the Endicott divorce hearing to-day Dr. Endicott, the defendant, took the witness chair.

We assumed yesterday that the President was his own master. We were bound in decency to assume that. Respect for his office forced us to believe when he had written a message, with the approval of his advisers, and announced that he should send it to Congress, that he would do so.

The Grand Jury yesterday found a indictment against Martin Thorn and Augusta. Nack for the murder of William Guldensuppe. The principal witness against them was John Gotha, the barber, of 2,335 Eighth Argue, to whom, it is alleged, Thorn told the Story of the killing at the Woodside house and the explained how the murder was done, and the actions of Mrs. Nack that made it possible.

The women had entire charge at Prohibition Park, Port Richmond, S.I., yesterday, the day being devoted to meetings held under the auspices of the Women's Christian Temperance Unions of Richmond Kings, and New York Counties. The meetings were held in the big tabernacle, and were attended by from 500 to 800 women, the number varying during the day, and half a dozen lonesome-appearing men.

A practical business pamphlet, which is in course of preparation for distribution by the Merchants' Association, will set forth some significant facts in a graphic manner. There will be a pictorial illustration of New York's bigness as compared with other American cities. The annual business of New York is twice as big as the combined annual business of the forty-three next largest cities in the United States.

An agent of the Bergh society took an overworked horse from the shafts of a wagon yesterday and left the wagon backed against the curb of Twenty-second Street, near Second Avenue. The shafts were tied up with rope. Half a dozen small boys took possession of the wagon as a playground. Johnnie Donahue, ten years old of 225 East Twenty-second Street, climbed the shafts, and was swinging on the rope when it broke.

What is the matter with the Sultan of Morocco? Does he think that he is a Turk? Or does he imagine that the United States is a concert of powers which can be put out of tune by a brown-skinned barbarian who lives on the shore of "a tideless, dolorous, midland sea"? The poor fellow never went to a public school, to be sure, and hence has never studied the history of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- With the Tariff bill through, the Senate work in that body resumed normal conditions to-day. During the routine business Mr. Berry (Dem., Ark.,) offered the following resolution, which was referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations:

Several days ago the members of the Executive Committee of the State League of Republican Clubs went on an excursion to Long Branch as the guests of ex-Treasurer Jewell of the league. They had a pleasant outing, and in the course of the day they decided that a State Convention of the league should be held in this city late in August.

Everybody knows what it is that makes the average kitchen in Summer a place of torment comparable to the stokehole in an ocean steamer. It is that ugly structure of iron known as the coal range. In the light of modern ideas and practice, it is little better than a barbarous instrument of torture.

The stock market continues narrow. Quotations do not have any pronounced tendency up or down. The talk of reaction goes on as aggressively as hitherto, and bull confidence does not abate. With the hot weather, however, there has come so much restriction in the volume of transactions that the irregular market has become rather uninteresting.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A good deal is heard here of the chances of agreement between the conferrees between the Senate and the House on the Tariff bill, and for a moment the impression seems to have been entertained that the Tariff bill to come out of the conference may be what the more conservative men of the two committees may insist upon making it.

BLACK ROCK, Conn., July 8. -- The Atlantic Club yachtsmen left Riverside this morning with regret. The entertainment provided by the Riverside Club had been a thoroughly enjoyable one, and all had had a good time.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 8. -- The thermometer to-day registered 102 in the shade, beating the record for many years.

In the interests of "unity and harmony" our Republican contemporary The Sun has issued an irade against "rebellion, revolt, personal spites and enmities, and petty private ambitions." Whoso disobeys shall politically die. He will not "be tolerated by the people."

Deputy Sheriff Walgering arrested Eugene Van Nest yesterday on an order issued by Justice Aims of the Supreme Court of Broome County, in a suit brought against him by Christopher H. Yelvington and Alfred P. Yelvington of Binghamton, N.Y., to recover $2,185.
LONDON, July 8. -- Eastern affairs shown but little change during the last twenty-four hours.

It is a notable fact that at the present time the majority of Wall Street's more prominent financiers, men who are in positions to speak understandingly, are inclined to talk rather conservatively. With hardly an exception such men are hopeful and confident that the country is on the road to better times. But the greater number of them are by no means believers in any immediate business boom.

A decision having an important bearing upon a business firm's exclusive right to the use of its own trademark was handed down by Justice Beckman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. An action had been bought by Brill Brothers, the men's outfitters, to restrain the use of their name by a competing firm, and, through their counsel, Blumenstiel Hirsch, they succeeded in obtaining an injunction.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The House today sent the Tariff bill to conference Chairman Dingley, Messrs. Payne (N.Y.,) Dalzell (Penn.,) Hopkins (Ill.,) and Grosvenor (Ohio,) Republicans, and Bailey (Texas,) McMillin (Tenn.,) and Wheeler (Ala.,) Democrats, were appointed conferrees. This action was taken under a special order brought in by the Committee on Rules. The order was presented by Mr. Dalzell (Rep., Penn.)

The decision of Justice CULLEN of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn declaring the franchise of the Brooklyn Trolley Company a non-taxable asset is not only important, but is rendered with a clearness and positiveness that will probably give it a controlling influence over the action of the Boards of Assessment who have been accustomed to proceed on the opposite principle.

There is something pathetic as well as comic in the latest performance of the Populists. Indeed, that may be said of all their performances. The pathos arises from the fact that they have real grievances, although the real grievances are not the grievances which they formulate. The comedy is in the grotesque and hopeless inadequacy of the means they propose to the end they desire.

Even though four of the six favorites were beaten at the Sheepshead Bay races yesterday, the sport was so good, the weather so charming, and the music so exhilarating that all of the big crowd there had a pleasant day of it, with the possible exception of Riley Grannan and some of the other plungers, who play Sloane every time he rides, no matter What the animal.

Funeral services were held at Scottish Rite Hall, on Madison Avenue, last evening for Capt. William Fowler, founder and custodian of the Thirteen Club, who died suddenly at his residence in Jersey City Tuesday.

The Great Assassin is undoubtedly a shrewd politician. He has to be. It is the condition of his existence as a Caliph that he shall manage the Christian powers which, if they were united, could and would drive him out of Europe, and prevent their union for that purpose. He must play off the interest of one against that of another and keep their mutual jealousies in active operation.

-- In the newspaper that is especially desirous of discrediting the current explanation of New York's latest murder mystery, attention is called to the utter improbability that any criminal not an utter imbecile would divulge his guilty secret to a man who is not only a barber, and therefore garrulous by profession, but who is married, and therefore under the most sacred of obligations to keep nothing either interesting or important entirely to himself.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 8. -- Baron Thielmann, the German Ambassador, recently appointed Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, will leave Lenox on Saturday for Washington, where he will present his letter of recall to the President early next week. He has secured passage on the Hamburg steamer Fuerst Bismarck, which sails on July 22.

Three amateur and two professional events will be decided at the race meet to be held to-morrow afternoon under the auspices of the Union County Bicycle and Athletic Club at Linden track, near Elizabeth, N.J. Bert Ripley, Varley, and a number of other Jersey cracks will start in the amateur races. Frank and Nat Butler will make their initial appearance in the East in the professional events.

After more than seven years of continued litigation, the contest over the will of the late Andrew J. Davis has finally been settled. The estate was originally worth about $14,000,000, but it has dwindled to such an extent that a conservative estimate of its present value would be about $3,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, in an opinion by Commissioner Prouty, announced its decision in the case of Brewer and Hanleiter against the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company. Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway Company, Western and Atlantic Railroad Company, and Central of Georgia Railway Company.

A report for 1896, signed by Mr. Walter J. Howell of the Board of Trade on the sight tests used in the Mercantile Marine has just been issued as a Parliamentary paper. Since Aug. 31, 1894, Holmgren's wool test has been used, supplemented by tests for form vision and for color ignorance. In 1896, 5,051 were examined in form vision, and 34 failed; 5,017 were examined in color vision, and 51 failed.
An explosion, which could be heard a mile off, occurred last night on the naphtha launch Rambler, lying in Gravesend Bay, near Bath Beach.

A Bishop must have learning, and generally has the deportment without which even erudition lacks dignity, and yet he may have a sense of humor, and the will as well as the skill to apply it when occasion offers. But, even then, because he is a Bishop, he is apt to be taken too seriously.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8. -- There was enough hitting to make the game interesting to-day, and the errors on both sides were costly enough to make it uncertain. The winning run was made on Ely's wild throw to the plate. Warner was put out of the game for abusive talk to the umpire.

CLEVELAND, July 9. -- A successful shell game of a new brand was worked on Cleveland egg consumers here to-day by an honest Ohio farmer, who lives down on the Cleveland, Akron and Columbus road, seventy-five miles southeast of this city. This time the farmer came near victimizing his city cousin, and all but succeeded.

Frank E. Bliss. President of the American Publishing C0mpany of Hartford, returned to Hartford a week ago bridging with him from London the manuscript of two-thirds of Mark Twain's new book, Mr. Clemens is at comfortable quarters in Chelsea, a suburb of London. On his arrival there Mr. Bliss wrote home to his. brother:

As part of the ceremony at Bristol, England, in celebration of the Cabot fourth centenary, Lord Dufferin on June 24 officially laid the foundation of a memorial tower on Brandon Hill, a high point in the centre of the city. The tower when completed will be 100 feet high, squarely built, and divided into two stages, each relieved by an ornamental balcony.

Leo Wachter, bartender for Joseph Gluckman at 1,828 Second Avenue, went to the cellar yesterday to help a truckman store a barrel of ale. He heard a peculiar noise and lighted the gas to investigate. The noise was a snore. It came from a tramp lying asleep on a hogshead and surrounded by empty bottles and broken delicatessen cases.

QUEENSTOWN, July 9. -- The North, German Lloyd steamship Spree, Capt. Meier, which sailed from New York on June 26 for Bremen via Cherbourg, and which should have arrived there on July 4, reached here to-day in tow of the British steamer Maine, Capt. Tubb, from Philadelphia on June 25 for London.

CLEVELAND, July 9. -- The situation in this city over the coal strike is becoming desperate. The Cleveland railroads are growing bolder in confiscating coal, and those who depend upon a regular supply are becoming anxious. The schooner B.W. Parker of Detroit has been delayed in Cleveland since Sunday owing to the action of the Erie Railway.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 9. -- The lines are tightening in all sections of the Pittsburg mining district, with the exception of a few localities. The diggers of the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal Company are still working, but President Dolan and Secretary Warner are preparing for a move at that point. It was looked for to-day, but will be made some time to-morrow or Sunday.

One life -- that of a parrot -- was lost in a fire which broke out early yesterday morning in the Saratoga tenement house, at 213 West Sixtieth Street. This is one of a row on the north side of the street, between Amsterdam and West End Avenues, occupied entirely by colored people. Two persons who were asleep in their rooms were almost suffocated before their neighbors aroused them.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9. -- Glorious weather prevailed again to-day, and the Christian Endeavorers crowded the various churches where meetings were held. The topic was "The Christian Endeavor Pledge," and the leaders were the Rev. C.H. Phillips, Jamestown, N.Y.; the Rev. C.W. Finch, Cookshire, Quebec; the Rev. J.H. Barton, Caldwell, Idaho; Miss Tyler Wilkinson, Temple.

Some one has called Miss Guiney (who, it may be said here, recently resigned as Postmistress at Auburndale, Mass.) "too bookish" to be a model essayist, and there is proof enough in this little sheaf of "patrins," (a title explained in the dedication) that "the words Greek and scholar are not words of reproach" with her.

PITTSBURG, July 9. -- The greatest gathering of labor leaders that ever assembled in this country during a strike was held in this city to-night to devise means to assist the coal miners in their contest for increased wages. The conference was called suddenly, but the officials responding represented nearly every branch of organized labor in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Navy Department is about to undertake to get more Western blood in the navy, and to this end Lieut. Commander J.M. Hawley, with a surgeon and a boatswain, will start from Washington on a tour of the larger Western cities with a view of securing recruits. The first stop will be made at Duluth, and then Chicago, Milwaukee, Toledo, Buffalo, and other lake cities will be visited.
Manufacturers of machinery in America and horse breeders will be particularly interested in the July report of United States Consul Taney at Belfast Ireland.

Lizzle Francis, a colored girl of 115 West Sixteenth Street, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night, on the charge of stealing $300 and a $350 gold watch from the home of Mrs. William P. Hurd, 27 West Twenty-fourth Street, where she works, yesterday afternoon. The property belongs to Kirke Munson of Wallingsford, Vt., who boards with Mrs. Hurd.

The wisdom and foresight of the National Democrats in declaring the old faith and raising the old standard at Indianapolis are demonstrated by every day and every hour of Republican legislation and administration at Washington.
LONDON, July 9. -- Mr. William Gillette, the American playwright and actor, has been dangerously ill for more than a week, and has been confined to his bed most of the time.
LONDON, July 9. -- A marriage has been arranged between the Duke of Manchester and the daughter of Mr. Ogden Goelet of New York.

The early riser yesterday morning looked at the thermometer with a gleam of hope in his eye, for at 5 o'clock it marked only about 72. The mercury began rising steadily, however. By the time the day's business commenced it was nearly 80, and by noon it was already 86 in some places, with no sign of decrease.
According to The Tribune's Washington dispatches, Mr. McKINLEY is something of a Pecksniff:
The Hudson County Tax Board yestera completed is table of the county ratable for 1897-8. It is as follows:

The summary of the receipts and expenditures of the Government for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, has heen published. They amount to exactly $5 per head. Specie payment was resumed Jan. 1, 1879, and had been substantially the rule for the previous six months. The data of nineteen fiscal years on a specie basis may now give a rule on which the cost of conducting the Government may be considered established.

Trolley Car No. 4,221 of the Brooklyn Heights Company, Brooklyn, smashed into an ice wagon of the Consolidated Ice Company yesterday morning, killed a boy, seriously injured the driver, and damaged property to the value, to $400.

ORANGE, July 9. -- The Middle States championship tennis tournament reached the finals to-day in all events. As predicted, Larned easily beat Whitman in the championship singles, and the final for the cup will be between Larned and Stevens Larned will try to rush the play, while Stevens, who has great staying powers, will play a waiting game in the hope of tiring out Larned.
BATAVIA, N. T., July 9.-At the trial ol Howard C. Benham for the murder of; hts Wife to-day, Dr. Frank P. Vandenburg oi. Buffalo, a chemist, was the principal. witness.

The results of experiments in making distance signals by means of kites conducted on Monday evening last by Lieut. WISE at Governors Island and WILLIAM A. EDDY of Bayonne ought to be of more than ordinary interest to military and naval officers. The distance between the two points of communication was not more than eight miles, and it is doubtful whether that distance cannot be as successfully covered by extant methods of night signaling.

LEXINGTON. Ky., July 9. -- Jacob T. Harris is under arrest for shooting and killing Thomas H. Merritt. Harris has a beautiful wife of twenty-four, who was Miss Effie Thompson, daughter of a prominent minister, the Rev. F.S. Thompson of Missouri. She has been employed by Merritt as a copyist for three months.

PLAINFIELD, N.J. July 9. -- There was an exciting meeting in the school district of Washingtonville, a few miles from this city, last night. The proposition was to appropriate money to erect a new schoolhouse, the present one being too small and not affording seating places for all the children desiring to attend.

Francis Bennoch, who died seven years ago in London, published at his own expense, in 1837, a small volume of poetry, entitled "the Storm and Other Poems," which he sent to Wordsworth. The latter praised the book, which really contains some admirable things, but repeated Sir Walter Scott's remarks on literature as a staff an a crutch, and advised him not to take to authorship as a profession.

The romance of John Patrick Noonan, able-bodied seaman and adventurer, hailing from Brooklyn, contains a chapter as thrilling as any in Thackeray's "Henry Esmond" and a verse as sad a any in Longfellow's "Enoch Arden."

ORANGE, July 9. -- The Rev. Dr. Samuel Bryan Halliday, pastor of the Beecher Memorial Church in Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, and formerly assistant to the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher in Plymouth Church, died at 4:15 o'clock this afternoon at the residence of his friend, Phineas P. Stanton of this city.

That was a characteristic sneer of Lord SALISBURY'S when he was asked in the House of Lords how the arbitration in the Delagoa Bay case was coming on. He said it was not coming on at all, so far as he could find out, and that he could only administer "such consolation as was afforded by the reflection that the matter had been left to the sacred principle of arbitration."
BOSTON, July 9. -- Grace Stevenson disappeared from her home on Beacon Street, Brookline, on April 26, and since that date her parents have received no information concerning her.

We differ with those who may think that Samuel Johnson is more quoted to-day than is Alexander Pope. Both have left their imprint on an English thinking and speaking people. Pope flashes as does the lightning, while Johnson rumbles. But In the affections of the multitude Johnson holds the very first place.

Reminiscences of a great American, Andrew Jackson, as given by his granddaughter, Rachel Jackson Lawrence, may be-read in McClure's Magazine for July, and to this most interesting article Mr. Charles Henry Hart has added the history of the portraits of Jackson, giving reproductions of the best-known pictures.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 9. -- The condition of the Rev. Dr. E.H. Stokes, the venerable President of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, is causing his friends much alarm. He is seriously ill at his home here. He is eighty-four years old, and during the last few years has aged rapidly.

A great find has been made at the Necropolis of Vetulonia, and what was discovered may be Considered as notable among Etruscan ornamental objects. There were eight large fibulae, a fine necklace, two large earrings, (decorated with meanders of tiny grains of gold,) some splendid hairpins,: and other articles of jewelry.

A writer of letters whom The London Globe calls "a female Pepys" was a certain Lady Pye, whose letters, written some years after the time of Pepys, have just come to light in London. They appear in the fourth volume of the Historical Manuscripts Commission, which deals with the contents of the Welbeck muniment room, and form the second volume of the Harley letters and papers.

BERLIN, July 9. -- Prince Hohenlohe, the Imperial Chancellor, is credited with declaring to well-known politicians at Munich that he has no idea of resigning the Chancellorship, but enjoys the fullest confidence of the Emperor and intends to conduct affairs with even greater energy than heretofore.

About one generation ago Mr. T.W. Higginson wrote an interesting article on "The Health of Our Girls," which has not been included in the recent reprints of his essays probably because it is so obviously out of date. Health was just then "coming in." It was just becoming fashionable for girls to take out-door exercise, to row and swim a little, and to skate.

Some idea as to how a great public library grows is given by the statement of Director John S. Billings of the New York Public Library that it required nearly 4,000 feet of shelving to house the books bought last year. About 30,000 volumes were purchased, and it is estimated that eight volumes occupy a foot space.

In Dr. John Punnett Peters's first volume entitled "Nippur," published by Messrs. Putnam's Sons, (see notice in The Saturday Review of Books and Art of July 2,) will be found the history of the work undertaken by the University of Pennsylvania, with the narattive of exploration, which ended somewhat abruptly in 1800.

The passing of the dress-suit case is a subject which must now or never receive some sort of grave attention. It will not be worth while to shed tears for the dress-suit case when it has gone forever. It is not an object to inspire sentiment. Nobody loves the dress-suit case. It is not nearly as useful as an old-fashioned carpet bag which can be stuffed out of all shape.

The Rev. Dr. Henry A. Stimson, pastor of the Manhattan Congregational Church, Boulevard and West Eighty-third Street, is spending the Summer with his family at Bass Rocks, Gloucester, Mass. The church services in Leslie Hall will continue every Sunday morning under the charge of different pastors.

The efforts of Postmaster Van Cott to interest the National postal authorities in the subject of the improvement of the mail service in this city and in plans to adapt that service to whatever change of conditionsmay arise from the Greater New York, resulted in the coming to New York yesterday morning of Perry S. Heath, First Assistant Postmaster, General.

LIVERPOOL, July 9. -- The correspondent of The Associated Press has had an interview with Mrs. Andrew Christie, widow of Capt. Christie of the wrecked British ship Traveller, which went on the reefs off the Island of Rodrigues, in the Indian Ocean, 330 miles northeast of Mauritius, on Feb. 4 last.

NEW LONDON, July 9. -- In spite of the festivities at Black Rock, which kept the Atlantic yachtsmen up to a late hour, they were up bright and early this morning and ready for the sixty-mile run to New London. A brisk wind had blown all night from the west, and there was every prospect of a good race.

A report on the American tin-plate industry prepared by Mr. O'Beirne, Second Secretary of the Embassy at Washington, has been published by the Foreign Office. During the three years following the passing of the McKinley tariff in 1890 the production of tin and terne plates in the United States expanded rapidly, and its growth was not checked by the reduction of the duty under the Wilson tariff, passed in 1894.
PEEKSKILL, July 9. -- Col. Green says the Seventy-first men have made a creditable showing in the different drills, and he will return to New York to-morrow night satisfied with the week's tour.

The true lover of Nature who appreciates the loro of field and hill of lake and riverside, and who, with Thoreau and John Burroughs, has wandered in fancy through Nature's scenes, and has penetrated into the secrets of bird, animal, and tree life, will find these pages from the note book of a field, naturalist a. ad antiquary filled with interest and charm.

The disappearance amid peculiar circumstances of George Jin, a Chinese laundryman, caused intense excitement yesterday in Second Avenue, between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets and several neighboring blocks, and caused a widespread rumor that he had been abducted for cutting wash rates.

The title, "The Academie des Goncourt," may at first strike the ear as somewhat pretentious, but the mistake arises from placing too much stress on the word "academie," the meaning of which is of little significance in Europe. What is not to be overlooked is the end the brothers Goncourt had in view.

" Mr Quiller-Couch's competition in the Pall Mall Magazine has closed. He offered guinca to the person who should state correctly the name of the man (or woman) who is (or has been during the past ten years) master (or inistress) of the best style in English prose"; and at the same of time he wrote his own selection on a piece of paper and inclosed it in an envelope.

The actual work of this season's sessions of the Catholic Summer School at Cliff Haven, Lake Champlain, will begin to-morrow. The Rev. Father Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, is President of this assembly, and the Rev. Thomas McMillan of the Paulist Fathers is Chairman of the Board of Studies.

Another word most be said concerning the Gutenberg Bible. The sale of this book in London last week for u4,000, or nearly $20,000, (the largest price ever brought at auction for any one book,) indeed calls for a detailed account of the origin of the book.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Senate met to-day under the depressing influence of the death of Senator Harris of Tennessee, who had been one of the conspicuous figures in the upper House of Congress for over twenty years. The desk he occupied so long not draped, as the Senate had as yet no official knowledge of his demise.

BOSTON, July 9. -- The Prudential Committee of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions hold a charter, granted by the State of Massachusetts, incorporating them as Trustees of Anatolia College, Marsovan, Western Turkey. The decennial report of this college, just received, shows that it has 110 American and 39 Greek students.

Martin Thorn and Augusta Nack, jointly indicted for the murder on June 26 of William Guldensuppe, were arraigned together yesterday morning before Judge Newburger in Part I. of General Sessions to plead to the indictment. After Clerk Hall had read the charge and asked the prisoners to plead, Mr. House of Friend, House Grossman, counsel for the woman, asked that the proceedings be delayed until Monday.
A young man, fairly well dressed, walked into the City Hall-Police Station yesterday afternoon, and in a calm and unconcerned manner told Sergt. Murphy he had just killed his father.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 9. -- Matters of great moment to the Baltimore and Ohio Railway Company occupied the attention of United States Judges Morris and Golf in the United States Circuit Court here today. The principal subject under discussion was the application of the receivers for permission to issue $680,000 in certificates for the purpose of paying for 40,000 tons of steel rails ordered from the Carnegie Company.

WSHINGTON, July 9. -- The President and the members of the Civil Service Commission have had a number of conferences recently on the revision of the civil service rules, so as to exempt certain important places which were included in Mr. Cleveland's last extension order.

The radical silver men in the Democratic Party are now turning their attention to the Democratic State Committee with the hope of securing from it, when it meets in September, the nomination of a Bryan Democrat upon the Chicago platform for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

NEW LONDON, July 9. -- The cruise this year of the Atlantic Yacht Club is the most successful in the history of the club. Forty-four yachts have been in the squadron, and among the guests have been the following:

To speak of the big Cunarder Campania and the fleet American Liner St. Louis as racing is to do neither vessel justice as they are not in the same class. The Campania has 30,000 horse power and the St. Louis has 20,000. The Campania is 620 feet long and has a tonnage of 12,950, the St. Louis is 554 feet long and has a tonnage of 11,629.

Among the Successful books of the season is Mrs. John Sherwood's. "An Epistle to Posterity." Reports of large demand for it come from many centres. It is a book well worthy of reading for its pictures of the past not only, in this city, but in Boston Washington, rural New England, .and the West.

Although meeting with three defeats in as many days, no one can justly say that the St. Paul's School boys of Concord, N.H., are not a thoroughly sporty and clever lot of golfers. Yesterday, the team met the Richmond County Country Club golfers, on the links at Dongan Hills, S.I., and were defeated by 29 holes.

If we take the best-accredited lists of the works of Rembrandt and Vandyke, which would be those of Prof. Wauters's, the statement is made that in European galleries there are 803 paintings attributed to Rembrandt and 727 to Vandyke. These numbers may be augmented by the works of both these masters which are to be found in the United States.

ALBANY, July 9. -- A certificate was filed with the Secretary of State to-day of the consolidation of the Newburg Electric Railway Company. Walden and Orange Lake Railroad Company, and the Newburg and Orange Lake Railroad Company into a single corporation to be known as the Newburg Electric Railway Company.

Our Republican neighbor The Sun is carrying on Mr. PLATT'S campaign against President Low with a zeal that seems to us to be not merely misdirected but undirected. On Thursday it made a scalding appeal to everybody to love, honor, and obey PLATT. No more of this anti-Platt nonsense, it exclaimed.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- President McKinley will spend most of his Summer vacation on the shores of Lake Champlain. He will leave Washington on Aug. 1, and go direct to Lake Champlain.

The National Sculpture Society announces that through the generosity of Mr. T. Kelly of New York. It will offer a prize for the best and second-best design for a sun dial, to be competed for under its direction, the designs to be exhibited in the society's exhibition in 1838, and the award to be made at that time.

LONDON, July 10. -- The Australian Premiers are gradually letting the cat out of the bag in regard to the conferences they have had with the Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, and it proves to be an absolute failure of Mr. Chamberlain's pet project for colonial representation at Westminster. One who was present at these conferences said to a representative of The Associated Press:

The mirror is an article not too much, but too little, used. There are too few women who make good use of the hand mirror to study artistic effects of the back of the head. There is one charming and clever woman in New York the back of whose head is so attractive that her friends have begged her to have it photographed.

This novel engineering work is called a "Pont Transbordeur," and is designed to fulfill all the purposes of a bridge, while it will offer no obstruction to the passage of ships with towering masts. On each side of the river will be erected a small Eiffel tower, about 170 feet in height, and these towers will be joined at the top by a latticework bridge upon which lines of rails will be laid.

The sky-line of New York is changing so rapidly that the American traveler who goes abroad can recognize with more certainty the profiles of the foreign cities he approaches than that of his own metropolis as he sees it from the deck of the steamer on his return. It may be his first visit to Europe; he may know London, Rome, and Paris only from views of them in old prints.
Thomas J. Lipton, the British millionaire who gave $125,000 to the Princess of Wales to feed the outcast poor of London during the jubilee, arrived in the city yesterday by the Campania.

Nearly 1,900 excursionists, principally down town children, went to Islandwild, Glen Island, yesterday, on the annual excursion of the Sunday school of Trinity Church. They underwent an experience shortly after getting started that many of them will remember.

The remains of the Rev. S.B. Halliday, the late pastor of the Beecher Memorial Church, Brooklyn, were brought yesterday to the family residence, 77 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, from Orange, N.J., where his death occurred. The body was accompanied by his daughter, two sons, and several friends from Orange.

LONDON, June 26. -- For a hard day's work in this town I can confidently recommend a visit to the Inns of Court. They contain so many curious old things that one walks on and on without taking note of distance, till by the time the fountain is reached he is ready to rest his weary bones on one of the iron benches.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Word has been received from the band of 100 unemployed men who left San Francisco on the brigantine Percy Edwards several months ago for the Adamless Eden in the Pacific Ocean. Dr. Carpenter of this city has a letter from one of the party, John Ohlsen, formerly in his employ.

FRANKFORT-ON-THE-MAIN, July 1. -- Americans who visit the leading cities of Germany, such as Hamburg, Berlin, Dresden, Frankfort, and note the tremendous strides they have made during the last twenty years in population, buildings, public and private, in parks and fine broad streets, in comforts and cleanliness, are easily induced to overlook the backwardness of the people in the country and in the lower quarters of the cities.

Occasionally one hears of a student who is stricken with brain fever as a result of long and puzzling study, and in such cases, if the student recovers, a long rest is advised. The victims in such cases are usually not so strongly constituted as another class of students who are at present in dire need of a long rest, as a result of their long, patient, and puzzling studies.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 10. -- The season at the Long Beach Hotel has developed with a bound. Six hundred regular guests now enliven the house. Marquee tents, where children are sheltered, dot the beach below the cottages. Surf bathers are out regularly, boating parties try the sea's adventure with some doughty longshoreman, hops are planned, and social sets among the young folk are gradually forming and assuming identity.

The Sick Children's Mission of the Children's Aid Society is engaged in its usual Summer work of ministering to the sick children of the poor, especially those in the crowded east side tenement houses. In the most favorable circumstances the parents of these children have difficulty in providing for them the necessaries of life, and when sickness overtakes either the mothers or the little ones the situation is distressing in the extreme.

The Pall Mall Gazette is of the opinion that the time has come for our English brethren to issue another challenge for the America's Cup. As a representative of English feeling, the journal named cannot be said to hold a very authoritative position, but being in England, it might at least be conversant with public opinion.
MARK FORRESTER was no common Mark; he was an honorable, and consequently a noble, Mark.

July's second week has been marked in the society world by a gradual quickening of the pace at the leading Summer resorts, both far and near, by the final desertion of the city by all those who have been able to lay aside business and other obligations, and by the first of the distinctive entertainments of the Summer season at Bar Harbor, Newport, Southampton, and Narragansett.

A woman, apparently about seventy years of age, was found yesterday wandering about in One Hundred and Sixth Street near Third Avenue. She appeared to be confused, and a policeman took her to the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station, where he preferred a charge of vagrancy against her. She was ordered to be taken to the One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station, where there is a matron.

Chairman Allen of the Tours and Runs Committee of the League of American Wheelmen Meet, to be held in Philadelphia, Aug. 4, 5, 6, and 7, has arranged an elaborate programme of short and long distance runs, which will give the visitors an excellent opportunity of becoming acquainted with the famous riding district of Philadelphia.

It is too soon to predict the outcome of the strike of the coal miners. So far the workmen have made pretty steady progress until it is admitted that the key to the situation is in the Pittsburg district. If the men there can generally be brought into the movement the labor leaders are confident of success.

The National Cycle Track Association is up in arms against the League of American Wheelmen, and unless the existing differences are patched in the near future, open warfare may be declared. The refusal of the Racing Board to grant sanctions upon several occasions is the point of contention, and the track owners say they are tired of being dictated to by the league.

Undoubtedly the bicycle has wrought for rationality in dress, and the improvement is especially welcome in hot weather. The mere abridgment of the trouser is an incalculable boon to mankind. It is true that the vacancy thus created might be better occupied than by the golf stocking, of which it has been ably said that it was violently suggestive of prickly heat.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 10. -- Last Monday was the hottest day this village ever enjoyed in more senses than one. In the real, genuine, bona-tide hotness of a thermometer at 92 degrees, Richfield reached about the maximum of heat ever known here; but it was not hot enough to mar the enthusiasm or attendance for the great day's sport and celebrating.

LONDON, July 10. -- It at last has dawned upon the English people that the Turk, having got his slice of Thessaly, is hardly likely to let it go until some one takes him by the throat. Indeed, the business instinct of this commercial nation is veering round to the view that a conquered province is a species of extension of legitimate business, to which the wily, hard-working Eastern trader has after all some right.

WILLIAM HENRY WEBB, who demonstrated the possibilities of steam as a motive power for propelling vessels, after its practicability had been demonstrated, and established for himself a world-wide reputation as a designer and builder of seagoing vessels, was born in New York City, June 19, 1816, the year that Robert Fulton died, Mr. Webb's father having completed his first steamboat that year.

CLEVELAND, July 10. -- Alarm over the possibility of a coal famine in this city as a result of the miners' strike is rapidly increasing. Frantic efforts were made to-lay by the little dealers to secure coal from the big dealers to supply the retail consumers. In every instance the dealers refused to deliver the coal, and the effects of the strike are beginning to be felt in the homes.

That the shamrock was used as diet before it was adopted as the national emblem is conclusively demonstrated, though Mr. Colgan shows that one writer borrows from another; very few drew their information from personal observation. Spenser undoubtedly did, and he is perhaps responsible for the familiarization of this fact to his contemporaries.

Crime is contagious and infectious. To the young and ignorant, to those whose daily life has made them familiar with crime, it has all the glamour and attraction of chivalry and bravery. The bold robber, the cunningly planned house or bank breaking, the street fight, the homicide, and the still more dreadful incendiary, are discussed with an eagerness and an awe not unmixed with admiration.

Brahms's songs seem to be more generally appreciated than his other works. They, too, made their way slowly at first, but now Brahms's Lieder are included in the repertoire of almost every concert singer of eminence, and are heard with growing frequency even in America, where Brahms has been far more neglected than in Germany and England.

BIRMINGHAM, July 10. -- The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and a Warwickshire eleven, which began on Thursday last, ended to-day and resulted in a victory for the American players.

NEWPORT, July 10. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Yawl Albacore, owned by S. Hyde; schooner Monrive, owned by the New York Yacht Club; steamer Conqueror, owned by F.W. Vanderbilt; steamer Indolent, owned by the Eastern Yacht Club; thirty-footers Vaquero III., owned by H.B. Duryea; Wawa, owned by J. Stillman; Hera, owned by Ralph N. Ellis, and Puck, owned by E.D. Morgan.

This is emphatically the season of fruit stains and mildew. Fortunately, too, it is the season of grass bleaching and hot sunshine. Mildew is easily taken out of white goods with chloride of lime, but it cannot be used on colored clothes. Put a small amount of lime in cold water and stir until it is entirely dissolved; then strain through cheese cloth and immerse the mildewed article.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 10. -- Frank Klein, Benham's coachman, was the first witness in the Benham murder trial this morning. He testified that he frequently saw Benham and May Wiard together. Once Benham told him be had been to Buffalo with Miss Wiard and had a very nice time. "I asked him," continued the witness, "what he wanted to go with that girl for, and he said he loved her.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Impressive funeral services over the late Senator Isham G. Harris were held in the Senate Chamber at noon to-day, in the presence of President McKinley and the members of his Cabinet, Senators and members of the House of Representatives, members of the Diplomatic Corps, Justices of the Supreme Court, and officials from all branches of public life.

LONDON, July 10. -- J.H. Leibes, the expert on sealing of the American Commercial Company, has sent to John W. Foster, the United States Seal Commissioner, a severe criticism of the report recently made to the British Government by Prof. D'Arcy Thompson. In his communication, Mr. Leibes says:

ST. PETERSBURG, June 25. -- The approaching visit of President Faure of France and the proposed triple alliance between Russia, Germany, and France against Great Britain are the leading topics here. The Russians are visibly annoyed at the tone of a certain portion of the Parisian press concerning the Presidential visit to St. Petersburg.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- The Seventy-first Regiment and the First Provisional Battalion left the State Camp this afternoon after having endured a week of scorching weather. They were succeeded by the Twenty-second Regiment of New York City, Col. Franklin Bartlett, and the Second Provisional Battalion, consisting of the Fourth Separate Company of Kingston, the Sixteenth of Catskill, the Thirty-sixth of Schenectady, and the Forty-seventh of Hornellsville.

Two policemen of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station were attacked by more than a score of boys last night at One Hundred and Third Street and Madison_Avenue. The boys had been playing ball, and when Policeman Gannigan tried to disperse them they stoned him. When Policeman Herald came to his brother officer's assistance the mob threw stones, baseballs, and bats at the officers, but did not effect the release of the prisoners.

BAYPORT, L.I., July 10. -- The deaths of Charles Le Cluse and his wife, in the opinion of Dr. Greenough, who was called shortly after their bodies were found last evening, were natural. Coroner Bennett of Patchogue, who was summoned, is holding an inquest.
A red-faced woman in a black gown and a black bonnet came aboard a Euclid Avenue car last Monday and seated herself next to a young man whose face was concealed behind a Plain Dealer.

TIFFANY CO.'S new sterling silver and plated ware works, just completed at Forest Hill, Newark, N.J., furnish a notably conspicuous illustration of the progressive spirit of this old and world-famed house.

NEW LONDON, July 10. -- The harbor was a blaze of light to-night; all the yachts of the Atlantic Club squadron were illuminated and there was a fine display of fireworks from Commodore Adams's schooner Sachem and Rear Commodore Whitlock's Hilde-garde, while from the other boats the red and white night signals burned continuously.

What the Long Island City police believe was a deliberate murder occurred a few minutes before 7 o'clock last night. The victim was a fifteen-year-old boy. James Grimes, of 71 Bodine Street, Long Island City. His alleged murderer was John Buck, a widower, fifty-four years of age, who lived at 69 Nutt Street, Long Island City.

Measured by the test of creative power and the persistency of spiritual purpose, how variable is the duration of human life! Sometimes the creative power appears in early youth, but when that happens there is generally an early surcease. Sometimes the power comes late and remains long. Sometimes it flashes forth in the early morning and remains in the after twilight.

The leaves of the bright tobacco are thin and small veined. To be of good quality they must possess good body and texture as well as uniform and attractive color, and, therefore, high manuring with nitrogenous fertilizers, which latter tend to produce rank growth and give the plants a dark or red hue, should be avoided.

It inspires some sort of confidence, however, to know that the wholesale adulteration once so common in China teas is no longer tolerated here or in America, which ranks as the second largest consumer, and that the Celestials have themselves partially recognized the injury which these adulterations worked to their trade.

BALTIMORE, July 10. -- Judge Goff of the United States Circuit Court this afternoon put his seal of approval upon the policy of the receivers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad in issuing $680,000 of certificates to pay for 40,000 tons of new steel rails. The petition was opposed by attorneys of J.P. Morgan Co., who are trying to get control of the road and conduct the reorganization.

Daniel Greenleaf Thompson, the well-known lawyer and author, died suddenly of apoplexy yesterday morning in his apartments at the Chelsea, 222 West Twenty-third Street. Mr. Thompson had remained unusually late at his office Friday afternoon, getting matters in shape for his vacation, which he intended to spend in Canada, and on which he proposed to start to-morrow.

Nearly 4,000 out-of-town merchants have asked to be enrolled as non-resident members of the Merchants' Association of New York. Several hundred of these applications were received yesterday. This association was incorporated less than a month ago, yet so strongly have its objects appealed to the merchants of this city that there are already more than 250 resident members on its roll.

LOUISVILLE, July 10. -- Judge Barr, in the United States Court to-day, refused to reduce the upset price on the Ohio Valley Railroad, which was heretofore fixed at $1,050,000, and the road will be sold next Tuesday by the Commissioners.

AS an illustration of how far drill, uniform, and discipline will go toward changing a motley aggregation of boys into clean-cut youngsters of attractive and even imposing appearance, the St. Paul Cadets of this city may be cited.

The mercury went soaring again yesterday, ambitious to break records. The maximum heat of the day was 86 at noon according to official figures. But these were recorded at the local Weather Bureau Station, 300 feet above the hot street that has been absorbing the rays of the sun now for a full week. Down on the ground where mortals lived and suffered the thermometers marked a much higher figure.

Gertie Horn, the four-year-old daughter of Morris Horn, a presser of 10 Essex Street, was killed in front of her home last night by a horse car of the Avenue B line. She was playing tag with a brother and sister when she was hurt and died in a few minutes.

Some people seem to have the notion that the rule that any one can use the Park lawns when no harm is done is a new one, and also that it gives every one the right to go where he or she chooses in the Park. The rule is not new, but its announcement by the President of the Park Board makes it seem so and also gives an unfortunate idea of its scope.

Thomas Butler, twenty-one years old, of 214 West Twenty-eighth Street, and Jessie Lewis, twenty-nine years old, of 222 West Sixty-fourth Street, both colored, were locked up in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station last night on a charge of assault preferred by James O'Rourke, twenty-two years old, a white laborer living at 243 West Sixty-first Street.
