PARIS, June 29. -- In politics France is threatened just at this moment with a resuscitation of the fold Panama scandal. A special committee has been appointed to conduct an investigation, and M. Naquet, Boulanger's old henchman, who is accused of being seriously implicated in the affair, declines to leave the safe refuge which he has sought in London.

Midsummer amusements will have a seasoning of comic opera at popular prices, beginning to-morrow night, at Madison Square Garden, with the production of "Captain Cook." The work is the creation of Sands W. Forman and Noah Brandt. Both are Californians. The story of the opera is connected with the landing of Capt. Cook at Hawaii in 1778.

PITTSBURG, July 10. -- The week closes with the forces engaged in the miners' strike as determined as ever. No open aggressive work was done to-day by either side, but the miners' officials held a secret meeting, at which it is believed a vigorous campaign against the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal miners to be inaugurated tomorrow was decided upon.

Newspaper writers are now appraised according to their merits, and the measure is taken very swiftly, whether the individual be man or woman. Women are succeeding, and have succeeded, in every branch of journalism, from the mere setting of the type to the absolute control of a great publication. Men as a class are apt to employ slang, colloquialisms, technical phrases, and business language.

Detectives' search for evidence in the Guldensuppe murder case resulted in no discoveries yesterday. The police are still scouring the city and the districts around Woodside, L.I, for witnesses to corroborate the statement alleged to have been made by Thorn to John Gotha. A search of the pawn-broking shops of New York and Brooklyn for Guldensuppe's watch and chain has been without result.

He must be the guest of the evening at the Inkslingers' annual dinner in the Holborn Restaurant, and there he must make an impromptu speech full of quaintly characteristic sayings. He must be the observed of all observers at the soiree given by the Institute of Second-Rate Lady Journalists and be seen at Private Views, bronzed and vigorous after his recent cruise on the Norfolk Broads.
Mrs. Della Johnson, a widow, aged twenty-five, from Charleston, S.C., lies dying in the Seney Hospital, Brooklyn, from poison taken with suicidal intent.

A quarrel over a game of cards yesterday afternoon, on the roof of the six-story tenement house at 83 East Third Street, ended in a fight, in which Henry Schurmer of 720 Sixth Street, a stock clerk in a Broadway clothing store, had his throat cut from ear to ear, and may die.

"Dr. Fowler, Bishop of Gloucester in the early part of the eighteenth century, was a believer in apparitions. The following conversation of the Bishop with Judge Powell is recorded: 'Since I saw you,' said the lawyer, 'I have had ocular demonstration of the existence of nocturnal apparitions.'

AUSTIN, Texas, July 8. -- John H. Reagan, sole survivor of the Davis Cabinet, to-day furnished his statement regarding the report so generally current that President Lincoln proposed at the Hampton Roads conference that the United States would pay $400,000,000 for the Southern slaves if the Confederates would abandon the war and return to the Union.

Analyzing the status of electric railroading, an editorial in The Railroad Gazette demurs to the idea, popular with many, that the steam locomotive is about to be relegated to the scrap heap by the electric motor. Taking up published rumors or circumstantial statements of this character in regard to certain steam railroads, it gives a few instances where electricity has superseded steam, and goes on to say:

NEWPORT, July 8. -- During last week there has been more or less talk about the condition of the Cliff Walk, and at the meeting of the City Council on Tuesday night the matter was brought before that body. One of the Councilmen asked the opinion of the City Solicitor as to the right of the citizens to the Cliff Walk and to Bailey's Beach.

A correspondent at Tangier gives the following account of the execution of a native for the murder of Herr Hassner, a German banker, in December last: The circumstances of the murder have remained extremely mysterious. The German Legation here put pressure on the local authorities. After a short time a woman went over to Gibraltar for safety, and sent word from there that she could throw light on the affair.

German cooking has some marked characteristics. It is not quite like the cooking of any other nationality. To many persons not born Germans, most of it is an acquired taste, but some of it is found delicious by every one, even without previous acquaintance.
BERLIN, July 10. -- The German exports to the United States during the last three months show, with few exceptions, a large increase over those of 1896.

Ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower said some-interesting things yesterday at Manhattan Beach, about politics. He was somewhat reminiscent and somewhat sarcastic in his remarks. A reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES met him at the Manhattan Beach Hotel, and called his attention to some utterances made by Mayor Strong at Richfield Springs, in reference to the ex-Governor's article in the July Forum, in which Mr. Flower advocated partisan municipal government.

Golf was very active all day yesterday on the links of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club, at Livingston. The third monthly handicap for members was played and twenty-eight contestants turned in cards. A comfortable breeze sprang up late in the afternoon, making the sport on the links somewhat endurable, but those who played around in the morning were nearly baked by the time they finished.

HENLEY, July 10. -- The regatta which begins on Wednesday bids fair to be a record one in this record year, as far as the number of spectators is concerned. Henley certainly has never been so full as it will be next week at the last social function of a memorable season.

The rowels of nature's most powerful spur, hunger, are continually reddening the flanks of the primitive community. The apostle's scathing arraignment of the Cretans, "whose god is their belly," would literally apply to every savage tribe -- and many a civilized one. Hunger is one of the mainsprings of progress.

Mr. WILLIAM T. BAXTER, Jr., in The Popular Science Monthly, warns the overenthusiastic against undue speculation as to the scientific progress of the future. There is no good reason to expect that the next century will outrank the present as an age of discovery and invention.

This famous "gin law," passed in 1736, is interesting as the earliest severe blow at liquor dealing among civilized nations. It levied a tax of 20s. a gallon on spirits, and a license of 50 for any one selling or dealing in it. And, being in advance of public opinion, it failed, much as other more stringent prohibition laws have failed in our own day.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- The opening ball of the season took place to-night in the spacious ballroom, and over 400 guests enjoyed the mazy waltz. The Kaaterskill orchestra was concealed behind a bower of palms and evergreens, entwined with laurel, and discoursed sweet strains of music.

Two weeks ago a resolution was introduced in the Health Board proposing an amendment to the Sanitary Code by which the speed of street cars on Curves was to be reduced. Yesterday Charles G. Wilson, President of the Health Board, received reports from his men detailed to watch the work of the cars on the curves with the grip just put in use.

AN interesting feature of the recent State Teachers' Convention at the Normal College of this city was the physical culture exercises executed by classes of children from several grammar schools, and the illustrations presented in this issue are from photographs taken on the spot.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The conferrees on the Tariff bill suspended their labors long enough to-day to attend the funeral ceremonies conducted over the remains of the late Senator Harris, but resolved before dispersing for this purpose to reassemble immediately after the conclusion of the obsequies, and to continue their work, not only to-night, but all day to-morrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10. -- No definite figures have been given out as to the total registration of Christian Endeavorers, but it is understood that something over 22,000 have appended their names to the roll of attending delegates. Nineteen more trains yet to come is the latest announcement by Secretary Baer, and the last of these probably will not arrive before Monday.

DENVER, Col., July 10. -- The history of the Centennial State would be incomplete that neglected to devote several pages to the Hon. John Evans, the pioneer war Governor of Colorado, whose death occurred here recently.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Angry protests and stern denunciations filled the columns of the local press on the morning after Independence Day. Heretofore the annual maiming and killing have been accepted rather as a necessary evil, but the long list of dead and wounded in Chicago this year has aroused the sane portion of the community to a realizing sense of the barbarity which marks the celebration of the Nation's birthday.

DENVER, Col., July 10. -- The history of the Centennial State would be incomplete that neglected to devote several pages to the Hon. John Evans, the pioneer war Governor of Colorado, whose death occurred here recently.

Some excellent racing was furnished by the Harlem Wheelmen at their annual meet at Manhattan Beach yesterday afternoon, and about 2,000 persons enjoyed the sport and a cool breeze that blew in from the ocean.

The foremost lawyer of New England during the decade preceding the War of the Rebellion was Rufus Choate, who died at Halifax, on his way to Europe, In 1859. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College, class of 1819; served in both branches of the Massachusetts Legislature, and also in both houses of Congress, filling in the Senate the unexpired term of Daniel Webster after the latter's death in 1852.

I have made, in a number of years of ardent collection, quite a library of my own notes; and the fact that I have already lived two-thirds of my probable tether of life, and am a "buccaneer" of the newspaper world, by stress of circumstances, sometimes gives me a pang. I recognize the ludicrousness of my collection for an impossible future of comfort and leisure, for even one possible posthumous work.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 10. -- The seventh annual Hollywood Futurity Handicap was the principal event decided at the Hollywood traps this afternoon. The conditions were: $50 entrance, twenty-five birds; ties at five birds; cup and 50 per cent. to winner, 30 per cent. to second, and 10 per cent. to third.

CONFORMING to the general features of the brownstone facade of a block of New York dwellings, there is nothing outwardly to indicate that the interior of the home of Mrs. Joseph Keppler, the widow of the genial founder and proprietor of Puck, differs from the usual conventional lines upon which prosperous citizens set up their Lares and Penates.

All sorts of advice seem seasonable. If you can't keep cool keep as cool as you can is the common suggestion. It is well to remember that open windows or doors do not necessarily mean a cooler house or store. If the air is warmer out of doors than within, to open the doors and windows raises the temperature within.

LONDON, July 10. -- George Edwardes has entered into partnership with Albert Gilmer for the management next season of the Princess' Theatre. They will open in the Autumn with a spectacular melodrama now being written for them by Cecil Raleigh and Seymour Hicks, and which they announce will be produced on a scale of magnificence as yet unequaled on the London stage.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 10. -- Capt. John Kirk, a veteran fisherman, reported to-day that he had seen a sea serpent this morning. He explains that he was overhauling his trawl, and he heard a puffing and felt an unusual swell near the Half Way Rocks.

Parricide is considered only one degree less culpable than treason, and is punished as a crime of the deepest dye, such a violation of the ties of nature being held to be evidence of the most unprincipled depravity. Any person convicted of a design to kill his or her parents or ancestors, whether a blow be struck or not, is liable to suffer death by being beheaded.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 5. -- The individual who is looking for that illusive quality called style would better keep away from Asbury Park.

LENOX, July 10. -- It is rarely that the mercury reaches 80 degrees in the shade here. This week, however, on Monday and Tuesday, it climbed up to 86, which is altogether too hot for playing golf or driving, so that the cottagers staid either on the shady side of their piazzas or remained in the coolest part of their country houses.

Any person convicted of a design to kill his or her parents or ancestors, whether a blow be struck or not, is liable to suffer death by being beheaded.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 5. -- The individual who is looking for that illusive quality called style would better keep away from Asbury Park.

LENOX, July 10. -- It is rarely that the mercury reaches 80 degrees in the shade here. This week, however, on Monday and Tuesday, it climbed up to 86, which is altogether too hot for playing golf or driving, so that the cottagers staid either on the shady side of their piazzas or remained in the coolest part of their country houses.

DULUTH, Minn., July 10. -- The great water power of the St. Louis River is soon to be developed, and it is extremely likely that in the course of eighteen months all the manufacturing plants, mills, elevators, and street railways at the head of the lake will be operated by electricity generated at the falls, ten miles west of the cities of Duluth and Superior.

" It is apparent," remarks the Washington correspondent of THE TIMES, "that JONES of Nevada has it in his power, if he chooses to exert that power, to go into the conference with a slate indicating the things he wants and must have."

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The army officer in charge of the Pueblo and Jiccarilla Indian Agency in New Mexico has submitted a very vigorous report on the dances carried on by the tribe, and has asked for instructions looking to giving the teachers on the reservation security from insults from the Indians in the future.

Commenting upon the recent tea legislation passed by Congress in the interest of pure teas, Fred C. Williams stated in a recent interview that the new laws would have a wholesome and beneficial effect on the tea trade in this country, which had recently suffered from the fact that the sending of impure teas to the markets of America had resulted in curtailing the consumption of the article.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 11. -- To-morrow morning 1,600 miners who have been working in the Springfield district will refuse to return to work. This action was decided upon this afternoon at a delegate meeting held three miles from the city, attended by over 100 delegates and 500 other mine workers.

Harlem River oarsmen were unusually active yesterday, and all kinds of racing craft were on the water early and late. The majority of the crews were out for pleasure, as there is little or no training being done on the river at present. At the Metropolitan Boat Club's house every boat was in use.

Ex-Queen Liliuokalani of Hawaii and her party spent all the day yesterday in her apartments at the Hotel Albemarle trying to keep cool. They are not accustomed to such warm weather, even in the Summer months in the Hawaiian Islands, said her private secretary, Julius A. Palmer, the maximum temperature there being about, 81 degrees, while the temperature was generally in the seventies.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 11. -- A.R. Milne, Collector of Customs at this port, has made public a statement replying to the criticism of Prof. Thompson's sealing report made by J.H. Liebes, the sealing expert of the American Commercial Company.

ATLANTA, July 11. -- A charge of burglary brought by Mrs. W.R. Jester against Miss Emma Dimon last Friday led to a demonstration by the congregation of the fashionable St. Paul's Methodist Church to-day. Miss Dimon is the daughter of the Rev. Dr. S.H. Dimon, pastor of St. Paul's, and Mrs. Jester is her Sunday school teacher.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 11. -- The whisky distillers of Kentucky are seriously considering the formation of a mutual insurance company. For some time the distillers have complained that the rate of 6 and 7 per cent. was too high, and have made repeated efforts to have it lowered. The Louisville Board of Fire Underwriters is favorable to a reduction and has taken the matter up with the Executive Committee of the Kentucky and Tennessee Board.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The conferrees on the Tariff bill held a four-hour session to-day. The anxiety to reach a complete agreement as early as possible induced them to meet on Sunday, and to-night both the House and Senate conferrees appear satisfied with the progress that has been made.
OSWEGO, July 11. -- Peter Kellar and Thomas Lanning, farmers, living a few miles from here, dropped dead from the heat yesterday afternoon.

Showers and a falling of temperature came as a blessing to all sections of the coast, from Boston to Norfolk, and to the interior as far as Indianapolis. If New Yorkers did not thoroughly appreciate the boon, it was because the streets were hotter than the official register in the Weather Bureau's tower on lower Broadway recorded, and because there was a great deal of humidity to rob the charitably inclined temperature of its bounties.

Representative Lemuel E. Quigg, President of the Republican County Committee, yesterday gave out the following statement concerning the purging of the rolls, with the results tabulated according to Assembly districts.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Beyond the fact that the General Deficiency Appropriation bill probably will be passed and that the Senate will stand ready to take up the Tariff bill at any time that a report may be brought in by the Conference Committee, little can be predicted of the course of events in the Senate this week.

FOND DU LAC, Minn., July 11. -- An old Chippewa Indian medicine man named Manitowasa died here a few days ago after telling a sensational story concerning a young woman who is now the wife of a half-breed living at Superior, Wis. Manitowasa had been on earth about fifty years, according to the Indian system of computing time, and was counted among the great men of the Chippewa tribe.

BAYPORT, L.I., July 11. -- The funeral of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lecluse, who were found dead in their home in this village on Friday, was held at the house this afternoon. The Rev. W.T. Wooley of the Methodist Church conducted the services. There were many mourners present. The burial was in the Union Cemetery at Sayville.

A family quarrel which began at Atlanta, Ga., and continued at Garrison's Landing, N.Y., was aired in the Gregory Street Police Station, Jersey City, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. The persons concerned in the affair are G.V. Gress of Atlanta, Ga.; Mrs. May Gress, his wife; May Gress, their ten-year-old daughter; Morgan K. Gress, twenty years old, Mr. Gress's son by his first wife, and Dr. and Mrs. Van Doran Young of New York.

Imperial Federation was doubtless what might be called the "business end" of the Queen's Jubilee. In this Mr. CHAMBERLAIN has discerned greater power to the British Empire, greater profits to the British merchant, and incidentally honor and success to himself. But he finds it very difficult to formulate just what he means by it.

It was learned yesterday that the pardon of Edward R. Carter, serving a six and a half years' sentence for robbing the National Bank of Commerce, of which he was transfer and coupon clerk, in December, 1894, was due to the efforts of his nineteen-year-old daughter, Miss Mary Carter.
DETROIT, Mich., July 11. -- The hotel lobbies are crowded to-night with the advance guard of the delegations to the convention of the National League of Republican Clubs, which commences Tuesday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11. -- William H. Gates was arrested at his home in the town of Gates to-day by Detective Lynch and Lieut. Stetson. He was brought to this city charged with the murder of his wife, Carrie Gates, which occurred at 2 o'clock this morning in a room in the flat at 219 North Clinton Street.

A West Indian coolie, with an unpronounceable and unspellable name, has attracted a good deal of attention at the Barge Office for three weeks past. When he first appeared, he said that he had arrived a week previous on the steamship Caribbee, from Trinidad. He had meantime been robbed of $100, he said, and having become penniless, asked to be sent back to Trinidad.

TACOMA, Washington, July 11. -- W.N. Coler of the New York banking firm of Coler Company, is here en route home from a fifteen months' tour around the world. He spent several weeks in Tokio, Japan, and to-day said:

PARIS, July 11. -- The Grand Prix cycle race at Vincennes took place to-day. Bourrillon finished first, but was disqualified on a claim that he had committed a foul, and the first prize, 8,000f., was awarded to Morin; who agreed to divide the prize with Massam; who finished third. The decision created great dissatisfaction among the spectators, and a tremendous uproar ensued.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 11. -- New Bedford's celebration during the week of Oct. 10 of the semi-centennial anniversary of the city's incorporation is to be made the occasion of a grand reunion of the old residents and a gathering home of the old town's sons and daughters from the four corners of the earth.

The question of gold exports has been practically dropped from Wall Street's list of impending bearish developments. The apparently weak position of sterling exchange and the prospects of large grain shipments to Europe in the Autumn have convinced the Street that further heavy exports of the yellow metal to Europe are almost impossible.

For the first time in the history of the Kings County Pharmaceutical Society the degree of Doctor of Pharmacy was conferred Saturday evening at an adjourned meeting held at 329 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn. Six diplomas and three certificates were awarded without the usual exercises.
PITTSBURG, July 11. -- The second week of the coal miners' strike began to-day. It now gives promise of being one of the greatest wage struggles in the history of the country.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Details are made public here of the plan for carrying into effect the consolidation of the Chicago Gas properties in accordance with the recent permissive enactment of the Illinois Legislature.
SYDNEY, N.S.W., July 11. -- The Hon. Sir Patrick Alfred Jennings, K.C.M.G., LL. D., formerly Premier of New South Wales, is dead. He was sixty-six years of age.

Local cricketers are keeping up their struggles for the possession of the Metropolitan Cup, which will go to the winner of the championship series of games of the Meropolitan League. The New Jersey Athletic Club still maintains an unbeaten record in the series, but both the Staten Island and Manhattan teams still preserve the hope that they will be able to reduce this.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 11. -- Holder Alonzo Tripp, a farmer of Westport; was found dying on the New Bedford Road at a late hour last night. He died before a physician reached him. Jeremiah Manchester, another Westport farmer, is under arrest in this city charged with killing Tripp.

Francis R. Hope, thirty-six years old, of 174 West Tenth Street, a bookkeeper in the employ of the Sunlight Soap Company, at the corner of Hudson and Harrison Streets, was drowned yesterday afternoon while bathing off Heinemann's pier at Norton's Point, Coney Island. Hope was one of a party who went in a rowboat to the scene of the accident from Gravesend Beach.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 11. -- The Upper New Rochelle Methodist Episcopal Church, on the White Plains road, four miles from this village, was destroyed by fire to-night.

The chances of Mr. GAGE'S proposition to put into the Treasury the $14,000,000 of the $16,000,000 profit voted to the Sugar Trust in the Tariff bill are in inverse proportion to its merit. Its merit is very great; its chances are less than nothing. Not only will Congress not accept the proposition, but it would, if it were pressed, reject it absolutely.
NEWPORT, July 11. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Schooner Montauk, owned by L.C. Ledyard; steamer Sylvia, owned by Mr. Metcalf; sloops Ilderim and Veda, owned by C. Vanderbilt, Jr.

The friends of Mr. AIKIN, the late Supervising Architect, have been inclined to resent his removal by Secretary GAGE and to hold that it does not augur well for the future of our public architecture. It is quite true that the work of the late Supervising Architect is very superior, artistically, to that of most of his predecessors.

Brighton, the comfortable race track by the sea, once the home of the beach comber, but now a handsome fashionable track, will open its gates to-day for an uninterrupted stretch of two weeks' racing. Workmen have been busy at the track ever since the Summer began, for President Engeman has advanced ideas about racing and race tracks, and the ambition to make the Brighton track one of the most attractive in the country.

Here is the admonition of the Merchants' Association of New York to its 4,000 out-of-town members: "Keep your home trade by visiting twice a year or oftener the largest and broadest market in the world. All the most successful merchants do this."

There is a touch of pathos in that tale of the benevolent produce dealer and his turnips. There were 171 barrels of last year's turnips and they were left on his hands, wherefore he determined to give them to the poor. But the ungrateful and reckless poor neglected to take the turnips, and they were sent to the garbage dump.

The monthly series of games of the West Side Athletic Club were held yesterday at their grounds on Fifty-fourth Street. The games will continue to be held monthly until October, when gold and silver medals will be awarded to those having scored the highest points.

The heart of the Summer resort man rejoiced with exceeding great joy yesterday as he looked toward the sweltering city and noted the host fleeing therefrom. Of every degree was the host, and in every direction it fled until steam cars, trolley cars, and boats were filled, crammed and jammed, while legion upon legion of bicycles turned on country roads.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 11. -- The usual Young People's meeting in the Temple, led by Charles Yatman, opened the religious services here to-day. The holiness meeting was held in the Tabernacle at 9 o'clock, led by the Rev. J.R. Daniels. About 7,000 people attended the morning service in the big auditorium at 10:30 o'clock.

At the Church of St. John the Evangelist the Rev. Dr. De Costa yesterday delivered the first of a series of hot weather sermons, entitled "The Morals of Warm Weather." He took his text from Jeremiah xlviii., 32: "The spoiler is fallen upon them." The sermon was general in its nature, but he said that before he got through with the series he would come down to concrete matters.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 11. -- The new features in the situation to-day were the arrival of the Ohio and Indiana State Boards of Arbitration, the meeting to-night of the United Labor League of Western Pennsylvania, and the report that a movement was on foot to import new men to take the places of the strikers at the Pittsburg and Chicago Company's mines.

The correction given me by the Superintendents of two cancer hospitals, that my idea of a place for incurables is, strictly speaking, only a home, pleases me very much, as it is perfectly true. The definition falls in with my determination that no operations should be performed in the home, as those who need operations can go elsewhere and be welcome.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- A discussion of Union Pacific Railroad affairs occupied the attention of the Senate to-day.

PITTSBURG, July 12. -- Beyond the strengthening of the miners' line along the river, there was little change in the strike situation to-day. The ironclad contracts which were in force in several mines in the Monongahela Valley were swept out of existence to-day, and the strike was made general in the fourth pool.

ALBANY, July 12. -- The Police and Fire Club of New York City was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day. The Directors are James M. Kelley. J.L. Bridgeford, Walter G. Phillips, Francis J.P. Smith, and William N. Search. The club is organized for social and benevolent purposes.

Work will begin to-day for the construction of 100 homes that the City and Suburban Homes Company intends to build in Brooklyn. This cluster of homes will lie between Ovington Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, and on both sides of Seventeenth Avenue. They will be known, collectively, as "Homewood."

PARIS, July 12. -- Pere Charmetant, Director General of the French Mission in the Levant, has received by way of the Caucasus and Tiflis a report prepared by a number of Armenia notables and Gregorian Bishops on the situation in Armenia.

Mrs. Fannie Belkaiser, or Blanchard, was yesterday arraigned before Magistrate Deuel, in Centre Street Police Court, on a charge of perjury. The perjury is alleged to have been committed during a hearing in the contest over the late W.L. Blanchard's will, Mrs. Belkaiser, who is colored, swearing that she was married to Blanchard in Monmouth, N.J., April 26, 1896.
ALBANY, July 12. -- The following is Justice Chester's decision in the Coal Trust matter in full:

The most interesting fact about an interesting interview with Mayor STRONG, reported in The Mail and Express by its correspondent at Richfield Springs, is the vigorous testimony the Mayor bears to the necessity of separating municipal government from partisan politics. His evidence could not be more direct or emphatic.

About 100 residents of Augusta, Ga., including some of the most prominent business men of that city, and their families, arrived in New York yesterday on the steamship Kansas City of the Savannah Line. Nearly all of them went to the Hotel Gerlach, in West Twenty-seventh Street, where special arrangements had been made for their accommodation.

BOSTON, July 12. -- Massana Mayeda, ex-Minister of Agriculture and Commerce of Japan, and President of the Society of Agricultural, Manufacturing, and Commercial industry of Japan, who is at present making a tour of inspection of this country, has arrived in this city from Washington, and visited the Boston Chamber of Commerce, where, by appointment, he had a long conference with the President, Wallace F. Robinson.

Detective William Boyle of the One Hundredth Street Police Station last night arrested James W. Tirro, who has been charged with robbing several up-town houses, to which he gained access by representing himself as an employe of the Consolidated Gas Company.

Children danced and romped merrily in the cool basements of several of the public school houses yesterday morning, and subsequently on the upper floors they engaged in a variety of object lessons for two or three hours. The character of the instruction was in each instance suited to the age of the pupil.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 12. -- Lightning struck the Young Men's Christian Association tent in the State camp this afternoon. One man, a Corporal of the Twenty-second Regiment, was killed, and nine other guardsmen were badly hurt.
ANNAPOLIS, July 12. -- These two orders were read at evening formation to-day on the United States ship Santee to the naval cadets of the fourth class, quartered on the ship:

QUIGG'S purged enrollment will not bear a moment's examination. He set out with the intention of striking off from the roll the names of dead men and those of obliging Tammany heelers with which it was charged and practically admitted that it had been overstuffed by the too zealous agents of Mr. PLATT.

LOUISVILLE, July 12. -- Judge Toney, in the Law and Equity Court, to-day, rendered a decision concerning $150,000 of bonds of the Louisville Southern Railroad Company of Kentucky. W.T. Grant, assignee of the Southern Contract Company, sought to recover the amount of these bonds from the stockholders of the Louisville Southern Railroad Company.
When the Minneapolis was at Gibraltar, Spain, a clipping from THE TIMES was placed upon our bulletin board, of which we have this to say:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- John Russell Young has not yet begun to develop his plans for organizing the Library of Congress under the law that took effect July 1, when he was sworn into office as Librarian of Congress. Before he was appointed the President said to him: "Mr. Young, I shall appoint you Librarian, to have full control of this great collection of the literature and art of the country.

While the case of Commissioner PARKER was still pending before the Mayor, THE TIMES urged that it did not really present the case against PARKER. An official who knew nothing of the matter except the charges and the testimony taken under them might very well think the case inadequate for removal.
ALBANY, July 12.--Gov. Black, in a decision rendered to-day refusing to remove Police Commissioner Parker of New York from office, says:...

With five exceptions, every State in the Union has been heard from favorably by the Secretary of the Merchants' Association of New York regarding the proposed trade excursions to this city in the Fall. The exceptions are excusable, for the silent States are a great ways off. They are Washington, Oregon, Wyoming, New Mexico, and Arizona, California sent greeting in a cordial note from Secretary J. Richard Freud of the Merchants' Association in San Francisco.

Charles Bertrand, whose true name is Griffis, but who has traveled under innumerable aliases, being known as Col. Hay, Lord Ashburton, C.C. Joy, and Charles Griffiths, and who was recently sentenced to ten years' penal servitude in the Central Criminal Court of London, is a well-known character to the New York police.

Three interviews given yesterday by representatives of three sections of the Democratic Party here are said to be significant of a common impulse or a quiet understanding in the direction of getting the party together for fights on State and municipal issues and allowing the National questions which have caused the split to drop out of sight, temporarily at least.

Tired, ill, and apparently hopeless, Mrs. Pauline Richter, a well-educated woman, a teacher by profession, a globe-trotter by choice, decided to end the struggle for existence by taking carbolic acid in Central Park yesterday afternoon. After taking the poison she became unconscious, but her groans attracted the attention of a number of little children to where she lay among the bushes between the lake and the east drive near Seventy-second Street.

Mrs. Augustus Nack and Martin Thorn, jointly indicted for conspiring to kill and killing William Guldensuppe, on June 25, were arraigned in Part I. of General Sessions before Judge Newburger yesterday to plead. There was a large crowd present. Every seat in the courtroom within and without the rails was occupied, and the prisoners walked to the bar through an aisle of men and women, whispering and pointing.

NEWPORT, July 12. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Schooner Columbia, owned by J. Judkins; schooner Glendevere, owned by Mr. Carpenter; schooner America, owned by Mr. Ames; schooner Clytie, owned by H.C. Ward; sloop Carmita, owned by W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.; sloop Modist, N.Y.Y.C.; steamer Duquesne, owned by Theodore Hostetter.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 12. -Mayor Strong was somewhat indisposed this afternoon, and declined to be interviewed regarding the Governor's refusal to dismiss Police Commissioner Parker. Mr. P. Bradlee Strong said that his father had dictated a dispatch to The Associated Press to the effect that Gov. Black had performed a public duty, and the people must acquiesce in the verdict.

The Los Angeles (Cal.) Evening Express gives appropriate prominence in its report of one day's happenings in that city to "le banquet classique" tendered by the polished and wealthy Populists of Los Angeles on the day of celebrating the anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence to Monsieur WILLIAM JENNINGS BRYAN, who was then in town.

DETROIT, July 12.--All fears of light attendance at the tenth convention of the National League of Republican Clubs were dispelled this evening by the arrival of big delegations from all directions. According to the registration there are already 1,000 delegates on hand, besides many other visitors.

John Larsen is a Norwegian and a fisherman of Gravesend. He was out in his eighteen-foot sloop when the squall of yesterday afternoon swooped over the bay, and Larsen and his boat came near being lost. It is doubtful which he prizes the most.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- President McKinley's message to Congress, requesting authority to appoint a Currency Commission, said to have been ready last week and promised with some positiveness for to-day, is still at the White House, and this evening there is no intimation that it is to go to Congress to-morrow.

The first of a series of trial races to determine the challenger for the international small yacht trophy, to be sailed for in Bay St. Louis, near Montreal, was sailed yesterday over a triangular course of six miles, twice around, in Long Island Sound off Oyster Bay, L.I. The cup was won last year from the American twenty-footer El Heirie, designed by C.H. Crane, by the Canadian Glencairn, designed by Diggan.

The Executive Committee representing the depositors of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn yesterday issued their fourth statement. The last one was given out on Dec. 3, 1893. The latest statement reports that dividends to the amount of 88 per cent. have been secured. Continuing, the statement says:

Judge Russell of the Supreme Court yesterday appointed Frank Sullivan Smith of 54 Wall Street receiver of the property in this State of the Worcester Cycle Manufacturing Company, whose salesrooms are at 17 Murray Street and 461 and 463 Boulevard, and factories at Middletown, Conn., and Worcester, Mass., on the application of John Byrne, who is a creditor for $5,481, and owns two shares of stock in the company.

WHEELING, West Va., July 12. -- A great change has come over the miners of this State, and the operators do not disguise their intention to do their best to keep the organizers from doing effective work. Meetings of miners were held at Thacker, Elkhorn, and Bluefield last evening. No definite action was taken, though sympathy for the strike was expressed.

Ruland Whiting have sold for Mandelbaum Lewine to Francis L. Glover, for $45,000, the four-story brick building, with store, 98 John Street, 25.6 by 90. In part payment, $20,000, the buyer gives the four-story and basement brownstone-front dwelling, 9 Livingston Place, southeast corner of Sixteenth Street, 17.3 by 84.

CINCINNATI, July 12. -- The New Yorks defeated the Reds in a fine game here today by bunching Their hits. Rusie pitched fine ball and had good support. The New Yorks scored three runs in the fourth inning on scratch hits and were never again headed. Score:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The tariff conferrees have struck some snags in their work. The minor matters were easily adjusted, but on all important features there has been no agreement, and the outlook to-day was that several reports would have to be made before an adjustment could be reached.

Comparatively few of our citizens adequately appreciate the arboreal attractions of our convenient and peerless Park. Nowhere is there a finer collection of noble trees. We have at least a dozen kinds of maples, from the showy Norway to the lovely little Japanese, all of them conspicuously and correctly labeled.

After further conferences with the political guides of his party the President has again postponed sending in his message about the currency. The President abdicates in favor of the politicians. The tariff has the right of way, the currency can wait.

DELHI, N.Y., July 12. -- Edwin J. Betts, a farmer, living near this village, and his wife were killed by lightning last night while standing beneath a tree where they were seeking shelter from the rain.

LONDON, July 12. -- A conference was held at the Foreign Office to-day between Senator Wolcott, former Vice President Stevenson, and Gen. Paine, the members of the United States Bimetallic Commission, and Ambassador Hay and Lord Salisbury, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chancellor of the Exchequer; Mr. Arthur Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury, and Lord George Hamilton, Secretary of State for India.

After a long incubation Gov. BLACK has finally hatched out the revised civil service rules in accordance with his absurd law of last session. From the point of view of the public service they are ridiculous, or worse. If they are obeyed by intelligent and faithful officials, they will, by twice the expenditure of time and effort, result in getting as good civil servants as were got under the old law.

Sugar Trust stock furnished more of a sensation for Wall Street yesterday than the Street has known for some time. The stocks sold up to 135 1/8, higher than ever before in its history. Sugar's previous high-water mark was made Feb. 6, 1893, when it reached 134 3/4.
" Are your gas bills any less than they used to be?"

BATAVIA, July 12. -- When the trial of Howard C. Benham for the murder of his wife was resumed to-day the cross-examination of Frank Klein, Benham's coachman, was at once proceeded with. Witness was asked: "On either occasion when Mrs. Benham was ill or when she died, did Benham assist her in any way?"

Dr. Charles A. Tinker of Harlem was yesterday arrested on a judgment obtained against him for $50,653 by Ferdinand B. Colwell, a broker, for alienating the affections of his wife. Over a year ago Colwell secured a divorce, which was later set aside on appeal. He then sued Tinker for $50,000 for alienating the affections of his wife, and a jury gave him a verdict for the full amount, with costs.
JAMAICA, L.I., July 12. -- This village, by an election held to-day, resolved to issue $200,000 more bonds.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The Senate to-day rejected the nomination of Lieut. Col. H.E. Noyes, Second Cavalry, to be a Colonel.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The representatives of the two Houses of Congress in the conference on the Tariff bill spent a busy day, devoted for the most part to work in the conference room. There were occasional consultations with other Senators or members of the House upon points at issue, but these were brief, so that comparatively little information as to the progress made found its way to outsiders.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Rarely in the history of the Navy Department has a boat offered for acceptance received such severe criticism from the Inspection Board as the little torpedo boat Foote, built by the Columbian Iron Works, has received in a report just made public.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 13. -- At the meeting of the Board of Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company to-day the resignation of President Elisha P. Wilbur was accepted. Alfred Walter, President of the Delaware, Susquehanna and Schuylkill Railroad, was elected to succeed Mr. Wilbur as President of the company.

HAVANA, July 13, (via Key West, Fla.) -- The Avisador Comercial, a political and commercial daily, in a leading editorial article, makes a bitter attack upon United States Consul General Lee on account of his report to the Government at Washington on the Ruiz ease. The paper says:

On Dec. 31, 1894, the United States Civil Service Commission, of which THEODORE ROOSEVELT and CHARLES LYMAN, Republicans, were a majority, wrote as follows to the President regarding the proposition to put the Collectors of Internal Revenue under the merit system:

Liliuokalani, former Queen of Hawaii, has settled down in a hotel here into, a sort of literary retirement. There she devotes herself to composing Hawaiian melodies and songs, and to collecting material for her eventful autobiography.

-- The prevalent idea that American man-o'-war's-man is the typical ignorant and rough sailor of the merchant marine occasionally receives a shock which shakes, but for some reason does not shatter, it. It is quite true that when Jack gets liberty after a considerable term of imprisonment at hard labor within the steel walls of a warship, he sometimes swallows more grog than is good for him and gets into trouble.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- The Atlantic League magnates, held a meeting at the Park House last night, and all minor difficulties and differences were straightened out satisfactorily. Every club in the league was represented. Applications were received from New Haven, Wilmington, Portsmouth, Va., and Bridgeport.

Justice CHESTER goes to the very heart of the so-called anti-trust law in his decision in the coal company's case. Though he turns the prosecution out of court on points relating to procedure, those points are vital. They are decided on two Constitutional principles of the highest importance, and the violation of these principles in the Lexow act was of the very essence of the unjust and mischievous purpose of the law.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 13. -- Convict William Kennedy, a," lifer" in the prison north of here, reached Indianapolis this morning unattended by a guard, and, after a personal conference with the Governor, the latter paroled him on condition that he should lead an honorable life and find employment as soon as his health permitted.
LONDON, July 13. -- The Parliamentary South Africa Commission that has been inquiring into the Transvaal raid has agreed upon its report.

If surface indications count for anything, yesterday's market was the beginning of new activity and new strength in securities. Over 300,000 shares were dealt in, and, with few exceptions, advances were scored throughout the list. Reaction talk continues, but gets small attention. Important operators who have been trying to help along traders trying to produce a setback are now inclined to give up the experiment.

The remains of Corp. J.J. McDonnell of Company A, Twenty-second Regiment, who was killed last night in the State Camp at Peekskill by a bolt of lightning, arrived at the Grand Central Station at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

The heavy weather of Monday was too much for several of the twenty-footers, and five of them were unable to race yesterday. This fact, together with the inclement weather, caused a postponement. The owners of the small boats, in spite of the weather, were hard at work getting ready for the next contest, which will be sailed to-day.

Messrs. Belmont and Keene, Chairman and Vice Chairman of The Jockey Club, had a secret and prolonged session with Messrs. Bradford, Miller, and Hitchcock, who had acted as Stewards at the recent meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday afternoon, while the racing was in progress.

Three young highwaymen who had been waiting in the shadow of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, on Thirty-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, shortly after midnight this morning, choked a woman and stole her pocketbook, containing 40 cents. She was Mrs. Elizabeth Ketchum and at the time of the attack was on her way to the Long Island Railroad Ferry.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Consideration of the Deficiency Appropriation bill was resumed in the Senate to-day. The question of armor plate for new battleships led to considerable discussion. The bill provided a total appropriation of $3,410,725 for armor for the three battleships authorized in 1896 and limited the cost per ton to $425.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 6. -- As I cabled to The Associated Press yesterday, twelve Cubans, the last survivors of an insurgent camp in the district of Camaguey, reached Rio Nuevo, a little port on the north side of the island, a few days before, in an open boat.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 13. -- Delancey McIntyre, President of the First National Bank of Batavia, was the first witness in the trial of Howard C. Benham for wife murder, this morning. He was asked the condition of the defendant's account, but the question was objected to and the objection was sustained.

It is really a distinct triumph for justice that a committee of the House of Commons should have been brought to the point of a direct and emphatic censure of CECIL RHODES. The South Africa Chartered Company has exerted in the closing years of the nineteenth century as great a political and social influence in London as during the closing years of the eighteenth was exerted by the British East India Company.

Henry Walsh has, sold to Henry G. Gabay, for $105,000, the old two-story tenements, 143, 145, and 147 Franklin Street, 68.10 by 100 by 75 by 71. The old buildings will be removed and a large business structure erected on the plot.
A fire that resulted in the death of two children and the injury of four adult persons and two young girls, occurred at 112 and 114 Coles Street, Jersey City, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

Mrs. Eugenia Reineman was the star witness for the prosecution when the examination of the four alleged Costa Rican counterfeiters, Louis Hanoman, Mrs. Betsy Chevin, Frederica Mora, and Herman Dohn, was resumed yesterday before UnitedStates Commissioner Shields. She was arrested and indicted several weeks ago, with Ricardo de Requesens, who owns the Spanish-American printing establishment at 126 Maiden Lane.

Neither Martin Thorn nor Mrs. Nack was in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for examination on the charge of killing William Guldensuppe. Magistrate Flammer decided last week that the indictment found by the Grand Jury did not take the case out of his jurisdiction, and instructed the Assistant District Attorney, and counsel for. Mrs. Nack to submit briefs.

WASHINGTON, July 13.. -- The House Republicans are working themselves into a fever over the reporst of a compromise agreement having been reached on sugar but the tafiff conference committee of of basis tantamount to the acceptance of the Senate schedule. The House adjourned in about towminutes to-day but two-thirds of the Republicans remained in their seats and collected in excited groups and discussed the all-absorbing tehene--sugar.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13. -- President Ratchford of the United Mine Workers of America is greatly pleased with the campaign in West Virginia, and has just perfected plans for pushing the battle through, it having been decided that West Virginia holds the key to the situation.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 13. -- The funeral train bearing the body of Tennessee's distinguished Senator, Isham G. Harris, arrived in this city at 7:30 o'clock this morning.

While it is to be regretted, we are, nevertheless, under a system of controlment. This is a sad commentary on a high conception of what we claim as self-government. We may submit to the one, but what the people would consent to is quite another matter. This suggests the inquiry: Why is it that our system of rule does not sufficiently comprehend our necessities?
NEWARK, July 13. -- The Endicott divorce trial was resumed this morning. The majority of the spectators were women.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 13. -- Within forty-eight hours developments of a very definite character are expected to take place in the West Virginia coal fields. A leading operator received a long-distance telephone message to-day, stating that nine organizers had just left Pittsburg for the fields.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 13. -- Anything like a forecast of the winners during the three days' racing which begins to-morrow would be exceedingly difficult, for the races are the most open in the matter of entries that have been planned here for years.

Beginning with Monday, Oct 11, three days are to be set apart at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition for the people of New York. The 11th is to be "Brooklyn Day," the 12th "New York State Day," and the 13th "New York City Day." The Mine is so chosen as to make a visit to Nashville enjoyable, and the attendance should be large.

Keep up the fight against the fraudulent monopolistic gas companies. If they would only rob one in the gentlemanly manner of a Claude Duval it would not be so bad, but their ways are those of a Bill Sykes.

That was an extraordinary ruling made by Judge VAN WYCK in the City Court Chambers, in regard to the actionable quality of the word "spy" when used as a term of reproach, but unquestionably it was good law. A slander suit is not often brought on precisely that ground. In this case the plaintiff, who has a picturesquely Polish name, demands $10,000 damages for combined slander and assault.

At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon Max Danz of 166 East One Hundred and Seventh Street stopped his horse and wagon at the corner of Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street to feed the animal some oats. He took off the bridle and attached the nosebag, and half an hour later proceeded to hitch up.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 13. -- The Hempstead Town Board, at a meeting last evening, fixed the boundary of Greater New York so far as the town of Hempstead is concerned. Part of the town is to be included in Greater New York. Previous action was rescinded. The board yesterday decided that the boundary would be determined by the location of the inlet at the time the bill was signed and became a law.

PITTSBURG, July 13. -- There is a lull in the miners' strike in this district, attributable to the fact that nearly every mine in the district is idle. To keep up the enthusiasm and prevent the strikers from becoming lukewarm in the cause, the officials have arranged for a series of meetings in different sections every day.

Interest in the work of the Merchants' Association is increasing at home as well as in remote parts of the country. John C. Juhring of the firm of Francis H. Leggett Co., and a Director of the new association, has been instrumental in adding a large number of names to the resident membership list. He said yesterday:

LONDON, July 13. -- L.H. Davies; the Canadian Minister of Marine, who was summoned to London in connection with the Bering Sea seal controversy and the Belgian and German trade treaties, said to the correspondent of The Associated Press to-day:

ORANGE, N.J., July 13. -- The Common Council last night refused to turn over to the Essex County Park Commission the care, custody, and control of Park and Central Avenues, as had been requested by the latter body some time ago, and as a result discussion of the matter is hot to-day, charges and counter-charges, of trolley road influence being made.

A mechanic, doing daily labor with his hands, we presume, but also working to good purpose with his head, has solved a problem which was the despair of some of the best business men and some of the ablest public officials of the city. Only a week or two ago the Broadway cable railroad curve at Fourteenth Street was the theme of discussion which was at once excited and pessimistic.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July13. -- Nicholas C. Creede, millionaire mine owner, after whom the town of Creede, Col., is named, committed suicide with morphine last evening at his home, in this city, because his wife, from whom he had separated, insisted upon renewing their married relations.

Commissioner Willis of Brooklyn was put into a quandary when the Common Council voted for a bond issue of $100,000 for the building of a by-pass pipe around Ridgewood Reservoir. The Commissioner asked to have certain unexpended balances transferred, so that he could get $100,000 immediately for the work, but the Council did not see it that way, and preferred the bond issue to the shifting of the ready money.

It is very interesting to read the statement of chief engineer of the Consolidated Gas Company. He says that since the reduction of the price of gas by the act of the Legislature there has been no decrease in the illuminating power of the gas supplied. According to another authority, the various gas companies supply 10,500,000,000 feet of gas a year.

At full speed Fire Engine No. 1, the driver, Thomas Kelly, and the three horses dashed into a trench at the corner of Thirtieth Street and Fifth Avenue at midnight last night. As the engine went over one of the horses was wedged under the engine, while, singularly enough, the driver, though pinned down and strapped to his seat, was not too badly injured to give directions for his own rescue.

Much stress has been laid by the Audubon Societies of the State of New York upon the wearing of birds, bird wings, and plumage, and in their efforts to discourage the wearing of such millinery trimming they have practically overreached themselves. Chapter 699 of the Laws of 1897, which was signed by the Governor May 22, simply refers to the protection of wild birds within the domain of the State of New York.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The Soo Line has made another cut in eastbound rates from Minneapolis and St. Paul. The new reduction is in rates to Toronto. All the Western roads had agreed on a rate of one fare -- $28 -- for the round trip for the meeting of the Epworth League, which is being held in Toronto.

CONVENTION HALL, DETROIT, Mich., July 13. -- The tenth annual convention of the National League of Republican Clubs was called to order this morning. Life-sized portraits of President McKinley, James G. Blaine, Washington, and Lincoln were among the decorations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 13. -- The State Convention of the National Democrats of Kentucky will be called to order at 2 P.M. to-morrow by Secretary Carroll, State Chairman Davie being in Europe. J.C. Sims of Bowling Green will be temporary Chairman, while ex-Secretary John G. Carlisle will be permanent Chairman.

Mr. A. Oppenheim, Vice President of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company, who is at present in New York, talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the prospects for the crops and for general business throughout the West and for the future earnings of the Granger railroads.

CINCINNATI, July 13. -- The Giants lost to Cincinnati in a close and exciting game to-day. Both teams played snappy ball. The Reds were unable to hit Seymour until the fourth inning, when they touched him up for five singles and a triple, and four runs was the result. Attendance, 4,500. Score:

The rain that fell to the extent of an inch and three-quarters in this section of the country yesterday supplied a long felt want to agriculturists. To the city it brought a humidity averaging close up to the limit of 100 per cent., which, in fact, at times it reached.

Decker, Howell Co., the well-known Stock Exchange firm of 44 Broadway and 45 New Street, were caught as bears in the "rocketing" of Sugar on Monday, when the certificates of the American Sugar Refining Company advanced nearly 6 points. Before the day closed papers had been drawn up by Sullivan Cromwell of 45 Wall Street for an assignment to Alanson Fisher, Jr., once cashier of the firm.
CHESTER, Mass., July 14. -- A bad washout occurred near here early this morning, which effectually blocked both tracks of the Boston and Albany Railroad. The washout is about 135 feet in length.

TACOMA, Washington, July 14. -- A great slump has taken place in the tea markets in Japan and China since the fast steamer sailed that could land tea on this coast before July 1, when the new tariff was expected to go into effect.

Representative DINGLEY and Senator ALDRICH, and their associates who are struggling with the Tariff bill, do not appear to derive any pleasure from the contemplation of the Treasury report for April that shows that we exported during the ten months ending with April $224,023,006 in manufactured goods, as compared with $184,574,692 in the corresponding period of the former year.

-- A timely and just letter from a resident Frenchman appeared in last week's Homo Journal. The gentleman very naturally objected to the wide public forgetfulness of the services rendered by LAFAYETTE and France to the United States in the war for independence. The writer of the letter knows that the name of LAFAYETTE is loved by all Americans, but he calls attention to a few facts which are generally forgotten.

We can hardly claim the members of the Winnipeg Rowing Club as representatives of our National oarsmanship, but they belong to this side of the Atlantic, and, together with Dr. W.S. MCDOWELL of the Delaware Boat Club of Chicago, they took a large share of the honors in the trial heats of the Henley Regatta yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14. -- The State Convention of the National Democratic Party to nominate a candidate for the Clerk of the Court of Appeals assembled at 2 o'clock this afternoon in Music Hall in this city. The nomination was given by unanimous vote to James R. Hindman of Adair County.

CONVENTION HALL, DETROIT, Mich., July 14. -- In to-day's session of the convention of the National League of Republican Clubs Col. Leonard J. Crawford was elected President of the league, and the committee on place and time of the next meeting selected Omaha.
WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 14. -- The announcement of the death of Baron Camoys to-day cast a shadow over the regatta. He was an enthusiastic patron of high-class sport, and greatly in favor among rowing men. His home at Stonor, only a short distance from the regatta course, was the home of university oarsmen.

Ex-President of the New York Stock Exchange James D. Smith talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the stock market outlook. Mr. Smith expects to see much higher prices in Wall Street, and believes that, although there is a possibility of a slight decline after the passage of the Tariff bill, stocks will be very much higher at the end of the year than at present. Mr. Smith said yesterday:

Mrs. Fannie W. Korn, who on May 5, 1893, shot and killed her daughter, Florence, six years old, and wounded her son, Edwin, eleven years old, and who was subsequently declared insane by a jury in the Court of General Sessions and sent to the Matteawan Asylum for the Criminal Insane, was arrested in West Forty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon as a fugitive from justice.

There was so little of interest in the racing at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday that even the speculators who fared well on the results of the several events could find nothing to enthuse over. The racing was in the fiercest kind of a storm, with the wind howling a gale through the open iron grand stand, and in most cases the winners floundered home in the sea of mud, winning easily.

HAVANA, July 14. -- A dispatch from Cienfuegos to the authorities here says the Governor of Santiago de Cuba has received information from a private source to the effect that epidemic diseases are playing sad havoc with insurgent forces in the eastern districts. Calixto Garcia, Rabi, Lora, and nearly all of the more prominent insurgent leaders are reported ill, according to the Governor's informant, and the forces lack competent physicians and medicines.

BALTIMORE, July 14. -- It is asserted here to-day that J.P. Morgan Co. and Speyer Co. of New York are negotiating with a view of agreeing upon a plan looking to the early reorganization of the Baltimore and Ohio Railway system.

A report from Capt. Schmittberger of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Precinct, read at yesterday's meeting of the Police Commissioners, brought up the vexed question of obtaining evidence against the keepers of disorderly houses. Capt. Schmittberger sent a list of twenty-five alleged disorderly houses in his precinct, and said he could not suppress them because he has no money with which to secure evidence.

MATTEAWAN, July 14. -- The Melzingah dams, which supply Fishkill Landing and Matteawan with water, burst at 2:30 o'clock this morning. The waters rushed down the mountain, following the old bed of the Melzingah Brook. Two bridges were swept away. The great volume of water struck the little settlement occupied by the laborers of Frank Timoney's brick yard at Dutchess Junction.
WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations agreed to-day to report a resolution for The ratification of the Hawaiian annexation treaty without amendment.

LONDON, July 14. -- The Evening Standard regards the situation in Southeastern Europe as extremely grave, and says there is no doubt that, unless appearances are most deceptive, hostilities between Turkey and Greece will shortly be renewed.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 14. -- The attachment suit of Joseph Starr against Cashier Chew of the Union Bank and Philip C. Dunford, President of the Fisher's Island Brick Works, has caused no little talk and unpleasantness here. Six Boston gentlemen are also involved in the suit. One hundred thousand is the amount claimed as damages.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14. -- The Gold Democratic State Convention to-day adopted the following resolutions:

It is reported, according to London dispatches, that the famous Gainsborough masterpiece; a portrait of the Duchess of Devonshire, which was stolen nearly nineteen years ago, is shortly to be recovered from a Belgian convict who was recently released from prison.

After Oregon had been counted for HAYES by the Electoral Commission of 1877, JEREMIAH S. BLACK, of counsel for TILDEN, told his associates that as it was evident that the tribunal would decide against them at every point, he would like to "say his say." Agreeing with him that freedom of speech could not endanger a cause already lost, his associates consented to his freeing his mind, which he did in a memorable speech.
Will you kindly answer for me the following questions?

City Works Commissioner Willis of Brooklyn has decided to award the contract for building the by-pass pipe around Ridgewood Reservoir to Michael J. Dady, as the lowest bidder. Mr. Dady's bid is $55,302.50, nearly $6,000 under the next lowest bidder. The award is dependent upon the passage of an ordinance by the Board of Aldermen authorizing a transfer of $100,060 for the work.

Three persons, one a Catholic priest, were seriously burned by an explosion of gas yesterday afternoon in the basement of the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary, at Pompei, on Sullivan Street, near West Third Street. The injured are:

William C. Whitney, former Secretary of the Navy, entertained about a dozen men at dinner last night at the Metropolitan Club. The dinner was served in a retired room on the third floor, and the servants of the club had strict orders not to send up cards or visitors during the evening.

Blair Crouse, lawyers, of Jersey City, have been retained by William F. Kidder to bring suit to set aside certain transfers of land in Bergen County, N.J., made by the heirs of Theodore Houston, formerly of this city.

Momo, the twenty-footer owned by A.W. Durkee and J.H. Crane, won the trial race off Oyster Bay yesterday by six seconds. The Skate, owned by Irving Cox, was the second boat. The Momo really won the race twice over, and the close proximity of the Skate at the finish was due to a good piece of luck.

The statement of Mr. DE ARMITT, which we published yesterday morning, confirms the opinion we have already expressed that the most serious difficulty in the coal trade is the lack of effective organization among the operators. Mr. DE ARMITT, whose men have not gone out, said:

LONDON, July 14. -- Lady Selina Scott, better known as Lady "Tina," Scott, mother-in-law of John Francis, Earl Russell, who in January last pleaded guilty at the Old Bailey to the charge of criminal libeling the Earl in conjunction with John Cockerton, an engineer, and William Aylett, a valet, and was sentenced to eight months' imprisonment in Holloway Jail, will be released to-morrow.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., July 14. -- Official advices state that a band of insurgents approached Gibara on the night of July 6 and placed a dynamite bomb upon the railroad track. They then retired and lay in wait until 7 o'clock the next morning, when the bomb was exploded by an electrical device, wrecking an engine and one car.
WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Senator Davis, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, to-day reported from that committee the following joint resolution:

MATTEAWAN, July 14. -- Coroner H.B. Bevier of this place, who will to-morrow begin an inquest upon the bodies of the victims of this morning's flood at Dutchess Junction, to-night made the following statement:

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 14. -- Amid beautiful weather, although a stiff wind blew at intervals from the Berkshire shore, the Henley regatta of 1897 began to-day. The crowd on the banks was not so large or so demonstrative as usual. But the celebrated stretch of a mile and a quarter just below Henley Bridge, which is the course of the regatta, was the scene of some admirable racing.

PITTSBURG, July 14. -- The prospect for a settlement of the miners' strike is brighter to-night than at any time since the struggle began, and both sides are almost ready to count on a resumption of work in the near future.

LONDON, July 15. -- The Times this morning says there is reason to believe that the Duke of Connaught will not succeed Gen. Sir Redvers Henry Buller as Adjutant General. Gen. Buller's successor has not yet been appointed, but it is believed that he will be Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood.

The swift mind of our neighbor The Sun divides itself upon the burning questions of the day with a celerity that would have made ULYSSES envious. It was in its issue of yesterday that it rebuked an up-country Democratic contemporary for the impudent suggestion that the Democrats would do better to make the fight this Fall, not upon last year's National issues, but upon the bad record of the Republican Legislature.

BOSTON, July 14. -- Judge Morton, in the Suffolk Supreme Court, to-day withdrew from hearing a case. His action, he explained, was due to the unprofessional conduct of counsel in making an undue reference to the Judge in the Insolvency Court and in circulars. Lawyer Southard used the name of the Judge as one of the persons who knew his client, James E. Windward of Fall River, which also is the home of the Judge.
In presenting, for the consideration of out-of-town merchants, facts regarding the advantages of New York as a place to visit in the Summer and Fall, the Merchants' Association says:

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Miss Mattie R. Tyler, granddaughter of the former President of the United States, was to-day appointed Postmistress at Courtland, Va. The selection ends a long contest, in which Miss Tyler came here and presented her claims in person to Postmaster General Gary and Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow.

PARIS, July 14. -- The usual celebrations in honor of the Fourteenth of July (anniversary of the fall of the Bastile) and the events commemorated to-day passed off gayly. Magnificent weather prevailed throughout France.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 14. -- Important Ministerial councils were held Sunday and Monday, at which an indemnity of f6,000,000 was agreed upon as the extreme limit of Turkish concession. This agreement was sanctioned by an imperial trade. The councils further prepared a report stigmatizing the concert of Europe as "a league of Cross against Crescent."

George R. Bidwell began his official duties as Collector of the Port of New York at the opening of business hours yesterday. His first act was to reappoint Joseph James Couch Special Deputy Collector. Afterward he renominated Samuel W. Thompson as Acting Disbursing Officer. Flowers were sent to the new Collector, among them a horseshoe from the Nineteenth Assembly District Republican Club and a steamship from Orin C. Frost.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Davis, (Rep., Minn.,) from the Committee on Foreign Relations, presented a report on the resolution recently introduced by Mr. Berry (Dem., Ark.,) requesting the President to demand the release of the Competitor prisoners held by the Spanish authorities.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 14. -- The rainstorm which has prevailed since Monday afternoon has been almost unprecedented in violence for this time of the year, Along the line of the Maine Central numerous washouts have prevented the running of through trains, while all traffic on the White Mountain Division of the Boston and Maine is at a standstill.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The conferrees on the Tariff bill remained in session until 6 o'clock to-night, and made a little progress with the work before them. There are numerous questions of difference, according to the members of the conference, but they all refuse to discuss these matters, even with other Senators and members.

LONDON, July 14. -- The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council has refused leave to appeal from the judgment entered at Yokohama on Feb. 1, sentencing to death Mrs. Carew, convicted of poisoning her husband, Walter Raymond Hallowell Carew, Secretary of the Yokohama United Club, which was subsequently commuted by the British Minister to Japan, Sir E.M. Satow, to imprisonment for life.

There are lively times in the auction room of the conference committee on the tariff. These are, of course, confined to the majority members. The minority members have not yet been "called in," and will not be until prices and terms on all the chief seeds in stock have been arranged.

The Bradley Currier Company has sold the vacant plot at the southeast corner of Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, having a frontage of 100.11 feet on the avenue and 75 feet on the street. The buyer will improve the property by the erection of flats with stores.
The Long Branch bicycle parade and carnival will be held Saturday afternoon. From present indications it is expected that 15,000 wheelmen will participate in the parade and festivities.

I have read with interest your views as to annexation of Hawaii. Having spent many years in the South Seas, and been from time to time in Hawaii, I know of nothing sadder than the extinction of a fine race and the aggrandizement of those who went there nominally to convert them, and of their immediate descendants.
The spectacle presented by the Secretary of the Interior these days is not an agreeable one for those who would like to respect him.

PORTLAND, Me., July 14. -- The unprecedented gale of Tuesday continued with increased fury to-day. None of the coastwise steamers have left the harbor for two days. The harbor is full of small craft and yachts anchored inside the breakwater.

LONDON, July 14. -- Ambassador Hay, accompanied by Messrs. White and Carter, the First and Second Secretaries of Legation, paid a formal call at the French Embassy to-day in honor of the 14th of July.

Senator HALE made a serious mistake in opposing Mr. BUTLER'S amendment to the General Deficiency Appropriation bill limiting the cost of battleship armor to $300 a ton, instead of $425 a ton, as reported in the bill. The Senate agreed with Mr. BUTLER in thinking that $300 a ton was enough. Probably it is. Armor

The funeral services of Alexander Fletcher were held last night at the family residence, 280 Montgomery Street, Jersey City. They were conducted by the Rev. Henry C. Cronin, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church, of which deceased was a member, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Fisher, a former pastor, who had been Mr. Fletcher's lifelong friend.

LONDON, July 15. -- B.F. Hawksley, Counsel for Cecil Rhodes in the South Africa investigation, in the course of an interview with a representative of The Associated Press to-day, said he believed that nothing would come of the Investigating Committee's report. He was astonished that Cecil Rhodes should have been condemned for deceiving his subordinates by leading them to suppose that his plans were approved by his superiors.

-- The London Referee is a sporting paper, and may not be accepted in Grub Street as an authority on the Queen's English. It is to be hoped that it is not, for it is written in a slovenly, Cheapside style of colloquial banter which would not be regarded as "good form" even in one of our freak contemporaries.

BOSTON, July 15. -- While the body of Miss Edith C. Ward, who died at the home of Mrs. Dr. Clara Leach Austin in Allston last Tuesday, was being prepared to-day, in accordance with the young woman's alleged wishes, for cremation, an order from the police to hold the body until an autopsy could be performed was received by the undertaker.

The same indecent haste and secrecy that marked the framing of the Hawaiian annexation treaty marks its treatment by the Senate committee. That committee, by a vote of 5 in 7 of the 11 members, has reported the scheme to the Senate.

LONDON, July 15. -- While among the general public here the tone of Secretary Sherman's letter to Ambassador Hay regarding the Bering Sea seal regulations is greatly resented, the correspondent of The Associated Press is in a position to say that, Whatever criticism the British Government may have to make on the phraseology of the communication, the letter has not in any way affected unfavorably the negotiations which Col. Hay has been conducting.

The New York Yacht Club cracks will have a number of special cups to race for on their Summer cruise this year. Commodore J. Pierpont Morgan has offered four cups of the value of $5,000. L. Cass Ledyard, August Belmont, and E.M. Brown have supplemented this with other cups, while the Regatta Committee has offered cups for a race by schooners and single stickers from Saddle Back Ledge Rock to Bar Harbor.

Entry blanks for the midsummer meeting at Fleetwood were issued yesterday. Six purses of $300 each are offered for 2:18, 2:24, and 2:50 trotters and 2:12, 2:19, and 2:40 pacers. Rules of the National Trotting Association will govern. The entrance fee is 5 per cent., with 5 per cent. additional from money winners.

The Immigration Bureau made an astonishing discovery yesterday when a Boyish-looking second-cabin passenger of the steamship Seguaranca, which arrived Tuesday night, who was booked as Alyanovro Velos of Vera Cruz, appeared for examination.

The new Collector begins with excellent promises. "I shall," said Mr. BIDWELL to a reporter for THE TIMES, "conduct the business of the Custom House as if it were a mercantile or banking business in which I had a personal interest. I believe in civil service rules and shall not make wholesale removals.

BERLIN, July 15. -- A fire broke out last night in a large building on the Hausvoigtoi-platz, the centre of the dress and mantle trade, causing a loss of between 6,000,000 ($1,440,000) and 7,000,000 ($1,680,000) marks. The firms of Fraenckel and Bachor Loon were the chief sufferers. The goods destroyed represented large American orders.

The first marriage ceremony to be performed in the Criminal Court Building took place there yesterday, the contracting parties being Isaac Goldstein, aged nineteen, of 82 Ludlow Street, and Ida Greenberg, aged fifteen, of 42 Allen Street. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Isaac Cohen of 57 Mott Street, and is the culmination of an east side romance.

Each succeeding day increases the prospect of an unusually lively Fall trade in New York.
