Assurances already received by the Merchants' Association indicate visits from several hundred out-of-town merchants who have never before been in this city. Many of these promised visits come from remote districts in the South and West, and in each instance the reduced railroad rate is the effective force in bringing the people.

BOSTON, July 15. -- Mrs. Stevenson, mother of the missing girl, to-day received word from Ireland that Grace had not gone to her uncle in Belfast, as was reported. She also received the following letter, which she and the rest of the family regard as an impudent fraud:

The romances of Mr. GUY BOOTHBY are not literature, but they frequently make the blood tingle. His favorite locale is Southern or Southeastern Asia with the islands and seas thereto pertaining. Mongolian persons of tremendous prowess, profound learning, and terrible depravity are favorites with him.

The District Attorney's office is busily engaged preparing the ease against Mrs. Nack and Thorn, accused of murdering and dismembering William Guldensuppe, so that if Judge Newburger dismisses the indictment against them on the demurrers raised, another indictment can be found. It is not yet finally decided where the trial will take place.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 15. -- The New York State Bankers' Association began its fourth annual convention here to-day. The session was opened with prayer by the Rev. T.F. Chambers, and an address of welcome was made by Village President Knapp.

Already we have information that Mr. SHERMAN'S rude blurting out of the truth about the behavior of Great Britain in the matter of the seals has had its natural effect. The London press concentrates its attention upon the blustering tone of the dispatch, and The London Graphic amiably observes: "Our experience of the incurably bad manners of American diplomacy renders it unnecessary to regard Secretary SHERMAN'S explosion seriously."

The head of a well-known Broadway commission house yesterday made the statement that in the past five weeks his firm had purchased for customers, who are a part of what Wall Street calls the public, stocks, such as Northwest, St. Paul, Burlington, New York Central, , to the value of over $1,500,000.

READING, Penn., July 15. -- Reuben Hunsicker, a retired farmer in Lynn Township, Lehigh County, has decided to divide his personal property among his relatives, leaving his real estate to be sold or divided after his death. He is eighty-six years of age, was paralyzed about two years ago, and has been helpless ever since.

The efforts of the Merchants' Association of New York to induce out-of-town buyers to visit this market are attracting much attention among the wholesale dealers of the West. While they concede that these efforts will result in an increase of business for the New York merchants, they do not apprehend any decrease in their own trade.

The disappearance of Isaac Coates, collector of the Union Free School at Mariners' Harbor, and sexton of the First Reformed Church at Port Richmond, S.I., remains a mystery. Nothing has been learned of the missing man since last Saturday, when he left his home at Mariners' Harbor to attend to his duties at the church.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The monthly statement of the exports and imports of the United States, issued to-day by the Bureau of Statistics, makes a remarkable showing. Never before in the history of the country have the exports of merchandise reached so high a figure as during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, nor has the excess of exports over imports ever been so large.
HENLEY-ON-THE-THAMES, July 15. -- The second day of the regatta witnessed more victories for the American rowers.

We observe that some of our contemporaries show some excitement about a casual remark of The London Globe to the effect that the Japanese Navy could blow the American Navy out of water. The London Globe, so far as we know, carries no weight in its most deliberate statements. This particular statement, however, cannot have been deliberate.

Mayor Hoos of Jersey City on Wednesday night sent to the Board of Finance a communication complaining of past extravagance in city expenditures. He called attention to a recent report of the City Controller showing that the city debt was greater by $777,917.23 on Dec. 1, 1896, than it was on Dec. 1, 1892.
Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold for Henry W. Schloman, to Meyer Hecht, for about $45,000, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 49 West Eighty-seventh Street, 21 by 60 by 102.

BOSTON, July 15. -- Under the most favorable weather conditions to-day the new revenue cutter Daniel Manning proved herself to be a valuable addition to the revenue marine by making an average of nearly seventeen knots an hour in four-hour speed test under forced draught, in Massachusetts Bay.
The work of the Bureau of Statistics, under its able and accomplished chief, Mr. WORTHINGTON C. FORD, has never been more valuable than during the extraordinary session of Congress.

In respect of his slyness and shrewdness the Sultan represents the popular notion of the "coon," insulting to that animal as would be any comparison in point of moral character. The resemblance is greatly heightened just now by the similarity of the Sultan's behavior to that of the legendary "coon" which was treed by the infallible marksman.

Tea importers in this city are confronted by the prospect of a heavy loss on their importation of 15,000,000 to 20,000,000 pounds of tea, which began arriving in this city about the 1st of July. It was ordered when the general impression was that Congress would put a duty on tea. It is of the first crop, the finest tea of the year, and to forestall the tariff the importers took all they could get.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 15. -- William Walsh, one of the incorporators of the Volkmar Publishing Company, which was organized not long since under the laws of this State with an authorized capital of $50,000, was arrested to-day, charged with swindling.

SALT LAKE, Utah, July 15. -- The Trans-Mississippi Congress was called to order to-day with a large audience in the galleries and the delegates' seats well filled. The large attendance was due to the fact that William J. Bryan, President of the congress, was expected to be present. Resolutions were introduced by Keller of North Dakota favoring the Government taking control of the Union and Central Pacific Railways.

LONDON, July 15. -- At the third day's racing of the Newmarket second July meeting to-day the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's bay colt Elfin ran second in the race for the Chesterfield Stakes, Leopold de Rothschild's bay filly Ayah being first.

NEWPORT, July 15. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Sloop Navahoe, owned by Royal Phelps Carroll; steamer May, owned by Mrs. S.V. Fell; steamer Admiral, owned by Mr. Comstock; steamer Stella, owned by J. Beckwith; steamer Ozhesta, owned by Mr. Rogers; schooner Comet, owned by Mr. Tappan; sloop Thistle, owned by Mr. Chapman.

DETROIT, Mich., July 15. -- The new President, Mr. Crawford, called the convention of the National League of Republican Clubs to order at 11 o'clock. A motion was passed directing that copies of the plank in the platform urging the passage of a discriminating duty act for the protection of American shipping in the foreign trade be sent to the President, Vice President, and members of Congress.

Brooklyn Bridge and railroad officials interested in the bridge-crossing problem believe they have at last found a plan for the New York terminal which will meet the approval of every one. The principal feature of the new plan is that there will be no encroachment upon Park Row.

VIENNA, July 15. -- At Laibach, thirty-five miles northeast of Trieste, a slight earthquake shock occurred this morning at 4 o'clock. It was followed just before 7 o'clock by one much more severe. The latter lasted six seconds.
The most vigorous and effective campaign for free silver coinage now anywhere in progress is that carried on by the Platt Republicans of New York City.

ALBANY, July 15. -- It is not an uncommon occurrence throughout the State for persons to pose as special excise agents or exployes of the Excise Department, with a view of blackmailing liquor dealers. Few complaints against these blackmailers, however, have been made to the Excise Department, and therefore no cases of this kind have been taken to the courts.

With Thomas Fitchie as Commissioner of Immigration, Robert A. Sharkey as Naval Officer, and, in all probability, Walter B. Atterbury as Postmaster, Brooklyn Republican politicians are looking for a large harvest of plums. Mr. Atterbury said yesterday that if the appointment came his way he would carefully consider the matter of acceptance.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The tariff conferrees were in a more hopeful mood to-day than yesterday, and one of the leading representatives of the Senate expressed the opinion that the Republicans would be able to conclude their labors to-morrow and to summon the Democratic members by Saturday.
Will you permit me to dispute the correctness of the story "Steamers Racing at Sea," which appeared in your paper this morning?

LONDON, July 15. -- The evening newspapers gnash their teeth with rage over the sharp reply of Secretary Sherman to Lord Salisbury in the seal controversy. The half-penny journals issue sensational placards bearing such lines as "Twisting the Lion's Tail Again," and "America Shrieks at England."
ALBANY, July 15. -- Gov. Black has appointed Jacob William Miller of New York Captain of the Naval Militia of the State.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 15. -- The taking of evidence for the defense in the Benham wife murder trial was continued here today. Mrs. Benham, the mother of the defendant, in testifying regarding her daughter-in-law, said: "Florence was always hateful about taking her medicine. She said she wanted only Dr. Townsend's medicine, because that would make her have a good long sleep.

That was a very sensible and pregnant suggestion which Mr. JACOB A. RIIS, as Secretary Of the Committee on Small Parks, made to the Board of Education at its meeting on Wednesday. The suggestion was that the small parks should in all cases where it was possible be established near schools, and serve as the playgrounds of the school children, and also as public playgrounds.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 15. -- President James B. Angell and his wife left yesterday for New York, on their way to Turkey. They will sail for Havre on Saturday on the Normandie, and will go by the overland route to Constantinople. Before leaving Dr. Angell was questioned as to the nature of his mission, and the length of time he would probably stay abroad.

SEAGIRT, N.J., July 15. -- Capt. Cornelius A. Reilly of Co. K, First Regiment, N.G.N. J., was shot in the head during regimental drill at the State Camp this afternoon. The wound is not a serious one, and the Captain expects to be able to be at his post to-morrow, although his friends think his head will be too sore to permit this.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 15. -- The seventh International Convention of the Baptist Young People's Union of America began in this city this morning with about 4,000 delegates and some of the most prominent Baptist leaders in the country present.

J.F. Durlacher, ex-Vice President of the Progressive Democratic League, gave out yesterday the interview he claims to have had with John C. Sheehan, arid the authenticity of which Mr. Sheehan has denied. Mr. Durlacher says that he was accompanied to Mr. Sheehan's office by his friend, Mr. Campbell, who heard all of the interview.
WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15. -- Anthony Williams, the negro who was suspected of having assaulted and murdered Miss Rene Williams, the eighteen-year-old sister of the telegraph operator at West Point, Tenn., just over the Alabama line, last Tuesday, was caught this afternoon at 2 o'clock at Pruitton, a small town in Lauderdale County, Ala., by the infuriated mob which has been following him since the killing.

PITTSBURG, July 16. -- The Arbitration Commissioners of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, West Virginia, and Pennsylvania have formed a permanent board with the object of urging the uniformity plan upon all operators as the means of settling the coal strike. Gen. Little of Ohio was made President and B. Frank Schmid of Indiana Secretary.

The Rev. Joseph H. McMahon of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in this city, will give five morning lectures on the liturgy of the Catholic Church, at the Catholic Summer Home, on the banks of Lake Champlain, next week. Father McMahon is director of the Cathedral Library, and an authority on the liturgy of the Church.
STOCKHOLM, July 16. -- The Aftonbladet has received the following telegram from Herr Andree, via Tromsoe, written just before the balloon was cast loose:

The Equitable Gas Light Company is likely to unite with the New York and East River Gas Company, and in such case to work in harmony and to mutual interest with the East River Company's new ally, the Central Union Gas Company, which absorbs the Central Gas Light Company of Morrisania.

Duff Rusher have sold for Walter Reid to Henry T. Seymour, for $32,500, the five-story apartment house, with stores, 212 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 21 by 90 by 100.11. In part payment Mr. Seymour gives two lots on the north side of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 100 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue, each 25 by 100.11.

The repairs on the West Side Branch of the New York Port Society's building, at Charlton and Washington Streets, which have been contemplated for some time, have been begun and are to be completed by the middle of August. When the alterations are finished the mission will be very much enlarged and better fitted for doing its work among the seamen and crews of the great Atlantic steamship companies that dock in the North River.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Senate spent more than four hours in executive session to-day in an effort to confirm the nomination of Myron H. McCord to be Governor of Arizona, and adjourned after 6 o'clock without having succeeded in that purpose. The failure was due, however, only to the absence of a quorum. A vote was secured, showing 26 votes for and 11 against confirmation -- 8 less than a quorum.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 16. -- City Judge Gray Falconer late this afternoon acquitted Jacob Sharris for killing his wife's lover, Thomas H. Merritt, here last Friday night. After reading the facts in the case and the contentions of the Commonwealth and the defense, he closed by saying:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The conference report on the Deficiency Appropriation bill was considered as soon as the Senate met to-day. Mr. Hale, (Rep., Me.,) in charge of the bill, stated that the price of armor plate was not included in the report. Nothing had been done on that subject, except that the Senate conferrees had stated positively that the Senate would not consider any sum over $300 per ton for armor.

The drinking fountain at the northeast corner of Union Square has been boarded over for some time because it was found that its designer, the late Olin L. Warner, had so constructed it that wagon poles and other parts of the vehicles whose drivers drew up there often knocked against the rim of the basin, injuring the carving and making it hard for the horses to get at the water.

" There is something in a deep crimson rose which makes me happy. I love all roses, but I am sensible of a singular exaltation of all my senses when I look into a deep red one. I think of old George Herbert's line:

Our light-hearted neighbor The Sun waxes merry over THE TIMES'S estimate of the cost of annexing and defending Hawaii. Its ribs heave with laughter over this statement, which it gleefully quotes from our columns: "Since 1894 we have expended $275,000,000 in building and maintaining our navy."

As the Tariff bill went to the Senate it gave the sugar refineries a protective tax "on sugar above No. 16 Dutch standard in color, and on all sugar which has gone through a process of refining" of $1.87 1/2 per 100 pounds. As the bill passed the Senate it gave the refineries a protective tax of $1.95 per 100 pounds.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, July 16. -- E.H. Ten Eyck of Massachusetts won the final heat for the diamond sculls to-day, beating Blackstaffe, the Englishman. Ten Eyck had the Berks station.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- The Associated Press has received a letter from H.A. Stanley President of the Binghamton (N.Y.) Evening Herald Company, telling of the wonderful gold discoveries in Alaska. Mr. Stanley wrote from St. Michael's Island, where he stopped on his way to the Yukon mining region. Writing under date of June 30, he says, in part:

A Sheriff's jury, presided over by Dr. Austin Flint, Charles W. West, and Thomas J. Miller, Commissioners, has pronounced Robert Livingston Reade insane. This action was taken Thursday afternoon after a hearing as the result of proceedings brought in the Supreme Court by Mrs. Reade through her attorney, M.O. Milnor, asking for the appointment of a committee to take charge of the person and estate of Mr. Reade.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 16. -- In the examination this afternoon of the wrecked Melzingah Dam by Coroner Bevier and his jury John Robertson, the civil engineer, handed a NEW YORK TIMES reporter the following signed statement:

High Spanish authority in this city, Senor Arturo Baldasano, the Consul General or the Peninsular Kingdom, and high Japanese authority, Consul Uchida, representing here the majesty of the Mikado, agree that no credence should be given to the report from Europe that an alliance against the United States has been formed by their respective Governments.
The committee appointed to pronounce upon the pledges made for the payment of the debts of the American Baptist Home Mission Society and the American Baptist Missionary Union has reported as follows:

Martin Thorn, accused of the murder on June 25 of William Guldensuppe, was before Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus issued on his petition to be admitted to bail. A curious crowd followed him as he walked from the Tombs Prison in charge of two keepers and fern detectives, and thronged the courtroom and the corridors of the Court House.

The committee having in charge the selection of the plans in the first competition of architects for the New York Public Library Building held its first meeting yesterday in the office of the Secretary, George L. Rives, 32 Nassau Street. There were present Prof. William R. Ware of Columbia University, Bernard R. Green, Constructor of the new Congressional Library, and Dr. J.S. Billings, the Director of the New York Public Library.

George Jin, otherwise known as Jin Bing, the Chinaman of 1,386 Second Avenue, whose arrest last week caused rumors of abduction and highbinding operations and the dead locking of the laundry of his neighborhood, resulting in woes unutterable and social calamities, appeared before Justice Acker on Staten Island yesterday for judgment.

LONDON, July 16. -- In to-day's proceedings at the Bankruptcy Court the failure was announced of the Hon. James Boothby Burke Roche, Nationalist Member of Parliament for East Kerry, who married Miss Fannie Work, daughter of Frank Work of New York. The bankruptcy proceedings were subsequently annulled, all the claims against Mr. Roche being paid.

ALBANY, July 16. -- The State Board of Charities has appointed a committee to investigate the complaints of the Western States that incorrigible children from New York State are unloaded upon them to the detriment of the native-born children. The resolution was adopted upon receipt of a protest by the citizens of Council Grove, Kan., against the method.
LONDON, July 16. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Pall Mail Gazette says:

It has been known for some time that among the papyri discovered by one of the expeditions of the Egyptian Exploration Fund at Oxyrhynchus, on the border of the Libyan desert, was a fragment purporting to contain words of JESUS. Last Monday the document was published in London, under the editorship of Messrs. BERNARD P. GRENFELL and ARTHUR S. HUNT of Queens and Magdalen, at Oxford.

BRISTOL, R.I., July 16. -- The new torpedo boat Dupont, built by the Herreshoffs, started out on her official speed trial this morning, but owing to an accident the trial was called off. The boat, however, on a six-mile run, developed the remarkable estimated speed figure of 31.7 knots, the fastest speed ever made by any craft in American waters. To-day's mishap will keep the boat tied up for some time.

PARIS, July 2. -- The tendency which is now most marked among the younger school of novelists in France is to go back to models of style and taste anterior to Balzac and the pleiad of great writers who created the modern romance. It is no longer sufficient to divide the French novel writers of to-day into Idealists and Realists.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 16. -- President Rayman of the Wilkesbarre and Eastern Railroad, when interviewed to-day concerning the report sent out from New York, that the Wilkesbarre and Eastern would shortly be extended to Williamsport, Penn., said it was only a rumor. "Eventually," he said, "the road will be extended, but not at present."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 16. -- While Engineer Conroy of Timoney's brick yard was at Verplanck's Point this afternoon, attending the funeral of his wife, who was drowned in the flood at Dutchess Junction on Wednesday, the bodies of his two children were found floating in the river opposite Dutchess Junction.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Ex-Secretary Foster is believed to be meeting with a large share of success in his efforts to secure from the British Government additional measures of protection for the seals in Bering Sea. While he has not yet reported that the British have formally consented to participate in a conference with this object in view, unofficial advices indicate that this is about to be accomplished.

William F. King takes issue with the statement made by Jonathan Rice of the St. Louis dry goods jobbing firm of Rice. Stix Co. The assertion that New York dry goods jobbers do not carry as welt-assorted stocks as St. Louis and Chicago firms is questioned particularly by Mr. King.

LOUISVILLE, July 16. -- The New Yorks and the Colonels played two games to-day, both going to the credit of the latter. Intense excitement swayed the crowd in the last inning of the second game, as the Colonels gradually overcame New York's big lead. Rusie was put in to pitch in the ninth with the bases full, and his wildness was mainly responsible for the home team's victory.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 16. -- Emanuel Rich, a member of the firm of M.R. Rich Brothers, one of the largest dry goods and furniture house in the South, committed suicide at his home in this city at 7 o'clock this morning by cutting his throat with a fruit knife.

In Cosmopolis, Prof. MAX MULLER, who in the tranquil evening of his long and useful life, is giving less heed than was his wont to the Oriental languages and the vedas, and more to subjects within the grasp of common men, describes a test of royalty which seems new and conclusive.

Since the meeting opened, last Monday, the management of the Brighton Beach Racing Association, has made it manifest that everything possible that they can do for the convenience and protection of patrons shall be done. A new arrangement was made yesterday by which a lot of annoyance to the public and pecuniary loss to the layers of odds will be averted.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 16. -- It became known to-day that G.W. Lynde, said to be a millionaire, has won the first step in the action brought by his former wife to have her divorce suit against him reopened.

One of the cleverest, most elaborate, and most ingenious schemes for depriving the unwary of their money that unscrupulous brains have ever devised has been in successful operation in this city and New England during the last few months, and hundreds of women of the wealthy and well-to-do classes have been the victims.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Ten days in the House and eight weeks in the Senate was the time given by the Republican Party for the discussion of the Tariff bill of 1897. The theory of the Republicans was that there was no use in giving more time in the House, as it would be squandered in declaration without changing a schedule.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Millionaire Bradbury of California and his wife met here to-night for the first time since the woman eloped two weeks ago with H. Russell Ward. They became reconciled and will return to California to-morrow.
SARATOGA, July 16. -- The State Bankers' Association to-day, in the closing session of its convention, unanimously adopted the following resolution:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hawley, (Rep., Conn.,) rising to a question of privilege, protested against published statements accusing him of Senatorial discourtesy in connection with editorials appearing in The Hartford Courant. He stated that his active connection with the paper ended twenty years ago, and that he was in no way responsible for its editorial utterances.

According to reports received at the headquarters of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, the roads in Greater New York and round about are expected to be in excellent condition for tourists to-day and to-morrow.
LONDON, July 16. -- A special supplement to The Gazette publishes the following letter from the Queen to Sir Matthew White Ridley, the Home Secretary, dated Windsor, July 15th:
LONDON, July 16. -- Charles Hudson, the actor, is dead. He accompanied Wilson Barrett on the latter's tour of the United States.

The remarkable subscription for two millions of 5 per cent. gold bonds offered by the Metropolitan Street Railway has impressed Wall Street, as it could not help doing. The subscriptions for the two millions amounted to more than fifty millions. Such a result showed, of course, great confidence, which has been abundantly justified, in the earning capacity of this corporation.

Lieut. H.D. Wise, son of John S. Wise of Richmond, Va., who is detailed with the Eighth United States Infantry at Sacket's Harbor, started at 12:09 o'clock this morning from the City Hall on a bicycle for Washington, with the intention of breaking the wheeling record for the route.

An attempt to enforce the old blue laws of New Jersey was unsuccessfully made in Jersey City yesterday. David Driscoll, John Gorman, John Moritz, John Norton, and William Holland, members of the Arlington Baseball Club, whose grounds are on Phillips Street, near the bay, were arrested for playing baseball last Sunday.

The visit of the special Japanese envoy whose ostensible mission was to bestow a Japanese order upon the King of Spain has evidently been the occasion of an extraordinary demonstration in Madrid. The envoy was accompanied by Marquis ITO, the most eminent of Japanese statesmen, and special honors were bestowed upon them both by the authorities and by the populace.

-- A good many persons who do not take a deep interest in yachting may be puzzled by the names applied to pleasure craft in the racing classes. The yachtsmen themselves would no doubt be at a loss to account for the fact that with one accord they selected fanciful and freakish names for the vessels of the fanciful and freakish classes, while the larger and more elegant craft have received more pretentious names.

Pasteur's home life was one of absolute repose, and his surroundings were associated with and entirely subject to his scientific work. Oftentimes when possessed by some absorbing idea, or seeking a solution to some difficult problem, Pasteur would remain silent and immovable for hours, deep in profound meditation.

To speak of the inviting resort in Long Island Sound which is visited daily by so many thousands of pleasure seekers simply as Glen Island is inadequate. This famous island retreat was long since taken out of the singular number and made diversifiedly and delightfully plural. Seven is the number that constitutes the picturesque cluster.

One of the queerest houses in New York was standing last night in East Sixty-first Street, bearing the number 413. Its occupants were doubtful whether it would be standing to-day, and thought it would have fallen, anyhow, if it had been numbered as high as 415, because it can barely sustain what it has.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- After disheartening months of victorious vice, Chicago has finally witnessed a triumph of honest decency, and its citizens as they give each other the glad hand of congratulation exclaim on the turning at last reached in the long lane of fraud and corruption.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- This Government has directed United States Minister Woodford to formally present to the Spanish Government and press the claim of the family of the late Dr. Ruiz for indemnity in $75,000 on account of his death in jail in Cuba. Mr. Woodford's instructions, just completed, set out the reason for the presentation of the claim in detail.
LONDON, July 17. -- A somewhat pessimistic view of the proposed Debs Collectivists in the West is taken by The Spectator, which says:

LENOX, Mass., July 17. -- The cottagers have given much of their time this week dinners and other small entertainments for their house parties. They have been kept much of the time indoors, as there has been so much rain that it was impossible to play golf, and it was to muddy for driving until late in the week.
JAMAICA, L.I., July 17. -- Two burglars visited Hollis last night, and they used chloroform in one of the four houses they entered.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Secretary Gage has issued an order reducing the salary of the Commissioner of Immigration at New York from $6,000 to $4,500 per annum and of the Assistant Commissioner from $4,000 to $3,000. The salary of the Commissioner General of Immigration remains unchanged at $4,500.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- The storm this week, lasting from Monday night to Thursday, interfered with many arrangements for social diversion and kept many persons away from Newport who had planned to be here this week. The wind blew almost a gale from the southwest, making it rough in the bay and causing heavy surf at the beaches.

-- Henry R. Elliot, the editor of The Church Economist, is a zealous and persistent globe-trotter. He enjoys tramps and rambles and excursions that contain elements of instruction. Two or three years ago he organized, purely as a matter of good nature, an excursion to Europe in which two or three hundred persons joined with much satisfaction.

Albert Smyth, five years old, of 415 First Avenue, was playing in front of his residence last night and was run over by a cab, in which were riding J. Horace Harding, a Philadelphia newspaper man, and a young woman. The child was not seriously hurt, but was removed to Bellevue. The driver of the cab was locked up in the East Twenty-second Street Station House.

SUPERIOR, Wis., July 17. -- A new method of traveling has been invented by hobos. It is much easier than the old tie walking system, and it obviates the necessity of inconvenient and dangerous truck riding, but it is not every hobo that can travel the new way. He must first procure himself an outfit, and to do this entails considerable exertion, and some, if only a trifling, expense.

The recent dealings of the official organs of this municipality with questions of public art are surprising and inexplicable. In the case of the Botanical Garden, the Park Commissioners, after employing experts to advise them whether the designs for the Garden would unnecessarily injure Bronx Park, and receiving the advice that they would, cheerfully adopted the designs with only one dissenting voice.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Two thieves had just finished ransacking the basement of Mrs. A. White's home, 417 Jackson Boulevard, at 3 o'clock this morning, and were making off with a coil of new garden hose and a lawn mower, when they met the milkman coming in with three quarts of cream. The thieves were equal to the emergency.
The Convention of the Socialist-Labor Party of Greater New York was held last night in the hall of the Labor Lyceum, 64 East Fourth Street. Ninety-four delegates were present.

The animal which most frequently came before the criminal courts was the pig. At Mesnil St. Denis, near Paris, there still exists a spot called Truye Pendue, after a sow which was once hanged there for killing an infant, and about twenty similar cases are recorded in France alone by the writers above mentioned.

The Twenty-second Regiment, 650 strong, arrived home from the State camp yesterday afternoon. The regiment marched to the Forty-second Street station of the Sixth Avenue elevated road and took cars for the armory at Sixty-eighth Street and the Boulevard. As the men filed past the ticket chopper they were counted by the chopper and the fares paid for in a bunch.

Lord Playfair has recalled the fact that Queen Elizabeth used to write her Lord Mayor scolding letters because he allowed the city to grow so fast; it actually contained at the time 160,000 people, who, as the Queen wrote, "became heaped together and in a sort smothered," and accordingly she forbade any more houses to be built within three miles of London and Westminster.

THE great road from Paris to Belgium is both long and dull, stretching away mile after mile in a perfectly straight line, through a hideous country of yellow mud, without trees or hedges, and nearly perfectly flat.

There is an ugly, heavy black line in the opening section of the Tariff bill as it passed the Senate. Mr. DINGLEY had boldly written: "Be it enacted, , That on and after May 1, 1897," such and such duties shall be imposed. The Senate drew a black line through the date, and substituted in italics the words "the passage of this bill."

There are many objections to mountain stations. The cost of building is very large. M. Vallot's Observatory on the flanks of Mont Blanc (14,321 feet) cost $74 per cubic meter. The cost of M. Janssen's small observatory building on the summit (15,781 feet) is said to have been $60,000. Again, such establishments are very expensive to maintain.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 17. -- The announcement by Tewfik Pasha to the Ambassadors yesterday that the Sultan had agreed to the principal of their demands and was prepared to accept their views on the conditions of peace was due to a message sent him prior to the meeting to the effect that if the Porte had not previously replied satisfactorily the Ambassadors would adopt an important decision with regard to their attitude toward Turkey.

A Massachusetts woman who wears feathers is now an offender against the law and liable to a fine. In this and other States there is always a well-defined if not very formidable opposition to the use in millinery of the bodies and plumage of birds, because it is believed that so long as that custom is tolerated just so long will the killing of song birds and insectivorous birds continue.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Russia has experienced some difficulty in reversing her standard of value by simple decree, as shown in a report to the State Department by United States Consul Heenan at Odessa. He says:

LONDON, July 17. -- The weekly papers take virtually the same view as the dailies with reference to Secretary Sherman's dispatch on the sealing question. The Spectator says: "He scolds the British Government as if Ministers were a set of mean, underhand, thieving scqundrels. It is absolutely essential that Lord Salisbury should refuse to consider the question in any shape until he has received an apology for such wanton imputations."

The practice, which has been attempted in England, of doing away with the use of table napkins is not likely to prevail here to any extent soon. The idea in not using napkins is that table manners should be so perfect that the fingers will be as daintily clean at the close of a meal as at the beginning.

BOSTON, July 17. -- There has been great activity all day and to-night on board Lieut. Peary's arctic cruiser Hope, now lying at Long Wharf, and it was hoped that her stores would all be loaded, so as to permit the sailing of the vessel to-night.

The international meeting of the Society of Christian Endeavor which has just closed at San Francisco has been in all respects the most successful as yet held by the society. There have been great numbers and great enthusiasm, and a sincerity and earnestness of purpose in almost all that has been said and done which give assurance that the practical usefulness of the society is not likely to diminish with the increase in its membership.

Washington has kept Wall Street in a calm during the week past. Investors and speculators alike have been waiting for tariff schedules. Much "news" has come from Washington, but it has conveyed little information.

Frank Starbuck of Lewistown, Penn., defeated Fred J. Titus of New York in a twenty-mile paced race for a purse of $1,000 at the meeting held yesterday under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association at Manhattan Beach. Titus was compelled to retire after the sixth mile because of a severe pain in his right side, probably due to lack of condition.

The Roman pontiffs corrupted the calendar rolls -- for instance, ordaining special intercalculated days to favor a moneyed friend who wished to retain office. At last the seasons fell months out of time, so that the festival of Spring was celebrated in July. Julius Caesar unmade this confusion, decreeing that the year 46 B.C., then current, should contain 445 days, and instituting leap years, though he never lived to see one.

LONDON, July 17. -- Every intelligent Englishman cherishes the hope that nobody will have to take seriously this new international exchange of epithets on the subject of the pup seals. About the earnest merits of the question at issue there is a complete popular ignorance here, which, I am bound to say, is shared in Parliamentary circles as well.

Lowell had engaged himself to one of the loveliest girls who ever lived, Maria White, of Watertown. He was always writing poetry, and in the enthusiasm of the new engagement, he determined to publish a volume of poems.

The United States cruiser Brooklyn cast anchor off Tompkinsville shortly before noon yesterday, after a run of eleven days from Southampton. The white flier stood her maiden voyages across the Atlantic wonderfully well, not a single mishap occurring to mar the serenity of routine work, and the health of the 557 officers and men is exceptionally good.
The twentieth annual games of the Pastime Athletic Club were held yesterday afternoon on their grounds, at Sixty-sixth Street and Avenue A.

Larchmont race week began yesterday with a regatta for all classes. The harbor was filled with yachts of all sizes and descriptions and they will remain there all this week in order that their owners may witness the regattas and participate in the festivities prepared by the Larchmont yachtsmen.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Mr. Quay, (Rep., Penn.,) who yesterday tried to induce the Senate to adjourn over until Monday, made the point of no quorum as soon as the Journal had been approved in the Senate to-day. Only forty-one Senators answered to their names, and on motion of Mr. Jones (Dem., Ark.,) the Sergeant at Arms was instructed to notify absentees that their presence was required.

It is curious how much discussion of public questions proceeds on the assumption that the people have very short memories. In a New York newspaper, which distinguished itself by supporting Butler for the Presidency in 1884, there appeared a statement the other day to the effect that in that year the condition of the Democratic Party was most reassuring to all who wished well for Democracy.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 17. -- Considerable excitement was occasioned at the Chicago and Alton station to-day by the colored troops, Ninth Battalion, I.N.G., of Chicago, refusing to ride on their return trip in old coaches provided by the Chicago and Alton Company, asserting that they were condemned, and demanding Pullman chair cars.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
SAN MATEO, Cal., July 17. -- Col. Charles F. Crocker, Vice President of the Southern Pacific Railway Company, died at his home here to-night.

Consul Miller sent the following from Hull to the State Department under data of May 20 "Two enterprises of considerable magnitude are on foot in this borough. One of them has been determined on positively, and the work will be let to contract. The plans and specifications (now being drafted by the borough engineer of Hull) will be submitted to the public for bids in about two months."

LOUISVILLE, July 17. -- Another double header was played to-day and each team scored a victory. The first game was hotly contested, and the Giants won out in the ninth inning. The visitors were never in the second game. Clark was batted hard, while Dowling, a recent acquisition to the home team, was very effective against the Giants. Attendance, 4,000. Score:

Most women -- and I am afraid, a good many men, too -- imagine that book learning is synonymous with education. It never strikes them that if it were so our bookworms would be the great leaders of humanity. They see games playing a great part in boys' schools, and they immediately wish these games introduced into girls' schools.

MAZAMAS. That's a queer word, but "thereby hangs a tale." Two tales, in fact. One is a tale of a goat, and the other is a tale of recreation and pleasure. In natural history mazama is that species of the chamois known as the mountain goat, and is found in the mountains of the Pacific coast of the North American Continent.

LONG BRANCH, July 14. -- "Long Branch is not what it used to be." That is what we all of us here say, we who care to think and moralize and wonder why it all is and compare the past with the present with a wise air, and imagine we are philosophers and not quite as other men are.

The identity of the young woman in the insane pavilion in Bellevue Hospital who gave her name as Edith L. Hooper, and who afterward told a visitor she was Grace Stevenson, is still somewhat of a mystery.

LAMAR, Col., July 17. -- Commander Booth-Tucker of the Salvation Army, in company with James A. Davis, General Industrial Commissioner of the Santa Fe route, and John E. Frost, Land Commissioner of Santa Fe, is looking over the lands of this country with a view of selecting a location for one of his colonies.

" In 1848 Sam Phillippi, a gunsmith at Easton, Penn., got hold of some Calcutta bamboo, used and sold some for fishing rods in the natural state. This cane was long, slim and tapered, with greater distance between the leaf joints, which, you know, show elevated rings on the outside and have a diaphragm across the hollow. Haven't you cut into them and seen this?"

A larger crowd than has been seen at the Brighton Beach race course this year was there yesterday afternoon to see six races decided. It was a good-natured crowd, one that was out for fun and that had it, for they cheered everything that ran and made as much noise and fuss as if the races were for a series of the richest of stakes.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., July 17. -- It is announced that 441 men, attached to the Government navy yard, went on a strike yesterday. The claim is made that the Government is six months in arrears of payment of the strikers. The men secured advances on their salaries from the local money lenders.

There are some "professing" Christians who are born cross and disagreeable, with shard angles sticking out all over them, and have never subjected these natural dispositions to the rounding and smoothing influences of the Gospel. They have -- let us charitably suppose -- entered upon the way, but have been content to remain just inside the gate, making no attempt to advance a step in the Christian life.

It may have been the warm weather or it may have been some mysterious shifting of the centre of gravity, but whatever was the reason there was a great falling off in the sport of cycling yesterday. Not that there was a diminution in the number of bicycle riders. There was a falling off, literally, of wheelmen and wheelwomen.

It is historic Congregationalism, with some modifications suited to age and clime, which alone can fulfill the Congregational ideal of the future, or at least afford the building base for such a superstructure. The absolutely essential condition of any "Congregational," or, at all events, Christian success, is a definite and vital appreciation of the great evangelical doctrines as commonly interpreted.

CINCINNATI, July 17. -- Ornament, which has been rated the greatest three-year-old of the year, met his downfall to-day in a contest for the Buckeye Stakes at Oakley. He was beaten by Fleischmann, which up until this afternoon was never able to break out of the maiden class. Whether Fleischmann is really the better horse of the two, however, is still a matter of doubt.

Representatives of two cycling organizations that have had rival claims for the same name, "The Greenwich Wheelmen," will meet to-morrow night at 278 West Twenty-fifth Street to arrange for a union. This step, it is said, is not so much the result of a growth of brotherly love as a desire to avoid mistakes in mail delivery.

PARIS, July 6. -- The banquet of the American Chamber of Commerce, at the Grand Hotel, last night, was certainly the most brilliant function of the kind that has yet been held in Paris. The circular grand hall in which the dinner was given blazed with myriads of electric lights; the table of honor where sat the distinguished guests shone with magnificent plate and was gorgeous with flowers.
William Brookfield said yesterday that while little active work is being done in the local political field the situation is becoming more interesting daily.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:

The Bedouin is decidedly a handsome individual, lithe of limb like his goats and with a cafe-au-lait-colored skin. He has a sharp profile, excellent teeth. He often wears a stubby black beard and has beautifully penciled eyebrows, and, though differing entirely in language, in physique, and type, he closely resembles the Bedouin found in the Mahrl and Gara Mountains.

Corporation mysteries may not at once go out of fashion, but there are many growing indications suggesting that we are likely from this time forward to have understandable financial statements more intrigue than, unfortunately, has been usually the past. The announcement made in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the formation of "The Audit Company" is indicative of tendencies toward beneficial results.

DENVER, July 17. -- The last vestige of the magnificent fortune of J.J. Reithman, President of the defunct German National Bank, was swept away to-day when a judgment for $92,216 was entered against him in the United States Court in favor of the National Bank of Commerce of Kansas City.
Local cricketers put in their usual Saturday afternoon's work yesterday at the wickets. Both the New York Cricket Association and the Metropolitan League had games scheduled.

Some of the bonds recently authorized or issued in such haste by the village of Jamaica have already got into the courts. Yesterday morning Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court of Brooklyn, granted a permanent injunction against the village Trustees to restrain them from putting in the tax levy and collecting money to pay the interest and principal of the $50,000 of bonds for the purchase of the old King estate as a public park.

The Al-Anka won the trial race for twenty-footers sailed on Oyster Bay yesterday. The Momo was second. C.W. Wetmore of the Race Committee, announced after the contest that Momo and Al-Anka would probably be sent to Montreal, and that the two yachts could get in shape there, and whichever Mr. Crane decided was the better of the two could race for the cup.

THE question as to what constitutes a toy dog has frequently been under discussion, and the consensus of opinion nowadays is that it includes some of the spaniels that were formerly used for sporting purposes, as well as light-weight terriers.

The capitulations of the Ottoman Empire are a series of grants of privilege and immunity, accorded by various Sultans to those Christian nations with which they have desired to maintain commercial or political intercourse. The name is derived from the sections or capitula into which they are divided.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 17. -- The second of the preliminary trials for the Ballantine Trophies was played to-day by forty-four contestants. The first trial tournament, played July 3, resulted in 3 points for Arthur Berry, whose net score was 68, and 2 points for Mrs. Phipps and 1 for A.G. Hackstaff. The score to-day follows:

Probably the most interested woman in New York during the celebration of the Queen's Jubilee was Mrs. Jane Johnson. Mrs. Jane Johnson approves of Queen Victoria. She approves of her as a Queen and as a woman, and she has followed her life since her coronation with great interest up to this Jubilee celebration, which she considers a well-earned honor.

PERCHED on a high bluff and surrounded by an immense park of beautiful trees, between which can be seen sparkling the waters of the Hudson, stands Castle Point, the spacious mansion and estate of the Stevens family at Hoboken, N.J. No more attractive spot can be found near New York than this place, as it possesses many natural beauties.

A striking illustration of Ruskin's unselfishness is seen in the manner in which he has disposed of his fortune, which at the time of his father's death amounted to a million dollars. With this money he set about doing good. Poor young men and women who were struggling to get an education were helped, homes for working men and women were established, and model apartment houses were erected.

Of unwittingly ludicrous or humorous signs there are plenty. A tinsmith near Exeter, England, has a sign which reads, "Quart measures of all shapes and sizes sold here." At a market town in Rutlandshire the following placard was affixed to the shutters of a watchmaker who had decamped, leaving his creditors mourning: "Wound up and the mainspring broke."

The American Summer marches on, steadily deteriorating each year, with more hot waves, of longer duration and greater intensity. Summer after Summer the record is broken and a new one made. The towns have become mighty ovens, storing up heat by day to emit by night, and even the rural districts have become infected, and this phenomenal Summer heat seems to find its way into the most quiet and secluded nooks.

H.O. Havemeyer and J.E. Searles, President and Secretary, respectively, of the American Sugar Refining Company, as well as John D. and William Rockefeller, are enthusiastic wheelmen. There are nearly 200 bicycle racks at the Metropolitan Club for the use of members.

LONDON, July 17. -- The report that an international conference on the seal controversy will be held at Washington in the Autumn is confirmed by an official paragraph issued to-day by the British authorities and which will be printed here to-morrow. The statement says:

LONDON, July 17. -- The season, so far as the theatres are concerned, may be regarded as definitely over. What novelties, if any, managers still have up their sleeves have been got ready not for the metropolitan public, but in view of their provincial tours, and, if played at all in London, the performances will partake more of the nature of dress rehearsals than of anything else.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- When the Republican conferrees on the Tariff bill, representing the two houses of Congress, adjourned at 6 o'clock to-day, the announcement was made, on behalf of each of the houses, that they had agreed upon all the items of the bill, and that the result of the partisan conference would be submitted to the Democratic members of the conference at a full meeting to be held on Monday.

That may not be a strictly true story which comes from Tokio by way of Tacoma about the Japanese movement in favor of a new religion, but it is delightfully characteristic of the Japanese mind. The idea seems to be to manufacture a good working religion for immediate use out of such elements in three existing religions as seem to a convention of scholars most suitable.

About the same period at which Queen Caroline was earning notoriety for herself, there resided in a small town in the North of Germany a man noted for his skill as a public executioner. Late one evening two men in military uniform called upon this person and requested him to accompany them, as his services were required at some distance, and would be liberally rewarded, but that he must consent to be blindfolded.

A number of the policy holders of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association who are residents of this city met yesterday afternoon in the office of A.E. Woodruff 120 Broadway, to discuss plans to protect their interests and to save the company, if practicable, from going into the hands of a receiver.

The extraordinary address delivered from the bench by a Kentucky Judge before releasing from custody a man who had killed another man for destroying his home will be accounted in questionable taste in this part of the country. Yet we must admit that the escape of the slayer from punishment would have been equally sure in any State.

LONG BRANCH, July 17. -- The bicycle parade here this afternoon was one of the most successful events in the history of this resort. Over 10,000 wheelmen were in line, and it is estimated that the spectators numbered over 75,000. Largs crowds came from New York by boat and train to witness the event, and many others from nearby places.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 17. -- The Papal Legate, Mgr. Martinelli, and party, consisting of the Rev. Dr. John A. Watterson, Bishop of Columbus; Mgr. Sbaretti, Papal Secretary, and the Rev. Joseph H. McMahon of New York, arrived at the Summer School this evening, and were escorted to the Champlain Club, where they will remain during their stay.

The announcement of a two-thousand-dollar handicap race, trials at one mile, and final heat at two miles, has caused quite a sensation among the professionals, who were anxiously waiting for some club to offer a cash prize that was worth the time and expense to train for.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Vice President P.B. Weare of the North American Transportation and Trading Company has received dispatches from the Klondike placer gold fields of Alaska, which confirm the stories of its fabulous wealth received from the Pacific coast last week.

Leon Graves and John P. Ryan were held by Magistrate Crane yesterday in $5,000 bail and committed to jail on a charge of assaulting and robbing Lawyer Robert S. Clarke at Graves's room, 237 East Eighteenth Street. Mr. Clarke is a member of the firm of Scott Clarke of 150 Nassau Street. He lives at 19 Shepard Avenue, Brooklyn.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 17. -- The young society people are now engaged in preparing for a series of amateur theatricals, which will be attended by many city people who are spending the Summer here, including many guests at Maplewood. Two plays will be presented at Central Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings of next week for the benefit of a local charity, and a number of theatre parties have been made up to attend.

The regiment was in service against Fort Ticonderoga, (1757.) The assault, which was made on most imperfect information of the strength of the fortifications, was a disastrous failure. The "Black Watch," which could hardly be called back from the attack, lost 647 men, of whom nearly a half (314) were killed.

LONDON, July 17. -- At Bisley to-day, in the shooting for the "Imperial" prize, second stage, squadded competition, ten shots each at 800 yards, with service rifles, Sergt. Whitehead of the Third South Staffordshire Regiment was first, with a score of 144.
" Talk about shopping in New York," said the woman with the traveling bag, "it does not begin to come up to Cleveland, where you know just where to find everything."
