SEATTLE, Washington, July 17. -- The steamer Portland was reported passing Cape Flattery at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The news dispatches from San Francisco announcing the arrival of the Excelsior at that port, with many miners and a large quantity of gold, has created a public demand for the latest and most authentic news from the gold fields of Alaska.
Consul Monaghan sent an undated communication to the State Department from Chemnitz, received by the department May 26, in which he says:

On the 15th The World published a very full and careful statement, prepared on the authority of the head of each department, of the work of the Strong administration in the Departments of Public Works. Docks, Parks, Fire, and Street Cleaning, and a brief statement as to the Charities.

PITTSBURG, July 17. -- District miners' officials have come to a realization of the gravity of the coal strike situation as far as the shipments of coal from the district just east of Pittsburg and the Clearfield-Cambria field are concerned. Coal from these producing centres is playing havoc with the cutting off of the supply for the Pittsburg trade, thus militating against the success of the strike.

LONDON, July 17. -- The proposition to confer upon the Archbishop of Canterbury an official status as head of all branches of the Episcopal Church in all parts of the world, which was one of the most interesting questions before the Lambeth Conference, will come to nothing.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Senate today confirmed these nominations: Myron H. McCord, Governor of Arizona; George W. McGowan, Collector of Customs, District of Bridgeton, N.J.; Horace N. Allen of Ohio, Minister Resident and Consul General to Corea; William J. Merry of California, Minister to Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Salvador.

BRANDENBURG, June 6. -- This little town on the Havel has been in a state of mild excitement over the visit of two scientific societies from Berlin, some forty miles distant up stream. One is the society that devotes itself to birds, separates the beneficial from the harmful, issues books to encourage the protection of songsters, and fulminates against traps, birdlime, and wings in ladies' bonnets.

SAN BERNARDINO, Cal., July 17. -- In the harrowing tales of suffering and death in the desert told here by prospectors straggling in from the Mojave, we now see the force of the timely warning given last Winter in the Randsburg correspondence of THE NEW YORK TIMES. It is an awful sequel to the wild rush of gold seekers only a few months ago.

The bitter warfare which has been declared between the Mallory Line and the Southern Pacific Railway Company on one side and the new Lone Star Line, of which T. Hogan Sons are the local representatives, was formally opened yesterday afternoon. The first battle for supremacy took the shape of a race between the Mallory steamer Lampassas and the Lone Star liner Miami from this port to Galveston.

The Bushman divests himself of all his incumbrances; water vessels, food, cloak, assegai, and sandals are all left behind. Stark naked, except for the hide patch about his middle, and, armed only with his bow, arrows, and knife, he sets forth. The nearest ostrich is feeding more than a mile away, and there is no covert but the long, sun-dried, yellow grass, but that is enough for the Bushman.

It was a bright Summer morning when the pale-green shades at 13 West Thirtieth Street were pulled down by the janitor and a man in blue overalls proceeded to remove from the glass of the middle window the magic name "Bernhardt." In big letters of gold the name flashed back the sun's rays for the last time into the eyes of the people passing.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 17. -- Prof. William Libby of Princeton University, accompanied by several scientists of repute, will begin Monday an exploration of the famous Mesas cliffs in the United States Indian Reservation of New Mexico. It is expected that the task will require many weeks for its completion, and the scientific world will watch with interest the results of the experiments which the Princeton professor will conduct.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 18. -- At Saturday's sitting of the Peace Conference Tewfik Pasha, the Turkish Minister of Foreign Affairs, arrived late. He submitted to the conference a new frontier scheme, which was unacceptable to the powers, and the Ambassadors thereupon informed Tewfik that the conference would adjourn until he brought a written acceptance by his Government of the frontier line traced by the military attaches.

The statement has been made, with considerable details of apparent evidence, that the reason why it is difficult to induce men to enlist in the navy is the discrimination shown in the infliction of punishments upon seamen and officers. Instances have been cited which seem to show that comparatively small offenses by seamen are severely punished, while more flagrant derelictions on the part of officers are dealt with much more leniently.

PITTSBURG, July 18. -- The events of to-day in the Pitsburg coal-mining district, indicate that there is trouble ahead. The strike has been on for two weeks, with no cause for alarm in any quarter, but to-day the pangs of hunger and mutterings of discontent have taken tangible form, and before morning 1,000 miners will have marched on Cannonsburg, the objective point being the Boone and Allison mines.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 18. -- H.P. Lillibridge, who was Consul General from Hawaii to Japan during the reign of King Kalakaua, has written a letter to Senator Hanna, in which he says:

Perry Belmont, who returned last Saturday from a two months' stay in Europe, expressed his views freely yesterday on several of the engrossing topics of the day as they are regarded abroad. To an inquiry regarding the attitude of Europe toward the proposed new tariff he replied that Europe, having never before seen anything like it, was naturally bewildered for the moment.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 18. -- Dr. Robert Hubbard, a physician well known throughout the country, while ascending the steps to his office on State Street this morning, fell and received injuries to his head from which he died soon after.

BALTIMORE, July 18. -- Lieut. D.H. Wise, United States Army, was compelled to-day to abandon his attempt on the New York and Washington cycle record, owing to the condition of the roads near Baltimore, recent rains having made them almost impassable.

The Board of Directors of the Eastern League held a meeting yesterday morning at the office of President P.T. Powers, in the St. Paul Building, and formally transferred the Rochester franchise to Montreal. Those present at the session were President Powers, James Franklin, Buffalo; E. F. Bogert, Wilkesbarre; W.H. Draper, Providence, of the board, and Charles Englert, Jr., representing Rochester, and W.H. Rowe, who looked after the interests of Montreal.

It was 1 o'clock yesterday morning when Bicycle Policeman Connelly dismounted at the Arsenal in Central Park, removed a string of beads from his brow with the right index finger, and reported to the Sergeant on duty that he had chased a bucking bronce for any distance ranging from one to a thousand miles.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The indications to-night are that the Tariff bill, as agreed to by the Republican conferrees yesterday, probably will have passed both houses of Congress and be a law at the end of the present week. Delays and complications now unanticipated might, however, prolong the final struggle.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- One lone Anarchist went to the Haymarket Monument this morning to lift his voice against the tyranny of government. It was announced at the meeting there last Sunday that another and a greater meeting would be held on the same spot to-day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 18. -- Howell C. Rees, President of the Phoenix Gas Company of Matteawan, arrived here to-day with a thrilling tale of confinement in a sanitarium against his will, his escape, and a night spent in the mountains evading bloodhounds and attendants on his trail.
LOUISVILLE, July 18. -- The Louisvilles to-day won in the game with the St. Louis club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- William A. Bellwood of this city, who was arrested in New York yesterday, charged with swindling Marcus Co., jewelers, out of considerable money, is a dealer in old books and curios at 1332 Walnut Street. He has a private residence at 1510 Diamond Street, in the northern section of the city.

Local cricketers are still struggling for the Metropolitan Cup, the emblem of supremacy which will reward the winner of the championship series of games of the Metropolitan League. The cup is now in possession of the New Jersey Athletic Club, and the indications are that it will remain with that enterprising organization for another year.

In the opinion of some experienced observers "good times" have already come. They are close at hand, say others, but all the financial doctors agree that we are getting cured of our longstanding complaint, want of confidence. Good news and a hopeful spirit are the dominant factors in the present situation.

Peter Cunningham, thirty-eight years old, who has for some time gained a subsistence by doing odd jobs about Bellevue Hospital, was taken to that institution last night to have a wound in the head dressed, and thence was taken to the East Twenty-second Street Police Station, charged with disorderly conduct.

William A. Bellwood, forty-three years old, a well-known dealer in antique books and jewelry at 1332 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, and living in this city at the Plaza Hotel, is a prisoner at Police Headquarters on the charge of having swindled Marcus Co., jewelers at Seventeenth Street and Broadway, out of jewelry valued at many thousands of dollars.

It seems that it is asking too much to expect American newspapers to deal fairly and squarely with the Cuban question. Even those who try to be impartial oftentimes let their judgment be carried away by prejudice.

Up to the time of the opening of the Brighton Beach race track last Monday owners of race horses in the vicinity of New York were complaining that the purses offered for overnight events were too small. They argued that with but three or four days' racing each week and six races a day the possibilities of earning enough to maintain their stables were insufficient.

We have received from the editor of The New Orleans Times-Democrat a printed letter in which we are asked to consider the ownership and operation by the Federal Government of all the telegraph lines in the country, and if we approve the proposition, to lend our aid and advocacy to a Congressional measure for its accomplishment.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- As stated in the Washington correspondence of THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 15, the petition of Gen. George A. Forsyth, United States Army, (retired,) praying the House to strike the sugar schedule out of the Tariff bill, contains a severe arraignment of the Sugar Trust.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18. -- President Ratchford to-day summed up the strike situation as follows: "The manner in which the miners are conducting themselves commends itself to the country and gives their officers renewed encouragement, and strengthens the belief that victory ultimately will crown their efforts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 18. -- Joseph Ladue, the owner of the town site of Dawson City, Alaska, the nearest town to the Klondike section, started last night for his home, in Plattsburg, N.Y. Besides owning the township of Dawson, where land is already selling for $5,000 a lot, Mr. Ladue brought with him enough gold dust to keep him in comfort for some time to come.
NEWPORT, July 18. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Enterprise, owned by A.J. Cassatt, and steamer Stranger, New York Yacht Club.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 18. -- The love affair of Archie Hoffman, a clerk in the Dover Plains Bank, and Miss Minnie Reimer, daughter of Adolph Reimer, a wealthy manufacturer and promoter of that village, is talked of throughout the Harlem Valley.

Watchfulness the duty of the Christian was the theme of Dr. Benjamin F. De Costa at the Church of St. John the Evangelist yesterday. He preached the second sermon of a series on the subject of religion in warm weather, taking his text from Proverbs, x., 5: "He that gathereth in Summer is a wise son."

One of the most active talkers and disturbing spirits of the Progressive Democratic League has shaken the dust off his shoes and quit, and several of the leaders are apparently glad to be rid of him. J.F. Durlacher, who has recently published accounts of interviews that he claimed to have had with John C. Sheehan, is the seceder. His enemies charged that he had been faking.
Mr. Robert P. Porter says of Mr. W.W. Astor:

Dennis Ford of 559 1/2 Henderson Street, Jersey City, was sitting on the stoop of his house yesterday morning when Daniel Murphy of Hoboken offered to sell him a watch. Ford refused to buy it, and Murphy challenged him to fight. Ford declined, and Murphy picked up brick and threw it at him.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- The commercial representatives of Mexico, Central America, and South America, who last night returned from their forty days' tour of the industrial centres of the country, assembled to-day at the Philadelphia Commercial Museum, and held a symposium on the subject of reciprocity.

BOSTON, July 18. -- "Her army record transcends that of any other woman," said Mrs. Mary A. Livermore, speaking to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, yesterday, of "Mother" Bickerdyke. "If she only lived in Chicago, I should have started by this time to be with her on her eightieth birthday, but Kansas -- 'Bunker Hill, Kansas' -- seems so much further away, that I do not feel as if I could try it.

It is finally settled that Fleetwood Park will be the scene of a three days' trotting meeting, beginning on Wednesday, with purses of $300 for 2:50, 2:24, and 2:18 classes, trotting, and 2:40, 2:12, and 2:19 classes, pacing. Entries close with L.A. Burke, Secretary, to-day.

Harlem River oarsmen did very little rowing yesterday, as the rain kept most of them away from the boathouses. A few of the crews in training went out despite the weather, and took their regulation spins.

Maria Hochteller, a Swede, twenty-two years old, of 1,982 Park Avenue, drowned herself yesterday afternoon in the Harlem River at the One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street slip, on the south side of the river. At 5 o'clock she was seen by a policeman in company with her cousin, Victor Dannerman of Hoboken, N.J., at the corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street.
Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Department of Public Works announces that bids for the proposed Willis Avenue Bridge, the ninth to span the Harlem River, will be advertised for in a few days.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 18. -- Among the miners who arrived on the Portland from the Klondike gold fields were Clarence Berry and his wife. Accounts of his phenomenal success have already been published. To-day he said to a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The unfavorable weather could not drown out politics yesterday, either by the sea or in the city. Politicians and men with political aspirations note the flying minutes and add so much more earnestness to their labors.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Hawaiian commerce during the last ten years is the subject of a circular just issued by the Department of Agriculture. The paper was prepared by F.H. Hitchcock, Chief of the Division of Foreign Markets, under the direction of Secretary Wilson.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The conference report on the Tariff bill was presented to the House by Mr. Dingley a few minutes after the reading of the Journal. The announcement in the newspapers of this morning that the report would be presented today had caused a large attendance of members of the House and of visitors in the galleries.

The northeast corner of the floor of the Stock Exchange was yesterday the busiest and noisiest part of the busiest and noisiest place in New York in business hours. Here the "Sugar crowd" has a rendezvous round a stand ticketed "Sugar," and these specialists transacted a huge business from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.

It has often enough been pointed out that it is only in Protestant countries that the notion prevails that it is "wicked" to indulge in any recreation on Sundays that would be innocent on any other day in the week. The Puritanism which insists upon a literal enforcement of the fourth commandment is confined to the British islands and the countries colonized from them.

CONSTANTINOPLE, July 19. -- The terms of the Turkish Government, as submitted to the Ambassadors by Tewfik Pasha on Saturday, not only proposed a change of frontier, but fixed the amount of indemnity at 4,500,000 Turkish, and renewed the demand for abolition of the capitulations granted the Greek subjects in the Ottoman Empire.

This is the Novena, or nine days' religious observance prior to the Feast of St. Anne, the mother of St. Mary, and the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, in Seventy-sixth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, which boasts of a relic of St. Anne, is now a centre of attraction to the Roman Catholic community in this city.

It is very plain that the Sultan's pretense of compliance with the demands of the powers was only a pretense. When his terms of peace were presented they were found to include new frontier which was neither the line originally demanded by Turkey nor that traced by the powers.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- At least eight Eastern clubs, members of the Amateur Athletic Union, will withdraw from the organization, so it is asserted by local sportsmen. The clubs are the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, the New York Athletic Club, Pastime Athletic Club, New Jersey Athletic Club, Manhattan Athletic Club, Orange Athletic Club, Boston Athletic Association, and the Staten Island Athletic Association.

Where shall my offending sex hide their diminished heads? We are first to be legislated against because of our large hats, which, it appears, obstruct the view of the masculine eye at the theatre -- and then our headgear, adjusted to a size to suit the man of diminutive stature, must be shorn of all adornment save flowers.
Mrs. Reineman, He Says, Was Jealous, and Her Testimony Instigated by Spite and Cupidity -- The Bargain for Bad Money Made Years Ago.

FAIRMOUNT, West Va., July 19. -- As a result of yesterday's meeting at Willow Tree Grove, near Monongah, 225 miners refused to go to work this morning. The drivers being in sympathy with the miners, refused to haul and consequently the rest of the miners who had gone to work were compelled to come out.

GREENFIELD, Mass., July 19. -- The trial of John O'Neil, a resident of this place, for the murder of Mrs. Hattie McCloud, on Jan. 8, 1897, was begun at the Franklin County Court House to-day. Chief Justice Mason of Brookline and Judges Fessenden of Greenfield and Sheldon of Boston are sitting in the case. The Attorney General is assisting the District Attorney, and O'Neil is represented by able counsel.

The canvass of the Nineteenth Assembly District of New York City, just completed by the Federation of Churches and Christion Workers under the direction of the Rev. Walter Laidlaw, is, perhaps, the most exhaustive and detailed canvass ever made of any section of a large city. The result gives an almost perfect panorama of the district.

LONDON, July 19. -- A representative of The Associated Press called to-day upon Col. J.W. Macfarlane, a prominent Hawaiian, as well known in London and San Francisco, as in Honolulu, in order to ascertain his views on the Hawaiian situation.

The Sabbath is for man, and it is for the best part of him, the only part that will endure. It is most reasonable, therefore, to ask him to observe it. It is intended wholly for his happiness. In wasting it he is wasting himself. We invite him to church because there he can get the most out of the Sabbath for himself.

BALTIMORE, July 19. -- The Mercantile Trust Company Of Baltimore, as Trustee under the mortgage of 1887 on the main line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, to-day filed objections to the issuance of the $2,345,550 in receivers certificates, recently asked for by the receivers for the purpose of purchasing new rolling stock for the system.

Controller Ashbel P. Fitch has transferred the lot on Fifth Avenue, 25 feet south of Sixty-second Street, 25.5 by 100, recently purchased by him from J. Sergeant Cram, to Mrs. Josephine Schmid, who owns the adjoining corner. The consideration is $92,500.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- At 12:15 o'clock this morning the House agreed to the report of the Conference Committee on the Tariff bill by a vote of 185 yeas to 118 nays. The conference report now goes to the Senate for concurrence.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- President McKinley is understood to be prepared to send in a message on Wednesday, asking the Congress for authority to appoint a Currency Revision Committee. It is expected that the Tariff bill will be by that time in his hands, and no longer subject to hazard in the Congress.

The R. Rothschild's Sons Company, manufacturers of bar, saloon, office, and store fixtures, at 579 Broadway and at Cincinnati, Ohio, made an assignment yesterday in both cities to Benjamin F. Cahn, without preference. It is an Ohio corporation, organized on Jan. 12, 1889, with a paid-up capital of $25,000.

That is an extraordinary idea of the celebrated Mr. T.P. O'CONNOR that "the Episcopalian body" in this country represents about all the "pro-English feeling," there is here. In the Protestant Episcopal Church, Mr. O'CONNOR declares, are "some of the greatest financiers of America."

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., July 19. -- Preparations are making by the residents of this village to celebrate the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the Baptist Church of this place on Aug. 5. Arrangements are now being made by several societies affiliated with the Baptist churches in the State to make a pilgrimage to the old church upon the day of its celebration.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- At 8 o'clock this evening, when the night session of the House began, the galleries were crowded, many ladies being present. Mr. Dingley stated at the outset that he hoped to secure a vote by 10 o'clock. Mr. Bailey said 10 o'clock was too early, but he thought the vote could be taken by 11.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Tariff bill as reported by the conference committee provides that the act shall take effect immediately upon its passage.

-- Those who recall the dirty and disheveled appearance of New York after the Columbian parades will readily fancy what must have been the state of London after the Queen's jubilee. One of the English papers says that the dust carts brought in hundreds of broken loaves, piles of half-finished sandwiches, great sirloins of beef, heaps of cooked vegetables, scores of unopened tins of fish and meat, and unfinished champagne bottles by the dozen.

The hearts of all those who love the dumb creation must surely be thrilled with delight on hearing, through THE NEW YORK TIMES and other papers, that the Massachusetts Legislature has passed a law prohibiting within that State the wearing of feathers, wings, and the stuffed bodies off birds by women.

Col. John Bradbury and his handsome wife, Mrs. Lucy Bradbury, nee Lucy Banning, are in New York and are seemingly as happy as a bridegroom and bride on their honeymoon trip. They are perfectly reconciled, and could not be better satisfied, apparently, than if they had been wedded but yesterday.

Mr. DINGLEY promises two millions a year increased revenue from the new sugar schedule, points out that it will give greater protection to the beet sugar industry, and complacently announces a victory for the House. The Republican members, ready to put through any sort of a schedule that the tariff makers offer them, shout for a vote on the bill as amended, by the conferrees.

LONDON, July 19. -- In the House of Commons to-day, the Hon. George Curzon, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, replying to Mr. Michael Davitt, Anti-Parnellite member for South Mayo, said the Government was convinced that the seals in Bering Sea were in no imminent danger.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 19. -- The amount of treasure brought down from the Klondike by the steamship Portland is now placed at $1,500,000, and there is reason to believe the sum was nearer $2,000,000. Each man was required by the rules to place his gold chest in the ship's safe, but many of the miners secreted their dust in blankets and luggage, which were either taken to their staterooms or thrown carelessly about the ship.

Another day with a very muddy track and the falling of occasional showers spoiled all chance for sport at the Brighton Beach race course yesterday. The feature was to have been a handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, which has fourteen horses of very fair class, including Sir Walter, Flying Dutchman, Belmar, Peep o'Day, and Deerslayer, but all these and five others of lesser class were stricken out.

The body of Selma Larsen, the young woman who suddenly became insane on a train while on her way from Staatsburg, N.Y., to this city last Saturday, and died the following day at the General Hospital at Fishkill, arrived here yesterday, and will be cared for by her sister, Mrs. Charles Wickstrom of 164 East Ninety-second Street.

W.H. Bellwood of Philadelphia was arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday charged with grand larceny. He was said to have stolen a large number of diamonds from the jewelry firm of Marcus Co., but a definite charge was made against him of having stolen diamond earrings to the value of $2,200 and a necklace worth $375.

CAMP GRIGGS, Sea Girt, N.J., July 19. -- Almost one-third of the members of the Fourth Regiment, which began active work in camp this week, are sick. More than 200 members have been treated for camp cholera, and many of them are so weakened as to be unable to perform any active duty.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -- The following yachts arrived to-day: Steamer Illawarra, owned by E. Thompkins; sloop Columbia, owned by Mr. Post; sloop Keetwadid, New York Yacht Club. The only departure was the steamer Stranger, owned by Miss Lewis.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 19. -- A dispatch from Johnson City says that Gov. Taylor has appointed Thomas B. Turley of Memphis United States Senator to succeed the late Senator Harris.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in New York City yesterday announced the appointment of three Commissioners to take testimony and to report to the Court whether the new rapid transit route, as last planned by the Rapid Transit Commission, ought to be constructed. The Commissioners appointed are Arthur D. Williams, John Sabine Smith, and Algernon S. Frissell. Messrs, Williams and Smith are well-known lawyers. Mr. Frissell is President of the Fifth Avenue Bank.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 19. -- A letter telling of the recent trip of the steamer Excelsior to Alaska has been written by Capt. J.F. Higgins of the steamer to a friend in this city. Capt. Higgins says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 19. -- The question of the mental condition of Howell C. Rees will be reviewed before Judge Barnard, in his chambers in this city, to-morrow, and some disposition will be made of the proposition to detain Mr. Rees in an insane asylum, which is opposed by his friends.
BERLIN, July 19. -- The best scientific opinion here is not sanguine of the success of Herr Andree's undertaking.

Our neighbor The Sun is skeptical about Mr. PLATT'S free silver propaganda among the Tammany Democrats. It scoffs at our statement that his hirelings and emissaries are at work in the Tammany organization to force Bryanism to the front.
PITTSBURG, July 19. -- Pittsburg councils to-day, in regular session, passed a resolution calling on President McKinley to use his good offices in the settlement of the coal miners' strike.

The show of hands necessary to determine whether those who issued the circular recommending the consolidation of the New York and East River Gas Company and the Equitable Gas Light Company over the authority of the Central Trust Company or the Directors and officers of the Equitable control the situation is for the future.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Republican conferrees to-day made public a statement concerning the conference report on the Tariff bill, in which they reviewed the changes made. Of sugar the statement says:

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The Chicago firemen and policeman entered for the tournament at Manhattan Field next Saturday left this afternoon for New York. The party consisted of Marshal Champion of the Chicago Fire Department, Second Assistant Chief, who goes us the representative of the department to look after the men. Accompanying Marshal Champion is Charles Siferlich, Chief of the Second Battalion, who joined the party to see the tournament.

ALBANY, July 19. -- Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn has refused permission to do business in this State to the Aachen and Munich Fire Insurance Company,, the Magdeburg Fire Insurance Company, and the Prussian National Insurance Company, on the ground that the Prussian Government discriminates against the Mutual Life Insurance Company, the New York Life, and the Equitable Life.

Odors from the crematory at New Brighton, S.I., have long been a source of trouble to the residents of that village. Yesterday they had the Trustees brought into court. Justice Gaynor, in Brooklyn, laid down the opinion' that the Trustees should stay up nights, if necessary, to see that the garbage is properly burned.

ALTOONA, Penn., July 19. -- Some time ago gold quartz was discovered in the mountains near the village of Titusville, Blair County. The finders sent to Denver for an expert, who came and made an examination and essay of the ore.

PITTSBURG, July 19. -- Some new features will likely be introduced into the mining struggle within the next two days, but the leaders are maintaining the strictest secrecy regarding their movements. It is believed they contemplate calling upon the railway organizations for assistance. Secretary Warner gave out the information today that a meeting of railway employes was held here yesterday, and the situation of the miners' strike thoroughly discussed.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 10. -- The schooner Herbert Rice, at Carlisle Bay, Barbados, brought in 325 cases of oil picked up at sea. They were from the American ship Belle of Bath, which as before reported, was abandoned at sea June 18, on fire and sinking from a leak which she had sprung when bound from New York for Hongkong.

TOLEDO, July 19. -- Secretary Bishop of the Arbitration Commission, which has in charge the settlement of the mining difficulties, who came here to see Gov. Bushnell on a private mission, consented to talk about the strike. He said that the members of the commission had all gone to their respective States, and reported great progress.
St. Swithin's Day was an unlucky one for the Brighton Beach Racing Association. It was raining, and there has been rain every day since as if to make good the old weather myth doggerel beginning:

A recent dispatch from St. Joseph, M., stated that F.W. Yale, Vice President for Missouri of the National Association of Credit Men, had sent his resignation to the National President, James G. Cannon, of this city, and that the Missouri organization had withdrawn from the National organization.

WHEELING, West Va., July 20. -- Changes that have an important bearing upon the coal strike situation in West Virginia came to-day. The State, taken as a whole, is against the strike for financial reasons, and all who have struck have been brought out under the pressure of the organizers and agitors from elsewhere.

Mayor STRONG has not been very happy in his appointments to the Park Board. Of his first quartet, three most respectable citizens, without any special fitness for the duties of Park Commissioners, accepted them only on the condition that the fourth, a man in some respects very well qualified to take charge of public improvements, should do all the work.

BOSTON, July 20. -- If James Stevenson, the Boston millionaire and father of the missing Grace Stevenson, can be found by a Deputy Sheriff or constable, he will be cited to appear at the poor debtor session of the Municipal Court on the morning of Aug. 3 at 9 o'clock, to show cause why he should not pay an execution for $619 held against him by Louisa K. Wilson and Sarah S. Kimball.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union, at its meeting yesterday afternoon, received a report from its Chairman, James B. Reynolds, that the organization is now complete in every borough and every Assembly district. The Union is now ready, he said, for an aggressive campaign on every inch of the territory of Greater New York.

Capt. George W. Sumner yesterday succeeded Capt. F.J. Higginson as Captain of the navy yard. There were no ceremonies in connection with the change, except the formal transfer. Capt. Higginson will assume command to-morrow of the battleship Massachusetts, now lying at Tompkinsville.

Among the headlines with which our interesting contemporary The Sun adorned its columns yesterday were these, over a news article in which Chairman DANFORTH was reported as saying that the Democratic State Committee, at its September meeting, would have no authority to indorse or disapprove the Chicago platform:

The House of Representatives is called the popular branch of Congress. It is supposed to represent the people, to promote their welfare and safeguard their interests, in distinction from the Senate, whose members, chosen by the Legislatures, are in theory the representatives of the power and interests of the several States.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 20. -- Dispatches received from Talbotton to-day confirm the reported lynching near here last night of Dr. W.L. Ryder, who murdered Miss Sallie Emma Owen at Talbotton a year ago.

The Battalion of the East of the New Jersey Naval Militia, under the command of Washington Irving, will start for a two weeks' cruise on the old sloop-of-war Portsmouth, from the foot of Fourteenth Street, Hoboken. The battalion comprises three divisions of about sixty men each, one division of Jersey City and Orange young men; another of Stevens Institute graduates and students, and another of Newark young men.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- P.B. Weare, Vice President of the North American Transportation and Trading Company, is receiving hundreds of letters asking for information regarding Alaskan gold fields. He said yesterday: "The boats which sail from Seattle this month are full -- every passage taken.

A new record was made yesterday in the quotations for the certificates of the American Sugar Refining Company, the price going to 146 1/4. While the brokers at the Sugar stand dealt in the five hours' trading in about 84,000 certificates and 3,600 shares of Sugar preferred, there was at no time any scene that could be called exciting.

ODELL, Ill., July 20. -- William Van Buskirk, cashier of the McWilliams Bank, yesterday saved the bank's cash from a pair of robbers, and after chasing the two crooks out of town on a bicycle, captured them with the aid of some energetic citizens and locked them up.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- "I don't put any faith in the story that Mrs. Luetgert was seen in New York in May," said State's Attorney Deneen when asked his opinion on the latest rumor in the Luetgert case. "The story looks like a fabrication, and is one, I think, beyond a doubt. We shall go right ahead with the case, and do what we can to unravel the mystery.

When the Senate Finance Committee reported its Tariff bill THE TIMES pointed out the many ways in which it had aggravated the evil effect of the House bill, the greater favors it had offered to the large Trusts, the new and stronger fetters it had forged for American industries, and the series of deals it proposed with the Senators from the Rocky Mountains.

The three Prussian fire insurance companies that have offices in this city and have been trying for two years to do business in this State are not at all pleased with the decision of Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn, who refused them authority to write their policies here. The three companies are the Magdeburg and the Aachen and Munich Fire Insurance Companies and the Prussian National Insurance Company.

Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for the Gunther estate the four-story brown-stone-front dwelling 9 West Fifty-seventh Street, 30.6 by 100.5. William H. Gunther paid $100,000 for this property in June, 1875.
One of New York's quiet millionaires -- a woman -- barely escaped going to a police station in a patrol wagon last Monday afternoon.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20. -- Surrogate Silkman of Westchester County a short time ago issued an order citing Andrew G. Green, John Bigelow, and George H. Smith executors of the will of Samuel J. Tilden, to appear before him to show cause why they should not pay to Adelaide E.P. Buchanan a legacy provided for in the will of Lucy F. Tilden, under the tenth article of the will of Samuel J. Tilden.

BALTIMORE, July 20. -- Charles H. Isham, who was yesterday nominated by President McKinley to be United States Commissioner in Alaska, and credited to Baltimore, is not now a resident of this city. His name does not appear in the Directory for 1897, although a year or two ago he owned a "pure-food market" on West Fayette Street, and lived at 303 North Gilmore Street.

Gen. Wade Hampton, United States Railway Commissioner, arrived in the city yesterday from Denver, accompanied by his daughter, Miss Mary E. Hampton, Miss Herndon, and C.A. Calhoun. The noted ex-Confederate commander is Government Commissioner for the five subsidized railways of the West.

PITTSBURG, July 20. -- The home team won two games to-day from the Brooklyns. Both games were pitchers' battles. The Brooklyns outbatted the Pittsburgs in both contests, but the latter played the better game at critical stages. Scores:

The body of a man supposed to be A.W. Wallroth was found in Prospect Park early yesterday morning. The man was about fifty years of age, weighed 180 pounds, and was about 5 feet '8 inches in height. A letter was found in the pocket of his coat addressed to R.A. Ottiwell, Vineyard Haven, Mass.

The restoration by President McKinley of Consular fees calls to my remembrance the extortions to which in common with other shipmasters in days gone by I was subjected until we were relieved from them by wise legislation that deprived these Consular sharks of their power to rob the own-era, the officers, and the crews of ships in our merchant service.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 20. -- Howell C. Rees, President of the Matteawan Gas Company, will have to remain in the Hudson River State Hospital until Sept. 13 in order that the State physicians may determine his mental condition. This decision was reached by Justice Barnard of the Supreme Court this morning after a hearing of both sides of the case.

Larchmont Clubhouse, the grounds around it, and the harbor seemed to be the abode for fairies last night. The Larchmont yachtsmen had a Venetian fete and ball, and the scene rivaled any witnessed heretofore.

PITTSBURG, July 20. -- Great interest is manifested in the return to the city of the Inter-State Arbitration Board to-morrow, as the adoption of the true uniformity plan is largely dependent upon the success attained by the members of the board in their efforts to enlist the support of the operators of their several States in the movement.

MONTREAL, July 20. -- A blue book has just been issued by the Department of the Interior, at Ottawa, which contains some very interesting facts in relation to the gold-bearing regions of the Yukon. According to this report the major portion of the gold-producing soil is in Canadian territory, though the boundary line between Alaska and the British possessions is still a subject of dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Dr. William H. Dall, one of the Curators of the National Museum, is familiar with the region of country in which the Klondike gold fields are situated through having been on several geological expeditions to the region in Alaska adjoining the gold district, and says that in his opinion the reports from there probably are not exaggerated.

It is impossible for any person of sensibility not to experience a thrill of admiration and sympathy with the three brave Scandinavians who have taken flight in a balloon from the "jumping-off place" at the top of Norway in the hope that they may be blown upon or over the north pole.

The will of William T. Moon, who died in Paris, France, May 19 last, was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office. The value of the estate is placed at $1,320,000, all of which is left to his widow, Katherine E. Moon.

With the amendments and alterations which the rules of the Road Ordinance has received from the Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen, after granting hearings to all parties interested, the new code of street regulations will probably pass the board in the form in which it was introduced at yesterday morning's meeting.
MADRID, July 20. -- Senor Moret y Prendergast, the Liberal leader and former Minister, delivered a brilliant speech at Saragossa last night on the Cuban question.

It is eight years ago that the Bourne Mills of Fall River began the experiment of dividing with their help every six months a certain proportion of the profits in the form of a percentage dividend on the wages earned. This percentage has ranged from 2 1/3 to 7 per cent. semi-annually, or an average rate of 3 3/8 per cent. on the wages.

CINCINNATI, July 20. -- The Reds and Bostons played two games here this afternoon and broke even. Lewis pitched fine ball for the visitors in the first game. Klobedanz, the Bostons' pitcher, in the second game was touched up for nineteen hits, while the visitors made only two off Rhines's delivery. Umpire Hurst called the game after the sixth inning on account of darkness. Scores:
