In the State of Kentucky they seem to have the habit of saying things in high places that might better be left unsaid. The recent speech of Judge FALCONER declaring murder in certain circumstances justifiable is a case in point; the expression of unreasoning hostility to mothers-in-law in Gov. BRADLEY'S pardon of MARKS is another.
Why are the prosperous times for this country so largely due to the whimsical intervention of that Providence which our French friends say watches over fools, drunkards, and Americans?

The summons and complaint in an action brought by the administrators of the estate of the late Frank R. Hadley of New Bedford, Mass., against E.W. Scott, President of the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society of this city, and others were served yesterday on the Continental Trust Company, which is made a party to the suit.

LONDON, July 21. -- VIr. Dobell's five-yearold bay gelding Dolg. bra, by Em10erorDolinka, formerly the property of P. Lorillard, achieved a remarkable performance at the Liverpool July meeting to-day, having tied with lIatd of Valetta for first place in the race for the Windermere -ll-Aged Plate, and winning the Seaforth Welter Handicap, all within an hour and a half.
The Westchester Racing Association announces the closing of stakes for its Autumn meeting at Morris Park, on Monday, Aug. 16. The race meeting will begin Thursday, Oct. 14, and close Tuesday, Nov. 2.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 21. -- All the Lake AIichigan and Lake Superlor lines have decided to reduce the rate on grain products from A1inneapolis to :ew York ,from :_ to 20 cents a hundred during tire znonth of _ This action is understood to be made to induce the flour manufacturers to ship their products east during August, so that the enormous wheat crop uay. be handled f,'om September on.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 21. -- A letter has been received from Surveyor Ogilvie, who spent the Winter in the Yukon country. It is dated June 7, and made the quickest passage of any letter yet sent out from that country, arriving here July 20. It reads is follows, and is addressed to the Surveyor General:

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Those persons who have expected to read a message from President McKinley calling upon Congress to empower him to name a currency commission have been encouraged from time to time with reports that a message would be sent in when the Tariff bill was safely out of the way.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- William Berthius, a peddler of 315 Cortland Avenue, found the body of a man in the weeds and grass under the sidewalk at Grand and Kedzie Avenues this evening, and the police look on the case as one of mysterious murder. Around the body was wrapped many feet of barbed wire, the sharp points cutting through the clothing and into the flesh.

- The "press agent" is a nuisance or not, entirely according to the point of view. If you are not in a way to be interested in the object he is employed to boom, you are likely to find him an extremely irritating personage. But it must be admitted that his employment by an actress, a statesman, or the promoters of any sort of an enterprise is generally an indication of some prosperity.
CONSTANTINOPLE, July 21. -- The Sultan has issued an irade sanctioning the settlement of the frontier question in accordance with the wishes of the powers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 21. -- An explosion occurred this morning at the armory of the Winchester Repeating Arms Company here, and seven of the company's employes were instantly killed. At least a dozen more were more or less seriously hurt, but it has been impossible to obtain a corrected list of their names.

The National Democrats are organizing for a spirited campaign that will test the vitality of the party. This was the chief subject of discussion at the conference of the National Executive Committee yesterday afternoon. It was determined that the fight should be concentrated in Kentucky, Iowa, and Ohio, where the National Democrats have their strongest following, so that the real strength of the party may be subjected to a decisive test.

The law of the State of New York practically prohibits the employment of prisoners at any gainful or productive industry. The exception is that "the State or the political divisions thereof" not only may, but must, buy prison-made goods whenever it is certified to them that the prisons are prepared to supply their requirements.

The Hoboken Independent Frauen Verein is a beneficial organization composed wholly of women who meet regularly in Vasiel's Hall, Hoboken. Their Secretary is, or rather was, Mrs. Elizabeth Livermore, for Mrs. Livermore died a short time ago. She was a companionable woman, and when she was attacked by the illness which caused her death she summoned her lawyer and told him to draw up her will.
One of the clauses of the "free list" of the "act to provide revenue for the Government and to encourage the industries of the United States" now pending in the Senate reads as follows:

DENVER, Col., July 21. -- The first of the rush from the East of men who are going to the Klondike gold country in Alaska arrived in Denver to-day in the person of Herman Lowe of New York City. Mr. Lowe left here to-night for Seattle, and will wait there until four other New Yorkers, who are to form his party, arrive.
LONDON, July 21. -- The Morning Post continues to keep its columns open for correspondence on the subject of the alleged desire of Americans to provoke a quarrel with England.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 21. -- New York took two games from St. Louis to-day. The first was very closely played on both sides. Donahue took Hart's place in the box in the ninth inning, and the Giants batted out the game. The New Yorks won the second game in a walk, knocking McDermott out of the box in the sixth inning, and Coleman was batted equally hard. Score:

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 21. -- Cashier Stone of the defunct Sioux City Savings Bank is not out of the woods. For months he has been dodging indictments for forgery and fraudulent banking. A week ago friends partly made up his defalcations, the cases were dropped, ann he was expected home.

HAMPTON, Va., July 21. -- Here within the hospitable precincts of the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute a conference of colored people began to-day, its purpose being the agitation of questions of interest to their race. Such conferences are not rare at this place, where, since 1868, the negroes of America have found helpful friends, practical instruction, and wise counsel.

Commodore C.A. Postley's schooner yacht yesterday gave the Emerald the worst beating she has had this year. The race was sailed in a stiff northwesterly breeze off Larchmont, and the Colonia won by 12 minutes 89 seconds and beat the Emerald on all points of sailing. The Emerald, though, was badly handicapped, as she had a mixed crew on board and sails were not handled as smartly as they usually are.

Heitner o1 ,have archasecl from the Bryce .estate the old brick building 20 E Seven.tnth Street, adjoining th corner of Broadway, 25 by 100. The same firm purchased the four-story.brick building 15 East Seventeenth Street about a month ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 21. -- The steamship Umatilla, which arrived to-day from Puget Sound ports, brought down almost $200,000 worth of Alaskan gold, of which $136,700 was in gold dust from Seattle, consigned to the Wells-Fargo Company. There were several other shipments of gold in sacks.

The steamer Saturn, Capt. J.M. Lewis, bound from Newport News, Va., for Boston with coal, put in at Quarantine late yesterday afternoon with three of her crew badly injured as the result of the blowing out of a water column valve on one of her boilers.
READING, Penn., July 21. -- An angry mob of persons pushed a four-horse team drawing a wagonload of lions up the main street of Pottstown Monday evening. It culminated in a breakdown and runaway.

President King and many of the prominent and active members of the Merchants' Association of New York were busy yesterday afternoon exchanging views as to the most satisfactory dates for the first excursion to New York, under the auspices of the association. They were led to this action by the receipt, yesterday morning, of the following dispatch, which they interpreted as a virtual compliance with the request of the association for reduced rates:

The National Democrats are not waiting for some "accident and flood of fortune" to bear their party onward to its destiny. They are at work all over the country. They have their conventions, their committees, and their candidates, they are firm of purpose and of courage. They have the organization and the discipline of a well-seasoned party.

M. Mosler, President of the Mosler Safe Company, yesterday positively denied the rumor of an impending combination of the safe interests of this country or the formation of a trust in that branch of trade. He sent telegrams to his managers in Boston, Hamilton, Ohio, and Cincinnati, instructing them to notify the newspapers there to that effect. To a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES he said:

Only harness-racing enthusiasts ventured to Fleetwood Park yesterday afternoon, when the first day's card of the Summer meeting was successfully pulled off in spite of the rain. About 300 men occupied the veranda of the clubhouse and endeavored to secure places where the rain would not beat down on them.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The formal reading of the conference report on the Tariff bill was concluded in the Senate today, much time being consumed by the minority in asking questions and in attacking various features of the report. It is probable that the final vote will be taken in the Senate on Friday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 21. -- While Henrietta Hewson was asleep in her home, at 131 North Delaware Avenue, at no today, she was attacked by Maud Jones, who, rushing into the house flourishing a razor, slashed her in the stomach and face and almost severed her right arm. Mrs. Hewson died this afternoon. Both women are colored. The murderess was captured. It is believed that jealousy actuated the deed.

LONDON, July 21. -- The Duchess of Hamilton was married quietly Tuesday morning at Leicester to Mr. Foster. Little is known locally of the bridegroom. It is stated that the Duke of Devonshire was present at the ceremony.
The result of the preliminary competition of plans for the New York Public Library Building, to be erected on the site of the Forty-second Street reservoir, has been announced.

The regatta at Larchmont yesterday was for sloops of the fifty-one-foot class, with flush decks, thirty-footers, twenty-footers, and all classes of cabin catboats, sailing to-gether. In the fifty-one-foot class the yachtsmen were treated to an odd contest between the Awe and the Choctaw, which the Choctaw won.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for W.L. Crow Taylor, the builders, to a Mr. Foster, the three and a half story brownstone front dwelling 626 West End Avenue, 19 by 100. This is one of a row of eight houses recently completed by the sellers.

The public is prepared to believe almost anything about the Klondike gold fields. The latest reports carry the probable production to date rather above $5,000,000. What it will be after the thousands of miners now madly racing for the placers have staked out claims and begun to work them can only be conjectured.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 22. -- Oscar Williams, the negro who committed an assault on the daughter of a Henry County farmer last week and was transferred to the Macon Jail for safe keeping, was taken from the Central Railroad train, on which he was being brought to Atlanta, at Griffin, this morning and lynched.

LONDON, July 22. -- Whitelaw Reid, special envoy of the United States to the recent diamond jubilee festivities, gave a notable dinner this evening at his temporary residence, in Charlton House Terrace, as a return for British hospitality extended to him and Mrs. Reid during the last six weeks.

Any one interested in natural history who is compelled to live in the city and cannot get away to the woods and green fields for any length of time to collect, study, and observe the little creatures we call insects may still find something of interest in his daily walk to and from the workshop, even though the roads are paved with granite blocks and lined with brick walls.
BATAVIA, N.Y., July 22. -- The principal testimony in the Benham murder trial to-day was given by Prof. Rudolph A. Witthaus of New York.

The letter of "Old South Sea Trader" in your issue of the 15th inst. calls attention to another phase of the Hawaiian iniquity -mentioning the "fine race." Of what use or benefit has the native Kanaka ever been to civilization except as a "boat steerer" in old style whaling days? (if kept well primed with New England rum.)

President King and his co-workers of the Merchants' Association of New York had hopes of fixing definitely yesterday with the Joint Traffic and Trunk Line Associations the dates for excursions from the vast territory within the jurisdiction of those associations. But there are matters of detail which the railroad men must first arrange, and so a definite agreement was delayed.
PROVIDENCE, July 22. -- Dr. E. Benjamin Andrew's has resigned the Presidency of Brown University, and also his professorship therein.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 22. -- Marcus G. Nichols, an aged and wealthy farmer residing in Daniels Farm, in the Town of Trumbull, was foully murdered by two masked burglars at his home early this morning. His sister, Mary, who lived with him, was seriously and perhaps fatally shot, and the murderers and thieves abandoned the scene after ransacking the house and securing money thought to be about $200 in amount.

GALION, Mich., July 22. -- Frank Piscator has come back from the Yukon with $50,000, which is his share of a few weeks' work in the Klondike gold fields. A mortgage on the old Piscator homestead was about to be foreclosed, and he wished to save the dwelling. He came just in time to keep it from being sold over his father's head.

John Brooks Leavitt, Chairman of the Fourteenth Assembly District Branch of the Citizens' Union, in a speech which he delivered last night at a meeting of the branch, charged that certain influential men were trying to bring about an arrangement between the union and the Platt machine in the campaign for Mayor of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Prof. Willis Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, was very much interested in the report cabled from Christiania, Norway, that a carrier pigeon arrived yesterday bearing the significant message stamped on its wings: "North pole, 142w. 47.62." Prof. Moore, however, is inclined to look upon the report as a canard.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- At the close of the discussion in the Senate to-day on the tariff conference report Mr. Allison (Rep., Iowa) asked that some hour be fixed for to-to-morrow when the final vote should be taken. Objection was made by Senators Morgan, (Dem., Ala.,) Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) Harris, (Pop., Kan.,) and Pettus, (Dem., Ala.) Mr. Allison then suggested that the vote be taken at 1 o'clock on Saturday, and Mr. Morgan again objected.

The plans of the Brooklyn trolley companies were filed with Superintendent Martin at the Brooklyn Bridge office yesterday. They have been agreed upon as to their main features, and the only tracings now to be furnished are those for raising the train shed roof at the New York terminal. The elevated railroad plans will be in within the next few days.

PITTSBURG, July 22. -- Excitement was at fever heat in local mining circles to-day. The operators were convinced that matters had taken serious turn. Early in the morning about 500 miners from the Finleyville district marched on the Bunola mines and succeeded in bringing out the men at work.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 22. -- District Attorney Wood and Coroner Bevier had a consultation in this city to-day with regard to the case of Selma Larson, whose mysterious death is under investigation. They decided to have the stomach and its contents submitted to a chemical analysis, and Coroner Bevier proceeded with the preserved organs to Albany, where the analysis will be made by Edward J. Wheeler.

Ernst Krohn, until he dropped out of sight about ten days ago, Secretary of the Mozart Verein, at Eighty-sixth Street and Second Avenue, and member of half a dozen other German clubs, is missing from his accustomed haunts, and the police have a warrant for his arrest, charging him with the embezzlement of nearly $5,000.
PITTSBURG, July 22. -- A telegram from the Pittsburg and Lake Erie operator at Youngstown says a disastrous cloudburst occurred there this evening.

For some time past Wall Street has had the theory, that Chicago, speculatively, was bearish. Boston has been accredited with hopefulness and resultant profits in the upward movement; Chicago, however, has been left out of the bull calculations. From the tenor of the opinions of Chicago brokers, however, such is evidently not the case; on the contrary, Chicago, as a whole, seems to have become quite bullish.
Edward W. Scott, President of the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society yesterday made the following statement to a reported for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- It can be stated upon the authority of a gentleman having the closest relations with Secretary Gage that the Administration has prepared, and, in its view, perfected a plan for currency reform, which will be kept secret until the meeting of the next Congress, to be then presented to that body as the first business of the session.

HAMPTON, Va., July 22. -- A spirit of enthusiasm entered the conference of colored people in Hampton Institute to-day. Nearly 400 active clergymen from various sections of the South held morning, afternoon, and evening sessions and took up a wide range of topics pertaining to the everyday life of the Southern negro.

Insanity first half of 1896, 1 2-3 per cent. Insanity first half of 1897, 2 1/2 per cent. These figures, correct within fractions, are from official reports of the Kings County Penitentiary, and illustrate the result of partial enforced idleness among the convicts.

There was sunshine at Brighton Beach yesterday, but the track was heavy and the fields small in spite of the fact that the purses were fat. There was a little excitement occasioned by a very bad race by Nana H., whose manipulators got badly bitten when Ein beat her, and R.W. Walden gave the public another of his periodical surprises, winning a stake race with his maiden colt Don't Care.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- The attention of Secretary Sherman was directed to the published statement that he had been induced to sign the letter of instructions to Ambassador Hay relative to the seal controversy, which has so excited the British press, only under severe pressure and against his own judgment.

The irade of the Sultan ordering the settlement of the Thessalian boundary according to the orders of the powers seems to be a complete and final surrender. But there is no telling. The Sultan may not yet be at the end of his resources. Of course he was acting under duress when he issued this irade, and would not have issued it if he had not been forced to do so.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- In reply to a telegraphic request, Gen. A.W. Greely, the Arctic explorer, has sent the Associated Press, from Linden, Va., the following signed statement regarding the Andree expedition:
BOSTON, July 22. -- "Lieut. Lang knows too well the cause of our separation," said Mrs. Lang to-day at Fort Warren. She then gave out the following signed statement:

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 22. -- E.T. Hubbell of Rogers Hubbell, brokers in this city, has absconded, leaving his partner short by about $10,000. Hubbell had previously spent two years in the penitentiary for speculating with the funds of a bank in which he was employed.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- There has been a heavy run on Collectors of Internal Revenue in all of the larger cities of the country by brewers, who are purchasing beer stamps in large quantities at the 7 1/2 cents discount allowed under existing law, in anticipation of the final passage of the Tariff bill, which repeals the discount now allowed.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Tillman offered a resolution discharging the Committee on Contingent Expenses from further consideration of his resolution for an investigation of alleged Senatorial sugar speculation. Mr. Jones of Nevada immediately presented the report of the committee on the resolution. Mr. Tillman moved that the report be read, but his motion was lost on a viva voce vote, and the resolution went to the calendar.

It is a pity that the stock gamblers in the Senate of the United States are not better equipped for their vocation as stock gamblers, as well as for their avocation as lawmakers. If they were, they would know that there are two sides to the market, and that money is to be made on the "short" side as well as on the "long."

A vote will be taken on the Tariff bill to-day and an adjournment is expected to-morrow. At the present writing it is still uncertain whether the much-promised currency message will be sent in or not. It is clear that, if sent in, it will not be acted on in the Senate.

The efforts of the Executive Committee of the Southwestern Freight Bureau to bring about an understanding between the steamship lines whose vessels run between New York and Galveston have come to naught, and nothing remains for its peace committee but to report its failure to end the freight war.

LONDON, July 22. -- A special dispatch from Copenhagen says that a carrier pigeon has been caught in the vicinity of Tromsoe Island, near the north point of Norway, with the following stamped upon its wing:

While Dr. EKHOLA, who was associated with ANDREE last year, is inclined to frown upon the first of the carrier pigeon stories, that from the neighborhood of Soevda, in Rifylke, the second tale about a second bird, from near Tromsoe Island, in Norway, whence ANDREE started for Spitzbergen, seems to be credited.

Acting Mayor Jeroloman, ex officio member of the Law Committee of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday gave an extended consideration of the proposed ordinance regarding the rules of the road which was introduced before the Board of Aldermen last Tuesday as the report of the Law Committee. Next Tuesday the rules will come before the board, and, it is hoped, will be passed without material opposition.

FAIRMONT, West Va., July 22. -- Armed Deputy Sheriffs now guard the Hite mine at Kings, three miles above here, on the Tygarts Valley River. The Sheriff was called there this afternoon, as the operators feared an outbreak, but no arrests were made. Early this morning the drivers at that mine joined the strikers.

The force of the coal miners' strike seems to be broken by the substantial failure to make it general in West Virginia and in Illinois. The only hope that the leaders of the strike had of being able to enforce their demands lay in their ability practically to stop production and bring the pressure of interests thus injured upon the employers.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 22. -- Cliff Porter, the well-know trainer, is dying at St. Joseph's Hospital. To-night he decided to sell his twenty-two head of thoroughbreds, in training at the various Western tracks. His physicians say he will never recover.

It is reported to be the belief of President MCKINLEY that when he puts his name to the Tariff bill the country will enter on at least ten years of repose from further legislation and even from effective agitation of that subject.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- A number of Newark men have formed a company, and propose to send men to Alaska. A meeting was held in Huelsenbeck's Hall, 270 Fifteenth Avenue, Tuesday night, and the first step toward sending out a party of about 200 men was taken.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- W.R. Cregier, son of ex-Mayor De Witt C. Cregier, had his right arm shattered this afternoon by the premature discharge of a cannon on board the yacht Leywandyne, cruising in the harbor near the Randolph Street viaduct.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Representative C.W. Stone of Pennsylvania, who was Chairman of the Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures of the last House, to-day introduced in the House a bill to authorize the appointment of a Monetary Commission and to provide for its expenses. The text of the bill is as follows:

A further batch of testimony in the suit brought by Mrs. Sarah Ann Angell to recover her dower right from the heirs-at-law of Jay Gould, to whom she says she was married in 1853, was filed yesterday in the office of the County Clerk. The evidence is in favor of the Gould heirs. It was taken before Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court at Tarrytown, and also at the Plaza Hotel, in this city.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 22. -- At 3:37 o'clock this afternoon the North American Transportation Company's steamer Portland sailed from Seattle to St. Michael, Alaska, from which point her passengers will be transferred to Yukon River steamers and carried to the famous Klondike gold fields.

The resolution passed by the House yesterday authorizing the President to investigate the obstacles to the sale abroad of American tobacco and to open negotiations to secure their removal is a sensible measure and should promptly be approved by the Senate.
YORK, Penn., July 23. -- The fact of valuable silver and copper discoveries in the South Mountains, in which York County capitalists are interested, was made public in York to-day.

The new bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange in the first half of this year amount to less than a fifth of the average for the corresponding six months of the past twelve years, but the amount of new bonds substituted for old ones was more than double the average of the past twelve years.

President Coffin of the General Electric Company reaches London to-day. It is semi-officially admitted that one of the largest contracts ever taken by the General Electric Company is to be closed during the coming week, an important Europen railroad proposing to follow the New York and New Haven, and adopt the third rail system for moving heavy trains.

BALTIMORE, July 23. -- Receivers Cowen and Murray of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad were sustained to-day in two decisions by the Judges of the United States courts for the District of Maryland. The first case was a petition by the receivers for permission to issue receivers' certificates to the amount of $2,300,000 for the purchase of new freight cars and locomotives.

Mr. PLATT refuses to be coaxed. He thinks he cannot be driven. The possession of the Federal offices gives him a sense of power and majesty. He imagines that he is in a position to dictate terms, to make or reject treaties of alliance, and to exercise all the prerogatives of unhampered sovereignty.

The following appeared in a recent letter from Paris to The London Daily Telegraph: "Some literary and journalistic Germans having recently resolved to repair and decorate Heine's grave in Montmartre Cemetery, the guardian or chief caretaker of the graveyard in question has given them a lesson in the exigencies of French official formality.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The final vote on the tariff conference report will be taken in the Senate at 3 P.M. to-morrow. A unanimous agreement to that effect was reached in the Senate late this afternoon, after an exciting and dramatic debate.

The general consuming public must regard with some degree of satisfaction the fact that the attorney for one of the local branches of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association of this city has taken in hand the question of investigating retail liquor establishments where spirituous drinks are disposed of at 5 cents each.
BUFFALO, July 23. -- The Commissioner appointed by the Surrogate to ascertain the value of the estate of the late E.G. Spaulding, the "father of The greenback," began taking testimony to-day.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 23. -- The steamship Saturn, Capt. Lewis, from Newport News for Boston, arrived here at noon to-day, and reported the loss of the barge P.C. Merriman, which she was towing from Norfolk to Boston, with a cargo of 1,357 tons of coal.
In the State of Guerrero, in Mexico, there has been found by Mr. William Niven a ruined city, "Omitlan." Guerrero skirts the Pacific. Acapulco is its port, and its capital is Chilpancingo.

A fair-sized crowd of horsemen had assembled on the clubhouse veranda at Fleetwood yesterday, and had seen three capital heats pulled off, which whetted their appetites for better sport to come, when the storm that had threatened for an hour burst in full fury, driving every one to cover and deluging the track beyond hope of further racing.

Fire in the American Biscuit Company's cracker factory at 92, 94, and 96 Elizabeth Street, between Grand and Hester Streets, last night, gave the firemen a hard fight, and for a while it looked as if it was likely to spread to other buildings. The structure was erected thirty-five years ago and occupies a front of 75 feet on Elizabeth Street, with a depth of 100 feet, half way through the block toward the Bowery.

In the British Museum there is at present an exhibition of ancient manuscripts, papers, and printed books relating to the early history of the English Church. The earliest relic is a Psalter, after the version of St. Jerome, the date of which is about A.D. 700. It is filled with miniatures executed in the Anglo-Hibernian manner.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- Two British steamers laden with valuable cargoes of sugar are to-night scudding over the seas toward this port as fast as their engines can carry them, in a race against time, tide, and tariff.

There are few American books more worthy of reproduction than "Georgia Scenes." Its author, Augustus Baldwin Longfellow, who was Gen. Longstreet's uncle, was a minister in the Methodist Episcopal Church. He lived for may years in Augusta, Ga., where he was born. He was President of Emory College, and afterward President of a college in Louisiana.

It is probable that the records of lynching for the past few weeks in the older and more settled parts of the United States have never been equaled before. That is a very sad thing in itself in a country in which laws are the expressions of the public opinion of the community.

At the dinner recently given in London to celebrate the completion of some of the editorial work connected with the great Dictionary of National Biography, it was stated that up to the present time fifty-one volumes of the dictionary had been published. During thirteen years a volume had been produced quarterly with exemplary punctuality -- in fact, not a single volume had been a day behind its time.

Lord Dufferin presided a few weeks ago at St. Martin's Town Hall, in London, over a meeting of the Irish Literary Society, when a lecture was delivered by Mr. Richard Ashe-King on "Richard Brinsley Sheridan." The lecturer warmly defended Sheridan's character against the popular conception of it. Lord Dufferin, who was warmly greeted, afterward said:

The most violent thunderstorm New York has seen in a long time passed over the city yesterday afternoon, crossing the river from New Jersey. The sky began to darken to the westward soon after 3 o'clock. In a few minutes a veil of cloud and mist was thrown over Jersey City, completely hiding it from view.

The advocates of Hawaiian annexation attempt in various ways to meet the objection that if we take the islands we must build a powerful Pacific navy to defend them. It is asserted that nobody else wants Hawaii, which is equivalent to saying that it is not worth taking. No other power would dare meddle with the possessions of the United States of America, we are told.

Postmaster General Gary paid a flying visit to New York this week, arriving at the Waldorf Thursday, and leaving yesterday morning. It is supposed his visit was on private business, as he did not call at the General Post Office, nor did he meet Postmaster Van Cott. The Postmaster called at the Waldorf Thursday evening, but the Postmaster General was not in.

Several more interesting developments in the Worth-Platt affair in Kings County came to light yesterday, and among other things clearly indicated the increasing sentiment across the river for Seth Low.

PADUCAH, Ky., July 23. -- The Casino Summer Theatre Building was burned tonight. The fire originated on the stage. Six hundred people were panic-stricken, and about 200 injured. Three children are missing, and are supposed to have perished in the flames.

PITTSBURG, July 23. -- The coal strike situation in this district has not materially changed to-day. The efforts of the Arbitration Commissioners have been so far successful that a call for a meeting of operators on Tuesday next has been issued.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The House spent the greater part of to-day awaiting final action by the Senate on the Tariff bill. After routine business was disposed of Mr. Dingley, the leader of the majority, announced that he had been informed that the Senate might vote on the conference report to-day, and on his motion a recess was taken until 5 P.M.

The Century Company has just announced an offer made by itself of three prizes of $250 each, to be given during four successive years to college graduates for excelence in literary work. Competition will be open to all persons who, in any college or university in the United States, receive the degree of Bachelor of Arts during the commencement seasons of 1897, 1898, 1899, and 1900.

NEWPORT, July 23. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day; Sloop Navahoe, owned by Royal Phelps Carroll; sloop Lotowana, owned by Mr. Bourne; sloop Wasp, owned by R. Lippit; sloop Thistle, owned by Mr. Chapman; schooner Elsie Marie, owned by J.B. King; schooner Carlotta, owned by C.F. Ulrichs; schooner Ingomar, owned by Mr. Barrett; steamer Conqueror, owned by F.W. Vanderbilt, and steamer Wadena, owned by G.H. Wade.

Valuable as is Prof. Frederick William Maitland's Domesday Book and Beyond," the study of it is only to be undertaken by the rare specialist. As the learned author expresses it, "unless we have mistaken the general drift of legal history, the law implied in Domesday Book ought to be for us a very difficult law -- far more difficult than the law of the thirteenth century, for the the seventh.

The numerous east-side tenants who live in the areas that are soon to be converted into two parks are in consternation over notices that were posted on the walls announcing that the houses in the districts would be sold at public auction on July 27, and that the purchasers would have to tear them down within twenty days after Aug. 1 or forfeit the purchase money.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Senator Clark of Wyoming was taken suddenly ill at the Capitol to-day with a severe attack of stomach, trouble. He fainted, but was soon revived, and was taken to his home.

Within the metropolitan district lovers of cycle racing have their choice to-day between two big meets, and most of the fast riders are entered in the one or the other. The nearest of these for New Yorkers is The Herald's Free Ice and Charity Fund athletic and bicycle tournament at Manhattan Field, where the events, if not, strictly speaking, of the highest class of cycle racing, will be most entertaining.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 23. -- A desperate fight took place yesterday between Senator Carey's force of cowboys and a party of outlaws known throughout Wyoming as the "Hole in the Walt Gang," in which R.H. Devine, foreman of the cowboys, and Lee Devine, his son, were wounded, and "Bob" Smith, one of the outlaws, was killed, and "Bob" Taylor captured.

Joel B. Goodman and his wife were chloroformed and robbed by burglars early yesterday morning at their Summer home in Far Rockaway. This is the twelfth robbery that has occurred in Far Rockaway during the past ten days. There are only five men on the village police force, three of whom are on duty during the day and two at night.

Eleanora Duse's Parisian season is over and the passing of a remarkable paradox is completed. In Paris more than anywhere else in the world the opinion of the theatre-going public follows the dictates of the dramatic critics. The critics shelved the plays of Balzac and made fame for the dramas of Victor Hugo and the Dumases.

PEORIA, Ill., July 23. -- The main building of the Peoria Grape Sugar Company was completely destroyed by fire this evening. The loss is $500,000, the total insurance carried being $460,000, of which nearly $300,000 was on the burned building and contents.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- A disastrous wind, hail and rain storm swept over Philadelphia late this afternoon. The storm entered the city from the west and took a northeasterly course, the greater part of the damage being done in West Philadelphia. Growing crops near the city were damaged to the extent of thousands of dollars.

The name of Ruth McEnery Stuart has become pretty well known to the readers of Harper's Magazine. Her Southern studies have the charm of sunshine and deeply fragrant gardens, and her Simpkinsville is a village very different from the austere "volcano under snows" type of New England town with which we at the North have become so well acquainted.

There is no doubt that in bringing together these selections from the "sources" of our National history in a form convenient to schools and libraries and to the general public Prof. Hart has struck the note of his time. The serious public tends to outgrow historical judgments at second hand, and craves a chance to get hold of the plain tale as told by eye-witnesses.

There is no principle of Congressional procedure more clearly sound, or more generally acknowledged in theory, than that conferrees cannot put new provisions in a bill referred to them. Their sole authority is to seek to adjust differences between the two houses. The reason for such a principle is obvious.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Bills and joint resolutions were introduced in the House to-day as follows:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 23. -- A dreadful explosion occurred on the steamer Nutmeg State of the Bridgeport Steamboat Company's Line at 6:30 o'clock this evening while she was lying at her slip at the foot of South Street, and as a result four men are dead, three others are thought to be fatally injured, and a number more are in a serious condition.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23. -- The Klondike craze has struck the speculative element hard. Companies of all kinds are being organized, while the signs and window letterings are appearing with marvelous rapidity in the principal business streets. Such titles as "Yukon Trading and Development Company," "The Yukon Gold and Supply Company," and the "Klondike Improvement Syndicate" are to be seen on every hand.

Mrs. Rosina Vollhart has bought from the estate of Julius Lipman the seven-story apartment house, St. Beran, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 50 by 100. The pride is reported at about $200,000.
Canon Ainger, who wrote for the Dictionary of National Biography the article on Charles and Mary Lamb, will write for it the one on Tennyson.

How charmingly and tenderly Charles Lamb has written on this subject, and how delightfully he could have expatiated upon the treasures to be unearthed in even the shabbiest and dirtiest of old shops! How quaint, too, are some of the old shopkeepers, and what delightful talks one may have with them, for there seems to be a kind of freemasonry among book-lovers, bringing them together at once, and for all time.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 23. -- The cloudburst which struck this city and vicinity at 7 o'clock last night was very disastrous. Carl Henry Mayer was struck by lightning and instantly killed, while his sweetheart, who stood near by, was badly shocked.

The deal by which the Rapid Transit Company, the financiering organization of the Brooklyn Heights Electric Railway system, will purchase the Brooklyn Union Elevated Company with all its assets and franchises seems to be almost complete. It is understood that a large sum in cash will he paid down, and that the entire indebtedness will be assumed by the syndicate representing the Transit Company.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 23. -- All the railways centring in Pittsburg suffered from the great storm which swept through the Mahoning and Shenango Valleys. On the Erie and Ashtabula Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad the rain resembled a cloudburst in many places. Landslides and washouts were frequent, and many bridges and trestles were rendered unsafe.

Moncure D. Conway writes in The Athenaeum that the portrait of Thomas Paine, painted by Romney, (the only portrait of Paine ever painted from the man himself and long believed to be lost,) he is convinced, hangs now in the National Portrait Gallery in London. His interesting article we give in full:

Charles Sing, who lives at 958 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, was the owner of a mastiff dog which he valued at $200. Last night it attacked Venie Sing, the owner's twenty-year-old daughter, who had a narrow escape.

A complaint was recently made that repairs were badly needed in Central Park; that buildings and bridges required painting; that the roads were in poor condition; that the lawns were worn out, and that the large lake should be drained for sanitary reasons.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Black, who lived yesterday morning at 148 Clinton Street, are probably the oldest of all the many married couples of this big town, and they were saved from death by burning by the vigilance of their little dog.

" We may be proud of the architectural charms of our library building, and find delight in its artistic decoration, but if the institution does not accomplish the work for which libraries are designed it is not a success." Such are the forceful words used in the opening paragraph of the forty-fifth a annual report (for 1896) of the Boston Public Library.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- In view of the present rush of travel to the Klondike gold fields, Secretary Gage has established a sub-port of entry at Dyea, Alaska. The action was taken as the result of an application to the Treasury Department by Canada for permission for Canadian vessels to enter at Dyea, Alaska, and land passengers and baggage there.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 23. -- Coroner Bevier of Matteawan received a letter this evening from William Charvell, late butler at the Dinsmore mansion at Staatsburg, whose name has been mentioned in connection with the mysterious death of Selma Larsen.

The hearing before the Commissioner of Public Works on the application of the Metropolitan Street Railway for permission to change the motive power of the Fourth Avenue line from horses to underground trolley was closed yesterday. Commissioner Collis reserved his decision, announcing that he had not reached any conclusion in the matter. He said that the statement published in a morning paper that he had decided to grant the application was untrue.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Senate Committee on Immigration failed again today to secure a quorum. It is believed that no other effort will be made to secure a meeting during the present session, and that the nomination of Mr. Powderly, as well as that of Mr. Fitchie, will be allowed to fail.

When the Apostle Paul declared at Thessalonica and Berea that Christ, the expected Messiah, must suffer and die, that He must rise again from the dead, and that Jesus of Nazareth was the Messiah, he at once aroused the most bitter enmity of the Jews. The Messiah or Christ for whom they looked would deliver their nation from all oppressors and re-establish it with the ancient splendor and power of King David.

The Vencedor and Syce and The Raccoon and Musme furnished two rattling good contests at Larchmont yesterday. In each race were sailed in a fresh breeze from the south-finish, and the races were in doubt until the finishing line had been crossed. The races were sailed in a fresh breeze from the south-southwest, which held true all day.

A mock murder trial, conducted in a vacation school at 25 Norfolk Street, with the assistance of two teachers, has surprised and shocked the officers and members of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, which carries on and controls the school.

The curious inaccessibility to public opinion of the Senate of the United States, as at present constituted, is very well illustrated by the report of Senator JONES of Nevada on Senator TILLMAN'S resolution for an investigation of the charges of speculating in Sugar. Nobody doubts that Senators have speculated in stocks that might be affected by their votes.

SING SING, N.Y., July 23. -- Warden Sage of Sing Sing Prison set a gang of twenty-five convicts at work to-day on the road improvements he intends to make on Durston Avenue, the main approach to the prison from the railroad station, and the Secor Road. Durston Avenue, named for the late Warden Charles Durston, was some time ago nearly all washed down at the north end upon Secor Road.

In The Outlook, Mr. S.D. McCormick gives his reminiscences of Gen. Robert E. Lee as a college President. The wonderful memory that Gen. Lee had is illustrated. Some thirty students, newcomers, had called on the President of the university to pay their respects to him, and among them was Mr. McCormick. In the course of a week fully 400 students were introduced.

Some of the policy holders of the Massachusetts Mutual Benefit Life Association, who did not say all they wanted to say at the indignation meeting in the Equitable Building Thursday, met in A. Edward Woodruff's office yesterday afternoon, thinking they would have another chance. There was no formal meeting, however, although a great deal of irritation was expressed in a personal and individual way.

COLUMBIA, Ohio, July 23. -- Judge Taft of the Federal Court issued an order to-day authorizing Receiver Monsarrat of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway to issue $500,000 receiver's certificates to draw interest at 5 per cent., the proceeds to be used to relieve the receiver's notes outstanding.

Secretary of State John Sherman, with his secretary, E.J. Babcock, reached this city last night on their way to Amagansett, R. I., where they will stay a few weeks for rest and recuperation. The Secretary said he had felt the heat in Washington very much, and was looking for a cool place.

The first service connected with the first session of the Jewish Chautauqua Summer Assembly was held in Temple Beth Israel, Atlantic City, last evening, when the address was made by the Rev. Joseph Krauskopt. The divine service in connection with the opening is to be held this morning, when the address will be delivered by the Rev. Joseph Silverman of this city.

According to the recently published annual report of the managers of the American Bible Society, there were issued by that organization during the year ending March 31, 1897, 1,513,499 copies of the Scriptures, or portions thereof. Of these, 847,325 were issued from the Bible house in this city, and the remainder, 666,174, in foreign lands, under the society's direction.

MARIENBURG, West Prussia, July 2. -- Among the many plans and projects of the German Emperor to recall the past and at the same time encourage the public taste in architecture and the arts is the complete restoration of the old castle of Marienburg, on the Nogat, a branch of the Vistula, near the outlet of that historic stream into the Baltic.

HAMPTON, Va., July 23. -- It is the prevailing sentiment among the colored teachers, missionaries, clergymen, and lay workers, who have just brought their conference at Hampton Institute to a close, that much good has been accomplished this week for the cause of the elevation and advancement of the negro race. An earnest spirit has pervaded all the deliberations, and there has been considerable instructive matter and much good sense in the addresses.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 23. -- The jury which has been investigating the flood caused by the bursting of the Melzingah dams, and which caused the death of seven persons, finished the inquest at Matteawan to-day and returned to Coroner Bevier a verdict holding the Matteawan and Fish-kill Water Company responsible for the disaster.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 23. -- From 2:30 o'clock this afternoon until 4 o'clock a succession of thunder storms poured a flood of water upon the country in this vicinity. There was also a remarkable display of electrical phenomena. In addition to the showers there was a heavy fall of hail, which did great damage to the tobacco and corn crops and all standing grain.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Friend again faced the Giants to-day, but the strain of two successive games proved too much for him, and he was very wild and was hit hard at the right time. AIeekin pitched a steady game, received good support, and kept his hits well scattered excepting in one inning. Callahan made the star play of the game by a running catch in deep centre.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The signing of the Tariff bill by the President at 4:04 o'clock this afternoon was an interesting event. It had been arranged that the President should go to the Capitol to perform that function, but owing to uncertainty as as to the time that the bill would be ready, that plan was abandoned.

Running a gambling casino is a much more profitable business than editing a literary periodical, says a writer in The Month. The annual balance sheet of the Monte Carlo Casino has just been issued, and shows a profit of nearly 800,000. This means that the bank, not the gambler, has been the greater winner. Items of expense are given in this balance sheet, one of them being 62,000 for subventions to the press.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The Post says: "An industrial combination on a scale which will mark an epoch in centralization is promised in the near future. According to Stock Exchange gossip the following corporations are mentioned as likely soon to merge their identity in one colossal whole:

A new specimen of the finny tribe of the Bermuda coast has been placed on exhibition at the Aquarium. He is called the "trunk fish," though his body is more the shape of a traveling bag. He at all events has his trunk, and viewed head on he looks more like a pig. He is eight inches long and yellow in color, though mottled with white spots.

One day, while dining together the French Ambassador and a Grand Duke of Russia were discussing the cleverness of the pickpockets of their respective countries. The Grand Duke claimed that the Russian pickpocket was the more skillful. Seeing the Ambassador incredulous, he told him he would, without knowing it, be relieved of his watch before leaving the table.

All there is of Boer history for the last eighty years is a struggle for personal liberty. The Boer is the embodiment of republicanism without a republic. The Boer ideal is to live upon a farm so big as to conceal from view his next neighbor, and to be exempt from all government interference, particularly that of the tax collector.

IN the dearth of new English plays of good promise, Sydney Grundy bethought him of the elder Dumas, the most prolific of novelists and dramatists, and his "theatre," a whole library of smart plays, supposedly almost unknown to the present generation of playgoers.

GLASGOW, July 12. -- The Clyde's jubilee of yacht racing is finished. The racing to-day was spoiled by a flat calm which prevailed till noon, and by faint and shifty breezes in the afternoon. The bigger yachts with their long courses could only complete one turn round the course. The Emperor of Germany's cutter Meteor did not arrive, and the first-class match was confined to the Hester and the Duke d'Abruzzi's Bona.

LENOX, Mass., July 24. -- The Golf Club proposes to give a dance in the assembly rooms some evening next week, probably Wednesday. This will be the first large dance held in Lenox this season. There are so many young people in Lenox now that it will be fully attended.

Charles Frohman arrived on the Paris yesterday from a long visit to England an the Continent. He has thoroughly established himself as a theatrical manager in London and Paris, and spoke with confidence of the success to be won abroad by American playwrights, actors, and managers.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The approaching visit of the German Emperor and Empress to Russia will be signalized by a great display of Muscovite pomp and ceremony. The programme is not definitely arranged. The German visitors will arrive on Aug. 7, at Cronstadt Roads, where the Emperor Nicholas and the Empress will meet them on board the Russian imperial yacht Alexander.

On the evening of the 29th of August, 1864, I directed the telescope for the first time to a planetary nebula in Draco. The reader may now be able to picture to himself to some extent the feeling of excited suspense, mingled with a degree of awe, with which, after a few moments of hesitation, I put my eye to the spectroscope.

The teachers in the Summer vacation schools, which are conducted by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, have a great deal of crude material to work upon. A large proportion of their pupils are of foreign parentage and very poor. No text books are used in these vacation schools, and the methods of instruction adopted encourage the children to think and speak freely.

The Larchmont race week is over, and all the members of the club will take a week for rest. The race week this year has been remarkably successful, and the yachtsmen have been heartily congratulated by all those who have been at Larchmont during the week. There were seven days of racing.

Eighty bricklayers employed at Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook, have struck for higher wages, and the work is at a standstill. The contract for the work was awarded to a Newark firm, and the firm paid the bricklayers forty cents an hour. The men demanded fifty cents, the same rate that prevails in this city, and when this demand was refused they went out.

One cannot help wondering whether there has not been an undue reaction against the moral tale, and whether in consequence the vast opportunity for ethical training which is presented by the child's first contact with the world of letters is not now in a measure lost. When all simple narrative is thrilling to his unjaded taste, we need not fear that he will be bored by even an obtrusive moral.

Some of the owners of fine horses, especially in the West, are encouraging the use of paper horseshoes. Several sets of these shoes have been put on by Chicago blacksmiths. They are said to be more durable than iron shoes, and are more easily and snugly fitted to the horse's hoof. The blacksmith fastens them on with nails in the usual manner.

Perhaps there are as many fair fish stories now as there used to be, but one is apt to grow fastidious in the matter of fish stories as he grows older and to take delight only in those of superlative quality. The first essential of a good fish story is truth, clear, crystal-like, unadulterated truth.
We published yesterday morning a very interesting letter from Mr. O'REILLY, the editor of The Liquor Trade Review.

A handsome bronze tablet to the memory of Canvass White and William C. Young, the surveyors and constructors of the Erie Canal, from the studios of the Tiffany Glass and Decorating Company of this city, has been erected in the main hall of the Oneida Historical Society at Utica.

During the heavy rainstorm Friday evening, about 6 o'clock, a car of the Marcy Avenue branch of the Nassau Railroad left Sheepshead Bay for the Broadway ferries, Brooklyn. It was packed with passengers, among them being a woman with four little children, one of them a babe in arms.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor to-day sent telegrams to officers of thirty-eight National trades unions calling for a conference to be held at Wheeling, West Va., at noon, Tuesday, July 27. This was done in response to a telegram from President W.D. Ratchford of the United Mine Workers of America, in which he says that peaceable assemblage and free speech have been forbidden and suppressed in West Virginia.
LAGUNA, N.M., July 24. -- The Mesa Encantada was climbed yesterday by Prof. William Libbey's party. The apparatus of the life-saving service was used with success.

A bright anecdote is related in The Temple Magazine concerning Marion, the two-year-old baby of the Cleveland family. The three children were taken to Princeton by Mrs. Cleveland about two weeks before the inauguration of Mr. McKinley. When they had their wraps and bonnets on ready to start, and were about to kiss President Cleveland good-by until he should join them in Princeton, the father asked:

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- Of several vessels which were known to be steaming for this port laden with products dutiable under the new tariff act, and which were due here last night and to-day, the only one to arrive was the British steamship Hurworth, which sailed from Samarang, Java, May 22, heavily laden with sugar.

OUT at the end of an East River pier, at the foot of Delancey Street, two blocks above Grand Street Ferry, one of the most interesting pieces of engineering work that New York has seen for a dozen years and more has just been started.

The jubilee celebration seems likely to start a craze for collecting relics of the Queen's early days, writes Henri Labouchere in Truth. I wonder that nobody has thought of hunting up the satin shoes she gave to painters of full-length portraits. There was an unwritten law then against, showing more than the tip of one shoe.

On Friday morning, referring to the doubt as to whether the President would send a currency message to Congress at the extra session, THE TIMES remarked: "The alternatives are simple -- a good message or none."

The redwood is the glory of the coast range. It extends along the western slope, in a nearly continuous belt ten miles wide, from beyond the Oregon boundary to the south of Santa Cruz, a distance of nearly 400 miles, and in massive, sustained grandeur and closeness of growth surpasses all the other timber woods of the world.

WICHITA, Kan., July 24. -- A charter was granted to-day to the Superior, Hutchinson and Little Rock Railroad, which is to be built between Fort Smith, Ark., and Superior, Neb. The road is capitalized for $10,000,000. It will pass through Tahlequah, Indian Territory, the capital of the Cherokee Nation; Wichita, Kan.; Hutchinson, Kan., and many other important business centres.

Many of our contemporaries can write more symmetrical essays than Margaret Fuller ever wrote. All her work is fragmentary. But what about the illuminating citicism, the suggestive, original thought in her letters, her diaries, and her books? She was the first to say certain things, the first to introduce certain great subjects and great men to the American people.

A round head shows well-balanced character; the symmetry of the head is only the outcome of the symmetrically developed brain. If the head is knobby and has angles and corners, it is perhaps the head of a crank, or just as possibly, it may be the head of a genius, the strong points of whose mind have made themselves prominent through the skull.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The extra session of Congress came to an end at 9 o'clock to-night. The adjournment came about through the adoption by both House and Senate of a resolution originating in the House Ways and Means Committee. This resolution was reported to the House by Mr. Dingley immediately after the Tariff bill had been signed by the Speaker.

The sudden opening to mankind of the Klondike region calls attention anew and most powerfully to the vast area of the globe which has not yet been brought into subjection to mankind. Here is a region six thousand miles of land and water away from the nearest point of departure.

IN Madison Avenue, facing Madison Square and close by Dr. Parkhurst's church and within a stone's throw of the site of the building formerly occupied by the Union League Club, stands, at No. 33, the mansion of Mr. Clarence Armstrong Seward. Jr., President of the Union Club, and nephew of the famous statesman, William Henry Seward.

If rich mines of the precious metals were the sure foundation of national greatness, Peru would not be to-day an unstable republic shaken by continual revolutions, and Mexico would be one of the powers of the earth. Gold and silver alone have not usually blessed the land of their origin.

The United States battleships Massachusetts and Texas passed out at Sandy Hook at 5:10 P.M. yesterday, bound for Newport, where they will be joined by other ships of the North Atlantic fleet, for the Summer manoeuvres under Admiral Sicard. The whole fleet is expected to be at the rendezvous by Aug. 1.

PARIS, July 13. -- The Chamber having made up its mind to sit for another month, the holidays, for most of us, have been postponed. Not much attention has been paid to the Yellow Book on Cretan affairs, published yesterday, for the whole situation is supposed to have been accurately delineated long ago in the public press.

ALBANY, July 24. -- International Revenue Collector Louis W. Pratt of the Fourteenth District, which extends from the Harlem River to the Canada line, since Thursday has received demands for about $400,000 in beer stamps, the purchasers desiring to secure the rebate of 7 1/2 per cent, before the new tariff law went into effect.

With a cloudy sky and a stiff wind the Second Battalion of Naval Militia the Brooklyn organization, left the pier at East River, foot of Twenty-eighth Street, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning to cruise for nearly a week along the Jersey shore. The Brooklyn tars numbered 160, all told, and were under the command of Capt. W.A. Stayton.

Perhaps one of the most remarkable uses to which bacteria have been put is that of vermin exterminators or poisoning agents. It was in the year 1889 that Prof. Loeffler, while experimenting with mice in his laboratory at Greifswald, discovered a micro-organism which was extremely fatal to all kinds of mice.
-- Franchetti, the banker-composer, is building an opera house at his country seat, where he can have his own works performed without subjecting them to the judgment of managers.

The circumstances in which the President of Brown University has resigned his Presidency are discreditable to no one, least of all to himself. In the evolution of politics it happened that his views on bimetallism, which for many years he might have held as harmless opinions without disturbing or much interesting anybody, became fraught with the most practical consequences.

A. Minister or high official who has an appointment at his disposal usually looks more to his own advancement than to the interests of his party, or the merits of the applicants, in its bestowal. Personal excellence stands for little in Spain. All that is worth having is more easily attained by intrigue, bribery, or a quid pro quo in some sense than the sterling qualities of the solicitant.

William K. Vanderbilt has qualified as a founder of the New York Zoological Society by paying the prescribed fee of $5,000. There are but two other founders at present -- Levi P. Morton and Oswald Ottendorfer -- but the recent revival of interest in this project has been accompanied by encouraging intimations from at least half a dozen rich New Yorkers.

" As the Queen's son he has, of course, his own share of that loyalty which burns in all British hearts, but he has a great deal more than that. It is felt that he has done much, in very difficult circumstances, to earn the good will, and even affection, of the people whom he will some day address as 'my people.'

PITTSBURG, July 24. -- If the plans, as outlined, do not fail, the majority of the coal operators of the Pittsburg district will get together at the Court House in this city next Tuesday at 11 o'clock in the morning. The call was sent out to-day, and enough signatures were attached to it to make the meeting a very interesting one.

Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott, who is Chairman of tile Committee on Organization of the Republican County Committee, said yesterday that the Republican City Convention may nominate Seth Low for Mayor.

ST. CLAIR McKELWAY is the editor and one of the owners of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle. He is a Western man, who came East early in life. His birthplace was Columbia. Boone County, Mo., the seat of the State University.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 24. -- Three negroes, James Anderson, Paul Rogers, and William J. Samuels, left Black Point, five miles south of here, early this morning to come to the city with a boatload of melons. As the tide was against them they went in bathing while waiting. Samuels swam out in the river. Suddenly he was heard to scream for help.

M. Daguerre's invention enables him to combine with the camera obscura an engraving power -- that is, by an apparatus, at once to receive a reflection of the scene without, and to fix its forms and tints indelibly on metal in chiaroscuro -- the rays of the sun standing in the stead of burin, or, rather, of acid -- for the copies thus produced nearly resemble aquatina engravings exquisitely toned.

" The rains descended and the floods came." This is the record of New York society, now scattered through all the various inland and coast resorts since last Sunday. From Sunday until Thursday afternoon it rained persistently, continuously, and consistently, and confined within doors the lovers of gayety could only look out upon muddy roads, sodden fields, cloud-covered hills and mountains, or angry seas lashing the dull brown strand.
