A chapter of accidents brought the Larchmont race week to a close yesterday, and the most serious of all was the mishap that happened, to John E. Sanborn and his friends on the catboat Dorothy. It was shortly after 1 o'clock, and the boats were all beating back to the starting line from the eastern mark in a brisk northwest wind.

Walter S. Jenkins of Buffalo, N.Y., has been nominated for Chief Consul of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, to succeed the present incumbent, Isaac B. Potter, who has given notice that he will not serve another term. The Nominating Committee was appointed at the semi-annual meeting of the State Board of Officers in Saratoga on June 21, and consists of William C. Vrooman, F.M. Frobisher, and William H. Baker.

The weather yesterday was in sullen mood after the violent outburst of the day before. It had all the caprice and none of the beauty of April, and completely and flagrantly violated the promise of late Friday evening, when the setting sun diffused an indescribably soft and beautiful light upon the slight mist that yet lingered over the cities and the rivers.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 24. -- The sale of the boxes this afternoon for the Horse Show to be held on the grounds of the association, Hollywood Park, Long Branch, was remarkably successful The prices secured were at an increase of 50 per cent. over those of last year. This is taken as an indication that this show will break all previous records for success.

If our civilization has not entirely spoiled the taste of the noble savage, how he would gloat over a necklace of artificial eyes, which, as trophies, would far surpass in interest the now out-of-date scalps. All his relatives and wives would scarce be too big a price to offer for such a treasure, such a perfect museum of expression, combining educational and utilitarian benefits at one and the same time.

Although the street cleaners and park laborers cleared the streets and walks of the broken limbs and scattered leaves, many visible evidences of the storm of Friday afternoon remained yesterday, and narratives of experiences more or less exciting and of personal sensations more or less interesting were exchanged copiously from the Battery to Westchester.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24. -- The Rev. Cyrus K. Capron and a boss carpenter named King came to blows in the entrance of 765 Broad Street to-day. The first blow drew a crowd, but Officer Decker, an attache of the building, separated the men, although he did not cause their arrest.

President Isaac B. Potter of the League of American Wheelmen has come in for a great deal of criticism since the announcement that he would spend two months in France and Italy in the interests of a New York newspaper. Last Wednesday Mr. Potter, accompanied by Mrs. Potter, sailed on the steamer New York for Southampton.

THE latest performance of the Elizabethan Stage Society in London comprised the old play, "The Lamentable and True Tragedy of Master Arden of Feversham, in Kent," and a part of "Edward III." These performances of drama current in Shakespeare's time are given with Elizabethan costumes, before a curtained background.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The President to-day sent the following message to Congress:

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Not even the prospect of an early adjournment, which has always been an absorbing topic in Washington, particularly with the employes of the Congress, has been interesting enough this week to keep almost everybody from talking in the most excited fashion of Clondike, or Klondike, as it is variously spelled.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The President's message on the currency question did not receive prompt attention in the Senate. With the message lying on the Clerk's table, the Senate went into executive session, and after the doors were opened the message was ignored until in the debate on the House resolution to adjourn at 9 o'clock Democratic Senators insisted that the message be read before a time for final adjournment should be fixed.

Prince Takehito Arisugawa, Rear Admiral of the Japanese Navy, who was the representative of the Japanese Government at the jubilee celebration of Queen Victoria last month, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon on the Cunard steamship Umbria, on his way home by way of Vancouver.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 24. -- Clarence Armstrong Seward, who had been gradually sinking for several weeks from general debility, died at the Dezeng homestead, his country home, at 3:15 o'clock this afternoon. The immediate cause of his death was heart failure. He was surrounded by his family in his last moments, including his wife and two daughters, Mrs. Endicott and Miss Seward.
Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City had a relative of Chris Graver appointed on the police force.

MONTREAL, July 24. -- C.H. Wilkinson, Canadian representative of the British Yukon Mining, Trading, and Transportation Company, which company received incorporation in Ottawa a few weeks ago, said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day that it is the intention of his company to proceed at once with the construction of a railroad connecting the Yukon was the coast.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Though no official advices have been received at either the State Department or the Japanese Legation here confirmatory of the report that Japan has agreed to the proposal of the Hawaiian Government to arbitrate the questions at issue between the two Governments, it is not doubted that this is the fact.

Almost 10,000 names are now on the nonresident membership roll or the Merchants' Association, and the active resident list includes nearly 500 additional names and firms. This is the largest combination of merchants yet formed In this country for the express purpose of stimulating and facilitating trade.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 24. -- Robert Burns, an employe of the Long Island Railroad, confessed to-day that it was he who placed an eighteen-foot rail on the track near the station on Thursday night.

By the falling of a large derrick yesterday at Riverside Drive and One Hundred and Fourth Street, four men were injured. They are Harold Cropton, eighteen years old, of 79 Palmetto Street, Brooklyn; Peter Heckert, forty-eight years old, of 161 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street; Morris Ferriester, thirty-one years old, of 1,863 Park Avenue, and James Ross, twenty-nine years old, of 219 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24. -- A.B. Schanz, one of the officers of the Frank Leslie expedition of 1890 and 1891, organized by W.J. Arkell, is now Secretary of the Sterling Remedy Company of Chicago and New York. In an interview to-day on the subject of Mr. Arkell's claims to the gold fields of the Klondike district by right of discovery for the estate of E.J. Glave, Mr. Schanz said:

The day comes for the youngster to go down from the university. He has, let us suppose, taken his degree. Henceforth he is supposed to have finished his education and qualified to instruct men. On the ordination morning he slides into new clothes, and, from that day, becomes a stereotyped being. Parochial life runs in very narrow channels, and these tend to become narrower every day.

NEW LONDON, July 24. -- Cortland Palmer, son of Elisha Palmer, the bed-quilt manufacturer of this city, has been traveling in the West India islands. Palmer and his companion were on horseback, in Martinique one day, when the former, a little ahead, stopped to rest. As he dismounted he sat down in the grass, which was cool and inviting.
Capt. Alva Santelli, master of the crack steamship of the fleet of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique. La Touraine, was yesterday 210 seconds too late to enter his vessel at the Custom House.
LONDON, July 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, who are passengers for New York by the St. Paul, left Waterloo station this morning for Southampton in a special saloon carriage.

IN the good old days when "Big Mike" Shannahan, "Piggy" Noles, "Denny" Mahoney, "Tommy" Holland, "Juggy" McCarthy, and their pals were in their prime -- and that's a good twenty years ago -- the business of "river speculating" was worth talking about.

A new law compelling men to marry is proposed by CHARLOTTE SMITH, a lady whose theories and whims have made a lot of "good stuff" for the sensational press in the last year or two. She declares that the population of these United States includes a million women unable either to get husbands or to support themselves.

HONOLULU, July 17. -- The schooner Norma arrived from the South Seas on July 15. While the vessel was cruising Capt. Rosehill secured sufficient evidence to warrant the belief that England had taken formal possession of a number of small fertile islands in that portion of the globe without stopping to inquire who the owners might be.

Brawny policemen and muscular firemen, in the name of charity, pitted against each other in athletic events of diverse character, attracted a crowd of 5,000 persons to Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon in The New York Herald's tournament for the Free Ice, Police Gymnasium, and Firemen's Pension Funds.

The United States Marine Hospital Service, which will soon celebrate its hundredth anniversary, is the most distinctively American institution in our country, says a writer in the August Lippincott. There is nothing exactly like it abroad, and foreigners, endeaving to comprehend its scope, are constantly confusing it with the naval service.

EAST MORICHES, L.I., July 24. -- In the storm last evening what was evidently a large piece of the cabin from some shipwrecked vessel came ashore opposite this place. It was built of pine, and was about 30 feet long, 7 feet high, and 16 feet wide.

Years and years ago, when the Press Club of Washington, of more or less blessed memory was in existence, a British newspaper man was at the club one evening. He had been in Washington for some time, and was leaving next day. During the evening Mr. Carl Decker, who was also present, addressing him, made the following speech:

It was a bright woman who, being complimented upon the wide variety of her general information, said that she gained the greater part of it from reading advertisements. The advertisements are a commentary upon the life of the people of the country or locality in which they appear. They differ in different places. The advertisements which appear in English papers show national traits and customs.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 24. -- To-day began the last week of the State Camp this season. The camp was opened by the Seventh Regiment, and the Seventy-fourth Regiment of Buffalo and the First and Second Batteries of New York, due here to-day, will have the honor of closing the camp.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 24. -- Work has completely suspended, owing to strikes and disturbances arising from political disputes between masters and men.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Some of the members of Congress are just waking up to the fact that the officers of the Geological Survey anticipated in their recent reports the news from Alaska and British possessions of the presence in that region of gold in quantities to make it worth while to look for it.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Speaker Reed to-night at 8:30 o'clock announced House committees as follows, the Committees on Ways and Means, Accounts and Mileage having been announced at the beginning of the session:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 24. -- A number of the Summer people are interesting themselves in preparations for the "Kirmess" to be held in the Ocean Theatre Aug. 2, 3, 4, and 5 for the benefit of the Monmouth Memorial Hospital. Nearly 200 young people are in training for the entertainment.

BUFFALO, July 24. -- John Griffin, eighteen years of age, a laborer employed at the Buffalo Cold Storage Company's warehouse, was frozen to death by ammonia last night. So low was the temperature that the unfortunate man's body was blistered, the same effect being produced as though he had been burned to death. Three other men were injured, but not seriously.

George Washington Aldridge was born in Michigan City, Ind., Dec. 28, 1856. He was a son of George Washington Aldridge and Virginia Aldridge, natives of Chazy, Clinton County, N.Y. His father was a prominent contractor and railroad builder, and it was while he was constructing a railway in the State of Indiana, which brought his temporary residence in that State, that the present Superintendent of Public Works of the State of New York was born.

BERLIN, July 21. -- In the lower house of the Prussian Diet the discussion of the Law of Associations bill, as modified in the upper house, was begun to-day. Baron von der Recke urgently requested the Deputies to pass the bill in the form approved by the upper house. He said: "The bill constitutes an effective remedy against the evergrowing agitation of the Social Democrats, especially in the rural districts and among the reservists."

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- It is said at the State Department that the changes made in the consular regulations will touch both the official and unofficial fees, but it is said that in no case will the fees on invoices in Great Britain he reimposed, as has been alleged.

MONTREAL, July 24. -- There is no doubt that the Cabinet at Ottawa is considering means to preserve to Canadians the lion's share of the profits which will flow from the northern Eldorado, but it is highly improbable that there is any foundation for the report that the exclusion of all but British subjects is under contemplation.

It is almost pathetic to see a great, lusty country like ours still hugging the political delusion that a campaign for an executive officer settles the policy of the legislative branch of our Government. No matter what the views of a President, he cannot carry them out until they have become enacted into the law of the land.
SARATOGA, N.Y., July 24. -- "Blessed be the shops." That is what every woman here says.

CHATEAU BELLERIVE, near Geneva, July 6. -- A moment ago all was quiet on the lake; the Jura cast its shadows from deep ravines along the shore and upon the surface of the water, which was dotted with lateen sails. Now all is changed, and from the deepening shadows the thunder comes forth, echoing from the hillsides; the lake is as black as night, and the white sails have disappeared.

In a warship like the Massachusetts of the United States Navy, there are altogether eighty-six steam engines, big and little, in the equipment, and many of these engines have double steam cylinders; in fact, there are no less than 158 steam cylinders, all told.

What motives impelled those early navigators and explorers to make such sacrifice of time and money, to embark upon such uncertain expeditions upon unknown waters and desert wastes; to imperil their lives and fortunes upon such rash ventures: to undergo years of toil, such terrible anxiety, and suffering?
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Dingley Tariff bill became a law at 4:04 o'clock this afternoon by receiving the signature of President McKinley. By its terms the act takes effect immediately.

The committee appointed by the Central Labor Union to investigate the fight between the brewers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the Knights made its report yesterday. The Knights were charged with securing the discharge of Federation brewers, and with working in brewery washhouses for lower wages than Federation men were getting.
The whale is dead, and its death is attributed to drowning. An autopsy may reveal some other cause or causes, but the circumstances attending the demise serve to bear out the drowning theory.

J.P. Morgan Co. are soon to undertake a reorganization of the Madison Square Garden Company. The second mortgage on the Garden will probably be foreclosed and the property and its franchises will be sold to the Reorganization Committee, subject to the present first mortgage of $1,250,000 and unpaid taxes which are said to amount to about $100,000.

TORONTO, July 24. -- The various committees having in charge the arrangements for the Toronto World's Women's Christian Temperance Union Convention have about completed their work. The convention will begin on Saturday, Oct. 23, and continue four days. The day sessions will be held in the pavilion of the Horticultural Gardens, and the evening sessions in the Massey Music Hall, which has a seating capacity of about 4,000 persons.
Patrick Sullivan and his pretty cousin, Annie Sullivan, committed suicide yesterday with gas in Martin Ritz's hotel at Green Avenue and Second Street, Westchester.

WEST POINT, July 25. -- It is not generally known that hundreds of eagles have their homes among the rocky cliffs and steep precipices of Storm King, Cro' Nest, Butler Hill, and other lofty points in the Highlands, near this place. From the beginning of May until the middle of September scores of eagles may be seen after daybreak soaring aloft in quest of food.

Harlem River oarsmen were out in full force yesterday, and many of them were caught in the shower that came up during the afternoon. The various crews in training for the Middle States and National regattas, were in the water as early as 10 o'clock and several lively brushes took place.
Private James R. Flynn of Company B, Thirteenth United States Infantry, stationed at Governors Island, was seriously wounded by a mosquito while at target practice last Saturday.

LONDON, July 25. -- Peter McNally, the Boston swimmer who was scheduled to make an attempt to swim the English Channel on July 4, telegraphed to The Associated Press to-day from Calais that he made the attempt yesterday.
PITTSBURG, July 25. -- Trouble is feared before daylight at the mines of the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal Company.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Col. William Holloway, former editor of the Indianapolis News, was a few years ago a strong Gresham man, when it was popular with the Republicans to support Gen. Harrison.

Coney Island had an exciting day and a big crowd yesterday. There were two drownings, a dog under suspicion of hydrophobia ran amuck and bit one boy, the police again suppressed the barkers, and there was a fight on the Iron Pier.
A number of serious bicycle accidents occurred yesterday, two of which may result fatally.

As the contests for the cricket championship of New York near their completion additional interest is aroused and the games are watched closely. The New Jersey Athletic Club still preserves its unbeaten record and should be able to hold its own to the end of the competition, but Staten Island and Manhattan are having a close struggle for second place.

A movement is on foot in Kentucky to raise a fund for the erection of a monument to John Ritchie, who is called Kentucky's greatest pioneer, (not barring Daniel Boone,) and lies in an unmarked grave in Nelson County. For the benefit of readers not closely familiar with the history of Kentucky it should be explained that John Ritchie was a pioneer in the manufacture of whisky.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- The steamship China, arrived from Hongkong and Yokohama, brings Japanese advices to July 7. The Japanese papers contain more fully an interview with Count Okuma, the Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs, a brief synopsis of which was telegraphed a few days ago. In the interview which was published in the Yomikri, Count Okuma is quoted as saying relative to the proposed annexation of Hawaii by the United States:

TACOMA, Washington, July 25. -- So great has been the demand during the last week for clothing and provisions by hundreds of men outfitting for the Klondike gold fields that many dealers in the Northwestern cities are entirely short. Early last week hardware firms on Puget Sound ran out of gold pans, whipsaws, and pickstell. Carloads were ordered from New York and San Francisco.

ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- The Twenty-fifth United States Infantry Bicycle Corps reached this city last night, completing their 2,000-mile ride from Fort Missoula, Mont., in forty days, thirty-five of which were actually spent on the road. They are encamped at Forest Park. Despite the rain that fell last night and this afternoon, thousands of persons visited the troopers at the park.

No matter how long the Klondike gold fever prevails, or how rich the field is, a great deal of substantial benefit will accrue from it, to the Dominion of Canada, for instance, in duties upon goods imported into the Northwest territory, in taxes, and in the opening up and settlement of a country which may develop eventually other resources than gold mining.
Mary Lukowska, eight years old, yesterday followed a man who had robbed her mother's house until she met a policeman and then caused his arrest.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- The Customs' officials here have discovered a blunder in the new Tariff bill which may be troublesome to importers.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 25. -- The steamship City of Mexico left this port at noon to-day carrying for Dyea over 400 passengers, 80 horses, about 1,200 tons of freight, and about 25 dogs. Of the passengers there were very few who will not, as soon as they can be landed at Dyea, start for the far North. They hope to reach Dawson City before those who went north on the Portland.

The true character of the Tariff bill which was finally passed on Saturday was plainly and completely shown by the rejection of two amendments offered by Senator GRAY on July 7. By this action the majority admitted that the bill was absolutely without justification or excuse on the professed principles of the extremest protectionism.

Nearly all of the seventy-five riders who started in the Manhattan Bicycle Club's century run through Staten Island and New Jersey yesterday finished within the stipulated time. Among the first batch of survivors to reach Weehawken were four members of the fair sex.

The refusal of public or semi-public bodies either to ask for expert advice, or to take it after they have asked for it, has been doing much mischief to public art. The former fault is that of the commission for the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument. The latter is that of the Park Commissioners in the matter of the Botanical Garden.

NEWPORT, July 25. -- The following yachts arrived to-day: Schooner Iroquois, owned by H.C. Rouse; schooner Clytie, owned by H. Ward; steamer Oneida, owned by E.C. Benedict; steamer Nerada, owned by H. Walters; steamer Eugenie, owned by J.G. Cassatt; steamer Nada, New York Yacht Club.

The Church of the Strangers, on Mercer Street near Waverley Place, was well crowded yesterday morning. The announcement that a sermon would be preached by the Rev. D. Asa Blackburn on the Klondike excitement was the cause of the large attendance.

---- A great many persons who go to hear opera singers are much more interested in their private lives than in their public performances. Consequently when last Fall some malicious busybodies set afloat a report that M. JEAN DE RESZKE, the impersonator of the youthful Romeo and Siegfried, was really a very old man, badly disguised, the report really bade fair to do the great tenor some harm.

Whatever may have become of ANDREE and his companions, and whether we think their intrepidity heroic or only insane, it is certain that the method of locomotion they employed has received an immense impetus from their adoption of it. If the air be not entirely pathless except to birds, then assuredly it offers a more practicable path than the broken ice which surrounds the pole.

The most important feature of the bill passed by the House in response to the President's currency message is the provision leaving the appointment of the commission wholly to the President. As the bill was promptly and quietly sent to its grave in the Committee on Finance by the Senate, this provision will have no practical effect.

Prince Takehito Arisugawa, nephew of the Emperor of Japan, and Rear Admiral of the Japanese Navy, who arrived on the Umbria Saturday on his return from the Queen's Jubilee, spent a quiet day at the Waldorf yesterday. At 1 o'clock the Prince and his entire staff, accompanied by Capt. W.H. Jacques of the Naval Reserves of New Jersey and late of the United States Navy, were driven to Grant's Tomb.

On the whole, the new duty of 25 cents a pound on foreign rags cannot be considered a National calamity. Like most prohibitory or protective duties, it is vicious in principle, but will not be harmful in its working.

New York Branch, No. 187, of the National Association of Post Office Clerks has presented to ex-Postmaster Dayton an embossed album, containing a brief outline of the distinctive features which marked his administration as Postmaster.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 25. -- Details of a horrible case of butchery have been received here from Prescott, this State, to-day. It seems that bad blood had existed among the white and colored laborers of the lumbering district of that section for some time past, and frequently efforts have been made by the employes of the Nevada County camps to run the negroes off, but always without avail.
Referring to Mr. J. Fanning O'Reilly's article in your morning's issue upon the subject of "Pure Liquors," I would like to ask him to define what pure liquors should be? what his standard?

A sort of craze seems to have fallen on our people. "We want Hawaii" is the general cry, and the only reason given is the woman's reason, "I want it." This is as much as to confess that there is neither justification nor excuse for taking -- euphemistically annexing -- an island; but its being fair and useful to possess, we shall take it, reason or no reason.

" Except the action of the House in adopting it," said Carl Erdt, "there never was anything much more absurd than the resolution offered Wednesday by Representative Evans of Kentucky in relation to the foreign sale of American tobaccos."

BOSTON, July 25. -- Miss Alice Barrett, who was reported to have been killed by lightning on Saturday, died a suicide. This announcement was made by the police to-night. Saturday afternoon during the heavy thunder shower, a bolt of lightning struck the three-story brick building, 40 Kilby Street, setting it on fire.

FISHER'S ISLAND, July 25. -- The sailor boys of the New York, New Jersey, and Brooklyn militia have arrived at Fisher's Island. Early this morning the great hulls of the battleships Texas and Massachusetts were seen passing Gull Island and slowly working their way eastward. The Portsmouth, having the New Jersey men on board, was sighted shortly after noon.

WHEELING, West Va., July 25. -- Local labor leaders predict there will be a large attendance at the conference here Tuesday of the executive officers of the labor organizations of the country, called by President Ratchford of the Miners' Union.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Probably not since the days of Prince Bismarck has there been such an all-important sitting of the lower house of the Prussian Diet as was that of Saturday. The excitement inside and outside of the House was intense. Crowds gathered outside the building two hours prior to the opening of the sitting.

It cannot be true that some of the white people in the Southern States are seriously thinking of depriving the negroes in those States of free educational facilities, thus punishing the race because of the sins of a few of its representatives. The only hope for the elevation and development of the negro race is through education.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Speaker Reed has furnished no food for sensational paragraphs in the make-up of the House committees. Following the practice hitherto observed by himself and former Speakers, he has respected the so-called "claim" to promotion that enabled the leading man on a committee to retain his place, unless it appeared to the Speaker that he could be more useful by advancement to another Chairmanship.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 25. -- The Spring House, the principal hotel in this resort, was totally destroyed by fire early this morning. The fire started at 1 o'clock, and is said to have originated in the laundry in the northwest corner of the building, a four-story structure, situated in a handsome park close to the famous sulphur springs of Richfield.

PANA, Ill., July 26. -- Isaac N. Weaver, late Secretary of the Citizens' Loan and Building Association of Pana, was arrested this morning on a warrant sworn out by A.B. Corman, Sr., President of the association, charging him with embezzlement. Corman's action was authorized by a unanimous vote of the Board of Directors this morning.

-- There are whales and whales, and perhaps some members of the numerous and widely differentiated family do, or at least can, subsist on a diet of eels, but the lamentable result of such fare on the amiable cetaceans that have been playing an all too short engagement at the Aquarium gives good ground for suspecting that these particular whales, like the vast majority of their tribe, required a very different sort of provender.

Otto T. Bannard, President of the Continental Trust Company, said yesterday that the 1,025 shares of stock of the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society would be sold at auction to-morrow, all reports to the contrary notwithstanding.

PITTSBURG, July 26. -- The mining situation in this district is quiet and unchanged. Both sides are waiting for the result of the meeting of the operators to-morrow. The arbitrators are highly elated at the prospects. All agree in saying that it will be the largest meeting of operators ever held in this district.

An acrimonious meeting of the Board of Police Magistrates adjourned last evening after a two hours' session, leaving the affairs of the board in a tangle that can only be straightened out by a special meeting, and the Magistrates themselves apparently hopelessly divided on the question of the legality of a certain act of the Legislature.

The arrest of a woman in Hagerstown, Md., for beating her husband has caused some commotion among those advocating the restoration of the whipping post for wife beaters. They are waiting somewhat anxiously to see what effect it will have on the movement.

Residents of the United Stales who go abroad during the operation of the Dingley tariff law, which went into effect at the stroke of 12 on the night of July 23-24, will find, when they return, that their personal baggage will be ransacked, overhauled, and scrutinized as it has never been before in the history of customs collections in this country.

HAVANA, July 26. -- According to an official statement, Major Juan Calangas, an important insurgent chief, with nineteen cavalrymen, well armed and supplied with munitions of war, surrendered to the authorities this morning at Los Palos, in the Havana Province.
In vain the spyglass of the shallow pessimist sweeps the financial horizon in quest of a portent of disaster. Everywhere good auguries swim into his ken. There are no bad signs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 26. -- At the National Jewish Chautauqua to-day the principal speaker was Dr. K. Kohler of New York. In his discussion on Bible ethics he asserted that "the Jew is the genius of the Bible ehtics, and therefore the best interpreter of it. The Bible is the whole Jewish literature and would be a dead work were it not for the survival of the Jewish people."

As part of the twenty-seventh annual report of the Massachusetts Bureau of Statistics of Labor, Horace G. Waldin, chief of the bureau, has issued a volume dealing with graded weekly wages in Massachusetts, other States of the Union, and in foreign countries.

We trust that the illness of Mr. DANA only temporarily withdraws that unflagging mind from the service of our neighbor The Sun. He is by no means an old man. Seventy-eight is not an advanced age for one who has thoroughly mastered the art of sound living and has practiced it as wisely as Mr. DANA has done.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 26. -- A story is current that the Pennsylvania Railro.d Company has under consideration the buildIng. of an extension to Ocean City, Aid. Two routes are reported as being considered-one from Showell's and the other from Friendship.
Lieut. Gov. Woodruff has been selected as a peacemaker between Senator Platt and Jacob Worth. At least this was said yesterday to be one result of the conference at the Oriental Hotel last Sunday.

M. Bargebuhr Son have sold for Dr. D. Dressler to Charles Beekman, for $34,000, the two four-story brick flats, 330 and 332 East Thirty-seventh Street, each 24 by 98.11. In part payment, about $22,500, Mr. Beekman gives the five-story brownstone front flat, 500 Manhattan Avenue, 18.9 by 95.

CLEVELAND, July 26. -- The Giants and Clevelands played a very scrappy game of eleven innings here to-day. There was almost constant wrangling, and Umpire O'Day was compelled to order Gleason out of the game. He also ordered the police to keep Meekin, who was on the bench, out of the grounds.

Several hundred children, accompanied by their mothers, and in some instances older sisters or brothers, gathered on the pier at the foot of Eighth Street, East River, yesterday afternoon to take advantage of the offer of The Tribune and enjoy an outing at Excelsior Grove, above Yonkers.

The Independent prints the results of a careful investigation by the Rev. B.L. McElroy of Ohio into the condition of the miners in the coal regions of Ohio, West Virginia, Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois, and Pennsylvania. His deductions are very freely quoted from in the following:

An epidemic of fright, heightened by sea-sickness and justified to a degree by the inexperience of the man in charge, imperiled the lives of twenty-three excursionists returning from a fishing trip late Sunday night, cost many of the fishermen all the clothes they wore, ran the smack Georgianna Young aground on the Romer Shoals, and left her owners liable to a suit for salvage.

The scheme to consolidate the New York and East River and Equitable Gas Companies assumed a new aspect yesterday through purchases of Mutual Gas stock Shareholders of the Equitable are still holding back for their price, which the East River people do not seem at present disposed to give.

As foreshadowed in THE NEW YORK TIMES, yesterday was made a test day by the reactionists in the stock market. They were alert and active from start to finish. At the opening of business they made a concerted charge, which had some effect; stop orders were caught and quotations thereby made to look weak.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The Treasury officials have already discovered a number of inconsistencies in the new Tariff act. some of them, it is feared, being ineaiable of reconciliation. It is pointed out that Section 62 places the duty on plums at 25 cents per bushel, and Section 2G4 fixes the rate at 2 cents per pound.

George Wuest, a driver employed by the New York Cheese Company, yesterday saved Gertrude Winchester, four years old, from probably instant death by catching her in his arms when she fell head first from the window of her parents' apartments on the third floor of 20 Ten Eyck Street, Brooklyn.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., July 26. -- The Trustees of the Lehigh University have authorized an emphatic denial of the report that the university may be compelled to close its doors in September. This report was entirely unauthorized. The university will be open as usual in September, with all departments in full efficiency.

We have hitherto maintained a discreet silence on a subject which now positively compels some sort of discussion. "New York as a Summer resort" is a favorite topic of our neighbor The Evening Post, and one of the essentials of a prosperous Summer resort is the absence of mosquitoes.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 26. -- The Brooklyn battalion of the Naval Reserves, which was in camp last night at Sands Point, had a lively time of it after they had retired. One of the lookouts reported that a cutter was coming ashore. The men secured her and then went back to bed.

With the closing of the ceremonies in honor of St. Anne at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste last night many cures as a result of days of prayer were attested to. According to the statements of many persons, St. Anne hearkened to their prayers and relieved them of bodily suffering.

The burning of the principal hotel of Richfield Springs at the height of the season is a calamity not only to the owner and the "proprietor," but also to the business community of the village. What remains of the season might be expected to be at least as profitable as what has already elapsed.

LONDON, July 26. -- The House of Commons was crowded this afternoon in expectation of a spirited debate upon the report of the Select South Africa Committee, appointed to inquire into the circumstances of Dr. Jameson's raid into the Transvaal, and into the general conduct of the affairs of the British South Africa Chartered Company.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26. -- William Karstens, twenty-six years old, a teamster, was killed on a telephone pole in front of Kafhold's Hotel on Commerce Street this evening. Karstens formerly lived at the hotel. While there he was in the habit of climbing up the high pole to the first cross arm used by the telephone company and sitting on it to sing.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 26. -- By Aug. 15 5,000 people will be struggling over the Chilcat Pass above Dyea, en route down the Yukon Valley to the Klondike. There are now fully 5,000 people at Dawson and vicinity. Ten thousand people thus will be sealed up in the country Sept. 15, with weather 30 degrees below zero. To get out will be practically impossible, and many are asking what they will do for food.

A combination of circumstances made racing at Aqueduct yesterday anything but pleasant, and on the homeward journey from the track disgust was depicted on almost every face. There were many reasons why the visitors should depart from the track in an unpleasant frame of mind, and chief among them was the wretched work with the flag of Starter Pettingill.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Representative Payne of New York has been talking to-day about the prospect for prosperity, which he believes will be steady under the new tariff, and has given some reasons for opposing the commission plan for reforming the currency that are accepted as reflecting the views of the Speaker and most of the members of both houses.

CLEVELAND, July 26. -- Four mortgages were filed by the O.D. Myer Company, running a big department store, in the County Recorder's office to-day. The total amount of the mortgages was $30,913.77, as follows: Central National Bank, $4,855.79; the Root McBride Company, $8,766.86; Kinney Levan, $11,006.89; Realty Investment Company, $6,284.73.

Assistant Secretary Mead of the Merchants' Association began yesterday morning the mailing of the handsome lithograph certificates of membership to the 10,000 out-of-town members. It is desired that each non-resident merchant who has joined the association shall receive his certificate before he leaves home on his Fall excursion to this city.

That boy of fourteen, BENJAMIN SIMON, who died by his own hand because he felt that the object of his ambition was unattainable, has left an extraordinary and suggestive letter. BENJAMIN was possessed by a desire to benefit his fellow-beings, to do something to lift them out of poverty and toil.

BOSTON, July 26. -- The tennis tournament opened at Longwood to-day under a dull sky and with a heavy easterly breeze sweeping over the courts. The tournament was late in starting, but good progress was made, and before play closed for the day the preliminary and first rounds were finished.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The Secretary of the Treasury holds that the new tariff act was in effect at the beginning of the day on which it received the approval of the President, and therefore became operative after midnight on Friday, July 23.

The very flattering prospects of the New York Merchants' Association are undoubtedly due to the sound sense and broad intelligence of its managers. They have honestly and practically applied the principle which their President, Mr. KING, happily terms "the golden rule that has made this country so prosperous.''
LAGUNA, Neb., July 26. -- My ascent of La Mesa Encantada on Friday was made in exactly two minutes and forty seconds by the watch.
